title: Reds-Tigers Deal
description: The Cincinnati Reds traded Wayne Krenchicki, an infielder, to the Detroit Tigers today for Pat Underwood, a pitcher, who was assigned to Indianapolis of the American Association.

title: A TRIUMPH FOR THE 'ABORTION PURVEYORS'
description: To the Editor:

title: 6th Shuttle Flight Member
description: Charles D. Walker, an engineer for the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company, was named Wednesday as the sixth crew member for the 12th space shuttle mission next March. He will be the first payload specialist for a project designed for commercial purposes, a space agency spokesman said. The project is a machine developed by McDonnell Douglas in partnership with Johnson & Johnson that will be used to purify pharmaceuticals.

title: TAINTED SAUCE LINKED TO EXTORTION
description: A man who authorities believe laced bottles of Gravy Master Seasoning and Browning Sauce with poison demanded $1 million from Pathmark Supermarkets, the chain of stores where the contaminated product was found, people familiar with the case said today.

title: U.S. REMOVES KEY OBSTACLE TO SHOREHAM STARTUP
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that, in principle, the Shoreham reactor on Long Island could be allowed to load fuel for low-power testing, even though it may never be permitted to operate commercially.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 1, 1983; The Economy
description: The third and final stage of President Reagan's income tax cut, the keystone of his economic program, takes effect today, and is expected to save taxpayers $30 billion over the next 12 months. Many economists believe the tax cut will stimulate consumer spending and an economic recovery in the second half of 1983. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan has delivered both personal income tax reductions and an improving economy, but they follow a severe recession. (B9.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Now, 'Campaign Manager'

title: The filming of New York's youngest.
description: IF you're a kid living in New York, and you haven't been cast in a movie, you're just not trying. Even pictures that aren't shooting in the city have dispatched operatives to wander through schools public and private searching for talent. Take the director Moshe Mizrahi (who made the Academy Award-winning ''Madame Rosa''), for instance. He begins filming ''The Children's War'' in Budapest this week, and he chose New York teen-agers, five boys and two girls, to be his leading players. The screenplay, by Abby Mann, based on ''The Survivor,'' an autobiographical book by Jack Eisner, is about children of the Warsaw ghetto who rose against the Nazis in 1943, and Mr. Mizrahi wanted the cast to come from one place, so moviegoers wouldn't be jarred by a variety of accents. ''They have to speak the same music,'' he says.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Large Supporting Cast For the Apollo

title: A Vote for Public Radio
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting said tonight that 93 percent of the public radio stations polled had voted to adopt a plan intended to keep National Public Radio in operation.

title: JOHN NELSON, NEW CHIEF AT CARAMOOR
description: Tomorrow night at 8:30, the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts will begin its 38th season with high spirits and a brand new music director. John Nelson, the director, will begin his tenure at Caramoor with a program consisting of Berlioz's Overture to ''Beatrice et Benedict,'' Mendelssohn's incidental music to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto. Mr. Nelson will conduct the Caramoor Festival Orchestra, with Jaime Laredo as the soloist in the Barber.

title: Fraser Claims Proxy Victory
description: The board of the House of Fraser, Britain's biggest department-store chain, proclaimed victory today in its battle to hold onto Harrods, the internationally known London store.

title: WEAK SPOTS IN A 'STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM' FOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COLSON UNITY TROUPE
description: TWO groups with styles rooted in 1960's jazz performed at Soundscape on Tuesday as part of the jazz festival. The Colson Unity Troupe, a quintet led by the pianist and saxophonist Adegoke Steve Colson, is affiliated with Chicago's Association for the Advancement of Creative Music.

title: MEMORIES OF 'LES AND BESS'
description: When Lee Kalcheim was gobbling up his childhood cornflakes in Philadelphia, he thought husband-and-wife chitchat shows such as ''Dorothy and Dick'' and ''Tex and Jinx'' were ''the ultimate in New York sophistication leaking into my brain through the radio.''

title: Kaiser and Gulf May Merge Units
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and the Gulf Oil Corporation are holding discussions about the possibility of combining some of their chemical operations, Kaiser said.

title: Dalto and Band
description: The Argentine keyboardist Jorge Dalto and his Inter-American band, featuring the conga player Carlos (Patata) Valdez, will appear tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets begin at 10:30 P.M. and 12:15 and 2 A.M. Admission is $7, and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Judy Strauss Is a Bride
description: Judy Ruth Strauss, daughter of Mrs. Harold Leon Strauss of New York and the late Mr. Strauss, was married yesterday to Rodolfo Martinez. Rabbi Joel Goor of the Metropolitan Synagogue performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother. The bride, who will keep her name, is merchandise manager of dresses for the buying office of Felix Lilienthal & Company in New York. Mr. Martinez, a travel consultant in New York, is a son of Mrs. Rodolfo Martinez of Acapulco, Mexico, and the late Mr. Martinez.

title: ECONOMIC ILLS ARE IMPERILING PERU'S DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: German to Visit Washington
description: The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, will visit Washington on July 11 to report to United States officials on Chancellor Helmut Kohl's scheduled talks in the Soviet Union next week, the State Department said today.

title: NORTON ACCEPTS BID BY ESMARK
description: Norton Simon Inc., the big consumer products company, has accepted a sweetened takeover bid from Esmark Inc. estimated at $918 million, the companies announced last night.

title: Broadway; 'Wiz' is following the Broadway road again next season.
description: DOROTHY and her familiar trio of companions - the tin man, the lion and the scarecrow - will be following the yellow brick road on Broadway again next season. They will return in a revival of ''The Wiz,'' the black musical based on Frank Baum's much-loved fairy tale, ''The Wonderful Wizard of Oz.'' The show is coming back with some familiar faces from its original 1975 production - Stephanie Mills, who will star again as Dorothy; Geoffrey Holder, who will repeat his roles as director and costume designer, and George Faison, who will recreate his choreography.

title: A ROMANCE FROM FRANCE
description: IN a short story called ''The Sensible Thing,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote: ''There are all kinds of love in the world, but never the same love twice.'' Given the tedious passion on display in ''Drugstore Romance,'' a French film opening today at the Cinema Studio, it is to be hoped Fitzgerald was right.

title: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Turning Point on Acid Rain
description: Each year the eastern half of North America is drenched with rain turned acid by waste gases. Some of the acid arises locally but much comes from coal-fired power plants in the Ohio Valley. The giant smokestacks built there since the Clean Air Act of 1970 inject sulphur and nitrogen oxides into winds that carry the gases eastward, converting them into sulfuric and nitric acids that wash down in rain.

title: Jetliner's Crew Reports Near Miss Over Sound
description: The crew of an American Airlines jumbo jet reported that it had missed a small private plane by a vertical distance of 200 to 250 feet yesterday morning as the airliner was coming in to land at La Guardia Airport.

title: ADMINISTRATION DRAFTS RULES TO LIMIT LOBBYING BY NONPROFIT GROUPS
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted new rules that would sharply restrict lobbying and other political activities by private nonprofit organizations receiving money from the Federal Government.

title: SHULTZ TELLS INDIA THAT U.S. WILL DROP REACTOR-PARTS BAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the Indian Government today that the United States would export nuclearreactor components to India if other suppliers could not be found.

title: WATSON POSTS A 67 IN WESTERN OPEN
description: Tom Watson completed a 5-under-par 67 with a 30-foot birdie putt today and took a 1-shot lead after the first round of the $400,000 Western Open tournament.

title: Wien Air Buyout Deal
description: The chairman of Wien Air Alaska, James J. Flood, said yesterday that a company he controls has purchased the carrier from Household International Inc. for $37 million through a leveraged buyout. Mr. Flood said financing for the buyout was provided by Chemical Bank with the participation of an affiliate of Central Bank of Pleasant Hill, Calif.

title: 4 Jersey Students Sue Test Service
description: Four former high school students in Millburn, N.J., and their parents are suing a student testing service, contending that administrators unfairly threatened to cancel their scores on a college entrance examination. The testing service did so on the basis of statistical evidence of copying from one another.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Alfresco Lunch A mid the rhythms of a seven-piece samba band and vendors purveying croissants, chitlins, falafel, pizza, pastrami and about two dozen other kinds of food, throngs of people gathered yesterday to have lunch and to catch some sun at Pier 11, the new and popular Wall Street lunch spot.

title: GAINERS AND LOSERS IN FIRST HALF OF '83
description: The first half of 1983 was a time of plenty on Wall Street, with the vast majority of stocks surging upward in a continuation of the powerful bull market that began last summer.

title: Toss to Nebraska
description: That was a short offseason in college football. Penn State, which won the top ranking in last season's final college football polls, has lost the first coin toss of the 1983 season.

title: Regan Cites Waste In Transit Unit
description: The New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, yesterday accused the City Transit Authority of wasting ''untold millions of dollars'' by failing to put into effect recommendations, made by its own consultants, aimed at increasing efficiency.

title: PLAYER CHIEF ASSAILS HOWE PUNISHMENT
description: The fine imposed by the Los Angeles Dodgers on Steve Howe, believed to be the largest ever assessed against a player, brought charges from Ken Moffett yesterday that Commissioner Bowie Kuhn had misled him in the matter and that the punishment was improper.

title: OF LASER WEAPONS AND DR. TELLER'S STOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: Charming bistro and Tex-Mex pair
description: ONE of the more charming and ingratiating little French restaurants in Greenwich Village is La Ripaille, opened three years ago by Patrick and Alain Laurent, and their wives, Theresa and Nelly, who are in charge of the kitchen. This small bistro has maintained its rustic and charming setting, with wooden beams, bits of tapestry and graceful bouquets. And because the food is much better than it used to be, a promotion from one star to two is in order.

title: KOCH ENDS BID TO TAX CULTURAL GROUPS
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he was abandoning his policy of trying to collect property taxes from many cultural and other nonprofit organizations.

title: JAPAN WILL END PACT ON CARS
description: Sosuke Uno, Minister for International Trade and Industry, reiterated today that Japan would not extend its voluntary restraint of auto exports to the United States for another year.

title: ARAFAT GUERRILLAS AND REBELS SAID TO CALL A TRUCE
description: Representatives of Palestinian guerrillas who have been battling each other in eastern Lebanon said today that they had called an immediate cease-fire.

title: Lauren Peltz Is Bride Of John James Veronis
description: Lauren Peltz, president of the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research, was married yesterday to John James Veronis, chairman of Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment banking firm specializing in the communications industry.

title: Brink's Informant Has Case Severed
description: Samuel Brown, a defendant in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and murders case, will be tried separately from his co-defendants in the case because his lawyer has ''divided loyalties'' between Mr. Brown and another defendant, a judge ruled today.

title: TRIBUTE TO MONK
description: THE highlight of Soundscape's triple bill on Monday was an hour of Thelonious Monk tunes, played as alto saxophone solos by Marion Brown.

title: HARVARD FOURSOME ADVANCES AT HENLEY
description: ON-THAMES, England, June 30 - Four members of the Harvard varsity heavyweight eight that decided not to compete here this year won their heat of the four-oared Visitors' Challenge Plate today in the opening round of the 134th Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Bridge: Defender Solves Problem In Trumps in an Odd Way
description: In most of the world, and at most of the world's bridge tables, shortages are a recurring problem. But in rare circumstances the problem may be one of oversupply. In Western Europe it relates to butter. And in the diagramed deal, played in Greece, it concerned trumps.

title: Palmer Perturbed
description: Arnold Palmer has never missed a starting time in more than 30 years of professional golf, but he came close yesterday.

title: Computer Bid
description: Computer Associates International Inc., a Jericho, L.I., maker of software for large mainframe and minicomputers, said it had entered into an agreement to buy Information Unlimited Software Inc. of Sausalito, Calif. The company said it would acquire Information Unlimited, which markets several popular programs for the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer, for $5 million. The deal calls for an additional payment of up to $5 million, depending on Information Unlimited's performance in the next two years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Kubek has signed a long-term contract to continue as a baseball analyst with NBC. ... Rod Thorn, general manager of the Chicago Bulls, has received permission from the club to resume his pursuit of the free agent Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.

title: 4 on L.I. Seized In an Abduction
description: Three men and a woman have been arrested and charged with abducting the woman's husband and shooting him five times, the police said today. The victim, though seriously injured, survived the attack.

title: Nuclear Activists Negotiate Reduced Fines
description: Nuclear protesters won reduced fines or jail terms today and the authorities also agreed to drop a two-year probation the activists especially opposed.

title: DEMOCRATS' ARMS STANCES CRITICIZED
description: Representative Les Aspin, a leading Democratic critic of President Reagan's military policy, turned his guns on his own party today, charging that Democratic Presidential candidates had taken ''very dangerous'' positions on the nation's defense.

title: CABLE PACT FOR ALL OF CITY PASSES
description: Agreement was reached last night for six cable television companies to bring service to Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. The Board of Estimate voted unanimously last night to approve the franchises, and no significant changes were made from the terms that were reached a week ago.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT COUNSELOR MISSES CAPITOL HILL
description: Edward J. Derwinski misses Congress. After 24 years on Capitol Hill, the Illinois Republican moved across town in March to a big seventh-floor office at the State Department to take up the post of counselor. Mr. Derwinski confesses that he's still a little perplexed.

title: Breland Recuperating
description: Mark Breland, considered to be the American boxer most likely to win a gold medal at the 1984 Olympics, is recuperating from surgery on his right hand and will miss this summer's Pan American Games.

title: Ranger Prospects
description: It was not a momentous goal, the South team's fourth goal in an 8-4 loss to the North in the opening round of National Sports Festival ice hockey competition Wednesday night. But to one man in the audience, and another back in New York, it was special.

title: Dynamic Baseball?
description: Can baseball be presented in the same dynamic fashion demonstrated in the boxing film ''Raging Bull''? Alan Shapiro, who will direct the cable-TV movie ''Tigertown,'' for which he wrote the screenplay, thinks so. ''I want to do baseball the way you've never seen it before,'' said Shapiro. The story will be based loosely on the career of Al Kaline, the former star outfielder of the Detroit Tigers - though the character will be called Billy Williams, to be played by Roy Scheider - and on Detroit's world championship season of 1968.

title: PUBLISHING: A VENTURE IN SCIENCE FICTION ENDS
description: POCKET BOOKS and the Scott Meredith Literary Agency have called off their short-lived plan for a joint science-fiction and fantasy publishing program, and the Science Fiction Writers of America is overjoyed by the decision.

title: Latin Jazz at Blue Note
description: The trombonist Raul de Souza will lead a quintet featuring the trumpeter Claudio Roditi in Brazilian and Latin-style jazz tonight and tommorow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. Admission is $8.50, with a $7.50 minimum at tables, and there is a $5 minimum at the bar.

title: EAST GERMANY HAS FOUND ITS OWN MARTIN LUTHER
description: Five hundred years after Martin Luther was born, German theologians and historians are still wrestling with his legacy.

title: WILLIE NELSON FESTIVAL ROLLS INTO MEADOWLANDS
description: THESE days, Willie Nelson is as much a symbol of steadfast American individualism as a Buffalo nickel. His albums of standards - ''Stardust,'' ''Somewhere Over the Rainbow'' and ''Always on My Mind'' - have sold in the millions, and he's become a compelling movie presence that Hollywood still doesn't quite know how to use.

title: AIRLINERS DEVOID OF UNPOLLUTED AIR
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEN DEFEATS METS 2D TIME SINCE TRADE
description: Neil Allen now has perspective. He left the Mets just over two weeks ago, part of the trade for Keith Hernandez, and tonight he helped beat his former teammates for the second time.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Engineer Chosen to Run Real Estate Developer
description: Skender Ghilaga has been named president of R.H. Sanbar Projects Inc., the company that recently completed the Dag Hammarskjold Tower, a luxury condominium in Manhattan.

title: KEAN SIGNS BILL EASING AUTO TESTING
description: Governor Kean today signed a package of bills that he said would eliminate long lines at automobile inspection stations and enable the state to meet Federal air quality guidelines.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: E.E.C. Steel Cutbacks Set
description: The cutbacks in steel production to be imposed on member nations of the Common Market were announced today by the European Commission.

title: No Headline
description: About Real Estate Ruling on Dual Taxation May Be Costly By LEE A. DANIELS

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error in some copies yesterday, type was misplaced in the final paragraph of a news analysis article on the ethics of acquiring Carter campaign materials. It should have read: ''People on the inside of both administrations agree that public attention will not abate in the current situation until key questions are answered. They also agree that the ethical and moral questions will not be answered until it is known for sure who let the documents out, and why.''

title: WHITE PLAINS WOMAN TAKING LEADING CHURCH ROLE
description: Her church does not have bishops and the job to which she was elected this week bears the unexalted title of secretary. But when the Rev. Carol Joyce Brun becomes secretary of the United Church of Christ this fall, she will be one of the highest-ranking women in American Protestantism.

title: A.M.A. DISAVOWS JAB AT DIOXIN REPORTS
description: A representative of the American Medical Association said today that he regretted ''imprudent'' language in a resolution the organization approved last week condemning the press for conducting a ''witch hunt'' and engaging in ''hysterical malreporting'' on dioxin contamination.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Found: One Snake; Claimed: One Fox

title: Louis Armstrong Day
description: On Monday, the Fourth of July, which is Louis Armstrong's 83d birthday, radio station WKCR-FM, 89.9 on the dial, will present more than 20 hours of the trumpeter's music. The program, which will also A.M. and continue until 10:30 P.M. The number for information is 280-5223.

title: LAST UNION REACHES AGREEMENT TO END 108-DAY PHILADELPHIA COMMUTER RAIL STRIKE
description: An agreement that will permit the Philadelphia area's commuter trains to run again, ending a 108-day strike, was reached late today between the region's transit agency and the signalmen's union, the last holdout of 13 unions.

title: TO HELP SOVIET JEWS
description: In 1974, a debate raged within the Jewish community about whether support should be given to the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which drew a direct link between trade benefits granted by the United States and a country's emigration policies. The amendment was approved, but whatever might have been said about its effectiveness then, it clearly has no relevance today,

title: Mitsubishi's 128K Chip
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it had started to ship samples of three models of a new high-capacity chip used to store information for computers. The 128K chips are erasable and reprogrammable, and can store about 131,000 characters, or enough to fill three standard-size newspaper pages, the company said. Production at a rate of 50,000 a month is to start in August.

title: WITHHOLDING TAX ON WAGES DECLINES TODAY
description: The third and final stage of President Reagan's income tax cut, the keystone of his economic program, becomes effective Friday. It is expected to save taxpayers $30 billion over the next 12 months.

title: A LEADER IN MAGAZINE DESIGN
description: Allen F. Hurlburt, former design director and vice president of Cowles Communications who was a leading figure in magazine design, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital, Sarasota, Fla., after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Nokomis, Fla.

title: WEAK SPOTS IN A 'STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM' FOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor: The ''basic curriculum'' proposed by Jean Mayer lacks one vital ingredient: A contemporary course of study in high school, or even in elementary grades, is incomplete when it does not include an introduction to the complexities of our business world and our political system at all levels of legislative, administrative, judicial and electoral processes.

title: AN 'OPEN' TOUR DE FRANCE
description: SOUS-BOIS, France, June 30 - The 70th Tour de France starts here Friday with an amateur team entered for the first time against the professionals, making the world's premier bicycle endurance race an ''open'' contest. But what makes it wide open is the absence of Bernard Hinault, the winner of four of the last five Tours de France and now a victim of tendinitis in his right knee.

title: BREEZY RETURN OF CONVERTIBLES
description: People in convertibles may be a bit out of step. They admit it. ''I'd say convertible people are a little more adventurous than other people,'' says Richard Titcomb, a Triumph convertible owner in Central Islip, L.I. ''There's always a chance of rain and bugs in the teeth.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Library Catalogue Takes a New Form

title: FOR 2 NEW POLICE CHIEFS, DUTY IS NO. 1
description: A man with a gun was holding a hostage. Deputy Chief Robert J. Johnston Jr., who had traveled to the scene to assist his men in the Police Department's Emergency Service Unit, crouched against a wall with other police officers. As shots fired by the assailant echoed through the air, the chief turned to Inspector Daniel St. John and said: ''God forgive me, but I love it.''

title: SEALING OF PRETRIAL RECORD IS AT ISSUE IN 2 LIBEL CASES
description: In fighting a libel suit, a news organization usually tries to prove that the offending article is true. One opportunity to do that arises in pretrial depositions, when the defendants have a broad license to inquire into the plaintiff's activities, finances and personal life. Depositions are generally a matter of public record, meaning that the news organization can publish material from them and possibly embarrass the subject further.

title: BOND PRICES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday in quiet trading despite a sharp increase in the cost of overnight interbank loans. Traders said an injection of money into the banking system by the Federal Reserve encouraged them to bid up prices.

title: Friday; SHAKESPEARE BACK IN PARK
description: Kevin Kline is the cunning protagonist in ''Richard III,'' the only Shakespeare production this season by the New York Shakespeare Festival, which has begun previews at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. There's no official opening date yet for the play, which will run through July 31 at 7:30 every night except Mondays and July 21. Free tickets are distributed starting at 6 at the theater, but people usually start lining up hours before, many horizontally on picnic blankets. The Delacorte is reached best from the entrances at Central Park West and 81st Street or Fifth Avenue and 79th Street. VIDEO WORKS AT THE MODERN

title: ART: REGINALD MARSH IN NEW YORK OF THE 30'S
description: NEW YORK in the Depression era was a lively proletarian crowd scene, its seedy streets swarming with Bowery bums, burlesque performers, dance-hall hostesses, shopgirls and men who stood on breadlines. That, at least, was the vision of Reginald Marsh (1898-1954), a Paris-born, Yale-educated boy from the suburbs who -with such other old-master-oriented painters as Isobel Bishop and Kenneth Hayes Miller - lived and worked on 14th Street, and saw Manhattan with the same ''regionalist'' eye as Grant Wood saw Iowa. It's a vision brought alive again in ''Reginald Marsh's New York,'' a show of 38 paintings, drawings, prints and photographs from Marsh's prolific output, installed at the Whitney Museum's new outpost in the new Philip Morris building, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street.

title: U.S. BACKS SYNTHETIC FUELSPLANT
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation announced today that it would provide $120 million in guarantees for a California project to convert coal to gas, the first financial commitment the corporation has made since Congress created it in 1980.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article on home health care was labeled incorrectly.

title: A $400 Million Telephone Merger
description: The Allied Telephone Company and the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation approved a definitve merger agreement providing for a combination of the two companies into a company with a market value of more than $400 million.

title: Apollo Stompers Play
description: The pianist Jaki Byard will lead the Apollo Stompers, a big band with dancers, tonight through Sunday night at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 268 Eighth Avenue, at 28th Street (244-0997). Shows begin at 10 each night, and admission is $8.

title: GUIDELINE ON DIOXIN IS OFFERED
description: Scientists from across the country meeting at the national Centers for Disease Control on Wednesday agreed that a safe level of dioxin contamination in soil was one part per billion.

title: Kodak to Defer U.S. Pay Increases
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would delay by six months the pay increases normally given at year-end to its United States employees.

title: VOLUME DECLINES
description: Buoyed by the generally positive tone of the economy, equities continued their restrained but broad-based rally yesterday in subdued pre-holiday trading.

title: Louisiana Law Permits Shooting of Intruders
description: Gov. David C. Treen has signed into law a ''shoot-a-burglar bill'' that allows a citizen to pull the trigger to deal with an intruder in his home.

title: Judge Says U.S. Avoided Its Duty on Segregation
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Reagan Administration did not honor a court order to help desegregate Chicago's schools. He ordered the Government to set aside $250 million to aid in financing the effort in the next five years.

title: Payment by Utility System
description: A King County Superior Court judge today declined to prohibit payment of $94 million to the holders of bonds sold to finance two abandoned nuclear power plants. The money is held by Chemical Bank of New York, trustee for the bondholders, and will be distributed on Friday as planned.

title: 2. SALARY DISPARITIES CONTINUE
description: Now that President Reagan has called it ''the American way'' to improve the public schools, merit pay for teachers has become a conspicuous issue in the incipient 1984 political campaign. Merit pay deserves sober consideration before ideologues and educationists mangle it beyond recognition.

title: THE OLD AND THE NEW AT FESTIVAL'S LAST SESSIONS
description: THE music in the closing weekend of the Kool Jazz Festival will range from the oldest, most traditional jazz to explorations of what's just ahead. Specifically, the 14 concerts to be heard in the festival's last three days will go from the blues of Big Joe Turner, B.B. King and Joe Williams and the jazz of the Depression years through the 40-year span of influence of Gil Evans to the plowing of new ground by Charlie Haden's Liberation Orchestra, by Jimmy Lyons and by Billy Bang.

title: WEAK SPOTS IN A 'STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM' FOR HIGH SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: HE coined the term ''jet set,'' and on Wednesday night many members o f that flighty group turned out to greet Igor Cassini, better known a s the former gossip columnist ''Cholly Knickerbocker,'' at a party i n his honor at Le Club.

title: STATION HALTS 007 SPOT USING REAGAN
description: A local television station has taken off the air a promotional announcement that gave the impression that President Reagan was endorsing ''James Bond, the First 21 Years,'' a television special about the fictional spy hero.

title: The Tour Guide
description: The way they walked onto center court yesterday, 39-year-old Billie Jean King looked as if she were taking 18-year-old Andrea Jaeger on a summer tour of the British Isles.

title: Lexicon
description: The ways of Washington, says Representative Thomas N. Kindness, are all too often taken at face value by the uninitiated. With that in mind, the Ohio Republican has furnished his constituents, by way of a newsletter, his own lexicon of Washingtonese:

title: BROKER RATE RISES
description: The U.S. Trust Company yesterday raised its broker loan rate to 10 1/4 percent, from 9 3/4 percent. The level at most other major banks is 10 percent.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Red Sox are at the Stadium for the first time this season with Dennis Eckersley (5-5) trying to move over the .500 mark. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia. Tom Seaver, beaten by the Phillies at Shea Stadium last Sunday after the Mets had given him a 4-1 lead, tries to reverse that result. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Sting, at Chicago. Seninho, released by the Cosmos last year and signed by the Sting, got an assist on the winning goal in Chicago's triumph at Giants Stadium last week. Giorgio Chinaglia is expected to return to action tonight, having returned from his business with the Lazio club in Italy. (Television -Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Tennis All-England Championships, men's semifinals, at Wimbledon. The spotlight is on John McEnroe vs. Ivan Lendl. In the other match, Kevin Curren, who defeated Jimmy Connors, meets Chris Lewis. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Other Events Amateur Athletics: National Sports Festival, at Colorado Springs.

title: MUSIC: 'L'HISTOIRE DU SOLDAT' WITH BAIRD MARIONETTES
description: AT the end of Stravinsky's ''Histoire du soldat,'' the soldier, who had earlier beaten the Devil in a game of cards, finally falls prey to his powers. On Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, as the musicians under the direction of Lawrence Leighton Smith played the piquant and emphatic concluding music for the work, the soldier's defeat was particularly disturbing. Though the soldier was played by one of Bil Baird's Marionettes, and though his devilish opponent was also a marionette, with a green face and loose-limbed roving arms, their battle seemed over flesh and blood.

title: British Unemployment
description: The British unemployment rate was 12.4 percent in June, unchanged from a month earlier, the Government said today.

title: REGULATORS LIFT RATE LID ON MOST TIME DEPOSITS
description: Bank regulators decided today to eliminate all remaining interest rate ceilings on savings certificates purchased after Oct.1, 1983, and to ask Congress for legislation to permit banks and thrift institutions to pay interest on checking accounts held by businesses. Some checking accounts for individuals already pay interest.

title: 3 Men Arrested In Fireworks Raid
description: Three men were arrested and $15,000 worth of illegal fireworks were seized yesterday in a raid on a Bronx apartment building, the police said.

title: U.S. Fighters Intercept Two Libyan MIG's
description: American F-14 fighters from the aircraft carrier Eisenhower intercepted two Libyan MIG-23's Wednesday when they came within 108 miles of the vessel in the Mediterranean, the Pentagon said today.

title: U.S. UNIT OF VW IN BLACK
description: Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, reported today that its United States unit made a ''slight profit'' in the first half of 1983, and said it was under no pressure to conclude a cooperation agreement with the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Kaiser Steel Bid Is Withdrawn
description: An investors group headed by the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs has pulled out of an agreement to buy the Kaiser Steel Corporation, a Kaiser official said today.

title: THE RICHEST FILLY, UNOFFICIALLY
description: The easiest way to cash a bet this summer might be to challenge an otherwise savvy race-tracker to name the top money-winning filly or mare in racing history. He will probably say Dahlia and point to the record books, which list that French filly on top with earnings of $1,462,014. But Dahlia is the wrong answer, and by almost $1 million.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 1.9% IN MAY
description: New orders placed with the nation's factories rose 1.9 percent in May from April, to a total value of $169.6 billion, the highest level in 21 months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Major change in Cleveland.
description: TODAY marks the end of an era at the Cleveland Museum of Art. After 25 years, Sherman E. Lee, an outspoken scholar of Oriental art who built the institution into one of the nation's three or four most important museums, is retiring as director. Replacing him is Evan Hopkins Turner, former director of the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and, most recently, of the Ackland Art Museum of the University of North Carolina.

title: Mishap Snarls the Thruway
description: Traffic was backed up for six miles in both directions this morning on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Westchester and Rockland Counties after a tractor-trailer filled with garbage and other debris overturned on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Two drivers were injured slightly in the mishap, which occurred at 8:46 and blocked traffic on the bridge for about an hour.

title: BUILDER CITES PLOY IN MINORITY HIRING
description: A construction company executive testified yesterday that his company had complied with state requirements on hiring minority subcontractors by forming a temporary partnership with a black contractor who had no office, no employees, no equipment and no funds.

title: FOX AGREES TO REVIEW OF ITS AUDITING METHODS
description: Fox & Company, a major accounting firm that has been fighting charges of improper auditing methods, yesterday signed a consent decree with the Securities and Exchange Commission that restricts the firm from accepting new business from publicly traded companies while a special committee of outside accountants reviews its procedures.

title: Choice Is the Only Just Remedy
description: ''This is not an exercise in futility,'' Senator Orrin Hatch said Monday after the latest effort to overturn the 1973 Supreme Court decision making abortion legal. ''The women's suffrage issue took 93 years to resolve.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly described Douglas A. Fraser, former president of the United Automobile Workers. He has never been an ambassador. His predecessor at the union, Leonard Woodcock, was Ambassador to China.

title: MARY LIVINGSTONE, RADIO ACTRESS
description: Mary Livingstone, the widow of Jack Benny, who for decades on radio and television served as her husband's comedic foil, died after a short illness yesterday at her home in Holmby Hills near Los Angeles. She was 77 years old.

title: SARAH VAUGHN IN 'SASSY THE GREAT'
description: SARAH VAUGHAN was in a frisky mood on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, where she headlined a program entitled ''Sassy the Great.'' Appearing with her trio, she performed an extended set that opened with a scat rendition of ''Autumn Leaves'' and culminated with a version of ''Misty,'' part of which was sung as an amusing male impersonation in the singer's booming contralto.

title: Nixon's Son-in-Law Resigns
description: Edward Cox, a son-in-law of former President Nixon, resigned his $67,200-a-year job with the Government's Synthetic Fuels Corporation today to return to private law practice in New York City. Mr. Cox, who married Tricia Nixon, joined the corporation two years ago and was later named its general counsel, vice president and secretary.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Ronald Reagan entered the White House promising substantial reductions in personal income taxes; with the arrival Friday of the third and final cut of his program, the President has delivered. Mr. Reagan also promised to fight inflation and to reduce the burden of Government regulation. There, too, he has delivered.

title: MISS JAEGER TROUNCES MRS. KING
description: Several days ago, when someone asked Billie Jean King when she might retire, she bristled. ''It's like asking Nureyev to stop dancing and Sinatra to stop singing,'' the 39-year-old six-time Wimbledon champion said. ''Why don't they stop?''

title: Turn Welfare in a New Direction
description: The fragmentation of poor black families is an undeniable and unhappy fact of life that burdens all society. For years, however, black leaders resisted direct efforts to help the black family by arguing that the real issue was racism.

title: Pimlico's Owners Will Buy Bowie
description: The owners of Pimlico Race Course have struck a deal to purchase Bowie Race Course, according to representatives of the two Maryland tracks, who said that only legal technicalities remained before the signing of papers.

title: YANKEES APPOINT GENERAL MANAGER
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, named Murray Cook as the team's vice president and general manager yesterday. Cook, 42, who joined the Yankees last January after spending 21 years in the Pittsburgh Pirates' organization, will assume control of baseball operations in what a news release called a newly created position.

title: Renault, Michelin To Offer Bonds
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the state-owned automobile manufacturer, plans to raise at least $39 million and as much as $156 million by issuing variable-rate bonds next week, bond market sources said today.

title: WHERE FANTASY AND NOSTAGLIA MIX
description: Even in these days of ''E.T.,'' ''WarGames'' and ''Return of the Jedi,'' many still recall with some nostalgia that Saturday matinee almost 30 years ago when they took their first step into highvoltage science fiction. Fortified with popcorn and Milk Duds, they sat transfixed by the adventures of a mad inventor named Captain Nemo, played by James Mason, whose submarine, the Nautilus, was fitted out with plush 19th-century velvet interiors, a spooky pipe organ and a picture window as big as those in their suburban living rooms. Walt Disney's ''20,000 Leagues Under the Sea'' seemed almost a quantum leap from the pulp science-fiction magazines that youngsters of the 50's read on the sly at home. Today, it seems a quaint footnote in film history in the face of Jabba the Hutt.

title: Dancing at Lunch
description: A modern-dance troupe called Baker's Half Dozen will give free lunchtime performances today at noon and 1 P.M. at the Upper Plaza on Water Street between Old Slip and Coenties Slip.

title: CANADA FREEZES FUEL PRICES
description: Canada today effectively froze the domestic prices of natural gas and much of its crude oil for 18 months. The action ended months of debate between Ottawa and Alberta, where 90 percent of Canada's oil is produced.

title: American Is Named President of Miles
description: Miles Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that its board had elected Richard B. Kocher as president. Mr. Kocher, 63 years old, succeeds Dr. Franz J. Geks, 64, who continues as chairman and chief executive. Miles, which makes such products as Alka-Seltzer and One-A-Day vitamins, is owned by Bayer A.G. of West Germany.

title: West German Sees No Gains At the Arms Talks in Geneva
description: Soviet and American negotiators met for two and a quarter hours today to discuss limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: WYNEGAR CLOUT BEATS ORIOLES
description: When the Yankees visit Baltimore, they enjoy getting their fill of crabcakes, but when the Orioles visited New York this week, they did not enjoy getting their fill of Butch Wynegar.

title: MANHATTAN SOUTH HEAD QUITS AFTER NOT GETTING PROMOTION
description: Assistant Chief Milton Schwartz, police commander for the Manhattan South area - regarded as the Police Department's most challenging and prestigious field command - resigned yesterday.

title: Funds Shrink $1.3 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $1.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $165.6 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Required Reading; About Bill Miller
description: Remarks on the Senate floor by Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the majority leader, regarding the death of William E. Miller. June 28, 1983:

title: PANEL OFFERS GOVERNMENT A PLAN ON SAVING $137 BILLION IN OUTLAYS
description: A Presidential advisory group offered a blueprint today of how the Federal Government could save $137 billion over the next three years, two-thirds of it in military spending.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 1, 1983
description: International A new effort to remove foreign troops from Lebanon has been made by Washington, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the Administration had asked Israel to agree now to a timetable for a step-by-step withdrawal of its forces in the hope that such a move might bring about a similar withdrawal of Syrian forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ignorance of Central America policy was reflected in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Only 25 percent of the respondents knew that the Reagan Administration supports the Government in El Salvador, only 13 percent knew that it sides with the rebels in Nicaragua and only 8 percent was aware of both stands. (A1:4-5.)

title: Security Pacific Seeks Ralli Equity
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said it received approval from the Federal Reserve Board and the Swiss Federal Banking Commission to acquire 66.7 percent of Ralli Brothers S.A. through its Security Pacific Capital Markets Group subsidiary.

title: Texas Instruments And Mattel Layoffs
description: Texas Instruments and Mattel, two of the manufacturers that have been hardest hit by the sudden downturn in home computer and home video game sales, announced layoffs yesterday, in what analysts said was more evidence that the companies are sharply curtailing production.

title: TRADING IN BALDWIN SUSPENDED
description: Trading in the stock of the Baldwin-United Corporation was suspended yesterday at the request of the big insurance conglomerate while it tries to negotiate a new extension of debt payments. The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the suspension of trading in Baldwin shares on all of the nation's exchanges until July 9.

title: CONVENTION HALL STILL ENMESHED IN UNCERTAINTY
description: It has been nearly three months since Governor Cuomo ordered a report within 20 days on New York City's troubled Convention Center. ''I am disturbed that both its ultimate costs and its completion date are still unclear,'' the Governor said on March 31, when he asked William J. Stern, head of the state's Urban Development Corporation, and Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, for the analysis.

title: CSX Asks Court To Back Takeover
description: The CSX Corporation, seeking to dislodge its $1.07 billion takeover of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation from a last-minute snag, asked a Federal appeals court today to set aside a lower court order blocking the transaction.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Golden Nugget Inc.'s offering of 250,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1993 and 12 pre-split five-year common stock purchase warrants, was priced at $1,000 a unit, through Drexel Burnham Lambert. The notes, issued through a subsidiary, Golden Nugget Finance Corp., are unconditionally guaranteed by the parent company.

title: Cleveland Bond Issue Welcomed in Market
description: Cleveland has returned to the financial markets, selling $27.5 million in general obligation bonds in its first long-term borrowing since 1978, when it became the first large city to default since the Great Depression.

title: ART: RELIVING THE HEYDAY OF THE SAVOY BALLROOM
description: THE most spectacular installation of the year to date can be seen through Sept. 4 at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. A three-dimensional reconstruction of the Savoy Ballroom, which flourished from 1926 to 1959 on Lenox Avenue at 140th Street, it is the work of Richard Yarde, a painter now in his 44th year and known for his imaginative approach to subjects drawn from the black experience.

title: WIM WENDER'S 'HAMMETT'
description: ''HAMMETT,'' the first major American movie by Wim Wenders, the sometimes excellent German director (''The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick,'' ''The American Friend''), isn't quite the mess one might expect, considering the length of time it's been in production and the number of people who seem to have contributed to it. It's not ever boring, but heaven only knows what it's supposed to be about or why it was made. One answer would serve both questions.

title: TEACHERS' MERIT PAY: 1. NARROW
description: President Reagan, visiting Tennessee to support Governor Lamar Alexander's proposal to give merit pay to teachers, in a Knoxville school read from ''Macbeth'' -life ''is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.'' He concluded with the hope that none of the students would ever be so cynical. But Mr. Reagan's support for a merit pay program without evidence of its effectiveness and without a coherent, comprehensive plan for improving education nationwide is itself sound and fury signifying nothing - at least nothing good for education -and a cause for cynicism.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Cuomo's major accomplishment during his first legislative session was to banish the ghost of Hugh L. Carey from the halls of the Capitol and thus get legislators talking to, instead of screaming at, the Governor again.

title: People
description: * Francisco Vergara joined the Campbell-Ewald Co. as senior vice president, creative director, for Latin American operations based in Miami.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DEUCES WILD. By Bernard Lenteric. Translated from the French by William Byron. 208 pages. Coward-McCann. $13.95.

title: SALVADOR TOWN DANCES TO ITS OWN TUNE
description: The moon was high, the band loud, the beer running freely, and no one wanted to miss the dance celebrating the first graduation of students at the new high school.

title: JUNE FARM PRICES FELL
description: Prices paid to farmers fell 2.2 percent in June from May, the first decline in five months, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: TASS REPORTS 'SPACE TUGBOAT' IS ATTACHED TO SALYUT STATION
description: The two Soviet astronauts aboard the Salyut 7 space station opened doors to a large attached module yesterday in a development that is expected to afford greater capacity, maneuverability and flexibility to the Soviet Union's manned space operations.

title: No Headline
description: Books: The Best of Guilt By Dan Carlinsky HOW TO BE A GUILTY PARENT. By Glenn Collins. Illustrated by Gahan Wilson. 109 pages. Times Books. $7.95.

title: ISRAELI TIMETABLE FOR WITHDRAWAL IS SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: The United States has asked Israel to agree now to a timetable for the step-by-step removal of its forces from Lebanon in the hope of getting a similar agreement from Syria, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Twin Phyfes set record.
description: TWIN Duncan Phyfe tables from twin owners sold yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72 Street, for $275,000, a record price for Federal furniture and the second highest auction price for 19thcentury furniture. ''They are a bargain - I expected they would sell for much more,'' said the buyer, Berry B. Tracy, an antiques dealer from Goshen, N.Y., after the sale. Mr. Tracy, who was curator in charge of American decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from 1968 to 1981, bought them for a client whose name he would not disclose.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SETS A FORMAL INQUIRY ON CARTER PAPERS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would conduct a formal investigation into how Ronald Reagan's campaign in 1980 secretly obtained debate strategy material prepared for President Carter.

title: Private School Aid: Still Unwise
description: The Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality - but not the wisdom - of tax breaks for parents of private and parochial school children.

title: Australian Visits Hanoi On the Cambodia Issue
description: Foreign Minister William Hayden of Australia met with Vietnam's Prime Minister, Pham Van Dong, today for talks aimed at bringing peace to neighboring Cambodia.

title: SHARING DATA OF GRAND JURY IS RESTRICTED
description: The Supreme Court today limited the ability of Federal prosecutors to share grand jury information with other Government lawyers and agencies. The Justice Department said the two decisions would make it more difficult for the Federal Government to pursue civil investigations for fraud, bribery and income tax violations.

title: POLISH PRELATE SAYS SOLIDARITY ISN'T DEAD
description: A Polish archbishop said on arrival here today that the outlawed Solidarity movement ''is not finished.'' This statement, made to reporters by Archbishop Henryk Gulbinowicz of Wroclaw, came at a time when unconfirmed reports were circulating that Pope John Paul II had reached an understanding with the Government of Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski during the recent papal tour of Poland and counseled Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, to leave public life.

title: News Analysis
description: The question most frequently asked this past week was whether Pope John Paul II had made a deal with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski to get Lech Walesa, the leader of the banned Solidarity free trade union, out of Polish politics. But the more important question, in the view of diplomats here, is what the Russians will do now that the Pope has come and gone. What will the Kremlin make of the crowds joining together again in their millions, after the lonely isolation of martial law, flourishing their forbidden Solidarity banners and cheering the way the Pope upbraided the authorities from the moment he stepped off the plane and kissed his native soil.

title: Woman Admits Larceny at Bank
description: An East Brunswick woman admitted in Federal court today that she had typed in false deposits of more than $100,000 in her savings account book and then withdrawn the money, authorities said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The A.M.A. does not pooh-pooh dioxin.'' - Dr. John R. Beljan of the American Medical Association.

title: Danger of Asbestos Stressed in Schools Study
description: About 10 percent of the nation's public schools have crumbling asbestos insulation that is a potential cancer risk to four million pupils and school employees, according to a union survey made public today.

title: Paris Reports Sending More Arms to Chad
description: French officials said today that the Government had delivered 200 tons of military equipment to Chad since rebel forces captured a town in the north of the country last week.

title: Patty Davis Is Wed to Martin J. Raynes
description: Patricia Ann Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Davis of Cherry Hills, Colo., and Palm Springs, Calif., was married in New York yesterday to Martin J. Raynes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius B. Raynes of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, performed the ceremony in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel.

title: JEWELER CHARGED WITH ROLE IN SALE OF STOLEN JEWISH RELIGIOUS OBJECTS
description: The owner of a Brooklyn jewelry exchange was arrested yesterday on charges that he served as a conduit for thousands of dollars worth of stolen Jewish relgious articles, a spokesman for the police said.

title: LOYALTY IS THE THEME AS ROY COHN FEASTS FRIENDS
description: On the guest list were Andy Warhol and Carmine G. De Sapio, Calvin Klein and Abraham D. Beame, along with assorted entrepreneurs, judges and politicians. They were Republicans and Democrats, conservatives and liberals, and they came from as far away as California and Washington, D.C.

title: A STAR-SPANGLED THREE-STATE FOURTH OF JULY WEEKEND
description: RUFFLES and flourishes will herald the celebrations by land, air and sea of the nation's 207th birthday this Fourth of July weekend. Most of the festivities, which will resound especially loudly around Manhattan's shores, will be free, with the public definitely invited.

title: UPDATING 2 BETHLEHEM PLANTS
description: In a major move to modernize its plants, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, announced yesterday that it would spend $500 million to build continuous casters at its two largest plants.

title: REAGAN SAYS SECURITY OF THE U.S. IS 'WHY CENTRAL AMERICA MATTERS'
description: President Reagan, using some of his sharpest language, said tonight that the security and safety of United States citizens were at risk in Central America.

title: REAGAN PRAISES SCHOOL FOR IMPROVED PROGRAMS
description: It was, above all, something of a school rally. There were banners, there were cheers, and, before it ended, there was President Reagan, using the occasion and the setting to celebrate how a problem school had turned itself around.

title: Officials Tie Cache of Bombs To Holiday Plot by F.A.L.N.
description: Explosives and disguises that a Puerto Rican independence group was said to have planned to use in Fourth of July weekend bombings at Illinois prisons and military sites were seized today in a raid by Federal, state and local officials.

title: ARGENTINE ENVOY SAYS DEMOCRACY IS THE GOAL
description: Since Argentina's Ambassador to the United States, Lucio Garcia del Solar, joined his country's Foreign Service in 1944, he has resigned twice over political principles. The first time was in 1946, when he resumed the life of a private citizen for nine years. The second time was in 1966, when he resigned as Ambassador to Moscow after a military coup toppled the Argentine constitutional government.

title: Economic Scene; Understanding Role of Budget
description: HOW can the job of creating a budget for the nation be improved? One fundamental need, says the Committee for Economic Development in its recently issued report, is an increased understanding by Congress, the White House and the public of how the budget affects the economy and how the economy affects the budget.

title: Banks to Extend Credit to Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines' banks have agreed to resume extending credit to the financially troubled carrier just a day before the company could have run out of cash, Eastern officials said.

title: BOY, 11, IS 3D DROWNING VICTIM IN DELANEY MISHAP
description: An 11-year-old boy died in a hospital here early today, the third drowning victim in a waterhole that claimed the life of Joe Delaney, the 24-year-old halfback for the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Orosco Is an All-Star
description: Jesse Orosco was the only member of the Mets to be chosen for next Wednesday night's All-Star Game in Chicago as the National and American Leagues completed their roster selections yesterday.

title: THE MASTER OF THE CHIFFON DRESS
description: George Stavropoulos is known for designing important dresses at, let's face it, important prices. The styles change, of course, from season to season, but not enough to make them obsolete. This, of course, is one of their charms.

title: 'STROKER ACE' AT WHEEL
description: HAL NEEDHAM'S ''Stroker Ace,'' which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters and stars Burt Reynolds as a stock-car racer, is the must-miss movie of the summer. It's a witless retread of the earlier, far funnier road-movie collaborations of Mr. Needham and Mr. Reynolds, especially of their two ''Smokey and the Bandit'' movies.

title: ROCK: ALARM AND THE IRISH U2 OPEN PIER 84 CONCERT SEASON
description: BACK in the 1970's, the low-priced concert series staged by the rock promoter Ron Delsener traditionally opened in Central Park with a comfortably middle-of-the-road act so that the assembled city dignitaries, whose favor was curried to keep the concerts in the park, could avoid having their eardrums ruptured by the rudeness of rock.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Is Agency For CBS
description: IN a departure from network TV tradition, CBS has gone outside its own facilities to hire an ad agency to create and produce its promotional commercials for the fall season.

title: Lewis Out Of Festival
description: Carl Lewis, who says he has injured a leg, has withdrawn from the three-day track-and-field competition that will begin Friday at the National Sports Festival.

title: Football Planned Round the World
description: Some fans may think that the saturation point may have been reached with the arrival of the United States Football League this year, but there is more professional football on the way. And the backers of the new league say they are serious.

title: Birkenmeier Stands Firm In the Goal
description: The Vancouver Whitecaps entered Wednesday night's game at Giants Stadium with 13-1 record, the best in the North American Soccer League, but they were able to create only two genuine scoring chances in a 3-0 loss to the Cosmos.

title: Eurobonds Move Higher
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds in Europe maintained their early gains of as much as half a point on professional short-covering, dealers said today.

title: TRIBUTE TO THE LATE BILL EVANS
description: THE jazz festival's tribute to the late pianist Bill Evans at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, produced by his longtime manager, Helen Keane, did not lack for top-notch talent.

title: Freeport to Buy Stone Exploration
description: The Stone Exploration Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by Freeport McMoran Inc. for 3.2 million Freeport shares. Stone said the agreement also provides for up to an additional 1.5 million shares to be issued subsequently, based on further gas reserves being established at Stone's Lac Blanc field in Vermilion Parish, La.

title: BASF Sales Rise 3%
description: BASF A.G., a leading chemicals concern, recorded a 3 percent rise in group sales in the first half of 1983 from the comparable 1982 period, the company's chairman, Mathias Seefelder, told a shareholders' meeting today.

title: MEXICO'S BIGGEST NEED
description: Time and money, it is argued, are what Mexico needs to survive its economic crisis and to avoid political chaos. We hear it from President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, who took office in 1982 after six years of economic mismanagement by President Jose Lopez Portillo. The point is echoed by United States bankers who contributed to the $80 billion lending avalanche and are eager to secure their loans. It is echoed by academic analysts who failed to notice Mexico's slide toward disaster and now hope for recovery through huge doses of optimism.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Federated Department Stores, Cincinnati, has named Clinton A. Clark president and chief executive officer of its Children's Place division.

title: Feldstein Links Rates to Budget
description: Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the Administration's expectation that interest rates will fall is based on Congressional approval of the Reagan budget.

title: DeLorean Funds Frozen
description: A Federal Bankrupcty Court judge ordered today that proceeds from the sale of a company owned by John Z. DeLorean be put in an escrow account.

title: Dubinskys Close Cycle
description: The Dubinsky Duo - the violinist Rostislav Dubinsky and his wife, the pianist Luba Edlina - will close a cycle of the complete Beethoven sonatas for violin and piano tonight and tomorrow night at 8 at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Running Advice
description: The familiar yellow buses that carry millions of American youngsters to school each day do not enhance a nation's Olympic prospects, according to African sports journalists touring the United States.

title: 'SPARKLE'?
description: President Reagan's cheering announcement of ''sparkle'' in the U.S. economy hasn't brightened eyes here. Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt says bluntly that the recovery will be ''short and flat'' compared with previous business cycles. ''It will peter out in 1984 if the U.S. doesn't reduce the enormous budget deficit, measured against the American rate of savings,'' Mr. Schmidt said in a conversation. For world economic recovery, he said, it is ''absolutely necessary that the U.S. not delude itself about the upswing in turnover and production.''

title: Market Place; Recent Lag For A.T.& T.
description: ''THE performance of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's common stock this year has been a disappointment,'' Leonard S. Hyman of Merrill Lynch said yesterday. ''But I still believe that sometime in 1984, once the dust of the company's reorganization has settled, the equivalent price could be in the 80's.''

title: HAULER IN MISSOURI HAD SITE IN ILLINOIS
description: Russell Bliss, a waste hauler who has been linked to numerous cases of dioxin contamination in Missouri, is under investigation again, this time because toxic chemicals have been found in a tank pockmarked with holes that he buried near the Mississippi River in Illinois.

title: WIMBLEDON, HEROES AND IRELAND
description: THE official title of the event is the All-England Lawn Tennis Championships. Just about everybody, though, knows it as Wimbledon. The 106th playing of the matches reaches the final rounds this weekend and will be broadcast on Channel 4 by NBC Sports live from London tomorrow and Sunday, beginning at 9 A.M.

title: 2 Votes for Kuhn
description: At least two baseball officials, both former players, believe that Bowie Kuhn, who was voted out of office by the owners last winter, will nonetheless be reappointed commissioner when his term expires in a month and a half. One of them, Hank Aaron, remains a candidate to succeed the commissioner, but the former home-run king, now a member of the Atlanta Braves' front office, says that ''I think Kuhn's chances of being reappointed are very good.''

title: POLL FINDS AMERICANS DON'T KNOW U.S. POSITIONS ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Despite months of controversy over United States policies on Central America, most of the American public does not know which side the Reagan Administration supports in either El Salvador or Nicaragua, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: 60 BRIDGES LIKE THE SPAN THAT FELL BEING INSPECTED
description: Connecticut officials said today that they had identified and begun inspecting 60 bridges with designs similar to the one here on which a section of roadway collapsed Monday, killing three people.

title: GUATEMALANS SWEAR IN TRIBUNAL ON ELECTIONS
description: The Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt swore in an electoral tribunal today charged with beginning a process of democratization.

title: Curtains for Murder
description: Murders takes the stage this weekend. The Apple Corps Theater Company is performing Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's ''Hound of the Baskervilles,'' the Sherlock Holmes novel, adapted by Tim Kelly, tonight and tomorrow night at 8, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 P.M., at its stage on 11th Avenue at 51st Street.

title: Contract Study
description: Jack Hamilton, the general manager of the Victorian Football League of Australia, and his legal advisers have met with Charles Feeney, the president of the National League, and with Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League.

title: American Killed During Visit
description: Two American Embassy staff members, one an American and the other Indian, were killed and two Americans critically injured today when their car and a truck collided on the Agra road during the visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Mr. Shultz and his wife arrived in Agra Wednesday night to view the Taj Mahal. The embassy did not release the names of the victims pending notification of next of kin.

title: SIX POLICE DOGS TO BE ASSIGNED TO CENTRAL PARK
description: Nero, the Hero, and his five canine colleagues took up their posts in Central Park yesterday, as final preparations got under way for introducing patrol dogs into the New York City Police Department.

title: SUMMER GUIDE TO ADVENTURE, ON WATER, LAND AND IN THE AIR
description: On summer weekends near New York, enthusiasts jump off cliffs, climb mountainsides, glide through the sky and skitter over the ocean. On any bright summer day, hundreds of New Yorkers can be found canoeing down the fast-flowing waters of the Delaware River or swimming under the sea near ancient shipwrecks. Here is an abbreviated guide to where people in the area can receive instruction in and try their hands at adventurous outdoor sports, for a weekend or a day. Call at least a few days in advance for reservations.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Including a net nonrecurring charge of $7.8 million for the quarter and year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $69,000.

title: 'Big Knife' at Berkshire
description: A production of Clifford Odets's ''Big Knife'' began the 55th season of the Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass., last Wednesday.

title: P.L.O. CHIEFS URGE CEASE-FIRE
description: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization called today for a cease-fire between rival Palestinian factions in eastern Lebanon and decided to send a mediation team to talk to all sides in the dispute.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Aims of Sandinismo
description: No words come easier to the ruling Sandinistas in Nicaragua than pluralism, a mixed economy and nonalignment - ostensibly the hallmarks of their brand of Marxism. It is surely worth considering what they mean before dismissing all their aims as incorrigibly totalitarian.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $52,439. c-Net income.

title: ROCKWOOD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a credit of $100,000 repreRsenting the reversal of a reserve provided in prior years that no longer is considered necessary. c-After interest of $214,000 on the company's convertible income debentures and includes $183,000 of expenses representing payments for the settlement of certain litigation and claims. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title:
PATENTS;
Implantable, Artificial Heart System Devised
description: An implantable blood-pumping system, or artificial heart, has been patented for Foxcroft Associates, a sponsor of research projects, in San Antonio.

title: Legal Routes Dwindle For Killer in Mississippi
description: A Federal district judge today denied a stay of execution for Jimmy Lee Gray, who is scheduled to die Wednesday in the gas chamber for the 1976 slaying of Deressa Scales, 3 years old. Mr. Gray's lawyers appealed the decision.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $75,000 for the quarter and $213,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $76,000 for the quarter and $254,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ivy League Boats Gain at Henley
description: Two Harvard entries and one from Princeton advanced today to the quarterfinals of the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Woman, 20, Found Strangled Near a House in Coney Island
description: The body of a 20-year-old woman was found early yesterday in the yard of a home about a mile from her own home in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: REAGAN RENEWS ARMS CUT PLEDGE
description: President Reagan, noting the 15th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, today reiterated a commitment to ''take whatever steps are necessary'' to make progress toward reaching a strategic nuclear weapons agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: ONE VIEW OF NORTON'S CHIEF
description: In 1972, David J. Mahoney, the chief executive of Norton Simon Inc., declared in an interview that he planned to stay on for 8 or 10 years. ''By then, I'll either have made my pile or flopped,'' he said.

title: Guidry Lost to All-Stars
description: The Yankees notified the American League office yesterday that an aching back would not permit Ron Guidry to pitch next Wednesday night in the 50th anniversary All-Star Game in Chicago.

title: U.S. WEIGHS PANEL ON LATIN AMERICA
description: The Reagan Administration is moving toward setting up a commission that would seek a national consensus on policies involving Central America, Administration officials said today.

title: COURT REJECTS NEW YORK OFFICERS' SUIT
description: A badly fractured Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal appeals court in New York properly refused to award back pay and retroactive seniority to a group of black and Hispanic police officers who were laid off in the New York City fiscal crisis in 1975.

title: AMERICAN INDUSTRY'S ROLE IN COMBATING HUNGER
description: To the Editor:

title: Natt Accepts Terms
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers have signed the free agent forward Calvin Natt of the Portland Trail Blazers to a multiyear offer sheet.

title: King Signs Davis
description: Howard Davis Jr., the lightweight contender, has signed with the promoter Don King and has become a junior welterweight contender.

title: Budget Impasses Freeze Checks in Two States
description: California and Pennsylvania withheld issuing checks yesterday because of impasses over their state budgets.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALFRESCO JAZZ

title: FATHOMING THE ESSENCE OF AMERICAN COOKING
description: The Fourth of July is perhaps the best time to try to decide what is and what is not American food. The subject has been much discussed in the last year and a half at conferences around the country on what is being called the new American cuisine.

title: Bridge: A Strange Play May Lead To Well-Deserved Disaster
description: When people walk a tightrope across Niagara Falls, they are expecting to attract attention. The bridge player who does the same thing in a technical way in defense must realize that he will atract the attention of his opponent as well as his partner, and the result may be a disastrous crash.

title: New Job for Csonka
description: Larry Csonka has joined the front office of the new Jacksonville franchise of the United States Football League. Csonka will work with the player personnel director, Nick Kish, who was his college roommate at Syracuse. The former fullback left the Miami Dolphins to go to the Memphis franchise of the World Football League and then played for the Giants before returning to the Dolphins.

title: OFFICER SHOT AND SUSPECT SLAIN IN MIDTOWN AFTER A ROBBERY
description: A gunman was killed and a suspect and a city detective were wounded in an exchange of gunfire last evening across from Pennsylvania Station, the authorities reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a House subcommittee hearing on dioxin incorrectly described the Congressional district of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of New York. It includes parts of the Bronx, Queens and Nassau County.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Important Question
description: His baseball days seemingly over, Mark Fidrych, the former Detroit pitcher, is back on his 123-acre farm in Northboro, Mass. Fidrych, who is 28 years old, said his farm needs a lot of work and won't support him. ''It's a weight off my shoulders,'' he said, ''but there's a weight put on as well. Where am I going to get my next job?''

title: INSURGENT CANDIDATE SETTLES A SUIT WITH DEMOCRATIC LEADERS IN CITY
description: A lawsuit accusing Democratic Party leaders in New York City of using state and city employees to help block anti-organization candidates has been settled, with both sides claiming victory.

title: ISRAEL OPPOSING U.S. SUGGESTION ON WITHDRAWAL
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel had not abandoned its determination to see simultaneous Syrian and Israeli withdrawals from Lebanon.

title:
PATENTS;
Trademark Exposition Set for Next Weekend
description: A trademark exposition, open to the public, will be held in the Great Hall of the Department of Commerce building in Washington next Saturday and Sunday, July 9 and 10.

title: LICENSE OF TRAINER IN BOXING REVOKED
description: Carlos (Panama) Lewis, who has worked in the corners of such successful fighters as Aaron Pryor, Roberto Duran and Vito Antuofermo, appeared to have been permanently banned from boxing yesterday when the New York State Athletic Commission revoked his manager's and second's licenses.

title: NORBERT L.H. ROESLER
description: Norbert L.H. Roesler, an international banker in New York City for more than three decades, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: News Analysis
description: It has become increasingly clear since Syria expelled Yasir Arafat a week ago that the rebellion among his Fatah guerrillas in Lebanon is another variation of the long-running power struggle between the P.L.O. chairman and President Hafez al-Assad.

title: Las Vegas Bank Closed
description: Bank regulators said today they had closed the Mineral Bank of Nevada in Las Vegas, the first bank failure in the state since 1933. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said it had acted after it became clear that it could not merge the bank into another institution.

title: Smooth Start for a Summer of the Bard in the Park
description: ''Now is the winter of our discontent,'' intoned Kevin Kline, playing Richard III. ''Ja, ja,'' an audience member said contentedly. And so began the 28th season of free Shakespeare in Central Park, when 1,100 people Thursday night saw the stage and film actor's first outing with the Bard.

title: Dr. Nathan Halper Dies at 75; An Authority on James Joyce
description: Dr. Nathan Halper, a writer and authority on James Joyce, died June 26 at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., after emergency intestinal surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Provincetown, Mass., and Manhattan.

title: TOO MUCH FOR BROOKLYN
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERN JAZZ QUARTET AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: The new career of the Modern Jazz Quartet is taking on definite characteristics since the four musicians came together a couple of years ago after seemingly going their separate ways in the mid-1970's.

title: Four Share Lead In L.P.G.A. Golf
description: Hollis Stacy sank a 60-yard sand wedge shot on the final hole, and Sandra Spuzich played the back nine in five under par today as they earned a share of a four-way tie for the lead after two rounds of the $250,000 Peter Jackson Classic.

title: Ex-Brooklynites Pursuing Ralph Cramden's Uniform
description: Wife jokes, sewer jokes, fat jokes, thin jokes and above all, Brooklyn jokes - for years, Robert Columbe and Peter Crescenti have been retelling gags from ''The Honeymooners,'' the television series that immortalized Brooklyn and Jackie Gleason.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS STOCK ANALYST WHO TOLD CLIENTS ABOUT A FRAUD
description: The Supreme Court vindicated Raymond L. Dirks today, ruling that the securities analyst did not misuse inside information in warning several clients that the Equity Funding Corporation was about to collapse.

title: TV: CUBANS IN NEW JERSEY
description: ''Made in Cuba,'' a documentary written and narrated by Pete Hamill, examines life among Cuban emigres. In particular, it examines life in Union City, N.J., which is ''very much a suburb,'' Mr. Hamill says, ''of that lost city of Havana.''

title: DECADE OF UNCERTAINTY ENDS IN 'FINALITY' FOR 2 VIETNAM WIDOWS
description: Beside each of the 57,939 names of the American dead and missing inscribed on the gleaming black granite walls of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington there is a symbol: a diamond for the confirmed dead and an asterisk for the missing in action.

title: OFFICIALS BLAME SEPARATIST GROUPS FOR SERIES OF BOMBINGS IN CORSICA
description: A police patrol boat was sunk, a police station was bombed and then sprayed with machine-gun fire and about 20 cars were destroyed in attacks during the night on Corsica.

title: F.B.I. LIKELY TO ASK KEY REAGAN AIDES ABOUT 1980 DEBATE
