description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that its inquiry into the 1980 Presidential campaign would probably require interviews with leading Reagan Administration officials.

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $38.5 million for the quarter and $39.7 million for the year. c-Net income after net gain from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and $5,013,000 for the year.

title: 3 Data Services Join in Venture
description: Dow Jones & Company, The Associated Press and Telerate Inc. have announced an agreement in principle to form a company to market Telerate's financial information services and the AP-Dow Jones newswires to subscribers outside the United States and Canada.

title: A SCHUMER INQUIRY BY MISS HOLTZMAN PERMITTED BY COURT
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn should not be disqualified from investigating or prosecuting Representative Charles E. Schumer. Allegations have been made that Mr. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, illegally used State Assembly personnel and funds in his 1980 race for the House of Representatives.

title: MGF Oil Suit
description: The MGF Oil Corporation said it will fight a bondholder suit filed Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio that charges that the company has defaulted on an interest payment. The suit could force MGF into involuntary bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code. MGF has until July 19 to respond to the suit.

title: GRAND OLE OPRY FINDS A BUYER
description: It was founded in 1925 and became an entertainment staple in the Great Depression, the answer to an impoverished people's yearning for inexpensive family entertainment. At one time, it was likened to a religion for the spiritual hold it had on millions of Americans of simple means.

title: JMB REALTY CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $573,109, or 81 cents a share, from the sale of two land investments.

title: An Eternal Inning
description: In the second round of a Dizzy Dean League baseball tournament for 7-year-old boys at Boynton, Ga., on Wednesday, Rossville held a 23-19 lead as the teams went into the fifth and final inning.

title: New Yorkers in Edinburgh
description: Six New York dance and theater groups have been invited to perform at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in Scotland from Aug. 22 to Sept. 10. The groups are: Ruth Barnes, with Susan Alexander and David Robinson; Ara Fitzgerald and Wall Matthews; Erin Martin, Davidson Lloyd and Denman Maroney; Peter Lobdell and Joanne Munisteri; Pink, and Mark Taylor and Friends. Information: 420-0260.

title: QUESTIONS ON INFANT DEATHS BESET SAN ANTONIO HOSPITAL
description: Doctors and staff members at a hospital under investigation for possible ''multiple infant homicides'' were aware as long as two years ago of a significant increase in infant deaths.

title: ANDERSON WEIGHS NORTON MOVES
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company, so far unsuccessful in its effort to buy part of Norton Simon Inc., said yesterday that it was ''reviewing its options'' following Norton Simon's acceptance of an estimated $918 million takeover bid from Esmark Inc.

title: HOUSE UNIT PUTS OFF TAX BILL
description: Despite a Congressional instruction to draft a tax bill by July 22, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has decided to put off that task until after Labor Day, staff aides said today.

title: Index; International
description: On the Honduran coast, a world apart 2 Reagan considering panel to seek a consensus on Latin policy 2 Bombings in Corsica blamed on separatists 3 Around the World 4 The P.L.O. leadership calls for a cease-fire in Lebanon 4 Washington Talk Potent bloc from Rockies in Sen- ate 7 Briefing 7 Government/Politics Air Force finds no high death rate among defoliant sprayers 9 Ex-prosecutor wins libel award against Philadelphia Inquirer 9 Investigation of Schumer by Miss Holtzman is permitted by court 25 Insurgent candidate and city Democratic leaders settle suit 40 Obituaries Mary Livingstone, radio actress 8 Len B. Jordan, ex-Governor and U.S. Senator from Idaho 8 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Monday is Independence Day.Fol- lowing are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: STING AND SENINHO BEAT COSMOS, 5-2
description: Seninho, the forward who signed with Chicago after being released by the Cosmos, scored two goals against his former teammates tonight and led the Sting to a 5-2 victory.

title: CRUZ DRIVES IN SIX AS ORIOLES WIN, 9-5
description: Todd Cruz, playing his first game with Baltimore, hit his eighth home run of the season and drove in six runs tonight as the Orioles rebounded from losing three straight against the Yankees with a 9-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS MAJOR MEASURES AFFECTING TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo has signed measures affecting rent controls, tax abatements for developers and pensions for public employees, his office announced today.

title: Tests for Palmer
description: Jim Palmer, the three-time Cy Young award winner, has left the Orioles in Detroit to return to Baltimore for tests on his sore arm.

title: Court Approves Numex Unit Plan
description: The Numex Corporation, Hartford, announced that its United States Machine Tools Inc. subsidiary's plan of reorganization had been approved by bankruptcy court officials in Connecticut. The subsidiary, Numex's only operating unit, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1982.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $90,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss.

title: SOVIET EASES STAND AT MADRID TALKS
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was prepared to reach a compromise to bring the long-deadlocked Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to a ''successful and immediate conclusion.''

title: Gaylord Perry Has No Regrets
description: For the moment, Gaylord Perry is working 120 acres of peanuts, 200 acres of corn and 200 acres of soybeans at his home in Williamston, N.C. The 44-year-old pitcher, who had won 310 major league baseball games before he was waived by the Seattle Mariners last Saturday, is waiting for a call from a team.

title: GREENWICH BRIDGE COLLAPSE CAUSING HARDSHIPS IN PORT CHESTER
description: In the aftermath of a bridge collapse in nearby Greenwich, Conn., a flow of rerouted traffic here, particularly heavy trucks, has disrupted business, worried officials, annoyed residents and provoked some interstate animosity.

title: LONDON CRITICS ARE COOL TO 'BURIED INSIDE EXTRA'
description: British critics have given generally negative reviews to ''Buried Inside Extra,'' Thomas Babe's play that the New York Public Theater brought here in exchange for Caryl Churchill's ''Top Girls,'' which has become an Off Broadway hit.

title: TO HELP THOSE FORCED TO SEEK NEW SKILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL STUDENTS AID'S WORTHY PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Ambulator-Wheelchair Combination Invented
description: A combination wheelchair and ambulator is designed to enable paraplegics, persons with paralyzed legs, to stand up and move themselves around in narrow spaces.

title: Celtics to Stay At Boston Garden
description: The Boston Celtics agreed today to a four year lease with the owners of the Boston Garden, apparently settling differences that had prompted the team's owner, Harry Mangurian, to offer the club for sale.

title: The Talk of La Ceiba
description: If the image of Central America is one of mortar-pocked hills and people living on the edge of war and revolution, then this sultry Caribbean port is part of another world, living in another age.

title: Lewis In Final
description: Chris Lewis, an unseeded player from New Zealand who is ranked only 91st in the men's international computer rating, reached the men's singles final at Wimbledon today and upstaged John McEnroe's 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 semifinal victory over Ivan Lendl.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Wednesday incorrectly described a joint oversight hearing on the Environmental Protection Agency in 1982. Five House subcommittees participated.

title: FIRST U.S. WOMAN IN SPACE CALLED 'EQUAL' TO MEN
description: Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman to travel in space, proved that women are equal to men as astronauts, her commander said yesterday. And Dr. Ride said there were ''no problems with a mixed crew'' on the recent flight of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO CO reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $3,030,000.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $600 MILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $600 million in the week ended June 22, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The increase surprised analysts, who had expected a decline, and interest rates rose sharply.

title: LOVELADY, IKE, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Carroll O'Connor Plans Broadway Show in Fall
description: Carroll O'Connor, who is best known as Archie Bunker in the television series ''All in the Family,'' will appear on Broadway next fall as the star and director of ''Brothers,'' a play by George Sibbald.

title: COMPUTER SCHOLARS LIVE FOR MORE THAN GRAPHICS, CHIPS AND PIXELS
description: It was the usual computerese one hears around the new cognoscenti - talk of chips and programs, pixels and peripherals, hardware and software, commands and graphics.

title: PRETORIA ENDS BANNING ORDERS FOR 50
description: The Government dropped more than 50 names today from its roster of those who are forbidden by state decree to belong to organizations, attend meetings or have their words - spoken or written - printed in any form.

title: Fresh Air Fund to Pay Girl, 8
description: The Fresh Air Fund has agreed to pay $125,000 to Iona Brasier, an 8-year-old East Harlem girl who said she was beaten and burned during a two-week stay that the fund had arranged with Brian and Robbin Nisen of Moretown, Vt., in the summer of 1980. A spokesman for the Fresh Air Fund, Mary Jane Brubaker, said the fund ''deeply regrets the unfortunate incident,'' and noted that it was the first such occurrence in the 107 years that the fund has been providing summer vacations for disadvantaged city children.

title: Former Hospital to Shelter The Aged and Handicapped
description: The Francis Delafield Hospital, closed since 1975, will reopen as a 227-unit housing development for the elderly and handicapped. Mayor Koch, armed with a sledgehammer for the concrete-breaking ceremonies, joined Federal and local officials yesterday on the front steps of what will be called Fort Washington Houses at 163d Street and Riverside Drive in Washington Heights.

title: MARY LIVINGSTONE, RADIO STAR WITH HUSBAND, JACK BENNY
description: Mary Livingstone, the widow of Jack Benny, who for decades on radio and television served as her husband's comedic foil, died after a short illness Thursday at her home in Holmby Hills, near Los Angeles. She was 77 years old.

title: FOR CONTROVERSIAL BROKER: VINDICATION
description: Raymond L. Dirks began his day yesterday by getting beaten on the tennis court. ''I couldn't keep my mind on the game,'' he said, explaining that he was waiting to hear from the Supreme Court. He did, and ended the day savoring champagne and a significant victory.

title: T.E.A.'S NEED T.L.C.
description: Idealized and immortalized in the Beatles song ''Lovely Rita,'' traffic enforcement agents - meter maids, in common parlance - in fact do one of the city's most wearing and thankless jobs, and get little or no support from the public they serve. It is time to give them the recognition they deserve.

title: SATURDAYSPORTS
description: Baseball

title: UNHAND THAT SET!
description: Dozing by the videoside, the milk of human kindness coursing as serenely as always through my arteries, I suddenly became aware the other night that somebody was abusing the Chablis-and-Brie set again. But who? I was alone in the room except for ...

title: FOR BRIDGE INSPECTORS, PRIVATE FEARS
description: In Ron Anino's line of work, the efforts are often anonymous, occurring literally in the shadows. But the problems are often public and, as this week proved, occasionally catastrophic.

title: EFFICIENCY IN HOME COOLING
description: WHEN temperatures move to the wrong side of 90 degrees and stay there, air-conditioning equipment is pushed to its limits. In coping with summer heat, homeowners and apartment dwellers often wonder whether it is best to turn off their air-conditioners while they are a way from home or to let them run, perhaps with the thermostat, if there is one, set at moderate levels.

title: U.S. and Palau Sign Nuclear Transit Accord
description: Officials of the United States and Palau signed an agreement today allowing the United States to transport nuclear materials through the island republic but banning tests or storage of nuclear weapons in the area.

title: LEN JORDAN, A FORMER SENATOR
description: Len B. Jordan, a former Governor of Idaho and United States Senator whose political career spanned a quarter of a century, died Thursday night after suffering a stroke two days ago. He was 84 years old.

title: TALKS FAIL TO PRODUCE THEATER PACT
description: The Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers has unanimously voted to withhold the services of its members from the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers as of yesterday. But negotiations on a contract are expected to resume next Thursday.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Press Notes column yesterday misstated the status of plans by the Reuters news agency. Reuters is conducting surveys to determine whether to start a picture service.

title: Stokely-Van Camp Gets Pillsbury Bid
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc. said its board met today to consider an unsolicited request from the Pillsbury Company to acquire Stokely common stock for $62 a share, or about $170 million.

title: COLLEGES CRITICIZE COURT ORDER TYING STUDENT AID TO DRAFT LAW
description: Despite widespread practical concerns and philosphical disagreements over an order by the Supreme Court this week that will deny financial aid to students who fail to register for the draft, local college and university officials say they will try to comply.

title: GETZ, BRUBECK, MULLIGAN
description: In a nostalgically conceived program that brought three pillars of 1950's jazz to the festival - Stan Getz, Dave Brubeck and Gerry Mulligan -to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday, Mr. Getz walked away with the evening.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 10.

title: Blackout in Eastern Salvador
description: Guerrillas blew up two power pylons today and blacked out eastern El Salvador, an official of the stateowned electrical utility said. About 1.5 million people in Usulutan, San Miguel, La Union and Morazan Provinces were affected.

title: PRESERVATIONISTS VS. FREEDOM OF RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
Kentucky Governor 'Stable'
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr., being treated for complications arising from triple bypass heart surgery, was reported in ''stable'' condition today.

title: Tokyo Stocks at Peak
description: Stock prices rose sharply today in fairly active trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, pushing the market average to a record 8,935.66 at the close, up 64.71.

title: DOW RISES BY 3.30, TO 1,225.26 CLOSE
description: The stock market rose again yesterday in light pre-holiday trading, recovering from its plunge earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average - ahead 1.60 points at 3 P.M. - showed little movement until the final hour of trading, when it rose to close ahead 3.30 points, at 1,225.26, cutting its loss for the week to 16.43 points. The Dow advanced 8.12 points on Thursday.

title: MORSE ELECTRO PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,183,170 on the sale of the company's Hong Kong subsidiary's manufacturing operations. c-Includes a gain of $1.2 million resulting from the sale of the company's limited partnership interest in a partnership which owns a building.

title: 'Back to Square 1' In Con Ed Strike
description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday withdrew the only contract offer it has made to striking workers.

title: FUTURIST BUILT GEODESIC DOME
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, the forward-looking inventor best known as the father of the geodesic dome, died of a heart attack yesterday while visiting his wife at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.

title: YANKS LOSE 7-0 LEAD BUT WIN
description: The game reached the point, Butch Wynegar remarked, ''where it's almost funny.'' It was not, to be sure, funny to Dennis Eckersley, and it certainly wasn't funny to Jay Howell. Mark Clear wasn't laughing either. But they were the pitchers. The hitters roared with laughter, though the Yankee hitters were just a little louder because they outlasted Boston, 12-8, at the Stadium last night.

title: Marseilles Ballet Opens July 18 at Met Opera
description: Roland Petit's Ballet National de Marseilles will open at the Metropolitan Opera House July 18 for a two-week season.

title: BURST PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Goodyear Charge
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it planned to take a $45 million after-tax charge against second quarter earnings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We think all sides must be faithful to the principle of simultaneous withdrawal.'' - Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. (1:5.)

title: HALMI, ROBERT, INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $8,600 for the quarter and $69,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $240,000 for the quarter and $515,000 for the year.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Denver Mayor Sworn In
description: Federico Pena was sworn in today as the city's Mayor, becoming the first Hispanic person to hold the post. Mayor Pena, a Texas-born lawyer and former Colorado legislator, was sworn by Justice Joseph Quinn of the Supreme Court in the City-County Building.

title: Sweden Letting Navy Attack Foreign Subs
description: New regulations giving the Swedish Navy more scope to deal with intruding foreign submarines went into effect today.

title: U.S. Backs Swap Of Stroh Plants
description: The Justice Department has endorsed a brewery swap plan that would avoid the need for the Stroh Brewery Company to give up either of its Schlitz plants in Winston-Salem or Memphis.

title: 50 Officers Dismissed By Guatemalan Leader
description: President Efrain Rios Montt dismissed about 50 army officers from their high-level Government jobs today and sent them back to their barracks, a spokesman for the President said.

title:
Patents;
Automated Banking System
description: WASHINGTON AN automated banking system, with a central computer connected to remote teller machines, was patented this week for Honeywell Information Systems of Waltham, Mass. According to patent 4,390,968, the system prevents unauthorized users from learning the customer's personal identification number.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSTRIES LTD (ISRAEL) reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $7,437,000 representing Elron's increase in the equity of an affiliate resulting from the affiliate's public offering of shares. c-Including a capital gain of $1,155,000 from the sale by Elron of shares in an affiliate.

title: United Brands Reports Loss
description: The United Brands Company, citing a $120 million charge for restructuring its banana and meat operations, yesterday reported a loss of $130 million for the quarter ended March 31.

title: Allwin Steady Wins Rich Pace
description: Allwin Steady, the 13-10 choice, won the $537,000 New Jersey Classic for three-year-olds tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: No Headline
description: Sometimes the classic matches leap out of the draw sheet, and sometimes they evolve on the tennis court. It happened both ways yesterday.

title: SHULTZ TRIP A HELP TO U.S.-INDIA MOOD
description: An improvement in relations between the United States and India that began last year seems to have been solidified by two days of talks between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Indian leaders.

title: A SOLO PIANO FULL OF POWER FROM OZONE
description: Makoto Ozone, a relatively unknown young pianist who has won the Down Beat magazine Student Achievement Award for Outstanding Jazz Performance, walked out on the stage at Carnegie Recital Hall late Wednesday afternoon, sat down at the piano, looked it straight in the keyboard and took total possession of the instrument.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 2, 1983
description: International

title: One-Way Street
description: The 24 athletes competing in the New York 6-day run, beginning Monday at Downing Stadium, will probably have to withstand discomforts caused by several harsh elements: heat, humidity, possible thunderstorms and very little sleep.

title: 4 STUDENTS SUE OVER SUGGESTION THEY CHEATED
description: Ten months after four Millburn (N.J.) High School students took Scholastic Aptitude Tests required for college entrance, a form letter from the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., arrived in the mail for each of them.

title: Back at Shortstop
description: After missing 224 games recuperating from a shoulder injury, Rick Burleson was back in the lineup of the California Angels on Thursday night. The former all-star shortstop, who suffered a torn rotator cuff April 17, 1982, and underwent major surgery 10 days later, went 2 for 5 in California's defeat by the Texas Rangers.

title: 4 in Houston Found Slain In Video Game Arcade
description: Four young men were found dead today in a video game arcade.

title: POTENT BLOC FROM ROCKIES IN SENATE
description: ''The Rocky Mountains are erupting,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee.

title: Prague Said to Freeze Ties With Vatican
description: Czechoslovakia, concerned over the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, has frozen relations with the Vatican, Vatican informants said today.

title: Your Money; Ways to Settle With Insurers
description: MORE and more individuals who are seeking large liability awards - usually after an accident - are opting for what is called a structured claims settlement, rather than the traditional lump sum payment.

title: Cuomo, the Non-Candidate, Taking West Coast Trip
description: Other than brief sorties to Washington, Governor Cuomo has not set foot outside the state since his election. But Tuesday night he plans to fly to Los Angeles to address the national convention of the American Federation of Teachers, at the invitation of the union's president, Albert Shanker. Mr. Shanker had invited Mr. Cuomo to speak at the teachers union's state gathering in Albany, but Mr. Cuomo was unable to make it.

title: CITY TO PROPOSE BETTER CABLE TV FOR MANHATTAN
description: A New York City official said yesterday that he would move before the end of the year to win the same level of cable television service in Manhattan that has been negotiated for the four other boroughs.

title: Cattle Car Justice
description: Thousands of New Yorkers each year get their first glimpse of justice in the Criminal Court. As a series of articles in The Times this week showed, it's likely to be a depressing view of an institution in the throes of collapse. Remedies are possible, but only with a more serious commitment of political leadership than any now apparent.

title: SEARLE SWEETENER WINS APPROVAL FOR SOFT DRINKS
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it had approved the use of aspartame, the low-calorie sweetener of G.D. Searle & Company, for use in soft drinks in the United States. Aspartame, the first sweetener to be approved in 25 years, now becomes the only rival to saccharin in the $4 billion diet softdrink market.

title: A WONDERFUL PRETEND
description: Like millions of other would-be sports idols, I am addicted to watching baseball, preferably at the park, but television will do in a pinch, which is most of the time. It is my great escape.

title: U.S. and Soviet Editors Adopt Exchange Plans
description: A group of New England and Soviet editors agreed today to an exchange of reporters who would work directly for publications in the other country.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 2, 1983
description: International

title: Miller Beer Ads Assailed in Suit
description: Consumers Union charged in a Federal suit filed in New York yesterday that the Miller Brewing Company had engaged in misleading advertising by asserting that its Miller High Life beer had been ranked No. 1 in the current edition of Consumer Reports magazine.

title: A CREDITOR ACCORD REVIVES BALDWIN
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation averted possible bankruptcy when five groups of creditors agreed Thursday night to a new accord covering more than $1 billion in short-term debt.

title: REAL NUCLEAR WAR FOR LESS THAN $1
description: Could nuclear war happen by accident? Yes, flaws in computerized military systems could indeed cause such a catastrophe, and the participation of human beings at key points in the nuclear war launching process would not necessarily protect us against the ultimate disaster. We must squarely face that danger -and consider how to avoid it.

title: PRESIDENT AT TRIAL OF THE CHICAGO 7
description: Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who presided over the tumultuous Chicago Seven conspiracy trial that became a symbol of domestic turmoil in the Vietnam War, died yesterday at his home in Chicago. He was 87 years old.

title: DANCE: NEW LEADS IN 'GISELLE' BY AMERICAN BALLET THEATER
description: The American Ballet Theater presented disappointing new leads in ''Giselle'' Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House. There was nothing wrong with the dancing of Susan Jaffe and Patrick Bissell, though it was oddly low-keyed at times.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: MERIT PAY DRAWS CRITICISM AND PRAISE FROM TEACHERS
description: Ordinarily, a teachers' union leader like John P. O'Sullivan would be delighted to see his school district raise salaries, but he is not very happy about the merit pay plan that is the basis of the higher pay scale in Houston.

title: Owners Win Pay Issue
description: Raymond Goetz, baseball's impartial arbitrator, has ruled that players who were disabled during the 50-day strike of 1981 are not entitled to their salaries for that period.

title: PRESERVATIONISTS VS. FREEDOM OF RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: BOB SEGER IN JERSEY
description: Outside of Bruce Springsteen, Bob Seger is probably the most inspiring exponent of a rock-and-roll classicism that is quintessentially American in spirit. Rooted in 1950's and early 60's rhythm-and-blues, with secondary echoes from country music, Mr. Seger's songs deal honestly and sympathetically with the lives of working people.

title: Books of The Times; Clothing as Language
description: THE FASHION SYSTEM. By Roland Barthes. Translated from the French by Matthew Ward and Richard Howard. 303 pages. Hill & Wang. $20.50.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 41.

title: AT 43, AN ATHLETE STARTS OVER
description: Dave McKenzie beat Ed Burke in the hammer throw today for the third time in two weeks. Still, Burke and his coach-wife, Shirley, said that Burke, at 43 years of age, was learning and getting closer to the perfect throw.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'A Little Socialism'

title: CITIZENSHIP LOST IN NAZI CASE
description: A Federal district judge today revoked the citizenship of a 63-year old Ukrainian immigrant accused of slaughtering Jews and collaborating with the Nazis in World War II.

title: Chad Rebels Report Seizing an American
description: The leader of the rebels in northern Chad said today that he was holding an American, Mark Frohardt, 32 years old, of Colorado Springs, Colo., and said he was a spy for the Central Intelligence Agency, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: AN OVERDUE BREAK FOR STATEN ISLANDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $381,869 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,287,074, net of a federal tax credit of $950,000.

title: Honduras Reinforces Border
description: Honduras has moved more combat troops to its border with Nicaragua and started airlifting supplies to villages isolated by border fighting, the armed forces said today. A spokesman did not say how many troops were involved but said they were being deployed between the villages of Las Trojes and Cifuentes.

title: SEX-BLIND WRITING
description: To the Editor:

title: TECTEL INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
AIR FORCE REPORTS NO HIGH DEATH RATES AMONG DEFOLIANT SPRAYERS
description: The men who flew the planes that sprayed the defoliant Agent Orange on the jungles of Vietnam are not dying in unusual numbers or from unusual causes, the Air Force said today after surveying more than 1,200 pilots and crew members who had been exposed to the herbicide.

title: Racing to Enter the Race
description: Several were in shorts and running shoes, others in pin stripes, and all exuded anxiety as they rushed to window No. 47, the special marathon window, at the General Post Office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday.

title: IN SEARCH OF EFFICIENT JUSTICE: REFORMING THE CRIMINAL COURT
description: In spite of everything, a few New York officials have a vision of a Criminal Court that could work. They imagine a court that would combine efficiency with justice; a court in which cases not warranting trials would be quickly disposed of and those that went to trial would be heard expeditiously; a court in which judges would treat misdemeanors seriously and mete out punishments that not only fit a particular criminal but also deterred others.

title: Italy Reshuffles an Old Deck
description: Italy's voters have shuffled the cards but dealt from the same deck. The still dominant Christian Democrats suffered a rebuke but the governing coalition they lead survived with virtually undiminished strength. The next government will therefore resemble the last, will hold to the same policies and be plagued by the same instability.

title: PHILLIES DEFEAT SEAVER
description: The new month opened the way the old one closed for the New York Mets, in defeat. The Mets, who arrived here after losing their third straight game in St. Louis, managed only two second-inning hits against John Denny tonight in a 5-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Jet Order Won By McDonnell
description: American Airlines has agreed to obtain up to 13 jetliners from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation rather than the Boeing Company.

title: Counterfeit Tickets
description: The Meadowlands put the remaining tickets for the Aug. 29 Nebraska-Penn State football game on sale yesterday, and Omaha police said counterfeit tickets were being circulated in Nebraska. Les Unger, director of college athletics for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said that he understood there were only a few such tickets in existence.

title: 'Today's Chuckle' Writer, 60
description: Beulah Stowe Collins, author of the nationally syndicated ''Today's Chuckle'' and the ''Senior Forum-Golden Years'' columns, died Thursday after a short illness.

title: AN OVERDUE BREAK FOR STATEN ISLANDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-PROSECUTOR WINS LIBEL SUIT
description: A former prosecutor has won a $4.5 million libel judgment against The Philadelphia Inquirer for articles that he contended suggested he took part in a cover-up to keep a friend's son from being accused of a man's death.

title: U.N. TRADE PARLEY LIKELY TO SIDESTEP 3D WORLD DEMANDS
description: A conference of the world's rich and poor nations moved toward adjournment today with agreement near on a resolution that sidesteps the demands of the poor nations for emergency economic aid.

title: MANY SPEAKERS ALTERED OWN REMARKS IN DISPUTED TRANSCRIPTS
description: Of 52 instances of altered remarks cited by House Republicans as evidence that Democratic staff members were doctoring the official transcripts of committee hearings, most appear to have been requested by the speakers themselves.

title:
PLAYERS;
A PITCHER REMAKES HIMSELF
description: Ray Fontenot stood on the mound at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, and he felt strong. Perhaps the energy came from the adrenaline that had been produced by his first appearance in the major leagues. Perhaps it was the 12 days of rest since his last appearance with the Columbus Clippers of the Class AAA International League, before the Yankees brought him to the major leagues.

title: QUARTET LED BY CYRILLE ON DRUMS
description: Andrew Cyrille, who brought his current quartet to Soundscape for Wednesday's jazz festival program, is a consummate modern drummer. In tunes with a steady beat, his mastery of jazz and various African rhythms takes shape in a brisk chatter of cymbals and tom-toms that moves along unobtrusively on its own, yet stays on the heels of each soloist.

title: Lava Approaches Homes Near Hawaii Volcano
description: A 10-foot wall of lava from Kilauea crept relentlessly to within a quarter mile of a home in a subdivision today, cutting down tall ohia trees in its path and forcing the evacuation of some residents.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for 12 wks to May 22.
OPENING-NIGHT STRIKE SET AT THE CITY OPERA
description: New York City Opera employees represented by the American Guild of Musical Artists - soloists, chorus, ballet and stage staff - reached a tentative agreement for a new contract with the company at 12:30 this morning, after 3 1/2 hours of negotiations. But the opera orchestra has formally told the company that it will strike next Thursday, the opening night of the company's 19-week summer-fall season, unless a new contract has been negotiated.

title: U.S. DUTY TO URUGUAY
description: .6,2Ten years ago, Uruguay was an advanced democracy - a middleclass, 90 percent literate welfare state. Now it is an advanced dictatorship - a computerized, totalitarian state. And at a time when turmoil elsewhere in Latin America suggests that only tolerant and pluralistic, democratic governments offer any real hope of hemispheric stability, Washington is not using its influence to press for the restoration of Uruguayan democracy.

title: U.S. Is Still Groping for the Exit in Lebanon
description: Syria's campaign against Yasir Arafat and what passes for moderation within the Palestine Liberation Organization is propelling the Reagan Administration's grand design for Middle East peace toward a dead end. Discouraged, perhaps, but unable to give up, the Administration tried an end run last week but it was quickly blocked by an ally, Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: PUBLIC TV-STILL POOR BUT NEWLY HOPEFUL
description: Late last month, more than 800 representatives from public television's hierarchy gathered in a hotel ballroom outside Washington, D.C., to thank the U.S. Congress for its financial support. The occasion was a festive one attended by nearly 100 Congressmen who heard testimonials to the virtues of public television's programs from an eclectic group including LeVar Burton, star of ''Roots,'' Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, and Roberta Peters of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Miss McInerney Will Wed July 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. Denis McInerney of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maura Irene McInerney, to Gary Joseph Romano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Romano of Union, N.J.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ONE recent evening, Thomas Sweeney, the county's Deputy Commissioner of Public Safety, inspected a county park and found only a raccoon, which, he noted, ''had a right to be there.'' According to Mr. Sweeney, that meant the county's new Parks Enhancement Enforcement Task Force had been a success.

title: An Appreciation
description: R. Buckminster Fuller was a preacher as much as an architect, a town crier as much as a scientist. He was among this century's first minds to see that every aspect of man's physical environment was connected to every other; he believed that out of simple geometric truths we might build whole worlds, and he saw his mission as spreading the gospel of this realization.

title: MAFIA LINK SEEN IN TRASH CARTING IN WEST FLORIDA
description: Florida has begun to crack down hard on racketeers from New York who, according to Federal and state prosecutors, are invading the garbage collection and disposal industry here on the state's west coast.

title: A 'GROTESQUE TOUR' OF PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON PERCHED atop the ivy over the arch of 1879 Hall at Princeton University, a solemn building of red brick, a monkey with a camera sits, grinning slyly and ready to photograph passersby.

title: TAKING A CLOSER LOOK AT PUCCINI
description: When starting on a risky venture, it's nice to have a friend along. The New York City Opera begins its new, daring and controversial summer format on Thursday (provided contract disputes between management and orchestra musicians are resolved by then) and to make it work, the company is relying on the best friend a modern opera house ever had -Giacomo Puccini.

title: QUESTIONS OF IMAGE; A Weed Worth Keeping
description: As if to make amends for all those soggy weekends, spring has left us a floral legacy with an attractive face and a quaintly lethal name. Maybe because of the rains, the daisy fleabane has been growing more bountifully than usual in vacant lots, pavement cracks, along roadsides and in the untended edges of lawns.

title: ENERGETIC LEADER FOR TEACHERS' UNION
description: Mary Hatwood Futrell recalls that when she was a child her mother would write long lists of chores for her and her older sister. If the tasks were not done when her mother arrived home late at night from her job cleaning offices, the children would be awakened to finish them.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
TERCENTENARY CONCERT
description: Although Suffolk County has been celebrating its Tercentenary in spurts since the start of 1983, the festivities get into high gear tonight at Westhampton Beach when the Long Island Philharmonic performs the world premiere of ''Honor Song,'' an overture by David Amram. Commissioned to mark the occasion, the piece, Mr. Amram said, draws on Indian and other ethnic musical strains to capture the spirit of one of New York's oldest political entities. The orchestra, led by Christopher Keene, will also play Stravinsky's ''Firebird Suite'' and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 5. A fireworks display by the Grucci family caps the evening. The free concert, which will be repeated at 8:30 P.M. Monday at Heckscher Park in Huntington, is at 8 P.M. at the Suffolk County Airport, but get there early with your own seating.ROUSING FOURTH

title: Miss Powel Plans October Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. H. Powel of Southport, Conn., and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Hyde Powel, to Justin David Parks, son of Mr& and Mrs. Charles H. Parks of Southport and Woodstock, Vt.

title: 'Racial' Killing
description: A 19-year-old New Jersey youth was accused of deliberately running over a 7-year-old Hispanic boy with his car after making racial slurs to his passengers about how many ''points'' he could get for killing a Hispanic boy.

title: HIGH COURT SETS FORCED-SALE RULES
description: LEGAL authorities in the metropolitan area are reviewing a United S tates Supreme Court ruling that holders of mortgages and liens a gainst real properties are entitled to direct notice before state a nd local governments can sell such properties for unpaid taxes.

title: JAPANESE LEADER ESCAPES THE GRAY AREAS
description: Perhaps the biggest winner in Japan's national elections last week was not on the ballot - Yasuhiro Nakasone, the Prime Minister for the last seven months.

title: COMPARING FOOTBALL LEAGUES, NEW AND OLD
description: WHILE most people have watched only portions of United States Football League games in its first season, I have observed and analyzed at least one game a week. In looking back over the first regular season, which ends today, I think the league not only surprised the people who followed the games, but also made strong moves that will help its continued existence. The first sign of that is its willingness to acquire more young talent than anyone thought it would and build an organization that can last.

title: A PRIEST'S INDULGENCE
description: ASCENT INTO HELL By Andrew M. Greeley. 371 pp. New York: Bernard Geis Associates/Warner Books. $16.50.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: LEGION By William Peter Blatty. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART There is no better guide to a certain New York in the 1930's than Reginald Marsh (1898-1954) who is now (through Aug. 24) the subject of an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TWO Suffolk County residents have received the newly established Luke Smith Award for their efforts to help the county's low-income citizens. Olga Nelson of Coram and Joop van der Grinten of Brookhaven were awarded plaques last week for their ''uncommon commitment'' to Suffolk County's ''poor and working poor citizens.''

title: '48 ISRAELI TIE TO PHALANGISTS REVEALED
description: An Israeli journalist has uncovered official Foreign Ministry documents showing that Israel's relationship with the Lebanese Christian Phalangists goes back to 1948, when the Phalangists asked for Israeli help to organize an insurrection to overthrow the Lebanese Government.

title: Valerie Sims Is Married
description: Valerie Nanette Sims, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Sims of Orange, N.J., was married yesterday in Washington to Walter Ignatius Willard, son of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Willard of New Orleans. The Rev. Matthew O'Rourke performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation. The bride graduated recently from the National Law Center of George Washington University. Mr. Willard graduated from the American University's Washington College of Law.

title: MILLSTONE IS FOCUS OF RATE PLAN
description: SOME time around the beginning of next year, if Northeast Utilities has its way, 900,000 electric customers around the state will start paying higher bills to cover the cost of the Millstone 3 nuclear reactor in Waterford.

title: MARKING REVOLUTION OPPOSING REVOLUTION
description: The Reagan Administration is commemorating the 207th birthday of the American Revolution by escalating United States military force against revolutionaries in Central America. Secretary of State George P. Shultz laid down the rule when he warned recently that the Administration will not tolerate ''people shooting their way into the government.'' Given George Washington's and Thomas Jefferson's dependence on American riflemen, it is well for Fourth of July celebrations that Mr. Shultz's law cannot be applied retroactively.

title: No Headline
description: The Sons of Divorce I read with great interest the article on the sons of divorce since I am the parent of a boy who is now 13, and my marriage ended a year and a half ago.

title: No Headline
His Teammates Mourn Gordon of the Dolphins
description: Larry Gordon, the Miami Dolphin linebacker who collapsed and died while jogging last Saturday, was cited today as ''one who made life worth living, who let us know that through hard work one can get to the top.''

title: NEW DIRECTIONS BY PLAYHOUSES
description: FOR two vastly different summer theaters, the past has been problematical. For each in its own fashion, the present means a transformation with an emphasis on mass appeal.

title: 300,000 RECORDINGS BECKON
description: Tower Records, a retail chain with headquarters in Sacramento, Calif., has just opened its first New York store, and its 33d in the United States (it also has four in Japan). The company - without contradiction - calls this New York branch the world's largest record store. It has four selling floors, 300,000 records and tapes, nine departments and a Ticketron outlet. And it is open 365 days a year from 9 A.M. to midnight.

title: BY PATRICIA HUBBELL
ITALY
description: To the Editor:

title: South America
description: To the Editor: Edwin McDowell's tribute to ''The South American Handbook''(Travel, May 15) was excellent. My spouse and I toted the guidebook (in actuality it is closer in size to a hymnal than a handbook) on a yearlong march to Tierra del Fuego and back. t found us a good, cheap hotel two blocks from Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro, a commuter canoe service between Oiapoque, Brazil, and Saint-Georges, French Guiana, and a restaurant in Piura, Peru, that served 15 kinds of ceviche. DANIEL BUCK Washington

title: IN TINY GUTTENBERG, A CITY WITHIN A CITY
description: FOR the Galaxy, a luxurious, 1,075-unit residential complex c onsisting of a 50-story building, 2 44-story towers and 2 16-story c onnecting structures, its location on the Hudson River in the tiny H udson County community of Guttenberg is both its greatest advantage a nd its biggest drawback.

title: 'PSEUDO-GATE' OR NOT, REAGAN IS IN TROUBLE
description: WASHINGTON WITH the Justice Department investigation of how President Reagan's campaign aides obtained President Carter's research material before their 1980 debate, two of the capital's hoariest questions gained new life last week. First there is the matter of whether ''dirty tricks'' are standard practice in Presidential campaigns. Second and of greater importance to the Reagan White House is the question of how swiftly and brutally a President should act to separate himself from subordinates who get into trouble.

title: THE SHIPBUILDER'S LITTLEST MATE
description: At Hitachi's mechanical engineering research laboratory in Tsuchiura, 40 miles northeast of Tokyo, Fumio Fujisawa walks past small groups of scientists clustered around the appendages of robots and offers his view of where the industry is headed.

title: NEW LAW WILL LIMIT BENEFITS IN GUT REHABILITATIONS
description: THE State Legislature's revision of the city's J-51 tax-incentive p rogram has fundamentally changed the course of housing policy in NewY ork City, but it may be years before the figures on the number of a partments benefited reflect the new direction.

title: FILM-MAKING SEMINAR
description: Four intensive seminars in directing, acting, editing and cinematography are to be conducted from July 5 to July 28 at Wesleyan University by Robert Wise, Jane Alexander, Ralph Rosenblum and Michael Chapman. In addition, Steven Ross will teach a graduatecredit course titled ''The Film-Making Process'' within the same dates.

title: TRAVELING ALONE
description: Drew Middleton is The Times's military correspondent. To the harassed father of clamorous tots, the sight of the unencumbered male traveler striding through an airport or railroad station is the vision of a better, freer world. Some day, when the kids are at school, or throttled, he, too, will move jauntily through the crowd, halting, if necessary, for the nourishing martini, boarding with a minimum of fuss and warm smiles from the attendants.

title: Wales
description: To the Editor: The fascinating article ''Capturing the Essence of Wales'' by Emlyn Williams with the additional guide by David Wickers (Travel, May 22) brought back a special memory of my first visit to Cardiff Castle a few years ago. was overwhelmed by the elaborate decor of its various state rooms which depicts in murals and designs embellished with much gold leaf and precious stones themes from the Bible, classical mythology, science and literature.

title: NJ TRANSIT FAMILY PLAN: WHAT'S THE BIG SECRET
description: Users of NJ Transit buses should be made aware that the agency has come up with a magnificent idea, but for some reason is not publicizing it.

title: AMERICAN MAOIST IN CHINA
description: SHENFAN By William Hinton. Illustrated. 785 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: A BOOK TO TELL ABOUT LIFE
description: The first thing the majority of grandmothers told Judith Levy was that they felt their grandchildren thought of them mostly as a voice on the phone or a present in the mailbox.

title: White Sox 4, Twins 2
description: MINNEAPOLIS (UPI) - Greg Walker hit a towering two-run homer, and Jerry Dybzinski drove in two runs to lead Chicago.

title: W.B.C. Says Holmes Must Fight Greg Page
description: The World Boxing Council president, Jose Sulaiman, said today he will revoke the heavyweight champion Larry Holmes's title unless Holmes agrees to defend it in a bout with Greg Page.

title: THE SPECIAL APPEAL OF AMISH QUILTS
description: Unraveling the story of Amish quilts is not as simple a task as it seemed a decade ago when the first specialty exhibitions of these coverlets commenced. At that time, the meticulously stitched quilts appeared to be esthetically all of a piece - color-pulsing, graphically bold, somber studies with highly sophisticated quilting patterns.

title: Inside the Pigeonholing Process
description: A certain look comes over people's faces when they are confused, and you see it a lot in bookstores. As customers head for particular sections in search of particular titles, their quizzical expressions may reflect an internal monologue: ''Is Biography the right place to look for 'The Dark Side of Genius' or would any fool go to Show Business?'' ''Will I find 'Our Bodies, Ourselves' under Health or Women or somewhere else?'' ''Does it make sense to try Travel or Sociology for 'Blue Highways'?''

title: NOVELIST OF POWER AND PRIVILEGE
description: JAMES GOULD COZZENS A Life Apart. By Matthew J. Bruccoli. Illustrated. 343 pp. New York and San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: Miss DeMeo Sets October Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo George DeMeo of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Angela M. DeMeo, to John H. Works Jr., son of Ellen Johnson Works of Shawnee Mission, Kan., and Mr. Works of Denver. An October wedding is planned.

title: OLYMPICS '84
description: If SYMBOLISM PLAYS A ROLE IN SPORTS - AND who can doubt that it does? - the 1978 decision of the United States Olympic Committee to move its headquarters from the Park Avenue town house where J.P. Morgan once kept his mistress to an abandoned NORAD base in Colorado Springs represented more than a change of scenery. For years, the American Olympic movement had been trying to shed the elitist attitudes that had prevailed during the long tenure of Avery Brundage as this country's chief Olympic spokesman, fanner of the flame and zealous champion of amateurism.

title: Bull Market In Marijuana
description: Liberalized laws and Police Department budget cuts have created an open market in marijuana, New York City officials complained last week. So-called smoke shops are springing up like weeds.

title:
STAMPS;
TRIBUTE TO THE AUTHOR OF 'THE SCARLET LETTER'
description: Nathaniel Hawthorne, one of the towering figures of American literature, is taking his place in the ongoing Literary Arts Series with a 20-cent commemorative being issued this Friday at Salem, Mass., his birthplace and the locale of much of his writing.

title: BURDENS SHED BY WASHINGTON FALL UNEQUALLY ON THE STATES
description: From the day he took office President Reagan has consistently tried to shift the Federal Government's recently acquired domestic responsibilities back to the states. He was at it again last week, declaring that if new revenues were needed for the nation's faltering system of education the money would have to come from someplace other than Washington.

title: A JOGGING TRACK, WITH HOT TUB
description: More than a few of the prospective buyers who have been in to look over Skytrack, a new condominium building at 122-134 Boerum Place in Brooklyn, have been as curious about its roof as the size, layouts and features of its 56 apartments.

title: BENJAMIN GOLLAY
description: Benjamin Gollay, a lawyer who represented a number of artists in New York and the Hamptons, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 76 years old and also had a home in Greenwich Village.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Prospects column last Sunday misidentified Ellen S. Levin.

title: Karen A. Eckrich to Marry C.W. Tyler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Eckrich Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Ann Eckrich, to Cameron Wat Tyler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Justin Tyler of Swanton, Vt.

title: No Headline
description: The Sons of Divorce Missing from Linda Bird Francke's article was mention of a dynamic which appears repeatedly in my clinical work - namely, the ''he's just like his father'' syndrome.

title: OBSESSED WITH THE CONQUEST OF A CONTINENT
description: FRANCE AND ENGLAND IN NORTH AMERICA By Francis Parkman. Edited by David Levin. Volume One: Pioneers of France in the New World; The Jesuits in North America in the Seventeenth Century; La Salle and the Discovery of the Great West; The Old Regime in Canada. 1,504 pp. Volume Two: Count Frontenac and New France Under Louis XIV; A Half-Century of Conflict; Montcalm and Wolfe. 1,620 pp. New York: The Library of America. Distributed by The Viking Press. $30 each.

title: DEMOCRATS COURT TEACHERS AT GATHERING
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates were wooing teachers at the annual meeting of the National Education Association here the last few days, and the teachers said they were delighted to see education back at the top of the nation's agenda.

title: AN AFGHAN SETTLEMENT PROCESS UNDER WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I win, it is routine; when I lose, life comes to an end.'' - Martina Navratilova. Section 5, Page 8.

title: PANEL FINDS TAXPAYERS SUBSIDIZE NONRESIDENTS ATTENDING STATE U.
description: New York taxpayers pay most of the bill for educating out-of-state students at the State University of New York, a legislative panel has reported.

title: THE PASSAIC: IT'S TIME TO MAKE WAVES
description: ICOULDN'T help but think about William Carlos Williams's impression of the Passaic River. He once branded it ''the Passaic, that filthy river.''

title: A SALUTE TO OLD-FASHIONED GYMS
description: BEFORE the spa, there was the New London Y.M.C.A. Weight Lifting Club. The club, now part of a vanishing breed, exemplifies the archetypic ''body shop,'' a mesomorphic mecca in the epoch of the spa.

title: Carter Christensen Will Wed on Aug. 6
description: Anne Carter Christensen, who received a bachelor's degree in nursing in May from Georgetown University, and Howard Macfarland Fish 3d, who received a master's degree in May from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, plan to be married Aug. 6.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: In the aftermath of John Paul II's visit, questions were raised about the import for state and church. Below, six leading authorities make an assessment. Strong Symbols

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: Solidarity's Future

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Juan N ieves, 18-year-old pitcher out of Avon Old F arms School, Avon, Conn. He was as- s igned to Class A Midwest League team in B eloit, Wis.

title:
DINING OUT;
'ITALIAN LOOK' UNDERGOES A CHANGE
description: THE mere mention of an Italian restaurant in New Jersey brings visions of intricate wallpaper and dark wood, combined with heavy food that sticks to the ribs. Even though that was never a completely true picture, things have been changing considerably over the last few years.

title: THE FIRST SINCE 1981
description: A convicted burglar escaped from Rikers Island yesterday afternoon by slipping into civilian clothes and walking past guards at the jail's visitors house, authorities reported.

title: PROFESSOR WINS PRIZE
description: ROCHESTER (AP)-Allan Blank, a music professor at Virginia Commonwealth University, has been awarded the first annual George Eastman Prize for his composition Duo for Bassoon and Piano. Judges were the composers Milton Babbitt, Gunther Schuller and Samuel Adler and the bassoonists Sol Schoenbach and K. David Van Hoessen.

title: Bandits Miss Playoffs
description: Bob Lane passed for two touchdowns and set up another to lead the Birmingham Stallions to a 29-17 victory over Tampa Bay tonight, killing the Bandits' chance for the United States Football League playoffs.

title: YANKEES FALL TO RED SOX, 10-4
description: There were two positive notes for the Yankees in their 10-4 loss to the Boston Red Sox last night: Dave Winfield hit his first home run in 18 games and drove in runs for the first time in 11 games, and Dale Murray pitched four scoreless innings of relief.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: What Trade-Offs?

title: BOOMING JERSEY CASINOS SEEK SITES FOR BRANCHES
description: With revenues rising, casino companies here are maneuvering to acquire choice sites for second casinos. Caesars World, which is spending $90 million to renovate and expand its Boardwalk Regency casino hotel, is also interested in the 58-year-old Coast Guard station in another section of town.

title: PASTORAL POLITICS
description: ROME POPE John Paul II and the Primate of Poland, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, were closeted in the Vatican again this weekend as they have been many times in the 18 months since Solidarity, the movement that owes so much to the Roman Catholic Church, was put under ban. Once again, decisions that may shape Poland's future were being made far from Warsaw - in Rome as in Moscow, where the Warsaw Pact countries met last week, and in Washington. President Reagan said the United States would be willing to ''turn back'' from some of the economic sanctions that the West has imposed if Poland acted on the Pope's call for free trade unions.

title: TAKING THE SLOW WAY OUT
description: MEMORY BABE A Critical Biography of Jack Kerouac. By Gerald Nicosia. Illustrated. 767 pp. New York: A Fred Jordan Book/Grove Press. $22.50.

title: STRANGE FISH
description: Have you ever noticed that writers of fiction tell lies about themselves? American writers, for instance, often like to present themselves as ignorant naturals, quicker to claim the influence of their neighborhood bartender than their literary forebears. Stanley Elkin once boasted that ''no writer I can think of ... thinks.'' His very ruminative friend William Gass should have called him on that. Many European writers, on the other hand, like to pretend that their work is constructed on the most bona fide of current critical principles. Marguerite Duras admits to feeling like an outsider because she is almost the only French novelist of her generation who has ''no theory of the novel.''

title: FORMER CONVICT FIGHTING TO RIGHT 50-YEAR WRONG
description: Fifty years ago, William Fisher stopped at a Harlem speak-easy and dance hall for ''a drink and a dance'' and wound up being convicted of shooting a man to death.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My husband and I are planning to take a trip to the national parks in Arizona; we are on a tour that will start and end in Las Vegas, Nev. We have it in mind to continue our trip by visiting Yellowstone National Park, and would like suggestions about how to proceed from Las Vegas to Yellowstone. Are reservations required for staying overnight in Yellowstone, and how do we get there from Las Vegas? - S.S.F., White Plains, N.Y. Answer:Reservations are needed in July and August, the park's peak season, and are recommended throughout the year. Overnight accommodations range from campsites for $5 a night a vehicle to hotel rooms or cabins for $48 a night for one or two people. In between are rustic shelters and cabins with varying levels of amenities such as running water, toilet facilities and fireplaces.

title: INITIATIVES PROPOSAL ADVANCES
description: TRENTON ARESOLUTION that would amend the State Constitution to include initiatives and referendums - that is, provide a mechanism by which voters can petition for a change in a state statute or the Constitution - passed the Senate last month by a vote of 32 to 4.

title: Power Defined Is Not Power Lost
description: ''In one fell swoop,'' said Justice Byron White in angry dissent last week, the Supreme Court wiped out more provisions of more Federal laws than all its previous decisions put together. The decision in question undid the so-called legislative veto. It was sweeping, or swooping, but it was also a sound reading of the Constitution's apportionment of power.

title: U.S. IS SENDING AFRICAN NATIONS MORE ARMS AID
description: The Reagan Administration, concerned about Soviet and Cuban involvement in Africa, has quietly doubled military aid to key countries in the region.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: Moscow, Beware

title: PRODUCTION OF BREL ALIVE BUT NOT WELL
description: EITHER you take to Jacques Brel's songs or you don't. To some, they sing of heartache. To others, they supply a headache. The version of ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'' presented by the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport is not likely to change a thing.

title: IN THE REIGN OF THEODORIC
description: DECADENT SOCIETIES, By Robert M. Adams. 196 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $16.

title: NEW BRITAIN SHOW HELPS CELEBRATE AN ANNIVERSARY
description: EIGHTY is a respectable age for any institution, but for a museum specializing in native painting and sculpture it is almost certainly a record - and one held by the New Britain Museum of American Art.

title: COUNTY OFFERING PROGRAM ON AIDS
description: THE county has established an informational program to ''separate fact and fiction about AIDS,'' the disease that destroys the body's immunity system and leaves its victims highly vulnerable to a wide range of fatal illnesses. The program, designed for inmates and corrections officers in the county's jail, penitentiary and medical center, features a video-taped panel discussion on the disease.

title: JOHN M. MAURY
description: John M. Maury, an Assistant Secretary of State in the Ford Administration, died today after being hospitalized six weeks ago for cancer treatment.

title: O.E. Mertz 3d to Wed Catherine Noel White
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph White Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Noel White, to Oscar Ernest Mertz 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mertz Jr. of Philadelphia.

title: MONDALE AND GLENN LEAD IN SURVEY OF DEMOCRATS
description: In the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio are running virtually even among Democrats, although Mr. Mondale encounters more unfavorable comments from the public than Mr. Glenn, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO
description: UNTIL recently, Ann Taylor, the wife of a home improvement contractor on this city's Southwest Side, was being ''eaten up'' by gas and repair bills on her old 1975 Cadillac Fleetwood. But now, with her husband's business picking up, she has plunked down $20,000 for a new two-tone blue Sedan de Ville.

title: CORRECTION
description: The unkind description of Ralph Waldo Emerson was wrongly attributed in the Reading and Writing column 'Literary Invective' (June 19). It was written by Algernon Swinburne

title: CONSUMER RATES
R. BUCKMINSTER FULLER, FUTURIST INVENTOR, DIES AT 87
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, the forward-looking inventor best known as the father of the geodesic dome, died of a heart attack Friday in Los Angeles at the Good Samaritan Hospital while visiting his wife, who is critically ill. He was 87 years old, and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: SUMMERFARE: A MONTH OF LIVELY ARTS
description: PepsiCo Summerfare, the fourth in a series of annual celebrations of the ''lively arts,'' opens Thursday at the Purchase campus of the State University of New York. Produced by the college and its corporate neighbor, PepsiCo, the month-long festival will present theater, jazz and folk music concerts, dance, operatic performances and an international jugglers convention.

title: A HOLIDAY GUIDE TO THE CELEBRATIONS
description: MOST of what John Adams foresaw as essential to an Independence Day celebration will be lit, shot, heard, seen and enjoyed throughout the county this weekend. In a letter to his wife Abigail, John, a delegate to the Constitutional Convention, made some predictions about future observances of the Declaration of Independence.

title: CAn the Pentagon Save a Bundle?
description: The idea that smarter shopping would save billions for the Pentagon got a 21-gun endorsement last week from a Presidential task force of business executives.

title: ONE VILLAGE WITHOUT A BANG
description: OUR little community does not have a fireworks display on the Fourth of July. Picnics, games, rides, yes. Fireworks, no. Twelve years ago we had a fireworks display, and that was enough for a lifetime. Never to be forgotten, and, God and community forbidding, never to be repeated.

title: WHAT CAUSED THE DECLINE AND FALL OF OPERA IN ITALY?
description: One of music's great perplexities is what happened to Italian opera after the death of Puccini in 1924. Suddenly the line of royal succession, which extended back through Verdi, Donizetti, Bellini and Rossini gave way. After ''Turandot,'' which Puccini did not live to complete, Italian opera shows little sign of creative vitality. Some of the composers who followed Puccini, such as Franco Alfano, were extremely talented men of the theater. Some, such as Pizzetti, Casella, Malipiero and Respighi were international figures, respected by their colleagues and known to audiences. Alfano's stature in Italy was such that Toscanini chose him to complete the last act of ''Turandot,'' which was rather like being named ''most likely to succeed'' by your senior class.

title: STUFFED CHICKEN LEGS
description: A while ago we had the pleasure of having four of the great chefs of France - Michel Rostang and Andre Genin of the Rostang and Chez Pauline restaurants in Paris, Jean-Paul Lacombe of Leon de Lyon in Lyons and Michel Chabran of Restaurant Chabran in Pont-de-l'Isere -in our kitchen.

title: Token Sucking
description: ''I frankly couldn't think of anything more downright unhealthy,'' said Hugh A. Dunne, a special assistant to the president of the Transit Authority.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Summer time is out-of-town tryout time at many photography galleries, when a great many photographers hoping to break into the exhibition circuit get to strut their stuff. ''Eleven Southern Photographers: A Contemporary Survey,'' curated by Fay Gold for the Robert Freidus Gallery (158 Layfayette Street, through July 30), is one of the most interesting of these shows, most likely because the pictures in it depict things that seem very out of town indeed.

title: Lola Anne Brock to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James G. Brock of Utica, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lola Anne Brock, to Jeremy E.J. Meakin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Meakin of Great Missenden, Buckinghamshire, England. An Aug. 20 wedding is planned.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY TO STRESS FIGHT AGAINST HEROIN
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the new United States Attorney in Manhattan, has announced that his main priorities are combating narcotics, organized crime and some white-collar crimes.

title: Russia's Great Tinker Toy
description: The Soviet Union may or may not be hellbent on widening its earthly realm, but last week it took a nifty expansionary step in space. Two astronauts arrived at the Salyut 7 space station, attached their Soyuz craft to it and opened the Cosmos ''space tugboat'' module that had ferried up supplies four months ago.

title: Italian Vote: More Confusion
description: Governing Italy was likely to be harder than ever, if such a thing is possible, after last week's muddy election results. The Christian Democratic Party, which has led all but two of the 43 Governments since World War II, saw its percentage of the popular vote for the Chamber of Deputies drop from 38.3 percent in 1979 to 32.9 percent.

title: Glacier Park
description: To the Editor: In reference to the story, ''Exploring Five National Parks'' (Travel, May 15), I wonder how many Montanans, or others, have written to say that the hotel and the area in Glacier National Park are referred to as Many Glacier and not Mini Glacier? There is nothing diminutive about the size of Glacier Park's glaciers. SUSAN TALBOT Missoula, Mont.

title: BEEF IN VARIOUS CUTS IS A SPECIALITY
description: FOR a restaurant that emphasizes beef in its name, Luca's Steak House in Greenwich has a surprisingly diversified menu, including quite a number of seafood choices. Even the decor is not the usual steak house image. Pale coral walls with dark wood paneling, colonial-style brass chandeliers, decorative paintings and fresh daisies in milk-glass bud vases, all create a comfortable setting for dinner. The staff is attentive, and the owner seems genuinely happy to greet and welcome the guests at each table. (Our lunch visit was less auspicious, with wilted or dead flowers on every table, and a waitress who was distracted, forgetful and prone to mixing up orders.)

title: Decontrol Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATION COMMISSIONER STRESSES TEACHER QUALITY
description: LIKE most educators, Saul Cooperman, Commissioner of the state's Department of Education, believes that the success or failure of an educational system depends largely on one critical factor: the quality of the teacher in the classroom. According to Dr. Cooperman, all other aspects of the educational process, from curriculum to expectations to time spent on academics, are secondary when compared to the interaction of a teacher and his pupils.

title: LEGISLATIVE VETO CASE LEAVES MUCH UNSETTLED
description: The framers of the Constitution not only expected but desired conflict among the branches of the government they created in 1787. ''Ambition must be made to counter ambition,'' James Madison wrote in The Federalist. That way the people would be protected from power concentrated in one place, from autocracy.

title: Congress Praised on MX Vote
description: President Reagan marked the Fourth of July weekend today by praising Congress as showing ''political courage'' in backing the MX missile and thereby enhancing prospects for an arms control agreement with Moscow.

title: Barbara Kaul Plans to Wed P. L. LeBlanc
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Kaul of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lee Kaul, to Paul Lanford LeBlanc, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moreland Paul LeBlanc Jr., of Darien, Conn.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE WORLD IS MADE OF GLASS By Morris West. 322 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95.DEFECTS OF THE HEART By Barbara Gordon. 324 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: CULTURAL POTPOURRI AT FESTIVALS GALORE
description: MUSIC MOUNTAIN may be the oldest, and Norfolk the most glamorous, of Connecticut's summer festivals, but the cultural calendar is excitingly full at other locations, too.

title: LOVE AND GROWTH IN 'CAMELOT'
description: THE production of ''Camelot'' currently playing at the Westbury Music Fair has less to do with Lerner and Loewe's musical mythical kingdom than it does with its star, Richard Harris. Mr. Harris plays King Arthur, an ordinary man charged by fate to establish civilization and English common law.

title: THE CENTENARY OF A CONTEMPORARY
description: THE world into which Franz Kafka was born 100 years ago today is dead and gone. A modest plaque marks the spot, near Prague's main square, where he first saw the gloom of day, but the building itself was razed long ago, the Hapsburg Empire has crumbled into oblivion, and the vibrant, polyglot city of his youth is now the dreary capital of a Socialist Republic. The thousand-year-old Jewish presence in Prague has been reduced to the eloquent silence of weathered tombstones in an ancient cemetery and a memorial wall bearing the name of 77,290 Holocaust victims, among them Kafka's three sisters.

title: TWO POLITICAL THRILLERS
description: THE ZOLTA CONFIGURATION By David Quammen. 256 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.HOLY WARS By James Brady. 366 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: 4 SOVIET SCIENTISTS ASSAIL SAKHAROV ON ARMS VIEWS
description: Four Soviet scientists bitterly attacked Andrei D. Sakharov today for a recent article he sent to the United States on the nuclear arms race. The scientists focused on Mr. Sakharov's contention that the United States might have to match the Soviet Union in nuclear weapons before effective negotiations could begin.

title: Mailbox
description: To the Sports Editor: An Open Letter to Chris Evert Lloyd. Dear Chris: Just a line to thank you for providing me with so many years of pleasure.

title: NEW COLOR FILMS: FASTER, SHARPER AND BRIGHTER
description: A new generation of 35mm color films recently introduced by Kodak, Fuji, and the 3M Company will deliver better and brighter color, extraordinary skin tones, very fine grain, and in some instances, emulsion speeds that are as much as 2 1/2 times faster than the fastest ISO emulsion now available. What all this means to the photographer is that quality heretofore obtainable only with larger format cameras is now possible with 35mm equipment.

title: No Headline
description: The Sons Of Divorce Social-science researchers are doubtless competent to use tape recorders and count (''The Sons of Divorce,'' by Linda Bird Francke, May 22). But when will they see that the last thing anyone needs these days is a new reason to worry about being dangerously different, somehow nearer peril than the folks down the street? A son is a son, a home is a home, and a parent is an idiot to open the door each week to admit a different expert freshly arrived to paint a ring of voguish woe all around.

title: State of Alert, Days of Alarm
description: Two of Washington's Central American allies were on the defensive last week but a third promised to launch a military offensive. Guatemala. Ducking mounting demands for immediate elections, President Efrain Rios Montt reimposed a ''state of alert'' that suspended many civil liberties, dismissed 50 army officers from Government jobs, and announced an election for July 1984 - but only to rewrite the Constitution.

title: Nancy Mandel Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Mandel of Somerset, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Mandel, to Peter Scott Feinerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Feinerman of Freeport, L.I.

title: MCCARTHY'S 'PURGE' AT FORT IS RECALLED
description: LONG BRANCH BOOKS about Senator Joseph R. McCarthy are likely to continue to be written and published, and each time there probably will be a retelling of how, 30 years ago, his forays for evidence of espionage - accompanied by scare headlines - centered around the Army's Signal Corps laboratories at Fort Monmouth.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: FRESHMEN in college are not the only freshmen put to the test, as State Representative Theodore A. Gagne Jr., a Republican from Thompson, discovered recently at the State Capitol.

title: Pan Am Plane Seized And Diverted to Cuba
description: A Pan American jetliner carrying 61 people was hijacked to Havana today by two men who shouted ''Go to Cuba!'' and flicked cigarette lighters near a bottle of gasoline, Federal agents and passengers said.

title: Sarah H. Arnold Engaged To F.A. Rossetti, a C.P.A.
description: The engagement of Sarah Hart Arnold to Frederick Anthony Rossetti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Rossetti of New York and Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Doris Arnold of Cos Cob, Conn., and William Arnold Jr. of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Pamela Kimball To Marry July 30
description: Pamela Ashley Kimball, who teaches at St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School, and David Anderson Kenney, a vice president pf E.F. Hutton & Company, plan to be married July 30.

title: Agonizing Season For Orioles' Palmer
description: On those good days, when his muscles are loose and pain is only a word, the thought floats through Jim Palmer's mind that he could pitch five, maybe six more years in the major leagues. Although he is 37 years old, he has learned well over the years, and his body has responded in a manner that should take him as far as the Hall of Fame.

title: No Headline
description: Butterfly Words I'd like to suggest a theory in support of Claire Martin's theory that ''... K's could attract more customers than C's could'' (''Butterfly Words,'' by William Safire, On Language, June 5). Like her, I've noticed how many businesses seem to choose to spell their names with K's replacing C's or Q's, as in Kwik Kopy and Koin Klean.

title: Vietnam Punishes 13 After Subversion Trial
description: Thirteen people accused of plotting to overthrow the Vietnamese Government have been punished by the People's Court in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, the Vietnamese press agency reported today.

title: Clare Verow Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Earle A. Verow of Westbury, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Clare Marie Verow, to Steven Douglas Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hart, also of Westbury. The wedding is planned for next May. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Mr. Verow, is a secretary with the European American Bank in Westbury. Mr. Hart is an art assistant with The New York Times.

title: No Headline
description: The Sons of Divorce In her article, Linda Bird Francke acknowledges that ''custody of the children still goes to the mother more than 90 percent of the time.'' According to the author, this happens by ''parental agreement or paternal default.''

title: SEARCH FOR STAINED GLASS LEADS TO SOME SPARKLING FINDS
