description: THIRD and fourth graders in Glastonbury, a women's club in Danbury and high school students in Thomaston are participating in the same project -the great stained-glass hunt.

title: Eurailpass
description: To the Editor: As much as I enjoyed E. J. Dionne Jr.'s ''Getting in Gear for the Voyage'' (Travel, March 13), I would point out that the article has perpetuated an unhelpful myth about where one can and cannot buy a Eurailpass. When he asserts that ''you have to buy the pass ahead of time in the United States,'' he is in agreement with everything I have ever read on the subject, yet nonetheless in error.

title: WESTERN GOLF 2D ROUND PUT OFF BY RAIN AGAIN
description: Heavy overnight rains forced postponement of the second round of the $400,000 Western Open golf tournament today for the second straight day.

title: John T..F.Carr And Ruth O'Neil Become Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. O'Neil of Watertown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Quinn O'Neil, to John Thomas Fisher Carr, son of Mrs. Alanson B. Houghton of Charleston, S.C., formerly of New York, and the late Oscar Clark Carr Jr.

title: TRADE TALKS END IN COMPROMISE
description: A conference of rich and poor nations ended today with a compromise agreement that committed industrial countries to continue to help the third world but rejected the principal economic demands of developing nations.

title:
GARDENING;
FRESH, QUALITY VEGETABLES: YOUR OWN
description: GROWING one's own vegetables is very popular these days, and there are many reasons for doing it. For one thing, it is much handier to be able to step out into the back yard for a head of lettuce or a bunch of carrots than to drive to market. Freshly harvested vegetables are always tastier and more nutritious than those purchased, assuming that they are harvested while they are in peak condition. Certain varieties are preferred to others by some gardeners. One can be better assured of having these varieties by growing them oneself. Then there is always satisfaction that comes with growing at least a portion of one's own food.

title: 'Forgotten Victim'
description: They were both 20 years old, they had met only a few days earlier at a Beefsteak Charlie's restaurant during a ''Gong Show''-style talent show, and they were on their first date.

title: AFTER EIGHT MONTHS, ENTERPRISE ZONES GET MIXED REVIEWS
description: EIGHT months after Connecticut became the first state to establish Urban Enterprise Zones, the program has drawn mixed reactions on its potential.

title: FIVE CLIMATES IN THREE HOURS
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL, who now makes his home in Honolulu, is the author of several novels; his latest, ''Poker Game,'' will be published by Doubleday in the fall.

title: Paying a Debt
description: Life, like a football, takes funny bounces, Kirby Criswell has found. A year ago, when he was sentenced to five years in prison on drug charges, his pro football career apparently bounced out of bounds.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLONIAL KITCHENS HAD THEIR CHARM
description: FEW owners are as truly romantic in their regard for their homes as those who have lovingly and at great expense restored fine old 18thcentury Connecticut houses.

title: CUTTING LOOSE: THE DRIVE TO DIVEST
description: FOR more than a decade, Beatrice Foods prided itself on its aggressive acquisitions strategy - one that steadily transformed the Chicago concern into a $10 billion-a-year conglomerate that sold everything from luggage to orange juice. But this past winter, faced with a sharp decline in profits, the buying spree has shifted into reverse. Now Beatrice plans to unload some 50 of its companies.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SUNNYSIDE
description: FROM the heart of Sunnyside, Queens, the midtown Manhattan skyline i s a looming presence, obscured in some places by heavily leafed s treet trees and at some times by a soft industrial haze, but close e nough to offer a panoramic view from many apartments.

title: Pillar of the Church
description: When the vote counting was over last week, the Rev. Carol Joyce Brun emerged as one of the people chosen to lead the United Church of Christ.

title: Richard Hillary
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO REFLECTS ON HIS TERM AND DISCOVERS A FEW FLAWS
description: Governor Cuomo says that he has been misunderstood on several important issues during the first six months of his administration, and that this is partly his own fault.

title: Sports of the Times; THE FIRST SECOND-OFFENDER
description: IN baseball, a rookie pitcher or hitter is never accepted as having ''made it'' the first time around the league, no matter how sensational a start he may have had. The test is always the second time around. That's when a rookie proves he belongs. Or when opposing hitters or pitchers discover a weakness that wasn't quite apparent the first time around. Out on the mound, Steve Howe long ago proved to the Los Angeles Dodgers that he belongs as a relief pitcher. But now, after having required treatment as a cocaine addict for the second time in seven months, the cocky 25-year-old left-hander must prove to himself that he belongs.

title: Albany Comes To the End of Lost Weekends
description: The 206th session of the New York State Legislature didn't so much adjourn last week as collapse from exhaustion. As Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader, put it as the Senate's final all-nighter ended: ''What in the world am I doing this for at 7 in the morning?'' Still, Mr. Anderson called it a ''rather successful'' effort and Governor Cuomo was even more upbeat. ''By almost every standard,'' he said, ''it has been an extraordinary session.''

title: ON THE GLENN TRAIL
description: At a breakfast given for local politicians by Presidential hopeful John Glenn, as the candidate was making his inspirational remarks about the need for America to ''go for it,'' an uncommitted county chairman whispered his analysis of '84 politics: ''If Reagan stubs his toe, this guy Glenn could make it. For Mondale to make it, Reagan would have to break his leg.''

title: TWO EFFORTS TO EMBRACE AMERICAN PAINTING
description: One of the things that George Orwell did not foresee about the year 1984 was that American painting would be in demand the world over. Yet that is the way it has turned out to be. Anyone who doubts it has only to look at the exhibition schedule of the Grand Palais in Paris for the year in question, and coincidentally at ''The Lane Collection: 20th Century Paintings in the American Tradition,'' which can be seen now and through Aug. 7 at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: PRESIDENT SENDING SHULTZ TO MIDEAST ON PEACE MISSION
description: The White House announced today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would stop in the Middle East on his way home next week from Pakistan.

title: WEST BANK TIDE
description: As a territorial entity, the West Bank can almost no longer be separated from Israel. The major protagonists in the Middle East should face that fact -and consider the consequences.

title: VISITOR TO MANDELA IN PRISON FINDS HIM IN GOOD HEALTH AND SPIRITS
description: Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress, was reported today to be in good health and spirits by an opposition Member of Parliament who was allowed to spend nearly an hour and a half with him and his cellmates on Friday.

title: Literary Prizes
description: To the Editor:

title: Friedrich Who?
description: It could be that James Nederlander thought the best way to get the doctor to make house calls was to name the house after him.

title: SOME IDEAS TO HELP KEEP THE SUMMER KITCHEN COOL
description: THIS is the time of year when the prospect of spending hours in the kitchen is less than alluring. The last thing anyone wants to do, especially when guests are in the house, is to hover over a hot stove. One of the most convenient - and economical - dishes for summer is a simple salad that can be prepared in advance and be served as a main course for a lunch or light supper. This can be followed by cheese and fruit. You might begin the gazpacho or cold watercress soup.

title: Robert Trumbull was a foreign correspondent for the Times for 37 years.
description: MOHANDAS K. GANDHI'S grandson, Rajmohan Gandhi, is the editor of the magazine Himmat, published by the Indian chapter of Moral Re-Armament, and he was talking about -e influence of the Mahatma on Indians today. ''It is greater than it superficially appears,'' he said. ''Gandhi is very close to the consciousness of many people. His existence is a very real thing, and frequently becomes a rallying point when crises take place. There are literally hundreds of volunteer groups all over the country working on projects inspired directly by Gandhi's life and teachings. They are working against untouchability, for women's rights and for the rights of landless men and for those who wish to work for interreligious unity.''

title: A CONCERTO BY ANY OTHER NAME MAY SOUND JUST AS SWEET
description: Concerted works for instruments and orchestra are not always called concertos. If this is a terribly obvious statement, it nevertheless serves to introduce a number of compositions that are concertos in essence but bear other names. The practice of giving more glamorous titles to such combinations is relatively recent, and contemporary composers are more likely than not to label their solocum-ensemble efforts as something special. William Schuman's elegant and sensitive recent piece for horn and orchestra was christened ''Colloquies'' after rejecting the concerto term. Ernst Bloch's gorgeous ''Schelomo'' for cello and orchestra has proved to be one of the most popular solo pieces in symphony concerts partly because its substance and style are identified in the title. The English cellist Julian Webber has a recording due that combines the Delius concerto with Holst's ''Invocation'' and Vaughan Williams's Fantasia on Sussex Folk Tunes, all of them similar in their cooperative components.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: Strong Symbols

title: URBAN RANGERS JOIN FIGHT TO RESCUE CROTONA PARK
description: On a recent Saturday, two uniformed rangers led a group of local school-children on a walking tour of Crotona Park in the South Bronx, explaining how the American Indians who once lived there worshiped nature.

title: Celine Larkin Weds Daniel Tenney 3d
description: Celine Maria Larkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Frank Larkin of Scituate, Mass., and Daniel Gleason Tenney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tenney Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Paul Smiths, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. George C. Nagle performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's in the Wilderness, a summer chapel in Paul Smiths.

title:
ANTITRUST CHIEF'S MID-TERM GRADE;
A REORDERING - AND A SLOWING DOWN
description: TWO years into the Reagan Administration, the simultaneous euphoria a nd panic that accompanied the induction of William Baxter as a ntitrust chief has subsided, and a cooler evaluation of what's doingi n antitrust may be in order.

title:
ANTIQUES;
RELICS THAT SURVIVED A REVOLUTION
description: JULY 4, 1777 was a day of contrasts. In New Jersey, it had been scarcely two weeks since the Battle of the Short Hills in Union County (not the Essex County community of the same name) and the near-ransacking of parts of the towns of Scotch Plains and Westfield; in New York City, American prisoners were dying in the sweltering heat and brutal conditions of the infamous Sugar House prison.

title: Baltimore's Gain
description: As part of a shakeup that saw them change managers, the Seattle Mariners released their shortstop, Todd Cruz, last weekend.

title: BRIDGES IN COUNTY CONSIDERED SAFE
description: THE 156 bridges owned and maintained by the county are considered safe, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week. Mr. O'Rourke's remarks followed the collapse Tuesday morning of the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike, in which three people were killed and three others injured.

title: West German Warns About Missile Protests
description: Interior Minister Friedrich Zimmermann called today for new laws to deal with expected protests against the deployment of NATO missiles late this year.

title: CASINO 'DONATIONS' TO STATE QUESTIONED
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH prohibited by the Casino Control Act from making political contributions, the gambling-casino industry is making substantial donations of time and money to a Kean administration program that seeks to improve efficiency in the state government.

title: GOVERNMENT SOAP OPERA
description: MARIE A True Story. By Peter Maas. 420 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE YALE MURDER. By Peter Meyer. (Berkley, $3.50.) When he was tried for the murder of Bonnie Garland, a Yale junior from Scarsdale, her lover, Richard Herrin, a Yale graduate student from the Los Angeles barrio, was found guilty of first-degree manslaughter. Peter Meyer, who interviewed Mr. Herrin and captured some of Miss Garland's ''apparently not undevious charm'' in talks with her friends, offers an account of the crime and its aftermath, along with ''a quick tour of the development of the insanity defense,'' Victor S. Navasky said in his review. The strength of Mr. Meyer's narrative, Mr. Navasky noted, comes from his reporting.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor: The article on Italy brought back memories of my Fulbright days at L'Istituto Superiore di Sanita in Rome some 20 years ago. Another proof that the more things change, the more they stay the same. Mr. Hechinger did not, however, have one compensatory ''pleasure.''

title:
GARDENING;
FRESH, QUALITY VEGETABLES: YOUR OWN
description: GROWING one's own vegetables is very popular these days, and there are many reasons for doing it. For one thing, it is much handier to be able to step out into the back yard for a head of lettuce or a bunch of carrots than to drive to market. Freshly harvested vegetables are always tastier and more nutritious than those purchased, assuming that they are harvested while they are in peak condition. Certain varieties are preferred to others by some gardeners. One can be better assured of having these varieties by growing them oneself. Then there is always satisfaction that comes with growing at least a portion of one's own food.

title: Ford's New Midsize Twins
description: WHEN Ford Motor Company unveiled its Tempo and Topaz models in New York recently, it was marking not only its latest line of mid-size cars but its long history on the American scene.

title: BY BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes frequently about London theater. LONDON Whatever current myth may say, the theatrical traffic over the North Atlantic is not all one way. ''Children of a Lesser God'' is deep into its second year in the West End, and, perhaps more surprisingly, Bernard Slade's ''Romantic Comedy'' is safely into its fourth month. And the summer - insofar as one can describe as summer this year's amalgam of cold, wind, rain, storm and late-arriving sunshine, no doubt with biblical plagues of frogs to follow - has brought Londoners three more plays recently presented in New York: Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart,'' A.R. Gurney Jr.'s ''Dining Room'' and Thomas Babe's ''Buried Inside Extra.''

title: STOCK SPLITS - NOT ALWAYS A BONANZA
description: I n April, after one of the more spectacular run-ups of the bull market, Metromedia Inc. had become the subject of mounting interest among a peculiar breed of investor: those who try to anticipate stock splits.

title: INTERESTING FOOD AND PIAF SONGS
description: THE songs of Piaf, Aznavour and Brassens fill the air in the Cafe Pompidou, a new restaurant-bistro in Southampton. Framed pages of French comic strips cover the walls, and the yellow ashtrays and beach umbrellas placed about advertise Ricard. The atmosphere is very French. It also has a casual summertime gaiety about it (but if the day's a scorcher, the ventilation may be inadequate).

title: Dana M. Louttit Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James R. Louttit of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dana M. Louttit, to John W. Loonsk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman P. Loonsk of Buffalo.

title: BUSY DAYS FOR RED SOX FANS
description: IF Henry Berry had his way, every baseball fan in Connecticut would be polled to determine his or her favorite major league baseball team. The outcome of such a poll, Mr. Berry contends, would surprise those who think the New York Yankees and the New York Mets are the most popular teams in the state.

title: DANIEL PONCE'S CUBAN FUSION
description: Jazz is a music in a constant state of flux, but jazz festivals tend to emphasize jazz as history. The change and mutation that make the music so lively and unpredictable happen more comfortably in clubs and lofts than in concert halls. Thursday night's program of jazz-Latin and jazz-funk at Soundscape showed the wisdom of the jazz festival's decision to co-sponsor programs there.

title: No Headline
description: Inside Citicorp As indicated in Robert A. Bennett's article ''Inside Citicorp'' (May 29), Citicorp's chairman, Walter Wriston, likes to portray himself and his bank as ardent champions of a free-market economy. However, in reality, Citicorp's behavior is inconsistent with this philosophy, for Citicorp is the beneficiary of major Government subsidies and interventions.

title: U.S. Copter Crash Injures 6
description: A United States helicopter crashed today during an Atlantic alliance show for the Fourth of July weekend, severely injuring six soldiers, three of them Americans and the others West Germans, the police said.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ John Eaton, who was once described by George Shearing as ''the best pianist in Washington,'' made his first appearance in New York last October after playing in Washington for 20 years. Since then Washington has had to share him with New York as the enthusiasm aroused by his debut performance at Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 91st Street, has brought him back for further appearances there.

title: ANYONE CAN DEVISE A TAX BUT WHO CAN PASS ONE?
description: Taxes can be raised in any number of ways. Ask any member of Congress who has an interest in making the Government's books balance and he or she can produce a list. Many of the revenueraising measures add up, too, reaching the $73 billion over three years that Congress mandated in the 1984 budget resolution approved over President Reagan's objections.

title: PETER GRIGGS'S EXPERIMENTS
description: The Experimental Intermedia Foundation's commendable summer concert series came to a disappointing close Wednesday night with a performance of music by Peter Griggs. Accompanied by the flutist Iris Brooks and the percussionist Glen Velez, Mr. Griggs offered some recent compositions for chamber ensemble that he said ''reflect classical, folk, experimental and world music traditions.''

title: Life Sentence Changed
description: When it came time for Jerry Helm to pay his debt to society, he was overcharged. The United States Supreme Court voted 5 to 4 last week that Mr. Helm should be resentenced or released from the South Dakota prison where he is serving a life sentence for writing a bad check for $100. Mr. Helm pleaded guilty to the crime in 1979 and was sentenced under a state law authorizing life without parole for sixtime felons, even though all his crimes were nonviolent and involved thefts totaling only $230. State officials were given 60 days to comply with the Court's ruling.

title: 3 Killed as Man Ignites Gasoline in Supermarket
description: Three people were killed and at least 10 others were injured tonight when a man poured gasoline on the floor of a supermarket near here and set it afire, sheriff's officials said.

title: FILM OF CANCER CASE WINS AWARD
description: GERALD WENNER, an independent film maker who lives in New Haven, won a blue ribbon in the 1983 American Film Festival held in New York City last month.

title: Further Fallout In the Debate Over Acid Rain
description: Should Washington have an action policy on acid rain? Last week the Federal Government seemed to be going back and forth, and forth again.

title: TRACKING THE SMART MACHINE
description: Robot experts here often speak in terms of generations and the third -and latest - one that has drawn widespread attention is the robot with artificial intelligence, a development far more sophisticated than mere movement. Aided by sophisticated sensors and computer software, these ''smart'' machines are being developed to respond to outside changes, make judgments, communicate with human operators and process information.

title: Martha Quits 49ers
description: In a move from son to father, Paul Martha, the San Francisco 49ers vice president and general counsel for the last six years, has resigned and will assume the duties of president of the fledgling Pittsburgh franchise in the U.S.F.L. The expansion club is owned by Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. of Youngstown, Ohio, and Martha currently works in similar capacities for a portion of the DeBartolo sports properties, including the Pittsburgh Spirit, an indoor soccer team, the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League and the Pittsburgh Civic Arena. Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., who owns the 49ers, said a replacement for Martha would be announced soon.

title: Money Belts
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATORS GAIN THREATENED MARSH
description: A CONTRACT to acquire the first of 25 ecologically endangered sites in the state, under a three-year, $3 million private program, was signed by the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy last week. The nonprofit national organization has an option to purchase 30 acres of marshland in Sharon, known as the Benton Hill Fen, to prevent its conversion to homesites.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: Complex Motives

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: AVOIDING PITFALLS IN CLEARING CUSTOMS
description: On the last day of her vacation in Paris, Anita Evers splurged on a can of pate de foie gras, which she planned to serve to friends in her Maryland home. But as she was going through customs at Washington's Dulles International Airport, the pate was discovered in her suitcase by a customs agent and confiscated. Mrs. Evers did not see herself as a smuggler. In fact, she saw no reason why canned goose liver should not be allowed into the United States, since she had been snacking on similar pate in France and had come to no harm.

title: PRO-SHOREHAM GROUP: VOICE NOW HEARD
description: BY last February, the 50 nuclear scientists from the Brookhaven National Laboratory who make up Citizens for an Orderly Energy Policy were discouraged by the fact that despite all their hard work in support of opening the Shoreham nuclear power plant, no one was paying attention to them.

title: SHOW OF FIBER ART BRINGS A REVELATION
description: AT a time when so many nontraditional materials are part of artists' explorations, it comes as no surprise to find that fiber is taking a prominent role in the expansion of arts' language. The best introduction of this development would be an examination of the work of those regarded as particularly significant, and fortunately it is possible to do just that in a survey exhibition, ''Fiber: The Artist's View,'' at the C.W. Post Center's Hillwood Art Gallery.

title: Rutgers Woman Takes First In 400 Hurdles in Record 55.69
description: Lori McCauley, a 21-year-old Rutgers senior from Hillstown, Pa., said she was ''really discouraged'' Friday. She had just finished sixth in the women's 400-meter hurdles in the National Sports Festival, only to learn that because of an error she was the only one of the eight starters to have run the full distance.

title: A Third-Rate Iceberg?
description: Silly, partisan sniping: initially, that's all the flap over the debate papers seemed to amount to. So what that someone in the Carter camp gave the Reagan forces a heap of briefing papers? Such papers usually don't amount to much - and probably even less in the televised debate just before the 1980 election. After all, it was not Ronald Reagan who made viewers wince by sarcastically citing his daughter's views on nuclear proliferation.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: HIGH-PRICED 1984 OLYMPIC SUMMER GAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: 16-Year-Old Captures Festival Cycling Event
description: Annika Olson of Manhattan, a 16-year-old sophomore at Brearley School, won the women's 40-kilometer (24.8-mile) cycling road race today at the National Sports Festival.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE students at Mount Pleasant Elementary School in West Orange know more than most children about wind direction and air currents, thanks to a balloon experiment launched on May 26.

title: Kean Retouches Jersey Budget
description: New Jersey lawmakers may have thought they were carving the state's $6.8 billion budget in stone when they overwhelmingly approved it last week, but that didn't stop Governor Kean from chipping away. Using his power to veto appropriations line by line, Mr. Kean trimmed $26 million and then signed the plan as the new fiscal year began.

title: HAITIANS' AIDS SUSCEPTIBILITY QUESTIONED BY DOCTORS' PANEL
description: A group of physicians and scientists said in New York yesterday that they believed Haitians were not more susceptible than most people to the fatal disorder called acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: On Threadneedle Street: Robert Leigh-Pemberton; COUNTRY SQUIRE TURNS CITY'S BANKER
description: LONDON IT has long been said in the City of London that the mere raising of an eyebrow by the Governor of the Bank of England can be a more powerful force for change than any law. Thus, Robert Leigh-Pemberton was more amused than startled by the way many bankers expressed their surprise at the announcement last December that he would succeed the highly regarded Gordon Richardson as Governor on July 1.

title: Economic Laws
description: To the Business Editor: Lester Thurow's essay (''It's All Too Easy to Be a Critic,'' June 19) is an ingenious apology for the shortfalls of economics. But if anything, it reinforces rather than lessens public suspicions concerning this so-called discipline.

title: Physicist Is Wed To Dr. Goodman
description: Dr. Nancy B. Goodman and Dr. Peter A. Torpey, research physicists with the Webster Research Center of the Xerox Corporation in Rochester, were married there yesterday by Judge Donald J. Mark of the Monroe (N.Y.) County Court. The ceremony was performed at the H.M.S. Bounty, a restaurant.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor: I must say that I greatly admire Mr. Hechinger's attitude concerning the ''scioperos'' and ''chiusos'' he encountered in his travels in Italy. , too, felt this way on my first visit back in 1955 as the recipient of a professional study award to the famed Forlanini Clinic for Chest Diseases.

title: Australians Assail U.S. Visit
description: Several thousand antinuclear demonstrators marched through the port of Fremantle today to protest visits to western ports by 13 United States Navy ships led by the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Carl Vinson. Those protesting included members of the Labor-dominated Fremantle City Council, which opposed the visit but had no power to stop it.

title: Diana Ballin, a Singer, Is Wed to Allen Eastridge
description: Diana Linton Ballin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas D. Ballin Jr. of Thetford Center, Vt., was married there yesterday to Allen Edward Eastridge, son of Virginia Collison of Lusby, Md., and the late William Fredric Eastridge of Greensboro, N.C. Justice of the Peace Edwin Mead of Ely, Vt., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Progress Reported In Sudan Hostage Case
description: Western diplomatic sources said today that negotiators were making progress toward persuading Sudanese guerrillas to free five hostages, including two Americans.

title: The Algarve
description: To the Editor: My husband and I found Portugal's Algarve to be intriguing, as did Ralph Blumenthal in his article ''The Algarve: Not Just a Sunny Place'' (Travel, June 5). This past February, we explored the Algarve by renting a car in Faro and spent a week traveling from coast to coast, a distance of about 100 miles. n his article, Mr. Blumenthal mentions the Government-owned pousada at Sagres. There is another pousada in the Algarve at Sao Bras de Alportel. This appealing little inn is located in the mountains 15 miles north of Faro; it is a good stopover for travelers who don't want to stay in the city and who are not in a hurry to reach the seashore, which lies southward.

title: CITY MEETS COUNTRY AT THE FRESH AIR FUND 'TOWNS'
description: From her living-room window, 13-year-old Nereida Padilla can see abandoned buildings sealed with cinder blocks, and the fire hydrant where she cools off on hot summer afternoons. ''It's a bleak outlook,'' said her father, Louis.

title: Swaziland Executes 8
description: A woman convicted of the ritual killing of a child was hanged in Swaziland early today along with seven other convicted murderers, the Justice Ministry announced.

title: P.L.O. RIVALS RENEW FIGHTING IN BEKAA
description: Fighting broke out between rival Palestinian factions in eastern Lebanon's Bekaa region today, breaking a two-day-old cease-fire, Lebanese security officials said.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Full Figuring

title: LAND REFORM MAKES LIFE BETTER, THOUGH NOT EASIER
description: The sun had just started to peek over the volcano and throw light over the fields owned by the El Sunza Cooperative in the western province of Sonsonate. The campesinos were already at work on 860 acres of sugar cane, 860 acres of coffee trees and 90 acres of corn and other grains.

title: MUSIC SPARKS POLITICAL PROTEST OF CHILE YOUTH
description: A popular Chilean folk singer was ostensibly singing a love ballad, but it was the forbidden political meaning and President Augusto Pinochet's Chile that excited the young people crammed into the smoky cafe.

title: WALTER BISHOP ON SOLO PIANO
description: Walter Bishop's solo piano recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday afternoon for the jazz festival got off to an uncertain start as Mr. Bishop first seemed to be about to launch into his musical autobiography and then to peddle a book explaining his piano method. But after a brief foray into Chopin, played straight and then swinging, to demonstrate his musical start in the classics, and after playing two compositions from his book, he turned to the music of jazz musicians with whom he has been associated.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
OLD-FASHIONED FOURTH
description: An authentic, old-fashioned Fourth of July celebration - with the documents to prove it - will be held tomorrow at Allaire Village, where the buildings and setting retain a 19th-century character.

title: Beth D. Titus to Marry Christopher Cox Cullen
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Richmond Titus of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Diane Titus, to Christopher Cox Cullen, son of June Cox Cullen of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late James Freston Cullen. A September wedding is planned.

title: Princeton Crew Gains
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 2 - Princeton University's varsity lightweight crew and Harvard's freshman heavyweights won their heats of the Ladies' Challenge Plate today and advanced to Sunday's semifinals in the 134th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: CARTER AIDES FEAR DEEPER INFILTRATION
description: Aides to former President Jimmy Carter are now attempting to determine whether White House security flaws extended well beyond the 1980 Presidential campaign in time and substance.

title: April Lynn Colby Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Colby of Massapequa Park, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, April Lynn Colby, to Peter Guardino Jr., son of Mr. Guardino of New York and the late Arlene Smith Guardino.

title: FAMILIES SEEK GENETIC COUNSELING
description: WHEN Dr. Jessica Davis does her detective work, she searches for the basic fabric of life: genetic material. Last summer, for example, she was called upon to confirm the identity of the father of Henry Ferdinand Karlin, an adopted infant whose natural mother - neurologically impaired -could not help with the identification.

title: Rightists Kill Two in Salvador To Avenge Politician's Slaying
description: A right-wing terrorist group dumped the bodies of a strangled man and woman in a hotel parking lot today, and left a note saying they had been killed to avenge the slaying of a rightist politician by leftist guerrillas.

title: Cancer Gene Meets Its Match
description: Scientists know that some cancer genes have chemically similar counterparts among genes found in noncancerous human cells. Understanding the function of these seemingly harmless genes is a research priority, for if their cancerous cousins could then be found, scientists would have clues to how cancer genes work.

title: Miss Carroll Wed To J.D. Dana Jr.
description: Grace C. Carroll, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Carroll of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to James D. Dana Jr., son of Mr. Dana of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Mrs. Horace Shepard 3d of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Regis Ryan, assisted by the Rev. John Spencer, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Spoleto
description: To the Editor:

title: BY STEPHEN HARVEY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Harvey is assistant curator in the Department of Film of the Museum of Modern Art. LOS ANGELES Nothing excites the diehard movie aficionado so much as the news that the missing reels of a heretofore lost or mangled classic have suddenly been unearthed, after moldering for decades in a studio vault or somebody's cobwebbed attic.

title: MEMORIES ON ENERGY MORE MYTH THAN REALITY
description: A HUNDRED years ago, commercial electric service came to Connecticut when 21 arc lights began to illuminate downtown Hartford's railroad station and five nearby businesses. It was, of course, only the first flicker of what would soon become a major energy resource. By 1902 the electrical inspector for the Hartford Board of Fire Underwriters would declare that Hartford was then ''far in the lead of any other city in the world in the use of electricity for light and power per capita.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A map in Metropolitan Report yes- terday incorrectly depicted the site of the bridge collapse on the Connecticut Turnpike. The bridge is between Exits 4 and 5.

title: LLOYD WEBBER: HITS BUT NO HIT SONGS
description: When the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim Rice musical ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' ended its long Broadway run 10 years ago, few would have predicted that Mr. Lloyd Webber would be a dominant musical force on Broadway a decade later. Appearing as a record album in 1969, then revamped into a ''rock opera'' for the stage and the movies, ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' struck many as a sensational fluke. A ''rock opera'' whose music wasn't really rock, a show whose songs ventured outside the stylistic conventions of Broadway, ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' fitted no categories. And because it didn't, it was viewed with curiosity and some contempt by the rock and Broadway establishments alike. A real ''rock opera'' was the Who's ''Tommy.'' A real musical comedy was ''Gypsy.''

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Between Arms And Arms Control
description: Between dealing with Congress and negotiating with the Soviet Union, there wasn't much to choose last week. The Reagan Administration's simultaneous attempts to bolster American and Allied defenses and to inch toward arms control agreements placed it in a delicate position on Capitol Hill and in Geneva.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
ELLIS ISLAND: THE MEMORIES LINGER ON
description: JERSEY CITY MIRIAM DRUCKER of Verona walked slowly down the silent corridors of the defunct Jersey Central Railroad terminal in what is now Liberty State Park, her footsteps echoing off the archways. However, her memories were of a time when one could barely hear one's own voice in the crowded, noisy station.

title: CENTER SOLVES CRISES IN ADOPTIVE FAMILIES
description: They were the answer to a caseworker's prayer - a white middleclass couple in their late 30's with two children of their own, a large Brooklyn apartment and a desire to expand their family by adopting the sort of children other couples had rejected.

title: Jane Shellenberger to Wed in Colorado
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Adamson Shellenberger of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Wadsworth Shellenberger to Jonathan Macaulay of Boulder, Colo., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Macaulay of Naples, Fla.

title: AUTOISTS GIRD FOR CHANGES IN REGULATIONS
description: TRENTON THE state's 5.1 million licensed drivers and the more than five million cars and trucks that they own or operate have come under close scrutiny by the Legislature in recent weeks. Facing a courtimposed deadline of last Friday, legislators took a hard look at New Jersey's motor-vehicle inspection system and voted to make sweeping changes in how inspections are made. Although Governor Kean signed the changes into law, they are not expected to immediately eliminate the anticipated long lines at the state-operated stations.

title: 2 RECYCLING PROJECTS
description: In step with a current trend in commercial real estate to reuse rather than tear down or relocate are two new ventures under way in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Gwen Dixon Becomes Bride
description: Gwen Ann Dixon, daughter of Margaret Dixon and William R. Dixon of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas H. Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Morrison of Harrisburg, Pa. Justice of the Peace Loren Jaffee of Stamford, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Stamford Yacht Club. The bride is an account coordinator with Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising in Chicago. Mr. Morrison is a candidate for a doctorate in clinical pyschology at Northwestern University Medical School.

title: CAMPAIGN 'CIRCUS' IS PLAYING TRENTON
description: TRENTON THE Presidential election is more than a year away, but the campaign circus that precedes the balloting is already in town. Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, came to the State House last Thursday to talk to reporters and to visit the Democratic and Republican Party caucuses in the Legislature.

title: YOU AND THE NIGHT AND THE MUSIC
description: IN the summertime, when the living is easy, most of the music on Long Island is free - and outdoors. Courtesy of the towns and counties - and, naturally, the taxpayers - local parks will allow music lovers the luxury of listening al fresco.

title: A STAMP OF DISAPPROVAL FOR JUNK MAIL
description: OUR DOOM is close upon us. Are we going to control the junk-mail explosion or let it control us? What an absurd exercise in waste and futility it is! Order one item from one mail-order house, subscribe to one magazine or donate to one good cause, and you set off avalanches of junk mail that will fill your trash cans to overflowing for months.

title: Carin E. Townsend to Be Wed to David A. Boss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Townsend of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carin Elizabeth Townsend of New York, to David Andrew Boss, son of Coleen Kiebert-Jones of Santa Cruz, Calif., and W. Andrew Boss of St. Paul.

title: Break on Wages
description: To the Business Editor: Your article on the causes and effects of the decline in the level of wage increases (''At Last, a Good Break on Wages,'' June 12) was very well researched and presented. Nevertheless, I wish you had not overlooked in the text what I found to be the salient point made by the graphs that accompanied the article.

title: KEEPING COOL IN THE FACE OF A SURPRISE
description: No matter how much forethought you have given to the problem of meeting a surprise thrown at you by a clever opponent, it just isn't easy to keep your bearings.

title:
ART;
NEWARK MUSEUM PUTS FOCUS ON PUEBLO POTTERY
description: NEWARK INDIAN pottery from the American Southwest is at home in the Newark Museum, which has collected it since 1913. The museum also has a renowned collection of Tibetan art, which is a relative of the Indian pottery in terms of mystery and ancientness, and is also currently displaying American folk art.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE VON BULOW AFFAIR By William Wright. Illustrated. 372 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $16.95.

title: CARDINAL NEWMAN MEETS AMBROSE BIERCE
description: LEAD TIME A Journalist's Education. By Garry Wills. 389 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $18.95.

title: U.S.F.L. SEES PROGRESS
description: As the United States Football League ends its first regular season today with playoffs to follow, a group of perceptions emerges rather than a definable success or failure.

title: THE POPE AND POLAND: A SYMPOSIUM
description: Of 'Legitimization'

title: INGMAR BERGMAN PAYS HOMAGE TO A FAMILY
description: It's Christmas Eve, 1907. Helena Ekdahl, the matriarch of a large, prosperous family in a town very much like Uppsala, Sweden, moves around the family apartment making a hostess's last-minute inspection before the arrival of the guests - her sons, daughters-in-law, grandchildren and old friends. As she passes through the handsome rooms, cluttered with the beloved debris of time, now ablaze in the light of hundreds of candles, she has the manner of a captain followed by his sergeants, except that the sergeants are two elderly housemaids.

title: SPEAKING OUT ON BEHALF OF UNIONS
description: TO those who set store by titles, Gus Tyler of Great Neck is the assistant president of the 300,000-member International Ladies Garment Workers Union, a post he has held for about 20 years. But it may be more illuminating to visualize the 71-year-old Mr. Tyler as philosopher in residence.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE American Ballet Theater will be offering some very interesting new casting at the Metropolitan Opera House this week. On Tuesday, the company will pull out all the stops with its revival of ''Three Virgins and a Devil,'' Agnes de Mille's saucy look at the wages of sin.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF THE AMERICAN AUTOMOBILE INDUSTRY By Brock Yates. 301 pp. New York: Empire Books. $13.95.

title: COUNTY MOVES ON TWO FRONTS IN AIRPORT DISPUTE
description: THE county's plans for a permanent noise monitoring system at Westchester County Airport moved a step closer to reality last week as formal proposals from two firms willing to furnish and install the equipment were opened by officials.

title: EDUCATION'S FAILURE AT THE RECEIVING END
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Cleveland Robertson Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bolling Robertson 3d of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Cleveland Robertson, to Stephen Jan Abarbanel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Abarbanel of North Bellmore, L.I.

title: WATT'S LIBERAL SINS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Keeping Memories Of Stamford's Station The wrecker's ball should have no effect on blotting out the memory of the Stamford railroad station (''Stamford's Station Has a Long History,'' June 5) for a model of it in all its splendor exists, alive and working, at the Stamford Model Railroad Club at its quarters in the St. John's Episcopal Church in downtown Stamford. HARRY M. LESSIN Norwalk --------------------------------------------------------------------- The Times welcomes letters from readers.

title: QUEBEC FINDS FRANCE WARM, UP TO A POINT
description: The relationship between Paris, Ottawa and Quebec suffered some new twists and tugs this week as Rene Levesque, the Premier of the French-speaking Canadian province, visited Paris and met for the first time with President Francois Mitterrand.

title: A CRITIC CELEBRATES THE UNPREDICTABLE
description: I think my friends lack imagination. When I tell them that I shall now be retiring from regular reviewing in this space, they look at me in consternation. Not because they feel they won't be able to get along without my sage observations, nothing like that. They stare, lips frozen into stunned little ovals, because they simply cannot conceive what I'll do with myself.

title: Dello Joio Captures Jumping at Lake Placid
description: In a battle of show jumping's two most recent World Cup champions, Norman Dello Joio edged Melanie Smith to win the $2,000 Adirondack Speed Stake, the feature event at today's 14th annual Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: 2 TYPES OF VIDEO RECORDERS
description: Home cassette recorders are available in two noncompatible formats. Approximately one out of every four recorders sold is a Beta model, made primarily by Sony, Sanyo and Zenith.

title: Value of Water To the Athlete
description: To the Sports Editor: The recent story on ultra-athletes (''Ultra-Athletes Take It to the Limit,'' The New York Times, June 19) was accurate in attributing improved performance in part to better understanding of sports medicine and the biologic demands of various athletic activity.

title: METS BEAT PHILS, 4-3, AFTER LOSING OPENER
description: After falling victim to a trick play by Philadelphia and losing, 6-5, in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader, the Mets returned with some timely hitting for a 4-3 victory that snapped a five-game losing streak.

title: David W. Kilbride Will Be Married To Miss Burnside
description: Announcement has been made by Rosemarie C. Burnside of Cutchogue, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Kathleen Marie Burnside, to David Williams Kilbride, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kilbride of Bellerose Village, L.I., and Cutchogue. An Aug. 27 wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Driving in State Poses Challenges We have lived in Connecticut long enough (two years) to have discovered two major problems with the attractions described in ''Time to Explore the State's Backyard'' (May 29): Connecticut roads and Connecticut drivers.

title: Lucca
description: To the Editor: A. Alvarez's ''Afoot and Unhurried in Lucca'' (Travel, June 12) brought back memories of my brief tour afoot in Lucca a week after the town's liberation from the Germans in October 1944.

title: EXPLORATIONS BY DICK HYMAN
description: Dick Hyman, who can do practically anything on a piano, seemed to be going down a middle path in his solo concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday afternoon. For this jazz festival performance he was choosing pop tunes - ''What Is This Thing Called Love,'' ''Memories of You,'' ''Lover Come Back to Me'' - and improvising on them in ways that enabled him to display his imagination and virtuosity.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Letters; Yorkville Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
53 YEARS OF PLAYLAND MEMORIES
description: WHEN the fireworks explode in the night sky over Playland tomorrow, there will be one person who may be a little jaded about the rocket's red glare. Al (''Ginger'') Roscia has seen the Fourth of July roll around on the calendar for 69 years now, and for 53 of those years he has been working at various maintenance jobs at the Art Deco amusement park in Rye, which he affectionately calls ''the most beautiful place in the world.''

title: Six Concerns Accused By U.S. of Bid Rigging
description: A Federal grand jury indicted six corporations and five executives Friday on charges that they rigged bids for electrical construction at eight United States Steel Corporation plants in the Pittsburgh area.

title: GENEALOGY SESSION ATTRACTING EXPERTS
description: FOR four days this month, 1,000 genealogists from the United States, Canada and England, including some of the noted names in the field, will attend the Fifth Annual Genealogy Conference in Hartford.

title: WHAT THOSE HANDBAGS REALLY CONTAIN
description: WE bring my 86-year-old mother-in-law home from the nursing home on Sundays. She sits quietly in her chair, totally removed from our world. The only conversation I can have with her is over the terrible price of food; all I have to do is tell her how much a pound of butter or ham costs, and I get an instant response.

title: HOW SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 20-26 with 1,365 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Fatal Bridge Collapse Heightens Urgency on Repairs in Three States ; 'INFRASTRUCTURE' MEANS LIFE AND DEATH; CUOMO PUSHES $1.25 BILLION IN BONDS
description: ALBANY AFTER a catastrophic accident, officials usually rush to reassure the public that goverment is working to protect them. Last week, Governor Cuomo warned ''it can happen here.''

title: DEVELOPMENTS FROM DOWN UNDER
description: Normal American visitors to the lands down under are usually struck by some obvious differences: The night sky is a conspicuous example, but there is also the tendency of numbers on the telephone dial and departing bath-water to proceed in unexpected directions.

title: TB REMAINS A STUBBORN FOE FOR ALASKA
description: The killers that destroyed whole villages of Alaskan Indians, Aleuts and Eskimos - diseases such as measles, smallpox and influenza - have been wiped out or contained by advances in medicine. One of the most pernicious of the diseases brought here by the white man, however, lurks among a major portion of the native community. With a population of 460,000, Alaska reported 96 cases of tuberculosis last year, mostly among natives living in the bush. That ranks it second, after Hawaii, on the nation's tuberculosis charts, with an overall incidence rate of about 22 cases in every 100,000 residents.

title: PLEA IS MADE TO RETAIN WATER PIPELINE ON SPAN
description: According to the New Jersey Weekly of May 29, the water pipeline across the George Washington Bridge, constructed only a few short years ago at a cost of millions of taxpayer dollars, is being dismantled.

title: Sarah Kelly Is Affianced
description: Col. John J. Kelly, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kelly have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Eustis Kelly, to Andrew deWitt Vigneron, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Vigneron.

title: A PEEK AT THE MIDNIGHT SUN
description: DOUGLAS MARTIN is the Toronto bureau chief of The New York Times.

title:
ART;
ONCE-NEGLECTED AREAS OF AMERICAN ART YIELD DELIGHTS
description: THE past decade has seen some remarkable developments in the art market, among them a renewed interest in two areas of American art that had, until recently, been of relatively little concern to collectors: late 19th-century American Impressionism and early 20thcentury Modernism. Both these schools were often considered to be mere derivations of the European avant-garde movements and, as such, second rate.

title: CHicago Needs Three to Tango
description: The way things are going in Chicago, Mayor Harold Washington's term may be up before he and the City Council shake hands and get on with the business of governing.

title: A HANDY CD PLAYER ARRIVES
description: Back in the days when the ultimate sound equipment was a walnutveneered ''console'' with voluptuous curves, the name of Magnavox reigned supreme. Since then the company veered off toward the manufacture of television sets and lost its former prominence in audio. But now Magnavox has decided to revisit the scene of its former glory, and the new digital technology provides an open gate for the company's re-entry into the audio arena. With a bold opening gambit - an all-digital laser player for Compact Disks - Magnavox returns to the fold.

title: COSMOS MISS CHANCES IN LOSS
description: The Cosmos controlled the ball, but Chicago did most of the scoring and Coach Julio Mazzei of the New Yorkers had little argument with the outcome.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SWITZERLAND'S VALAIS
description: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a correspondent for The New York Times, lives in Rome.

title: Money Is Nonobjective
description: ''I've seen a lot of Mondrians,'' Shigeki Kameyama said last week.

title: MISS SMITH'S 72-208 LEADS JACKSON BY 1
description: M.J. Smith of New Zealand recovered from a string of bogeys to hold a one-stroke lead with an eight-under-par total of 208 after the rain-delayed third round today at the $250,000 Peter Jackson Classic.

title: EMOTION RULES THE WAY MARTIN LIVES AND WORKS
description: The chef wore spikes. A pair of pork chops was sizzling on the skillet in the kitchenette and he swabbed them with a slab of butter. It was late afternoon of a recent weekday and this scene of tender domestic bliss in the manager's office in Yankee Stadium was unexpected.

title: Headliners; The Nation's Attic
description: Among the people who run the Smithsonian Institution, there's no denying that Philip Leslie counts. Last week he announced that a five-year, $8 million tally of objects in the Institution's complex of museums, its first complete inventory, showed more than 100 million items. Mr. Leslie, the registrar, said that in its 137 years of collecting the Smithsonian had accumulated, among other things, 4 million moths and butterflies, 35,594 human skeletons, the remains of 8,424 shrews, 10 pipe organs and hair from the heads of Presidents from Washington through Pierce.

title: 6-Day Race To Start
description: Long-distance runners are converging on New York for two major events, including one that will last nearly a week. National championships are at stake in the Pepsi Challenge 10,000-meter run today, but a six-day race starting tomorrow at Randalls Island provides a more novel touch and memories of an endurance test that was popular in the late 1800's.

title: Miss Smith Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Pichard Smith of Mendham Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Hawkins Smith, to Christopher Rory Corrigan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Paul Corrigan of Water Mill, L.I.

title: HIGH COURT'S WORDS MEAN THE MOST IN DEBATE ON EDUCATION
description: THE education issue got fresh impetus from several directions last week, probably insuring it a leading spot among domestic political themes for 1984. The United States Supreme Court raised new questions with a favorable ruling on a tuition tax deduction measure; President Reagan hammered his Government-out-of-the-classroom message as he jet-stopped westward for the weekend; and at the National Education Association convention, you couldn't fling an eraser without beaning a Democratic candidate.

title: PUBLIC'S APPROVAL OF REAGAN IN POLL RISING BUT LIMITED
description: A plurality of the public thinks that professional tennis players who argue with officials are behaving like spoiled brats. Section 5. By HEDRICK SMITH

title: KOHL IS GETTING RESULTS, EAST AND WEST
description: If report cards were given for style in statesmanship, Chancellor Helmut Kohl would probably pull a C. He is a fumbling orator, with an unerring knack for the platitudinous. He is monolingual. He articulates no grand vision of West Germany's place in a fragile world order.

title: Astros 3, Dodgers 1
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Nolan Ryan pitched a five-hitter and Jose Cruz hit a three-run homer to pace Houston.

title: BITTERSWEET MEMORIES OF THE 1930'S
description: Musicians who thrived during the Great Depression and those who struggled just to survive will recreate some of the spirit of the 1930's in their own music and their own words at Town Hall tonight at 8 o'clock as part of the Kool jazz festival.

title: SPACE FOR LAW
description: When the City Bar Association built itself a ''house'' at 42 West 44th Street in 1896, the structure more than amply served the needs of its 1,500 members for a place to meet and study. But as the association's membership grew - currently some 14,000 lawyers belong - so, too, did its space requirements.

title: PILOTS ARE BLAMED IN A JERSEY CRASH
description: The pilots of two small planes that collided over Livingston, N.J., last November were not looking carefully enough for other aircraft, the National Transportation Safety Board has ruled.

title: Jeannette T. Vogel Weds E.S. Jacobs in Greenwich
description: Jeannette Torrey Vogel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ross Vogel of Chatham, N.J., and Edward Stanley Jacobs, son of Mrs. David Marshall Pomfret 3d of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Brannan Jacobs of St. Croix, Virgin Islands, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert Corin Morris, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's uncle, Walter Harvey Weed 3d.

title: Lita Kean to Wed Frederick Haack 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Joan Jessup Kean of New York and Hobe Sound, Fla., and John Kean of Bedminster, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lita Kean, to Frederick L. Haack 3d, son of Mrs. Harry R. Neilson Jr. of Malvern, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me., and Mr. Haack Jr. of New Orleans.

title: 55 YEARS OF THEATER: RETROSPECTIVE BY AL HIRSCHFELD
description: Al Hirschfield has been caricaturing the theater for the New York Times for exactly 55 years. Just how thoroughly he has done it will be clear from the small-scale retrospective on this page.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Banks Hold Their Own

title: A DANCER, TEACHER, AND CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Judith Dunn, a modern dancer and choreographer who was one of the founders of the Judson Dance Theater, died of a brain tumor Friday at her home in Burlington, Vt. She was 49 years old.

title: QUESTIONS OF IMAGE; Demystifying
description: Why did Spain's La Pasionaria always wear black? In the years of the Spanish Civil War, legend had it that the state of the world impelled her to perpetual mourning.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: THIS Fourth of July week, it would be most appropriate to examine the paintings of Charles Rosen at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences in Morristown.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TAKES FOURTH WIMBLEDON TITLE
description: Martina Navratilova summed it up nicely. ''It wasn't a thrilling final,'' she said today, after winning her fourth Wimbledon singles title, 6-0, 6-3, from Andrea Jaeger in a 54-minute match. ''But it was very satisfying.''

title: 2 Arrested, One Sought In Video Arcade Killings
description: Two teen-agers were arrested today and a third person was being sought in connection with the stabbing deaths of four young employees during the robbery of a miniature race track and video game center, a homicide detective said.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 3, 1983
description: International Secretary of State George P. Shultz will visit the Middle East on his way home next week from Pakistan, the White House announced. The brief announcement did not give the purpose of the trip nor name the countries that Mr. Shultz would visit. One official said details of the visit were still being worked out. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.S. is giving key nations in Africa twice the military aid they had been receiving because of the Reagan Administration's concern about Soviet and Cuban political and military activity in Africa. At the same time, the Administration has tried to broaden ties with South Africa, marking a significiant break from Carter Administration policies, as Administration officials acknowledge. (1:5.)

title: CONCERT: HARPIST PLAYS IN SERIES ON NEW MUSIC
description: There was not much exciting or even interesting music in Wednesday night's concert at the N.Y.U. Forum for New Music Series at Loeb Center. The most professional part of the evening, in fact, was Sylvia Kowalczuk's harp performance. She was a generally sensitive player, even though in Debussy's ''Fille aux Cheveaux de Lin'' and Tournier's ''Matin,'' she tended to distend the line with ritards and extraneous detail. The harp Capriccio by Aristide von Wurtzler displayed some energetic charms, but Jacqueline Fontyn's Intermezzo for solo harp proved to be a cluttered work and not entirely in Miss Kowalczuk's grasp.

title: The Insurers of Times Books Reach Settlement of Lawsuit
description: A settlement of a libel suit has been reached between the insurers of Times Books, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company, and Tscherim Soobsokov of Paterson, N.J., who charged that he was unjustly accused of being a Nazi war criminal in a book published by Quadrangle/New York Times Book Company in 1977.

title: Lee Lincoln Estin Married
description: Lee Lincoln Estin, daughter of Hope Wonham Estin of Aspen, Colo., and the late Peter George Estin, was married yesterday to Olivier Alfred Cauro, son of Mrs. Henri Grimond and Jean Cauro of Paris. The Rev. Edward O. Miller Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Hans H. Estin, uncle of the bride, in Manchester, Mass. The bride graduated from the Chapin School and the University of Denver. Mr. Cauro, who received an M.B.A. degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is with the Nephele Maritime Agency in London.

title: MUSICAL CHAIRS
description: The technological developments that can make great waves in the market for robots are not the sort of breakthroughs that would interest the Nobel jurors for scientific achievement. But they are of compelling importance to Japanese industry.

title:
TV VIEW;
SPAIN BRACES FOR CABLE
description: Afew weeks ago, a group of Americans descended on Spain for a fiveday conference on the subject of television. The city was Barcelona, certainly the country's liveliest and most attractive center of culture. It seems that television in Spain, as in most European countries, is preparing for the introduction of cable and satellite transmissions. It also seems that Spain, like much of Europe, is nervous about the prospect. In contrast to the United States experience, where broadcasting developed within the general context of a free marketplace and commercial interests, the European systems have evolved much more cautiously under varying degrees of government control. Understandably, many of those governments are not anxious to diminish that control.

title: THINGS TO DO ON THE FOURTH
description: THERE is more to Independence Day in Connecticut than just fireworks. The Fourth may be spent listening to a concert, watching or running a road race, cheering for a favorite auto racer, seeing a parachutist descend in a blaze of flares or visiting a Civil War encampment.

title: Leslie Froehlich Is the Bride of Andrew Schwartz
description: Leslie Joanne Froehlich, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Froehlich of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Andrew Reid Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Schwartz of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Deborah Zecher performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: COMPLEX RENT-GUIDELINE RULES TROUBLING BOTH SIDES
description: DURING his four years as chairman of the New York City Rent G uidelines Board, Marvin Markus has repeatedly said that the r entstabilization system works best when its rules are kept simple a nd can be easily understood by tenants and owners.

title: NEW LIGHTS IN THE WINDOWS OF MAIN STREET
description: IT didn't take my full 32 years to fall in love with this town - it just took most of them to realize it. The feeling was always there, deep and ignored, then recently surfaced from some ancestral memory and restored by instinct. I love this town, my town - how could I have ever thought I'd leave it? I realize now that this is where I belong. We have a mutual relationship that wasn't always there.

title: ABortion Foes Overreach in The Senate
description: In nearly a decade of Congressional debate, those who oppose Federal laws limiting a woman's right to abortion have been aided in no small way by squabbling among those who favor limitations. Such was the case again last week in the Senate, where a restrictive constitutional amendment lost 50 to 49, 18 votes short of the necessary two-thirds majority.

title: UPSTATE FRUIT RESEARCHERS HUNT SECRET OF THE ULTIMATE APPLE
description: From late July until November, Roger D. Way bites into about 200 apples almost every day. Dr. Way, a professor of pomology and viticulture at the State Agricultural Experiment Station here, is a plant breeder trying to develop new and better apples for New York State. Pomology is the science of fruit cultivation, and viticulture is the cultivation of grapes.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE SUMMER OF KATYA By Trevanian. 242 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95.

title: A CORPORATE EQUIVALENT OF THE CLASSICAL VILLA; RYE BROOK, N.Y.
description: If Palladio had designed a spaceship, it might have looked something like the new headquarters of General Foods Corporation, which opened last week in this small village in the center of Westchester County. The building is perhaps the most curious mix of classicism and futurism ever produced; it is as sleek as any corporate headquarters anywhere, yet it seems, at the same time, to want to make us think of great country villas.

title: Topics; Questions of Image; Quintessence
description: Since it can cost something over $200,000 to raise a child born in 1983, the tab for Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Pisner's five may be a cool million. And they won't save on hand-me-downs: the Pisner children were all born at the same time, last month.

title: Cribbs to Leave Bills
description: Joe Cribbs, the all-pro running back, announced yesterday that he would be leaving the Buffalo Bills after the 1983 season and joining the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League in his home state of Alabama. Cribbs, a native of Sulligent and a former standout at Auburn University, is in his option year with the National Football League team.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
RARE U.S. COINS TO BE FEATURED AT AUCTION '83
description: United States coins of unusual rarity and quality will be featured during Auction '83, which will be held in New York on July 29-30. Staged by four major firms, there are 2,000 lots to be sold, with several hundred likely to bring five-figure prices, and at least one that should be well up in the six-figure range.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from two weeks in Italy, I was interested in reading Mr. Hechinger's piece on Italy. If, before leaving for New York, he had done some research (i.e., Michelin's Green Guide to Italy, which lists not only the closing hours of the major attractions but also the closing days), he could have saved himself some of the backtracking he had to do.

title: 20 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday cited 20 food establishments for health code violations. In its weekly report, the department also listed seven that were allowed to reopen following correction of violations, and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Koch Sees Light On Exemptions
description: There's not much political capital in taxing nonprofit institutions, Mayor Koch evidently decided last week. Abandoning his campaign to collect property taxes from cultural, social service and educational organizations, Mr. Koch said he would propose a bill entitling as many as 300 of the groups to exemptions.

title: LOW COPPER PRICE BRINGS END TO JOBS IN BUTTE
description: The giant trucks that hauled the copper ore from the mines of the Anaconda Minerals Company have been parked and their engines have been turned off, perhaps for the last time in this city once called The Richest Hill on Earth.

title:
ART;
A SENSE OF RENEWAL IN PORT CHESTER
description: ONE sure sign that a town is breaking out of the seediness to which time and economics have consigned it is the appearance of an active art gallery. As a repository of creative life, a gallery signals growth and change.

title: HOW TO KEEP 'TECH ISLAND' BURSTING WITH DISCOVERIES
description: Following are excerpts from a recent commencement address at the Polytechnic Institute of New York by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Amityville.

title: MAKING A VIRTUE OF NECESSITY
description: DESPITE its name, Le Shack d'Alsace approaches with timidity that robust provincial cuisine, one that weds German heaviness with French subtlety. This union is not as absurd as it might first appear. The quality of the soil plays a great role in defining the limits of a region's cooking, and Lorraine and Alsace, joined as they are by the Vosges Mountains, share the poor harvest of a rocky, wooded terrain.

title:
ANTITRUST CHIEF'S MID-TERM REVIEW;
BAXTER'S CONFUSING SIGNALS TO BUSINESS
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's appointment of William Baxter to head the D epartment of Justice's antitrust division in April 1981 was hailed b y some and decried by others - basically for the same reason. The p erception was that the appointment of Mr. Baxter - a former Stanfordl aw professor known for his conservative philosophy - signaled a t urning away from previous enforcement policies in favor of what was b illed as a more ''pro-business'' line. As one observer put it at t he time, the nomination was a ''message appointment.'' But two yearsl ater, the message seems more confusing and not as helpful as many h ad expected or hoped.

title: A FIRE, AN INQUIRY AND A WAITER'S RESEARCH FOR A THESIS
description: IN March, an explosion and fire caused extensive damage to a restaurant on the Island's North Shore. The Nassau County District Attorney's office, suspecting arson, subpoenaed the lengthy chronicles kept by a waiter at Le Restaurant in Glen Cove.

title: SHOPPING AROUND FOR A DISCOUNT BROKER
description: THE continuing bull market may have made it harder to find bargains i n the stock market. But there are now enormous opportunities to get b argain-basement prices on stock brokerage services. The enthusiastice ntry of the nation's commercial banks into the discount brokerage b usiness has dramatically widened investor access to trading c ommissions that are well below those charged by traditional b rokerage firms.

title:
GARDENING;
FRESH, QUALITY VEGETABLES: YOUR OWN
description: GROWING one's own vegetables is very popular these days, and there are many reasons for doing it. For one thing, it is much handier to be able to step out into the back yard for a head of lettuce or a bunch of carrots than to drive to market. Freshly harvested vegetables are always tastier and more nutritious than those purchased, assuming that they are harvested while they are in peak condition. Certain varieties are preferred to others by some gardeners. One can be better assured of having these varieties by growing them oneself. Then there is always satisfaction that comes with growing at least a portion of one's own food.

title: Portland, Me.
description: To the Editor:

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE MALIGNED CITY DOG
description: My own city dog, Pye, is a cream colored standard poodle. Her resemblance to a lamb is not lost on the 6- to 12-year-old set. Herself fond of children and also of being petted, she is likely to be surrounded, when we appear together on the street, with little people. Even smaller people, as they are rolled by in their strollers, reach out fat arms and make a brave attempt to say ''doggie.'' If a glance at the mother reveals that she is smiling, I will call the poodle over to nuzzle the baby. The resulting screams of delight assist me in carrying through sometimes discouraging days. However, there is a darker side to the picture. When I am caught on the street without the dog, I am severely criticized and even threatened. It is fortunate for me that 8-year-olds do not come in larger sizes.

title: IN THE WAKE OF THE POPE'S TRIP: TWO STRUGGLES
description: To the Editor:

title: WILTING OF FARM RESEARCH PROMPTS CRITICAL QUERIES
description: When the Department of Agriculture was established by President Lincoln in 1862 its sole mission was agricultural research and education. Virtually its entire attention in that second year of the Civil War was directed toward how to make better wine from American grapes and better use of horse manure.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 4 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 2 16 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) A British actress caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 3 3 13 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 4 11 14 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century Southern California. 5 6 8 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 6 10 2 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 7 7 5 ASCENT INTO HELL, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Bernard Geis/Warner, $16.50.) The ordeal of a man who leaves the priesthood to enjoy the pleasures of secular life. 8 4 10 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron.

title: Panel Votes Dr. King Holiday
description: A House subcommittee has voted to make the third Monday in January a national holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., 15 years after the civil rights leader was assassinated.

title: Brewers 6, Indians 5
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Cecil Cooper slammed his 16th home run and the reliever Pete Ladd helped Milwaukee hold off a ninth-inning rally for the victory.

title: Patricia Houlihan To Wed a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Houlihan of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Maureen Houlihan, to Schulyer Van Rensselaer Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Burritt Winter of Garden City, L.I., and Windham, N.Y.

title: INTERIOR DEPARTMENT MEMO URGES EXPANDED USE OF WILDLIFE REFUGES
description: The Interior Department has circulated guidelines for ''expanded economic and public use of national wildlife refuges,'' according to internal departmental documents.

title: AT THE TREASURY, A FIGHTING NEWSMAN
description: LONDON NIGEL LAWSON is a large man with a confessed fondness for food and drink, especially food. But his appetite is tantalized just as strongly by a good battle over politics and economics, and now the City of London is poised for the fireworks.

title: Tippy Martinez Selected
description: Tippy Martinez, a relief pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles, has been named to the American League all-star team for Wednesday's 50thanniversary game at Comiskey Park in Chicago. He replaces Ron Guidry of the Yankees, who cannot pitch because of a sore back.

title: Meredyth Hull and H.Brooks Smith Are Planning a September Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Hull of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Meredyth M. Hull, to H. Brooks Smith, son of H. Hanford Smith Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mrs. Smith. A September wedding is planned.

title: THE PERIL IN PLACING WEAPONS IN SPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Tom, Ben and Ron

title: Italy Arrests 11 In Drive on Gangsters
description: The police arrested 11 people suspected of being gangsters and issued warrants for 19 others in a campaign against the Camorra crime gang, officials said today.

title: NEW ESMARK OFFER CONVINCES NORTON
description: Esmark sweetened its bid for Norton Simon, the company accepted the offer and David Mahoney is getting richer. The price tag is about $34 a share, or $918 million, plus Esmark gets a ''right of first refusal'' to buy any of Norton Simon's companies for one year. This will probably discourage Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts and last week's newcomer - Anderson-Clayton - from pursuing their own takeover bids. As for Mr. Mahoney, right, his ''motivation all along has been to get the best deal for the shareholders,'' his spokesman said. And Mr. Mahoney is no small shareholder. His 718,513 shares will be worth some $25 million under the new deal - $3.5 million more than the value under his initial $29 a share offer. Moreover, his five-year, $9 million employment contract will be honored, even though he will probably leave the company after the acquisition.

title: Nancy Lynn Kruh Is Wed
description: Nancy Lynn Kruh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kruh of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert J. Meyer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer of Cincinnati.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: DURING the summer, most people find simple pleasures after a hard year's work - like sun, sand or backyard barbecues. For some New Jerseyans, however, the summer is a bit out of the ordinary.

title: Satellite Put in Its Place
description: It was a tossup whether luck or skill played the bigger role, but last week the National Aeronautics and Space Administration managed to put its $100 million data relay satellite where it should have been nearly three months ago.

title: Nina Lori Bogosian Wed to Matthew W. Quigley
description: Nina Lori Bogosian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nishan B. Bogosian of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew William Quigley, son of Amy Wing Quigley of Wilton, Conn., and the late Stephen Middleton Quigley. The ceremony was performed at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., by the Rev. Ronald P. Jaynes, assisted by Archpriest Moushegh Der Kaloustian of St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
FRESH, QUALITY VEGETABLES: YOUR OWN
description: GROWING one's own vegetables is very popular these days, and there are many reasons for doing it. For one thing, it is much handier to be able to step out into the back yard for a head of lettuce or a bunch of carrots than to drive to market. Freshly harvested vegetables are always tastier and more nutritious than those purchased, assuming that they are harvested while they are in peak condition. Certain varieties are preferred to others by some gardeners. One can be better assured of having these varieties by growing them oneself. Then there is always satisfaction that comes with growing at least a portion of one's own food.

title: A FINE NEW BALLET HONORS THE CLASSICAL TRADITION
description: One of the best new ballets of the season is Helgi Tomasson's beautiful and original ''Ballet d'Isoline'' and its importance for both the New York City Ballet and American ballet in general cannot be brushed aside.
