In this work, only the second he has created, Mr. Tomasson emerges as a potential major choreographer in the purely classical strain of which we may, unfortunately, see less in the immediate post-Balanchine era.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM COAST TO COAST: 13 SPECIAL SUMMERTIME OUTINGS
description: In this season of getaway excursions and long weekends - as well as longer vacations - 13 national correspondents of The New York Times suggest short trips into areas surrounding the cities in which they are based. Their recommended routes are designed for travelers wishing to make the most of a three- or four-day itinerary, and they stretch from Colonial inns and untrammeled beaches on the Atlantic to prairie towns and island havens in the Midwest and a fashionable enclave overlooking the Pacific.

title: 'Imprudent' Words on Dioxin
description: The American Medical Association tried a little fast footwork before Congress last week, but still seemed a bit out of step on the issue of dioxin contamination. ''We regret some of the imprudent language of our Missouri colleagues,'' an A.M.A. representative told a House subcommittee, referring to a recent resolution that accused the news outlets of ''hysterical malreporting'' and conducting a ''witch hunt'' on dioxin.

title: Miriam M. Landis Planning to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Wilder Landis Jr. of Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Manning Landis, to Frederick Howard Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bodine Babcock of New York and Millbrook, N.Y. A Sept. 17 wedding is planned in Sharon.

title: LEGAL GROUP HELPS THE ELDERLY
description: A SMALL group of Legal Aid attorneys in Willimantic is taking on the Federal Government on behalf of the poor and sick elderly, and saving the state money as a result.

title: Acaroid Wins United Nations
description: McKEE CITY, N.J., July 2 (AP) -Acaroid, a 14-to-1 choice, scored a half-length victory in the $150,000 United Nations Handicap on the turf at Atlantic City Race Course tonight.

title: Hoover As Translator
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 AFGHAN REFUGEES FREED IN BROOKLYN
description: Five of 46 aliens from Afghanistan who have been confined in a former Navy jail in Brooklyn for as long as 17 months have been released on parole under a revision in immigration policy.

title: ATTENDANCE, REVENUES UP AT PLAYLAND
description: DESPITE an often rainy spring, attendance and revenues have increased at Playland and Edward J. Kilcullen likes what he sees as summer fun and games begin in earnest this Fourth of July weekend.

title: Vizi Lange Is the Bride Of Charles W, Miles 3d
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Marie-Louise Virginia Anne Lange and Charles Williams Miles 3d, graduates of the University of Denver, were married by the Rev. Stephen F. Chinlund, assisted by the Rev. Robert N. Back.

title: ORIGINAL ALL-STAR RECALLS THE EARLY GAMES
description: WHAT I remember most about baseball's first All-Star Game on July 6, 1933, is that it wasn't the great social event that it is today. There were no special luncheons or awards to be given out to the player who got the most votes. The game had humble beginnings. Those of us on the American League team held a meeting at the Del Prado Hotel on Chicago's South Side on the day of the game, and Connie Mack, our manager, gave us the batting lineup and pitchers. Then we all got into various taxis and headed to Comiskey Park, just like we did with our own teams during the season.

title: Judith G. Silberner to Wed Haim Erder This August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Silberner of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Gail Silberner, to Haim Erder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Avram Erder of Bat Yam, Israel.

title: FINANCIAL SCREENING TOUGHENS
description: BUYING a cooperative apartment is unlike other housing purchases in t hat the would-be buyer must withstand an examination by a panel of s trangers who, if they approve his application, will be his new n eighbors. Buyers are now likely to encounter even stricter financials creening from their prospective co-op's board of directors than in t he past.

title: New Yorkers Impressive
description: It was safe to say that the basketball at the National Sports Festival was less than classic. But that does not mean it was less than exciting.

title: How Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from June 20 through June 26 with 1,365 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.

title: Miss Green, a Soprano, Marries Jack J. Frazier
description: Constance E. Green, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Green of Rock Island, Ill., and Jack J. Frazier, son of Joseph F. Frazier of Kinnelon, N.J., and the late Georgina M. Frazier, were married yesterday. The Rev. Raymond Harrison performed a Protestant ceremony at the Alpine (N.J.) Community Church.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BAN SHOCKS BOXING TRAINER
description: Banned from boxing for life, Carlos (Panama) Lewis refuses to believe his career is ended just when it was reaching its peak. ''I've got to get my head straightened out,'' said Lewis in a telephone interview from his Brooklyn home after the New York State Athletic Commission ''permanently and immediately'' revoked his licenses as manager and trainer, a revocation that Lewis conceded would be honored by commissions in other states.

title: TIRELESS SUSHI CHEF, FEARLESS LUMBERJACK
description: Some improvement is in sight, however. Sales are expected to strengthen as the economic recovery, which is just beginning here, picks up steam and customers start spending again. Analysts predict that the Japanese robot industry will grow by more than 30 percent this year to more than $775 million as measured by production value.

title: A Safe Ladder?
description: To the Business Editor: With respect to Murray Weidenbaum's attack on the United Nations' proposed consumer guidelines (''The U.N.'s Bid to Play Consumer Cop,'' June 26), I can't help thinking he has overstated his position in his eagerness to paint the whole concept of consumer protection as a form of totalitarianism. Take those poor families he says will have to use chairs and tables because they can't afford a safe ladder and business isn't allowed to sell them a cheaper, unsafe one.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR JONES BEACH
description: JUST a few steps from the boardwalk, behind two sets of heavy doors that unlock with electronic buzzers, is a large office with a chart on the wall. Stuck into the chart's glossy white face are colored pushpins and tags, which give the chart the same kind of graphic precision as the maps that generals use in military campaigns.

title: PLEASE USE THE POSTCODE
description: 1930's, the New York Yankee pitcher Vernon (Lefty) Gomez earned himself the reputation as the coolest man in Yankee pinstripes for pausing on the pitching mound and staring at an airplane flying overhead. They don't call Martina Navratilova Lefty, but yesterday she paused in the middle of the final at Wimbledon so she could stare at a modest one-engine plane pulling a banner over the sacred air space of the All England Lawn Tennis Club. Not only did she stare, but she also did an eloquent double take worthy of a Lily Tomlin or a Johnny Carson as the message sunk in.

title: Shira Dicker Planning Wedding in September
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry I. Dicker of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shira Roni Dicker, to Ari Lionel Goldman, son of Marvin Goldman of Hartford and Mrs. Jacob E. Goldman of Westport, Conn. The wedding is to be in September.

title: 'INFRASTRUCTURE' MEANS LIFE AND DEATH; JERSEY SEEKS KEY TO MORE FUNDS
description: TWICE, Governor Kean has set out to reverse years of not-so-benign neglect and find the funds to repair the state's highways and bridges. Twice, he has been detoured by the Legislature.

title: 37 Are Hurt as Roof Collapses
description: The roof of a discount store collapsed in a heavy thunderstorm tonight, injuring at least 37 people, the authorities said.

title: THey Stand Miscorrected
description: The printed record of Congressional testimony often makes politicians look bad enough, but now somebody evidently has decided to make them look worse. Last week the House of Representatives, responding to complaints by Republicans that committee reports had been tampered with, directed its ethics committee to look into the rewriting.

title: LEWIS RELIES ON FITNESS IN FINAL
description: In the long and grueling two weeks of Wimbledon, Chris Lewis has learned to value the last few months of rigid tennis drills. The 26-year-old from New Zealand has advanced to Sunday's final with John McEnroe on the strength of his conditioning.

title: A BRIDGE FALLS, AND CONCERNS RISE
description: HARTFORD THE sudden collapse of a section of I-95 over the Mianus River in Greenwich early last Tuesday will have far-reaching - and costly - effects across Connecticut, according to state officials. As state and Federal agencies investigated the cause of the bridge collapse, which killed three people and critically injured three others, the state began round-the-clock work to try to temporarily repair the broken link in the highway, also known as the Connecticut Turnpike, within two weeks.

title: Suzanne Schwind To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Suzanne Kirkwood Schwind to Andrew Henry Barada has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edmond Moran of New Canaan, Conn., and North Palm Beach, Fla., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Silvestre Barada 3d of New Canaan and Nantucket, Mass.

title: CAPITALIST'S GUIDE TO BERIOZKAS
description: Inexpensive carved bone brooches in a delightful variety of animal and flower motifs could be bought by the handful last March in the Soviet Union. By April, the pins had vanished. Instead a profusion of nested metal ashtrays bristling like hedgehogs spilled over the shelves of the Beriozka stores, the state-run shops to which only foreign tourists with hard currency have access.

title: Trade Policy
description: To the Business Editor: As President of the National Association of Export Companies, I endorse Secretary Baldrige's call for a Department of International Trade and Industry (''At Last, Hope for Coherent Policy,'' June 19). I strongly concur with the Secretary's advocacy primarily because of anticipated benefits to our nation's industrial productivity.

title: Hayes of U.S. Winner In 200-Meter Freestyle
description: Bruce Hayes surprised himself, his coach and the world today by winning the gold medal in the 200-meter freestyle swim in record time during XII World University Games.

title: Cherokee Bingo Session Attracts Thousands
description: Nearly 2,400 people, paying $500 each, jammed into a factory today in this remote Indian reservation town to play in what was billed as the world's biggest bingo session.

title: FOREIGN TRADE BECOMES A LOCAL ISSUE
description: The legend of the Yankee trader, the ingenious New England merchant plying the routes of the world, has faded with time, but selling abroad has never been more important to the nation's economy or politics.

title: WHAT EVEN MORTALS MAY DRINK
description: AS BUDS APPEAR IN THE vineyards, the wine dinner season is already in full flower. Night after night, week in, week out, the hotels and restaurants open their doors to yet another battalion of wine lovers, eager to honor the grape and, of course, each other.

title: Blanche Baker Plans October Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Carroll Baker of London and Jack Garfein of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Blanche Baker, to Bruce vanDusen of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips vanDusen of Princeton, N.J.

title: Suzan Greenleaf Hurd Marries John Greenup
description: Suzan Greenleaf Hurd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hurd of Milton, Mass., was married yesterday to John Elmore Greenup, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harold Wilson Greenup of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Robert B. Appleyard Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Milton.

title: FAIR'S FINAL DAYS
description: Caroline Doctorow and her country rock band, Michael McCreesh & Company, the Dixie Dandies, Shinbone Alley, New Rochelle Civic Theater and Trio Chanticlaire are a sampling of the entertainment to be seen and heard today and tomorrow, final days of the annual fourday Ward Acres Country Fair in New Rochelle.

title: Condominium Rent Rules
description: Question: I am buying a condominium apartment in a building that has a noneviction plan. The apartment, which was once under rentstabilization regulations, is vacant and I plan to rent it out. May I charge market rates, or would I come under rent-stabilization guidelines? ... F.S.M., Manhattan Answer: You may charge market rates. Rent stabilization is applicable in a cooperative or condominium apartment, a spokesman for the State Attorney General says, only if it is occupied by a tenant who had been renting it before the building was converted.

title: HELP WANTED, MALE: GIRL SCOUT LEADERS
description: MILLTOWN LOUIS SILVESTRI had a pleasant surprise the other day. Another father in this Middlesex County community volunteered to be a Girl Scout leader and that, he said, means he will not be alone any more.

title: Trains
description: To the Editor: In one of the articles entitled ''All Aboard: Three Great Trains'' (Travel, May 8), Joseph Lelyveld incorrectly refers to the track on which the Blue Train runs as wide gauge.

title: Insanity Defense Is No Easy Out
description: A defendant who successfully pleads not guilty by reason of insanity had better be prepared for a long haul on the mental ward. The Supreme Court ruled last week that reaching the end of a prison sentence has no connection to getting released from a hospital.

title: Sports, Science and Sharks
description: BAY SHORE, L.I. Inert and flaccid on a dock, its skin dried and wrinkled by the sun, a shark loses the almost spectral quality it possesses in water. Alive in its milieu, it is utter grace and undulating power, an ancient creature with a boneless skeleton seeming to flow rather than swim.

title: THE KISSINGER ANTIMEMOIRS
description: THE PRICE OF POWER Kissinger in the Nixon White House. By Seymour M. Hersh. 698 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: Lucinda Herrick, Analyst at Bank, To Marry in Fall
description: Daniel K. Herrick of New York and Edith B. Herrick of Princeton, N.J., and Browington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucinda Jackson Herrick, to J.A. Gunther Strothe, son of Franz Strothe of Erkelenz-Holzweiler, West Germany, and the late Mrs. Strothe.

title: Barbara J. Asch Plans Late August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules T. Asch of @Jamesburg, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jane Asch, to Jonathan Geoffrey Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton J. Weiss of Skillman, N.J. A late August wedding is planned.

title: KEY WITNESS ENDS TESTIMONY IN BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A key witness has completed his testimony in the Brink's trial after several days of cross-examination that included some bitter questions portraying him as a ''traitor.''

title: PLAYERS SPOILED, SURVEY FINDS
description: Tennis players who act up on the court are behaving more like spoiled brats than intense competitors, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: NEW LAW IMPERILS PRISON ROAD SIGN INDUSTRY
description: Prison officials in New Jersey and 37 other states are worried about losing their share of an industry that brings in $19 million a year - the making of highway road signs by inmates, according to a State Corrections Department spokesman.

title: Player Is Suspended For Clubbing Heckler
description: Barbaro Garbey of the Evansville Triplets has been suspended for an indefinite period by the National Association of Professional Baseball Clubs.

title: AU POINT, $17, TAKES DWYER AT BELMONT
description: After the first nine furlongs of the Belmont Stakes, Au Point was leading the best 3-year-olds in the country. He had to run another three furlongs that day, however, was bounced around between Caveat and Slew o' Gold at the top of the stretch, and tired badly to finish 10th behind those two colts.

title: PROGRAM HELPING CITY YOUTHS TO GET JOBS
description: Raymond Alston, a slim, soft-voiced 17-year-old, returned from the Virgin Islands last year to his former home in the Bronx. He said he had done well in school in St. Croix but was told here that he would have to enter the 9th grade instead of the 11th. This setback, he said, prompted him to quit school last spring.

title: Michal Keeley and Jon Frank to Marry
description: Michal Mathilde Keeley and Jon Abner Frank plan to be married Aug.6 in Bethesda, Md. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Keeley of Harare, Zimbabwe, and Washington.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: AMEASURE that environmentalists said was among the most important to come before the Legislature so far in the 1980's received final approval by the Assembly last week, over the objections of New Jersey's powerful business and industry lobby.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Fun Things To Do With Fiber

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Reviving Sheer Fun ''Light, machine-gun paced. Nothing too heavy. Just entertainment for the folks. Not anything topical or satirical.'' That's Chris Bearde's description of a summer-replacement series ''The 1/2 Hour Comedy Hour,'' for which he and Dick Clark serve as executive producers. It will be broadcast Tuesday evening from 8 to 8:30 on ABC. Thom Sharp and Arsenio Hall, two of eight comedians in the resident-company lineup, are the hosts. Burt Reynolds, Joan Collins and Henny Youngman will make ''special appearances'' on the premiere.

title: HABIB FLIES TO BEIRUT AGAIN FOR PULLOUT TALKS
description: Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy for the Middle East, returned here from Israel today and met with Foreign Minister Elie Salem on Israel's latest position in troop withdrawal talks.

title: VATICAN WARNS MALTA ON SEIZING CHURCH PROPERTY
description: The Vatican has warned in unusually grave language that ''religious peace'' in Malta will be affected by Government seizure of most Roman Catholic Church property there.

title: Amy Kasimer to Marry William Scher in 1984
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eli H. Kasimer of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Ruth Kasimer, to William G. Scher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Scher of Great Neck, L.I., and Copake, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: Miss Fields Plans to Wed Jeffrey Wolfson in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nat Fields of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Frances Fields, to Jeffrey Shane Wolfson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Wolfson of Cincinnati.

title: JAYS RALLY TO DOWN MARINERS
description: Barry Bonnell singled with two out in the ninth inning to drive in Lloyd Moseby with the winning run as the Toronto Blue Jays overcame a six-run deficit to beat the Seattle Mariners, 7-6, today.

title: Apartheid Resolution Rejected at Columbia
description: The trustees of Columbia University have voted against selling all the school's stock in companies doing business in South Africa. ''Total divestment,'' the trustees said in a statement last week, ''would contribute little, if anything, to the elimination of apartheid and, indeed, might prove to be counterproductive to this goal and injurious to the university.''

title: The Talk of Lawrence County
description: The Rev. William Kirkland had a .30-.30 rifle sitting just inside his front door, a .243-caliber Browning rifle inside the back door and a shotgun under his bed. He wears a .38-caliber

title: IT'S AS EASY AS PAINTING WITH A ROLLER IF YOU DO IT RIGHT
description: MOST do-it-yourselfers have discovered that putting paint on with a roller is a lot faster and easier than putting it on with a brush when large, comparatively flat surfaces are involved. However, many still do not realize that while the roller has long since been accepted as the ''standard'' painting tool for interior walls and ceilings, it is equally useful for many exterior surfaces. And, with the right type of cover, rollers can also be used to speed up the job of painting rough or textured surfaces.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FLASHBACKS By Timothy Leary. Illustrated. 397 pp. Los Angeles: J.P. Tarcher/Distributed by Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title: BY BARRY LAINE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance.

title: GARDEN CREATED FOR DEAF-BLIND
description: THREE years ago, Alvina Wiles suggested to her Sands Point Garden Club that it honor the 100th birthday anniversary of Helen Keller with a garden where, through the senses of touch and smell, deaf and blind people might enjoy and learn from plants with various textures and fragrances.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics National Sports Festival at Colorado Springs. Third day of track and field competition, including a marathon. (Television - Channel 7, 4:45 P.M.). World University Games at Edmonton, Alberta, second full day of competition involving more than 5,000 athletes from 97 countries in 10 sports. The games run through July 12. Friday's opening ceremonies and focus on swimming, diving, men's gymnastics and basketball will be shown. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.).

title: A LANDSCAPIST AND MUCH MORE; BOSTON
description: Those who question the persuasive efficacy of photographs should pause to consider the legacy of Carleton E. Watkins, whose 1861 views of Yosemite Valley helped convince Congress to pass legislation insuring its preservation. Watkins's pictures of Yosemite were not the first to be made there - that honor belongs to C.L. Weed, who photographed the valley in 1859 - but they were certainly the most awe-inspiring, having been made with a mammoth camera that produced 18-by-22-inch glass plate negatives. Besides shaping the contemporary conception of what Western terrain looked like, they have served as models of sublimity for landscape photographers ever since, from Eadweard Muybridge to Ansel Adams.

title: A TURN IN THE MARKET FOR NEW APARTMENTS
description: INCOME apartment shoppers in Manhattan are wending their way these days through the largest i nventory of newly constructed condominium and cooperative apartmentse ver offered in the city.

title: Australia II Captures Two Races
description: Australia II continued its success among the foreign challengers in the America's Cup elimination races today with two victories at the start of the July series.

title: MEMORIES OF HOLIDAY FIRECRACKERS
description: WHEN I was a child in White Plains in the 1920's, the Fourth of July ranked right behind Christmas on my excitement roster. The holidays had points of similarity: both were preceded by almost unbearable anticipation, and ended with rituals that were just as satisfying as you expected. Looking back, though, I'm aware of a tinge of amazement along with nostagia.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Still Growing Up

title: Urbino
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's article on ''Ageless Urbino'' (Travel, May 8) was of special interest to me since I spent a summer in this beautiful city studying Italian with Rutgers-Fairfield Universities. In addition to bus service from Rome, Urbino may be reached by bus or train from the Adriatic resort of Pesaro (Rossini's birthplace), a train stop on the Milan-Bari line. WILLIAM FIORELLI Staten Island

title: NEW HORIZONS IN SPAIN; COLORADO OPERA FETE
description: One summer late (but solvent), Colorado's Central Opera House Association is celebrating its 50th Anniversayry Festival now through Aug. 6. Last year, association directors canceled the annual summer opera program to devote their time to eliminating the organization's debts of $640,000 and to raising funds for future productions.

title: Koch Nominates Four For Posts on the Bench
description: Mayor Koch has nominated three people to be Criminal Court judges and one person to be a Civil Court judge, his Committee on the Judiciary has announced.

title: CLSFIED RDR FINDS THRILLS
description: IAM addicted. I had no idea this was happening to me until one day w hen I had the urge I could not suppress it. But it is out of hand n ow.

title: RENAISSANCE CENTER: FORD'S COSTLY AND FAILING BID TO REVIVE DETROIT
description: DETROIT HENRY FORD 2d has driven through downtown Detroit almost every day since he became vice president of the family automobile company in 1943. That's when he began commuting from his home in Grosse Point, a suburb east of the city, to Ford Motor Company headquarters in Dearborn, 11 miles west of it.

title: FOUNDATION LEADERS PRESS FOR CHANGES IN TAX LAW
description: Foundation leaders have defended their record of charitable giving before a Congressional subcommittee and pleaded for changes in Federal tax laws that they argued have impeded philanthropy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doyle Alexander, released on June 1 by the Yankees after winning only one game for them in a season and a quarter, has replaced Mike Morgan, also a right-handed pitcher, on the Toronto Blue Jays' roster. Toronto signed the 32-year-old Alexander on a conditional basis June 21, making the Blue Jays the seventh team he has pitched for.

title: A NEW MALL
description: In its fashionable days before World War II, Long Beach, L.I., was a goal for vactioners seeking gleaming beaches and opulent seaside hotels. When a decline set in after the war, many of the hotels became homes for the aged and the downtown area was blighted by abandoned stores and homes.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: OUR nation's first Independence Day expressed the national yearning to be free of obtrusive outside influence. As time went on, Independence Day has come to symbolize, for many Long Islanders, the start of a summer season of occupation by outsiders who settle on choice parts of our island domain and proceed to soak up our sun and soak in our water. They are not war-making redcoats, but they are occupiers in battalions of city folk who clog highways, crowd beaches and lay waste to the countryside while stimulating its economy.

title: CUBS TOP EXPOS, WIN 5TH STRAIGHT
description: Jody Davis hit his 13th homer of the season and Warren Brusstar pitched four strong innings in relief today as the Chicago earned its fifth straight victory.

title: Boat Racer Seeks 7th in Row
description: Tony Garcia, the first offshore powerboat driver to win six consecutive races, will try to extend his record in the New Jersey Offshore Grand Prix.

title: DOGS AND CHILDREN SEEM A LOT ALIKE
description: ''WHO wants to go out with Mommy?'' Footsteps scurry above and there is a wild rush down the stairs follows - the treat might be a ride to the supermarket or a fast game of catch in the backyard.

title: LED DU PONT IN MAJOR GROWTH
description: Lammot du Pont Copeland Sr., former chairman and chief executive officer of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the world's largest chemical concern, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Mount Cuba, Del. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW PARK TO BE DEDICATED AT HISTORIC SITE IN DOBBS FERRY
description: WILLOW trees were once plentiful along the bank of the Hudson across from the Dobbs Ferry railroad station. But in recent years only one from the original grove remained in the area known as Willow Point, home, at various times during the village's history, to a coal yard, a seaplane base, a lumberyard and, most recently, unsightly debris. Tomorrow, if the weather cooperates, it will be dedicated as Dobbs Ferry's newest park.

title:
THE FREE MARKET AND CHILE;
AN ABORTED ECONOMIC TEST
description: THE much-acclaimed ''free market experiment'' in Chile is now being p ronounced a failure. The damning evidence is a two-year-old d epression, which has finally brought hundreds of thousands of C hileans into the streets, protesting the 10-year-old military rule o f President Augusto Pinochet.

title: Pirard Wins Tour Leg
description: Frits Pirard of the Netherlands led a sprint to the finish and won the first leg of the Tour de France bicycle race today. The 99-mile leg went through the Paris suburbs from Nogent-sur-Marne to Creteil.

title:
THE NEW WAVE OF PUERTO RICAN IMMIGRANTS;
Howard Bray is a freelance writer in Washington.
description: LILLIAN SANTIAGO LEANED against the the grimy elevated platform in Long Island City as she awaited the subway to Manhattan. Feeling cheerless, she comforted herself for a moment by telling a new-found friend about the endless summer of her native Puerto Rico. Then the El arrived, as packed as always, and with it an end to her reverie and the start of another grueling day of job-hunting. A year ago, the slender, 27-year-old woman with two university degrees was a supervisor of social services for children and the elderly in San Juan. Then the island government -doubly battered by depression and deep cuts in Federal aid - fired thousands of public employees, Miss Santiago among them. Unable to find another comparable job, she gave up her apartment near the sea and headed north. And to stretch her savings after weeks without work, she took a part-time job as a clerk in a midtown variety store, receiving $3.35 an hour. Her self-esteem was at a low ebb until, months later, she found a public-school post as a bilingual teacher. ''It's better to live in your own country,'' she says. ''It's hard to be here.''

title: BY SAM H. SHIRAKAWA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sam H. Shirakawa writes frequently on the performing arts.

title: Horse Show Title To Miss Monahan
description: Katie Monahan of Upperville, Va., rode Jethro and Noren to first and second place today in the $10,000 jumper classic, the final event of the annual Lake Place horse show.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aminoil USA Inc., Houston, has appointed Roger L. Billings vice president-Eastern region; William L. Donnelly vice presidentproduction, and Theodore W. Ehring vice president-Western region.

title: Judgment for Decency
description: Three years ago the Supreme Court upheld a life sentence for a Texas man whose three convictions -for frauds that enriched him by $229 - earned him the status of habitual offender. It said the Constitution's deference to state powers in matters of penology required Federal acquiescence in any punishment unless ''cruel and unusual'' and thus barred by the Eighth Amendment. What might be cruel and unusual? Well, maybe life imprisonment for parking overtime.

title: THE CIVIL WAR'S LURE
description: Our Civil War won't go away. It is an old-fashioned bit of history that you would have thought we would have put in the attic long ago. But somehow we can't. It has a tug on our imaginations, even our affections, that we continue to feel. We can't let it go away.

title: Meeting Set In Caribbean
description: OF-SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago, July 3 (Reuters) -Heads of state from 12 English-speaking nations in the Caribbean Community, or Caricom, start a three-day meeting here Monday to discuss ways of combating the effects of recession and of accelerating economic integration.

title: Egyptian Opposition Leaders Plan a Boycott of Elections
description: Egypt's three opposition parties said today that they would boycott local elections set for November because President Hosni Mubarak had decided to hold them under an absolute majority system.

title: FLORIO PREPARING NEW GUBERNATORIAL BID
description: In the dining room at the world headquarters of the American Cyanamid Company, overlooking the wooded hills around Wayne, Representative James J. Florio dined the other evening with a small group of top executives and chatted about politics and economics.

title: WOMEN ON THE SIDE OF VICTIMS OF BRUTALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ASSAILS U.N. TRADE STATEMENT
description: A United Nations trade conference ended today with the United States disassociating itself from a final statement on world economic problems.

title: CASEY MADE CALL ON CARTER PAPERS
description: William J. Casey, the chairman of Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign, has apparently sought to refresh his memory about Carter White House briefing papers supplied to the Reagan campaign with a telephone call to a one-time aide of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Phillies at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. Walt Terrell is scheduled to start against Steve Carlton. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Dave Righetti is expected to oppose John Tudor. (Television - Sports@Channel, 2 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 2 P.M. California Angels vs. Kansas City Royals at Anaheim, Calif. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.).

title: GENERALS LOSE IN FINALE, 34-10
description: The long 18-week season ended for the New Jersey Generals today, and their last performance was one of their poorest. They lost to the Boston Breakers, 34-10, at Nickerson Field, with Boston scoring all its points in a 35 1/2-minute span in which the Generals scored none.

title: MUSIC DAY IN STADIUM IS A PICNIC
description: Lukie McClelland left home in Cockeysville, Md., at 3 A.M. with his Confederate flag flying on his Chevy van. He got lost somewhere in New York City, he said, but by 11 A.M. he and his friends were camped out in the Giants Stadium parking lot waiting for the music to begin.

title: MONDAY, JULY 4, 1983
description: International A rallying speech to Afhgan refugees in Pakistan was delivered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He told about 4,000 refugees in the Nasir Bagh camp in Peshawar: ''Fellow fighters for freedom, we are with you.'' Mr. Shultz went to the camp before flying to Saudi Arabia to begin a visit through the Middle East to discuss the possibility of the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon. Page 1, Column 6.) Syria remains inflexible in its opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord, according to senior Syrian officials and Western diplomats in Damascus. Syria is expected to tell Secretary of State Shultz on his forthcoming Middle East visit that it will refuse to participate in negotiations concerning the withdrawal of its troops from Lebanon as long as Beirut adheres to the American-sponsored withdrawal agreement. (3:1.)

title: A Big Inning for Rangers
description: The Texas Rangers set a majorleague record for most runs in an extra inning when they scored 12 times in the 15th tonight in a 16-4 triumph over the Oakland A's.

title: ON A BUSY FLIGHT DECK, FEW THOUGHTS OF THE HEAT
description: The black sedan pulled up to the end of Pier 86, its trunk stuffed with gleaming cargo. A pallet was lowered from Hangar Bay 3. The driver piled several dozen bags on the wooden platform. He watched intently as the irreplaceable load was hoisted aboard the aircraft carrier.

title: Another Polish First
description: The Pope's dramatic visit to Poland and the enigmatic eclipse of Solidarity leader Lech Walesa have obscured more important, gradual developments.

title: COMPUTERS AS A LEARNING TOOL
description: What happens to the ability of children to learn and reason when they are taught to use a computer, when they master the language it requires, when their labor is accomplished with methods that are a bold departure from paper and pen?

title: Harold J. Kalikow Dead at 73; Chairman of Realty Company
description: Harold J. Kalikow, chairman of the board of H.J. Kalikow & Company and the Kalikow Construction Company, real estate developers in New York City, died Saturday at New York Hospital following a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MOURNING FRIENDS REMEMBER ARTIST'S TALENT AND LOVE FOR SON
description: Last Thursday night, Jamie Summers, a SoHo artist, set off on a bicycle ride with a friend. They had planned to ride from Miss Summers' apartment to Central Park. But on Waverly Place, as they prepared to cross the Avenue of the Americas, Miss Summers fell under the wheels of a sanitation truck and was killed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pyrotechnic Preparations

title: SWIFT HIGHWAY JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTISAN DISPUTE BLOCKS BUDGET IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Pennsylvania has entered the holiday weekend facing the prospect of fiscal paralysis, with more than 50,000 welfare checks that it cannot legally mail stacked in the treasurer's office.

title: BILLY BANG AND THE GANG
description: Billy Bang and the Gang reveled in the sounds of strings - plucked and bowed, blended and independent - at Soundscape's jazz festival program Saturday. Mr. Bang, New York's finest jazz violinist, led a four-piece version of his String Ensemble.

title: BELMONT FEATURE TO MARE
description: Belmont Park has seemed downright European on recent weekends and not because of the charm of the place or the manners of its customers. In Europe, fillies and mares run and win consistently against males. Now, that seems to be happening in big races at Belmont.

title: RIVERA AND SALSA REFUGEES
description: Jazz and Latin music enjoyed a close embrace in Friday's jazz festival set at Soundscape by the Dominican saxophonist Mario Rivera and his Salsa Refugees. The nine-piece group came across as two bands in one.

title: WOMEN ON THE SIDE OF VICTIMS OF BRUTALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Flee Illinois Prison
description: Four prisoners escaped from the Menard Correctional Center by sawing through the bars on a window last night, prison officials said. One prisoner was recaptured shortly afterward.

title: A VILLAGE'S FAITH IS REWARDED
description: AU-PIRE, France, July 3 - Nearly a year late, The tour de France arrived today in this village of 1,217 inhabitants, fulfilling Fontaine-au-Pire's dream of becoming the smallest community to be host to the world's premier bicycle endurance race.

title: Hi-Shear's Chief Adding Raymark Chairman Post
description: David A. Wingate, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Hi-Shear Industries, has been named to the additional post of chairman of the Raymark Corporation, a maker of industrial abrasives and automotive parts in which Hi-Shear holds a 30.6 percent interest.

title: APPEALS JUDGES BACK DISMISSAL OF SUIT ON SHAH
description: An appeals court has ruled that the Government of Iran may not bring a $56.5 billion lawsuit against the estate of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his widow in New York State's courts.

title: Books of The Times
description: LOOK AT ME. By Anita Brookner. 192 pages. Pantheon. $11.95. ALICE IN BED. By Cathleen Schine. 228 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Seattle Retailer Named Thousand Trails Officer
description: Jerry Horn, a retailer and until last Friday part owner of the Seattle Sounders soccer team, has been named president and chief operating officer of Thousand Trails Inc., a campground operator based in Seattle. He succeeds C. James Jensen, chief executive, who had previously held the titles of both chairman and president.

title: Playground Fantasy
description: You crash against Tom Heinsohn in a desperate battle for the rebound and come down with the ball. Tom Sanders tries to block your shot but it clears the rim.

title: YOUNG DAREDEVILS FLOCKING TO BICYCLE TRACKS
description: Clay Bernabeo is obsessed with racing. He races every Saturday and Sunday and at least three nights during the rest of the week.

title: CHARLIE HADEN'S BAND PLAYS LIBERATION MUSIC
description: Last year, the bassist Charlie Haden reassembled the Liberation Music Orchestra, a group he originally put together in the late 1960's to record music from the Spanish Civil War and from more recent revolutionary struggles. Using many original members of the group and associates from his early days with Ornette Coleman, Mr. Haden presented his revived orchestra at the Public Theater last fall.

title: JAPAN: LAND OF LAW GRADUATES, IF NOT LAWYERS...
description: To the Editor:

title: Dixon Wins 10,000-Meter Run
description: Thankful for every opened fire hydrant and water hose along the way, Rod Dixon, a three-time Olympian from New Zealand, finished ahead of 4,200 other runners to win his second consecutive Pepsi Challenge 10,000-meter National Championship yesterday. Anne Audain, 27 years old, also of New Zealand, won the women's division. For both her and Dixon, the heat and humidity supplied the severest test.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a gathering in the name of freedom, a gathering in the name of self-determination, a gathering in the name of getting Soviet forces out of Afghanistan, a gathering in the name of a sovereign Afghanistan controlled by its own people.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (1:6.)

title: SMITH AND MISS ASHFORD SET WORLD RECORDS IN 100
description: In a span of 15 minutes, 22-year-old Calvin Smith of Bolton, Miss., and 26-year-old Evelyn Ashford broke the world records today in the 100-meter dashes.

title: BALLET THEATER: RADOJEVIC IN 'PUSH'
description: American Ballet Theater tripped the light fantastic Saturday afternoon, when two charming and choreographically eccentric ballets were on the bill at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: EXPERTS FAVOR YOUNT
description: Some of the best baseball talent scouts and experts agree with the major league players' opinion that Steve Carlton is the dominant pitcher in the big leagues. But they lean toward Robin Yount as the best player, ahead of Andre Dawson, and believe that Ralph Houk probably matches Whitey Herzog as the best manager.

title: Miss Stacy Winner
description: Hollis Stacy shot a finalround 68 today and won the $250,000 Peter Jackson Classic by two strokes.

title: Libya and Morocco Say They're Ending Long Rift
description: After being at odds for more than a decade, Libya and Morocco affirmed their determination today to put an end to their disputes and establish ''fraternal relations.''

title: THERAPISTS' DECOR: DO THE PATIENTS COUNT?
description: The patient settled back on the analyst's couch and began to free associate. ''My mother,'' she said. ''Lying on this couch reminds me of my mother. She used to put plastic covers on the living room furniture, and I hated that, and I hate lying on a couch with strips of plastic under my head and my feet. Why do you put plastic on the couch?''

title: AMERICA HASN'T RUN OUT OF HEROES
description: Too frequently, I hear the complaint that America has run out of heroes. I think the Fourth of July is a good time to reflect on whether that is an accurate observation.

title: And the Colonies Dwindle
description: For most Americans, colonialism ended with the great Declaration signed with defiant optimism 207 years ago today. But American colonialism is still alive and well - if generally forgotten - on 2,000 Micronesian islands strewn over 3 million square miles of the Pacific. It hasn't been a brilliant chapter. So there's the more reason to welcome the news that this embarrassing affair is finally ending.

title: 2 Million Elderly Chinese Replaced in Bureaucracy
description: Nearly two million elderly officials have been replaced at the national and provincial levels, with a major purge set for later this year, Peking Review said today.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook Requiem for At-Large

title: Reggie Jackson Lost to All-Stars
description: Reggie Jackson said today that badly bruised ribs would keep him out of the All-Star Game Wednesday in Chicago.

title: Report Calls for U.S. Pressure On Pakistan to Grant Rights
description: Two American legal groups are urging the Reagan Administration ''to exert pressure'' on Pakistan for the restoration of civil rights in that country.

title: Teachers at Lincoln Center
description: The Lincoln Center Institute's summer session, which is intended to give high-school teachers a better understanding of the arts, begins tomorrow at the Juilliard School.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pennsylvania to the Rescue

title: VICTORIES IN FEDERAL FIGHT AGAINST NARCOTICS HAVE BEEN SHORT-LIVED
description: Federal efforts to reduce trafficking in narcotics in the United States have never achieved lasting or widespread success, though several Administrations have taken up the banner.

title: Sweet Bird Of Baseball
description: HE landed at baseball's center stage in 1976 as if he were a Bird from another planet. Mark Fidrych was different. He talked to the ball before he pitched. He smoothed the dirt on the mound before each inning. In his gawky stride, he shook hands with his fielders after a good play. In his curly hairdo, he resembled a rock star more than a ballplayer, a Bird for his time. As a 21-year-old rookie righthander with the Detroit Tigers, he had a 19-9 record and led the American League with a 2.34 earned run average. He led the world in enthusiasm.

title: Concert: Mal-Sun Pak Sings Korean Music
description: The soprano Mal-Sun Pak, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, was at her best in some contemporary Korean material by Dong-Jin Kim, Sang-Gun Lee and Dae-Ung Ha, to which her direct manner and cultivated musicianship were admirably suited.

title: MALAWI'S ELITE ACADEMY: THE VERY MODEL OF ETON
description: The dirt road twists and turns through okra and arid bush, fringed with villages where wolen pound corn in large wooden mortars and the children are thin and ragged.

title: WRONG WAY TO CATCH INTOXICATED DRIVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUANS REPORTED CAPTURED
description: Nicaraguan rebels captured 37 Government soldiers amid heav? fighting for control of a southern Nicaraguan town on Saturday and turned them over to Costa Rican authorities, a rebel spokesman said today.

title: Nixon Son-in-Law Leaves Fuels Corp.
description: Edward F. Cox planned to stay no more than ''a short while'' - a year or so - when he joined the Synthetic Fuels Corporation in 1981. When he announced his resignation last week as the corporation's vice president, general counsel and corporate secretary, he had stayed more than two.

title: Aileen Bloom Becomes the Bride of Paul Lindner
description: At Temple Beth El in Stamford, Conn., yesterday, Aileen Debra Bloom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Bloom of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Paul Scott Lindner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lindner of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony.

title: Brazilian Trade Surplus
description: Brazil's trade surplus in June should be between $600 million and $700 million compared with $671 million in May, according to figures released by the planning ministry.

title: NUN SEES A 'BIG TRUTH' IN NICARAGUA
description: ''I've gotten to hate so much the lies on both sides, the distortions from both sides, so I concentrate on my work,'' said Lisa Fitzgerald, a nun in street clothing who has come back to bear witness to Congress about the war in Nicaragua.

title: Zaire Sends Commandos To Fight for Chad
description: Zaire sent three fighter aircraft and 250 para-commandos today to fight beside Chadian Government forces against Libyan-backed rebels in northern Chad, officials said.

title: A Marathon Wait
description: After 2,333 years, the marble pillar erected to the memory of an original Marathon Man is going to get a permanent home this autumn. The 1,850-pound marble stele will be placed in the rotunda area of City College's new North Academic Center, after having been crated in the basement of the college's School of Engineering and ignored for many years.

title: A.M.C. Car Prices
description: The American Motors Corporation announced that prices for its new 1984 Renault Encore hatchback tentatively will start at $5,755, while prices of the Renault Alliance will rise an average 2.9 percent from 1983 levels, to start at $5,959.

title: APPROVAL SOUGHT FOR JERUSALEM GATE
description: For the last four years, the 49-year-old Israeli-born artist Gyora Novak has been working to realize his dream of building a modern gate to Jerusalem, a gate 25 stories high that could mark the approach to a city he describes as ''the one place on earth that is a part of everybody.''

title: Storm Collapses Roof, Injuring 52 Shoppers
description: Water dumped by a heavy thunderstorm may have caused the flat roof of a discount department store to collapse, injuring 52 holiday shoppers and trapping 20 of them for a short while, officials said today.

title: Examination For Martin
description: Billy Martin will undergo an examination and possibly rectal surgery tomorrow. The Yankees' manager said yesterday he would check into a hospital, which he declined to identify, after the game today against the Red Sox.

title: Miss Boatwright Weds Rev.Timothy Mulder
description: Cynthia Blakely Boatwright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Purvis James Boatwright Jr. of Gladstone, N.J., was married at St. Luke's Episcopal Church there yesterday to the Rev. Timothy John Mulder, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Mulder of Holland, Mich. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, who is senior pastor of Christ Memorial Reformed Church in Holland, assisted by the Rev. George Kyle of St. Luke's.

title: HARVARD FRESHMEN TRIUMPH AT HENLEY
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 3 - Harvard's freshman heavyweight crew gave the American spectators at the 134th Henley Royal Regatta a chance to cheer today by winning the final of the Ladies' Challenge Plate in convincing fashion.

title: ARGENTINES STAGE A PROTEST MARCH
description: Tens of thousands of young Argentines marched through the capital on Saturday to denounce the military Government and underscore their demand for a return to civilian rule.

title: HEROIN CHASE MIXES FRUSTRATION WITH SUCCESS
description: Just before Christmas in 1977, a suitcase unloaded from an Alitalia flight from Sicily was discovered going round and round, unclaimed, on a Kennedy Airport luggage carrousel. The Customs agents who opened it found heroin, but no clue to the owner.

title: BUSH HOPEFUL ON ARMS TALKS
description: Vice President Bush said today that a breakthrough was possible this summer in the Geneva nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union, according to Danish officials.

title: DEVIL'S OPPORTUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSACHUSETTS MOUNTS CAMPAIGN TO GET DRUNKEN DRIVERS OFF ROAD
description: The state police set up nine roadblocks across Massachusetts over the holiday weekend in a new effort to get drunken drivers off the roads.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review on June 26 of a perform- ance by the folk singer Steve Good- man at the Lone Star Cafe incorrectly ascribed the song ''City of New Or- leans.'' It is by Mr. Goodman.

title: MCENROE CAPTURES WIMBLEDON FINAL BY 6-2, 6-2, 6-2
description: The artistry and mechanics that separate the good from the great in tennis were dramatized at Wimbledon today when John McEnroe won his second men's singles title.

title: TV: LONGTIME EXECUTIVES AND SUDDEN DISMISSAL
description: ''After All Those Years'' looks at some lower-to-middle-management executives, longtime employees, who in return for security, pledged their talents and loyalties to corporations. The corporations, however, reneged on the bargain. The executives were dismissed or, as everyone in the documentary calls it, were terminated. Terminated is a dispassionate word; the documentary is dispassionate, too. It will be seen on Channel 2, at 10 tonight.

title: Lau Hospitalized
description: Charlie Lau, the White Sox batting coach, has been hospitalized for tests after experiencing stomach discomfort, the club said today.

title: CUBS DEFEAT EXPOS, 7-4, FOR 6TH IN A ROW
description: The Chicago Cubs won their sixth straight game and moved within two games of first place in the National League East yesterday with a 7-4 victory over the division-leading Montreal Expos before 41,283 at Wrigley Field. It was the largest home crowd of the season for the Cubs.

title: CORRECTION
description: The U.S. Petroleum data chart in Business Day last Tuesday carried two figures incorrectly reported by the American Petroleum Institute. Daily crude oil imports for the week ended June 24 were 3.4 million barrels and gasoline inventories were 222.1 million barrels.

title: DAWSON: SENSITIVE, QUIET AND POWERFUL
description: ''He may not say six words a day,'' a friend of Andre Dawson said the other day. ''He is a quiet, deep-thinking, sensitive, lovely individual.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Young at Heart

title: News Analysis
description: Over the last several months, as the tale of widespread dioxin contamination across Missouri unfolded in the news media, many physicians there became more and more incensed about what they saw as exaggerations and distortions of the presumed health dangers of the toxic compound, particularly as the subject was covered on television.

title: Actors and Producers Reach Hollywood Pact
description: The two major actors' unions have reached tentative agreement on a three-year contract with movie and television producers.

title: SENATORS OPPOSE REAGAN GIFT CURBS
description: Twenty-one Democratic and eight Republican Senators have asked President Reagan not to carry out new regulations for this year's Federal employee charity drive.

title: President's Son Ends Bid for Mark
description: Equipment trouble today forced President Reagan's son Michael to end his bid to set an endurance powerboating record about a third of the way from Miami to New York.

title: A FELLOW NAMED RONALD GETTING AWAY FROM IT ALL
description: It was just an hour after dawn, and Dennis LeBlanc's van was climbing the lonely yellow knobs of the San Rafael Mountains. On the north side of the road were tangerine and lemon trees, to the south lolled a few black bulls in the high grasses, and all around was the smell of ocean salt.

title: JAZZ: 'TEMPO,' REMINISCENCE BY HENDRICKS
description: Twenty years ago Jon Hendricks created a program called ''Evolution of the Blues,'' which ran for several years in California although it never reached New York. Now he is putting together another program, ''Reminiscing in Tempo,'' which is intended to be an overview of jazz seen through Mr. Hendricks's perspective as a performer and lyric writer over the last 40 years.

title: Magadan's Reality
description: When cynics hear of the .533 batting average Dave Magadan accumulated while leading the University of Alabama to the finals of the national collegiate baseball championship, they often ask him if the figure is ''for real.''

title: ERA OF THE GREAT SAILING SHIPS IS RECALLED
description: day Great Schooner Race takes place.

title: William H. Lantz Sr. Is Dead; Ex-Chase Manhattan Official
description: William H. Lantz Sr., retired vice president of the international department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died of a heart attack Friday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: 32 More Die in Indian Floods
description: Monsoon rains swept western Indian today, causing flash floods that killed at least 32 people, the Government announced.

title:
RELATIONSHIPS;
PRESSURE TO HAVE CHILDREN
description: TROUBLE didn't really erupt, Alice Gellis recalled, until she had been married for about two y ears. Then, as though the unspoken expectation was more than her mother c ould bear silently any longer, the pressure on Mrs. Gellis, who is n ow 36 years old, to produce a child began in earnest.

title: METHODIST UNITS ASK PANEL FOR RULING ON HOMOSEXUALITY
description: More than two-thirds of the 73 regional units of the United Methodist Church have asked the denomination's 1984 General Conference to clarify the church's position on homosexuality, according to a survey in Newscope, a weekly newsletter produced by the denomination's publishing house.

title: Orioles' Palmer On Disabled List
description: Jim Palmer, the Baltimore Orioles' right-hander, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list because of recurring problems with his right shoulder.

title: Reagan Tells Officials to Draft A Foreign Policy Success List
description: President Reagan has told the heads of the State Department and the Pentagon to report on likely areas of foreign policy successes by the end of his current term.

title: CONCERT: NELSON LEADS 38TH CARAMOOR SEASON
description: The Caramoor Festival opened its 38th season tonight in the Venetian Theater on the grounds of the opulent estate of the late Walter and Lucie Rosen, about an hour north of New York City. The site is attractive, the weather was hot but otherwise lovely and the ample audience appeared to be having a civilized good time.

title: Las Vegas Dilemma
description: In the desert oasis of Las Vegas, Nev., where the temperature ''cools down'' to 100 degrees about game time in the evening, minor league baseball is booming. On any given night, about 5,000 people will leave air-conditioned homes and gambling casinos to watch the Las Vegas Stars of the Pacific Coast League. This represents a successful start for a club in its first season; through May, according to the league office, the league's average attendance was 2,874.

title: DR. JOHN M. MARSALKA
description: Dr. John M. Marsalka, an expert on Russian and Czechoslovak history, died of a heart attack June 5 in Prague, where he was to be a delegate to the World Assembly for Peace.

title: VERMONT'S LAWMAKERS TO RETURN TO DEAL WITH BUDGETARY DEFICIT
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling will call the Vermont Legislature back for a special session this month to deal with a serious budget deficit for the fiscal year that ended June 30.

title: SHULTZ SEES LITTLE HOPE OF LEBANON BREAKTHROUGH
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he did not see ''any real prospects'' of achieving a breakthrough on the issue of a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon during a trip to the Middle East this week.

title: B.B. KING FOLLOWS RAY CHARLES
description: Lovers of blues and soul music couldn't wish for a more enticing double bill than one of Ray Charles and B.B. King, who brought their bands to Avery Fisher Hall for two performances Saturday. These two musical giants make a particularly winning combination because one is an inspired iconoclast, the other a monumental classicist, and the contrast is refreshing. Saturday's early show demonstrated that great music can come as easily out of eccentricity as out of reliablity.

title: Liechtenstein Prince To Cede Power to Son
description: Prince Franz Josef II, the ruler of Liechtenstein and Europe's longest-reigning sovereign, has announced he will cede most of his constitutional powers to his son, Hans Adam, next spring.

title: Man Who Gave Resume To Reagan Gives Up Job
description: Ronald Bricker, the unemployed steelworker who got a job after giving his resume to President Reagan, has quit the job to go back to being a steelworker.

title: MAN, HIS WIFE AND SON KILLED IN HOME ON L.I.
description: A 49-year-old foreman for a New York City sheet-rock company, his wife and their teen-age son were found shot to death yesterday morning in various rooms of their home on Long Island.

title: BID FOR CHEAPER, BETTER ROADS
description: A handful of highway officials and engineers say there is a less expensive method of building highways, which also produces virtually maintenance-free pavements - but, they say, it is not being widely used, both because the Federal Government has been slow to issue the necessary design and construction manuals and because no industry group stands to make more money from the new method.

title: TRAGEDY OF JONESTOWN CULT IS SHIFTING FROM COURTS TO HISTORY
description: The stark wording of the final legal document filed by the State Attorney General barely suggests the magnitude of the tragedy.

title: Dance From Out of Town
description: Dance Theater Workshop will present its sixth ''Out-of-Towners'' season Aug. 4 through Aug. 28 in the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: How Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times 1983 Baseball Players Poll was conducted between June 17 and June 27, in clubhouses in 14 American and National League cities. Of the 650 major league players, 466 voted, for an overall response rate of 71.6 percent.

title: Philadelphia Rail Lines Return With Free Rides
description: Riders were many and delays sometimes were long, but everyone rode free as the Philadelphia commuter lines came back to life today at the end of a 3 1/2-month strike.

title: JOE WILLIAMS, AN EVENING OF TRIBUTE
description: The Joe Williams evening at the Kool Jazz Festival on Friday was filled with reflections and memories for Mr. Williams and for those members of his audience who picked up on him at almost any stage of his career.

title: Brown's Lenox Bid
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, which is to acquire Lenox Inc. for about $426 million, began accepting Lenox shares at midnight Friday and will begin payment tomorrow. Lenox shareholders will receive $45 a share for their shares after the effect of a 100 percent stock dividend.

title: Bridge: An Organizer Gets Chance To Shine in His Own Event
description: In any sport or recreation it is rare indeed for the chief organizer of a major event to be a defending champion. In New York's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout, a prestigious event that attracts almost all the ranking players, that distinction belongs to Drew Casen, a young expert of great talent.

title: U.S. ATOM SMASHER ATTAINS A RECORD
description: One of the biggest gambles in the history of particle physics paid off yesterday when Fermi National Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., announced that it had successfully pushed protons to nearly the speed of light with a new atom smasher of revolutionary design.

title: NEW BUSINESSES CITE LACK OF CAPITAL
description: Elizabeth L. Hubbard had long dreamed of owning her own business. Last March, however, the opportunity came a bit more abruptly than she expected when she was laid off by Atari Inc.

title: Goldin Still Unhappy With Grumman Buses; United Press International
description: Serious mechanical problems persist on many of the city's 850 Grumman Flxible buses despite a series of major structural changes made by the manufacturer to correct deficiencies, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: A SAUDI MEDICAL PRIZE IS BECKONING ISRAELIS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'SHE'S WITH ME,' A NEW COMEDY ON CBS
description: There's a certain fascination in watching a show bomb. No one, after all, sets out to make a flop. The producers really believe they have a hot property and set about devoting themselves to what they hope will be its profitable realization. And then, as happens so often even on Broadway, comes the premiere, and most of the audience is wondering how any reasonably intelligent person could have got involved with such a disaster. On Broadway, though, the victims in the audience number, at most, a couple of thousand. Television inflicts its duds on millions.

title: German Court Bars Philip Morris Tie
description: The West German Supreme Court has rejected the merger of Philip Morris Inc. and Rothmans Tobacco Holdings Ltd. as far as their West German operations are concerned.

title: RIVERBOAT SPIRIT RECALLED
description: The annual ''Jazz on the Ferry'' episode of the jazz festival began more than a decade ago as an attempt to recreate the spirit of the riverboats that plied the Mississippi River carrying music by New Orleans jazzmen. In New York the venue was, and is, a Staten Island Ferry on the Hudson River, but at least one of the two bands on board usually had some New Orleans roots.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Musical Expansion

title: Miss Schweitzman Weds
description: Stephanie Ellen Schweitzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schweitzman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in Rockville Centre, L.I., to Jonathan Seth Garay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Garay of Rego Park, Queens.

title: TEACHERS' MEETING DEBATES MERIT PAY
description: Dissidents within the National Education Association failed today to reverse the decision of their union's leaders to consider the possibility of merit pay plans for teachers.

title: SALE OF CONRAIL NOW APPEARS ATTRACTIVE
description: Conrail is suddenly looking good enough to put on the market - a surprise even to the railroad's own management - and the sale may come soon, as a public stock offering.

title: JULY 4, 1933: A GOTHAM GLANCE
description: It was supposed to be a really big show in New York City on July 4, 1933. Radio City Music Hall was planning a stage spectacular featuring an ensemble of 500 artists, and the prices were scarcely a big bang, ranging from 35 cents to 75 cents. Jean Harlow and Clark Gable were opening in ''Hold Your Man,'' and not a vacant seat was expected at any of the holiday showings. Saks 34th Street was renewing its hold on men, by advertising Fuji silk robes ($4.85) ''with hand-embroidered dragons across the back,'' almost certain to appeal ''to every man's ego.'' And subway travel within the city was expected to be smoother than silk after the opening of the Bronx Concourse line on Saturday, June 1.

title: JOB NEWS, BAD NEWS; CITY IN, CITY OUT
description: At 5:30 p.m., I arrive in Milwaukee. Local church representatives meet me. We go over plans for the evening meeting. I am here to bring ''national perspective'' to organizing activities by local churches and unemployed Milwaukee residents.

title: A FLOOD OF REFUGEES FROM SALVADOR TRIES TO GET LEGAL STATUS
description: The Reagan Administration is resisting growing pressure to allow hundreds of thousands of Salvadoran refugees, who have entered this country illegally, to remain.

title: THE PLAYERS' CHOICE: DAWSON
description: TO the players in the major leagues, the best all-round performer in baseball today is Andre Dawson of the Montreal Expos, the best pitcher is Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies and the best manager is Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: A STRANGER ON THE COURT
description: WIMBLEDON, England PLAYING a game but unequal opponent yesterday may have been one of the best things that ever happened to John McEnroe. Not only was he able to demonstrate his exquisite touch against a decent and willing foil like Chris Lewis, he was also able to enjoy being at center court at Wimbledon, portraying the kind of John McEnroe he would like the world to see.

title: BONN LEADER OFF TO MOSCOW TODAY FOR VITAL TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl travels to Moscow Monday on an official visit that is expected to highlight how the Soviet leaders plan to approach East-West relations as the deadline nears for the deployment of American missiles in Europe.

title: Hawaiian Ordeal
description: For most people, skiing is a distant notion on the Fourth of July. But for the United States Women's Ski Team, it is time to get down to work. On this date, the season officially begins -not on snow, but beneath palm trees and on white sandy beaches.

title: SYRIA CALLED ADAMANT ON PULLOUT TALKS
description: There is virtually no chance that Syria will back down on its opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord, according to senior Syrian officials and Western diplomats in Damascus.

title: Ansel Adams Meets Reagan, Disapproves
description: A meeting set up to ease the hostility Ansel Adams has expressed toward President Reagan left the photographer convinced a ''stone wall'' stands between them on environmental issues, it was reported today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Golfer A hits a long wood shot from the fairway to an elevated green on a par-4 hole. The ball goes into the cup, but none of the players in the foursome is aware of it. After a search, Golfer A returns to the spot from which he hit the supposed lost ball and drives a second ball over the green. One of the other players now notices the ball in the cup and Golfer A contends it is his. What is the ruling?

title: ANTILLES FIGHTS U.S. ASSERTIONS
description: Officials of the Netherlands Antilles have formally challenged charges that the islands are used to evade American taxes and that the Dutch colony does not cooperate fully with law enforcement officials in the United States.

title: MANY THAI COMMUNISTS GIVE UP THEIR LONG WARFARE IN THE JUNGLE
description: Since December, groups of up to 1,000 Communist insurgents and their supporters have been marching out of the jungles waving red flags, to be greeted by speeches, television cameras, meals and the Thai Army's senior generals.

title: DAVE GRUSIN AT FISHER HALL
description: The acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall are so tricky that electric music, be it jazz or rock, often becomes swamped in echoes. But poor acoustics were only part of the problem facing Dave Grusin and the N.Y./L.A. Dream Band, a jazz-fusion septet that performed there Friday as part of the jazz festival.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Independence Day holiday. Government agencies, banks and most businesses will also be closed. The Treasury has postponed its weekly bill auction, normally held on Mondays, to tomorrow.

title: UTILITY DEBT ACTIONS EXPECTED
description: Lawyers for the Chemical Bank are expected to ask Washington's State Supreme Court on Tuesday to reconsider its June 15 ruling that Washington cities and public utilities lacked the authority to repay $7 billion in principal and interest on bonds for two nuclear plants that have been left incomplete.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Summer in the City

title: MOUNTAINS OF HUBCAPS FORM BRIDGE BETWEEN HOUSTON AND THE PAST
description: Probably the first thing that newcomers to Houston notice is the drama of its glittering skyline. With the exception of Atlanta, which does things on a somewhat smaller scale, no city in the Sun Belt is more fervent in its headlong architectural plunge into the 21st century. On a sunblinding Texas afternoon, the gleam of Houston's mirrored towers, in every pastel hue, is nothing short of dazzling.

title: AUDIT CRITICIZES U.S. PROSECUTOR ON SECRET PLEAS
description: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan has ''extensively used closed proceedings'' for accepting guilty pleas and sentences, according to a Federal audit.

title: METS BEATEN BY PHILLIES, 6 TO 4
description: The sources of heat were threefold. The artificial turf at Veterans Stadium was smoldering at more than 100 degrees. Mike Schmidt's bat was on fire. And Willie Hernandez, the Phillies' 27-year-old relief pitcher, was throwing smoke.

title: SUMMER ISN'T JUST BANTER FOR L.I. COASTGUARDSMEN
description: In the hot, muggy air, half a dozen of the men on duty at the Coast Guard station here were scattered about the front porch drinking soda or iced tea. There was banter and easy talk about parties, concerts and the cold beer some looked forward to when the weekend was over.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Edited T-Shirt

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAPPY 207TH

title: FERVOR FOR POLO SURVIVES L.I.'S CHANGED TIMES
description: Why, with the temperature at 95 degrees, would eight people struggle into tight leather boots, hop onto lathered horses and gallop across a field to whack a little white ball with a mallet?

title: PANTHERS TAKE DIVISION TITLE
description: Ken Lacy, a running back, threw for one touchdown and ran for another in the first quarter today as the Michigan Panthers defeated the Arizona Wranglers, 33-7. The Panthers thus captured the Central Division championship of the United States Football League on the final day of the regular season.

title: 6 HURT AS FREIGHTER AND FERRY COLLIDE IN RHODE ISLAND SOUND
description: A freighter and a passenger ferry filled with tourists collided in heavy fog on Rhode Island Sound Saturday, injuring six people.

title: ...AND WEAK COLLEGES
description: To the Editor:

title: HOWARD L. KATZANDER
description: Howard L. Katzander, a journalist and editor of International Art Market, a monthly periodical listing auction prices, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Woodbury, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: REGIME IN POLAND RALLIES THE YOUNG AFTER POPE'S VISIT
description: A senior Polish official acknowledged at a weekend meeting of young Communist Party members that the Government was having difficulties with Polish youth and that it was working to try to win their support.

title: A Second Defeat For Australia II
description: Australia II suffered only her second loss in 15 races, and Advance finally won her first race as foreign boats continued their round-robin competition today in the America's Cup trials.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS VYING TO OVERCOME A DIFFICULT PERIOD
description: It has been a rough year for the tobacco industry. First, there was the doubling of the Federal excise tax on Jan. 1, to 16 cents a pack, pushing cigarettes into the dollar-a-pack range. That led to heightened competition as producers tried to entice brand-switching with giveaways and bargains.

title: Washington Watch; Trying to Alter Banking Laws
description: WASHINGTON AMAJOR new effort to rewrite banking legislation will be undertaken by the Reagan Administration as a result of a Cabinet Council meeting last Thursday, but the chances of Congressional approval are rated no better than fair.

title: HOCKEY OLYMPIANS TO BE DESIGNATED
description: The Fourth of July is the day for naming the successors to the hockey team that stirred such intense patriotic feelings throughout the United States in February 1980.

title: NEW HEAD PLANS TO MAKE PRADO 'LIVING' MUSEUM
description: The new director of the Prado is determined to reverse 20 years of pollution, neglect and tangled administration that he says have made Spain's venerable art museum ''the great invalid of our culture.''

title: Allegheny Ends Nippon Steel Deal
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it had terminated a deal to sell its Special Metals Corporation to Japan's Nippon Steel Corporation because of objections by the Department of Defense.

title: AFGHAN REFUGEES HEAR SHULTZ VOW 'WE ARE WITH YOU'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a crowd of cheering Afghan refugees at a camp near here today: ''Fellow fighters for freedom, we are with you!''

title: Red Sox Homers Stop Yanks
description: After hitting his first home run of the season in helping to beat the Yankees yesterday, Gary Allenson was asked, not seriously, when he thought he would catch his Boston teammate, Jim Rice.

title: WIDOW OF FUTURIST ARCHITECT
description: Anne Hewlett Fuller, the widow of the futurist, inventor and architect R. Buckminster Fuller, died early yesterday morning at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles, just 36 hours after her husband's death.

title: 'JUNGLE MAN' GOT REBELS TO GIVE UP
description: To some, the colonel was ''Jungle Man.'' To an armed company of former Communist insurgents, he was ''Chief.''

title: Miss Neyer Upset
description: Megan Neyer of the United States, the world champion, was upset by Meiguin Shi of China today in the women's three-meter springboard diving competition at the World University Games. Sylvia Bernier of Canada took the bronze medal.

title: CITY WELFARE WORK PROGRAM GROWS
description: Nina Brown and Beatrice Stahl were sitting on a couch in Mrs. Stahl's Brooklyn apartment, trying to coax a breeze from a worn electric fan. The women exchanged good-natured banter.

title: BRITISH BELL MAKER SEES BETTER TIMES
description: Come the Fourth of July, there will be a day-long ringing of bells around the carriage yard of the old Artichoke Inn. No one will be celebrating American independence, of course. It's just business as usual at the Whitechapel Bell Foundry.

title: Steel Chiefs' Merger Views
description: David Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, has told a Congressional committee that antitrust laws should be revised to encourage mergers and more efficient operations in the steel industry.

title: GLOBAL STOCK MARKETS STRONG
description: Stock prices on the world's major equity markets continued to climb in the second quarter, bolstered by signs that economic recovery in the United States was gathering momentum.

title: British Cup Yacht Keeps Her Lead
description: Victory 83, the British entry in the second round of trials to select a challenger for the America's Cup, beat Australia's Advance today and retained her series lead.

title: HOW TO TEACH KINDERGARTEN: THE DEBATE IS ON
description: It was time for learning in Ursula Davis's full-day kindergarten class at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side. In one corner, Jennifer, Amy, Kimberly and Kendra were working with illustrated letter cards. In another corner, Kandia was making a ''one way'' sign for the farm he built of wooden blocks. Next to him, two children listened to a recorded story.

title: Bus Crash in Kentucky Kills 2 and Injures 19
description: At least two people were killed and 19 were injured today when a bus carrying a church group went out of control on a rain-slick highway, crashed through a guardrail and overturned, a state police trooper said.

title: An Ex-Pharmacologist Is Archbishop of York
description: A former university scientist, John Habgood, was appointed Archbishop of York today, the second-ranking prelate in the Church of England.

title: LEAN, STRONG PUBLIC RADIO FORESEEN
description: Sharon Rockefeller, the chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, said she believed a stronger but leaner public radio system would emerge from the effort to restore National Public Radio to financial health.

title: U.S. Volcano's Soviet Sister
description: In October 1955, Bezymianny, a seemingly dormant volcano in a remote part of Kamchatka, an extension of Siberia into the northwest Pacific, began a series of eruptions that culminated the following March in a catastrophic explosion. The entire east side of the volcano was blown out.

title: VALUE OF EXERCISE AFTER A MEAL CITED
description: EXERCISE after eating helps the body get rid of extra calories beyond the number of calories used directly to perform the activity, according to a study at Cornell University's Division of Nutritional Sciences. Even the day after a calorie-rich meal, exercise helps the body burn off extra calories, the study showed.

title: LE MONDE STRUGGLING TO STEM LOSSES
description: Le Monde, the most influential French newspaper, has started thinking about new techniques to win and hold readers after a serious drop in circulation and the largest operating loss in its history.

title: AFRIKANER'S SATIRE A BOX-OFFICE HIT
description: Gatherings by black nationalists here are routinely declared illegal under a law known as the Riotous Assemblies Act. Pieter-Dirk Uys, a thoroughly uninhibited satirist who hones his sense of the absurd on the blatant contradictions of South African politics, has subtitled his latest effort ''A Legal Assembly in Two Riotous Acts.''
