title: RIGHETTI PITCHES FIRST YANKEE NO-HITTER SINCE 1956
description: Dave Righetti, who last year at this time was banished to the minors because of his disappointing efforts, pitched the Yankees' first no-hitter in 27 years in a 4-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox at the Stadium yesterday.

title: PUROLATOR UNIT NAMES WELLS, RICH, GREENE
description: Wells, Rich, Greene on Friday was named agency for Purolator Courier and thus enters its creative talents into battle for dominance of the sky by the nation's air express companies.

title: BIG GOLD PROJECT SPLITS COAST AREA
description: High in the chaparral country on a remote 9,000 acres of land, a project for a large open-pit gold mine where an estimated 3.2 million ounces of gold lie buried has been delayed by county, state and Federal regulations and resistance by environmentalists and local farmers.

title: MILITARY DIVIDED OVER SPACE POLICY
description: A dispute over space policy has erupted within the Defense Department as the Navy has resisted an Air Force proposal that all military space operations be unified under one command.

title: MEN'S BUYING HABITS STUDIED
description: One of the nation's largest manufacturers of men's clothing found in a recent study in the Chicago area that American men are more sensitive than expected about the clothing they buy.

title: Auto Racing Charges
description: Mario Andretti has rebutted charges by Wally Dallenbach, the former driver who is now the chief steward for Championship Auto Racing Teams, that he was responsible for a series of accidents in Sunday's Cleveland 500. Dallenbach charged that Andretti, who was leading the 500-kilometer race when the field was slowed by a yellow caution flag, had not followed pre-race instructions for the re-start.

title: A SPARK OF LIFE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's visit to the Soviet Union this week could help revive the Soviet-American negotiations on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe - talks that are widely regarded as moribund but may have more life in them than is immediately apparent.

title: BUSH, JOINING A DANISH FETE ON 4TH, STRESSES NEED FOR NEW MISSILES
description: Vice President Bush, sweeping through the final stages of his mission to try to bolster NATO's northern flank, today visited Denmark, the shakiest partner in the alliance's plan to deploy medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: At least 130 women and children belonging to the Bahai sect, which is banned by Iran's Islamic Government, were attacked and forced to hide in a forest in northern Iran last week for refusing to change their religion, the Bahai organization in Britain said today.

title: A CHASM TOO WIDE
description: A serious race-relations controversy is brewing in this city. Some black ministers, community spokesmen and elected officials are charging that police brutality is on the rise here. The Police Department says it's not true, that its figures show complaints to be down sharply. Mayor Koch says that those making the loudest charges are playing politics, trying to find an issue that can unseat him and place a black in the mayoralty in 1985.

title: 17 Injured at Kansas Fair
description: A fireworks stand at the Kansas State Fairgrounds collapsed Saturday night, sending fireballs into a crowd of spectators and slightly injuring at least 17 people, the police said.

title: FOREST'S ROLE IN WEATHER DOCUMENTED IN AMAZON
description: RESEARCHERS studying the dynamics of South America's tropical forest have produced scientific evidence showing with precision for the first time that a forest can return as much as 75 percent of the moisture it receives to the atmosphere. The finding indicates that the forest plays a much more important role in weather generation than had been previously believed.

title: WILLIAM C. MILLER
description: William C. Miller, a partner in Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., died of a stroke yesterday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: FLORIDA SCHOOLS FACE CUTS IN BUDGET IMPASSE
description: School systems throughout Florida are slashing budgets, scaling back programs and planning layoffs because state leaders are in a stalemate over money to improve public education.

title: Ally May Go Public
description: Amil Gargano, president and chief executive of Ally & Gargano, confirmed last week that the agency has been talking to an investment banking firm about the possibility of going public later this year. It was a move that the agency stepped back from at the last minute in 1972 and one that no important advertising agency has taken since BBDO International did it in 1973. The 1972 plan called for issuing 300,000 shares at $13 a share.

title: DR. THOMAS D. LENCI
description: Dr. Thomas Dexter Lenci, associate corporate medical director of the General Electric Company, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: 1,000 Young Filipinos Stage Anti-U.S. Protest
description: About 1,000 young Filipinos staged a protest in front of the American Embassy here today, which is officially observed as Filipino-American Friendship Day.

title: THE LEGACY OF JOE DELANEY
description: I t was a week ago, in the morning, and in the shadows in a corner of the living room Joe Delaney, 24 years old, sat and quietly played his guitar.

title: Lime Rock Race To Englishman
description: The Englishman Jim Crawford took the lead on the 25th lap today and held on through searing heat to win Lime Rock Park's Can-Am race with an average speed of 107.448 miles and hour.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS CITED IN SURVEY
description: The nation's economic prospects continued to brighten in June, with industrial companies reporting a step-up in orders and employment, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in its monthly survey.

title: News Analysis
description: With two scientific reports published last week, the uncertainty about the causes and probable cures for acid rain was sharply reduced. So, too, it appears, were the Reagan Administration's options for delaying regulatory action on the problem.

title: SCIENCE USING NEW TOOLS TO VERIFY CONTINENTAL DRIFT
description: ALTHOUGH earth scientists are convinced that the world is coming apart along its midocean seams, carrying Europe and America away from one another and bringing Japan closer to California, there has never been direct observation of such motions. Now, however, such measurements have become possible by using radio emissions from what are supposedly the most distant objects in the universe - the quasars.

title: Firecracker 400 Taken by Baker
description: Buddy Baker sped to an easy victory in the Firecracker 400 stock-car race today when Terry Labonte, leading with only one lap of two and a half miles remaining, ran out of gasoline.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF A FEDERAL RACKETEERING LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: RESORT CLOTHES AT CENTER STAGE
description: Summer was once a quiet, relaxing time for fashion designers. It was a time to travel, to play and to recharge batteries for the next major collection.

title: News Analysis
description: When Mayor Koch announced last week that he was dropping his policy of collecting property taxes from many cultural and social-service groups, the action had the appearance of a surrender. But lost in the much-publicized reversal was the fact that Mr. Koch's five-year effort to reduce the number of properties getting exemptions has otherwise enjoyed success. According to the city's Department of Finance, properties owned by more than 100 nonprofit groups, assessed for tax purposes at $157 million, have been taxed since Mr. Koch first announced a more restrictive policy in 1978. The group that Mr. Koch decided last week deserved exemptions includes as many as 300 properties, but they have a similar assessed value, about $150 million, officials say.

title: Looking to 1984
description: Upgrading performances and players, position by position, will be the goal of the New Jersey Generals for next season, according to Chuck Fairbanks, the coach and the team's president. But that does not mean a wholesale revision of the squad, which has a solid nucleus for 1984 in Fairbanks's opinion.

title: Heat From Barn: An Energy Source
description: Using electric heat pumps, farmers could use the heat from cows' milk to heat their homes, according to an agricultural engineer.

title: Chilean Copper Union Meets Interior Minister
description: Leaders of the Copper Workers Confederation, seeking the release from jail of their union's president and the rehiring of 700 strikers dismissed by the Government mining company, met today with the Interior Minister.

title: TWO ROCKETS FIRED FROM JORDAN HIT NEAR AN ISRAELI TOWN IN GALILEE
description: Two rockets fired from Jordanian territory exploded in the Jordan Valley Sunday night, the Israeli Army announced today. There were no casualties and no damage.

title: The Calendar
description: Tuesday

title: ALL-STARS OF 1933 RECALL SCENE OF GLORY
description: The Golden Anniversary of baseball's All-Star Game will be celebrated tomorrow night, 50 years to the day, in Chicago's Comiskey Park, where on a sweltering afternoon in 1933 Babe Ruth thrilled a crowd of 49,200 with a two-run homer that sent the American League to a 3-0 lead and an eventual 4-2 victory.

title: Death Row Population Was Record 1,050 in '82
description: There were 1,050 prisoners on death row in the United States at the end of last year, the largest number ever and 22.7 percent more than a year earlier, the Justice Department said today.

title: Few New Issues Planned for Week
description: With financial markets closed yesterday for the Fourth of July holiday, credit market participants say this week will be unusually light in terms of new corporate and municipal bonds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cruises and Crossings

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VERDI GODFATHER

title: ARAFAT IS SAID TO ACCEPT REBEL DEMAND FOR PANEL TO DISCUSS MUTINY
description: Yasir Arafat has agreed to at least one of the key demands of mutineers in Al Fatah, his guerrilla organization, a senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.

title: INHABITANTS OF PIGALLE
description: ''Neige'' was shown as part of the 1982 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby that appeared in The New York Times of April 17, 1982. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: BUTCH WYNEGAR MAKES RIGHT CALL
description: W ith two out in the ninth inning, Dave Righetti's no-hitter on the line and a two-ball, two-strike count on Wade Boggs of Boston, Butch Wynegar found himself torn between two calls yesterday.

title: Steeplechase Won by Marsh
description: Henry Marsh of the United States, who has not lost a race in the 3,000-meter steeplechase since 1980, unleashed a powerful kick tonight and won the event in the world's fastest time of the season in an international track and field meet.

title: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J.  High above the town, in the densely forested Somerset Hills, is a rambling house with several drawing rooms. Outside, the mistress of that house and what used to be a 500-acre property sits on her porch, sipping minty iced tea.
description: Her view extends for mile upon mile of rolling lawns and trees. Yet she is watching a wren, whose family has settled in a light fixture. It is clear the wren is not pleased by her presence. It hops about nervously while its mate swings in the wisteria behind her, hissing furiously.

title: NURSING 'HOMES'
description: Few thoughts inspire a greater sense of dread in the elderly than the prospect of spending their last years in a nursing home. Today, 1.3 million reside in such institutions. Despite the emergence of programs to care for them in their own homes, one in five persons is likely to spend time in a nursing home.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review Saturday of a festival program, two musicians in the Stan Getz Quartet were misidentified. The bassist was George Mraz and the percussionist was Adam Nussbaum.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Holiday Commerce

title: Eagle Owner Set Back
description: A Delaware County judge in Pennsylavania has stopped, at least temporarily, Leonard Tose's sale of 48 percent of the stock in the Philadelphia Eagles. The judge, Howard Reed, acted on a suit filed by three investors who contend that Tose, before negotiating the 48-percent sale to a group in which they were included, promised to sell the group 99 percent.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 5, 1983
description: International Yuri V. Andropov canceled a meeting planned in Moscow with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov, who took the Soviet leader's place, warned that if the Atlantic alliance proceeded with deployment of new American missiles in Europe, the Warsaw Pact countries would respond ''without delay.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) Total debts of $700 billion have been amassed by developing nations in Latin America, Africa and Asia and a number of Eastern European countries. A large part of these loans cannot be paid on time. At stake, should a significant amount of these debts be repudiated, would be the solvency of some of the world's largest multinational banks. (A1:4-5.)

title: U.S. Envoy Reported to Seek Salvador Contact With Rebels
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America will return to El Salvador this week to arrange a meeting between the Government and leftist guerrillas, two television networks reported tonight.

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Independence Day holiday. Government agencies, banks and most businesses were also shut down. The Treasury's weekly bill auction, normally on Mondays, was postponed until today.

title: CARLTON STOPS METS, STRIKING OUT NINE
description: The Mets went into the All-Star Game break with a 4-0 loss to Steve Carlton and the Phillies tonight, further cementing their hold on the bottom of the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Marijuana Pollen Found Allergenic
description: Hay fever sufferers in the West are having to contend with a newly discovered irritant pollen from marijuana, a plant not native to the western states but which is being widely harvested there on illegal plantations.

title: 6 Electrical Companies Indicted
description: Three of six companies indicted by a Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh Saturday on charges that they rigged bids for electrical contracts already face earlier indictments on contract bid-rigging charges.

title: A PITCHER WHOSE TIME HAS COME
description: Three years after he said he was ''tired of being called a 'flamethrowing prospect,' '' two years after he was American League rookie of the year, but only a year after he was returned to the minor leagues in what he called ''a very humbling experience,'' Dave Righetti can finally say goodbye to Columbus, Ohio, and the Yankee farm team there. The first Yankee pitcher to throw a no-hitter in 27 years ''is just coming into his own now,'' said Butch Wynegar, the catcher who called the pitches yesterday when Righetti defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-0, at Yankee Stadium.

title: GUATEMALA'S NEW STRIFE: A SAVAGE WAR OF WORDS
description: The air of this city, which once crackled with the gunfire of death squads, is bombarded these days mostly by political oratory.

title: MUSIC: WILLIE NELSON AND FRIENDS PERFORM AT JERSEY 'PICNIC'
description: THE temperature at Giants Stadium Sunday was a few degrees lower and the humidity a few percentage points higher than they were at Willie Nelson's last Independence Day country music ''picnic,'' which took place near Austin, Tex., two years ago. But though the two events had a lot in common, including the astonishing fact that tens of thousands of fans would show up at all for an outdoor concert on the hottest day of the year, the differences went beyond geography.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review last Tuesday of a Kool Jazz Festival program, the bassist with the Miles Davis group was incor- rectly identified. He was Darrel Jones.

title: Bridge: Theorists Prefer to Make; An Idle Bid Do Some Work
description: Idleness is almost as abhorrent to bidding theorists as it was to the Puritans. Any unemployed bid, they feel, should be harnessed and put to work. And the work does not have to be artificial: There are plenty of natural meanings available for those who look.

title: McEnroe Shows Dinner Manners
description: The most interesting turnabout at Wimbledon this year may have come from John McEnroe, the champion. As the 1981 men's singles winner, he was criticized two years ago for missing the Champion's Dinner, a misunderstanding that took a full year to resolve.

title: 'BOAT PEOPLE' IN BRITAIN: A VOYAGE OF HARD LUCK
description: Three years have passed since the Golden Dolphin, a British ship, plucked Van Thinh and other Vietnamese refugees from a wave-tossed boat in the South China Sea.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Energy Management Corp.'s 15 percent participating certificates due in 1992 and its 12 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1996 received a lower rating from Moody's Investors Service. Moody's lowered the certificates to CAA from single-B3, and the debentures to CA from CAA.

title: Jackson Replaced
description: With Reggie Jackson still suffering from bruised ribs, Ben Oglivie of the Milwaukee Brewers has been named by Manager Harvey Kuenn as an outfield replacement on the American League all-star team that will play the National League tomorrow night in Chicago. Jackson, voted to the starting team by the fans, was injured June 21 when he tripped over a bullpen pitching mound while chasing a foul ball, and has not played since for the California Angels. Kuenn did not say which reserve would start in Jackson's place.

title: WOMEN'S FUNCTION IN OUR 'PATRIARCHY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodities; Exchange Celebrates 50th Year
description: TRADING in gold and silver futures on New York's Commodity Exchange will start one hour later than normal this morning, while the Comex copper market will be delayed 20 minutes. It will be the first time that the exchange intentionally delayed its openings.

title: South Africa Investigates 3 of Its Newsmen
description: Two newspaper editors and the head of the South African Press Association said today that they were being investigated by the police for publishing charges of police brutality.

title: 3-MONTH-OLD EMERGENCY ACT HAS CREATED FEW JOBS AS YET
description: Three months after it became law, the Federal $4.6 billion emergency job program has produced few of the new jobs it was designed to create. Most of the money is tied up in red tape and debate over how it should be spent.

title: Martin, Sturtevant Gets Spanish Tourist Office
description: The National Tourist Office of Spain has selected Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall to be its ad agency in the United States. And, according to the agency, the budget is around $2.5 million.

title: TYLER, LYONS AND NEW MUSIC
description: THE jazz festival's new-music program concluded Sunday at Soundscape with a vigorous double bill of under-recognized saxophonists, Charles Tyler and Jimmy Lyons.

title: Talking Business With Howe of Tool Builders' Group; An Industry In a Squeeze
description: In May the machine tool industry experienced a 28 percent upturn in orders from the level of a year before. But the industry, which has been forced to close plants and lay off thousands of workers, is still far below its break-even point.

title: BEACH BOYS ON THE SAND OFFER GOOD VIBRATIONS
description: The carolers of summer came here to the queen of seaside resorts tonight, and thousands of people gathered by the ocean to celebrate the event and the music that has marked the season for more than two decades.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, has named H.J. Braverman chairman of two of its units, the National Life and Accident Insurance Co. and Casualty Insurance Co. of Tennessee.

title: LIFE IN SHEFFIELD, ALA.: A BLACK'S OLDS, A WHITE'S SAX AND A NEW HARMONY
description: Willie Ruff has come home for the summer. When he arrived here the other day, he placed his usual call to Jimmie Kirsch, who runs a body shop in town. He told Mr. Kirsch he was ready to do some more work on his 1958 Oldsmobile. ''O.K.,'' Mr. Kirsch said, ''and I'll bring my saxophone down.''

title: Required Reading; Abortion and Responsibility
description: Remarks of Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, in Senate debate on the defeated constitutional amendment to allow Congress and the states to ban abortions, June 28, 1983:

title: Chinks in the Armor
description: Procurement, Soviet-Style

title: CRITICS DIVIDED ON WHAT TO DO ABOUT UNPOPULAR INCOME TAX
description: The 10 percent tax cut on July 1 completed the three-stage, 25 percent Reagan tax cut and also ended the second major round of tax-rate cutting since World War II. Despite these cuts the personal income tax, the workhorse of the Federal revenue system, is increasingly unpopular with taxpayers, members of Congress and intellectuals from across the political spectrum.

title: SEARCH FOR THE NATURAL HISTORY OF AIDS: SO LITTLE IS KNOWN
description: AIDS is proving to be one of the most challenging problems ever to face medical researchers. Scientists know virtually nothing about the natural history of the syndrome that is causing one of the most frightening epidemics in recent years.

title: NBC PUT FINAL IN PERSPECTIVE
description: I n the past, NBC and tennis fans were delighted to have John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg participating in the men's final at Wimbledon. That pairing was a built-in ratings winner of the kind that carried two previous ''Breakfasts at Wimbledon'' into the lunch hour. On Sunday, however, McEnroe was the only one of the two who was playing. Borg, who is retired, joined Dick Enberg and Bud Collins as part of the NBC broadcast team.

title: Chess: Gurevich Takes First Place In Heraldica-Ruslan Event
description: Dmitry Gurevich, a 26-year-old emigre from the Soviet Union who lives in Brooklyn, won the Heraldica-Ruslan International Tournament in New York. His 8-3 score earned him $2,000 and apparently completed the requirements for his grandmaster title.

title: New Change For Sambo's
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. said it is planning to raise more capital through another change in its restaurant concept.

title: THE ROLE OF 'BARNACLES' IN FOREIGN AID
description: Congress doesn't want the Palestine Liberation Organization ''or any other guerrilla type organization that has engaged in acts of terrorism'' to receive foreign aid funds.

title: Transamerica Selects Della Femina Agency
description: After an agency review that originally included 14 agencies, Transamerica in San Francisco has selected the Los Angeles office of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners to handle its corporate advertising, with between $13 million and $15 million being spent between now and the end of 1984.

title: Soviet Violinist Flees To Sweden After Tour
description: A 23-year-old Soviet violinist, Viktoriya Mullova, left a Stradivarius on her hotel bed in Finland and fled with her accompanist to Sweden, the police reported.

title: People
description: * John Shima promoted to executive vice president at Wyse Advertising.

title: WITH THE VETO GAME
description: The United States Supreme Court's decision striking down the legislative veto corrects a longstanding defect in the Federal legislative process.

title: WRONG WEAPON FOR MOST WEIGHT PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUG INDICTMENT VOIDED FOR PROSECUTION 'ZEAL'
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a narcotics indictment in Connecticut must be dismissed because ''prosecutorial zeal'' had violated the grand jury's integrity.

title: John Henry Is Winner
description: John Henry returned to the races after an eight-month absence today, pulling away in the final yards to score a 1 1/4-length victory in the $164,600 American Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: NETWORK OF 'ALTERNATIVE' PHILANTHROPIES IS FORMING
description: When George Pillsbury and Sarah Pillsbury, who are brother and sister, inherited a share of the family flour fortune, they were interested in helping members of minority groups, low-income families and disarmament activists by creating new community foundations. So were other young heirs to great American fortunes.

title: SOFTWARE ON A DISK ACTS AS A GUIDE TO THE I.B.M.
description: ONE of the great mysteries of personal computing, for me, is the steady flow of instructions on tape cassettes that crosses my desk on its way to that bulging circular file on the floor. Why design a tutorial that requires you to listen to someone murmuring from the low-fidelity speaker of a cassette recorder as you stare at a video screen? Programs on computer disks that take you step by step through the workings of a particular piece of software or introduce you to the basic functions of a new computer system make so much more sense.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TILL DEATH DO US PART. Bendix vs. Martin Marietta. By Hope Lampert. 264 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. THREE PLUS ONE EQUALS BILLIONS. The Bendix-Martin Marietta War. By Allan Sloan. 270 pages. Arbor House. Il- lustrated. $15.95.

title: Man's Body Recovered Near Bridge on Hudson
description: Police divers today recovered a body believed to be that of a man thrown from the Tappan Zee Bridge when his disabled car was hit from behind by a truck pulling a horse trailer.

title: Tiger Debt Agreement Detailed; Swap Involves Two Issues
description: TroubledTiger International Inc. announced the terms today for its offer to exchange two issues of outstanding debt worth $112.5 million for two combinations of debentures, common stock and common stock warrants.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY TO BE REPAIRED STARTING IN FALL
description: Scaffolding will soon rise around the Statue of Liberty in preparation for a two-year, $30 million restoration of the decaying monument.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Reactivated Joe F erguson, catcher, and designated him f or assignment.

title: ALVARADO REVIEWS TOLL OF MEDIOCRITY
description: In a recent interview, Anthony J. Alvarado, the Chancellor of the New York City school system, discussed issues raised in the current debate over the quality of American education. What follows are excerpts from that interview with Joyce Purnick.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Local electricians tell me a television antenna serves as a good lightning rod but no one seems to know what gauge of wire is required to transmit the bolt to the ground. Wouldn't an antenna without a heavy-gauge wire grounding it simply be an attractive hazard?

title: West Undecided on Response To Soviet Rights Compromise
description: Western countries at a European security conference failed to agree today on their response to a human rights compromise by the Soviet Union that could bring the three-year-old talks to a close, diplomats said.

title: TEAM BELIEVES IT HAS FOUND WRECK OF NAPOLEON'S SHIP
description: green sea, French and Egyptian divers are exploring what they are convinced is the wreck of l'Orient, the flagship of the ill-fated fleet that convoyed Napoleon Bonaparte and his army to Egypt.

title:
THIRD WORLD'S $700 BILLION DEBT POSING THREAT TO RICHER NATIONS;
Questions and answers on the debt problems, page D8.
description: Over the last two years, a dark shadow has fallen over the onceglamorous world of international finance. Developing nations in Latin America, Africa and Asia plus a number of Eastern European countries have amassed total debts of about $700 billion. A large portion of these loans cannot be paid on time.

title: Racal Electronics Picks Deputy Chief Executive
description: David C. Elsbury has been appointed to the newly created position of deputy chief executive of Racal Electronics P.L.C., a company that has been one of Britain's industrial success stories.

title: Fix the Plumbing for Poisons
description: Last winter's scandal at the Environmental Protection Agency focused on the Superfund, a program that taxes producers to pay for cleaning up the foulest toxic waste dumps. But the Superfund addresses only existing waste deposits. Unless disposed of safely, the new poisons produced each day will create new problem dumps as fast as the old ones disappear.

title: UNORTHODOX SAVINGS BANK
description: Their is little elegance about the mortgage department of the Green Point Savings Bank in Flushing, Queens. It has the tone of an emergency room in a city hospital. The walls are dirty, manual typewriters are still used and there is a constant buzz of activity.

title: Fed Reported Weighing Higher Discount Rate
description: The Federal Reserve is considering several formal proposals to increase the discount rate from its current level of 8.5 percent, well-informed analysts said over the weekend. However, there is a possibilty that the central bank will defer action on these requests for the time being to avoid a confrontation with Congress.

title: The U.N. Today; July 5, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIREWORKS, FIERY DAY HEARALD 4TH
description: With booms and bangs and brilliant displays of fireworks, the metropolitan area celebrated the Fourth of July holiday in sweltering heat yesterday.

title: Market Place; Wary Traders Ready to Go
description: TRADING resumes today on the New York Stock Exchange and other markets, following a week when investors' worries about interest rates surfaced anew and encouraged some profit taking. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.43 points last week, finishing at 1,225.26.

title: Close to Home
description: She had dreamed since junior high school of playing basketball for the University of Southern California. But when time came for the final decision, Clemette Haskins chose Western Kentucky instead.

title: Business People; Mitsubishi Official To Stress Car Sales
description: Late last Friday in Tokyo, before Takeo Kondo climbed aboard a jet for New York, where he becomes the new president of the Mitsubishi International Corporation, he pondered how much things had changed since the first time he went to the United States in 1954.

title: 3,000 Attend Delaney Rites
description: Three thousand mourners jammed Haughton High School's gymnasium today for the funeral of Joe Delaney, the star running back for the Kansas City Chiefs who drowned last week trying to save three boys floundering in a pool.

title: FETAL RESEARCH: NEW FIELD OFFERS PROMISE AMID PROBLEMS
description: MEDICAL scientists are confronting a new and potentially explosive issue: the treatment of human illness, particularly diseases of the brain and central nervous system, by transplanting tissue from aborted human embryos.

title: Rich Airways Files Under Chapter 11
description: Continuing financial losses and pressure from a major creditor has forced Rich International Airways to file for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, according to Jean Rich, the carrier's founder.

title: Inmates Kill a Prison Officer And Injure Five in Missouri
description: A corrections officer was stabbed to death and five others injured late Sunday when inmates at the Missouri Training Center for Men attacked them with homemade weapons.

title: TEMPLE'S BUILDING PLANS CRITICIZED BY NEIGHBORS
description: A plan by the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue to develop part of its property on Central Park West has provoked a bitter dispute about a house of worship's responsibility to its community.

title: BIG CROPS LIKELY DESPITE CUTBACKS
description: The latest Agriculture Department survey of this year's crop acreage has found that an area half the size of Texas has been left unplanted by grain and cotton farmers participating in the new payment-in-kind program.

title: A HEALTHY DIALOGUE AMONG U.S. JEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHTER SOVIET CROP OUTLOOK
description: The road winding through the Naryn River valley from this remote spot in Soviet Kirghizia is bordered these days with a scene to gladden hearts in the Kremlin 2,000 miles away - irrigated fields bursting with grain, cotton, fruit and vegetables of every variety.

title: Accounts
description: * Pittsburgh Pirates to Creamer Inc., Pittsburgh.

title: SHANKER SAYS UNION COULD BACK A MERIT PAY PLAN
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, told union members today that it might no longer be a question of whether public education adopts a merit pay plan, but whether it is ''a better plan or a worse plan.''

title: TWO STARS DIFFER IN OUTLOOK ON GAME
description: At the beginning of his first trip to New York in the last season of his baseball career, Carl Yastrzemski stopped to talk to the next generation. Four youngsters had been allowed to sit in the third-base dugout at Yankee Stadium and ask him questions for a publication aimed at young people. They walked past the skeptical security officers and sat around Yastrzemski.

title: TEACHERS FIND POLITICIANS' ATTENTION NOT ALL WELCOME
description: Lila M. Cook, who teaches a class of fifth and sixth graders in Waukesha, Wis., says she is full of resentment over the way people are blaming teachers these days for so many of the problems in the public schools.

title: BLACK LEADER URGES INQUIRY INTO KLAN DISCLOSURES
description: Recent disclosures by a former member of the Ku Klux Klan should reopen a Justice Department investigation of a 1979 shootout between robed Klansmen and black marchers, according to the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

title: JAPAN ADDS FLAVOR TO ENGLISH IT USES
description: In Japan, the parched-throat crowd slakes its thirst with the best-selling soft drink ''Pocari Sweat.'' Those who do not fancy black coffee use the popular powdered creamer dubbed ''Creap.'' Menus tout such tempting morsels as ''sand witches'' (sandwiches) and ''miss gorilla'' (mixed grill). Smokers puff away on cigarettes branded ''Hope.''

title: WALESA SAID TO TAKE VACATION FROM JOB WITHOUT PERMISSION
description: Lech Walesa has reportedly taken an unauthorized two-week vacation that might jeopardize his job at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk.

title: Soviet Swimmers Sweep 5 Races
description: The Soviet Union swept to victory in all five swimming events of the World University Games tonight, led by Irina Laricheva, who won her third and fourth gold medals.

title: Miss Comaneci a Coach
description: One of the biggest little stars of the 1976 Olympics at Montreal was back in Canada for the World University Games in Edmonton.

title: Baseball; NO-HITTERS; AMerican League
description: Baltimore - Jim Palmer, Aug. 13, 1969 vs. Oakland. Boston - Dave Morehead, Sept. 16, 1965 vs. Cleveland. California - Nolan Ryan, June 1, 1975 vs. Baltimore.

title: A SUBURBAN DOUBLE FOR WINTER'S TALE
description: When Paul Mellon named his yearling crop of 1977, he chose Winter's Tale for a son of Arts and Letters out of Christmas Wind. The name, taken from Shakespeare's comedy ''The Winter's Tale,'' played cleverly on the names of both the sire and the dam. But Mellon had no way of knowing how prophetic his choice would be.

title: THE LASTING GRUDGE OF TUTHMOSIS III
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER RIGHTS STIR LEGAL SNARL
description: The nation's copyright and patent laws, which have protected literary works and inventions for nearly 200 years, apparently fail to safeguard much of the computer technology that many people hope will help revive America's economy, according to a growing number of legislators, judges and computer executives.

title: Belgian a Winner On Bicycle Tour
description: Ruddy Matthys of Belgium won the third stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, biding his time and overhauling Kim Andersen of Denmark in the final sprint after an 89.7-mile run from Valenciennes. But Andersen, who broke away from the field with Matthys midway through the stage, took the overall lead in the race from one of his teammates, Jean-Louis Gauthier of France.

title: GUNMAN IS SOUGHT IN 4TH RAPE AT PARK IN QUEENS
description: A young woman was raped at gunpoint over the weekend in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the fourth such incident there since May 11, the police said yesterday, prompting them to increase the number of officers patrolling the Queens park.

title: BRIEFING
description: Opening at the Pentagon

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I didn't look in the dugout because I didn't want to get more nervous.

title: Officer Says 2 YouthsConfessed to 4 Slayings
description: Two teen-agers arrested in the killings of four people in a robbery at an arcade have signed ''businesslike'' confessions and expressed no remorse about the slayings, a detective said today.

title: REFORM IN THE PAST: WHAT WENT WRONG?
description: EFFORTS now being made to improve science and mathematics education will fail unless they become part of the reform of all subjects and the entire school system. And if the new science curriculum is to succeed, it must focus on ''science for all,'' not just for future scientists.

title: Keller Haver Sets Test Of French Lemon Juice
description: Next month in one small Southern town and one Northeastern city, the Keller Haver agency will be testing which advertising assertion - all natural or ''The Gourmet Lemon Juice from France'' - will work best for a product they are introducing in this country for the first time.

title: Brazil Gets Debt Extension
description: Brazil, the most heavily indebted of the developing countries, has been given a two-week extension to repay a $400 million bridging loan from the Bank for International Settlements, European banking sources said today. The report was confirmed by a spokesman for Brazil's central bank in Brasilia.

title: Surgery for a Whaler
description: Pierre Lacroix, the Hartford Whaler defenseman, remained in the intensive-care unit of a Quebec hospital after a five-hour operation to repair a perforated aorta suffered in an automobile accident.

title: MCDONALD'S BAND AND AMAZON PLAY
description: TWO dissimilar jazz groups -Thiaga de Mello's nine-piece Amazon and the Tri-State McDonald's High School Jazz Ensemble - played a free jazz festival concert Sunday afternoon at the Damrosch bandshell at Lincoln Center to an audience that huddled under the trees to avoid the broiling sun.

title: U.S. HOCKEY SQUAD EMPHASIZES YOUTH
description: The youngest Olympic ice hockey team the United States has ever had was introduced today, when 27 players were named to the 1984 squad for the Winter Games. Selected at the National Sports Festival, which ended here Sunday, the group has an average age of 20.7 and includes 3 players who are still in high school.

title: SON-IN-LAW HELD IN TRIPLE MURDER AT A L.I. HOME
description: The 29-year-old son-in-law of a Long Island family found slain in an execution-style murder has confessed to killing the couple and their teen-age son so that his wife would receive a large inheritance, spokesmen for the Nassau County Police said early this morning.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Old-Timers' All-Star Game, at Chicago. Fourteen players who were named to the first All-Star Game at Comiskey Park in 1933 will celebrate its 50th anniversary there.

title: MEXICAN INDEMNITY ON BANKS
description: Stockholders in Mexico's nationalized banks will receive interest-bearing bonds to cover the shares they lost when the Government took over financial institutions last fall, the Finance Minstry announced today.

title: GIL EVANS, HIS MUSIC AND BAND
description: THE jazz festival's tributes to important jazz figures were all admirable in intent. But jazz is a living art, and all too often tributes to musicians who are no longer with us seem to have trouble recreating both the spirit and the musical substance of their subjects.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bicentennial Songs

title: WEST BANK PALESTINIANS' HOPE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR 6-DAY RUNNERS, THE ULTIMATE TEST
description: Jogging slowly, grabbing slices of watermelon as they kept on, 21 men and three women began the New York Six-Day Run yesterday. When the race started at 4:12 P.M., officials said the temperature was 104 degrees on the track at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. If the forecasts hold up, the runners will encounter scorching heat and possibly thunderstorms. They will average only two and one-half hours of sleep a day, but they say they are not masochists.

title: HELP FOR SETTLERS STIRS ISRAELI POOR
description: The Government's generous financial aid to Israelis who move out to settlements in the occupied West Bank has begun to set off a small backlash among Jews from impoverished Jerusalem neighborhoods, who argue that they should receive the same help if they stay in the city and try to improve their housing here.

title: A Profitable Shift on Nonprofits
description: After a second look at the question of taxing nonprofit institutions, Mayor Koch has taken a step back that is actually a good step forward. The nimble Mayor deserves credit for letting the evidence change his mind.

title: Nevada Governor Says Errors Led to Flooding
description: Floods that killed six people and caused millions of dollars damage along the lower Colorado River were caused by a ''monumental mistake'' in Federal computer projections of snow meltoff flow along a system of dams, Nevada Gov. Richard Bryan said today.

title: Ariane Rocket Contracts
description: The European Space Agency, which is competing against the United States in the lucrative satellitelaunching market, today announced two new contracts for its Ariane rockets worth $130 million. One contract is for the launching of the European Telecommunications Satellite, Olympus, in 1986 and the other is for three European Meteosat weather satellites between 1987 and 1990.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Staten Island Soliloquy: Secede, or Not Secede

title: TUESDAY, JULY 5, 1983; International
description: Worldwide economic recovery and baking stability is at stake if a significant portion of $700 billion in debt amassed by developing nations should be repudiated, bankers and economists say. Political conflicts further complicate the issue. (A1.)

title: SONGS AND STORIES OF 30'S
description: AN evening of songs of the Depression years of the 30's, presented at Town Hall on Sunday, the final evening of the Kool Jazz Festival, was built on the idea that during those hard times there were many escapist songs as well as doleful songs and that for musicians, like everyone else, life was more difficult.

title: PREMIER OF SOVIET WARNS KOHL ON BID TO DEPLOY MISSILES
description: Yuri V. Andropov canceled his first meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany here today, but Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov, who took the Soviet leader's place, exchanged blunt remarks with Mr. Kohl.

title: LOWER EAST SIDE DRUG TRADE EVADES CLEANUP
description: Sixty-five tenements on the Lower East Side of Manhattan have been demolished and 121 buildings have been sealed there in the past year as part of a program started by the city to try to eliminate the lucrative drug industry that operates in abandoned buildings.

title: McCumber Beats Watson by Shot
description: Mark McCumber came from seven shots behind with rounds of 4-under-par 68 and 71 to beat Tom Watson by a shot today in the 36-hole finish to the Western Open golf tournament.

title: Dollar Jumps; Gold Is Stable
description: The dollar rose sharply on world currency markets today on the strength of an unexpected increase in the United States money supply. Gold prices were little changed.

title: THREAT TO TREES EASED BY A DROP IN GYPSY MOTHS
description: This year, for the second year in a row, the gypsy moth population has dropped sharply in the New York metropolitan area, according to state and Federal forestry officials.

title: Taming the Wild Bee
description: Scientists with the Federal Agricultural Research Service have found that a species of wild bee may be a more efficient pollinator of some food crops than the common honeybee. As a result, the researchers have attempted to colonize the wild bees which, unlike the social honeybees, lead solitary lives.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE sight was almost staggering. Norma Kamali, the New York designer, was conducting a tour of the s tore being built for her on 56th Street and to do it she wore a pairo f metal-studded high heels and a black cotton jersey jumpsuit that f it the way a black cotton jersey jumpsuit should - snugly.

title: Kenyan Captures Peachtree Race
description: Michael Musyoki, a marathon runner from Kenya who studies business at Texas-El Paso, led a field of 28,000 runners today in winning the Peachtree Road Race, a 10-kilometer event down Peachtree Street, Atlanta's main thoroughfare.

title: SHULTZ FLIES TO SAUDI ARABIA TO TEST LEBANON PROSPECTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here today intent on finding out, according to American officials, how hard Saudi Arabia is prepared to press Syria to withdraw its forces from Lebanon.

title: Ex-Marketer of Perrier To Sell French Wines
description: Bruce S. Nevins thinks Americans like to drink French. He brought Perrier, the effervescent mineral water, to the United States in the 1970's, and now he has moved on to something a bit harder: French wine.

title: Advertising; Agency's Rebate Test
description: COLORADO was the setting over the weekend for the beginning of a test, by Bacardi Imports, of a major American Express entry into the growing couponing/rebate war.

title: Worker Lost in Mine Blast
description: A coal mine inspector has been missing since an explosion ripped through a shaft Saturday, and rescue workers have little hope of finding him alive, officials said today. Bruce Dallas, spokesman for the state Department of Environmental Resources, said there was a heavy buildup of explosive methane gas in the mine where Lee Mitsko of the Helen Mining Company was working when the explosion occurred.

title: East River Barge Blast Laid to Faulty Valves
description: The barge in the East River on which an explosion injured two men Sunday had faulty safety valves, fire officials said yesterday. The explosion on the barge occurred at 5:50 A.M. Sunday, shortly after the barge had unloaded gasoline at a dock in the Bronx.

title: Work to Start On Rail Line
description: Construction begins this week in Wyoming and Nebraska on the second-longest stretch of railroad tracks built anywhere in the United States in more than a half-century.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: TERM RATES Last Week (In Percent) Tax-Exempt Bonds* 9.36 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer.

title: 4 U.S. Bishops Meet Pope
description: Pope John Paul II held private audiences today with four United States Bishops. The Pope met separately with Bishops Joseph H. Hodges of Wheeling-Charleston, W. Va., John L. Morkovsky of Galveston-Houston, Tex., James J. Hogan of Altoona-Johnstown, Pa., and John A. Marshall of Burlington, Vt.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wanted: A Change of Scene

title: INFLUENCE OF SUB-CABINET CONSERVATIVES IS MIXED
description: In a recent speech, President Reagan said, ''For the first time in half a century, we've developed a whole new cadre of young conservatives in Government.''

title: Economic Scene; 'Expectations' And 'Reality'
description: THE second half of 1983 begins with economists voicing increasing confidence about the strength of the recovery and investment advisers expressing growing concern about the outlook for the stock market.

title: Dome Debt Extension
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., Canada's largest and most indebted energy producer, announced yesterday that it had received an eight-week extension of its July 5 deadline for repayment of $2 billion of its $6.35 billion total debt. Dome came close to bankruptcy last year when it was unable to repay $1.35 billion of principal to four big Canadian banks.

title: A Canadien Returns
description: The Montreal Canadiens returned to their past for another of their former stars to assist Coach Bob Berry. Jacques Plante, a veteran of 17 N.H.L. seasons and a member of the Hall of Fame, signed a two-year contract as a special goaltending coach.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Raspberries in Chocolate

title: Highest Soviet Award Is Given to Jaruzelski
description: The Soviet Union today bestowed its highest award, the Order of Lenin, on the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. The award marked General Jaruzelski's 60th birthday, and Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported that it was made ''in recognition of his services in the development of the fraternal friendship and cooperation'' between Poland and the Soviet Union.

title: Kaypro Planning First Sale of Stock
description: The Kaypro Corporation, a maker of portable computers, said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial public offering of 5 million shares, to be made through Prudential Bache Securities Inc.

title: Canadian Vision
description: There is a nightmare that troubles some major league baseball fans. The World Series is staged in mid-October between the only two teams in the major leagues that are situated in Canada.

title: BALDWIN SELLS 5 LOAN UNITS TO HUTTON
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which averted bankruptcy last week and is now trying to raise cash, yesterday announced the sale of its five mortgage banking subsidiaries to E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: LOUISIANA REPEALS BLACK BLOOD LAW
description: Gov. David C. Treen today signed legislation repealing a Louisiana statute that established a mathematical formula to determine if a person was black.

title: A LIFE ON THE RUN CAN SEEM HOMEY
description: The days begin early at Camp Lebow. When a runner lifts the flap of his or her tent on these steamy summer mornings and steals a peek at the world outside, he or she probably will see another runner already busy circling the track at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, counting the miles while others sleep.

title: ISRAELIS PLANNING PARTIAL PULLBACK OF THEIR TROOPS
description: Israel will undertake a partial, staged pullback of its troops to more secure positions in Lebanon, turning over the territory to the Lebanese Army, Israeli officials said today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: With the ink barely dry on a $918 million deal to buy Norton Simon Inc., the big consumer products company, Donald P. Kelly, 61-yearold chairman and chief executive of Esmark Inc., leaves for London today on a mission of good will - and hard dollars.

title: Envoy Is Hopeful On Hostages in Sudan
description: A diplomat said today that he expected a breakthrough in negotiations with guerrillas holding five Western aid workers in the Sudan.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's auction of $100 million of its 91-day commercial paper drew an average bid of 9.42 percent, up from 9.355 percent last week.

title: A BAD DEAL FOR THE CONRAIL WORK FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Reunion of Rangers
description: Beginning with the 1948-49 National Hockey League season and three seasons thereafter, Emile Francis was the Rangers' goalie and Jack (Tex) Evans a Ranger defenseman. More than 30 years later, the two are expected to be reunited with the Hartford Whalers, for whom Francis was recently named president and general manager.

title: The U.N. Today; July 6, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on World Disar- mament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INTEREST RATES SHARPLY HIGHER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, with the longer-term Treasury issues bearing the brunt of a broad decline in prices.

title: A U.S. OMISSION IN SUPPORTING SOUTH AFRICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: NEAR VAL D'AOSTA, Italy WHERE this is being written is not exactly Val d'Aosta. That's down there in the valley somewhere, about 3,000 feet below the clouds. This tiny Alpine village clinging to the side of a snow-capped mountain is called Salasses. Off to the west is Mont Blanc, or Monte Bianco as they call it around here, and the Swiss border is a 10- or 12-mile hike away, most of it decidedly uphill.

title: TOP OFFICIAL IN BRIDGE INVESTIGATION
description: Shortly after midnight on June 28, J. William Burns and his wife, Ann-Sylvia, went to bed. They had just finished packing for a vacation in Scandinavia that was to begin that afternoon.

title: EX-DIRECTOR OF PEMEX FACES LOSS OF IMMUNITY
description: Three committees of Mexico's Congress, beginning the process that could allow the former head of the national oil company to be prosecuted for fraud, have voted that ''the acts attributable'' to him ''are susceptible to being considered crimes.''

title: Correct Film Listings For 6 Revival Programs
description: The listing of film revivals in The Guide on Sunday carried next week's programs instead of this week's for six theaters. Here are correct listings of those theaters' programs for the rest of this week: Bleecker Street Cinema - Wednesday: Paul Morrisey's ''Trash'' (1970) and David Lynch's ''Eraserhead'' (1976). Thursday: Francesco Rosi's ''Eboli'' (1980). Friday-Saturday: Lina Wertmuller's ''Swept Away'' (1975) and ''Seven Beauties'' (1976). 144 Bleecker Street. (674-2560) Cinema Village - Wednesday-Thursday: Francois Truffaut's ''Last Metro'' (1980) and ''Day for Night'' (1973). Friday-Saturday: John Huston's ''Fat City'' (1972) and Dennis Hopper's ''Easy Rider'' (1969). 12th Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

title: FOR PITTING CHERRIES
description: FOREMOST among summertime's culinary delights, for me, are fresh cherries. Every summer when I see them in local markets it sparks memories of my grandmother, who used to make a wonderful sour-cherry tart that I can remember as if it were yesterday.

title: PLAYED WITH JULLIARD QUARTET
description: Claus Adam, a composer and cellist who played with the Juilliard String Quartet for 19 years, died Monday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 65 years old and had been in a coma since a stroke on June 9.

title: CITY OPERA STRIKE SEEN AS TALKS BREAK DOWN
description: Talks at the New York State Theater between the New York City Opera and its orchestra broke off again yesterday evening, making almost certain a strike by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians before tomorrow's scheduled opening night.

title: Inquiry on Crash Cause Continues in Kentucky
description: Investigators said today they had not been able to determine whether speed, bad weather or mechanical failure caused a church bus to swerve off Interstate 71 and tumble down a 140-foot embankment, killing two people and injuring 30.

title: Race Postponed
description: The sixth yacht race in the second roundrobin series among America's Cup challengers was postponed today because of thick fog on Rhode Island Sound.

title: U.S. CURBS IMPORTS OF SPECIALTY STEEL
description: President Reagan today granted four years of trade protection to American producers of specialty steel. The move angered nations that export steel to the United States and only partly appeased the domestic industry.

title: Revised and Extended
description: One way to make politicians look silly is to quote their careless speech. The cure for this in Congress is the favor, generously extended to members, to ''revise and extend'' remarks they make on the official record.

title: Investors Control Capitol Air
description: A group of investors active in the New York real estate business reached an agreement to buy 1.7 million shares, or 54.9 percent, of Capitol Air's outstanding stock.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 600 Waging Fight To Clean Up Subways

title: Japan-U.S.  Talks on Oil
description: Japan and the United States held discussions today on the possibility of shipping Alaskan oil across the Pacific to Asia, diplomatic sources said.

title: Two Bouts Canceled
description: Two 10-round bouts this month featuring the former three-time world champion Alexis Arguello, and the current World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion, Aaron Pryor, have been canceled, Caesars Palace Hotel in Las Vegas announced yesterday.

title: Pillsbury Stokely Stake
description: The Pillsbury Company, which has made a bid of $62 a share for Stokely-Van Camp Inc., said today that it had purchased 241,935 shares of Stokely and had agreements to buy an additional 258,065 shares. That block would make up about 18.1 percent of Stokely's outstanding common stock, and 17.4 percent of its voting securities. Pillsbury's offer, valued at about $170 million, is conditioned upon a minimum of 1.1 million additional shares being tendered.

title: Kean Signs Bill On Lethal Injection
description: TRENTON July 5 - Governor Kean today signed a bill making lethal injection the state's method of capital punishment. New Jersey is the ninth state to authorize the injection of a quick-acting lethal substance.

title: AMERICANS MARRYING LATER
description: Americans seem to be reverting to the patterns of their great-grandparents, postponing marriage in favor of education and a career, a new Census Bureau study shows.

title: BOSTON FIRM MAY BREATHE NEW LIFE INTO CITICORP SITE
description: With the changing tide in the Manhattan office market, the once troubled site at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street, one of the largest undeveloped plots in midtown, seems to have acquired a new future.

title: REAGAN'S APOLOGISTS ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 6, 1983
description: International Israel plans a partial pullback of its troops to more secure positions in Lebanon, turning over territory to the Lebanese Army, according to Israeli officials. Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the pullback, which is called a ''redeployment'' in Jerusalem, would be carried out in stages, with the Lebanese Army and the multinational peacekeeping forces asked to take control of areas left by Israeli forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) No accord to resolve a P.L.O. mutiny has been reached after three days of negotiations, according to the chief of a six-member Palestine Liberation Organization team seeking to mediate the split between Yasir Arafat and anti-Arafat rebels. (A6:1-4.)

title: Breaking a Habit
description: Jose Oquendo, the Mets' shortstop, has built a reputation with his glove as one of the finest defensive infielders in the game. But it is taking the 20-year-old rookie two gloves to break a bad habit.

title: Philadelphia Sale Of Notes Canceled
description: Philadelphia announced yesterday that it had canceled the sale of $150 million of temporary loan notes. It also said it was putting off a sale of $75 million of commercial paper that would have followed the note sale.

title: G.M.'S FLEET PRICES TO RISE 1% to 3%
description: The General Motors Corporation told dealers today that it expected to post price increases of 1 to 3 percent on its 1984 cars and trucks sold in early orders to fleet owners.

title: Fire Department Adds 142 Recruits
description: The New York City Fire Department swore in 142 probationary firefighters yesterday to begin six weeks of what Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinnato told them would be ''a period of rigorous and demanding training.''

title: N.E.A. IN SUPPORT OF MINORITY HIRING
description: The National Education Association voted today to support certain affirmative action programs that would permit the dismissal of white teachers with seniority so that lessexperienced teachers who are members of minorities could keep their jobs.

title: ENVOY SEEKS TALKS WITH SALVADOR REBELS
description: Administration officials said today that Richard B. Stone, President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, would try to talk with Salvadoran guerrilla leaders on a trip to the region he is scheduled to begin Thursday.

title: Boston's Harvard Bridge Closed to Heavy Trucks
description: The heavily traveled Massachusetts Avenue Bridge, also known as the Harvard Bridge, was closed indefinitely to heavy truck and bus traffic today after inspectors found cracks in bridge supports, officials of the Metropolitan District Commission said.

title: RICHARD GREEN
description: Richard Green, a boxing referee who officiated at the 1980 heavyweight title fight here between Larry Holmes and Muhammad Ali, died at his North Las Vegas home last Friday. He was 46 years old. The county coroner's office ruled his death a suicide. Mr. Green was a native of Louisiana and was a Golden Gloves boxer in the 1960's.

title: Utility Curb on Bank Is Kept
description: A state judge today called ''premature'' the Chemical Bank's attempts to lift court restraints that prevent Chemical from forcing the Washington Public Power Supply System to default officially on bonds floated to construct two abandoned nuclear power plants.

title: CASEY SAYS HE 'WOULDN'T TOUCH' PAPERS FROM THE CARTER CAMPAIGN
description: William J. Casey said today that it would have been ''totally uncharacteristic and quite incredible'' for him to have obtained President Carter's debate strategy plans for use by the aides who prepared Ronald Reagan for the 1980 campaign debate with Mr. Carter.

title: ANDROPOV STARTED STRONG. BUT NOW?
description: With Yuri V. Andropov running things, the Soviet Union's economy has made a small recovery. When he emerged as leader, it looked as if he would move vigorously to shape the economy. Now, increasingly, his own vigor suddenly looms as a concern.

title: Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., said its 60 percent owned unit, Union Carbide Australia, planned to sell its polyethylene operations at Altona, in Australia, to the Altona Petrochemical Company, in line with a forecast of extremely competitive conditions in the later 1980's for polyethylene. The 40 million Australian dollars to be received will have no material impact on the earnings of the parent company, Union Carbide said, adding that the deal requires approval of the Australian Government and shareholders of the Australian unit. The Australian unit will continue to make Eveready and Energizer batteries, industrial plastic film, Glad plastic bags and food wraps, aluminum foil and other products, Union Carbide said.

title: HARRY JAMES, TRUMPTER AND BAND LEADER, DIES AT 67
description: Harry James, a major figure of the swing era whose strong, urgent trumpet was a driving force in Benny Goodman's orchestra in the late 1930's and who formed a band of his own in 1939 that remained popular for more than 40 years, died yesterday in Valley Hospital in Las Vegas.

title: FIGHT OVER HOME VIDEOTAPING
description: The thorny controversy over whether consumers should be freely allowed to tape television programs off the air has been lying nearly dormant for 20 months, awaiting a ruling by the Supreme Court on whether such taping violates copyright laws.

title: Westchester Buses Idled by Walkout
description: Bus drivers and mechanics of the Mount Kisco Bus Line Inc. walked off the job today, halting service on three bus routes and inconveniencing 800 riders in northern and western Westchester and part of Putnam County.

title: Honduran Heads for U.S.
description: President Roberto Suazo Cordova left today for the United States. The reason for his visit was not disclosed. Last year he conferred with President Reagan in Washington and had a medical examination in Houston.

title: Accounts
description: * Masonite Corporation to Campbell-Mithun, Chicago, for its paneling and door lines.

title: CHINA'S HONG KONG VENTURES
description: In a city bustling with high finance and low intrigue, Wang Guangying has drawn more than the usual curiosity. He heads the new Everbright Industrial Corporation, which is taking over a highrise floor in Hong Kong's gold-colored Far East Finance Center.

title: 'Jedi' Print Stolen
description: A print of the film ''Return of the Jedi'' was stolen from a movie projectionist who was held hostage for two hours by an armed man, the police said. The value of the stolen print is between $5,000 and $15,000, but it could eventually be worth considerably more if transferred to tape for illegal use on the growing home video market.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Drew Middleton THE BATTLE FOR THE FALKLANDS. By Max Hastings and Simon Jenkins. 340 pages. $17.50. W.W. Norton & Com- pany.

title: RATE FEARS PUSH DOW DOWN 16.73
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday as Friday's announcement of an increase in the basic money supply and the specter of a rise in interest rates combined to shake investor confidence.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the job emergency program misstated the amount of Federal money New York City is to receive for community development. It is $952,000.

title: TV: BACHAUER PIANO COMPETITION
description: FOR two hours, beginning at 8 o'clock tonight, WNET-TV, Channel 13 will be offering a videotaped recording of the Gina Bachauer International Piano Competition that was held in Salt Lake City in June 1982. Actually, this is only the competition's concluding concert, featuring the three finalists who were chosen from among 54 entrants representing 10 countries.

title: ETHIOPIAN CONFLICTS: ALL IS NOT QUIET IN THE 'NORTHERN COMMAND'
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO WON'T GIVE THE M.T.A. ADVICE ON LAW ON DISABLED
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would not give any advice to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on how to deal with the current law that requires subway stations, if they are being rehabilitated, to be made accessible to the handicapped.

title: Natt Stays in Portland
description: Larry Weinberg, the owner of the Portland Trail Blazers, carried out his promise yesterday to match any offer tendered Calvin Natt, the free-agent forward. Under the right of first refusal, the Trail Blazers matched the offer sheet that the 6-foot-6-inch Natt had signed last Friday with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: McIver Expected To Quit Labor Post
description: Mayor Koch is expected to announce today the resignation of Bruce C. McIver, the city's chief labor negotiator. Mr. McIver, a 42-year-old native of Montana, plans to take a similar position with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, city officials said.

title: THE REGION;
description: A 29-year-old Long Island man was held in $3 million bail today on charges of murdering his wife's father, mother and brother to get their $150,000 estate.

title: Richard Burton Married To an Aide in New Film
description: Richard Burton was married for the fifth time Sunday during a break from his New York stage play co-starring Elizabeth Taylor, to whom he was twice married.

title: TO SAFEGUARD THE DOLLAR'S PURCHASING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REFRESHING FRUIT SHERBERTS
description: SOME people call them sherbets, some fruit ices, while others prefer the more fanciful term sorbet. But it's really too hot to quibble. Let's just call them exquisitely refreshing treats on sultry summer days and get on with it.

title: 10% of Redshaw To Lumbermens
description: The Hartford Insurance Group, a unit of the ITT Corporation, said it had agreed to sell a 10 percent stake in its Redshaw Inc. subsidiary, which supplies automated systems to insurance agencies, to the Lumbermens Mutual Casualty Corporation, parent of the Kemper Insurance Group, for an undisclosed price.

title: 23 Killed in Guinea Crash Of a North Korean Plane
description: A Soviet-built plane carrying North Korean construction workers crashed in a mountainous region of the west African nation of Guinea, killing at least 23 people, the Nigeria radio said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: The bell rang at 1 A.M. and Mr. Peterson opened the door to find his 10-year-old neighbor, Jean Ellen, standing there asleep with her eyes open. This wasn't the first time she had sleepwalked to his house so he knew just what to do: he walked her home and guided her upstairs to her room and into bed. Jean Ellen's parents, who made sure to double-lock the doors from then on so she could not get out, were troubled. Was her sanity involved? Was her safety threatened?

title: SHULTZ IS IN SYRIA TO PRESS PULLOUT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has apparently made little headway in his effort to find a formula for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.

title: HOWARD'S PRIORITY: BOOST METS' HITTING
description: Frank Howard was the last of the Mets to leave Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium Monday night, doing so just as thousands of fans began filing out of the stands after a postgame Fourth of July fireworks display.

title: Aspiring Models
description: A t the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this week, 500 women, men and children are smiling their way through ''go-sees'' during the International Talent Modeling Schools and Agencies convention.

title: HOW FAMOUS NICKNAMES WERE BORN
description: What's in a name? That which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet. - Shakespeare, ''Romeo and Juliet''

title: CONFUSION REIGNING OVER W.B.C. TITLES
description: Larry Holmes will not be stripped of his title, but Marvis Frazier will not be fighting for it, if they meet this fall. Jose Sulaiman, the World Boxing Council's president, who has been threatening to withdraw recognition from so many champions that he can be called Jose the Stripper, says, ''I don't want to act on Larry Holmes.''

title: PROPOSALS TO SCREEN CHILDREN FOR LEAD POISONING DEBATED
description: ALTHOUGH she looks perfectly healthy, 7-year-old Tracey Galindez of Trenton may be facing permanent learning disabilities. And all that her mother and father can do is wait.

title: Jobs Saved, Minus Jobs Lost
description: The United Auto Workers union is pressing for legislation that would require foreign cars sold in America to be built in America. And obligingly, the House Commerce Committee has approved a ''domestic content'' bill. But the going in Congress will get tougher. Even the friends of organized labor now understand that such protectionist laws would increase car prices without creating many jobs. Indeed, by inviting retaliation, protection could, on balance, destroy jobs in America's export industries.

title: OILERS REACT TO DRUG PROBLEM
description: As bad as the 1982 season was for the Houston Oilers - they finished 1-8 - the months that followed were in some respects worse. In two incidents, three defensive backs who had been starters when the season began were arrested on charges of drug or alcohol abuse.

title: New Tunnel Open After Slide
description: Trains are rolling again through central Utah with the opening of a tunnel bypassing a huge mud slide that severed tracks through Spanish Fork Canyon in April.

title: Airport in Afghan Capital Is Reportedly Attacked
description: Rebels attacked the Kabul airport and Soviet military air base with rockets and machine guns, damaging some of Afghanistan's American-built DC-10 jetliners, a diplomat said today.

title: Drug Tests Derided
description: Dr. Allan Ryan, the secretary general of the International Federation of Sports Medicine, attending the World University Games in Edmonton, Alberta, called the testing of athletes for the illegal use of drugs was ''the biggest scam in sports.'' Dr. Ryan said, ''Testing is futile. Athletes will sort out the situation for themselves.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball All-Star Game, at Chicago. Dave Stieb of the Toronto Blue Jays gets the start for the American League and will be trying to break an 11-game National League winning streak.

title: CHIEF OF P.L.O. MEDIATION TEAM SAYS RIFT REMAINS
description: The head of the six-man Palestine Liberation Organization mediation team trying to patch up the rift between Yasir Arafat and a group of anti-Arafat rebels indicated today that three days of talks in Damascus had not been able to produce a reconciliation.

title: Stormy 4th Leads to Fights
description: At least 10 people were injured and 14 were arrested as fights broke out at Point State Park after a thunderstorm interrupted a free Fourth of July concert by the Pittsburgh Symphony that was to have been followed by fireworks, the authorities said.

title: China Details Stock Offering
description: China announced some details today of the first Chinese stock offering to foreign investors in 34 years. Last month the official New China News Agency reported that the Sanhe Corporation of the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, near Hong Kong, planned to set up four enterprises by selling $25 million of stock to foreign investors.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error in The Living Section on June 29, the last two steps of a recipe for parsleyed rack of lamb were misplaced. Following is the correct recipe: Carre d'Agneau Persille (Parsleyed rack of lamb) 2 racks of lamb, about 2 1/2 pounds combined weight Salt to taste if desired Freshly ground pepper to taste 4 tablespoons butter plus butter for greasing baking dish 1/2 cup bread crumbs 3 tablespoons chopped parsley 1 clove garlic, finely minced 1 shallot, finely minced 1 teaspoon olive oil.

title: TWO OLD YANKEES REMEMBER
description: At the age of 68, Allie Reynolds says that baseball for him is now mostly a game of memories and sensations. The memories are stored in scrapbooks and photo albums around his home. The sensations, he says, are kept in his heart, and they resurface every time he is reminded of 1951.

title: Buckingham Leaves Scali
description: The Buckingham Corporation, an importer of alcoholic beverages, and Scali, McCabe, Sloves yesterday announced their decision to part company after six years.

title: 'Prevailing Wage' Ruling
description: A Federal Court of Appeals panel, dealing a blow to construction unions, today upheld a Labor Department proposal to lower wages that are required under a law originally passed to protect workers on Federal construction projects.

title: Second to None In Frustration
description: Most trainers would be thrilled to see one of their horses finish second in a rich and prestigious race like the Suburban Handicap Monday at Belmont Park. But after Allen Jerkens watched Sing Sing finish second to Winter's Tale, he rolled his eyes skyward with the look of a man under a hex.

title: ISRAELIS UPSET BY SPY NOVEL
description: A novel not widely read here and a movie based on it that has yet to be filmed have fueled debate in this nation especially sensitive to international opinion.

title: BASEBALL TRAINS-GONE LIKE LOU, TY
description: For years, baseball and the railroads shared kinship. The season and rail journey were both linear experiences with a beginning and an end, a series of prearranged stops, and a deliberate unfolding. For several hours each week, the experiences merged, since trains carried ball clubs from one assignment to another. For these hours, baseball and the railroads moved at the same luxurious pace.

title: The Pet Problem
description: Webster's defines a pet as ''an animal that is tamed or domesticated and kept as a companion or treated with fondness.'' Ask pet owners, and they'll say pets are all that and much more. For the lonely, a pet can be what Frankie in ''The Member of the Wedding'' called her brother and his fiance, ''the we of me''; for the very young, the only creature that really understands them; for the very old, the last responsibility, literally a raison d'etre.

title: SCHOOL THAT SHARPENS JUDGES'S SKILLS MARKS 2 DECADES OF UNUSUAL MISSION
description: A large bag of marijuana supplied by two undercover narcotics agents is passed around a classroom and sniffed curiously by the students. They have just heard a nondrinking alcoholic named Sue tell her life story, including the December day her neighbors found her singing naked on the roof.

title: Amritraj Outlasts A 17-Year-Old
description: Vijay Amritraj withstood a challenge from a 17-year-old in the first round the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame tennis tournament today.

title: People
description: * Thomas Hartje promoted to senior vice president at Needham, Harper & Steers International.

title: Safeguard Shares
description: Safeguard Scientifics Inc. said it had agreed to purchase more than 2 million shares, or 44.7 percent, of its stock within the next three years from Swiss American Securities Inc. Safeguard, a small machine-parts manufacturer based in King of Prussia, Pa., said it purchased 400,200 shares from Swiss American, a New York brokerage firm, last Friday for $1.8 million. It did not disclose terms for its purchase of the remaining 1.6 million shares. Swiss American acquired the stock in March 1982, after Gary Llewellyn, an Iowa stockbroker, defaulted on his account. Mr. Llewellyn was convicted last November on 15 counts of fraud and embezzlement.

title: Wise Guys Finish Last
description: Early in life I resolved to be as dumb as the next guy. It seemed to improve your survival chances. Thus I have made it a point never to learn the capital cities of the states because of a fear left over from childhood that if I do somebody will punch my nose for being a wise guy.

title: EX-COLLEGE AIDE ARRESTED IN ART THEFT
description: The former director of the art gallery at C.W. Post College in Greenvale was arrested today on charges that he stole several paintings and two sketchbooks from the gallery's permanent collection and tried to sell them to galleries on Long Island and in Manhattan, the Nassau County police said.

title: FILES SHOW DIOXIN MAKERS KNEW OF HAZARDS
description: The Dow Chemical Company knew as early as the middle 1960's about evidence that exposure to dioxin might cause people to become seriously ill and even die, but the company withheld its concern from the Government and continued to sell herbicides contaminated by dioxin to the Army and the public, according to documents opened to public inspection yesterday.

title: HOMECOMING SENATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Part of Guardrail Falls From Roof
description: A section of a guardrail fell from the roof of a 23-story office building at 488 Madison Avenue, between 51st and 52d Streets, at 8:16 A.M. yesterday, narrowly missing a pedestrian, the authorities said.

title: Back in the Swim
description: For someone who had just completed a swim of the English Channel, even though it took a lengthy 17 hours 55 minutes, Julie Ridge found herself strangely unhappy last September. The 26-year-old actress, who had appeared on Broadway in ''Oh! Calcutta!'' in 1981 and until May of 1982, when she began training for her Channel attempt, said she found herself ''very depressed.''

title: STORM DAMAGES SUBURBAN AREAS
description: After three sweltering days, the skies over New York City darkened yesterday afternoon and erupted in a brief explosion of thunder, lightning and rain that dropped temperatures into the 70's.

title: AUCTION SALES OF ART IN U.S. IMPROVE
