description: The world's two top auction houses yesterday released annual United States sales figures, indicating that last year's downward slide has been arrested in part and that both houses have shown gains in such important sales areas as jewelry and Impressionist, modern and post-World War II art.

title: DESEGREGATION PLAN FOR ST. LOUIS REGION APPROVED BY JUDGE
description: A school desegregation plan that would exchange students voluntarity between St. Louis, which has a largely black enrollment, and its mostly white suburbs was approved today by a Federal district judge.

title: Unicare Bought By Extendicare
description: Extendicare Ltd., of Toronto, announced that it had completed the acquisition of all the outstanding and issued shares of Unicare Services Inc., a Milwaukee-based health-care company, for $142.9 million (United States).

title: APPALACHIAN TRAIL GETS BUFFER ZONE
description: Sixty years after its first section was opened, the Appalachian Trail is still changing shape. ''The length of the trail changes almost daily because of land acquisition,'' said Laurence R. Van Meter, executive director of the Appalachian Trail Conference. ''Someday,'' he added, ''that won't happen.''

title: Mitsumi Venture With Commodore
description: Commodore International, a leading manufacturer of personal computers, and the Mitsumi Electric Company of Japan said they had established a joint-venture concern to develop and make floppy-disk drives in Japan.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Steel Export Co. has named Michael C. Ferrara president and chief operating officer, succeeding Lawrence C. Hickey, who is retiring.

title: SOVIET INVOKES GERMAN PARTITION IN WARNING KOHL ON NEW MISSILES
description: Yuri V. Andropov today warned the visiting West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, that deployment of new American missiles in Germany would create a serious new military threat to West Germany, damage its relations with Moscow and line the gulf between the two Germanys with ''thick palisades of missiles.''

title: Bridge:; Latest Book by Blackwood A New Sign of His Talents
description: Writers of bridge columns often continue to a great age, but when it comes to books there are few major contributions by authors over the age of 70. A new record in this department appears to have been set recently by Easley Blackwood, inventor of the convention that bears his name.

title: Chrysler Reported To Plan 2 Engines
description: The Chrysler Corporation is considering expanding its current four-cylinder gasoline engine and also building a V-6 engine to keep up with consumer demand for performance vehicles, an industry report said.

title: EX-U.S. AGENTS TELL OF EFFORTS TO HELP BARBIE
description: Former United States intelligence agents have provided new details about how they hid Klaus Barbie, the Nazi war criminal, from the French authorities and helped him flee Europe in 1951.

title: Instead, Prove Insanity
description: The Supreme Court has confirmed the utility of a modest reform in the insanity defense. If Congress and the states will put the burden on the defendant to prove he's insane, instead of requiring the prosecutor to prove sanity, several problems disappear -and drastic changes in law can be avoided.

title: Patricia Neal Divorced
description: The actress Patricia Neal divorced the author Roald Dahl today, ending a 30-year marriage that was itself the subject of a film. The television film, which starred Glenda Jackson and Dirk Bogarde, showed how Mr. Dahl nursed Miss Neal back to health after she suffered a series of brain hemorrhages in 1965. Miss Neal won an Academy Award for her performance in ''Hud'' in 1953.

title: WASTE BINS IN PLANES' LAVATORIES FACE INSPECTIONS OVER FIRE SAFETY
description: Increasing concern about lavatory fires on airliners has prompted a Government order for inspection of waste bins to insure that access doors fit tight and can keep trash fires from spreading.

title: DANIEL J. CRIMMINS
description: Daniel J. Crimmins, former vice president of the industrial products division of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, died of a heart ailment Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 6, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices declined sharply as investors reacted to a $600 million increase in the money supply and reports that the Federal Reserve is thinking of raising the discount rate. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.73 points, to 1,208.53. Volume on the Big Board edged up to 67.3 million shares from Friday's preholiday turnover of 65.1 million shares. (Page D1.)

title: Trucks From I-95 Snarl Port Chester
description: Trucks rerouted through this village by last week's collapse of the Mianus River bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike continued to snarl traffic today as officials met to discuss the problem.

title: Angolan Rebels Claim Town
description: Angolan guerrillas in the Union for the Total Independence of Angola said today that they captured the town of Mussende in the coastal province of Kwanza Sul on Sunday, killing 248 Government soldiers. The guerrilla group, with South African support, has been fighting the Marxist Government of Angola since 1975.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy's Poll Showing

title: Russians Capture 4 Swim Events
description: The Soviet Union continued its domination in the swimming events of the World University Games tonight with victories in four of five events.

title: Careers; This Age Of Flexible Benefits
description: ''I 'M buying two extra weeks of vacation,'' an engineer for the Exxon Corporation said at a party. It seems he was planning to take his family on a six-week trip to Europe, although he was normally entitled to receive only four weeks of vacation.

title: JUSTICES LIMIT CLIENT'S ROLE IN DEFENSE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 7 to 2, that an appointed lawyer representing an indigent defendant on appeal does not have a constitutional duty to argue every issue that his client wants to raise.

title: Court Explains Ruling On Offshore Oil Leases
description: A Federal appellate court, upholding Interior Secretary James G. Watt's five-year offshore oil-leasing plan, said today that Mr. Watt went beyond legal requirements for considering risks and benefits to the public.

title: Third Victim of Tampa Fire
description: A 4-year-old girl today became the third person to die after being sloshed with gasoline in a supermarket and set afire.

title: U.S. Plans Mideast Exercise
description: About 7,000 American soldiers will hold military exercises in Egypt, Somalia, the Sudan and Oman next month to test their ability to fight in the area's hot summer months, defense informants said today. Earlier exercises in the region were staged in the winter, and the informants said the Pentagon wanted this year's maneuvers to be held when the weather was at its hottest in the countries participating.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AAV Cos., a Cleveland concern, said the sale of its vending/food service and wholesale distribution businesses had been halted by the unnamed prospective purchaser.

title: Hercules Inc.  Dispute Settled
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said today that it had settled a dispute with Hercules Inc. over a joint venture and that, as a result, it would receive a $3.7 million payment from the venture.

title: CURRIER AND IVES SHOW, A RELIVING OF THE 1800'S
description: They were bullish on America, and America loved them. For half of the 19th century, their pictures, many of startling immediacy, chronicled the dreams and catastrophes, cityscapes and landscapes, heroes and villains and everyday events of a young, muscle-flexing nation. Before photographs made Currier and Ives obsolete, at least one of their lithographs had found its way into virtually every home in the country.

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS TEXAS BANK TAX
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 6 to 2, that states may not levy a tax on a bank's assets without deducting the value of Federal notes and bonds that the bank holds.

title: REAGAN IMPLIES THAT N.E.A. LESSONS ARE AIMED AT BRAINWASHING STUDENTS
description: President Reagan, continuing his offensive on education issues, accused the nation's largest teachers union today of efforts aimed at ''brainwashing American schoolchildren.''

title: Udall Opens Drive in Arizona For Favorite Son Nomination
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, seeking to give Arizona more leverage in Washington if the next President is a Democrat, has opened a campaign to be Arizona's favorite -son candidate at the 1984 Democratic National Convention.

title: FRANCE DROPS PLAN FOR WORLD'S FAIR ON BICENTENNIAL OF ITS REVOLUTION
description: The French Government abandoned plans today to hold a 1989 World's Fair here, thus ending months of controversy over an exhibition the ruling Socialists had hoped would be a tribute to their achievements - and France's - on the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced t hat Bryan Burns, director of marketing a nd broadcasting for the Kansas City R oyals, has been named director of broad- c asting for major league baseball. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Acquired Gay- l ord Perry, pitcher, on waivers from Seat- t le; sent Russ Stephans, catcher, to O maha of the American Association.

title: CHAD, REPORTING HEAVY FIGHTING, SEEKS FRENCH AID
description: President Hissen Habre said today that heavy fighting had broken out in eastern Chad, with Libyan-backed insurgent forces embarked on a push apparently aimed at a town 450 miles east northeast of this capital. He appealed to France to intervene ''to repulse this external aggression.''

title: Swiss Bicyclist Wins Tour Stage
description: Serge Demierre of Switzerland, staging a lone breakaway, won the fourth and longest stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, but Kim Andersen of Denmark retained the overall lead.

title: Carriage Flips in Park Injuring Four Tourists
description: Four tourists from Ontario received minor injuries yesterday when the horse-drawn carriage they were riding in overturned in Central Park, according to a police spokesman.

title: Maoists in Peru Set Off 25 Bombs in One City
description: Guerrillas simultaneously set off more than 25 bombs in Ayacucho on Monday night, and shortly afterward about 45 rebels attacked a civil guard post outside the city.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WELCOME to Scam City. Our tale today comes from a normally mildmannered publishing house editor named Vance Muse, recent victim of an old sidewalk swindle we shall call the Rare Coin Caper. The tale features a phony bum, a doctor who is not a doctor, a chase scene and a surprise ending. At least Mr. Muse was surprised.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. POLICY CONTRASTED
description: It is no exaggeration to say that, aided by the Lebanese-Israeli agreement, Washington plans to further consolidate its military presence in the Middle East and to increase its military contingents staying there under the flag of an ''international force.'' At the same time, American military activities in close proximity to the Soviet frontiers are accompanied by allegations that the Soviet Union is nurturing plans for an armed invasion of the region with a view to seizing oil-bearing areas.

title: INVESTIGATORS CHARGE CONTRACTORS FORMED 'CLUB' FOR TAX FRAUD
description: Federal investigators say they have uncovered evidence of multimillion-dollar fraudulent schemes and instances of tax evasion by a group of New York City building contractors who secretly banded together and called themselves ''the Club.''

title: Required Reading
description: No Chance to Fish

title: A PENTAGON NEWSPAPER CONSISTING OF CLIPPINGS
description: At 2 A.M. each weekday, Daniel Friedman is reading and clipping newspaper articles from America's major dailies, preparing a collection of what the Pentagon considers to be the top military reports of the day.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE conviction that progress is both necessary and inevitable is as American as apple pie. And it is this idea that has profoundly shaped our understanding of jazz, which is perhaps the most American of all our art forms.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALES OF THE SHTETL

title: SOTO AND STIEB START FOR STARS
description: Baseball reconstructed a piece of its history today when 90 stars of the past gathered on the home field of the Chicago White Sox, where the first All-Star Game was played 50 years ago.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My husband came home with several fresh conch shells from the ocean. I was at a loss as to whether they may be cooked and eaten. Can you tell me?

title: Factory Production Up
description: The world's industrialized nations posted a 2.1 percent jump in factory production for the first quarter of 1983 that snapped a 12-month decline, the International Monetary Fund said today. The fund said that Canada led the way with a 5.8 percent surge in industrial output, while Finland posted a 4.1 percent gain over the last quarter of 1982. Factory production in the United States rose 2.2 percent to reverse a decline that began during the third quarter of 1981.

title: Woman Said to Bear Girl Long After Brain Death
description: A 3-pound 11-ounce girl was born today to a brain-dead woman who has been kept breathing mechanically for 84 days since a seizure in April, a newspaper reported.

title: RELAXED STYLES FOR SUMMER
description: THIS time of year, men's fashions tend to lose their businesslike demeanor and take on an air of summer casualness. Take the three outfits here, for instance, which have little in common with each other, except that all convey a cool, unhurried feeling.

title: Royals Acquire Perry
description: Gaylord Perry, the oldest pitcher in the major leagues, was acquired on a waiver claim yesterday by the Kansas City Royals. Perry, 44 years old, had been designated for assignment 10 days earlier by the Seattle Mariners.

title: U.S.F.L. TO ADD 2 TEAMS
description: Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League, said today that the league will announce the awarding of two more expansion franchises ''within five days.''

title: GAZPACHO: VERSATILE SOUP
description: GAZPACHO, the cold soup from Spain, is a popular summer dish that offers many variations. The name is Arabic, meaning ''soaked bread,'' and many traditional recipes call for mixing bread with the other ingredients as a thickener. The origins of gazpacho are said to be ancient; it was introduced into southern Spain by the Moors.

title: Sanderson Sidelined
description: The right-hander Scott Sanderson will be lost from the Montreal Expos' starting pitching rotation for at least 12 weeks because of an injured thumb, the team said yesterday.

title: U.S. SOCCER TEAMS IN ACTION
description: The United States has long been criticized in soccer circles for failing to develop national and Olympic teams that could compete favorably with those of the rest of the world.

title: ON SOVIET-CHINA BORDER, THE THAW IS JUST A TRICKLE
description: This bustling Central Asian city is barely 100 miles from China, yet for 20 years it has had virtually no contact with the other side of the frontier.

title: Widow's Suit on Cancer And Fallout Dismissed
description: A Federal district judge ruled here today that above-ground atomic bomb testing in Nevada in the early 1950's and 1960's did not cause cancer in a northeastern Utah man.

title: AN OLD-TIMER RETAINS SWING
description: CHICAGO B illy Williams still works in the business of hitting baseballs. His specialty now is teaching, as the hitting instructor for the Oakland A's. Once every two to three weeks, Williams can walk into a batting cage and swing at more than a dozen pitches. ''I figure that's enough,'' he said.

title: Head of Two Divisions Named President of Izod
description: Izod Ltd., the General Mills subsidiary with the alligator emblem, announced yesterday that Robert Tutnauer, hired five months ago to head the unit's small international and accessories divisions, had been named to the presidency and to a newly created position as chief operating officer.

title: All-Male Begin Cabinet Is Joined by a Woman
description: Sara Doron, a member of the Liberal Party, was inducted tonight as Minister Without Portfolio. She is the first woman to become a minister in Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government.

title: Penthouse Cuts Back Its Rate Base by 15%
description: Judging from what has been happening to the circulations of Playboy and Penthouse magazines, the economy has had a negative impact on hedonism, or at least reading about it.

title: ICE CREAM VERY MUCH THE THING IN SICILY
description: When art collectors travel they look for good buys in paintings and prints. Dedicated gardeners may try to carry home seeds and cuttings rolled into their most personal effects. Antiques buffs search out ancient porcelains and other fragments of bygone eras. Those with a high-fashion bent shop for fabrics, scarves and handbags. The only things a food lover can carry home are savory memories, some extra pounds, a cookbook or two, and ideas for duplicating or adapting dishes enjoyed en route.

title: SUMMARY OF MAJOR ACTIONS BY NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN '83
description: The 206th session of the Legislature was the first chance for the new Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, to make his mark on the state government. He won swift approval for most of his nominees to state posts, and came to a harmonious agreement with the legislative leaders on a new state budget - including nearly $1 billion in taxes.

title: THE CITY
description: A defendant in the Brink's trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan lost his bid yesterday to be treated as a ''prisoner of war.''

title: STATE COURT LIMITS HYPNOTISM AS TOOL
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that hypnosis is an unreliable tool for refreshing memories and that testimony induced by hypnotism should therefore not be allowed in court.

title: Coal Projection Drops
description: The National Coal Association today revised its projection of 1983 coal production to 780 million tons, the lowest level since 1979. Last December, the trade group predicted that production this year would reach 837 million tons.

title: WHAT TV CAN'T SEE IN THE CAPITAL
description: There was a certain irony in watching major news stories unfold in the past few weeks. There was Pope John Paul II preaching freedom to huge throngs in Poland, which has known little freedom throughout its tortured history. And there was the Congressional budget resolution working its way through the legislative mills.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BACK in the days when I was an apprentice chef, virtually every salad we made was served either cold or at room temperature. We rarely if ever served a lukewarm salad. Salads then were long on fairly heavy vegetables such as potatoes, carrots and green beans.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 6 From Fidelity Union Join Carteret Thrift Unit
description: Robert J. Mueller prefers the word ''transition'' in describing the sudden move that brought him and five other Fidelity Union Bank officers to the Carteret Savings and Loan Association last month. Others call it corporate raiding; most agree there will be more of it in the savings and loan industry.

title: Fears for Heater Safety Said to Be Unfounded
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission's concern last fall about the safety of kerosene heaters has proved to be largely unfounded, staff scientists told the commission today.

title: BABE BAPTIZED ALL-STAR GAME
description: CHICAGO T o honor baseball's most famous player, a 20-cent Babe Ruth stamp will go on sale before the 50th anniversary All-Star Game at Comiskey Park tonight. If only the mail would move now as fast as Babe lived. Or as fast as his All-Star home run soared into the right-field stands half a century ago. That's when the Babe put his own stamp on the first All-Star Game, a stamp that made it official. At the time, the All-Star Game had been created to coincide with the World's Fair here as a one-time-only event. But after Babe Ruth baptized it in a 4-2 victory for the American League, the All-Star Game has flourished as one of baseball's traditional treasures.

title: EMPLOYMENT OF CHAPLAINS UPHELD FOR PRAYER IN LEGISLATIVE SESSIONS
description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule today on whether the taping of television programs at home violates copyright law. Page D1.

title: NOUVELLE CUISINE INSPIRES SALADS AS CENTERPIECES
description: THE salad has come a long way lately in this country. To realize just how far, you need only glance back at the typical restaurant menu of a few years ago, where either a fruit salad (one of gastronomy's more forgettable items) or that unsophisticated blend of apples, walnuts, celery and mayonnaise known as Waldorf salad was bound to appear. For green salads, the standard item was iceberg lettuce.

title: COURT WON'T REHEAR CASE ON CASINO UNION CONTROL
description: An appellate court has voted against rehearing a case in which New Jersey unsuccessfully sought authority to regulate casino unions.

title: NOMURA, MORGAN TO START TRUST
description: The Nomura Securities Company, the largest securities firm in Japan, and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York have signed a basic agreement to set up a jointly owned investment trust fund. The companies said that it would be the first of its kind in Japan.

title: Steel Output Down Slightly
description: Domestic steel production slipped again last week, but still exceeded the depressed level of a year ago, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: COAST MILLIONAIRE TO OPEN ART MUSEUM IN SOHO
description: The rich are different. If they get the notion, they can start their own art museums. Edward R. Broida, who made his fortune as a California real-estate developer, got the notion one day while sunbathing at home in Beverly Hills, and now workers are preparing to transform a four-story former bakery in SoHo into the Broida Museum.

title: POSNER LETS EVANS RUN ITSELF
description: When Monford A. Orloff, chief executive officer of the Evans Products Company, learned that Victor Posner had begun to purchase a sizable number of shares in his company, his first thought was to resist a takeover.

title: FOR BROADWAY: A NEW HOTEL WITH A THEATER
description: A five-story forest of girders bristles at Broadway and 45th Street. Inside it is an empty space that is to become the theater district's newest playhouse. Above it looms a tall concrete tower, built to carry elevators, that looks like a minaret.

title: Grey Extends Contract And Acquires New Unit
description: Two things have happened of note at Grey Advertising. Over the weekend it was reappointed as agency for the Joint Advertising Program of the Department of Defense, an account it has been handling since 1981.

title: 1. Flowers on Madison
description: What could be more summery than a flower cart? Answer: a white wooden flower cart with lace-edged white parasols tended by a young woman in white pinafore and flower-trimmed straw hat. It is set up on the southwest corner of 65th Street and Madison Avenue every sunny day from 10:30 A.M. until 5 P.M. The cheerful young person who presides over it, Persephone FitzGerald, says her wares are all potted plants because it would be difficult to keep cut flowers fresh on hot days.

title: TOP SOCCER COACH ONCE LED COSMOS
description: Hennes Weisweiler, one of soccer's greatest tacticians and a former coach of the Cosmos, died of a heart attack early today at his home in Aesch near Zurich. He was 63 years old.

title: GERALDINE SOUVAINE, PRODUCER OF FEATURES FOR MET'S BROADCASTS
description: Geraldine Souvaine Davidson, former producer of the intermission features for the Texaco-Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts, died Monday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 74 years old.

title: Advertising; Consumers Union and Miller Spar
description: PAGE newspaper ads by the Miller Brewing Company promoting an article in Consumer Reports magazine that ran in major newspapers across the country last week bring back memories of 1969 and similar ads from the Seagram Distillers Company and the Theodore Hamm Brewing Company.

title: Market Place; Stock Outlook Vs. Rising Net
description: CORPORATIONS will begin to report their second-quarter earnings soon and results should paint the picture of an economy on the rebound. But whether the market is still on the rebound is a different matter.

title: Prices Weaker For Eurobonds
description: Eurobond prices were lower today in light trading. Dollar-denominated dollar bonds fell as much as 1/4 point on some professional selling in the morning.

title: National Can To Buy 4 Plants
description: The National Can Corporation of Chicago announced that it had agreed in principle to buy four manufacturing plants from the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation for $55 million in cash. National said the acquisition of the plants, which primarily manufacture beer bottles, would broaden the market coverage of its glass business.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It would be totally uncharacteristic and quite incredible that I would hand anybody a book I knew to be from the Carter campaign and say this might be helpful to the debate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The film revival listing in The Guide on Sunday carried next week's programs in place of this week's for six theaters. Correct listings for the six -Bleecker Street Cinema, Cinema Village, Film Forum 2, Hollywood Twin I and II and Metro Cinema - appear today on page C17.

title: Mayor Gives Blood To Make a Point
description: T o counteract the idea that AIDS can be spread by donating blood, Mayor Koch gave a pint of his own, type A positive, yesterday.

title: BRONX AUTO CRASH DISRUPTS METRO-NORTH
description: A car plunged from a Bronx overpass onto the Metro-North Commuter Railroad tracks yesterday, and all service on two of the railroad's lines was knocked out for part of the afternoon.

title: DON'T FORGET THE FAILING STUDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: There Are Harpsichords And Harpsichords

title: STEINBRENNER PLANS REWARD FOR RIGHETTI
description: Before the days of million-dollar contracts, it was virtually automatic that when a pitcher threw a no-hitter, the team owner would magnanimously tear up his contract and reward him with a $5,000 or $10,000 raise. Dave Righetti will receive no new contract from the Yankees, but George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he planned to commemorate Righetti's no-hitter in another way.

title: Technology; Basis for Hope At Foundries
description: FOUNDRIES were shut down in the United States at the rate of 17 a month during 1982, and 32 more were closed during the first five months of 1983, according to the Steel Founders Society of America. So the foundry business is not exactly booming.

title: Mortage Rates Go Up
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that the average interest rate for new mortgages rose to 13.01 percent in early June, from 12.99 percent in early May, ending a decline from 17.23 percent last July. The average covers long-term, fixed-rate loans for newly built houses.

title: COMBING THE BEACHES FOR EXOTIC EDIBLES
description: B eachcombing may involve no more than a casual stroll along the high-tide mark, finding, perhaps, a fragment of a trawler's net, a plug lost by a surf fisherman, or even, a rare and delightful discovery, a message in a bottle.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Stan Musial, the former Cardinal slugger, underwent tests in a St. Louis hospital after abdominal cramps forced him to miss the Old-Timers' All-Star Game in Chicago Tuesday. His wife, Lillian, said, ''The doctor isn't sure whether the cramps were from something he ate, or whether he might have an ulcer.''

title: Exxon Fuel Contract
description: The Exxon Corporation's Exxon International Company unit won a $226.5 million contract from the Defense Logistics Agency for jet and diesel fuel, the Defense Department said today.

title: Excellent Advice About Excellence
description: Commissions, task forces and politicians have all discovered excellence with a vengeance - excellence in education, that is, where they seem to believe it can be measured. As this campaign unfolds, it will surely lead to new batteries of tests to root out mediocrity and to threats that students who fail to measure up will be denied diplomas.

title: HOME BEAT
description: NOT long ago, Stephen Barany started collecting folk art and country-style pieces and having them reproduced. Mr. Barany uses ''country-style'' as a phrase to describe his reproductions of furniture and accessories inspired by English Chippendale, rusticated French, and American folk art - all now on the sixth floor at Bloomingdale's.

title: French Jobs Program
description: France's Socialist Government today announced plans to hold unemployment to its current level of about two million. Max Gallo, a Government spokesman, said Cabinet ministers discussed a four-part plan to shorten the workweek from 39 hours to an eventual 35 hours, create jobs, improve services for job seekers and increase youth training programs.

title: HOPES RISE FOR ACCORD IN CITY OPERA DISPUTE
description: Hopes rose last night for a last-minute settlement of the New York City Opera labor dispute after the New York State Mediation Board intervened in the deadlocked negotiations. The opera orchestra has threatened to strike before the season's opening at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: Mating and Mischief
description: Eskimos, like other hunting peoples, had as a centerpiece of their nuptial ritual the abduction of the bride. At worst it was a cruel occasion, though often wives staged later abductions to get clear of an unhappy marriage and into the igloo of the man they had preferred.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
LYNN HITS SLAM
description: In a record-setting performance that included the first grand slam in the 50-year history of the All-Star Game, the American League ended its 11-year losing streak tonight and overwhelmed the National, 13-3.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
STAIRCASES OF ORNATE IRON
description: STEPTOE & WIFE ANTIQUES in Ontario, Canada, has introduced two decorative cast-iron staircases to its line of restoration products for the home. They come in kit form, including treads, risers, side panels, balusters, handrails and center pole, and can be assembled by either professionals or amateurs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Century Telephone Enterprises, Monroe, La., promoted Glen F. Post 3d to senior vice president of financial operations and controller.

title: Vilas Makes Appeal
description: Guillermo Vilas has officially appealed the one-year suspension and $20,000 fine imposed by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, which charged that he took a guarantee to appear at a Grand Prix tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, last March in violation of council rules. Vilas, who denied the charge, said he did not receive a fair hearing before the penalties were made public.

title: BUILD YOUR OWN AIRY GAZEBO
description: GARDEN gazebos have always had a special charm. They are freestanding structures that offer shelter from the sun along with the benefit of stray summer breezes and can provide a gentle place to have a cup of tea or read a book.

title: SULLIVAN MINING GROUP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-There were no revenue figures for the quarter and 9 months. c-After tax credits of $385,000 for the latest quarter and $58,000 for the year- earlier period. d-After special gains of $984,000 for the latest 9 months and $310,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: SYSTEMHOUSE LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
THE EVENING NEWS: A 'GALVANIZING FORCE'
description: As counsel to the President in the Carter Administration, Lloyd N. Cutler, now a Washington lawyer, was privy to the role that news deadlines play in policy decisions in the White House. Here are excerpts of his remarks on that subject in a taped television interview with C-Span, the public affairs cable channel:

title: News Analysis
description: The inability of Secretary of State George P. Shultz to make any apparent headway with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon leaves the country partitioned between Israel and Syria indefinitely, with the Lebanese Government's control limited to parts of Beirut.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 14 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 10.

title: WHITE HOUSE DIVIDED
description: The Reagan White House, which has long been divided ideologically, is now divided on the simple question of who is telling the truth.

title: Chacon Wins Round
description: Bobby Chacon is still the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight champion as the result of a decision by a court judge, not a boxing judge. The title was stripped from Chacon last week for rule violations related to his refusal to make a timely defense against Hector Camancho.

title: DESIGN OF BRIDGE IN I-95 COLLAPSE CALLED 'SUSPECT'
description: Connecticut officials said today that the entire Connecticut Turnpike bridge from which a 100-foot section fell last week might be unsafe.

title: French Envoy Held as Spy
description: A French diplomat who once served in Peking and Mongolia has been arrested here and charged with spying for China, a Government spokesman said today. Bernard Boursicot, who has worked for the Foreign Ministry for about 15 years, was arrested last week.

title: EMPIRE CO reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Including gains on the sale of securities of $1,009,000 for the latest year and $4,557,000 for the previous year.

title: QUEENSBORO BRIDGE LANES TO CLOSE
description: Beginning at 10 A.M. today, the two-lane upper roadway on the south side of the Queensboro Bridge linking Manhattan and Queens will be closed to all traffic for major repairs, the State Department of Transportation announced yesterday.

title: Canada Aid to Mexico
description: The Canadian Government and eight banks have pledged up to $185 million (Canadian), or about $150 million in United States funds, in aid to debt-ridden Mexico as part of an International Monetary Fund effort.

title: STROKES OF A KOCH PEN YIELD LAWS BROAD AND NARROW
description: The price of a marriage license in New York City was raised to $10. Thelonious Monk's son thanked Mayor Koch and the City Council for naming a section of a West Side street after his late father, the jazz musician.

title: CHOOSING A POLISH FOR FINE FURNITURE
description: The wide range of products for cleaning and polishing furniture makes it difficult to pick the one that is most suitable. Yet while there is disagreement about which type of product is best - paste, cream, oil or liquid or spray wax - all agree that regular care keeps furniture looking better longer.

title: U.S. Steel to Sell Cyclone Fence Unit
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its Cyclone Fence division to Gregory Galvanizing and Metal Processing Inc. of Canton, Ohio.

title: SECONDHAND GAMES FOR VIDEO BUFFS
description: FOR some players of home video games, boredom sets in quickly. After a cartridge has been played over a two- or three-month period, the same old bombers and mutants begin to pall. Familiar waves of attacking enemy craft no longer terrorize. The player is ready to explore a new alien galaxy.

title: LED MUSEUM
description: Alberto Raurell Soto, director of the Tamayo Museum in Mexico City and a familiar figure in the New York art world, was shot and killed on June 29 in Mexico City. He was 34 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Arthritis Drug Termed Risk to Ulcer Patients
description: A drug used widely in the treatment of arthritis and allergic diseases slightly increases the risk of peptic ulcers and gastrointestinal hemorrhage, a study said today.

title: HERS
description: THE headline in The New York Times of May 31 read ''Long Lives Seen as Threat to Nation's Budget'' and the story said that two economists had calculated that ''if all the people who died prematurely in 1978 from cancer, heart disease and violence (including accidents) had been able to reach their full life expectancy, the Federal Government would have suffered a net loss of $15 billion.''

title: THE LIBRARY OF TOMORROW: NO BOOKS
description: To the Editor:

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Volleyball Tour
description: Beach volleyball until recently was only a diversion between dips in the ocean for people who enjoy running, jumping and diving into the water.

title: Senate Finance Leader Calls For 'Summit' on the Budget
description: President Reagan should meet with Congressional leaders at a ''budget summit'' to develop the budget outline for the 1984 fiscal year, Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a special gain of $3,283,000.

title: A Double Murder And Suicide on L.I.
description: A 64-year-old retired construction worker shot and killed his wife and their 24-year-old retarded daughter with a pistol before committing suicide, the Nassau County police reported early this morning.

title: Walesa Pledges Lawsuit To Keep His Job
description: Lech Walesa defied Poland's authorities today, refusing to end his unauthorized vacation and vowing a court battle to keep his job.

title: The U.N. Today; July 7, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on World Disar- mament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a tax credit of $140,000. d-Including a tax credit of $1.5 million. Revenue figures represent contract income.

title: TRAFFIC IS BUILDING AT AIRLINES
description: Most of the nation's major airlines recently reported hefty gains in traffic for June, indicating that the recovery in traffic that the industry experienced in the first quarter was building even though some discount fares were phased out last month and some fares have increased.

title: Woman, 55, Slain
description: A 55-year-old Brooklyn woman was found shot to death in an apparent robbery in her apartment in the Midwood section yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. announced that it had acquired 7.5 percent of Paine Webber Inc., or about 1.1 million shares, for $54.3 million.

title: PRICES MOVE SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Prices in the credit markets recuperated a bit yesterday after the sharp declines of the previous two days, but investors remained wary. The Government's 10 3/8 percent bond, maturing in 2012, rose almost half a point, to 93. Yields on three-month Treasury bills declined 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 8.94 percent, and six-month bills declined 14 basis points, to 9.11 percent.

title: Australia Bond Set
description: Australia filed for an offering of up to $400 million of bonds, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. Underwriters will be named later. The proceeds of the offering will be added to Australia's international reserves.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: POURED concrete is probably the most durable and maintenance-free material for a patio, but having a professional contractor build it can be quite expensive. This is especially true if the concrete cannot be dumped directly into the forms.

title: PLAYING HOST TO A BAT UNDER STRESS
description: ARMAGEDDON? Or was it the two-minute warning before a nuclear attack? ''The burglar alarm!'' shouted my husband, racing along the second-floor hallway. By the time I joined him at the head of the stairway, he'd punched in the code that would turn off the alarm. We stood there, listening for the sounds of pillage below.

title: HIJACKED IRAN JET LEAVES KUWAIT WITH 185 HOSTAGES
description: Hijackers seized an Iranian jetliner on a domestic flight on Wednesday and flew it to Kuwait, where they released 186 women, children and old men before taking off for Paris with 185 hostages still aboard, officials said.

title: ROOKIE REACHES THE STARS
description: CHICAGO W hen the telephone rang in a hotel room in Atlanta at 8:30 A.M. a week ago, Bill Dawley was not thrilled. The Houston Astros had played the Braves the night before, so Dawley, a right-handed rookie relief pitcher for the Astros, did not get to sleep until late.

title: KOHL'S VIEW OF SOVIET TALKS: BLUNT AND USEFUL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that meetings with Yuri V. Andropov had not produced any initiatives on missiles or other matters but had been useful for discussing these issues directly and for each leader to get the measure of the other.

title: BOTH SIDES IN PENSION DISPUTE HAIL COURT RULING AS A VICTORY
description: Advocates and opponents of nonsexist insurance tables took comfort in the Supreme Court ruling today prohibiting employers from alloting smaller monthly pension payments to women than to men.

title: CALENDAR: CRAFTS WORKSHOPS
description: Three Crafts Workshops, Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue (53d Street), 212-755-4500, ext. 59.

title: EAST SULLIVAN MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including special gains of $336,086 for the latest 9 months and $266,935 for the year-ago 9 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was a Foreign Service officer for 16 years. The things I had to deal with were terrorism, civil wars and riots.

title: HIGH COURT BANS UNEQUAL PENSIONS FOR THE TWO SEXES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal law against sex discrimination in employment prohibits employer-sponsored retirement plans that give men and women unequal benefits. But the Court said its ruling would affect only future pension contributions.

title: HOUSE COMPROMISE SOUGHT ON NICARAGUA
description: The Reagan Administration is negotiating with Republicans and Democrats in Congress to devise a compromise that would avoid a vote in the House of Representatives to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, high Administration officials said today.

title: Nicaraguan Guerrillas Increasing, U.S. Finds
description: The number of rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government has grown to between 8,000 and 10,000, the State Department said today.

title: Norelco Shaver Claim Spurs Suit
description: The American distributor of Norelco shavers is facing a $50 million suit for its claims that its electric shavers are preferred by astronauts on trips into space.

title: BOMAC BATTEN LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including a gain of $279,800 on the sale of real estate.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Michael Bonnes, 19 years old, of 1364 East Fourth Street in Brooklyn, was arrested Tuesday night in the firebombing on Monday of a yeshiva, Chaim Berlin, in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. ... A 15-year-old Queens boy was charged yesterday with attempted murder in the shooting of Ray Tamayo, 14, in the playground of Junior High School 217 in Jamaica. The victim, who was shot in the left eye, was in critical condition at New York Hospital. ... An unidentified man described as an emotionally disturbed derelict was charged with stabbing a transit police officer, Michael Lenahan, 40, in a scuffle on a Queens subway train. Officer Lenahan was treated and released at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst.

title: NEW GENTRY ARE KEY TO BOSTON RACE
description: From the outside, with its small front lawn decorated by a single rosebush, it looks like any other triple-decker house in Dorchester, long a predominantly working-class and Irish-American section of Boston.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES JUMP 55.2%
description: The Big Three car makers reported today that their sales jumped 55.2 percent in the June 21-30 period, continuing a rebound that started in May.

title: STOKELY MOVES TO DELAY TAKEOVER BY PILLSBURY
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc., in a first indication of opposition to a takeover bid by the Pillsbury Company, told its shareholders yesterday not to tender their stock until antitrust questions can be answered.

title: KENTUCKY EXPLORES BUTCHERS' BANKING
description: C.H. Butcher Jr., whose Tennessee banking network collapsed last spring, was using a separate chain of Kentucky banks to finance millions of dollars of business investments for himself, his brother and their associates, according to a lawsuit and Kentucky banking regulators.

title: STUDY INSISTS DIABETICS CAN HAVE SOME SUGAR
description: The widely accepted notion that diabetics should avoid eating table sugar and foods containing sugar is being challenged by groups of medical researchers at the Universities of Minnesota and Colorado.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 5 and a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 15, 1982.

title: SYRIAN PRESIDENT WARNED BY ISRAEL
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, said today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria would be making a ''big mistake'' if he thought Israel could be compelled to withdraw its forces from Lebanon.

title: Head of Yale Elected To Ford Foundation
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, Yale University's president, was elected to the board of trustees of the Ford Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

title: Rita Lavelle Ordered to Trial On July 21 in Contempt Case
description: An effort by Rita Lavelle to get an indictment for contempt of Congress thrown out of court was dismissed today by a Federal district judge, who ordered the former official of the Environmental Protection Agency to stand trial July 21.

title: HIJACKERS TO CUBA GIVEN STIFF TERMS
description: Hijackers who divert planes to Cuba are treated harshly by the Cuban authorities and have recently been sentenced to 10 to 20 years in prison, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
description: b-After a charge of $17.6 million from the disposition and redeployment of certain assets.

title: DEATHS BRING AIR OF MENACE TO MALAWI
description: Since May 18 the much vaunted tranquillity of this central African nation has taken on an air of menace after the deaths of three Cabinet ministers and a legislator in circumstances that have raised questions the Government will not answer.

title: U.S. to Try Computers To Investigate Fraud
description: The Federal Government is moving its inspectors general into the computer age, officials announced today. ''We are finally taking our inspectors general into the 20th Century,'' Joseph Wright, deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, told a news conference. Mr. Wright is also chairman of the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency, which includes all agency inspectors. The 17 inspectors general, spread among Federal agencies, head teams of auditors who check for fraud and abuse.

title: Appeals Judge Questions Draft Prosecution Policy
description: A Government attorney faced hard questioning today from a Federal appeals judge about the Reagan Administration's policy in the prosecution of draft resisters.

title: From Continental To Bear, Stearns
description: George R. Baker, the former heir-apparent of the Continental Illinois Corporation who resigned last December as a result of Continental's energy-related loan losses, has become a special limited partner in the investment banking firm of Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: THE RESTORATION OF GARDEN AND GROVE AT MONTICELLO
description: ''No occupation is so delightful to me as the culture of the earth, and no culture comparable to that of the garden. Though an old man, I am but a young gardener.''

title: Advertising; A Case of Magazine Piracy
description: ANY number of exciting things have happened to the Johnston International Publishing Corporation in the 107 years since it began servicing far-off continents with trade and business publications. But only once, and just recently, has the company been used in a scam when hustlers sold ads for bogus issues of one of Johnston's eight magazines.

title: Equatorial Guinea Kills 2
description: Equatorial Guinea executed two noncommissioned officers today after convicting them of taking part in an attempt to kill President Teodoro Obian Nguema on May 11, the Spanish news agency E.F.E. said.

title: Ruling on Hydroelectic
description: The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision that makes it easier for municipal authorities to take over hydroelectric projects now in the hands of investor-owned utilities.

title: Newspaper Bill in Canada
description: The Canadian Government proposed legislation today to regulate the newspaper industry. The bill would limit the growth of newspaper chains, establish a national press council to hear complaints, and commit the Government to financing of up to $1 million a year to help newspapers establish foreign or out-ofprovince bureaus.

title: Agreement Settles Wildcat Bus Strike
description: Drivers and mechanics of the Mount Kisco Bus Line settled a wildcat strike against its management today and were to return to work Thursday.

title: DEVELOPER OF THE QUONSET HUT
description: Peter Dejongh, an engineer and designer who developed the Quonset hut during World War II and who later supervised the construction of the United Nations Secretariat in New York City, died Sunday at his home in Arlington, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: RACIAL PROBLEMS CONTINUE IN A CALIFORNIA CITY
description: In awarding $3 million in damages last month to the families of two black men slain by police officers in Richmond, a city of nearly 75,000 people about 15 miles northeast of here, a Federal jury said it was sending a message to that city to change its ways.

title: CANADA, TO SPUR SALES, TRIMS EXPORT GAS PRICE
description: Canada today reduced by 22.8 percent the price of some of the natural gas that it exports to the United States, a move prompted by a sharp fall in American demand.

title: SLAM HIT TO AVOID STRIKEOUT
description: CHICAGO F red Lynn first made the observation during batting practice. Comiskey Park has always been a difficult place to hit home runs, but this evening, before the 50th anniversary All-Star Game, baseballs were flying out of the park. ''The balls they were using seemed pretty lively,'' Lynn said. ''I was hoping they would use them in the game.''

title: THE PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: THE summer solstice has recently passed leaving gardeners with long hours of daylight and a sun that is hot and high overhead. This is the month to sit and enjoy the shifting patterns under trees in full leaf and tend to tasks in a leisurely manner. Snip Spent Blooms

title: ACRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: LINING UP FOR PASSPORT: 'NIGHTMARE' OF A WAIT
description: Out the door the line stretched, past the pretzel vendors on Fifth Avenue, past the statue of Atlas bearing the world on his shoulders. Under the bright sun, passport applicants waited, some looking as if Atlas had the easier task.

title: Phibro/Salomon Issue Attractive to Investors
description: A six-million-share offering of Phibro/Salomon Inc. common stock, priced at $35.63 a share, was sold out almost immediately yesterday, with a large participation by institutional buyers, according to the lead underwriter for the offering, Lazard Freres & Company.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALL THE COMFORTS OF HOME AT THE BEACH AND THE POOL
description: WHILE it may seem that everyone else is already organized enough to relax and enjoy an outing at the beach, the season is only just beginning. In many households, the umbrellas and rafts are just now being pulled out of garages or the backs of closets. Quite a few pools that are usually cleaned and ready to go by Memorial Day seem to have had their real unveiling over the July 4 weekend.

title: COSMOS TURN BACK TEAM AMERICA, 4-0
description: In its brief existence in the North American Soccer League, Team America has become respected for its defense and feared for its rough style.

title: CUOMO CHARGES REAGAN PROMOTES POLICY OF 'SUPPLY-SIDE EDUCATION'
description: Governor Cuomo of New York today accused President Reagan of promoting a policy of ''supply-side education.'' In an address here to the convention of the American Federation of Teachers, he defined that as meaning that ''we will take resources from those most in need and move them to those we deem the strongest.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM HIGH COURT DECISION ON INEQUALITY IN PENSIONS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's actions today on sex discrimination in retirement plans. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall wrote the opinion on the discrimination issue, which four others joined. Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell wrote the opinion on the remedy, which four others joined. Per Curium

title: Northern Telecom Has PBX System
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., the Canadian telecommunications concern, said that it would market a new private branch exchange system, or PBX, in Canada and United States. The new system is designed for customers with between 20 and 130 telephone lines, and it can handle both voice and data transmissions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Planning for a Salute To French Culture

title: JERSEY STUDENTS' SPACE ANTS APPARENTLY DIED
description: The first ants in space apparently did not survive. Students at two high schools in Camden, N.J., who worked on a fiveyear science project that culminated in their ant colony's orbiting the earth aboard the recent flight of the space shuttle Challenger, were told this week that their ants had died.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
TV: 'SLEEPING BEAUTY' ON PAY CABLE
description: ''FAERIE TALE THEATER'' is a cable-television project started by Shelley Duvall, the film actress and collector of rare fairy-tale books. She has gone about recruiting different directors, writers and set designers, using visual styles based on familiar illustrations, to produce a series of monthly programs for Showtime Entertainment, a pay-cable service. Tonight's installment, being shown at 8 o'clock, is ''Sleeping Beauty'' and it is one of the better offerings.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 17.
COURSES ARE OFFERED ON INTERIOR DESIGN
description: The following classes on the basics of home carpentry and interior decorating are being offered in Manhattan this summer. Home Decorating

title: GOTBAUM PLANS TO QUIT HIS POST ON STATE BOARD
description: Victor Gotbaum, an early supporter of Mario M. Cuomo's 1982 gubernatorial bid, yesterday sharply criticized the Governor and the man he appointed to head the state's Urban Development Corporation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC MAN

title: NONSMOKER PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUGANIS TAKES DIVING GOLD
description: Greg Louganis of the United States outdistanced his nearest competitor by more than 65 points to win the gold medal in 3-meter diving in the 12th World University Games today and the American men's and women's teams continued to win in basketball.

title: Beatty Aide Makes Deal on Charges
description: A 28-year-old campaign aide charged with forgery for helping former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn try to upset his loss in a 1982 Congressional primary has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors against him, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Topics; Times of the Signs; Capsule
description: The Comptroller of the Currency is the fellow who took over the assets of banks that failed in the early 1930's. Among the things he acquired in the process were contents of thousands of safe-deposit boxes whose owners couldn't be found.

title: Three for Three
description: When Norman Friedland, an attorney who lives in Glen Cove, L.I., goes to a major league baseball game, something exceptional seems to happen. He has attended only three games.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $115,000 for the quarter and $413,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $211,000 for the quarter and $822,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quaker City Filing
description: Quaker City Industries said it had filed a voluntary petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey. The company makes steel utility buildings.

title: Toshiba's Net Declines
description: The Toshiba Corporation, citing declines from two of its divisions that have been dissolved, said today that its consolidated net earnings for the year ended March 31 fell 13.3 percent, to $160.2 million, from $184.7 million in the previous year. Sales at the company, a leading maker of consumer electronics and electrical machinery, edged up to about $10 billion, from $9.7 billion the previous year.

title: Compute! Deal Brings ABC Publishing Shifts
description: Two months ago, ABC jumped into the fast-growing computer magazine sector with its purchase of Compute! Publications for $18 million in stock. Yesterday, it announced shifts in the management of its ABC Publishing unit to accommodate the new division.

title: GUATEMALAN'S SISTER KIDNAPPED
description: Four armed men kidnapped the pregnant sister of President Efrain Rios Montt last week, officials said today.

title: Age No Factor
description: The respective ages of the four highest-ranked male table tennis players in the United States are 19, 15, 20 and 47. The five men who will represent the United States in table tennis in the Pan American Games in August are 15, 19, 23, 23 and 47.

title: Pemex Fraud Session Set
description: Congressional leaders decided today to hold a special session of the House of Deputies to discuss a $34 million fraud charge against Senator Jorge Diaz Serrano, the former director of Petroleos Mexicanos, the state oil monopoly known as Pemex, a spokesman said.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Dr. Lester Donald Crow Dies; Educator and Author of Texts
description: Dr. Lester Donald Crow, an educator and author of educational textbooks, died Thursday at the House of the Good Samaritan Hospital in Watertown, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Watertown.

title: WHY THE DEATH PENALTY IS NEVER THE SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE LIBRARY BRANCHES TO BE OPEN ON SUNDAYS
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the New York Public Library will use city funds to open some branches on Sundays. Beginning in September, the Donnell Library in Manhattan, the Fordham branch in the Bronx and the St. George branch on Staten Island will have Sunday hours.

title: Pope Talks of His Polish Trip Without Mention of Politics
description: Pope John Paul II prayed to the Madonna of Jasna Gora today for all those who made possible his trip to Poland last month, but made no reference to the political situation in his native country.

title: People
description: * George S. Fabian promoted to executive vice president at SSC&B.

title: JOHN S. W. WASLEY SR.
description: John S. W. Wasley Sr., vice president of the International Advertising Association of New York City, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Wasley, who also lived in Black Point, Conn., was 61 years old.

title: ANTIQUES SYMPOSIUMS DRAW MANY COLLECTORS
description: IF collectibles are a growth industry, so are the conferences about them that are held around the country each year. Symposiums on antiques and the decorative arts are drawing thousands of dealers, scholars, collectors and would-be collectors at about $50 to $200 a head, excluding food and lodging. Indeed, it is difficult to open a copy of a collectors' magazine without finding an advertisement for a symposium on 18th-century ceramics or cameo glass or antebellum architecture.

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
description: b-Including tax credits of $849,000 for the quarter and $1,169,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Burns Predicts Higher Rates
description: Arthur F. Burns, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that United States interest rates would rise in 1984 and that agreement on how to combat the United States budget deficit would not be reached until the end of next year at the earliest.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Martin Delays Surgery
description: After running a series of tests on Billy Martin, doctors at a Minneapolis hospital determined that the problem from which he had been suffering was inflamed hemorrhoids. Told that an operation would keep him away from his job as Yankee manager for three weeks, Martin decided to put off the surgery until after the season. He will be treated in the meantime with medication and he plans to join the team tomorrow night in Kansas City for the start of a series.

title: CONSERVATOR IS APPOINTED FOR MERRICK
description: Morton J. Mitosky, a lawyer who has been a close friend and business associate of David Merrick, the theatrical producer, has been appointed sole conservator of Mr. Merrick's estate by Justice Hilda G. Schwartz of State Supreme Court.

title: Penn Square Suit
description: More than 160 investors in 19 states have filed a Federal lawsuit contending that they were bilked out of more than $14.5 million in a conspiracy involving the defunct Penn Square Bank and others. The investors say the bank's holding company and directors, the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand and eight oil and gas drilling ventures headed by Carl W. Swan, a former Penn Square director, were part of the conspiracy.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Bruce Curry, champion, vs. Hidekazu (Rocky) Akai, World Boxing Council's superlightweight title bout, at Osaka, Japan. This is the first defense by Curry, who won the crown in Las Vegas, Nev., two months ago with a unanimous decision over LeRoy Haley. Akai, undefeated in his 13 professional bouts, is ranked ninth by the W.B.C. Kenny Bogner vs. Trevor Evelyn, lightweights, and Roger Stafford vs. Darryl Fuller, welterweights, 10 round co-feature bouts, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Golf Greater Milwaukee Open, first round, at Franklin, Wis. Calvin Peete is the defending champion.

title: Ukrainian Accused of Aiding Nazis Is Found Shot to Death
description: A 63-year-old Ukranian immigrant, threatened last week with loss of his American citizenship because of charges had had collaborated with Nazis against Jews in World War II, was found shot to death today in his apartment in what the authorities said appeared to be a suicide.

title: Xerox Cuts Some Prices
description: The Xerox Corporation announced price reductions of 20 percent to 28 percent on three of its smaller copiers and reductions of 11.5 percent and 16.7 percent on two of its electronic typewriters.

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 7, 1983
description: International Syria remains totally opposed to talks for a removal of its forces from Lebanon, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said after a fivehour meeting in Damascus with President Hafez al-Assad. However, Mr. Shultz said the Syrian leader had agreed to form a working group with the United States to explore how Lebanon might regain independence. (Page A1, Column 1.) Israel warned Syria it would be making a ''big mistake'' if it thought Israel could be compelled to withdraw its forces from Lebanon. The statement was made by Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir at a meeting in Jerusalem with France's Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson. (A6:1.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article by United Press In- ternational yesterday about Richard Burton's marriage misstated the length of Elizabeth Taylor's absence from the Broadway production of ''Private Lives.'' Miss Taylor, who had been ill, returned Tuesday night.

title: INQUIRIES START ON CARTER BRIEFING DOCUMENTS
description: Investigators for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and for Congress began separate rounds of interviews today in an effort to find out how the 1980 Reagan campaign obtained copies of strategy papers prepared for President Carter's debate with Ronald Reagan.

title: Scali and Gianettino Attract Accounts
description: And now in the frenetic world of account movement, yesterday's action concerned Scali, McCabe, Sloves and Gianettino & Meredith. The Heublein Spirits and Wine Company, now part of R.J. Reynolds Industries, has assigned Harvey's of Bristol, which is mostly Harvey's Bristol Cream Sherry, to Scali, an Ogilvy & Mather subsidiary.

title: DOW GAINS 12.12 AFTER LATE RALLY
description: Stock prices, aided by a late surge of bargain hunting, yesterday recovered much of the ground lost in Tuesday's precipitous decline. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.12 points, to 1,220.65, while advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by 1,084 to 555. Volume rose to 85.7 million shares from 67.3 million on Tuesday.

title: FOSTER CARE: BEFORE THE DAMAGE IS DONE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN TRUCK MAKER'S U.S. BID
description: After deciding against a joint venture with the Ford Motor Company, Japan's biggest heavy truck manufacturer is setting out on its own to capture a share of the American market.

title: Rates Up At Banks
description: Interest rates on banks' money market accounts continued to rise in the week ended Wednesday, both in New York and around the country, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: 2 Killed in Air Force Crash
description: Both crewmen were killed when an Air Force F-4D Phantom jet on a training mission crashed Tuesday in the Straits of Florida, an Air Force spokesman said. The victims' names were not released.

title: ORGANIST: LARRY ALLEN
description: FOR a quarter of a century now, Riverside Church has been sponsoring a summer series of organ recitals that have attracted sizable audiences, and on Tuesday evening the 26th annual presentation began. The performer was Larry Allen, an organist who has concertized in Norway as well as in this country and who is director of music at Immanuel Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
Thrift Unit Adds Adjustable Loans
description: Empire of America of Buffalo announced that it had committed an additional $1 billion to extend its adjustable rate mortgage program for an additional 12 months, through July 1984.

title: NO TIME FOR NOTING A DESEGREGATION VICTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: British TV Asserts Employees Bombed Beirut U.S. Embassy
description: A British television report says the bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut last April 18 that killed more than 60 people was carried out by 16 Islamic extremists employed in the building.

title: VOTERS FEND OFF ATTACKS ON BONUS CHECKS AND THE PENINSULA SENDS UP SMOKE
description: Because of bad weather on the Alaska Peninsula and in the Aleutians, Mount Veniaminof, on the peninsula, has erupted largely unseen.

title: More Than a Tax Reform Slogan
description: Could 1983 be the year for a national debate on major tax reform? Early endorsements for the ingenious Bradley-Gephardt proposal by Presidential candidates Walter Mondale and Gary Hart certainly point in that direction. Now it is up to President Reagan and others who seek to succeed him to explain how they would improve our disgraceful income tax system.

title: Brain-Dead Mother Dies
description: A brain-dead who woman gave birth to a 3-pound 11-ounce girl Tuesday after being kept alive by life support systems for 84 days, died shortly after life-support equipment was disconnected, doctors said today. The baby, delivered by Caesarean at Roanoke Memorial Hospital, ''appears to be an extraordinary normal'' baby, Dr. Robert Allen said at a news conference.

title: Kaat, 44, on Waivers
description: Jim Kaat, the second-oldest player in the major leagues and only the seventh man to have played in the majors in four different decades, may finally have to call it quits. The 44-year-old lefthanded pitcher was placed on waivers by the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday to give him his unconditional release.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for year to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. GIVING EGYPT A $100 MILLION POWER PLANT
description: The United States has decided to give Egypt $100 million in economic aid to complete the fourth unit of a 600-megawatt power plant at Ismalia, on the Suez Canal, American and Egyptian officials announced today.

title: Computeristics Sells a Division
description: Management Science America Inc. said it acquired Computeristics Inc.'s software division, which accounts for virtually all of Computeristics' business.

title: BALLET THEATER: REVIVAL OF 'THREE VIRGINS'
description: AGNES DE MILLE'S ''Three Virgins and a Devil,'' sporadically revived by the American Ballet Theater, is one of the most hilarious ballets in the international repertory.

title: IMPASSE ON BUDGET PERSISTS ON COAST
description: Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, is refusing to give ground in a bitter dispute with the Democraticcontrolled Legislature that has left California technically insolvent since Friday.

title: EUROPEANS UPSET BY U.S. BARRIER ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: The West German Economics Minister, Otto Lambsdorff, echoing widespread European sentiment, expressed ''astonishment'' today at the United States Government's decision to impose tariffs and quotas on specialty steel imports.

title: A TORRENT OF REQUESTS FOR ASYLUM
description: The poem on the Statue of Liberty promises refuge to all the world's ''tired and poor,'' to the ''homeless'' and the ''tempest-tossed.''

title: Western Union Sells Space Share
description: The Western Union Corporation of Upper Saddle River, N.J., announced that it had sold its share in the partnership known as the Space Communications Company, or Spacecom, for $29 million, to its two partners. Spacecom had been a joint venture of Western Union, Fairchild Industries of Germantown, Md., and Continental Telecom Inc. of Atlanta to send satellites into space and operate them as communications devices.

title: CONROY INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
ERRONEOUS HEARSAY ABOUT KISSINGER
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL TO PUT CONNECTICUT DRINKING AGE AT 20
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would sign legislation raising Connecticut's legal drinking age to 20 from 19, effective Oct. 1.

title: Previn Advised to Rest
description: Andre Previn has been advised by doctors to rest completely to avoid aggravating the osteo-arthritis in his feet, his personal assistant says. The 53-year-old conductor had to withdraw from three concerts this week because of the disease in his joints. ''He is in constant pain,'' said his assistant, Angela Taylor.

title: Market Place; Bank Stocks' Growth Seen
description: PLUMMETING interest rates last summer touched off a dramatic increase in stock prices and a corresponding expansion in priceearnings ratios. But now, with interest rates apparently stabilizing, the consensus on Wall Street is that the continued rise of most stock groups henceforth must depend upon higher profits, rather than the willingness of investors to push up multiples.

title: MUTUALLY ACCEPTING NUCLEAR PARITY
description: Traditionally, before the nuclear arms race began in earnest, it was possible for a powerful state to insure its national security by building stronger defenses than its adversary. The nuclear competition has changed all that, snatching away the hope of total security once pursued by all great powers. But neither the United States nor the Soviet Union have yet taken account of this revolution. Neither has recognized that we have to learn to live with a state of nuclear parity - and to find other, nonmilitary means to manage the conflicts between us.

title: Robert S. Fougner, 70, Former Federal Official
description: Robert S. Fougner, chief rent control attorney for the New York State region in the Office of Price Administration from 1942 to 1945 and later a senior attorney in the Justice Department's antitrust division, died Sunday at his home in East Williston, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Greymac Trust
description: The Greymac Trust Company of Toronto, one of three trust companies seized by the Ontario Government in January in connection with a sale of apartment buildings, said it planned to close all of its branches except its main one in Toronto. The Standard Trust Company, the Government-appointed agent for Greymac, said that under an agreement with the Government, Greymac is no longer able to accept new deposits. As a result, Standard Trust said, the branches are no longer economically viable and must be closed.

title: Topics; Times of the Signs; Oxymorons
description: When George Carlin, the comedian, speaks of ''jumbo shrimp'' or ''military intelligence,'' he's illustrating the oxymoron - a figure of speech that combines contradictory terms for emphasis.

title: THE FIREWORKS FOR THE 50TH
description: CHICAGO I n the American League clubhouse before last night's All-Star Game, their sluggers were talking about the fireworks that explode above the Comiskey Park scoreboard after a home run.

title: NEW PARKING LOT HAILED IN BRONX
description: A 10-year quest by residents and merchants along Arthur Avenue in the Bronx ended yesterday with the opening of the first off-street parking lot in the busy shopping district of Italian food stores and restaurants.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Placed Jim Kaat, p itcher, on waivers for the purpose of giv- i ng him his unconditional release.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 7, 1983; The Economy
description: New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers soared 55.2 percent in the June 21-30 period, continuing a rebound that began in May. Analysts predicted that strong sales would continue. G.M.'s sales were up 44.3 percent, while Ford's climbed 76.8 percent and Chrysler's 58.6 percent. Total sales in June rose 48 percent. (Page D1.)

title: South Korean President Shuffles His Cabinet
description: President Chun Doo Hwan replaced the Deputy Prime Minister and the Interior Minister, one of his closest associates, in a Cabinet shuffle announced today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Time for Reading T he dread television monster crept into the New York Public Library the other day but it was O.K. He was plugging reading. At the preview of ''Reading Rainbow,'' a 15-part public television series beginning Monday on WNET in New York, a dozen kids in the cast played with balloons in the Trustees Room and flipped through their favorite books.

title: Miss Boudin Gets A Separate Trial
description: An Orange County judge ruled today that Kathy Boudin could be tried separately from three defendants scheduled to go on trial next week in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and killings in Rockland County.

title: Topics; Times of the Signs; Gategrate
description: To get the gate used to mean to be dismissed, but since 1972, in the wake of Watergate, writers have relentlessly made ''-gate'' a suffix connoting political scandal: Koreagate, Lancegate, Billygate.

title: BRITISH RENEW THEIR COMMITMENT TO THE DEPLOYMENT OF U.S. MISSILES
description: The Government reiterated its commitment today to the stationing of new American missiles in Britain later this year unless the Soviet Union makes concessions in strategic arms limitation talks.

title: Warnaco's Puritan Unit Names New President
description: After two years with Warnaco Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel companies, Daniel B. Kriegel has a new job - president of the Puritan Sportswear unit - and an imposing challenge. ''What we have are products for middle America,'' he says. ''I see tremendous growth potential over the next five years.''

title: Cauthen Is Suspended
description: Steve Cauthen, who rode Affirmed to the Triple Crown in 1978 and has been racing in England the last five years, was suspended there for 12 days for reckless riding, but he says he is considering an appeal. The stewards at Newmarket imposed the penalty Tuesday after Cauthen had ridden Hollywood Party to a third-place finish in the Ward Hill Barbury Cup.

title: Pitino a Knick Aide
description: Rick Pitino, Boston University's basketball coach for the last five seasons, has been named an assistant coach of the Knicks, replacing Mike Fratello, the Atlanta Hawks' new head coach. Pitino, 31 years old, compiled a 91-51 record with the Terriers, including a 21-10 mark last season, in which Boston U. played in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship tournament for the first time in 24 years.

title: I.B.M. Fee Plan
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said that it would pay a fee to selected software and service concerns to help sell and install I.B.M. smaller computers, ranging from the personal computer to the medium-sized System/38.

title: Norton Simon Disclosures
description: Norton Simon Inc. disclosed yesterday that it had rejected a combined offer of $1.2 billion from Anderson, Clayton & Company and Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts before it accepted a $918 million takeover bid from Esmark Inc. last Thursday. It contended that the combined offer was uncertain.

title: HOW ABOUT DOMESTIC COOPERATION?
description: There are many important issues to be taken up in the forthcoming Presidential campaign: Arms control and education, industrial and infrastructure investment, the international financial system and the balancing of our budget. The various candidates will undoubtedly have positions on each of these issues, and many more. However, a question that deserves to be explored, and about which little is heard, is that of cooperation versus confrontation.

title: Diana Ross Concert Set In Central Park July 21
description: Diana Ross will give a free concert in Central Park July 21 that will be televised worldwide, New York City officials said Tuesday. The proceeds from the sale of promotional items at the concert will go to the city's Parks Department.

title: BRAZIL'S NEW GOVERNORS FIND THE CUPBOARDS BARE
description: In Sao Paulo, the new government found that its predecessors had hired 51 lifeguards, 47 of whom could not swim.
