The only utility the new Governor of Ceara was able to keep functioning in his suddenly incommunicado executive mansion was the lights because the power company belonged to the state.

title: BRIEFING
description: In All Seriousness

title: Hattie Hartman, Brazil Aide, Wed To Josue Tanaka
description: Hattie Higginbotham Hartman was married yesterday to Josue Tanaka. She is a daughter of Mrs. Joseph A. Hartman of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Giulio Ascarelli of Paris. Mr. Tanaka is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Shiro Tanaka of Paris.

title: REAGAN AIDES DESCRIBE OPERATION TO GATHER INSIDE DATA ON CARTER
description: An operation to collect inside information on Carter Administration foreign policy was run in Ronald Reagan's campaign headquarters in the 1980 Presidential campaign, according to present and former Reagan Administration officials.

title: Battleship New Jersey Joins Exercises With Thai Forces
description: The 58,000-ton battleship New Jersey, on its first deployment since rejoining the fleet, is taking part in exercises off Thailand, the Pentagon said today.

title: CITY OPERA: PUCCINI FESTIVAL'S EVENTS
description: THE formal opening of the New York City Opera's new summer season tonight may be in doubt, but the company's Puccini Festival is already under way.

title: AMERICA'S UNELECTED LAWMAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Watson Awaits Final Results
description: To a professional golfer one of the greatest honors is to represent his country in the Ryder Cup matches between the United States and Europe each odd-numbered year. He qualifies by accumulating points in tournaments.

title: South Africa to Inquire Into Death of a Black
description: A police commissioner ordered an investigation today into the shooting death of a 23-year-old black at Soweto police headquarters.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One Path to Relaxation: Snipping and Gluing

title: A BRUEGEL FAILS TO SELL IN LONDON
description: The earliest known signed and dated painting by Pieter Bruegel the elder and the only painting by the artist to appear at auction since World War II failed to sell at Sotheby Park Bernet today.

title: Record Pace in 6-Day Run
description: Siegfried Bauer of New Zealand was leading 23 other runners after 48 hours of the New York Six-Day Run yesterday. As day 2 blurred into day 3 at 4:12 yesterday afternoon, Bauer, 41 years old, had run 202 miles on the Downing Stadium track on Randalls Island.

title: Bridge: Problems Can Be Avoided If You Understand English
description: At almost every world championship, a language problem develops. Since English is officially required on such occasions, those who use it in everyday life have an obvious advantage. An example is the diagramed deal, from the 1982 world team championship for the Rosenblum Cup in Biarritz, France.

title: HIGH COURT DELAYS VIDEOTAPE RULING
description: The Supreme Court today deferred a decision on whether the use of home video recorders violated Federal copyright law, surprising Hollywood, the electronics industry and much of the Washington legal community.

title: Former Cleveland Mayor Wins Council Primary
description: Former Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, whose two-year term was marked by feuds with his Police Chief and the city's plunge into default, placed first Tuesday in a special primary election for a City Council seat.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ACID RAIN. By Robert H. Boyle and R. Alexander Boyle. 146 pages. Nick Lyons/Schocken. Hardcover, $14.95; paperback, $8.95. AT THE TOP OF THEIR GAME. By Rob- ert H. Boyle. 204 pages. Nick Lyons/ Schocken. Hardcover, $12.95; paper- back, $8.95.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TEACHERS' MEETING
description: The ghost of Ronald Reagan seemed to fill the vast Civic Center here for the five days of the National Education Association's convention. Though the President was 3,000 miles away in California, he was the bete noire around whom this meeting, which ended today, often seemed to be revolving.

title: CLEANING SERVICES FOR WINDOW BLINDS
description: VENETIAN blinds may be age-old, but they are also a timeworn cleaning nuisance. Homeowners and apartment dwellers can either clean the blinds themselves, a cheap but laborious alternative, or send them out to companies that specialize in such cleaning.

title: ART MUSEUM ON COAST ASTIR FOR OPENING IN FALL
description: Museums come in all kinds and sizes. There are those that sit out the centuries like outsize stone lions and there are those that are hyperactive, like the kitten on the keys in the piano rag of that name by Zez Confrey.

title: Canadian Trade Surplus
description: Canada sold $1.64 billion (Canadian) more in goods during May than it imported, raising the 1983 trade surplus so far to $7.6 billion, the Government agency Statistics Canada reported today.

title: AMERICA'S UNELECTED LAWMAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income

title: Debt Issues
description: * Arizona Public Service Co.'s $100 million issue of 12 3/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2013 was priced at 99 1/4, to yield slightly less than 12.85 percent, through Kidder, Peabody & Company. The bonds are rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service, and A by Standard & Poor's Corp. Common Stock

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12 wks to May 21.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for a 50 percent stock dividend paid in November 1982.

title: SHULTZ SAYS SYRIA IS FIRMLY OPPOSED TO TROOP PULLOUT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met with President Hafez al-Assad today and said Syria remained totally opposed to negotiations about the removal of its forces from Lebanon. But he said the Syrians had agreed to form a working group with the United States to explore how Lebanon might regain its independence.

title: A 119-POUND CHAMPION HAS HEAVYWEIGHT GOALS
description: Floyd Favors remembers how he became a boxer. ''I was 11 1/2,'' he said. ''A friend wanted me to slap-box with Reynard Knight, my best friend. I said no. I knew Reynard was strong, and I didn't know how to box.

title: Workers Partly Plug Leak in Earthen Dam
description: Construction crews partly plugged a stubborn leak tonight in the Pinopolis Dam at Lake Moultrie that forced the evacuation of 1,500 people and threatened thousands more down river, the authorities said.

title: NOLES RECEIVES JAIL TERM
description: The Chicago Cub pitcher Dickie Noles was found guilty by a county judge today of having assaulted a Cincinnati police officer and was sentenced to jail for the next 16 days.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to Roy Blough, professor emeritus at Columbia University. He is 81 years old.

title: Bus Driver Lacked License
description: The driver of a Tennessee church bus that ran off a highway and tumbled down an embankment Monday, leaving two people dead and 30 injured, had no valid operator's license, according to the state police. They said the license of Carl Wheeler, 53 years old, was revoked last December for his failure to show proof of insurance coverage or post bond after an accident in Memphis.

title: Woman Is Killed in Ambush
description: A man armed with a machine gun killed a woman and wounded four other people Tuesday as they sat in an automobile. Four of the victims were members of the same family who lived in a primarily Armenian neighborhood in Hollywood, the police said. They said the ambush might have been a staged in revenge for a shootout last year, involving the same family, that left one person dead and eight wounded.

title: JERSEY REASSESSING ITS NO-FAULT INSURANCE SYSTEM
description: New Jersey has the highest average automobile insurance rates in the country, and the causes and possible remedies are the subjects of intense debate between the Kean administration and the State Legislature.

title: General Mills Rises; Marriott Up 26.3%
description: Ending a record year for sales and earnings, General Mills Inc., the diversified food processor and retailer, reported that earnings in its fourth quarter jumped 58.8 percent, to $55.1 million, or $1.13 a share, from $34.7 million, or 68 cents, a year earlier.

title: PARIS SHOW DISPLAYS MYSTERY OF MAGRITTE
description: How many times have you seen a large, green, seductive apple dominating an advertisement that has absolutely nothing to do with apples? And how many pictures have you looked at in which a surrealistic cloud passes through a window from the great outdoors into a room that looks as if it badly needed an airing out?

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS EXPEDITED HANDLING OF DEATH ROW CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that a Federal appeals court properly refused to grant a stay of execution to a Texas inmate whose constitutional challenge to his murder conviction was technically still pending.

title: BONN VISITOR RATES CAPITAL, CALLS IT 'NICE'
description: Horst Ehmke, a 56-year-old West German politician, first visited the United States as a student more than three decades ago. Since 1967 he has come to Washington several times a year as a Social Democratic member of the Bonn Government and, after the German national elections last March, as the No. 2 leader of the opposition. In an interview in German and English on his latest visit, he made these observations about the American capital:

title: Unions Lose Court Fight On Construction Wages
description: A Federal appeals court panel, dealing a blow to construction unions, has upheld a Labor Department proposal to lower wage requirements under a 52-year-old law passed to protect workers on Federal projects.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our house is built on a concrete slab and every summer we have a problem with green mold in our closets. All the shoes and much of the clothing in these closets develop a horrid green color from the mildew. What can I do to prevent this?

title: Assault on Rebels Reported in Chad
description: Government forces counterattacked rebel positions today in the second day of fighting at an oasis crossroads in northeastern Chad, officials in Ndjamena, the capital, reported.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cuomo Diary: (Cont. From 1974)

title: BALDWIN UNIT SELLS ASSETS
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which is trying to raise cash to avoid insolvency, said yesterday that its leasing subsidiary had sold almost all the assets of its automobile, agricultural and general equipment divisions for about $63.8 million.

title: FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SOBEYS STORES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After $5,396,000 gain on sale of securities and other special items.

title: 'PROTECTIVE' SEARCH INSIDE AUTOMOBILE BACKED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that the police can conduct a ''protective'' search of the passenger area of a car without a warrant even if the suspect is out of the car and in custody.

title: Executive Changes At Meredith and 13-30
description: In magazine publishing circles, the news yesterday was that Stephen R. Burzon, 42 years old, is joining the Meredith Corporation as publisher of Metropolitan Home, and that Nicholas Glover, 40, an Annapolis graduate and one-time vice president, marketing, at R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, is coming aboard at the 13-30 Corporation in Nashville as president and chief executive officer.

title: Welcome to Carcassonne
description: The first walled city was not a city at all but a ring of fire inside which people huddled against the unknown beasts in the darkness outside. Eventually, it was discovered that other people were more threatening than any beast.

title: U.S. LAWMAKERS, IN MOSCOW, DISAGREE ABOUT A 'SIGNAL' ON MISSILES
description: A delegation of 21 American members of Congress ended a visit to the Soviet Union today in agreement that the Russians had been ''extraordinarily straightforward.''

title: NO, 'DEBATEGATE' ISN'T QUITE WATERGATE II
description: Spotting Debategate parallels is easy for an old Watergate wallower. One notes the initial public relations improvisation, ''Much ado about nothing!'' ''Third-rate burglary,'' falling back, in quick succession to an internal White House inquiry, then an F.B.I. investigation. And what to do about Congress?

title: COX PICKED OVER EVANS FOR S.E.C.
description: President Reagan, ending protracted and intense speculation, said today that he would nominate Charles C. Cox to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: No Headline
description: The Worm and the Apple If Fishermen, Why Not Bikers?

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Smaller Cities Led Increase In Population From 1970-80
description: Smaller cities and towns grew far faster in the 1970's than did bigger cities, expanding by nearly a third over the decade, according to a major summary of the 1980 census released today.

title: CITY TRANSIT OFFICER ACCUSED OF ASSAULT IN ARRESTS OF 5 MEN
description: A 34-year-old Transit Authority police officer has been indicted on charges of assaulting five men between August 1978 and April 1982 in the course of arresting them.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Lending to Latin America Declines
description: Borrowing by Latin American nations dropped sharply during the second half of 1982 as banks became reluctant to grant new short-term loans, according to a survey published today by the Bank for International Settlements.

title: BOY, 5, TESTIFIES THAT PARENTS KILLED HIS BROTHER, 3
description: A 5-year-old boy testified against his parents in Superior Court today, saying they beat his 3-year-old brother to death because they ''hated'' him.

title: FUTURIST AND THINKER ON NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: Herman Kahn, one of the nation's leading thinkers on nuclear strategies and the future, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Friday; OPENERS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra under Seiji Ozawa and the soprano Leontyne Price will open the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., tonight at 9 with a program featuring vocal works by Strauss and Brahms's Symphony No. 1. Brahms will also be performed at a prelude concert at 7 with Tom Krause, bass-baritone; Jules Eskin, cellist, and Gilbert Kalish, pianist. Sunday's program, starting at 2:30, will include Haydn's ''Creation.'' Tickets for tonight's music, including the prelude concert, are $9.50 to $45 for seats in the Shed or $7 for admission to the lawn; Sunday: $7.50 to $35 for the Shed, $5.50 for the lawn. Available at Ticketron outlets and through Chargit: 944-9300. Information: (413) 637-1666. FAIR DAYS IN WESTCHESTER

title: Foreign Debt Worries Send Dow Down by 10.21
description: Confusion over the prospects for higher interest rates and renewed concern over Brazil's ability to repay its large foreign debts caused stock prices to decline along a broad front in the final hour of trading yesterday.

title: BRIEFING
description: Getting Voters' Attention

title: AETNA CUTS LAST YEAR'S PROFITS 38%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company agreed today to eliminate $203 million in tax benefits from its 1982 earnings, thus settling a dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accounting practices.

title: MISSOURI FLOODING YIELDS ANCIENT INDIAN ARTIFACTS
description: Spring flooding of the Mississippi River has yielded Indian artifacts archeologists believe are from an 800-year-old city.

title: COURT UPHOLDS A CONFESSION OFFERED BEFORE PROSECUTION
description: When a defendant, on the advice of his lawyer, confesses to a crime before the prosecution has begun its case, he has not been denied effective assistance of counsel, the New York Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

title: TOURING OLD STONE HOUSES OF HUDSON VALLEY TOWN
description: In 1777, as British forces advanced up the Hudson River, the Council of Safety, the governing body of New York State, moved to Hurley in the central Hudson Valley and established a temporary capital.

title: Noles Is Freed on Appeal
description: A judge today freed the Chicago Cub pitcher Dickie Noles from jail on $1,000 bond, pending the outcome of Noles's appeal in a case involving an assault on a policeman.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blyth Eastman Paine Webber has named John W. Hyland a senior investment banker and managing director.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Bridge: One Must Be Very Careful When Going Into Reverse
description: A defender at the bridge table, like an automobile driver, must exercise considerable caution if he moves into reverse gear. Using standard leads, in which the king can be from A-K or K-Q, it is safe enough to reverse the A-K play to show a doubleton: Partner will quickly discover what is happening.

title: ADAM CLYMER NAMED TIMES POLLING EDITOR
description: Adam Clymer has been appointed by The New York Times to supervise news polling and other statistical news projects. He will be an assistant to the executive editor, A.M. Rosenthal, who announced the appointment yesterday.

title: ONE VIEW OF 'EXCESS BUREAUCRACY'
description: At one stop on his recent cross-country swing to talk about better schools, President Reagan provided an illustration of what he called ''excess bureaucracy.''

title: Ex-Rumasa Head Indicted
description: The former owner of Spain's largest private business empire has been charged in a Madrid court with a series of financial crimes.

title: A twin success in Italian cuisine.
description: TO achieve consistently high standards of food and service in one restaurant is a triumph in itself. To do so in two restaurants is a Herculean task, and one that has been accomplished by Adi Giovanetti. He has managed to maintain the three-star rating that his restaurant Il Nido on East 53d Street was given when it opened in 1979, and at the same time he has improved his first restaurant, Il Monello on Second Avenue, between 76th and 77th Streets. Given a two-star rating in 1978, Il Monello now rates three.

title: Commerce Dept. Choice
description: President Reagan has appointed former Ohio Representative Clarence J. Brown, a Republican, to replace Guy W. Fiske as Deputy Commerce Secretary. Mr. Brown, 56 years old, served in the House from 1965 until 1983, was a member of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and made an unsuccessful bid for governor of Ohio last year.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: People
description: * Carole Renz Kulman, director of marketing, promoted to vice president at Fidelity Union Bank, Newark.

title: 700 Claims Listed By Wilson Foods
description: In documents filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court, the Wilson Foods Corporation, the nation's largest pork processor, has listed 700 claims filed against it, and debts of more than $200 million.

title: Mireille Darc Injured
description: The French film actress Mireille Darc was seriously injured today when the car in which she was riding collided with a truck. The star of Jean-Luc Godard's ''Weekend'' and Yves Robert's ''Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe'' was reported in grave condition in a hospital in this northern town near the Swiss and French borders, suffering from head injuries and a damaged spleen.

title: U.S.F.L. Team to Tulsa
description: Commissioner Chet Simmons of the United States Football League announced today that a new franchise originally designated for San Diego was being moved to Tulsa. The team will be called the Oklahoma Outlaws and will begin play next spring.

title: Connecticut Light Bonds Are Priced
description: The Connecticut Light and Power Company's $85 million issue of 12 1/4 percent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1993 was priced at 99.71 percent, plus accrued interest, to yield 12.30 percent.

title: BAGS WITH CASH PART OF EVIDENCE IN A HEROIN CASE
description: Forty-four plastic bags filled with $1,379,240 in cash were presented as evidence yesterday at the Federal trial of eight people accused of being involved in a major heroin ring in Manhattan.

title: PUBLISHING: ON 'EXPURGATING' BOOKS
description: DURING the American Library Association's recent convention in Los Angeles, the group's young-adult services division issued a background report that said the three major school book clubs were ''expurgating books'' offered for sale through classrooms. The division formally notified Scholastic, Xerox Education Publications and Troll that they may not use its ''best books for young adults'' designation on a book or in promotional material for the book if the title or text has been changed from the book as originally published.

title: Hartford Asks U.S.  For Bridge Funds
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill asked the Federal Government today for emergency funds to replace the section of the Connecticut Turnpike bridge that collapsed last week. Three people were killed and three others badly injured.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: Two Share Lead by Shot at 65 MILWAUKEE, July 7 (AP) - Lon Hinkle, recovering from a long bout with shoulder problems, and Mark O'Meara, considered to be one of the PGA Tour's rising stars, shot seven-under-par 65's today and shared the first-round lead in the Milwaukee Open golf tournament. Both players carded eagles on the 524-yard, par-5 sixth hole.

title: A FAMILY OF BUILDERS DEVELOPS ITS FARM
description: The progeny of Alfred Kaskel, one of the city's major builders of the postwar period, spent the happy summers of childhood surrounded by the beauties of Doral Farm, the Kaskel estate in Connecticut.

title: Victoriana in spotlight.
description: DECORATIVE arts from Victorian times and later will be in the spotlight next week at two of New York's art-auction houses. Highlighting a sale next Wednesday at 10 A.M. at the William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street, is an 11-piece suite of Victorian parlor furniture made after the Civil War, for a house in Irvington, N.Y.

title: 18-Month Low In Car Layoffs
description: Indefinite layoffs among American auto workers fell below 200,000 this week for the first time in a year and a half, the major companies said today.

title: Warning by Phelps
description: Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame basketball coach, charges that ''misguided'' and ''misdirected'' parents are ''creating monsters'' when they push their children to excel in sports.

title: Expecting the Worst; And Not Getting It
description: Y esterday morning Samuel I. Schwartz said he woke up thinking, ''This is a not a good day to be chief of the Bureau of Traffic Operations.'' Mr. Schwartz, however, is the chief. And facing him was the task of closing half the upper roadway of the Queensboro Bridge.

title: 'Reagan Wants Peace,' Bush Says in Iceland
description: Vice President Bush said today that no agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States could be reached in arms reduction negotiations in Geneva unless the Russians came up with a new proposal.

title: IRANIANS, IN PARIS, BOW TO REBEL CHIEF AND GIVE UP
description: Six Iranians who seized an airliner over Iran on Wednesday released their remaining hostages here today and surrendered on orders from an exiled Iranian guerrilla leader.

title: Passing Up Football
description: While most outstanding collegiate athletes in the big-money sports look forward to a successful senior season so as to enhance their prospects for a pro career and a lucrative contract, Michael Carter, the burly nose guard of last year's Southern Methodist football team, has chosen to forgo his final year of eligibility to concentrate on shot-putting for the 1984 Olympics. On Wednesday, Carter won a shotput gold medal at the World University Games, as he did in 1981, and then said: ''I might lose a lot of money, but I'd rather be happy.

title: 3 FREE NIGHTS OF BLUES IN BROOKLYN
description: BROOKLYN does not appear on the list of the world's blues capitals. It's a long way from Chicago, Houston, Memphis or the Mississippi Delta. But the borough has blues fans aplenty, and this weekend ''Celebrate Brooklyn '83'' will present a weekend of blues at the Ninth Street Bandshell in Prospect Park. The three free concerts, tonight through Sunday at 8 P.M., will be double bills, including - of all things -Brooklyn-born blues musicians.

title: ARAFAT DEVELOPING STRATEGY AGAINST REBELS AND SYRIANS
description: Yasir Arafat has begun a series of moves designed to outmaneuver the Palestinian rebels and Syrian officials seeking to undermine his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization, senior Arafat aides indicated today.

title: A NIGHT OF LONG HITS AND ONE-LINERS
description: Harvey Kuenn may have set the tone when he told his American League players to forget their 11-year losing streak and ''go out and have some fun'' in the All-Star Game.

title: CBS Closes Down Gospel Music Unit
description: CBS Records Group has shut down its twoyear-old gospel music affiliate, Priority Records.

title: ALLEN SINAI NAMED LEHMAN FORECASTER
description: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. has named Allen Sinai, the financial forecaster, as a senior vice president and its chief economist. He will head the investment concern's new economic and financial markets department.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article June 2 about Israeli plans in Lebanon incorrectly described the Peace Now movement. Tzaly Reshef, a spokesman, says that although the group opposed the Israeli invasion of Lebanon as unjustified, its members would fight a war for Israel's survival.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS FEDERAL RESERVE TO AVOID RATE RISE
description: The Reagan Administration sought today to dissuade the Federal Reserve Board from provoking a sharp rise in interest rates, which could slow the economy's lively recovery. .

title: Oil Demand Rise Seen
description: United States petroleum demand has bottomed out and will rise through the first half of 1984, the Energy Information Administration said today. Demand is projected to rise to 15.7 million barrels daily in the first half of 1984, after reaching a low of 14.8 million barrels a day in the first half of 1983, the administration said. As consumption picks up in the second half of this year, it added, demand for 1983 as a whole is expected to rise to an average of 15.1 million barrels a day, compared with 15.3 million in 1982.

title: ART: THE CASE FOR CRAFTS
description: DESPITE the seeming openness of the art world today, a painter practicing a craft other than the application of pigment to canvas is regarded with suspicion by a ''vocal and powerful group of galleries, museums and critics,'' who tend to put down such craftart as ''decorative,'' according to William P. Miller Jr. That, at least, is the premise on which Mr. Miller, curator and deputy director of the Jamaica Arts Center in Jamaica, Queens, has assembled a show called ''Wallworks.'' It presents pieces by seven artists who've branched out - by Mr. Miller's lights - from more traditional fine-art mediums, such as paint, steel or stone, to ''craft'' materials, i.e., clay, fiber, paper.

title: SHULTZ LEAVES MIDEAST WITHOUT PROGRESS ON PULLOUT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his trip to the Middle East today saying that ''I can't point to any substantive achievement.''

title: Danish Unemployment
description: Unemployment in Denmark fell in May, for the first time this year, to 10.7 percent from April's 10.8 percent, the Government said today.

title: THEATER: 'FUNHOUSE' AND 'EMMETT' AT PUBLIC
description: IF you've previously encountered Eric Bogosian, you know that the title of his new one-man show at the Public Theater, ''FunHouse,'' is to be taken advisedly. Mr. Bogosian, a wiry young actor who performs his own material, specializes in impersonating the sleaziest of contemporary characters. He's a funny fellow, all right, but not what you'd call cheery. His favorite subject is death.

title: The U.N. Today; July 7, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee of the World Dis- armament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Vicki Morgan, a Model, Is Beaten to Death
description: Vicki Morgan, the former model who sued Alfred Bloomingdale for $10 million, was beaten to death with a baseball bat, and the police said her live-in companion turned himself in today and confessed to the murder.

title: Europe And The Wolf
description: Common Market Europe has cried ''wolf'' so often that scant attention is paid nowadays. But a seminar at the Aspen Institute here on what can be done to advance the European Community showed how far the goal of integration has receded.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P)(N reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: b-Including tax credits of $4 million for the latest first quarter and $2,550,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Off to See the Russians, A Maine Girl Is Excited
description: Samantha Smith, flashing her passport and sporting buttons promoting Maine, left today for a two-week trip to the Soviet Union at the invitation of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.

title: TAKING A MIDSUMMER DAY'S STROLL IN A SUBURBAN GARDEN
description: When the concrete sidewalks seem too harsh under foot, it is time to head out of the city and make contact with nature. There are guided trails through woodlands or grassy patches under shade trees, cool canopies for a picnic. Formal gardens have stately spires of hollyhocks and delphiniums, or informal ones show off sweeps of orange-yellow daylilies and the purple-blue spires of hostas.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
Lonnie Smith Returning
description: Lonnie Smith, the St. Louis outfielder who has been on the disabled list for a month because of a drug problem, is to be reactivated before tonight's game at San Diego, the Cardinals announced yesterday. The 27-year-old Smith was a big factor in the Cardinals' World Series championship last year and was batting .311 on June 9 when he disclosed his problem to Manager Whitey Herzog.

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-The company did not provide comparable year-ago results because it was in the development stage.

title: SIX-DAY RUNNERS TAKE PAIN IN STRIDE
description: Late yesterday afternoon, Siegfried Bauer, the leader of the New York Six-Day Run, now in its fourth day, lay on an air mattress in his tent for another brief rest. His face was so drawn that it appeared rubbery, and the dark shadows around his eyes were now creeping toward the bridge of his nose.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
No Dioxin Found At Site Near Plant
description: Tests taken on the grounds of a former pesticide plant in Bound Brook and in the surrounding area of the Somerset County community show no evidence of dioxin contamination, state officials said today.

title: Power System Unit To Be Mothballed
description: A nuclear power plant under construction in Washington will be mothballed because the company building it cannot come up with the nearly $1 billion needed to finish the project, a senior official said today.

title: Prime Computer Sees Lower Net
description: Prime Computer Inc. said that it expected its earnings this year to be ''significantly below'' 1982 levels. Second-quarter per-share earnings, the company said, are expected to fall about 25 percent below those of the first quarter, after a recent 3-for-2 stock split is taken into account.

title: U.S. Protests Barclay Ad
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would ask a Federal court to block the maker of Barclay cigarettes from advertising them as being 99 percent free of tar.

title: 28 Suspects Arrested In Florida Drug Raid
description: Federal agents arrested 28 people today and said they were seeking 13 others in a two-year crackdown on smuggling that has already led to the seizure of about 350,000 pounds of marijuana and the arrests of 94 people on Federal charges.

title: NOTEBOOK: EQUANIMITY RULES AS THE SHULTZES TAKE A TOUR
description: Although Secretary of State George P. Shultz travels with all the trappings of power, including an Air Force jet, security agents and instant communication links to the White House, he and his wife, Helen, sometimes try to be plain tourists.

title: Vatican Told Kidnapping Is Tied to Freeing Turk
description: The Vatican has reportedly received an anonymous telephone call demanding that Pope John Paul II press the Italian Government to free the Turkish gunman who shot him in St. Peter's Square in 1981. In return, the caller was quoted as saying, the 15-year-old daughter of a Vatican employee would be freed by men who kidnapped her last month.

title: Filipino Pay Is Raised
description: The minimum wage went up 8 percent today, to the equivalent of $3.10 a day, to help Filipinos cope with inflation stirred by devaluation of the peso two weeks ago.

title: 2 Lotto Winners To Split $3 Million
description: A 37-year-old member of Morocco's delegation to the United Nations and a 58-year-old window cleaner for the city will split the $3 million prize in last Saturday's Lotto drawing, lottery officials said yesterday.

title: PEKING AND HANOI BATTLING WITH BULLET AND BUFFALO
description: A sugar-cane farmer pointed out of his front door to the street where he said a Vietnamese sniper shot his only son as he was spreading turnips out to dry 16 months ago.

title: Plato Software By Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation said that it would introduce a software package that would enable users of the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer to gain access to a data base containing Plato, a popular instructional computer program used primarily in elementary schools.

title: Race and Responsibility
description: Black political, civic and religious leaders have summoned a House subcommittee to New York to examine their charge of increasing mistreatment of blacks by the police. Mayor Koch resents the charge and the appeal to Washington and fears the hearings may themselves damage community relations. He accuses a handful of black leaders of stirring discontent because they want his job.

title: NBC FILM ON TERROR WINS PRIZE
description: ''Special Bulletin,'' a controversial madefor-television film about nuclear terrorism that implicitly criticizes the way television handles news, was awarded the $25,000 Humanitas Prize today.

title: 19 SEEKING HOUSE SEAT VACATED BY CHICAGO MAYOR
description: With 19 candidates now in the running, a major battle has shaped up for the First Congressional District seat vacated by Harold Washington when he was elected Mayor in April.

title: NEW UPSTATE PRISON IS AUTHORIZED
description: New York's highest court ruled today that the state could begin converting part of the Marcy Psychiatric Center near Utica to a state prison.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America announced that it would restart 28,750 metric tons of capacity at its Badin, N.C., plant during the week of July 25, bringing the plant's operating rate to 100 percent of its 115,000 metric ton primary aluminum capacity.

title: OAKS DRAWS A BIG CAST BUT LACKS A STAR
description: The Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park tomorrow, the richest and toniest American race for 3-year-old fillies, is going to look like an auto race at the start. A record field of 17 was entered yesterday, a staggering number but not a surprising one.

title: A.& P. Surges 54%; Abbott Up 20.7%
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which has slipped to seventh from fifth in size among the nation's biggest food chains because of weak sales, reported yesterday that net income rose 54 percent in its first fiscal quarter ended June 18, while sales increased more than 10 percent.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Signal Plans to Assume Wheelabrator Unit Debt
description: The Signal Companies announced yesterday that if had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to assume $84.5 million principal amount of debentures issued by its Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. subsidiary.

title: All-Star Batboy Of the Ruth Era
description: John McBride, the batboy for the Chicago White Sox from 1929 through 1934, performed that job for the American League when it played in the first All-Star Game in Comiskey Park in 1933. He happened to be caught in the middle of a photograph taken at home plate when Babe Ruth, who hit the first home run in an all-star game, was welcomed with a handshake from Lou Gehrig.

title: Texan Drowns as 2 Men Walk Off, Witness Says
description: A man drowned in the San Antonio River running through this city after his pleas for help were ignored by two passersby, a witness said.

title: Reagan's Latin Envoy Arrives in Salvador
description: President Reagan's special envoy for Central America arrived today in San Salvador, where leftist leaders said earlier that they were ''interested and willing'' to talk to him.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''A LL of us ladies seek a little help from time to time,'' Arlene Dahl was saying, ''and now that the grandest lady of them all needs a little assistance, it behooves us to help.'' Miss Dahl, looking great in a deep mauve Helen Rose dress and seemingly in need of no help at all, was, of course, talking about the Statue of Liberty. The occasion Tuesday evening, at the Vista International Hotel's Nieuw Amsterdam Ballroom, was New York State's kickoff dinner-dance to raise funds for the restoration of Miss Liberty in time for her 1986 centennial.

title: GRIFFEY IS PLACED ON DISABLED LIST
description: As the Yankees left for Kansas City yesterday and the start of the second half of the season, they took a surprising step, placing Ken Griffey on the 21-day disabled list after he supposedly had been ready to play again.

title: Charges of Rape Are Dismissed
description: Rape charges were dismissed today against two Syracuse University basketball players when the woman who had made the charges said she would refuse to testify against them in Hartford Superior Court.

title: ALLEN REPORTED TO HAVE NAMED DEBATE INFORMER
description: A White House official said today that Richard V. Allen had identified a member of President Carter's National Security Council staff as the source of the ''innocuous'' material he received in the 1980 political campaign.

title: RATES JUMP IN ANTICIPATION OF FED MOVE
description: Interest rates climbed sharply yesterday when prices of fixedincome securities plunged in anticipation of a rise in the Federal Reserve's discount rate later this month. Increases in the rates ranged between one-tenth and five-tenths of a percentage point.

title: Miss Taylor's Illness Halts Production Anew
description: Lingering bronchitis and laryngitis problems prevented Elizabeth Taylor from going on last night in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives'' and the performance was canceled. A statement about the actress's condition was read to a crowd of patrons outside the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: Peabody to Get 68 Deak Units
description: The Peabody International Corporation said it had agreed to acquire 68 retail offices of Deak-Perera in the United States, Canada, Guam and Saipan for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: CHIEF IS REPLACED AT TROUBLED ATARI
description: Raymond E. Kassar, the mercurial executive who led Atari Inc. through a period of breakneck growth and sudden collapse, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday.

title: COUNTRY CLUBS LURE THE YOUNG
description: For Brian Silvestro, a 34-year-old lawyer in Fairfield, Conn., his wife, Jane, and their two sons, leisure outings on weekends and evenings normally mean a visit to either the Country Club of Fairfield, which they joined a year ago, or the Fairfield Beach Club, where they have been members for six years.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $299 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $165.28 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ORCHESTRA STRIKE CANCELS OPENING OF CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera canceled its season's opening last night, and all subsequent performances ''until further notice,'' after the collapse yesterday of last-minute contract negotiations between the company and its orchestra.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The Mets must contend again with Nolan Ryan, who struck out 12 batters in 72/3 innings the last time he pitched against them, on May 2 at Shea. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. The Yankees begin the second half only two games out of the division lead. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Harness Racing Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. Crash Town, Conan and Party Whip are considered the top contenders in the final of the third annual Peter Haughton Memorial Pace, for 2-year-olds. The purse is worth $559,800.

title: SCULPTURE OF SUMMER IS IN FULL BLOOM
description: THIS is the time of year when outdoor sculpture seems to sprout overnight from the ground of New York City. One night a city dweller may go to sleep, confident all outdoors will be as it was. But the next day, walking through a familiar park or campus, he may find himself face to face with an unexpected block of wood or steel. Reading a newspaper in Madison Square Park, he may look up and see a procession of papier-mache cows strung between trees by J. Nebraska Gifford. Or, sitting on a bench at Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn, he may find himself staring in disbelief at four wood nudes in the grass by Rolando Briseno or at scaffolding with a swing inside by James Swank.

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SYDNEY DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After special gains of $460,000.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $653,000.

title: AUSTRALIA II WIDENS LEAD IN CUP TRIALS
description: Australia II beat France 3 today in the trials to select the America's Cup challenger, strengthening her hold on first place.

title: Careless Justice for the Death Penalty
description: In upholding the death penalty seven years ago, the Supreme Court acknowledged that ''death is different'' and that the ultimate punishment deserved special handling. This week the Court approved procedures barely fit for protecting debtors against unlawful repossession of a car.

title: Court Clears Way For Lincoln West
description: An appeals court has unanimously overturned a lower-court decision that had brought a halt to the proposed Lincoln West luxury housing development along the Hudson River.

title: RULE-MAKING POWERS: AN AMERICAN DILEMMA
description: To the Editor:

title: 'DEADLY FORCE'
description: ''DEADLY FORCE,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, is full of the utterly witless, rhythmical motion associated with manufactured-for-television movies, in which one can predict plot developments by the placement of the commercial interruptions. There are, unfortunately, no commercial interruptions here. However, it isn't necessary to be a seer to know what must happen next in this story of a young, tough, macho former policeman, his wife, who is a television news reporter, and the hunt for a homicidal maniac in Los Angeles.

title: Open Houses in Litchfield Tomorrow
description: Residents of Litchfield, Conn., will open their homes and historical sites in the town to visitors tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., as part of the town's annual open-house day. Visitors will be able to tour such sites as the Tapping Reeve House and Law School, where Aaron Burr and Horace Mann studied, and the Trick House, named for the intricate electrical devices installed by a former owner.

title: Lockheed Missile
description: The Air Force today awarded a $1.05 billion contract to Lockheed Missiles and Space Company of Sunnyvale, Calif., to develop a jam-resistant communications satellite system for the military. The award comes more than four months after the Air Force chose the Lockheed Corporation unit to develop and build a system of eight Milstar satellites to be placed in orbit 22,300 miles above the earth.

title: 6 BEGIN SERVING TERMS IN PRISON IN ABSCAM CASE
description: With all appeals exhausted, six men convicted in the Abscam bribery case three years ago, including three former Congressmen, began serving their sentences yesterday. They were the first major figures in the case to go to prison.

title: VIC WERTZ, PLAYER IN MAJOR LEAGUES
description: Vic Wertz, a power-hitting first baseman who played in the American League for 17 seasons, 8 of them after making a stirring recovery from polio in 1955, died early this morning during heart surgery. He was 58 years old.

title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
description: b-After tax credit of $424,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: LAUNDRY WHITES FRESH APPEAL
description: Any sensible person knows that if you wear white in the city in summer you're going to look a mess by the end of the day. There's soot to contend with, not to mention heat, fumes, humidity and sweat.

title: FEDERAL HOUSING OFFICIAL QUITS AFTER INQUIRY CITES ABUSES OF OFFICE
description: Emanuel S. Savas, an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, resigned today after a Justice Department investigation found he had ''abused his office'' by having his staff work on his book on Government time.

title: HELPING THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS FULFILL ITS MISSION
description: When Dr. Daniel J. Boorstin, the social historian, Rhodes scholar and Pulitizer Prize-winning author, was invited by President Ford in 1975 to become the 12th Librarian of Congress, his nomination was vigorously opposed by professional librarians who charged he lacked experience as a professional librarian. Dr. Boorstin himself was not convinced he was right for the job.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
SPECIALIST IN POLITICS STARTED RIPON GROUP
description: Dr. John S. Saloma 3d, the founding president of the Ripon Society and a leading specialist on American politics, died of pneumocystic pneumonia at the Kaiser Foundation Hospital in San Francisco Wednesday. He suffered from Kaposi's sarcoma, a lymphatic cancer associated with the immunity breakdown of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Saloma was 48 years old.

title: Denmark's Oil Search
description: Denmark will begin accepting bids from foreign companies Friday for permits to look for offshore oil.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 8, 1983
description: International The failure of a Middle East mission was acknowledged by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. As he ended a four-day effort to bring about a withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon, Mr. Shultz concluded, ''I can't point to any substantive achievement.'' (Page A1, Columns 1-3.) Yasir Arafat has begun efforts designed to outmaneuver the Palestinian mutineers and Syrian officials seeking to undermine his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization, his aides indicated. (A3:5-6.)

title: SOIL CONSERVATIONISTS' CONTRIBUTION TO CLEAN WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: The Kelly-Springfield Tire Company, a unit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said that it would lay off more than 500 workers at its truck tire plant here starting Aug.12, bringing the total number of workers laid off at the plant to 1,023.

title: Feud Takes Wings
description: Dennis Walker, a Pete Rose fan, plans to continue his vendetta against the Cincinnati Reds and Dick Wagner, their president, for allowing Rose to go to the Philadelphia Phillies as a free agent four years ago. When the Phillies went to Riverfront Stadium last season, Walker, the 33-year-old manager of a sporting goods store, put up a banner there that read: ''Pete Rose Forever, Dick Wagner Never.''

title: A job for fans of Burt Reynolds.
description: DESPITE the lack of enthusiasm by New York critics for ''Stroker Ace'' (at the U.A. Gemini Twin, Gramercy and other theaters), its producer, Walter Wood, thinks Burt Reynolds fans will probably turn out. ''For the past five years,'' Mr. Wood says, ''Burt has been No. 1 at the box office, and during that period, there has seldom been a good review of anything he's done.''

title: Ex-Officer Gets Weekends in Jail
description: A former New York City police officer convicted last May of second-degree assault for striking a handcuffed prisoner on the head with a night stick in a Brooklyn station house was sentenced yesterday to spend weekends in jail for one year.

title: STANFORD'S ADVISERS REAFFIRM DISMISSAL FOR ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: A special panel of professors has found that Stanford University was justified in dismissing a graduate student last winter because of his conduct while working in China, the school said yesterday.

title: U.S. REJECTS DESEGREGATION PLANS FOR UNIVERSITY SYSTEMS OF 5 STATES
description: The Department of Education has rejected desegregation plans submitted by five states for their public college and university systems, a department spokesman said today.

title: Workers Plug Leak in Dam
description: Workers plugged a leak in the Pinopolis Dam today, clearing the way for 1,500 to 3,000 downstream residents who had been evacuated to return home. Workers spied muddy water churning from the ground on the downstream side of the structure about 9:30 A.M. Wednesday. A dam failure would have affected up to 30,000 people on the Cooper River beneath Lake Moultrie and the adjoining Lake Marion, civil defense officials said.

title: JULIA WALSH TO SELL FIRM TO TUCKER, ANTHONY
description: Julia Walsh, the 60-year-old chairman of Julia Walsh & Sons and one of the most prominent women in financial management, has agreed to sell her firm for an undisclosed price to Tucker, Anthony & R.L. Day Inc., a Boston investment and brokerage concern. The transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval, is expected to be completed in August.

title: INFRARED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
'Tap Dance Kid' joins schedule in a season of musicals.
description: ENTER the new Broadway season, singing and dancing. No one but a perennially optimistic producer would predict how the coming musicals are going to fare, but one thing is clear: there are going to be a lot of them. The schedule already includes ''La Cage aux Folles,'' opening Aug. 21 at the Palace; ''Zorba'' on Oct. 9 at the Broadway, and ''Doonesbury'' on Nov. 10 at the Biltmore. In addition, ''Mame,'' ''Chaplin'' and ''The Wiz'' are beginning pre-Broadway tryouts, and there are some new musicals fermenting in workshop productions around town.

title: Chock Full Stake
description: Milton Petrie, chairman of the Petrie Stores Corporation, has purchased 4.2 percent of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, Chuck Full said. It said that Mr. Petrie had bought the stock from Lillian Schwartz Black, former wife of William Black, chairman of the company until his death last March. The company has been engaged in a running battle with Jerry Finkelstein, a dissident stockholder, who has been attempting to replace current management. Mr. Petrie could not be reached for comment.

title: EXPLORING ROUTE 66
description: SUNDAY at 11 P.M. on Channel 13, ''Matters of Life and Death,'' one of the more unfortunate titles for an anthology series, returns for a second season on public television. The ''matters'' covered in the weekly presentations of independently produced half-hour documentaries can include anything from personal viewpoints and regional social issues to what a news release describes as ''universal truths about the human experience in America today.'' In any event, the series has a disarming way of coming up with offbeat gems, material you are not likely to see elsewhere on television.

title: Amsterdam News In Pact With Union
description: The New York Amsterdam News and its striking employees reached a tentative agreement yesterday to end the 22-week-old strike against the black-oriented weekly. Neither side would give details of the settlement pending ratification by the workers and the newspaper's directors.

title: 3 in Presidency At Pinkerton's
description: Three executives of Pinkerton's Inc. have been appointed to the new office of president.

title: PULL ALL ISRAELIS OUT OF LEBANON
description: It is time for Israel to begin withdrawing its troops from all of Lebanon and to replace them with alternative military arrangements -provided by the multinational force and the militia of the Lebanese commander Maj. Saad Haddad - that assure our security.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani DISRAELI. Sarah Bradford. 432 pages. Stein and Day. $19.95.

title: Davis Advances To Semifinals
description: Unseeded Scott Davis advanced to the semifinals of the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame tennis championships today with a 7-5, 7-5 victory over Tim Gullikson.

title: IT'S A BUSY TIME FOR DODY GOODMAN
description: Dody Goodman was wandering through Bloomingdale's the other day, sporting pink ruffles and her usual tousled mop of strawberry-blond ringlets, when she was recognized by several fans as Mary Hartman's mother, Martha Shumway. But when Miss Goodman paused to chat, her fans were stunned. ''They said, 'Oh my goodness, you really talk that way!' '' Miss Goodman reports.

title: U.S. PREMIERE FOR WAGNER'S 'LIEBESVERBOT' AT JERSEY FESTIVAL
description: For nearly a century, Richard Wagner's music was thought of largely in terms of the 10 music dramas that make up the standard canon, from ''Der Fliegende Hollander'' to ''Parsifal.'' But in recent years, increased attention has been paid to his three-plus earlier operas, as well.

title: Judge Orders Hearings For Jailed Cubans
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Government to begin hearings within 60 days for more than 1,000 Cuban refugees seeking release from the prison where they have been held since their 1980 flight from Cuba by sea.

title: Umpire Faces Suspension
description: Joe West, a National League umpire, is reportedly facing a three-day suspenson without pay and a $500 fine for shoving Joe Torre after a Braves' game against the Houston Astros on June 28.

title: GAF Sale Plans
description: The Southwestern General Corporation withdrew a $140 million offer to buy the GAF Corporation's roofing business, GAF said, because of what it called the ''uncertain status'' of a proxy fight against the company. GAF, which has an agreement to sell the operations to Odyssey Partners of New York if the other plan collapsed, said it was negotiating with Odyssey to close the deal next month on ''substantially similar'' terms.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Charter Medical Corp.'s $25 million issue of 13 percent notes due in 1993 was priced at par, plus accrued interest from July 1, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Common Stock

title: Arson Suspect Arrested In Six Church Blazes
description: A car salesman was charged today with setting fires earlier this week at six central Texas churches. Most of the targets of the arson attacks were churches with predominately black congregations.

title: SCRANTON HAULER IS ACCUSED OF FELONIES ON TOXIC WASTE
description: Pennsylvania prosecutors today announced the filing of two felony racketeering charges against a Scranton hauler of toxic wastes who served major manufacturers in three states.

title: HOMELESS FEEL LOST AS CHURCH SHELTERS SHUT FOR THE SEASON
description: The woman, her downcast face a network of lines, sat inside a storefront center for the homeless and pointed to where she had slept the previous night.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review yesterday of Robert H. Boyle's book ''At the Top of Their Game'' misidentified the publisher. It is Nick Lyons Books/Winchester Press.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Assets figures represent net assets.

title: NEW METROPOLITAN AREAS AND THEIR POPULATIONS
description: The 38 areas in the United States designated by the Federal Government since the 1980 census. Two others, in Puerto Rico, are not shown.

title: ART: SIX PAINTERS AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: ''SIX PAINTERS'' is the title of an exhibition that can be seen at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers through July 17. Organized by Peter Langlykke, the museum's director, it is of painters born between 1939 and 1948 who have found favor with Mr. Langlykke. As he is roughly their contemporary, it can be construed as a generational manifesto.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-There were no comparative per share figures since Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association converted to a stock association in November 1982.

title: Allen Kanfer, English Teacher And Prolific Poet, Dead at 78
description: Allen Kanfer, a widely published poet who taught English at Grover Cleveland High School in Ridgewood, Queens, for 40 years, died Wednesday night after a long illness at his home in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: POP JAZZ
description: UB40, the British band that will be at the Ritz tonight and tomorrow night, and Dennis Brown, the Jamaican singing star who will be at My Father's Place in Roslyn, L.I., tomorrow night, represent two sides of a complex and increasingly influential pop phenomenon - reggae. This lilting Jamaican music has become one of today's most pervasive pop influences; reggae rhythms and reggae-influenced record engineering and electronic effects have figured prominently in million-selling pop hits by the Rolling Stones, Paul Simon, the Police, Men at Work and many others.

title: INDEX OPTIONS KEEP GROWING
description: Less than a year ago there were no options on stock indexes, only options on individual stocks. Now there are several, and new ones keep springing up, each with a different slant.

title: Tribute to Fullers Tuesday
description: A memorial service for R. Buckminster Fuller, the inventor, and his wife, Anne, is to be held at 1 P.M. Tuesday at the Unity by the Sea Church, 1245 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, Calif. The Fuller family called on the couple's friends to set aside a minute at that time to ''reaffirm their own commitment to the success of all of us aboard spaceship earth.''

title: Kenya's Ruling Party Suspends Key Politician
description: Charles Njonjo, once one of East Africa's most powerful politicians, was suspended today from Kenya's ruling party.

title: Market Place; Coal Stocks: Bleak Outlook
description: OLD KING COAL is no merry old soul these days. ''Coal is a horror story in terms of demand,'' said Joel Price of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''We cannot think of any major positive for the coal industry at the current time,'' said Charles A. Bradford of Merrill Lynch.

title: NEW PORT OFFICIAL FOUND HER JOB IN NEWSPAPERS
description: Susan Frank read in the newspapers that New York City was looking for a Commissioner of Ports and Terminals. ''So I sent in a resume,'' she said yesterday in Mayor Koch's office in City Hall after her appointment to the $62,000-a-year job was announced.

title: Armed Men Raid Offices Of Chilean Labor Group
description: About two dozen men armed with machine guns raided the Santiago headquarters of a labor organization tonight and abducted several people, a union official said.

title: Recruiter Picks Himself For B.& J. Position
description: About six years ago, James Raineri, an award-winning art director, gave up the agency business to go into personnel recruitment. He recently got an assignment from David A. Bell, president of Bozell & Jacobs for the Atlantic and Middle West, to find a team to serve as creative directors at B.& J./New York.

title: Widow of Ex-Justice Named To Supreme Court of Maine
description: A lawyer who is the widow of a Maine Supreme Court Justice was nominated by Gov. Joseph E. Brennan today to be the first woman on the state's highest court.

title: Guggenheim Concerts
description: The Guggenheim Concert Band is giving free concerts in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park today and Sunday and at Seaside Park, on Ocean Parkway and Sea Breeze Avenue in Brooklyn, tomorrow.

title: Prudential-Bache To Buy Gelfand
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Gelfand, Quinn & Associates Inc., an investment advisory firm in Cleveland.

title: MARYLAND REALTY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $340,000 for the quarter and $350,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $12,000 for the quarter and $21,000 for the 6 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Going Right to the Top, Or Trying to, Anyway

title: U.S. War Games Set In 4 Mideast Nations
description: The Pentagon announced today that 5,500 United States troops will take part next month in the largest American military exercises held in Egypt since the two countries began cooperating militarily.

title: Esmark Bid Is Altered
description: Esmark Inc. said today that it had waived a condition of its tender offer for Norton Simon Inc. regarding the exclusive distributorship agreement for Johnnie Walker Scotch whiskies and Tanqueray gin with Norton's subsidiary, Somerset Importers.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Results for the latest year include a gain of $3.5 million, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of interest in a subsidiary. Results for the previous year include a gain of $3.7 million, or 40 cents a share, from exchange of company's investment.

title: GOVERNORS URGE A SINGLE DRINKING AGE
description: The Governors of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey said last night that they would work together to legislate a uniform drinking age for the three states.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 12 Graduating Dogs to Get Police Shields Today

title: BIG ISLAND NEAR MIAMI BEING DEVELOPED
description: Nearly a century after developers began transforming Florida's pristine east coast and barrier islands, the last sizable island in Miami's Biscayne Bay is being turned into a half-billion-dollar resort community.

title: U.S. Jury in Chicago Indicts 4 In Bomb and Terrorism Case
description: Four Puerto Ricans were indicted Wednesday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to bomb military facilities and rob Chicago Transit Authority money collectors.

title: 3 Gold Medals Won By Nigeria in Track
description: Three Nigerians attending colleges in the United States each won a track-and-field event today to give Nigeria its first gold medals ever in the World University Games.

title: DOCTOR'S N.B.A. DIAGNOSIS
description: T he Philadelphia 76ers' 10th and last choice in the recent college draft, and the National Basketball Association's 228th and final selection, was Dr. Norman Horvitz, a graduate of the Philadelphia School of Pharmacy, class of '56. He is 49 years old, 5 feet 10 inches, 205 pounds. Not the artist's conception of a hoop star.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a very intelligent commission. I intend to take this salary.''

title: CABARET: LAURA THEODORE
description: NOT many cabaret singers can claim a fully developed four-octave range and a stylistic versatility that encompasses sophisticated popjazz, 1960's soul music, hard rock and big cabaret ballads. But Laura Theodore, who opened a five-night engagement at Sweetwaters on Tuesday, has that kind of vocal endowment combined with a genuine feel for widely divergent pop idioms.

title: Baseball Bonanza
description: A devoted New York baseball fan who attends the games of the Yankees and Mets with regularity can accumulate a trove of gifts that also make the teams happy.

title: BLACKS FORM UNITED FRONT IN VOTE DRIVE
description: Albert Vann's beard has become flecked with gray, he has traded his dashiki for three-piece suits and monogrammed shirts, and he has graduated from a teaching post to a seat in the New York State Assembly.

title: Monsanto Sees Silicon Demand
description: The Monsanto Company's Monsanto Electronic Materials unit said that a temporary shortage of silicon for microprocessors and computer memories may develop later this year because of an extremely sharp rise in demand.

title: CHEMICAL COMPANIES ASK E.P.A. FOR MAJOR ROLE IN CLEANUP EFFORTS
description: The chemical industry has formally proposed to William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency that the industry take a major role in the cleanup of toxic waste dumps, an official of the Du Pont Company said today.

title: Chrysler Reshapes Leadership; Iacocca Forms 4-Man Office
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today a major reorganization of its top leadership into a four-man office of the chairman headed by the company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 8, 1983; The Economy
description: The Administration sought to dissuade the Federal Reserve from taking any action that could provoke a rise in interest rates. The Fed is reported to be concerned that rapid growth in the money supply will touch off a new surge of inflation and that such growth should be curbed by an increase in interest rates. (Page A1.)

title: NEW YORKERS' LUNGS NEED E.P.A. ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Doyle Dane Acquires Brignull Le Bas Gould
description: Brignull Le Bas Gould in London, two years old and billing about $4.5 million, has been acquired by Doyle Dane Bernbach International. And although it will operate for a time under its own name, it will ultimately be merged into the D.D.B. London office.

title: METS AT MIDPOINT: HOWARD SEES GAINS
description: The manager, admittedly, is an optimist, which explains Frank Howard's enthusiasm in the face of adversity. The Mets begin the second half of the National League season against the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium tonight, and Howard says that progress is being made despite the team's 30-50 record.

title: REAGAN, RECALLING NIXON ERA, SAID TO SHUN HIS OWN INQUIRY
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had decided as a matter of post-Watergate prudence not to personally call in chief aides to conduct his own inquiry into their conflicting accounts about the 1980 campaign debate controversy.

title: Foote, Cone; Marschalk, And Ally Gain Business
description: New business was awarded yesterday to Foote, Cone & Belding, to Ally & Gargano and to Marschalk, all of whose managements are quietly pleased.

title: Advertising; Bates Unit Uses Japan System
description: SAWDON & BESS, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide since 1979, is experimenting with some of the well-publicized forms of Japanese management, the ones that give the work force more say in operations.

title: A GRADUATE SCHOOL THAT REALLY ISN'T
description: The largest graduate school here is not within the ivy-covered walls of Georgetown University or along the downtown streets of George Washington University. It's at the Department of Agriculture, and it's not animal husbandry they're teaching there.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
BRITISH TO WEIGH A DEATH PENALTY
description: A motion to reintroduce the death penalty for murder was placed today on Parliament's agenda for next Wednesday. The motion, and accompanying amendments naming various types of murder that might carry a death penalty, is the third major attempt to reintroduce hanging since the death penalty was abolished in 1964. The previous attempts, in 1979 and 1982, failed by a wide margin, but this week's motion is given a much better chance of passing. It comes just one month after general elections brought a large, new group of Conservatives in favor of capital punishment into Parliament.

title: U.S.I.A. Chief Repays $22,000
description: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, reimbursed the Federal Government for much of the cost of installing a $31,713 security system in his home after the White House cautioned him that the expenditure could embarrass him and President Reagan.

title: British G.E.  Profit Up 9%
description: The General Electric Company of Britain said today that profits rose 9 percent in the year ended March 31, to 389 million, or the equivalent of $596 million, from 358 million a year earlier.

title: MANHATTAN TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $249,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Placed Ken Griffey, o utfielder-first baseman, on 21-day dis- a bled list retroactive to last Saturday. Re- c alled Steve Balboni, first baseman, from C olumbus farm team in International L eague. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Optioned Kevin H agen, pitcher, to Louisville in the Ameri- c an Association. Announced reactivation o f Lonnie Smith, outfielder, from disabled l ist before game with the Padres at San D iego Friday night. Smith had been off r oster with a drug problem. TEXAS (AL) - Reactivated Mike Ri- c hardt, second baseman, and sent him to O klahoma City farm team for rehabilita- t ion for maximum of 20 days. Richardt s uffered a knee injury in April.

title: JERSEY IS OFFERED NEW DISTRICTING PLAN
description: TRENTON July 7 - A new Congressional redistricting plan was introduced in the State Assembly today by the Democrats to replace the current map, which was ruled invalid last month by the United States Supreme Court.

title: NEW SCHOOL BOARD CHIEF
description: James F. Regan said yesterday after he was named president of New York City's Board of Education that he had one problem: He did not want to leave his office for a larger one down the hall because ''I can see

title: DEVELOPMENT PLANS DIVIDE V.I.P.'S IN A CALIFORNIA DESERT RESORT
description: The company that wants to build a 250-room hotel, a conference center and 240 condominiums and townhouses on 90 acres in the hills behind City Hall counts former President Gerald R. Ford and Leonard K. Firestone, former United States Ambassador to Belgium, among its supporters.

title: CHILD SUPPORT FREQUENTLY NOT PAID
description: Fewer than half of the women awarded child-support payments are collecting the full amount, and even those who do are losing ground to inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: BIG RAISES SOUGHT FOR CITY OFFICIALS BY MAYORAL PANEL
description: All elected officials in New York City, from the Mayor to members of the City Council, should get substantial pay raises, a mayoral panel recommended yesterday.

title: A DISPUTED BALANCE
description: After some tough talks with Yuri Andropov of the Soviet Union, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said he was of the opinion that ''there is still a chance to get somewhere in Geneva.''

title: ARAB MAYOR AND COUNCIL OUSTED
description: The Israeli military government in the occupied West Bank dismissed the Arab Mayor of Hebron and the City Council Thursday night after an Israeli student was stabbed to death in the city's vegetable market.

title: KOCH TO IMPOSE CULTURAL AID LIMIT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he intended to limit the city's financial contributions to cultural institutions to 50 percent of their budgets. The limit was recommended earlier in the day by the Mayor's Advisory Commission for Cultural Affairs and strongly endorsed by Cultural Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson.

title: News Analysis
description: As far as Republican and Democratic campaign officials over the last two decades can recall, the quantity and quality of information coming from the Carter Administration to the Reagan campaign team in 1980 was not business as usual.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Lanier, the Milwaukee Bucks' 34-year-old free-agent center, who is constantly bothered by knee problems, underwent surgery again, this time for the removal of bone and tissue fragments from the joint in his left knee. Similar surgery was performed on Lanier's right knee last December. Dr. David Haskell, the Bucks' orthopedic surgeon, who performed the arthroscopy, said Lanier should be able to play next season. ... Beth Heiden, the speed-skating and bicycling champion, reached a $60,000 out-of-court settlement with the owners of her Madison, Wis., apartment.

title: Picture of Health
description: The Philadelphia Stars, who won 15 games and lost 3, the best record in the United States Football League, have only one minor injury to contend with as they prepare to play the Chicago Blitz tomorrow in the playoffs. Ken Dunek, a tight end, pulled a hamstring muscle last weekend but is expected to be ready to play.

title: BALLET: 'LA SONNAMBULA'
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater has turned its production of George Balanchine's ''Sonnambula'' into an action-packed Gothic romance. The result, when the ballet was seen for the first time this season Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, made for deeply moving and even chilling theater. Every member of the cast led by Chrisa Keramidas, Victor Barbee and Susan Jaffe seemed to sense the dramatic intensity below the surface of the work.

title: JAZZMOBILE BEGINS SUMMER CONCERTS
description: The Jazzmobile began its summer series of free concerts this week, and it is sponsoring tonight's performance by the tenor saxophonist Johnny Griffin and his quartet. Mr. Griffin, who has performed with Art Blakey, Thelonious Monk and Bud Powell, lived in France from 1963 to 1978, when he returned to the United States to wide acclaim. He will perform at 7 P.M. at 132d Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and Lenox Avenue.

title: A 9% Lenox Stake
description: The Ivan F. Boesky Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that, together with others, it had acquired 406,700 shares, or 9 percent, of the common stock of Lenox Inc. In its filing, the Boesky group said it had acquired the shares for risk arbitrage and other investment activities, and said it intended to tender its shares to the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, which is trying to acquire Lenox for $90 a share. The group purchased the shares from June 8 through June 28 at prices ranging from $76 to $89.50 a share, for a total of $33.9 million, it said. It also sold 71,000 shares between June 10 and June 23 at prices ranging from $78.79 to $85.50.

title: MINI MART CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in May 1983.

title: Economic Scene; 'Scientific' Role Attacked
description: informed criticism of their failings as forecasters and policy advisers, are expressing increasing anxiety to each other over the state of economics.

title: 5-WEEKEND ARTS EXTRAVAGANZA IN PURCHASE
description: LIKE a seemingly endless stream of colorful scarves emerging from a magician's sleeve, Pepsico Summerfare '83 begins this weekend with music, theater, dance and art, then stretches for four more weekends of inspired play. This major summer arts festival brings together performers from all over the world for 140 events staged in four theaters, amid 500 acres of lawns and gardens on the grounds of the State University college at Purchase in Westchester County.

title: Quartet on West Side
description: The vibraphonist Milt Jackson and the bassist Ray Brown are leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). The group also includes Stanley Cowell on piano and Mickey Roker on drums. Sets begin at 10:30 P.M. and 12:30 and 2 A.M.; there is an $8 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: MISGUIDED REAGAN PARTISAN ON STUDENT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From the People Who Gave You ZIP: 10128

title: HIGHLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Per share figure for the latest period includes a provision of $1.85 for income taxes that may be payable with respect to net unrealized appreciation in the corporation's portfolio of investments at said date, if the net appreciation is realized by the company. Assets figures represent net assets.

title: EX-TYPIST FOR WACHTELL ACCUSED OF INSIDER TIPS
description: A former typist at a New York law firm that is one of the nation's specialists in corporate mergers was accused today of illegally passing tips about pending mergers to friends and relatives who were said to have used the information to make $2.7 million in the stock market.

title: A TENTATIVE ACCORD IS REPORTED AT THE EAST-WEST PARLEY IN MADRID
description: Delegations from East and West reportedly reached tentative agreement here today on a proposed final document for the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Diplomats said the development brought nearly three years of often-deadlocked talks on detente close to an end.

title: One of a Kind
description: Viewers of the All-Star Game on Wednesday night may have been puzzled to see George Brett of the Kansas City Royals wearing shoes that did not match. The mismatch was not, as was mirthfully suggested on television, to enable Brett to collect endorsements from two shoe manufacturers.

title: Whalers Name Coach
description: Jack (Tex) Evans, a former National Hockey League player and veteran coach, was named head coach of the Hartford Whalers yesterday and warned fans not to expect miracles from a team that, he acknowledged, is in poor shape. The 55-year-old Evans was chosen by Emile Francis, a former Ranger teammate who is the Whalers' new director of operations, and was given the task of helping to rebuild a franchise that barely escaped the worst record in the league last season. ''I would like to be able to sit here and say I have a magic wand to turn things around in Hartford,'' Evans said, ''but I don't.''

title: 'TOO LITTLE, TOO LATE' ON AIR FIRE SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Discussion Puzzles the Public
description: The Rome Zoning Board of Appeals met in an open meeting Wednesday night, as a new state law requires.

title: Leonard's New Fight
description: Forced into premature retirement from boxing by a detached retina a week before his 26th birthday last year, Sugar Ray Leonard continues pushing himself out of fear of boredom.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
