QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After tax credits of $409,000 for the quarter and $731,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $88,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 6 months. Revenue represents sales by the company and its subsidiaries and franchise operations.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 4.
Curry Retains Title
description: Bruce Curry, a 27-year-old Californian making his first title defense, stopped Hidekazu (Rocky) Akai in the seventh round tonight and retained the World Boxing Council's superlightweight championship.

title: Tracy Caulkins Loses and Wins
description: Tracy Caulkins was beaten in the 100-meter butterfly but came back to win the 400-meter individual medley tonight in the opening events of a Winners international meet at the Maryland Farms Racquet and Country Club.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: L.I. Clam Beds May Remain Shut
description: Nearly 20,000 acres of polluted clam beds on Long Island's South Shore probably will remain closed permanently because of the high cost of improving the beds' water quality, a Long Island official said today.

title: CBS HALTS FILM ON NICARAUGA
description: CBS News announced today that it had scrapped a documentary on Nicaragua because the producer who was preparing it had been suspended in connection with a controversial documentary on Vietnam.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The martial law administrator, Lieut. Gen. Hussain Ershad, announced today that a general election would be held by March 1985, three years after he seized power in a military coup.

title: STAKE IN HUTTON IS REPORTED SOLD
description: The Transamerica Corporation, a big West Coast financial services company, has sold its stake in the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: I.M.F. Head Views '83-'84
description: The head of the International Monetary Fund forecast today a relatively moderate and gradual recovery for the industrial world this year and next.

title: OPERA: 'NABUCCO' IN THE PARK
description: The New York Grand Opera began its 10th anniversary season of free summer performances Wednesday night with a concert presentation of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' at the Central Park Bandshell.

title: Drug's Ads Held Deceptive
description: There is insufficient evidence to support advertising claims that the medication Aspercreme relieves minor pain caused by arthritis and rheumatism, a Federal administrative law judge ruled today. Upholding a 1981 Federal Trade Commission complaint against Thompson Medical Company of New York, Montgomery K. Hyun, an administrative law judge for the commission, said said the product's advertisements were false and deceptive. He ordered them halted unless a disclaimer was carried.

title: UNIVERSITY FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: Views of America Through Foreign Eyes
description: T hey gathered in Battery Park and shared a picnic and their reflections on life in the United States. For their last weekend before returning home, 35 exchange students from 24 nations arrived here after a year in several towns in Maine.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: If You Want a Limo, Call, Don't Wave

title: COURT BLOCKS RULE ON NOTICE BY FAMILY PLANNING CLINICS
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Reagan Administration had no legal authority to require federally financed family planning clinics to notify the parents of young women who were given birth control devices.

title: E.E.C. to Act On Steel Curb
description: The European Economic Community decided today to press for compensation from the United States for recently announced import curbs on high-grade steel, European Commission sources said.

title: BELIZE BREATHING A BIT EASIER OVER LATIN NEIGHBOR
description: ''Time longer than rope,'' goes a favorite Creole proverb here. The saying, meaning that sooner or later justice prevails, has taken on a new timeliness for Belize, which finally seems to be inching toward a settlement of an old border dispute with Guatemala.

title: Police Accused Of Sunbathing
description: Five officers assigned to the police detail at Orchard Beach in the Bronx were suspended without pay yesterday for being off their post and out of uniform, authorities said, after they were found sunbathing at a small pool they had put on the roof of a beach building.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: CITY WEIGHS SUIT ON ABATEMENT GRANTED TO CBS
description: The Koch administration is considering a lawsuit against CBS Inc. in an effort to recover tax money that it has allowed the company to avoid paying, a city official said yesterday.

title: F.T.C. Reports Avco Agreement
description: Avco Financial Services Inc. of Newport Beach, Calif., has agreed not to use such abusive tactics as threats of violence and profane language to collect debts, the Federal Trade Commision said.

title: Ex-Official Fined In Princeton Theft
description: A former Princeton University official who pleaded guilty to misappropriating $127,500 in university funds has been fined $6,000 in New Jersey Superior Court.

title: Bridge: Possibilities of Play Seem To Be Limited on Occasion
description: Some people think that all the possibilities in card play have long ago been exhausted, but that is a serious misconception. As an example, consider the diagramed deal, played by Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., one of the country's most brilliant and successful young players. He brought home a part-score contract, thanks to a most remarkable and interesting ending.

title: Marcos Threatens 2 American Bases
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos threatened today to remove Americans from their two military bases here and seek a military pact with the Soviet Union if Congress refused to provide $900 million in rent for the installations.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes $177,000, or 7 cents a share, tax benefit recognized in the first quarter of 1983 for an investment incentive in the company's Belgium operation. The share earnings were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 2.

title: A SEASON FOR LOOKING AT ALL THE TALL BUILDINGS
description: Leading his family on a forced march through Manhattan, Tom Sparacio of Snohomish, Wash., looked over his shoulder to announce that the next stop on their sightseeing tour was the New York Stock Exchange. His 6-year-old son, Jeff, could not wait to see the cows and pigs.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Frank Hewlett, 74, Journalist; Covered War and Washington
description: Frank West Hewlett, an award-winning correspondent in World War II and longtime reporter in the nation's capital, died Thursday of bronchial pneumonia in Arlington, Va. He was 74 years old.

title: NEW YORK'S JOBLESS RATE HELD STEADY LAST MONTH
description: The unemployment rate in New York City remained steady at 8.9 percent last month, but rose sharply to 8.4 percent in New Jersey and to 9.2 percent in New York State, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: The Police Blotter
description: An agitated man barged into the midtown Manhattan offices of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan yesterday and demanded to go to Ireland, the police said. The man, identified only as Jeremiah Sullivan, was taken by the police to Bellevue Hospital for psychiatric tests.

title: Hughes Expects Loss in Quarter
description: The Hughes Tool Company said it expected to report a loss in the second quarter of $19 million to $22 million, in contrast to net income of $45.4 million, or 81 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Second-quarter sales are expected to total $256 million to $277 million, compared with $426.6 million in last year's second quarter.

title: Injury Report
description: The Cosmos' recent 4-0 victory over Team America may have cost them the services of Giorgio Chinaglia for as long as two weeks. Chinaglia, who suffered a hamstring injury, played 222 games before missing 3 on a recent business trip to Europe. ... ''There is now joy in his life,'' said a therapist for Normand Leveille, 20, the former Boston Bruin, who is undergoing treatment in Montreal after a nearfatal cerebral hemorrhage during a National Hockey League game last season.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income

title: Sun Banks Sells Nine Branches
description: Sun Banks Inc. of Orlando said it had arranged the sale of nine branch offices for $17.5 million to facilitate its merger with Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami.

title: U.S. MEDICAL AID TO EL SALVADOR 'MUST BE CONDEMNED'
description: The Reagan Administration is evincing a new-found interest in health care in El Salvador. The Defense Department has sent about 25 military medical men to El Salvador ''to help in the regeneration of the medical infrastructure,'' and the Agency for International Development will undertake a health system vitalization project through the Salvadoran Ministry of Health that may cost $24 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: President and Pen Pal

title: ALASKA MUTUAL BANK (ANCHORAGE, ALASKA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The company went public in March 1982.

title: YANKS, RAWLEY DEFEAT ROYALS
description: The Kansas City Royals rapped 10 more hits against the Yankees tonight than the Boston Red Sox got in the last game the Yankees played. But the hits didn't do the Royals any good as the Yankees won, 9-2, behind Shane Rawley's pitching.

title: WARSAW PRESSING DRIVE ON DISSENT
description: Despite public hints that martial law restrictions may soon be lifted after the visit of Pope John Paul II, the Polish authorities are continuing, and in some ways intensifying, a crackdown on dissent.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 9, 1983
description: International Improved Soviet ties with the U.S. interest Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, according to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who completed a visit to the Soviet Union. He said that Moscow could make a counteroffer at the medium-range arms limitation talks when the stalled Geneva negotiations resume in the fall. (Page 1, Column 3.) The attempt to murder the Pope in May 1981 was aided by the Soviet secret police and ''Bulgarian services,'' Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish terrorist who was convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II, told journalists in Rome. (1:2.)

title: IN ITALY, AN ELEGANT DESSERT OF FRUIT
description: One of the pleasantest and more enduring mealtime customs in Italy is the way in which fruit is served for dessert. There have been many changes and modifications in Italian eating habits during the last 10 or 15 years (for the most part for the worse), but when fruit is ordered for dessert, as it almost always is, an assortment arrives accompanied by a big glass bowl of cold water.

title: Feldstein Backs Rein on Money
description: Martin S. Feldstein, President Reagan's chief economist, said today that the growth of the nation's money supply has become excessive and it ''has to be brought down'' to contain incipient forces of renewed inflation.

title: HOW SHOULD WE FIX I-95'S AILING BRIDGES? BY SELLING THEM OFF.
description: The collapse of a section of Interstate 95 in Greenwich, Conn., costing three lives, is not the first major United States bridge disaster. Nor will it be the last. Indeed, the way in which we operate and maintain most bridges virtually guarantees more such disasters.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
UNDER THE TALL PINES, YADDO NURTURES THE ARTISTIC SPIRIT
description: Just after breakfast, while the sun warms the listless air of the Hudson Valley, the artistic proletariat of Yaddo grab their black metal lunch pails and wander off to labor under the pines.

title: Views Vary on Value of the Bell Name
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has used Bell as a name and in its symbol for more than a century, was told yesterday by a Federal judge that the name should now belong to the local phone company subsidiaries that it is spinning off.

title: CONDITIONS PLACED ON A.T.& T. BREAKUP BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal judge said today that he would give final approval to the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company once certain changes were made to protect the principle of universal telephone service at a reasonable cost.

title: Sinatra Praises Harry James Before Las Vegas Mourners
description: Harry James, the trumpeter and swing-band leader who discovered the young Frank Sinatra in New Jersey 42 years ago, was eulogized by the singer yesterday as ''a dear friend and a great teacher.''

title: Audi Profit Rise Seen
description: Audi, prestige car builders in the money-losing Volkswagen group, today reported a strong performance in the first half of this year and forecast further progress for 1983. Wolfgang Habbel, chairman, told shareholders that output of the new Audi 100 saloon, voted car of the year for 1983, rose 72 percent in the first six months of this year, to 75,000. He predicted Audi's profits would top last year's $45 million.

title: Singing the Praises Of Seagirt Beach
description: I love Seagirt Beach. It's the Newport of New York. It's the Rockaway Riviera, And it's causing a lot of talk.

title: Memorial for Herman Kahn
description: A memorial service for Herman Kahn, one of the nation's leading thinkers on nuclear strategies and the future, will be held at 10:30 A.M. next Friday at the National Defense University at Fort McNair in Washington. Mr. Kahn died of a heart attack Thursday morning at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Racing a Horse
description: Rick Cave, a 26-year-old high school mathematics teacher from Trenton, N.J., is a middle-distance runner for the Shore Athletic Club. He has covered a mile in 4 minutes 1 second and a half-mile in 1:51 within the last year.

title: U.S. ENVOY GETS SALVADOR REQUEST
description: The Salvadoran Government today asked President Reagan's envoy for Central America, Richard B. Stone, to seek the participation of its leftist opponents in elections scheduled for December if he meets with them in Costa Rica.

title: Ford's '84 Prices Expected Soon
description: Dealers for the Ford Motor Company said Ford is expected to disclose price increases on its 1984 model cars, for fleet ordering purposes, early next week. The measure is seen by industry analysts as a tip-off for official pricing plans for all 1984 cars normally disclosed in late August by the General Motors Corporation and in September by other auto makers.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Reflects increase of $267,000, or 4 cents a share, from LIFO inventory liquidation.

title: U.S. SEEKS EXPANSION OF BANKING ACTIVITIES
description: The Administration announced today that it had submitted to Congress a bill that would allow banks and savings and loan associations to expand the scope of their businesses considerably by underwriting municipal bonds, engaging in insurance and real estate brokerage and entering other activities ''of a financial nature.''

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the quarter and $1,038,967 for the year. c-After a loss of $1,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $16,000. d-Net income including income of $218,371 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $355,000.

title: JUDGE INDICATES HE WILL END WESTCHESTER AIRPORT CURFEW
description: A Federal judge said last night that there was a ''likelihood'' he would rule in favor of the Federal Aviation Administration in its battle with Westchester County over whether the county could continue to ban night flights at the county's airport.

title: NO PROGRESS IN CITY OPERA STRIKE
description: No progress was reported yesterday in the labor dispute between the New York City Opera and its orchestra. The orchestra formally struck the company on Wednesday and set up a picket line Thursday before the scheduled season opening that night at the New York State Theater. The company has canceled all performances ''until further notice.''

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On Business in South Africa Let Black Unions Monitor the Workplace To the Editor: Your June 15 editorial ''Doing Business With Racists,'' commenting on Representative Stephen Solarz's bill and its provision for fair employment standards for American companies in South Africa, is misleading and incomplete in a number of respects.

title: News Analysis
description: The cast of characters in the dispute between the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra is as colorful as any opera plot, and just about as convoluted. It includes an opera company that has long struggled to define itself artistically and to survive financially in the competitive arena of New York City's cultural life, and that has attempted in the past four years to realign itself under a new general director, Beverly Sills.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 9, 1983; The Economy
description: The overall jobless rate fell to 9.8 percent in June, and the number of people employed rose 1.2 million, one of the largest such increases on record, the Labor Department reported. Officials said the figures indicate a strong recovery is under way. A labor spokesman noted, however, that the number of people without jobs is virtually the same and that less than half of the jobless now receive benefits. (Page 1.) The jobless rate in New York City held steady, at 8.9 percent. (12.) Judge Harold H. Greene said he will approve the A.T.& T. divestiture plan if certain changes are accepted by the company and the Justice Department. (1.) One of the changes specified by the judge was that the Bell name could be used only by the local phone companies. Analysts are divided on the value of the name. (35.)

title: ADVANCE REPORTED BY CHADIAN REBELS
description: New gains by insurgent forces were reported today in eastern Chad, about 400 miles from here, adding to fears that another battle for this capital may be approaching.

title: First the Costume, Now a Convention
description: T he Royal Association for the Longevity and Preservation of the Honeymooners, or Ralph, flushed with success after winning its $650 bid for Jackie Gleason's bus driver costume from the based-in-Brooklyn television series, is planning the First International Honeymooners Convention, to be held next March.

title: Joint Appearance
description: Though neither of them admitted to a reconciliation, Jimmy and Patti Connors put on a convincing show for photographers in Sun City, Bophuthatswana, a tribal homeland in South Africa, where Connors is competing in the $1 million Sun City tournament. ''We're good actors,'' Connors said as he and his estranged wife hugged, kissed and walked arm-in-arm after his final practice for a first round match with Kevin Curren, a South African who eliminated Connors from Wimbledon in the quarterfinals. The practice paid off last night as Connors defeated Curren, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2.

title: Syncrude Expansion
description: Syncrude Canada Ltd. and the Alberta government have reached agreement on a $1.2 billion (Canadian), five-year expansion at Syncrude's oilsands plant near Fort Mc-Murray, the provincial energy minister, Jon Zaozirny, told a news conference.

title: 90 YEARS AFTER AMERICANS TOOK CHARGE, SOME HAWAIIANS STILL DISTRUST U.S.
description: Ninety years after Queen Liliuokalani was deposed by an American diplomat backed by marines and working with American businessmen, native Hawaiians' distrust still affects their relationship with the United States.

title: KNUCKLEHEAD TAKES TO TURF
description: T he chestnut gelding named Knucklehead Smith poked his head out of the stall to say hello yesterday morning, but when someone reached out to stroke his nose he drew back fearfully.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 9.8% ON SURGE OF HIRING
description: The number of people with jobs rose sharply last month and the unemployment rate, when the armed forces are included, declined to 9.8 percent of the labor force from 10 percent, the Department of Labor announced today.

title: SALVADORAN TIED TO KILLINGS NOW IN INTELLIGENCE JOB
description: A member of El Salvador's Human Rights Commission drove out to the western province of Sonsonate in February and then hiked to a river near Las Hojas, where the blood of 18 murdered peasants was still caked on nearby leaves.

title: Righetti Shuts Out Offers To Market His No-Hitter
description: A little more than a year ago, in the darkest moments of his baseball career, Dave Righetti said he had always been most at home on a mound. He was never one to enjoy the sideshow. He is not a regular in Manhattan's postgame watering holes. His face never smiled down from billboards overlooking the Long Island Expressway. He would rather look down from a mound.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Put simply, to allow a physician or a family member to disconnect life-sustaining treatment to a person solely because that person's lack of intellectual capacity precludes her from enjoying a meaningful quality of life would establish a dangerous precedent that logically could be extended far beyond the facts of the case before us.'' - New Jersey appeals court ruling. (24:2.)

title: 4 COWBOYS NAMED AS COCAINE USERS
description: Four members of the Dallas Cowboys - Harvey Martin, Tony Dorsett, Ron Springs and Larry Bethea - have been involved in discussions with Federal authorities after their names surfaced in a cocaine investigation, according to Federal law enforcement officials and the Cowboys' president.

title: Mobil Oil Canada
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 8 (Reuters) - The federal Government said nine exploration agreements had been reached with Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. for lands off Newfoundland, including the Hibernia oil discovery area.

title: A City Crew
description: Rowing may never replace basketball as the favorite sport of New York City high school students, but thanks to the Beach Channel High School crew, the sport is growing in popularity locally.

title: U.S. PANEL BACKS CURB ON TAKEOVER TACTICS
description: A special panel of the Securities and Exchange Commission that has been studying takeover regulations today endorsed wide-ranging revisions that could lead to new Government curbs on many of the tactics used in recent takeover battles.

title: News Analysis
description: The fatal bridge collapse on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich last week was a chilling reminder that many thousands of bridges throughout the nation are in various stages of disrepair.

title: RICH PACE GOES TO A 22-1 COLT
description: Apache Circle, a bay colt and 22-1 choice in the wagering, came from fourth place at the three-quarter mark tonight and edged previously unbeaten Party Whip by a neck in the $559,800 Peter Haughton Memorial Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: CSX Reports Tally In Texas Gas Bid
description: The CSX Corporation, the giant transportation concern that is seeking to buy the Texas Gas Resources Corporation for $1.07 billion, said that as of 11:45 P.M. Thursday, 18.8 million shares had been tendered by Texas Gas shareholders to a CSX depository.

title: Rutgers Tuition Up at Least 9.1%
description: Full-time undergraduate and graduate students at Rutgers University will pay at least 9.1 percent more in tuition next year, university officials said today. The increase is needed to offset cuts in the new state budget, the officials said.

title: FOR ME, IT'S STILL 1949 IN NOO YAWK CITY
description: Once upon a time, a long time ago, I courted a girl in New York City. We didn't have much money, but we didn't need much, either. We were young, and back then you could still ride the subway for a dime.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Wrong Medicine for Sick Housing
description: New York is probably the only city in the nation that has had rent controls uninterruptedly since 1943. It also continues to suffer from an acute housing shortage, despite a population loss of about one million in the 1970's and the country's biggest governmentally assisted middle-income and low-rent public housing programs.

title: Tom Meyer Sues
description: Charging that he had been undercut by some of his players, sabotaged by an assistant coach and embarrassed by various school officials, Tom Meyer, the former head basketball coach at University of Illinois-Chicago, has filed a $1 million suit against top school officials and an assistant coach. Meyer, whose father is Ray Meyer, the DePaul coach, said his problems began last spring when players complained that he had not provided academic or personal counselling.

title: Wright Promises Inquiry Into Releases of Water
description: Representative Jim Wright, Democraat of Texas, the House majority leader, has promised a Congressional investigation of the Bureau of Reclamation's controlled flooding of the Colorado River.

title: INDIANA GUZZLES GASOHOL, UNKNOWINGLY
description: Nearly a third of all motor fuel sold in Indiana now is gasohol, a blend of gasoline and alcohol. And few motorists know it.

title: SCM Will Sell Proctor-Silex
description: The SCM Corporation, a diversified producer of consumer and industrial products, said it had agreed to sell its Proctor-Silex appliance unit to a newly formed affiliate of the Wesray Corporation, a private concern, for $56 million.

title:
Patents;
Satellite Retrieval System
description: WASHINGTON ASATELLITE retrieval system, intended for use by such craft as the space shuttles, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The invention includes grappling equipment to be borne by a spacecraft for securing it to a satellite.

title: FIRST-PLACE JAYS TOP FIRST-PLACE RANGERS
description: Willie Upshaw slammed a three-run homer and scored three times as he led the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-5 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight in the opener of a three-game series between the American League division leaders.

title: A CENTRAL AMERICAN 'TIDAL WAVE' OPPOSED TO U.S. INTERFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a credit of $84,000 for the quarter and a charge of $759,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $285,000. d-Net income after a charge of $1.1 million.

title: 2 Die in Shootings; A 3d Is Wounded
description: A man shot a woman to death on a street today, critically wounded her father and then killed himself as the police closed in on him, officials said.

title: Conrail Lowers Shipping Rates
description: Officials of the Consolidated Rail Corporation have announced a dramatic reduction in some of its shipping rates in an effort to meet or beat truck competition.

title: Morgan Library Grant
description: The Pierpont Morgan Library has received a grant of $89,695 to catalogue its historical manuscripts and its Gilbert and Sullivan collection. The money was awarded to the library by the Federal Department of Education as part of its program to strengthen research library resources.

title: Night and Day
description: In what may be the oddest instance yet of work-release, Mike Reilly, a Los Angeles Rams linebacker, will be allowed to leave prison on a daily basis to attend the team's training camp. According to team officials, Reilly, a second-year player who has been serving a one-year prison term at the Theo Lacy minimum security facility in Orange, Calif., for drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter, will practice with the Rams during the day and serve time at night.

title: COLUMNIST HELPED REAGAN ON DEBATE
description: George F. Will, the conservative political columnist and commentator for ABC News, helped coach Ronald Regan for his 1980 debate with Jimmy Carter and then told television viewers after the debate that Mr. Reagan had performed very well.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System yesterday announced a $3 billion decline in the money supply for the week ended June 29, a development that eased concern for the moment that the Fed might tighten monetary policy against the wishes of the Reagan Administration.

title: First, Make Jobs That Work
description: Unemployment is edging down some more and the number of jobholders is up over 100 million. That's almost a million more than in March, when Congress voted in a $4.6 billion jobs program. But there's hardly any connection between one and the other. Congress does better at creating jobs programs than creating jobs.

title: White-Collar Wage Gains Decline
description: Lawyers, engineers, secretaries and other white-collar workers averaged smaller raises last year than in the previous two years, the Government has reported.

title: TELEFRANCE USA CUTS SERVICES IN EFFORT TO STAY ALIVE
description: TeleFrance USA, a cable television service that has brought French culture to the American television screen for the last seven years, has cut back staff and services in an effort to keep alive for the fall season.

title: TEEN JOKES
description: Under the title ''Screwballs,'' a wizened clone of ''Porky's'' opened yesterday at the National and other local theaters. Afflicted with an intermittent greenish tint, bereft of adequate acting, starved for wit and originality, generally miscast and directed with a palpable lack of grace, ''Screwballs'' is set in a fictitious high school called Taft and Adams.

title: Concerts in Queens
description: The Seuffert Band will give free concerts in two Queens parks this weekend.

title:
PATENTS;
Dialing Phone Number With TV Selector Unit
description: A method has been devised to combine the selection of television programs with telephone calls. Without leaving the chair, a viewer with a hand-held remote control unit can make phone calls and control appliances.

title: A LEADER IN CANCER RESEARCH
description: Wallace Prescott Rowe, an internationally known virologist and cancer researcher who was the chief of the laboratory of viral diseases at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, died of cancer Monday in Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 57 years old.

title: Nancy Knowlton Weds Jeremy Jackson
description: Nancy Knowlton, a professor of biology at Yale University, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Jeremy Bradford Cook Jackson, professor of ecology at Johns Hopkins University. Civil Court Judge Shirley Fingerhood performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Reed Erskine.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
UNITED BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
18-6 1/2 Wins Pole Vault
description: Konstantin Volkov of the Soviet Union overcame swirling winds to outduel Thierry Vigneron of France and win the pole vault, the feature event of the track and field program in the World University Games tonight.

title: Oneness With Two Sticks A String and Some Feathers
description: A s the top-ranked practitioner outside Japan of kyudo, or Zen archery, Michel Martin came to New York from Paris to demonstrate it at Japan House.

title: Cut Phone Cable Disrupts L.I. Calls
description: Long distance phone calls to and from Long Island were disrupted today when workers accidentally cut a main cable while doing road repair work on Little Neck Parkway.

title: RYAN STRIKES OUT 12 AND GETS 8TH VICTORY
description: The Mets may seldom put their names in the record books this season, but they are helping others to do so. Nolan Ryan struck out 12 Mets last night at Shea Stadium to regain the career lead in the major leagues at 3,573 as the Houston Astros' right-hander won his eighth game in nine decisions, 6-3.

title: Hip Boots Or Gloves?
description: Since I am about to embark on vacation, I went in search of an appropriate subject for my getaway column. Something a little carefree - even silly. The search was very short. The new nudesunbathing law seemed perfect.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: NEW DIRECTOR OF CITY LABOR RELATIONS: ROBERT WECHSLER LINN
description: For four years, Robert W. Linn has played ''the bad cop'' in New York City labor talks, laying out the city's demands. Then Bruce C. McIver, the amiable Director of Municipal Labor Relations and ''the good cop,'' would make the deal.

title: WASHINGTON UTILITY PUTS ATOM PLANT IN MOTHBALLS
description: One of the two remaining nuclear power plants of the Washington Public Power Supply System was mothballed today for up to three years.

title: Italy-Soviet Gas Deal
description: Italy is preparing to complete its longstalled deal with the Soviet Union to buy gas through the Siberian pipeline, a Government spokesman said today.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS FULL STAFF TO AID IN F.B.I. INQUIRY
description: President Reagan today underlined his concern about the investigation of his 1980 campaign by interrupting a meeting of his senior staff and dictating an order that every Administration worker, ''including me,'' cooperate fully.

title:
PATENTS;
Amusement Device For Dogs and Cats
description: An amusement device for dogs and cats, as described in a patent this week, is a ball that rolls when an animal with a radiotransmitting collar gets close enough to it. The radio actuates a motor inside.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bendix Corp., a unit of the Allied Corp., said it had agreed to acquire the Timex Corp.'s Gyro and accelerometer business in Middlebury, Conn.; terms were not disclosed.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
POWER OF WOMEN'S VOTE CITED AT CONVENTION
description: The 2,000 women attending the National Women's Political Caucus convention here were told in opening ceremonies today that women could elect the President in 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Weekend yes- terday, with an article about outdoor sculpture, misidentified a work at Bellevue Hospital. It is ''Mitochon- dria'' by John Rhoden.

title: A Prize Recruit Like His Sister
description: Reggie Miller is a talented basketball player, talented enough to be the top freshman recruited by U.C.L.A. for next season, talented enough to have averaged almost 30 points a game his senior year in high school in Riverside, Calif.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ANDROPOV REPORTEDLY TOLD KOHL OF SOVIET 'FLEXIBILITY' ON MISSILES
description: After his visit to the Soviet Union, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is said to believe that Yuri V. Andropov would like to improve relations with the United States and that Moscow might make a counteroffer this fall at the stalled talks in Geneva on mediumrange missiles.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2.8 million for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $4,954,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $166,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $7,258,000 for the year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIVING IN NEW YORK

title: NEWS PLUS EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Stokely Attempts To Block Pillsbury
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc. asked the United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana to enjoin the Pillsbury Company from proceeding with its $170 million tender offer on the ground that a merger would violate United States antitrust laws. Pillsbury, which is primarily a consumer food marketer, began its tender offer for Stokely, primarily a food canner, on July 6.

title: FUN IN THE DOLDRUMS
description: No news is bad news for the Reagan Administration this summer. The news industry, which abhors a vacuum, is surviving the doldrums on the tail of the purloined papers, the entertaining but scarcely earthshaking story of unsportsmanlike shenanigans behind the Carter-Reagan Presidential campaign debate of 1980.

title: Bankruptcy Asked For Robintech Inc.
description: Robintech Inc., a Fort Worth-based maker of plastic pipes, said yesterday that three of its suppliers had filed a petition to have the company declared bankrupt under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy code.

title: City Officials Seek U.S. Help Against AIDS
description: Health officials from 11 cities called on President Reagan today to provide more funds to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, an incurable disease claiming an increasing number of victims and causing public anxiety.

title: COURT OFFICIALS CONSIDER WORKING ON SATURDAYS
description: Court officials in New York City are considering a proposal to conduct Saturday sessions in State Supreme Court this summer - when fewer judges are available during the week -as a way to speed the processing of felony cases and ease overcrowding in the city's jails.

title: Bonn Regains Export Lead
description: West Germany regained the lead position in world merchandise exports in 1982 after coming in second to the United States in 1981, the Department of Commerce said today.

title: Sudan Attacks Rebels, Freeing 5 Foreigners
description: Sudanese troops today freed five foreign relief workers, including two Americans and a Canadian, who had been held for a week by rebels in the southern Sudan, the official Sudanese press agency reported.

title: DRUG USERS WARNED OF EFFECTS
description: THE carefully calculated tradeoffs between the benefits of certain p opular prescription drugs and their often dangerous side effects h ave been of concern for years.

title: Allen Kanfer, English Teacher And Prolific Poet, Dead at 78
description: Allen Kanfer, a widely published poet who taught English at Grover Cleveland High School in Ridgewood, Queens, for 40 years, died Wednesday after a long illness at his home in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Victory 83 Loses As Rigging Fails
description: An internal mast fitting that anchors a shroud gave way on Victory 83 today, causing it to withdraw from its match with Australia's Challenge 12 in the series to select the America's Cup defender.

title: Kurt L. Hanslowe, Professor At Cornell and an Arbitrator
description: Kurt L. Hanslowe, a professor at Cornell University and a labor arbitrator, died of cancer today at his home here.

title: Shellfish Beds Reopened
description: Some 20 miles of coastline shellfish beds have been reopened to harvesting after a poisoning scare. The areas from Gloucester to the New Hampshire border were closed last month because of a contaminating algae known as red tide.

title: Promises at the Khyber Pass
description: That was the easy half of an Afghanistan policy that Secretary of State Shultz expressed in Pakistan the other day. Speaking at the Khyber Pass to cheering Afghan refugees, he was direct and emotional: ''We are with you!''

title: U.S.F.L. PLAYOFFS TO BEGIN
description: The Philadelphia Stars had the best record, 15-3, in the United States Football League during the regular season and their defense, which gave up only 204 points, ranked No.1. Nevertheless, the concerns of their coach, Jim Mora, with regard to Saturday's playoff game against the Chicago Blitz, focus on two Blitz offensive players, Trumaine Johnson and Bobby Scott.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: HOW TO REDISTRICT NEW JERSEY FAIRLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Caterpillar Loss Is $92 Million
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that it lost $92 million in the second quarter, which included the final weeks of a seven-month strike against the company by the United Automobile Workers union.

title: Spanish Theater Group Receives $45,000 Grant
description: A Spanish repertory company, Repertorio Espanol, has been given a three-year $45,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

title: MORTGAGE RATE RAISED
description: Government-backed home mortgages will increase to a rate of 12.5 percent from 12 percent on Monday, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; July 9, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title:
PATENTS;
Products Slow Growth Of Mosquito Larvae
description: Preparations that inhibit the growth of mosquito larvae are covered by patent 4,391,828 obtained this week by Leonard Jurd of Berkeley, Calif., for the Department of Agriculture.

title: STERLING CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
THE REAL END OF THE RECESSION
description: For months, economists and Wall Street pundits have been saying a recovery is under way. Yesterday, the nation's main arbiter in such matters made it official: The recession ended late last fall.

title: An Italian Cyclist Wins Leg of Tour
description: ST. PIERRE D'OLERON, France, July 8 (AP) - Riccardo Magrini of Italy won the seventh leg of the Tour de France cycling race in a sprint finish today.

title:
PATENTS;
Process to Manufacture Cancer-Test Product
description: A process for the industrial production of a product for the diagnosis of carcinoma, which describes some forms of cancer, was patented this week by Giulio Tarro of Naples, Italy.

title: COMPUTERS AT DISADVANTAGED'S CAMP
description: It couldn't be called an orderly scene. Pigtails bobbed, caps were pushed back ready for action, elbows nudged, hands reached out to shove, gently and otherwise, and scores of fingers attempted to claim the keyboards.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for qtr to June 21.
description: b-Net income.

title: Your Money; Bid to Tax Health Benefits
description: APROPOSAL by the Reagan Administration to tax employees for their e mployer-paid health insurance has stirred up a bitter controversy a mong some of the nation's major lobbying groups. And organizations o n both sides of the question assert that they are representing the p ublic interest.

title: CHASE AND IRAN IN ACCORD ON CLAIMS
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had settled its disputed accounts with Iran that stemmed from the hostage crisis of three and a half years ago.

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
First Chicago Earnings Up
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the country's 11th-largest banking company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 47.3 percent, to $43 million, or 91 cents a share, from $29.2 million, or 73 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.

title: HOW G.O.P. TACTICS CAME UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The controversy over the 1980 Presidential campaign is rooted in the fact that the Republican campaign somehow came into possession of some of President Carter's private strategy papers in preparing Ronald Reagan for the debate with Mr. Carter a week before the election.

title: THE OPERA DISPUTE IN BRIEF
description: The New York City Opera orchestra established a picket line at the New York State Theater Thursday night following months of preliminary talks and the collapse of last-minute negotiations that afternoon. The last-minute talks were called after the intervention of the New York State Mediation Board, which continues to monitor the situation.

title: Lester Wolfe, 86, an Inventor Of Equipment for the Military
description: Lester Wolfe, former president of William J. Rountree Company, steamship agent and broker, and an inventor of instruments that aided American armed forces in World War II, died of heart failure Wednesday at his summer home in Southampton, L.I. Mr. Wolfe, who also lived in Manhattan, was 86 years old.

title: Books of The Times; Emancipation as It Was
description: FREEDOM: A Documentary History of Emancipation, 1861-67. Edited by Ira Berlin, Joseph P. Reidy and Leslie S. Rowland. 852 pages. New York: Cam- bridge University Press. $37.50.

title: Pooley, O'Meara Lead by Stroke
description: Don Pooley, aided by a spectacular 8-iron shot, birdied his final hole today and tied Mark O'Meara for the lead after two rounds of the $250,000 Milwaukee Open golf tournament.

title: SHERMAN DEAN FUND INC reports earnings for As of May 31.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Spy Parley Begins
description: Would-be James Bonds and armchair secret agents will gather today and tomorrow at the Prince George Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 28th Street, to buy and sell spy-story memorabilia, discuss their favorite agents and preview the Sean Connery Bond film ''Never Say Never Again'' at Spy-Con, a convention devoted to spies in film, television and literature.

title: Group Seeks to Trap And Protect Island Goats
description: Three members of an animal preservation group today began to trap and save some of the 600 goats on San Clemente Island from annihilation by the United States Navy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: QUEST FOR HELP FOR THE HARD OF HEARING
description: Every day is something of a crusade for Rocky Stone, president of Self Help for Hard of Hearing People. For four years Mr. Stone and his staff of four full-time volunteers have been building an organization capable of dealing with the problems of the 15.7 million Americans who suffer from loss of hearing but are not classified as deaf.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Ross Claiborne Leaves Post at Warner Books
description: In what both sides term a mutual parting of the ways, Ross Claiborne is no longer publisher of Warner Books' hardcover division. Howard Kaminsky, president and publisher of Warner Books, said that he had no one in mind to replace Mr. Claiborne, the former editorial director of the Dell Publishing Company, who joined Warner in September 1981.

title: WALL & REDEKOP CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Warning on Tariffs
description: Tariffs and quotas pose ''a serious threat to the health and stability of U.S.-Japan economic relations'' and most should be eliminated, according to a report by a group of business leaders from the two nations. The recommendation came in a 109-page report by the Japan-U.S. Businessmen's Conference, a panel of more than 100 heads of corporations. The report was released Thursday as the group opened a two-day meeting here.

title: TOKEN ARITHMETIC
description: To the Editor:

title: APPROPRIATE GESTURE TO AMERICAN INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG LOSS AT BALDWIN IN QUARTER
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation finally issued its earnings report for the first quarter yesterday, and its losses proved to be dramatically higher than it had previously indicated.

title: Iranian Vows Revenge On U.S. for Hijacking
description: A senior Iranian official today accused the United States, France and other countries of involvement in Wednesday's hijacking of an Iran Air jetliner and promised revenge.

title: Bauer Leads 6-Day Run
description: Siegfried Bauer of New Zealand covered 363 miles in the first 4 days of the New York Six-Day Run, but he had to alter his strategy in order to maintain his first-place position over Colin Dixon of England and Jean Giles Boussiquet, a Frenchman.

title: HELMS AND ANTI-HELMS CAMPAIGNS GOING STRONG
description: It was a cross between a prayer breakfast and a political rally. ''Jesse Helms is a national treasure,'' the Rev. Jerry Falwell told a group of 250 ministers and lay leaders. They responded with a chorus of ''Praise the Lord'' and ''Amen.''

title: Pink Checks for $1 Say Thank You for Christo
description: The artist Christo, who encircled 11 Biscayne Bay islands in pink plastic, is saying thank you to his 1,500 helpers by sending them pink checks for $1.

title: DOW DECLINES 3.21 IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices eased yesterday on uncertainty over the course of interest rates. Trading also decreased. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was about level at noon, repeated its recent pattern of late declines. It finished 3.21 points lower, at 1,207.23. Retreating stocks outnumbered those that advanced by 941 to 630, and volume receded to 66.5 million, from 97.1 million the day before.

title: THE IMMORALITY IN BACKING NICARAGUA'S 'CONTRAS'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO BE FIRM ON SYRIAN PULLOUT
description: President Reagan was reported to have said today that although Secretary of State George P. Shultz did not make any headway on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon when he visited the Middle East, ''there would be no reverse gear'' by the Administration in pressing Syria to pull out its forces when Israel does.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Tom Seaver will be opposed by the knuckleballer Joe Niekro. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. Dave Righetti, fresh from last Monday's no-hit performance, gets the start for the Yanks. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. California Angels, at Boston. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Football Stars vs. Chicago Blitz, playoff semifinal, at Philadelphia. Kelvin Bryant, the big running back from North Carolina, leads the Stars into the playoffs. (Television - Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.) Tiger-Cats vs. Edmonton Eskimos, Canadian Football League opener for both teams, at Hamilton, Ontario. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Tennis Miller Hall of Fame Championships, semifinals, as well as the induction of Johan Kriek and Hank Pfister. (Television - Channel 13, 2 P.M.) Davis Cup quarterfinals, second day, doubles play: France vs. Paraguay at Marseilles, France; Australia vs. Rumania at Brisbane, Australia; Sweden vs. New Zealand at Eastbourne, England, and Italy vs. Argentina at Rome.

title: STUDENT, 18, ACQUITTED OF ASSAULT IN DEATH OF A TEACHER IN BROOKLYN
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was found not guilty yesterday of assaulting a teacher who died shortly after trying to break up a fight between the youth and another student at Bushwick High School two years ago.

title: Donald Henderson, 61; Former Aide in Senate
description: Donald G. Henderson, a former deputy chief of staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, died of lung cancer today at Circle Terrace Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 61 years old.

title: Upper East Side Tours
description: The life of the rich on Manhattan's Upper East Side will be the focus of two walking tours tomorrow. New York Walk-About is conducting walks in the area where turn-of-the-century tycoons spent their leisure time.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Luis Lopez, New York State's high school baseball player of the year, will play for Oklahoma State next year. The former Lafayette High School student was also drafted by the Los Angles Dodgers in the recent professional draft. ... Sam Etcheverry was dismissed yesterday as the president and general manager of the Montreal Concordes of the Canadian Football League.

title: Federal Jury Indicts 33 In Drug Smuggling Case
description: Thirty-three people were indicted in connection with what Federal officials said was a $40 million drug ring extending from Colombia to Pennsylvania's Pocono mountain resorts.

title: 17 INDICTED IN INSURANCE FRAUD
description: Seventeen residents of the New York area, including insurance appraisers and owners of auto repair shops, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of joining in a scheme to collect more than $1.5 million from fraudulent car-accident insurance claims.

title: Japan Store Offers Robots
description: The Seibu group today became the first Japanese department store to offer robots for sale. ''Our aim is to serve as a contact point between owners of small firms, schools and restaurants on one hand and the robot maker on the other,'' said Naoyuki Moriyasu of Seibu.

title: WHAT DEREGULATION WILL COST CONSUMERS
description: For most consumers, the average cost of maintaining a checking account has climbed more than 100 percent in the last four years. For most consumers, the cost of stopping payment on a check has risen more than 90 percent. But while these consumer costs have risen, people who can keep $2,500 or more on deposit are finding that they can command much higher interest rates from banks.

title: 62 Youths Taken Away From Religious Camp
description: Sixty-six children who live in a religious camp where a 12-year-old boy was beaten to death for refusing to do his chores were ordered removed today and placed in protective custody.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for year to May 31.
'JEDI' PRINTS STOLEN FOR CASSETTE PIRACY, MOVIE INDUSTRY SAYS
description: During the last two weeks, this summer's blockbuster movie ''Return of the Jedi'' has been stolen six times, from theaters in three states and in Britain. The movie industry is certain that the objective in each case was to turn these 35-millimeter prints into illegal home video cassettes to be shipped around the world.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including special writeoffs of $567 million. c-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Continental Plans To Sell Two Units
description: The Continental Corporation announced that it had signed a letter of intent to sell two of its insurance business subsidiaries to the St. Paul Companies for an undisclosed amount, as part of Continental's strategy to concentrate its resources on the retail agent and brokerage market.

title: MASCAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: THE NEW SPOT MARKET FOR GAS
description: The Weirton Steel division of the National Steel Corporation was faced last year with a cost increase it could not stomach: a 25 percent rise in the price of natural gas.

title: Commuters in Boston Get Free Ride for Day
description: Thousands of Boston commuters were treated to a free ride on the city's subways and trolley cars Thursday as the local transit authority tried to make amends for stranding them in a power failure the day before.

title: Louis XVI Cabinet Nets A Record $1.39 Million
description: An 18th-century French cabinet that once stood in the study of King Louis XVI at Versailles was auctioned for a record $1.39 million today, Sotheby's said.

title: JERSEY COURT BARS HALT IN FEEDING IF PATIENT, NOT IN COMA, WOULD DIE
description: A New Jersey appeals court ruled unanimously yesterday that the removal of a feeding tube from a mentally incompetent, gravely ill woman would have ''constituted homicide'' and violated a fundamental medical principle to ''do no harm.''

title: The Worst Loss
description: Gene Brabender took some tough losses during his nine-year career as a major league pitcher, but the former Baltimore Orioles player said that none hurt as much as his most recent one. Brabender's onyx and diamond 1966 World Championship ring was recently offered for sale by the State Bank of Cross Plains, Wis., because of an unpaid loan steming from his construction business in Black Barth, Wis.

title: POOR ARGUMENTS AGAINST COAL PIPELINES
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL SAYS IT'S 'NOT TOTALLY PESSIMISTIC' ABOUT A SYRIAN WITHDRAWAL
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens said today that he was ''not totally pessimistic'' about achieving a withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon.

title: FRENCH BISHOPS TO BACK NUCLEAR DETERRENCE POLICY
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of France are preparing a document on the nuclear arms race that promises to differ in significant ways from the American bishops' pastoral letter on the issue.

title: Bee Gees Did Not Steal Hit Song, Judge Rules
description: A Federal district judge today overturned a jury's finding and ruled that the Bee Gees did not steal their hit song ''How Deep Is Your Love.''

title: MISSING IN GUATEMALA: THE CASE OF ONE STATISTIC
description: On June 6 Lucrecia Orellana Stormont left her office at Guatemala's University of San Carlos to attend a meeting in a downtown hotel. Her family has not seen her since.

title: MIDDLE-CLASS DILEMMA
description: To the Editor:

title: INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM PROPOSAL FACES SHOWDOWN
description: NO ONE blurts them out immediately, but the words "Proposition 13" inevitably creep into almost every discussion of a proposal to grant powers of initiative and referendum to New Jersey voters.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: REPRESENTATIVE James J. Howard recently rallied the support of some 30 environmental groups in New Jersey for his bill to reauthorize and strengthen the 1972 Federal Clean Water Act. However, the new measure is already being criticized as having some shortcomings.

title: 15 More Suits Filed in Crash
description: Fifteen more lawsuits have been filed against Pan American World Airways in connection with a jetliner crash that killed 154 people last year. A total of more than 180 claims have been filed as a result of the crash, which occurred soon after the jet took off in heavy rain from New Orleans International Airport on July 9, 1982. The statute of limitations required that all lawsuits be on file within a year after the crash.

title: IN THE SWIM OF THINGS BY THE DAWN'S EARLY LIGHT
description: FOR the last three summers I've had a most unusual schedule, and I owe it all to a couple of our children, who moved from recreational swimming to serious swimming. The recreational swimmer jumps in the pool for fun; the serious swimmer is on a team year round and works out daily. In the summer, teams most often work out at 6 A.M. because that's when no one else wants to use the pool.

title: MOSCOW OPPORTUNITIES
description: A visit to Moscow is a depressing experience. One comes away with the powerful, inescapable impression that our policies toward the Soviet Union are based upon erroneous assumptions and are having effects that are contrary to our interests. Measures that the Administration believes will make Moscow more compliant have left the leaders puzzled, angry and defiant, determined to show muscle to prove they are not intimidated. This is a dangerous state of mind.

title: DOWN ON THE FARM, IT'S AN OPEN HOUSE
description: TO help acquaint city and suburban folk with the importance of dairy and crop farming, nine farms in six counties will hold open houses from 1 to 5 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: IN TRENTON, A NEW FINANCING PROGRAM
description: NEW JERSEY's Republican Governor and Democratic-controlled Legislature have have joined in a housing finance program that its sponsor says is the most comprehensive in the nation.

title: The Cloistered Life
description: Sisters Carolyn and Rachel are among the more than 3,800 Roman Catholic nuns in the United States who have removed themselves from the distractions of a worldly life to the cloister, devoting their lives to the search for God through prayer. It is not a self-centered meditation. They believe that their union with God contributes to the salvation of all people, and that their prayers for humanity touch the lives of the suffering everywhere. In an earlier century, they might have been respected by families and friends as women with an exceptional calling. Today, they are often viewed as rebels by a secular society that values action over contemplation. Their special way of life sets them apart in a world where even many Catholics dismiss the cloister as an archaic institution and the nuns inside as people with an unhealthy attraction to solitude - weak women who are not carrying their weight in the world.

title: Tropical Rhythms Weave Their Spell on Pop Music
description: In the mid-1970's, when North American pop fans began paying attention to Jamaican reggae, many observers predicted that reggae would be the next big thing. But while British and American musicians from Paul Simon to Eric Clapton to Stevie Wonder to Elvis Costello had reggae-style hits, and Jamaica's Bob Marley and the Wailers became internationally popular, a reggae craze never materialized.

title: Making a Day of Beethoven Sonatas
description: At 10 A.M. on Saturday, July 23, the pianist Gary Goldschneider will sit down at the piano at the Philadelphia Bourse and begin playing a Beethoven sonata. Twelve hours and 32 sonatas later, Mr. Goldschneider will have presented Beethoven's entire piano sonata canon in chronological order. The pianist says the project represents an attempt to "present the complete creative life of our greatest Western composer to the public, so that they can experience his incredible evolution for themselves."

title: THE DESTROYER ARRIVES FOR REFITTING AT NAVY YARD
description: The antisubmarine destroyer Stump sailed smartly into New York Harbor yesterday morning for refitting, the first modern warship scheduled for overhaul at the Brooklyn Navy Yard in 20 years. Two other vessels are expected to follow in the next two years.

title: Article 162068 -- No Title
description: The authorities seized $5 million in counterfeit $100 bills and arrested a former football star today on counterfeiting charges.
To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: GEOFFREY K. ORLANDO, the prosecutor in some of Westchester's biggest trials, including those involving the county's two most serious fires, is leaving the District Attorney's office after 13 years to practice civil and criminal law with the White Plains firm of David E. Worby.

title: Blue Jays Defeat Rangers
description: Barry Bonnell hit a two-run homer in the fourth inning, and Luis Leal gave up eight hits in seven and onethird innings today to lead the Blue Jays to a 5-1 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Did Shostakovich Have a Secret?
description: Myths and legends attach themselves to famous dead people like barnacles to a ship's bottom. It is as if the human animal has an inborn need to deny the mundane, to fantasize and embroider, to make a good story better. Responsible historians try to keep things straight and within the bounds of evidence, but it's a losing struggle: Everyman loves a mystery and so does Everywoman.

title: Pamela Deely Weds John Van De Loo
description: Pamela Sayre Deely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Sedgwick Deely of Stockbridge, Mass., and New York, was married yesterday in Stockbridge to John William Van De Loo, son of Mrs. Robert Van De Loo of Albany and the late Mr. Van De Loo. The Rev. Luke Fennessey and the Rev. John Bradley performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Lea A. Thomas Is Married To Frank B. Olson, Broker
description: Lea Allen Thomas and Frank Blakely Olson were married yesterday at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Lynchburg, Va., by the Rev. Stephen J. Schulz.

title: Topics; Guides and Goads; Starring New England
description: In Salem, Mass. the other day, a well-traveled friend spotted a familiar deep green: the cover of a Michelin guidebook. Titled ''Nouvelle Angleterre,'' it was being soberly perused by a French couple drawn to Salem by its three-star rating.

title: SURVIVAL KITS FOR CAMPERS
description: Busy days spent diving, sailing, passing bunk inspection and pitching tents can exhaust even the most enthusiastic camper. To perk up the energy level of children at camp, parents have traditionally sent food and small favors. Such packages of nonperishable treats are commonly known as survival kits.

title: STATE IS PRESSING ITS FIGHT TO PREVENT ARSON
description: EVEN though arson is for the moment on a downward trend in the state, fire officials continue their efforts to prevent this crime. ''Arson in Connecticut is declining from its peak in the years of 1980 and 1981,'' said. Lieut. Edmund Dunstone, commanding officer in the investigation section of the State Fire Marshal's office in Meriden.

title: APPROVAL SEEN FOR CANCER DEVICE
description: Sometime this summer the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve a new cancer treatment involving microwave heat applied directly to tumors, a spokesman for the agency said today. The treatment, hyperthermia, uses a directed microwave beam to raise the temperature of cancer cells enough to damage them.

title: Too Close To Homicide
description: If the case of Karen Ann Quinlan established the right to withhold medical care from the gravely ill, the case of Claire C. Conroy may come to define its limits. So it seemed last week after a New Jersey appeals court unanimously ruled that the removal of a feeding tube from Miss Conroy, who suffered a brain disorder that causes a loss of memory, orientation and judgment, but was not comatose, like Miss Quinlan, would have been ''homicide.''

title: William Calley Jr.
description: In 1971, First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was convicted of murdering 22 unarmed civilians, including women and children, in the South Vietnamese hamlet of My Lai.

title: OPERA: 'THE TAMING OF THE SHREW' IS PERFORMED BY REIMANN STUDIO
description: New York University's Reimann Opera Studio offered ''The Taming of the Shrew'' by Vittorio Giannini on Friday and Saturday nights at the University Theater off Washington Square. Giannini was an American born at the turn of the century who managed to juggle his Romantic European ancestry and his American identity very gracefully. This opera -though written in 1952 when American music bristled with serialism and the avant-garde - has its roots in a far earlier operatic tradition.

title: A Series Aims at Turning Young Viewers Into Readers
description: A new television series that begins tomorrow will be telling youngsters to turn off the television set, pick up a book and read. The series, called "Reading Rainbow," is the latest effort to teach children reading skills through television -- the very medium that many educators consider the No. 1 enemy of books.

title: Fees Refundable
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: NADIA CREAMER WORK
description: Just because certain psychiatrists and occultists insist that dreams can be significant, it does not follow that all artistic depictions of dreams will automatically be interesting. As evidence, one can cite Nadia Creamer's ''Beginnings,'' a section from a workin-progress called ''Choices: A Dream Pilgrimage'' that the Impulse Dance Company presented Thursday night at the White Dog Studio.

title: Brighton Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FANTASY WORLD OF ITALO CALVINO
description: Calvino's house seemed an extension of his fantasy. Built on a low knoll, it is surrounded by thick lawns and a profusion of flowering trees and bushes. Standing on the flagstone terrace, waiting for the doorbell to be answered, I could see that Calvino had created out of nature itself an elegant improvement on the reality of the ordinary summer cottage.

title: TRAINER'S LUCK GOOD AND BAD
description: At two harness-racing tracks Friday night, miles apart, Eldon Harner found himself talking about ''racing luck'' after one of his pacers, Fortune Teller, lost when it figured to win and another, Apache Trial, won despite being a 22-1 shot.

title: Scrambling for The High Ground
description: ''There is a real effort not to muck up the investigation with White House fingerprints,'' an Administration official said last week, explaining why President Reagan had been keeping his distance from the mounting controversy over the purloined Carter campaign papers.

title: ITALY'S ALPINE AERIE
description: HENRY KAMM is chief of The New York Times bureau in Rome.

title: Yolanda Turocy to Marry Robert Taub in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steve Turocy of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Yolanda Turocy, to Robert M. Taub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Taub of Edison, N.J. The wedding is to be Aug. 27.

title: WEATHER OR NO: BELGIANS AT THE BEACH
description: JANE GROSS, a sports reporter for The Times, recently spent six months in Belgium.

title: Ruth B. Pollack Married to Judge
description: Ruth Bridget Pollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Pollack of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to William Jeremiah Coughlin, a Detroit jurist and novelist, who is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Coughlin of Detroit. The Rev. Carl Underhill Quinn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: Industry Moves
description: Perhaps in an attempt to wash some linen soiled in the past, the Chemical Manufacturers Association announced last week that it would sponsor a $1 million, 10-month study to gather information about public health and hazardous wastes. ''The lack of evidence of significant health effects makes us believe a major problem is unlikely,'' said William C. Simeral, a DuPont vice president and outgoing chairman of the association.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW; 
Meeting The Artistic Challenge of The Nude
description: Since the middle of the 19th century, the nude has been one of the staple subjects of photography. It has also been one of medium's most difficult subjects. During the Victorian era most nude photography was either scientific (ethnographic or medical) or pornographic. And when toward the end of the 19th century serious art photographers began to attempt the nude, they adopted many devices used by the academic painters in their day to render this potentially embarrassing subject acceptable.

title: Improving Our Schools
description: Colleges and universities are currently competing for fewer students than was the case a few years ago. How does Dr. Botstein propose to persuade institutions to raise admissions standards under these conditions? David H. Fowler Professor of History Lois J. Fowler Professor of English Carnegie-Mellon University Pittsburgh

title: REGGAE: PETER TOSH, BAND
description: The reggae singer Peter Tosh was in his best hortatory form Wednesday at the Pier. Raising his arms, pointing his finger and sometimes quoting Scripture while his white robe billowed in the wind, Mr. Tosh looked like an Old Testament prophet with dreadlocks.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The Westchester Weekly, appearing in copies of The Times distributed in Westchester County, includes an article today on the Hudson Institute and mentions its director, Herman Kahn. The section went to press shortly before his death on Thursday.

title: Miss McDade Is Bride Of David Adams Taft
description: Theresa Ann McDade, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Brian George McDade of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Adams Taft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Millens W. Taft Jr. of East Longmeadow, Mass. The Rev. Thomas McGinnis performed a Roman Catholic ceremony in Mother Butler Chapel at Marymount College in Tarrytown.

title: TEACHERS GATHER TO STUDY FUTURE
description: ASMALL group of high school teachers from Westchester and Rockland counties went to school recently to study the future of the world. They were the vanguard for a national teaching program that their host, the Hudson Institute, hopes will counteract the ''grim images of the future'' it believes are prevalent among students. The Visions of the Future program, directed by Herbert London, a consultant to the institute and dean of the Gallatin Division of New York University, is intended to ''restore balance to the record of human accomplishment.''

title: Alison Bishop Is Married
description: Alison Conover Bishop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Conover Bishop of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Curtis Henry Laub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry George Laub of Bay Village, Ohio. The ceremony was performed in St. Clare Roman Catholic Church in Lyndhurst, Ohio, by the Rev. Robert La Bella, chaplain of St. Vincent Charity Hospital in Cleveland, where the bride is an anesthetist. Her husband is a chief resident in orthopedic surgery at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation.

title: BOARD SEEKS AN END TO WIRETAP CASE
description: NEW HAVEN THE Board of Aldermen here is seeking a settlement of a six-yearold lawsuit over an illegal police wiretapping operation. But the Mayor, a defendant in that lawsuit, recently vetoed a measure by the aldermen that urged settlement negotiations.

title: BIG STEEL'S PUZZLING STRATEGY
description: THE harsh glare of the television lights filled the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing room as a senator shot questions at David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation. The audience was spellbound and two other chairmen of major steel companies listened from front row seats. In a voice that cut through the hushed chamber, Mr. Roderick took to the defense - explaining why his company made the controversial decision to import steel slabs from Britain instead of making them here.

title: MEMO TO HOTEL MANAGERS
description: ENID NEMY is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: A FETE FOR CINCINATTI SOCIETY
description: THE Connecticut Society of the Cincinnati last Monday observed the bicentennial of its founding by officers who served in the Revolutionary War under George Washington.

title: U.S. ECONOMY: THE GAINERS AND THE LOSERS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE AGREEMENT ON GUNS AND ADS IS DISPUTED
description: millimeter guns, the state swapped aging .357 Magnums and promised the cooperation of the state police in the advertising campaign of Beretta-U.S.A., the United States subsidiary of an Italian gun manufacturer.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''WESTFIELD may not seem the likeliest place for a best-selling British author to live, but it suits me fine and I owe it a lot,'' said Bernard Cornwell, a resident of this Union County community since 1980.

title: 18 FOOD PLACES LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments yesterday for health code violations.

title: Kimberley Thomas Weds Christopher Henderson
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Kimberley Carson Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Drummond Thomas of Princeton, was married to Christopher John Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter William Henderson of Rumson, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wallace M. Alston Jr., senior minister of the church, assisted by the Rev. Russell Abata, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: WAYS TO HELP MAKE YOUR HOME SECURE WHILE YOU'RE AWAY
description: SUMMER is a time of many things, including - at least for many homeowners in this area - going off on vacation. Unfortunately, this often means leaving an empty house that is an inviting target for burglars, who invariably prefer houses that they know are unoccupied for days at a time.

title: CAN VECOR DO IT AGAIN?
description: TWO years ago, when Vector Graphic was a hot company in the small-computer business, Time magazine called it one of the industry's wildest success stories. Its chief executive, Lore Harp, made the covers of several business magazines, The Harvard Business Review published a question-andanswer article with her, and the manager of a European venture capital firm that had invested in Vector predicted that she would be the first woman to found a company listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title:
For Nassau Truck Farms, a Hazy Future; 
Some Prospering, But Developers Cloud the Horizon
description: HEAVY traffic, one of the banes of urbanization, roars by in a steady stream at the intersection of Hempstead Avenue and Ocean Avenue in Malverne. But for George Grossmann, whose family has operated a truck farm on 7 1/2 acres at the fork of the road for 60 years, urbanization is not a threat to his way of life, but the key to his survival.

title: Avalanche in France Kills 5
description: An ice avalanche caught 15 French mountain climbers in the Alps at dawn today, killing five and injuring five, the police said. The climbers, members of a club from Rouen, left their camp at dawn with two guides to begin the ascent. Ice roared down on the group at 5 A.M., the mountain police reported.

title: BRAVES BEAT EXPOS, 8-5, IN 10
description: A two-out single by Randy Johnson, a pinch-hitter, broke a 10th-inning tie and Rafael Ramirez added a tworun single tonight as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Montreal Expos, 8-5.

title: INSURANCE IN THE SALE OF PRE-OWNED HOMES
description: THE process of buying and selling a house is so complicated and so l oaded with uncertainties that anything offering protection from the u nexpected is most welcome.

title: RESTORING, AND CONTROLLING, A COLLEGE SPORT
description: AT my recommendation last month, the University of San Francisco board of trustees acted to re-establish a Division I men's intercollegiate basketball program for 1985-86. The return of U.S.F. basketball will take place under an explicit policy of recruiting quality athletes in the West rather than competing for the ''glamour'' recruits being pursued nationally.

title: A Spectrum of American Furniture
description: The marvels, mysteries and misidentifications in American furniture produced between 1850 and 1900 have occupied an increasing number of scholars, museum curators, collectors and dealers in recent years. Questions about what was made when, where and by whom -- and its esthetic worth -- continue to mount as specialists uncover, from the wealth of material of the period, chairs, tables, settees, beds, chests and plant stands, ranging from the ordinary to the esoteric.

title: Consumer Cop
description: To the Business Editor: What, actually, are the United Nations Draft Guidelines on Consumer Protection? The attack on them by Murray Weidenbaum (''The U.N.'s Bid to Play Consumer Cop,'' June 26) would leave the reader misinformed. He describes the guidelines as ''international regulation of the production and distribution of goods and services.'' He says the guidelines involve the U.N. ''intervening in matters which are essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of any state.'' He writes, ''Nowhere do the guidelines stipulate that there are costs attached to the litany of benefits.'' Here are the facts:

title: Patricia Murray Married in Darien
description: Patricia Bradley Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Darien, Conn., yesterday to Peter B. Derr, son of the Rev. Virginia Bush Derr of Rochester and the Rev. Dr. Thomas Sieger Derr of Northampton, Mass. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Is 'Berlin Alexanderplatz' a Vision of the Movies' Future?
description: Next month's New York theatrical premiere of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "Berlin Alexanderplatz," the later German director's masterly, 15 1/2-hour television adaptation of Alfred Doblin's epic 1929 novel of postwar Berlin, stands to become one of the year's most important cinema events. Its importance goes far beyond the Fassbinder career, though we must now reevaluate that career in light of "Berlin Alexanderplatz," a 1980 work that has the effect of being the coda we did not see in Fassbinder's final film, the recently released, lamentable "Querelle."

title: Dr. Jane M. Doyle and Dr. J.A. Day Jr., Internists, Are Married in Connecticut
