description: Dr. Jane Marie Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Doyle of New York and Roxbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. John A. Day Jr., son of Mr. Day of Lafayette Hill, Pa., and the late Marcia O'Brien Day. The Rev. John M. DeZinno performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Roxbury.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I have sailed extensively along the East Coast from Nova Scotia to the Virgin Islands as well as in the Grenadines and on the Great Lakes. We are planning a trip to Greece next spring, and would like to charter a sailboat to explore the islands. Requests for information from Olympic Airways and from the Greek Tourist Board have brought us many pamphlets but little else; where can we get the names of some charter organizations? - D.S., Raleigh, N.C. Answer:In an article entitled ''Sailing the 'Wine-Dark Seas' '' (Travel, Jan. 17, 1982), Joan Gould wrote about sailing with companions around the Peloponnesian peninsula in a flotillla of sailboats that was put together by a British organization. The concept is known as ''flotilla sailing'' or ''sailing in company.''

title: Tinkering With the Soviet Economy
description: U.S.S.R. IN CRISIS. The Failure of an Economic System. By Marshall I. Goldman. 210 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $15.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has a new unit that can actually take over the functions of the human brain, should the brain become injured through trauma or disease. Called the Neurosurgical Intensive-Care Unit, it is part of the division of neurosurgery at University Hospital in Newark.

title: Carole Menzi, Banker, Wed to Art Historian
description: Carole Anne Menzi, daughter of Gida Caronna Menzi of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Richard Menzi, was married yesterday to James Mitchell Collier, son of Helen Collier of Vancouver, Wash., and the late Sidney M. Collier. The ceremony was performed by Msgr.

title: VANDER MEER HELD HIS BREATH
description: HIS name is a synonym. Johnny Vander Meer means double no-hitter, arguably the most remarkable pitching feat in baseball history. Over his 13 seasons, mostly with the Cincinnati Reds, he had a 119-121 career record. But as a 23-year-old left-hander in 1938, he pitched a 3-0 no-hitter against the Boston Braves at Crosley Field on June 11; in his next start, he pitched a 6-0 no-hitter against the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field on June 15 in the first night game there.

title: Fashion; SOCIAL GRACES
description: This fall will be Jacqueline de Ribes's first attempt at styling her own collection and selling very expensive fashion to American women, a very tough business. After the collection was launched in Paris with effusive hyperbole, it was well received by American stores.

title: WORKS BY BENN ARE BACK IN VIEW
description: IF Ben Benn had lived in Europe, he might have had a securer place in art history, but not the critical attention that he received here. As it was, this painter, who arrived here in early youth from Russia and then seldom strayed more than a hundred miles from New York, was primarily inspired by the European masters. El Greco was one painter he admired, Manet another; his color, especially in the late works on view at Branchville's Soho Gallery, occasionally resemble Vlaminck's, although it was often applied in a manner akin to Raoul Dufy's.

title: Naples
description: To the Editor: Travelers in Italy on their way to Capri, Amalfi and points south should be prepared for a new twist to the unpleasantness one can usually expect to encounter in the Central Railroad Terminal in Naples. v. hen we got off the train from Rome, a uniformed man with a shoulder patch that proclaimed him an official interpreter of the Italian Tourist Bureau approached and asked if he could be of help.

title: EGYPT WINS ANOTHER SUMMER BATTLE AGAINST CHOLERA
description: Abdul, 5 years old and obviously terrified, grimaced as the nurse at the clinic plunged the needle into his arm. ''Ouch!'' he yelped.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: GOVERNMENT BY CONTRACT. By John D. Hanrahan. 354 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $17.

title: Mumbles
description: To the Editor: To me the Welsh seaside resort of Mumbles is even more idyllic than described by Sara Evans (what a proper last name she has) in ''Mumbles: Childhood's Summer Idyll'' (Travel, June 12).

title: Suzanne Fusco, Nurse, Wed to John G. Muller
description: Suzanne Mary Fusco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Clifford Fusco of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to John Gerard Muller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Muller of Bayside, Queens. The Rev. James J. Keenan performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove.

title: Pamela Cutrone Marries Lawyer
description: Pamela Marie Cutrone, daughter of Anita Terry of Sacramento, Calif., and Benedict Cutrone of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday in Harrison to David William Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Smith of Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. Joseph Raimondo performed the ceremony at St. Gregory the Great Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE RARITAN: A BIG BAD BAY IN NEED OF FRIENDS
description: THE sampling area this day is Raritan Bay. The trawl goes over the stern of the research vessel Kyma, the wooden doors spread the net and soon it is dragging over the bottom of the bay. In exactly 12 minutes (for these are scientific samples), the trawl is hauled back. Soon, as the net comes over the stern, two people lift it on to the deck and spill the contents. During the day, nine stations in the bay are sampled.

title: THE CITY'S SHRINKING HOUSEHOLDS
description: NEW York City's housing stock changed dramatically in the 1970's, largely in response to equally dramatic shifts in the c ity's households and population. The contrasts were striking: In M anhattan, where growth was rapid, scores of factories and w arehouses were transformed into lofts and apartments, while the B ronx and Brooklyn led the nation's counties in housing units lost toa bandonment and demolition.

title: ALBANY SCOREBOARD: SOME RUNS, SOME HITS, SOME ERRORS
description: THE just completed 1983 legislative session in Albany has produced many significant laws covering such areas as Medicaid reform, criminal sentencing, consumer protection and local government cost controls. Some bills of special importance to Long Island's 2.6 million residents died in committee or passed only one house. Because these bills affected such areas as the costs of Shoreham, senior citizens and tenant protection against unnecessary evictions, they are worth noting for future legislative action.

title: Outsider and Leader
description: DISRAELI. By Sarah Bradford. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $19.95.

title: Lise Olney Engaged
description: Susan Truitt of Washington and Warren Olney 4th of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lise McLean Olney, to David Robison Bridge, son of Mrs. Theodore C. Conderman of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., and the late Joseph Bridge. A Sept. 24 wedding is planned.

title: Sale of Watkins Glen To Corning Unit Near
description: The bid of a Corning Glass Works subsidiary to buy the Watkins Glen race track is ''down to the paperwork'' and could be announced next week, a company official says.

title: ANTIROBBERY PROGRAM TO GROW
description: A new antirobbery operation in New York City that has resulted in a large increase in arrests will soon be expanded to 14 other police precincts, including the two that cover much of the midtown area.

title: A CHILD'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING THE FIRST SUMMER AT CAMP
description: EVERY summer, a new crop of youngsters departs for sleepaway camp for the first time. Being away from home is a difficult adjustment in itself, but when coupled with the stresses of being a ''new kid'' in camp, the situation can become unbearable.

title: SPAIN SEEKS VOICE IN CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: The Spanish Government, venturing into a head-on conflict with the Roman Catholic Church, is working on legislation to change the operations and character of thousands of parochial schools.

title: Data Bank; July 10, 1983
HOW TO KEEP THEM ON FAMILY FARMS?
description: When Jim Riordan wakes up shortly after 6 A.M. these days, he puts on a tie and a suit, like millions of other commuters. And he makes the one-hour drive from here to his office in downtown Des Moines for a day's work for the state of Iowa. If he is lucky and the traffic isn't too bad, around 6 P.M. he is back home again, where he dons a different suit of clothes - denims and boots - for his other life.

title: Best Sellers
description: This Last Weeks

title: Sports of The Times; Look of Eagles
description: JOE LAZARRO was telling about arriving at a local golf club near his home in Waltham, Mass., and, not having come with a group, asking the starter to fill him with any threesome. The group he was put with knew nothing about Joe, but they immediately noticed something odd.

title: SOLDIERS' LETTERS INSPIRE COMPOSER
description: ''IHAVE never been a soldier, only a man in uniform.'' That line was written by a German soldier of the ill-fated Sixth Army, which invaded Russia during World War II. But the sentiment also expresses the view of the composer Elias Tanenbaum of New Rochelle. A veteran who lost a leg fighting in Europe during the war, he has produced a musical composition based on letters home written by German soldiers.

title: Improving Our Schools
description: I wish that legislators and school administrators woud translate treachers' "pay" into terms that address our intellectual as well as our material needs. Ann Sevcik Herndon, Va.

title: PENNEY'S $1 BILLION GAMBLE ON CHIC
description: WHEN First Lady Jackie Kennedy needed a new wardrobe during her W hite House years, she went to Halston, a designer who built his r eputation on creating glamorous and expensive clothes for celebratedw omen. Today, his client list, which includes Nancy Reagan, ElizabethT aylor and Liza Minnelli, reads like a Who's Who of the rich and f amous.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AUNT JULIA AND THE SCRIPTWRITER. By Mario Vargas Llosa. (Avon, $3.95.) While Mario, a newswriter for a radio station in Lima, Peru, scandalizes his family by falling in love with and marrying Julia, his aunt by marriage, his colleague Pedro, who concocts radio soap operas for the station, gets himself entangled in the lives of the bizarre characters he has created. This remarkable melange of dreams and realities, spun from personal experiences of Mario Vargas Llosa, was chosen by the Book Review's editors as one of the best books of 1982.

title: FRANCE MAY GIVE ASYLUM TO IRANIAN HIJACKERS
description: Six Iranians who hijacked an Iran Air jet may be granted political asylum after a trial, officials said today. Teheran announced the closure of two French Government offices in Iran in retaliation for France's handling of the incident.

title: LAWMAKERS GET CAUGHT IN THE ALBANY CRUSH
description: ALBANY WITH the Senate due back this week to put the final touches on the 206th session of the New York State Legislature, some lawmakers are still wondering just what they passed and how they passed it so quickly. In a single weekend last month, about 500 bills were sent to the Governor - nearly half of the 1,137 approved during the session. The last-minute measures ranged from Medicaid financing and rent control all the way to bills banning hunting, fishing and trapping on school grounds, backyard nudity (when visible by the public) and the use of earphones while driving. It was all part of the annual rush to adjourn, when the corridors of the Capitol are clogged with lobbyists and deals are cut by the dozen, with little time for reflection or public scrutiny. Said Assemblyman Kemp Hannon, the G.O.P floor leader: ''I went through intellectual overload.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 10, 1983
description: International Whether the United States goes along with a compromise effort led by European neutrals to conclude the East-West conference in Madrid could depend on a meeting in Washington tomorrow. The Reagan Administration has summoned its chief negotiator, Max M. Kampelman, from Madrid to attend the meeting with senior officials. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Japanese educational system is ''shaping a whole population'' to a standard inconceivable in the United States, according to a research associate of Stanford University who has recently completed a study of Japanese high schools. But the quality of universities is far below that in the United States. (1:3.)

title: UPZONING GAINS IN EAST HAMPTON
description: A PROPOSAL to upzone the last large tracts of land in the Town of East Hampton to five acres in an effort to preserve some 4,000 acres of open space has received unusual bipartisan support.

title: GUITAR: BLUES PLAYER AT FIRST CITY
description: The Texas blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan came to First City Thursday with a strong pedigree. He plays solos on David Bowie's current album, his brother Jimmie leads the well-regarded blues band the Fabulous Thunderbirds, and he has the endorsement of John Hammond, who discovered Billie Holiday and Bob Dylan.

title: 'Staying Alive' Revives Travolta
description: In Los Angeles most people are blase about celebrities. After all, it's not uncommon to spot a star banking at the automatic teller, buying ice cream or working out at the next Nautilus machine. But a few stars still have the power to make the natives restless. Even jaded Angelenos gawk at John Travolta as he dines at one of the city's popular new side-walk cafes. One well-dressed matron approaches him nervously and gushes, "I just want to tell you that I really enjoy your work. And you're just as beautiful in person!"

title: SCHLICHTER: A PATTERN OF GAMBLING THAT BEGAN IN HIS YOUTH
description: BILL HANNERS remembers the old days, when he and Art Schlichter, his best friend since grade school, used to hang aroundt he race tracks near their homes in central Ohio. It was fun back t hen in those innocent days of youth. Both of their families owned a nd raced horses, making it only natural that they spent much of t heir after-school hours learning the nuances of the sport. The f amilies were so close that a few years ago, Hanners and Mila S chlichter, Art's mother, bought a pacer together, Phantom Bret, who h as since been sold.

title: Barbara Hulsart, Stephen Taylor Exchange Vows
description: Dr. Barbara Hulsart, daughter of Shirley Hulsart of South Kent, Conn., and the late C. Raymond Hulsart, was married yesterday to Stephen Taylor, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Taylor of Brooklyn. Town Justice Shepherd Frood of East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's residence there.

title: Books Into Movies
description: The best way for an author to deal with Hollywood, Ernest Hemingway once declared, was to arrange a discreet rendezvous at the state line: "You throw them your book, they throw you the money, then you jump into your car and drive like hell back the way you came." Certainly, the alliance between novelists and film makers has been an uneasy one. In return for money and the promise of reaching a larger audience, authors have seen their work subjected to all manner distortion on the screen. Hemingway, himself, was appalled to discover that the 1932 version of "A Farewell to Arms" was shot with two alternate endings -- one in which Catherine dies, as in the novel, and another in which she revives on her sickbed and appears to live happily ever after. A version of Nathanael West's "Miss Lonelyhearts" also featured a happy ending, and an early adaptation of Melville's "Moby Dick" gave Ahab a "love interest" leading to marriage.

title: STates Squeeze And Squirm
description: The hard times that have befallen many states - and the politicalscramble to avoid blame - were on partisan display last week as gloomy fiscal years dawned in several capitals.

title: JERSEY CITY: THE WORKS OF VISUAL ARTS FELLOWS
description: JURYING an art exhibition can be as chastening an experience for the judges as it is for the judged. Usually, there is a vast quantity of work to be examined and, in this reviewer's limited experience as a juror, there is a space to hang only about one-sixth of it. Many acceptable pieces can get lost in that shuffle alone.

title: THE TURNPIKE: A ROAD TO TROUBLE
description: WHEN it was completed in 1958, the Greenwich-Killingly Expressway was hailed as the solution to Connecticut's highway problems. It was to relieve the traffic jams on the Post Road along the shoreline and open up access to the remote areas of eastern Connecticut.

title:
ART;
CREATURES OF MANY SIZES CAVORT IN MANY STYLES
description: ''CREATURES LARGE AND SMALL,'' an exhibition that began as a benefit for the Animal Rescue Fund, has become a popular annual attraction at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton, where all manner of fauna are on view through Tuesday. Thirty-one artists are represented, and as usual there is enough variety of styles and media to satisfy all tastes.

title: Joseph Stephen Bartusis Is Wed to Mary E. Hilton
description: Mary Elizabeth Hilton, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund W. Hilton Jr. of Tacoma, Wash., was married there yesterday to Joseph Stephen Bartusis, son of Donald Bartusis and Dr. Mary Ann Bartusis of Morrisville, Pa. The Rev. Joseph Marquart performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church.

title: STUDENTS' BONUSES END AT 2 COLLEGES
description: Smith and Mount Holyoke Colleges have dropped new merit scholarship programs that were criticized by other private colleges in the Northeast.

title: CON ED AND UNION MEET ON WALKOUT
description: Representatives of striking workers and the Consolidated Edison Company, responding to pressure from a Federal mediator, met yesterday for two hours in an effort to end the 22-day walkout against the utility.

title: Susan M. Foster Greenwich Bride
description: Susan Melissa Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Knight Foster of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to Trevor Fetter, son of Mr and Mrs. Thompson Fetter of La Jolla, Calif. Bishop Harold Barrett Robinson of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York, who married the bridegroom's parents 26 years ago, performed the ceremony.

title: East Germans Dominate Rowing Events
description: East Germany's national rowing team dominated the first day of the 50th-anniversary Lucerne international regatta today, winning six of the eight men's events and all six women's finals.

title: TENSIONS RISE IN HONDURAS AS BASTION OF WASHINGTON
description: ''We have lost our national honor. What else will we lose in this?'' asked a Honduran opposition politician as the first contingent of an expected 2,400 Salvadoran soldiers arrived to be trained at the new American-built camp on the Caribbean coast.

title: Ethics and the New Medicine
description: If Mr. Abram had to rely solely upon medical-insurance coverage for his medical care, he would have been faced with such exclusions in his policy as "no benefits are availabe for services that, in our judgement, are not needed for your proper medical care or treatment ... we will not cover procedures that are no longer generally regarded as effective or are experimental, in the sense that their effectiveness is not generally recognized."

title: S.I. HILLTOP HOME
description: Even though Federal authorities cannot confirm the claim, Staten Island officials have long believed their Todt Hill at 409.8 feet to be the highest point on the Atlantic Coast between Maine and Key West, Fla.

title: Daniel W. Lauck, Television Producer, Wed to Meg Streeter, an ABC Director
description: The marriage of Margaret Montgomery Streeter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Streeter of New York and Darien, Conn., to Daniel Wayne Lauck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bob Lauck of Topeka, Kan., took place at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien yesterday. The Rev. Lawrence M. Horton performed the ceremony.

title: Books Are in Focus On This Cable Show
description: A long-standing bromide, vigorously supported by frustrated teachers and indignant sociologists, insists that books and television don't mix. Nothing could be further from the truth. More books are being sold today than ever before, and television has been a key instrument in this phenomenon. There are the direct promotional linkups, the kind of packaging that can restore novels like Herman Wouk's "Winds of War" to the best-seller lists following the success of an adaptation into a television mini-series. And there are indirect spinoffs. The popularity of "Up-stairs, Downstairs" on public television several years ago led to an increased demand for histories of Edwardian England.

title: FOR TEANECK ACTOR, PLAY IS THE THING
description: THE ''Fourth of July is like Christmas - comes but once a year,'' Nat Miller observes. It is Independence Day, 1906, and ''getting to the picnic or going for a ride in the Buick,'' as Effie, Nat's wife says, are the big holiday events in the small town where the Miller family lives.

title: HOBOKEN: THE TIDE MAY BE TURNING
description: HOBOKEN IN 1954, when Marlon Brando was prowling the Fifth Street pier here during the filming of ''On the Waterfront,'' the city's docks were alive with cargo and passenger ships. Almost 30 years later, those once-busy docks are a virtual marine ghost town, with some of the piers so dilapidated that they have been condemned.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: FORMER State Representative Ernest N. Abate, a Democrat from Stamford, served as Speaker of the House - that chamber's highest leadership post, and ran unsuccessfully for Governor last year. But now Mr. Abate says he is considering returning to the State Capitol, and this time in the State Senate.

title: GUIDES AND GOADS; Public Servants
description: What is honored in a country, someone said, is what is practiced there. Two items from Friday's news tell something about how some people in Washington seek honor these days.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CHICAGO
description: NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr. is a correspondent in the Chicago bureau of The Times.

title: Air Fares
description: To the Editor: This is to correct some facts in Fred Ferretti's article entitled ''Air Fare Bargains Over the Atlantic'' (Travel, June 19).

title: Dolphins Sign Marino, Their No.1 Draft Pick
description: Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphins' No.1 draft pick, signed a contract with the National Football League club today, then attended a news conference at which no one would reveal details of the pact.

title: U.S. Says China Trade Dipped Sharply in May
description: Trade between the United States and China dipped to $238 million in May, the lowest monthly level since October 1979, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Speak Softly About Dioxin
description: A cache of several hundred thousand company documents released by a Federal district judge last week may turn out to be a mother lode for Vietnam veterans and a Pandora's box for some chemical manufacturers. The papers, handed to the court in a class action brought by 20,000 vets who claim injury by exposure to the dioxin-laden Agent Orange herbicide, suggest the companies have been less than generous with their knowledge about dioxin hazards.

title:
STAMPS; 
World Tour for Armchair Travelers
description: The travel season is now in full swing for philatelic globe-trotters, as well as tourists, because this is the time when many countries display their scenic glories and landmarks on stamps so that collectors can enjoy much of the world effort-lessly and inexpensively while staying at home.

title: SOMERS COMPLEX ADAPTS TO TIMES
description: THE imperatives of buyer preference are making themselves felt at H eritage Hills, the large adult community that is growing across h illy terrain in the Town of Somers in northern Westchester.

title: Cost of 1,000 Missiles Assessed at $70 Billion
description: The Air Force has estimated that it will cost $70 billion over 10 years to build 1,000 small missiles with single warheads, carried aboard blast-resistant trucks, an Air Force official says.

title: INDIAN PATCHWORK ON VIEW IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK NEW quilted wall hangings by Joy Saville of Princeton are on view at the Newark Museum Mini-Gallery through July 24. In relation to an exhibition of this artist's work at the Squibb Gallery in Lawrence Township last year, this can be seen as ''Chapter Two.''

title: CHINA'S WEST IS CHALLENGED BY ETHNIC MIX
description: A Han Chinese migrant to this western Chinese region said her husband once threw a pailful of dirty laundry water out the front door and nearly splashed a local Uighur, a Moslem who was going to the mosque to pray. Uighur neighbors came around to say they considered the practice offensive, and her husband apologized.

title: A Medal for The General
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski could breathe easier last week. With Pope John Paul II back in Rome came a pat on the back for the Polish leader from the Kremlin - the Order of Lenin, the highest Soviet award.

title: Agca Names His Handlers
description: For two years, Italian investigators have been quoting Mehmet Ali Agca as saying he received orders to shoot Pope John Paul II from the Soviet secret police - the K.G.B. -and Bulgarian accomplices. Last week, Mr. Agca said it in public for the first time.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
BOYS WILL BE BOYS, BUT FATHER STILL KNOWS BEST
description: ALTHOUGH I realize that the oversupply of lawyers in the United States almost mandates an increasing number of lawsuits, I did not think that people in my home state were an overly litigious breed or that our lawyers needed the business so badly.

title: BALLET: ROLE FOR MISS KIRKLAND
description: Gelsey Kirkland is a star who makes an unforgettable imprint on her roles. And so there was much interest in her New York debut performance of the title role of George Balanchine's magical ''La Sonnambula,'' presented by the American Ballet Theater on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was a performance that ended with affectionate, impromptu exchanges of a bouquet between Miss Kirkland and the cheering audience.

title: Can't Go Home
description: Once, visitors coming into Lebanon, Ind., were greeted with the sign ''LEBANON, Home of Rick Mount.'' Those were the days when Rick Mount was one of the nation's most heralded high school and college basketball scorers.

title: Australia II Beats Advance in Cup Trials
description: Australia II, after falling behind by 27 seconds at the start, defeated Advance, also from Australia, by more than 2 minutes today in the trials to select an America's Cup challenger.

title: Seeking Evidence
description: Argentine tennis officials, stunned by the recent one-year ban imposed on Guillermo Vilas, who was accused of accepting a $60,000 payoff to play in a Rotterdam tournament, revealed the contents of a two-page letter that had been sent to the International Tennis Federation and the Men's International Professional Tennis Council protesting the ban. In the letter to Philip Chatrier, a Frenchman who is head of the M.I.P.T.C., the Argentine Tennis Association demanded ''that we receive from the Pro Council the legalized copies of all files, including the said evidence, including the said evidence supplied by several tournament supervisors, within seven days.''

title: Bauer Still Leads in Run
description: As of 4:12 P.M. yesterday, after 120 hours on the Downing Stadium track on Randalls Island, Siegfried Bauer was still maintaining the lead that he has held virtually since the beginning of the New York Six-Day Run last Monday.

title: Queens Rowers 2d
description: The crew of Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Beach, Queens, lost by five seconds in the quarterfinals of the Bedford Regatta yesterday in Bedford, England. The Beach Channel rowers finished the 1,200-meter course in 3 minutes 50 seconds, behind the Shawnigan Lake crew of British Columbia, which finished in 3:45. More than 30,000 spectators watched the meet which was held on the Ouse River.

title: Pooley Posts a 68 For One-Shot Lead
description: Don Pooley, displaying a recklessness he says he usually suppresses, shot a 4-under-par 68 today for a onestroke lead over Wally Armstrong after three rounds of the $250,000 Milwaukee Open golf tournament.

title: Hearns Tries to Erase Memory of Loss
description: With a knot in his right fist and a lump in his memory, Thomas Hearns will resume his boxing career today by offering a left-handed complement of punches to Murray Sutherland.

title: RENT-CONTROL FOES STILL AT LOGGERHEADS
description: THE regulation of multiple-dwelling rents by municipalities has been under attack by landlords and building organizations since the wide adoption of rent control during the 1970's.

title: Statistic That Mystifies
description: To the Sports Editor: In the evolution of baseball's hallowed box score, no change has been so abused as the 1983 addition of the game-winning run batted in.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BECAUSE of the doings of her clan, Virginia Edwards is sometimes referred to as the state's version of Rose Kennedy. ''But we don't have money,'' she laughed.

title: INFIGHTING RISES IN WHITE HOUSE ON DEBATE ISSUE
description: The controversy over the 1980 Reagan campaign's use of President Carter's papers has touched off a power struggle within the Administration that could affect the ideological character of a Reagan re-election effort and of a possible second term, according to senior Republicans in and close to the Government.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Sons and Lovers' Revisited

title: Recordings;  Beethoven Quartets Pose the Challenge Of Greatness
description: Beethoven's five late string quartets are often considered to be the greatest music of the greatest composer who ever lived. Or, put more grandly still, the greatest achievement in any medium of the greatest artist who ever lived. "There is nothing like them in the whole of music," wrote the British composer and critic Robert Simpson. "It is a platitude to say that his range of expression is Shakespearean; so it is, but he has a commitment to humanity that Shakespeare does not reveal. There has been no greater artist, and it is to be doubted whether any can match him."

title: PROSECUTOR ASSERTS COWBOYS NOT ON TAP
description: A United States Attorney said today that ''no member of any professional sports team'' has been mentioned on wiretaps in connection with a Federal cocaine investigation here.

title: SALVADOR REBELS SPLIT ON U.S. ENVOY
description: Disagreements within the Salvadoran guerrilla leadership are apparently preventing a meeting between representatives of the guerrilla front and President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, according to informants close to the Government here.

title: MISCALCULATIONS ON MIDEAST ADD UP TO NEAR ZERO FOR U.S.
description: W ASHINGTON THE ''fresh start'' toward peace in the Middle East that President Reagan launched 10 months ago seemed last week to be at a dead end. Secretary of State George P. Shultz returned from the region acknowledging the failure of efforts to arrange simultaneous withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces from Lebanon. And there has been virtually no progress in tackling the broad, complex Palestinian question that was at the heart of Mr. Reagan's Sept. 1 plan.

title: Padilla Sets U.S. Record in 3,000 at Oslo
description: Doug Padilla, a Californian who did his collegiate running at Brigham Young, set an American record in the 3,000-meter run of the Oslo Games tonight with a time of 7 minutes 35.84 seconds, and Carlos Lopes of Portugal ran the third fastest 10,000-meter time ever recorded.

title: WALES
description: To the Editor:

title: BY FALL HEARING EXPECTED IN INMATES' SUIT
description: WHITE PLAINS A FEDERAL District Judge in Manhattan recently ruled that a group of inmates who were in the Westchester County Jail at the time of a riot there two years ago could sue state prison officials for damages for themselves and other prisoners.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: INDIA SAYS IT MAY MAKE PLUTONIUM AT TARAPUR
description: One of the country's top atomic energy officials says an American-built nuclear power plant near here may have to start reprocessing spent nuclear fuel into plutonium because it is short of storage space for the spent fuel and the plant needs to be decontaminated.

title: DINING DOWN BY THE RIVERSIDE
description: HOBOKEN THERE are some Hoboken residents who simply feel that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is not the right developer for the waterfront, and George Costa is one of them.

title: 3 ISSUES INVOLVE BASS, TROUT
description: THREE critical legal or legislative struggles involving either striped bass or trout are taking place in New York State this year. Late last month, the State Legislature approved a bill sponsored by Assemblyman Patrick Halpin of Suffolk County, which if signed by Governor Cuomo, would establish a length limit of 24 inches over all for stripers in the state's coastal waters and 18 inches over all for them in the Hudson River upstream of George Washington Bridge. The existing limit in all state waters is 16 inches from snout to fork of tail.

title: A QUIET SUMMER FOR PLAYHOUSE
description: THE roar of the greasepaint will be noticeably absent this summer from the quaint red Sharon Playhouse. For the first time since it was founded 33 years ago, there will be no summer stock season at the 388-seat country theater, where such performers as Bradford Dillman and Jane Alexander trod the boards.

title: California
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Mark Mohney And Miss Stewart Exchange Vows
description: Sally Slaughter Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Stewart Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark William Mohney, son of Dr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Mohney of Venice, Fla. The Rev. James Fenhagen, assisted by the Rev. Huntington Williams, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: It's Still the Festival That Mozart Built
description: It was only a week or so after the program brochures for the 17th Mostly Mozart Festival had been mailed, and a few days after the box office had opened. But already, the first angry letters were finding their way to the subterranean Lincoln Center office of William W. Lockwood Jr., the festival's managing director. Mr. Lockwood read them, noted their concerns, and then passed them on to Gerard Schwarz, the conductor who was appointed Mostly Mozart's first music advisor just before last summer's series began. Tomorrow evening, at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Schwarz will be on the podium for the opening concert of the seven-week festival, and he will return to conduct about a third of its orchestral concerts.

title: Guide Dog Agency: A 'Superb Service'
description: Re: ''Rift Besets Guide Dog Agency,'' June 5: I have been associated with the Smithtown Guide Dog Foundation and know it to have a dedicated staff doing a superb service of training both dogs as guides, and blind people to whom the perfectly trained dogs will be donated.

title: AN ARRAY OF TREATS FOR THE BLUEBERRY SEASON
description: THE blueberry season has begun and will last until fall. Plump, cultivated berries piled into pint containers are characteristically dark blue with a natural silvery blush. They are larger, sweeter and also somewhat blander than wild blueberries, but they have less obvious seeds in the berries you may pick along the roadside in New England.

title: CALIFORNIA
description: To the Editor: I was shocked and disappointed by Donald E. Westlake's nasty attitude toward bicyclists in his article on California. Mr. Westlake writes: ''I'm willing to watch for deer, for elk, even for the occasional pedestrians, and when I'm told to watch for trucks you'd better believe I do; but bicycles? ... I just think it's up to those bicycles to fend for themselves.

title: AFRICAN TREK: LAKE ASSAL
description: HUGH O. MUIR is the East Africa correspondent for the Voice of America, based in Nairobi.

title: Who Killed Wife No. 6?
description: BLUEBEARD. A Tale. By Max Frisch. Translated by Geoffrey Skelton. 134 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95.

title:
A FREEZE ON BANK DEREGULATION?;
TIME OUT FOR AN ORDERLY TRANSITION
description: BIG changes are ahead for American banking. More competition, more s ources of credit, new technologies and new services are beckoning. T he question is not whether these changes will occur, but how. Are wet o proceed in a disorderly rush? Or can we make an orderly transitiont o a more modern system?

title: ISRAEL'S STAGGERING ECONOMY LEANS HARDER ON WASHINGTON
description: An Israeli walked into his bank in Tel Aviv recently, wrote a check to ''Cash'' for the equivalent of several hundred dollars, handed it over the counter and waited. The teller consulted a computer printout and found that the customer had overdrawn his account by about 120,000 shekels ($2,553), more than double the amount of his credit line. But instead of reprimanding him or turning him away, she smiled, told him cheerily about his debt and then cashed his check.

title: NOISE RULE CALLED THREAT TO AUTO RACING
description: SOUTHAMPTON TOWN'S decision to adopt a new noise ordinance governing the two local race tracks has angered racing enthusiasts and the tracks' owners, who fear that the new regulations could close both the 520-acre Bridgehampton Race Circuit and the Westhampton Drag Strip.

title: PRISON LABOR CATERS TO DOLL COLLECTORS
description: CHIEF JUSTICE Warren Burger, who last month called for an increase in prison industry, may soon receive a package from the Ossining Correctional Facility. Not a license plate, typically associated with prison labor, or even one of the plastic bags manufactured at the facility, but a 12-inch porcelain baby doll.

title: SMITHSONIAN ENDS AN OLD SAFE'S ODYSSEY
description: FOR awhile, it looked as if it might be known as Felix Gremmo's folly: the squat, black safe he had picked up as scrap metal nine years ago through the state surplus system. Mr. Gremmo thought he would be able to sell it to the bank for which it had been made 109 years ago, but for almost a decade he could not give it away.

title: TAX SHIFTS HOME SALES PLANS
description: THE new state tax on the transfer of real estate, which went into effect on July 1, has been disrupting plans of many buyers and sellers scheduled to close around this time.

title: SAMPLING THE FARE AT A NEW HOTEL
description: THE spacious and elegant Polo Grill, which occupies one side of the lobby of the new Garden City Hotel, offers one of the more gracious dining settings on the Island. The two-level area, defined by low marble partitions, planters and gleaming brass railings, is plushly decorated with comfortable chairs and banquets in tones of beige and rose. Tables are roomy and well-spaced; lighting is soft and accented by pinpoints of candles in the evenings. A skylight provides a flood of daylight at lunch.

title: Hotel Heaven
description: To the Editor: I did enjoy ''Hotel Heaven - Make Mine Modern'' by Bernard Sloan (Travel, June 19). Several years ago, I too was disillusioned with charming and historical inns. A friend and I, two women past middle age, were being driven through Scotland and were to stay in a well-known hotel in Edinburgh but were shifted, too late to cancel, to a nearby castle. This proved to be 12 miles south of the city, set in farmland, with nothing of interest in sight, except the castle. ts thick stone walls had been blasted by Cromwell's men, we were proudly told by the owner, and we felt nothing had improved since then. The first-floor ''great room'' - 25 steps up from the courtyard - had been made near habitable, and boasted arms and banners on the stone walls, and a fireplace alight at one end.

title: IN SCULLING, IT'S EXERCISE WITH SERENITY
description: EACH morning, John Libaire lifts a 40-pound fiberglass scull from two sawhorses in his backyard in Oakdale and slides it into the quiet water of Brick Kiln Creek.

title: THE STORY OF THE ELEPHANT HOTEL
description: In the beginning, there was the elephant. It was an Indian subject and the biggest living thing that the people of the Tyrolean town of Brixen (Bressanone in Italian), had ever seen. King John III of Portugal had had it sent from Goa by ship to Genoa, his gift to the menagerie in Vienna of Emperor Ferdinand of Austria.

title: Judge the Brain, Not the Cap
description: I was shocked to see that more than half a page was devoted to what I would kindly refer to as ''plain rubbish'' (''Hospitals Need Dress Codes Again,'' June 12) by Jesse S. Manlapaz, M.D., and the pictures above the article deserve no better designation.

title: HOTEL HEAVEN
description: To the Editor: The story ''Make Mine Modern'' about comfort in hotels spoke the truth.

title: London's Best Is Very Good Indeed
description: The distance separating the theatrical worlds of London and New York seems to be narrowing all the time. In the honky-tonk precincts of the West End, as on Broadway, one finds too many dark theaters, too many theaters permanently occupied by long-running shows for the tourist trade (three of them, as always, by Andrew Lloyd Webber), too many empty seats and too few good plays. Musical revivals are ubiquitous -- from Topol in "Fiddler on the Roof" to a giddy 1929 Anglo-American oddity, "Mr. Cinders," starring the sublime Denis Lawson -- and, both on the West End and along the fringe, imports are the daily fare. As a New York visitor peruses the London theatrical listings of early summer -- among them, "The Dining Room," "A Moon for the Misbegotten" and "Romantic Comedy" -- he can forget he's ever left home.

title: COURTS, CITING DANGERS, TAKE A DIMMER VIEW OF HYPNOSIS
description: On the evening of May 19, 1978, Nancy Simmons, a young mother in Syracuse, tucked her four-year-old son into bed, then went to sleep. She left the door to the apartment open for her husband, who customarily returned from work about 2 A.M. When Bart Simmons came home, he found her sprawled on the landing, bruised, naked and covered with dirt. She had been raped; incoherant and hysterical, she could not identify her assailant.

title: A TIMES SQUARE VENTURE
description: So far, the focus of much of the revitalization of Times Square and its surrounding neighborhood has centered on various commercial development projects such as office towers and hotels and the refurbishing of the area's theaters and movie houses.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: GLOBETROTTING, DANISH DELIGHTS
description: Been to the Tokelau Islands in the South Pacific? To Tristan da Cunha in the South Atlantic? What about Ogasawara-gunto in the Bonin Islands off Japan or the Bismarck Archipelago in the Southwest Pacific?

title: Pamela Waterman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Proctor Spalding Waterman of Riverside, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Olry Waterman, to Kenneth Steven Paley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paley of Miami. A September wedding is planned.

title: CHAD ADMITS LOSING MORE GROUND TO REBEL FORCES
description: Libyan-backed rebel forces in Chad appeared to be strengthening their position today as a Government spokesman asserted that battles were taking place around the strategically important eastern towns of Biltine and Abeche.

title: OCEAN RELIC ROTS FOR LACK OF FUNDS
description: For nearly 50 years, ships of her kind helped open the Pacific Northwest, traversing the rugged coast with passengers to the Alaska gold fields and returning with lumber to build California's cities. Now the 67-year-old Wapama, the last example of the type, is rotting away in a backwater of the Oakland Estuary, a victim of what one National Park official called ''the ugly duckling syndrome.''

title: SOVIET DENIES AGCA CHARGE ON POPE PLOT
description: Reacting to the assertion by Mehmet Ali Agca on Friday that K.G.B. agents were involved in his attack on Pope John Paul II, the Soviet Union today called the accusation ''threadbare propaganda.''

title: ERICA BROWN is a London-based writer.
description: T he lot of the tourist is not necessarily a happy one. A day - or even a morning - spent visiting a museum, art gallery, ancient monument, or just shopping can be hard work, especially on the feet.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In the July 3 Postings column, the name of the architect for American-Standard Inc.'s new building, One Centennial Plaza, in Piscataway, N.J., was incorrectly reported. The project was designed by the architectural firm of The Grad Partnership.

title: Drawing the Line On Birth Control
description: When in 1981 Congress called for ''encouraging parent participation'' in teen-agers' birth control decisions, it did not intend family planning clinics to tell parents their children were seeking contraceptives, a three-judge Federal appeals court in Washington ruled last week. By requiring notification in federally aided clinics, the court said, the Reagan Administration exceeded its authority.

title: State to Require Report On Every Case of AIDS
description: The State Health Department issued a 60-day emergency rule yesterday requiring that it receive reports of all cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: LYME DISEASE CAUSING CONCERN IN PARTS OF COUNTRY
description: IT appears that Lyme Disease, which was first reported in the county last year, may become a recurrent summertime hazard in certain parts of Westchester.

title: On Raising a Bridge In Southold
description: The statement ''People who live on the creek want a higher bridge so they can sail large boats'' (''East End Approaches Choice on Bridges,'' June 12) is patently incorrect. It is proposed that the height of the Jockey Creek Bridge in Southold Village be raised from a shade over 5 feet to between 12 to 15 feet.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: JUSTICE AT NUREMBERG. By Robert E. Conot. Illustrated. 593 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: HOw Long Will The Economy Remain Lively?
description: Financiers were not happy people last week. Reagan Adminstration officials were even more uncomfortable. Faced with a stock market decline of more than 16 points and a rise of up to half a percentage point in interest rates on rumors of an imminent tightening of credit by the Federal Reserve, the White House took up the jawbone. ''Our view,'' declared Presidential spokesman Larry Speakes, ''is that we would not like to see interest rates increased.''

title: Wild Flowers To Grow from Seeds or Cuttings
description: In the resurgence of perennials, native American plants have become extremely popular. Commonly used in borders, these wild flowers usually flourish with little help. In fact, restraining them can be more of a chore than increasing their numbers. Many species are excellent in great masses, both in sunny borders and shaded woodlands. If a few simple propagation techniques are followed, great numbers of plants can be produced in a relatively short period of time.

title: Watery Echoes Of Napoleon
description: The Duke of Wellington was said to ''not care a twopenny damn what becomes of the ashes of Napoleon Buonaparte,'' his adversary at Waterloo. But archeologists have long cared what became of the ashes of L'Orient, Napoleon's flagship during the war with Britain for control of the Mediterranean.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: LITTLE FLOWER. The Life and Times of Fiorello La Guardia. By Lawrence Elliot. 256 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.95.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
MUSICAL REPRISE
description: Old orchestras never die; their sounds live on, even after their leaders depart. Take the famed Dorsey brothers, for example. Although both Tommy and Jimmy are no longer around, their bands, conducted by disciples, are still playing the kind of melodious swing that made the 1940's so mellow musically. And this week Long Islanders can refresh their memories, because both aggregations will be appearing on the free outdoor summer concert circuit: the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, led by Buddy Morrow with Helen Forrest as guest vocalist, today at Newbridge Road Park in Bellmore, and Lee Castle and His Fabulous Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra, with Ada Cavallo, vocalist, on Tuesday at Burns Town Park, Merrick Road in Massapequa. Both concerts are at 8:15 P.M. and audiences must bring their own seating.

title: ACTUAL PRICE OF HIGH DAMS ALSO INCLUDES SOCIAL COSTS
description: Among the wonders of the modern world are the high dams that tower above great rivers. For some 50 years, the big structures that create electric power and provide water to irrigate barren fields have also symbolized progress for the world's poor and hungry.

title:
A FREEZE ON BANK DEREGULATION;
MARKET FORCES CAN'T BE DAMMED UP
description: THE toughest political and economic problems are often those on w hich everyone agrees in principle but disagrees on particulars. R esponsible leaders in Government and business have long been callingf or less - and fairer - regulation of financial services. But how to g o about it has so far eluded consensus.

title: CELEBRATION IN THE SKIES OVER OSHKOSH
description: DIANE ACKERMAN, a writer and poet, recently became a licensed pilot. Her third collection of poetry, ''Lady Faustus,'' will be published by William Morrow in the fall.

title: A RAIL BUFF'S GUIDE TO THE U.S.
description: America by Train By Ira Fistell. Burt Franklin & Co., New York, 432 pages. (Paperback) $7.95.

title: TOPICS
description: AS a young boy I visited an aunt who lived in a large apartment house in Brooklyn. After lunch I went downstairs to play. But when I grew tired and wanted to go back upstairs, I discovered that I couldn't remember on which floor she lived. Since I hadn't yet learned to read, I stared at the long list of names and apartment numbers and couldn't find which bell to press.

title: BATTLE INTENSIFIES OVER I-95 DETOURS
description: New York fired a salvo of trucks at Connecticut today as the battle of Interstate 95 heated up. At noon, the New York authorities began permitting truck traffic to flow into Connecticut on the highway, after the trucks had been diverted through this village in Westchester County near the state line for 12 days because of the collapse of part of the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich, Conn.

title: REAGAN WILL OFFER FAIR HOUSING LAWS WITH 'REAL TEETH'
description: President Reagan, whose civil rights policies have been under fire recently, said today that he would send Congress proposals to put ''real teeth'' into the enforcement of fair housing laws.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FIVE TOWNS
description: COUNT carefully and you will find more than five towns in the Five T owns, an area in the wetlands of southwestern Nassau County that h as estates worthy of barons, striking contemporary palaces and s maller suburban split-levels.

title: IN ALBANY, HARD BARGAINING ETCHES HOUSING CHANGES
description: THIS has been a year of sweeping change, dramatic initiatives and g rudgingly reached compromises on an array of major housing and r ealestate issues in the New York State Senate and Assembly.

title: HOMESEXUALS OFFER HELP IN AIDS STUDY
description: RESEARCHERS at Yale-New Haven Hospital want to learn more about AIDS, and they have found the area's homosexual community eager to help.

title: THREE SISTERS TALK WITH HORSES
description: AS the sun rises over Belmont Park Race Track, the three Clayton sisters drive through Gate 6 to the stables, where they will spend their day. It is where they work: Barbara Clayton, 25 years old, assists Dr. Jay Miller, the track veterinarian; Christine Clayton, 24, gallops horses for the trainer Sidney Watters and Margery Clayton, 23, exercises horses she will probably ride in the afternoon races.

title: Caribbean Leaders Urge End To Central America Conflicts
description: Caribbean leaders called today for an end to foreign intervention in Central America and for talks among the nations to end the conflicts.

title: Susan Thebner Is Married To Dr. Richard E. Slutsky
description: Susan Lee Thebner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Thebner of Monsey, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Elliot Slutsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Slutsky of Bayside, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alan Lavin at Temple Sholom in Brooklyn.

title: Wall Across Europe
description: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE FOREST. An Iron Curtain Journey By Anthony Bailey. 332 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: AXIS: SLEEK AND CHIC IN TOKYO
description: TERRY TRUCCO is a Tokyo-based writer.

title: Sudan Accuses Libya In Kidnapping by Rebels
description: The Sudan accused Libya today of planning the kidnapping of two Americans and three other Westerners who were freed unharmed Friday by Sudanese in a commando raid.

title: MEDALS OF HONOR
description: For the last several weeks, workmen have been doing some medalpolishing on the roof of 29 West 57th Street. As part of an exterior restoration project on the New York Realty Building, the medallionlike ornaments that adorn each side of a water-tower covering on the building's roof are being restored as the entire building is cleaned and gold-leafed.

title: NAIROBI,KENYA
description: Afew months ago, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi celebrated the 13th anniversary of Libya's revolution with a harsh attack on Arab conservatives. But in recent weeks, the Libyan leader has lived up to his reputation for unpredictability by meeting with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, Jordan's King Hussein, whom he has described as ''worthless,'' and Morocco's King Hassan II, whom he has called ''cowardly.''
To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: SUMMERMUSIC ENDS WITH HAYDN AND DEBUSSY
description: The Summermusic series at the 92d Street Y offered its sixth and last chamber-music concert of the year Thursday night. All the music may not have adhered to the seasonal flavor of Summermusic's title, but the combination of Haydn with Debussy was a graceful and a winning one.

title:
THE PAST MAY NOT BE PROLOGUE;
TWO SCENARIOS FOR SHARPLY HIGHER RATES
description: THE suspense is over. President Reagan has reappointed Paul A. Volcker to a second four-year term as Federal Reserve chairman. T his move is expected to steady the jittery bond market - at least b efore long. Most forecasters continue to project a fairly narrow t rading range for long-term interest rates over the next year (even t hough temporary nervous runups in rates are expected to recur). M oreover, forecasts of moderately lower interest rates by year-end a nd through mid-1984 still outnumber projections of persistent rate i ncreases.

title: The Case for Consumerism
description: He apparently relies on a nonpublic memorandum alleging that a commission economist had stopped the investigation. As Mr. Pertschuk has been told: (1) the author of the leaked memorandum never spoke to the economist whose views he claims to be summarizing; (2) the economist never said what he is alleged to have said; (3) the economist supports the investigation.

title: THE JOY OF HOUSE GUESTS
description: ILOVE having house guests. Not many household chores are more a greeable, more worth the trouble, more full of the promise of g uaranteed good things to come than whipping the guest room into s hape, even if that means finding a place for the overflow from dailyl ife that seems to accumulate there.

title: Miss Bodine Wed To Dr. R.M. Lee
description: Tracy Warden Bodine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Bodine of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church to Dr. Randolph Mitchell Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Lee of Glenside, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank G. Kirkpatrick, chairman of the department of religion at Trinity College, from which the couple graduated and where Dr. Lee is associate professor of psychology and associate college counselor.

title: PLAIN TALK ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Bases, it seems, are the sticking point. ''If the Soviet Union or the Cubans, in conjunction or alone, were to establish a major base or military position in Central America, I think it would be a matter of very, very, serious concern,'' former Vice President Walter Mondale told a television audience last month. ''I think it would go to the vital interests of our country, and it would raise grave challenges.''

title: Shooting in Sequence Leads to Better Pictures
description: Although sports photographers and other professionals have long used expensive add-on motor drives to shoot action sequences of athletic events and fast-moving subjects of all kinds, the average user will find one of the light-weight auto-winders that are available for many SLR cameras equally useful, less expensive, and more convenient to use. These can shoot 1 1/2 to 2 frames a second, compared to five to six frames a second with a motor drive, but this is generally adequate for most amateurs.

title: POLITICAL STRATEGISITS AIM AT WOMEN AND MINORITIES
description: A year before 1984's first Presidential nominating convention, the partisan balance sheet looks reasonably close, though in some ways quite untraditional. ''Peace,'' for example, used to be a good Republican issue and economic recovery a plus for the Democrats. The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows those roles reversed in the public mind, with the Democrats preferred, 40 percent to 27 percent, for keeping out of war, and the Republicans liked better, 40 percent to 36 percent, for economic recovery.

title: BUSINESSES FIND THE ALLURE OF RURAL LIFE
description: THERE are Persian rugs on wide colonial floors, early American Windsor chairs clustered around an antique mahogany desk, delicate moldings gracing doorways and a cast-iron grate crafted during the Civil War adorning an elaborate Victorian fireplace.

title: 2D TERM OPPOSED
description: The chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus today called on President Reagan not to run for reelection.

title: GUIDES AND GOADS; Iconoclast
description: In 1967, Herman Kahn and a colleague published a list of 100 technical innovations likely by the year 2000. Some, like computers and electronic communication in the home, have already materialized.

title: Raclette
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's article ''In the Swiss Valais, Raclette Is a Ritual'' (Travel, June 19) brought back fond memories of my own Swiss holidays. But if he has concentrated on the Valais region he has never savored the magnificence of raclette as prepared in nearly every restaurant in the village of Gruyeres.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: ON BECOMING A NOVELIST. By John Gardner. Foreword by Raymond Carver. 150 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: BRETT IS MAKING A COMEBACK AFTER TWO YEARS OF PROBLEMS
description: ''Comeback'' may not be the best word to apply to a player who is hitting over .300 for the fifth consecutive season, who made the allstar team for the eighth consecutive season and who is earning $1 million every year.

title: Heidi Brieger and David Mackey Wed
description: Heidi E. Brieger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gert H. Brieger of Berkeley, Calif., was married yesterday to David S. Mackey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Mackey Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Virginia Mackey of Rochester, an aunt of the bridegroom and a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony in the nondenominational chapel at Hancock Point, Me.

title: A GROWING STORM OVER INTEREST RATES
description: NEXT Thursday, when Paul A. Volcker rides up to Capitol Hill to testify on his renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve, he might well ask himself how he got into such a predicament. If there was ever a time when the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve System was a thankless task, this is it.

title: A BLEND OF BAKING AND MEDITATION
description: AT midnight each night, the workers in a small bakery in Yonkers stop kneading dough and take their eyes off the clock timing the muffins, cookies and macaroons in the ovens. They gather their thoughts into a minute of silent meditation on behalf of world peace. Though this is a special moment of reflection, the cooks at the Greyston Bakery on the corner of Riverdale and Ludlow try to infuse the mixing, kneading and baking with the intense spirituality practiced by Zen Buddhists.

title: PRESIDENTIAL DISTINCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine Ulrich Becomes a Bride
description: Catherine Anne Ulrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Alden Ulrich of Orange, Conn., and Grafton, Vt., was married yesterday to Peter Michael Connorton, son of Mrs. John V. Connorton of New York and Carmel, N.Y., and the late Mr. Connorton. The Rev. Ernest Heeren performed the ceremony at the Orange Congregational Church.

title: Kimberly Griffin Wed To Richard Reynolds
description: Kimberly Ellen Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Griffin 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Richard Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Reynolds of Delray Beach, Fla., and Brielle, N.J. The Rev. James Fisher performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: Nancy White Has Nuptials
description: Nancy Carolyn White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. White of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to George Frank Bryant Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bryant of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard B. Martin performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont.

title: HEALTH UNIT TO ISSUE BLUE-CRAB ADVISORY
description: TRENTON TESTS conducted by the state's Department of Health will show that the blue crab does not contain dangerous levels of a toxic metal, as had been suspected.

title: Soviet Cyclist Wins Event in Coast Race
description: Sergei Kopylov of the Soviet Union, the world sprint champion in 1981 and last year, switched to distance racing Friday night and romped to an easy victory in the 1,000-meter race that highlighted the opening day of the International Cycling Invitational, a dress rehearsal for the 1984 Olympics.

title: SANDY SANDY HOOK SANS SAND?
description: ALOT of people hate sand. I can dig that. It invariably finds its way to where you don't want it: eyes, food, sneakers, bathing suit elastic, belly buttons. That's the rub.

title: Hillary D. White, Geneticist, Is Wed
description: Hillary Dinsmoor White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Finley Tomlinson White of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday to Philip Dechert Jr., son of Mrs. Dechert and the late Mr. Dechert of Nonquitt, Mass. John Brooke Mosley Jr., the Assisting Episcopal Bishop of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony at St. Aiden's Chapel in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: ABORTION FOES END MEETING OPTIMISTIC DESPITE SETBACKS
description: Local and national leaders of the National Right to Life Committee gathered here this week to celebrate what they consider major victories against abortion and to plan ways to take the sting out of recent defeats.

title: TOWNS SCRAMBLE FOR STATE LANDFILL FUNDS
description: STATE officials said last week that they hoped a compromise could be worked out to keep Huntington and Babylon from losing $28 million that the state had agreed to contribute toward a resource-recovery plant to end their dependence on garbage dumping and landfills.

title: THE DEFICIT SPEAKS
description: This is your deficit speaking. I am usually referred to as ''the horrendous deficit,'' ''the unprecedented peacetime deficit,'' and ''the grim $200 billion overhang that threatens to abort the recovery.'' I am constantly portrayed as ominously ''looming.''

title: STARS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: The first United States Football League playoff game turned out to be one for the archives of sports. Its distinction came from what the Philadelphia Stars accomplished in the last nine and half minutes of the fourth quarter and in seven minutes of overtime.

title: Anne Fox Is Wed To Stewart Cutler
description: Anne Weldon Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Stephens Fox Jr. of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Stewart Lee Cutler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hinchman Cutler Jr. of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Homer L. Trickett performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church of America in Providence, R.I., assisted by the Rev. G. Scott Barnes of the Episcopal chaplaincy at Harvard College.

title: TOUGH AND LEAN QUALITIES BRING LONGHORN CATTLE BACK TO THE TEXAS RANGE
description: With the careless ease of a cowboy guiding his pony, 52-year-old Crawford Boyd, cattle breeder, nudged the nose of his chocolate brown Coupe de Ville around a big oak tree and into the middle of a bunch of cattle taking their ease from the hot south Texas sun. They did not take the intrusion well.

title: Freshman. Fireman. Diplomat?
description: In typical jet-age fashion, Secretary of State George Shultz has been dashing around the world touching bases that needed touching before his first year in office ends this week. It's not Mr. Shultz's fault that he's been doing freshman chores midway through President Reagan's junior year. But there's not much time left for this Administration to choose an area of diplomatic concentration.

title: FOUR VIEWS OF FRANCE
description: From the medieval streest of Dinan to the chateuay of Kerduel, the sights of France have fascinated travelers over the years. In his recent book, "Idylls of France," the photographer Proctor Jones has combined pictures of areas throughout the country with the literary insights of such writers as Henry James, Thomas Jefferson, Mark Twain, John Ruskin and Edith Wharton. JOHN RUSKIN Stones of Venice, 1853 Wherever Christian church architecture has been good and lovely, it has been merely the perfect development of the common dwelling-house architecture of the period; when the pointed arch was used in the street, it was used in the church; when the round arch was used in the street, it was used in the church; when the pinnacle was set over the garret window, it was set over the belfry tower; when the flat roof was used for the drawing-room, it was used for the nave. There is no sacredness in round arches, nor in pointed; none in pinnacles, nor in buttresses; none in pillars, nor in traceries. Churches were never built in any separate, mystical, and religious style; they were built in the manner that was common and familiar to everybody at the time.

title: Innovation Isn't Enough
description: Everything is on the side of the surpriser and yet he does not always succeed. The innovation could be both ingenious and correct, yet he is vulnerable to the countersurprise -- even one hastily concocted and spurred by fear.

title: PRECOLLEGE COURSES REBOUND IN CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: Mary Lynn Joseph entered Clara Barton High School for the Health Professions in Brooklyn four years ago with what she conceded was a ''terrible'' background in math. But instead of being shunted into a course called ''fundamentals of mathematics,'' where she might have spent an entire year sharpening her addition, Miss Joseph, an immigrant from Haiti, was allowed to take elementary algebra. Last month, she was graduated with advanced credit in calculus and honors in physics and chemistry. She will enter Brown University in the fall as a pre-med student.

title: Sandra White Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. White of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Shelton White, to Peter Louis Altieri, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Altieri of Weston, Conn.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Ads for Aspercreme Halted
description: Upholding a 1981 complaint against the Thompson Medical Company, Montgomery K. Hyun, an Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge said advertising claims that a product called Aspercreme relieved minor pain of arthritis and rheumatism were false and deceptive. He ordered the ads halted unless a disclaimer was carried.

title:
GARDENING;
TRIMMING BACK SUMMER GARDEN CHORES
description: ''SUMMERTIME and the livin' is easy,'' seems best in ''Porgy and Bess.'' At least it was along Catfish Row in Gershwin's folk opera. Can you sing the same song about your own summer weekends, or are you a slave to an endless list of garden chores? Do you always have a lot of hand-trimming and edging to do? Are your shrub and flower borders filled with weeds? Do weeds grow in the cracks in your sidewalks and take you hours to dig them out?

title: League Distressed Over Vote Issue
description: The League of Women Voters of Westchester is very distressed about the growing controversy surrounding post-election procedures at the Westchester Board of Elections. Patricia Treanor, deputy commissioner of the board, has resigned because of disagreements with the two commissioners regarding the effectiveness of and the conformity with State Election Law procedures followed by the board in conducting the preliminary and unofficial canvass.

title: A Clue, Maybe, In Connecticut Bridge Collapse
description: It has been a frustrating week for officials trying to find the cause of the collapse of Connecticut's Mianus River bridge and motorists trying to find their way around it. Divers recovered a piece of a seven-inch steel pin, one of four that held the fallen roadway in place and was suspected of playing a major role in the accident which left three dead and three critically injured.

title: CONSERVATION CORPS: THE GLORY LINGERS
description: MORE than a decade ago, I bought the house where I still live. I recall that my decision to buy was almost immediate because it was located on a hillside with a magnificent stand of trees.

title: For Art's Sake
description: The joy of collecting fine art may be exceeded only by that of giving it away, especially if you can get a fat tax deduction by donating it to your own museum. Edward R. Broida, who made a fortune in California real estate, was busy last week making just such an arrangement. He plans to spend $4 million to establish the Broida Museum for his highly regarded collection of modern works in New York City's arty SoHo district. Mr. Broida didn't say just how big a tax break he expects, but his hundreds of paintings include many a pricey piece.

title: NEW YORK'S SOUR-CHERRY CROP TO BE 10% LARGER THAN IN '82
description: On the eve of the sour-cherry harvest in New York State, Lee D. Brown stopped for a moment on his Cherry Ridge farm here overlooking the Hudson River and said, ''My crop is light this year.''

title: AT KATONAH, A GLIMPSE OF ARMAGEDDON
description: FOR those who know Robert Osborn primarily as a cartoonist, the current exhibition at the Katonah Gallery, through July 18, will come as something of a surprise. Although ''Osborn on Conflict'' may sound like a show about the squabbles of everyday life, it is in fact a grim depiction of the outbreak and consequences of thermonuclear war.

title: IN HARTFORD, A NEW TAX ON SALES
description: IN its perennial search for additional revenue, the Connecticut G eneral Assembly has enacted a new tax on real-estate transactions t hat will affect anyone who buys or sells a house in the state.

title: 2 SHELTERS FOR ABUSED TO OPEN
description: PLANS are under way for the opening of Suffolk County's first two homes for abused and battered women and children. The Long Island Women's Coalition will open Safe Harbor in Islip Town sometime this month. And Rainbow Retreat, which will be situated at the Suffolk County Airport, Westhampton Beach, is to open next month.

title: An Obedient Monster
description: EICHMANN INTERROGATED. Transcripts From the Archives of the Israeli Police. Edited by Jochen von Lang with Claus Sibyll. Introduction by Avner W. Less. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 293 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: Christine Stillger Weds Jonathan Mills
description: Christine Fran,coise-Louise Stillger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter M. Stillger of Muttontown, L.I., and Jonathan Scott Mills, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Mills of Los Alamos, N.M., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Msgr.

title: Home Design; A Sentimental Journey
description: When the house was purchased, it was fully, if uninspirationally, furnished. In addition, Mr. Lookstein and Miss Creveling each had inherited furniture in storage in New York.

title: BASTILLE DAY MEMORIES: A WEB OF CHANCE AND FRIENDSHIP
description: IN July, after a five months' trek through Europe, we blithely drove into the vast sea of cars that darted along the Champs-Elysees.Coming to Paris was a sentimental journey to celebrate our wedding anniversary on Bastille Day, the 14th of July.

title: Food; Smooth as Ice
description: We are inevitably asked how an ice differs from a sherbet. They are basically similar, but with sherbet one adds either beaten egg whites or a meringue to the basic fruit and sugar mixture. The word fruit is used loosely here, for on a recent occasion we happily sampled one of the most unusual and delectable ices we've ever encountered, this one made with dried rosemary and a simple syrup. It was the creation of Josef (Seppi) Renggli, the inspired chef of The Four Seasons restaurant in New York, who offered it at a special banquet. Dried rosemary was steeped in a hot syrup overnight. It was then strained, blended with a bit of white wine and lemon juice, and frozen. It was given a final garnish with sprigs of fresh rosemary that had also been sugared and frozen.

title: Lawyer Is Married to Barbara Reuter
description: Barbara Ann Reuter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Henry Reuter of Freehold, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to William J. Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Vero Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Gerald A. Levesque, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by the Rev. Evert M. Olson of the Church of Sweden in New York.

title: Old Hatreds Flare As P.L.O. Feud Defies Mediation
description: The will to kill remained strong last week in the Middle East. Would-be assassins in Beirut set off a car bomb that missed Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, on his way to work, by seconds.

title: GUIDE DOG AGENCY: A SUPERB SERVICE'
description: With great interest I read the article ''Rift Besets Guide Dog Agency.''

title: Richard III' Stalks Into Central Park
description: The day before the company of "Richard III" moved from a downtown hall to final rehearsals in Central Park, good triumphed repeatedly over evil. Wearing a crown, a hump and a scruffy beard intended to disguise the matinee idol dash, Kevin Kline lurched about the big room calling for a horse and died six times, gracefully and with considerable variety. All this took place under the eye of a brisk, sturdy, barefoot, exhausted-looking woman who consumed bottled water and cigarettes without pause and rallied the company on to new effort with cries of "Come on, my darlings" and "O.K., my lovers."

title: Arriving at Decisions
description: At every major tournament there is a group of experienced players making important decisions that they silently pray will prove irrelevant. This is the Appeals Committee, which gathers in the small hours, and sometimes at other times, to decide questions which have not been settled by the directors to the complete satisfaction of the players. The members of the committee always hope that their decisions will not decide a major championship. Fortunately they hardly ever do.

title: USING YOUR CHILDREN TO SHELTER INCOME
description: TALK of tax shelters often brings to mind convoluted oil and gas d eals created by high-priced lawyers for the super rich. But there a re very attractive ways for people of more moderate means to s helter income from taxes while putting aside money for their c hildren. Although these tax shelters are available for virtually anya mount of money without steep legal fees, ''not enough parents fully u nderstand the options available to them,'' says Jeffrey Ashendorf, d eputy general counsel to the Bowery Savings Bank.

title: About Men; Cars and Self-Image
description: Ford had a V-8 engine. You could put dual exhausts on it. You could top it off with a whole gaggle of carburetors. You could throw in a hot cam and have something that was truly the terror of the streets. Or you could take a Jimmy truck engine, stuff it into a Chevy sedan and make a mohair monster that ate Fords for lunch. It all depended.

title: SCHOOL TEACHES ROAD RACING
description: Skip Barber was one of the best road-racing drivers in the United States when he retired from competition in 1975. Since then, he has introduced thousands of men and women to the sport, first with a school to train racing drivers and more recently with a racing series that emphasizes skill rather than financial resources.

title: What About Male Nurses?
description: There is at least one important question that Dr. Manlapaz failed to address in his essay on hospital dress codes: Will male and female RNs wear caps of identical design? CHRISTINA J. TAYLOR Fairfield

title: Olympic Dispute Rises On Cost of Security
description: A payment dispute between the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee and Los Angeles County has resulted in the use of private security guards at pre-Olympic cycling competition this weekend.

title: Miss Smith Weds R.C.D. Fleming
description: Sarah Barbara Smith, a developer with the Colorado Rural Housing Development Corporation in Denver, was married there yesterday to Richard C.D. Fleming, president and chief executive officer of the Denver Partnership. The Rev. Gary Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the couple's home, with the Rev. Gary Wolfer, a Presbyterian minister, assisting.

title: Mixed Results
description: The astronauts may have had fun aboard the space shuttle Challenger, but for the ants it was no picnic.

title: RACLETTE
description: To the Editor: Paris-bound readers whose appetites were whetted by Paul Hofmann's piece on raclette can sample the dish without traveling to the Valais. Located just off the Champs Elysees, La Boutique a Sandwiches (12, rue du Colisee; closed Sundays and the month of August) serves -you guessed it - sandwiches in its streetlevel room and delicious raclette in its tiny upstairs restaurant. LINDA BRELER New York

title: PROTECTIONISM AND FREE TRADE-RHETORIC AND REALITIES
description: A textbook writer would be hard-pressed to find a clearer case of the problems and pressures of international trade circa 1983 than last week's White House decision to give American speciality steel producers four years of special protection.

title: Voices of Hoot Owl Holler
description: ORAL HISTORY. By Lee Smith. 286 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: 'HOME' FUNCTIONS AMID RIFT
description: SHE has a busy schedule. Five days a week she attends a day treatment center from 9 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Then she returns home to relax and attend to her share of household chores.
