This summer she plans to work in a Comprehensive Employment and Training Act program. In September this well-spoken woman, in her early 20's, hopes to enroll in nursing school.

title: Adapt Caps To New Styles
description: As a patient, I say ''Amen'' to Dr. Jesse S. Manlapaz's call for dress codes for hospital personnel. I would advocate two other practices for the professional staff attending patients: (1) wash hands between attending various patients; (2) avoid coughing or sneezing in the face of a patient while injecting needles or drawing blood.

title: OFFERING OF HUMOR
description: If you ever have had a problem figuring out the difference between a humorist and a comedian, you might like Jean Shepherd's thoughts on the subject:

title: Robbin's Paradoxical New Works
description: The talk of the ballet town this season has been, as expected, of the two premieres Jerome Robbins choreographed for the New York City Ballet. There is always interest, certainly curiosity, about any Robbins ballet. He remains one of the international dance world's chief creative voices.

title: Wounded Israeli Envoy Assails Lebanon War
description: Israel's former Ambassador to Britain, who was partly paralyzed and blinded in an assassination attempt by Palestinian terrorists three days before the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last year, has been quoted as condemning the war in an interview with an Israeli newspaper.

title: CHARLESTON'S FORT SUMTER
description: ANDREW L. YARROW is a researcher on the staff of The New York Times Magazine.

title: IN BETHEL, AN INTERNATIONAL MENU
description: MAYBE it is the influx of new corporations, such as Union Carbide and others. Whatever the reason, the Danbury area recently has had a flowering of new restaurants. The spillover even extends a few miles south to the town of Bethel.

title: OPERA COMPANY'S PLAN TO CUT COSTS LED TO DISPUTE
description: The strategy the New York City Opera was about to carry out to try to restore its economic well-being is at the heart of the strike called last week by its orchestra.

title: Playing for Keeps
description: Among the reasons Viktoriya Mullova, a Soviet violinist, gave for seeking political asylum at the American Embassy in Stockholm last week was one New Yorkers will certainly appreciate - the 23-year-old said she couldn't get her own apartment.

title: Elizabeth Ann Holland Wed to John S. Lewis
description: Elizabeth Ann Holland, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mellor R. Holland of Minnetonka, Minn., was married yesterday to John Stuart Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Lewis of Washington. The ceremony was performed at the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Washington, by the Rev. John J. O'Callaghan, assisted by the Rev. George Gerberding, a Lutheran minister.

title: ON THE ROPES, EVERLAST STRIVES TO SCORE A COMEBACK
description: PLAYING the part of a tough Philadelphia club fighter in ''Rocky'' a nd ''Rocky II,'' Sylvester Stallone battled his way from obscurity t o glory by defeating the world heavyweight champion. Perhaps not s urprisingly, along the way, Rocky used Everlast equipment - the ' 'choice of champions.''

title: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS: INTENT ABOUT THE BASICS
description: The education system in Japan, in its strengths and weaknesses, is virtually everything that its counterpart in the United States is not.

title: U.S. Cup Twelves Undergo Revisions
description: New masts, new sails, new hull and keel shapes. The search continues to find the perfect Twelve. Next Saturday, when the second round of United States trials to select the America's Cup defender is scheduled to begin, American sailors will learn whether they have come closer to the ideal.

title: A TALE OF TWO CITIES AND MILLIONS IN AID
description: HARTFORD and New Haven officials had a problem meeting a July 1 national deadline to qualify for $2.5 million under the Federal emergency job program.

title: 2 Brothers Sentenced In Abduction of Doctor
description: Two brothers have been sentenced to prison for their parts in the abduction of a gynecologist and his wife to protest the doctor's involvement in an abortion clinic.

title: Have Cultural Centers Benefited The Arts?
description: Before 1962 there were none. Then Lincoln Center in New York opened its doors. Today, according to an estimate by the National Endowment for the Arts, there are some 2,000 cultural centers in the United States, and more seem to be coming every month. Cultural centers are a way of life for many American cities. Many of them were put up at great expense, using top architects and acousticians. But now that they are a reality, what do they mean? Have the arts in America benefited? Or are cultural centers merely supermarkets for the arts?

title: NEW YORK HAS ITS OWN 'MIDWEST' AND THE WOES TO PROVE IT
description: After the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825, Buffalo, the small town at its western terminus, blossomed as the bridgehead to what was then the West. Later, as cities and industries flourished in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois and Michigan, Buffalo prospered, too, becoming not so much an eastern city as the eastern outpost of the great Middle West.

title: Kohl Sticks to His Guns - and Plans For New Missiles
description: Moscow sounded its usual warnings against German ''revanchism'' last week as Helmut Kohl arrived to defend plans to deploy new American missiles in Europe. But the West German Chancellor surprised the Kremlin by unashamedly asserting German national aspirations in terms rarely heard in Moscow but calculated to win support back home.

title: CITY CONSIDERS WELFARE CLIENTS' ILLEGAL INCOME
description: Officials of the city's Human Resources Administration are seeking permission from New York State to match computer welfare rolls with Criminal Court records.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Brazilian pop music is one of the world's best-kept musical secrets. The leading Brazilian pop singer/songwriters enjoy an artistic and expressive freedom comparable to the carte blanche given top rock groups in the United States.

title: DUTCH CYCLIST WINS
description: Bert Oosterbosch of the Netherlands won the eighth stage of the Tour de France today, covering the 131.4 miles from La Rochelle in 6 hours 16 minutes.

title: Mechanics Return
description: An Eastern Airlines Lockheed L-1011 with 172 people aboard lost power on all three engines and almost had to ditch in the ocean off Miami on May 5 because one mechanic failed to install six tiny rubber seals and another did not catch the mistake.

title: For a Change, French Dance Comes to America
description: In the last 20 years or so, American modern dance has become a more or less constant presence in French cultural life, not only through the frequent visits of companies led by Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Alwin Nikolais, Murray Louis and others, but through such collaborative events as the Paris Opera Ballet's all-American program this spring that included world premieres of dances by Alvin Ailey and Andrew deGroat.

title: Betsy West Wed to Pilot
description: Elizabeth Kearney West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps West of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Harwichport, Mass., was married in Harwichport yesterday to James Thornton Sneath, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Shepherd performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: LOWERING THE PERIL POINT OF NUCLEAR WAR IN EUROPE
description: GENERAL ROGERS, the former army chief of staff who became NATO's Supreme Commander in Europe in June, 1979, was interviewed recently at his headquarters in Casteau, Belgium, by John Vinocur, Paris bureau chief of The New York Times. Excerpts from the discussion follow.

title:
GARDENING;
TRIMMING BACK SUMMER GARDEN CHORES
description: ''SUMMERTIME and the livin' is easy,'' seems best in ''Porgy and Bess.'' At least it was along Catfish Row in Gershwin's folk opera. Can you sing the same song about your own summer weekends, or are you a slave to an endless list of garden chores? Do you always have a lot of hand-trimming and edging to do? Are your shrub and flower borders filled with weeds? Do weeds grow in the cracks in your sidewalks and take you hours to dig them out?

title: On Language; Under Covert
description: For example, when Allen Walker Read recently gave a paper on "The Criteria for a Class of Jocular Words in English" at Arizona State University, he made a valiant effort to find a covert class in the lexicon of funny words. Pixilated, a word first spotted in 1848 to mean "eccentric," now defined as "kooky," came from the English pixieled. The familiar dingbat, popularized on television's "All in the Family," was first spotted by Professor Read in an 1838 reference to an alcoholic beverage. Another deliberately humorous word was hugeacious, coined by the Canadian author Thomas Haliburton in 1843 and since replaced by humongous.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor: Lester C. Thurow's apologia for his specialty (''It's All Too Easy to Be a Critic,'' June 19), notes: ''Exaggerating the qualities of the product is more effective and thus more common among economists, as well as others, who seek to alter public decisions.'' I'll grant it is more common, but is it true that it is more effective? The great danger in exaggeration, of course, is that eventually the public will greet all pronouncements by economists with skepticism and disdain.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN W150 ants went into outer space with the Challenger, I wanted to get right on the phone to NASA and say, Hold the shuttle, stop the countdown - we've got extra passengers for you! And these are no tame little Camden, N.J., ants; these are more than 150 times 150 wild, mean and hungry Baldwin, L.I., termites.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ In the 1960's, jazz musicians looked toward Africa and rediscovered the vamp. A repeating bass riff, a chord or two and an insistent rhythm allow a soloist to play for as long as an inspiration lasts.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART As of Thursday next, we can see at the Museum of Modern Art an exhibition that documents one of the more remarkable episodes in the cultural history of New York.

title: CONSUMER RATES
RECENT SALES
description: Hillsborough $91,500 *2*102 Columbia Common 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*4-year-old town- house condominium; *2*eat-in kitchen, free-standing range, fireplace. *2* $85 monthly common charges; taxes $1,852. Jersey City $95,000 *2*115 Wayne Street 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old *2*brownstone; fireplace, original shutters; *2*taxes $1,530. Lake Hopatcong $110,000 *2*92 Ripplewood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, finished *2*basement with bar; taxes $2,122. Ramsey $112,900 *2*175 SnyderAvenue, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old *2*ranch; recreation room with bar, central *2*vacuum system; taxes $2,726. Union Township $65,000 *2*26 The Crescent 1-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*3-year-old town-house condominium; carpeting, *2*two decks, $115 common charges; taxes $1,200. Westfield $116,500 *2*627 Prospect Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*63-year-old colonial; new gas furnace, *2*den; taxes $2,439. OTHER AREAS Guilford, Conn. $87,000 *2*40 Preble Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1970 contemporary; *2*fieldstone fireplace, walk to village green, *2*0.8 acre; taxes $1,248. Ossining, N.Y. $93,000 *2*1 Collyer Drive, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*19-year-old Cape Cod; family room, *2*deck; taxes $3,384. Massapequa, L.I. $76,000 *2*43 Midlawn Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old *2*ranch; formal dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished *2*basement; taxes $2,294.

title: Music and Sports
description: Three organists - Nancy Faust of the Chicago White Sox, Vince Lascheld of the Pittsburgh Pirates and Fred Costello of the Rochester Redwings - will be panelists at a July 19 seminar on sports music at the University of Rochester's Eastman School of Music. The seminar will be conducted by Robert Freeman, the school director, who said the techniques of music at sporting events have developed in the final decade.

title: STATE COLLEGES FACE CHANGE IN ADMISSIONS
description: THE President's Commission on Excellence in Education has recommended that four-year colleges and universities raise their admission standards. Already 27 states are doing just that, and Connecticut will not be far behind.

title: Those 'Indispensable Presences Who Prefer to Be Called Pianists
description: It is said that in times past, a certain tenor -- doubting his high notes -- was known to stride onstage during a recital muttering to his accompanist, "Take it down a third, buddy boy."

title: SMITH ESTATE TO REGAIN ITS SPLENDOR
description: ''FIVE years ago,'' Thomas McMillen said, ''when a friend took me for a drive in Head of the Harbor, I spotted this house, and it became my favorite. It wasn't for sale at the time.'' Mr. McMillen recently purchased the almost-300-year-old home of Adam Smith, son of Richard (Bull) Smith, the founder of Smithtown.

title: 3 HOME RUNS BEAT SEAVER, 7-3
description: The Mets will have a state-of-the-union team meeting this afternoon before their game at Shea Stadium. And it should be brief, because their state for the last two weeks can be summed up in one word: Losing.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE North Hills Zoning Appeals Board, which has dealt over the last few years with many problems as condominium construction proliferated in that affluent North Shore village, is now addressing an unanticipated new situation. At their meeting Tuesday, board members will continue consideration of an application by Dr. Robert Swersky, a resident of the High Point town-house condominium development, for construction of a pool in his basement.

title: THE CHANGING CHESAPEAKE
description: Waggoner is one of an estimated 8,000 watermen on the Eastern Shore - eight counties in Maryland and two in Virginia, and the region most influenced by the Chesapeake's economic and oceanic tides - who work the bay for a living. He sometimes samples a bit of his own bait, french-fried. Waggoner's eel pots - slender, galvanized-wire traps made enticing with cracked claims - are scattered all along Cox Creek, not too far from the parallel bridges that soar up and over the Chesapeake and connect the heart of the Easter Shore with the rest of North America.

title: Darrell Hack Has Nuptials In Greenwich
description: Darrell Claire Hack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Oivind Lorentzen 3d, son of Mr. Lorentzen Jr. of Greenwich and the late Evelyn Byrd La Prade Lorentzen. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS'CHOICES
description: DANCE This week comes as a reminder that it is the last chance to catch the new productions and revivals of American Ballet Theater before the company closes its season next Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Among the season's novelties still on view is the new production of Jerome Robbins's ''N.Y. Export: Op.

title: Blaming the Other Side
description: THE SOVIET VIEWPOINT. By Georgi A. Arbatov and Willem Oltmans. Introduction by J. William Fulbright. 219 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $13.95.

title: DIVERSITY IS KEYNOTE AT MUSIC FAIR
description: ''WHERE'S Long Island?'' That was Lee Guber's response when he and Shelly Gross were advised to have a theater built here. The time was 1956, one year after the producing partners from Philadelphia scored a success with their first such venture, the Valley Forge Music Fair in Devon, Pa.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON SYMPHONY OPENS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Every summer, the Boston Symphony Orchestra moves west, a goodly amount of New York's music community moves north, and the two intersect at an enchanted spot known as Tanglewood.

title: Rally, Anyone?
description: To the Sports Editor: Serve and volley, serve and volley. The semifinal between McEnroe and Lendl at Wimbledon was a very dull affair.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
IN BRITAIN, GOLF'S EQUAL-OPPORTUNITY EVENT
description: PROMINENT among the tribal superstitions of American professional golfers is the notion that the Open championship, or British Open as they call it, is old-fashioned and unbearably pretentious. This notion is based in part on received wisdom that has been handed down through successive generations, such as Sam Snead's declaration that any time you go to Britain, you are camping out. Sam was a callow youth in those days, which roughly dates his remark in the era when we natives were just abandoning the practice of painting our bodies with woad. In part the legend derives from the fact that the Open, which is being played this week at Royal Birkdale in Southport, actually is old-fashioned and unbearably pretentious.

title: WRAPPING UP THE BELL CASE
description: Judge Harold H. Greene, right, set the final conditions for his approval of the break-up of Ma Bell. If A.T.& T. and the Justice Department accept the modifications, it will set the stage for A.T.& T. to proceed with the final steps of its spin-off of 22 operating companies. Among the prerequisites for his approval is that the name ''Bell'' be used only by the operating units and not by A.T.& T. The development caused a little dismay to the company, which has invested some $30 million in promoting its American Bell subsidiary. Yet a spokesman said he was ''jubilant'' about the ruling.

title: Margaret McMenamin, a Law Student, Becomes the Bride of Patrick P. Grace
description: Margaret Patricia McMenamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert McMenamin of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Patrick Peyton Grace, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Grace of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Patrick J. Peyton of Albany, a close friend of the Grace family, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church.

title: SOME TOP CONCERTS MANY OF THEM FREE
description: THE best things in life are free, the songwriter says, and so are some of the best summer concerts in Connecticut. We can go right through the week with chamber music, chorales, orchestral pops, even a contemporary composers' festival, all of which are yours for the listening.

title: Jonathan W. Kenyon Wed To Celia Hayden Mulligan
description: Celia Hayden Mulligan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Mulligan of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Ward Kenyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Kenyon of Summit, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward N. Maxwell at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday referred incorrectly to the recipient of a 1973 memo by Michael T. Harrigan, then a White House staff member. It was received by H.R. Haldeman, President Nixon's chief of staff.

title: Fermilab's New Accelerator Is A Smash Hit
description: In time for July 4th, the United States last week announced firing a shot heard round the world of high-energy physics. At Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., an atom smasher of revolutionary design pushed protons to nearly the speed of light. It was the opening salvo in America's effort to regain the lead in particle physics.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: STRATEGIES FOR GETTING TO NEW YORK AREA AIRPORTS
description: T here are so many ways to get to and from the major New York airports by public transportation that it is wise to examine the options carefully. Efficiency and comfort are not necessarily determined by how much you pay but can be influenced greatly by when you go, how far you go, the size of your party and the amount of your baggage.

title: Murderer of 2 Girls in Jersey Is Sentenced to 2 Life Terms
description: A 31-year-old Hopatcong, N.J., man has been sentenced to two life prison terms for sexually assaulting and strangling two second-grade girls in February 1982.

title: Steadfast Colonel
description: A year ago, Col. Eli Geva commanded an Israeli armored brigade poised on the edge of West Beirut. Faced with the possibility of being ordered to lead his brigade into the city, something he was opposed to as a matter of conscience because of the likelihood of civilian casualties, the career officer asked to be relieved of his command.

title: MEXICANS TIE CRIME SURGE TO ECONOMY
description: Shortly before midnight one evening last week, three men raided a restaurant in a quiet Mexico City neighborhood, searching the patrons for watches, wallets and jewelry. When one of the diners resisted and ran for the door to call the police, he was shot and killed.

title: DISMISSALS SOUGHT IN 13 ZONING SUITS
description: The Public Advocate's office has offered to drop lawsuits against 13 Morris County communities charged with practicing exclusionary zoning.

title: Historic Registry
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKETING PLAN CENTERS ON HARTFORD
description: WHEN Gerard M. Peterson takes office Aug. 1 as executive director of the Hartford Civic Center, he will start a campaign to persuade more performing artists to add Hartford to their national tour schedules.

title: HIGH SCHEMES WINS THE OAKS
description: There are four major races for 3-year-old fillies that lead to the Coaching Club American Oaks - the Kentucky Oaks, the Black-Eyed Susan, the Acorn and the Mother Goose. This year, all but one of the seven fillies who ran first or second in those four races were sidelined with injury by the time the gate opened yesterday at Belmont for the Oaks.

title: Michael Wolpert, 75, Is Dead; Labor Mediator for New York
description: Michael Wolpert, who retired in May as the senior mediator in the New York City office of the State Mediation Board, died of a heart ailment Thursday night at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 75 years old, and lived in Yonkers.

title: KENNEDY REMAINS A FAVORITE IN STATE
description: TRENTON THE national poll released last week that shows Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts to be the strongest potential Democratic candidate for President at the present time probably did not surprise too many people, since the active candidates in the field have not established themselves as prime contenders.

title:
NUMISMATICS; 
Poland Honors Pope John Paul II
description: One of the most remarkable coin sets of modern times has just been released by the National Bank of Poland: a set of five legal-tender Polish-government coins honoring Pope John Paul II. The coins were issued to commemorate the pontiff's recent visit to his Polish homeland. He himself received a set as a gift from government leaders during that trip.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics World University Games, at Edmonton, Alberta. Competition in track and field, gymnastics, men's 3-meter diving and basketball will be featured in live and taped highlights. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.).

title: PUPPETS DEPICT LIFE OF DISABLED
description: Renaldo Rodriguez is blind. But as he tells an attentive group of third graders at Public School 170 in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn: ''I still do lots of stuff. I get around real good with my cane, and I even play baseball with a special beeper ball.''

title: CITY FINANCIAL AIDE SELECTED AS A TOP ALVARADO ASSISTANT
description: Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado has rounded out his senior staff with the selection of a chief administrator for business and finance.

title: THIRD WORLD GETS IMPATIENT IN ITS LONG WAIT FOR RECOVERY
description: Western industrialized nations are hewing to a tough line on the third world's $600 billion debt crisis despite warnings of danger to global economic recovery and potential harm to relations between rich and poor countries.

title: GIVING MINORITIES A BOOST
description: ''IKNOW that it is expensive to be poor,'' said Roland H. Davis of Hempstead. ''And as chairman of a multimillion-dollar bank, I have some understanding of the power of the dollar.''

title: Dissident Jailed in Soviet
description: Galina Barats, wife of Vasily Barats, an imprisoned human-rights and religious activist, has been sentenced to six years in a labor camp for anti-Soviet agitation, dissident sources said today.

title: WHEN A SON STRAIGHTENS A FATHER'S PUBLIC IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE L.I. COMPANIES DOING BUSINESS THE JAPANESE WAY
description: TO an outsider, Yoshiaki (Bill) Date might appear to preside over the Panafax Corporation in a manner that is both unacceptably casual and implicitly threatening to his American counterparts.

title: Sex and the Practical Economy
description: Judy Goldsmith, the president of the National Organization for Women, called it ''a victory for women's rights.'' But a close reading of the Supreme Court's decision against segregating men and women in reckoning annuity payments shows it to be Solomonesque and limited in scope. The Court is divided about the underlying issue. And it remains up to Congress to decide the extent to which the insurance and pension industries may distinguish between the sexes in setting premiums and benefits.

title: Checks in 2 Large States Delayed in Budget Strife
description: By The Associated Press A second week without welfare, unemployment, disability or salary checks has begun in California and Pennsylvania as stalemates over state budgets dried up payments and prompted lawsuits.

title: Sunday Observer; Gnats And Ghumans
description: After that a lot of us would get rich lobbying for or against the bill, newspaper columnists would have controversial subject matter for dull days, and there would be a great deal of profitable ghuman activity. Try suggesting this to a gnat sometime if you want to see the height of stupidity. The gnat's idea of profitable activity is flying into somebody's nostrils.

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE MAGELLAN FUND
description: B Y all counts, Peter Lynch has one of the hottest hands in money management. He is portfolio manager of the Magellan Fund, a growthstock mutual fund, which is part of the Fidelity Management and Research Company in Boston. During the past five years, Mr. Lynch has piloted Magellan to a 582 percent return on investment, compared with 129 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500, putting the fund ahead of all other growth-stock funds for the period, according to the June 30 ranking of Lipper Analytical Services. And, in the past year, Magellan's 114 percent advance in share price was nearly double the S.& P.

title: Equalize Pension Pay, Court Rules
description: The Supreme Court was in its usual race to finish up last week. When the dust settled, the Justices had issued 10 decisions for a total of 43 in the final two-and-a-half weeks of its 1982-83 session - almost one-third of their full caseload. Several major decisions were held over to next term, which begins Oct.3, including a ruling on whether the use of home video recorders violates Federal copyright law. The deferred judgment surprised many, since the Court heard arguments in January; presumably, a majority had not coalesced.

title: THE CHOICE IS GETTING BROADER
description: IT IS hard to go through the mail or pick up a newspaper these days w ithout being enticed by offerings of generous second-mortgage loans f rom savings institutions, banks or independent mortgage companies.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS SAMPLING NATURE
description: It was almost 1 o'clock, and Dante Campbell was getting nervous. In a few minutes, he and 50 other boys would leave on an overnight camping trip, and Dante, who is 13 years old, had never done anything like that back home in Brooklyn.

title: BRIDGE'S FALL REOPENS CONNECTICUT TOLL ISSUE
description: The issue of removing the 35-cent tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike, which the General Assembly thought it had resolved last month, may be reopened as the state searches for money to repair its bridges.

title: Improving Our Schools
description: A "real" gesture at education reform must include a provision to give students the ability to apply classroom concepts by participating in simultaneous work experience. We should immediately begin to redefine a curriculum that addresses the specific knowledge and skills young people need to find meaning and function effectively in a rapidly changing world. Audrey C. Cohen President and Founder College for Human Services New York City

title: Polish Advisory Group Calls for an Amnesty
description: A citizen's advisory body set up by the authorities called today on the Government to lift martial law completely and grant amnesty to political prisoners.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editig error, an item in the Westchester Journal last Sunday about Cheryl M. Bradley's confirmation as a Family Court judge incorrectly identified the law school she attended. It was New York Law School.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: MASS MARKET

title: U.S. WOMEN REACH FINAL IN BASKETBALL
description: Carol Menken-Schaudt scored a basket with 13 seconds left to secure an 86-85 victory over Yugoslavia today that put the United States women's basketball team into the gold medal game of the 12th World University Games.

title: The Roots of Modern Capitalism
description: THE WHEELS OF COMMERCE. Civilization and Capitalism. 15th-18th Century. Volume Two. By Fernand Braudel. Translated by Sian Reynolds. Illustrated. 670 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $35.

title: Diminution of Service
description: Question: In 1975, my landlord dismissed one of the two porters in the rent-stabilized building in which I live, and ever since then it has been maintained poorly. The superintendent, now having more seniority, earns longer vacations, and there are occasions when emergencies occur and there is no one to call. What can we do to restore the porter? ... J.W., Forest Hills, Queens Answer: Ellis S. Franke, executive director of the Conciliation and Appeals Board, said that when the board gets complaints that the hours of service employees have been cut, it determines if the cutback was significant and whether it had any impact on service delivery. She suggested that you file a buildingwide service complaint so the board can investigate. While it may not not direct the rehiring of a porter discharged eight years ago, she added, it may order the owner to provide better maintenance and repair service. Write the C.A.B., 10 Columbus Circle, New York, N.Y. 10019, for a ''B'' form. When Landlord Bars Cable Question: For four years, tenants in my building have requested installation of cable television, but the owner is not cooperating. What can we do? ... R.A., Manhattan Answer: Something already has been done, by Manhattan Cable TV, holder of the cable franchise for your area of Manhattan. It has filed suit against your landlord to compel him to allow the building to be wired for cable.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT is the afternoon of a cloudless day, and Natalie Feigenbaum and Sandi Wertkin are hanging out at the Scarsdale pool. Now, that is probably not how Mrs. Feigenbaum and Mrs. Wertkin, stylishly slender in chic bathing suits and delicate gold necklaces, would describe their activities. But what they are doing here, where the chlorinated water reflects the blue of the sky, is not so different from what the teen-agers a few feet away are doing -sunning and swimming; meeting, greeting and watching people.

title: A BUFF OF THE BARD?  MUCH ADO AT DREW
description: MADISON DEVOTEES of English history and Shakespeare can get totally immersed in both subjects by attending performances of ''War of the Roses,'' a five-play production by the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival that is currently being offered at Drew University.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: World of Variety In One Village

title: A DIFFERENT TUNE
description: Donald V. Seibert, who will wind up a 36-year career with the J. C. Penney Company when he retires in September, sat last week in his office staring at a Telex video display terminal. The chairman was studying information on weekly store sales and the daily news summary. Occasionally, he deftly tapped out a message on the keyboard.

title: Marla Chizner Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Marla Chizner, daughter of Gloria Chizner of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Leo Chizner, to Cliff Zelenko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Zelenko of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A December wedding is planned. Miss Chizner's mother is Commissioner of Human Rights for Nassau County.

title: From Palm Forest to Ice Floe
description: AN AFRICAN IN GREENLAND. By Tete-Michel Kpomassie. Translated by James Kirkup. Preface by Jean Malaurie. Illustrated. 298 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: White House Policies On Women Protested
description: About 300 people unhappy with President Reagan's policies toward women demonstrated outside the White House today at a rally sponsored by the National Organization for Women.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Housing Plateau?

title: Man Kills Two While Shooting Into Crowd at Brooklyn Party
description: A man trying to crash a Brooklyn birthday party pulled a gun when he was refused admittance and shot into a crowd of 60 celebrators yesterday, killing two and injuring one, authorities said.

title: Miss Burr Completes A Sweep in Jumping
description: Leslie Burr completed a sweep of all intermediate jumpoff classes at the sixth annual I Love New York Horse Show by winning today's feature event at the Lake Placid Horse Show grounds.

title: LAYOFFS A CHALLENGE TO UNIONS
description: WHEN Western Electric, New Jersey's largest private employer, announced earlier this year that it would begin phasing out its Kearny plant, about 4,000 union workers faced a problem that has become all too common in New Jersey: finding work in shrinking industrial fields after a lifetime at one plant.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING STEPS FOR SHULTZ TO MEET GROMYKO
description: The Reagan Administration has recalled its chief negotiator at the East-West conference in Madrid to discuss a compromise that might lead to an early meeting of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, State Department officials said today.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Four years ago, TWA Flight 841, a Boeing 727 flying from New York to Minneapolis with 89 persons on board, fell six-and-a-half miles, 33,000 feet, in 44 seconds - sprialling earthward, uncontrolled for more than five miles. Miraculously, the pilots and the flight engineer landed the aircraft safely.

title: EX-REAGAN AIDE SAYS HE KNEW OF CARTER MATERIAL
description: Richard V. Allen, a high-level campaign aide to Ronald Reagan in 1980, said today that he had been aware the campaign had President Carter's debate briefing book and had thought it was ethically wrong. He did not, however, recall urging that it be returned.

title: Builders 'Club' May Go Broke
description: Investigators are building yet another corruption case against the New York-area construction industry. The target this time, according to a report in The New York Times last week, is a band of contractors who call themselves ''the Club'' and are believed to have swindled employees, their union and Uncle Sam.

title: AT MEDICAL COLLEGE, VIEW IS OPTIMISTIC
description: VALHALLA DR. SAMUEL H. RUBIN has seen New York Medical College through many ups and downs since joining the faculty in 1949. Last week, retiring as both provost and dean of the school, he saw it more ''up'' than ever. ''The school is in an excellent position,'' he said, ''with the potential of being one of the medical schools in the country.''

title:
DINING OUT;
THAT HOTEL WITH A WISHING WELL
description: WITH the return to Broadway of Rodgers' and Hart's ''On Your Toes,'' the time seemed right for a visit to Colligan's Stockton Inn, the inspiration for ''There's a Small Hotel,'' one of the show's hit tunes.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest:

title: Boy, 8, Missing a Week, Found on Mountain Peak
description: Michael Reel, an 8-year-old missing for a week on 6,285-foot Roan Mountain, was found unharmed today.

title: TRIATHLON TRIAL
description: One of the questionable rewards of winning a U.S. Triathlon such as the one to be held at Lake Mahopac in Putnam County at 7 A.M. Saturday, is the opportunity to repeat the ordeal Sept. 17 in Yosemite, Calif., where the national championships are to be held.

title: SMOKED SALMON-NOVA SCOTIA'S PRIDE
description: LINDA JEFFRIES is a writer who lives in Cambridge, Mass.

title: FOR THE HOMOSEXUAL MAN OR WOMAN, LIFE CAN OFTEN BE LONELY
description: ALICE, a 44-year-old divorced lesbian with three children, has been living with one foot in her quiet neighborhood in a suburb of Plainfield and one in the bars and organizations that make up what homosexual subculture exists in New Jersey.

title: War Within War in Lebanon
description: GOING ALL THE WAY. Christian Warlords, Israeli Adventurers, and the War in Lebanon. By Jonathan C. Randal. 304 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.75.

title: Seeing the Light
description: It is a measure of how things are going in Washington that a man can win admiration simply by acting ethically without being forced to.

title: Susan M. Giusti Bride Of Dr. David G. Bristol
description: Susan Marie Giusti, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gino P. Giusti of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. David Goodwin Bristol, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bristol of Greeley, Colo.

title: LOOKING AT THE BRAIN AS NEVER BEFORE
description: ALFRED P. WOLF, chairman of the chemistry department at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, says that ''just exploring nature doesn't seem to be fashionable anymore.'' Basic research, he says, is old hat to some.

title: FOUR-TOED SALAMANDER; Hemidactylium scutatum
description: Size: Two to four inches. Color: Upper surface reddish brown, fading to dull gray on the sides.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is one thing President Reagan can do to help women and clean up his name with us. And that's what I ask him to do today. Mr. President, one term is enough.'' - Kathy Wilson, chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus. (18:1.)

title:
GARDENING;
TRIMMING BACK SUMMER GARDEN CHORES
description: ''SUMMERTIME and the livin' is easy,'' seems best in ''Porgy and Bess.'' At least it was along Catfish Row in Gershwin's folk opera. Can you sing the same song about your own summer weekends, or are you a slave to an endless list of garden chores? Do you always have a lot of hand-trimming and edging to do? Are your shrub and flower borders filled with weeds? Do weeds grow in the cracks in your sidewalks and take you hours to dig them out?

title: FM Stereo Gets a Boost
description: With the digital phonograph drawing the limelight, other valuable attainments of recent audio design are being unfairly upstaged. Those laser disks have us all agog by the sheer force of their conceptual novelty; yet in other areas the incremental refinement of traditional methods may be quite as beneficial if it solves specific problems.

title: 3 Opposition Leaders Arrested in Chile
description: A magistrate arrested three opposition leaders today for alleged involvement in plans for a mass protest against the 10-year-old military regime.

title: 42 Hurt in Kansas City As Truck Hits Tour Bus
description: Forty-two people were injured, 17 of them seriously, when a cement truck struck a tour bus here tonight, the authorities said.

title: One More Year
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has denied the University of Kentucky's informal request to add a year of eligibility for Sam Bowie, its 7-foot center, sidelined the last two seasons with a stress fracture in his left shinbone. Joe B. Hall, the Wildcat coach, said he still plans to file some kind of formal request even though he ''doubted seriously'' that Bowie would use an additional year even if it were granted.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A CLEAN HOUSE MEANT WORK
description: IT took a lot of sand, grit and elbow grease as well as soap to keep a colonial house clean. Although soap makers were among the first tradesmen to work in colonial cities, many rural householders made their own cleansers from saved-up waste fats and lye obtained by leaching wood ashes.

title: Hollywood Boulevard and Times Square
description: BODIES AND SOULS. By John Rechy. 421 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $14.95.

title: HANDICAP SERVICE ATTRACTING GOLFERS
description: WHITE PLAINS A NEW program designed to provide handicaps for all of Westchester's public links players is now being offered by the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: When Expressionism Invaded Realism
description: Mining its extensive lode of German Expressionist material, the Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, has mustered an exhibition with the labored title "Early and Late: Drawings, Paintings and Prints -- From Academicism to Expressionism." The idea is to show how the dramatic distortions of Expressionism began to invade, after the turn of the century, the work of Austrian and German artists nurtured on the tradition of academic realism, among them Gustave Klimt, Lovis Corinth, Alfred Kubin, Egon Schiele, and Kaethe Kollwitz. The material here -- mainly prints and drawings -- is somewhat wispy for such an ambitious theme, involving as it does a recycling of works familiar from other St. Etienne exhibitions.

title: Journals And Notebooks
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
WHERE SOME DEALERS LIKE TO DEAL
description: PEMBERTON WHERE do antiques dealers buy? Many collectors have posed that question, not only to themselves but also to the dealers. The responses have varied from ''I have relatives in a rural town in Maine (or upstate New York or western Pennsylvania) and they tell me when important estate sales are coming up'' to ''I take a yearly trip to England (or the Continent, or the Orient) to purchase important pieces.''

title: BRAHMSIAN EVENING
description: Aimez-vous Brahms? If so, the program at the Unitarian Church in Westport this evening will be of special interest. It incorporates the playing of recorded conversations and performances of people who knew, played or studied with Johannes Brahms into a lecture by Laurence C. Witten, a graduate of the Yale School of Music.

title: Midsummer Stirrings at The Museum of Modern Art
description: Not to have the Museum of Modern Art in full operation is bad for the New Yorker, bad for the visitor from out of town and bad for the museum. We need the Modern Museum. We need it on esthetic grounds, in that despite worldwide competition it is still the greatest single repository of the art of our century. We need it on intellectual grounds, because from the very day of its inception it was the servant of scholarship, as much as the servant of delight. And we need it on moral grounds, because a great museum is a school of discrmination. Without the Museum of Modern Art in full operation our city is a thinner, weaker, shoddier place.

title: Life and Death of a Terrorist
description: THE QUEST FOR THE RED PRINCE. By Michael Bar-Zohar and Eitan Haber. Illustrated. 233 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95.

title: REPORT ON SALEM I FAULTS MANAGEMENT
description: NEWARK AN INDEPENDENT consultant has found numerous deficiencies in the management and operation of the Salem I nuclear-power plant, but none ''of sufficient significance to require immediate corrective action.''

title: COMMUNITY CREDIT UNION OFFERS FINANCIAL SERVICES TO THE POOR
description: On Tuesday evenings and Saturday mornings, the Bliss Street Federal Credit Union takes in deposits, pays out withdrawals and issues loans to a constant bustle of customers.

title:
GARDENING;
TRIMMING BACK SUMMER GARDEN CHORES
description: ''SUMMERTIME and the livin' is easy,'' seems best in ''Porgy and Bess.'' At least it was along Catfish Row in Gershwin's folk opera. Can you sing the same song about your own summer weekends, or are you a slave to an endless list of garden chores? Do you always have a lot of hand-trimming and edging to do? Are your shrub and flower borders filled with weeds? Do weeds grow in the cracks in your sidewalks and take you hours to dig them out?

title: SECOND BROOKLYN YOUTH ON TRIAL IN KILLING OF BLACK
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth went on trial last week on a seconddegree murder charge in the second case stemming from the beating death of a black transit worker by whites on a street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn a year ago.

title: Where $1.50 Buys It All
description: To the Sports Editor: The man pays top dollar to put the best team possible on the field. You come on the 4th of July and you get a free Yankee hat, the kids get a free baseball shirt and your bleacher stub entitles you to participate in several lotteries. All this for probably the cheapest seat in baseball at $1.50 and you get a no-hitter in the bargain. As one who had been unemployed for a long time, I can only say, ''Bravo George Steinbrenner!'' EDWARD F. FLYNN New York

title: Improving Our Schools
description: Second, the academic departments will not pay attention to such vital institutional concerns as classroom management, curricular design, evaluation of student learning, the impact of multicultural variables in organized classrooms, handicapping conditions, learning how to work in differentiated professional teams and the like. Hendrik D. Gideonse Dean College of Education University of Cincinnati
To the Editor:

title: The Poems of an Aristocratic Marxist
description: COLLECTED POEMS OF JOHN WHEELWRIGHT. Edited by Alvin H. Rosenfeld. Introduction by Austin Warren. 278 pp. New York: New Directions. Paper, $10.

title: Susan S. Little, Editor, Weds James Varn in Maine
description: At the First Congregational Church in Kittery Point, Me., Susan Smith Little, daughter of Ann Burnham Smith of New Canaan, Conn., and Harry L. Smith of New York, was married yesterday to James Samuel Varn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Varn of Westfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carolyn Hofacker.

title: KEAN GETS PROPOSALS TO FOSTER JERSEY INDUSTRY
description: A Commission on Science and Technology appointed by Governor Kean a year ago has made a number of proposals that it says would make New Jersey more attractive to industry.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE FORECAST
description: President Reagan says the economy has begun to sparkle. Some prominent forecasters say business is enjoying a ''miniboom.'' And one top Wall Street research house says the economy is ''set to sizzle.'' It is, in short, one of those rare times when the Administration, economic seers and Wall Street analysts agree on the economic outlook: 1983's second half will see a strong, widespread recovery.

title: BUdget Warriors Back in Trenches
description: Senator Robert Dole must have struck a certain note of hollow recognition in the hearts of Congressmen on home leave last week. ''So far,'' the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee said, ''every budget plan has failed. The net result is that the American people are the real losers, or will be unless we act quickly.''

title: STATE AGENCY CONSIDERS ENERGY CONSERVATION PLAN
description: The State Public Service Commission will hold a hearing this week on whether utility companies should be required to encourage energy conservation by offering their customers incentives to buy energysaving devices.

title: Randi Lupton Is Married
description: Randi Leigh Lupton, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barry Lupton of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lawrence Mitchell Pines, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Pines of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Paul F. Bubna of the Christian and Missionary Alliance Church performed the ceremony at the Long Hill Chapel in Chatham, N.J.

title: OSGOOD V. TRACY
description: Osgood V. Tracy, a former executive vice president of W.R. Grace & Company and a former president of the Esso Standard Oil Company, died of a stroke last Sunday at a nursing home in Mendham, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Morristown, N.J.

title: FORCEFUL TERM OF SUPREME COURT PUT REINS ON CONGRESS AND REAGAN
description: Both Congress and the executive branch must adjust to life within new limits as a result of the Supreme Court term that concluded this week.

title: California Lawyer Is Elected President of Hispanic Group
description: A 28-year member of the League of United Latin American Citizens has been elected to a one-year term as president of the organization.

title: TICKS BEGINNING TO THRIVE AS THE SUMMER HEATS UP
description: TWO factors, a mild winter and cyclical increases in population, portend a significant increase in the number of potential diseasecarrying ticks on Long Island, according to Dr. Jorge Benach, an assistant professor of pathology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and a leading researcher in the field.

title: TESTAMENT OF DISTRESS
description: KING SOLOMON. By Romain Gary. Translated by Barbara Wright. 255 pp. New york: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: TAXES, YES, BUT HOW MUCH
description: IF the experience of the last several decades is any criterion, we should change the old expression ''nothing in life is certain but death and taxes'' to ''death, taxes and annual increases in municipal budgets.''

title: Hello in There
description: When motorists get stuck in the the Lincoln or Holland Tunnels, they can't pass the time listening to their favorite radio stations, nor can they find out the cause of the delay or how long it will last.

title: The Comintern
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila Mahony Becomes Bride of Charles Riggs
description: Sheila Mahony, daughter of Mrs. Paul A. Mahony of New York and the late Mr. Mahony, was married yesterday to Charles A. Riggs. The Rev. Brian Joyce performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the bride's home in New York.

title: LEST WE YEARN FOR THE VICTORIAN FAMILY
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Figures Who Aid Charities
description: The article about sports figures on June 12 (''Sports Figures Aid Charities'') omits players and coaches who also have played a large part in helping Long Island charities.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nancy Lopez, who is five-and-a-half months pregnant, will not compete in the remainder of this year's Ladies Professional Golf Association tournaments. She was forced to withdraw from the Peter Jackson Classic in Canada last week, complaining of severe stomach pains.

title: AN INMATE'S MURAL ENHANCES LIFE IN JAIL
description: NEW HAVEN IN one corner of the mural a country scene shows some people playing tennis. They are surrounded by green forests beneath a clear blue sky, and boats float in the water nearby.

title: TWO KINDS OF DIVESTITURE FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCILLE LORTEL TO BE FETED TONIGHT
description: A ''SURPRISE PARTY'' is in store for Lucille Lortel tonight, but she's expecting it. The occasion is the 35th anniversary of the producer's venerable White Barn Theater in Westport, the showcase for new works that Miss Lortel had built as a stable, rather than a staple of summer theater.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Learning to Love to Read

title: YANKEES LOSE, 3-2, ON ERROR IN 12TH
description: Since Johnny Vander Meer pitched no-hitters in two successive starts in 1938, 99 pitchers had tried to duplicate his feat after pitching no-hitters of their own but had failed. Dave Righetti became No.100 tonight.

title: A NEW THEATER, AND THEREIN LIES A TALE
description: PORT CHESTER IT could provide the plot for a play in progress. The head of a troupe of strolling players, tired of transiency, is seeking a theater to call home. The owner of a contracting corporation, a specialist in buying and repairing what many consider to be derelict buildings, has acquired his first theater.

title: Special Insignia For Doctors
description: It is my opinion that the trappings will never bring about the ideal hospital setting which Dr. Jesse Manlapaz is seeking.

title: FROM LIGHT OPERA TO PUPPETS IN PARK
description: ''ASCENE of grassy meadows and pleasant paths, sparkling fountains and statuary overlooking reflecting pools.'' That's part of the official description of Untermyer Park on North Broadway in Yonkers, and should that Versailles-like ambience be an insufficient attraction, consider also that the park houses the Untermyer Performing Arts Festival, remarkable for its wide gamut of attractions and for the fact that they are all free.

title: The Emigre Influence
description: EXILED IN PARADISE. German Refugee Artists and Intellectuals in America, From the 1930's to the Present. By Anthony Heilbut. 506 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $20.

title: JUdge Approves St. Louis Busing
description: Students enrolled in St. Louis's predominantly black public schools this fall may get ready access to classrooms in the city's mostly white suburbs. Last week, Federal District Judge William L. Hungate approved a voluntary plan - first presented to him in March - that would end more than a decade of litigation.

title: NO PROGRESS MADE IN SETTLING CITY OPERA ORCHESTRA STRIKE
description: Members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians continued to picket yesterday at the New York State Theater, with no progress reported in settling the labor dispute between the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra.

title: CAMERA VISIONS OF THE HAMPTONS
description: WHILE necessity is often the mother of invention when it comes to fashioning a better mousetrap, it rarely works that way in the creative arts. That is, unless you are Genie Chipps and Ken Robbins, a writer-businesswoman and photographer, respectively, who recently joined forces to produce and publish a book, ''The Hamptons, America's East End,'' and, in the process, establish what they hope will be a permanent regional press.

title: WATERFRONT DINING: A CRITICS' CHOICES
description: WHEELING gulls; pilot boats, yachts, barges, sailboats, tankers and speedboats; glittery river and bridge lights: food eaten by the water always seems to taste better. Westchester County may lack the throbbing shores of Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey, but just as stirring to soul and appetite are the tranquil waters of the Hudson River, the Long Island Sound and a number of silvery lakes. During these long days of summer, when the sun takes its time moving over the horizon, diners can linger over drinks or dinner on breezy decks or in glass-walled dining rooms witnessing the whole technicolor, kaleidoscopic collaboration of water and sky.

title: CHICAGO COUNCIL RIFT STALLING ACTION
description: While Mayor Harold Washington and the City Council fight for control of the city government, Chicago's troubles with the budget, the schools and the unions have intensified.

title: COURT HAS HIGH AIM, BAD PLAN ON BIAS
description: The Supreme Court has again provided us with some spine-tingling rhetorical flourishes designed to convey a national commitment to racial equality in general and to integrated schools in particular. Unfortunately, as in the past, the Court has coupled its statements with actions that undermine the achievement of equal opportunity in education.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ROBARDS IN 'HUGHIE'

title: WATSON SEES BEAUTY IN LINKS
description: The piper. The memory that Tom and Linda Watson cherish the most is of the bagpiper who walked beneath their hotel window in the Scottish gloaming, serenading Watson after his victory in the 1977 British Open at Turnberry.

title: SALVADOR REBELS REFUSE TO SEE HIM
description: The United States special envoy to Central America, unable to meet with Salvadoran rebels, today cut short his trip to the area and returned to Washington without explanation.

title: People
description: * Barbara Feigin, director of marketing and research, named an executive vice president and member of the agency policy council at Grey Advertising.

title: WHITECAPS HALT COSMOS
description: David Cross scored the game's only goals tonight to lead Vancouver to a 2-0 triumph over the Cosmos and keep the Whitecaps on top in the North American Soccer League.

title: JAPANESE RECONSIDER A PLAN TO BUILD BUSES IN NEW YORK
description: A proposal to build buses in New York State, moribund only six months ago, has recently been resuscitated through new legislation, renewed interest by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and state efforts to smooth damaged relations with a Japanese company.

title: 5 COWBOYS FACE CHARGE, PAPER SAYS
description: Federal authorities first agreed not to prosecute five Dallas Cowboys on charges of possessing cocaine if they underwent drug rehabilitation, but they changed their minds and are now thinking of filing charges, according to a report published today.

title: Fitzgerald Takes Final
description: John Fitzgerald of Australia recovered from a sloppy first set today and defeated unseeded Scott Davis, 2-6, 6-1, 6-3, in the final of the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame grass tournament.

title: Nonunion Workers To Get 7% Raises
description: New York City's middle-level managers and other employees not covered by collective bargaining agreements will receive 7 percent raises this year, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: NO NEED TO BE GOOD
description: .6,0,165.6,2,533.6,0The nuclear freeze debate has been of great value in reviving intense public interest in the atomic arms race. But it has gone about as far as it can go.

title: Nicaraguan Says U.S.  Ships Honduras Arms
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge Martinez has charged that the United States is shipping the Honduran Army weapons and equipment to wage war on Nicaragua.

title: Saudi Minister Meets Assad In P.L.O. Mediation Attempt
description: A Saudi Government minister met President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today in what was seen here as a new attempt to mediate the dispute within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: FROM 'NICE LITTLE NANCY' TO 'EFFECTIVE'
description: In the 1982 election campaign, the weekly luncheon meeting of Republican Senators was debating the causes of the preference, reported in polls, of female voters for Democrats over Republicans. Dozens of judgments and justifications bounced off the walls like squash balls, propelled by opinionated male lawmakers, while the only female Senator in the room remained silent.

title: IN OKLAHOMA, A BANKER IS READY FOR EXPANSION
description: In anticipation of a change in Oklahoma law that will allow limited bank expansion, Dale Mitchell, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company in Oklahoma City, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Fidelity of Oklahoma Inc., a one-bank holding company.

title: 3 GO ON TRIAL TODAY IN GOSHEN IN '81 BRINK'S SLAYINGS
description: The state trial of three suspects in the 1981 Brink's triple murder and $1.6 million robbery in Rockland County will begin Monday in this quiet village 60 miles northwest of Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: Morris Hatalsky charged from four strokes back and tied the leader today, then parred his second extra hole in a sudden-death playoff with George Cadle and won the $250,000 Milwaukee Open golf tournament.

title: Plays by Black Women
description: A series of four new plays by black women playwrights will begin July 20 at the New Federal Theater, Grand and Pitt Streets.

title: 3 French Die on Matterhorn
description: Three French mountaineers were killed when they fell 1,000 feet from the east face of the Matterhorn yesterday, the police said today. Rescuers recovered the bodies and took them to Zermatt. Earlier yesterday, Five French climbers were killed on Mont Blanc when part of a glacier broke loose.

title: ARKANSAS RECALLS A NEW YORKER IN LITTLE ROCK
description: Winthrop Rockefeller migrated to Arkansas 30 years ago, and soon afterward a correspondent advised him, ''Take your carpetbags and your bank accounts and go back to New York.''

title: HOUSE PANEL SEEKS CARTER DOCUMENTS IN REAGAN ARCHIVES
description: A Congressional committee staked out its claim today to take the lead over the White House and the Justice Department in the investigation of how the Reagan Presidential campaign obtained Carter White House documents.

title: Nina Pat Freedman Is Married on L.I.
description: Nina Pat Freedman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alan Freedman of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Lee Rosenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rosenbaum of Colonia, N.J., and North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Freedman home in East Hampton.

title: DEMS' LATIN DILEMMA
description: With the economy rebounding, the Reagan Administration's increasingly unpopular Central American policy is a logical target for the Democrats. And in the last several weeks, several Democratic presidential candidates have warned that the Administration's current course will inevitably lead to the intervention of United States troops. But the Democrats have so far failed to come up with an alternative policy for the region.

title: SIX-DAY RACE ENDS IN FLOW OF EMOTION
description: The runners cried after the finish of the New York Six-Day Run yesterday. So shared was their suffering on the Downing Stadium track at Randalls Island that they grabbed, hugged and kissed one another in an outpouring of emotion. ''It would hurt to keep running,'' said Stu Mittleman, ''but it's going to hurt to leave.''

title: Old-Timer's View
description: In their heyday, Fred Stolle, Alex Olmedo and Frank Sedgman were among the best tennis players in the world. Stolle won the 1966 United States title, Olmedo was considered the best player to come out of South America after he won Wimbledon and the Australian title in 1959, and Sedgman captured the 1952 United States championship at Forest Hills without losing a set.

title: Soviet Reports New Envoys Named to Warsaw and Sofia
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it was naming new ambassadors to Poland and Bulgaria.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: EVEN WHETHER SESSION IS OVER IS DISPUTED IN ALBANY
description: Unlike most sessions of the Legislature, which end rather suddenly, this 206th session is slowly fading away. A week and a half ago, with a tumultuous end-of-session rush, both houses left town, almost as if their work was done. But on Tuesday the Senate returns for a short session to pass measures - including a $1.25 billion bond issue - that were passed in the Assembly earlier.

title: RISE IN RATES HURTS DEVELOPING NATIONS
description: After an eight-month respite, one of the main culprits in the international debt crisis - interest rates - are on the rise again. Since late May, the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, which determines the size of interest payments on at least two-thirds of the $600 billion debt owed by developing countries to foreign creditors, has risen about a percentage point, to the 10.3 percent level. Morgan Guaranty put the rate as high as 10.5 percent on Friday.

title: CONGRESS BACK TO FACE BUDGET ISSUES
description: When Congress returns to work on Monday after a weeklong recess in observance of the the Fourth of July holiday, it will confront the tax and spending legislation needed to carry out the Federal budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GODPLAYER. By Robin Cook. 368 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS.Lee Kanner QUESTION: With a man on first, the batter drives the ball into the right-field stands for a home run. The runner, in rounding third, stumbles and twists his ankle and cannot continue to home plate. What happens? Also, in another version, suppose the batter, in racing round the bases, inadvertently passes his teammate, who is not hurt but has hesitated because he is not sure the ball is dropping into the stands. Can the batter return to the previous base?

title: Panthers Down Invaders and Gain Final
description: Bobby Hebert passed for one touchdown and ran for another today to lead the Michigan Panthers to a 37-21 victory over the Oakland Invaders in a United States Football League division playoff game.

title: CRIMINAL COURT: TASKS UNDERTAKEN, TASKS AHEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: BALDWIN'S CHIEF SHUNS BANKRUPTCY
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, now technically bankrupt as the result of the $617 million first-quarter loss it reported last week, will resist filing for protection from its creditors to avoid the legal wrangling that would be likely to result, the company's president and chief executive, Victor H. Palmieri, said over the weekend.

title: POP: PARTY MUSIC WITH A MESSAGE FROM FUN BOY 3
description: LIKE the Specials, the English rock group that it fronted until 1981, the group called Fun Boy Three uses pop eclecticism not just for its own sake but also to express an interracial musical solidarity.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Grange Reopens

title: TV:'READING RAINBOW,' NEW SERIES
description: WITH underwriting from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and a cereal manufacturer, ''Reading Rainbow'' makes its debut today with the avowed purpose of introducing young viewers to books so as to offset ''summer loss phenomenon,'' which can result in some slippage in the reading skills of children. The program can be seen Mondays through Fridays for the next three weeks. On Channel 13, it will be shown daily at 10:30 A.M. and 6 P.M.

title: STOCKPILE TO JUNKPILE
description: Last fall, approximately 25 percent of the American voters were given an opportunity to consider a proposal for a balanced and verifiable freeze on the development, testing, and deployment of nuclear weapons and their delivery systems. A majority of those who voted were for it. More recently members of the House of Representatives endorsed a similar proposition by nearly two to one. On July 13, a freeze resolution is scheduled to come to a vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Yet it is still not being considered seriously by the Administration or the Congress.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 11, 1983
description: International Dismissal of Hebron's Arab mayor was endorsed by the Israeli Cabinet. Cabinet officials said the Government would go ahead with a decision to restore the old Jewish quarter in Hebron, a city on the West Bank. The acting Mayor of Hebron, Mustafa Natshe, was dismissed last week by the commander of the Israeli forces in the area after an Israeli student was stabbed to death by a group of Arabs. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Francois Mitterrand is said to have acknowledged mistakes in economic policy since he took office in 1981. According to an article by a French radio reporter, Mr. Mitterrand said the mistakes included a failture to devalue the franc when he first took office and a slowness to undertake an austerity program. He is also said to have found fault with his Socialist Government for underestimating the gravity of the world economic crisis and with himself for expecting too much assistance from President Reagan. (A1:4.)

title: A CITYWIDE FUND TO AID HOUSING IS BEING STUDIED
description: The Koch administration is considering proposals that would require developers of office buildings and luxury apartments in Manhattan to contribute to a fund for housing in lower-income neighborhoods throughout the city.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Out of Exile'

title: Racing Association And McCann Parting
description: The New York Racing Association and McCann-Erickson have separated after about 12 years together. Edward P. Sigenfeld, vice presidentmarketing of the association, said the move was mutually agreed upon.

title: Pope Says All Possible Steps Are Being Taken to Free Girl
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he was doing ''all that is humanly possible'' to help free a 15-year-old girl apparently being held as a hostage for the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who shot the Pope.

title: Golf's Jet Set
description: Bobby Clampett is a young and talented professional golfer and he has a knack for attracting attention. He once scandalized officials at the United States Open by driving twice from his knees. Last year, in the British Open, he wore plus-four knickers while leading for the first two rounds of the championship. Clampett will again appear in the British Open, which begins Thursday, and again he is planning something special - this time for the day after the championship.

title: News Analysis
description: Murky issues on the fringes of the law are raised by the investigation into whether any crimes were committed when President Reagan's aides accepted and used confidential materials from the

title: Melanie Smith Takes Jumpoff
description: Melanie Smith, show jumping's 1982 World Cup champion, topped a record field to win the $35,000 Mercedes ''I Love New York'' Grand Prix today.

title: SOCIETY'S STAKE IN SOME HOUSES OF WORSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PRICE OF A DENT IN THE CRIME RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: ENCOURAGING CRAFTS WHILE BUILDING NEW BUSINESS
description: They both worked on Wall Street, she as a stockbroker, he as a lawyer. Like many young couples they had talked for years about leaving the din of the city to pursue a personal and professional dream. Unlike many young couples they made the move, going 130 miles up the Hudson River in May 1982 to 160 acres of hilly terrain in Columbia County and a home and a business named Chatham Fields.

title: CASSETTES ARE CHANGING MOVIE-AUDIENCE HABITS
description: It's 3 o'clock on a summer afternoon in this town 200 miles northeast of Los Angeles, and Margaret Johnson is renting her movie for the night. Only 10,000 people live in this Central Valley town, where the local industry is growing peaches, grapes, cotton and alfalfa. But there are four retail stores that sell and rent videocassettes of movies. All four are thriving.

title: PARISHIONERS BACK PASTOR WHO OPPOSES A 'WAR TAX'
description: For the last two years, the Rev. Carl Lundborg, pastor of the First & Summerfield United Methodist Church here, has not paid half of the Federal income tax he owed.

title: SENATORS WITH NO TIME FOR SECOND CAREERS
description: To the Editor:

title: KELLY LEADS AS TOUR REACHES PYRENEES
description: After nine days on the flat roads of northern and western France, the Tour de France bicycle race rolled today to the foot of its first major challenge, the Pyrenees. The arrival here was marked by an exchange of the overall leader's yellow jersey, with Sean Kelly, a 27-year-old Irishman and a favorite in the race, moving into first place.

title: Article 026775 -- No Title
description: The Brooklyn Museum has received a $1 million grant from the Vincent Astor Foundation, which will help the museum to finance a plan to move its art school to new facilities and to renovate the galleries that the school now occupies. The galleries, which were used for display before the school moved into them in the 1940's, will accommodate the museum's growing collection and house special exhibitions.

title: Elizabeth G. Hoffman Marries Michael Perry
description: Elizabeth Grace Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Hoffman of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married in White Plains yesterday to Michael Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Perry of Apex, N.C. Rabbi Michael Luckins performed the ceremony at the Westchester Inn.

title: GLEMP CHIDES WESTERN REPORTERS
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Cardinal Jozef Glemp, criticized foreign journalists today for political speculation during the Pope's trip home last month and said foreigners should not ''stick their noses'' into Poland's affairs.

title: POP: WAYNE NEWTON AT TRADE CENTER
description: THE ''I Love New York'' Summer Concert Series of musical events presented in the outdoor plaza between the twin towers of the World Trade Center got off to a shaky start Saturday with the appearance of the Las Vegas star Wayne Newton. Because the reserved seating was indicated only by directions written in chalk on the pavement, patrons who had paid as much as $125 for tickets couldn't find their places.

title: ANOTHER LIGHT WEEK FOR DEBT ISSUES
description: For the third consecutive week, analysts are reporting an unusually light debt calendar. Higher interest rates are keeping many corporations out of the bond market, and many municipalities have slowed their borrowing because of the elimination of bearer, or nonregistered, bonds, analysts said.

title: JUDICIAL LEGISLATIVE DISPUTE CENTERS ON OFFICIAL OF HOUSE
description: Federal District Judge Edward S. Northrop is to decide early this week whether to fine the Clerk of the United States House of Representatives $500 a day for contempt of court.

title: CHICAGO FAULTED ON DESEGREGATION
description: A confidential report by three experts on school desegregation appears to contradict assertions by the Chicago Board of Education that progress has been made in desegregating the public school system.

title: 2 Killed in Sikh Clash in India
description: Two people died in an exchange of gunfire in a clash today between rival Sikh sects over control of a temple in the city of Chandigarh in the northern Indian state of Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported. The police said the dead were members of a Sikh sect known as Nihangs, who guard Sikh temples and traditionally carry swords or spears. The police said 31 members of the sect were arrested on various charges including murder, rioting and possession of illegal weapons.

title: Bridge:
description: Should Marriage Partners

title: Peking Frees Woman; French Role Hinted
description: A 26-year-old woman, a former dissident jailed two years ago for trying to marry a French diplomat, has been released from a labor camp, diplomats said today.

title: TALKS IN STRIKE AT CITY OPERA MAY RESUME
description: As picketing continued over the weekend at the New York State Theater, attention turned to a possible resumption of negotiations this week between the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra. The strike has forced cancellation of all City Opera performances since Thursday's scheduled opening night.

title: Huston to Go to Mexico To Film Lowry Novel
description: John Huston, who directed the classic film ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'' in Mexico, will return there next month to make a $4 million version of Malcolm Lowry's novel ''Under the Volcano.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fighting AIDS

title: REVIVAL OF JAPANESE EXPORTS
description: Japanese exports, after sputtering for more than a year, are starting to revive. The turnaround began to take shape in the last few months, as overseas demand for such products as office equipment, video cassette recorders, semiconductors, ships and automobiles picked up.

title: DAVID HARTFIELD JR., A LAWYER AND EX-U.S. PROSECUTOR, DIES
description: David Hartfield Jr., a retired partner of the Wall Street law firm of White & Case and an assistant United States attorney in New York in the 1940's, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Hartfield, who also had a home in Key Largo, Fla., was 64 years old.

title: Advertising; Phase 3 Of Wild Dior Antics
description: ONE OF THE most talked-about campaigns of the last year has to be the Christian Dior print advertising. To which the people at Lansdowne Advertising say, ''Thank goodness.''

title: Metzdorf Acquired
description: Marschalk, another of the Interpublic operations, last week acquired the Metzdorf Advertising Agency in Houston, which is 15 years old and billing $25 million. Marschalk had a four-person agency office in Houston, opened two years ago to service the Coca-Cola Foods account. It will be absorbed into the new big Marschalk office, of which Lyle Metzdorf will be chairman and chief executive.

title: DEMOCRATS LINE UP ON FEMINIST ISSUES
description: At the convention of the National Women's Political Caucus today, four Democratic Presidential candidates said that, if elected, they would use political deals and trade-offs to put pressure on states that refuse to ratify the proposed Federal equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: P.& G. TESTS AN ORANGE JUICE LINE
description: A move late last year by Procter & Gamble, the huge consumer products concern, into the $3 billion a year market for orange juice has rattled Florida's citrus industry.

title: AN ILL-REASONED ATTACK ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Diver 'Very Critical'
description: A Soviet diver who struck the back of his head on a platform during competition at the World University Games was on a life-support machine today after undergoing brain surgery.

title: STORM CLOUD SETTLE OVER INDIA'S ELDER STATESMAN
description: At the age of 87, India's elder statesman, who served as Prime Minister from 1977 to mid-1979, still gets up at 4 A.M. and spins yarn for more than an hour. He eats two meals a day of nuts, fruits, milk and vegetables, answers letters in his own handwriting, fasts once every two weeks and maintains a lively interest in national and international affairs.

title: ABC WILL BROADCAST APOLOGY TO VICTOR LASKY
description: ABC will broadcast an apology to Victor Lasky, the writer, for a reference that was made to him in ''The American Inquistion,'' an ABC television documentary, June 23. At issue is the charge that Mr. Lasky called an art teacher a Communist in a lecture he gave in Fairmont, W. Va., in 1951.

title: FOES OF MOWING ARGUE GRASS HAS FEELINGS, TOO
description: A coalition of vegetarians and wildlife preservationists has just the advice that many homeowners in the New York metropolitan area have been waiting to hear this summer: Don't mow the grass.

title: LOUGANIS RAISING THE LEVEL OF HIS ART
description: Greg Louganis stood at the back of the 3-meter diving board at the Air Force Academy Natatorium in Colorado Springs, waiting. As is customary at diving competitions, the spectators were hushed. The divers had finished their five required dives, and now it was time to start the rounds of optional dives -the more difficult ones.

title: Miss Perlmutter, Teacher, Is Wed to Louis B. Kravitz
description: Bonnie Barbara Perlmutter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Norman Perlmutter of Forest Hills, Queens, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Louis B. Kravitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kravitz of Coconut Creek, Fla. Rabbi Joshua Glatzer performed the ceremony in the Belvedere Suite of the Rainbow Room.

title: RACONTEUR CONDUCTS TOUR ALONG MILLIONAIRES' ROW
description: Herman Storick had a bad spring. Rain is an unwelcome element in the life of an itinerant storyteller, and for months, he said, he was in a sodden mood. Yesterday, however, as the day turned warm, he strode up Fifth Avenue in good humor and good voice, proffering his tales of the city and its gilded age.

title: Krishna Leaders Expel A Founding Member
description: Leaders of the Hare Krishna sect have expelled one of their founders for what they called ''bizarre, aberrant behavior'' after he developed a ''fascination'' with weapons and filed for bankruptcy.

title: BREWERS TRIUMPH AFTER FOUR HOURS
