description: Ted Simmons drove in five runs to help the Milwaukee Brewers defeat the Chicago White Sox, 12-9, in the longest nine-inning game in American League history.

title: Paying the Team What It's Worth
description: Concert masters and mayors may hold office for the glory it confers, but the boys and girls in the back of the band or the less prominent city offices find glory gets tiresome unless it pays the rent. That is the most important reason for New York's City Council to approve big salary increases for the Mayor and other officials, as recommended by a five-member panel headed by Richard Shinn, former chairman of Metropolitan Life.

title: Nancy Schwartz Marries Dr. Alan Marc Freedman
description: The marriage of Nancy Schwartz, a May graduate of Smith College, to Dr. Alan Marc Freedman, a resident in surgery at the University of Kentucky Medical Center in Lexington, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Cantor Hilda Abrevaya performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.

title: AN ILL-REASONED ATTACK ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Kohlmann and Josephine A. Perrella Marry
description: Josephine Alexis Perrella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felice Perrella of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Peter Stephen Kohlmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Kohlmann of the Riverdale section of the Bronx and South Salem, N.Y. Justice Hortense W. Gabel of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: OUTDOORS: CLIMBING MT. HOOD WITH PLENTY OF COMPANY
description: GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. From a distance, the bobbing flashlights suggested a torch light parade. But the climbers, unlike marchers, moved unevenly in two's and three's or in groups of 20 or more, and their progress up the glacier was slow.

title: Hogs Loosed After Collision Create Havoc on a Highway
description: A truckload of hogs was rammed by a car Saturday night, killing two people, freeing 23 hogs on a busy interstate highway and setting off a chain reaction of collisions that killed another person and injured at least two more, the Highway Patrol reported today.

title: STEELMAKERS' NOVEL FINANCING
description: American banks, with foreign banking partners, are developing cheaper ways to finance major capital goods investments in the United States steel industry by availing themselves of tax credits and foreign loan subsidies.

title: OPERA: EARLY WAGNER EFFORT HAS U.S. PREMIERE IN NEW JERSEY
description: WAGNER'S second opera, ''Das Liebesverbot,'' finally found its way to this side of the world Saturday night. The American premiere took up the whole of the Waterloo Festival's second concert of the year in Stanhope, N.J. And even though this was a concert version - with only minimal stage movement and a simple arrangement of shrubs and latticework as a backdrop - the audience had no trouble creating its own pictures of the action. In ''Das Liebesverbot,'' the young Wagner wallows joyously in a thick conglomerate of Italian and German operatic situations. Their elements were familiar to all.

title: THEATER: NEW MUSICAL, 'AMERICAN PASSION'
description: ONE of the few egregious by-products of Broadway's longest-running musical, ''A Chorus Line,'' is the endless parade of knockoffs it has inspired since it opened in 1975. The latest and perhaps the least - but probably not the last - of these clones is ''American Passion'' at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea. Let it be noted in passing that the Joyce, now mostly used by dance companies, could serve as an excellent home for a moderate-size musical. ''American Passion,'' alas, is puny.

title: 12 Crew Victories For East Germans
description: The East German national team dominated the 50th anniversary Lucerne International Rowing Regatta again today, duplicating its gold medal totals of the previous day in sweeping the six women's races and six of the eight men's events.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.55 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.50 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: A CHANCE FOR AVERAGE GOLFER
description: Dr. Richard S. Silver, a member of the United States Golf Association's public links committee, once defined a public links golfer as follows:

title: MURPHY LEADING APPRENTICE SURGE
description: Apprentice jockeys are known as bug boys because there is an asterisk - which looks a bit like a squashed bug - beside their names in the racing program, signifying that their mounts carry less weight to compensate for their riders' inexperience. There is another good reason for the name: The careers of most apprentice jockeys can be as brief and precarious as those of insects.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Rules for Better Living Help Wanted

title: BIRTH OF A HEALTH-CARE CONCERN
description: The formula for striking it rich used to involve oil wells. Then it was computers. Now the key phrase is health care. Michael Le Coney, a health-care analyst at Merrill Lynch, figures that there is no easier way to raise money than to start a healthcare company. At a clip of something like one a week, new entrants with big dreams and scant revenues are going public. Investors pounce. Stock prices soar. ''Seemingly anybody can do it,'' Mr. Le Coney says. ''It's beyond belief.''

title: AN UNEASE SETTLES OVER VILLAGE ON EVE OF BIG TRIAL
description: This tranquil, historic Orange County village, with its church steeples and surrounding horse farms and black-dirt onion farms, is abuzz.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. Yankees open a threegame series before returning home Thursday. Jay Howell, moved back a day in the rotation, will start against Bobby Castillo. (Radio -WABC, 770; 8:35 P.M.). Dodgers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.). Braves vs. Expos, at Montreal. The conclusion of the four-game series that could be a preview of the National League Championship series. (Television -WTBS, 7:35 P.M.).

title: Debt Issues
description: * Hardwicke Cos. said it has not paid the semiannual interest payments due June 30 on $22 million of subordinated debentures.

title: 36-Day Walkout Ends In 14% Raise at Utility
description: Workers at Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. returned to their jobs this morning after ratifying a contract proposal that ended a 36-day strike, a company spokesman said.

title: Gains for Magazines
description: Member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau had their best advertising gains of the year in June, with pages up 9 percent and revenues up 13 percent over June 1982. The pages totaled 9,775 and the revenues, $295.5 million.

title: THE PROBLEM NOW AT THE IRANIAN EMBASSY IS GRASS GONE WILD
description: Diplomatic relations between the United States and Iran crumbled in 1980. Now the abandoned buildings here that once housed Iranian diplomats are threatening to crumble.

title: SUSAN E. WEINER AND CHRISTOPHER K. AIDUN MARRY
description: The marriage of Susan E. Weiner, an associate with the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, to Christopher K. Aidun, an associate with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, also in New York, took place yesterday. Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weiner, father and stepmother of the bride, in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: SOVIET JEWS NEED HELP
description: The position of the Jews of the Soviet Union is deteriorating rapidly. There is growing harassment and muzzling of cultural and religious expression that is harsh even by Soviet standards. Iosif Begun, the mathematician, has been arrested and faces a third trial because of his attempt to teach the Hebrew language, which has been interpreted as anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda. Aleksandr Paritsky, an engineer, was arrested, tried and found guilty for the crime of defaming the Soviet state, but his real ''crime'' was his leadership in organizing Jewish cultural and educational activities in the Ukraine.

title: MARKETS AWAIT FED DECISIONS
description: The financial markets are expected to remain edgy this week despite the welcomed $3 billion drop in the money supply that was announced Friday by the Federal Reserve System.

title: A MOMENT IN A LIFE
description: IT is curious that sometimes one may live a long life but be remembered primarily for just one moment in it. It strikes the famous as well as the obscure. David, for one, could play the lyre and whip off a psalm and run a kingdom, but he is especially known for having smitten a guy with a rock. Mrs. O'Leary's cow, regardless of how serviceable a bovine she may have been, is remembered for having kicked over a lantern.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: No Headline
description: Topics Rules for Better Living Smoked Out

title: METS DEFEAT ASTROS BY 7-5
description: There are instances, as in the eighth inning yesterday at Shea Stadium, in which Darryl Strawberry looks like at least part of the answer for the Mets. He can hit. Above all, the Mets need someone who can drive balls into the alleys, rattle the walls and crush a pitch or two into the great beyond.

title: Accounts
description: * Connoisseur Magazine to McCaffery & Ratner.

title: QUEENS COUPLES DIE IN A MURDER-SUICIDE AND DOUBLE SUICIDE
description: An elderly Queens couple leaped to their deaths from the 15th floor of a Rego Park apartment house yesterday, according to the police. Seven hours earlier, another Queens couple were found dead in their home as a result of a murder-suicide, the police said.

title: Plunge in Colombia Kills 7
description: A truck driving peasants and food to the eastern Colombian town of Betulia plunged 500 feet into a ravine today, killing 7 of the passengers and injuring 10 others. The police said the accident, which took place 160 miles from Bogota, was caused by mechanical trouble with the truck.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson The Thermal Last Stand

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Old-Time Stickball

title: Market Place; Rate Fear and Earnings
description: THERE is nothing like the fear of rising interest rates to send stock prices downward, and last week was no exception: the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 18.03 points, to 1.207.23. A week earlier, interest-rate concerns helped lead to a drop of 16.43 points.

title: Police Kill Gunman After a Chase
description: The police shot and killed a gunman who had tried to rob the driver of a gypsy cab in midtown Manhattan early yesterday, the police said. The gunman, who was not identified, pulled out a .32-caliber pistol and tried to rob the driver as the cab was heading up Eighth Avenue at about 5:45 A.M., the police said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Dance Immersion

title: BLUEJAYS WIN AS GARCIA EXTENDS STREAK
description: Damaso Garcia extended his hitting streak and Buck Martinez hit a two-run homer as the Toronto Blue Jays maintained their lead in the American League East yesterday with a 6-4 victory over the Texas Rangers before 32,071 at Toronto's Exhibition Stadium.

title: U.S. WOMEN TAKE GOLD IN BASKETBALL
description: Deborah Lee of Delta State scored 24 points and led the United States women's basketball team to an 83-61 victory over Rumania and won the gold medal at the World University Games.

title: TOLERATING THE FRIEND OF A FRIEND
description: IF names have been changed here, or left out altogether, it's to p rotect the innocent from their friends. The problem, you see, is t his: Someone you like is hanging around with someone you don't.

title: A MAGAZINE SAYS MITTERRAND ADMITS TO ECOMOMIC MISTAKES
description: In a series of private talks that the French press has dubbed ''the confessions of the President,'' Francois Mitterrand has been quoted as acknowledging a variety of economic errors since he took office in 1981.

title: Connors Beats Lendl
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Ivan Lendl, 7-5, 7-6, today and won the $400,000 first prize in the four-player Sun City tennis exhibition.

title: Diane Korntheuer Is Married to Peter C. Grzybala
description: At St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Port Chester, N.Y., yesterday, Diane Korntheuer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Korntheuer of Port Chester and Dennis, Mass., was married to Peter Carl Grzybala, son of Helen M. Grzybala of Chester, Conn., and the late Dr. Henry S. Grzybala. The Rev. John B. Sanborn performed the ceremony.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The economic recovery in the United States is finally spreading to other countries and may help the world break out of its long period of economic stagnation. But officials, worried about interest rates, trade deficits and international debt problems, still face a summer of anxiety.

title: SURVEY OF NEWSPAPERS FINDS SUPPORT FOR COLUMN BY WILL
description: Some newspapers and magazines have decided to keep the columns of George F. Will, the political analyst, or have not considered the issue raised yesterday when The Daily News dropped them.

title: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS STRESS GROUP AND DISCOURAGE INDIVIDUALITY
description: Tomiko Yusa was teaching a lesson in negative numbers one day recently to her seventh grade mathematics class at the Uchikoshi Junior High School here, and she called on a student seated near the window to solve a problem on the blackboard.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HISTORY LESSON FOR FEMINISTS
description: A big drawing card at the convention of the National Women's Political Caucus here was Gloria Steinem's workshop, ''What Is Feminism? A Conversation With Young Women.''

title: Psychiatrists Tell Soviet To Halt 'Political Abuse'
description: The World Psychiatric Association urged the Soviet Union today to end its ''political abuse of psychiatry.'' It also called on Moscow to rejoin the organization, which it quit earlier this year in the face of a growing storm of protest.

title: 5 Shot and 5 Others Hurt In Greek Political Melee
description: Five people were shot and five others injured with clubs and chains during political clashes in Kalamai, on the southern coast of Greece, Saturday night, the police reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; July 11, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHAD REPORTS COUNTERATTACK TO RECOVER CITY NEAR SUDAN
description: The Government of President Hissen Habre said today that the strategic eastern town of Abeche had been taken briefly by anti-Government rebels, that a counteroffensive had been ordered and that fighting continued.

title: ISRAELIS APPROVE OUSTER OF MAYOR IN WEST BANK CITY
description: The Israeli Cabinet today endorsed a decision to dismiss the Arab Mayor of the occupied West Bank city of Hebron. Cabinet officials said after the meeting that the Government would go ahead with a decision to restore the old Jewish quarter of that city despite local Arab resistance.

title: Advance a Winner Over Canada 1
description: Advance, the Australian 12-Meter, won her first race today since the America's Cup trials began, by 4 minutes over Canada 1, whose crew could not raise the spinnaker on the second leg.

title: NEW YORK THREATENS TO TAKE I-95 DISPUTE TO FEDERAL COURT
description: The turnpike dispute between New York and Connecticut intensified yesterday, with New York officials threatening Federal legal action and angry residents of Greenwich, Conn., where part of the Mianus River bridge collapsed two weeks ago, protesting attempts to build new access ramps from Interstate 95.

title: Addenda
description: * Family Circle will introduce new graphics and an 8 percent advertising rate increase with its Oct.4 issue.

title: OPERA STRIKE MEDIATOR SEES SOLUTION 'IN TIME'
description: It was 4 o'clock in the morning. The 1979 New York milk strike had dragged on for six weeks when Irving Wisch, chairman of the bargaining committee for the Greater Metropolitan New York Milk Dealers, left the union negotiators on the seventh floor of a midtown Manhattan hotel and returned, dejected and frustrated, to the company-owners' room on the eighth floor.

title: IN COTTON, PAYMENT IN KIND BACKFIRES
description: Fred Klostermann popped a pinch of Copenhagen snuff into his mouth, waved a forearm as big as a ham at verdant acres of new cotton, and scowled.

title: STARS SHOW THEIR 1, 2 PUNCH
description: Pro football is full of labels for its performers. An appropriate one for Kelvin Bryant, the Philadelphia Stars' spectacular rookie running back from North Carolina, would be a ''franchise player.''

title: Naval Victory in Gulf Is Claimed by Iraq
description: Iraq said its navy and air force attacked and destroyed ''three enemy naval targets'' at the northern end of the Persian Gulf today in its war with Iran.

title: YANKS' 5 IN THIRD DOWN ROYALS, 6-4
description: When their premier relief pitcher goes to the mound, the Yankees should post a sign for the protection of their other players: ''Danger - Goose at Work.''

title: CONTROVERSY IS RENEWED OVER JAPANESE TEXTBOOKS
description: A long-running dispute over how public school textbooks should treat Japanese history has been renewed recently with new Government changes in accounts of this country's wartime conduct.

title: MOLDER OF MERGER PERCEPTIONS
description: When David J. Mahoney tried to buy Norton Simon Inc., Gershon Kekst was there. He was there, too, when the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation made its successful bid for Lenox Inc. and when General Felt Industries Inc. bid, less successfully, for Sotheby Parke Bernet Group P.L.C.

title: The Sentencing Trap
description: In the last days of the legislative session, Governor Cuomo pushed through a bill that could either ease New York's prison problem - or make it catastrophic. That uncertainty is regrettable, unnecessary and still avoidable if the Governor reconsiders his support and withholds his signature.

title: 2 Psychiatrists Liable For a Patient's Act
description: Two psychiatrists have been found liable for $177,100 in a malpractice suit filed by a couple whose son allegedly was killed by one of their patients.

title: FRANCE, SWEDEN ADVANCE
description: France and Sweden had to struggle yesterday to advance to the Davis Cup tennis semifinals. France, which lost last year's final to the United States, downed Paraguay, 3-2, in the three-of-five series at Marseilles.

title: Commodities; Growth In Futures Funds
description: COMMODITY funds have long been heralded as the prudent investment vehicle for small futures traders. For relatively small cash outlays, these mutual funds offer professional management, diversification and the avoidance of broker calls for more cash margin when markets move against the trader.

title: No Deal on Missiles, Yet
description: The standoff in Moscow on the Euromissile issue between President Andropov and West German Chancellor Kohl was determined in advance, by the calendar. The West is not scheduled to start deploying 572 American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles for another five months and full deployment will take three years. The crunch - and the possibility of a deal - still lie ahead.

title: ANTI-MX FILIBUSTER IS PLANNED
description: Senator Gary Hart, a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984, plans to try to kill the long disputed MX missile this week with an ''extended debate'' on the floor of the Senate.

title: Female Driver Seriously Injured
description: One driver suffered serious injuries and two others escaped with minor injuries in two crashes today at Brainerd International Raceway.

title: CHIEF GETS UTILITY ITS OWN COAL SHIP
description: Guy W. Nichols, chairman and chief executive officer of the New England Electric System, did not get to sail his family's 40-foot sailboat, the Partenope, off Nantucket Island Saturday. Instead he was showing off a bigger vessel - a new 665-foot coal-burning collier, the Energy Independence - to Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, and other public officials at the Quincy, Mass., shipyard of the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: FOR WEST INDIANS, CRICKET FIELD IS BIT OF HOME
description: The cricket players clad in white are hard to miss, moving gracefully across the green grass under blue skies, a contrast to the softball players and Frisbee throwers in cut-off dungarees and Tshirts.

title: Soviet Bomber Downed, Afghan Rebels Say
description: Afghan rebels say that a Soviet bomber was downed in fighting northeast of Kabul, the Afghan capital, and that the pilot and a Soviet military adviser were taken prisoner, the Yugoslav press agency Tanyug reported today.

title: SPACE TRAVEL MAY SLOW AGING
description: The weightlessness of space may slow the aging process by as much as 15 percent, but it can damage major bones and muscles needed on Earth, researchers say.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN CHARTS SCHRODER WAGG COURSE
description: Winfried F. Bischoff, 42, chosen last week to succeed John Hull, the 57-year-old chairman of J. Henry Schroder Wagg & Company, acknowledges that the venerable merchant bank has lost ground to its competitors in London in recent years.

title: A Touch of Class
description: For a quarter of a century the sounds of Vernon Martin's singsong chants - ''I've got $10,000, who will make it $20,000, I've got $20,000, who will make it $30,000,'' - have been heard at standardbred horse sales around the country, in such settings as horse farms, sales pavilions and harness tracks.

title: MARY SEXTON IS MARRIED TO MICHAEL G. MEZZAPELLE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Flushing, Queens, yesterday Mary E. Sexton was married to Michael G. Mezzapelle by the Rev. Joseph F. MacDonnell. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Sexton of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Point Lookout, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Dominick M. Mezzapelle of Stamford, Conn.

title: Jewish Demonstrators Jostle Mayor of Moscow in London
description: Jewish demonstrators, some wearing prison camp clothing, jostled and shouted at the Mayor of Moscow today as he arrived for lunch with representatives of London's Metropolitan Council.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Leader Asks Unity at Convention
description: The national vice chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People says he hopes the group will put internal strife behind it at its convention this week in New Orleans so it can devote full attention to civil rights issues.

title: CSX Asks Lifting Of Texas Gas Curb
description: The CSX Corporation asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger on Saturday to vacate a Federal Court of Appeals ruling that enjoined the giant rail corporation from buying shares of the Texas Gas Corporation.

title: TRACK BARRON WINNER
description: When Leroy Jolley was training for the Firestone stable, he sent out a bunch of hot 2-year-olds each spring, many of whom developed into top 3-year-olds, including Honest Pleasure, General Assembly, Genuine Risk and Cure the Blues. He parted with the Firestones two years ago and took over Peter Brant's stable, which was long on European pedigrees and distance horses but short on precocious 2-year-olds.

title: Washington Watch; White House's View on Taxes WASHINGTON
description: THE President's top advisers, in an unusual show of unanimity, have given the straight line on tax increases to Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., the top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP CALLED A THREAT TO THE ECONOMY
description: The United States deficit in foreign trade, which has widened to record levels, is a serious threat to the economy and the threat is unlikely to diminish as the economy recovers, officials in the Reagan Administration now believe.

title: 47,191 SEE EXPOS BEAT BRAVES
description: Al Oliver's fielder's-choice grounder in the eighth inning scored Tim Raines with the tiebreaking run today as the Montreal Expos posted a 7-6 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: SALVADOR REBELS KILL CAPTIVE MILITIAMEN
description: Rebel forces battled for seven hours over the weekend with the civil defense force here and put to death members of the local militia, according to several residents of this town in southern El Salvador.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

title: HEARNS TAKES DECISION
description: Thomas Hearns never liked his nickname of Hit Man, anyway. Today, in his first fight in seven months, the World Boxing Council junior middleweight champion reminded everyone that his label now was boxer, not puncher.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading What Is Wrong

title: SEX ABUSE: THE CHILD'S WORD ISN'T ENOUGH
description: It took nine months for Alan, a 5-year-old living in a quiet Westchester County town, to tell someone what had been happening to him. Alan told his cousin, who promptly told Alan's mother, Mary. Thus she learned that Alan had been sexually abused nearly every weekend, on close to 30 occasions, by his Uncle Henry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some people may use words like journey, but to me it was a race.'' Siegfried Bauer, who ran 511 miles to win the New York Six-Day Run. (C6:1.)

title: REGGAE: UB40 PLAYS THE RITZ
description: AS the 1970's ended, some British bands began writing politically conscious songs with music rooted in ska and reggae, the Jamaican rhythms of the 1960's and 70's. While most of those bands have branched out or broken up, UB40 (the number on a British unemployment benefit card) has remained loyal to Jamaican music.

title: STRIKE AT CITY OPERA POINTS UP MUSICIANS' RELIANCE ON UNION
description: The strike by the orchestra members of the New York City Opera demonstrates that today's musicians are ''not tolerating as much as the previous generation did,'' according to Jack Golodner, executive director of the Department for Professional Employees of the A.F.L.- C.I.O.

title: Women in Army Oppose Plan
description: An advisory panel has asked Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to reverse an Army decision closing additional military specialties to women on the ground that those jobs might involve women soldiers in combat.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Three in Iranian Family Are Killed After Threats
description: An Iranian whose husband had returned to that country three months ago was shot to death early today along with her son and daughter by two men who invaded their home, the police said.

title: BANCO DE PONCE (NYC) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PEOPLES BANKING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Tarkanian Stays
description: The contract of Jerry Tarkanian, basketball coach at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, has been extended for three years.

title: Message Purportedly Written By Girl Is Left in Rome Chapel
description: A scrawled message addressed to the parents of the kidnapped daughter of a Vatican employee was found Sunday night in the chapel of Rome's Leonardo da Vinci Airport.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A New Soap Saga

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Comings and Goings
description: Earl Averill, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, was hospitalized yesterday for treatment of pneumonia, his family reported. Averill, 81, of Snohomish, Wash., was in serious condition at Providence Hospital in Everett, said Mrs. Alice Gilmore, supervisor of nursing services. ... Dave Parker, who won the National League batting title in 1977 and 1978 but is now hitting .244, has spurned the suggestion of the Pittsburgh Pirates' management that he undergo an eye examination.

title: G.M. Changes In Steel Orders
description: The General Motors Corporation will reduce its steel purchases from the Republic Steel Corporation in the 1984 car-model year, starting this October, according to G.M. sources.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 12, 1983; International
description: Ashland Oil made payments totaling $17 million to a former Abu Dhabi official in an unsuccessful effort to retain an oil contract, according to company officials. They said the payments, in 1980 and 1981, had gone to Sadiq Attia, who had connections with Abu Dhabi National Oil, but his exact position is now unclear. The payments are being investigated by two Congressional subcommittees. (Page A1.)

title: Maislin U.S. Unit
description: Maislin Industries Ltd.'s trustees, Richter & Associates, said the company's United States unit had filed to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Richter also said that the company's Maislin Transport unit had filed a holding proposal, under which it is seeking a moratorium on payments to creditors until Oct. 31. Maislin is a Montreal-based trucking concern.

title: ACTION ON SHOREHAM DELAYED
description: Governor Cuomo tonight put off action on legislation designed to delay sharp increases in electric rates on Long Island once the $3.2 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant begins producing electricity.

title: Two Officers Accused Of Thievery on Duty
description: Two Jersey City police officers have been suspended without pay on charges that they stole drugs, cash and property while on the job, authorities said.

title: PAN AM COMES OFF THE ROPES
description: From the September day when he took over the helm at Pan American World Airways two years ago, C. Edward Acker has had to scramble to buy the time he needed to restructure the company. As losses mounted, scaring off travel agents and passengers who feared the company's demise, it looked at times like Mr. Acker might be losing the battle.

title: MOSQUITO: THE ENEMY REVEALS ITS WAYS
description: AS hordes of mosquitoes once again descend upon Americans, their numbers swollen in the Northeast and the West by heavy spring rains, reports of ingenious new methods to control this pest promise relief to the evening stroller and porch sitter, the early morning jogger and the sleeper tortured by the insistent hum of a female mosquito in search of a meal.

title: A Sale by U.P.I.
description: Commodity News Services Inc., a subsidiary of Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., said it had acquired United Press International's share of Unicom News, a commodity and economic information service.

title: WORKERS IN BRAZIL PROTEST AUSTERITY
description: The head of the Bank for International Settlements said Brazil would not get an extension for a repayment due Friday. Page D7.

title: TESTING OF SKILLS MATTER OF DEBATE
description: WHEN school districts across the country were searching in the 1970's for ways to help their students learn more, many turned to competency tests as a tool for prodding performance and measuring progress.

title: STATE SENATE RECONVENES TODAY TO WEIGH TRANSPORTATION BOND
description: The State Senate will reconvene Tuesday to complete the work of the 206th legislative session, taking up measures already approved in the Assembly, including a $1.25 billion transportation bond issue.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN 4TH IN ROW, 7-4
description: Willie Upshaw opened the 11th inning with a triple to center field and scored on a single by Lloyd Moseby tonight to spark the Blue Jays to their fourth straight victory, a 7-4 decision over the Kansas City Royals. Toronto maintained its three-game lead in the American League East.

title: SUGAR RAY VIEWS HAGLER-DURAN BOUT
description: M ore than a year has passed since Sugar Ray Leonard required surgery for a detached retina in his left eye, more than eight months since he announced he would never put on boxing gloves again. Sugar Ray Leonard has quietly settled into another life as a television analyst. The ironic twist is that the boxer he embarrassed and always will be linked with, Roberto Duran, now has the big fight against the boxer he had planned to challenge, the middleweight champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler, in what might have been his most memorable bout.

title: RECORD TIME HAS LITTLE TOWN TICKING
description: In the town of Bolton, Miss., population 3,000, the big happening was not so much that a native son, Calvin Smith, had broken the world record for the 100-meter dash, but that four days later he appeared on a national television show.

title: CLERK OF U.S. HOUSE IS FINED IN CONTEMPT OF COURT CASE
description: A Federal district judge imposed a $500-a-day fine today on the Clerk of the United States House of Representatives for contempt of court. The House had earlier asserted a constitutional right to defy a court-approved subpoena.

title: Fire at Coral Gables Club
description: A fire that may have started in a kitchen destroyed much of the 60-year-old Coral Gables Country Club early today. The fire destroyed the part of the Spanish-style clubhouse that contained the main ballroom.

title: SATELLITE SENDS NEW VIEW OF THE OCEAN
description: TWO young scientists hunkered over computer terminals last autumn to explore the earth's last unmapped regions - vast stretches of ocean floor never surveyed by ships.

title: INVESTORS SHUN CREDIT MARKETS
description: With yields for Treasury notes and bonds near their highest levels of the year, investors shunned the credit markets yesterday as they awaited testimony by Paul A. Volcker that might shed light on the direction of interest rates.

title: SHOEBOX ORGANIZER PROGRAM HAS ITS DRAWBACKS
description: MANY people use the shoe box method of accounting in their annual tax preparations. I don't know whether it's that my family doesn't buy as many shoes as other people do or whether shoes, especially sneakers, no longer always come in boxes, but I never seem to have enough shoe boxes for the occasion.

title: Israelis Protest Excavation
description: Hundreds of Orthodox demonstrators clashed with the Israeli police tonight during a violent protest against an archeological excavation project that was renewed last week in an area of Jerusalem's Old City that rabbis believe to be an ancient Jewish cemetery. A police spokesman said about 40 demonstrators were arrested and at least six police officers, including a woman, were injured.

title: U.S. Tops Canada For Soccer Berth
description: The United States amateur soccer team qualified for the Pan American Games by defeating Canada, 3-2, at Hamilton, Ontario, on Sunday.

title: GIFTED RETARDATES: THE SEARCH FOR CLUES TO MYSTERIOUS TALENT
description: DENVER EVEN as a teen-ager at the state training school in western Colorado, the one thing that Alonzo Clemons wanted to do more than anything else was to work with modeling clay. Retarded since early childhood, he would sit silently for hours, kneading the clay into the shapes of tiny animals.

title: KOOSMAN HAS VINTAGE TOUCH
description: T here had already been many jokes about the competition between elderly pitchers that took place two weeks ago at Chicago's Comiskey Park, so Jerry Koosman thought, why not carry the joke a few steps further? ''I figured I'd carry it out to the mound,'' he said. So when Gaylord Perry, that master of foreign substances, stepped to the mound, he discovered something that was foreign, even to him. He reached down and picked up a set of false teeth.

title: BILL WOULD FREEZE TOBACCO SUPPORTS
description: The House passed a simplified bill today that would freeze 1983 tobacco support prices at last year's levels, a measure sought by hard-pressed growers who contend that their product is being priced out of world markets by an artifically high support level,

title: CHILEANS CALL FOR A MASS PROTEST
description: Opposition politicians said today that Chileans would stage a third mass protest against President Augusto Pinochet's military Government despite its attempt to suppress the movement by arresting the president of the Christian Democratic Party.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for year to May 31.
UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Riding the Rails For the Homeless

title: Wheat Pact Renewal
description: President Reagan asked the Senate today to ratify a three-year extension of the International Wheat Agreement. It sets grain trading rules.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Britoil P.L.C. plans a dollar-denominated Eurobond issue, through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International, to refinance part of its $400 million floating-rate credit signed last year.

title: SPEEDING MOTORMEN CALLED FACTOR IN RASH OF CITY SUBWAY DERAILINGS
description: Subway motormen who drive too fast have contributed to a recent rash of derailments in New York City, a consultant studying the accidents said yesterday, and the Transit Authority has begun using radar guns to catch violators.

title: US HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 50 percent stock dividend paid May 31.

title: Rank's Profits Decline by 10%
description: The Rank Organization, the entertainment and industrial conglomerate, reported today that after-tax profits in the 28 weeks ended May 14 had declined 10 percent from a year earlier, to 16.3 million, or $24.9 million.

title: Archer Daniels Facing Redemption Challenge
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm, filed a lawsuit last Friday challenging the Archer Daniels-Midland Company's plan to redeem its 16 percent debentures due in 2011.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
METS' CHANGES PRODUCE RUNS
description: How many had it been this time? How many games did the Mets lose before Sunday's 7-5 victory over the Houston Astros? Hubie Brooks wanted to know.

title: JUDGING POLISH MOVES
description: Before the Reagan Administration hurries to restore ''normal'' economic relations with Poland, we should ask ourselves what are the real criteria for judging progress or regress under the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Are there any realistic signposts for what is somewhat misleadingly called ''lifting sanctions'' - meaning the restoration of economic privileges, credits, trade and state aid for the crippled Polish economy?

title: From Pitching To Politicking
description: For 17 seasons, Jim Bunning whipped across pitching mounds throughout the major leagues. Some moments were splendid. A no-hitter for Detroit, 20 victories in his third big-league season, four other seasons with 19 victories.

title: New-Crop Corn Futures Rise on Weather News
description: New-crop corn futures prices soared their daily limit of 10 cents a bushel yesterday as hot, dry weather caused traders who had previously sold short to buy out of their positions. As prices rose, farmers became even more reluctant sellers, adding to the upward pressure on prices.

title: HONOR FOR CANNON PUT ON HOLD
description: Officials of the National Football Foundation said today that a decision to induct Billy Cannon Sr., the former Heisman Trophy winner, into the College Football Hall of Fame was on hold pending the outcome of Federal charges he was involved in a multi-million dollar counterfeiting ring.

title: THE $30 MILLION NEW YORK INDUSTRY BEHIND BARS
description: To the Editor:

title: CAUSE OF 1908 BLAST OVER SIBERIA REMAINS ELUSIVE
description: ON the morning of June 30, 1908, a tremendous explosion in the sky over northern Siberia flattened trees for 25 miles around and sent out shock waves that were recorded around the world. Now, 75 years later, scientists are still debating the cause of the blast, one of the most powerful ever felt on earth.

title: BROKERS PLAN A PHONE FUND
description: Four brokerage companies, assuming that the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will create confusion among stockholders, announced plans yesterday to create a unit trust, or fund, that will hold the stock of A.T.& T. and its subsidiaries once they are broken apart.

title: WOMETCO CABLE TV INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
New Hampshire Ratings Lowered
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating of the New Hampshire Municipal Bond Bank's state-guaranteed bonds to AA-minus from AA, and it downgraded the bank's moral obligation bonds to Aminus from A.

title: Loan Bank Board Bars Bowery Takeover Plan
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday rejected a proposal by the Bowery Savings Bank of New York to acquire the Commonwealth Savings and Loan Association of Margate, Fla. , according to Ira Tannenbaum, a Washington lawyer who represents the Bowery.

title: People
description: * Bernard Ryan Jr. coming to the American Association of Advertising Agencies in the new position of vice president, public affairs.

title: Tour's 10th Stage Is Won by a Scot
description: DE-LUCHON, France, July 11 (UPI) - Robert Millar of Scotland won the 10th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, covering the 123 miles from Pau in 6 hours 23 minutes 27 seconds.

title: SALES ROSE 14.5% IN JUNE FOR CITY'S BIG RETAILERS
description: Sales at seven major New York City department stores rose an average of 14.5 percent in June, the biggest gain in more than two years, a spot-check showed yesterday.

title: Market Place; Bank's Role As a Broker
description: THE Chemical Bank's discount brokerage service, which irked some old-line investment houses with its hard-sell TV advertising this spring, is off to a running start.

title: Protest Disrupts Service In Washington Mosque
description: Forty protesters were arrested today and charged with disrupting a service at the National Islamic Center, the District of Columbia police said.

title: ASHLAND PAYMENTS ON OIL QUESTIONED
description: Ashland Oil Inc. made payments totaling $17 million in 1980 and 1981 to a former Abu Dhabi official in an unsuccessful attempt to retain a crude oil contract with the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, according to current and former Ashland officials.

title: MEXICO'S RULING PARTY SET BACK
description: Opposition parties won elections in 12 northern cities, including 2 state capitals, dealing the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party the worst reverse in its 54-year history, official returns showed today.

title: Chess:; Predrag Nikolic Captures Bosna Tourney in Sarajevo
description: The international master Predrag Nikolic of Yugoslavia captured first place in the Bosna 1983 International Tournament in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, with a 10 1/2-4 1/2 score.

title: A PHONE SYSTEM'S NET CLIMBS
description: United Telecommunications Inc., operator of the nation's secondlargest independent telephone system, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose 31.3 percent while revenues advanced 8.9 percent.

title: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS: EXAM ORDEAL RULES EACH STUDENT'S DESTINY
description: American students, by and large, take examinations to get out of school. Japanese take them to get in. One result is that once Japanese students get to college, they can relax. Their life bears little resemblance to the regimen of lectures, seminars, exams and papers that are the pattern in the United States. ''We are supposed to spend two hours preparing for every hour of class,'' said Masato Koiso, a 20-year-old sophomore at Sophia University here, ''but nobody does that. This is the only time that you can take it easy and enjoy life.''

title: Dome Plans to Sell TransCanada Stake
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it and its Dome Investments Ltd. unit had agreed to sell 4.3 million shares of TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. at $28 (Canadian) each, or a total of $120.4 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: Debate Fears Recalled

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Data Resources Inc., the Lexington, Mass., forecasting concern, has chosen David A. Wyss, currently chief economist for its European Forecasting group, to lead its United States economic service. He will replace Allen Sinai, who announced last week that he was resigning to become an economist at the Wall Street firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: JUDGE TESTIFIES IN OWN COURT ON HIS FITNESS TO RULE
description: A hearing in an unusual and long-running libel suit is scheduled to resume here Tuesday. For Philadelphians, it has already provided the spectacle of the trial judge taking an oath and testifying on his own fitness to preside, alternating on the bench between testifying himself and ruling on the suitability of questions from trial lawyers.

title: Central Banks Pick Chairman
description: Central bank presidents of the Group of Ten countries and Switzerland elected Karl-Otto Pohl, head of the Bundesbank, as their new chairman at a meeting here today, the Bank for International Settlements said.

title: Morocco Reports Repelling Sahara Rebels
description: Moroccan forces killed 50 Polisario guerrillas and wounded many others who attacked Moroccan positions in Western Sahara, the official Moroccan press agency reported today.

title: Panhandle to Buy Less Algeria Gas
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said it had agreed with Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil company, to reduce its purchases of liquefied natural gas from Sonatrach by 40 percent from last April 1 to Nov. 30, 1984. At the reduced level, purchases for the period are expected to be 156 billion cubic feet.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
description: b-Net income. Restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: WAGNER DISMISSED AS REDS' PRESIDENT
description: Dick Wagner was dismissed as president of the Cincinnati Reds today and his predecessor, Bob Howsam, agreed to return as chief executive officer and general manager of the struggling National League club on an interim basis.

title: Tests Find No Dioxin At a Hawthorne Plant
description: Samples from a chemical plant in Passaic County show no trace of dioxin, State Environmental Commissioner Robert E. Hughey announced today.

title: FIRST BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COUPLE WHO SUED NEWSWEEK WERE GIVEN A GUEST COLUMN
description: Newsweek magazine's publication of a column by a California couple, Warren M. and Patricia Becker, came in settlement of the couple's libel suit against the magazine, according to Mr. Becker and others connected with the case.

title: Sandick Revue to Start At Baldwin Thursday
description: The Baldwin Theater, an Equity showcase theater associated with the Baldwin School, will present Paul Sandick's original revue ''World War Won, or That's the Wrong Way to Tickle Mary,'' beginning Thursday.

title: 60,237 LESSONS
description: The Michigan Panthers may have learned a valuable lesson from the crowd of 60,237 that they drew to the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich., on Sunday for their playoff game with the Oakland Invaders. It was the largest crowd in the short history of the United States Football League.

title: MABEL M. RODGERS
description: Mabel Mitchell Rodgers, co-founder of Merritt Associates, a realestate concern serving Westchester and Fairfield Counties, died on Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., from injuries sustained in an automobile accident July 1. She was 72 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y., and Naples, Fla.

title: Trail of the Gypsy Moth
description: Gypsy moths are known for the male's ability to identify and follow, for a mile or more, the trail of the chemical pheromone the female moth emits. Although relatively little has been known about how the insects follow the airborne plume of scent, researchers have assumed that the males simply traveled wherever the odor led them, even though wind currents bending the plume made their path long and winding.

title: Data General Job
description: The Data General Corporation said it had been awarded an eight-year contract by the Department of Agriculture to provide a nationwide network of office automation and management systems for the department's Forest Service. During the first three years of the contract, the Forest Service has the option to purchase or lease more than 800 systems with an average hardware value of about $85,000 each. The total hardware system value of the first three years would be more than $70 million if all systems were purchased, it said.

title: Staying at Home
description: Art Fowler, who was removed as pitching coach of the Yankees on June 17, is at his home in Spartanburg, S.C. Reached there by telephone yesterday, he said he was disappointed that no one from the Yankee front office had called him since his 15-year association with Manager Billy Martin was ended. Fowler had served as pitching coach under Martin since 1969 with Minnesota, Detroit, Texas, Oakland and the Yankees.

title: E.P.A. THREATENS TO SUSPEND APPROVAL OF PESTICIDES OVER TEST FLAWS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would suspend approval of pesticides invalidly tested by Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories unless new information supporting the safety of the chemicals was offered or promised.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After securities losses of $1,364,000 for the quarter and $1,355,000 for the 6 months. c-After securities losses of $3,157,000 for the quarter and $3,120,000 for the 6 months.

title: OUR AND OUR ENVIRONMENT'S FUTURE DEMAND NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: BULLETIN BOARDS HINTS AT THE END OF THE I.C.C.
description: A top official calls it a ''transition'' phase that the Interstate Commerce Commission is going through these days. To the agency's dwindling ranks of bureaucrats, that seems to be an understatement.

title: N.C.A.A. LOSES BID FOR STAY ON TV PACT
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association suffered another setback today in its effort to retain exclusive control of college football telecasts.

title: PANEL URGES ABANDONING LONG ISLAND ACCELERATOR
description: AFEDERAL panel of physicists yesterday recommended that a halfbuilt atom smasher at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island be abandoned despite the expenditure to date of more than $200 million.

title: OVERTHRUST RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Reagan to Name Envoy to Mozambique
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Peter Jon de Vos, a career diplomat, as the first United States Ambassador to Mozambique since the Marxist Government expelled American diplomats more than two years ago.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
M.T.A. OVERSEER TO LIMIT ROLE
description: Governor Cuomo's nominee to oversee the operations of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said today that the New York City subway system is a continuing source of ''frustration to riders,'' but that his office would not handle routine rider complaints.

title: Lesley Ballantine, 84; Wrote Children's Books
description: Lesley Frost Ballantine, an author of children's books and lecturer on English literature, died Saturday at the North Fairfield Geriatric Center in Fairfield, Conn. She was 84 years old.

title: 12% Drop Reported In Vehicle Thefts
description: The number of reported motor-vehicle thefts in the city, which reached a record in 1982, declined 12.1 percent in the first five months of this year compared with the same period last year, according to a Police Department report released yesterday. From January through May this year, there were 37,606.

title: SEX TAPES ARE SAID TO SHOW U.S. AIDES
description: A lawyer who said today that he saw videotapes of sexual scenes involving Government officials later gave an unclear account of just who appeared in them.

title: O'NEILL SEEKING A TRUCE IN BATTLE OVER I-95 TRAFFIC
description: Governor William A. O'Neill of Connecticut appealed to New York for peace and patience today in the battle over where to detour trucks around the partially collapsed Connecticut Turnpike bridge here.

title: Kleindienst Gets Bar Backing
description: An Arizona bar committee urged today that Richard Kleindienst, the former United States Attorney General, be readmitted to practice as a lawyer. Mr. Kleindienst, who resigned in the Watergate scandals, was suspended from practicing law by the Arizona Supreme Court for lying under oath in an investigation by the state bar. His yearlong suspension ended May 9, but those suspended must petition the court for readmission. The bar board's support of Mr. Kleindienst's petition is not binding.

title: Gault Upset as Games End; U.S. Teams Win Relays
description: Andrei Prokofyev, ranked ninth in the world in the 110-meter hurdles last year, upset Willie Gault of the United States tonight to cap the Soviet Union's domination of the 1983 World University Games.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banks of Iowa Inc., Cedar Rapids, has elected Brian C. Scott president of its subsidiary, Banks of Iowa Computer Services Inc., replacing Brian R. Phillips, who resigned to pursue work with Allied Bancshares Inc. in Houston.

title: 2 Killed in Leftist Attack On Peruvian Party Office
description: Left-wing terrorists attacked the main headquarters of the governing Popular Action Party with bombs and submachine-gun fire tonight, killing two people and wounding 30, officials reported.

title: Castro Sends Aide to Tunisia To Discuss Arafat-Syria Split
description: A special envoy of President Fidel Castro is in Tunis to mediate a dispute between the Palestine Liberation Organization's leader, Yasir Arafat, and Syria after a revolt by guerrillas in Lebanon.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Refurbishing 3d Ave.

title: Rudis Has Links Lead After a 70
description: Paul Rudis, a 47-year-old teacher from Olympia, Wash., shot a 35,35-70, two under par, to take the firstround lead in the stroke-play portion of the 58th United States Amateur Public Links Championship today at the Hominy Hill Golf Course.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
POLISH PARLIAMENT TO SIT NEXT WEEK
description: The Polish Parliament will discuss martial law at a two-day session next week, the House Speaker, Piotr Stefanski, said tonight.

title: Steel Output Declines
description: Last week's steel output was 1.58 million tons, down seven-tenths of 1 percent from 1.59 million tons the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 12, 1983
description: International A compromise on human rights and East-West security issues is acceptable to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, according to Administration officials. Moscow has agreed informally to the compromise document and Mr. Shultz was said to be ready to recommend its approval by President Reagan. (Page A1, Column 3.) American-Chinese military ties are to be the subject when Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger visits Peking in late September or early October, according to Pentagon officials. He is to discuss possible sales of weapons to China. (A10:4-6.)

title: VICON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Decision Delayed
description: Chub Feeney, the president of the National League, reserved decision yesterday after hearing Umpire Joe West's appeal of his three-day suspension and $500 fine for shoving Joe Torre, manager of the Atlanta Braves. West, a six-year veteran, admitted that he had shoved Torre in the incident following a game June 28. Richie Phillips, attorney for the Major League Umpires Association, said West should not have put his hands on the manager, but that the penalty imposed by Feeney was too severe.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART OPENS AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: LINCOLN CENTER looks a bit dismal these days, with the strikebound New York City Opera prominent by its absence, but trust Mozart to brighten up any dull party. The Mostly Mozart Festival opened its 17th season last night at Avery Fisher Hall with a concert that went from one incandescent performance to the next. Under Gerard Schwarz, Mostly Mozart's music adviser, the orchestra played all evening with more verve and precision than would seem possible so early in the summer season. And not one but two upper-crust soloists shared the spotlight in a program that added up to an exhilarating bargain.

title: BIRDS' PHYSICAL DEVELOPMENT LINKED TO HABITAT
description: AFLORIDA biologist who transplanted the eggs of red-winged blackbirds between nests hundreds of miles apart has found that the hatchlings take on some of the physical characteristics of their foster parents rather than those of their natural parents.

title: Cup Races Off
description: Three races for foreign challengers in the America's Cup sailing eliminations were washed out today after light winds had flattened the chance of finishing. The second series of round-robin races among seven yachts from five foreign nations was extended to Friday. Australia II leads the challenger series with 10.2 points.

title: Manville Mine Investor Is Appointed Chairman
description: Peter D. Kyle, an accountant, has been named chairman and chief executive of Johns-Manville Canada, the soon-to-be-divested unit of the troubled Manville Corporation.

title: BLACK GROUP MAY BUY SHARE OF COKE BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company, once a target of boycotts by minorities seeking participation in major corporations, said it is negotiating to sell a portion of its 36 percent interest in the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York to a group of black investors led by Bruce Llewellyn, chairman of the Fedco Foods Corporation. The group includes Bill Cosby, the entertainer, and Julius Erving, the Philiadelphia 76ers basketball player.

title: LeRoux Reported In Bid for Indians
description: Buddy LeRoux was negotiating to buy 90 percent of the Cleveland Indians for $20 million last winter, five months before he signed a letter of agreement to sell his shares of the Boston Red Sox to a group including Carl Yastrzemski, a witness testified today.

title: Thrift Unit Expansion
description: The Justice Department today supported a proposal by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to relax restrictions on interstate branching by federally chartered savings and loan associations and other thrift institutions.

title: Michelin Acts in Strike
description: The Michelin Tire Company Ltd. said today that it had laid off 2,000 workers and halted tire production at its Stoke-on-Trent plant because of a strike by 1,000 workers over a proposed new system of weekend work. At present the plant only operates five days a week. A spokesman declined to estimate the financial impact of the production stoppage.

title: CALMAR STEAMSHIP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
description: Share earnings have been calculated on a pro forma basis with 5 million shares outstanding. Calmar Inc. was spun off from Diamond International on June 21.

title: PNC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SHULTZ PLEASES CAIRO BY VISIT TO BRIEF LEADERS ON MEETINGS
description: Egyptian officials were encouraged by the visit here Saturday of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, but at the same time they expressed mild disappointment that he had failed to make progress toward a withdrawal of foreign troops in Lebanon.

title: REPORT FAULTS ARMY'S TEACHING OF BASIC SKILLS
description: AN important military program for teaching soldiers basic skills in reading and mathematics has been found so deficient that the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, has recommended that all its contracts be deferred until the program is revised.

title: Entrance-Test Suit Opens in Jersey
description: Opening arguments were heard today in the case of four students accused of cheating who say that the Educational Testing Service unfairly invalidated their college entrance exam scores.

title: UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for qtr to June 24.
YANKEES LOSE, FALL TO 4TH
description: Gary Ward, Minnesota's left fielder, labored in the minors for eight years before he became a full major leaguer. At the age of 29, he is in only his third season with the Twins. The Yankees, though, have seen enough of him this season.

title: Welcome State Aid for Medicaid
description: Finally, the New York Legislature has permanently improved the way the state handles Medicaid, the Federal program for the poorest of the sick. In no other state have local governments been expected to pay so large a share (25.875 percent) of the cost. Now the state will pick up a gradually increasing share via grants that will give New York City, for example, $465 million in 1987. So far the state has shouldered only 50 percent of the burden. Now the state will pay up to $3.2 billion, which may well equal 65 percent of the non-Federal costs.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There are stalactites and stalagmites growing in my local subway station. Why?

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DEMOCRATS CAN'T HOPE FOR AN F.D.R. COALITION
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRBAGS NEED A MAJOR, 'REAL WORLD' TRYOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Curtis; The Melville Treasures; Scholars' mouths are watering, says Public Library's president happily.
description: HERMAN MELVILLE wrote his brother saying he was glad his sister-inlaw was doing so well and then, so typical of new fathers, proceeded to fill the rest of his letter with delicious exaggerations about the way in which the world celebrated the birth of his son Malcolm, ''our little phenomenon.''

title: Key Parmaceuticals New Financial Officer
description: David L. Weinberg has been named chief financial officer of Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., a big drug maker based in Miami. Mr. Weinberg replaces Ronald M. Feinberg, who resigned to pursue ''other business interests.''

title: David Allan Shepard, 80, Dies; Standard Oil and Rand Official
description: David Allan Shepard, a retired chemical engineer who had been an official of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, now Exxon, and the Rand Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: Iranian Compensation
description: Iran has paid the Bridgestone Tire Company Ltd. and the Marubeni Corporation a total of five billion yen as compensation for nationalization of their jointly owned Iranian concern - Bridgestone Iran Company Ltd. - and as repayment of loans made to it by them, Iranian Embassy sources said today.

title: Quake on Coast 'Heard' Far Away
description: A destructive earthquake that shook Coalinga, Calif., on May 2 was detected more than an hour later by instruments at Los Alamos National Laboratory. It was the first time an earthquake had been detected by low frequency sound waves at such a great distance.

title: STATES WARNED TO PREPARE FOR WIDE CUTBACK IN FOOD STAMP BENEFITS
description: The Reagan Administration has ordered states to prepare for an across-the-board reduction in food stamp benefits because funds are running low at the end of the fiscal year.

title: VIDEO TERMINALS HARMLESS TO EYE, STUDY ASSERTS
description: There is no valid scientific evidence that video display terminals - those television-like devices used by increasing millions of office workers - permanently damage vision, a panel of experts assembled by the National Research Council reported today.

title: Danes Buying U.S. Missiles
description: The Pentagon told Congress today that it intends to sell Denmark 33 antiship Harpoon missiles for $37 million.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STUART HALL CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Business and the Law; Hiring Away Legal Talent
description: NOT too long ago, the idea that a group of partners from a major law firm would pick up and move to another firm was all but unthinkable. But these days, such defections are fast and furious, creating in the process a boon for the people who find and place legal talent.

title: CONGRESS: NO LOSS IN RULING BY COURT
description: The long-running debate over legislative vetoes was once described as ''50 years of sparring between the executive and the legislature.'' Now that the Supreme Court has clearly held such devices to be unconstitutional, rhetorical flourishes have continued. Some suggest that the Supreme Court has delivered a devastating blow to Congress's ability to oversee the executive's execution of the law. Others suggest that Congress will respond by stripping the executive of important discretionary power previously granted by Congress with legislative-veto strings attached.

title: BRAZIL FAILS TO EXTEND A DEADLINE
description: The Bank for International Settlements is not prepared to extend the Friday deadline for Brazil to repay $400 million of a ''bridge loan'' owed to central banks, the bank's president, Fritz Leutwiler, said today.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $2,254,000 on the divestiture of certain banking assets in the settlement with Southeast Banking Corp.

title: U.S. Agency Wants to Spend $3.4 Million on Salvador Voting
description: The Agency for International Development today requested that Congress allow it to spend $3.4 million in aid to help El Salvador conduct its general elections later this year.

title: TASK FORCE BEGINS HEARINGS ON TEACHERS' MERIT PAY IDEA
description: A task force today began exploring the pros and cons of merit pay for exceptional teachers, a topic that has been pushed to the forefront by recent reports on the shortcomings of the nation's schools and by President Reagan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Care Corp. said its board had declared a 2-for-1 stock split, in the form of a stock dividend of new class A common stock, to be paid on Aug. 3 to shareholders of record on July 27.

title: U.S. BLAMES SALVADOR REBELS FOR FAILURE OF TALKS
description: A demand by Salvadoran rebel leaders that Costa Rica's President be a witness to talks with President Reagan's special envoy was an obstacle that prevented the talks from getting under way, United States officials said today.

title: Fusion With Mirrors
description: The ''tandem mirror'' approach to harnessing the hydrogen fusion power source of the sun has come a step closer to reality in new tests announced Friday by the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The device under development uses two electrostatic mirrors as ''plugs'' at opposite ends of a chamber in which a hot gas, or plasma, can be confined, heated and compressed until fusion occurs.

title: Michigan Agency Prices AAA Issue
description: A $130 million bond issue of the Michigan State Housing Development Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9 7/8 percent for interest-paying bonds due in 2008 and 10 percent for zero-coupon (noninterest-paying) bonds due in 2008, according to underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, contiue to deal with factual errors.

title: Brink's Jurors To Be Anonymous
description: Judge David S. Ritter of Orange County Court has ruled that all potential jurors in the Brink's triple murder and robbery trial, as well as those ultimately seated, will remain anonymous. He said in court today as the initial phase of jury selection began that he was doing so ''in the interest of protecting the privacy of the jurors and their families.''

title: Ford Sports Car
description: Next year the Ford Motor Company will offer only one two-seat sports car, the Ford EXP, it said today. The similar Mercury LN7 will be dropped. The 1984 EXP will add a turbocharger to its 1.6-liter, four-cylinder engine.

title: TWO YOUNG INNOVATORS IN JEWELRY DESIGN
description: It is a section of Manhattan entirely devoid of glamour, a midtown neighborhood packed densely with trucks, disheveled storefronts and people who lean against buildings while they drink their morning coffee and stretch. Nevertheless, the area bounded by 23d and 36th Streets and Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas is the heart of New York's costume jewelry business. Many of the city's leading costume designers have showrooms there. The factories that cast their settings are there. It is also where one can find two of the leading young costume jewelry designers working today: Marla Buck and James Murphy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EDWARD J. BRESLIN
description: Edward J. Breslin, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Mendes & Mount, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

title: MUSIC: BEACH BOYS AT PIER 44
description: WATCHING the Beach Boys perform at Pier 44 on Friday was a reminder of just how firmly most popular music is rooted in the cutural ethos of its time. Contradictorily, it was a reminder also of how the most durable rock-and-roll lives on as a folk art through the sheer power of its tunes and of the myths it enshrines.

title: Germaine Monteil In Search of Spokesman
description: Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques will begin a two-month search in September for a advertising spokesman for its Supplegen skin care products - an over 40 woman, who represents the group that is the target of the line.

title: COUNTERING FRENCH SOCIALSIM
description: When Francois Mitterrand took the reins of Government in 1981, he also took command of many French businesses by nationalizing key companies and banks.

title: FRANCE WEIGHING TROOPS FOR CHAD
description: French officials said today that the Government had not ruled out the possibility of sending troops to Chad, where an insurgency backed by Libya is under way.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DOW ADVANCES BY 8.31 IN SLOW DAY
description: Blue-chip stocks led the market upward yesterday, but trading volume was very light, reflecting continued investor concern about a possible spurt in interest rates.

title: CHINESE MOBILIZE FOR NEW FLOODING
description: China's heartland is bracing for potentially serious flooding along the Yangtze River after torrential rains last week that inundated the industrial city of Wuhan.

title: TO NOMINEE FOR NATO, TIMING SEEMS RIGHT
description: David M. Abshire, whose nomination as United States Ambassador to NATO is scheduled for a Senate vote shortly, is a believer in timing. There is, he feels, a season for everything.

title: HIROHITO, AT 82, REDUCING HIS OFFICIAL DUTIES A BIT
description: Japan's best-known marine biologist is about to slow down a bit. Most people recognize the biologist more readily as Emperor Hirohito, and today it was announced that age was forcing him to cut back his official duties. The changes are not monumental, but they nonetheless reminded Japanese - not that a reminder was needed - that Hirohito is 82 years old and has reigned longer than any of Japan's previous emperors in a line stretching back into antiquity.

title: CYCLE OF VENGEANCE HAUNTS HEBRON'S RECENT HISTORY
description: Occupied West Bank, July 11 - There were shoppers today in the casbah of this ancient Arab city, just down the road from Bethlehem. Worshipers went to the mosque at the cave of Machpelah, where the patriarch Abraham is said to be buried.

title: BAKER, FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Year-ago results reflect a 200 percent stock dividend paid May 4.

title: The U.N. Today; July 12, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Chipping the Education Gap
description: The information age will surely reward those who can operate a computer and program its memory. All students, even poets, and the poor as well as the rich deserve a chance to learn how the new machinery works. But this school computer craze can be overdone. No less than in the time of mules, life's greatest rewards will still go to those who can read, write and count.

title: GREENLANDERS FIND THE LIMITS OF DANES 'HOSPITALITY'
description: For two centuries Denmark ran its Greenland colony as a closed society. Outside of Danish fishermen, seal hunters and priests, no one was allowed into Greenland and the indigenous people were not allowed to travel beyond their Arctic land.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LAST week, when Zoran, the Yugoslav fashion designer known for his m inimalist cashmere sweatshirt dresses, declined a nomination for oneo f this year's Coty Fashion Critics Awards, he created some m uchneeded commotion in a fashion world hypnotized by the sun.

title: Dibbs Is Winner In Stormy Match
description: Eddie Dibbs fought off an upset bid by Stanislav Birner of Czechoslovakia in a stormy match at the start of the United States Pro tennis championships today.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 11.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared March 29.

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Net losses for the 6 months periods include gains of $782,000 for the latest period and $943,000 for the year-ago period from the purchase of $1.7 million face value of the company's 4 and 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures in each year.

title: 119 DIE IN ECUADOR AIRLINE CRASH
description: An Ecuadorean jetliner struck a mountain and exploded while trying to land at the Andes city of Cuenca today, killing all 119 people aboard.

title: A BIRD IN THE HAND
description: If Ronald Reagan wants to insure his re-election in 1984, his best policy would be an agreement with Moscow to limit deployment of medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: SHULTZ SUPPORTING COMPROMISE TERMS AT EAST-WEST TALK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has decided to recommend to President Reagan that the United States agree to a compromise document on East-West human rights and security issues, Administration officials said today.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY APPROVES BILLS TO END 'NO FAULT' CAR INSURANCE
description: The New Jersey Assembly today passed a package of bills that would eliminate the state's ''no fault'' automobile insurance system, as well as compulsory liability insurance, and establish an open market in which insurance companies would be able to set their own rates, subject to review by the Insurance Commissioner.

title: Strawberry Hits Slider In the Clutch
description: When Darryl Strawberry went to bat for the Mets in the eighth inning of Sunday's game, many in the crowd of 17,666 at Shea Stadium booed.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORP (MT LEBANON,PA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CONGRESS FINDS VOTERS CONCERNED ABOUT ISSUE
description: Congressmen returning to Capitol Hill today from the Fourth of July recess said that many of their constituents were curious and concerned about reports that Ronald Reagan's staff used documents from the Carter White House in the 1980 campaign. So far, they say, Mr. Reagan is not being blamed personally, but that could change if more evidence is uncovered.

title: J. WOLFE CHASSEN
description: J. Wolfe Chassen, a former judge of the New York City Criminal Court, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 75 years old and a former resident of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Persian Gulf Spill Is Called Catastrophic
description: The oil spill in the Persian Gulf has caused ''catastrophic pollution'' that threatens to cause lasting damage to fresh water supplies and marine life, a World Wildlife Fund report said today.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. This is the opener of a three-game series between the teams with the worst records in the National League. The series features the last New York appearance of Johnny Bench, who has announced that he will retire after the season. Bench will be honored in pregame ceremonies tomorrow night. (Television -Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. The Yankees look for their third victory of the season over Frank Viola, the former St. John's star. He will be opposed by Matt Keough, who has won only one of three decisions since joining New York in a trade with Oakland last month. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Golf United States Amateur Public Links Championship, at Hominy Hill Golf Club, Colts Neck, N.J., 7 A.M. This is the second day of medal-play qualifying for match play, which begins tomorrow. Michelob New York State Open, at Grossingers Country Club, Grossingers, N.Y., 8 A.M. This is the second round of a 54-hole stroke-play tournament.

title: LING-LING: IS SHE OR ISN'T SHE?
description: The baby watch has begun again at the National Zoo. Lester Benjamin, a volunteer, is checking each day to see if the panda Ling-Ling loses her appetite, is lethargic or starts building a nest.

title: WROTE PRINCIPALLY FOR THEATER
description: Werner Egk, a prominent German composer, died of heart disease Sunday in Inning, West Germany, his family said yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 4.
Books Of The Times
description: THE PASSIONATE WAR. The Narrative History of the Spanish Civil War. By Peter Wyden. 574 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Continental Group
description: The Continental Group announced the sale of six plants that manufacture plastic soft-drink bottles to the Tricoast Holding Corporation for about $32 million. The transaction will not have a material impact on earnings, it said. The plants, in California, Washington, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Texas, make two-liter, oneliter and half-liter containers.

title: 6-WEEK PLUNGE IN BLOOD SUPPLY ALARMS OFFICIALS
description: The director of the Greater New York Blood Program said yesterday that there had been a sharp drop in blood donations over the last six weeks, creating a shortage that might force hospitals to forgo some surgery.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS RETIRES 70 OF ITS TOP EXECUTIVES
description: British Airways, the Government-owned carrier, announced today that 70 top executives were being retired early - 20 percent of its senior management.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a net gain of $2.4 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of certain mortgage loan servicing by an unconsolidated subsidiary. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1982 and a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1983.

title: Bradshaw Out of Action
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers placed the veteran star quarterback Terry Bradshaw on the physically-unable-to-perform list yesterday.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Bridge: New Yorker, 16, Is Lauded As Top High School Player
description: Parents have been known to discourage their children from playing bridge, fearing that it would damage academic grades. But experience has shown that bridge-playing complements academic skills. This is recognized by an annual award to the Scholastic King of Bridge given by the International Palace of Sports in North Webster, Ind., to the outstanding bridge player among graduating high school seniors.

title: OFFICIALS TESTIFY ON WAY TO STOP 'CRIME FAMILIES'
