description: More resources, stricter laws and greater coordination to combat organized crime were urged at a special hearing conducted in Manhattan yesterday by the United States Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: LEGAL BAR REMAINS TO CSX BID
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused yesterday to lift an order of a Federal appeals court that has temporarily blocked the CSX Corporation from acquiring the tendered shares of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation in a deal valued at $1.07 billion.

title: MUSIC: ANTHEIL AND YEATS
description: George Antheil seems destined to go down in history as one of those composers whose music is more talked about than performed. Antheil, the self-described ''bad boy of music,'' lived until 1959, but he is best remembered for an atypical work he produced in his early 20's: the once sensational ''Ballet Mecanique.''

title: TV: MEN WITHOUT JOBS
description: WHAT price unemployment? It's hard to quantify the human cost. It's even harder to say anything new about it, although ''Our Times With Bill Moyers'' succeeds tonight to a remarkable degree. In Gadsden, Ala., Mr. Moyers finds that unemployment has changed the ways in which some Americans now view their lives. The CBS program will be seen on Channel 2 at 8:30 P.M.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''About one-third of the motormen are what I call cowboys.'' - Harry M. Williamson, a consultant to the M.T.A.(A1:1.)

title: PENTAGON AUDIT FINDS SHARP PRICE INCREASE FOR PARTS
description: A simple three-inch steel bolt that had a list price of 67 cents cost the Defense Department $17.59 upon delivery. Military procurement officers paid $57.52 for a small bushing originally priced at $2.83.

title: SUN BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
F.B.I. MOVES TO GET DIRECT ACCESS TO ARCHIVES IN CAMPAIGN INQUIRY
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation moved today to gain direct access to documents in the Reagan archives at Stanford University that could be pertinent to its inquiry into the 1980 Presidential campaign, according to Government officials.

title: Turkey Clears 13 Hangings
description: The military appeals court today approved 13 sentences to death by hanging and more than 250 jail terms for people convicted of taking part in riots in the southern city of Karamanmaras in 1978. More than 100 people died in the riots between mainly Sunni Moslem rightists and mostly Alawite Moslem leftists.

title: The Fed Needs More Than Lectures
description: With the nation just beginning to appreciate the economic recovery, some financial authorities already talk about applying the brakes to keep inflation down. The 12 members of the Federal Reserve System's Open Market Committee, meeting in Washington today and tomorrow, must weigh this advice as they shape monetary policy for the weeks and months ahead. It is always a difficult task, made even harder now by the White House.

title: CITY OPERA AND MUSICIANS TO RESUME TALKS
description: A resumption of negotiations between the New York City Opera and its striking orchestra has been set for 4 P.M. tomorrow in the law offices of Leonard Leibowitz, chief negotiator for the musicians.

title: Alaska's Native Corporations
description: There is a roller-coaster quality to the collective business performance of the native-owned corporations that were created 12 years ago by the Alaska Native Claim Settlement Act.

title: Kevin Porter Named
description: The former pro basketball star Kevin Porter has been named head coach at his alma mater, St. Francis College of Loretto, Pa. Porter, 33, succeeds a former college teammate, David Magarity, whose contract was allowed to expire after last season.

title: N.A.A.C.P. BOARD REBUFFS CHAIRMAN IN HER BATTLE WITH HOOKS
description: An investigation of charges of mismanagement against the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People shows that they are ''not substantiated by the facts,'' the N.A.A.C.P. board said today.

title: Williams, Bucs at Odds
description: Training camps of other N.F.L. teams will be opening during the next week, but Doug Williams, the Tampa Bay quarterback, says he will not be there. The Buccaneers' management, in turn, has said its contract offer will be withdrawn if Williams is not present for the first practice, on Friday.

title: Tennessee Bank Failure
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had arranged the takeover of the failed First Central Bank of Smithville, Tenn., by the City Bank and Trust Company of McMinnville, Tenn.

title: Conventional vs. Nuclear Deterrence
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT ORDERS CHANGES IN BOOK ADS
description: A Federal judge has ordered a publisher to change its advertising and method of presenting two volumes of short stories by Louis L'Amour, the best-selling writer of western novels. The case could widen the power of some authors to control the way their books are marketed.

title: U.S. SUES ALABAMA OVER 'DUAL SYSTEM' ON RACE IN SCHOOLS
description: The Reagan Administration filed its first school desegregation suit today, asking a Federal judge to dismantle what it said was a ''dual system'' of public colleges for blacks and whites in Alabama.

title: Dow Jones Net Rises
description: Dow Jones & Company reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of this year increased 20.4 percent, to $28.9 milion, or 45 cents a share, from $24 million, or 38 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues advanced 19.3 percent, to $219 million, from $183.6 illion. The Wall Street Journal reported advertising linage increases on a per-issue basis of 8.3 percent for the latest three months.

title: HOW NOT TO REACT TO SOVIET ANTI-SEMITISM
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAD SAYS IT HAS RETAKEN EASTERN OASIS
description: The Government said tonight that its troops, pressing a counteroffensive begun over the weekend, had retaken an eastern oasis lost to Libyan-backed insurgents on Friday.

title: COMMITTEE SEEKS RECALL OF ATLANTIC CITY'S MAYOR
description: A year after this city shifted from a commission to a mayor-and-council form of government in an effort to deal more effectively with problems caused by the introduction of casinos, the Mayor is the subject of a recall movement.

title: Space Shuttle Ants Are Found Dead
description: The ants sent into orbit aboard the space shuttle Challenger as part of a science project at two Camden, N.J., high schools all died, students in the project said yesterday. The ants may have died of dehydration on the ground before or after their journey into space last month, the students said.

title: Radiologist, 36, Is Found Dead
description: The body of a 36-year-old radiology resident at St. Vincent's Hospital was found Sunday in the 16th-floor compactor room of an apartment building at 165 West End Avenue, the police said yesterday.

title: Nationwide Advertising Sold to Gund Brothers
description: Theodore J. Stepien, 57-year-old president and owner of Nationwide Advertising Service, Cleveland, the country's largest independent recruitment advertising agency, has sold his business to the Gund brothers, Gordon and George 3d, who own the largest single block of stock in Amertrust, formerly Cleveland Trust.

title: An Appraisal
description: This is a city, as busy and prosperous as any in Westchester County, and it is also a suburb, as organized around the automobile as it could possibly be.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
EMBARRASSING NIGHT IN BOXING
description: I t was a club fight, typical of those held in dozens of small arenas across the country every week. The result, according to boxing observers, was also typical. When a bout is close, the decision more often than not is awarded to the hometown fighter or the one who is considered on the way up. Call it the home-ring advantage, although this practice will never be mentioned in any discussion of boxing rules.

title: WEINBERGER PLANNING TO VISIT CHINA IN THE FALL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger plans to visit China in late September or early October to expand United States military relations with the country, Defense Department officials disclosed today.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CO (NYC) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Arson Indictments Said to Accuse 8
description: Eight people - including two lawyers, three landlords and an insurance agent - have been indicted on Federal racketeering and fraud charges in connection with an arson-for-profit ring that set fires in 37 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, investigators said yesterday.

title: ILLINOIS CASE MISTRIAL DECLARED
description: Federal District Judge John A. Nordberg granted a mistrial today to Joseph C. Calandra, one of four men accused by the Government of supplying false laboratory reports on the toxic and cancer-causing effects of four drugs or pesticides.

title: OWNER PULLS THE PLUG ON ULSTER COUNTY LAKE
description: John Rao recalls stepping out of his Tillson Lake vacation home on a recent morning, shaking his head to see if there were some mistake and hurrying back to tell his wife the rather alarming news: ''The lake is gone.''

title: Phils Win in 11th On Schmidt's Slam
description: Mike Schmidt's 11th-inning grand slam, giving him six runs batted in for the game, powered the Philadelphia Phillies to an 11-7 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: Advertising; Direct Marketing Bonanza
description: ''I wouldn't touch 60 seconds on the Super Bowl,'' said Sheldon Hechtman, media specialist. ''The people watching it won't get up. They don't want to be interrupted.''

title: 'American Passion' Closes
description: ''American Passion,'' the musical by Fred Burch and Willie Fong Young, has closed after one performance at the Joyce Theater. Directed and choreographed by Patricia Birch, the play ran for 42 previews.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Strawberry Fields

title: Baldwin Shares Plunge $1.125
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation resumed trading yesterday for the first time since June 30, and shares of the diversified financial services company plunged $1.125, to $7.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Chicago Bank Insolvency
description: The Office of the Comptroller of Currency announced today that the Union National Bank of Chicago had been declared insolvent, and that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had been appointed as receiver.

title: BROOKLYN GAGS ON AID
description: I see that the Regional Plan Association has put forward yet another bold scheme for the revitalization of downtown Brooklyn. While I am hardly qualified to comment on the bulk of the association's no-doubt imaginative proposals - beyond remarking, as a longtime Brooklyn resident, that imaginative proposals for the area's redevelopment seem to occur with marginally greater frequency than eclipses of the sun and with about as much effect -my eye was irresistibly drawn to the sentences advocating new housing for the district south of Fulton Street, which is where I happen to live.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANALIA

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid on May 23.

title: 'THE GREY FOX,' A WESTERN
description: ''THE GREY FOX,'' Phillip Borsos's Canadian film that opens today at the Baronet, is a gentle, intelligent, very leisurely paced western with one terrific asset: Richard Farnsworth.

title: SLICER FOR FRENCH FRYING
description: IT'S the time of year when backyard gardens and commercial vegetable farms become virtual Mount St. Helenses of zucchini, spewing those bent green tubes in every direction. Using them up over the next few months is one of the major culinary challenges of summer.

title: Solomon Advances In Court Comeback
description: Harold Solomon, an invited guest to Thierry Tulasne's 20th birthday party, beat the Frenchman tonight in the first round of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

title: AMERITRUST CORP OF CLEVELAND reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Explosion Kills 3 in Belgium
description: Three people were killed today in an explosion followed by a fire in a gunpowder factory, the police said. The cause of the explosion was not known and the police said it was under investigation.

title: Winter Wheat Harvest Is Seen as Near Record
description: The nation's winter wheat farmers, although idling nearly a fifth of their land, will harvest 1.94 billion bushels this year, the third-largest crop on record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Iceberg Lettuce (Again)
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Some years ago I wrote to protest the vendetta against iceberg lettuce by The Times.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Sporting With Hunger
description: In the rush before the August break, the House and Senate have passed dissimilar supplemental spending bills to keep a variety of programs alive through the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. The Senate has appointed conferees to resolve them, the House hasn't yet and the President has threatened to veto the result, whatever it is. Probably the most painful aspect of the floundering concerns hunger.

title: Haddad Urges Israel to Give Militia More Freedom to Act
description: The commander of an Israeli-backed militia in southern Lebanon, Maj. Saad Haddad, urged Israel today to pull back in Lebanon and leave it to his troops to keep terrorists away from the Israeli border.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Challenge 12 Triumphs
description: The Australian yachts Advance and Challenge 12 exchanged the lead twice today in the America's Cup eliminations before Challenge 12 won by 3 minutes 25 seconds.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect the merger with Bancshares of North Carolina Inc.

title: Hertz Car Orders
description: Frank A. Olson, the chairman of the Hertz Corporation, said that the company had tentative plans to place its biggest order for new cars and trucks in its history for the 1984 model year. He said that the company at this time would not release specifics on the models and number of cars for competitive reasons. He added that the company's car rental transactions had been at or near record levels for more than four months.

title: 1. Bedroom Moonlight
description: Most little children sleep more securely if a night light is casting a soft glow. The crescent-shaped porcelain man in the moon makes a particularly charming light, with its soft blue and white tones and its star-shaped dangling baby figure. Made by Enesco, it is $30 at Serendipity 3, 225 East 60th Street.

title: Prices Continue to Tumble
description: Prices of fixed-income securities continued to tumble yesterday as investors remained on the sidelines in expectation of further rises in interest rates.

title: Hijacker Slain, Tass Says, In a Foiled Attempt
description: The crew and passengers of a Soviet airliner killed one hijacker and overpowered another after the two threatened to blow up the plane if they were not flown out of the country, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS PLANS BIG MERGER
description: In a new expansion of its financial empire, the American Express Company announced yesterday that it would acquire a major marketer of mutual funds and life insurance for $1 billion.

title: 2 CEREMONIES IN BROOKLYN, AND 2 SIDES OF KOCH
description: He used a wood-handled shovel at one ground-breaking, a giant Bucyrus-Erie backhoe at the other. Within an hour yesterday, Mayor Koch dug up earth in two very different parts of Brooklyn and displayed two very different facets of his mayoral style.

title: PUBLIC WORKS WILL NOT CURE OUR ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: I-95 COULD REOPEN FOR CARS IN WEEK
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that it would be ''a week on the outside'' before the partly collapsed turnpike bridge near Greenwich would be reopened for cars. But he said repairs to accommodate trucks could take much longer.

title: PASTORE'S 6-HITTER STOPS METS
description: In the opener of a series that could help determine the National League's worst team, the Mets lost to the Cincinnati Reds last night, 6-2, before 11,800 fans at Shea Stadium. The Mets are last in the East and the Reds are last in the West.

title: Losses Deepen At British Steel
description: The state-owned British Steel Corporation, citing low worldwide demand for steel products, reported today that it lost 386 million, or about $591 million, for the year ended March 31.

title: IN PEKING, NEW TALKS ON HONG KONG
description: China and Britain opened a fresh round of confidential talks today concerning the future of Hong Kong after the British lease over most of the colony expires in 1997.

title: Peru Mobilizes 15,000 To Fight Maoist Rebels
description: The Government mobilized 15,000 police officers today and a national police official said more than 500 people were picked up for questioning within hours after the Monday night attack by Maoist guerrrillas on the headquarters of the Government centrist party.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alaska Housing Finance Corp. said it would offer between $50 million and $100 million of state-assisted mortgage bonds on July 27, through Salomon Brothers, and an as yet undetermined amount of tax-exempt veterans mortgage bonds, which will be sold through competitive bidding.

title: New Service Magazine
description: The preview of a new service magazine for black women called Elancee will be coming out of Chicago in August with Thom Rivers as publisher. Subtitled ''The Magazine for Career Direction and Successful Living,'' it will have a $2 cover price and a 200,000 rate base. Mr. Rivers will charge $5,000 for a four-color page and $3,400 for black and white. Offices are at 600 S. Dearborn Street, Suite 704, Chicago, 60605.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Stamford Conn., has appointed Dr. William N. Knopka director of product and process development in its chemical research division.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Stern & Ingalls Account
description: Stern & Ingalls, a recently opened New York joint venture of Boston and Cleveland ad agencies, will be doing the advertising for Jacques Cohen Ltd., importer of women's casual shoes. According to a spokesman for Ingalls Associates, the account will bill more than $1 million and much of the money will be going to promote the Jacques Cohen brand name. The account was formerly handled by Shriber Associates.

title: TALKS RESUMING TODAY IN STRIKE AT CITY OPERA
description: Both sides in the deadlocked dispute between the New York City Opera and the striking orchestra prepared yesterday for the resumption of talks today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Citizens and Southern Corp. declared a 2-for-1 stock split, payable on Aug. 15 to shareholders of record on July 29.

title: LOPSIDED ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: The Western industrialized world is entering a period of lopsided economic recovery with the United States and Japanese economies likely to perform significantly better during the next 18 months than those of Western Europe, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its semiannual forecast released today.

title: JOHN BRANCA HEADS SPORTS COMMISSION
description: John Branca, an Assemblyman from Westchester County, was named by Governor Cuomo today to be the chairman of the State Athletic Commission, which regulates boxing and wrestling in New York State. Mr. Branca will head a three-man commission that, the Governor said, will have entirely new membership.

title: TWO GOVERNORS WOULD KEEP COST OF TEACHER RAISES IN STATES
description: Two Governors said today that the Federal role in merit pay for teachers should be to provide leadership, with actual costs borne by the states and local school districts.

title: Choice for Mediation Board
description: President Reagan said today he would nominate Helen M. Witt, a private arbitrator, to be a member of the National Mediation Board. She is a lawyer who has been involved in arbitration in the steel industry.

title: India's I.M.F. Loan
description: India will not have to draw on the full share of its loan from the International Monetary Fund this year because of growing foreign exchange reserves, according to India's Finance Minister, Pranab K. Mukherjee. He said on Monday that India would pass up $320 million of the $1.6 billion it could have drawn this year in its four-year loan program totaling $5.6 billion.

title: REAGAN'S SHINING HOUR IN A COLLEGE SCRIMMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN WOULD BAR OFFICIALS FROM WRITING SCHOOL PRAYERS
description: WASHINGTON July 12 - President Reagan, in an effort to end disagreement among advocates of a Constitutional amendment for periods for voluntary school prayer, today proposed language that would bar Federal or state officials from composing specific prayers for students.

title: Cuomo Press Aide Named to U.D.C.
description: Peter J. Johnson, a press aide to Governor Cuomo, has been appointed vice president for public affairs for the state's Urban Development Corporation, replacing Howard Brock, who has resigned, the corporation's president and chairman, William J. Stern, said yesterday.

title: Shell to Begin New Atlantic Well
description: A Federal official said that the Shell Oil Company would begin drilling this month for oil and gas in new territory in deep waters off the Middle Atlantic coast.

title: Gas Decontrol Survives a Test
description: President Reagan's plan to end Federal price ceilings on all of the nation's natural gas survived a crucial test in the House today.

title: GLOBE THEATER SITE DEDICATED
description: The actor-director Sam Wanamaker saw a long held dream take shape today with the dedication of the site on which he intends to re-create Shakespeare's Globe Theater.

title: Ralph Hanover Favorite in Pace
description: Ralph Hanover, winner of six of eight starts this year, including the Messenger Stakes, was made the early line 3-1 favorite today for Friday night's $1.2 million Meadowlands Pace.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER UP 20.9% IN QUARTER
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper producer, reported yesterday that a pretax gain of $15.7 million from the sale of land in Okaloosa County, Fla., caused net income in the second quarter to increase 20.9 percent, to $49.8 million, or 88 cents a share, from $41.2 million, or 70 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: STATE BOND ISSUE FOR ROAD REPAIR VOTED IN ALBANY
description: The Senate gave final legislative passage today to Governor Cuomo's $1.25 billion ''Rebuild New York Bond Issue'' for transportation improvement, amid warnings that voters would reject the bond issue in November unless they were told in detail what the money would be spent on.

title: British Bank Plans Cuts
description: The Midland Bank P.L.C. plans to close 150 branches and reduce its staff by 3,000 employees in the next three years, a spokesman said today. The bank currently has 2,568 branches and 49,800 employees. Barclays Bank recently announced plans for the early retirement of 350 managers, the downgrading of 700 branches and the closing of 150 others.

title: HERITAGE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BACKBONE OF ALLEGHANY IS THE I.D.S. FUND GROUP
description: Beginning in 1940, salesmen from Investors Diversified Services Inc. fanned out through America, urging people to save for their future by buying mutual funds. The pitch worked, and through the 1960's and early 1970's the company was the nation's largest mutual fund group.

title: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $186,000 for the quarter and $304,000 for the year.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
A BRITISH OPEN FOR CAREFUL DRIVERS
description: Lee Trevino, twice the winner of the British Open, approached Keith Mackenzie, secretary of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, with a proposition today: ''When you mow this place after the tournament, sell me a half-interest in the balls you find.''

title: AIDE ACKNOWLEDGES WASTE IN PENTAGON SPENDING
description: Deputy Defense Secretary W. Paul Thayer acknowledged today that the Pentagon suffered from ''waste and abuse'' and other mismanagement, but he denied that Reagan Administration officials had been lax in correcting it.

title: STRIKE CASUALTIES: VOICES AND CAREERS
description: It was a wonderful part for him, ''absolutely perfect in every note,'' and it was to be sung on an important occasion: the opening night of the New York City Opera season. For Jon Fredric West, who was scheduled to sing the role of Calaf in ''Turandot'' last Thursday, the engagement represented a significant moment in his career.

title: Geoffrey Bocca Is Dead at 59; British Novelist and Historian
description: Geoffrey Bocca, a British author who lived part time in the United States for many years, died in London last Thursday. He was 59 years old.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest quarter included the operations of Girard Bank and Girard Bank Delaware & Mortgage Trust which were acquired on April 6.

title: DOZENS HURT IN ORANGE DAY PARADE
description: Thousands of Protestants marched in Northern Ireland's Orange Day parades today after overnight street battles injured more than two dozen police officers.

title: MEANING OF ITALY'S VOTE
description: Monica Vitti, the Italian actress, was famous for her stubborn request to photographers. She would personally review negatives and burn the ones she did not like. I know of many Italian politicans who would be glad to do just that with the June 26 ballots. To them, the result was the unflattering picture of something moving, taken at its worst moment.

title: Suspect Added In Cannon Case
description: An electrician who officials believed was the printer of $6 million in bogus $100 bills turned himself in today. He was the sixth suspect in what officials called the most extensive counterfeiting ring ever in this country.

title: Ovett Wins 1,500 With Late Sprint
description: Steve Ovett of Britain, the world-record holder, tagged behind until a final stretch sprint and won the 1,500-meter event at the Fanny Blankers-Koen games tonight.

title: HIS SPECIALTY: QUALITY COPPER COOKWARE
description: nonsense businessman, is not one to crow about how long he has been influential in the American cookware industry as an importer of fine French pots, pans and other cooking utensils. Suffice it to say that if Calvin Coolidge had ever looked for a heavy-gauge copper saucepan for the White House kitchen, Mr. Lamalle would have been the man to see.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEN OF THE CLOTH

title: Stock Index Futures Set
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a Chicago Mercantile Exchange proposal to trade a Standard and Poor's 100 stock price index. The index is a capitalization-weighted measure of the market value of 100 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, the agency said. Delivery under the contract will be by cash settlement only.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $67,000. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 1.

title: DANCE: FRENCH TROUPE AT NORTH CAROLINA FESTIVAL
description: The American Dance Festival has selected and invited five French modern-dance companies to make their American debut at the festival and Monday night's opening by the Ballet Theatre de l'Arche started the series with great success.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted for a 20 percent stock distribution paid May 27,1983.

title: JAPAN'S SCHOOLS: NOT VERY MUCH U.S. CAN BORROW
description: Japanese schools are so closely tied to the culture and economy they serve that the question of what American educators might borrow is complex.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MALCOLM MCLAREN was the proprietor of a trendy London boutique called Sex in the mid-1970's when he collided head on with the emergence of the new punk-rock subculture and encouraged a band called the Sex Pistols to become its avatars. Since then, Mr. McLaren has become one of pop's most vocal and outspoken trend setters. He has spent much of the last two years making on-location recordings of Afro-Cuban ritual drumming, East African and South African tribal music, black rapping and break-dancing crews in the South Bronx and other vernacular dance music. These recordings are the basic materials of his new Island album called ''Duck Rock.''

title: How to Word-Process Congress
description: Senator James Exon, the Nebraska Democrat, may think the way to protect small businesses from ''unfair treatment and abusive marketing practices'' is by passing the proposed Office Machine and Equipment Dealers Act. But the bill looks more like unnecessary special-interest legislation that could set an ugly example for other groups eager to squash competition.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-3 stock split going to holders of record July 18.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes income of $256,116 from discontinued operations.

title: 'THE FIRST TIME,' CAMPUS FUN
description: AT Blossom College, the women outnumber the men eight to one. And when it comes to experience with the opposite sex, a freshman named Charlie Lichtenstein, whose true love is the movies, is outnumbered by practically everyone on campus.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $130,000,000, or $1.23 a share, from an accounting change.

title: Film Maker Covered Up, Coast Grand Jury Told
description: Witnesses before a grand jury testified that the makers of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' tried to cover up the illegal employment of two young children. The children and the actor Vic Morrow were later killed in a filming accident.

title: LET'S USE U.S. EDGE IN AFRICA
description: The Soviet Union is not a giant in Africa. The Reagan Administration's focus on Cuban and Soviet influence in Africa is misplaced. Washington's decision to double military aid to ''friendly'' African countries is misguided.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 30.

title: DOW LOSES 17.02, FALLS BELOW 1,200
description: Interest rate jitters caused stock market prices to plunge yesterday. In a relatively light trading session, the closely watched Dow Jones industrial average closed below the 1,200 level for the first time since June 10, dropping by 17.02, to 1,198.52, on volume of 70.2 million shares.

title: Tend Your Economies, U.N. Chief Tells Poor
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today urged third-world nations to improve their own economies before seeking help from the rich.

title: HOW STAFF OF A HOUSE SUBCOMMITTEE BEGAN INQUIRY ON CARTER BRIEFING DATA
description: John M. Fitzgerald was browsing through the newspaper one morning last month when an op-ed column by Jody Powell caught his eye.

title: A Lawyer's Worth and Duty
description: What is the measure - and obligation - of a court-appointed lawyer in a serious criminal case? The Supreme Court has grappled with the question but produced no definitive answer.

title: IN WALES, CRESCENDO OF ENNUI
description: Two organists sweltered and yawned in the summer heat today, playing what some people consider the world's most boring piece of music.

title: PHILS SWEEP BRAVES, TAKE LEAD IN EAST
description: Ozzie Virgil raced home from second on Glenn Hubbard's throwing error at second base in the ninth inning to cap a three-run rally as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Braves, 7-6, in the second game and swept a doubleheader tonight.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LIKE most dedicated cooks, I feel strongly about the proper procedures in serving food. Not the least of these is that cold food should be served well chilled on chilled plates, iced foods served directly from the freezer on plates that have been stored in the freezer and hot foods served piping hot on hot dishes. Which brings us to lukewarm foods, which should be served at room temperature or slightly warmer.

title: '84 Education Budget Assailed
description: President Reagan's proposed 1984 education budget is 13 percent less than the 1983 education budget approved by Congress and the reduction would especially hurt members of minority groups and women, the Federal Commission on Civil Rights asserted today.

title: Chrysler Plans Minivan
description: TheChrysler Corporation's minivan will go on sale early next January for about $10,000, Joseph A. Campana, Chrysler's vice president of marketing, said today. The front-wheeldrive vehicle, the first domestically produced small van, will be powered by a four-cylinder engine and get an estimated 25 miles a gallon in the city and 40 on the highway, he said. The General Motors Corporation plans a rear-wheel-drive small van for introduction in 1985, followed by the Ford Motor Company in 1986.

title: SCREEN: SAUL LANDAU DOCUMENTARIES
description: TWO Saul Landau documentaries, ''Quest for Power: Sketches of the American New Right'' and ''Target Nicaragua: Inside a Covert War,'' comprise the new program opening a special one-week engagement at the Film Forum today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Who would eat An egg you fry On the sidewalk In July?

title: PENTAIR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Ex-Congressman Aaron Ford Dies After Auto Strikes Tree
description: Aaron Ford, a lawyer who served four terms in Congress in the 1930's and early 40's, died Friday night after he was involved in an automobile accident. He was 80 years old.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
On Myasthenia Gravis
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: With regard to Jane Brody's Personal Health column of June 15, I would like to bring to the attention of your readers the fact that people with myasthenia gravis can receive a wide range of medical and related services at no direct charge to them at any of some 230 Muscular Dystrophy Association clinics throughout the country.

title: M.P.'s Seize 6 Women Protesting at a Depot
description: Six women demonstrating against the nuclear arms race outside the gates of the Seneca Army Depot were arrested on trespassing charges by riot-clad military policemen and detained for two hours on the post, a spokesman for the depot said early this morning.

title: Amana Accord
description: The manufacturer of Amana Radarange microwave ovens has agreed to stop saying that the appliance is the only brand to pass ''torture tests,'' the Federal Trade Commission says.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Accord Is Reached In Co-op Evictions
description: The State Attorney General's office yesterday announced a courtapproved agreement between the Attorney General and a division of the American Invsco Corporation that would require the company to provide the grounds and documentary evidence for seeking to evict any tenants from a luxury East Side building that has been converted to a cooperative.

title: 21 Injured in Explosion At a Plant in Louisiana
description: A storage tank exploded in flames today at a Du Pont Company chemical plant, injuring 21 workers, eight of them seriously, and forcing the plant's evacuation, the state police said.

title: 4 HOMERS HELP BLUE JAYS TOP ROYALS, 9-6
description: Willie Upshaw hit a tiebreaking two-run single in Toronto's three-run eighth inning tonight, and the Blue Jays got home runs from Barry Bonnell, George Bell, Buck Martinez and Dave Collins to beat Royals, 9-6, for their fifth straight victory.

title: COMING OF AGE
description: Around the house we always call it ''the column.'' Not The Column with capital letters, just ''the column,'' though we don't use quotation marks when we talk.

title: TWO KINDS OF EQUALITY IN PENSION PAYMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY CAR DEALERS ARE SMILING
description: Karen and John Niebling decided two years ago that they needed a new car. But when they piled their two children into their 1977 Chevrolet Malibu and made the rounds of dealers they were shocked - not by high sticker prices but by high interest rates on new-car loans.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $450,000 from the settlement of litigation. c-Net loss.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 13, 1983; Companies
description: American Express will acquire Investors Diversified Services, the principal subsidiary of Alleghany, for $1 billion. The acquisition will add substantially to American Express's insurance and stock sales. (Page A1.) Some analysts feel I.D.S. has successfully diversified and may be on the rebound. (D21.) The acquisition symbolizes the vast changes under way in the American financial system. (D21.)

title: STUDY OF NATURAL SUBSTANCE BEGINS IN EFFORT TO FIGHT IMMUNE DISEASE
description: Researchers at the National Institutes of Health have begun preliminary experiments on AIDS patients to determine if a naturally occurring substance could be used to treat the usually fatal disease. The substance, called interleukin-2, is so named because it is derived from a type of leukocyte, or white blood cell.

title: HOUSE LEADERS OBJECT TO INQUIRY ON CAMPAIGN AS PANEL PRESSES ON
description: House Democratic leaders said today that a subcommittee's investigation of conduct in the 1980 Presidential campaign would be perceived as partisan and divert attention from the fundamental flaws of the Reagan Presidency.

title: DECISION LETS TRUSTS AWARD SCHOLARSHIPS TO MALES ONLY
description: The state's highest court ruled today that charitable trusts could award scholarships on the basis of sex, but that public schools could not participate in making the awards.

title: GIVING PICNICS A SHARP LITERARY FLAVOR
description: ONE evening last winter, when a testy wind rattled the windows and the thermometer plunged near zero, I tried to forget the razor cold by reading a favorite novel for the fifth time. It was ''Ada,'' Vladimir Nabokov's chronicle of the love affairs of a family of Russian aristocrats. Drifting through an enchanted summer at the Veens' country estate, I came to ''a picturesque glade in an old pinewood cut by ravishingly lovely ravines.''

title: MATTEL RESHUFFLES ITS ELECTRONICS UNIT
description: Mattel Inc., which has been badly hurt by the slump in the sales of video games, announced yesterday that it was replacing the management of its electronics subsidiary, which includes Intellivision. Last month Mattel laid off about 260 office workers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times yester- day on the particle accelerator pro- gram at Brookhaven National Labo- ratory misstated part of a subcommit- tee recommendation of the High Energy Physics Advisory Panel of the Department of Energy. In urging the development of a larger, more power- ful machine than the one now being built, the panel left open the question of who would build it.

title: RIGHTS LEADERS SEE U.S. SUIT IN ALABAMA AS A POLITICAL ACT
description: Civil rights leaders said today that the Reagan Administration's school desegregation lawsuit against Alabama was a political move designed to soften criticism that President Reagan was an enemy of civil rights.

title: Data General Pact
description: The Data General Corporation said it had signed agreements with three independent electronics distributors that will allow those concerns to sell Data General Nova 4-family computer systems and peripherals. The distributors selected were Scweber Electronics of Westbury, L.I., Almac Electronics of Bellevue, Wash., and RAE of Vancouver. Separately, Data General announced the introduction of a new shipment program, called Data General Express, that will allow terminals and printers to be shipped within 48 hours after receipt of telephone orders.

title: Reverse Progress
description: A month ago, Howard Davis Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I., was the secondranked lightweight contender of the World Boxing Council, rated behind Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico and ahead of Roberto Elizondo of Corpus Christi, Tex. Then, in one of his finest efforts as a pro, Davis knocked out fourth-ranked Greg Coverson.

title: Good Numbers
description: Paul Hammond, a 29-year-old goalie for Team America in the North American Soccer League, is pleased with the performances of both himself and the newly formed franchise that was created to form the nucleus of the team that will represent the United States in international competitions, such as the World Cup.

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $71,000 from an insurance claim and expenses of $64,000 related to a merger.

title: U.S. TAKES A STEP TO PROMPT POLES TO FREE PRISONERS
description: The United States has told Poland that it would take steps to relax some of the sanctions imposed at the time martial law was declared in 1981 if Warsaw released a significant number of political prisoners, it was reported today.

title: Banks Put Pressure On Brazil
description: Brazil is coming under increasing pressure to reach agreement with the International Monetary Fund on modifying the nation's economic program, government officials, economists and monetary sources said yesterday. The economic targets represent the underpinning of the I.M.F's $5.4 billion loan package extended to Brazil last February.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: The results for 1983 are after a payment of $2.85 a share during the 12 months ended June 30. Asset figures represent net assets.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes income of $328,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $80,000 for the quarter and $101,000 for the 6 months.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
CITY NATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
WAR HERO REGAINS DISABILITY BENEFIT
description: The Social Security Administration said today that it had restored disability benefits to Roy P. Benavidez, a Vietnam War veteran who was awarded a Medal of Honor by President Reagan.

title: Careers; More Jobs For Middle Managers
description: THE outlook has begun to brighten for job-seeking middle managers, those business people who earn anywhere from $35,000 to $100,000 a year.

title: Miles Is Links Medalist
description: Michael Miles, a 21-year-old student at California State-Long Beach, shot a 3-under-par 69 today for a 36-hole total of 142 that earned him the medal in the stroke-play qualifying for the United States Amateur Public Links championship at the Hominy Hills Golf Club.

title: A YOUNG CHILD LIVES, A HOSTAGE TO MEDICINE
description: The windows on the 11th floor of Babies Hospital look out over New York - an awesome vision of grays and blacks. It is the only view of the world Taina Cabreja ever gets.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The person who first came up with peanut butter should be enshrined in some sort of national hall of fame. Can you tell me who this was?

title: Kaufman Expects Increase in Yields
description: Henry Kaufman, managing director and chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said yesterday that he expects long-term Government bond yields to rise as high as 12 percent by the year-end.

title: ROSS MACDONALD, NOVELIST, DIES AT 67
description: Ross Macdonald, whose tightly written novels about the hard-boiled private eye Lew Archer lifted the modern detective novel to the level of literature, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday night in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 13, 1983
description: International An effort to spur Poland's authorities to ease martial law restrictions has been initiated by the Reagan Administration, according to Polish informants and Administration officials. They said Poland's charge d'affaires had been told that Washington would take steps to relax some of the sanctions it imposed when martial law was declared in 1981 if Warsaw released a significant number of political prisoners. (Page A1, Column 6.) The future of Hong Kong when the British lease over most of the colony expires in 1997 was the subject of a new round of confidential Chinese-British negotiations that opened in Peking. The discussions are scheduled to end today. (A3:1-3.)

title: NEW YORK LAW SCHOOL APPOINTS A NEW DEAN
description: Eugene V. Rostow, Sterling Professor of Law and Public Affairs at the Yale Law School and former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency under President Reagan, was named yesterday dean of the New York Law School.

title: World Bank Sets Records
description: The World Bank said today that its borrowing and lending reached record levels in the year ended June 30 as it sought to cushion the effects of the global recession on developing countries.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.

AMERICAN EXPRESS: SYMBOL OF CHANGE;
News Analysis
description: The American Express Company's proposed billion-dollar re-entry into the mutual fund industry through the acquisition of Investors Diversified Services is a symbol of the vast changes sweeping through the American financial system.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
BALLET: NEW A.B.T. CASTS
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER is now in the last week of its 11-week season. Yet new casts are still being introduced, thanks to Mikhail Baryshnikov's admirable policy of letting many of his company's members attempt solo roles.

title: Rams Get Dickerson
description: The Los Angeles Rams signed their No.1 draft choice, Eric Dickerson, the running back from Southern Methodist, to a four-year contract last night. ''I have always felt Eric Dickerson was a Ram since the day we drafted him,'' said Georgia Frontiere, the Rams' president and owner.

title: A Decision Awaited
description: With the Cleveland Brown rookies due to report to training camp Friday and the veterans July 22, time is running out on Ron Brown, the team's top draft choice, to decide between playing pro football or trying out for the United States Olympic track team. ''My mother is not pleased,'' the outstanding sprinter and wide receiver from Arizona State said.

title: SOTHEBY'S PREDICTS MODEST PROFIT FOR '83
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet is projecting a slight improvement in worldwide art-auction sales and a modest profit, according to figures released in London yesterday for the season and the fiscal year, both of which end Aug. 31.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: President C harles Feeney upheld the three-day sus- p ension of Umpire Joe West for pushing M anager Joe Torre of the Atlanta Braves after a n argument b ut reduced the fine from $500 to $300. Torre w as fined $200. METS (NL) - Signed Eddie Williams, 17- y ear-old third baseman who was the t eam's first-round choice. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Placed Ned Y ost, catcher, on 15-day disabled list and c alled up Bill Schroeder from Vancouver t o replace him; placed Rick Waits, pitcher, on t he 21-day disabled list and a ctivated Mark Brouhard, outfielder. MONTREAL (NL) - Dropped Jerry W hite, outfielder, from 25-man roster; r einstated Woodie Fryman, pitcher, from t he disabled list. YANKEES (AL) - Reactivated Willie Ran- d olph, second baseman, from 15-day dis- a bled list; returned Bobby Meacham, in- f ielder, to Columbus.

title: Kaiser Price Rise
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company, Oakland, Calif., said it was raising prices 4 percent on a wide range of flat-rolled products, effective immediately.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Do I think there should be a legislative investigation? No. Why? Because it will turn political.

title: SEMICONDUCTOR RISE HELPS INTEL SURGE
description: The Intel Corporation reported yesterday that a general turnaround in the semiconductor industry helped its earnings nearly triple in the second quarter while revenues grew 20 percent.

title: 'UNBECOMING REASONING' IN A RIGHTS DEBATE
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 FACE U.S. CHARGES IN ARSON-FOR-PROFIT SCHEMES IN NEW YORK
description: Eight people, including two lawyers, were charged by Federal authorities yesterday with having operated a series of arson-forprofit schemes that led to 43 fires in 37 apartment buildings in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: Zungul Ban Sought
description: The continuing contract dispute between Steve Zungul and Hajduk Split, his team in Yugoslavia, has forced the Yugoslav Soocer Federation to ask that Zungul be banned from playing in the North American Soccer League. ''Zungul does not have our permission to play full-time soccer in the N.A.S.L. and we are asking the U.S. Soccer Federation to impose a ban on his playing for the Golden Bay Earthquakes,'' Dusan Marovic, a Yugoslav Federation official, said.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a charge of $7,200,000 for loan loss provisions, a gain of $3,400,000 from the sale of banking facilities, and a gain of $2,500,000 from the sale of securities. c-Includes tax credits of $1,024,000 for the quarter and $2,050,000 for the 6 months.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BASEBALL'S GREAT EXPERIMENT. Jackie Robinson and His Legacy. By Jules Tygiel. 392 pages. Illustrated. Ox- ford. $16.95.

title: Baldwin Unit In Kroco Sale
description: Baldwin-United said that its National Investors Insurance Company unit had agreed to sell for $60.9 million cash its interest in Kroco Inc. to the Kroger Company, a joint owner. The sale is subject to approval of the Arkansas insurance commissioner.

title: BRIEFING
description: An Anti-Israel List?

title: Sotheby Profit Seen
description: Officials of Sotheby Parke Bernet said today that they expected to register a pretax profit of 4 million, equivalent to $6 million, for this fiscal year, after losing $4.5 million last year.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Executives in Shift At Kemper Group
description: The Kemper Group of Chicago, the big financial-services concern, announced a major restructuring of management yesterday following the announcement that James W. Harding, 64 years old, would retire on Nov. 1 as chief financial officer.

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS: THE U.S. OBLIGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MILITARY AIDE SAYS REAGAN CRITICS DAMAGE U.S. STAND IN ARMS TALKS
description: A senior Pentagon official charged today that critics who questioned President Reagan's seriousness about arms control were damaging the American position in arms negotiations.

title: ROADBLOCKS' MESSAGE TO DRIVERS WHO DRINK
description: To the Editor:

title: REPUBLICBANK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TV: A DOCUMENTARY ON JOHN UPDIKE
description: YOU can make a good argument that John Updike is now America's most prominent man of letters. Other people may write novels, poetry, essays and short stories that are as good as his, but no one does all of them in such abundance and so well. For 25 years, Mr. Updike has been toiling, giving us a book each year, annotating our times as he sees them. ''What Makes Rabbit Run?: A Profile of John Updike'' shows us how he likes to see himself. The documentary will be shown on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: JAPAN HOLDS '84 RISE IN ARMS SPENDING TO 6.9%
description: The Japanese Cabinet put limits today on military spending for next year, setting in motion a fresh debate over whether the country gives its military too much or too little money.

title: Amdahl Offering Begins
description: The Amdahl Corporation said today that an offering of 1,350,000 common shares was under way, priced at $26.50 a share, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The offering was increased by 100,000 shares.

title: 3-Run Series Of Mistakes For Dodgers
description: D uring his more than 30 years as a pitcher, coach, minor league manager, and manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, Tom Lasorda thought he had seen just about every zany play in baseball. That was until the sixth inning Monday night when his team showed him something new when it allowed the St. Louis Cardinals to score three of their five runs in the inning on a walk, a passed ball and a throwing error by the catcher.

title: Corporate Jet Skids Off Runway
description: A two-engine corporate jet carrying five people skidded off the runway while landing at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon and slammed into a chain-link fence 70 feet from busy Grand Central Parkway, according to officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: SUNOCO PRODUCTS reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,400,000 for the quarter and $3,700,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of ,000 for the quarter and $362,000 for the 6 months.

title: Product Introductions Were Up 17% in June
description: Big increases in new product introductions must be a positive economic indicator, so it is encouraging to hear from the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News that June introductions were up 17 percent from the same month last year and the first half of the year is 28 percent ahead of the first half of 1982.

title: BEAUMONT REOPENING PROVOKES A DISPUTE
description: A disagreement over who is in charge of the troubled Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center yesterday provoked conflicting announcements about plans to open the theater for the first time in two years.

title: Why Truckle to the Teamsters?
description: What, another truck deregulation bill? Congress thought it deregulated the industry in 1980. The Motor Carrier Act of that year eliminated most of the waste and truckers' monopoly power, which had kept rates high for large shippers. But the act brought no relief for shippers who spend only a few thousand dollars a month on freight. That will take a new deregulation law - which is possible only if the Reagan Administration's deregulators persuade the President that free markets are more important than the Teamsters' political support.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,400,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: CHAD SAYS ITS TROOPS RETOOK A TOWN FROM THE INSURGENTS
description: The Government announced tonight that troops loyal to President Hissen Habre had recaptured a second eastern town seized by Libyan-supported insurgents over the weekend and were pursuing the rebels northward.

title: Hard Luck Afloat
description: The Australian 12-Meter yacht Advance has had a run of bad luck this year. In the trials off Newport, R.I., to select the challenger for the America's Cup, Advance lost 23 straight races before finally winning one this week from Canada 1, whose crew could not raise its spinnaker.

title: YANKS GET 3 IN 8TH TO WIN
description: Matt Keough, who watched Dave Righetti pitch a no-hitter eight days ago, teased the Minnesota Twins with six hitless innings of his own tonight. Before the teams were finished playing nine innings, though, the direction of the game turned around twice.

title: Toyota Insurance Cut
description: The Allstate Insurance Company is reducing the cost of collision and comprehensive coverage on 1983 Toyota Camries by as much as 20 percent because the cars have features that save on accident repair costs, Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. said in a statement on Monday. The model has cost-saving designs such as bumpers that can withstand crashes of 5 miles an hour and major engine components that have been moved back a few inches to avoid crash damage, the statement said.

title: BEST WAY IS MERIT PAY
description: The Democrats have finally started to speak up about the sorry state of our public schools. But their main solution -more money, mostly in across-the-board pay increases for teachers - won't work. Instead, it betrays the party's most fundamental ideals -and allows Ronald Reagan to seize the high ground on the key issue: merit pay.

title: Georgia-Pacific Net Off
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the country's largest domestic producer of plywood, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter fell 21.1 percent, to $56 million, or 52 cents a share, from $71 million, or 68 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Europe Shuns Energy Tax
description: Energy ministers of the European Economic Community today rejected the idea of a tax on energy consumption to finance a five-year, multibillion-dollar energy program.

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
Debt Switch By Argentina
description: Argentina will pay the interest arrears due in May on the public sector's foreign debt with the final $300 million parcel of a $1.1 billion bridging loan from creditor banks, senior Government sources said today.

title: Trial of Testing Aides To Proceed, Judge Rules
description: A motion for mistrial by three defendants in the Government's case against Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories was denied today by Federal District Judge John A. Nordberg. The three former officials of the concern are charged with falsifying laboratory reports on potentially toxic or cancer-causing effects of four drugs or pesticides.

title: 2 Symbolic Bridges
description: A s if joining Manhattan and Brooklyn weren't enough, the Brooklyn Bridge has been given the additional responsibility of symbolically joining Brooklyn with Rome.

title: Dutch Jobless
description: Dutch unemployment rose to a postwar record of 810,400 in June from 793,300 in May, the Social Affairs Ministry reported today. In June 1982, seasonally adjusted unemployment stood at 655,500.

title: AMERICAN VARIETY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for year to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: CHILEANS BATTLE POLICE IN CAPITAL
description: Residents in some neighborhoods here skirmished with the police tonight while many others throughout this city banged cooking pots to protest the continued rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: CHRYSLER SEEN RETIRING LOANS EARLY
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to repay the entire $800 million remaining of its federally guaranteed debt by the end of this year, sources in the auto industry and in the financial community said today.

title: King Losing Grip as Promoter
description: In Don King's ''Crown Affair'' on May 20, Larry Holmes and Michael Dokes narrowly retained their respective heavyweight titles, but apparently the promoter is losing one of his shiniest baubles.

title: PRUDENTIAL IS CUTTING 1,700 JOBS
description: The Prudential Insurance Company said yesterday that it would shift 800 jobs out of northern New Jersey and eliminate a total of 1,700 jobs nationally as part of a consolidation program that would save $50 million a year.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
General Defense Plans Share Offer
description: The General Defense Corporation, a principal manufacturer of tank ammunition for the Army, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of one million common shares, all of which are to be sold by the company's principal shareholder, the Clabir Corporation of Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Greyhound Unit Sells 3 Airliners
description: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation said that it had sold two 747's and one DC-8 jumbo-jet airliner to National Airlines after terminating a lease for them by mutual agreement with World Airways. Greyhound Leasing, a subsidiary of the Phoenix-based Greyhound Corporation, said World had been paying $10 million a year under a 15-year lease term expiring in 1988 and 1989.

title: KOCH RAISES PAY FOR 5,100 CITY ADMINISTRATORS
description: The salaries of New York City's three Deputy Mayors were raised from $76,650 to $88,500 yesterday as part of a package of wage increases for 5,100 top-level city officials and addministrators.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Another Transformation For Harper's Magazine

title: News Analysis
description: Efforts to heal the rift between Syria and Yasir Arafat appear to have reached a dead end. Rather than settle its differences with the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Syrian Government of President Hafez el-Assad seems intent on keeping Mr. Arafat frozen in the political wilderness of his Tunis headquarters, where he is cut off from his guerrilla supporters in Lebanon as well as from the battlefront with Israel.

title: 5 EX-HOSTAGES REACH KHARTOUM
description: Five foreign relief workers who were rescued from their Sudanese guerrilla kidnappers on Friday arrived here today and told of an escape attempt that failed and of beatings they received as a consequence.

title: Hearsay Is Cited In Red Sox Case
description: John Harrington, a spokesman for Jean Yawkey, the principal owner of the Boston Red Sox, testified today that a complaint that Buddy LeRoux, one of the team's co-owners, was trying to buy the Cleveland Indians had been based on hearsay evidence.

title: Averill Improving
description: Earl Averill, the 81-year-old member of baseball's Hall of Fame, is in serious condition but improving after being hospitalized with pneumonia, a Providence Hospital spokesman said today. He was an outfielder for Cleveland, Detroit and the Boston Braves and had a career batting average of .318.

title: TAKEOUT MOVIE: WOODY ALLEN SHOOTS IN A DELI
description: LEO STEINER said that he had never seen such a crowd. In fact, over in normally blase midtown Deli Country, tongues are still wagging about the times Woody Allen dropped by with more than 100 co-workers and an assortment of cameras and cables.

title: The U.N. Today; July 13, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Brazil to Tax Orange Juice
description: Citrus growers in the United States welcomed a ruling under which Brazil agreed to tax exports of concentrated orange juice.

title: WHITE HOUSE LINK: COMPUTER IN OHIO
description: When President Reagan or his staff wants to rush a written message to one of the members of the Cabinet, they no longer dispatch a messenger in a car through the traffic-clogged streets of the capital. They send the memorandum at the speed of light by a computer 431 miles away in Columbus, Ohio.

title: IRWIN WEINER, A SPECIAL AGENT
description: Eastchester's finest had an outing last Sunday to raise funds for their association, and a detective was ladling his homemade clam chowder from a deep steel pot, a captain was dishing up the host sausage and peppers to the chow line, and the Police Commissioner was out on a field playing volleyball with some of the men.

title: PRESIDENT ASKING EXPANDED POWERS FOR FAIR HOUSING
description: President Reagan asked Congress today for new powers to enforce the law against housing discrimination. But Administration officials opposed a fair housing bill that has drawn the most support from civil rights groups and members of Congress.

title: Cuomo Seeks Stay Of Shoreham Tests
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday urged Federal officials to stay their recent decision to let the Long Island Lighting Company apply for a license to start low-power tests at its nuclear power plant at Shoreham.

title: HOUSE PASSES JOB-RELATED PUBLIC WORKS BILL
description: The House passed today a multibilliondollar plan to help communities suffering high unemployment by providing funds for public works programs.

title: Invasion of Mayflies Disrupts Life in Iowa
description: Millions of smelly, sticky flies are making highways slick, obstructing windows and piling up a foot deep as they die in their annual invasion of Mississippi River towns.

title: Maislin Unit Seeks Debt Delay
description: Maislin Industries Ltd. said its trucking unit, which filed a holding proposal under Canadian bankruptcy law Monday, had stopped accepting new business. In its holding proposal, the company's Maislin Transport unit sought a moratorium on payment of debts until Oct. 31.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $200,000 from the termination of a lease.

title: HAROLD J. HOLLENBECK
description: Harold J. Hollenbeck, a former Mayor of East Rutherford, N.J., died Sunday of a heart attack at the Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey.

title: Market Place; The A.& P.'s Quiet Rebound
description: PROSPECTS are looking up for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the once-mighty giant of food retailing, but the stock has virtually no cheering section on Wall Street. When money managers talk business these days, they rarely mention the issue with the ticker symbol of GAP on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HONEYWELL, PRIME ADD TO COMPUTERS
description: Both Honeywell Inc. and Prime Computer Inc. announced new microcomputer products yesterday. Honeywell's computer division at Waltham, Mass., announced two new moderately priced microprocessor-based systems.

title: PHH CAPITAL FILES NOTES FOR UP TO $100 MILLION
description: The PHH Group Inc. of Hunt Valley, Md., said yesterday that PHH Capital Inc., a company it established to raise funds for its Canadian subsidiary, had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $100 million of mediumterm notes due in from nine months to eight years.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $15,700,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of land in laloosa County, Florida and $63,500,000 for the 6 months from the sale of timber. c-Includes a credit of $26,700,000 from the sale of tax benefits.

title: MELLON, MARINE MIDLAND NET INCOME UP
description: Two large banking companies yesterday reported strong earnings gains for the second quarter. But in both cases, some of the strength was the result of accounting procedures. Mellon National Corp.

title: Dioxin Discovered In a Newark Park
description: Dioxin has been found around a drain at the Hayes Park swimming pool in Newark, state and Federal officials announced today.

title: G.E.'s Hybrid Test Car: Manager's Role Is Cited
description: One might suppose that the head of a team assigned to build a new type of complex experimental automobile -one that operates on gasoline as well as electricity - would need an extensive technical background. Mechanical or electrical engineering, perhaps.

title: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income which includes tax credits of $27,358 for the quarter and $122,770 for the 6 months.

title: Salvador Rebels In Touch With Regime
description: Salvadoran rebel leaders got in touch with the Government's Peace Commission today, according to a member of the commission. The contact came two days after the United States special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, failed to meet with guerrilla leaders in Costa Rica.

title: Bridge: Youngest Team Takes Aim At National Championship
description: Setting a record before a competition begins does not happen very often, but it will on Friday in New Orleans. Competing in the Master Mixed Team Championship, a tough event that opens the Summer National Championships will be by far the youngest team ever to contest a major national event.

title: FAR-FLUNG ENGINEERS
description: To the Editor: Frederick C. Thayer is much to be thanked for his fine fine essay.

title: TACOMA GETS CHOICE: CANCER RISK OR LOST JOBS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today asked the citizens of Tacoma, Wash., to take part in a difficult decision: Should they accept some risk of cancer from arsenic in the air rather than face the probable closing of a copper smelter that provides 800 jobs?

title: Source of a Nickname
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Mookie Wilson, the Mets' centerfielder, who is unaware of the origin of his moniker, might do well to trace the roots of his sobriquet back to his parents' sense of humor (''How Famous Nicknames Were Born,'' July 6).

title: IDEA OF OFFICE CONDOMINIUMS AT WORLD TRADE CENTER
description: Dividing the World Trade Center into office condominiums is an idea to which Guy F. Tozzoli has given serious attention lately. Mr. Tozzoli is director of the World Trade Department for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which means he is in charge of management and leasing transactions for the Trade Center.

title: Infante Named Coach
description: Lindy Infante, the offensive coordinator with the Cincinnati Bengals, accepted the head coaching job with the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League. The Bulls' owner, Fred Bullard, said Infante would stay with the National Football League Bengals until his contract expires Jan. 31. Jacksonville was awarded a franchise June 14 and will begin play next year.

title: THE 'NEW' ITALIAN CHEESES: A SHOPPER'S GUIDE
description: IT is no longer enough for gastronomes to know that Brillat-Savarin, besides being the name of a legendary chef, is also the name of a French triple-creme cheese, or that crottins de chavignol are tiny, hard goat cheeses so sharp and salty that only the most dedicated cheese eaters profess a desire to consume them. No, to be current the true cheese aficionado must be conversant not only with the riches of France but with those of Italy as well. For, as Americans are discovering, the world of Italian cheese goes far beyond the firm or hard products that have long been established in this country - the Parmigiano Reggiano, provolone, romano, Bel Paese and fontina.

title: LAWYER SAYS SEX TAPES ARE MISSING
description: Robert K. Steinberg, the lawyer who said he had videotapes of top Government officials and associates of President Reagan in sex parties, said today that the tapes had been stolen.

title: ABUSE OF AGED IS OFTEN IGNORED
description: Too many doctors, clergymen and lawyers look the other way when they see an unpleasant problem, old people abused by their own grown children, say health care professionals.

title: Bloedel Newsprint Price Incentive
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a major newsprint supplier, introduced a 5 percent newsprint ''incentive allowance'' retroactive to July 1 for United States West Coast customers who purchase 100 percent of their annual contract tonnage.

title: Lunch and a Check
description: T he Chase Manhattan Bank, in awarding $695,000 in arts and cultural grants, chose to deliver the checks at luncheons this week so bank officers could get acquainted with the recipients.

title: 2 CYCLISTS PENALIZED FOR DRUGS
description: Organizers of the Tour de France said today that the Dutch star Joop Zoetemelk and another rider, Jean-Francois Rodriguez of France, had failed drug tests but would be allowed to continue the race, the world's most prominent endurance event for bicyclists.

title: Jefferies Trades a Stock After Trading Is Halted
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted trading last Wednesday in the stock of the Alleghany Corporation amid rumors that the company was about to be acquired. But that did not stop Boyd L. Jefferies from trading the shares.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The results for 1983 include the operations of WUI Inc., a subsidiary acquired last year.

title: BONDHOLDERS OF BRANIFF AGREE TO PLAN BY HYATT
description: A group of Braniff International's secured bondholders, the last holdouts blocking a plan of reorganization for the bankrupt airline, agreed late yesterday to drop their objections to the plan.

title: SUBWAY MOTORMEN'S UNION URGES A RULE BOOK SLOWDOWN ON SPEED
description: The union that represents subway motormen called for an immediate rule book slowdown on speed yesterday, in response to accusations that its members ran the trains like ''cowboys,'' screeching into stations and speeding between them.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets will hold pregame ceremonies paying tribute to the Reds' Johnny Bench, the veteran star who has said that he will retire at the end of the season.

title: Advertising; Weighing End of TV Regulation
description: HOW does the advertising community feel about the shifting of the Federal Communications Commission away from the regulation of television?

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DR. RICHARD GERSHON, LEADER IN RESEARCH ON IMMUNE SYSTEM
description: Dr. Richard K. Gershon, professor of pathology, immunology and biology at the Yale University School of Medicine and a leader in the exploration of the immune system, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in New Haven. He was 50 years old.

title: JUDGING SAFETY OF ASPARTAME IN SOFT DRINKS
description: ASIGNIFICANT move was made this month in the checkered career of artificial sweeteners. Aspartame, approved two years ago as a lowcalorie sweetener for such dry foods as drink mixes, breakfast cereals and chewing gum, was released for use in by far the largest market for sugar substitutes: diet carbonated soft drinks.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
WINE TALK
description: WHEN Charles Fournier died upstate early last month he was described as a French immigrant who had become one of America's leading wine makers.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $71,000 for the quarter and $126,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $285,000 for the quarter and $539,000 for the 6 months.

title: Aide to Who Sentenced
description: Tony Branch, who managed the finances of The Who rock group for 18 months, was sent to prison for three years yesterday today after admitting that he had stolen at least $275,000 from the group. Mr. Branch, 36 years old, told the court he had lost the money gambling on horse and greyhound races.

title: Sanitation and Art
description: T he Sanitation Department's first artist in residence, financed by a $10,000 Federal grant, has completed a two-year-long tour of New York, shaking the hands of some 8,500 sanitation workers and thanking them ''for keeping New York City alive.''

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split declared today for payment August 16 to stockholders of record July 29.

title: YOUTH CURFEW IN DETROIT STIRS EMOTIONAL DEBATE
description: After years of decline, crime in Detroit is again on the rise, and the Mayor's plans to curb it are bringing protests from civil libertarians.

title: A Look Ahead At the 6-Day Run
description: Next year, when the New York Road Runners Club stages its second six-day race at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, the event will take place in May or June, not in the blazing heat of July as the inaugural did last week.

title: SPECIAL CHALLENGER FOR THE AMERICA'S CUP
description: One spring morning in 1970 at Derecktor's Yard in Mamaroneck, N.Y., the Australian Alan Bond, Ben Lexcen and the rest of the crew from Bond's yacht Apollo spotted an unusual craft and went aboard to inspect her. This was the newly launched 12-Meter Valiant, in which all the winches were below deck.

title: FOR 2 APARTHEID FOES, A SISTERHOOD OF SHARED FATE
description: Although they have encountered each other only once and come from political backgrounds that are now sometimes represented as being in conflict, Winnie Mandela and Mamphela Ramphele can be said to share a highly unusual kind of sisterhood.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Low-Calorie Bread

title: Economic Scene; Briefing Book For Volcker
description: TOMORROW Paul A. Volcker goes before the Senate Banking Committee to testify on his renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. What sort of briefing material has been prepared for him as he girds his loins for his debate with such Republican conservatives as Jake Garn of Utah, the chairman; John G. Tower of Texas and William L. Armstrong of Colorado, and such Democratic liberals as William Proxmire of Wisconsin, Alan Cranston of California and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan?

title: AN OLD WAR AGAINST THE NEW CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: Like Pavlov's dog, members of Congress tend to start salivating when a plate of Federal money is placed in front of them. Bringing home the bacon from Washington is a time-honored way of pleasing constituents and reinforcing re-election prospects.

title: 2 Jockeys Penalized
description: The Nebraska Racing Commission has revoked Jerry Compton's jockey license for one year and suspended Tom Greer, another jockey, for 20 days after an investigation into drug abuse at the Ak-Sar-Ben race track.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Advertising Strength Seen
description: ''We get a sense from most of our clients, a sense of optimism that continues to grow every month but is very guarded,'' said Don Johnston, president of the JWT Group, echoing the comments of a half a dozen other top people in the business.

title: Noranda Shows Gain
description: Noranda Mines announced that it had a net income in the second quarter of $9.2 million, contrasted with a deficit of $57.1 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 6.1 percent, to $795.1 million, from $749.1 million. Earnings were less than one cent a share after the application of preferred dividends.

title: NORANDA MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $22,400,000 from the sale of an office building and a gain from share issue by Placer Development. c-Net loss. Share earnings for the latest and year-ago quarters were less than one cent. For the 6 month periods, there were no share earnings applicable to common stock after preferred dividend requirements.
