The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: FISHER FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: b-Net income which includes a gain of $971,000.

title: THE CITY
description: A coalition of religious and civic leaders yesterday urged Governor Cuomo to convene a special session of the Legislature next fall to enact legislation to ease overcrowding in state prisons.

title: TODAY, VOLCKER GETS HIS SAY
description: The heat is on Paul A. Volcker, the heat of a clammy Washington summer, and of television lights, and of politicians, businessmen, labor leaders and economists - few of whom believe he is doing his job quite right and none of whom professes to know how to do it much better.

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: REOPENING OF BEAUMONT WITH 'CARMEN' APPROVED
description: Final approval for Peter Brook's radical production of Bizet's opera ''Carmen'' to play at the Vivian Beaumont Theater was given yesterday by the executive committee of the board of directors of Lincoln Center. Scheduled to open Oct. 24, ''Carmen'' will be the first presentation at the playhouse in more than two years.

title: Rape Charges Dropped
description: Charges of statutory rape that had been filed against Julio Valdez, a seldom-used infielder for the Red Sox, were dropped yesterday when a county grand jury in Boston refused to return an indictment. The office of District Attorney Newman Flanagan said the jurors had not found enough evidence to warrant a case.

title: Racal-China Pact
description: A British company, Racal Survey Ltd., signed contracts establishing two joint ventures in China to support offshore oil exploration and production, China's official New China News Agency said.

title: CON ED WALKOUT DISRUPTS LIVES ON BOTH SIDES
description: Bill Wareham's family wanted to see more of him. So he quit the Merchant Marine after six years of service and got a job as a supervisor trainee with Consolidated Edison last June 20 - just two days after the strike started. He has been home twice in the last 17 days.

title: POTPOURRI OF WEEKEND EVENTS
description: R esidents of New York City who do not own an automobile and have a yen for saltwater angling might wish to take advantage of special package trips offered by the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Chilean Court Frees Political Activists
description: An appeals court tonight ordered the release of Gabriel Valdes, leader of the Christian Democrat Party, and five other jailed party activists, ruling that their call for a peaceful protest against the Government did not threaten national security.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
OTHER SIDE OF THE COIN IN KENYA: HARD VILLAGE LIFE
description: The average Kenyan, according to the World Bank's figures, can expect to live 55 years and be valued, in terms of gross national product, at $380 a year.

title: Polish Debt Talks Start
description: A team of Western bankers opened talks with Polish officials on deferring the country's commercial debt repayments today as two reports offered gloomy news for its economy.

title: Nissan Net Up 2.3% for Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's secondlargest auto maker, said today that its consolidated net income for the last fiscal year rose by 2.3 percent, to the equivalent of $432 million.

title: Ambrosiano Bank Change
description: An special general meeting of Banco Ambrosiano Holding S.A. in Luxembourg appointed three partners of the London accountants of Touche Ross & Company as administrators after the bank's board of directors resigned, the bank said today.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
OPERA'S OWN DRAMA PLAYED BEHIND SCENES
description: THE dispute that has closed the New York City Opera is not just another orchestra strike. The libretto looks familiar and the arias do have a traditional ring, but the drama being played out by the company and its musicians is a potentially fatal one. Unless some feat of economic legerdemain can be performed to end the strike quickly, the final curtain could fall on a beleaguered troupe that has been scraping by for years.

title: BONN PROPOSES A TOUGHER LAW ON DEMONSTRATIONS
description: Anxious over announced plans for further protests against the stationing of new American missiles in West Germany, the Government approved a proposal today that would make it a criminal offense not to obey police orders to leave a violent demonstration.

title: Mitsubishi Net Off 25%
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation, Japan's largest trading company, said Tuesday that its earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31 plunged 25 percent, to $105 million, while sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to $65 billion. Mitsubishi blamed the worldwide recession.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
James River Buys Mills
description: The James River Corporation has finished buying certain assets from the Diamond International Corporation for about $171 million. The assets, James River said Tuesday, include paper mills in Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and New York and the Campbell Stationery Company.

title: Ryan Wins 8th In Row
description: Nolan Ryan won his eighth consecutive game, and George Bjorkman, a rookie, drove in five runs as the Houston Astros beat the Montreal Expos, 9-4, tonight. Ryan (9-1) struck out five, walked three and scattered five hits in eighth innings as the Astros won their seventh game in their last eight. Houston has won 11 of the 12 games Ryan has started.

title: DEAN AT N.Y.U. URGES APPROVAL OF LIBRARY
description: The New York University law school must build an extension of its library or face ''a crisis in accreditation,'' the school's dean told the city's Planning Commission yesterday.

title: HERS
description: THEY just gave out the Mother of the Year awards again, and I didn't win. You could have fooled me. You could have even fooled my sons. It's easy. I've been doing it for 24 years. Take Sundays when they were real little. The mother's helper was off and so was the husband I had divorced after a three-year marriage - an act that certified my insanity in a suburban community where you only divorced a man if he was a mass murderer, and then only if he had been kicked out of the country club. (The stampede to the divorce courts that followed later recertified me as a pioneer.)

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a minority interest of $1,700,000. c-Including a gain of $51,000,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes and a minority interest of $3,400,000.

title: Soviet Output Rises by 4.1%
description: Soviet industrial production grew by 4.1 percent in the first six months of this year compared with a 2.7 percent rise in the first half of 1982, according to a Government report issued today by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Reagan Domestic Aide Quits
description: Edwin L. Harper, President Reagan's chief adviser on domestic affairs, resigned today, saying he would return to the private sector. Mr. Harper, 42 years old, has served since March 1982 as assistant to the President for policy development. No successor was named.

title: MGM Refinances $250 Million in Debt
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said today that it had completed a $250 million debt refinancing package with its six major banks.

title: BRIEFER, BRIEF THYSELF
description: Briefing books are much in the news these days, but few Americans have ever seen one, much less used or prepared one.

title: Cantor, Fitzgerald Link to London
description: The Cantor, Fitzgerald Securities Corporation, a major broker of Treasury securities, on Tuesday began opening its New York office at 4 A.M. to provide service to clients in London.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Trip to City Island

title: Connecticut Raises Drinking Age to 20
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed legislation today raising Connecticut's legal drinking age to 20 from 19 on Oct. 1 and increasing most penalties for drunken driving.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING CARD

title: WESTINGHOUSE PROFIT OFF
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income dropped 12.7 percent, to $96.4 million, or $1.09 a share, from $110.4 million, or $1.28 a share, a year before. Sales fell 3.2 percent in the latest quarter, to $2.39 billion, from $2.47 billion.

title: DEFECTING RUSSIANS TELL OF PLAN THAT LED TO U.S.
description: Victoria Mullova, a violinist, and Vato Jordania, a conductor, said here today that they defected last week from the Soviet Union because their artistic freedom had been curtailed. The two musicians, who defected while on tour in Finland by taking a taxicab over the Swedish border, arrived in the United States last Saturday.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $612,000.

title: The Meager Meal of Madrid
description: It stretches euphemism to describe the fruits of the Madrid conference on East-West security and human rights as satisfactory. After three years of mostly idle talk, 35 nations will conclude with a ''compromise'' that submits their most serious disagreements to yet more meetings. Why should the United States acquiesce in this charade?

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes income of $1,200,000 from the sale of Chrysler Corp. securities.

title: Caveat Out of the Travers
description: Woody Stephens, the colt's trainer, announced yesterday that Caveat, the Belmont Stakes winner, would not run in the Travers Stakes at Saratoga on Aug. 13. Stephens said that Caveat was making a successful recovery from a strained ligament in his right foreleg, which was injured when the colt was bumped at the top of the stretch in the Belmont, but that Caveat had lost too much training time to make the Travers.

title: F.B.I. TAKES OVER SEARCH AT HOOVER ARCHIVES
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation took charge today of the search for evidence in Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign archives that his staff had access to materials from the reelection campaign of President Carter.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected July 1.

title: BETTER SALES HELP CBS NET JUMP 35.9% IN QUARTER
description: CBS Inc., citing improved sales by its records business and stringent cost controls, yesterday reported significantly higher income for the second quarter.

title: SERVICES FOR TROUBLED YOUTHS: WHEN THE CHILD IS THE ABUSER
description: To the Editor:

title: JUNE RETAIL SALES ROSE SLIGHT 0.7%
description: Retail sales cooled somewhat in June after strong month-to-month gains in the preceding three months, but were up sharply from the weak performance of a year earlier, according to Government figures released today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: ANOTHER PART OF THE FIFTIES. By Paul A. Carter. 328 pages. Columbia University Press. $19.95.

title: Tyco Official Adds Post of Chairman
description: John F. Fort, the 41-year-old president and chief executive officer of Tyco Laboratories Inc., who was given the additional post of chairman yesterday, has some big shoes to fill.

title: 'INSIDER' TRADING LEGISLATION
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, reaffirming a position that has been opposed by the securities industry, has urged Congress not to narrow the scope of a bill that would set stiffer penalities for trading securities on the basis of inside information.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 14, 1983; International
description: Canada is violating world trade rules by imposing too many curbs on foreign investors, a GATT panel ruled. The decision, in response to complaints by the U.S., noted in particular Ottawa's requirement that foreign companies buy Canadian raw materials for their manufacturing. The ruling could permit the U.S. to take reciprocal actions against Canada. (Page A1.)

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from the exchange of stock for long- term debt of $2,900,000 for the quarter and $5,256,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: CHAD HOLDS TOWN REBELS STILL CLAIM
description: With insurgent broadcasts continuing to say the rebels hold the upper hand in eastern Chad, the Government opened the eastern town of Abeche to inspection today to prove that its forces were in control there.

title: Fire in the Pinelands Burns Out of Control
description: A forest fire in the Pinelands in Ocean County destroyed more than 250 acres today and threatened to destroy still more as it continued to burn out of control tonight.

title: Howe's Fine Protested
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association filed a grievance against the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday in which it seeks to overturn the fine of $53,867 imposed against the pitcher Steve Howe after his second rehabilitation for cocaine addiction. In announcing the penalty on June 29, Pete O'Malley, the team's president, says that Howe had also been placed on a three-year probation that the commissioner's office would help monitor.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Loans
description: Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, which operates one of the nation's largest banks, said its mortgage unit had acquired $1.7 billion worth of the mortgage servicing portfolio of Genstar Mortgage, composed of Government National Mortgage Association pooled home loans.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STOP SENDING US YOUR DISPLACE, KEAN TELLS CITY
description: Governor Kean demanded today that New York City stop sending displaced families from the city to hotels in New Jersey, calling the practice ''the height of irresponsibility.''

title: Meals May Be Factor In Fainting by Elderly
description: The blood pressure of elderly people drops suddenly after they eat their meals, a discovery that may help explain why some of them have fainting spells that cause boneshattering falls, researchers say.

title: SUIT CONTENDS NAVY RIGGED BIDDING PROCESS
description: A maritime trade group filed a lawsuit today charging the Navy with rigging bidding procedures last year to favor the Navy over civilian contractors in the operation of Government vessels.

title: CANNON SHOCKS HIS FRIENDS
description: In Louisiana football lore, Billy Cannon's run is legendary. It was his 89-yard punt return that enabled Louisiana State University to beat Ole Miss and helped win him the Heisman Trophy in 1959.

title: U.S. REPORTS PLOT TO KILL FEDERAL JUDGE IN JERSEY
description: Investigators have uncovered a plan to kill Judge Herbert J. Stern of Federal District Court here, United States Attorney W. Hunt Dumont said today.

title: Extradition Treaty Is Signed By Officials of U.S. and Ireland
description: The United States and Ireland signed a treaty today to permit law enforcement authorities in each country to apprehend and extradite fugitives sought by the other country.

title: WHAT'S BEST FOR ISRAEL?
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
JULY 1-10 CAR SALES UP 41.9% AT BIG THREE
description: The Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that sales of new cars rose by 41.9 percent in the July 1-10 period, continuing a trend of improving sales that began late in May.

title: Tobacco Bill Clears Senate
description: Legislation freezing Federal price supports for this year's tobacco crop at last year's level won unanimous approval today from the Senate.

title: NOT A SINGLE SET OF BOUND FEET IN THE HAREM
description: To the Editor:

title: Dallas Club Audience Panics Over Tear Gas
description: A nightclub audience broke windows and stampeded into the street, coughing and crying, after a tear gas bomb was tossed onto the dance floor of the crowded club early today.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,752,000 from the sale of property. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translation.

title: Lush Greens
description: Mowing the rough of a golf course is a bit like getting a haircut - it's better to take off a little at a time than too much and then wait for it to grow back. That's the way the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews views the problem of rough at the Royal Birkdale Golf Club at Southport, England, where the 112th British Open Championship begins today.

title: ECONOMIC RECOVERY IS FOOL'S GOLD
description: The Administration is celebrating what it calls a ''sparkling'' recovery. But the economy sparkles like fool's gold. So far, this is the weakest recovery in the postwar period.

title: Retired Officer Shot in Holdup
description: A retired police officer was shot and wounded early yesterday when he surprised two gunmen robbing a Brooklyn fast-food restaurant, authorities said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.C. Nielsen Co., Northbrook, Ill., has elected Rick Stanits vice president-account manager of the marketing research group in the United States.

title: SALARY INCREASES VOTED BY PANEL OF CITY COUNCIL
description: In a raucous session that had to be gaveled back to order more than once, members of a City Council panel yesterday voted raises for themselves and other elected officials, turned back efforts to limit their outside incomes and moved to strip Board of Education members of luxury-size cars.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEEK COMPROMISE ON NICARAGUA
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials and leading House experts on foreign policy and intelligence met today in an effort to find a compromise on the issue of United Statessponsored covert military operations in Nicaragua, but some participants said little progress had been made.

title: Kean Asks Session On Car Insurance
description: TRENTON July 13 - Governor Kean said today he had asked the leaders of the State Senate and Assembly to return to Trenton to revise the state's car-insurance system.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL MAJOR LEAGUE PLAYERS ASSOCI- A TION - Filed a grievance against Los A ngeles in connection with the club's disci- p linary action against Steve Howe, pitch- e r, on June 29. MINNESOTA (AL) - Placed Pete Wil- s on, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list be- c ause of a sore left shoulder.

title: Advertising; Optimism At Last on Spending
description: ROBERT J. COEN, advertising's superior seer, has rediscovered optimism. After revising his advertising spending predictions downward twice last year, the senior vice president of McCann-Erickson said yesterday that he believes 1983 will come in better than he forecast in January.

title: Jury Accuses Man Of Kidnapping
description: A grand jury indicted a Bronx teen-ager yesterday for kidnapping the wife of a mayoral aide at gunpoint.

title: Desai Obtains Ban On Hersh Book in India
description: Former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai obtained a temporary ban in India today against an American author's book that says Mr. Desai was once a paid agent for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Minnesota Bond Issue Yields 5.5% to 9.35%
description: An $89 million issue of Aa-rated Minnesota general obligation bonds was well received yesterday, with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 8.25 percent in 1993 and 9.35 percent in 2003.

title: TREES THAT CAN REPLACE A BLIGHTED DOGWOOD
description: THE native dogwoods in the Northeast are ailing. Each year, more of these magnificent spring-flowering trees must be cut down, leaving gaping holes in many gardeners' landscapes. A few sentimental homeowners are replacing the lost trees with new dogwoods, while others are simply leaving the spot empty, uncertain what to use as a substitute.

title: Ameritech Plan
description: Ameritech and its five Middle Western Bell Telephone companies said they plan to re-enter the equipment market after they are separated from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company early next year. The Ameritech companies - Illinois Bell, Indiana Bell, Michigan Bell, Ohio Bell and Wisconsin Telephone - said they would provide state-of-the-art telecommunications equipment.

title: NEWARK TO INCREASE POLICE PATROL FORCES AT LEAST 45 PERCENT
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that the city planned to increase the number of police officers on patrol by as much as 45 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reunion at Belvedere

title: BRIEFING
description: Memorial to Eisenhower

title: 5 Years' Jail for Having Gun
description: A black mechanic was sentenced to five years' imprisonment today for possessing a Soviet-made pistol that he said had been sent to him by members of the banned African National Congress in Mozambique. Moses Langa, 38 years old, told the Johannesburg regional court that the pistol had been smuggled to him after he met members of the nationalist group while visiting Mozambique, where he was born. He gave the gun away to a friend.

title: AN ILL-CONCEIVED VETO OF A LOAN TO NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: METS FALL TO REDS' 3-HITTER
description: In light of the dark days that have fallen on Shea Stadium, it was only fitting that an opponent would provide Met fans with their most enthusiastic moment.

title: A SMALL BLUE RIDGE PINE CABIN IS THE CARTERS' RUSTIC RETREAT
description: ELLIJAY, Ga. THE sun filters in through groves of towering white oak and hemlock, and the sound of water is constant as it trickles over the rocks of Turnip Town Creek from a small waterfall and continues for seven or eight miles to the Ellijay River.

title: British Concern To Buy Marquardt
description: International Signal and Control Group P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the Marquardt Company, an American subsidiary of the CCI Corporation, a privately held military contractor, for $43.5 million in cash.

title: SUMMER HAZARDS FOR HOUSEHOLD PETS
description: THE situations may seem innocuous: a door open to a freshly manicured lawn, a window open to a warm summer day, a brisk jog through the park with a dog at your side. But according to veterinarians these seemingly innocent summer scenes are often preludes to serious accidents for dogs and cats.

title: GERTRUDE JEKYLL, GARDEN REFORMER
RATES EASE ON WEAK DEMAND
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday, reversing some of the increases of earlier in the week. Investor demand for Treasury notes and bonds remained weak, analysts said, but prices rose and yields fell on speculative buying by some dealer firms.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
THE SPORTS BLOTTER
description: M ore and more, the sports pages resemble a police blotter. Five members of the Dallas Cowboys, including Tony Dorsett and Harvey Martin, have been linked to a Federal cocaine investigation. Dickie Noles, a right-handed pitcher for the Chicago Cubs, has appealed a jail sentence for assaulting a Cincinnati police officer. Dr. Billy Cannon, the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner who is now a Baton Rouge, La., orthodontist, has been charged in the production of more than $5 million in counterfeit $100 bills.

title: CONCERT: TOKYO QUARTET
description: THE Tokyo String Quartet that came to prominence in the early 1970's had an entirely different violin complement than it does today. First, Kikuei Ikeda replaced Yoshiko Nakura as second violinist. And then, two years ago, Peter Oundjian came in as the ensemble's first non-Japanese member, and in the crucial first violin role to boot, supplanting Koichiro Harada.

title: CUOMO OUSTS HEAD OF STATE'S AGENCY FOR INVESTIGATION
description: Governor Cuomo replaced the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation and one of its commissioners today and gave the new chairman, David G. Trager, instructions to wind up the commission's work with an eye toward abolishing it next year.

title: High Honor for Delaney
description: President Reagan has awarded the Presidential Citizens Medal, one of the two medals the President of the United States is authorized to issue on his own, to Joe Delaney, the Kansas City Chiefs' running back who died June 29 in Monroe, La., while trying to save three youngsters from drowning.

title: The Talk of Greenwich
description: In the last three weeks, Gordon Gilman has learned a harsh truth of the real estate business. It is hard to sell a house near a bridge that falls down.

title: COSTS TO REPAIR I-95 BRIDGE PUT AT $37 MILLION
description: The cost of temporary repairs and a permanent replacement for the fallen bridge section of the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich could exceed $37 million, the State Transportation Commissioner said today.

title: Diane Keaton in New Film
description: Diane Keaton will star in ''The Little Drummer Girl,'' a Warner Bros. film based on the John le Carre novel and scheduled for release late next year. Miss Keaton will play a British actress who becomes involved in a plot by Israeli intelligence agents against Palestinian terrorists. The film is being directed by George Roy Hill.

title: SUSPECT DENIES TACKLING BLACK KILLED IN ATTACK
description: A Brooklyn youth charged with murder in the beating of a black transit worker by a group of whites denied yesterday at his trial that he had pulled the victim from a station wagon and tackled him to prevent his escape.

title: COURT TO SELECT TRUSTEE FOR HUGHES INTERESTS
description: The question of who will run the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, and thereby control the Hughes Aircraft Company, a leading aerospace and military contractor, has been placed in the hands of a Delaware Chancery Court judge.

title: Bank Rates Still Rise
description: Interest rates for bank money market accounts continued to rise in major cities in the week ended Wednesday, but dropped slightly in the New York area, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: The Drinking Age Matters
description: Over much opposition, Connecticut's Governor O'Neill has wisely signed a measure to raise the minimum age for public drinking from 19 to 20. The change will save lives on the highway.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. To the surprise of many, the Rangers are still on top of their division with the season slightly more than halfway gone. Tonight, Texas sends Charlie Hough against another former reliever, Shane Rawley. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Tom Seaver faces Charlie Puleo, whom the Mets sent to Cincinnati in the deal that allowed Seaver to return to New York last winter. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Golf British Open, first round, at Southport, England. Tom Watson is the defending champion, but he has not won a tournament since capturing last year's Open, at Royal Troon in Scotland. Johnny Miller, who was the winner the last time the tournament was played on the course in Southport, is recovering from surgery and has withdrawn. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M.) United States Amateur Public Links Championship, second round of match play, at Hominy Hill Golf Club, Colts Neck, N.J., 7 A.M. New Jersey Open, second round, at Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J., 8 A.M. Quad Cities Open, P.G.A. tournament, first round, at Coal Valley, Ill.

title: MRFY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: OAHU ELECTRIC FAILURE DISRUPTS LIFE FOR 800,000 IN HONOLULU
description: Five major transmission lines to Honolulu went out of service in ''a domino effect'' today, knocking out power to the 800,000 residents of Hawaii's capital city and the rest of the island of Oahu, utility officials said.

title: Ruling Limits Eagles
description: Leonard Tose, the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, must deal with a group of investors with whom he has had a falling out if he wants to sell the team between now and Sept.15, a judge ruled today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kim Linehan, the world-record holder in the 1,500-meter freestyle, says she has quit the University of Texas swimming team and will pass up her senior year of competition and a chance for a tryout for the United States' 1984 Olympic team. ''Swimming just isn't fun anymore,'' she said. ... Lonnie McFarlan, a 6-foot-6-inch forward and guard and the second-leading scorer of the St. Joseph's University of Philadelphia team, will sit out the 1983-84 basketball season.

title: STOCKS SLIGHTLY LOWER IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices drifted slightly lower in light trading activity as the 11-month-old rally settled down in a correction that many analysts expect to last throughout the month. The last four trading sessions have been characterized by low volume and scant interest from institutional investors whose buying power fueled the rally.

title: SALE OF SEX VIDEOTAPES DENIED
description: Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, said today that he had made a $1 million deal to buy videotapes reportedly showing Government officials in sex acts, but the lawyer who says the tapes exist denied any deal was made.

title: News Analysis
description: Like a weathered mountain, New York City's voluminous set of zoning regulations usually undergoes change in subtle ways. But every so often it becomes the focus of issues that can profoundly affect the way the city regulates development and the way it interprets the reach of its land use powers.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months, a gain of $7,600,000 for the 6 months from the acquisition of company issued debt, and a foreign currency loss of $300,000 for the 6 months. c-After gains from the sale of tax benefits of $24,000,000 for the quarter and $44,500,000 for the 6 months, losses from discontinued operations of $3,100,000 for the quarter and $4,700,000 for the 6 months, a gain of $8,500,000 for the 6 months from the acquisition of company issued debt and a foreign currency gain of $4,500,000 for the 6 months.

title: 3 REAGAN RIGHTS NOMINEES TOUCH OFF A HEATED CLASH IN SENATE
description: Senators clashed today in impassioned debate over the wisdom of confirming President Reagan's three nominees to the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: SOVIET BROADENS ARMS PROPOSALS, RAISING U.S. HOPE
description: The Soviet Union has both broadened and slightly moderated its strategic arms proposals, causing the White House to voice hope today that Moscow intends now ''to move the negotiations forward.''

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: The police have tentatively ruled out politics and robbery as motives in the murders of three members of an Iranian family and are offering up to $1,000 for information in the case.

title: 'Adam' Settlement
description: Coleco Industries of Hartford has reached a settlement with the Logical Business Machines Corporation of Sunnyvale, Calif., over the trademark ''Adam,'' according to Coleco. It said that it would have unlimited right to the trademark on its new $600 home computer, while Logical Business Machines would be licensed by Coleco to use the name on its business computers, which sell for $20,000 or more.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 14, 1983
description: International A shift in Moscow's arms proposals was reported by well-placed officials, prompting the White House to express hope that the Soviet Union intends ''to move the negotiations forward.'' The officials said that Soviet negotiators in Geneva had both broadened and slightly moderated Moscow's proposals for limiting strategic weapons. (Page A1, Column 6.) A new group of nerve gas bombs and artillery shells would be produced under a $130 million authorization approved in the Senate, with Vice President Bush casting a tie-breaking vote after an impassioned debate. (A1:5.)

title: British Oil Price Steady
description: Most of the oil industry has agreed to hold the reference price for British North Sea oil at $30 a barrel for the third quarter, industry sources said today. The price was reduced to $30 from $33.50 in March.

title: CHINA AND BRITAIN PLAN MORE TALKS ON HONG KONG
description: China and Britain today ended a two-day round of talks on the future of Hong Kong with an announcement that their delegations would meet here again in two weeks.

title: Pemex Aides Convicted
description: Three former Petroleos Mexicanos officials were convicted today of accepting bribes in return for awarding lucrative equipment purchase contracts to Crawford Enterprises of Houston.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF NEW JERSEY (TOTOWA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MUSIC: VAN TIEGHEM'S PERCUSSIONS
description: Around twilight Sunday afternoon, the percussionist David Van Tieghem climbed into a multilevel sculpture by the architect Billie Tsien, pulled out a pair of drumsticks and began to tap. Suspended inside the sculpture, which stood on the sand at the Battery Park Landfill, were toys, automobile parts, scrap metal and dismembered xylophones. Mr. Van Tieghem has aptly described the visual effect of this presentation: ''The performer may at times appear to be an interplanetary traveler, a series of nerve impulses in the brain or a child in a playroom.''

title: PERU'S CHIEF LEADS CORTEGE FOR 2 SLAIN IN REBEL ATTACK
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry led thousands of Peruvians today in an emotional funeral procession for two people killed Monday in a terrorist attack on the headquarters of the country's ruling political party.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AROUND THE NATION;
description: Thousands of claims filed against the MGM Grand Hotel after a 1980 fire in which 85 people died were settled today for more than $138 million.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Hearings on Braniff's Revival Plan
description: Judge John Flowers of Federal Bankruptcy Court held hearings in Dallas yesterday on part of the Braniff International reorganization plan that would resolve the major obstacles to a revival of part of the airline.

title: IOWA CAUCUSES LOOKING MORE LIKE PRIMARY
description: Success in the Iowa caucuses, the first major test of the Presidential campaign year, has long depended on a candidate's grass-roots organizations and his skill at folksy, face-to-face campaigning.

title: Fraud Figure Ordered Jailed
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, a former boxing promoter, has been ordered by Federal District Judge Consuelo Marshall to report to Federal prison on Aug. 8 after an appellate court rejected an appeal of his conviction in a $21.3 million bank fraud. Mr. Smith and a co-defendant, Sammie Marshall, were convicted in 1981. The two were ordered to prison Monday after their appeals lost.

title: Chief Executive to Stay At the Boston Exchange
description: Charles J. Mohr has agreed to remain as chairman and chief executive officer of the Boston Stock Exchange for another two years. Mr. Mohr, 35, became the Boston Stock Exchange's first paid fulltime chairman in October 1981. He had been vice president of planning for the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SIX BALDWIN UNITS PUT UNDER STATES' DIRECTION
description: The six main insurance subsidiaries of the Baldwin-United Corporation were put under state supervision yesterday. The move would temporarily allow the subsidiaries to limit payouts on policies but could force Baldwin into bankruptcy.

title: Drifter Is Hospitalized In Market Firebombing
description: A 30-year-old drifter accused of splashing gasoline on a crowded supermarket checkout area and lighting it was declared mentally incompetent today to stand trial.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TV: 'PLANE THAT FELL FROM THE SKY'
description: THE makers of ''The Plane That Fell From the Sky,'' a CBS News production on Channel 2 at 10 o'clock tonight, have taken a controversy over a nearly disastrous airline flight and shaped it into an absorbing, innovative, intensely human docudrama.

title: BOLD IMAGININGS: 10 CALIFORNIA ARCHITECTS
description: California architecture, like California itself, holds both a promise and a threat. One somehow expects young California designers to be young Turks wielding the sharpest cutting edge in the profession, building the nation's forbidden buildings.

title: Tylenol Extortion Case Figure Sentenced on Fraud Charges
description: James W. Lewis, who faces trial on charges of trying to extort money in the Tylenol cyanide poisonings, was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years in prison on mail fraud charges in an unrelated case.

title: RETURN OF THE MUTUAL FUNDS
description: After nearly 10 years of listless performance and sluggish sales, stock mutual funds have returned to the investment limelight. Since the Wall Street bull market began last August, the assets in the funds have mushroomed, rising 60.7 percent, to $70.7 billion, in May, according to the Investment Company Institute, a mutual funds trade group. Some of the top-performing funds have grown more than fivefold since the market began its climb.

title: FEARS GROW ON PLIGHT OF 200,000 UGANDA REFUGEES
description: Concern is growing among Western relief agencies and embassies here over the plight of as many as 200,000 Ugandans displaced by fighting between Government troops and guerrillas.

title: OREGON REGULATES WOOD-STOVE OUTPUT
description: The crackling fire of the wood stove has become the biggest unregulated polluter in Oregon. As a result, a new law setting pollution emission limits on the stoves has been approved by state legislators. The measure, the first such state law in the nation, was signed recently by the Republican Governor, Victor G. Atiyeh.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ABC PLANS TO RIVAL '60 MINUTES'
description: ABC News said yesterday that it would create a new program to compete with CBS's ''60 Minutes.'' ABC also announced that it was canceling ''One on One,'' an interview program that is broadcast following ''Nightline,'' a news program anchored by Ted Koppel.

title: MORGAN, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Physicians' Travel Reports Strong Start
description: The Physicians' Travel & Meeting Guide, which began its twice-ayear publishing schedule last January, is being called by its publisher ''the largest circulation periodical for doctors.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Secret Got Out On the Mayor's Stroll

title: Shrews in Male Form
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I enjoyed June P. Wilson's thoughts on irritability in the June 16 Hers column, being afflicted with the same excesses of sensory joy and frustration. Although I claim 40 years' less reason to be irritable, I believe the crowding of city existence - lives that overlap but do not intersect - induces symptoms of irritability virtually identical to those of the aging person's ''damaged sense of self.''

title: BIG ACCELERATOR ON LONG ISLAND GETS A 'NO' VOTE
description: A panel of top physicists who advise the Federal Government recommended yesterday that an incomplete atom smasher at the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island be scrapped.

title: Birdie Wins for Tuten
description: Billy Tuten of Palatka, Fla., the defending champion, defeated Billy Reilly of Tallassee, Ala., 2 and 1, in the first round of the United States Amateur Public Links championship today at the Hominy Hill Golf Course.

title: First Night Launching Set for Space Shuttle
description: The first night launching and landing of the space shuttle should provide a spectacular visual show for Americans, but the rest of the eighth shuttle mission will not have a lot of ''pizazz,'' Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, the mission's commander, said today at a news conference with the rest of the crew of five astronauts.

title: Mortgage Rates At 12.21% in June
description: The average contract interest rate on conventional home mortgages arranged in early June was 12.21 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The rate was compiled from major lenders that arranged financing for purchases of previously occupied homes.

title: Browns Lose Brown
description: The wide receiver Ron Brown, the Cleveland Browns' top draft choice, decided to forgo professional football to pursue a gold medal as a sprinter in the 1984 Olympics. Brown, a second-round selection from Arizona State, boarded an airplane to compete in several European track meets, according to his agent, Steve Arnold. Jim Bailey, Cleveland's vice president and general counsel, said he was ''upset and disappointed'' and accused Brown and Arnold of misrepresenting Brown's intentions.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective March 31.

title: ROSE PLANTED AS A FENCE TOO 'ORNERY' FOR FARMS
description: Farmers in southeastern Iowa are battling a rose species that was planted because the Federal Government said it would make good fencing.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON NERVE GAS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved production of nerve gas. The senators tied 49 to 49, and Vice President Bush cast the deciding vote as President of the Senate.

title: The U.N. Today; July 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $859,000 for the quarter and $958,000 for the 6 months, tax credits of $486,000 for the quarter and $861,000 for the 6 months, and losses of $113,000 for the quarter and $295,000 for the 6 months from Interferon Sciences in which the company owns a 75 percent stake. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $252,000 for the quarter and $328,000 for the 6 months, tax credits of $363,000 for the quarter and $4,444,000 for the 6 months, proceeds from the settlement of patent litigation of $11,452,000 for the 6 months, and losses of $153,000 for the quarter and $285,000 for the 6 months from Interferon Sciences.

title: SOVIET PROMISES U.S. IT WILL FREE SOME DISSIDENTS BY END OF 1983
description: The Soviet Union has assured the United States that it will allow some dissidents to emigrate by the end of the year, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: ONE SECOND TOO SOON
description: To the Editor:

title: British Output Grows
description: British industrial production rose 1 percent in May after a revised increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Government reported today.

title: Bridge: Players, if Not Promoters, Enjoy an Uncertain 'Final'
description: In tennis and other sporting events the word ''final'' in a knockout means exactly what it says: the competition has come to an end. In bridge, however, it can mean ''probably the end, but possibly the semifinal.''

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
No Headline
description: Required Reading Victims of Crime

title: ITALIAN JUDGE VISITS BULGARIA IN INQUIRY ON PAPAL SHOOTING
description: The judge investigating the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II in 1981 flew to Bulgaria this week to discuss what a lawyer said were new developments in the case.

title: GUIDRY BEATEN, ALLOWING 13 HITS
description: Ron Guidry pitched tonight for the first time in three weeks, but he encountered Ken Schrom and a band of torrid Twins.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
5 Thrift Units Get Federal Assistance
description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation granted $2.17 million assistance to five thrift institutions, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 4.
description: Share earnings are adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: Gas-Price Bill In Committee
description: A proposal to stretch out the removal of all price controls on natural gas to six years failed today in the Senate Energy Committee on a tie vote of 10 to 10.

title: DANCE: TWO FRENCH TROUPES MAKE U.S. DEBUT
description: Two new and exciting modern-dance troupes made their United States debut Tuesday night as part of the fivecompany ''Dance From France'' series at the American Dance Festival here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unless the appointment in place of Bernard Smith is withdrawn, there will not be another gubernatorial appointment confirmed during Mario Cuomo's term of office.'' - Warren M. Anderson, majority leader of the New York State Senate. (A1:1.)

title: White House Is Categorical
description: Larry Speakes, the spokesman for the White House, said again today that the Administration opposes an increase in the Federal Reserve's discount rate.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $193,000,000 for the quarter and $243,900,000 for the 6 months.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Columbia Savings and Loan Association announced that it had begun a $50 million offering of 11 5/8 percent certificates of deposit due in 1987, through Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp.'s Bendix unit announced that it would establish a major manufacturing and assembly facility in Bessemer City, N.C., to produce a complete line of factory automation systems.

title: Layoffs Seen For Peugeot
description: Peugeot S.A. plans to abolish 7,570 jobs through layoffs and early retirement, labor union sources said today.

title: GERE TO STAR IN PARAMOUNT'S 'DAVID'
description: Nearly 30 years after Moses parted the Red Sea in Cecil B. De Mille's ''Ten Commandments,'' Paramount Pictures, the home of Mr. De Mille, is bringing back the religious epic.

title: INFANTE DISMISSED BY BENGALS
description: General Manager Paul Brown of the Cincinnati Bengals today dismissed the team's offensive coordinator, Lindy Infante, saying Infante had breached his contract by agreeing Tuesday to become head coach of a new United States Football League team next season.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Americans in Salvador Report Death Threats
description: The United States Embassy said today that it had received death threats against American military and other personnel and has ordered new security precautions to protect them.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described the World Bank's borrowing plans. It ex- pects to borrow more than $30 billion over the next three years.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Australia II Upset By Italian Entry
description: In a shifty, 12-knot northwesterly breeze on Rhode Island Sound, Azzurra today upset Australia II to win by 32 seconds in the series to select the America's Cup challenger.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The company said liquidation of certain LIFO inventory quantities decreased net loss by $7,800,000 for the quarter and $20,900,000 for the 6 months of 1983.

title: JACK KEMP'S PERSONAL POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEE
description: In an anonymous commercial building on Capitol Hill, just a few minutes' walk from his office in the Rayburn building, Representative Jack F. Kemp keeps another suite of offices, the headquarters of Kemp Associates.

title: EDWIN DENBY, DANCE CRITIC, DIES AT 80
description: Edwin Denby, a poet and one of the most influential dance critics in America, committed suicide Tuesday night at his summer home in Searsport, Me. He was 80 years old and had been in ill health for several years. His death was ruled a suicide by the Waldo County Medical Examiner's Office, which said the details were ''privileged information.''

title: Lutheran Group Favors Restriction on Abortions
description: North America's second-largest Lutheran body today approved an abortion resolution that would permit the procedure only if it was necessary to save the woman's life.

title: Merrill Lynch Pulls Out Of Project in Cincinnati
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has withdrawn from the national computerized stock trading system of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, which is an attempt to develop an alternative to trading on exchange floors.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST CO (VACHERIE, LA) Q reports earnings for Op earn.
ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: GARDENERS' SEMINAR
description: Fall Planting and Food Preservation, the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, 212-757- 0915.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a foreign exchange loss of $10,000,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,400,000 for the quarter and $9,900,000 for the 6 months, a loss of $2.8 million for the quarter from an accounting change and net income of $700,000 for the 6 months from an accounting change.

title: Murphy Loses Appeal Of Abscam Sentence
description: Former Representative John M. Murphy of New York, who was convicted in the Federal Abscam investigation three years ago, today lost his appeal for a stay from a three-year prison term pending an appeal for a new trial.

title: NORTH CAROLINA PASSES ANTISLAVERY BILL TO AID FARM MIGRANTS
description: The North Carolina House of Representatives, in a move intended to protect migrant farm workers, today approved legislation that makes it a felony to hold a worker in involuntary servitude.

title: ROBERT I. COWEN
description: Robert I. Cowen, retired president and chairman of A. Goodman and Sons, manufacturer of noodle and macaroni products in Long Island City, Queens, died Tuesday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Quaker Oats Moves An Account to B.B.D.O.
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn is going to get more business from Quaker Oats.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago figures have been restated.

title: VICIOUS LITTLE FEUD IN LEBANON MAKES ISRAELIS WANT TO WASH THEIR HANDS
description: The reason the Israeli army wants to pull out of the mountains southeast of Beirut becomes dramatically clear at the first checkpoint travelers meet on the virtually deserted Beirut-Damascus highway. Two young militiamen in tight jeans with black pistols tucked into their belts frantically wave cars to the side of the road and one asks urgently, ''What religion are you?''

title: JULY 4 COULD DO WITHOUT 'TOYS OF WAR'
description: To the Editor:

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes income of $44,000 from tax effects.

title: NASH-FINCH CO reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
PROFITS UP AT MORGAN AND IRVING
description: Two major New York banks reported increased second-quarter earnings yesterday. J.P. Morgan & Company, the holding company for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said its net income rose 31.9 percent, to $115 million, and the Irving Bank Corporation reported a 19.6 percent increase, to $23.8 million. J.P. Morgan

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
McClain to Join Bloom Agency
description: Dennis McClain, 34-year-old executive vice president and creative director of Leber Katz Partners, is heading for Dallas, where he has agreed to become president of the main office of the Bloom Agency.

title: VASQUEZ APPEAL BID IS REJECTED BY COURT
description: Jacinto Vasquez came closer yesterday to serving a one-year suspension for attempted bribery when the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest judicial body, rejected the jockey's request for permission to appeal the suspension.

title: Alexander Trading Halted
description: Trading in the shares of Alexander & Alexander Inc. was halted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at the company's request amid rumors of a possible takeover of the troubled insurance broker, one of the last remaining independent brokers.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
Mother Ordered to Stand Trial In Beating Death of Son, 12
description: A judge today ordered Ethel Yarbough of the House of Judah religious camp to stand trial for manslaughter in the beating death of her 12-year-old son.

title: Just $8.88 Short Of a Million
description: When Jane Blalock finished in 18th place in the Peter Jackson Classic in Montreal on July 3, she thought she achieved a milestone in her professional golfing career. But she narrowly missed becoming the seventh golfer in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf Association to accumulate career purse winnings of $1 million.

title: NICKLAUS CALLED MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED
description: By Tom Watson's estimate, Jack Nicklaus, with whom he practiced today, ''still has a major left in him.'' Nicklaus has not won a major golf championship since 1980, but there are many here who agree with Watson that Nicklaus is a considerable force in the 112th British Open, which begins Thursday at the Royal Birkdale Golf Club.

title: LESSONS IN THE ART OF URBAN BEEKEEPING
description: GARY and Paula Korshin could be considered A-student graduates of the ''Beekeeping Workshop in the Big Apple'' recently held at the Alley Pond Environmental Center in Queens. On three Saturday mornings this spring, the Korshins, a young couple from Lynbrook, L.I., attended lectures on the care of the different species of honeybees (the Italian honeybee is the most common in this country), beekeepers' tools and garments and the construction of an apiary.

title: Tenneco Price Cut
description: Tenneco Inc. said it had lowered wholesale gasoline prices at several terminals in the Southeast, New York State and Pennsylvania by a tenth of a cent to 1.4 cents a gallon. For example, the company said, prices charged dealers accepting deliveries from its Doraville, Fla., terminal were reduced to 87.80 cents for regular leaded gasoline, 90.80 cents for regular unleaded and 95.30 cents for premium unleaded.

title: Hilton's Net Up 21.5%
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its second-quarter net income rose 21.5 percent to $28.3 million, or $1.05 a share, from $23.3 million, or 87 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Hilton said revenues for the 1983 quarter ended June 30 were $178.9 million, up 10.8 percent from $161.4 million a year earlier. Hilton credited higher occupancy levels at its hotels and improved casino earnings.

title: Five From U.S. Among Dead In Ecuadorean Airliner Crash
description: United States consular officials have announced that five Americans, including a family of three from Keasbey, N.J., were among the 119 people killed in an Ecuadorean jetliner that crashed into an Andean mountain pass Monday.

title: Court Seeks Delay In Hyster Move
description: A Dutch court today ordered the Hyster Company, a United States concern based in Portland, Ore., to freeze for three months a plan to transfer part of its Dutch operation to Scotland - or face a $345,000 fine.

title: Brazil-I.M.F. Talks
description: Brazil and the International Monetary Fund made progress today in critical debt talks which could lead to release of a delayed $411 million payment to Brazil, a Brazilian central bank spokesman said. But no details were released. The payment forms part of a $4.9 billion three-year loan approved by the I.M.F. in February.

title: Consumer Debt Rises $2.7 Billion
description: American consumers took on $2.7 billion more in credit in May than they paid off - the highest monthly net increase in two years - as purchases of cars and other durable goods picked up, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Dumb - and Dangerous
description: ''Usually I feel mildly virtuous, and a little admiring of the nurses who prepare you,'' reports a friend who gives blood once or twice a year. ''They must go batty asking all those required questions: Have you had dizzy spells? Hepatitis? Tuberculosis? Breakfast? When I went to the blood bank yesterday, I felt more virtuous - and a rush of sympathy for the people who work there.

title: COMMONS DEFEATS A MOVE TO BRING BACK HANGING
description: The House of Commons voted overwhelmingly today against restoring the death penalty for acts of terrorism and other crimes.

title: Gannett Profit Rises 4%
description: The Gannett Company reported today that its second-quarter profit rose 4 percent, to $52.5 million, or 99 cents a share. The newspaper chain's revenues grew 11 percent, to $427.2 million.

title: Concepcion: Bittersweet Days
description: As Johnny Bench made the first stop in his farewell tour of America this week, and as the Cincinnati Reds organization began to rebuild its management, Dave Concepcion sat and watched. Concepcion celebrated his 35th birthday last month, if ''celebrate'' is the right word.

title: Principal in Coke Talks Has Broad Background
description: More than two years ago, the Coca-Cola Company began a nationwide search for minority entrepreneurs with enough management skills and cash to invest in and run a Coke bottling franchise. This week, Coke may have found the people it has been seeking.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TIME FOR A FIRM U.S. STAND AGAINST APARTHEID
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL-STANDARD CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago third quarter results reflect a charge of 14 cents a share associated with the closing of a plant.

title: HOUSE PASSES $15.6 BILLION HOUSING BILL AFTER REDUCTION FOR G.O.P.
description: The House of Representatives passed a $15.6 billion housing bill today, the first new housing legislation since President Reagan took office. The vote was 263 to 158.

title: BLOCK SAYS FARM SESSION YIELDED NO FRESH IDEAS FOR NEW PROGRAM
description: After a two day meeting with 75 farm and agricultural business leaders, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that everyone agreed the country needed a new long-range farm policy. But, he said, nobody offered any totally new ideas on what it should be.

title: U.S. Agent Dies of Wounds
description: A Federal agent who was shot last week in an undercover operation in Miami died of wounds Tuesday night, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms reported today. The agent, Eddie Benitez, 27 years old, died shortly before midnight at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, a bureau spokesman said. Mr. Benitez was the third agent to be shot in recent months.

title: On College Degrees
description: Ralph Sampson, the No.1 choice in the National Basketball Association draft, may have his degree from the University of Virginia but, according to a telephone survey by the Chronicle of Higher Education, only 36 of the top 116 N.B.A. draftees earned degrees and 77 did not. It was not determined what was the status of the other three. The survey was published in The Chronicle's July 6 edition.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM HAS WIDER DEFICIT
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company, continuing to feel the impact of the nationwide lag in demand for aluminum products, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $51.3 million in the second quarter compared with a $30 million loss in the same quarter last year.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I recently bought a one-family brownstone and am having trouble with flooding in my basement. Every time we have a hard rain the water seems to back up through the floor drain in the shower of the basement bathroom, then water flows out over the whole lower part of the floor until it is about one inch deep. I had a sewer cleaning service come in to clean out the drain and the sewer line, but the problem remains. When the service was called back, they ran water into the drain and it ran out fine, so they say there is nothing further they can do. Do you have any suggestions as to what the problem can be?

title: Colt Industries Shows Profit
description: Colt Industries yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $26.2 million, or $1.06 a share, in contrast to a net loss of $164.8 million a year earlier, which included a provision of $193 million for the disposition of its steelmaking facility in Midland, Pa.

title: CHRYSLER CONFIRMS EARLY REPAYMENT
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, announced today that the company would pay off within a few weeks the remaining $800 million of federally guaranteed loans that saved the company from bankruptcy.

title: THE N.A.A.C.P.: VERGING ON IRRELEVANCE
description: While the Reagan Administration by its pronouncements and actions has made it clear that the civil rights laws and decisions of the 1960's and 70's are to be functionally repealed or at best made meaningless, the dominant activities of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have involved litigation with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund and the internal bickering and personal conflicts between the chairman of the Board of Directors, Margaret Bush Wilson, and its executive director, Benjamin Hooks. These signs of the erosion and increasing impotence of the once-effective N.A.A.C.P. are beyond embarrassment. They reflect a serious systemic disturbance that has been festering in the national structure of the N.A.A.C.P. for the last five years.

title: Docutel/Olivetti Reports Price Cut
description: The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation of Dallas announced that it had cut prices on its M20 personal computer by about 22 percent, to $2,295 for a basic system. It also introduced a second model called the M20 BP, which will retail for about $3,295.

title: A Desk With Teeth
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In the article of June 16 on the Chicago furniture show (''Technology and Tradition Mark Chicago Show''), you illustrate a desk by Wendell Castle with ''crenelated detailing.'' Well, if you turn the table upside down, then place tiny warriors with bows and arrows between each of the little blocks, you might get away with calling it crenelated detailing, since that is the name for the notched crowns of castle walls and towers. The proper term for those little pendent teeth (dentils) on the table's cornice is dentilated detailing. ROBERT O. VAUGHN West New York, N.J.

title: F.T.C. RESTRICTS AD CLAIMS OF 'SUPERIOR' PAIN RELIEVERS
description: A decade after charging that advertising for major pain relievers was deceptive, the Federal Trade Commission today ordered two major drug makers to drop claims of superiority for Bufferin, Excedrin, Bayer Aspirin, Cope, Vanquish and Midol.

title: AGENCY REAFFIRMS SAFETY OF 'SPONGE'
description: The Food and Drug Administration, in the face of criticism that its studies before approving a new contraceptive sponge were insufficiently thorough, today reaffirmed that it considered the sponge ''a safe and effective alternative method of contraception.''

title: Filene's to Switch To Hill, Holliday
description: Filene's, the department store that is a Boston byword, will switch agencies Aug. 1, going from one Boston giant, Ingalls Associates, to another, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
RESIDENTS OF TACOMA DISAGREE ON HEALTH RISKS OF COPPER PLANT
description: Julie Holden remembers that as a little girl playing outside her home in suburban Ruston she could sometimes taste in the air the chemicals emitted by the Asarco Inc. copper smelter there.

title: NO PROPOSALS OFFERED
description: The two sides in the New York City Opera labor dispute resumed negotiations yesterday for the first time since last Thursday, but the talks adjourned after two hours and no further meetings are scheduled until Tuesday.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS: A COOL, CANDID DEBATE
description: Amid the debate in the United States and other countries about when nuclear weapons should and should not be used, the State Department has released two historical volumes that recall how, 30 years ago, the United States tried to persuade its allies that there was no real difference between the use of nuclear and nonnuclear weapons.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Exhibition Fines
description: The National Basketball Association has fined 10 players $2,500 each for competing in a series of off-season exhibition games. Two teams that gave the players permission to compete last month in the Stroh's Basketball Challenge, a series of six games, were also fined $2,500.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HUNDREDS of millions of years ago, when dinosaurs were relative newcomers, the cockroach was already a well-established insect. It has adapted to all kinds of conditions, can survive for weeks without food or water and in many areas has even developed an immunity to frequently used insectides.

title: When Weapons Flunk
description: The Defense Department is gearing up for its biggest peacetime spending program, but its ability to buy the right weapons at the right cost looks as uncertain as ever. The General Accounting Office now documents the troubling history of a big weapons project, the Navy's plan to spend $40 billion to buy 1,377 new F-18 warplanes.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
NEW WAYS TO SAVE OUR WATER
description: ALTHOUGH we do not have a shortage of water this year, summer is a good time to evaluate home consumption of it. Since water is a limited resource, it makes sense to be thrifty with it.

title: U.S. Curbing Transit Rights Of Chinese Crossing Country
description: Chinese citizens have been deprived of privileges to travel through the United States without visas in retaliation for Peking's breach of a practice of mutual transit rights, the State Department said today.

title: NERVE GAS ARMS ARE AUTHORIZED IN SENATE VOTE
description: With Vice President Bush casting a rare tiebreaking vote, the Senate decided today to authorize $130 million for production of a new kind of nerve gas bombs and shells.

title: Rowing Pressure
description: The New York Athletic Club will be aiming for its 10th consecutive overall team crown in the United States Rowing Association championships beginning today and running through Sunday at the Eagle Creek Reservoir in Indianapolis. But the chairman of the N.Y.A.C.'s 115-year rowing program is not taking it for granted.

title: HOME BEAT
description: TWO exhibits offer views on the design importance and originality oft extiles from India and Africa.

title: British-U.S.  Trade Talks
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, flew to Washington today on a three-day trip in a bid to roll back United States trade restrictions on European steel and other products.

title: TV: A NEW PYGMALION
description: DOING a revival of George Bernard Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' for television is a lovely idea. The play, after all, is one of the irascible Dubliner's more clever and popular works, having done well on stage, in the movies and as the source for the magnificent musical ''My Fair Lady.'' Tonight, then, at 9 o'clock, a new production of ''Pygmalion'' can be seen on Showtime, the pay-cable channel that is available on several systems around the metropolitan area.

title: SUBWAY MOTORMEN BACKED BY RAVITCH
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that subway motormen did not speed like ''cowboys,'' as an M.T.A. consultant charged this week.

title: Cheating on Test Denied by Student
description: One of four recent high school graduates accused of cheating on his college entrance examination testified today that he did not give or receive answers before or during the test.

title: SEARLE, G D, & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Nigerian Debt Is Consolidated
description: Nigeria has signed an accord with 25 international banks consolidating trade debt arrears in a three-year loan, Barclays Bank International said today.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid February 11.

title: Whirlpool Net Up 12.4%
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that it earned $40.7 million in the second quarter, a 12.4 percent increase over the $36.2 million earned in the comparable 1982 period. Whirlpool, a maker of washing machines, dryers, refrigerators and other household appliances, said it had sales of $672 million in the quarter ended June 30, a 5.4 percent increase over sales of $637.8 million in the second quarter of 1982.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Help on Home Care For Victims of AIDS

title: GLENN SAID TO FUMBLE BUDGET ISSUE IN CAUCUS
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio fumbled a key question, by many accounts, as he and Walter F. Mondale pushed their Presidential aspirations today before a caucus of House Democrats. But Senator Glenn said he simply didn't understand the question.

title: REAGAN ELECTION AIDE SAYS HE SAW CARTER PAPERS
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts said that when he was coordinator of briefing material for Ronald Reagan in the 1980 Presidential campaign, a Reagan campaign aide gave him documents that appeared to have been prepared for use by President Carter.

title: Technology; Electricity: Fuel Cell Gains
description: IN this age of high technology, the way electricity is produced remains relatively primitive. ''It's comparable to how we used to calculate before we had computers,'' says Jack T. Brown, manager of Advanced Energy Conversion Systems at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. But with a ceramic tube the size of a policeman's nightstick, he and his colleagues plan to revolutionize the generation and distribution of energy. The tube is the basic unit of a new design for fuel cells, which are battery-like devices that generate electricity from gaseous fuels without having to burn them.

title: N.A.A.C.P., EYE ON '84, TO FOCUS ON BLACK VOTER DRIVE IN THE NORTH
description: Citing what they called widespread apathy among potential black voters in Northern states, officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that they were intensifying their program of voter registration in the North in an attempt to increase the political influence of blacks in Presidential and other elections.

title: Market Place; Brokers' View Of I.D.S. Deal
description: THE American Express Company never leaves home without its entrepreneurial spirit. Its latest bold move - an agreement in principle to acquire virtually all assets of the Alleghany Corporation for about $1 billion in stock - is being viewed as both Wall Street smart and Main Street smart.

title: CANADA FOUND TO VIOLATE WORLD TRADE RULES
description: An international panel has found that Canada, by far the largest trading partner of the United States, is violating principles of international trade by putting too many restrictions on foreign investors.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRAZIL CURBS PAY TO PERSUADE I.M.F. TO RESUME LOANS
description: In a move aimed at getting the money it needs to meet a debt payment due Friday, the Brazilian Government has agreed to curb the so-called indexation of its economy, a once-hailed innovation that protected workers' salaries against large increases in the cost of living.

title: THE VICTORY LAPS OF JOHNNY BENCH
description: E ighteen years ago last month, Johnny Lee Bench gave the valedictory speech at his high school graduation in Binger, Okla., a town of 600. The speech was titled ''How the Youth of Today Will Be the Leaders of the Next Generation.'' It is just the kind of subject on which 17-year-old kids are expert.

title: STAGE: 'KING RICHARD III' AT SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL
description: IN his first major venture into Shakespeare, Kevin Kline proves - and it's no surprise -that he could become one of the best classical actors of his generation. As Richard III, he must contend with a hump and the second longest role (after Hamlet) in the canon, but his athletic grace is unflagging and his command of the verse is sure. The performance is not, however, a success - and neither is the New York Shakespeare Festival production that surrounds him at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Mr. Kline is very smart - his director, Jane Howell, rather less so - and, in the course of a long and erratic evening, Shakespeare outwits them both.

title: A BANK'S CLOSING CAN JOLT AN AREA
description: To the merchants along Avenue D in Brooklyn the empty storefront is a sore spot, as painful and unsightly as the space left by a newly missing tooth.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ANDERSON TELLS SENATE TO CONVENE TO FIGHT CUOMO ON APPOINTMENTS
description: The leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate today ordered the Senate to reconvene July 25 to retaliate against Governor Cuomo for ousting a Republican from the State Commission of Investigation.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Turk Slain in Brussels; Armenians Claim Deed
description: An Armenian terrorist fatally shot a Turkish diplomat in the head at point-blank range today. Two Armenian nationalist groups took responsibility for the assassination of Dursun Aksoy, a Turkish Embassy attache.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOL AID: FOR WHOM AND WHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Jazz at Atrium
description: There will be free jazz concerts tonight and tomorrow at the atrium of the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.

title: CAPTAIN LET OFFICERS SET UP ROOF POOL
description: The commander of the police detail at Orchard Beach in the Bronx allowed a group of officers to install a swimming pool on the roof of the police substation there, department officials said yesterday.

title: Robbery Suspect Shot by Witness
description: A man who snatched a gold chain from a woman on the Upper West Side early yesterday was shot and wounded by another man who had apparently witnessed the crime, the police said. The man who shot the suspect left the scene just before police officers arrived.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $39 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Ex-Im Bank Cuts Rates
description: The Export-Import Bank today reduced by one percentage point the interest rate it charges on mediumterm loans used to finance purchases of American goods abroad.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S. GOVERNMENT'S EARLY KNOWLEDGE OF DIOXIN IN AGENT ORANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: ALONG WITH DEMON GOSSIP, A BIT OF COMIC RELIEF
description: As the O'Connor family stood on Pennsylvania Avenue and peered between the bars of the White House fence, the freckled faces of the youngsters bore witness to the goodness of ordinary Americans that all Presidents say is out there.

title: THREAT BY YANGTZE CALLED 'GRAVE'
description: The rain-swollen Yangtze River has begun to subside around the industrial center of Wuhan in central China but authorities have warned that danger of serious flooding downstream persists.

title: WHERE HUDSON RIVER SCHOOL BEGAN
description: On a clear day in the 1840's, Thomas Cole, the landscape painter, could look west from his home on a hillside in Catskill, N.Y., and see a 3,945-foot peak that is now named for him.

title: SMOG AFFECTS CALIFORNIA AREA
description: As Southern California sweltered through one of its smoggier days of the summer today, major industries were ordered to reduce pollution and put car pools into effect.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results include investment tax credits of $16.5 million for the latest 6 months and $13.5 million for the year- ago 6 months.

title: Ethiopian Urges Famine Aid
description: An Ethiopian official appealed today for aid to four million drought victims. Dawit Walde Giorgis, commissioner of Ethiopia's Relief and Rehabilitation Organization, said more than a million children were among those affected. He said his country needed about 900,000 tons of grain, as well as medical supplies and trucks.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S. Envoy in Manila Is Confident on Bases
description: The United States Ambassador, Michael H. Armacost, said today that he was confident Congress would approve the $900 million package pledged by the Reagan Administration to the Philippines for the use of military bases.

title: Alpen Gemutlichkeit
description: This is the first weekend of the German Alps Festival and Goebelfest at Hunter Mountain on Route 23A in Hunter, N.Y. in the northern Catskills. Today, tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to midnight, the festival will feature German food, drink and entertainment, while artists from the Goebel factory in Germany will give demonstrations and show films of their creations, including Goebel china and Hummel figurines. Admission is $4; $1.50 for those younger than 12, and free for under-6's. Information: (518) 263-3800.

title: Knoxville Told to Rehire 56 Officers and Firemen
description: A Federal district judge ordered the City of Knoxville today to reinstate 56 police officers and firefighters who were forced to retire in a cost-cutting campaign.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY BANK (MILWAUKEE, WIS) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Central Bank & Trust of Marshfield, Wisconsin on a pooling-of-interest basis on May 27, 1983.

title: BRIEFING
description: Honduran's Complaint

title: Challenger May Press Spinks
description: On a scale of 1 to 10, Eddie Mustafa Muhammad judged himself in top shape today as he prepared to challenge Michael Spinks in Friday night's light-heavyweight title fight here. But then, Mustafa Muhammad does not trust scales, especially before title fights with Michael Spinks.

title: 'STAYING ALIVE'
description: ONLY the presence of John Travolta turns ''Staying Alive'' from an unqualified disaster into a qualified one. Mr. Travolta is able to radiate warmth and sweetness even under the direst of circumstances, which are certainly the ones in which he finds himself here. As directed by Sylvester Stallone, who is also co-writer and coproducer, ''Staying Alive'' is a sequel with no understanding of what made its predecessor work. The first film was funny and touching, powered by a phenomenally successful score. This one is clumsy, mean spirited and amazingly unmusical.

title: CONROCK CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a net gain of $3.2 million, or 79 cents a share, from the sale of land. Year-ago results include a net gain of $5.2 million on the sale of land.

title: FIREWORKS FLARE FOR BASTILLE DAY
