description: As France celebrated the anniversary of its revolution with street dancing, fireworks and a display of military power down the Champs-Elysees, President Francois Mitterrand reiterated his commitment to a tough military posture but came close to ruling out intervention in the war in Chad.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1982.

title: EX-SALVADOR ENVOY'S WIFE FREED
description: Federal agents last night rescued the wife of a former Salvadoran Ambassador to Washington, who was kidnapped from her home near Miami last Friday.

title: Scripps Executive Retiring
description: Gordon Hanna, vice president and general editorial manager of Scripps-Howard Newspapers, announced today that he would retire at the end of the year. Charles E. Scripps, chairman of The E.W. Scripps Company, said Mr. Hanna would be succeeded by William Burleigh, editor of The Cincinnati Post.

title: FILM: 'ZELIG,' WOODY ALLEN'S STORY ABOUT A 'CHAMELEON MAN'
description: WHO was Leonard Zelig? These facts we know: that he was born in New York around the turn of the century into a Jewish immigrant family and that his father, Morris, was a Yiddish actor. The only reference to Morris in theater archives indicates that he was coolly received when he played Puck in an orthodox version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HAYES-DANA LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: MUSIC WITHOUT WALLS IN ALL TYPES OF SETTINGS
description: MANY great composers have found inspiration in nature. It is said that Beethoven used to thrash through the woods, tinkering with nascent melodies along the way. The French composer Olivier Messiaen rises at dawn every day to listen to morning birdsong. Natural surroundings can provide an excellent ambience for experiencing music of all kinds.

title: GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 24.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Reactivated Joe N olan, catcher, out since June 21 with b roken left toe. Optioned John Stefero, c atcher, to Rochester of International L eague. CLEVELAND (AL) - Recalled Otto V elez, outfielder, from Charleston farm t eam. Sent down Miguel Dilone, outfield- e r, to Charleton.

title: IN STORIED ASIA MOUNTAINS, A SOVIET SUCCESS STORY
description: Traveling through this remote corner of the southern Soviet Union is a constant reminder of the country's suspension between two worlds - the worlds of Europe and Asia, of Communist atheism and Moslem traditionalism, of modern technology and of rural ways of life that in some respects have changed little since caravans passed this way along the old silk route to Cathay.

title: A Timely Award For Con Ed Striker
description: For John Jawor, the money could not have come at a better time. Yesterday he put down his picket sign at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., in Westchester County, long enough to receive a $15,000 award from Consolidated Edison, the utility he and 16,500 others have been striking for 27 days.

title: SINGLES ASK WHY A GOOD MAN NOW IS HARD TO FIND
description: ''Why is it,'' Ed Gittinger, who is in real estate, wanted to know, ''that the first thing women ask you when you meet is 'What do you do for a living?' ''

title: STADLER'S 7-UNDER-PAR 64 LEADS BRITISH OPEN BY 3
description: The Walrus and an albatross dominated the start of the British Open today. The Walrus, Craig Stadler, overwhelmed the Royal Birkdale Golf Club with a seven-under-par 64. On the back nine he birdied five consecutive holes, the last three on putts of 30, 30 and 40 feet.

title: News Analysis
description: Early this week, a difference of opinion developed between Martin E. Segal, chairman of Lincoln Center, and Richmond Crinkley, executive director of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, over who had the authority to schedule Peter Brook's adaptation of Bizet's ''Carmen'' to open at the Beaumont on Oct. 24. Mr. Segal was the one who negotiated the deal, and Mr. Crinkley enthusiastically approved of it, but there was a sharp difference of opinion between them as to whether the Lincoln Center board or the Beaumont board should have the final say.

title: HOUSE VOTES TRADE PART OF CARIBBEAN BASIN PLAN
description: The House of Representatives, with the nearly unanimous support of the Republican minority, today approved a scaled-down version of the trade portion of President Reagan's 1982 Caribbean Basin Initiative.

title: 2 SCHOOL PRAYER AMENDMENTS SENT TO SENATE FLOOR BY PANEL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today sent to the Senate floor two proposed constitutional amendments that would sanction different forms of organized prayer in public schools.

title: FILM: 'ZELIG,' WOODY ALLEN'S STORY ABOUT A 'CHAMELEON MAN'
description: WHO was Leonard Zelig? These facts we know: that he was born in New York around the turn of the century into a Jewish immigrant family and that his father, Morris, was a Yiddish actor. The only reference to Morris in theater archives indicates that he was coolly received when he played Puck in an orthodox version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Where to Put a Ship?

title: JUDGE BELITTLES REPORTS OF PLOT
description: A Federal judge today dismissed as ''a bunch of talk'' allegations that a defendant in a drug case he was handling intended to have him killed.

title: Token of Esteem
description: At 11 A.M. next Tuesday, Bryan Trottier and Denis Potvin of the Islanders and Nick Fotiu of the Rangers will demonstrate the basics of street hockey to 1,000 youngsters at a Mobil Big Apple Games clinic at the Felt Forum. Trottier, though, will do more than make an appearance.

title: EXHIBIT ON GROWTH OF NEW YORK AS A CITY OF RENTERS
description: Since early June, an exhibition on housing development in the city over the last 170 years has been on display, and to specialists in the housing field it has an interest that goes beyond the visual.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1983.

title: FOR L.I. ATOM LAB'S WORKERS, A DEATH WATCH FOR A DREAM
description: For five years, Marty Woodle has carried a small loose-leaf notebook, scribbling down ideas as he went about his job at the Brookhaven National Laboratory. Today, he crossed out almost everything in the notebook.

title: Topics; Changes of Atmosphere; Senior Campers
description: Country air, that heady scent of flowers, grass and trees, is a commonplace to those who live in it - and a great treat to those who live with exhaust fumes. It is also a luxury well beyond the reach of many older New Yorkers.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid March 25 and the sale through public offering of 410,000 shares on April 20.

title: LED U.S. AGENCIES
description: Joseph J. O'Connell Jr., a lawyer and former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board and the National Transportation Safety Board, died of a heart attack at his home in Delray Beach, Fla., on Wednesday. He was 77 years old.

title: PREHISTORIC ANIMAL DENS FOUND IN NEBRASKA
description: Scientists in Nebraska have discovered a large complex of prehistoric animal dens containing the fossils of predatory mammals, a finding that, they say, extends the record of denning behavior by large carnivores to 20 million years ago.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Jews Who Reject Israel Inflame Jerusalem Area
description: The police set up a special task force today to enforce law and order in the Mea Shearim quarter of Jerusalem, the bastion of Jewish religious militants who reject the state of Israel as a heresy.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
'THE MERRY WAHVS OF WINZUH' TOURS CITY
description: It takes a bit of getting used to at first. There is fat Sir John Falstaff, drawling out, ''Pistol, did YEW pee-ick Master Slender's purse?'' in an accent that is pure moonlight and molasses. But then the Riverside Shakespeare Company's version of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' takes the leap from Elizabethan England to post-Civil War New Orleans, and is off and running.

title: STOCKS UP SLIGHTLY; VOLUME GROWS
description: Reports of sharply higher corporate earnings lifted stock market prices yesterday by renewing investor interest in selective blue chip issues. But the gains from an early morning rally were cut by late afternoon.

title: Coach Is Angry
description: Jim Joseph, the owner of the Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League, is angry. He blames the intrusion of a rival U.S.F.L. club, the Los Angeles Express, for the loss of Eric Dickerson, the star tailback from Southern Methodist who signed this week with the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP (IBM) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
News Analysis
description: The Chrysler Corporation's announcement that it will repay within weeks the remaining $800 million of Government-guaranteed loans that saved it from bankruptcy just a few years ago is a dramatic indication, as it was intended to be, of the sharp reversal of the company's fortunes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dog Days on 47th Street S unlight glittered off the gems in some West 47th Street shop windows between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday. But many stood empty as the diamond district observed its vacation.

title: NAVY WARNED ON PARTS PRICES
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger told Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. today that he was extremely displeased with the Navy for paying $110 for electronic diodes costing 4 cents and then resisting auditors, the Pentagon's spokesman said.

title: DELOREAN LAWYERS CHARGE BREAK-IN
description: Lawyers for John Z. DeLorean and a codefendant in a $24 million cocaine smuggling case accused Federal agents today of committing illegal break-ins to obtain critical evidence.

title: Auto Racecourse Bought by Corning
description: Directors of a Corning Glass Works subsidiary voted today to buy the Watkins Glen race track from the Bank of New York and to open it for auto racing next year, a spokesman said.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN, 8-0, ON 2-HITTER BY LEAL
description: Luis Leal tossed a two-hitter and Buck Martinez and Rance Mulliniks hit home runs tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Chicago White Sox, 8-0.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: WOMETCO ENERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $777,000 from the sale of a small theater.

title: TESTERS VS. STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: New tandoori and old Continental.
description: GULMORE is the latest addition to the growing restaurant scene on Second Avenue between 80th and 85th Streets. A tiny, two-month-old Indian restaurant with a tandoori oven, it holds promise for inexpensive meals in an attractive, relaxed setting.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 15, 1983
description: International New fighting in Nicaragua is being pressed by rebels led by Eden Pastora Gomez with newly acquired aid from other Latin American countries, according to leaders of Nicaraguan exile groups in Costa Rica. Alfonso Robelo Callejas, an exiled former member of the ruling Sandinista junta, said the rebels were planning ''a few surprises'' next week for the fourth anniversary of the overthrow of Anastasio Somoza Debayle. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Brazil began a new austerity program in an effort to secure a resumption of loan payments from the International Monetary Fund. The Government has instituted a law restricting pay increases across the country in the next two years to a level 20 percent below the cost of living figure. (A1:4.)

title: CRUMP, E H, COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition.

title: EX-REP. RICHMOND AT HALFWAY HOUSE
description: Former Representative Frederick W. Richmond has been transfered to a halfway house in Brooklyn to complete his sentence for tax evasion, possession of marijuana and making an illegal payment, officials said yesterday.

title: Ford Will Resume Paying a Dividend
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would pay a dividend of 30 cents a share in the third quarter, its first dividend since the last quarter of 1981.

title: BETH DANIEL LEADS BY 2 STROKES ON A 67
description: Beth Daniel, who has not won a tournament since last August, took the first-round lead today in the $350,000 McDonald's Kids Classic with a five-under-par 67.

title: N.Y.R.A. CHOOSES SILENT SURRENDER
description: Who owns the race track? Horseplayers sometimes feel as if they do when they are on a winning streak, and in New York it appears they may be right: The New York Racing Association, which operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, finally may have conceded that those three tracks belong to the state of New York and its people, not to the N.Y.R.A.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
SENATE VOTES INDEPENDENT AGENCY TO MONITOR PENTAGON ARMS TESTS
description: Brushing aside Defense Department opposition, the Senate voted 91 to 5 today to establish an independent office to monitor the effectiveness of weapon testing by the Pentagon.

title: I.B.M. EARNINGS UP 24.1% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, citing a sharp rise in computer equipment sales and continuing improvement in operating margins, reported yesterday that earnings for the second quarter soared 24.1 percent, to $1.34 billion, one of its largest quarterly profits ever.

title: Fire at Luxury Condominium
description: Fire erupted on the 8th floor of a 32-story luxury condominium today, driving pajama-clad residents from their apartments.

title: Sprinter's Criticism
description: Mel Lattany is critical of the selection process that kept him off the United States team that will compete in the world track and field championships next month in Helsinki, Finland. ''Everything is won and lost at the U.S. championships,'' said the 23-year-old Lattany, who lost his shoe during the 100-meter dash in the championships last month and failed to reach the final in that event or in the 200 meters.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,858,000 for the quarter and $8,820,000 for the 6 months.

title: 'PIGS' ON THE TRAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: SUMMIT BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
EASTERN AIR LINES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CALIFORNIA IS TOLD TO PAY WELFARE
description: The California Supreme Court ordered the state today to send counties money so 1.6 million welfare recipients, mostly mothers and children, will receive checks despite a state budget deadlock.

title: Roosevelt Sykes, Blues Player Wrote Hit Songs
description: The Chicago blues pianist and singer Roosevelt Sykes died of an apparent heart attack on Monday at Charity Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Friday; MOZART AND FRIENDS
description: In 1981, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg won the Walter W. Naumburg International Violin Competition. Since then, she has performed at Carnegie and Alice Tully Halls. At Avery Fisher Hall tonight and tomorrow night at 8, she and the pianist Emanuel Ax will perform with the Mostly Mozart Festival orchestra conducted by Gerard Schwarz. The program consists of two Mozart pieces, the Piano Concerto No. 21 in C (K. 467) and the Violin Concerto No. 3 in G (K. 216). Also on the program are Bach's Sinfonia in D and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 4 in A (Op. 90). There are still tickets at $8 for the second and third tier. As is the custom, a free preconcert recital by one of the performers - which one has not yet been revealed - will be given at Fisher Hall from 7 to 7:30 P.M. Box office: 874-2424.

title: Whose Prayer to Whom?
description: If this nation chose to allow organized prayer in the public schools, who would write the prayer, and to Whom? Not the states or the Federal Government, now says President Reagan. Bowing to the valid concerns of some churches, he agrees that any constitutional amendment stipulate that no official shall ''compose the words'' of school prayers.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HOW AN AMENDMENT GREW AND GREW
description: Few things in Congress are as they seem, a tradition that is assiduously nurtured by the members themselves. Those watching televised debates of proceedings in the House of Representatives are sometimes surprised to find entire passages deleted from the Congressional Record. Similarly, the transcripts of committee hearings occasionally depart quite substantively from the hearings themselves.

title: SMITH, A O, CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'INNOCUOUS' VIDEOTAPES FOUND
description: Several videotapes were found in Vicki Morgan's apartment by detectives investigating her murder, but her lawyer said today that the material appeared to be innocuous and did not reveal Government officials in sex acts.

title: ASSETS RISE AT MONEY FUNDS
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $252 million last week, to $165.53 billion, for the first weekly gain since last Dec. 1, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $169,000 for the quarter and $311,100 for the 6 months.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HASBRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February and a 3-for-2 stock split in August.

title: NO NICE FACE FOR DEATH
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. -Sometime within the next year, if all goes according to schedule, Thomas E. Ramseur will be executed by the State of New Jersey. When that occurs, there will be another public confrontation over the morality of the death penalty and over its usefulness as a deterrent to criminal behavior. But in this instance, the method of execution will itself become a subject of controversy.

title: Home Loan Bank Board To Lose Senior Member
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is losing its most senior member with the resignation Sept. 1 of James J. Jackson. Mr. Jackson said the savings and loan industry is in a stronger position than it was last year, largely because of the board's efforts toward deregulation.

title: CLIFFORD E. PAINE
description: Clifford E. Paine, designer and supervising engineer of the 4,200-foot Golden Gate Bridge at San Francisco, died Tuesday at the Allegan County Medical Facility. He was 95 years old. Mr. Paine, who also worked on the Arlington Memorial Bridge over the Potomac River, is survived by two sons, Clifford Jr. and Robert, four grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COORS, ADOLPH, CO reports earnings for qtr to June 12.
Cannon Testifies
description: The former football star Billy Cannon appeared for 50 minutes yesterday before a Federal grand jury in Baton Rouge, La., having struck a deal to testify against those accused of being fellow conspirators in a $4.75 million counterfeiting scheme, court records showed. Papers signed by United States Attorney Rand Miller said Cannon would waive indictment and plead guilty to a single charge of conspiracy and possession of counterfeit $100 Federal Reserve notes.

title: RAYTHEON FALLS 9.3%
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that hightechnology sales and a rebound in consumer durables sales contributed to record second-quarter earnings. The company said net income increased by 12 percent, to $521 million, or $1.15 a share, from $465 million, or $1.03 a share, in the second quarter last year.

title: Jo Jo White Dropped
description: Larry Brown, who left the Nets late last season to replace Ted Owens as the basketball coach at the University of Kansas, dismissed Jo Jo White as one of his assistants yesterday.

title: SALNIKOV SWIMS TO 800 RECORD
description: Vladimir Salnikov of the Soviet Union broke his world record in the 800-meter freestyle today in the opening competition of a four-day international swim meet. It is the first competition at the new University of Southern California pool, which will be used for the Olympic Games next year.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES CLIMB A BIT
description: Interest rates fell early yesterday, but weak demand later eliminated most of the declines. By the close of the day, most shortterm rates were slightly higher, while yields fell for Treasury issues due in five years or longer.

title: Economic Scene; The Fading Of Monetarism
description: THE Fed-watchers - those financial hawks of Wall Street who are to the Federal Reserve what Kremlinologists are to the Soviet Union - will be putting Paul A. Volcker's testimony at his reconfirmation hearing yesterday under a high-powered microscope in an effort to discover what it signifies for future levels of interest rates, stock and bond prices and the economic recovery. In their zeal, they will probably discover more than is actually there, as the Fed struggles to keep its options open.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of 1,200,000 for the quarter and $2,800,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary gain of $4,500,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss after a loss of $2,200,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $3,000,000 from discontinued operations.

title: John Blair Stations
description: John Blair & Co. said it had agreed to acquire four Fairbanks Broadcasting Company radio stations for $50 million in cash.

title: Upstate Village Clerk Is Held As a Hostage for Two Hours
description: A man with a rifle held the Village Clerk here hostage in a bell tower for two and a half hours today before the state police shot him in the wrist and arrested him, the police said.

title: UNITED STATES HOME INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,026,000.

title: BLUES: ALBERT KING GUITAR
description: THE veteran blues guitarist Albert King showed up at the Lone Star Cafe on Thursday leading what may be the only blues band to include a pedal steel guitar. It was a smart choice.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Dutchman Wins 118-Mile Stage
description: Henk Lubberding of the Netherlands won the 118-mile 13th leg of the Tour de France bicycle race today with a time of 6 hours 6 seconds.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TEAMSTERS UNION HELD NEAR ACCORD
description: The teamsters' union and trucking industry officials are close to an agreement that would sharply cut the wages and benefits of workers who may be rehired from the current pool of unemployed drivers.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
Carmen Lundy at Noon
description: The singer Carmen Lundy and her trio will appear today at noon as part of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council's Women in Jazz Festival, at New York Plaza, Water and Broad Streets at South Ferry. Admission is free. The number for more information is 269-0320.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Tribune Co. May Offer $100 Million of Stock
description: The Tribune Company, which owns The Daily News in New York City, The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers and broadcast operations, indicated yesterday that it would try to raise $100 million through an initial public stock offering that could come as early as October.

title: Market Place; Cash Strategy In Bull Market
description: INTEREST rates have moved higher since the middle of May and stock prices have edged lower since the middle of June, proving again that rates often call the tune in advance for the equity markets. But money keeps pouring into the coffers of investment advisers. What stocks have they been buying lately?

title: GUARDING AGAINST HIGH-TECH ESPIONAGE
description: As world leader in computers and telecommunications, the United States entered the Information Age with a considerable head start over other developed nations. Yet our lead in high technology makes us a prime target for international espionage and even sabotage.

title: Mack Truck Debt Rating Lowered
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced its rating on senior debt of Mack Trucks Inc. to a speculative grade of BB+ from BBB and the senior debt of the Mack Financial Corporation to BB+ from BBB.

title: A WACKY POP ICONOCLAST
description: Every so often, Manhattan's percolating downtown music scene produces a personality so engaging and original that word of mouth spreads beyond bohemian inner circles to attract a larger cult audience. Frank Maya, the wiry, impish singer, songwriter, bandleader and poet who is performing two shows tomorrow night at Folk City (130 West Third Street), is a wacky pop iconoclast with enough star quality to have earned comparisons to performers as dissimilar as Laurie Anderson, David Byrne and Peter Allen.

title: NICARAGUAN EXILES RESUMING FIGHTING
description: The forces of Eden Pastora Gomez, bolstered by newly acquired aid from within Latin America, are resuming their fight against his former Sandinista comrades in Nicaragua, according to leaders of Nicaraguan exile groups here.

title: Topics; Changes of Atmosphere; Abridged
description: The collapse of the Mianus River bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike has made so much trouble for so many people that no one has yet stopped to recall another bridge collapse, only 28 years ago, on what was then the main highway leading from New York City to the Connecticut shore.

title: News Anaylsis
description: As an arm of government, the New York State Commission of Investigation has rarely been popular. In recent years, some detractors have accused the agency of undertaking partisan-style investigations to embarrass politicians. Other critics, mainly law-enforcement officials, said the commission was poorly run and had accomplished little over the last decade in exposing corruption or organized-crime activities.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Results have been restated to reflect acquisitions of Infotecs Inc. in September 1982 and Insurance blishing & Computers Inc. in April 1983, both of which were accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S.-SOVIET ARMS TALKS ADJOURN
description: The latest round of talks between the Soviet Union and the United States on reducing intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe ended here today with no outward sign of progress.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SALES RATIO FALLS
description: The nation's businesses increased their inventories by three-tenths of 1 percent in May, but sales rose a strong 3.3 percent, the biggest month-to-month jump in four years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $63,000 for the quarter and $161,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $86,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: METS AND SEAVER DEFEAT REDS
description: After being strongly criticized by Manager Frank Howard for uninspired play in recent games, the Mets played last night as if they were hungry again.

title: A Daily Double For Robin Hood
description: When an archer splits a competitor's arrow that is already imbedded in the target, the feat is called a Robin Hood. Allan Martin, the president of the National Archery Association of the United States, estimates that it occurs ''once in 20,000 to 50,000 shots in outdoor tournaments.''

title: PANEL PRESSING CARTER PAPERS INQUIRY
description: A House subcommittee voted unanimously today to pursue an investigation of conduct in the 1980 Presidential campaign and adopted guidelines intended to make sure the inquiry is bipartisan.

title: INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $63,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $38,000.

title: MARINE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
The long trip from idea to movie house.
description: WHETHER you're as unknown as Charlie Loventhal or as famous as Barbra Streisand, it sometimes takes a long while to get a beloved project into a movie house.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $1.4 million from discontinued operations.

title: St. John's Appeal
description: St. John's will appeal to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council next month for the eligibility of Walter Berry, the 6-foot-8-inch basketball star from Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan. Meanwhile, the university announced yesterday that Berry, a former secondary school all-American, had reached the status of a matriculating student and had completed 24 credits toward a college degree in teacher education.

title: MONDALE AND GLENN TEST THEMES OF CAMPAIGN AT DEMOCRATS' PANEL
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio tested the main themes of their Presidential campaigns here today on members of the Democratic National Committee.

title: GOLF TAKES OVER WITH BRITISH OPEN
description: GOLF is prominently on display this weekend as ABC Sports prepares to give considerable live coverage to the British Open, beginning at noon tomorrow and at 11 A.M. on Sunday. The 112th presentation of this classic meet will be held at Southport, England's Royal Birkdale site. Tom Watson, winner of four of the last eight opens, would have to be considered the favorite, but the sportscasters note, when the event was set in Royal Birkdale in 1976 he didn't even make the final-round cut. Hopping on Knuckles And Skinning a Seal

title: Officer Convicted Of Extortion
description: A suspended New York City police officer was convicted yesterday of extortion and conspiracy charges growing out of an investigation of after-hours clubs.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: JUNIOR MANCE was at the piano, Marty Rivera on bass; Virginia ham was being sliced, and biscuits, f ried chicken and cole slaw piled on plates. ''New Orleans North,'' s omebody called it, but what it was was a down-home party a few n ights ago for all the musicians who will be playing in the GreenwichV illage Jazz Festival next month.

title: Segregated Club Out as Golf Host
description: Amid a growing controversy over its racially exclusive membership policies, Northgreen Country Club announced today that it was withdrawing as the annual host of the Atlantic Coast Conference golf tournament.

title: STATEMENTS FROM GOVERNOR CUOMO AND SENATOR ANDERSON
description: Following are statements by the majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, a Republican of Binghamton, and Governor Cuomo on Mr. Cuomo's appointments to the agency formally known as the State Commission of Investigation: By Mr. Anderson

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on July 7 about a management change at Warnaco Inc. misidentified Arthur Warshaw. He is president of the company's knitwear division.

title: Still Soft on Housing Bigots
description: The Reagan Administration has embarked on a long-overdue civil rights offensive. One day it challenges segregation in Alabama colleges. The next day it proposes tougher enforcement of fair housing laws. The flurry of activity may be motivated by the political calendar and the knowledge that nine out of ten blacks disapprove of the Administration. But that makes it no less welcome.

title: Required Reading; Apologies to George
description: Colloquy about the 1964 and 1980 Presidential campaigns, between Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, in the Senate, July 11, 1983:

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION DOESN'T MEAN QUOTAS
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN MARCONI LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings do not reflect a proposed 4-for-1 stock split announced June 14.

title: GABRIELLE ROY
description: Gabrielle Roy died last night at the age of 74, just as the film version of her best-known novel, ''Bonheur d'Occasion,'' had its world premiere at the Moscow Film Festival.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Home Improvement column in The Home Section yesterday incor- rectly described the use of boric acid as an insecticide for cockroaches. It is poisonous to humans and pets.

title: PUBLISHING: WHAT'S SELLING BEST IN '83
description: SALES of best selling books were mixed during the first six months of 1983, according to figures compiled yesterday by The New York Times.

title: U.S. POLICY TOWARD LATINS: LINES OF CONTROL ARE BLURRED
description: For a month the State Department has been struggling to regain control of Administration policy toward Central America, but White House involvement remains strong and many officials say the lines of authority are so diffuse and collegial that it is hard to pinpoint precisely who runs policy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It means the end of a career. You just don't go around finding another job in cryogenics like you find a 7-Eleven.''

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 11.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest periods include the operations of Frank's Nursery & Craft Inc. since March 7, the date of acquisition.

title: ALLIED NET DECLINES 4.5%
description: The Allied Corporation reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings fell 4.5 percent, to $106 million, or $1.55 a share, from $111 million, or $1.86 a share, in the 1982 period.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
POLL FINDS TRUST IN GOVERNMENT EDGING BACK UP
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, Americans are expressing increased confidence in their Government, according to national polling by the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan.

title: Touring City Housing
description: The Municipal Art Society will offer a bus tour of housing developments in Upper Manhattan and the Bronx tomorrow from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. in conjunction with the society's ''At Home in the City'' exhibition, which illustrates New York's residential history and development.

title: Tandem Licenses Sought by O'Neill
description: Connecticut, which lost its first round in court to ban double-trailer trucks, moved today to require the drivers of the large rigs to obtain special licenses.

title: Australia II Wins Race in Cup Trial
description: Australia II, which was seeded first, defeated Challenge 12, the second-seeded yacht, by 47 seconds today in the series to select the America's Cup challenger.

title: Big market in Americana.
description: AMERICAN art, furniture and the decorative arts, with which the art-auction houses did well all season, were even better sellers for them after Jan. 1, producing some remarkable prices.

title: ART: PEARLSTEIN'S REALITY
description: THE touchy subject of realism is up for consideration again, at the Brooklyn Museum. This is where a retrospective by Philip Pearlstein, having originated at the Milwaukee Art Museum under the direction of its chief curator, Russell Bowman, opens tomorrow. The exhibition, on view through Sept. 18, is paralleled by a small display of the artist's recent works on paper at the Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57 Street (closing Aug. 17).

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SKETCHES OF 2 REPRESENTATIVES
description: Gerry E. Studds

title: REJUVENATED SEAPORT IS DUE TO OPEN JULY 28
description: The South Street Seaport - a new complex of restaurants, cafes, speciality stores, museum space, pedestrian malls, public terraces with waterfront views and restored 19th-century row houses - is scheduled to open July 28 in the area just southwest of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Sperry Venture
description: The Federal Reserve Board is allowing the Citicorp bank and the Sperry Corporation to operate a joint venture to finance farm equipment.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE FOREST. An Iron Curtain Journey. By Anthony Bai- ley. 332 pages. Random House. $15.95.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $32,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $338,000 for the 6 months, and a gain from the sale of securities of $545,000 for the quarter. c-After extraordinary credits of $205,000 for the quarter and $1,152,000 for the 6 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mayor Takes Subway With Plenty of Company

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
House Committee Approves New Head for Budget Office
description: The House Budget Committee unanimously approved Rudolph Penner today to be the new director of the Congressional Budget Office.

title: REFUSING THE ROPE
description: Despite the support of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the House of Commons has refused to reinstate the death penalty in Britain, leaving the Soviet Union, South Africa, Japan and the United States as the only industrialized states that officially put people to death.

title: Baldwin's Rating Cut, But 3 Units Fare Better
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced a further reduction in the debt rating of the Baldwin-United Corporation and one of its affiliates, but reaffirmed its high-grade ratings on the claims-paying ability of three of Baldwin's other affiliates.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
2 Gold Dealers Arrested
description: William and James Alderdice, owners of the International Gold Bullion Exchange, were arrested at their home here today. They were charged with grand larceny and securities fraud relating to their operation of I.G.B.E. The company, which had been one of the largest gold and silver dealers in the nation, is now in bankruptcy proceedings. Acting on indictments returned by a grand jury in Westchester County, the Fort Lauderdale police made the arrests.

title: Grumman Denies Reports of Move
description: The Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., in response to reports that it was meeting with Georgia officals, said it was not considering moving its principal aircraft operations to Georgia from New York.

title: LANDLORD GIVEN A YEAR FOR THREATS TO TENANTS
description: A Manhattan landlord was sentenced to a year in jail and fined $15,000 yesterday for using threats of violence to force tenants out of two Manhattan rooming houses he owns.

title: 15 HITS TROUNCE YANKEES
description: Charlie Hough knows his pitches are not the fastest in the big leagues. ''They don't use a radar gun,'' the Texas Rangers' knuckleball specialist said when asked the speed of his fluttering offerings. ''They use an hour-glass.''

title: THE QUEEN GIVES A GARDEN PARTY FOR 8,000
description: Pity the poor woman who upon arriving at Buckingham Palace to take tea with the Queen slipped and fell on the entrance steps and had to be carted off in an ambulance with a broken arm before the first crumpet was served.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Appeasing India's Nuclear Blackmail
description: On his recent visit to India, Secretary of State George Shultz brought a gift, a guarantee of parts to repair the radiation-leaking nuclear reactors at Tarapur. It was not only a gift but a giveaway: it undid the United States' main leverage over a country that has already exploded one atomic device by flouting nuclear safeguards and apparently intends to do it again.

title: VOLCKER SUGGESTS HE MAY NOT SERVE FULL 4-YEAR TERM
description: Paul A. Volcker indicated today that he might not remain as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for the full four years of a second term, and that he might resign in the months following the Presidential election next year.

title: Buffalo Thrift Unit To Offer Stock
description: Empire of America Federal Savings Association of Buffalo announced a major stock offering yesterday.

title: FILM: 'ZELIG,' WOODY ALLEN'S STORY ABOUT A 'CHAMELEON MAN'
description: WHO was Leonard Zelig? These facts we know: that he was born in New York around the turn of the century into a Jewish immigrant family and that his father, Morris, was a Yiddish actor. The only reference to Morris in theater archives indicates that he was coolly received when he played Puck in an orthodox version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: SOVIET COOL TO ARAFAT IN HIS DISPUTE WITH SYRIANS
description: In meetings this week with a high official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko appears to have refused to throw the Kremlin's weight behind Yasir Arafat, head of the guerrilla movement.

title: BLOOD SUPPLIES SAID TO REMAIN PERILOUSLY LOW
description: The director of the Greater New York Blood Program said yesterday that blood supplies remained critically low and that hospitals in the metropolitan region were being advised that type O negative blood should be used only in emergency cases.

title: Cabinet Asked to Help Recover Student Loans
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell asked fellow Cabinet members today to help recover more than $65 million in defaulted Government student loans from about 41,000 active and retired Federal employees.

title: Cardinals 6, Giants 5
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Floyd Rayford hit a two-run, pinch-hit homer in the ninth inning to cap a three-run rally for St. Louis. Trailing by 4-3, the Cardinals tied the score on a pinch-hit double by David Green and a run-scoring single by Tom Herr off Gary Lavelle (6-3).

title: BVD to Start Ads With Larry Hagman
description: Viewers of ''Dallas'' on CBS-TV on July 25 are in for a very special treat - a really inside look at Larry Hagman, who plays the hateful J.R. Ewing.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GEORGIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect an acquisition.

title: Tribute to Harry Chapin
description: A memorial concert for the singer and songwriter Harry Chapin will be given tomorrow at midnight at the Bottom Line, West Fourth and Mercer Streets.

title: BANK SECURITIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
The U.N. Today; July 15, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Amnesty Group Charges Torture in Mauritania
description: Amnesty International charged Mauritania's military rulers today with torturing prisoners suspected of political opposition.

title: 2 Bolivian Officials Quit
description: Bolivia's Planning Minister, Arturo Nunez del Prado, and its Finance Minister, Flavio Machicado, resigned today, saying they hoped their decisions would heal the split in the Popular and Democratic Union coalition of President Hernan Siles Zuazo.

title: FEWER MOSQUITOES, BUT OH, THOSE PALMETTO BUGS
description: At this time of year, much of Florida is not aggressively promoted as the place to be for fun in the sun. Tourists still pour in, but in streams rather than in the floods of the winter months.

title: 5 Face Cruelty Charges In Beating Death of Boy
description: The leader of a religious commune and four of his deputies were arrested tonight on child cruelty charges stemming from the beating death of a 12-year-old boy at the sect's camp, the state police said.

title: DR. CATHERINE U. LUTES
description: Dr. Catherine Urell Lutes, a former staff adviser on curriculum development for the New York City Board of Education, died of a heart attack last Saturday at her home in Brooklyn.

title: MONDRIAN'S NEW YORK YEARS AT THE MODERN
description: THE great Dutch painter Piet Mondrian (1872-1944) was not the man to draw attention to himself, but there did nonetheless grow up all manner of legends about him. In particular, and no matter where he was, his studio fascinated people by reason of its uncluttered radiance. When the English painter Ben Nicholson first called upon him in Paris, where Mondrian lived for 24 years, he was dumbfounded. ''The studio'' he said later, ''was like the hermit's cell in the desert to which a lion would come to have a thorn taken out of its paw.'' Other people told how, when for once Mondrian had a good view from his studio window, he boarded it up for fear of being distracted.

title: EASTERN AIR'S LOSS WIDER IN QUARTER
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $33.7 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $3 million in the period last year.

title: SALVADORANS HAIL U.S. ENVOY'S TALKS
description: Business leaders in El Salvador applauded a speech by Deane R. Hinton, the departing United States Ambassador, to the American Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday that was critical of violence from both the left and the right.

title: Bridge: Play in New Orleans Starts With New York Hopes Up
description: The quarterfinals of the Grand National Teams, raising the curtain for the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, began here this afternoon. After 16 deals, New York led the Midwest (Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio) by 11 points; Georgia/North Carolina led Florida by 20; Minnesota led Dallas by 32, and San Francisco led Seattle by 51.

title: U.S.F.L. Sells 35,000 Tickets
description: Ticket sales for the United States Football League championship game Sunday night between the Philadelphia Stars and the Michigan Panthers have reached 35,000, according to Dom Camera, the league's director of marketing.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. This is a matchup between a 10-game winner, Dave Righetti, and an 11-game winner, Rick Honeycutt. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. Ed Lynch, having his best year in the majors, gets the start for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Michael Spinks, champion, vs. Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, world lightheavyweight title bout, 15 rounds, at Washington. In the semifinal, Dwight Braxton, the former light-heavyweight titleholder of the World Boxing Council, meets Irish Jimmy Smith. Braxton changed his name to Dwight Muhammad Qawi, but uses Braxton for promotional purposes. (Television - HBO, 9 P.M., with the main event at about 10 P.M.) Golf British Open, second round, at Southport, England. The field tries to catch Craig Stadler, last year's Masters champion, who got off to a fast start yesterday with a 64. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M., live, and 7 P.M., tape.)

title: Gov. Brown Gets Throat Tube
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. underwent surgery Wednesday to insert a respirator tube into his throat to help speed his recovery from lung complications after heart surgery.

title: BRIDGE DESIGN EXPERTS DISCUSS ISSUES OF SAFETY
description: Five leading experts in bridge design were asked by The New York Times to discuss the broad implications of the collapse of a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge here on June 28 that killed three people and injured three others.

title: Imperial Group Profit Up 11%
description: The Imperial Group, the British conglomerate that owns the Howard Johnson restaurant and hotel chain in the United States, today reported that its net income in the six months ended April 30 rose 11 percent, to $85.5 million, or 11.8 cents a share, from $77.3 million, or 10.7 cents a share, a year before.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE New York City Bluegrass Festival is movin' on. After 10 years at the South Street Seaport in August, the contest and concert have found a larger, more bucolic site at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, and it takes place Sunday. More than 100 musicians will be picking, fiddling and harmonizing in what the festival's organizer, Doug Tuchman of the Bluegrass Club of New York, calls ''the biggest bluegrass festival ever held in New York.''

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect stock dividends.

title: Key Banks Inc.  To Buy Units
description: The Bank of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 29 of its upstate branches to Key Banks Inc. of Albany, which has been aggressively expanding in New York and New England.

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago results are for Transworld Bank which became the sole wholly owned subsidiary of Transworld Bancorp, a bank holding company, in October 1982.

title: Pirates 8, Padres 6
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Johnny Ray hit a two-out, two-run double to cap a four-run ninth inning that gave Pittsburgh its fourth straight victory.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOL AID: FOR WHOM AND WHY
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTER M. LANGSDORF
description: Walter M. Langsdorf, a former executive of an envelope company who had been a deputy administrator with the New York office of the Works Progress Administration and an official of other Government agencies, died Wednesday at his home in Armonk, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Chemical Up 20.9%; Interfirst Off 33.2%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, parent of the nation's sixthlargest bank, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose 20.9 percent, to $69.7 million, from $57.6 million in the 1982 period.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $306,000. c-Including a tax credit of $906,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $183,000.

title: HAWKEYE BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ETHICS PANEL SAYS 2 CONGRESSMEN HAD SEXUAL RELATIONS WITH PAGES
description: Two members of the House of Representatives had sexual relationships with teen-age Congressional pages, the House ethics committee said today. It recommended official reprimands by the House.

title: A WEEKEND VISIT TO SARATOGA IN DANCE TIME
description: FIRST it was the healthful mineral springs that brought the world to Saratoga Springs, N.Y., beginning in 1767, when an American Indian bathed the war wounds of Capt. William Johnson in the local waters. By 1820, Saratoga Springs was a haven for rich summer visitors, some of whom settled in elaborate mansions, which now make the town a place of exceptional architectural interest. Horses brought more such visitors, when racing and gambling were introduced in the 1850's.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings for the 1983 reflect the issuance of adjustable rate preferred stock.

title: DRUSE FIGHT LEBANESE PATROL IN MOUNTAINS OUTSIDE BEIRUT
description: Druse villagers clashed with a Lebanese Army patrol on a reconnaissance mission in the mountains southeast of the capital today.

title: NORTHERN TRUST CO (CHICAGO) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AMERICAN EXPRESS POSTS GAIN OF 35.4%
description: The American Express Company, the big financial-services concern, reported yesterday what it called its highest quarterly net income ever: $195 million, or $1.44 a share. That second-quarter result compares with the $144 million, or $1.11 a share, the company earned in the 1982 period.

title: 5 ATOMIC PLANTS ORDERED SHUT TO INSPECT PIPES FOR CRACKS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered the closing of five General Electric nuclear power plants to inspect cooling pipes for cracks that could set off a reactor meltdown.

title: Advertising; Networks And Cable Debated
description: ONE of the high points at yesterday's Cable Advertising Seminar, sponsored at the New York Hilton by the Turner Broadcasting System, was when Robert P. Sieber, vice president/research, said: ''One of the three broadcast networks will fail unless their program format is significantly altered.''

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Ex-Aide to Edwin Wilson Is Guilty of Tax Evasion
description: A man who worked for Edwin Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency agent, was convicted today on two counts of Federal income tax evasion, but his wife was acquitted of the same charges.

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HARTFORD NATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FRIDAY, JULY 15, 1983; The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker told a Senate panel he may not stay for a full four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. He suggested that his departure might come in the months following next year's election. Otherwise, his testimony on monetary policy was as anticipated, and there was little reaction on the markets. (Page A1.)

title: Lindsay's Son Pleads Guilty
description: John V. Lindsay Jr., the son of the former New York City Mayor, pleaded guilty today to reduced charges of marijuana possession stemming from a $200 sale of cocaine to a police undercover agent.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Fannie Mae Reports Profit
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, a leading supplier of home mortgage funds, reported yesterday that it had second-quarter net income of $22 million, or 34 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $43.1 million for the similar period last year.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: GRACE, W R, & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Mitsubishi Plans Chip Plant in U.S.
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said it plans to build a plant in North Carolina to assemble 64K RAM, or random access memory, computer chips.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including income of $177,000 for the quarter and $727,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $630,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a loss of $4,590 from discontinued operations and a gain of $116,000 from the sale of real estate. d-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $44,840 and a gain of $254,000 from the sale of a business. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the sale of Damon's veterinary products business.

title: GLATFELTER, P H, CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Lamaur Inc.  Picks Campbell
description: Out in the highly competitive advertising community of Minneapolis, Campbell-Mithun has picked up an important account - the consumer products division of Lamaur Inc.

title: RAISES FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS GET CITY COUNCIL APPROVAL
description: Pay raises for New York City elected officials - including the 35 members of the City Council - were approved unanimously yesterday by the Council, exactly a week after the raises were recommended by a mayoral panel.

title: A Tribute to Hirschfeld
description: S urrounded by 100 of his best drawings and more than 100 of his best friends in the theater, Al Hirschfeld was feted at Gracie Mansion last night. The occasion was a party, held by Mayor Koch, to celebrate the 80th birthday of the caricaturist, whose drawings of the stars of stage and screen have appeared in The New York Times for 55 years.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 6.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DELUGES TURN SOUTH OF BRAZIL INTO 'IMMENSE LAKE'
description: Heavy rains have provoked severe flooding in southern Brazil, isolating major cities and causing more than 100 deaths.

title: DANCE: FRENCH SERIES AT FESTIVAL IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: In an unusual gesture, the American Dance Festival has dedicated its current season to Nancy Hanks and Walter Terry, both of whom died within the last year.

title: 2 Days of Talks On Polish Debt
description: ''Progress has been recorded,'' a Polish spokesman said today as Western and Polish bankers ended two days of talks on rescheduling the nation's huge commercial debt.

title: 'PUBERTY BLUES'
description: BRUCE BERESFORD'S ''Puberty Blues'' from Australia begins with the sight of two decidedly unglamorous teen-age girls as they wend their way across a crowded beach, which is ringed with ugly high-rise buildings. The homeliness and candor of the moment prove to be the best qualities of a coming-of-age film that also has its familiar and even foolish sides, culminating as it does in one girl's brave, convention-shattering decision to buy and use a surfboard of her own.

title: POLAND TO AMEND CHARTER TO MAKE SPECIAL POWERS PERMANENT
description: Parliament began work today on legislation that would amend the Constitution to give all Polish Governments the special powers that the regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski assumed when it declared martial law on Dec. 13, 1981.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $150,000.

title: Caldor Chief To Carson Pirie
description: In a surprise announcement yesterday, Dennis S. Bookshester, the 43-year-old president and chief executive of Caldor Inc., was named president and chief executive of the department store division of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, effective Aug.1.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CONTINENTAL TELECOM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Honda Profit Climbs 20.2%
description: The Honda Motor Company, citing improved cost control and increased sales of higher-profit models, said today that its profit for its first fiscal quarter rose 20.2 percent, on a 3 percent increase in sales, compared with the corresponding period last year.

title: TESTERS VS. STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Model Coaches
description: In his 11 seasons in the National Basketbal Association, Kevin Porter played for five different head coaches on three teams - the Baltimore/ Washington Bullets, the Detroit Pistons and the New Jersey Nets.

title: 2d Time Around
description: Gene Littler, who will be 53 years old a week from today, is one of the most durable golfers in history. Given a second chance at life when he survived radical surgery for cancer in 1972, he has made the most of what he calls the rebirth for golfers over 50 -the PGA Senior Tour.

title: F.C.C. Official Gets Post at Metromedia
description: Cellular telephone service is said to be the wave of the future in mobile communications, replacing the slow, often congested service that plagues most car phones today. This week, Metromedia Inc. hired one of the leading experts in the field.

title: Jury Deliberates In Death of Black
description: A jury yesterday afternoon began deliberating the case of a Brooklyn youth who is charged with murder in the beating of a black transit worker by a group of whites.

title: Road business bad, revival of 'Mame' will come in early.
description: ''I AM bloodied but unbowed, and all I can tell you is I'm coming home,'' Angela Lansbury said over the phone from Philadelphia, where ''Mame'' has cut short its pre-Broadway run. The revival of the musical, which Miss Lansbury originated with memorable success in 1966, will begin previews at the Gershwin Theater next Wednesday and open July 24.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings have not been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid in August.

title: Clerc Wins In an Hour
description: Second-seeded Jose-Luis Clerc won a string of 10 games today en route to a one-sided victory in the United States Pro tennis championships at Longwood Cricket Club.

title: Braniff Per-Share Value Under 14
description: The Braniff International Corporation said that under its proposed plan of reorganization its existing common stock would be worth less than 14 cents a share and the existing 5 3/4 percent subordinated debentures of its Braniff Airways unit would have a value of about $32 per $1,000 principal amount.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Centex Acceptance Corp., a unit of Centex Corp., filed for an offering of $100 million of Government National Mortgage Association collateralized bonds, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Second Fire in Pinelands
description: The second forest fire in two days blazed out of control today in the Ocean County pinelands until there was ''nothing left to burn,'' the local police said.

title: SHIFTING SANDS IN CHAD
description: Government forces in Chad are advancing again. It looks as though the current effort by Libya's Colonel Qaddafi to install his current client in the big, strategic country to the south is being rebuffed.

title: A BITTER EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: Personal hostility among owners of the Boston Red Sox has become so great that Jean Yawkey, the principal owner, has refused to talk to a co-owner, Buddy LeRoux, since last fall even though they sit in adjacent boxes at Fenway Park, it was disclosed at the trial for control of the team this week.

title: ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
An Albatross by a Panther
description: iron. He is not a big hitter, and the thought of his knocking a 1-iron more than 200 yards is dubious at best. But conditions were in his favor yesterday in the first round of the 112th British Open at the Royal Birkdale Golf Club: The ground was hard and dry and he had a slight wind behind him.

title: FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
LANE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HOLLINGS AND CRANSTON APPEAL FOR N.A.A.C.P. SUPPORT IN '84
description: Senators Ernest F. Hollings and Alan Cranston presented themselves today to members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as strong allies in the civil rights struggle.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
4 Health Workers Get Cases of AIDS
description: Four cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome have turned up among health-care personnel, although there is no evidence that they contracted AIDS through casual contact with patients, Federal officials said today.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (STEVENS POINT reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated.

title:
PATENTS;
New Way to Study Biological Fluids
description: A new method of examining biological fluid samples, such as urine, has been patented for International Remote Imaging Systems, known as I.R.I.S., of Chatsworth, Calif.

title: FIDELITY OF OKLAHOMA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
China Reports Progress In Atom Talks With U.S.
description: Progress has been made in Chinese-American talks on nuclear energy, and the two sides have agreed to hold more talks soon, the New China News Agency said today.

title: REYNOLDS METALS LOSES $69.1 MILLION
description: The Reynolds Metals Company reported yesterday that it had a second-quarter loss of $69.1 million, which included a $52.7 million charge for the estimated cost of write-offs associated with the planned closing of several factories.

title: JAZZ: ROWLESES AT VANGUARD
description: There's a new addition to that list of parent-and-child jazz combinations that includes Ellis Marsalis and his sons Wynton and Branford; Von Freeman and his son, Chico, and Jackie McLean and his son, Rene. It's Jimmy Rowles and his daughter, Stacy.

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DOLLY JONAH
description: Dolly Jonah, an actress and singer, died Thursday in Bridgton, Me., after a long illness.

title: ALLEGHANY DEAL'S 'STEPCHILD'
description: The day after the American Express Company announced that it had agreed to acquire most of the assets of the Alleghany Corporation it sent 10 executives to Minneapolis to meet with their counterparts at Alleghany's prized subsidiary, Investors Diversified Services.

title: COMBUSTION EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $306,000. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $183,000 and a tax credit of $906,000.

title: GEAC COMPUTER reports earnings for year to April 30.
GETTING BIG IN LITTLE LEAGUE
description: T he road to Williamsport has begun again for 2.5 million Little League baseball players throughout the United States and 27 foreign countries. For the next 6 weeks, young Joey Jays and Boog Powells, ages 10 to 12, will put in almost as much practice and travel time as their major league heroes.

title: GRAINGER, W W, INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Article 039280 -- No Title
description: Ralph Hanover took another major step tonight toward recognition as this year's top 3-year-old pacer. The bay colt, driven by Ron Waples, won the $1,251,000 Meadowlands Pace, his seventh victory in nine starts this season.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses of $3,299,000 for the quarter and $3,530,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $257,000 for the quarter and income of $797,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Jet Crashes and Burns With Radioactive Cargo
description: A twin-engine cargo jet carrying low-level radioactive materials crashed and burned on landing tonight, and four nearby homes were evacuated, Federal and state safety officials said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Barber Pole Returns To Its Proper Place

title:
PATENTS;
Materials Seen Cutting Cost of Circuit Boards
description: A group of composite materials with excellent electrical and chemical properties, covered by one of this week's patents, was welcomed by Bell Telephone Laboratories, assignee of the patent.

title: SEN. HART AN ISSUE HIMSELF IN A DAY OF MX DEBATE
description: Piqued and frustrated, the Senate sputtered into a debate today on the MX missile. But by the end of the day, the weapon's major opponent, Senator Gary Hart, had become almost as much of an issue as the missile.

title: NEVER EAT AT 'MOM'S,' AND OTHER RULES OF THE ROAD
description: The peak vacation season is upon us, as is apparent by the number of overloaded station wagons on the highway with children crammed in the back waving and mugging at other drivers. Anyone who has partaken in this annual ritual knows that it usually isn't long - 15 minutes to an hour, depending on the ages of the children -before the initial glee of escape dissolves into the grumbles of hunger, and the frightful question must be faced: Where do we eat?

title: FORT WAYNE MOBILIZES TO AID THOSE LEFT JOBLES BY TRUCK PLANT'S CLOSING
description: As the final shift ended at International Harvester Company's truck-building plant here today, an era came to a close. That point is best understood by the 2,200 workers whose jobs were lost with the closing.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D, INC reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
Ohio-Sealy to Add Stearns & Foster
description: The Ohio-Sealy Mattress Manufacturing Company announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Stearns & Foster Company, a Cincinnati-based bed manufacturer, in a stock and cash transaction valued at about $46 million.

title: News Analysis
description: While Congress ponders a proposal for sweeping changes in immigration law, Federal judges here and in Miami have been issuing opinions and orders that are already having a significant impact on immigration policy.

title: Human Computer
description: The National Basketball Association schedule for next season has been completed and will be announced during the weekend. Figuring playing dates for the 23 teams is no easy task.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a charge of $52,700,000 for the estimated cost of write-offs associated with a planned closing of several production facilities. c-Net income.

title: ECONO-THERM ENERGY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
Appeals Court Rejects Condemned Man's Plea
description: A Federal appeals court rejected Jimmy Lee Gray's appeal of his death sentence today, and the Mississippi Attorney General said the state would seek to execute the convicted killer next week.

title: ARMENIANS CLAIM RESPONSIBILITY
description: A bomb exploded in a suitcase at a Turkish Airlines check-in counter at Orly Airport today, killing at least five people and wounding 56.

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Tandon Contract
description: The Tandon Corporation of Chatsworth, Calif. announced that it had signed an agreement to supply $310 million worth of its floppy disk drive products to a major microcomputer manufacturer, but said that under the terms of its contract, the buyer could not be identified. Tandon said the contract, which runs through the end of 1984, was still subject to definitive purchase orders, but that shipments had already begun.

title: No No-Fault Excuses in Trenton
description: All the commotion notwithstanding, the prospects for reform of New Jersey's appalling automobile insurance system are fading fast.

title: FLUKE, JOHN, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 24.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $20,199 for the quarter and $119,500 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $59,093 for the quarter and $91,500 for the year.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
10% OF BALDWIN ASSETS IS CARRIED AS GOOD WILL
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation disclosed last night that 10 percent of its assets, nearly $1 billion, are carried as good will, an intangible asset that Baldwin might be forced to write off as its financial problems eat away at its reputation.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CLOW CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include $400,000 from proceeds of a life insurance policy after providing $800,000 reserves for nonrecurring items.

title: UNION BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TAKEOVER STIR AT BELL & HOWELL
description: The Bell & Howell Company, disclosing that it had been approached by a smaller company that wanted to acquire its vocational training business, announced a two-step plan yesterday to discourage takeover attempts.

title: Delay Is Sought For TV Rulings
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today asked a Supreme Court Justice, Byron R. White, to stay the rulings of lower courts that would do away with the association's control of college football telecasts. ''Any attempt to revamp things for 1983 would produce wasted motion, chaos or both,'' N.C.A.A. lawyers said in their request.

title: Schlichter Gets Offer
description: Art Schlichter, the quarterback of the Baltimore Colts, who is under indefinite suspension by the National Football League for his involvement in gambling activities, has been offered a contract by the Ohio Bulldogs of the International Football League, which was formed last month. ''An informal discussion through a third party has taken place with Schlichter,'' said Joe Sommers, a spokesman for the Bulldogs, ''but nothing is concrete.'' Sommers refused to identify the third party. ... Wilbur Jackson, the running back, has retired from the Washington Redskins, the Super Bowl champions, after nine years in the N.F.L. Jackson, 31, has been bothered with knee problems.

title: Republic Air Asks Wage Cut
description: Republic Airlines, expecting a $100 million loss for the first half of the 1983 fiscal year, announced it would ask all employees to accept a 15 percent wage cut for at least nine months.

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
REAGAN AIDES SAY ONLY ONE PROTESTED USE OF CARTER NOTES
description: When Ronald Reagan's campaign aides received briefing papers from the Carter camp in October 1980, apparently no one asked how the documents had been obtained, according to former campaign officials. They said only one adviser raised questions about the propriety of using the papers.

title: Man Who Shot Father in Coma Guilty of Attempted Murder
description: Billy Ray Clore, who said he shot his comatose father to end the man's suffering, was convicted Friday of attempted murder.

title: Population Is at 233 Million
description: The population of the United States has climbed to more than 233 million, the Census Bureau reported today. In its latest estimate of the number of Amricans, the bureau put the total at 233,892,000 as of May 1.

title: NO MINOR CASES FOR U.S. NAZI-HUNTER
description: One wall reverberates with a World War II poster of Allied guns blazing in unison against the Nazi enemy. Under it sits a vintage Zenith transoceanic radio that seems ready to crackle into life with a clandestine broadcast of the Resistance.

title: Marc Rich Ordered to Pay $1 Million
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Marc Rich & Company, a Swiss company that is one of the world's biggest commodities traders, to pay $1 million on Monday for refusing to turn over records subpoenaed earlier by a grand jury in Manhattan.

title: MCGRAW-HILL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1983. The company said the 1983 results reflect a change in the timing of recording book sales to more accurately reflect, principally in the third and fourth quarters, revenue and net income from such sales.

title: BUSH IS BOOED AT N.A.A.C.P. MEETING
description: Vice President Bush met with open hostility today from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as he sought to portray the Reagan Administration as sensitive to the plight of black Americans.

title: Carter Says Documents Were 'Most Sensitive'
description: Jimmy Carter said today that the debate papers taken from his 1980 campaign were the most ''politically sensitive'' documents he had.

title: OREGON METALLURGICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Reagan Signs Salvador Bill
description: President Reagan signed legislation today making further foreign aid for El Salvador conditional upon his certifying that the Salvadoran Government is making progress on human rights and is trying to solve the murders of eight United States citizens there. The legislation shifts responsibility for the certification from the State Department to the White House and adds the requirement about the murders.

title: Wyoming Marks an End Of Amtrak Train Service
description: Two Amtrak trains made final runs through Wyoming today, ending an era of rail passengers service spanning more than 115 years.

title: Suspect Indicted In 2 Jersey Slayings
description: Richard F. Biegenwald was indicted today in the deaths of two women whose bodies were unearthed from a shallow grave near his mother's home on Staten Island, officials announced.

title: Braniff-Hyatt Plan Advances
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers approved tonight a disclosure statement that will be mailed to 80,000 Braniff International creditors.

title: Saturday Sports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Old-Timers' Day festivities begin at 1:15. (Television - Channel 11, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. Mike Torrez tries to cool the Astros, whose recent success has put them above .500. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Oakland A's, at Boston. (Television -Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.).

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for the acquisition of Eastern Aviation & Marine Underwriters Inc. on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Stokely Trading Halt
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the target of a $170 million Pillsbury Company takeover bid, halted trading on the New York Stock Exchange today amid rumors that it was entertaining a higher bid.

title: POST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: House Defeats Move On Daylight Savings
description: The House of Representatives, bowing to rural lawmakers, has defeated legislation to extend daylight saving time two more months each year.

title: CUOMO VETOES BILL ON USING BULLETPROOF VEST FOR A CRIME
description: Governor Cuomo today vetoed legislation that would have made it a crime to wear a bulletproof vest during the commission of a violent felony.

title: PRODUCER PRICES RISE BIGGEST IN 7 MONTHS
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, pushed upward by soaring energy prices, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the biggest increase in seven months, the Government reported today.

title: CRANE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including gains of $8,505,000 for the quarter and $23,387,000 for the 6 months on sales of shares of Atlantic- Richfield Co. c-Net income.

title: INDIGENTS MOVED BY CITY TRYING TO COPE IN JERSEY
description: The long corridors of the Lincoln Motel were quiet this morning. Maintenance men and chambermaids made their rounds while women and small children with sleep still on their faces began to emerge from behind closed doors. It hardly seemed like the center of an interstate feud, and yet that is what it has become.

title: A DIFFERENCE, TOO FOR U.S.F.L. PARTY
description: The United States Football League lost a lot of money in its inaugural season, as expected, but no one knows exactly how much, according to Chet Simmons, the commissioner.

title: THE DIRKS RULING: INSIDERS' LICENSE?
