description: At a track meet in 1981, Barry Switzer, the head football coach of the University of Oklahoma, overheard a conversation about the impending liquidation of Phoenix Resources, an oil and gas company. On the basis of the information, Mr. Switzer and several friends bought stock in the company - and together made a profit of $605,674 when the company actually announced its intent to liquidate.

title: ROUND 2 FOR U.S. YACHTS
description: Liberty will meet Defender when the second round of United States trials to select the America's Cup defender begins Saturday on Rhode Island Sound.

title: HOMERS BY BAYLOR, WINFIELD LIFT YANKS
description: This was not the proof as far as Don Baylor was concerned. There will have to be more home runs, more runs batted in, more nights when the scoreboard lights up. ''Then you can say that we're ready to make our move,'' said Baylor. ''But at least this is a start.''

title: 2 CONGRESSMEN FACE CONSTITUENTS' JUDGEMENT ON REPORTS OF SEX WITH PAGES
description: In three successful campaigns for Congress, Representative Daniel B. Crane has portrayed himself as a solid, churchgoing, family man, a conservative Republican who set himself apart from what he described as the fast-living ''Washington set.''

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Regan Criticizes Unit for Retarded
description: The State Comptroller's office said yesterday that an unannounced inspection last month of the state's Brooklyn Developmental Center for the mentally retarded and disabled found at least 10 employees asleep on the job and others who were signed in but could not be located.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Mr. Ruckelshaus as Caesar
description: ''For me to sit here in Washington and tell the people of Tacoma what is an acceptable risk would be at best arrogant and at worst inexcusable.'' That's William Ruckelshaus, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, explaining his reasons for polling the citizens of Tacoma as to whether they want to accept a higher risk of cancer from the arsenic emitted by a copper smelter or risk losing jobs if the smelter company is forced to clean up its act.

title: Tennessee Banker in Bankruptcy
description: C.H. Butcher Jr., who estimated his net worth last year at $60.7 million, was declared involuntarily bankrupt today by a Federal judge, clearing the way for liquidation of what remains of Mr. Butcher's banking empire.

title: VIDEOVISION INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $94,000. c-Includes income of $23,326 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES (TWA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a gain of $8,200,000 from the sale of tax benefits related to an aircraft delivered during the quarter. c-Net income which includes gains of $13,400,000 from the sale of tax benefits and $17,400,000 from the sale of used aircraft during the quarter.

title: SALVADORAN MILITARY IS SAID TO REGAIN MOMENTUM
description: Salvadoran and American officials say the Salvadoran military appears to have regained the momentum in the civil war with an offensive that began a month ago in several provinces.

title: DUQUESNE U. GIVEN $15 MILLION
description: Duquesne University has been given more than $15 million, which is believed to be the largest gift from an individual donor in support of a Roman Catholic college or university.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co. said the French chemical companies PCUK and Chloe Chimie had agreed to transfer their polyurethane polyol business to its Arco Chemical Co. division.

title: DST SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DANCE: 'SOLITARY GEOGRAPHY,' MIXED-MEDIA ODE TO NATURE
description: Elaine Summers brought the majesty of mountains, deserts and oceans to the Performing Garage on Thursday night in ''Solitary Geography,'' a mixed-media ode to nature.

title: Time to Regroup
description: Kim Linehan has been swimming competitively for half of her 20 years, 6 of them as a nationally known freestyle star at distances of 400 to 1,500 meters. But she decided recently to give up competitive swimming - forever.

title: U.S. ACCEPTS TERMS FOR HUMAN RIGHTS AT MADRID MEETING
description: The United States agreed formally today to a compromise document on security and human rights to end the East-West conference in Madrid and possibly open the way for high-level Soviet-American meetings.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The advantages of the library Mr. Rosenberg looks forward to are certainly welcome, but one of his predictions will certainly not be realized for some time: electronic translation.

title: Bridge: League's Board Opposes Exclusion of South Africa
description: For thousands of enthusiasts arriving here today, the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals was overshadowed by three other events, two of them away from the card table.

title: Uncle of Teamster President Faces Embezzlement Charge
description: Allen Friedman, an uncle of the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has pleaded innocent to Federal charges of posing as a phantom union official to embezzle $165,000 from a local chapter in which the teamsters' chief, Jackie Presser, is an officer.

title: YOUTH CLEARED OF MURDER IN BEATING IN GRAVESEND
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth was acquitted last night of seconddegree murder and other felony charges in the second trial stemming from the fatal beating of a black transit worker by whites in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn a year ago.

title: Senate Reaffirms Law to Link Students' Aid to Draft Signup
description: The Senate rejected an effort Thursday to repeal a law that denies Federal college loans and grants to men who fail to register for a possible military draft.

title: EDDIE FOY JR., VAUDEVILLE AND FILM ACTOR, DIES
description: Eddie Foy Jr., the vaudevillian who toured for more than a decade with his father and siblings in an act called ''Eddie Foy and the Seven Little Foys'' and who continued as a song-and-dance man in dozens of musical plays and movies, died of cancer yesterday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 78 years old and lived in Las Vegas.

title: The Talk of Berlin
description: There are two subways that daily whisk commuters from one corner of West Berlin under a slice of East Berlin and then back out again, to what is sometimes called the free world.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 16, 1983; The Economy
description: Industrial output rose 1.1 percent in June, the seventh consecutive gain, the Federal Reserve Board reported. It said the increase was the fourth in a row in excess of 1 percent, a strong performance underlying the gains in employment since last winter. (Page 29.)

title: Daily News Plant Given Abatement
description: The Daily News received a $10.2 million tax abatement yesterday to expand its printing plant in Brooklyn.

title: Olympics Define Soccer Eligibility
description: The International Olympic Committee and FIFA, soccer's world governing body, agreed today to ban professionals and those who played in the World Cup from taking part in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: FARM TROUBLES MEAN A DRY SPELL FOR CROP-DUSTERS
description: It is July now, the season when Tom Singleton spends most of his time about 10 feet off the ground, ripping along at 100 miles an hour as he trails a spray of insecticide from the wing nozzles of his single-engine crop-duster.

title: COOPER CANADA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings do not reflect a recently proposed 2-for-1 stock split subject to shareholder approval at a meeting July 29.

title: Cannon Pleads Guilty
description: The former football star Billy Cannon, as part of a bargaining agreement with prosecutors, pleaded guilty to a single charge today in a multimillion-dollar counterfeiting scheme.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: BANK LETS BRAZIL PASS DEADLINE ON DEBT PAYMENT
description: The Bank for International Settlements yesterday let pass Brazil's deadline for paying $400 million due on a $1.45 billion loan. Officials stressed that the unofficial reprieve was not an extension.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Including a gain of $389,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the settlement of certain state sales tax disputes. Year-ago loss reflects a charge of $2,580,000 for antitrust settlement.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. Tillson Lake, an artificial lake, was drained by its owner, who said he acted for safety reasons. Most of the homeowners, whose deeds give them the right to use the lake, called the draining an act of spite because of a long-running feud.

title: U.S. VOICES PLEASURE
description: The Canadian Government today approved testing of United States cruise missiles in Canada, resolving a delicate diplomatic issue between the two countries.

title: 2 CONGRESSMEN FACE CONSTITUENTS' JUDGMENT ON REPORTS OF SEX WITH PAGES
description: Sorrow, pity and disappointment were the primary reactions of Cape Cod residents today to the disclosure that Representative Gerry E. Studds had a homosexual relationship with a teen-age Congressional page 10 years ago.

title: I.M.F.-Lisbon Debt Parley
description: Representatives of the International Monetary Fund are due here next week for talks on medium-term financial assistance for Portugal, official sources said today.

title: THE IRREPLACEABLE BOOK IN OUR LIBRARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: DRILLERS INC ( Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 reports earnings for Revenue.
description: b-Net income. 1983 results include an $11 million writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Dome Canada, Home Oil in Pact
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said its Dome Canada Ltd. affiliate and Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.'s Home Oil unit had agreed on a major three-year exploration and development program.

title: LIBERAL SAYS PARTY DISPUTE LED TO JOB THREATS
description: A Liberal Party official said yesterday that about 15 party members told him they had been threatened with dismissal from their state jobs unless they switched votes in a party leadership battle.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS IN SOUTHERN LEBANON STRIVE TO BE INCONSPICUOUS
description: Despite persistent attacks on Israeli soldiers and tighter security measures, Israel's military presence here in southern Lebanon seems low-keyed and relatively inconspicuous.

title: A LONG HISTORY OF VENGEANCE
description: The bombing at Orly Airport yesterday and the assassination of a Turkish diplomat in Belgium Thursday were the latest in a long and bloody history of attacks by Armenians to avenge the massacre of hundreds of thousands of their countrymen in Turkey between 1894 and 1915.

title: 29 ARE ARRESTED IN POLICE SWEEP OF TIMES SQUARE
description: One hundred and thirty plainclothes officers were sent into the Times Square area last night in a move to catch marauding youths who the police say have been menacing, robbing and beating midtown visitors.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL CORP (OKLAHOMA CITY, OKLA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FUZZY WORDS ON BIAS
description: 2,0,3100,2This week's Congressional hearings on President Reagan's decision to replace three members of the Civil Rights Commission points up a dilemma that has plagued the civil rights community for many years. While most Americans today probably agree that race discrimination in employment and education is wrong and that some ''affirmative action'' is needed to equalize opportunities for Blacks and others previously excluded, there are wide differences of opinion about what steps should be taken.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: JEC LASERS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

PATENTS;
A System to Steer And Propel a Boat
description: Carl E. Moberg of Shrewsbury, Mass., was granted patent 4,392,832 this week on a steering and propulsion system for marine use.

title: New Claims by Jobless Decline
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits in the last week of June fell to their lowest level since the summer of 1981, the Government said Thursday. The Labor Department's weekly report said that the seasonally adjusted total of applications for basic 26-week state-paid jobless benefits was 392,000 in the week ended July 2.

title: RITZY'S, G D, INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TRANE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COURTS CAN'T DO IT ALL
description: A visit at almost any hour vividly demonstrates the sorry state of the Criminal Court of the City of New York.

title: 'NOW AND FOREVER'
description: Imagine the surprise of the mostly male audience at the National Twin when ''Now and Forever,'' which opened there yesterday, turned out to be a movie for the women. It stars Cheryl Ladd, sporting a headful of blonde curls and looking a little like Julie Christie turned sorority girl. She plays a boutique owner in Sydney, Australia, which is not the kind of detail best appreciated by the National's usual crowd.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest second quarter include a gain equal to 42 cents a share from the sale of Lockheed Co. warrants obtained in a past loan restructuring.

title: Brazil President in Surgery
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo of Brazil underwent successful open heart surgery tonight in the Cleveland Clinic, a spokesman for Mr. Figueiredo said. The spokesman said Dr. William Sheldon had recommended surgery after an examination earlier in the day.

title: MOHAWK RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
DOW DECLINES 12.03 IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Fears that a sharp jump in the nation's basic money supply and international debt problems would push interest rates higher kept investors aloof from the stock market yesterday as prices plunged in light trading.

title: Psychiatric Group's Chief To Seek East-West Unity
description: The World Psychiatric Association's new president promised today to smooth an East-West dispute in the organization.

title: CANCER BOARD SAYS VETERANS OF JAPAN FAILED TO PROVE CASE
description: A National Research Council committee has found no evidence that American troops who were in the Hiroshima and Nagasaki areas shortly after the atomic bombings of 1945 developed multiple myeloma, an often fatal bone cancer, more frequently than the general population.

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Celtics' Sale Near
description: Harry Mangurian, the owner of the Boston Celtics, said that, barring any snags, he will sell the National Basketball Association team to Steve Belkin, a Boston-based executive with interests in travel and figure-salon businesses.

title: PROPOSAL ON BASS SIZE SPLITS L.I. FISHERMEN
description: For a long time, the Bennett family has fished the bays here for striped bass. The youngest of the family line, 14-year-old Brent W. Bennett, learned from his father, Brent R. Bennett, who learned from his father, Brent M. Bennett.

title: Fed Panel Supported Tightening In May
description: The Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policymaking panel, decided by a narrow margin at its May meeting to tighten monetary policy slightly, the Fed reported yesterday.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
IMPORT LIMITS MAY PUSH CLOTHING PRICES UP
description: The Reagan Administration's crackdown on apparel imports from the Far East will push up some fall clothing prices by at least 20 percent, according to American companies that make and market the clothing.

title: Diamond-Natomas Suit
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today that a hearing on a shareholder's motion for a preliminary injunction to block its proposed acquisition of the Natomas Company had been postponed until July 27 in San Francisco. The company said it and Natomas would oppose the motion vigorously and are proceeding with steps necessary to complete the merger.

title: Consumers Power Continues Plant
description: The Consumers Power Company said that it would continue construction of a nuclear power plant in Midland, Mich., despite the Dow Chemical Company's announcement on Thursday that it was terminating an agreement to purchase steam from the plant.

title: America's Cup Goes Top-Secret
description: The armed guard paces the compound enclosed by a high chain-link fence. The electronic shield is activated. Will the secret keel remain the sole possession of the Australians or is there a spy capable of penetrating the security systems?

title: LOW-KEY OPEC TALKS SEEN
description: With crude oil prices finally stable, the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gather on Monday in Helsinki, Finland, for a semiannual meeting, and it is expected to be uneventful.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 16, 1983
description: International A step toward Soviet-U.S. meetings might result from a compromise document on security and human rights formally agreed to by the United States near the conclusion of an East-West conference in Madrid. American officials said the only remaining issue was a demand by Malta for a Mediterranean security meeting that is opposed by most of the other 34 states participating in the meeting. (Page 1, Column 6.) A battle in the heart of Beirut broke out between Lebanese Army units and Shiite Moslem militiamen when Government security forces tried to evict Shiite squatters from an abandoned Jewish school. (1:5.)

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest 6 months include an extraordinary credit of $1,277,000 attributable to the forgiveness of the remaining obligations o lending banks, less related expenses, and a provision for possible losses of $737,000.

title: PUBLIC RADIO MOUNTS EFFORT TO RAISE $1.8 MILLION BY JULY 29
description: Officials at National Public Radio pledged today to work ''round the clock'' to secure the $1.8 million needed by July 29 to meet payroll and other immediate expenses, and the $9.1 million needed to keep the network alive through next year.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: VADNA DAVIS DIBBLE
description: Vadna Davis Dibble, a former restaurant critic and head of entertainment and restaurant listings at Cue magazine, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan.

title: STOCK OFF AS TWO QUIT AT PRIME COMPUTER
description: Shares of Prime Computer Inc., a leading maker of minicomputers, plunged 2 1/4 points, to close at 17 7/8 yesterday, following the company's announcement that two marketing executives had resigned to form their own company.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINNCINNATI,OHIO) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BANCORP HAWAII reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PRESIDENT REPORTED SET TO PROPOSE PANEL ON CENTRAL AMERICA POLICIES
description: President Reagan plans to announce Monday that he wants to set up a bipartisan national commission on Central America, Administration officials said today.

title: PHASING IN DEPOSITS ON CONTAINERS
description: CITY officials are asking New York consumers this summer to notice the labeling on beverage c ontainers after the state's so-called bottle bill goes into effect. The law, which is being phased in between now and Sept. 12, r equires that a deposit of at least 5 cents be charged for every b ottle and can containing carbonated beverages, including beer. A c onsumer will be able to recover the deposit by returning the c ontainer to any New York State retailer who sells the same brand, t ype and size.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: COMPLETION DATE IN MID-'86 SEEN FOR CONVENTION CENTER
description: New York City's troubled Convention Center will probably not be completed until the summer of 1986, two years behind schedule, and will cost $125 million more than originally planned, according a report prepared for Governor Cuomo and released yesterday.

title: CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL'S ROLE GROWS
description: The first steps in revitalizing Carnegie Recital Hall and making it a part of Carnegie Hall's overall artistic policy will begin next season with nine subscription series totaling 48 concerts. The stress, according to Seymour Rosen, Carnegie Hall's artistic director, will be on a diversity of musical styles, which include jazz and contemporary classical music, and on young performers and composers.

title: MONDALE BACKERS WATCHING JACKSON
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and his staff have been meeting with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson to discuss issues including Mr. Jackson's reasons for wanting to enter the Democratic Presidential race, according to a Mondale campaign official.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After foreign currency exchange translation losses of $341,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 6 months, and expense provisions for the estimated contingent cost of settlement rights under stock option agreements of $378,000 for the quarter and $983,000 for the 6 months. c-After foreign currency exchange translation losses of $281,000 for the quarter and $602,000 for the 6 months, and charges related to the contraction of certain United Kingdom operations of $1,104,000 for the quarter and $1,764,000 for the 6 months.

title: WHEN A LANDMARK CAUSES HARDSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: BALINESE TROUPE
description: Art, spectacle and tradition came together in a magical way tonight, when the Pepsico Summerfare '83 festival presented ''Calonarang,'' a dance-drama purification ritual from Bali. Performed by a charming young company of 32 Balinese dancer-musicians led by I Made Bandem, director of the Academy of Indonesian Dance where they were trained, ''Calonarang'' had all the ingredients of good storytelling.

title: T.W.A. DEFICIT IS $16.2 MILLION
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $16.2 million for the second quarter, in contrast to a profit of $25.6 million in the 1982 period.

title: LEBANON TROOPS BATTLE MOSLEMS IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Lebanese Army units and Shiite Moslem militiamen clashed in the heart of Beirut today after Government security forces tried to evict Shiite squatters from an abandoned Jewish school.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FAUNA CITY

title: 15TH LOSS IN LAST 20 FOR METS
description: To the Mets, who do not thrive anywhere these days, there is still no place of horror like the Astrodome. They proved it again tonight when they took a 6-0 beating from the Houston Astros and made only five singles off Bob Knepper, a pitcher who had not won a game in five weeks.

title: SPORTS OF OUR CLIMATE
description: There was a time when Thanksgiving signaled the end of both the college and professional football ''season.'' Traditional rivalries were played out on that day, and only the serious football fan followed the season through the professional playoffs in December and the handful of college bowl games on New Year's Day. The season's beginning always used to coincide with the end of summer vacation and return to school. The game was kicked off in earnest with the changing of the leaves.

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1983.

title: ORIOLES BEAT ANGELS FOR 6TH IN ROW, 10-4
description: Eddie Murray knocked in four runs with a homer and a triple, and Mike Young's two-run triple was the key hit in a five-run sixth inning as the Baltimore Orioles downed the California Angels, 10-4, tonight.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
All Street Rhythms
description: I t was a typical Wall Street noontime crowd - maintenance men, office workers, businessmen in pin-stripe suites, messengers, a vendor from a Mister Softee truck - tapping feet to the jazz beat of Deuce.

title: F.B.I. Investigates 2 Bank Explosions
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining possible links between two bomb blasts this week at branches of the Marine Midland Bank in East Rochester and Latham, Special Agent George Mahoney said today.

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Italian Aides Interview Bulgarians in Shooting
description: Italian judicial officials, visiting Bulgaria, have interviewed key witnesses in an investigation into charges that Bulgaria was involved in the May 13, 1981, attempt to kill Pope John Paul II, a Bulgarian press official said today.

title: TV: INQUIRY ON THIEVERY IN ART WORLD
description: Most of the fun in ''Alias A. John Blake: The Underworld of the Art World'' comes early on. In the great tradition of the 19th-century journalists who stained their skins with betel-nut juice and put on caftans so they could slip into the Khyber Pass, Peter Watson, a reporter for The Sunday Times of London, puts on a Seville Row pinstripe, a tattersall shirt and a floppy bow tie; he also affects a limp. He is now A. John Blake, a shady art collector, looking for a Caravaggio on the cheap. The ABC documentary about his adventures will be shown at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BRIEFING
description: E.P.A. Chief Notes Changes

title: C3 INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Including tax credits of $132,000 for the latest first quarter and $103,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: O'NEILL SIGNS A BILL PHASING OUT CONNECTICUT TOLLS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, ending two weeks of uncertainty, signed legislation today phasing out the tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike starting in late 1985.

title: Frenchman Wins
description: Pierre le Bigaut of France went on a solo run today to win the 14th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race, covering the 84 miles from Aurillac in 3 hours 39 minutes 16 seconds.

title: POLICE DOUBT 'SEX TAPE' THEFT
description: A lawyer who reported the theft of what he called the Vicki Morgan ''sex tapes'' should be charged with filing a false police report, the Beverly Hills police recommended today.

title: A.T. & T. ASKS REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked a Federal judge today to reconsider one of his conditions for approval of the company's divestiture plan.

title: Journalists Slain in Honduras Killed by Land Mine, U.S. Says
description: The State Department said today that the two United States journalists who died in Honduras last month were killed by a United States-made land mine planted on the Honduran side of the border by Nicaraguan military forces.

title: 4 MORE HELD IN ABDUCTION OF EX-ENVOY'S WIFE
description: Federal agents today arrested four more people, two of them Guatemalan diplomats, in connection with the kidnapping of a former Salvadoran Ambassador's wife.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $331,528 for the quarter and $363,528 for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain from the sale of real estate of $488,181.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Perfect 'Little' Game
description: John Peters, the 12-year-old Little League pitcher for the Brenham All-Stars, struck out all 18 batters he faced for a perfect game Thursday in Navasota, Tex. Peters also hit three homers, including a grand slam. The 20-0 victory over the Giddings All-Stars advanced Brenham to the playoffs, which culminate in the Little League World Series.

title: Consolidated-Bathurst
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc. said today that it would close two of its newsprint machines Sept.15 because they cannot be modernized. The machines account for 55,000 metric tons of the company's annual one-million-ton production capacity.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title:
Patents;
Tuning In To Remote Stations
description: WASHINGTON THE inventors of a device with the trademark of Selectastation expect that it will permit remote listening to any local radio station in any American city where one of the units has been installed. Patent 4,393,277 was granted this week to Stuart D. Goldberg, sales manager of WRKS-FM, a New York radio station, and Peter D. Besen and Don H. Shulsinger of Arlington, Mass., engineers with degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
To the Editor:

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
The Majority and the Rope
description: In America and Britain, the polls show majority support for capital punishment, especially as a penalty for terrorism. Yet only hours after Irish terrorists killed four militiamen, Britain's Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a return to hanging. Although Prime Minister Thatcher favored the rope, as did her Home Secretary, Leon Brittan, a lopsidedly Conservative Parliament voted otherwise. Why?

title: BUCYRUS-ERIE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $80 million for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: U.S. REACHES PACT ON BASES IN GREECE
description: The United States and Greece announced today that they had reached agreement on allowing the operation of American military bases in Greece for at least five more years.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: LAKE ONTARIO CEMENT LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ANRET PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $104,496 for the quarter and $357,600 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $71,447 for the quarter and $222,460 for the 9 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: PRODUCTION CLIMBS FOR 7TH MONTH
description: Production of the nation's factories rose 1.1 percent in June, the seventh gain in a row, the Government reported today.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
description: b-Net income.

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
SYSCON CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
OLIVER SUTTON, 66, FORMER JUDGE
description: Oliver C. Sutton, a former New York State Supreme Court Justice and a prominent Harlem Democrat, died of a heart attack yesterday at Harlem Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''They're going to fish the bass out of existence. No reasonable man can set foot on this earth and not agree.''

title: Miss Taylor to Return
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who because of illness has missed a number of performances in the current Broadway revival of ''Private Lives,'' will return to the show this weekend, a spokesman for the actress said yesterday. Miss Taylor is scheduled to appear tonight and in the matinee tomorrow -the final performance before the show opens on Wednesday in Philadelphia.

title: SHUTDOWN PUT OFF FOR 5 ATOM PLANTS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday reversed itself on an order to close five nuclear power plants within 30 days to inspect for microscopic flaws in pipes carrying cooling water. The reversal came a day after the commission decided to order the shutdowns.

title: Unseeded Perez Upsets Vilas
description: Unseeded Diego Perez of Uruguay, scoring the greatest victory of his brief career, stunned top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, tonight in the United States Pro Tennis Championships.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FRENCH OPEN REPLICA OF PREHISTORIC CAVE MONDAY
description: More than 15,000 years after a Cro-Magnon man using crude materials daubed his heart and soul on the walls of the Lascaux grotto, 20th-century artists have re-created the famed paintings for public view.

title: Tuition Increased At Jersey Colleges
description: The State Board of Higher Education voted unanimously today to raise tuition at Rutgers University, the New Jersey Institute of Technology and at the eight state and 19 county colleges.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Chrysler in Talks With VW on Car
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said talks between his company and the West German auto maker Volskwagenwerk A.G. might result in joint production of a small car in the United States.

title: NOON BAND SET FOR TOUR IN FRANCE
description: ''Jazz at Noon,'' the popular weekly jam session of business and professional men who are also amateur musicians, will go on the road for the first time since it was formed in New York 18 years ago.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On Burdens of Proof No Cure for the Insanity Defense To the Editor: The July 6 editorial once again promises readers a rose garden in the matter of the insanity defense. Placing the burden on the defendant to prove insanity, instead of requiring the prosecutor to prove sanity, will, you say, cause several problems to disappear and make drastic changes in the law unnecessary.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.8 BILLION
description: The primary measure of the nation's money supply rose $5.8 billion in the week ended July 6, the Federal Reserve said yesterday. The increase was at the high end of the range expected by the financial markets.

title: DELAYS IN SUBWAYS EXPECTED TO LAST THROUGH SUMMER
description: Extensive delays on the city's subways will persist at least through the end of the summer so that repairs can be made at 400 sites where tracks are believed to be weak or poorly secured, the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: Two Orioles Testify
description: Two Baltimore Oriole players, Rich Dauer, the second baseman, and Sammy Stewart, a relief pitcher, have testified before a Federal grand jury hearing evidence against accused cocaine users, according to The Baltimore Sun.

title: SOVIET ASSERTS U.S. SEEKS EDGE IN ARMS
description: The Soviet Union charged today that Washington's proposals at the strategic arms talks in Geneva were one-sided efforts to gain military advantage. Moscow pressed its own plan for an overall limit on all types of warheads.

title: Big Card for Smaller Fares
description: J anet Sainer was given an outsized 22-by-17-inch half-fare card for her 65th birthday yesterday. But she won't be able to use it because, not surprisingly, she's not retiring.

title: MARION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 31.

title: SPECIES IN PERIL: RENTAL UNITS
description: The politicians in Albany have spoken, and another two year extension has been given to the ''temporary'' control of residential rents in New York City that for ''emergency'' reasons went into effect March 15, 1943.

title: Lendl Suspended
description: The Czechoslovak tennis authorities have fined Ivan Lendl and suspended him from that country's Davis Cup team for playing this month at a tennis exhibition in Bophuthatswana, the official news agency of Czechoslovakia reported. Bophuthatswana does not recognize the tribal ''homelands'' set up by the South African government. Lendl played exhibition matches there July 8-10.

title: Worker Is Slain In Jersey Shooting
description: One worker at a sandblasting plant was killed and a second was seriously wounded today when an unidentified man fired a handgun at them and then fled, the police said.

title: Your Money; Pension Plan Loan Rules
description: PRIVATE retirement plans that allow participants to borrow money from their accounts have strict rules that must be followed. These regulations apply only to company or union-sponsored plans, since no loans are permitted from personal pension arrangements, such as Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans.

title: Catholics Say Violence Is Rising in Zimbabwe
description: A Roman Catholic human rights organization here said today that the level of violence in Matabeleland Province was rising again.

title: Driver Killed by Car Bomb
description: Two early-morning blasts ripped through the car of Victor Galustian Thursday, killing the 42-year-old Armenian instantly, the authorities said. The incident came 10 days after a man armed with a machine gun fired on a car containing five Armenians, killing a woman and wounding four other people in Hollywood. The authorities said there was no initial evidence of a link between the two attacks.

title: ALASKA PACIFIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February 1983.

title: PENTAGON PLANS $530 MILLION ARMS SALE TO TAIWAN
description: The Pentagon told Congress today that it plans to sell Taiwan $530 million worth of arms, the largest such single sale under the Reagan Administration.

title: Winters Tale Is Injured
description: Winters Tale, the 7-year-old gelding whose career has been sidetracked by injuries, may have suffered his final setback yesterday morning when he suffered a vertical fracture of his right front cannon bone after a morning workout at Belmont Park.

title: FEMINISM MUST SPAN POLITICAL CHOICES
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
News Analysis
description: In the space of 24 hours this week, the harmony that has largely prevailed here since Mario M. Cuomo took office six months ago was abruptly shattered.

title: A SUBWAY SYSTEM UNFIT FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dollar-and-Change Man
description: D aniel Wolf, special adviser to Mayor Koch, was pondering his increased potential value in light of the proposed salary increases at City Hall.

description: b-Net income.

title: VALUE LINE INVESTMENT SURVEY reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago results are for the operations of Arnold Bernhard & Co. which were reorganized to become Value Line Inc. as of October 31, 1982.

title: CHALLENGER OVERWEIGHT
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, 2 1/2 pounds over the light-heavyweight limit of 175 at the official weigh-in this morning, played the heavy in a figurative sense as well today. When he failed to attempt to lose the weight in the two hours allowed, his challenge of Michael Spinks for the title was first reduced to a 10-round nontitle event and then canceled by Spinks four hours before it was to be held.

title: DIGITAL SWITCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $671,000. c-Net loss. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split in May 1983. The company was in the development stage until the end of the first quarter of 1982 and first reported revenue for the quarter ended June 1982.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title:
PATENTS;
Now, Rubik Snake: It Forms Different Shapes
description: Erno Rubik, inventor of Rubik's Cube, a puzzle toy, was granted a patent this week for a toy that has become known as the Rubik Snake and has been mentioned in several books.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about outdoor music omitted the area code for information on Tanglewood. The number is (413) 637-1600.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GARY BRADDS
description: Gary Bradds, a two-time all-America center at Ohio State University who went on to play five years of professional basketball, died today of cancer.

title: Rights Group Charges Uruguay With Torture
description: A human rights group said today that the military Government used cattle prods, rape and psychological torture to punish 30 students detained during the past month in a new crackdown on dissidents.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STADLER'S LEAD CUT TO SHOT IN BRITAIN
description: At age 43 Lee Trevino says he has ''another major left in me,'' and he worked at it today by shooting 66 in the second round of the 112th British Open. That put him just one stroke behind Craig Stadler and in a tie for second place with Tom Watson, the defender.

description: Share earnings reflect the effect of the June 1983 2-for-1 stock split.

EXPERTS CRITICIZE U.S. LABORATORIES
description: The Federal laboratory system has ''serious deficiencies'' that limit the quality of its work and the nation's ability to compete against foreign technological research, the White House Science Council said today.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DON'T DELEGATE CITY TAX LAW ENFORCEMENT TO THE LANDLORD
description: To the Editor:

title: Seniors Post Flock of Eagles
description: It was 8:05 this morning and all was calm over the Newport Country Club course when Charlie Sifford, about 215 yards from the pin, picked a 4-wood out of his bag for his second shot of the round on the 468-yard, par-5 first hole. The 60-year-old senior golfer struck the ball perfectly. It bounced once on the fringe of the elevated green and rolled into the cup for a doubleeagle 2.

title: THREE BOUNCE STUD
description: The way to rifle the U.S. Treasury these days is to tell Congress you need a bargaining chip. That's how the President gets money for the MX missile.

title: Missing Persons Squad Seeks South Korean Dance Student
description: The New York City police are looking for a 24-year-old New York University graduate student from South Korea who was last seen when she went to a dance performance with a cousin on July 1.

title: Books of the Times; 'Ordinary' SS Colonel
description: EICHMANN INTERROGATED. Tran- scripts from the Archives of the Israeli Police. Edited by Jochen von Lang with Claus Sibyll. Translated from the Ger- man by Ralph Manheim. Introduction by Avner W. Less. 293 pages. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: Shift for Judy Woodruff
description: Judy Woodruff, chief Washington correspondent for NBC's ''Today'' program, has resigned to join ''The MacNeil/Lehrer News Hour.'' Miss Woodruff will be chief Washington correspondent and backup for Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer and will do studio interviews and field reporting. The MacNeil/Lehrer program, which now runs 30 minutes each weeknight on Public Television, will switch to an hourlong format Sept. 5.

title: HOUGH'S CAREER TURNS FOR BETTER
description: C harlie Hough's customary postgame bandage was wrapped around and around and around his right shoulder. Inside that elastic bandage was a towel, and inside the towel was ice. The ice and the towel and the bandage made his shoulder appear almost as gigantic as the baseballs that leave his hand and slowly start toward home plate. In the eyes of the frustrated Yankee batters Thursday night, Charlie Hough's knuckleballs had somehow become much smaller before they reached their destination.

title: 6 Accused of Role In Gambling Ring
description: Government agents raided two hotel rooms at Caesars Boardwalk Regency Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City Thursday night and arrested six Pennsylvania residents who are accused of conducting a multimillion-dollar bookmaking operation, State Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman said today.

title: THE IRREPLACEABLE BOOK IN OUR LIBRARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTROMAGNETIC SCIENCES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results include operations of Gamma F Corp., acquired in May 1983.

title: Hughes to Sell Helicopter Unit
description: The estate of Howard R. Hughes plans to sell Hughes Helicopters Inc., a major builder of commercial and military helicopters that employs 5,000 workers in California and Arizona.

title: HOW TO CARRY OFF PICNICS IN STYLE
description: There is something about eating outdoors - whether one settles for a sandwich in a brown paper bag or enjoys a feast on the grass complete with candelabrum. But for those who are serious about making special food and serving it alfresco, nothing is as satisfying as a fitted picnic hamper.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 6 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 3 4 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 3 2 18 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) A British actress caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 4 4 15 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 5 5 12 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 6 15 2 GODPLAYER, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $13.95.) The marriage of two physicians crumbles as death stalks their hospital's corridors. 7 6 10 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 8 7 7 ASCENT INTO HELL, by Andrew M. Greeley.

title: PRANKSTERS FIND HAPPINESS IN SHELTON
description: MOTORISTS driving on Route 34 as it winds along the Housatonic River in Shelton see a small, hand-lettered sign that reads: ''Wholand Orchard. Free Apples. Take Your Own. Fun for the Whole Family.''

title: A ZEAL TO PRESERVE
description: CONFESSION OF A CATHOLIC By Michael Novak. 221 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. By RICHARD GILMAN

title: SON OF BRUNO BATHSHEBA
description: PINOCCHIO'S NOSE By Jerome Charyn. 384 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95.

title: BRAVES DEFEAT EXPOS
description: Jerry Royster broke a 3-3 tie with a tworun, pinch-hit double in the sixth inning, and Pete Falcone (8-1) won his seventh straight decision as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Montreal Expos, 6-3, tonight. The loss was the sixth straight for the Expos.

title: No Headline
description: In ''The Right Fit'' (About Men, June 19), Alan Flusser discusses various matters pertaining to men's clothes.

title: The Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: GEESE GO SOUTH, BUT IT'S NOT THEIR IDEA
description: PARTY balloons did not unperch them. New Year's Eve noisemakers and honking horns left them unruffled. They even adjusted to gunshots. Now the preponderance of geese on Long Island golf courses has become a perennial poultry problem.

title: CURBING THE DRUNKEN DRIVER
description: ACCORDING to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, some 26,000 highway deaths occurring each year involve drunken driving.

title: 'ANNIE' IN ELMSFORD
description: ELMSFORD LEAPIN' lizards. Now that all the performing rights have been released, the country is clearly in the midst of a real live ''Annie'' blitz. One theater after another is getting in on the ''Annie'' act. A local professional premiere, An Evening Dinner Theater's ''Annie,'' sets a high standard. It's going to be a tough act for other theaters, small or large, to match, and it's in tune with An Evening's apparent policy of presenting musicals fairly fresh off the Broadway boards. (This one closed Jan. 2 of this year, not Dec. 10, 1981 as An Evening's program erroneously indicates.)

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THOMAS B. DOOLAN of Glen Rock is breaking the sex and religious barrier at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. He's the first man - and lay person -to head the hospital in its 58-year history.

title: IS THE VEAL CALF BEING MISTREATED?
description: EVERY Tuesday afternoon at a Hackettstown auction, calves less than a week old are bought by veal raisers from surrounding counties. The animals are then reared in confinement so that they can be slaughtered and labeled ''gourmet milk-fed veal,'' the epicurean delight that commands premium prices.

title: Margaret Broughton, A Legal Aide, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phillip C. Broughton of Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Arndt Broughton, to Charles Elton Crockett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Crockett of Gladwyne, Pa., and Wellfleet, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: A HOUSE PANEL WILL HEAR CHARGES OF POLICE BRUTALITY TO CITY'S BLACKS
description: Charges that New York City police officers have abused and brutalized blacks will be presented tomorrow at a one-day Congressional hearing in Manhattan.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: REBELS OF THE HEAVENLY KINGDOM BY Katherine Paterson 229 pp. New York: Lodestar/Dutton $11.95 (Ages 12 to 15)

title: Too Fast, Too Slow
description: Delays of 30 minutes were common during some so-called rush hours on the New York City subway system last week, and the Transit Authority said about half the daily schedule was late. Motormen, who had the book thrown at them by a consultant who said they drove like ''cowboys,'' had decided to go by it, slowing trains to a crawl. ''We're not telling our members to slow down so the public will be delayed,'' said John E. Lawe, head of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. ''But we want to protect ourselves until management does the preventive maintenance they should have done a long time ago.''

title: No Headline
description: Dan Forsman shot a 5-under-par 65 in sweltering 91-degree heat today to take a one-stroke lead after the third round of the $200,000 Quad Cities Open.

title: ASTROS ARE REVIVED AFTER AN 0-9 START
description: Bob Lillis remembered it well. After the first nine games this season, his Houston Astros had a nine-game losing streak. Then, in the 10th game, they fell 6 runs behind Steve Rogers, the ace of the Montreal Expos.

title: Prost of France Wins Grand Prix in Britain
description: Alain Prost of France, driving a Renault-turbo, took the lead on the 20th lap and held on to win the British Grand Prix today, increasing his lead in the world championship standing.

title: MERIT IN TEACHER 'PROFIT-SHARING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuten Retains Title
description: Bill Tuten of Palatka, Fla., won his second straight United States Amateur Public Links title today by defeating David Hobby of Santa Ana, Calif., 3 and 1, at the Hominy Hill Golf Club.

title: LOSSES AND GAINS IN LEBANON
description: Secretary of State George P. Schultz has returned empty handed from the Middle East, and it is time to draw a balance sheet for last summer's war in Lebanon. What the war proves once again is that resort to force by a democratic nation for other than defensive purposes, clearly defined and publicly supported, rarely accomplishes anticipated results and, indeed, often produces perverse effects that are felt for a long time.

title: IN SUMMER, IT'S THE PARENTS' TURN TO BE TEACHERS
description: ONE of the recommendations of the recent Presidential Commission on Education was to extend the school year to include the summer. Although I've always believed that we have never even explored the educational potential of the extended vacation period, I smile when I think of the lobbyists our legislators will have to fend off if they intend to hold school in July or August.

title: A MAJESTIC OUTPOURING OF CEZANNES
description: It is common knowledge among foreign visitors to the United States that Philadelphia has more Cezannes on permanent public view than any other city of its size. Why this should be, few strangers can say. But when they count up the 65 and more Cezannes in the Barnes Collection, and add to them the 28 Cezannes in the Philadelphia Museum of Fine Arts, their heads spin.

title: Susan Hory Is Married
description: Susan Ann Hory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Hory of Buffalo, was married yesterday at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Williamsville, N.Y., to Bruce David Colley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Omer Colley of North Salem, N.Y., and Bermuda. The Rev. Jerre Faegin, associate rector, performed the ceremony.

title: HIS SPIRIT LIVES ON IN THE ANTI-MERAN
description: What would there be in the current openings repertoire to whet the appetite of a 19th-century romantic master of attack such as Adolf Anderssen?

title: Albany Feud Over Patronage Prerogatives
description: The squabble last week between Governor Cuomo and Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson almost seemed fit material for the State Commission of Investigation, had not it been about the State Commission of Investigation. The flap started when Mr. Cuomo fired Lola S. Lea, a Manhattan lawyer appointed by Gov. Hugh L. Carey to head the agency in 1981, and commission member Bernard C. Smith. Mr. Cuomo told their replacements, former United States Attorneys David G. Trager and Edward R. Korman, to complete the agency's work by April, when the Governor said he would let it go out of business.

title: CRUISE MISSILE PASSES TESTS BUT ITS CRITICS SCORE TOO
description: WASHINGTON APPROXIMATELY 120 air-launched cruise missiles, armed with nuclear explosives, are mounted on Air Force B-52 bombers that stand on ''airstrip alert'' at bases in New York and Michigan. Another 260 are on other planes or in storage. In December a minimum of 16 ground launched cruise missiles are expected to be placed on launch vehicles at a base in Great Britain. Ultimately, thousands of the flying torpedoes built at a cost of several billion dollars are likely to be a part of the United States arsenal.

title: Alfred T. Baker, 68, Is Dead; Senior Time Magazine Editor
description: Alfred Thornton Baker, a senior editor at Time magazine for nearly 30 years, died of cancer Friday at his summer home in Washington, Conn. Mr. Baker, who was also a resident of Manhattan, was 68 years old.

title: 15 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments yesterday for Health Code violations. In its weekly report, the department also listed seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and five that were closed for failing to do so.

title: 'Improved' Price?
description: To the Business Editor: The logic of ''while the price (of copper) has improved - to 76 cents a pound last week from its low of 59 cents a year earlier ...'' eludes me (''Prospects,'' June 26).

title: POP-FUNK: CHAKA KHAN AND MTUME
description: The pop-funk belter Chaka Khan has a voice so flexible and a personality so vivid that on a good night almost every style of pop and jazz seems accessible to her.

title: LEADERS WATCH WARILY AS ALBOSTA PRESSES FORWARD
description: ''I just don't see it as any clamoring issue out there,'' Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said, explaining his disdain for a House subcommittee's investigation of alleged political espionage involving President Reagan's aides in the 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: MASTERS IN BUSINESS SING ITS PRAISES
description: We like to eat out and drive fast cars, We take our dates to expensive bars Sing hey, hey we're the MBAs Having fun earning twice our age. - MBAs theme song By JOHN J. GEOGHEGAN 3d FAIRFIELD PETER WIRTH is the Clark Kent of Wall Street. By day the mildmannered Mr. Wirth commutes from his Fairfield home to his job as investment banker at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. By night he undergoes a transformation.

title: VLADIMIR SALNIKOV'S WORK ETHIC
description: After Vladimir Salnikov set a world record in the 800-meter freestyle at an international swimming meet here Thursday, he was approached shyly by a man who had been standing quietly nearby as Salnikov talked to reporters.

title: FRESH AIR ADVENTURERS OFF TO 'FRIENDLY TOWNS'
description: Children with color-coded destination tags dangling from their necks filled the George Washington Bridge bus station lobby. Parents were giving last-minute instructions - ''Call me'' and ''Don't give that lady any trouble'' - and counselors in green T-shirts were directing the small travelers to the buses.

title: Screening The Screen
description: Caution: Working on a video display terminal of a computer or word processor can cause eye strain, blurred vision and headaches. But V.D.T.'s are not inherently dangerous to your health, 12 experts assembled by the National Academy of Science's National Research Council reported last week.

title: Dodgers Suspend Howe
description: Steve Howe, the left-handed relief pitcher who has been treated twice for cocaine abuse, was suspended by the Los Angeles Dodgers last night, the club announced. The events leading to the suspension, the length of which was not disclosed, began Friday night, when Howe arrived three hours late for the game against the Chicago Cubs.

title: 17 MINIYACHT 'SKIPPERS' SET SAIL IN PARK REGATTA
description: There was no America's Cup for the winner of yesterday's regatta in Central Park, but for the ''skippers'' in the race of model ships on Conservatory Water the competition was no less intense and triumph was just as sweet.

title: SOME REFLECTIONS ON THE TECHNOLOGY OF EATING
description: All the world is divided into three parts - finger-feeders, forkfeeders and chopstick-feeders. Why people fall into these categories, however, is a mystery. ''There is no comprehensive account of the ways of putting solid food into the mouth,'' according to Dr. Lynn White Jr., an emeritus history professor at University of California at Los Angeles and an expert on medieval technology.

title: THE SALKIND HEROES WEAR RED AND FLY HIGH
description: In its fifth week, ''Superman III'' is flying high. Not so high as ''Superman I'' or even ''Superman II,'' ''but the amounts are very huge,'' said a satisfied Alexander Salkind, the series' executive producer. Almost certainly, that implies a ''Superman IV.'' But first, there will be ''Supergirl'' next summer, and then, for Christmas 1984, the newest airborne, red-clad Salkind cinematic hero: ''Santa Claus.''

title: MICRONESIA COMPACT: AN UNRESOLVED ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Life Or Your Job?
description: Life would be less complicated in Tacoma, Wash., if the Asarco Inc. smelter that pumps $20 million a year into the economy didn't also pump more than 1,700 pounds of arsenic into the air every day. While nearly 600 residents make their living from the plant, its emissions are thought to cause about four deaths a year from lung cancer.

title: LOVING THE ILLUSIONS
description: THE PHILOSOPHER'S PUPIL By Iris Murdoch. 576 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $17.75.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Will the Spending Last?

title: HOW TO CLEAN UP MASONRY SALTS DURING SEASONS SUCH AS THIS
description: CERTAIN questions pop up consistently in the mail that comes to this column each week, and one of the most frequent at this time of year (after a rainy spring) concerns the problem of efflorescence on masonry surfaces. A white powdery film or dusty residue seems to show up on all such surfaces around the inside or outside of the house.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TODT HILL
description: TO some people, Todt Hill conjures up feelings of status, wealth a nd property. But to its residents, Todt Hill is just the best, most u nspoiled place to live on Staten Island.

title: Sue S. Mould Weds Herbert Jaques Jr.
description: The marriage of Sue Shepard Mould, director of the New Jersey chapter of the National R.P. Foundation Fighting Blindness, to Herbert Jaques Jr., head of the middle school of the Princeton Day School, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Gund in Princeton. The Rev. Sarah H. Motley of Trinity Episcopal Church, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the garden ceremony.

title: ART DECO RENEWAL
description: For decades, much of the Waldorf-Astoria's splendid Art Deco interior details were covered up as various areas were redecorated and modernized. As part of an ongoing restoration project that has already left its mark on the Park Avenue lobby, the hotel's balconied grand ballroom is being refurbished in the 1930's style.

title: RECORDED PLAYS ADD UP TO A TREAT FOR THE EAR
Excerpts of U.S. statement, page 14.
description: State Department officials said today that Soviet authorities had given the last of the Pentecostals who spent nearly five years in asylum in the United States Embassy in Moscow permission to emigrate. Some officials say the move is connected to the forthcoming conclusion of the East-West conference in Madrid.

title: 22 Die in Philippine Typhoon
description: A typhoon called Vera, which hit the Philippines after eight months of drought, left at least 22 people dead and about 24,000 homeless, relief agencies said today. The typhoon swept through the southern region of the main island of Luzon Thursday night and Friday.

title: 2 Orioles Under Inquiry
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn is investigating any involvement of two Baltimore Orioles players in a Federal inquiry into suspected drug dealing. ''We're aware of it and looking into it.

title: Salazar Is Defeated
description: Jim Hill defeated Alberto Salazar in a slow 10,000-meter run at the Oregon All-Comers track and field meet Friday evening. Hill, a senior at the University of Oregon, was timed in 27 minutes 59.5 seconds.

title:
BOOK BUSINESS;
FROM BOOM TO CRUNCH
description: THAT the American book world, which has traditionally considered itself ''recession proof,'' is in the worst crisis in its 200-year history, is obvious to everyone now. How it fell into this predicament, and some indications of how book people are trying to find a way out, are suggested by three conventions held by the American Booksellers Association during the past three decades.

title: DEADLINE LOOMS FOR SEEKING PROPERTY TAX REDUCTION
description: TUESDAY is grievance day, the last day that property owners throughout the state may file with their towns to have their property taxes reduced. The assessor's office in Brookhaven, the largest and fastest-growing town in Suffolk County, is usually especially busy this time of year.

title: PATTERNS MADE BY PASSION
description: EROSION By Jorie Graham. 83 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: VOLCKER CONFIRMS TIGHTER FED POLICY
description: Paul A. Volcker had a surprise and some not-so-helpful news on monetary policy at his Senate confirmation hearings. The surprise was that he might leave his post as chairman of the Fed after the 1984 elections. As to monetary policy, he said the Fed had already been trying to slow money growth for a number of weeks, a move that had pushed interest rates up about a percentage point since May. For many Wall Street economists, this came as no surprise. Sam Nakagama noted in his recent newsletter that the economy's monetary base - currency plus bank reserves - has shown no growth over the last month, a sign that the Fed had been tightening for a while. Mr. Volcker had little to say about decisions made at the two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.''I don't think you'll find these decisions terribly dramatic.'' he remarked.

title: Wedding Planned By Hillary Bailey
description: Mrs. Renwick S. Tweedy of Concord and Wianno, Mass., and Vincent R. Bailey of West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hillary Converse Bailey, to Philip Webster Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and Tenants Harbor, Me.

title: Rising Trust In Government
description: The struggles over racial integration and the Watergate scandal are widely regarded as among the traumatic events of the last two decades that made public regard for the Federal Government drop to rock-bottom. But now, researchers say, Americans are discernibly more inclined to have confidence in their public institutions and the bureaucrats who toil therein.

title: BOBBO TAKES AMERICAN TROT
description: Bobbo, sidelined for more than two months this year with a hoof injury, won the $100,000 American Trotting Championship tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The 6-year-old gelding, driven by Norm Jones, was competing in his second race since returning to the races, and he staved off a closing rush by Yankee Predator to win by a nose.

title: BERGEN WARRING ON DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: LEONIA POLICE CHIEF Paul W. Dittmar waved the car to the curb and Officer Ronald C. Castronova approached it. With his flashlight, he probed the driver's face, especially his eyes, and the vehicle's interior.

title: Djuna Barnes
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Says U.S. Bases Must Go After 5 Years
description: Greece today rejected American interpretations that the agreement initialed between the two countries Friday allowed the possibility for United States military bases to remain beyond the duration of the five-year accord.

title: THE RON AND YURI SHOW
description: The march to the Reagan-Andropov summit has begun. Likeliest site: Geneva. Target date: April of 1984, in the midst of the Democratic primaries.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Not at Your Service

title: GUARDS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: PRISON guards, who spend their days watching over locked-up criminals, may soon become the object of scrutiny themselves under a plan of the State Department of Correction.

title: BLOOD DONATIONS UP AS FEAR OF AIDS FROM NEEDLES EASES
description: Fears that acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, could be transmitted by needles used to collect blood have eased, alleviating the concerns of health officials about blood shortages.

title: FRANCE'S MASTER OF STORY BALLET BRINGS HIS TROUPE TO THE MET
description: ''Not to be too shy. Too pretentious. But if there is one thing left, I want love.'' The speaker is Roland Petit, the French choreographer and director, who has been provoking and charming ballet audiences for nearly 40 years now. ''The theater is a way to make love with the others, with the audience,'' he continues, ''with what you know and don't know, with the abstract and the realistic.'' The tone is that of a boulevardier caught up in an almost solemn moment, full of an insouciant warmth that is at odds with the chrome and mirrored surfaces of the Manhattan hotel bar where he speaks, and with the formidable venture Mr. Petit is about to embark on.

title: ART AND DANCE IN COLLABORATION
description: ''ART AND DANCE,'' at the Neuberger Museum, on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York, is a thrilling spectacle, never mind that it's billed as the first comprehensive exhibition in a hundred years to survey the collaboration of artists and dancers. True as that may be, it raises the Wagnerian specter of the ''gesamtkunstwerk,'' and, along with the show's subtitle, ''Images From the Modern Dialogue,'' douses in high seriousness a partnership that must, at the least, be rather exhilarating. Artists get lonely in their studios and the chance to work with others toward a common end doesn't often come along.

title: MORE FIGHTING OUT OF THE RING
description: Six blocks from the Capitol, a luxury hotel was under guard by about 100 law officers for seven hours last night and early this morning before peace was restored to boxing.

title: GET READY FOR THE MUSIC OF HARMONICS
description: ''Hearing Solar Winds'' (Ocora), the first album by the composer David Hykes and his group the Harmonic Choir, asks the listener to abandon some basic preconceptions as to what ''listening'' is all about. ''The Well-Tuned Piano,'' by the pioneering minimalist composer La Monte Young, has similar aims and a similar vocabulary of sounds and effects, and new-music programs at the Kitchen, the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, and other downtown performance spaces also include this kind of music from time to time. It is music that requires new modes of composition and of sound-production as well as new modes of listening. It is a music of harmonics.

title: A NEW MENU, BUT STILL TERRIFIC
description: OWNERS may come and go, but Bon Appetit in Westport seems to go on forever. The former owner, Dolly Deaty, set a standard of excellence. Open only for lunch, with a limited menu, the restaurant was remarkable for its high level of consistency and quality.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED OFFERS TO PUSH THE E.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: UP FROM INDIVIDUALISM
description: STATECRAFT AS SOULCRAFT What Government Does. By George F. Will. 186 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $13.95.

title: Some Trade-Offs As Congress Tackles Budget
description: Its August recess looming closer by the day, Congress moved in on Federal spending last week. The contrast with the first two years of the Reagan Presidency, and acquiescence to the Administration's budget-cutting program, was marked.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: LOWENSTEIN Acts of Courage and Belief. Edited by Gregory Stone and Douglas Lowenstein. Foreword by Arthur Schlesinger Jr. Introduction by James A. Wechsler. Illustrated. 369 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95. By RICHARD J.MARGOLIS

title: TENNIS LEGENDS ON TOUR
description: Alex Ward is editor of The Times's Living Section.

title: THE DOLLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Parasite Invades Water Of a Town in Montana
description: An outbreak of an intestinal disease has been attributed to waterborne parasites in the mountain stream that supplies this city's water in the summer.

title: Ann Huntress to Wed E.M. Lamont Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Benton Huntress Jr. of Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Greenlee Huntress, to Edward Miner Lamont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamont of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: ART IS LONG AND SEEMS TO BE GROWING MORE EVERY DAY
description: Lately I have been thinking long thoughts about length. I am talking specifically about the duration of musical performances nowadays, but also of performances in general. The truth proclaimed from many a proscenium arch, that art is long, becomes more evident daily. And so the audience, or at any rate the part of it that comes in contact with the seats, has had to adapt. In fact, it is my deepdown conviction that we who incessantly attend artistic events are tougher, au fond, than our immediate ancestors. When it comes to long-term sitting, we are developing a master race.

title: Djuna Barnes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Misery Index Climbs in Brazil
description: Brazil ran out of miracles last week. President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, admitting ''the economy is very sick,'' sliced 20 percent off semi-annual mandated pay raises that had kept 17 million workers within hailing distance of the country's triple-digit inflation.

title: Armenians Claim More Victims
description: Turkish diplomats have been killed so frequently in recent years by terrorist Armenian nationalists that last week's assassination in Brussels attracted little attention. But the next day's atrocity, an explosion in the midst of a vacation crowd at Orly Airport in Paris was another story.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART PRESENTS TWO SOLOISTS
description: Mostly Mozart is on a winning streak. On Friday night the festival orchestra, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, played with a contagious vigor, sounding well-rehearsed and enthusiastic.enthusiastic.

title: Trevanian
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Thomas Ciborowski Weds Susan R. Thompson
description: Susan Ruth Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wright Thompson of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Thomas Ciborowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Peter Ciborowski of Baltimore. The Rev. David Ernest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., assisted by the Rev. John Sweeney of St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church, also in Short Hills.

title: O.A.U. Bids Outsiders Stop Intervening in Chad
description: Organization of African Unity leaders appealed today for an end to foreign intervention in Chad, saying it had worsened 20 years of civil strife.

title: Herpes Drug
description: To the Business Editor: The lackluster sales of Burroughs Wellcome's anti-herpes drug acyclovir may reflect its limited range of indications - the small proportion of herpes cases for which it is actually recommended by the manufacturer -and the cautious recommendations of the Food and Drug Administration (''Herpes: Burroughs Wellcome Sees Its Treatment as a Way to Cure Profit Ills,'' June 19). It is also possible that the disease is nowhere near the problem it has been perceived in the media.

title: AN OUTING ON THE CREEK BY TUBE AND BY TRAIN
description: Just the thing to do on humid, lazy afternoons these days in Woodstock - and in Shokan and Glenford and Mount Tremper and Boiceville - is to grab your truck-tire tube and head over to the the Catskill Mountain Railroad Company.

title: SOMALIA ANNOUNCES INVASION OF 2 AREAS BY ETHIOPIAN FORCES
description: Somalia announced today that Ethiopian troops with air support had invaded the central part of the country at dawn today and that there were many casualties.

title: CONGRESS SUSTAINS DOMESTIC SPENDING IN ITS BUDGET PLAN
description: Congress, if it follows its newest budget plan, will put a stop to the domestic budget cutting of the first two years of the Reagan Administration.

title: TEACHERS STUDYING HOW TO WRITE BETTER
description: SUMMER writing workshops seem to be as abundant in New England as the rocks in a Yankee garden, complete with famous authors expounding on such topics as ''the problem of dialogue'' or ''selling your script to the soaps.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE F.D.A.;
DOSE OF DATA FOR PATIENTS
description: The F.D.A. is expected to come under increasing pressure to require that prescription drugs come packaged with Government-approved leaflets telling about the drugs and any potentially harmful side effects.

title: K.L. Farley Wed To Dana Hanley
description: Katharine Dana Hanley, daughter of Mrs. James E. Cross of Gulf Stream, Fla., and William H. Hanley of Sewickley, Pa., was married yesterday to Kevin Lawlor Farley, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Farley of Cornish, N.H. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Max Eugene Smith at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Ligonier, Pa.

title: BROWN PELICANS FIND STATE TO LIKING
description: CAPE MAY POINT REPRESENTING one of the rarest ornithological phenomena in New Jersey, hundreds of brown pelicans have been sighted this summer along the coasts of Ocean, Atlantic, Cape May and Cumberland counties.

title: Barbara Ball Married To Daniel H. Simpson
description: Barbara Ashley Ball, daughter of Capt. Stuart Michael Ball, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Ball of Washington, was married there yesterday to Daniel Howard Simpson, son of Mrs. Howard Albert Simpson of Bellaire, Ohio, and the late Mr. Simpson.

title: Miss Gottlieb Engaged To Matthew Watsky
description: Dr. and Mrs. Solon H. Gottlieb of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Robin Gottlieb, to Matthew Watsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Robert Watsky of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title:
CAMERA;
BETTER COMPOSITION FOR BETTER PHOTOGRAPHS
Debra Burstein Is Married
description: Debra Jean Burstein, daughter of Florence Burstein of Madison, Wis., and the late Allen David Burstein, was married yesterday to Donald Alan Silversmith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Silversmith of St. Louis. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Kenneth D. Roseman at Temple Beth El in Madison. The bride is a vice president of Salomon Brothers in New York. Mr. Silversmith is a vice president of the Pearce, Urstadt, Meyer & Greer Realty Corporation in the Denver office of the New York company.

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. STATEMENT ON THE FINAL DOCUMENT AT EAST-WEST TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from a statement Friday by Max M. Kampelman, the chief United States delegate to the Madrid follow-up meeting to the 1975 Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe: Introduction and Summary

title: SNETCO TO LIMIT SOME CALLS
description: EFFECTIVE Tuesday, Connecticut telephone users who want to bill a long-distance call to a third number are going to have to wait until the operator gets authorization from someone at that number. If no one is there to approve the call, they will be out of luck.

title: TOWN HOPPING ON THE CAPE
description: MILTON MOORE is the graphics editor at The Cape Cod Times.

title: POP-ROCK: SEE WAYBILL AND TUBES
description: After gaining notoriety in the mid-1970's as a traveling rock-androll circus, the Tubes have smoothed out the rougher edges of their music in recent years and emerged as an imaginatively versatile poprock ensemble. The group, which used to be more theatrical than musical, now mixes satirical slapstick routines with straightforward rock numbers in the style of the Doobie Brothers and Chicago.

title: REVAMPING NATURE TO SAVE BIRDLIFE
description: THE wild chirping of the least tern fills the air of a flat, grassy beach in Islip. The area, which is dotted with look-alike least terns of various sizes, is a perfect nesting site - so ideal, in fact, that it is encircled by a low-voltage fence that deters predators: a clear indication that this haven was formed by man and not by some miracle of nature.

title: Margaret Rourke Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Ann Rourke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Rourke of University Heights, Ohio, was married there yesterday to James McDonnell Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Far Hills, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn. The Rev. Robert McAuley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Gesu.

title: CALIFORNIA
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from two weeks on the spectacular Northwest Coast, I was interested in Mr. Westlake's observations and share several of his impressions.

title: Jane Taylor Plans Bridal Next Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Blackstone Taylor of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ayres Taylor, to John Van Buren Hoes of Farmington, Me., son of Mrs. Bertram J.L. Ainsworth of Fairfield and Dr. John Spottswood Hoes of Cooperstown, N.Y. The wedding is to be next spring.

title: No Headline
