description: The article by Leslie Gelb leads to a question about proposals for negotiating reduction of weapons of mass destruction. In most such proposals, attention focuses almost exclusively on the weapons themselves.

title:
ADDRESSING THE DIRKS DECISION...;
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION IN THE MARKET
description: THE Supreme Court, in its decision against the Securities and E xchange Commission in my case, has cleared away an unworkable r egulatory practice that inhibited securities industry professionals a nd befuddled the investing public.

title: STATE'S '82 APPLE CROP TOTALED A RECORD 1.13 BILLION POUNDS
description: New York State set two records for apple growing last year, according to reports this week by the State Crop Reporting Service here.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Just two weeks remain in which to see what is on every count one of the most remarkable things of its kind ever seen in New York - the exhibition of portrait drawings by Holbein at the Pierpont Morgan Library, which stands on Madison Avenue at 36th Street.

title: SHELLING BREAKS OUT ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF BEIRUT
description: Heavy shelling broke out around the southeastern outskirts of Beirut tonight, witnesses and radio stations reported.

title: BEST WERE THE KIDS
description: Teachers and teaching are much in the news these days. Merit pay, standards of excellence or the lack of them, longer school years, many other things. We hear from spokesmen for the organizations that represent them. We hear from politicians, including the President himself. We hear from others who are often critical of the teaching profession. Oddly enough, not very much is heard about these matters from teachers themselves.

title: THE STRENGTHS OF HIS PASSIVITY
description: FIRST LOVE AND A FIRE AT SEA By Ivan Turgenev. Translated by Isaiah Berlin. 150 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75. TURGENEV'S LETTERS Edited and Translated by David Lowe. Volume One, 268 pp. Volume Two, 266 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis. $50 the set.

title: IRAN EMBASSY COOK PLAYED HEROIC ROLE IN AIDING HOSTAGES
description: Somchai Sriweawnetr, a cook at the Sheraton Hotel here, was cooking for employees of the United States Embassy in Iran when the embassy was taken over by revolutionary students in 1979.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Morris Abram, LBJ and Neutrality
description: They were nervous, milling about in Lyndon Johnson's White House. When was the last time a President had called together the press secretaries of all the departments? What did he want? He marched in, big, brown-suited and angry, and told them.

title: Hard-Luck Story
description: The 19-year-old defendant said his name was David Sanchez and admitted he had attempted burglary. But he had a strange story to tell State Judge Ted Poe in Houston last Dec. 7.

title: Jill McD. Armstrong Wed
description: Jill Macdougall Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Armstrong Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Calvary Episcopal Church to Thomas Scott Citron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry Citron of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony.

title: An Automatic Teller Machine Is Blown Up at Upstate Bank
description: Thieves using bombs attacked an automatic teller machine at a branch of the Marine Midland Bank shortly after midnight today, the third such incident involving the bank this month.

title: THE SEARCH FOR ONE'S OWN TRUE COLORS
description: ''IT'S changed my whole life,'' one woman confided to a group of women sitting in a half circle, faces scrubbed, ready for the lecture.

title: THE TWO SIDES OF SECURITY PACIFIC
description: LOS ANGELES BACK in March, the Security Pacific Corporation tried to buy the country's biggest commercial lending business from the Walter E. Heller International Corporation for $400 million. But when Japan's Fuji Bank topped the offer by $25 million, Security Pacific quietly walked away from further negotiations.

title: IF A PLANT'S ROOTS ARE TOO TIGHT, REPOT
description: There comes a time in the life of any containerized plant when a drastic change must take place. The plant must be repotted. Whether a house plant growing near a sunny window or a tubbed specimen being summered outdoors, the container becomes too small for the roots and something has to give. This means either a move to a new and larger pot or, if the present pot is already huge and hard to carry, some sort of root pruning is needed so the plant can continue to thrive.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Finale of the four-game series. (Television -Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 2 P.M.). Mets vs Astros, at Houston, 7:05 P.M. Nolan Ryan, undefeated in five appearances against the Mets since he was traded by them to the California Angels in 1971 and 2-0 against them this year, goes against Walt Terrell, a rookie. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7 P.M.).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''None of the problems in the world will be resolved lastingly, usefully by violence, above all by this blind, mad violence, this crime for crime's sake.'' - President Francois Mitterrand. (3:4.)

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: STRATFORD OFFERS A MIX OF SHAKESPEARE AND SARAYON; STRATFORD-UPON-AVON
description: England's Stratford is in the unusual position of being both a major year-round theater with its own repertory and artistic identity and also a nurturing place for the Royal Shakespeare Company's other home in the Barbican Center in London. There is a constant flow of plays from the two Stratford theaters (the main festival stage and the smaller Other Place) to the Barbican's two similar stages. The best of Stratford (and sometimes less than the best) moves to London, creating a double platoon system of actors and directors, with each group representing a first-string team of artists. This summer the Stratford stars include Daniel Massey, Gemma Jones, Zoe Wanamaker and Emrys James in plays by Shakespeare (''Twelfth Night,'' ''Julius Caesar'' and ''Henry VIII'') and William Saroyan (''The Time of Your Life''), shared billing that would have delighted the late American writer.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: COMMUTERS and others who use PATH will have to present strong arguments at public hearings this week if they want to head off increases that will more than double the fare by Jan. 1.

title: Headliners; False Indictment
description: ''Anti-intellectualism'' in America has ''asserted itself once more with regard to legal education,'' according to Eugene V. Rostow.

title: Sept. 5 Wedding For Miss Dichter
description: Frances R. Dichter of Lenox and Wellfleet, Mass., and Channing Dichter of Pittsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Lynne Dichter, to John Harris Schapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Schapiro of Buffalo.

title: Anne Haughton Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Haughton of Overbrook Hills, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne deSales Haughton, to Timothy Jack Schmitt, son of Mrs. Daniel Schmitt of Orange, Conn., and the late Mr. Schmitt. A September wedding is planned in New Haven.

title: U.S. and Greece Settle on Bases
description: Washington and Athens shook hands last week on an agreement extending the American military presence in Greece for at least another five years. Differences in interpretation made it sound like each side got more than the other side said it gave.

title: TO PROTECT SHIPWRECKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Poor Marks for Federal Labs
description: After a year's research, the White House Science Council could not find many positive developments among the nation's large and heretofore prestigious laboratories. The panel concluded last week that many of the labs in the Federal system - 755 facilities with a total budget of more than $15 billion a year - suffer from poor management, pursue outdated missions, are unable to attract topflight scientists and turn out low-quality work.

title: WHEN IT COMES TO KIDS, EXPERTS ABOUND
description: ONE of the many things I learned when I became a mother was that the world is full of experts on child care. These people, whose mission it is to see that the job of mothering gets done properly, can be found anywhere. They are your best friends (especially the ones who have no children) or perfect strangers you meet in the supermarket. Guilt is the main tool these experts use to keep mothers in line.

title: PAPA'S MOTHER AND WIVES
description: THE HEMINGWAY WOMEN By Bernice Kert. Illustrated. 555pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $20.00.

title: THREE POETS
description: AMERICAN PRIMITIVE, By Mary Oliver. 88 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown & Co. Cloth, $12. Paper, $6.95.

title: Down and Out
description: C. H. Butcher Jr., whose Tennessee banking empire failed earlier this year, went down with his ship last week. Mr. Butcher, who was chairman of the City & County Bank of Knox County, was forced into personal bankruptcy after he failed to pay debts of $13.4 million. The banker headed one of seven institutions that were dragged under by the failure of the United Bank of Knoxville headed by his brother, Jake, in February. Mr. Butcher, who claimed to be worth $60 million a year ago, stands to lose everything but his house, car and some personal effects.

title: DECADES OF STRIFE HAVE MADE SINHANOUK AN ARTFUL SURVIVOR
description: The Vietnamese call him a has-been, and he has held no power inside Cambodia for 13 years. But Prince Norodom Sihanouk, now 60 years old, keeps springing back from oblivion.

title: BY LEWIS BERGMAN
description: LEWIS BERGMAN was formerly the editor of The New York Times Magazine.

title: BOOK OFFERS TIPS ON COPING IN COUNTY
description: A BOOK designed to help residents manage life in the county, entitled ''The Westchester Tip Book,'' has just been published by the Echo Hills Mental Health Clinic, a nonprofit community clinic in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Kate Evarts Is Wed to Alastair Gordon
description: Kate Landon Evarts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Maxwell Evarts Jr. of New York and Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Garrison to Alastair James Gordon, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ernest Gordon of Washington and Amagansett, L.I.

title: BRANCA'S SEAT JOINS DEMOCRATS' OPTIONS
description: RONALD C. TOCCI decided several weeks ago, in the wake of a Republican-controlled reapportionment of the County Legislature, that if he were going to stay in politics he would have to move his residence in New Rochelle from the new 8th Legislative District, where he faced a difficult Democratic primary against Audrey G. Hochberg, to the 11th District, where he faced what he saw as a less difficult primary against John A. DeRario.

title: Figure in Cannon Case Faces Drug Indictment
description: Timothy Melancon, accused in the $6 million counterfeiting ring involving the former football star Billy Cannon, has been indicted on Federal drug-smuggling charges, authorities said today.

title: A One-Star Rating Draws Dissent
description: I disagree heartily with Florence Fabricant's modest, one-star award to the Petit Pourvoyeur as described on June 19 (''Stylish Setting, Ambitious Kitchen''). She has performed an injustice on an up-and-coming young chef.

title: A TAX PROTESTER STIRS JAPAN'S OFFICE WORKERS
description: About two months ago Daisuke Yagi quit his job at the Mitsubishi Corporation so he could run for the upper house of Parliament. He was a high-ranking official, a company man for 33 years. Now here he was, 56 years old and 18 months short of retirement, jumping into a pool that, for all he knew, was empty.

title: CUOMO INTERVENES IN L.I. ISSUE
description: ALBANY ''I BEGAN my career representing people just like them, fighting against the site selection of government,'' Governor Cuomo said he had told a group of Bethpage residents and representatives who met with him here recently to register their opposition to the proposed construction of the Long Island headquarters of the New York State Police in Bethpage State Park.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a trip to London this summer and I am interested in going across the channel to visit the American Military Cemetery at Omaha Beach. Can you tell me how to get there from London, and how to find places to stay? - J.T., Roxbury, Conn. Answer:Omaha Beach - one of several sites relevant to the June 1944 landing of the Allies that may be visited in the Normandy region of northwestern France - is about a 50-mile drive southeast of Cherbourg, about 95 miles southwest of Le Havre and about 140 miles southwest of Dieppe.

title: NICARAGUANS HOPE FOR AID IN DEFENSE
description: High-ranking Nicaraguan officials say they are hopeful that this weekend's meeting of four regional presidents in Mexico will forestall what they believe are United States plans for a major stepping up of hostilities against their Government.

title: TACKLING JERSEY CITY'S HOUSING DISPUTES
description: FOR Jersey City landlords and tenants, the three-year-old Municipal H ousing Court has become the court of first resort where problems cano ften be resolved without extensive litigation.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE F.D.A.;
GENERICS: GAME OF BEAT-THE-CLOCK
description: Billions of dollars are at stake in the increasingly bitter battle between brand-name and generic prescription drug companies over how long the original product can enjoy a monopoly position on the market.

title: FIGHTING DRIVES MOST FROM HONDURAN TOWN
description: Occasional mortar fire could be heard one recent afternoon at the border village of Las Trojes, but it was not clear whether it came from the Nicaraguan or Honduran side of the border.

title: 2 Jersey Men Arrested On Fake-Jeans Charges
description: United States Customs agents arrested two New Jersey men yesterday on charges of importing and selling more than 100,000 pairs of counterfeit Jordache and Sergio Valente jeans in the last 14 months.

title: PIANIST IN A TENT
description: Alicia de Larrocha, the queen of pianists, is no stranger to the world's top concert halls, but Saturday night she will be playing in a tent. Miss de Larrocha will be appearing at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, and the tent can hold 2,300 people.

title: N.J. Protests A 'Kochlift'
description: New Jersey may be a nice place to visit, but about 1,000 homeless New Yorkers are living there, sent by City Hall because of a summer shortage of hotel space, officials somewhat sheepishly explained last week. ''How this happened, I don't know,'' said Robert Jorgen, an official at the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: A BANKER MARRIED TO CONNIE CARTER
description: Constance Therese Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Carter of Washington, was married yesterday to William David Lawson 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson 3d of Gastonia, N.C. The ceremony was performed at the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington by the Rev. James English, assisted by the Rev. James Stuart of the First Presbyterian Church in Gastonia.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS MOVES ARE FAINTLY PRAISED
description: Not since Congress passed the Fair Housing Act of 1968, six days after the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has the capital seen such a flurry of official civil rights activity.

title: No Headline
description: The About Men Column I heartily support the addition of the column ''About Men'' to The Times Magazine, and was especially pleased to see the first article address the question of ''Male Humor'' (June 5). While reading Isaac Asimov's thoughts, I had a few of my own, which I present not as a rebuttal but as a gloss on his essay.

title: PLAYWRIGHTS ON THE HORIZON
description: John Lombardi is a New York freelancer who frequently writes on the arts.

title: TALENT AND VERSATILITY ENLIVEN THESE VOCAL SOLOS
description: The soprano Kira Te Kanawa has recently issued three solo albums on as many labels. That such a feat is still possible in an era of massive cutbacks in classical recording opportunities is a tribute to Miss Te Kanawa's talent and versatility, and her new albums are standouts among a recent crop of recital recordings.

title: Correction
description: Due to an editing error in the review of William Wright's ''The Von Bulow Affair'' (July 3), the number of books published about the case was misstated. Of seven books once in progress, Mr. Wright's is the only one published so far.

title: WHERE TIME STANDS STILL
description: Television, more than any other popular-entertainment medium, has just about demolished ordinary concepts of time. The past is constantly being recycled as stations search for material to fill their schedules. Old movies are so plentiful on television that today's children are growing up on the same films that proved so absorbing to their parents and even their grandparents. Pre-teens can be as knowledgeable as Woody Allen about such Humphrey Bogart movie classics as ''Casablanca.''

title: AUTHORITIES DIVIDED ON DIAGNOSIS-RELATED HOSPITAL BILLING
description: NEWARK OFFICIALS of the Medical Society of New Jersey told a Congressional panel here last week that the state's new hospital billing system should be scrapped because it has lowered the quality of care and has not been shown to reduce costs.

title: Liberty Beats Defender Twice in Trials
description: In the opening of the United States observation trials to select the America's Cup defender, Liberty today twice soundly defeated Defender.

title: SOVIET DIVER DIES ON INJURIES
description: The Soviet diver Sergei Shlibashvili died in a hospital here today as a result of severe head injuries he suffered a week ago when he fell on the concrete diving platform during competition at the World University Games.

title: The Economic Fire Next Time
description: The players have been shuffled, but the economic policy games go on. Especially the M-games.

title: A Harvest Of Bromides
description: A John Deere tractor isn't assembled by committee and neither, it seems, can be national farm policy. Last week, 75 farmers and agribusiness leaders met in Washington, at the invitation of the Department of Agriculture, and in two days of closed-door talks couldn't agree on how to fix up farm policy.

title: NEW PLATEAU FOR FRENCH FURNITURE
description: French 18th-century furniture - at least the finest examples - has enjoyed remarkable success at auction in New York and London in recent months. What happened was that a handful of wealthy American collectors and a few foreign residents in New York have competed for a score or more of important pieces, causing prices to escalate. The reasons given for the bullish mood, an attitude noticeable at sales since January, are a restored confidence in the art market and the renewed strength of the dollar.

title: LADYBUG MAY CURB DESTRUCTION OF RED PINES
description: A ladybug imported from China may help check the spread of scale insects that have been gradually wiping out red pine plantations in Connecticut and moving toward the red pine's native habitat in Massachusetts.

title: STATE U. BELIEVES THAT TUITION RISE WON'T DETER NONRESIDENT STUDENTS
description: The State University of New York will charge nonresident undergraduate students $900 more this fall. But university officials said they believe the higher tuition will not deter out-of-state students, who make ''important contributions'' to the state and its academic campuses.

title: RARE SATURDAY SENATE SESSION YIELDS LITTLE ON MX
description: In a midsummer Saturday session that most members did not want, the Senate bogged down in a debate today over the MX missile and other weapons systems.

title: FOR SUNBATHERS, THREAT OF SKIN CANCER PERSISTS
description: DERMATOLOGISTS say that the average person has not yet been impressed with the message that ultraviolet rays, while producing a fashionable tan, can also cause skin cancer.

title: Gayle Viebranz and Robert Welch Exchange Vows
description: Gayle Dyer Viebranz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Viebranz of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday to Robert D. Welch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Welch of Phoenix, Ariz. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ellen Shaver, assisted by the Very Rev. James R. Leo, dean of the American Cathedral in Paris, and Msgr.

title: BOXING HAS A HISTORY OF OUTLASTING ITS OPPONENTS
description: ''LET me tell you about boxing. It's the most treacherous, dirtiest, vicious, cheatingest game in the world ... That's the nature of the business. It's a terrible business.'' When Paddy Flood, a boxing insider, spoke those words in the late 1950's during an investigation of boxing, the critics of the sport readily, and happily, concurred.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONNALLY;
'I'M NOT JUST GOING TO TALK ABOUT RAPE'
description: ISAT in the pretty living room, spellbound by the woman's words, frightened beyond my expectations and depressed by the reality she sketched.

title: Arafat Gets A Busy Signal
description: If Yasir Arafat thought his Soviet friends would help him regain control of the divided Palestine Liberation Organization, he now has another think coming. Mr. Arafat had hoped to visit Moscow but last week even his name was absent from a statement issued after Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko met with Farouk Kaddoumi, the Palestinians' foreign affairs specialist. The communique simply urged the P.L.O. to ''strengthen cooperation'' with ''progressive'' Arabs, presumably Syria.

title: CONSUMER RATES
DETECTING THEM CAN SWAY DEAL
description: FOR most people who are about to buy an existing home, rather than an ew one, there comes a point in their dealings with the seller where t he condition of the property is put on the negotiating table. U nfortunately, that moment normally arrives after a price has been a greed upon.

title: FETA CHEESE: A SAVORY INGREDIENT FOR SUMMER MEALS
description: HALF one's friends may be sunning in the Greek Islands, but at least we have feta. This crumbly, salty white cheese is excellent in salads, with tomatoes, cucumbers, and black olives coated with a rich green extra-virgin olive oil. It is also a delicious hors d'oeurvre served with stuffed vine leaves and flat Arabic bread.

title: CANADA ISSUE: SELLING OF SEX ON THE STREET
description: Neighborhood associations in many Canadian cities are struggling against feminist groups while pressing demands that Parliament pass laws to rid their streets of prostitutes.

title: Mira Named Coach
description: George Mira, a former University of Miami quarterback, has been named head coach of the south Florida franchise of the new International Football League.

title: OBSERVING THE FORMALITIES
description: NEARLY A CENTURY has passed since Griswold Lorillard appeared in a tailless dress coat at the first annual Autumn Ball in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. It was not a sartorial gesture to be taken lightly, for it caused something of a minor revolution on that fateful evening in 1886. Immediately dubbed a "tuxedo," the outfit soon became a staple in the wardrobes of all well-dressed gentlement.

title: POLICE REPORT MOB INFILTRATION OF BUSINESSES
description: Organized crime has increased its infiltration of many legitimate businesses, from restaurants to toxic-waste disposal companies, according to a report by the New York City Police Department.

title: 4 Deny Bombing Plot Roles
description: Four suspected members of the Puerto Rican separatist group F.A.L.N. pleaded not guilty Friday to charges stemming from a reputed plot to blow up two military reserve training centers on July 4. Federal District Judge George Leighton set Oct. 24 as the trial date for the four, who are charged with seditious conspiracy. They are Alejandrina Torres, 44 years old; Edwin Cortes, 28; Alberto Rodriguez, 30, and Jose Luis Rodriguez, 22, all of Chicago.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Unusual Specialist The 1984 Olympic Summer Games will not include the four-man carry, the knuckle hop, fish cutting, seal-skinning, the blanket toss, the two-foot high kick or whale-blubber eating. Those are some of the more than 50 events in the World Eskimo-Indian Olympics, which have been held annually in Alaska since 1961. Skip Blumberg, a New Yorkbased cinematographer since 1969, carried his equipment to last summer's games in Fairbanks, and his videotaped record of the events will be presented as part of Channel 13's ''Matters of Life and Death'' series on Sunday at 11 P.M.

title: A Day to Honor Mark Fidrych
description: To the Sports Editor: Mark Fidrych's departure from organized baseball should be marked by more than a wire service announcement and a few newspaper columns. It's all well and good to eulogize Fidrych by referring to him as a comet who briefly illuminated the baseball horizon; meanwhile, there are bills to be paid in the real world.

title: Instant Sanctions For Beanballers
description: To the Sports Editor: Earlier in the baseball season, there was a great deal of talk about sanctions for pitchers throwing beanballs and brushback pitches. Art Shamsky, the former New York Met, proposed suspending a pitcher for as long as a batter was medically required to not play (''A Call and a Plan to Take Beanball Out of Baseball,'' The New York Times, May 15).

title: CURFEW SUBSTITUTES GAINING ATTENTION IN WAKE OF TRIAL
description: IF the curfew at Westchester County Airport banning takeoffs and landings at night is struck down in Federal Court - which a Federal judge has indicated he is likely to do - county officials will have to deal with the controversial issue of airport noise in an election year.

title: THE POWER BEHIND THE ALLEGHANY DEAL
description: THE enormous wealth that Fred M. Kirby 2d inherited from his father made him one of the richest m en in America. The reticence that, too, seemed to pass through the g enes has also made him one of the most private.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ON the East End, where the failure rate for shops and restaurants is notoriously high, the latest closing doesn't usually cause much comment. When the Sag Harbor Gristede supermarket suddenly shut its doors at the end of June, however, area residents were abuzz.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with moore than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Deborah Ivins to Wed David Taylor in September
description: Elizabeth W. Ivins and Dr. William C. Ivins of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ivins, to David Dows Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor of Camden, Me.

title: THE HOUSES THAT GOT AWAY
description: BREATHES there a Long Islander with a soul so dead who never to himself has said, about real estate, ''I shouldda?'' Our chase of the rainbow began in East Hampton about 12 years ago when my wife and I first began to hunt for the perfect country house at a price we could afford. With keen anticipation tempered by trepidation, we crossed the threshold of our first real-estate office. Before our search ended 10 years ago, we had worn out many a sales office welcome mat -and many agents as well.

title: George Is a Bully, and I Say, 'So What?'
description: I'm a Yankee fan, I'm for George Steinbrenner, and if you don't think I'm a contradiction in terms, you haven't read the sports pages in years. Unless you're a Yankee fan too, an old Yankee fan out of the Dynasties - any or all of the three Great Dynasties from Ruth to DiMaggio to Mantle. If you're an old Yankee fan like that, you know what I'm talking about already. The same goes for old Yankee haters: They know well where I'm coming from and where I'm going here. So this is for all the others, mainly the young, particularly the young baseball writers and a few older scribes whose memory banks seem to have emptied out.
To the Editor:

title: GAMBLING FOOTS THE BILL FOR MASSACHUSETTS ARTS
description: Six weeks ago, a man named Robert Brown stepped into Ted's Tobacco Shop on Court Street, gave the clerk a dollar bill and selected six numbers. A few days later the news reached him at home in New Hampshire: He was richer by $787,840, one of many winners in a game with the unabashed name of ''Megabucks.''

title: ANGLING FOR TROUT IN KASHMIR
description: WILLIAM K. STEVENS is chief of The New York Times bureau in New Delhi.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC The piano trio is not as immediately grateful a chamber-music format as the string quartet: the sonorities of the violin and cello can clash against the more percussive aggression of the piano. And yet perhaps for this very element of tension, the form has attracted important composers for more than two centuries, and this week two particularly adept modern piano trios will be playing as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: CALIFORNIA
description: To the Editor: Berkeley's Santa Fe Bar and Grill, described in Lacey Fosburgh's otherwise excellent ''The New Cuisine's Palace'' (Travel, June 19), is so named, quaintly enough, because it was formerly a station on the Santa Fe, not the Southern Pacific. It was the Berkeley stop for Santa Fe passenger trains, including the San Francisco Chief until 1958.

title: Miss Saunders to Wed R.L.Scheiner in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Saunders of Rockaway, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Saunders, to Richard L. Scheiner, son of Lila Scheiner of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the late Dr. Herman I. Scheiner.

title: Could This Be The Start of Something Big?
description: In the absence of solid achievement, the atmospherics of East-West relations can assume a curious importance. Is the barometer really rising? Western leaders last week weighed whether minor Soviet concessions on arms control and human rights could signal something major.

title: CANDIDATES BEGIN SPRINT FOR CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: The Democratic National Committee held its issues forum for Presidential candidates in a downtown hotel here last week. But another event that revealed a great deal about the status of the Democrats' contest took place a few miles away, at the Little Rock Missionary Baptist Church. There, on Thursday night, the choir of the black church sang ''Sign Me Up,'' a spiritual with voter-registration overtones, and the minister greeted the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson with a shout of ''Run, Jesse, run.''

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SUMMER FEASTING AT A CAPE CLAMBAKE
description: SUSAN DAAR is editor of the Time Out section of The Cape Cod Times.

title: IMPASSE OVER COLLEGE SPLITS NORWALK
description: BACK in the 1960's Norwalk made a brave and wise decision. It chose to start a community college on its own hook. It was not easy but the college survived and prospered.

title:
ANTIQUES;
QUILTS: GOOD ONES AND GREAT ONES
description: THE heyday for American quilts was a long one, roughly from about 1750 to 1860. During that time, quilts evolved from early homespun linsey-woolsey to French applique work on English cottons imported from India.

title: Letters; More Equal?
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT is a hot summer evening, but the sunlight barely filters through the drawn blinds in this apartment. The living room is dim, and the voices of the people gathered here seem almost hushed beneath the steady whirr of an electric fan.

title: A GIFT FOR THE NEEDY: LUNCH
description: THE park benches on Denton Green are filled to capacity now. Mothers wheeling toddlers and the elderly watching time pass share their summer retreat with an army of unemployed, many of whom are fathers. For the toddlers, the park is a playground - an island of grass and trees situated in the middle of busy Hempstead streets. For the unemployed, it is the place they have come to bury their dreams.

title: No Headline
description: Spaniard Wins Tour Trial LE PUY-DE-DOME, France, July 16 (UPI) - Angel Arroyo of Spain won the 15th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, a 9.4-mile individual time trial from Clermont to Fermand. The 24-year-old Spaniard was timed in 40 minutes 43 seconds.

title: STYLES DIFFER IN TITLE GAME
description: The United States Football League's first championship game matches two teams with greatly different styles. The Philadelphia Stars are conservative, cohesive and canny, and the Michigan Panthers tend to be blunt, brutish and bold. ''It's a good match,'' said Peter Hadhazy, the league's director of operations. ''We've done the best we could. We've got our two best teams in the championship and now it's up to the players to put on a good game. I think they will.''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: N othing better illustrates the intense competition in the cruise industry than the many bargains being offered for late summer and fall. Some lines, in fact, have announced that they plan to extend them or introduce new ones next year.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Rise of the Rose

title: 'FREEZE GIRL' BACKED ON VIEWS
description: PRINCETON BY THE time Ariela Gross was barely more than 3 years old, she had read all the books in the children's section of the public library in Geneva, Switzerland, where her father was involved in research at the European Center for Nuclear Research.

title: Sweetener for The Big Apple
description: It's better to give and receive, Mayor Koch evidently concluded last week. A few days before his $30,000 raise was approved, and other elected officials also moved into higher brackets, Mr. Koch awarded $23.5 million in increases to 5,100 city administrators, as he had promised.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN AMSTERDAM
description: JANE GROSS is a sports reporter for The New York Times.

title: Building at Beaches: Truth or Consequences
description: Just recently, a Fire Islander asked our village board for permission to build a helicopter pad, so that it might be more convenient for him to commute to his summer home. It was, of course, turned down, as it should have been.

title: No Headline
description: Surely, you jest! Or perhaps, being of the female persuasion, I found ''Male Humor'' went right over my head.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE F.D.A.;
A TUG-OF-WAR
description: For years, the F.D.A. has been tugged in two directions by an industry that wants to rush drugs to market and a public that wants safety more than speed. But lately, the pressure on the agency has intensified with the agency attempting to streamline procedures at a time when some drugs, already approved for sale, have run into trouble.

title: ATLANTA FACING SAN FRANCISCO IN BATTLE FOR BRIDGE TEAM TITLE
description: As the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships were beginning here, another event was ending. Groups from Atlanta and San Francisco qualified for the final of the Grand National Teams, which began at the grass-roots level eight months ago.

title: SABIN WINS SHEEPSHEAD BAY
description: The sound of applause rang through Belmont Park yesterday for a filly whose speed and heart are making her the most popular runner in New York. She is Sabin, a small 3-year-old filly who goes to the front, dares her rivals to catch her, and usually succeeds.

title: Once a Month, Protest in Chile
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet has never hidden his view that democracy is a dangerous notion, especially in Chile. Last week, he used troops and riot police to squelch a day-long national protest - the third in as many months - against his decade of authoritarian rule.

title: Elizabeth L. Wellman to Wed Allen Barr in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sanders Wellman of Nashville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lynn Wellman, to Allen Morford Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Barr of Stevenson, Md.

title: CASTLES IN THE SAND
description: There's more to going to the beach than just lapping up the sun and surf - at least, the folks who run Nassau Beach Park in Lido and Hither Hills State Park in Montauk hope there is. That's why they are giving beachgoers the opportunity to show just how creative they can be with sand castle competitions. The Lido facility, on Lido Boulevard, is holding its contest today at 10 A.M., with registration at 9:30 A.M. At Montauk, it's a weekly event through Aug. 26, at 9:15 A.M. Fridays. MUSIC OF THE 50's

title: A JUGGLE OF JUGGLERS
description: The 36th Annual International Jugglers Convention is to be held at the State University of New York in Purchase, Wednesday through Saturday, in conjunction with the Pepsico Summerfare Arts Festival now in progress on campus. Hundreds of professional and avocational jugglers from around the world will perform feats that defy reason and gravity.

title: SAMSON RAPHAELSON, AUTHOR OF 'THE JAZZ SINGER,' IS DEAD
description: Samson Raphaelson, who wrote such plays as ''The Jazz Singer'' and ''Skylark'' and screenplays for such movies as Alfred Hitchcock's thriller ''Suspicion,'' died yesterday in his sleep at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: SCOTT AND ASTROS TOP METS, 3-1
description: Remember Mike Scott, one of the ''losers'' exiled by the Mets last winter? He was traded to the Houston Astros in a purge of pitchers after he had lost 23 games in two seasons.

title: GROUP SEEKS ROLE IN PICKING PITTSBURGH BISHOP
description: A group of Roman Catholic priests, nuns and laymen met this week to discuss what type of priest should succeed Bishop Vincent M. Leonard as leader of the Pittsburgh Diocese. The meeting was held despite warnings from the Catholic hierarchy that the matter was not open to debate.

title: 20 LOST IN CHANNEL AS COPTER CRASHES
description: A British Airways helicopter shuttling passengers to the Scilly Isles crashed in the English Channel today, and 20 of the 26 people aboard are missing, officials said.

title: SHERRYE HENRY AND 'HOT TOPICS'
description: THE voice is pure antebellum: soft and melodious. Even decades away from her Tennessee roots - first in Washington as a participant in Democratic government circles; for the last 14 years in New York as a successful broadcaster - Sherrye Henry sounds the unreconstructed Southern belle.

title: Drugs in Colleges
description: Amid the outbreak of publicized drug problems in professional sports, Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State says that college football has a drug problem.

title: The Sound Of Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: WOODY ALLEN CONTINUES TO REFINE HIS CINEMATIC ART
description: In this land of unlimited opportunity, a place where, to paraphrase Woody Allen, any man or woman can realize greatness as a patient or as a doctor, we have only one commercial American filmmaker who consistently speaks with his own voice. That is Woody Allen, gag writer, musician, humorist, philosopher, playwright, stand-up comic, film star, film writer and film director.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TASTE OF BRITAIN IN MONMOUTH
description: THE Fox and Hounds, a restaurant in the Monmouth County community of Colts Neck, was listed in the telephone book many months before it actually opened last December. There was also a large advertisement stating that traditional English meals would be served on Sundays.

title: SERENITY AND PUMPERNICKEL
description: THEY have come for breakfast, rippling out of the reeds, circling the dock, gliding the gray waters of not-quite morning. I do not have to get out of bed to know that they are there.

title: FINDING A MORTGAGE TO FIT YOUR SITUATION
description: THE hard choice for house shoppers used to be which home to buy. Nowt he shopper has another hard choice: which mortgage to choose. As recently as five years ago, once a loan closed, none of the e lements of the mortgage - the amount, payback period and interest r ate - could change. But as home-mortgage lenders have adapted to newf inancial conditions, they are offering loans in which the interest r ate can fluctuate. And sometimes, even the term and principal b alance may grow.

title: A 'SWEENEY TODD' OF MERIT
description: ON the evidence of last Monday night's dress rehearsal of ''Sweeney Todd,'' the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield has come up with a technical marvel and a performance of many musical merits.

title: Plastic Etiquette
description: To the Business Editor: If Jean Meger of Anaheim, Calif., considers placing her Gold Card or her Visa Preferred card ''discreetly'' on the table (neatest trick of the week) before she orders at a restaurant good business strategy, she's refined the company-client dining out relationship to a point that makes a shambles of etiquette and severely debases the intelligent guest's sense of propriety (''Spending in Gilded Style,'' June 26).

title: New Film for David Lean
description: ''A Passage to India,'' a new film written and directed by David Lean, is scheduled to start production next September and will be distributed by Columbia Pictures. The screenplay is based on the E.M. Forster novel that explored India's fight for independence. Mr. Lean's past films include ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ''Dr. Zhivago.''

title: A SEASON OF SINGING BEGINS
description: IT'S a grand couple of weeks for singing, to paraphrase Rodgers and Hammerstein, with all manner of vocal programs and sing-along opportunities on the cultural calendar right through to the end of July. This afternoon, for example, one can choose between a free concert by the National Choral and an all-Bach program at Caramoor that includes the Cantata No. 209.

title: Jets' Top Pick; Misses Camp
description: Ken O'Brien, the quarterback who was the Jets' first-round draft choice, was not among the 62 players who reported to the rookie camp yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. The former California-Davis star has not agreed on a contract, and a quick settlement does not appear likely.

title: LOWELL'S PARK: OLD MILL TOWN
description: There is no "park" at Lowell National Historical Park; the entire city is the park. Normally the term national park denotes vast virgin forests, towering mountains or even the evocative battlefields of Gettysburg. But in Lowell, visitors tour the city's red textile mills, the canals that once powered them, the rooming houses where workers lived, the banks, shops, churches and public buildings erected in the heyday of New England's textile industry.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE STRIFE OVER A FALLEN BRIDGE
description: TWENTY days have passed since a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge collapsed in Greenwich. The three people who died in the accident are buried. The three who were injured are healing. The bridge is being repaired.

title: HEARING ON HAZARDOUS WASTES TO OPEN
description: THE transportation of hazardous wastes and materials over the roads of Long Island will be the subject of a Congressional hearing tomorrow at the United States District Court House in Uniondale.

title: THE POWER TO CONVINCE HAS FADED
description: The entry of photography into museums and galleries has not been without its casualties. Foremost among them has been social documentary photography - the kind of photography that deals directly with the human condition and is frequently referred to as ''concerned'' or ''humanistic.'' While some efforts have been made to rationalize this activity within the art arena - the International Center of Photography in particular is committed to such a project - generally it has been bypassed in the rush to celebrate photography as an art form. When it does enter into the gallery world and into photography history books (as it has in the case of Lewis Hine and W. Eugene Smith, for example), content invariably takes a back seat to style.

title: SERIOUS AIMS IN A RUSTIC SETTING
description: NEITHER the name, Wee Tappee Inn, nor the neon sign outside the small stucco building suggests that the establishment inside is a fairly elaborate Italian-Continental restaurant. Thanks to dark wood paneling and exposed beams, the small L-shaped dining room, dominated on one side by a large bar, has a pleasantly rustic look. Contrasted by formal table appointments, it creates an attractive country dining atmosphere.

title: HOW TO SELL GRANDMOTHER'S SAMOVAR
description: IN 1962, a California woman bought a picture at a garage sale for $ 4, largely because she liked the frame. Last month the picture was a uctioned by Sotheby Parke Bernet for $57,750. At the same auction, a school district in Seneca Falls, N.Y., collected $286,000 for a p icture that a janitor had been told to throw away 25 years ago but c hose to save.

title: W.A. Flint 3d to Wed Bonnie Hough Aug. 13
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Lord Hough of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lord Hough, to William Arthur Flint 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Flint Jr. of Woodbridge, Conn. An Aug. 13 wedding is planned.

title: 2 Men on Country Road Leave 4 Shot to Death
description: Two robbers shot and killed four people, including a volunteer sheriff's deputy and a passerby, on a country road today.

title: STRUGGLING TO MAKE THE BREAKUP WORK
description: WHEN the Justice Department settled its seven-year-old antitrust suit against A.T.& T. early last year, the initial perception was that the nation's largest company had hoodwinked the Government. Somehow, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, threatened with loss of the lawsuit, had managed to pull off a deal that left it with the most profitable parts of the telecommunications business, while foisting its dead wood onto the lumbering local operating companies.

title: HAVE RECIPES, WILL TRAVEL
description: UNLESS it has to do with real estate, the typical conversation on the beach in East Hampton is likely to involve the details of dinner last night or where and what to eat tonight. In cottages tucked into the dunes, as in mansions that rent for the price of a foreign car, planning and cooking meals of artful simplicity and analyzing the results of those created by others has become an activity that threatens to outclass tennis.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION BEFORE STUDENT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: California
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Donald Westlake's account of his drive ''From Point Reyes to the Top of the State'' (Travel, June 19), having just returned myself from a vacation in the Redwoods of California. I, too, traveled through the Redwood National Forest, not for the first time in my life, and found the trip neither repetitive nor in the least bit irrelevant.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: He That Filches From Me ...

title: STRATFORD FIGHTS EXPANSION OF BRIDGEPORT AIRPORT
description: IN 1937, Mayor Jasper McLevy of Bridgeport paid $125,000 for an 800-acre private airport in the neighboring town of Stratford, planning to make the facility Bridgeport's municipal airfield. In the years since, Bridgeport administrations have viewed the airport as a potential economic boon for the city, and have made plans for its growth.

title: A Consensus on Central America Won't Be Easy
description: The Reagan White House and some critics of the President's Central American policy may have found a neutral ground. Administration officials said the President would announce tomorrow that he plans to appoint a blue ribbon advisory commission similar to the commissions that smoothed the way toward consensus on Social Security and nuclear missile policy. The new group would study proposals for large-scale regional economic aid modeled on the Marshall Plan for Western Europe after World War II.

title: WHO'S WORRYING
description: THE recovery is now zipping along, not limping along as it was earlier this year. But the complicated task facing economic policy makers and money managers is how to insure that this expansion will have a long and healthy life, starting from where we are, which is where we shouldn't be starting from.

title: BRAZIL'S ECONOMY - AFTER THE MIRACLE
description: WHEN the Brazilian military grabbed power in 1964, the country was in economic shambles. Inflation was running at 94 percent. Union groups staged mass marches. Many of its citizens lived in abject poverty. But the new leaders had a plan to make Brazil an industrial power. They curtailed military spending, built up export industries, borrowed heavily - and, at the same time, dramatically reduced inflation. The country grew fast and furiously - in an economic turnaround that was widely hailed as ''the Brazilian miracle.''

title: PIANISTS SIMPLY CAN'T RESIST THOSE MOZART CONCERTOS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: MORTGAGE SPREAD CAN VARY WIDELY AMONG BANKS
description: WHEN the house-shopper walks in the banker's door and asks about w hat type of mortgage would be best for his family, the answer he g ets may say as much about the bank as about the buyer's finances.

title: BARBER LEADING SENIORS
description: Miller Barber's golf swing has been described in many ways because it looks like no other swing executed by old or young professional golfers. Amateurs do not even try to emulate it; they cannot.

title: SOME SECOND-ACT PROBLEMS
description: WRITERS IN AMERICA The Four Seasons of Success. By Budd Schulberg. 224 pp. New York: Stein and Day. $16.95.

title: IN SIMON'S 'LOVERS,' THE SCRIPT IS THE STAR
description: NEIL SIMON'S comedy ''Last of the Red Hot Lovers,'' now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, is a delicious tale about Barney Cashman. A hard-working, middle-class restaurant owner, he suspects the sexual revolution is being fought far away from his Queen of the Sea fish house. So, after 18 years of marriage, he's decided it's time to do what he reads that everyone else is doing.

title:
GARDENING;
A SUMMER BOUQUET OF FLOWERING TREES
description: ONE might well assume from observing the gardens in our suburban neighborhoods that all flowering trees suitable for the region bloom before July. In the three preceding months, flowering cherries, dogwoods and crab apples bloom in profusion in about every conceivable location, but, by the time July arrives, their flowers have long gone.

title: PLURALISM IN RUSSIA?  LET'S MIND OUR OWN BUSINESS
description: According to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, it is the goal of the Reagan Administration ''to encourage the gradual evolution of the Soviet toward a more pluralistic political and economic system.'' In this, the Administration violates the pragmatic tradition of American foreign policy that was stated most forcefully by George Washington in his farewell address on Sept. 17, 1796.

title: The Grand Tour
description: Come show-and-tell time back in school this fall, 11-year-old Samantha Smith will probably get top billing.

title: 2 Accused of Big Theft From Slot Machines
description: Two men suspected of stealing up to $10 million from Las Vegas slot machines and of plotting a major theft from safe-deposit boxes in Texas were held here today in lieu of $1 million bond each.

title: World Appeal Captures Jersey Derby in Record
description: McKEE CITY, N.J., July 16 (AP) -World Appeal scored a half-length victory over Parfaitement tonight and set a track record in the $100,000 Jersey Derby for 3-year-olds at Atlantic City Race Course.

title: Clerc, Perez Advance
description: Second-seeded Jose-Luis Clerc and the surprising Diego Perez advanced to the semifinals gf the $200,000 United States Pro Tennis Championships today by winning quarterfinal matches in straight sets.

title: Task Force of Police Sweeps Times Square Area a 2d Night
description: A task force of 130 plainclothes police officers went into the Times Square area for a second night last night in a drive against bands of youths who have been preying on tourists, the Police Department said.

title: UNPROFITABLE CASINO BANKS ON NEW SALON TO PUT IT IN THE CHIPS
description: DESPITE the throngs at the slot machines and gaming tables, three of the nine casinos here remain unprofitable. They are Playboy, the Claridge and the Tropicana.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's Food column, a recipe for blueberry pancakes omit- ted an ingredient. One cup of milk should be mixed with the egg and melted butter.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's Food column, a recipe for blueberry pancakes omit- ted an ingredient. One cup of milk should be mixed with the egg and melted butter.

title: APPEALING TO A NEW GERMAN PATRIOTISM
description: ''Sure, New York is great, but I like Munich better,'' says Susanne Sommer, a perky 17-year-old West German. ''I'd rather meet with Fritz in a Swabian pub than with any old Bob in a snack bar. Bum around the flea market instead of going through a shopping center. Eat leberkas rather than hamburgers and hot dogs.''

title: Busy Peter Lynch
description: To the Business Editor: Peter Lynch (''The Man Behind the Magellan Fund,'' July 10) has a remarkable record over the past five years and he should be very proud. The record of which he should be most proud, and it should be submitted to the Guinness Book, is if he accomplishes his statement that ''I will probably visit over 400 (companies) in 1983.''

title: INSIDE AND OUT, PRESSURES ON NICARAGUA ARE RISING
description: On Tuesday, Nicaragua will commemorate the hot July morning four years ago when thousands of disheveled, exhausted and ecstatic Sandinista guerrillas fired wildly into the air as they drove into the capital. Many of them now wear military or police uniforms or are farmers, bureaucrats and Government ministers. By most indications, the Government enjoys wide support. But some prominent former Sandinista supporters and Government members are no longer in Nicaragua, having fled in fear or anger at the ''betrayal'' of the revolution. Other Nicaraguans have joined the insurgents based in Honduras and financed by the United States - ''freedom fighters,'' President Reagan has called them, whose aim is to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: MOSCOW'S FAVORITE CAPITALISTS
description: RED CARPET By Joseph Finder. Illustrated. 372 pp. New York: New Republic/Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: COLLEGES IN BITTER CONTEST FOR STUDENTS
description: AS the number of college-age students diminishes and the funding for education shrinks, some public and private colleges in the state find themselves in a bitter battle for the same students.

title: V. William Gilligan Weds Miss Zriny in Morristown
description: Melinda Anne Zriny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Zriny of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to V. William Gilligan of Mendham, N.J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Vincent W. Gilligan of Point Pleasant, N.J. The Rev. Joseph McCarthy performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Morristown, N.J.

title: PROMOTING A NEW LITERACY FOR NUCLEAR AGE
description: THE rage is computer literacy. Freshmen at Hamline University will have to demonstrate it to graduate. Other institutions are adopting a similar requirement. ''Computing has become a new imperative in education,'' declares a report from the Federal Government's National Science Foundation.

title: COUNTRY-STYLE FAIRS PROVE A POINT
description: TWO forthcoming outdoor events affirm that craft fairs, countrystyle, are still a viable way for artisans to put their wares before the public.

title: THE DIPLOMA MAY LEAD TO BROADWAY
description: The scene is the mysterious tropical island of Mahahaneyheya, where a multimillionaire from Atlanta has just shipwrecked his yacht, along with his family. Dan Coupe was fleeing from the Coast Guard, you see, after breaking out of jail, where he had been committed for mass murder - having inadvertently poisoned 330 people with his latest invention, a barbecue special called Uncle Dan's Barbe-Coupe Chicken.

title: 'Annie II' Film Due in 1984
description: Jan Egleson has been signed to direct ''Annie II,'' planned for release by Columbia Pictures in 1984 at Christmas. Aileen Quinn, who starred as Little Orphan Annie in the original film adaptation of the stage musical, will repeat her role.

title: IMPROVING THE SOUND OF OUTDOOR CONCERTS
description: Summer music played outdoors loses much of its bucolic charm if you can't hear it well. With all that open air, the sound just flies away. Lacking walls to reflect and contain it, the music peters out a short distance from its source. That is why some kind of acoustic enhancement is essential for musical or theatrical outdoor performances, and a multitude of methods have been tried at various times.

title: 2 TOWNS DISPUTE PLAN FOR MALL
description: SOME call it a classic battle between the city and the suburbs. On one side is New Haven, a city struggling to revive its downtown retail area and stem the flight of its wealthier residents to the suburbs. On the other side is North Haven, a suburban town eight miles to the north whose plans for a huge new shopping mall threaten to destroy New Haven's planned revitalization.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Joe Steinmetz was not your Average Joe photographer. Socially connected and a graduate of Princeton, he became a professional at the urging of well-off friends on Philadelphia's Main Line, where he opened a studio in the mid-1930's.

title: ECONOMISTS WARY OF RAPID EXPANSION
description: WHILE unemployment on Long Island remains significantly lower than in the rest of the state and new jobs are being created here at a virtually unprecedented pace, some economists are concerned over the possibility that the Island's economy may be growing too fast and that the rapid expansion could push inflation here ahead of the national average by the end of the year.

title: DEATH TOLL CLIMBS TO 6 IN ORLY BOMBING
description: The death toll in the bomb attack at Orly Airport rose to six today with the death of a French boy, and the police announced that one of those killed was a Greek-American who was about to leave on a flight to Istanbul with his Turkish fiancee.

title: YANKEES AND FONTENOT TRIUMPH BY 3-1
description: There was a long list of names to be honored. DiMaggio was one, Maris another. There were Ford, Stottlemyre, Raschi and finally Fontenot.

title: Leslie Stoddard Bell Plans Marriage To John Desmond McCarthy Aug. 27
description: Mrs. Hadley Comstock Ford Jr. of Brooklyn and Pine Plains, N.Y., and David Procter Bell of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Stoddard Bell, to John Desmond McCarthy, son of Mrs. Miller McCarthy of Atlanta and Richard D. McCarthy of Winston-Salem, N.C. The wedding is to take place Aug. 27 in Wilton.

title: OFFICES TO RISE IN GREAT NECK HOLLOW
description: Because of its proximity to New York City, its track record for attracting a wide variety of commercial enterprises and the solid value of its residential properties, Great Neck, at the western edge of Nassau County near the Queens line, has long been a prime location in the commercial office-space market.

title: GRUMMAN CONCERNED ABOUT A LILCO RATE RISE
description: The Grumman Corporation, the largest employer on Long Island, says it has postponed some expansion plans because of its concern about the effect of the Long Island Lighting Company's proposed electric rate increases of 50 percent.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH 40% INCREASE IN MILITARY FUNDS FOR LATIN ALLIES
description: A secret ''working paper'' prepared for the White House proposes a 40 percent increase in military aid next year to United States allies in Central America.

title: Rules for Conversion
description: Question: Our building had received both a ''red herring'' and a ''black book'' and was negotiating with the sponsor over a plan to convert the building to a cooperative on an eviction basis when the law changed. Does the sponsor have to have acceptance of 35 percent of the tenants or 51 percent? ... J.P., Staten Island Answer: Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general, said the 51 percent rule became law in New York City on July 21, 1982, and applied to offering plans accepted for filing after that date regardless of when the so-called ''red herring'' was issued.

title: PORT CHESTER MAYOR WEATHERS STORM
description: HIS retail community is complaining. His grand plans for municipal development are threatened. He has had to squeeze emergency funds from his village's budget. He is all but at war with a neighboring state. And, almost as an aside, his own family business has been suffering.

title: Olympic Lures In Yugoslavia
description: Yugoslavia is expected to attract more than its fair share of visitors as host to the XIV Winter Olympic Games in 1984, but it will offer an assortment of travel bargains in an effort to attract even more tourists.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ORDEAL OF A FALLEN BRIDGE
description: GREENWICH TWENTY days have passed since a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge collapsed here. The three people who died in the accident are buried. The three who were injured are healing. The bridge is being repaired.

title: ARE U.S. SANCTIONS MOSTLY SOUND AND FURY?
description: The United States, the Soviet Union, and Poland are taking decisions that may set the agenda for East-West relations for months to come. At Madrid, the Russians and Americans have agreed on a document to conclude the review Conference on European Security and Cooperation. This will probably bring Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko together and may lead to a meeting next year between President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. And Polish authorities, presumably acting with Kremlin approval, are expected this week to end the form, if not the substance, of martial law and release many - but not all - of the political prisoners detained since Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski cracked down on Dec. 13, 1981. If so, the Reagan Administration will have to decide whether the liberalization justifies a rollback in sanctions levied against Poland and the Soviet Union. Whatever the verdict, the usefulness of sanctions in diplomacy will again be up for review.

title: CRANE ASKS FORGIVENESS FOR AFFAIR WITH PAGE
description: Representative Daniel B. Crane, Republican of Illinois, holding his 3-year-old daughter in his arms and with his wife by his side, today asked ''God's forgiveness'' for having had sexual relations with a 17-year-old female Congressional page.

title: U.S. AIDS A REVISION IN WESTERN STUDIES
description: With financing under a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities, the University of Chicago is planning to revise its classic Western civilization series in a form that will make it available to other colleges.

title: Louise Day Riker to Marry
description: The engagement of Louise Day Riker to Gregory John Ferrara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Ferrara of Morristown, N.J., and Hollywood, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carleton B. Riker Jr. of Chatham Township, N.J., parents of the future bride.

title: SUIT SUGGESTS 389 WERE LEFT AS PRISONERS OF WAR IN KOREA
description: The Pentagon may have withheld for three decades evidence suggesting that 389 American soldiers classified as missing in action in the Korean War were actually prisoners left behind when the shooting stopped, according to documents in a Federal trial that is to begin Tuesday.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile has been bringing dance to neighborhoods throughout the city for 17 summers now, which makes it just about the oldest such venture in New York. But this peripatetic dance festival, though venerable, is far from stodgy.

title: OBSERVING DEATH: A LAMENT ON THE WAKE'S PASSING
description: IN the recent past, there has been much discussion of death and grief, with particular emphasis on how to cope with the anguish and mystery long associated with man's final hour. In the late 1920's and early 1930's, just about the time I graduated from demeaning knickers to preening trousers, my friends and I often conducted reallife seminars on death, boyhood excursions into that eternal enigma that for us was an adventure, a journey toward maturity.

title: CALIFORNIA'S BANKRUPT SCHOOLS
description: It has been five years since enactment of California's Proposition 13, which slashed property taxes by 57 percent and placed a cap on future property-tax increases. With the bankruptcy of this city's school district last month - and the prospect of several more school bankruptcies in the next year or so - the wisdom of the measure is being widely questioned for the first time.

title: Kimberly Ryder Marries Steven White
description: Kimberly Louise Ryder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry V. Ryder Jr. of Kaduna, Nigeria, and West Harwich, Mass., and Steven Joseph White, son of Mrs. Lewis S. Robinson of St. Augustine, Fla., and the late Robert H. White Jr. of Atlanta, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Bowers of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Georgetown, Washington.

title: 4th Victim in Store Fire Dies
description: A fourth victim has died of burns suffered July 2 when a man splashed gasoline on customers and employees at a supermarket and set them on fire. Five other people remain hospitalized.

title: CELLS AND COURTS AREN'T THE ONLY ANSWERS
description: IT'S a cruel joke to call criminal justice in this state a system. Among the practitioners and among the politicians, there's very little consensus on what we ought to be doing to combat the issues of crime. Indeed, in the political sphere, things tend to be enormously symbolic and we tend to focus on a variety of issues, none of which really contain the solution to the problem. For example, in this session of the Legislature, the big issue was voir dire, the method in which we have lawyers select juries. It came to pass - and certainly Governor Cuomo supported the reform, but not to the point of trying to convince people that this was a cure-all for the system - that somehow if we changed the method of selecting juries our problems would vanish.

title: CELLS AND COURTS AREN'T THE ONLY ANSWERS
description: WHEN they weren't fighting each other, politicians in Albany spent much of the year trying to fight crime. Among the measures they enacted were bills calling for a $380 million bond issue to build more prison cells, raising the maximum jail term from 30 years to 50 years for people convicted of a series of three or more violent felonies and authorizing payments of up to $20,000 for families of Good Samaritans killed while attempting to stop a violent crime. Proposals to allow judges, rather than lawyers, to question potential jurors and to establish a new verdict of ''guilty but mentally ill'' were defeated, and Governor Cuomo vetoed a measure that would have restored the death penalty. Mr. Cuomo has until next week to sign a bill creating a sentencing guidelines commission to set fixed jail terms for specific crimes. It would replace the current procedure in which judges specify a range of years and the parole board determines the actual release date. But what will it take to reform a system that has left the courts paralyzed, the prisons jammed and the streets unsafe? Last week, three experts discussed the state of criminal justice at a forum sponsored by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research. Excerpts from their presentations follow. LAWRENCE T. KURLANDER Director of Criminal Justice New York State

title: CORPORATIONS PUT NEW WIND IN YACHTING'S SAILS
description: WHEN Philippe Jeantot crossed the finish line in Newport, R.I., two months ago to win the first major solo sailing race around the world, the exuberant 31-year-old Frenchman was kissed by his mother and hugged by his banker.

title: 'NO FAULT' IS A POLITICAL LIABILITY IN NEW JERSEY
description: New Jersey's ''no fault'' automobile insurance system, one of the state's most enduring and expensive problems, is also one for which politicians may no longer be able to escape blame. Last week, yet another attempt at reform fizzled when Governor Kean, a Republican, and the two leaders of the Democratic-controlled Legislature, Assembly Speaker Alan J. Karcher and Senate President Carmen A. Orechio, could agree only that they would try again this week.

title: NEW YORK-MONTREAL SUPERTRAIN TO BE STUDIED
description: Governor Cuomo met at a railroad station here this week with officials of Quebec and Vermont and conjured up visions of a superfast railroad train that would whisk passengers from Manhattan to downtown Montreal faster than they can fly the route now.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Haworth $97,000 *2*82 Schraalenburgh Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*30-year-old ranch; breezeway, sprinkler *2*system, attic fan; taxes $2,276. Randolph $178,500 *2*17 Wilkerson Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new *2*colonial; 2-car garage, full basement; *2*taxes to be assessed. Succasunna $109,000 *2*Righter Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/-bath, *2*new colonial; center hall, gas heat, *2*hardwood floors; taxes to be assessed. Wayne $205,000 *2*74 Darlington Drive,4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*15-year-old contemporary; deck, pool, *2*library; taxes $3,230. Westfield $180,000 *2*77 Barchester Way, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old splitlevel; free-standing fireplace, *2*pool, central vacuum; taxes $4,206. West Orange $89,900 *2*27 Silver Spring Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; fireplace, central *2*air-conditioning; taxes $2,933. OTHER AREAS Mastic Beach, L.I. $35,000 *2*37 Washington Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*30-year-old ranch; bay view, *2*eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,400. Lakeville, Conn. $180,000 *2*Race Track Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*12-year-old colonial; pastoral views, *2*detached studio, 2 acres; taxes $850. Ardsley, N.Y. $86,000 *2*10 Chestnut Street, 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old *2*stucco colonial; den, eat-in kitchen, *2*0.17 acre; taxes $2,623.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN ON 3-RUN 9TH
description: Jesse Barfield's single with two out in the ninth inning broke a 4-4 tie and Willie Upshaw followed with a two-run homer tonight, leading the Toronto Blue Jays to a 7-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title:
CAMERA;
A SIMPLIFIED GUIDE TO RETOUCHING TECHNIQUES
U.S. Mark Set at 18-10 3/4 In Outdoor Pole Vault
description: Jeff Buckingham set an American outdoor pole-vault record today by clearing 18 feet 10 3/4 inches at the Lawrence open track and field meet at Municipal Stadium. The previous American mark was 18-10 1/4 by Brad Pursley of Abilene Christian earlier this year.

title: DIOXIN TESTS CONDUCTED IN 60'S ON 70 PHILADELPHIA INMATES, NOW UNKNOWN
description: Somewhere, almost certainly in the United States, are as many as 70 men who could help researchers determine the risks of human exposure to the poison called dioxin.

title: Article 040592 -- No Title
description: Negotiable bonds worth $250,000 were taken at knife point Friday from a 21-year-old messenger riding on an IND J train in Brooklyn, the police said. The Blinder and Robinson Securities messenger, Robert Tinaro, said two men with knives robbed him at 3 P.M.

title: Richard M. Olcott And Miss Simitch, Architects, Marry
description: Andrea Lee Simitch, daughter of Rhoda S. Simitch of Dallas and Alexander S. Simitch of Paris, was married yesterday to Richard Melville Olcott, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Van Santvoord Olcott Jr., of Princeton, N.J., and Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Jerome Hevey performed the Congregational ceremony at the Vermont home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: No Headline
description: The Practical Way To Arms Control Leslie H. Gelb's article, ''A Practical Way to Arms Control'' (June 5), was an extraordinarily informative analysis. The main idea he put forth was to seek limited goals in arms control because broader goals have failed heretofore.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COVENTRY FESTIVAL TO HONOR PATRIOT
description: THE old roads that wind through the countryside to the Nathan Hale Homestead in Coventry follow the same paths they did when the youthful patriot worked and hunted in the woodlands that surround the handsome 18th-century Hale family house.

title: CONCERT: CUBA'S ORQUESTA ARAGON
description: The first of two shows Friday night at the Beacon Theater by the Orquesta Aragon was, at its core, a musical event - a performance by one of Cuba's grandest, longest-established bands, with two promising supporting acts. They sang, they played, they (and the audience) danced - a quintessential Latin concert, one might think, if a rather more distinguished one than most.

title: GORY CHAOS RULES 'WAR OF THE ROSES'
description: MADISON IN TURNING Shakespeare's 15-hour gargantuan tetralogy (''Henry VI,'' Parts I, II and III, and ''Richard III'') into a nine-hour trilogy (''Henry VI,'' ''Edward IV'' and ''Richard III'') that is being performed over three separate evenings under the overall title of ''War of the Roses,'' Paul Barry, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's director and adapter, is setting a local record for sheer enormity and establishing a new endurance test for festival audiences.

title: SUMMER'S THE BEST TIME TO TEST HEATING SYSTEMS
description: IN summer, a homeowner's fancy should turn lightly to thoughts of f ixing up the heating system. In fact, according to people in the h eating-fuel industry, it usually doesn't.

title: Elizabeth Dedick Wed To Michael Curtis Rau
description: Elizabeth Mary Dedick, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Dedick of Little Silver, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Curtis Rau, son of Dr. John H. Rau of Leonia, N.J., and Gail R. Brown of Bronxville, N.Y. Judge William T. Wichmann of New Jersey Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Rumson, N.J., Country Club.

title: Lisa W. Denton Marries
description: At St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., Lisa W. Denton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Denton of Short Hills and Bay Head, N.J., became the bride yesterday of Jesse L. Paynter, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Paynter of Brooklyn. The Rev. Gerald F. Greaves and Msgr. William N. Field performed the ceremony.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: IN TESTING for dioxin contamination at 12 priority sites in New Jersey, a new device that can measure minute amounts of the toxic chemical in 20 minutes, instead of days or weeks, is being used.

title: BOULEVARD OF THE STARS, WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: The Tented Village, a massive merchandise mart that is the commercial showpiece of the British Open, has become so big that it now needs ''streets.'' As a tribute to past champions of the Open, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews has put their names on pedestrian paths in the area. Each signpost is embellished with a huge color portrait of the player honored.

title: PRIVATE GROUPS LEND NEIGHBORHOODS A HAND
description: In Washington Heights in Manhattan, jobs have been found for 100 people. In the East New York section of Brooklyn, an anticrime program has reduced burglaries in the East Brooklyn Industrial Park.

title: GUITAR: YASHA KOFMAN DEBUT
description: The guitarist Yasha Kofman is a recent emigre from the Soviet Union. After studying in Kiev and Moscow, Mr. Kofman came to New York to work with Leonid Bolotine at the Mannes College of Music.

title: ARIZONA COPPER STRIKE IN 3D WEEK WITHOUT TALKS
description: A strike by more than 2,300 copper miners against the Phelps Dodge Corporation has entered its third week with little likelihood of a settlement soon.

title: No Headline
description: Isaac Asimov's article certainly provides some plausible explanations regarding why men engage in joke-telling more than women and remember jokes more frequently. However, he makes no mention of two additional factors that I consider central to the phenomenon.

title: Anne Lovett Is the Bride Of Executive
description: Anne Robertson Lovett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lovett of Walpole, Mass., and Holderness, N.H., was married yesterday to Stephen G. Woodsum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Woodsum Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Sidney Lovett of West Hartford, Conn., a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the summer chapel on Chocorus Island, Squam Lake, Holderness.

title: BOONS FOR RESALES
description: When homeowners make improvements, they also hope they are increasing the value of the house on the resale market. But how much value is added by various types of improvements?

title: CENTER FOR RETARDED CHILDREN IS ORDERED TO REPAIR BUILDING
description: The state has notified a financially troubled residential treatment center for retarded, multiply handicapped children that it will not be recertified, unless ''significant progress'' is made to correct building and fire safety deficiencies.

title: Politics as Usual At the N.A.A.C.P.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is the largest and most venerable of civil rights organizations. And perhaps because of its age as much as because of inhospitable times, it has been rent by internal bickering and dismissive attacks.

title: Timely Tale
description: The was a whiff of something from the Los Angeles law office of Robert K. Steinberg last week, and it may or may not have been scandal. Mr. Steinberg claimed that he had been given videotapes showing the late Alfred S. Bloomingdale and a couple of Reagan appointees frolicking with Mr. Bloomingdale's late mistress, Vicki Morgan, and two other women. But after authorities demanded the tapes as possible evidence in the trial of the man accused of Miss Morgan's murder, Mr. Steinberg said they had been stolen.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
GOSPEL SINGING: MORE THAN MUSIC
description: WHEN the 125 members of the Gospel Experience take to the stage of the Harry Chapin Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park tonight to join the Duke Ellington Orchestra in ''Jazz and Gospel Under the Stars,'' there will be more involved than just sharing 100 years of indigenous American music with a general audience.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC IS NO SMALL-TOWN AFFAIR
description: Traditionally, ''country music'' has been either disparaged or ignored by big-city sophisticates, who found it simpleminded or funny. But today, country music is everywhere, and musically more vital than ever. Sociologically speaking, it is hardly confined either to the country or to the Southeast. Almost anywhere you look in the American countryside, you will find a bar or tavern that advertises live country music on weekends. And nearly every big city boasts a country radio station and a country nightclub or two. In 1961, according to figures compiled by the Country Music Association, there were 81 radio stations devoted to country music, nearly all in the Southeast. In 1982, there were 2,014, spread throughout the nation.

title: THOREAU AND THE GREAT BEACH
description: ROBERT FINCH, director of publications at the Cape Cod Museum of Natural History, is the author of ''Common Ground: A Naturalist's Cape Cod'' (Godine) and ''The Primal Place'' (Norton).

title: No Headline
