description: Isaac Asimov concludes by accusing women of ''defaulting'' on their responsibility to remember jokes and thereby encouraging the malechauvinist joke session. He has trivialized the issue to be that of men needing a ''useful psychological'' outlet.

title: HAWAII TRUST WIELDS UNUSUAL POWER
description: In Hawaii, only the government has more power and influence than the five-member board of trustees of the Bishop Estate.

title: Kathryn Peper Is Wed to Nicolas Platt
description: Kathryn Peper, daughter of Ann Loomis Hersey of Saranac Lake, N.Y., and Warren Peper, was married yesterday to Nicolas Willem Platt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian T. Platt of New Vernon, N.J., and Norfolk, Conn. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond Downs at the New Jersey home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Clerk vs. Court
description: Rub two branches of Government together and sometimes you get fireworks.

title: Paisley Granted Visa For Visit to U.S.
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley has been granted a visa to visit the United States later this month, a United States Embassy spokesman in London said today.

title: FLOODS ALONG COLORADO RIVER SET OFF A DEBATE OVER BLAME
description: So much water is coursing through the Colorado River system that Federal engineers now say flooding will not end until September or later.

title: Katie T. Doremus Weds in Rumson
description: Katie Terhune Doremus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Peter Doremus Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and David Alexander Halsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Van Rensselaer Halsey of Locust, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. George J. Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Clowns, Free Popcorn And Markdowns

title: Seepage Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE TO FOCUS ATTENTION ON OLYMPICS
description: The first stamps to remind Americans of the Olympic Games that will take place in Los Angeles in 1984 are a block of four 13-cent stamps (the domestic rate for post cards) being issued on July 28 at South Bend, Ind.

title:
...ON INSIDER TRADING AND THE S.E.C.;
A CALL FOR STRONGER DETERRENTS
description: INJURY results from deception and fraud. There is no harmless d eception. Trading on material nonpublic information is both d eception and fraud. Simply put, it is stealing. The fact that it is a ccomplished in a professional environment without broken windows andp hysical abuse does not make it harmless.

title: MEXICAN AUSTERITY IS STARTING TO CHAFE
description: If frustration could be exported, Mexico would be a rich country. Business is frustrated by a slumping economy that has drastically reduced demand, by the weak peso and by Government restrictions that have made importing raw materials increasingly tough and expensive. Labor is frustrated by pay raises that have lagged far behind inflation, which has already boosted prices 40 percent this year. And just about everyone is frustrated - albeit with the equanimity born of long experience - by the country's endemic corruption.

title: AFTER CENTURIES, JAPANESE STILL LIGHT THE SKY
description: JARED LUBARSKY is a writer and an editorial consultant to the Japan Foundation in Tokyo.

title: Supersoldier
description: For years, the United States Army has been taken with the idea of equipping its soldiers to fly like Superman. As far back as 1945, the service became enthralled with a device called the Hoppi-Copter, a light helicopter blade and engine that a soldier strapped to his back.

title: Shrugging Off A Death Threat
description: An accused drug smuggler hoped to knock a few years off his sentence by knocking off Federal Judge Herbert J. Stern, law enforcement authorities in Newark said last week. John M. Salconi, who with eight co-defendants is charged with importing nearly eight tons of marijuana, planned to have Judge Stern ''hit'' because he feared his reputation for handing out lengthy prison terms, according to James M. Perry, who befriended Mr. Salconi while both were inmates at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

title: 5 SCHOOLS IN STATE CITED FOR EXCELLENCE
description: FIVE Connecticut schools will be listed in the October edition of ''America Can Do It,'' a catalogue of 144 model schools throughout the country that is published by the United States Department of Education.

title: FOR SENIORS OF '83, SPORTS ADDED VALUABLE DIMENSION TO COLLEGE
description: FOR those who have made the cut - the transition from i ntercollegiate to professional athletics - graduation bears no t remendous significance.

title: Johns Hopkins's Quiet Best Seller
description: Alzheimer's disease, senile dementia, presenile dementia, multiinfarct disease. Whatever words a doctor may use to talk about illnesses that diminish mental powers, the afflicted and their families find them frightening and arduous to deal with. To help people cope, Dr. Peter Rabins, Nancy L. Mace and others at the Henry Phipps Psychiatric Clinic of Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine put out a pamphlet for their patients' relatives back in 1979. Almost immediately, requests for copies began coming in from people unconnected with the clinic.

title: Chile's Test
description: To the Business Editor: In reading Claudia Rosett's ''The Free Market and Chile ...An Aborted Economic Test'' (July 3), one came away with the impression that she in no way took into account what the real experiment was. After the successful coup attempt against Allende in 1973 the military sought to rationalize and centralize the economy toward pro-investor priorities.

title: Taxing a Church
description: The problem was, the California Board of Equalization said, that while the Garden Grove Community Church was a bona fide religious organization, its famous Crystal Cathedral and other properties in Orange County were also being used for profit-making secular purposes. The activities included concerts by Lawrence Welk and Victor Borge, weight-reduction classes and psychological counseling.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: AWAKENINGS. By Oliver Sacks. (Dutton/Obelisk, $7.95.) Oliver Sacks, an English physician with a special interest in the rehabilitation of patients with neurological injuries and disorders describes the cases of 20 New Yorkers whose personalities had been submerged by brain damage. He treated them with a drug called L-DOPA. In each case the recovery was only temporary, but his account is written with such grace and perception that many critics call this 1973 book, now revised, ''a medical classic.''

title: Miss Zadik Wed To Brooks Jones
description: Joanne Marie Zadik, daughter of Joseph Stephen Zadik of Brooklyn and the late Justina Zadik, was married yesterday to Brooks Holroyd Dibble Jones, son of Charles Luther Jones 2d of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Charlotte Dibble Jones. The Right Rev. Peter Hotrovich performed the ceremony at St. Mary's American Orthodox Greek Catholic Church in New York.

title: ENGLAND'S PARADISE FOR BIBLIOPHILES
description: MICHAEL BILLINGTON is theater critic of The Guardian.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: JUVENILE DETENTION REPORT TO BE ASSESSED
description: A SPECIAL committee will be named by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke to evaluate the recently-released study of the county's juvenile detention system. The study - prepared by The Ehrenkrantz Group, architects and criminal justice planners in Manhattan - recommends that the county construct a new juvenile justice facility to replace Woodfield Cottage, a 25-year-old building on the Grasslands reservation that currently houses youths accused of being juvenile offenders or juvenile delinquents.

title: Yvonne Szeto to Wed David B.Everson Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wai Szeto of Hong Kong and New York have announced the engagment of their daughter, Yvonne Yan Szeto, to David Beatty Everson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Everson of Allentown, Pa.

title: Hamsho Triumphs
description: Mustafa Hamsho thoroughly dominated Wilfred Benitez today and was awarded a unanimous 12-round decision in a middleweight title elimination bout.

title:
GARDENING;
A SUMMER BOUQUET OF FLOWERING TREES
description: ONE might well assume from observing the gardens in our suburban neighborhoods that all flowering trees suitable for the region bloom before July. In the three preceding months, flowering cherries, dogwoods and crab apples bloom in profusion in about every conceivable location, but, by the time July arrives, their flowers have long gone.

title: By Sports of The Times; Mystique in Absentia
description: SEVERAL months ago, Ben Hogan was invited to this weekend's Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am as its annual honoree. Not to compete, merely to appear. He not only never accepted the invitation, he never acknowledged it. But that's part of the mystique of the ''wee ice mon,'' as the Scots called him in 1953 when he won the British Open after having won the United States Open and the Masters, the only golfer to sweep those three major tournaments in the same year. As he approaches his 71st birthday next month, Ben Hogan doesn't like to leave Fort Worth, and he doesn't like to be ''eulogized,'' as he says. But even in absentia, Ben Hogan remained the honoree here for those on the PGA Senior Tour who cherish their memories of him.

title: Two Adults and Two Children Drown in Tampa Bay Channel
description: Four people, including two children, drowned on a beach outing Friday when a woman stepped into deep water while wading on a sandbar and the other three followed, apparently trying to save her, the authorities said.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: One of the largest Conservative majorities in modern parliamentary history voted against bringing back the gallows in Britain last week. Not even the murder of four members of the Ulster Defense Regiment 14 hours earlier by the Irish Republican Army was enough to turn the tide for pro-hangers.

title: WILL THE REAL REAGAN JUSTICE DEPARTMENT PLEASE STAND UP?
description: It was the best of times and the worst of times for the Justice Department during the Supreme Court term that ended this month. In fact, it sometimes seemed there were two Justice Departments filing briefs and arguing cases before the High Court.

title: VIDEO-GAME LIMITS EYED
description: ON Saturday evenings the regular patrons of Henry's Inn of New Hyde Park rally around the pub's three electronic games and billiard table. This scene will change drastically if, on Tuesday, the Town of North Hempstead adopts an ordinance that will restrict the use of coin-operated games.

title: MEANWHILE, BACK AT THE BARGAINING TABLE
description: WASHINGTON THERE is little agreement on what can or should be done about cruise missiles in the Soviet-American arms talks now under way in Geneva. Moscow's aim has been to limit the numbers and range of cruise missiles in order to minimize the American lead in this technology. The Reagan Administration wants as few restrictions as possible.

title: WATSON LEADS BRITISH OPEN BY 1
description: An all-star cast of six of the world's best golfers formed up this afternoon to provide one of the tightest British Open contests of recent years. Tom Watson, Craig Stadler, Raymond Floyd, David Graham, Nick Faldo and Lee Trevino, who among them have won 18 major championships, completed the third round within three shots of one another.

title: IMPOSING ORDER ON LIFE, AT AN EARLY AGE
description: THERE are systems and then there are systems. The one I have in mind operates in my town among schoolchildren of all ages, though mostly, I suspect, among the younger ones. It is called making ''dates.'' ''Dates'' are necessitated, I conjecture, by the highly structured lives of the mothers as well as the children in this town. Children do not simply go out to play in the afternoon. Should one do this, he risks finding himself alone with the gardeners. Instead, he picks up the phone and calls a friend. He begins to do this at the age of 4.

title:
MUSIC;
ARS MUSICA CHORALE SINGING FOR BELGIANS
description: PARAMUS THE Ars Musica Chorale embarked on its first European tour last week, bound for two weeks of concerts in Belgium's landmark churches and cathedrals.

title: A RECITAL HALL TAKES ON NEW LIFE
description: Carnegie Hall is taking steps to remake the image of its somewhat seedy stepchild, Carnegie Recital Hall. Perched off to the side on the third floor of this honored institution on 57th Street, the 283-seat Recital Hall has served in recent years mostly as a rental establishment, and its reasonable rates -though allowing many poor but proud musicians an honorable format -have also attracted armies of more dubious talents from all over the world. The Recital Hall, in other words, has become the cheapest and simplest way of making a New York debut, of attracting a critic to cover it and enabling the performer ever after to append the word ''Carnegie'' to his or her list of accomplishments. (The farther one gets from New York the less the distinction between the big hall and the little one seems to be.)

title: Record $1,750,000 Paid For a Colt by Forli
description: A record $1,750,000 was paid today for a colt by the Argentine champion Forli at the Fasig-Tipton Kentucky Summer Yearling Sale.

title: Springsteen Captures Feature at Horse Show
description: Springsteen, ridden by Buddy Brown, won the $5,000 Heineken Green Mountain Speed Derby, the feature event at today's Killington Mountain horse show. His time was 54.001 seconds.

title: IN NORFOLK, IT'S MUSIC SEASON
description: NORFOLK, a tiny village of 2,100 in the foothills of the Berkshires, has been a farming community, a mill town and an elegant summer resort, all within the past 150 years.

title: Marilyn Horowitz Will Marry in Fall
description: David H. Horowitz and Louise S. Horowitz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn I. Horowitz, to Leszek E.J. Burzynski of London. A fall wedding in London is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Scots and Scut Work I was most interested to read William Safire's discourse on the word ''scut work'' (''Dangling Man,'' On Language, June 19). Scut work is in the normal vocabulary of Scots, and since it was used by my grandparents, goes back to at least the 19th century.

title: DEFYING THE LIMITS
description: FUZZBUSTER'' is such an apt name for a radar detector that it has become almost generic, a lower-case tag for the black boxes that sound off when police radar is lurking somewhere down the road.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 11 ARRESTED IN WASHINGTON SQUARE
description: Eleven people were arrested and two police officers were slightly hurt in a melee in Washington Square Park yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: SHIPSHAPE WEEKEND
description: The coming weekend at Mystic Seaport promises to be shipshape indeed. On hand for the eighth annual Antique and Classic Boat Rendezvous will be at least 50 freshly painted yachts, racing yawls, gaff-rigged schooners, Crosby catboats, Herreshoff sloops, ELCO cruisers, ketches, cutters, William Hand motor sailers, former oyster boats and other vessels that meet requirements for entry.

title:
ADDRESSING THE DIRKS DECISION...;
SETBACK TO S.E.C.'S ENFORCEMENT DRIVE
description: ON July 1, the Supreme Court handed down a decision that, because o f the other block-busting cases just decided, received less public a ttention than it normally would have. Dirks v. S.E.C. is an e xtremely important case. Some see it as a serious setback to the S ecurities and Exchange Commission's efforts to curtail improper i nsider trading practices.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: time Westchester resident, has gone Hollywood. For years, a life-size effigy of Paine resided in the writer's New Rochelle cottage, given to him in 1784 by the state in gratitude for his service during the Revolutionary War. Most recently, the deteriorating figure had been relegated to storage. The members of the Huguenot-Thomas Paine Historical Association, which maintains the cottage and the Thomas Paine Museum, decided to try to remedy that.

title: BY GLORIA LEVITAS
description: GLORIA LEVITAS is an anthropologist and writer who lives in New York.

title: THE PAST INSIDE US
description: DOCTOR BLUES By Mark Smith. 428 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95.

title: PROPERTY TAX: THERE IS A NEED FOR MORE RELIEF
description: IN 1982, the total net of property-tax valuation in New Jersey was $120,514,450,565, an increase of $9,511,920,454 over 1981. There was a $7,516,137,129 increase from 1980 to 1981.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's Food column, a recipe for blueberry pancakes omit- ted an ingredient. One cup of milk should be mixed with the egg and melted butter.

title: WHAT DID BALLET THEATER DO WRONG?
description: The 11-week season that American Ballet Theater ended yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House was, to say the least, one of its most unusual and one whose lessons all dance companies might ponder. Conceivably, this was the longest engagement of consecutive weeks any ballet company has played in so large a theater. The New York City Ballet commonly plays 21 weeks in New York, but these are weeks split into fall and spring seasons. Moreover, the New York State Theater, where the City Ballet performs, has 2,800 seats while the Met, in which Ballet Theater appears, has 4,000.

title: OF APPLES, ORANGES AND TV NEWS COVERAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridgeport U. Sells Higher Education Short
description: Leland Miles's editorial (''How to Revive the Liberal Arts and Humanities,'' May 22) is a work of salesmanship that even the great P.T. Barnum would envy. But I for one, as perhaps the last graduate student in English at the University of Bridgeport, do not buy it.

title: On $1 Million Road
description: Tom Sneva will be back on the road to a possible million dollars today in Brooklyn, Mich., when the green flag drops for the third annual Michigan 500. Sneva, who won the Indianapolis 500 in May, must sweep the other two races in Indy-car racing's unofficial triple crown - Michigan and Pocono - to win a special $1 million prize put up by Domino's Pizza, which will sponsor the Pocono 500 Aug. 14.

title: THE TEMPTING BIOTECHNOLOGY STOCKS
description: THE nation's emerging biotechnology industry is offering speculativei nvestors a high-risk, but potentially highly profitable, selection o f stocks. And since the onset of the bull market 11 months ago, i nvestors have been responding in growing numbers.

title:
GARDENING;
A SUMMER BOUQUET OF FLOWERING TREES
description: ONE might well assume from observing the gardens in our suburban neighborhoods that all flowering trees suitable for the region bloom before July. In the three preceding months, flowering cherries, dogwoods and crab apples bloom in profusion in about every conceivable location, but, by the time July arrives, their flowers have long gone.

title: LIVING WITH THE VIOLENCE OF BEIRUT
description: ALL CAR BOMB SCENES start to look the same after a while. You stop noticing the stunned pedestrians with blood trickling down their cheeks who happened to be standing on the street when the lethal Mercedes - the favorite choice of Beirut car bombers - suddenly turned into a ball of flame. You stop seeing the smoldering charred carcasses of the other automobiles engulfed in the blast or the chaos of the rescue workers as they scurry around on tiptoe between the shards of glass and twisted car parts to pry out the dead and wounded. Instead, after a while, you find your mind focusing on the incongruities: the juicy roast chickens that were blown all over the street from an adjacent restaurant but somehow still look good enough to eat, or the smell of liquor from a shelf full of broken Johnnie Walker bottles. And eventually, after seeing enough car bombs, you start to notice the leaves: When a car packed with 100 sticks of dynamite explodes on a crowded street, the force of the blast knocks all the leaves off the trees and the road is left choking with them like an autumn lawn. Red Cross workers still tell the story of the man they found at a car bombing near the Ministry of Information whose chest was blown open. They knew he was still alive because through the blood that filled his mouth, little air bubbles kept surfacing. The thing they remembered most, though, was that two leaves had come to rest gently on his face - one on each eye.

title: Walesa Feels 'Like New' After Unauthorized Trip
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity union, returned home today from his unauthorized vacation, saying he would be back at work at the Lenin shipyard in about two weeks. He refused to discuss reports that martial law is to be lifted next week.

title: Anne Givens Merriam Becomes Bride Of Gilbert Jones Jr. in Noroton, Conn.
description: Anne Givens Merriam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Thayer Merriam Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at the Noroton, Conn., Presbyterian Church to Gilbert E. Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Marion, Mass. The Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore Jr., former dean of the Episcopal Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: WANT TO FIX A HOUSE? PLANT A GARDEN? ASK RUSSEL MORASH
description: ''Get ready, gentlemen, we're coming to the rockpile soon,'' Russell Morash alerts a group of workmen sitting next to a partially completed stone patio as he walks across the bustling suburban set of ''The Victory Garden,'' the long-running how-to series he produces for Boston's public-television station WGBH. Dressed in a T-shirt, blue jeans and running shoes, Mr. Morash resembles an industrious landscape architect as he supervises this early-summer taping in the show's eighth season.

title: No Headline
THE SUN SHINES IN
description: While downtown Newark's Washington Park had become a shabby draw for loiterers in recent years, some of the streets that surround it survived through hard times because many of the city's important commercial, cultural and educational institutions there stayed put. Now commercial developers have shown renewed interest in the area.

title: Cindy Mogolowitz to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Mogolowitz of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Mogolowitz, to Marvin Rafeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Rafeld of Brooklyn.

title: PORT CHESTER'S MAYOR WEATHERS STORM
description: HIS retail community is complaining. His grand plans for municipal development are threatened. He has had to squeeze emergency funds from his village's bare-bones budget. He is all but at war with a neighboring state. And, almost as an aside, his own family business has been suffering.

title: DEALING WITH UNRULY CO-OP TENANTS
description: THE family gives big parties, the guests often spilling into the h allway and monopolizing the elevators while saying lengthy g oodnights. When they renovate their apartment, their workmen bang a way at night and on weekends, in violation of the building's rules. A nd they are always late with their monthly maintenance payments.

title: Study Sees Hispanic Growth
description: Barring new checks on immigration, Hispanic people likely will surpass blacks to become the nation's largest minority group by the year 2020, a population study says.

title: RESTAURANTS PUSH TO SELL WINE, BEER BY THE GLASS
description: ANTHONY BAIAMONTE, who owns an Italian restaurant in Toms River, has been reasoning for years that he should be able to serve his customers beer and wine by the glass, since this is permitted in every state except Alaska, Delaware, Oklahoma - and New Jersey.

title: REDISTRICTING PLAN FOCUSES ON HUDSON
description: TRENTON THE Democratic majority in the State Legislature, which wants to preserve its 9 to 5 edge in the state's Congressional delegation, has come up with a redistricting plan for next year's elections that should do the job.

title: Andrew Edelman Married To Patricia Kraft in Jersey
description: Patricia Kraft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Kraft of Somerset, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Edelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Edelman of West Brighton, S.I. Judge James J. Walsh of the Municipal Court of Scotch Plains, N.J., performed the ceremony at Snuffy Pantagis Renaissance, a restaurant in Scotch Plains.

title: Repairing Tackle Far From Home
description: TACKLE that breaks or malfunctions is an inconvenience when one is angling close to civilization, but on an extended wilderness trip such failures can be disastrous.

title: Curtis and Miss Cannon Are Triathlon Winners
description: Bob Curtis of Indianapolis won the New York part of the United States triathlon series today.

title: Panel Would Deny Benefits Where Fragile Land Is Eroded
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee, seeking to combat soil erosion that has destroyed millions of acres, has endorsed legislation that would deny Federal benefits to farmers plowing up fragile land.

title: FOLK PAINTINGS AT U CONN MIX MYSTERY AND ALLURE
description: EXCELLENCE and imagination are two of the stated reasons for which the Connecticut Commission on the Arts has just given the William Benton Museum an Annual Arts Award.

title: A BRILLIANT EFFORT
description: Two decades ago bridge was like tennis: A simon-pure activity for ladies and gentlemen, virtually free from the taint of professionalism. But tennis organization, rather quickly, and bridge organization, rather more slowly, has become less amateur and perhaps slightly less amateurish.

title: UTILITY WORKERS BEGIN A WALKOUT
description: About 2,200 meter readers, maintenance workers and clerical employees struck the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday after their negotiators rejected the utility's offer of a three-year contract.

title: More New York Pension Raids
description: While tax-conscious New Yorkers were fighting to save hundreds of millions in pension costs for recent state employees, the Legislature capitalized on their distraction by passing five other pension bills that would cost the city tens of millions. Governor Cuomo, who thinks of the state as one big family, should veto the lot of them so that people who do not work for government need not consider themselves mere in-laws.

title: BIRDS THAT AREN'T ON THE WING
description: Likes and dislikes of food are, for the most part, subjective matters. We have met -quite rarely, we admit - one or two unkindred souls who have a distinct distaste for cheese and chocolate. There are others who don't care a fig - and this is hard to conceive in our own minds - for fresh caviar or foie gras.

title: A SLY SCHOLAR
description: Speaking to Umberto Eco after reading his best-selling novel, ''The Name of the Rose,'' is like being in the presence of a Bolognese Roman candle. He illuminates his ideas with metaphysical fireworks. What Mr. Eco adds to Luigi Pirandello and Italo Calvino, no mean wits, is sly scholarship.

title: Trying for a Double
description: Willie Gault, the first-round draft selection of the Chicago Bears and the world's third-ranked 110-meter hurdler, said yesterday that he would ask the International Amateur Athletics Federation for permission to compete in both the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles and the Nati?nal Football League. Gault, a wide receiver and kick returner at Tennessee, said he was close to an agreelent with ?he Bears but would not sign until his status under I.A.A.F. Regulation 53 was clarified.

title: Pain Relief: Fact and Fancy
description: The Federal Trade Commission crumbled some cookies last week. Without scientific evidence to prove it, the commission ruled, drug manufacturers may not make claims about the superiority of one product over another.

title:
GARDENING;
A SUMMER BOUQUET OF FLOWERING TREES
description: ONE might well assume from observing the gardens in our suburban neighborhoods that all flowering trees suitable for the region bloom before July. In the three preceding months, flowering cherries, dogwoods and crab apples bloom in profusion in about every conceivable location, but, by the time July arrives, their flowers have long gone.

title: MISS COHEN SWIMS TO THIRD GOLD MEDAL
description: Tiffany Cohen of Mission Viejo, Calif., captured her third gold medal today in the LA83 McDonald's International Invitational.

title: Lawyer Married To Miss Gibbons
description: Constance Ann Gibbons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Gibbons of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Alexander Francis Vitale, son of Justice and Mrs. Alexander Vitale of Woodbury, L.I. The Rev. Francis J. McGuire of the St. Thomas Aquinas Institute at Princeton University performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: WALDBAUM WINS-AT A PRICE
description: THE controversy surrounding Waldbaum's purchase of Huntington's only bowling alley has ended. An oversized bowling pin that served as the facility's landmark was removed last week and the interior of the building was gutted.

title: Gimbel Gambol
description: To Jack Gimbel, the portly proprietor of Gimbel & Sons Country Store in Boothbay Harbor, Me., it always was a puzzle why Gimbel Brothers in New York thought anyone would ever confuse his store with their big department store. But the owner of Gimbel Brothers sued, charging that the coun-try store had ''irreparably damaged'' its name, and last March a settlement was reached.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 17, 1983
description: International Soviet exit visas have been given to the last of the Pentacostals who had spent nearly five years in asylum in the United States Embassy in Moscow, State Department officials said. Some officials believe that their permission to leave the country is connected to the forthcoming conclusion of the East-West conference in Madrid. (Page 1, Column 6.) A 40 percent rise in military aid to allies in Central America is being considered by the Reagan Administration. The Administration believes that further aid is needed, and feels that ''the situation in the region is nearing a critical point,'' according to senior Administration officials and White House documents. (1:4.)

title: CELLS AND COURTS AREN'T THE ONLY ANSWERS
description: WHEN they weren't fighting each other, politicians in Albany spent much of the year trying to fight crime. Among the measures they enacted were bills calling for a $380 million bond issue to build more prison cells, raising the maximum jail term from 30 years to 50 years for people convicted of a series of three or more violent felonies and authorizing payments of up to $20,000 for families of Good Samaritans killed while attempting to stop a violent crime. Proposals to allow judges, rather than lawyers, to question potential jurors and to establish a new verdict of ''guilty but mentally ill'' were defeated, and Governor Cuomo vetoed a measure that would have restored the death penalty. Mr. Cuomo has until next week to sign a bill creating a sentencing guidelines commission to set fixed jail terms for specific crimes. It would replace the current procedure in which judges specify a range of years and the parole board determines the actual release date. But what will it take to reform a system that has left the courts paralyzed, the prisons jammed and the streets unsafe? Last week, three experts discussed the state of criminal justice at a forum sponsored by the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research. Excerpts from their presentations follow.

title: TV PROGRAM HOPING TO ENLIST PUBLIC IN FIGHT AGAINST CRIME
description: A special effort to enlist the public's help in fighting crime, which will feature televised re-enactments of recent unsolved crimes, will begin Aug. 15 with the cooperation of the city's Police Department and representatives of the business community.

title: Miss Daniel's Lead Is Cut to 2
description: Beth Daniel showed signs of wilting in 100-degree heat today, but held on for a two-stroke lead after the third round of the McDonald Kids' Classic golf tournament.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Placed Willie Ran- d olph, second baseman, on 15-day dis- a bled list and bought contract of Larry M ilbourne, infielder, from Philadelphia. ATLANTA (NL) - Optioned Bob Walk, p itcher, to Richmond of the International L eague and purchased the contract of T ony Brizzolara, pitcher.

title: AN ARTIST WHO CAPTURES THE EYE, THEN THE MIND
description: TRENTON WERE the paintings of Gary T. Erbe not inspired, they might be seen only as a virtuosic tour de force. But in addition to their technical deftness, which is a formidable feat, his works, now on view at the State Museum, exhibit sociocultural savviness combined with a humanistic spirit and philosophical wit.

title: Raclette
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's piece ''In the Swiss Valais, Raclette Is a Ritual'' (Travel, June 19) brought to mind a recent similar experience. On a chilly, rainy night this past May, my husband and I enjoyed that soul-soothing dish in the Cafe des Philosophes in Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: COSMOS TRYING TO REGROUP
description: The Cosmos are unaccustomed to their present position. They have lost 7 of the 18 games they have played in the North American Soccer League this season and have fallen behind Vancouver by 28 points in the overall standing.

title: Peking Criticizes U.S.On Taiwan Arms Sale
description: China criticized the Reagan Administration today for plans to sell Taiwan $530 million worth of arms, saying the package showed the United States Government ''wants to continue the arms sale to Taiwan on a large scale.''

title: REDUCED LEVELS OF DIOXIN FOUND IN MICHIGAN FISH
description: The Food and Drug Administration has found sharply reduced levels of dioxins in fish taken from Saginaw Bay, raising the hopes of local commercial fishermen that their carp, catfish and whitefish will once again appeal to New Yorkers.

title: GAPS IN A SOVIET ANALYSIS OF THE MIDEAST
description: To the Editor:

title: 'LEMON LAW' BILL SIGNED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo has signed the ''lemon law'' bill intended to protect new-car buyers in New York State from problems with defective vehicles.

title: Sex, Ethics And Congress
description: Charges that sexual improprieties are rampant on Capitol Hill were found to be groundless, but the House Ethics Committee - in a report last week on its year-long investigation -said that two members of the House had had sexual relationships with teen-age Congressional messengers.

title: Dr. Alix Handelsman Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Alix Handelsman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Handelsman of Great Neck and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Andrew D. Christie Jr., son of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Christie of Wilmington, Del. The ceremony was performed at the Shelter Island home of the bride's parents by the bridegroom's father.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
TWO MORE BIG SALES SCHEDULED FOR NEXT YEAR
description: The 1983-84 coin auction season continues to shape up as possibly the best in history. With several blockbuster sales already on the numismatic calendar, Stack's of New York has now added two more to the list: between December of this year and March of next year the firm will sell major elements from the collections of John L. Roper II and Amon G. Carter Jr., two of the most important ever assembled.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE nursery-school table is covered with sheets of paper covered with brilliant color. The 3-year-olds dip sponges in the pans of paint and fervently dab on more.

title: COMMERCIAL LEASES BEAR CLOSE SCRUTINY
description: WHEN a commercial tenant recently leased about 40,000 square feet o f office space in a midtown Manhattan building, he thought his p ayment for taxes would be only $2 a square foot - a bargain.

title: Enlarging the U.S Arsenal
description: Exercise in futility or no, Senators opposed to the 10-warhead MX missile last week tried to make their own megapoint with slowdown tactics, provoking a rare Saturday session.

title: Family Businesses
description: To the Business Editor: While having all the family in the business may be nice for the family, such an arrangement can be totally discouraging for nonfamily employees (''On 7th Avenue, It's All in the Family,'' June 26).

title: Wage Philosophy
description: To the Business Editor: Your selective quotations (''Finally, a Good Break on Wages,'' June 12) have misinterpreted the point I tried to make. When I stated that ''...our economic philosophy was ...that individuals ought to make as much as they can ...'' I was referring to the underlying premise of any capitalist society, not the wage policy of our union. Doctors, lawyers, bankers, businessmen, professors and others are applauded as successful if they manage to raise their incomes by charging more for their services.

title: AT CLOWN COLLEGE, MIME AND JUGGLING ARE EARNEST ANTICS
description: IT was a Wednesday evening on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York and the sun had just set, bathing the buildings in a half light. Several groups of students headed back to their dorms to study for the next day's classes. Along one of the buildings, members of another group of students had lined up to work on their homework assignments - standing on their heads.

title: ALL'S QUIET ON GLEN COVE-SOVIET BATTLE FRONT
description: By nearly all accounts, the summer doldrums have settled in on this community's cold war with the Russians. Despite 15 months of on-and-off negotiations between the State Department and city officials, Soviet diplomats living at an old estate here remain barred from the city's beaches, tennis courts and golf course because they do not pay taxes.

title: No Headline
description: Ens. Brad A. Hastings Marries Laura Francis Coo k

title: RECITAL: ANTONIO FERMIN
description: This year the 200th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar is being marked, and in celebration the General Consulate of Venezuela sponsored a tribute to the Latin American leader Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House. The pianist Antonio Fermin, a native of Caracas, who studied at the Juilliard School and who is a doctoral candidate at New York of University, made his New York debut, performing music by Bach, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Chopin and three Venezuelan composers.

title: VINTAGE RHONE PHOTOGRAPHY
description: BARBARA L. MICHAELS is an art historian who teaches at New York University.

title: Sports of the Times; Some Old Faces in the Clubhouse
description: THE elderly, baldish man in glasses and T-shirt stood in front of Rich Gossage's locker in Yankee Stadium yesterday and worked intently to pull the ends of a belt round the waist of his Yankee pin-striped knickers. He was Bill Johnson, a Yankee infielder in the 1940's and early 1950's, here for Old-Timers Day. Beside him, sitting in front of George Frazier's locker, was Spud Chandler, the former pitcher who offered encouragement.

title: CELLS AND COURTS AREN'T THE ONLY ANSWERS
description: I would like to quote one sentence from ''Crime and Public Policy,'' edited by James Q. Wilson, that I found interesting. ''Parents of stealers do not track: ((they) do not interpret stealing ... as 'deviant'); they do not punish; and they do not care.''

title: Miss Groves Wed To J. B. Littlefield
description: Suzanne Groves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Freeman Groves of Southborough, Mass., formerly of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Joshua Bayley Littlefield, son of Mrs. W. Joseph Littlefield of Miami and the late Mr. Littlefield. The Rev. David Van Dusen performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass.

title: POP: EURYTHMICS AT THE RITZ
description: Further evidence of David Bowie's apparently never-ending influence on contemporary rock styles was offered at the Ritz on Thursday, where the Eurythmics, the successful British techno-pop duo, made their New York debut. Consisting of the singer, songwriter and flutist Annie Lennox and the guitarist and singer David Stewart, the Eurythmics were augmented by a strong rhythm section, a keyboardist and elaborate pre-recorded sound effects.

title: SEDUCED BY SPAIN
description: SHORT FLIGHTS By Barbara Probst Solomon. 313 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $18.75.

title: ITALIAN CUISINE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: THREE and a half years ago Michelangelo's received a two-star rating for its savory and authentic Italian cuisine. Since then, the kitchen has lost some of its spark, the magic and know-how that the talented Luigi and Adelaida Mazzariello once brought to kitchen and dining room. They're a hard act to follow, and one cannot ignore the fact that since their retirement, the restaurant has been slipping gradually; recent visits have been disappointing.

title: U.S. AGENTS TELL OF SHIELDING BARBIE
description: High United States Army intelligence officers paid and shielded Klaus Barbie as an informant for years after World War II, despite their knowledge that the former Gestapo officer was wanted in France for war crimes, according to a Justice Department investigation.

title: Miss Liberty Centennial
description: Jeremy Gury, the long-retired, one-time creative director of Ted Bates & Company, has reported that he has been named creative director for the Statue of Liberty Centennial and the Ellis Island Restoration Fund and that his many duties will include the selection of advertising and public relations agencies. ''Tens of millions will be allocated as the work goes forward,'' he wrote. The Advisory Council to the New York Statue of Liberty Centennial Commission, which informed Mr. Gury of his appointment, is at 17 Battery Place.

title: PEMEX: FOCUS OF A CRACKDOWN
description: Inside Jorge Diaz Serrano's home in a fashionable Mexico City neighborhood, the trappings are of comfort and success; outside, they are of an armed camp.

title: DIVERSE ANTIWAR MOVEMENT CITES GAINS
description: In a deceptively quiet period for their national activities, a deceptively small group of pacifists ended a four-day convention today, having attended workshops aimed at techniques for expansion, swum in a college pool and watched a softball game between two of the diverse segments of their organization.

title: News Analysis
description: Two years ago, economic relations between the United States and Canada had become muddy at best and stingingly acrimonious at worst.

title: 2 NEW HOUSTON TOWERS EMBODY ARCHITECTURAL SHIFT
description: Two skyscrapers that many people believe will profoundly influence the evolution of American urban architecture are nearing completion on the Houston skyline.

title: Miss Daniel Wins On Clutch Iron Shot
description: Beth Daniel considered her iron shot to the green during a sudden-death playoff today a do-or-die stroke. ''It either works or doesn't work. I wanted it to end,'' she said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Animals in Fact and Fancy

title: JETS' CAMP OPENS WITH O'BRIEN HOME
description: The Jets and the Giants opened their rookie camps yesterday, officially beginning their training agenda for the coming season. The Jets, losers to the Miami Dolphins in the American Football Conference championship game last season, had 62 players at their training facility at Hofstra University in Hemstead, L.I..

title: A DAY AT PENN STATION: LIFE IN A CITY INSIDE CITY
description: The summer season, the hectic season, is under way at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. Seven days a week more than half a million people pass through the railroad station, one of the nation's busiest. Many are commuters traveling to and from homes as far away as Pennsylvania. Thousands more are vacationers, loaded down with luggage, coolers and tennis rackets.

title: SAFETY OF DEREGULATION OF BANKING IS DEBATED
description: It was 50 years ago that Congress erected barriers between commercial banks and other types of financial institutions to protect the banks from the kind of excessive risktaking that led to bank failures during the Depression.

title: Kenyon C. Bolton Dies; Patron of Arts Was 71
description: Kenyon C. Bolton, a philanthropist and patron of the arts, died of cancer Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 71 years old and maintained homes in Shaker Heights and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Opera Dispute in Brief
description: The New York City Opera orchestra and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians established a picket line in front of the New York State Theater on July 7, and all scheduled New York City Opera performances have been canceled. Since then, there has been one negotiating session, last Wednesday, but it was adjourned with no progress reported. Another session is scheduled for tomorrow. Principals

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has named A. Clark Johnson president and chief operating officer of its Unit Texas Petroleum Corp. franchise.

title: TRADERS WARY ON BOND RATES
description: With an economic recovery well under way, bond market participants have become more skeptical about the prospects for lower interest rates. Their nervousness about the future explains why the yield on the bellwether 10 3/8 percent Treausry bonds due in 2012 closed Friday at 11.41 percent, up more than a percentage point from 10 3/8 percent at the beginning of May.

title: No Headline
description: Books: An Irish Diary By Richard F. Shepard UP IN THE PARK: The Diary of the Wife of the American Ambassador to Ire- land, 1977-81. By Elizabeth Shannon. 358 pages. Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Pope Issues New Plea Over Kidnapped Girl
description: Pope John Paul II appealed again today for the release of Emanuela Orlandi, the kidnapped daughter of a Vatican messenger. Hours later an anonymous caller warned that she would be killed unless Mehmet Ali Agca, who shot the Pope in 1981, was freed within three days.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER ENDS SEASON WITH 'GISELLE'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S New York season came to a tumultuous close Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The audience thronged to the front and stayed and stayed after the curtain came down on ''Giselle.'' There were shouts of ''Gelsey'' and ''Misha'' as Gelsey Kirkland and Mikhail Baryshnikov took their calls with stylish aplomb. Bouquets sailed over the footlights for all the principal dancers, and there was the traditional shower of paper from the top of the house.

title: U.S. AND LEBANON TO SEEK FORMULA ON SYRIA PULLOUT
description: Senior Administration officials said today that they hoped to work out with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon this week a new formula toward ending the impasse with Syria over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: CITY POLICE COMPLAINT PANEL IS AGAIN FACING CONTROVERSY
description: After 17 years, the Police Department's Civilian Complaint Review Board is again surrounded by controversy. On one side, it is attacked by some critics as ineffective in investigating charges of police brutality and other abuses. On the other, it is criticized by the police officers' union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which contends that the board has developed into an ''inquisition'' that discourages proper police work.

title: The Dioxin Legacy
description: Dioxin is the chemical industry's most unpleasant byproduct, an extraordinarily potent poison that lingers for years at sites where it was created or dumped. Newly detected dioxin deposits vex citizens in Missouri and New Jersey. And dioxin haunts its makers, too: Vietnam veterans claim millions in damages for being exposed to a defoliant that contained dioxin as a manufacturing impurity.

title: PART SAILING, PART SURFING, BOARDSAILING FINDING FANS
description: As if in a ballet they skim atop the water, dancing on narrow white boards as the wind balloons the orange sails in their hands.

title: INVITATION TO A LOCKER ROOM
description: THE political columnist George Will, it was recently reported, took part in the Ronald Reagan's rehearsal sessions before the debate with President Jimmy Carter in 1980. Mr. Will was supposed to have helped coach the Republican Presidential candidate, and then to have commented favorably on national television about Mr. Reagan's performance. He has been criticized for a conflict of interest. In defense of his presence at the rehearsal sessions, Mr. Will said: ''It's like being invited into the locker room for a sportswriter.''

title: Title to Miss Widman
description: Mary Ann Widman of Elmira retained her title by defeating Jamie DeWeese of Rochester, 4 and 3, in the 36-hole final of the State Women's Amateur golf championship today.

title: 4 LATIN PRESIDENTS URGE STEPS TO END CONFLICT IN REGION
description: The Presidents of four Latin American countries tonight expressed ''profound concern for the rapid deterioration'' of the situation in Central America.

title: BLUE JAYS DEFEATED BY WHITE SOX, 3-2
description: Floyd Bannister flirted with a no-hitter into the seventh inning, and Harold Baines and Carlton Fisk hit home runs today to lead to Chicago White Sox to a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Defying the Odds
description: Some athletes compete to discover their limitations. Willie Brown plays basketball to defy them. Brown, who is 18 years old, is a senior at the Georgia School for the Deaf in Cave Spring. He is expected to become the first deaf player to score more than 2,000 points in his high school career. He is also pursuing a near-impossible dream: He wants to play major college basketball and become a pro. No deaf person has ever done that. But there are a few people that think Willie Brown can.

title: Advertising; Glamour Magazine's Relevance
description: Our company is the best-kept secret in the business.'' That is one of the most familiar complaints among ad agency chief executives who feel that their non-news events are not getting the proper coverage.

title: KIM TAIK SOO
description: Kim Taik Soo, a member of the International Olympic Committee and a former majority leader of the National Assembly, died today of liver cancer. He was 56 years old.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Baxter Travenol Laboratories filed a $42.5 million offering of tax-exempt debt securities by the Puerto Rico Industrial, Medical and Environmental Pollution Control Facilities Financing Authority. Common Stock

title: PUZZLE FOR EUROPE: U.S. AND FREE TRADE
description: This month, the Reagan Administration decided to grant four years of increased protection from foreign imports to the American speciality steel industry. What struck a benevolent observer who was present among the hired hands in Williamsburg in June and in Geneva last November was that the United States was asking its allies to accept the odd notion that a country that is in principle committed to free trade can, in practice, engage in acts that inhibit free trade.

title: HOW TO BE AN EXPERT ON JOBLESSNESS FIGURES
description: How much do you know about one of the most widely watched statistics in the United States - the official monthly estimate of national unemployment?

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: A SHREWD INSIDER BATTLES FOR THE MX
description: In a room just off the House floor, Representative Les Aspin bent forward and listened intently as Gen. Bennie L. Davis, commander of the Strategic Air Command, talked about retirement pay and mobile missiles.

title: FORMER PRESIDENT OF BURUNDI
description: Michel Micombero, the former President of Burundi, died of a heart attack in Mogadishu, where he had lived in exile since his ouster in a 1976 coup, the Somali press agency said today. He was 43 years old.

title: CABARET: A TRIBUTE TO HARRY CHAPIN
description: THE late Harry Chapin, along with songwriters like John Denver and Jim Croce, used folk music as a populist storytelling medium. But more than any of his contemporaries, Mr. Chapin insisted that popular music could be an effective humanitarian platform.

title: OFFICIALS FORESEE RUDOLPH PENNER AS CONGRESS'S TOP BUDGET EXPERT
description: Rudolph G. Penner, a budget and tax expert for a conservative research institute, will be named this week as director of the Congressional Budget Office, Congressional officials said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SHORT CIRCUIT. Six Months on the Men's Professional Tennis Tour. By Michael Mewshaw. 306 pages. Atheneum. $13.95.

title: Never Say Never
description: As the 6-foot-10-inch Eric Fernsten crowds his long legs under the desk each morning at the Shearson-American Express office in Boston, his thoughts often wander from selling stocks and bonds, to again wearing a National Basketball Asssociation uniform. Possibly a Knick uniform.

title: Membership Aide Picked To Lead California NOW
description: Sandra Farha, membership coordinator of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women, was elected state coordinator of the group this weekend.

title: Raging Bull Killed in Florida
description: A ''berserk'' bull rammed a highway patrol officer in the abdomen and ''stomped him'' today, the police said. It was shot to death by other troopers after it kept charging into traffic on a busy truck route near here. The police said a bulletproof vest apparently kept the bull's horns from penetrating the body of Trooper S.A. Williams, who was taken to a hospital for examination.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook Those Connecticut Imperialists

title: Radiation Released At U.S. Military Plant
description: An equipment malfunction caused a small release of radiation at the Department of Energy's Savannah River Plant, a department spokesman said today.

title: Miss Cohen Captures 4th Gold
description: Soviet Union swimmers completed their domination as the McDonald's International Invitational meet ended today, but the performance of 17-year-old Tiffany Cohen, who won four gold medals, was the bright spot for the United States.

title: Laciar Knocks Out Korean in Round 1
description: Argentina's Santos Laciar knocked out South Korean Shin Hee-Sup today in the first round of a scheduled 15-round title bout to retain his World Boxing Association flyweight championship. The referee, Zack Clayton of the United States, stopped the bout at 1:19 after Laciar scored three knockdowns.

title: WATSON WINS 5TH BRITISH TITLE
description: Tom Watson broke a three-way tie with a birdie 3 on the 16th hole today to win his fifth British Open Championship by one stroke.

title: ANOREXIA: NOT JUST A DISEASE OF THE YOUNG
description: ''I feel terribly guilty when I eat. Depression envelops me like a heavy cloak. I have to go to the doctor tomorrow, and he will weigh me but I won't look at the scale. I become hysterical if I weigh more than 100 pounds. I am horrendously unhappy because I am fat and I envy everyone I see who is thin. I think I weigh between 105 and 110 pounds.''

title: POLICE BRUTALITY HEARINGS: 'POLITICAL CHARADE'...
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Suspended After Park Melee
description: A city police officer was suspended without pay early yesterday after a melee in Washington Square Park Saturday afternoon during which 2 other officers were slightly injured and 11 people were arrested, most on disorderly conduct charges.

title: DANCE: LUBOVITCH OFFERS 'TABERNACLE' AT PURCHASE
description: Lar Lubovitch can devise high-energy choreography for high-energy dancers. But sometimes, high energy is all his works contain, and they turn into blurs of activity.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS NEW LATIN PANEL UNDER KISSINGER
description: President Reagan is giving ''serious consideration'' to naming former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger chairman of a bipartisan commission aimed at seeking support for the Administration's policies in Central America, a senior Administration official said today.

title: SANITATION DEPTS. TAKES JOB DRIVE TO CITY'S STREETS
description: The voice over the loudspeaker broke the still of a hot afternoon: ''We have applications for jobs for the New York City Department of Sanitation. The starting salary is $20,000.''

title: INCOME GAP BETWEEN RACES WIDE AS IN 1960, STUDY FINDS
description: The gap between the average incomes of whites and blacks is as wide today as it was in 1960, primarily because the proportion of black families headed by women rose from one-fifth to nearly one-half and the proportion of black men with jobs dropped sharply in that period.

title: The U.N. Today; July 18, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Jordan Open to Talks, 2 Americans Tell Begin
description: Two Americans brought Prime Minister Menachem Begin a message from King Hussein of Jordan last week expressing the King's willingness to enter peace negotiations, the Israeli state radio reported today.

title: Somalia Says Its Forces Drove Off Ethiopians
description: Somalia said today that its forces had repulsed invading Ethiopian troops and that the situation along the border was back to normal.

title: Chicago Ballet Obtains Washington's Director
description: The Washington Ballet is losing its director to the Chicago City Ballet because he believed it would be too provincial not to move to a company ''ripe with potential.''

title: 2 Nations Cut Oil Subsidies
description: Mexico and Venezuela said today that they would reduce sharply the oil-import subsidies that they provide to 10 nations.

title: Marks Leaving Playboy
description: Henry W. Marks said Friday that there might be something to the seven-year-itch theory when he announced that he would be moving from Playboy, where for that length of time he has been director of advertising, to join the executive staff of Rolling Stone Magazine as associate publisher-advertising. The 53-year-old salesman had previously been top ad man at both Dow Jones and Psychology Today.

title: FOR FREE AGENTS, A SUMMER TO SURVIVE
description: Today, in the middle of summer, the Jets and Giants begin two-aday workouts in training camps. That signals the start of a struggle against almost hopeless odds for the players on the bottom rung of the pro football ladder - the free agents, especially the rookie free agents.

title: 3 Police Officers Shot In Londonderry Ambush
description: Masked gunmen shot three police officers late tonight in a carefully planned ambush in Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second largest city.

title: ROCK ON PIER: THE RAMONES
description: THE RAMONES played ''A Tribute to the Unemployed'' at Pier 84 on Saturday, which meant they had lowered the ticket price for their concert from $10 to $6. It apparently had nothing to do with the fact that the Miller Brewing Company, which sponsors the pier series, was dealing with 1,400 workers who went on strike in Milwaukee to reject a contract that would eliminate 500 jobs.

title: ANSWERING THE CHALLENGE
description: IN boxing, there's an ancient axiom - if you want to see a champion at his best, watch him when he's getting beaten, when he's in jeopardy of being dethroned, as Muhammad Ali was in Manila before he stopped Joe Frazier, as Sugar Ray Leonard was in Las Vegas before he knocked out Thomas Hearns. But that axiom applies to a champion in any sport, as Tom Watson now has shown by winning the British Open for the fifth time.

title: Sega Shifts to Dailey From Della Femina
description: Dailey & Associates of Los Angeles, which will officially become a subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies in about a week, last week got a promising piece of business from the entertainment industry - Sega Enterprises, a video games creator that is part of the Paramount Pictures division of Gulf & Western.

title: Play Fellow First
description: Play Fellow, the 3-to-10 favorite, pulled away from Le Cou Cou in the final furlong and won by 3 1/4 lengths today in the 73d running of the $108,500 American Derby at Arlington Park. Le Cou Cou was second, a nose ahead of Brother.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mission on West 4th St.

title: A New President For Midland-Ross
description: Probably no industry group was hit harder by the recession than capital goods, the heavy machinery used in manufacturing. Suppliers of capital goods were also hurt. Anyone doubting this might talk with Daniel W. Duval.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading No Quotes From Amy

title: Bench's Homer Lifts Reds, 5-2
description: Johnny Bench, who was honored in pregame ceremonies, hit a pinch-hit, three-run homer in his final appearance in Philadelphia, leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-2 victory over the Phillies today.

title: Delta Jet in Florida Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: A Delta Air Lines jet carrying 107 people from Miami to Tampa and Indianapolis was diverted to Cuba this morning by one hijacker who held a knift to a flight attendant's throat and another who threatened to ignite an aerosol spray, officials said.

title: Rochester Savings
description: The Rochester Community Savings Bank, the result of the merger of the Community Savings Bank and the Rochester Savings Bank, has decided that its ad agency will be Perri Debes Looney & Crane, formerly Community's promoters. The new agency says that its client is the nation's 10th-largest thrift institution and that it will be spending $2 million for advertising. Rochester Savings' agency was Stockdale Communications.

title: Clerc, Out of Slump, In Final With Arias
description: Jose-Luis Clerc, who had been in a long slump, moved to the final of the $215,000 United States Pro tennis championship today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Eliot Teltscher.

title: Deputy Minister Easily Wins Tom Fool
description: ''You wouldn't believe what this horse's foot looked like in February,'' the trainer Reynaldo Nobles was saying in the winner's circle at Belmont Park yesterday. ''He only had half a foot. He'd gotten it all infected with a piece of gravel, and we had to cut half his foot out. But it grew back, and he's all recovered from all his physical problems right now. He's the best he's ever been.''

title: PAUL F. JACOB
description: Paul F. Jacob, a restaurateur who had operated the Monk's Inn at 35 West 64th Street and other restaurants in Manhattan, Miami and Philadelphia, died of cancer Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Mr. Jacob, a resident of Manhattan, was 49 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with a review of the Riverside Shakespeare Company's ''Merry Wives of Windsor'' misidentified the actress. She is Sonja Lanzener.

title: STABILITY EXPECTED FOR OPEC
description: As oil ministers arrived here today for a semiannual meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, there appeared to be little chance that disputes within the group would erode its basic production and pricing policies.

title: Jerseyan Scores
description: Frank Iaconio of Totowa won his second national event of the season today at the Hot Rod Association Summer Nationals at Raceway Park, driving a 1983 Chevrolet Camaro to victory in Pro Stock. Joe Amato of Old Forge, Pa., captured his second straight Top Fuel dragster title.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.54 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.63 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: RIFLE WITHOUT A CARTRIDGE CASE
description: A West German arms manufacturer is developing a rifle that fires a cartridge without a case. Weapon experts say the design could revolutionize the manufacture of small firearms.

title: COMMODITIES
description: CAN gold be bought below current market prices or be sold for more than today's cash quotes? Yes, by properly selling put and call options on the underlying futures.

title: A DAY ON THE ROAD WITH I.D.S.
description: ''Walter, will you come down already,'' Anna Heinemann said. ''Mr. Cook is here.''

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 18, 1983
description: International The removal of foreign military bases and advisers from Central America was called for by the Presidents of four Latin American countries, who, at a meeting in Mexico, expressed ''profound concern for the rapid deterioration'' of the situation in Central America. They also called for a freeze on arms shipments and the establishment of international border patrols as key steps towards peace in the region. The Presidents of Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama attended the meeting in Cancun. (Page A1, Column 6.) Henry A. Kissinger might head a proposed bipartisan commission aimed at seeking broad political support for the Administration's policies in Central America. A senior Administration official said President Reagan is giving ''serious consideration'' to appointing the former Secretary of State as the commission's chairman. He said Mr. Reagan planned to call for the creation of the commission in a speech today at a meeting of the International Longshoremen's Association in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (A1:5.)

title: ELIZABETH MAYOR ORDERS CITY HALL EMPLOYEES TO SPEAK ENGLISH
description: Mayor Thomas G. Dunn of Elizabeth, N.J., had noticed - and others, he said, had complained to him - that ''some of the girls in the office were jabbering away in a foreign language while the other girls didn't understand what was being said.''

title: PANTHERS CAPTURE U.S.F.L. CROWN
description: The Michigan Panthers won the first championship game of the United States Football League before an audience of 50,906 in Mile High Stadium tonight, and the game had enough excitement to inspire some in the crowd to invade the playing field before the contest could conclude. The end was disorderly and bizarre.

title: 1984 CAMPAIGN CASH COUNTED
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn lead all candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination in campaign contributions received from individuals so far, according to forms filed Friday at the Federal Election Commission.

title: CRACKS IN WORLD COFFEE PACT
description: A six-year extension of the International Coffee Agreement, one of the most successful commodity agreements in the world, is awaiting ratification by the Senate. But while approval is expected, questions are now being raised about whether the pact can continue to function effectively.

title: Scout Cookie Profits Purloined by Parents
description: Add the Girl Scouts to the list of victims of the hard economic times in the depressed Beaver Valley. A Federal Magistrate has scheduled a hearing July 21 at the request of the Beaver-Castle Girl Scout Council, which charges the parents of 14 of its members have failed to turn over a total of $1,100 for cookies.

title: COSMOS GAIN FIRST PLACE, 3-0
description: The Cosmos defeated the Tulsa Roughnecks, 3-0, tonight for the 200th victory in the 13-year history of the franchise and their third consecutive shutout at Giants Stadium.

title: Deborah Stuart Price Weds John Wright 3d
description: Deborah Stuart Price, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Price Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to John Harrison Wright 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wright Jr. of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Neil Paylor, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Price home.

title: MONDAY, JULY 18, 1983; Companies
description: Quaker Oats offered $77 a share for all of Stokely-Van Camp shares. The $208 million offer has been approved by directors of both food companies. Pillsbury had offered $62 for most of Stokely's shares, but Stokely rejected the offer. (Page D1.)

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Placed Willie Ran- d olph, second baseman, on 15-day dis- a bled list and bought contract of Larry M ilbourne, infielder, from Philadelphia. ATLANTA (NL) - Optioned Bob Walk, p itcher, to Richmond of the International L eague and purchased the contract of T ony Brizzolara, pitcher.

title: Mark Oliva Is Married To Victoria McKittrick
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J., yesterday, Victoria McKittrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling McKittrick Jr. of Morristown, was married to Mark Oliva, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oliva Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. Mark Beckwith performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet's Ex-Envoy to Poland Gets a Foreign Ministry Post
description: The Soviet Union has appointed its former Amnbassador to Poland, Boris I. Aristov, to a post as one of nine Deputy Foreign Ministers, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: Head of Key Banks Inc.  Plans More Acquisitions
description: Consumer banking may be regarded by some people as a costly, burdensome line of business, but Key Banks Inc., a financial institution in upstate New York, is showing that consumer banking can be profitable. While other institutions are leaving the field, the president of Key Banks, Victor J. Riley Jr., says his organization plans to invest further in consumer banking.

title: MOTHER'S PERSISTENCE PAYS OFF
description: Guadalupe Quintanilla never doubted gradeschool teachers who labeled her a ''slow learner,'' because she could not speak English. But she refused to believe her three children were.

title: ABC TO TRANSMIT FILMS FOR SUBSCRIBER CASSETTE
description: Insomniacs who tune to Channel 7 in the early morning hours tomorrow and Thursday will see a blurred picture on their television screens and hear a garbled sound track.

title: French Tour Rider Winner on a Foul
description: ETIENNE, France, July 17 (UPI) - Michel Laurent of France won the 16th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race on the judges' decision today, after covering the 86.7 miles from Issoire in 3 hours 49 minutes 38 seconds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the Still of the Morning

title: Medicine & Computer
description: MRA Publications, which already has Family Practice Recertification, will add to its list in October when it brings out the first issue of Medicine & Computer. It will be sent free to 120,000 office and hospital-based general practioners, family physicians, internists, osteopaths and cardiologists. A black-andwhite page will sell for $4,260 and four-color will add a $990 premium.

title: EX-AIDE'S SOURCES TO BE QUERIED ON DEBATE PAPERS
description: A House subcommittee is to seek further information tomorrow from Wayne H. Valis, a former aide to Ronald Reagan who has named two men as the sources of a memorandum he received in 1980 dealing with plans of the Carter campaign staff for the debate between Mr. Reagan and President Carter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review of the movie ''Zelig'' in Weekend on Friday misidentified the production designer. He is Mel Bourne. Santo Loquasto designed the costumes.

title: ARMIES OF IRAQ AND IRAN FACING LONG STALEMATE
description: The Iraqi Government faces the prospect of its costly war with Iran dragging on, with neither side capable of a victorious offensive to end it, according to foreign military attaches here.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What happens, in a face-off situation, if all five skaters on a National Hockey League team are ordered replaced, one after the other, because of improper position?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday on Navy overpayments misstated the price charged by McDonnell Douglas for parts that should have cost $683,000. It was $3.2 million.

title: U.S. EFFORT TO DEPORT AFRICAN POET RESUMES TODAY IN CHICAGO
description: On Monday the Federal authorities will resume their efforts to deport Dennis Brutus, a black poet and a critic of South Africa's apartheid policy who has been in self-imposed exile from southern Africa for 10 years.

title: RATE RISE SEEN A THREAT TO RECOVERY
description: The Federal Reserve Board has pushed up interest rates by a percentage point since mid-May, but so far the increase has done little to dampen consumers' spending habits or the progress of the economic recovery.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Ron Guidry (10-5) will start. In his last outing against the Twins last Wednesday in Minneapolis, he gave up 13 hits and lost, 6-1.

title: Memphis Awarded U.S.F.L. Franchise
description: Memphis has been awarded the 18th franchise in the United States Football League, contingent on the team's ability to get a lease to play in the Liberty Bowl stadium, the league announced today.

title: News Analysis
description: In opening the 74th annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here, the vice chairman said the organization could not afford to ''hang onto the so-called status quo'' and would move into a new era.

title: COME BACK, TOM PAINE
description: Congress is arguing, without a hint of intentional satire, whether or not to give money for ''covert'' aid to guerrillas in Nicaragua.

title: M.T.A. WILL FIX ROAD WITH STEEL MADE OVERSEAS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will rebuild the roadway of the Throgs Neck Bridge with 15,000 tons of steel from Japan and South Korea. The decision came after Governor Cuomo signed a bill requiring the authority to give preference to steel manufactured in the United States.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At night, when it's not so crowded, there are seats available for those who want the coolness.

title: Paul Is Winner
description: John Paul Jr., in a Cosworth-powered Penske, charged past Rick Mears two turns from the end of the Michigan 500 race and scored his first Indianapolis-car victory today. Mears lost control, slammed into the wall and was hit by Chris Kniefel's car in the fourth turn.

title: BRIEFING
description: French Assembly Tour

title: STOKELY APPROVES QUAKER BID
description: Directors of the Quaker Oats Company and Stokely-Van Camp Inc., two of America's household names in food products, have agreed to merge, it was announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: San Francisco Overcomes Atlanta in Grand National
description: In a desperately close finish early today, San Francisco defeated Atlanta by 2 international match points to take the Grand National Team title here.

title: FADS: CHARMING FOOTWEAR
description: What are smaller than hula hoops, heavier than Strawberry doll stickers and as popular among pre-teens these days as slit-eyed sunglasses and Michael Jackson, not to mention Menudo?

title: 15 IN SOVIET PENTECOSTAL FAMILY TO LEAVE FOR THE WEST TODAY
description: The last two of the Siberian Pentecostals who spent five years cloistered in the United States Embassy and 13 of their family members are expected to leave for the West tomorrow, American diplomats said today.

title: COURAGEOUS WINS CLOSE RACE
description: In one of the finest and closest races, Courageous defeated Liberty by 8 seconds over a 19-mile course today in the trials to select the America's Cup yacht defender.

title: REFUGEES ACCUSE SANDINISTAS OF HARASSMENT
description: Intimidation and harassment by Nicaraguan armed forces of the Indian and Creole population along the country's Caribbean coast has increased dramatically over the last five or six months, according to refugees who have fled to Costa Rica.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CARTOONS

title: Traditional Music
description: Musicians and scholars from around the world will gather at Columbia University Aug. 8-15 for the 27th conference of the International Council for Traditional Music.

title: Seattle Slew Pair Bring $1.3 Million
description: Two yearlings by Seattle Slew, the 1977 Triple Crown winner, brought the top prices at the Kennington Select Summer Yearling Sale today.

title: Blue Bell Planning $2 Off Wrangler Jeans
description: Blue Bell, maker of Wrangler jeans, would very much like to sell more. It is so dedicated to this cause, in fact, that it is prepared to give $2 off the purchase price to any purchaser with an official cents-off coupon at any rate.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Universal Language

title: Stirrings Toward Arms Control
description: New proposals by each side have finally brought the Soviet Union and United States within negotiating range on strategic weapons. Two types of agreement now look feasible.

title: Kimberly Ann Campbell Marries David K. Serisky
description: Kimberly Ann Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse W. Campbell of Midland, Tex., was married yesterday to David Karl Serisky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Serisky of Malverne, L.I. Benton County Clerk Daniel G. Berk performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Corvallis, Ore.

title: SARANAC LAKE IN BOOM, BUT SKEPTICAL
description: The road leading west from Interstate 87 is unusually busy this summer, often jammed with cars riding low under the weight of canoes strapped to the roof and with mounds of tents, tackle boxes and portable stoves.

title: Brown-Lenox Tie
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation said 8.7 million shares of Lenox Inc., or 95.3 percent of those outstanding, had been tendered as of 4 P.M. Thursday and that the tender offer had been extended to 5 P.M. next Thursday.

title: OUTDOORS: EDUCATION OF A SAILOR
description: Cast off and head for the starting line. Or set a course for Block Island or the Virgin Islands. One of the most significant developments in sailing is the number of people entering the sport. Sailing certainly touches the elemental chords, man's basic relationship to the natural forces. It is fun - and work. While one can spend a lifetime studying seamanship and the ways of the sea, it is now possible, through the emergence of advanced courses given by sailing schools, to learn enough in a week to be able to charter a yacht or to start winning races.

title: COAST BUDGET BATTLE ROOTED IN FIGHT TO SURVIVE
description: An elderly man approached the marble-walled outer office of Gov. George Deukmejian last week, passed a sign posted by the Governor that read ''Budget Held Hostage 29 Days,'' pounded on the door and shouted: ''I want my check! I'm fighting for survival!''

title: U.S.F.L. HAS A PRE-GAME SURPRISE PARTY
description: An unanticipated crowd of hundreds of eager fans forced United States Football League promoters to open the gates for a ''tailgate party'' 45 minutes before the scheduled beginning of their first championship game today.

title: FRINGE BENEFITS OF FOREIGN-LANGUAGE STUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: RENTAL ARITHMETIC
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAD SAYS PRISONER IS PROOF OF LIBYA LINK TO REBELS
description: The Chadian Government publicly displayed a prisoner identified as a Libyan soldier today and said his capture was ''physical proof'' of Libya's role in the conflict between proand anti-Government forces.

title: BELL SYSTEM TALKS WITH 3 UNIONS EXPECTED TO ACCELERATE THIS WEEK
description: The three unions negotiating contracts with the Bell System expect the talks to accelerate this week, and two of the three said they believed that there would be enough time to fashion an agreement and avoid a walkout when the old contracts expire Aug. 6.

title: NON-TREASURY OFFERING PACE IS SLOW
