description: While many corporations and local governments are finding interest rates uncomfortably high and thus are not selling new debt issues, large Federal deficits mean that the United States Treasury has no choice but to continue borrowing, no matter how high rates are.

title: TALKS
description: Both sides in the New York City Opera labor dispute are preparing today for tomorrow's negotiating session, the first in the dispute since last Wednesday. But both continued to express pessimism about a quick end to the orchestra's strike, which has silenced all City Opera performances since July 7.

title: Washington Watch; S.E.C.'s View Of New Stocks
description: WASHINGTON THROUGH much of the last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been focusing its energies on companies that manipulate their financial reports. Such doctoring of financial data proliferates during recessions when companies, accustomed to courting investors with long strings of earnings gains, become tempted to camouflage sharp declines.

title: BARBER 5-SHOT SENIOR VICTOR
description: Miller Barber, who will attempt to defend his United States Senior Open championship later this week, gave fair warning today that he was ready for all comers 50 years and over. The 52-year-old professional won the $25,000 first prize today in the Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative senior tournament by five shots.

title: CHINAGLIA MOVING ON BEFORE A PASSION FADES
description: ALL the vital signs remain strong. When a soccer ball bounces his way, his eyes brighten and Giorgio Chinaglia is a still photograph come to life, full of spirit and boundless energy. When he whips his leg forward and drives the ball past a sprawling goalkeeper, Chinaglia is soccer's Roman candle, thrusting his arms to the heavens and dashing here, there and everywhere on the playing field in celebration of his grand achievement.

title: PHYSICAL AND MENTAL DISABILITIES IN NEWBORNS DOUBLED IN 25 YEARS
description: Physicians and statisticians who analyze patterns of births in the United States have concluded that the number of babies born with some physical or mental defect has doubled over the last 25 years.

title: ...STATESMANLIKE PRELUDE TO A 'NECESSARY HOUSECLEANING'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hampshire Party Picnic Casts a Big Vote for Askew
description: Reubin Askew overwhelmingly won a Presidential straw poll at a local Democratic Committee picnic today, a victory that indicates, the city's party chairman said, that the former Florida Governor is more organized than his fellow candidates.

title: OF HERPES, AIDS AND FEAR OF SEX
description: HAVE fears about herpes and Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome g iven sex a bad name? ''There's no question that AIDS has frightened p eople in the gay community and that many are cutting down on the n umber of partners and the number of sexual contacts,'' said Yehudi M . Felman, director of the Bureau of Venereal Disease Control of the N ew York City Health Department. ''But we don't see the same changes i n the straight community.''

title: Market Place; 1,180, Ford And Alleghany
description: JUST about a year ago, when long-term Government bonds were yielding 14 percent and the equity market was in shock, the Federal Reserve System actively began to push interest rates lower. By mid-August, when the stock market finally received the message, a roaring bull market was under way.

title: BROTHERS FIND IT'S BETTER TO GIVE THAN TO RECEIVE
description: John Matar said he thought it ''stunk'' last year when his brother gave him 45 goats for his birthday. This year he got 100 skunks.

title: DISABLED IN PROFESSIONS GROW
description: People with serious physical handicaps are beginning to enter the professions - science, medicine and law among them - in greater numbers, according to experts in the field.

title: HEAD OF STATE LIQUOR AGENCY GETS EMERGENCY POWERS FOR SIX MONTHS
description: The new chairman of the State Liquor Authority has been voted emergency powers for six months that permit him to make all appointments and to administer the agency.

title: METS STOP RYAN AND ASTRO STREAKS, 3-1
description: The Mets reached up from the gloom of the worst record in baseball tonight and scored an improbable coup: a 3-1 victory over the Houston Astros that broke the eight-game winning streak of Nolan Ryan, the strikeout leader of the big leagues.

title: REFORMING APARTHEID DOESN'T END SLAVERY
description: It is hard to know what to make of Under Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger's statement last month that South Africa's political system is ''morally wrong.'' At the same time, the Reagan Administration continues to propagate a deliberate falsehood by saying that change is taking place in South Africa - that the apartheid system is crumbling. Washington even has the gall to present a worsening situation as one that is improving. We in the African National Congress are therefore left with no alternative but to conclude that the Administration supports apartheid.

title: STUDENTS STRAIGHTEN OUT CITY'S ART FILES
description: The attic of City Hall is like the attic of childhood memory: cramped, musty, cob-webbed and mysterious, full of wonderful things you can never find when you're looking for them.

title: YANKEES WIN, 8-6, FOR THIRD STRAIGHT
description: Obscurity is easily found in the big leagues. Flop once or twice out of the bullpen or fail too many times out of the dugout, and a player can quickly go the way of the Hula Hoop.

title: CONCERT: NATIONAL CHORALE SINGS A BERNSTEIN PROGRAM
description: NEXT month, Leonard Bernstein will mark his 65th birthday. It is tempting to regard the National Chorale's sampler of Bernstein's music at the Damrosch Park bandshell Saturday night as an early celebration.

title: RELIEF FROM 93 DEGREE DAY IS SOUGHT AT BEACHES AND EVEN ON F TRAIN
description: Yesterday was clear, dry and hot in the New York metropolitan area. Hot enough to make a day at the beach ideal for many. Hot enough to make some people seek solace in the subways. Hot enough to make it the sixth day in a row when the temperature reached into the 90's.

title: Field to Shut TV Station
description: WKBS-TV, one of Philadelphia's three UHF stations, will be going off the air by Sept.1, a spokesman for the station's owner said Friday. Virginia Butts of Field Enterprises Inc. said the programming rights and some equipment of WKBS, Channel 48, would be sold to WPHL, Channel 17, for an undisclosed price. She said the company had decided that selling the programming rights was more profitable than selling the station itself.

title: CHEMICAL DOUBLES RUBBER CONTENT OF A SHRUB
description: Scientists have doubled the production of rubber from a desert plant by spraying it with a chemical stimulant, a development that could lead to less reliance on imported rubber, the National Science Foundation reported today.

title: THE LOW-PAID AFFLUENT IN PUBLIC-INTEREST WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: CATHOLIC PAPER, CHILD OF FRENCH HISTORY, IS REBORN
description: ''In our view, the daily press is the plague of our era,'' said the editorial in the very first issue. ''The best of the newspapers are worth nothing.''

title: Howe Gets Reinstated
description: Steve Howe, the relief pitcher who was suspended by the Los Angeles Dodgers Saturday night, was back in uniform today after having given the team results of a drug test. Vicky Watanabe, a team spokesman, said the tests on Howe, who has been treated twice for cocaine dependency, ''did not show the presence of any prohibited substances.''

title: Exhibition at Princeton
description: Art work and manuscripts by Leonardo da Vinci will be on display starting Sept. 18 at the Art Museum of Princeton University. The exhibition, ''Leonardo's Return to Vinci,'' will include four tempera studies from the 1480's, the oil painting ''Salvator Mundi'' and treatises on painting and the human figure written by the Renaissance artist.

title: New Outlook
description: Eddie Aliano, the cut man, and John Baskerville, the corner man, represent the only remnants of Mike Rossman's glory days. In 1978, at the age of 22, Rossman beat Victor Galindez to win the World Boxing Council world light-heavyweight title. Five years later, he no longer has the Star of David insignia on his satin boxing trunks, the symbol he displayed to promote his half-Jewish parentage, nor does he earn purses that once reached as high as $225,000.

title: A DIVORCE BILL THAT INVOLVES THE STATE IN RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. CRITICIZED ON ARSENIC MOVE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's decision to ask residents of Tacoma, Wash., how much risk of cancer they are willing to accept to keep jobs in their community is drawing criticism from air pollution specialists outside the agency.

title: HOW WOODY ALLEN'S 'ZELIG' WAS BORN IN ANXIETY AND GREW INTO COMEDY
description: WOODY ALLEN'S characters have always had more than their share of worries and insecurities: they worry about their lovers, their apartments and the health of their own fragile psyches - not to mention all the big questions about God and love and death. In ''Zelig'' - Mr. Allen's new film, which opened to critical acclaim Friday - the hero is so insecure, so anxious to be liked, that he literally assumes the personality and physical mien of anyone around him.

title: Matthias Lukens, 70; Ex-Port Authority Aide
description: Matthias E. Lukens, an executive with the Port Authority for more than a quarter-century and the agency's acting head from 1971 to 1973, died Friday. He was 70 years old and lived in Stowe, Vt.

title: A Matter of Inches
description: Dust puffed up under rhythmic hooves. The sun was high, and there was a sheen of perspiration on horse and rider. The tall bay, neck and tail arched, slowed down until he was trotting in place.

title: FOR A JEWISH STATE, ANNEX AND EXPEL
description: Will Israel opt for Jewishness and survival or democracy and national suicide? Few Israelis or Americans recognize the potential contradiction between a Jewish state and a Western-style democratic one. The contradiction is much too painful to contemplate, and so, dangerously, it is shunted aside. For me, there is no dilemma at all, and I choose a Jewish state.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After special charges of $63.9 million.

title: ELLIS BANKING CORP (BRADENTON, FLA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in January.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Incentive to Diet
description: Leonard Marshall, the rookie defensive end and the Giants' No.2 draft choice, is losing weight quickly.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income of $190,000 for the quarter and $242,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $203,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $400,000 on the sale of the asets of Key Electrosonic Corp.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE SWIM

title: Norton Simon Deadlines
description: The deadline passed yesterday for shareholders to withdraw shares tendered for Esmark Inc.'s $35.50 a share offer for Norton Simon, and a similar deadline expires tonight for Anderson, Clayton & Company's $35 offer. But few shareholders appeared to pay much attention.

title: HORSE CARRIES ZEBRA EMBRYO
description: If an experiment at the Louisville Zoo is successful, in nine months an American quarter horse will drop a foal that will make zoological history. It is carrying the fetus of a zebra.

title: AIM TELEPHONE reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $139,000 for the quarter and $281,000 for the 6 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Political Necessity

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including gains of $9.6 million, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $27.4 million, or 35 cents a share, for the year on the sale of securities after adjusting for a loss on redemption of debt.

title: GROSS TELECASTING INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
New Plapler Account
description: Plapler & Associates has been named agency for Page America, a telephone paging service that recently went public and has big expansion plans. According to Larry Plapler, his new client expects to spend $1 million for advertising between now and the end of the year. There was no previous agency, he said.

title: Cause of Pier Fire In Jersey Sought
description: Firefighters today were investigating the cause of a weekend fire that reduced three piers here to rubble. They said the blaze might have been caused by a careless picnicker.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Dismissed M anager Pat Corrales and replaced him w ith General Manager Paul Owens for re- m ainder of season. Tony Siegle, an execu- t ive assistant, will take over duties of gen- e ral manager. FOOTBALL JETS (AFC) - Signed Russ Carpenti- e ri, free-agent kicker from Syracuse Uni- v ersity. Cut four rookie free agents who f ailed to pass physical examinations: J ames Matthews, running back, Julius W allace, defensive tackle, Gary Birkholz, c enter, and Dan McShane, tackle. BUFFALO (AFC) - Cut six players w ho were unable to pass physical exami- n ations: DeWayne Chivers, tight end and s ixth-round draft choice from South Caro- l ina, and five free agents, Marion Body, d efensive back; Zack Grate, linebacker; A nero Ware, fullback, Paul Watson, place- k icker, and Mark Ehde, offensive tackle. P laced Rex Robinson, kicker, and Julius D awkins, wide receiver, on unable-to-per- f orm list. DENVER (AFC) - Cut Mark Richt, q uarterback; Pete Caruso, tight end; M ike Hembrough, Scott Pettis and Terry M orehead, running backs; Tony Dalton, S cott Homan, and David Joeckel, offen- s ive linemen; and Bob Lashley and Ty- r one Smith, safeties. HOUSTON (AFC) - Released 10 free a gents: Joel Baxter, kicker; Osby Mitch- e ll, offensive tackle; Rob Winship, defen- s ive end; Darren Blair, cornerback; Joe K ader, linebacker; Darnell Toy, running b ack, and four safeties, Donald Cook, Mat- t hew McKnight, Andrew Molls and George W illiams.

title: Heileman's Net Up 32%
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said today that second-quarter earnings rose 32 percent, to $19.6 million.

title: First Boston Soars 35%
description: First Boston Inc., holding company for the First Boston Corporation, the big Wall Street investment banking house, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter soared 35 percent, to $17.1 million, or $1.46 a share, from $12.7 million, or $1.11 a share, a year earlier.

title: New Tennis Inquiry
description: John Harris, the tournament chairman of the D.C. National Bank Tennis Classic, has accused top players of boycotting his event in favor of those guaranteeing money ''above any prize money they might win.'' The Washington tournament, which began yesterday, carries a first prize of $34,000, and has attracted only one player ranked in the top 10, Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina. Harris said: ''How else can you explain tournaments in Kitzbuhel and Hilversum offering $100,000 and $75,000 and attracting some of the players they have at the same time we are offering $200,000 in prize money?'' Tony Eugenio, the assistant administrator of the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, said in New York that ''We are starting an investigation of those two tournaments,'' referring to Kitzbuhel in Austria and Hilversum in the Netherlands.

title: BONN AIDE SEEMS TO ENDORSE '82 MISSILE COMPROMISE PLAN
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany urged the United States and the Soviet Union today to reconsider a compromise plan for reducing medium-range nuclear missiles. The compromise was unofficially discussed in 1982 and then abandoned.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. Quarterly results are for 13 weeks in the latest period and 12 weeks in the year-ago period.

title: Corrales Is Dismissed by Phils
description: The Phillies dismissed Manager Pat Corrales today and replaced him with Paul Owens, the general manger. Owens took over despite the club's being tied for first place with the St. Louis Cardinals in the National League East. In 1972, Owens served as interim manager for two and one-half months when Frank Lucchesi was dismissed and guided the team to a 33-47 record.

title: Polish Debt Plan Offered
description: Poland will get 10 years to repay the $1.5 billion in principal that it owes banks this year, according to a rescheduling plan offered by bankers, but it will have to pay slightly higher interest rates, banking sources said today.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS NOW OFFER SOME PRAISE
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has nearly completed the selection of his own team of top managers, and even the most militant environmentalists are praising him for picking what they see as a group of competent, experienced and professional people.

title: U.S. HUNGER ON RISE DESPITE SWELLING OF FOOD SURPLUSES
description: Hunger is emerging again as a national issue even as Government stocks of surplus dairy products rise to record levels.

title: VW and Chrysler
description: Press reports that Volkswagen of America is considering a joint venture with Chrysler to produce a small car for the United States market are speculative and premature, a VW spokesman said. The spokesman, speaking from Wolfsburg, said that the managing board chairman of VW, Carl Hahn, had met informally with the chairman of Chrysler, Lee A. Iacocca, but that no decision on a joint venture had been taken and no concrete timetable had been discussed.

title: Pay-TV Networks Alter Merger Plan
description: The second- and third-largest pay television networks yesterday proposed a new merger plan in an attempt to overcome Department of Justice antitrust objections to an earlier proposal, a department spokesman said.

title: Guinness Plans Cutback
description: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C. said today that it would eliminate 550 of 1,500 jobs at its Park Royal brewery in West London over the next three years, with most of the job losses coming in the first year.

title: GERMAN IS HAILED IN MATH ADVANCE
description: A German has solved a problem that has baffled mathematicians for more than 60 years and has taken a major step toward solving another that has stumped the profession for three centuries. The German mathematician is Dr. Gerd Faltings, 29 years old, of Wuppertal University, in Wuppertal, West Germany. The problems he has solved lie in the esoteric realms of number theory and algebraic geometry; they relate to the number of solutions that exist for certain kinds of mathematical equations.

title: GAME FOCUSES ON COMPUTER BASICS
description: A new program from The Learning Company - Rocky's Boots, written by Warren Robinett and Leslie Grimm -promises to become another software classic in the personal computing field, joining such stalwarts as Microsoft's Flight Simulator and Software Arts's Visicalc. Using the computer's unique pedagogical potential, Rocky's Boots is devoted to that most appropriate of tasks, teaching the basics of computers themselves.

title: Dorsett Speaks Out
description: ''I'm not guilty of anything.'' Tony Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys' running back, said at the team's training camp in Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: EIGHT-YEAR STUDY OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS FINDS CHRONIC PROBLEMS IN SYSTEM
description: The American educational system has ''deeply entrenched and virtually chronic'' problems and should undergo ''far-reaching restructuring,'' according to a comprehensive study that involved eight years and more than 27,000 interviews.

title: Leader, Injured, Out of Bike Tour
description: Pascal Simon of France, who had held the overall lead in the Tour de France bicycle race since last Monday, dropped out today because of a fractured shoulder blade.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results reflect extraordinary charges.

title: PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF TOLL ROADS SOLVES NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. to Purchase Comsat Section
description: The General Electric Company said it had reached an agreement with the Communications Satellite Corporation to purchase the digital electronics portion of Comsat's computer-aided engineering software subsidiary, called CGIS.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
IN 3 YEARS, MOST EFFECTS OF LARGEST TANKER SPILL WERE GONE
description: ON March 18, 1978, the supertanker Amoco Cadiz ran on rocks a few miles off the Brittany coast of France. Over the next two weeks of stormy weather its entire cargo of 223,000 metric tons - most of it crude oil -was discharged into the sea. It was the largest tanker oil spill to date, almost twice the volume of the largest previous spill, that of the Torrey Canyon off Cornwall in 1967.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect an 8-for-5 stock split paid June 20.

title: San Diego Utility's $65 Million Issue
description: A $65 million issue of San Diego Electric and Gas Company's 12 7/8 percent bonds due in 2013 will be offered for sale today at a price of 99.06 to yield 13 percent to maturity through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The size of the issue was reduced from $75 million.

title: PHILIP GLASS SETTLES SUIT ON MUSIC IN 'BREATHLESS'
description: The composer Philip Glass has been awarded a ''substantial'' settlement from Orion Pictures, according to both parties, for what Mr. Glass maintained was the unauthorized use of his music in the recent motion picture ''Breathless.''

title: CHITTENDEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After tax credits of $546,000 for the quarter and $728,000 for the 6 months.

title: Top Trotter Has Intestinal Surgery
description: Dancer's Crown, a leading 3-year-old trotter considered to be a top contender for the Hambletonian at the Meadowlands next month, underwent emergency surgery for a twisted intestine today at the Veterinary Hospital of Cornell University. His condition was later listed as guarded.

title: Watson Now Aims at P.G.A.
description: Most of the time when Tom Watson is asked when he will win the Professional Golfers' Association championship, he jokes and says, ''Arnie Palmer, here I come.''

title: COMPUTER TRANSCEIVER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
MERCHANTS BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
OFFICER PENALIZED FOR ARMS SPENDING
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a naval officer had been relieved of his command and civilian officials reprimanded for permitting military contractors to charge excessive prices for spare parts.

title: FOR COVERT ACTION...
description: The House of Representatives will soon be considering a bill amending the Intelligence Authorization Act for fiscal year 1983 that would cut off funds for any covert or overt United States support for the contras, or couterrevolutionaries, fighting against the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua. This vote will be one of the most important in this Congress, and if it goes the wrong way it could legitimize the ''Brezhnev Doctrine'' here in our hemisphere.

title: INDUSTRIAL VALLEY BANK & TRUST CO (PHILADELPHIA, P reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including gains from the recapture of tax credits of $508,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains from the recapture of tax credits of $386,000 for the quarter and $599,000 for the 6 months.

title: New York City Issue Oversubscribed in Part
description: A $150 million issue of New York City bonds was well received after underwriters at the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group tentatively priced them with yields ranging from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9 3/4 percent in 1993, and 10 3/8 percent in 2004-13.

title: CHRYSLER SEES NET UP TO $300 MILLION
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it expected a second-quarter net income of $275 million to $300 million - its largest quarterly profit ever.

title: Bridge: Respite Follows the Drama On and off Nationals Stage
description: Play in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here was low-key Sunday following 24 hours of drama at the table and away from it.

title: THE BOOM IN TAX SHELTERS
description: Tax shelters -investment devices designed to shelter income from taxation, usually for a period of years - appear to be on the rise, despite widespread predictions that lower tax rates would reduce their use.

title: CHASING A DREAM: A GOLF ODYSSEY
description: Having already played 18 holes of golf on another continent in the middle of the night, Bobby Clampett and three amateur golfers chased the sun into New York early yesterday morning for another round of golf. A few hours later, a bit haggard but still cheerful, they were off to California, where they played another game of golf and then watched the sun set over the Pacific.

title: Books Of The Times
description: IN SEARCH OF LOVE AND BEAUTY. By Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 251 pages. Wil- liam Morrow & Company. $12.95.

title: FEW LOANS FOR NATIONS IN 3D WORLD
description: Private banks virtually suspended new lending to developing countries and to smaller industrial nations during the first quarter, a major international financial instituion reported today. If such cutbacks continued, they could abort the emerging economic recovery, it added.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest quarter include a gain of $2,124,000, or 15 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt.

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NET RISES SHARPLY FOR AMERICAN AIRLINES' OWNER
description: The AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines, yesterday reported second-quarter earnings of $39.6 million, or 85 cents a share, up sharply from $466,000 in last year's second quarter. Revenues rose 11.5 percent, to $1.16 billion, from $1.04 billion.

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DRIVERS CAN BE FORCED TO TAKE TEST FOR ALCOHOL
description: Drivers involved in serious accidents in New York State can be forced to undergo a chemical blood test for alcohol or drugs, under legislation signed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If I were to choose between those new bills and martial law, I would choose martial law.

title: News Analysis
description: Henry A. Kissinger, who will head the Presidential commission on Central America, has already indicated he believes a firm American response is needed in that region to maintain the credibility of the

title: Feldstein Sees Peril in Deficits
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected the United States economy to grow by 6 1/2 percent for the rest of 1983, but added that large Federal budget deficits threatened the nation's long-term economic health.

title: Kansas Power, Gas Service Pact
description: The Kansas Power and Light Company said it had reached an agreement for a $68.7 million acquisition of the Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo., apparently ending a takeover battle between Gas Service and the Missouri Public Service Company.

title: Penn Central Profits Decline
description: The Penn Central Corporation reported yesterday that net income in its second quarter fell 24.1 percent, to $26.7 million, or 55 cents a share, from $35.2 million, or 73 cents, a year earlier.

title: The Coach's Hat
description: Joe Walton has been distinguishable, if not distinguished-looking, by the peaked cap he wears backwards on the sidelines during Jets games.

title: HEARING ON POLICE CUT OFF IN HARLEM
description: A Congressional hearing in Harlem into allegations of police brutality toward blacks convened and adjourned within 20 minutes yesterday, amid shouts of ''sham'' from spectators complaining that hundreds could not get into the overcrowded room.

title: PAINE WEBBER INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Q&A
description: Q. Shore and mountain resorts used to boast about the healthful effects of ozone in their air. Now ozone is considered so hazardous that minute traces in the atmosphere are considered harmful to health. Why?

title: Renault Model
description: The first 1984 Renault Encore hatchback rolled off the assembly line at the American Motors Corporation's Kenosha, Wis., plant to the cheers of A.M.C. autoworkers, the company said. The subcompact, to be introduced in showrooms this fall with a base price of $5,755, is built on the same platform as the No.4 United States auto maker's popular Renault Alliance subcompact, which was introduced last fall. The Alliance's appeal has brought A.M.C.'s United States car sales 117.6 percent ahead of 1982 levels.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
7 WHALING PROTESTERS ARE ARRESTED IN SIBERIA
description: Seven members of the Greenpeace protest group, including the organization's United States director, were arrested today after filming a Soviet whaling station in Siberia, members of the group said.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CANADA PACKERS LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
description: Share earnings reflect a recent 2-for-1 stock split. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: James Baldwin at 92d St. Y
description: The Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y will open its 1983-84 season in September with a reading by James Baldwin.

title: Study of Beaufort Port
description: Gulf Canada Ltd.'s proposal to build a seaport in the Arctic has been placed before a new federal committee, the Government announced today. Gulf wants to build a port at Stokes Point, on the Beaufort Sea, as a base for oil and gas development. Residents oppose the plan.

title: LIFEMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $318,000 for the quarter and $477,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $190,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1983.

title: Calvin Fentress Jr. Dies at 75; Led Allstate Insurance Co.
description: Calvin Fentress Jr., former chairman of the Allstate Insurance Company, died of a heart ailment Saturday at Lake Forest Hospital in Lake Forest, Ill. Mr. Fentress, who lived in Lake Forest, was 75 years old.

title: Dry Pollination Season Pushes Corn Prices Up
description: Prices of corn futures covering the new crop continued to climb yesterday as the nation's major farm product entered its critical 10-day pollination period in mostly hot, dry weather.

title: PRIVATE OWNERSHIP OF TOLL ROADS SOLVES NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM VIETNAM, ROAD TO WEST OFTEN ENDS IN CHINA
description: Some were expelled from Vietnam with little more than the clothes on their backs. Others paid out their meager savings to be smuggled across the border rather than face military service in Cambodia or exile to an inhospitable new economic zone.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $5 million, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter on the sale of a portion of Genex Corp. shares. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the 6 months.

title: MAINE NATIONAL BANK (PORTLAND, ME) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Colt Brings $4.25 Million
description: Robert Sangster, the British bookmaker whose penchant for expensive horses has made him perhaps the best-known figure in the thoroughbred industry, tied his world record today by bidding $4.25 million for a son of fabled sire Northern Dancer at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale.

title: MORE PLANT CAPACITY IN USE IN JUNE
description: American industry operated at 74.5 percent of capacity in June, the highest rate since February 1982, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: A CALL FROM THE PAST FOR EXCELLENCE
description: ''UNTIL we pay teachers at least as well as the middle echelon of executives, we cannot expect the profession to attract its full share of the available range of talents. Salaries must be raised immediately and substantially. Almost as important at the level of pay is the fact that the promotional policy for most school systems is routine and depends more on seniority than on merit. And the top salary is not sufficiently far above the bottom salary to constitute a meaningful incentive.''

title: Man Found Shot To Death on Pier 53
description: A 38-year-old man was found shot to death yesterday on Pier 53, the police said. The man, whose name was not relased by the police, was found at 6:45 A.M. on the pier, used by the Sanitation Department, at Little West 12th Street and the Hudson River. The man, who was shot once, was found face down by sanitation workers, the police said.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
BAYLESS, A. J., MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
The Police Hearing: Listen
description: Even though quickly aborted, the Congressional hearing on police conduct in Harlem yesterday yielded a valuable lesson: Blacks are genuinely angry and frustrated over this issue. Mayor Koch may think it motivated only by politics. He and Police Commissioner McGuire may defend themselves conscientiously. But to do only that is to misunderstand. This is not a debate. No true resolution is possible until the anger is heard. And to do that, New York does not need Congress.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed January 28.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest quarter include a gain equal to 3 cents a share on the repurchase of bonds.

title: Role of the Psychiatrist Argued in Hinckley Case
description: A psychiatrist who treated John Hinckley Jr. for five months did not know his patient was a potential assassin and should not be held liable for the attempt on President Reagan's life, the psychiatrist's lawyer said today.

title: SECURITY NEW YORK STATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
YANKS CAPTURE FOURTH IN ROW
description: There was a time when Ron Guidry's name was synonymous with strikeouts. Those times are no longer. ''Strikeouts are past me now,'' Guidry said last night after striking out only four in pitching the Yankees to a 4-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins in front of 20,448 at the Stadium.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha-Laval Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., has elected Michael Rosenberg a vice president.

title: GARN SUPPORTS BANK DEREGULATION IDEA
description: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that he favored early enactment of legislation that would allow banks to enter real estate and insurance brokerage, and some securities activites. Mr. Garn said he expected Congress to pass a bill before the end of the year.

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE news was from Europe and most of it had to do with Giorgio A rmani, the Italian designer, who said he would never stage a fashions how ever again in his life. title: Third World's Debt Burden
description: The World Bank, along with its affiliated institution, the International Monetary Fund, is playing a major role in dealing with international debt. Problems facing the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as the World Bank is formally known, were discussed by two of its officials, Moeen A. Qureshi, a senior vice president for finance, and Eugene H. Rotberg, treasurer, at a recent meeting with reporters and editors of The New York Times.

title: Ronald Edmonds Dies; Ex-City School Aide, 48
description: Ronald R. Edmonds, professor of education at Michigan State University and former senior assistant to the New York City Schools Chancellor, died Friday at Ingham Medical Center, Lansing, Mich., after a brief illness. He was 48 years old, and lived in East Lansing.

An Invasion of Suriname Is Reportedly Foiled
description: A planned invasion of Suriname with the help of Florida-based mercenaries was called off this month after the Netherlands internal security agency found out about it, the Netherlands News Agency said today.

title: TELLABS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NAUTILUS SHELLFISH GIVING UP SECRETS
description: Little has been known about the behavior and ecology of the chambered nautilus, the beautiful shellfish that lives a relatively secret life on the bottom of the sea where it is rarely seen except by divers. But scientists who have captured them and placed them in aquariums are now beginning to learn more about how they live and how they manufacture chambers inside their shells as they mature.

description: Courageous lost two races to Defender but rebounded to win the third today in the observation trials on Rhode Island Sound to select the America's Cup yacht defender.

description: The Peoria Journal Star, the largest Illinois daily outside Chicago, will be sold to its employees, the president, Henry P. Slane, said.

title: 20 ON FAST TO RELEASE EXTRA FOOD
description: For about 20 protesters camped in a park on the edge of the downtown area, the day begins about 8 A.M. with a worship service. About noon, some protesters file off to a nearby church to take showers. They are continuing a fast that they hope will relieve the plight of the hungry in a land of plenty.

description: An Army general testified today he was only following regulations in approving the dismissal of a sergeant who admitted being a lesbian.

description: The United States Football League's reason for being, Commissioner Chet Simmons has often said, is to provide entertainment and good television programming. On the day after the league's first championship game, its officials were convinced that their showcase event had done just that.

title: 15 Soviet Pentecostals Fly to Austria
description: Fifteen members of a Pentecostal family took off from the Moscow airport today for Vienna. Two of the 15 - Mariya Chmykhalov, now 60 years old, and her son, Timofei, 21 - had accompanied five members of another Pentecostal family, their neighbors from the Siberian town of Chernogorsk, in rushing into the United States Embassy in June 1978 after waiting a dozen years to emigrate.

description: The folks at Esquire, intent on making the 50th anniversary issue ''a media event'' - like ''Roots'' or the Olympics, according to Alan Greenberg, the publisher - went out looking for corporate sponsors and came up with Federal Express.

title: MOVIES BOLSTER ARTS CABLE SERVICE
description: Of the four major cultural services offered by cable television a year ago, only one, Bravo, is likely to be in service by the fall. CBS Cable and RCA's Entertainment Channel have disappeared, and Telefrance, a more modest venture that features French films and cultural programming, last week dismissed most of its staff and indicated that it would have difficulty surviving beyond September. The service has not been able to draw enough advertising support.

PROBLEMS ABOUND IN PICKING BRINK'S JURY
description: Almost 1,200 prospective jurors have paraded through the tiny courtroom of the Brink's murder and robbery trial since last Monday, each of them being told by the judge that the trial would last at least two months.

title: PHYSICIANS JOIN RANKS OF UNIVERSITY PRESIDENTS
description: FOR the almost four months last winter when Dr. Barney B. Clark struggled to live with an artificial heart, Dr. Chase N. Peterson became a familiar name as spokesman for the University of Utah medical team that cared for the pioneering patient. That exposure may have contributed to Dr. Peterson's selection as president of the University of Utah, a job he begins Aug. 1.

title: A.T.& T. Awards Cellular Contracts
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had awarded major contracts for the production of cellular mobile telephone equipment to Motorola Inc. and to its own manufacturing arm, the Western Electric Company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Campaigning for Art

title: ...FOR OPEN DEBATE
description: A policy debate on Capitol Hill often turns into a struggle for the dominant cliche - for the slogan that captures attention as the pithiest way of describing what is at stake and what should be done. So it is that when the House of Representatives this week debates a bill to end covert support for military operations in Nicaragua, opponents of the measure will be arguing for ''symmetry.'' Their proposal will be that the United States should continue to provide aid for those seeking to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua as long as that Government is providing support for the guerrillas in El Salvador. ''Symmetry'' does have a plausible ring to it. This makes it all the more important to understand why it is a dangerous and inappropriate guide to United States policy in Central America.

title: Gov. Brown Reported Better
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr., who has been hospitalized since undergoing triple bypass heart surgery on June 25, is continuing to improve, a spokesman at the University of Kentucky Medical Center said Sunday. Governor Brown, who is 49 years old, remained off his respirator for up to three hours and walked around in his room in the intensive care unit, the spokesman said.

New Chief for Dresser
description: John J. Murphy, the president of Dresser Industries, was elected to the additional post of chairman and chief executive in a special meeting of the board yesterday. Mr. Murphy, 51 years old, succeeds John V. James, who will step down on Aug. 1.

title: LAST SEASON'S TICKET SALES GET A MIXED REVIEW
description: A number of New York's major performing arts organizations sold fewer tickets last season than in previous years, and some were forced to cut prices in order to maintain ticket sales. But other sectors of the performing arts - notably the concert halls and Off-Broadway - sold tickets briskly.

title: A STATION IN SPACE PREDICTED
description: The head of the space agency predicted today that President Reagan will soon approve an American manned space station.

title: Washington State Again Calls Carlson
description: Edward E. Carlson, who in 1981 was chairman of a panel that tried unsucessfully to slow rather than terminate construction of two nuclear reactors by the Washington Public Power Supply System, is attempting again to resolve the supply system's problems.

title: OIL PRICES: TURMOIL IS COMING
description: Falling demand for oil, the weakening of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the changing role of international oil companies threaten to make oil a commodity like any other - any other raw material on the international market. The result may be great turbulence in the world oil industry and a painful process of adjustment no less momentous than the one that occurred after 1973.

title: WILLIAM CLARK, AVON HEIR, DIES
description: William Van Alan Clark Jr., an industrialist, yachtsman and heir to the Avon cosmetics fortune, died of cancer last Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 63 years old and lived in Marion, Mass.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 19, 1983
description: International Two Caribbean military exercises within the next four weeks are being planned by the Reagan Administration, according to Administration officials. They said the big exercises, which will be held in both the Caribbean and Central America, would involve ground, air and naval forces and are intended as a warning that Washington has the means to halt the shipment of military supplies from Cuba to Nicaragua. (Page A1, Column 6.) Bipartisanship on Central America is sought by President Reagan. He announced he would establish a bipartisan Presidential commission headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to ''lay the foundation for a long-term unified national approach'' to problems in the region. (A1:5.)

title: BANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STUDY SAYS CANCER KILLS 37.000 IN STATE EACH YEAR
description: More than 66,000 new cases of cancer are being diagnosed annually in New York State, and about 37,000 people die each year from the various forms of the disease, State Health Department officials reported today.

title: Games in Limbo
description: For more than 2,000 track and field competitors in the over-40 circuit, the World Masters Games is their so-called Olympics. But this international event, which is scheduled for Sept. 22 through Oct. 2 in San Juan, may be in limbo because of invitations that have been issued to 70 South African athletes.

title: IN ASTRONOMY, THE AMATEUR STILL MAKES HIS MARK
description: ONE night late in May an asteroid named Pallas passed in front of a star. In the grand scheme of things, this was a very small event. But it held the attention of more than 100 astronomers from Baja California to Florida. Before the night was over these astronomers gathered data that is expected to reveal the most detailed picture to date of the size and shape of any asteroid. They appear to have also chalked up another triumph for amateur astronomy. Most of the observations were, in fact, made by amateurs - and astronomy (along with archeology) is one of the few areas of scientific research where amateurs can make important, even stunning, contributions.

description: The Vatican said tonight that it had set up a special telephone line so that a man who said he kidnapped a teen-age girl could call the Vatican's Secretary of State to arrange her release.

title: COLLEGES PERPLEXED BY NEW DRAFT LAW
description: ANDRE GINGERICH is a 21-year-old sophomore at Swarthmore College. For the last three years he has been receiving $4,000 a year in Federal grants, loans and work-study funds to help finance his education.

title: DRUGS: NEW METHOD PROVES EFFECTIVE
description: ONLY hours before Capt. Richard H. Truly flew the space shuttle Columbia to a safe landing on a dry lake bed in California two years ago he was beset by the fear that he was developing motion sickness. Indeed, at least a third of the astronauts who have flown in space have been beset by feelings of dizziness and nausea, and for centuries, many otherwise dauntless travelers, from skippers of ocean going vessels to racing car drivers, have been similarly humbled.

title: Condemned Brothers Granted Late Stays
description: Two half-brothers were granted stays of execution today, less than 16 hours before they were scheduled to die in Florida's electric chair for the beating, raping and burning of a Pasco County woman four years ago.

description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was appealing a Federal district court order requiring the Government to spend more than $14 million to help desegregate the public schools of Chicago.

title: D.H. LAWRENCE ART ON VIEW NEAR HIS TAOS HOME
description: Saki Karavas doesn't pretend it's a tradeoff; just an exchange of good-will gestures. He would consider having the D.H. Lawrence's paintings returned to the British if Britain would restore the Elgin Marbles to Greece. The problem is that the British once banned the Lawrence art and have shown no inclination to return the marbles.

description: ''Buffalo Bill,'' NBC's summertime comedy about an outrageous, insensitive and boorish talk-show host who treats his guests like dirt, has been renewed.

title: ANSWERS STILL LACKING, THE QUESTIONS GO ON
description: As the Justice Department sets out to resolve this summer's political mystery, how documents from Jimmy Carter's White House found their way to Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign staff, it has yet to shed any light on last winter's raging controversy over the Environmental Protection Agency.

description: Hale Irwin finished the 112th British Open Golf Championship one stroke shy of the winner, Tom Watson. Irwin, a two-time winner of the United States Open, did not need to go far back to speculate on a reason for missing a tie by one shot.

description: Democracy or Abuse?

title: Bomb in Restaurant Aimed to Cover Robbery
description: A bomb placed in a fast-food restaurant on the crowded Las Vegas Strip today was a fake planted as a diversion to cover a bank robbery two blocks away, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: Bishop John R. McGann of Rockville Centre today asked Roman Catholics on Long Island to lobby for an end to military aid to El Salvador and to urge the United States to grant temporary asylum for an estimated 40,000 Salvadoran refugees now in the Long Island diocese.

title: BUSINESS BOOMING FOR RAY MANCINI
description: R ay Mancini was hot and tired. He had just spent more than two hours in a room at Madison Square Garden, much of the time under hot television lights, talking about a fight against a fighter he does not know. He will defend his World Boxing Association lightweight championship at the Garden on Sept. 15 against Orlando Romero of Peru.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 25.
Strike at Peugeot Unit
description: Unions halted production at Automobiles Talbot's plant west of Paris because of plans by the parent company, Peugeot S.A., to eliminate 8,000 jobs within the group. The two unions called for full strikes at Peugeot and Talbot factories on Thursday, when the group will announce details of the cutbacks. Peugeot, which has lost $900 million in three years as a result of strikes and shrinking markets, has told unions and the Government that it wants to reduce its work force by 10 percent.

title: East German Flees to West
description: A 24-year-old East German border guard dodged explosive charges in the ground, scrambled over a barbed wire fence and fled to West Germany today, the authorities said. The unidentified guard was patrolling near the Lower Saxony town of Duderstadt when he fled, a West German border official said.

title: WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $103,871 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $41,800 for quarter and $56,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $77,537 for the quarter and $134,017 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $312,000 for the 6 months.

title: Man Without a Country
description: Dennis Brutus is a renowned black poet. He is also a man without a country. He was born 58 years ago in what was then Rhodesia, spent most of his life in South Africa, where anti-apartheid activities landed him in prison, fled to Britain and has lived in the United States since 1970. Now the U.S. wants to deport him because of deficiencies in his visa. The legality of his status as an immigrant may be clouded. But especially after 13 years, the immorality of pushing him out is not.

title: ADDIS DURNING RANZINI
description: Addis Durning Ranzini, who for many years wrote ''The Correct Thing,'' a syndicated column on etiquette, for The Daily News under the name Elinor Ames, died Saturday after a long illness at the Waterbury Extended Care Facility in Watertown, Conn. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After pretax charges from the writeoff of idle capacity costs applicable to the power transmission segment of $4,800,000 for the quarter and $9,800,000 for the 6 months.

title: CITIZENS FIRST BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $496,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared in 1982.

title: Market Place; Texas Oil's Steady Growth
description: AN oversupply of natural gas, coupled with a decline in demand resulting mainly from the recession, has made operations difficult for many natural gas companies. Yet the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation reported last week that, for the three months ended May 31, its per share profits rose to 72 cents from 60 cents a year earlier.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

Stocks Sag on Profit Taking;
Rate Jitters Continue
description: Stock market prices sagged yesterday on slim volume as profit taking weakened blue-chip issues. All major indexes declined, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing off 2.41, to 1,189.90, and the New York Stock Exchange index slipping 0.32, to 94.96. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 0.34, to 163.95. Stocks that declined in price led those that advanced by more than a 2-to-1 ratio, as volume totaled 69.1 million shares, up slightly from 63.2 million on Friday.

title: METHOD USED IN SCHOOL STUDY
description: ''A Study of Schooling'' was carried out from 1975 to 1983 by 43 full- and part-time researchers who focused on 13 representative communities in seven areas of the country, from inner city to rural areas. In each case, teams studied a senior high school along with an elementary school and a junior high school that fed students into it.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,960,0000. c-Net loss.

title: THE CITY
description: A chunk of stone fell yesterday from an archway over an approach to the George Washington Bridge, forcing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to close two lanes of roadway and causing some traffic delays.

title: WALESA PREDICTS A TOUGHER REGIME
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity union, said today that new restrictive measures drafted by the Government would be worse than the martial-law regulations that they would be intended to replace.

title: Judge Bars a Forced Retirement at 65
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled Friday that the chief labor lawyer at the Union Carbide Corporation should not have been pushed out of his job last September, when he turned 65.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After an extraordinary net charge of $960,000 for the quarter and 6 months for the consolidation of manufacturing of high alloy heat resistance castings. c-Net income.

title: Nationals Win Old-Timers Game
description: Richie Ashburn singled home Bill Mazeroski with the tying run, and the National League added two runs on an error en route to a 5-3 victory over the American League tonight in the Old-Timers Baseball Classic.

title: U.S. Faulted On Steel Curb
description: The foreign ministers of the European Economic Community today criticized recent American efforts to restrict imports of specialty steel products.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on July 7 incorrectly described the Wonder Woman Foundation. The foundation, a nonprofit organization, is not affiliated with Warner Communications Inc., but is licensed by DC Comics Inc., a division of Warner Communications, to use the name Wonder Woman.

title: Domenici Has Lung Surgery
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico underwent diagnostic surgery today for removal of what was described by his office as a harmless lesion on his left lung. The lesion was found last week as the Republican Senator, who is 51 years old, underwent his annual physical examination. The benign area was scar tissue that resulted from an old, healed infection, doctors said.

title: A PRAYER AND A QUESTION
description: As chaplain of the Senate, the Rev. Richard C. Halverson well knows the fluctuating moods of the men and women in his very special flock.

title: Honeywell Accord
description: Honeywell Inc. said it had signed a three-year agreement with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to install more than 1,000 small computers in Metropolitan's personal insurance sales offices in the United States and Canada. The computer involved in the deal is the Honeywell DPS 6/40, a minicomputer driven by a microprocessor. Honeywell and Metropolitan would not disclose the terms of the deal.

title: Chamber Opera Adviser
description: Beni Montresor has been named artistic adviser to the Chamber Opera Theater of New York. Mr. Montresor designed the sets, costumes and lighting for Chamber Opera Theater's production of ''L'Ormindo'' by Pierre Cavalli and has worked with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, as well as operas in Paris, Italy and San Francisco. He has also designed sets and costumes for the New York City Ballet and several Broadway productions.

title: 3 Brink's Defendants Resist Judge's Order
description: The three defendants in the Brink's case here refused today to comply with Judge David S. Ritter's order that they submit a list of any witnesses they expect to call during their trial for robbery and murder.

title: MEESE AND DEAVER SAY THEY KNEW OF NO SPYING IN 1980 CAMPAIGN
description: Two top aides to President Reagan in the White House and in his campaign for the Presidency, said today that they had no knowledge of any political espionage in the 1980 Presidential race.

title: PANTHERS GUESS RIGHT
description: DENVER T he Philadelphia Stars, struggling to gain every yard, had come within 3 points of the Michigan Panthers in the fourth quarter of the United States Football League's championship game Sunday night.

title: DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. DISCLOSES PLANS TO PUT INVESTMENTS IN BLIND TRUST
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, who has been criticized in Congress for buying and selling millions of dollars' worth of stocks while he was a Government official, said tonight that he was placing his investments in a blind trust.

title: GERARD ALEXANDER
description: Gerard Alexander, a prominent figure in marketing radial tires, died at his home Friday in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: ZENITH ALSO CLIMBS
description: Strong sales of a staid old product, color television sets, helped the RCA Corporation to post higher profits and the Zenith Radio Corporation to rebound sharply in the second quarter from a year earlier.

title: QUAKER 'INSURANCE' ON BID FOR STOKLEY
description: The Quaker Oats Company, which has begun a $77-a-share offer for Stokely-Van Camp Inc., said yesterday that even if its bid failed, it had an agreement to acquire Stokely's Gatorade subsidiary at any time up to July 15, 1985, for $110 million in cash.

title: HOUSE UNIT POLL FINDS SUPPORT FOR CURBING FED
description: Many of the nation's leading economists, polled by the House Banking Committee, said that they favor a change in the Federal Reserve's method of operation to impose some Congressional control over the central bank's priorities, the committee said yesterday.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 2.
description: Revenue figures for 1983 include gains from the disposal of properties of $3,400,000 for the quarter and $3,800,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago revenue figures include $850,000 in the latest quarter and $8,150,000 in the latest 9 months representing the company's share of the gain on the sale of certain assets and tax benefits by Rogers UA Cablesystems Inc., a 49 percent-owned subsidiary. Revenue in the year-ago periods is after losses of $96,000 in the latest quarter and $306,000 in the latest 9 months from the disposal of properties.

title: Toshiba-Korea Accord
description: The Toshiba Corporation has signed an agreement with the Korea Electronics Company to provide technical assistance for the production of bipolar linear integrated circuits, Toshiba said today. Toshiba owns 6.25 percent of Korea Electronics, a major South Korean producer of semiconductors. The agreement covers a line of integrated circuits designed mainly for audio and video equipment.

title: Education Bonds Tentatively Priced
description: A $28.3 million issue of the New Hampshire Higher Educational and Health Facilities Authority was tentatively priced with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 9 percent in 1998 and 9 7/8 percent in 2013, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: NEW YORK'S LOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH DETAIN 51 IN ORLY TERRORISM
description: The French police, investigating the bombing at Orly Airport that killed 6 travelers and wounded 56, rounded up 51 people today for questioning and confiscated what an official called ''a significant number'' of guns, explosives and radio communication sets.

title: Volcker View On I.M.F. Bill
description: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, said today that he was strongly opposed to part of the legislation that raises the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund by $8.4 billion.

title: SHOPPING MALLS PROTEST INTRUSION BY PROTESTERS
description: Many shopping mall operators say they have had the uncomfortable feeling of late that the outside world is seeping into their cool, stone, windowless palaces of retailing.

title: Jerzy Lukaszewicz Dies at 51; High Polish Aide Under Gierek
description: Jerzy Lukaszewicz, a member of the Polish leadership in the 1970's under Edward Gierek, died here today at age 51, the official press agency P.A.P. reported.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN MILITARY EXERCISES IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The Reagan Administration, as a warning to Cuba and Nicaragua, is planning two large military exercises within the next four weeks in Central America and the Caribbean, Administration officials said today.

title: FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The latest 6 months operating income includes a one-time gain of $11.1 million from the sale of its building subsidiary.

title: OIL FLOW TO BE CUT BY NIGERIA
description: Nigeria promised its colleagues in OPEC today to cut back oil production to the 1.3-million-barrel-a-day ceiling that the group had agreed to in March.

title: A Subtle Shuttle Ruse
description: The Senate has just voted against the valuable, admittedly preferential access that New Yorkers, among others, have long had to Washington D.C. It asked that our shuttling air passengers be diverted from close-in National Airport to Maryland and Virginia airports an hour away. Call us parochial, but this is absurd, if not unconstitutional.

title: WHAT'S BLACK AND WHITE AND ALL OVER TOWN?
description: It is a color combination as old as, well, at least a couple of hills. Nevertheless, black and white is being worn on New York streets this summer by, it seems, every woman in town.

title: Chess: Bernard Zuckerman Takes Heraldica-Ruslan Masters
description: The Heraldica-Ruslan Reserve Masters Tournament in New York was won by Bernard Zuckerman, a New York international master. He scored 9-2 in the 12-player round-robin competition.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DRUG FOR HUMANS CHECKS PALM TREE DISEASE
description: A mysterious disease seriously threatening coconut palms and other economically important palm-tree varieties in the United States and other countries seems to have been staved off in parts of Florida, where palm trees have been injected with the drug tetracycline.

title: DEUKMEJIAN CALLS ELECTION AND DEMOCRATS PROTEST
description: Inviting what Democrats in the State Legislature called ''all-out war,'' Gov. George Deukmejian today called a special election on Dec. 13 on a Republican-sponsored reapportionment plan calling for a drastic realignment of legislative district boundaries.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET OFFICIALS SPAR IN MADRID
description: The United States strongly accused the Soviet Union and its allies today of continuing violations of human rights; the delegate from Moscow forcefully rejected the charges.

title: BUILDING BOATS, BUILDING TRADITION
description: hour by car from the Newport docks where the America's Cup yachts are strung up like marlins, a half-century from the tourists in Newport's boutiques and lobster restaurants.

title: HIDING BEHIND HENRY
description: President Reagan's decision to set up a ''bipartisan'' national commission to underpin his unpopular Central American policy is bad news for more reasons than the rebirth of Henry Kissinger.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Dieken, an offensive tackle for the Cleveland Browns who has played in 171 consecutive regular-season games, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday. He is expected to miss three weeks of training camp.

title: Jake Butcher Asset Sale
description: Assets of a bankrupt company tied to the financier Jake Butcher, including 74 houseboats and a helicopter, are being sold at a public auction.

title: Potlines Restarted
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would restart two aluminum potlines in the Pacific Northwest with a combined capacity of 49,000 tons a year. The restarts, at Longview, Wash., and Troutdale, Ore., would increase its primary aluminum operating rate to 64 percent of its North American capacity. About 200 workers would be recalled when the lines begin operating later this month.

title: U.N. CHIEF WEIGHS A TRIP TO SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is considering a trip to southern Africa late next month to try to break the deadlock over independence for South-West Africa.

title: The Talk of Ann Arbor
description: It's sad, in a way, that students at the University of Michigan, who face blustery winds and freezing rain so much of the time, must leave here each year just as things turn balmy. And yet their departure is what makes summers in Ann Arbor so special. Things have quieted down in recent years on this sprawling campus, once a center of student activism; conversations these days are more likely to center on fraternity rush or grade-point averages than on El Salvador or South Africa. Still, as most of Michigan's 35,000 students headed home for the summer, Ann Arbor breathed its annual collective sigh of relief.

title: Lebanese Leader Meets With Hussein in France
description: The Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, said today that he had held talks with King Hussein of Jordan to coordinate policies on the crisis in Lebanon.

description: Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy and the head of the state corrections system were fined a total of $1,000 today for failure to meet an April 1 Federal court deadline for renovation of two prison cellblocks.

description: Tracking of earth satellites has become so precise that it is now possible to detect such subtle effects as changes of the earth's shape that are still going on in delayed response to the removal of the last ice sheets.

FOR PODRES, SOBRIETY IS LIFE
description: Johnny Podres thought about his most glorious moments in baseball, the 1955 World Series, and said, ''That's a lot of cocktails ago.'' Nearly 28 years have elapsed since Podres dazzled the Yankees and pitched the Brooklyn Dodgers to their only World Series championship. His 8-3 victory in the third game and his 2-0 masterpiece in the seventh and deciding game are only memories now. So, Podres hopes, are the cocktails.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE sidewalk becomes a stage these long summer days for a chalkfaced mime who plays to the crowds on the steps of the Fifth Avenue library, and anyone who wanders onto the stage becomes part of the act. The executive with briefcase, the boy with a dripping ice cream cone, the elegant woman with a Lord & Taylor shopping bag - all provide life studies for the mime, who walks a little way with each one, imitating the walk and gestures precisely. The crowd on the library steps eats it up.
