title: REFORM AND RELIEF; All Can Learn
description: Ronald Edmonds, who died this week at the age of 48, was not widely known but his creative work in education touched many children in New York City and elsewhere. For three years he was an important innovator on the staff of Frank Macchiarola, the former Schools Chancellor, bringing to bear the perspectives of a black educator trained at Harvard.

title: TV: JULIE KAVNER IN 'FINE ROMANCE'
description: THE word ''pilot'' on a summer schedule usually spells trouble. More often than not, it refers to a half-hour situation comedy that has been rejected as a candidate for a regular weekly series. The network is simply cleaning out its programming shelves. Tonight at 8:30, however, CBS is offering a pilot entitled ''A Fine Romance'' and, incredibly enough, it looks like one of the more promising shows of the year.

title: REINSTATES INDICTMENT OF PROTESTER
description: In a victory for the Government, a Federal appeals court today upheld draft registration and reinstated an indictment against a 21-year-old man who refused to register, ruling that he was not the victim of ''selective prosecution.''

title: RAYMOND ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SPERRY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago quarter results include a gain of 25 cents a share from the sale of electronic systems operations in the United Kingdom.

title: VELOSO BRINGS NEWEST BEAT FROM BRAZIL
description: CAETANO VELOSO, who has been one of Brazil's most popular singersongwriters for some 15 years, sent the members of his band out, one by one, to open his concerts at the Public Theater over the weekend. They improvised a kind of loose, cheerful banter on their instruments - electric guitar and bass, drums, percussion and saxophone. Then Mr. Veloso himself appeared, flapping his arms in a kind of birdlike gesture as he bowed to the audience. He is a lithe, slender man with a dancer's grace who says he is 40 years old but who doesn't look much more than half that age. He began singing softly but insistently in Portuguese, and the band's scattered improvising coalesced into a slinky samba.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ARIZONA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
LEXICON CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
A BILL ON WITHHOLDING ELUDES CONFEREES
description: Disagreement over tax compliance provisions prevented Congressional conferees today from reaching agreement on compromise legislation that would repeal tax withholding on interest and dividend income.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Whenever I purchase crabs, I always recall my mother's admonition that you must always buy live crabs. Is there any validity to this?

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago figures restated for a pooling of interest acquisition in April.

title: U.S. ACTS ON TV CASE
description: Two universities were joined by the United States Justice Department today in urging Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court not to stay an order that would nullify the National Collegiate Athletic Association's exclusive control of college football telecasts and would allow individual colleges to make their own television deals.

title: SOO LINE RR CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FILM: WERNER HERZOG DOCUMENTARIES
description: THE way some writers keep notebooks about subjects that interest them and that may, one day, serve as the bases for works of fiction, is the way that Werner Herzog, the German director (''Fitzcarraldo,'' ''La Soufriere''), sometimes makes short documentary films. These Herzog ''notebooks,'' however, are complete in themselves - small, self-effacing works of art.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: 'Light' Beer: Low Calorie?

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The latest quarter net included a nonrecurring gain of 24 cents a share from the sale of property compared with the year-ago second quarter net which included a nonrecurring 5 cents a share gain from the distribution of stock received from Wells Fargo vestment Co., a small business investment company that was about 50 percent owned by Wells Fargo.

title: E.E.C. Opens Finance Talks
description: The European Economic Community opened tough bargaining today on reshaping its troubled finances and on curbing expensive farm subsidies.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
GIBRALTAR SAVINGS ASSN (BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF) Q reports earnings for Revenue.
description: b-Net loss.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Ultralight Plane In Fatal Crash
description: A Canadian man died Monday night after his ultralight aircraft crashed near the Brickyard Road Airport. The victim was identified as Robert Smith, 35 years old, of Oakville, Ontario, who had been visiting a cousin here.

title: CHIEF OF HEWLETT LEADS TRADE STUDY
description: As president and chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company, John A. Young has much to say about international trade. ''Not long ago, the subject didn't mean much to most American companies,'' he maintains.

title: Probation in Mercy Killing
description: A man convicted Friday of attempted murder in the mercy killing of his 63-year-old comatose father last March was sentenced Monday to three years probation.

title: Fire Breaks Out On Ship at S.I. Pier
description: A fire broke out in a container ship docked at a Staten Island pier yesterday, and four firefighters were injured battling the blaze, authorities said.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $146,000. c-Net loss.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $8,665,000 for the quarter and $10,629,000 for the 6 months.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY'S RESTORATION WILL FOCUS ON 13 TROUBLE SPOTS
description: To insure the life of the Statue of Liberty, all of the iron supports for the copper exterior of the 97-year-old monument will have to be replaced during two years of restoration work, a team of American and French architects said today.

title: House Votes Bill to Protect Farmers in Cotton Program
description: The House of Representatives, ignoring objections from the Reagan Administration, today approved legislation intended to protect cotton farmers who participated in the Federal program that would give farmers cotton for restricting production.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,950,000 from the sale of a subsidiary. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Foreign Auto Supply Falls
description: Stockpiles of imported autos fell to a 28-day supply at the beginning of this month compared with a 33-day supply in early June, according to an auto industry trade journal.

title: REVONE KLUCKMAN OF ZENITH IS DEAD
description: Revone W. Kluckman, chairman and president of the Zenith Radio Corporation, died Monday evening at Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elk Grove Village, Ill., after suffering a heart attack. He was 54 years old and lived in Northbrook, Ill.

title: FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BASEBALL'S GERMAN MARK
description: To the Editor:

title: Boys Survive Ordeal In the Black Hills
description: Two young boys from Masssachusetts missing for four days in the Black Hills walked out of the woods today, in good spirits but hungry.

title: Sanyo to Open German Factory
description: The Sanyo Electric Company plans to open a factory to produce video recorders in West Germany, a spokesman for the Bavarian economics ministry said.

title: Plan for Environment Aide
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Alvin L. Alm, an environmentalist who held posts in the last three Administrations, as deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, the White House announced today.

title: COUNTY TOWER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the year-ago second quarter reflect a net gain of $929,000, or 9 cents a share, from a non-monetary exchange of property.

title: Bahrain Leader Meets Reagan in Washington
description: President Reagan told the ruler of Bahrain today that the United States remains unshakable in its efforts to bring security and peace to the Middle East and ''to prevent the forces of violence from exercising a veto'' over the future of Lebanon.

title: FOR COMMUTERS, KEEPING COOL IS AN ELUSIVE GOAL THESE DAYS
description: On bus and train, by foot and by subway and in lines of crawling cars, millions of commuters are sweltering through a bad case of July. Their daily ritual has become a test of their mettle -physical and mental.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Elongated Sweater

title: Lockheed Sets New Jet Deals
description: The Lockheed Corporation will probably dispose of its remaining inventory of five L-1011 wide-body jets, valued at about $300 million, through lease-financing deals, James West, president of the Lockheed Finance Corporation, said.

title: Judge Finds Hiring Bias On Part of Steel Concern
description: The United States Steel Corporporation discriminated against thousands of blacks who applied for jobs as laborers in the 1970's at the Fairless Hills plant nearhere, a Federal District judge ruled today.

title: News Analysis
description: Two themes emerged this week from the aborted Congressional hearing into allegations of police brutality against blacks. First, there is a perception among segments of the black and Hispanic communities of New York City that the police treat them badly. Second, politics and personalities have complicated the issue, making it difficult to focus on the problem.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the quarter and $303,000 for the 6 months. The latest 6 months net includes gain of $4,258,000 from sale of a portion of a data processing subsidiary.

title: Coast Hotel Sold
description: The British-owned Sir Francis Drake Hotel in San Francisco has been sold to a hotel-owning group in California for $25 million, Lonrho P.L.C. announced in London. The company, while not disclosing the name of the buyer, said that the sale had been made by its Princess Properties Interational, Ltd. (Bermuda) subsidiary because it did not fit into the category of conference and resort hotels in which the subsidiary specializes in the Western Hemisphere.

title: A SCARRED KIBBUTZ IS AMBIVALENT ABOUT INVASION
description: Life in this hilltop kibbutz pressed against the Israel-Lebanese border is divided into two major periods: before last year's invasion of Lebanon, when there were frequent shellings and one terrorist attack, and after the invasion, when peace has prevailed.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss after writeoffs of $12,570,556 for the quarter and $12,602,392 for the year.

title: WHALING PROTESTERS SAY CHASE FOLLOWED INCURSION IN SIBERIA
description: A Greenpeace protest ship fled Soviet waters in a dramatic sea chase after seven of its crew were arrested as they went ashore to investigate the Lorino whaling station in northeast Siberia, the group said today.

title: Scott Paper's Net Rises
description: The Scott Paper Company, citing gains by its packaged products division, said today that its second-quarter net income rose 13 percent, to $33 million, or 72 cents a share, from $29.2 million, or 65 cents a share, in the second quarter last year. Sales rose 4 percent, to $613.8 million, from $587.8 million. The company said the increase was principally due to continued improvement by Scott's packaged products division and a sharp rebound by its international affiliates.

title: WESTERN COMPANY OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: WINE TALK
description: MOST wine drinkers have about as much interest in how wine is sold as motorists have in the retail tire business, but every so often something unusual comes along that is not directly connected with the bottle and the glass but is worth passing on. Something such as the American Classics Wine Company.

title: CHINESE FOOD PLACES VYING ON DELIVERY
description: THE city's Great Chopsticks Wars wax fiercely. No longer is it sufficient for a Chinese restaurant simply to have an adequate supply of woks, spatulas, beef, dried orange peel and hot chili oil to satisfy the heat-seeking palates of New York's lovers of Chinese food. These days stopwatches are as important as dried black mushrooms, sneakers as necessary as bok choy.

title: RAWLEY STOPS TWINS ON 6-HITTER
description: There are bigger names on the Yankee pitching staff. Ron Guidry for one. Dave Righetti for another. ''In my opinion,'' said Shane Rawley, another of New York's lefthanded starters, ''those two guys are the elite in the league. They're in the top five of all pitchers.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America announced that it had raised the price for its unalloyed aluminum ingot by 4 cents, to 76.5 cents a pound, effective Monday.

title: 3 in Cannon Case Plead Not Guilty
description: Three men accused of having been accomplices in a $6 million counterfeiting scheme masterminded by the former football star Billy Cannon pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
UTAH BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BURNETT LIBEL AWARD CUT
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled Monday that the actress Carol Burnett must accept a $600,000 reduction, from $750,000 to $150,000, in a punitive damage award for libel by The National Enquirer or undergo a new trial.

title: REFORM AND RELIEF; Civility Underground
description: Subway conductor George Galloway on the F train says the weather is driving civilized citizens back into the air-conditioned cars of the Jamaica line. They ride at slightly off hours, bringing books, crossword puzzles and fruit (with a brown bag for the pits and peels).

title: GERMANIA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (ALTON, ILL) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SALVADOR RIGHTS: SOME GAIN
description: Has certification been a charade? In a way, yes. In the longer view, however, the process by which the President certifies that the Salvadoran Government is making a significant effort to improve its record on human rights has been a success because it has accomplished a little in El Salvador and also embarrassed the Reagan Administration into improving its policies elsewhere - in Argentina and Chile.

title: Warrant Holders At Chrysler
description: Unidentified holders of warrants for 5 million shares of the Chrysler Corporation common stock plan to exercise those warrants, while financial institutions are preparing to sell up to 9.51 million shares of Chrysler common stock, according to a prospectus filed by the company.

title: 'Grin and Bear It' Artist Dies
description: George Lichty, creator of the ''Grin and Bear It'' cartoon series, died Monday at Santa Rosa Hospital of a heart attack. He was 78 years old. ''Grin and Bear It'' was a regular feature in hundreds of publications for 42 years. Mr. Lichty, who was born George Maurice Lichtenstein in 1904 in Chicago, is survived by his wife, Eleanor, and two daughters.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: In Defense of 212
description: I n the brief interlude between a mayoral news conference at the head of the front steps of City Hall and a band concert at the foot, a handful of officials held a hasty news conference yesterday to oppose plans to split New York City into two telephone area codes.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the year-ago 6 months do not reflect the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S. TO TIGHTEN SECURITY AFTER LATEST JET HIJACKING
description: Frustrated by the second hijacking of an American jet to Cuba in 36 hours, the eighth this year, Federal officials said today that they will begin taking new measures to ''tighten security.''

title: NICARAGUA OFFERS TO JOIN IN TALKS ON REGIONAL PEACE
description: The Nicaraguan Government, marking the fourth anniversary of its revolution, announced today that it was willing to participate in international talks to achieve peace in Central America.

title: Cable TV Pacts Signed by Koch
description: Contracts to bring cable television to the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were signed yesterday by Mayor Koch in a ceremony at City Hall.

title: AMNESTY BILL IS READY IN POLAND
description: The Government has sent to Parliament a draft decree that would provide amnesty to hundreds of political prisoners and to members of the Solidarity underground willing to renounce opposition activities, parliamentary sources said today.

title: BRITON DISCOVERS DINOSAUR REMAINS
description: An amateur fossil collector was credited today with discovering the skeleton of a new species of dinosaur, a flesh-eater that would have been terrifying when it lived 125 million years ago. It had claws a foot long.

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DAY CARE IN NEW YORK: A GROWING NEED
description: IT may not have been the most scientific way to conduct market research, but Susan Weissman measured the need for day-care services on the Upper West Side by counting boxes of paper diapers on supermarket shelves. ''I realized that there was a baby boom, and I knew, with the numbers of women working, that help was needed,'' she said. She was right. In March 1981, three months after renting space in a brownstone at 9 West 82d Street, equipping it and arranging for the requisite licensing by New York City, Mrs. Weissman, a psychiatric social worker and teacher, opened the Park Center for Preschoolers. Now the program, which operates from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., weekdays yearround, has an enrollment of 60 children ranging in age

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HEAT AND HOLIDAY COLLIDE IN CAIRO, AND HEAT WINS
description: Cairo has been sweltering through its annual three-day religious holiday that marks the end of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month of fasting from sunrise to sunset.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a gain of $16,403,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes. c-After a gain of $4,632,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Nicholas F. Brady
description: Appointed to the United States Senate from New Jersey last year to serve out term of Harrison A. Williams Jr. ... Managing director of Dillon Read & Company, investment bankers ... Chairman of Purolator Inc. and director of several businesses ... Chairman of the Jockey Club in New York and an official of the Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia ... Born in New York City April 11, 1930 ... Graduated from Yale University and Harvard Business School ... Lives in Far Hills, N.J., with wife ... Three sons and a daughter. Henry G. Cisneros

title: DOES THE WORKLOAD JUSTIFY A NEW APPELLATE COURT?
description: With the Supreme Court out of town, the issue of its workload, which Chief Justice Warren E. Burger warned six months ago was approaching ''disaster,'' has once again faded from view. But for once in the long history of public debate on the subject, out of sight is not out of mind.

title: PILLSBURY HALTS OFFER FOR STOKELY
description: The Pillsbury Company withdrew its $62-a-share offer for Stokely-Van Camp Inc. yesterday following Stokely's announcement last weekend that it had agreed to merge with the Quaker Oats Company for $77 a share, or $269 million total.

title: SAMPLING THE FOOD IN BROOKLYN'S 'LITTLE ODESSA'
description: THERE aren't many beaches this side of the Baltic Sea where sunbathers can cool off at a boardwalk food stand with a chilled bowl of beet-red borscht and sour cream. In the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, not only can bathers do that, at a takeout lunch stand called Gastronom Moscow, but they can also walk a block away to restaurants that serve such Russian specialties as Caucasian lamb casserole, grilled chicken with walnut sauce, Ukrainian dumplings, mutton soup, piroshki and, of course, caviar and iced vodka.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Dave Righetti, who didn't pitch so well in his last outing but still beat Rick Honeycutt of Texas, gets the start against the former St. John's star Frank Viola.

title: Market Place; Fast-Food Forecasts
description: SHARES of the McDonald's Corporation, the fast-food giant, have lagged behind the market since selling at a record price of 74 1/2 in April. Wall Street analysts attribute the recent behavior of the stock to disappointing store-traffic trends, as well as inroads made in the hamburger business by the Pillsbury Company's Burger King chain. Nonetheless, some analysts have been recommending purchase of McDonald's, along with other fast-food issues.

title: WATERGATE INVESTIGATOR JOINING POLITICAL INQUIRY
description: James Hamilton, a former Watergate investigator, was unanimously approved today as special counsel to the House subcommittee investigating conduct in the 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: GIANT ROOKIE STARTS ON A DIFFERENT FOOT
description: When the Giants open their National Football League season Sept. 4 against the Los Angeles Rams, their starting left offensive tackle will be one of three players: Karl Nelson, Rich Baldinger or Brad Benson.

title: AIDE FOCUSES ON 'ABILITY TO LOOK FOWARD'
description: Long-range planning has not received much priority in the modern White House, as recent Administrations have rarely looked more than a few months ahead. But President Reagan has just hired Bruce K. Chapman, a Harvard-trained former liberal, to think about what the future of the national Government ought to be.

title: From Brooklyn, Help For the Handicapped
description: A free, comprehensive guide to resources for New York City's handicapped was published yesterday by the Brooklyn Advisory Committee on the Handicapped. Distributed in Brooklyn through community organizations and public libraries, it is also available by mail from the Borough President's office at Borough Hall.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $20,158,000.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (MIAMI,FLA) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Addendum
description: * Personal Computing magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 50 percent, to 525,000, from 350,000, effective with the September issue. The advertising page rate for four-color will go up 58.4 percent and black-and-white 43.2 percent.

title: Castle & Cooke Shows Increase
description: Higher banana prices helped Castle & Cooke Inc., the processed and fresh food and real estate company based in Hawaii, to report fourthquarter net income of $15.9 million, or 51 cents a share, a sharp increase from the $1.2 million reported in the final quarter last year.

title: A Booming Sport
description: Since 1977, when seven wheelchair-bound athletes competed officially in the Boston Marathon, wheelchair racing has become an increasingly popular sport.

title: U.S. NAVY BATTLE GROUP OFF CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The Pentagon today ordered an eightship aircraft carrier battle group to take up stations off the Pacific coast of Central America ''to underscore U.S. support for friendly nations in the region.''

title: Women's Panel Gets Chairman
description: President Reagan today appointed Angela Buchanan, a former Treasurer of the United States, as chairman of a new advisory committee on women's business ownership.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the year-ago quarter in= clude a loss of $9,000,000 resulting from the closing of a density polyethylene plant in England.

title: Ford Offers Methanol Car
description: The first of nearly 600 methanolpowered Escort automobiles were delivered to their new owners today, part of the largest test fleet of the wood alcohol-powered cars yet developed by the Ford Motor Company.

title: Dow Up 7.22; Bond Strength Cited
description: After two days of decline, stock prices rose yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had fallen 2.41 points on Monday and 12.02 on Friday, closed 7.22 higher yesterday, at 1,197.12, and the New York Stock Exchange index closed at 95.48, up 0.52. Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was 0.88 higher, to 164.83. Advancing stocks led declines, with 946 issues higher and 653 issues lower on volume of 74 million shares, up from 69.1 million.

title: FORTUNE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: Uruguay's Diego Perez outlasted Spain's Juan Avendano, 1-6, 6-4, 7-5, today in the opening round of the D.C. National Bank Classic.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CARESSA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Advertising; Attracting Companies To the Fair
description: WHEN it comes to world's fairs and similar extravaganzas, sophisticated major marketers who are frequently approached to exhibit no longer see them merely as an opportunity to show the corporate flag. They are now considered regular promotion opportunities.

title: HOUSE HOLDS SECRET DEBATE ON AID
description: President Reagan today appointed the 12 members of his National Bipartisan Commission on Central America and told it to report by Dec. 1 on how to build a national consensus behind a policy of dealing with ''threats'' to United States interests in the region.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
OLIN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
VF CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 10, 1982.

title: AMERICAN HOME, MERCK GAIN
description: Three leading pharmaceutical companies yesterday reported generally substantial gains in earnings for the second quarter. The American Home Products Corporation reported a 13.4 percent gain; Merck & Company, 10.8 percent, and Eli Lilly & Company, 9.3 percent. David Saks, drug analyst at A.G. Becker, said the strong earnings results ''reflect the ongoing record demand for medical and drug products and a cessation of the downward trends in the cyclically sensitive businesses such as chemicals, agriculture and animal health.'' He added that ''another not insignificant factor is that foreign-currency penalties are becoming less.'' American Home

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Handyman Seized In Arsons at Mills
description: A 37-year-old handyman who had assisted city firefighters in the past has been charged with setting a fire that heavily damaged silk mills selected as the centerpieces of a city renovation project, according to authorities.

title: F & M NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TV: PROBLEM OF UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT
description: SAY this for ''Who's Supporting the Kids?'' - it's not simpleminded. It deals with the apparently growing problem of unpaid child support, but doesn't pretend to offer the solution, at least not the final one, to the problem. Jailing fathers who don't pay is one solution; a civilized joint custody procedure is another. Implicit in the documentary, meanwhile, is the suggestion that some people have no business having children. The documentary, produced by WHA Television in Madison, Wis., will be seen locally on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Regan Sees Recovery Lifting Federal Revenue
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration expects the economic recovery to produce at least $10 billion more in revenue for the fiscal year 1984, beginning Oct. 1, than previously estimated, and more than $15 billion in additional revenue for the fiscal years 1985 and 1986.

title: KOHL AND MITTERRAND MEET ON MISSILES
description: President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl met today for five hours of talks that centered on nuclear arms reduction. Mr. Kohl said later that he now felt there were ''real chances'' for a successful conclusion at the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allison Manufacturing Co., a subsidiary of Beatrice Foods, announced that Marvin Herbert, president, was taking early retirement.

title: OMNICARE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CROWN ZELLERBACH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $9.3 million on the sale of an investment.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.2 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: News Analysis
description: By establishing a National Bipartisan Commission on Central America, President Reagan acknowledged today that a dramatic step was needed to rescue his military policies in the region from rejection by the Congress and the public.

title: HOMER NEWELL, LEADER IN U.S. SPACE SCIENCE
description: Dr. Homer E. Newell Jr., who was primarily responsible for organizing early American scientific efforts in space, died of a stroke Monday night at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 68 years old.

title: Make It the Ex-MX
description: The MX, a new missile that threatens the United States more than it does the Soviet Union, has nonetheless outlived three Administrations, 34 basing systems, a half-dozen Congressional vetoes and two arms control treaties. Today, however, Congress may finally drive a stake through its heart.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
U.S. Team Gains In Federation Cup
description: The United States opened the defense of its Federation Cup tennis trophy today with a 3-0 first-round victory over Norway, losing only 12 games in 3 matches.

title: OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1983.

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose yesterday for the second consecutive day. Dealers in Government securities said investor demand was the strongest they had seen in a week.

title: U.S. Military Aid to Chad
description: President Reagan has decided to use his executive power to supply the Government of Chad with $10 million in military aid to help it fight Libyan-backed rebels, the State Department announced today. The United States previously helped Chad in 1981 during a similar outbreak of fighting.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (SAN DIEGO, CALIF reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. c-After an extraordinary charge of $2,755,000 from the prepayment penalties on early retirement of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a net gain of $7.7 million, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of Arrowhead Products division and an extraordinary gain of $2 million, or 16 cents a share, for the 6 months from an exchange of debt for equity in the first quarter.

title: A Fountain is Cleaned, Mouthful by Mouthful
description: A round Columbus Circle, Candy is regarded as a deserving candidate for a city award for public service. Candy, a 10-year-old golden retriever, assumes personal responsibility for keeping the Delacorte Fountain, which surrounds the Columbus monument, clear of discarded cans.

title: REASONS NOT GIVEN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin told President Reagan by telephone today that he was postponing his visit to Washington next week for personal reasons.

title: 21 Haitians Rescued
description: Twenty-one Haitian migrants apparently bound for the United States were rescued from a sinking boat 100 miles off the Haitian coast, Coast Guard officials said today. The crew of the cutter Steadfast sighted the crowded 25-foot boat at 6:30 P.M. Monday, according to a Coast guard spokesman.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
LIMITS INCREASED FOR RESTITUTIONS FROM CRIMINALS

description: The date for a Congressional hearing into allegations of brutality toward blacks by New York City police officers could be announced as soon as this week, according to a spokesman for Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan.

title: Treatment Completed
description: Rick Upchurch, the Denver Broncos' wide receiver and kick returner, said he had completed a rehabilitation program to shake off a marijuana habit. ''I'm clean,'' he told The Rocky Mountain News. ... Pete Johnson, the Cincinnati Bengals' fullback who testified that he had purchased cocaine from a local plumber, plans to discuss the matter soon with Commissioner Pete Rozelle, according to the player's lawyer, Mark Vander Laan. ... Eight members of the Cleveland Browns with a history of drug abuse have been participating in a rehabilitation program run by Coach Sam Rutigliano, according to Newsweek magazine. The report said that the players, who were not named, had attended weekly meetings and received other counseling for the last two years.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF you are tailoring your menu so the dishes can all be prepared in one hour or less, it may be necessary at times to alter standard techniques in order to expedite matters. For example, if you are going to serve a stuffed vegetable dish, it will speed things up if you cook the vegetable for a brief period before adding the filling.

title: ALL THAT MONIES
description: I have been puzzling all morning about the distinction between money and monies. The question arises because of a contract I am asked to sign. If it is fulfilled adequately, I shall receive monies. If not, I shall have to pay monies.

title: FRANK REYNOLDS, ABC NEWSMAN, DIES
description: Frank Reynolds, the ABC News anchorman, died in Washington early today, a spokesman for the network said.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Bond Rates Set By Loan Bank
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank yesterday announced the interest rates for a three-part, $1.395 billion financing. The $550 million of bonds due July 27, 1987, are offered with a 11.35 percent yield; the $320 million due Nov. 27, 1989, yield 11.55 percent, and the $525 million due July 26, 1993, yield 11.7 percent.

description: The former head of the treasury police has been called to testify on a previously undisclosed inquiry into the killing of four American churchwomen, judicial sources said today.

title: CUISINART'S DEAL IN PRICING SUIT
description: It chops, it slices, it minces, it kneads - and between 1973 and 1981, it may have cost more than it should have. The Cuisinart food processor has for years been the subject of a price-fixing class action lawsuit on behalf of more than a million consumers who contend they were overcharged by $32 to $75 for their food processors.

description: Walt Disney Productions said yesterday that net income for the its third quarter fell 35 percent, to $21.4 million, or 61 cents a share, from $32.9 million, or 98 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues, however, reached record levels.

description: Rarely in pro football have two new line coaches been asked to take over units with so many all-stars, as in the case of the Jets.

Hoping to Return
description: Carol Blazejowski, one of the outstanding players in the history of women's basketball, thinks there is still hope for a women's professional league. ''But it will have to start on a regional level, with divisions in such places as the West Coast, the South, the Midwest and the Northeast,'' she says.

description: Preparatory Commtttee for the In- ternational Conference on the Ques- tion of Palestinians - 10:30 A.M.

News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 20, 1983
description: International Nicaragua expressed willingness to participate in international talks to achieve peace in Central America. The Government, marking the fourth anniversary of its revolution, also called for negotiations on other points previously raised by the United States, including arms supplies and military support for the leftist rebels in El Salvador. (Page A1, Column 6.) A consensus on Central America is sought by President Reagan. He appointed the 12 members of his National Bipartisan Commission on the region and instructed the panel to report by Dec. 1 on how to build a national consensus behind a policy of dealing with threats to the United States's interests there. (A1:4-5.)

description: John W. Hinckley Jr. wrote ''I'm not the least bit dangerous'' in a letter mailed Monday from St. Elizabeths Hospital here and received today.

description: b-Net income includes an extraordinary credit of $210,000.

title: REAGAN PLEDGES HIS SUPPORT FOR GENERAL REVENUE SHARING
description: President Reagan told county officials today that he would fight for renewal of the Federal revenue-sharing program and was committed to state and local government.

title: USAir Reports Record Period
description: The USAir Group yesterday reported record earnings for the second quarter totaling $28 million, or $1.22 a share, up 40 percent from $20 million, or $1.15 a share, in the second quarter last year.

description: b-Including tax credits of $964,000 for the quarter and $1,471,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $829,000 for the quarter and $1,327,000 for the 6 months.

title: Northrop Turnaround
description: The Northrop Corporation yesterday reported net income of $27.5 million, or $1.81 a share, for the second quarter, in contrast to a net loss of $1.6 million for the period a year before. Sales were up 42.3 percent, to $804.1 million, from $565 million.

title: REAGAN URGES THE HOUSE TO BACK I.M.F. INCREASE
description: Although it was unclear whether proponents had the votes to win, the Reagan Administration today urged the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives to hold a scheduled vote Thursday on the $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund.

title: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
5 HELD IN BRONX HOSPITAL INVASION
description: Five members of a South Bronx gang, ranging in age from 14 to 20, were arrested yesterday after they invaded the emergency room at an annex of Bronx Lebanon Hospital and stabbed a guard during a scuffle, the police said.

title: MASLAND, C H, & SONS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Heat Wave Prompts Emergency Declarations
description: By The Associated Press St. Louis officials declared a heat emergency yesterday and opened shelters in the second week of a heat wave that has killed at least eight people nationwide.

title: 'Submarine' Off Sweden Turns Out to Be a Prank
description: A suspected submarine periscope spotted on Sweden's northeast coast turned out to be a sewage pipe placed in the water by pranksters, a military spokesman said today.

title: Latin Foreign Ministers To Discuss Peace Plan
description: Four Central American foreign ministers planned urgent talks here today to analyze a peace plan forged by the Presidents of four Latin American nations last weekend.

title: GENERAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 9.568 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, up from 9.542 percent at last week's auction.

title: Rebels Said to Kill 80 In Peruvian Village Raid
description: Maoist guerrillas joined by peasant sympathizers attacked a remote Andean hamlet in central Peru and killed as many as 80 pro-Government villagers, the local police reported today.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $27,169,000 from the sale of tax benefits.

title: A-PLANTS: INSURABLE RISKS?
description: As New York grapples with the controversy over evacuation plans for nuclear power plants, the fundamental question is: How great is the risk? Should the public believe industry assurances that an accident is so improbable that ''perfect'' evacuation plans are unnecessary?

title: Baxter Travenol To Yield 7.31%
description: A $42.5 million financing by the Puerto Rico Industrial, Medical and Environmental Authority on behalf of Baxter Travenol Laboratories was tentatively priced by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group with 7 1/4 percent bonds at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 7.31 percent to 1988.

title: THRIFT INSTITUTIONS EXTENDING ROLE AS EQUITY PARTNERS
description: As the state and Federal governments relax banking regulations, allowing thrift institutions to broaden their activities, the shift has had an indirect effect on real estate development.

title: Morgan Stanley Picks Head of New Tax Unit
description: For years, Morgan Stanley & Company has been what Richard Fisher, a managing director, calls a ''glaring exception'' among major securities firms because it has not had large operations in taxexempt securities.

title: Secret House Session The Third Since 1830
description: The secret session of the House of Representatives today was only the fourth time in more than a century and a half that the House has barred its doors to the press and visitors.

title: Senate Panel Calls For Talks on Space Tests
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee adopted a resolution today calling for negotiations with the Soviet Union for a moratorium on space testing of antisatellite weapons.

title: HOWARD BANK reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,250,000 for the quarter and 6 months from an exchange of stock for debentures. c-Including and extraordinary gain of $35,548,000 for the exchange of stock for debt.

title: Lightning Halts Practice
description: The Tuesday afternoon practice ended 40 minutes early because of lightning. Practice normally runs from 9 to 11 A.M. and from 3 to 5 P.M. daily except Sunday, when there is no morning workout.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $118,000 for the quarter and income of $259,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including a nonrecurring pretax gain of $11,254,000 on the sale of stock.

title: DONALDSON LUFKIN & JENRETTE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Teen-Ager Shot At Summer School
description: A teen-ager was shot in the back today by another student in a classroom while they were attending summer classes at the Farley Middle School, according to the police.

title: THE POST IN HOUSTON ON BLOCK AS OWNERS NOTE OTHER INTERESTS
description: The owners of The Houston Post said yesterday that they wanted to sell the newspaper because of ''tax considerations and changing interests of shareholders.''

title: Universal Adds Two TV Stations
description: The Universal Communications Corporation has agreed to buy two television stations - WJIM-TV in Lansing, Mich., and WKBT-TV in La-Crosse, Wis.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,872,000.

title: Van Munching to Raise Spending for Its Imports
description: Van Munching & Company, importers of Heineken beer and Amstel Light, is putting enormously increased ad budgets behind the two brands - a summertime media splash as it were.

title: CALIFORNIA BREAKS BUDGET DEADLOCK AS REDISTRICTING FIGHT SHAPES UP
description: Ending an 19-day deadlock in which the state had been technically insolvent, California legislators passed a new state budget today and then dug in for a Christmas season election battle on reapportionment that is expected to be one of the more costly in the state's history.

title: Republic Steel Narrows Loss
description: The Republic Steel Corporation yesterday reported a net loss of $45.4 million for the second quarter, an improvement compared with the loss of $85.2 million in the second quarter last year.

title: Kleindienst Recovers Right to Practice Law
description: Former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst was reinstated as a member of the Arizona bar today after a one-year suspension for perjury.

title: JERSEY JOINING CITY IN HELPING THE DISPLACED
description: New York City and New Jersey state officials agreed today to establish a task force to care for more than 1,000 displaced city residents sent to live temporarily in hotels in New Jersey and to come up with a timetable for relocating them in New York.

title: OPEC FAILS TO PICK SECRETARY GENERAL
description: The 13 member nations of OPEC agreed here today to postpone the appointment of a Secretary General and to continue debate on long-term strategy at their next regular meeting in December.

title: AMSTED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: End of Road for Kaat
description: Two weeks after he was dropped by the St. Louis Cardinals, Jim Kaat, the only pitcher to play 25 major league seasons, says he has given up hope of signing with another club and has accepted the fact that his career is over.

title: Warning on Knight
description: The executive director of the Los Angeles County Human Relations Commission has warned that ''there may be tension, demonstrations, who knows what,'' before next summer's Olympic Games in Los Angeles unless Bobby Knight, the coach of the United States basketball team, makes a further apology for remarks he made about Puerto Ricans four years ago. The official, Eugene Mornell, issued the warning after disclosing that the commission was pressing for a ''clarifying'' statement from Knight and Olympic officials.

title: 500 AT NASA MUSEUM HONOR THE CHALLENGER CREW
description: ''This is one of those occasions which is pure joy -to welcome back these people who have been a little bit outside our world,'' said Phillip S. Hughes, the under secretary of the Smithsonsian Institution, as he looked out over the the crowd of more than 500 people who had gathered in the Langley Theater of the National Air and Space Museum Monday evening.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PEPSICO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S. MEDICAL PROJECT TAILORED TO SALVADORANS' URGENT NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Deficits' Effect On Growth
description: MARTIN FELDSTEIN, the chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, has told the nation's county governments, meeting in Milwaukee this week, that they should expect not more but less Federal help because it is essential to shrink the share of gross national product going to domestic spending ''if we are to avoid perpetual deficits or unacceptable tax increases.''

title: HOCKEY MEANS JOY FOR OLD TIMERS
description: Every Monday night, from fall until spring, for 18 years now, 20 men - an engineer, a psychiatrist, a Greek teacher and a 75-year-old minister among them - have gone out into the night at about 9:30 and not returned home until the early hours of the new day.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
2D VICTIM DIES FROM LIGHTNING AT JONES BEACH
description: A second man has died after being struck by lightning Monday at Jones Beach in a thunderstorm. Lightning from the storm, which hit the beach near Freeport, L.I., shortly after 4 P.M., killed Steven Ahlstrom, 27 years old, after he had apparently fallen asleep while sun-bathing near an isolated part of the beach. Mr. Ahlstrom, an aspiring actor who lived at 362 West 52d Street and who worked as a waiter in a Manhattan restaurant, was pronounced dead at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

title: Expansion Keeps U.S.F.L. Busy
description: While the United States Football League was staging its first championship game last weekend in Denver, the league's competition committee was meeting there to plan for the first expansion draft later this summer.

title: Perkin-Elmer Selects AC&R for Some Units
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., has selected AC&R Advertising of New York to do its corporate advertising as well as advertising for its Instrument and Data Systems groups.

title: AMERICAN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1 million for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 6 months. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1983.

title: UNITED BANK F S B reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COLT IS PURCHASED FOR WORLD-RECORD $10.2 MILLION
description: A sheik bid a world-record $10.2 million tonight for a colt by Northern Dancer at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale, more than doubling the old world mark.

title: BACARDI CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PEKING IS LOW-KEY ON ARMS TO TAIWAN
description: China has responded with uncharacteristic mildness to the Reagan Administration's plan to sell $530 million worth of military equipment to Taiwan, directing its displeasure instead toward a dispute over transit visas.

title: Bristol-Myers To Build Center
description: The Bristol-Myers Company announced plans to build a new 192,000-square-foot pharmaceutical research center in the New Haven area costing $45 million and to be ready in 1985. Initially the new center will contain the basic research units in the company's antiinfective, anticancer and central nervous system therapeutic areas.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CYCLIST'S WIFE ENDURES 'MAN'S WORLD'
description: L'ALPE-D'HUEZ, France, July 19 - Like many American women, Anne Anderson likes to visit her husband at work now and then, ''just to understand better what he does and how he does it,'' as she puts it. But her husband, Phil Anderson, rides bicycles for a living and she finds that she is most unwelcome when she pays a call, especially on the Tour de France, the world's premier bicycle endurance race.

title: THE CITY;
description: A woman who said she was struck by an automobile after she was let off a city bus at an unauthorized stop in 1977 has been awarded $2.2 million by a Manhattan jury.

title: ROTELCOM INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Dr. Kissinger's Surgery or Massage?
description: It might have been arms control, and should have been the Middle East. Instead, it is the palpable dread of disaster in Central America that has impelled the Reagan Administration to seek the help of Henry Kissinger.

description: The winning of the Irish Tourist Board account by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Coseopulos of Boston has speeded up the agency's planning for a New York office that was already in the works to service Wang Laboratories, the computer company.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Indonesian Volcano Erupts
description: Mount Calo, a 984-foot volcano on Una-Una, 1,625 miles northeast of here, erupted for the third straight day today. There were no reports of casualties. About 1,600 people on the beach waiting for ships to take them to Central Celebes, newspaper reports said.

description: * Computed on revised capacity base of 16.3 million barrels a day.Source: American Petroleum Institute

title: Chaim Grade Awarded Prize for Jewish Fiction
description: Chaim Grade, a Yiddish poet, novelist and short story writer, has been named the posthumous winner of the first Harold U. Ribalow Prize, administered by Hadassah magazine.

description: b-Includes a gain of $8,307 from a tax credit. c-Net income includes an extraordinary credit of $16,612.

title: Dollar Bonds Firm in London
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds overcame some professional selling to hold steady late today at their early firmer levels, dealers said.

title: MALTA BLOCKS CLOSE OF EAST-WEST TALKS
description: Malta refused to yield today on its demand for a special conference to consider security problems in the Mediterranean, preventing the closing here of the nearly three-yearlong conference on East-West relations in Europe.

title: MANVILLE SUIT ASKS U.S. TO PAY ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: The Manville Corporation, asserting that the Government did not protect shipyard workers from the health hazards of asbestos during World War II, sued the United States today to recover money Manville has paid to some of those workers as a result of court awards or settlements of claims.

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Loss Widens for National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation reported a second-quarter loss of $99.2 million, reflecting a $100 million write-off for the proposed sale of its Weirton Steel division. The company lost $48 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Doctor's World column in Sci- ence Times yesterday misidentified Dr. Steven C. Beering. He is president of Purdue University.

title: JUNE STARTS IN HOUSING DOWN 2.9%
description: The start of construction on new housing in June fell 2.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.75 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 20, 1983; The Economy
description: Construction of new housing fell 2.9 percent during June, the Commerce Department reported. The new-housing starts had surged 19.5 percent in May, to the highest level in three-and-a-half years. Analysts predicted further retrenchment if mortgage rates, which have climbed to 14 percent, do not recede. (Page D1.)

title: Books Of The Times
description: FRANZ LISZT, VOL. I: The Virtuoso Years, 1811-47. By Alan Walker. 481 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $25.

title: Officer in Jersey Shot by Suspect
description: A Linden police officer was in guarded condition today after being shot in the face by a robbery suspect who he then shot to death, authorities said.

title: Tennis Spinoff
description: It started a few years ago in North Conway, N.H., while many of the world's foremost tennis players sought to kill time as they awaited their turns in the Volvo tournament. The Americans began playing pickup softball games.

title: British Gas Pipeline
description: Britoil P.L.C. said the $146 million northern leg of a gas pipeline to collect gas from the most northerly British North Sea fields has been put into use three months ahead of schedule. Britoil has been construction manager for a partnership with the British Petroleum Company P.L.C. and Conoco Inc.

title: CITICORP'S NET INCOME RISES 53.3%
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that the sharply increased profitability of its consumer business pushed up its second-quarter net income by 53.3 percent, to $210 million, from $137 million in the same period of last year. Per share earnings rose 50 percent, to $1.59, from $1.06.

title: New York City Bond Sold Out at Lower Yield
description: Strong demand for New York City's $150 million bond issue enabled underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group to reduce yields for short- and long-term bonds. Despite the reductions, the issue was sold out either to investors or to other securities firms.

title: Rich Pace to 12-1 Shot
description: Shannon Fancy, a 12-1 shot, won the $1,062,000 Sweetheart Pace for 2-year-old fillies and equaled a track record at the Meadowlands tonight.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GIVING MANAGERS NEW TOOLS
description: With the wave of an academic wand and the turn of a tassle, more than 50,000 students will soon be admitted to the ranks of American management. Thanks to the wonders of an M.B.A., they will have compressed perhaps a decade's worth of experience into an intense, two-year program that distills the essence of management. As luck would have it, my fellow graduates and I have arrived just in time to bear the brunt of a storm of criticism over the training and performance of American managers.

title: Ford Sets Layoffs At Rouge Mill
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had begun to lay off 425 workers and to close a portion of its troubled River Rouge steel mill outside Detroit following the collapse of contract talks with the United Automobile Workers that were aimed at reducing labor costs at the facility.

title: Halas Doing Well
description: George Halas, the 88-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears, is doing ''very well,'' following intestinal surgery at Northwestern Memorial Hospital last week, according to his physician, Dr. Neil Stone. Halas was hospitalized twice earlier this year.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: NOT too long ago a group of strangers were assigned to the same table at a charity benefit. The conversation was stimulating, and when the evening drew to close someone said, ''We must keep in touch!'' The men, all business executives, were in black tie, but they reached into their pockets, produced business cards and handed them around. The women were also business executives and they too were in evening dress, but they did not have business cards. Without exception, they borrowed pens and scribbled their names and telephone numbers on scraps of paper and place cards.

title: POLICE AND FIRE UNIONS TO END JOINT BARGAINING
description: The unions representing New York City's firefighters and police officers will no longer negotiate labor contracts together. The decision came in the wake of a dispute that has ruptured the coalition of 35,000 uniformed workers.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest second quarter reflect a provision for the closing of the company's Alumoweld Products division plant in Glassport, Pa.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $196,000, or 8 cents a share from sales of real properties. c-Includes a gain of $48,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Lions Trade Star End
description: Al Baker, the Pro Bowl defensive end who has been unhappy with the Detroit Lions, has been traded to the St. Louis Cardinals in exchange for the defensive tackle Mike Dawson and a draft choice. Dawson, who suffered a serious knee injury in 1980, started every game for the last two seasons.

title: GIGA-TRONICS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $69,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Brazil Group Near Default
description: The Matarazzo industrial group said today that it is unable to repay debts of about $120 million and has asked banks to reschedule its loan payments.

title: REAGAN IS TIGHTENING GRIP ON ARMS-CONTROL POLICY
description: President Reagan has acted to take responsibility for arms control policy away from the State and Defense Departments and place them in the hands of William P. Clark, the national security adviser, White House officials said today.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PAY-TV MERGER RULING SEEN
description: The participants in a proposed merger of the second- and thirdlargest pay-televison channels said yesterday that they expected the Justice Department to decide soon whether to accept a new proposal with guarantees of how the merger would operate.

title: BYRON KENNEDY, 33, PRODUCER OF FILM, 'THE ROAD WARRIOR'
description: Byron Kennedy, an Australian film producer whose movie "The Road Warrior" was an international hit, died after the helicopter he was piloting crashed into a lake on Sunday, the police said today. He was 33 years old.

title: MATTER OF MOTIVE, AND OF PARKING
description: The petunias and geraniums in the concrete planters that are used to keep traffic off East Executive Avenue near the White House are providing a colorful facade for a curious episode of territorial aggrandizement.

title: Law on Drug Items Upheld in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court unanimously upheld a law today that makes it a crime to sell or possess drug paraphernalia.

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NUTRITIONISTS ASSESS FEDERAL MEAL PLANS
description: HOW good are the United States Department of Agriculture's meal plans for low-income families? During the last few months, the department has been conducting a series of well-publicized workshops in various cities, Atlanta, Boston, Washington and Camden, N.J., among them, to show families how to shop and eat nutritiously on food stamps. The workshops are constructed around meal plans for a typical food-stamp family of four, consisting of a mother and three children 3 to 5 years old, 6 to 11 and 12 to 14.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $375,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $750,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: 7 and $6 Million In Cocaine Seized
description: A series of raids in northern New Jersey has resulted in the arrests of seven people accused of being ''drug brokers'' and the seizure of $6 million worth of cocaine stuffed in an air-conditioner, Prosecutor Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. of Hudson County said today.

title: BLACK COLLEGES' FAILURE TO DRAW WHITES IN SOUTH IS FOCUS OF DESEGREGATION SUIT
description: Several times a week, about three dozen white students from the local branch of Auburn University drive across town to Alabama State University for Air Force R.O.T.C. classes. That is the only time this many white students are on the campus of Alabama State, which has 12 whites among its 4,044 students.

title: Mexico Allows Debt Payment
description: Mexico, suddenly finding itself with foreign exchange to spare, said today that it would allow private companies to pay off some of their short-term debt to foreign creditors sooner than originally planned.

title: TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for As of June 30.
LIFE OF PEACE AND CALM ON THE ISLANDS SOMETIMES HAS ITS PRICE
description: HONOLULU July 15 - Not all of life here is sunbathing, surfboards and gentle trade winds. Last Nov. 23 it was Hurricane Iwa, and on July 13 it was a burn-off in a cane field, to remind everyone here that, regardless of tall buildings, congested traffic and comfortable life, this is a city on an island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.

title: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Bridge: 2 World Team Champions Lead in Life Master Pairs
description: Two reigning world team champions led into the final session of the Life Master Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League here tonight, with a group of formidable players in close pursuit.

title: AT STATE MOTOR VEHICLE OFFICES, TRAFFIC JAMS
description: Thousands of telephone calls and letters to the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles are going unanswered this summer, and thousands of motorists are waiting in line for hours to take driving tests and get licenses and registrations.

title: Injuries Deplete Cosmos
description: The Cosmos have been so badly depleted by injuries that Coach Julio Mazzei is thinking of keeping Hubert Birkenmeier, his No.1 goalkeeper, on the bench as a reserve striker in Wednesday night's game here against the Seattle Sounders.

title: Rockwell and Iveco
description: The European Economic Commission has given Iveco B.V., a subsidiary of Fiat, and the Rockwell International Corporation of the United States an 11-year exemption from Common Market restrictive business practice laws for a joint project to build truck drive axles, officials said today.

title: ZENITH'S CHANGING STRATEGY
description: In the late 1970's, the Zenith Radio Corporation was known as much for its crusade against Japanese imports as for its television sets. Lately, however, Wall Street analysts have been impressed because the company has abandoned this quixotic battle and refocused its energies on cutting manufacturing costs and capitalizing on its historically strong research efforts.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRAVES MATURE INTO WINNERS
description: Joe Torre does not gloat about it, but the irony of it is there in Atlanta Stadium: The Mets, who dismissed him, have the worst record in baseball. The Atlanta Braves, who hired him, have the best.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART
description: MUSIC'S quintessential Wunderkind had to vie for time with Mendelssohn and Haydn at Monday's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall. The program opened with a sweetly lyrical performance of Haydn's Symphony No. 6 in D, called ''Le Matin'' by the composer.

title: Monsanto Net Up 31%
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter climbed 31 percent, to $114 million, or $2.76 a share, from $87 million, or $2.17 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Second-quarter revenues, however, slipped to $1.6l billion, from $1.62 billion. The St. Louis-based company noted that results in last year's second quarter included a $9 million loss associated with its withdrawal from the European low-density polyethelene business.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $6 million, or $2.9 million after tax, on the sale of Bankers Trust Co. of Western New York and a nontaxable extraordinary gain of $4.3 million from the reacquisition of certain of the corportion's long-term debt. c-Includes a pretax gain of $24.3 million, or $14 million after tax, on the sale of the corporation's credit-card business.

title: ROY RADIN: LIFE AND DEATH IN SHOW-BUSINESS DEMIMONDE
description: The following article is based on reporting by Leslie Bennetts and Frank J. Prial and was written by Mr. Prial.

title: NVESTIGATOR WHO REVELS IN ROLE: JAMES HAMILTON
description: ''Jim Hamilton's one of the best lawyers of his age,'' former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said in a telephone interview from his home in North Carolina. ''They couldn't do better.''

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 11.
INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: SRI LANKA GROUP
description: ONE of the most joyful and exciting dance events of the year took place at New York University's Loeb Student Center on Monday, when the Kandy Dancers and Drummers of Sri Lanka gave a single performance of traditional Ceylonese dance and music. There was fire-eating and drum-spinning, a human whirligig and a deer hunt. And throughout, in this American debut performance presented by the Temple for Spiritual Research and Learning in New York, there was dancing and drumming of great energy, acuity and charm.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Feb. 25 and July 18.

title: CASEY EXPLAINS FINANCIAL PLAN
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, explained today that his decision to put his large investment portfolio in a blind trust was intended to end ''misunderstandings'' about his allowing a professional investment counseling concern to manage stock and bond purchases and sales for him amounting to several million dollars.

title: A WARNING ON CHILD ENCLOSURES
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission says collapsible wooden enclosures designed to keep small children out of danger have contributed to the deaths of three youngsters.

title: HEIZER CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Threats Cited In Laker Case
description: Major European airlines have acknowledged in court papers that they threatened economic reprisals against two United States companies if they proceeded with plans to help save Laker Airways from bankruptcy. But the airlines denied their action had helped the carrier's collapse.

title: Nynex Chairman-to-Be Introduces Phone Unit
description: More than 2,300 of the 54,000 shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company met in Boston yesterday with Delbert C. Staley, chairman of the New York Telephone Company.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Pepsico Net Drops 18.4% in Quarter
description: Pepsico Inc. yesterday reported an 18.4 percent decrease in earnings for its second quarter, ended June 11, and cited ''continuing difficulties in key international soft-drink markets'' as the main reason for the decline.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
description: b-Net income.

title: Prisoners Use Phones To Run Up Others' Bills
description: Inmates of a county jail spent thousands of dollars on long-distance calls, money orders, flowers and Candygrams by tapping into a local phone service and Western Union, the authorities said today.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
JEFFERSON AWARDS GO TO NINE, INCLUDING VOLCKER AND ACTORS
description: The actor Kirk Douglas, one of nine people honored today for public service, urged Americans to open their arms to the world's homeless and hungry.

title: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Low Protein in Wheat Is Problem for Millers
description: With the winter and spring wheat harvests nearly completed, flour millers and bakers have had some of their worst fears confirmed: The protein content of this season's crop is down for the second year, and protein wheat is essential for making bread and hard rolls.

title: Sports of the Times; Of Morals, Politics And Football Skill
description: T he awards committee of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame is supposed to announce today what to do about the canonization of Billy Cannon.

title: Senate Gets Aid Bill for Nuclear Power Plant
description: The United States Senate's Appropriations Committee today passed on to the full Senate an amended bill that would make it possible to raise money to finish a Washington State nuclear plant on which construction recently halted for three years because of a lack of financing.

title: Bad Bullpen Error
description: TORONTO I f this had been Kansas City, Mike Armstrong said ruefully, then the incident could never have happened. In the Royals' home ball park, the bullpens are not part of the playing field, and so relief pitchers can attend to their usual diversions without being concerned about having to evacuate the area on short notice.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1982.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Cuomo and Church Leaders Meet in Brooklyn on Housing
description: Governor Cuomo went to Brooklyn last night to tell church leaders that the state would provide $7.5 million in low-interest mortgages to spur a housing and commercial redevelopment plan.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BRAZILIAN SEEKING NEW LOANS IN U.S.
description: The governor of the central bank of Brazil, Carlos Langoni, flew to the United States last night to seek $3.6 billion in fresh loans to help the country remain current in its debt payments, a spokesman for the central bank said yesterday.

title: Dancer's Crown Dies in Surgery
description: Dancer's Crown, a leading 3-year-old trotter owned by Stanley Dancer, died during surgery today at Cornell University's Veterinary Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., the owner's son, Ronnie Dancer, said. The colt, who won 10 straight races until beaten July 3, was stricken with colic Monday morning. Dancer's Crown was the 2-year-old trotter of the year.

title: UNITED STATES INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes gains attributed to two acquisitions consummated in January of $800,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,800,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months, and income of $578,000 from discontinued operations for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $646,000 for the quarter and $1,197,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $4,000,000, or 17 cents a share, for the 6 months associated with litigation settlements.

title: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NOXELL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Company Accused Of Bidding Scheme
description: A Long Island contracting company and its president were indicted yesterday on charges of taking part in a bid-rigging scheme aimed at the State Transportation Department and the Suffolk County Public Works Department.

title: AS PROPOSALS LANGUISH, TAXI PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: More than a year ago, a blue-ribbon mayoral panel recommended sweeping changes in the New York City taxi industry. Six months later, Mayor Koch endorsed several of the recommendations, saying that as a result ''there will be positive and visible improvements in taxi service.''

title: GRUMMAN AND NAVY IN ACCORD
description: The Navy and the Grumman Corporation have agreed that the aircraft maker, once threatened with interrupted production, would continue building F-14 fighters and A-6 bombers into the 1990's, according to Congressional, Navy and industry officials.

title: Queens Symphony Grant
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra has received a $60,000 grant from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, an 8 percent increase over last year's award. The orchestra said the money will be used to help pay for a children's educational concert, its free ''Pops in the Parks'' concerts and its discount-ticket program for students and the elderly.

title: Trevino Wants Trade
description: Alex Trevino, the former Mets catcher who was traded to the Cincinnati Reds before the 1982 season but lost his starting position before the season was over, said he wanted to return to the Mets. ''I live in New York,'' Trevino said, ''and I really believe they need a catcher.''

title: PHILLIES' ROOKIE FAILS IN BID FOR NO-HITTER
description: Charlie Hudson, a rookie for the Philadelphia Phillies, pitched eight and a third innings without giving up a hit tonight before Craig Reynolds of the Houston Astros sent a single to center. The Phillies went on to beat the Astros, 10-3, after Hudson yielded two home runs.

title: WHERE DID ALL THOSE (PLASTIC) FLAMINGOS GO?
description: Although plastic was brought into industrial use in 1909 by L.H. Baekeland of Yonkers, it was not until after World War II that the modern miracle substance was used in a wide variety of consumer goods, among them speedboats, dentures and flamingos. Previously flamingos were made of cement. Before that they were made by God.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bengal Counterraid
description: The Cincinnati Bengals, who will be losing two starters to the United States Football League, have decided to retaliate by recruiting players from the same U.S.F.L. teams that signed the Bengals' veterans. Bengals officials said they had begun negotiations with Eric Truvillion, a leading U.S.F.L. receiver who plays for the Tampa Bay Bandits, the team that signed the Bengals' wide receiver, Cris Collinsworth, to a future contact for the 1985 season.

title: REVUE: STORY OF EDITH PIAF
description: THE Blue Note, the well-known jazz club, recently started its new theater series with the musical play, ''Piaf: A Love Song,'' a three-character revue chronicling the life of the Parisian singer. While songs associated with Edith Piaf have long been staples of North American cabaret, Miss Piaf's streetwise volatility eludes most performers, who prefer to re-invent her as a middle-class ''art'' singer.

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
No Word on Kidnapped Girl As Deadline Passes in Rome
description: A midnight deadline passed early today with no word on whether kidnappers had fulfilled their pledge to kill the abducted daughter of a Vatican messenger unless Mehmet Ali Agca, the papal assailant, was freed.

title: HOUSE, BY 220-207, AUTHORIZES FUNDS FOR MAKING THE MX
description: The Reagan Administration won a narrow but crucial victory tonight on the MX missile system. By a vote of 220 to 207, the House decided to authorize $2.6 billion in the coming fiscal year to produce the first 27 of the intercontinental nuclear weapons, which are to be deployed in underground silos in 1986.

title: METS DEFEAT BRAVES WITH RUN IN EIGHTH
description: After two catastrophic games in which they blew big leads, the Mets restored some order tonight and defeated the Atlanta Braves, 3-2.

title: A BACKFIRING WEAPON
description: ASAT, yet another acronym, has begun to invade the news columns. One is told that it is an antisatellite - a device that can destroy a satellite. But that still leaves many unanswered questions.

title: ASTRAL BELLEVUE PATHE LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
Chock Full In Riese Deal
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached real estate agreements with the Riese Organization, a New York restaurant and real estate operator, that, it said, would provide additional income to Chock Full of more than $1.8 million annually for up to 25 years.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
