New Visa Cards
description: In an attempt to control counterfeiting losses that amounted to nearly $11 million last year, Visa International will redesign its cards, putting into effect several new security measures, the company said. The new design will include a border of microprinted bank identification codes, an embossed security symbol and a trademark of a dove in flight that can only be seen under an ultraviolet light. The new design will also include a hologram or lenticular print of the dove in a security panel that will cover the last several digits of the account number. D.W. Hock, president of Visa International, said that would help prevent unauthorized changes in the account numbers.

title: CRAIG HARRIS'S HORN HELPS KEEP UP JAZZ HERITAGE
description: ''I DON'T think about trombone when I play,'' Craig Harris said the other day. ''I just think about music and improvisation.'' But since the late 1970's, when he began appearing in virtually every important new jazz ensemble, Mr. Harris has certainly made other jazz musicians and composers think about the trombone and its capabilities. While the trombone was eclipsed in post-1950's jazz by saxophones and guitars, such players as Roswell Rudd in the 1960's and George Lewis, Ray Anderson, Joseph Bowie and Mr. Harris in the 1970's kept up both sides of the instrument's jazz heritage - its noble, declamatory tone as well as the lowdown slides, sputters, growls, roars and ''tailgate'' noises that only a trombone can make.

title: NEW BREED OF MANNEQUINS
description: They're slim, beautiful and young, and time brings no wrinkles to their brow or cellulite to their thighs. Their hair is always immaculate and their nails never break. Sometimes they look like an idealized girl next door and sometimes they have a to-die-over elegance. They are, both literally and figuratively, clothes horses - the mannequins used by stores to display their newest fashions. Can they make the flesh and blood people gazing at them believe that they, too, would look like that if only they bought the right things to slide over their imperfect bodies? That's certainly the idea.

title: HATSHEPSUT'S STRATEGY OF PEACE FOR EGYPT

The reason for her action was not mentioned, yet that reason is known.

title: THEATER ADVENTURES UNDER A STRAW HAT

It is a fling in the midst of a lark, a vacation within a vacation. It is a walk in the woods before the curtain rises, a cool evening breeze at intermission, a sky full of stars at play's end.

title: Short-Term Rates Are Steady
description: Confusion over the near-term direction of interest rates sharply reduced activity in the credit market yesterday. Dealers said that short-term Treasury discount rates were basically unchanged, while prices of long-term Treasury coupon issues closed moderately lower with attendant rises in yields after a late flurry of selling. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds closed off as much as a quarter point in in equally dull trading.

title: NEARLY 40,000 LOSE ELECTRICITY IN FIERCE STORM

Areas of Long Island and New Jersey were hardest hit by the storm, which knocked down power lines and trees, delayed air travel and commuter trains and forced a halt to the Diana Ross concert in Central Park. Rain, hail and winds of up to 50 m.p.h. were reported.

title: Watergate Revisited
description: D uring Watergate summer 10 years ago, most New Yorkers were glued to their television sets. As PBS prepares to rebroadcast highlights from the hearings next week, the hearings appear to remain very much in people's minds, a random sampling around town in the last few days showed.

title: '83 BLUE JAYS: THE BIRDS OF PARADISE
description: The turnabout, Toronto baseball historians note, actually began during the second half of last season when teams in the American League East were preoccupied with the pennant race and thus failed to notice. It was then that the Blue Jays ceased being philanthropists, treating opponents like worthy causes. It was the first time, really, that they began to base their chances of winning on factors other than whether Dave Stieb was their starting pitcher.

The game finished with an 11.9 national Nielsen rating (the percentage of all television sets across the country) and a 23 percent share (the perecntage of sets in use).

title: NASHVILLE CITYBANK & TRUST CO (TENN) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Cigna Acquisition
description: The Cigna Corporation is buying Crusader Insurance P.L.C., a British concern, for about $123 million, a Cigna official announced. David W. Schrempf, president of Cigna's international division, said the move is part of the company's longrange plans to expand international insurance operations. Cigna already has direct insurance operations in 48 countries and representation in an additional 100, he said. Mr. Schrempf said Cigna was especially interested in Crusader's life insurance division, which accounted for 70 percent of its business last year.

title: Wynegar Profiting In Piniella's 'School'
description: In days gone by, if a fragilely built man was tired of having sand kicked in his face at the beach, he sent away for the Charles Atlas exercise program. With the Yankees these days, if a player is tired of having a fragile batting average, he inquires about the Lou Piniella hitting program.

title: YELLOW FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DANCE: 'PRIVATE LIVES,' CHAMBER DRAMA BY SYNERGIC THEATER
description: THE appeal of mixed-media, nonverbal theater has been particularly strong among experimentalists in dance, drama and the visual arts. The Synergic Theater, a company from Durham, N.C., that made its New York debut Wednesday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, falls well within this current. Nonetheless, the group, which performs through tomorrow night at the theater at 221 East 71st Street, speaks with its own fresh regional accent.

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,600,000 from the exchange of common stock for debentures. c-Includes a gain of $18,000,000 from the divestment of two businesses.

title: Economic Analysis
description: With a few puffs on his cigar, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, did what many a summer tennis player would like to do - change the out-of-bounds lines in the middle of the game.

title: Consumers Union Adds Agency to Miller Suit
description: The Consumers Union announced yesterday that it had added the Backer & Spielvogel agency to an earlier suit against the Miller Brewing Company. The action, which charges the brewer with misleading advertising for its use of Consumer Reports material in an ad, seeks compensatory and punitive damages of at least $1 million each.

title: CLUETT PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income of $5,000 for the quarter and a loss of $295,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations and a loss of $500,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Including income of $441,000 for the quarter and a loss of $165,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: O'BRIEN SIGNS FOR FUTURE ROLE
description: He had missed the first three days of practice at the Jets' training camp here, and when he finally threw a football this afternoon, he took his turn behind two other rookie quarterbacks.

title: Stocks, After Slide, Rise; Dow Up 1.51
description: A late burst of buying helped stocks close slightly higher yesterday, after trading lower most of the day on heavy volume. Analysts said it was normal for a market to lose a little steam the day after a strong rally. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.74 points, its biggest one-day gain in almost eight months. Yesterday the key market measure closed up 1.51, to 1,229.37. Volume declined to 101.8 million shares, from 109.3 million the day before. The number of stocks advancing in price slightly outnumbered those that declined, 886 to 766.

title: Better Facilities
description: New Jersey authorities will hold a hearing on Tuesday to decide if Tony Ayala, the junior middleweight boxer who was convicted of rape last month, can serve his 35-year sentence in a prison with a highly developed boxing program. Ayala, being held temporarily at the Yardville Youth Correction and Reception Center, hopes to be assigned to Rahway State Prison, where an active prisoners' boxing program has sophisticated training equipment and an occasional nationally televised bout.

title: Flxible Sale
description: The General Automotive Corporation, Ann Arbor, Mich., said it had completed the acquisition of the assets of the Grumman Corporation's Flxible bus subsidiary for an undisclosed amount of cash, notes and preferred stock.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: RICHARD FARNSWORTH, the star of ''The Grey Fox'' (a Canadian movie at the Baronet) has been getting the kind of notices generally reserved for Laurence Olivier, and he is pleased, amused and embarrassed in just about equal parts. Mr. Farnsworth started his movie career in 1937 in ''Marco Polo.'' ''They wanted about 400 Mongolians to come chargin' off a mountain,'' he says, ''and a bunch of the kids around the barn went over, and we got a job.''

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said directors declared a two-for-one stock split and increased the quarterly dividend. The stock split is effective on shares outstanding on Aug.1, the record date. The quarterly dividend on the post-split shares was increased to 4 1/2 cents, from an adjusted 3 3/4 cents, payable Oct.12 to stockholdders of record Sept.21.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
description: b-Including tax credits of $348,805 for the quarter and $643,081 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $198,329 for the quarter and $336,625 for the 6 months.

title: 'Midsummer Night's Dream'; With a Latter-Day Look
description: B abies in carriages, babies on parents' backs, kids on bikes (and one on stilts), teen-agers chatting in Spanish - the West Side Community Garden's first go at Shakespeare brings out a neighborhood audience.

title: WESTCHESTER VILLAGE IS STUNNED BY TWO MURDERS IN FOUR DAYS
description: For seven years this Westchester County village had gone without a murder. ''We mainly had to deal with the smaller crimes,'' said Police Chief Anthony M. Quatroni. ''Petty larceny, a stolen bicycle here and there.''

title: AT BATTERY PARK CITY, 'PIONEERS' LIKE LIFE
description: The Brooks Brothers crowd at the corner of Liberty and West Streets every evening is familiar. What is strange is the direction the young professionals take home from another working day in lower Manhattan.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AVX CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $602,000.

title: UNITED STATES TOBACCO CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Ford Price Rise
description: The Ford Motor Company, the nation's No.2 auto maker, said it planned to increase prices on its 1984 model cars by an average 2.3 percent, or $200 an auto. The increases range from 1 percent on small autos to 3.3 percent on larger cars. The General Motors Corporation, the largest United States auto maker, and the Chrysler Corporation, the No.3 auto maker, plan similar increases.

title: INDICTMENT OF REAGAN: NO BROTHER'S KEEPER
description: President Reagan has said that the American economy is rapidly rebounding from the recession. Only tax increases or a return to ''undisciplined'' spending on social programs now threaten the nation's ''hard-earned'' recovery.

title: No Headline
description: Steven Crist on Horse Racing YEARLINGS TOO RICH FOR MOST BLOODLINES

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid July 30.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Gift-Wrapped Water Tower
description: O n the skyline, sunset puts their conical ''hats'' in silhouette, evoking pagodas. What may appear as pagodas are actually water towers, and locals may forget that not all cities need them to boost the pressure of water from reservoirs.

title: BRIEFING
description: Computer Fraud and Abuse

title: Baldwin Policy Rates Are Cut
description: An order lowering the interest rate paid on the single-premium deferred annuities sold by an Arkansas subsidiary of the Baldwin-United Corporation was signed by Judge Perry Whitmore of Pulaski County Circuit Court in Little Rock.

title: WHITE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,800,000 before taxes from the sale of a division.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RISKING WAR FOR WHAT?
description: Where is the Reagan Administration's hardline policy against the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua taking us? Public opinion in the United States seems not much concerned, but the Mexican Government fears that the militaristic Reagan approach may lead to war between Nicaragua and Honduras at almost any time.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a charge of $10.4 million, or 42 cents a share, from a downward adjustment of coke inventories.

title: The U.N. Today; July 22, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 'CLASS,' TALE OF AN AFFAIR
description: ''CLASS'' is like the donkey who found himself at equal distances between two bales of hay and starved to death. The movie can't make up its mind whether it's a lighthearted comedy, set in what appears to be a posh New England-style prep school just outside Chicago, or a romantic drama about a teen-age boy who has a torrid affair with his roommate's mother. Either way it's pretty awful.

title: PENN BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SIGHTS AND SOUNDS OF CYPRUS AT A FOLK FESTIVAL IN ASTORIA
description: A Greek wedding in Cyprus is a gala affair, full of drinking and dining and spirited folk dancing. Clapping and stamping and slapping their feet, the male guests dance together, and then the women follow suit. Each dance tells the story of an old fairy tale, and in recounting it, each dancer tries to outdo the last. Finally, at midnight, the bride and bridegroom dance together. Their friends gather round them and, while they dance, pin money to their costumes, to wish them luck in their life together.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Sets Acquisition Of D.A.Y.
description: THE independent public relations firm has become more and more of an endangered species as the stronger ones continue to be gobbled up by the nation's growth-hungry advertising agencies.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Mass Grave in Chad For 30 Soldiers Reported
description: Chad said today that it had found a mass grave of 30 Government soldiers who it said were put to death several days ago by rebel units acting on Libyan orders.

title: COX COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ROCK: Z Z TOP, A TRIO THAT HAS CHANGED
description: Z.Z. TOP rolled out of Texas in 1969 with the basic trio sound of the time - a stomping, guitar-centered rock that was half power chords, half blues licks behind lyrics about getting drunk and having a good time. Through touring and sheer persistence, Z.Z. Top worked its way up to gold albums and the arena circuit without changing its sound.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
MEI CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $335,000, or 2 cents a share, from a reduction in income tax reserve.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CONAIR CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings do not reflect the company's previously announced 3-for-1 stock split which is payable Aug. 26.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring credit of $5,500,000. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in April 1983.

title: Uniroyal Profit Surges
description: Uniroyal Inc. said today that a rebounding auto industry helped lift its second-quarter profit to $25.2 million, or 83 cents a share, from $8.1 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest results included a $5.6 million gain in an exchange of equity for debt. Uniroyal's sales of chemical, rubber and plastic products grew to $546 million from $541 million.

title: PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2 percent common stock dividend paid June 30, 1983.

title: UNION VOTE LIKELY TODAY ON EARLY CHRYSLER TALKS
description: Local union leaders at the Chrysler Corporation are expected to vote Friday to begin early contract talks intended to win immediate pay increases from the newly prosperous company.

title: Senate Panel Backs Volcker
description: The Senate Banking Committee approved by a 16-to-2 vote today the reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Northeast Utilities Begins a Financing
description: Northeast Utilities Inc. of Berlin, Conn., yesterday offered 3 million shares of common stock at $12.40 a share, through an underwriting group managed by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: DELAY SEEN ON I.M.F. HOUSE VOTE
description: Prodded by the Reagan Administration, the House began debate today on the $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund. But both Democrats and Republicans said it would take a stonger push by the President for the bill to be approved, and a vote was not in sight.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. Results are in U. S. dollars.

title: 5 VARIETIES OF FRENCH MODERN DANCE
description: The rehearsal lights cast an early-morning chill over the stage and empty theater. The dancers' ragged practice clothes and hum of inquisitive chatter are familiar. But the command that suddenly cuts through that hum has a different ring. ''O.K., gar,cons et filles,'' a small, alert figure calls from the auditorium. ''Un, deux, trois ... '' French modern dance has come to New York.

title: PUBLISHING: DEALING WITH THE DELINQUENT AUTHOR
description: BURT REYNOLDS is more than a year overdue with his autobiography, so the actor's lawyer said this week they have notified Arbor House that they will return the six-figure advance.

title: SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Company noted that earnings per share are not relevant before the second quarter of 1982 since the bank had no shares outstanding prior to its initial public offering March 9, 1982.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP INC (WATERBURY, CONN) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Company reported that due to a $3.3 million allowance for loan losses in their international loan portfolio there were no per share earnings in the 1982 second quarter.

title: Apology, of Sorts
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad issued an apology of sorts yesterday for the cancellation of his light heavyweight title bout against the champion, Michael Spinks, last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those who poison the land must pay for its cure.'' - Justice Stewart G. Pollock of the New Jersey Supreme Court. (A1:1.)

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 22, 1983
description: International Plans for major naval maneuvers off Central America were defended by President Reagan at a brief news conference. He said it would be ''extremely difficult'' to bring stability to the region as long as the Sandinista Government remained in control of Nicaragua. Mr. Reagan said he ''would hope'' there would be no need to impose a naval blockade of Nicaragua to stabilize Central America. (Page A1, Column 6.) The formal lifting of martial law was announced by Poland's Government. But the end of 19 months of military rule is expected to make little difference in the lives of Poles because many of the controls have been institutionalized into the regular legal code and Parliament passed a series of special regulations to insure the authorities a firm grip on political and economic life. (A1:3-4.)

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Brazil Banker In Debt Talks
description: Carlos Langoni, governor of the central bank of Brazil, said today that he had received a ''concrete response'' from the Inter-American Development Bank and the World Bank on a request to speed up loan payments.

title: 150 Are Hurt in Mexico As Students Protest
description: A line of police motorcycles, followed by riot squads, plowed through at least 3,000 student protesters today at the city's major intersection.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HOCUS-POCUS OR POLICY?
description: The principle of seeking a basic bipartisan policy on Central America is a good one. The main concern about the United States in the rest of the world, friend and foe alike, is lack of continuity in its approach to foreign affairs.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Death Toll Rises to 7 After Terror at Orly
description: The mother of a teen-age boy killed in last Friday's bomb attack at Orly Airport has died, officials announced today, bringing to seven the total dead in the explosion at a Turkish Airlines counter.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
The Worm and the Apple; Quieter / Cleaner; New Brooms
description: That adolescent energy is awesome is a given. That it is seldom properly channeled is a fact. But for once that great force of nature is getting a good workout: 600 New York teen-agers are spending the summer cleaning subway stations.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
CURBS NOW PUT IN LEGAL CODE
description: The Polish Government announced today the longawaited, formal lifting of martial law. But the end of 19 months of military rule is expected to make little difference in everyday life. Many of the controls under martial law, imposed to break the independent trade union Solidarity, have been institutionalized in the legal code. And today, Parliament enacted a series of temporary regulations to insure a continued tight grip on political and economic life. Today Is a National Holiday

title: BEGIN BEATS CENSURE MOTION
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in leading the Israeli Parliament to reject an opposition motion censuring his Government for its overall performance, declined today to respond to charges that his emotional condition was interfering with his duties.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE FINAL DOCUMENT AND AN ANNEX AT THE EAST-WEST TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from the final document of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and an annex, as made available to The New York Times: Final Document Questions Relating To Security in Europe

title: Cantonese dining in a modish setting.
description: SINOPHILES can be forgiven if they do not recognize the starkly modish black-and-white setting of Auntie Yuan as a place to dine on Cantonese food. If it weren't for the chopsticks on the beige tablecloths set with Wedgwood drabware, the black Fitz & Floyd plates with pink flowers and the simulated bone-handled silverware, these stunning three-month-old premises might be mistaken for a restaurant serving nouvelle cuisine.

title: NEW QUAKES JOLT COALINGA AREA
description: A pair of earthquakes jolted the area near Coalinga tonight, knocking out electricity and starting grass fires as power lines fell, state and utility officials said.

title: DOWNTOWN FLUSHING GETS HIGH-RISE CONDOMINIUM
description: After building four low-rise condominium projects in Queens during the last four years, the Briarwood Organization has embarked on its first high-rise condominium, an 80-family building in downtown Flushing.

title: 'LIQUID SKY,' HIGH FASHION AND A U.F.O.
description: SLAVA TSUKERMAN is a Soviet emigre who has lived in New York City since 1976, apparently long enough for him to get the lay of the land. Mr. Tsukerman's ''Liquid Sky,'' which opens today at the Waverly, presents a vision of the city that is genuinely startling. His film, with a heroine who is sometimes a hero and who is apt to show up in a red corset with matching red-and-blond skunk hairdo, can hardly be for everyone. But the right audiences are bound to appreciate the originality displayed here, not to mention the color, rage, nonchalance, sly humor and ferocious fashion sense.

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,000,000 from an exchange of Textron stock for certain outstanding debentures.

title: G.E. Plant Change
description: The General Electric Company has announced a $60 million renovation of its refrigerator production plant here and said it expected a loss of 1,000 of its 13,500 jobs by mid-1986, when the changes are completed. The project is part of a $100 million, systemwide renovation program.

title: Officer Kills Man In IRT Shootout
description: A transit police officer, using his reserve gun, shot and fatally wounded a Bronx man on a subway train in the Bronx Wednesday night after the man had grabbed the officer's service revolver and shot him in the right foot, authorities said.

title: JORGENSEN, EARLE M, CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
A CALL FOR 'DESCALATION'
description: It's time for the word "descalate" to enter the language, for Congress to learn what it means - and to have the courage to act on it.

title: LABOR STATISTICIAN DISAGREES
description: President Reagan said at a White House news conference today that most unemployed people had been without jobs for only a short period, but a statistic he cited to prove his point was immediately called into question by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including $9.2 million resulting from a Supreme Court decision.

title: NORTON'S CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Esmark Inc. yesterday sweetened its offer for Norton Simon Inc. by $1.50 a share, to $35.50, all of it in cash, and Anderson, Clayton & Company, the only other serious bidder, said it was ending its quest for Norton Simon.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $61,937,000 from an accounting change.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ITALIAN SOCIALIST MAY BE NEW CHIEF
description: The Socialist Party leader, Bettino Craxi, was formally asked tonight to form Italy's 44th government since World War II. If Mr. Craxi succeeds, he would become the nation's first Socialist Prime Minister.

title: Economic Scene; Inching Ahead In Recovery
description: WHEN Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was doing the advance billing at his confirmation hearing a week ago for the policy decisions just taken by the Federal Open Market Committee, he said, ''I don't think you'll find those decisions terribly dramatic.''

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FIRST PANDA BORN IN U.S. DIES IN ITS MOTHER'S ARMS
description: Afer seven years of anticipation by her keepers at the National Zoo, Ling-Ling gave birth today to America's first panda cub, but within three hours the baby died.

title: Board of Estimate Aids Daily News
description: The key elements of a plan to help The Daily News shift most of its printing operations to Brooklyn were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Measles at 0 for a Week
description: For the first time in six months, no measles cases were reported in the United States last week.

title: Defender Takes 2 From Courageous
description: In southwesterly winds that built from 8 to 17 knots on hazy Rhode Island Sound, Defender today won two races from Courageous in the trials to select the America's Cup defender.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SHERMAN E. ROSE
description: Sherman E. Rose, chairman of Subaru of America, automobile importers, died of cancer on Sunday at Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Camden, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: A Rich Rookie
description: The Green Bay Packers signed their No. 1 draft choice, Tim Lewis, to a contract that reportedly includes a $500,000 signing bonus. Lewis, a defensive back taken in the first round from the University of Pittsburgh, signed a series of four one-year contracts. His agents, Craig Massey and Steve Weinberg, said the pact, reportedly for $2 million including a loan and incentive clauses, made him the highest-paid rookie defensive back in the history of the National Football League.

title: EGYPT MISSES AN INTEREST PAYMENT ON $2.1 BILLION ARMS DEBT TO U.S.
description: Egypt has failed to make the latest interest payment on its $2.1 billion military debt to the United States, financial sources said today.

title: U.S., Japan Bonds Advance
description: United States and Japanese convertible bonds moved sharply higher this morning, then firmed in quiet trading, dealers said.

title: Reagan's Latin Envoy May Meet Sandinistas
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, is to meet here Friday with Nicaragua's Foreign Minister and another Nicaraguan official, Mexican officials said today.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 13.
LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Belgian Captures 19th Leg of Tour
description: Lucien Van Impe of Belgium won the 19th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, finishing the 9.3 miles from Morzine to Avoriaz in 35 minutes 9 seconds.

title: AMERICAN APPRAISAL ASSOCIATION INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $8,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $148,000.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,433,000 and a gain of $210,666,000 on the disposition of the company's medical division.

title: ADVANCED PHYSICS TEACHING
description: Dr. Elbert P. Little, a physicist and educator who helped devise a revolutionary physics study program for secondary schools in the late 1950's, died Tuesday of Alzheimer's disease in Falmouth, Mass. He was 71 years old.

title: On the Mend
description: John Roman is one of the strongest Jets, able to bench-press 540 pounds. But yesterday he spoke of how pleased he was to be able to raise his left elbow to ''eating height.''

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ENDATA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $85,000 for the quarter and $11,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago share earnings are omitted because the company was a subsidiary during these periods.

title: Diamonds in Hamptons.
description: VACATIONERS in the Hamptons will have the chance to bid, mostly for jewelry, at an auction that Phillips, Son & Neale is holding July 30 at 6 P.M. in the Bridgehampton Community House, Montauk Highway at School Street. Of the 409 lots, the two expected to bring the highest prices are emerald-and-diamond designs - a necklace of 5 carats of emeralds and 9.5 carats of diamonds, and a bracelet of 5.5 carats of emeralds and 20 carats of diamonds. Each may sell for up to $15,000. The star of the sale carries a much lower estimate, It is an Art Deco cocktail shaker in the shape of a rocket ship, a German design in chromed zinc from about 1935 that is expected to sell for up to $600.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Order for Only English Leads to a Complaint
description: A complaint against Mayor Thomas Dunn has been filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission after City Hall employees were told to speak English only, even during private conversations, while on the job. The Puerto Rican Legal Defense Fund filed the complaint.

title: A SINGER, A THRONG IN CENTRAL PARK, A DELUGE
description: Driving rain, lashing winds and lightning forced Diana Ross to cut short her concert in Central Park last night with hundreds of thousands of her fans sprawled before her on the Great Lawn.

title: AMERICAN DISTRICT TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GERBER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AMERICAN IS FREED WITH HELP OF SYRIA
description: David S. Dodge, the acting president of American University in Beirut, who was abducted last year, has been freed with the help of Syrian leaders, the White House said today.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
News Analysis
description: Many of the human rights provisions that the West has been promoting for nearly three years at the Madrid conference on European security and cooperation have been watered down or omitted altogether in the final document, but enough remain for Western negotiators to say they have made a decent bargain with the Soviet Union. The catchword, now that the end of the conference is in sight, is ''balance.'' It is heard from diplomats from both NATO and Communist countries, and it reflects the idea that the ''Helsinki process'' - the reviewing and updating of the 1975 accords that codified detente -can advance only by consensus among the 35 nations involved.

title: TRANS WORLD OFF
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, yesterday reported a huge increase in profits for the second quarter, mostly from tax benefits. Earnings rose to $116.3 million, or $3.39 a share, from $5.5 million, or 18 cents a share, in the 1982 quarter.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Randy Gradishar, the Denver Broncos' linebacker, said he would retire at the end of next season, his 10th with the club. The Broncos' No 1 draft choice in 1974, Gradishar has made six Pro Bowl appearances. ... John Hannah, the All-Pro guard who recently retired from the New England Patriots after a series of disputes with Coach Ron Meyer, said yesterday that he was not reconsidering his decision and would not return to the team, as the club had suggested in a statement issued on Wednesday. ... Bob Lanier, the Milwaukee Bucks' center, underwent knee surgery, and club officials said he was expected to resume light workouts within three weeks and be ready for training camp.

title: Heileman Plans
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said it would expand its brewery in Baltimore to increase the plant's capacity by 30 percent, and would expand its Frankenmuth, Mich., brewery to increase the capacity by 50 percent. Costs of the two projects were estimated at $32 million.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income including a gain of $18.1 million for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of oil and gas properties.

title: People
description: * Lawrence M. Rau has been appointed senior vice president and director of creative operations, Chevrolet creative, at the Campbell-Ewald Company.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
TV Satellites Assigned
description: Government officials said today that the International Telecommunication Union had assigned to the United States eight orbits for television transmissions by satellite. The system, known as direct broadcast satellite, uses small dish antenna receivers. The companies that have approval to use the system in the United States are CBS, RCA, Western Union, Direct Broadcast Satellite, Graphic Scanning, United States Satellite, Video Satellite Systems and Comsat.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisition of Louisville Two Way Radio Service.

title: 2 WOMEN BECOME PREGNANT WITH TRANSFERRED EMBRYOS
description: A team of California doctors reported yesterday what it said were the world's first two pregnancies achieved as a result of a technique in which an embryo is transferred from one woman to another.

title: A History of Oz
description: An exhibition tracing the history of ''The Wizard of Oz'' will be at the Donnell Library Center of the New York Public Library, 20 West 53d Street, all this month. Books about the magical land of Oz, memorabilia of the several ''Oz'' authors who followed L. Frank Baum and stills from the 1939 movie as well as toys and games connected with it are featured. The exhibition also covers staged versions from 1902 to the 1976 musical ''The Wiz.'' Open today from 12:30 to 5:30 P.M.; tomorrow 12:30 to 8 P.M.

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a capital gain equal to 17 cents a share from the sale of a unit.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Consumer Saturday column on July 9 incorrectly described propoxy- phene, a drug sold under brand names including Darvon. It is used to relieve pain.

title: Study Questions Benefit Of Low Nicotine Content
description: People who smoke low-nicotine cigarettes may absorb as much nicotine as they would smoking regular brands, doctors said in the July 21 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: PRIME COMPUTER'S REVERSALS
description: When Joe M. Henson left a 27-year career at International Business Machines to take the reins of the Prime Computer Corporation 18 months ago, industry experts said he was a seasoned manager who would bring discipline to the company while helping it to continue a decade of extraordinary growth.

title: CRIME FIGHT AIMS AT BROOKLYN
description: The East New York section of Brooklyn will be the target of a twoyear, $120,000 crime-prevention program announced yesterday by the New York City Partnership and the Eisenhower Foundation for the Prevention of Violence.

title: ALLIED ENDS PACT WITH GAF
description: The Allied Corporation and the GAF Corporation said yesterday that they had terminated an agreement under which Allied would have bought GAF's chemical group because of Allied's fears that it would be at risk for some of GAF's asbestos-related liabilities.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: CONCERT: CURRAN'S MUSIC AND BURCKHARDT'S FILMS
description: THE New York performing avant-garde moves out of doors in the summertime, or at least out of its customary haunts and into odder public spaces scattered about the city. The principal entrepreneur of such excursions in recent years has been an organization called Creative Time, which this summer is sponsoring both the Art on the Beach series at the Battery Park landfill and another series called Art in the Anchorage.

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
KAISER CEMENT & GYPSUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. The year-earlier 6 months net includes nonrecurring after-tax gain of $4.7 million, or 65 cents a share, from sale of property.

title: Moral Heights and Economic Subways
description: Ever since Governor Cuomo said he deemed transportation for the disabled to be a moral and not an economic question, we've been wondering how he distinguishes. All important governmental decisions involve the morality of apportioning pain and satisfaction as well as the economics of balancing costs against resources.

title: CSX Locomotives
description: The CSX Corporation announced plans to purchase 51 new diesel-electric locomotives from a General Motors Corporation subsidiary at a cost of more than $47 million.

title: MEDICAL DIRECTOR OF HARLEM HOSPITAL IS DISMISSED
description: The medical director of the troubled Harlem Hospital Center has been dismissed by the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, the medical school that provides care at the municipal hospital.

title: DR. JOSEPH SAFIAN
description: Dr. Joseph Safian, an early plastic surgeon, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at the Miami Heart Institute.

title: ENSERCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
UNITED STATES GYPSUM CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a charge of $2,100,000 from the sale of Canadian roofing plants.

title: A POLICE COMMISSIONER FOR STRICT GUN CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,020,000 from the sale of investments. c-After a loss of $88,000 from the sale of investments and a gain of $4,518,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: MERRILL BANKSHARES CO (BANGOR, ME) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Money Fund Assets Decline
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $30.7 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $165.5 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Bill to Honor Dr. King Gains
description: The House Post Office and Civil Service Committee voted today, 20 to 1, to designate the third Monday in January as a legal holiday in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, which is Jan. 15. Representative William E. Dannemeyer, Republican of California, voted against the measure.

title: DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS TELL OF COMMITMENTS TO MEDICARE
description: Democratic Presidential candidates appealed today for support from the elderly, whose representatives said health care costs and the future of Medicare would be an important issue in the 1984 election.

title: Boys' Kidnapping Brings 2 Arrests
description: Two men have been arrested on charges of luring three teen-aged Bronx boys from a movie theater to a Queens apartment, where the youths were held captive and sexually abused, the police said yesterday.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
Reggae Festival Opens In Chelsea Tonight
description: ''Breakdown, Babylon, Breakdown,'' a three-day reggae festival with films, dance and theater performances and workshops, a photography exhibition and live music is being presented this weekend by Plexus, the performance loft at 516 West 25th Street run by the International Center for Urban Resources. The program in Chelsea begins tonight at 9 with films about Ethiopia and Jamaicans in Britain, followed by the first part of a ''choreo/ception'' called ''Black Woman Sweet, Eh!'' at 10 and a performance by the band Moja Nya at 11.

title: BRINK'S JUDGE OUSTS 3 DEFENDANTS FROM COURTROOM
description: The three Brink's defendants were ordered from Orange County Court this morning after an argument with the presiding judge in a dispute over meetings with their legal advisers.

title: ARTHUR M. WIRTZ, TEAM OWNER, DIES
description: Arthur M. Wirtz, a wealthy real-estate man who owned the Chicago Black Hawks hockey team and was a principal owner of the Chicago Bulls basketball team, died today at the age of 82. He had long been suffering from cancer and had been in Henrotin Hospital here since shortly after his wife's death last Dec. 28.

title: Red Sox, Up 9 Runs, Win in 10th, 14-13
description: Marty Barrett scored from second base when the left fielder Steve Henderson failed to hang onto Tony Armas's two-out line drive in the 10th inning to give the Boston Red Sox a 14-13 victory over the Mariners tonight.

title: KOCH NEWSLETTER TELLING THE PUBLIC HOW HE IS DOING
description: Mayor Koch has begun publishing a news-letter about his administration and sending copies free of charge to racial, ethnic and civic groups around the city.

title: RETROACTIVE LIABILITY OF POLLUTERS UPHELD BY NEW JERSEY COURT
description: Companies that spilled hazardous wastes must pay for cleanups no matter how long ago the spill occurred, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Less Aid to World Bank Seen
description: The United States plans to reduce the amount it gives the World Bank for loans to nations in need, sources at the bank said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Clairol, a subsidiary of Bristol-Myers, has appointed Michael E. DeGennaro president of the professional products division.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Triangle Industries announced that it would file later this month for an offering of subordinated debentures, and warrants to purchase common stock, but no further details were available. Common Stock

title: A Walk in the Village
description: A walking tour of the East and West Village sponsored by the Municipal Art Society will leave Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, at 2 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Encore Plans Acquisitions
description: The Encore Computer Corporation, a new venture headed by Kenneth G. Fisher, the former president of Prime Computer, said today that it would act as a holding company for a number of existing computer technology concerns, but officials declined to specify which ones.

title: CON ED PROGRESS CITED
description: A tentative agreement was reached yesterday in the 6-day strike by employees of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and a Federal mediator reported the ''foundations'' of a settlement in the 34-day strike by employees of the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on July 2 about the sweetener aspartame incorrectly reported its potency. It is 200 times as sweet as sugar and two-thirds as sweet as saccharin, another noncaloric sweetener.

title: BROADWAY
description: FOUR years ago, Russell Baker, reporter and columnist for The New York Times, found himself in the middle of one of the most colorful stories of his career. He had written the book for a Broadway musical that opened out of town and was in deep trouble. Like countless Broadway authors before him, Mr. Baker went to work day after day feverishly rewriting the show. But at night, in the solitude of his Toronto hotel room, his journalistic instincts took over. He recorded all the gory details of the experience in a diary.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
description: b-After a loss of $233,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $509,000 from discontinued operations. There were no share earnings for the latest second quarter because preferred dividend exceeded net income.

title: 'Career Criminal' Drive Leads to 928 Arrests
description: A 10-week crackdown on career criminals in Michigan produced 928 arrests of fugitives wanted on felony charges ranging from murder and rape to drug violations, the United States Justice Department said today.

title: REAGAN PLEDGES ACCESS TO PAPERS IF CARTER'S FILES ARE ALSO COMBED
description: The White House has offered a House subcommittee total access to President Reagan's campaign documents, ''but only if, in fairness, the subcommittee would agree to conduct such a review of the Carter White House and campaign files.''

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. There were no share earnings for the year-ago quarter after payment of preferred share dividends. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal Stock Exchanges.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,285,000 for the quarter and $1,377,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $59,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest second quarter include net income of $5,341,000, or $1.11 s share, attributable to the settlement of litigation with General Electric Co. Year-ago 6 months results include 76 cents a share attributable to gain from a real estate transaction and a contract closeout, both occuring in the first quarter.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: U.S. DIVESTITURE'S PRICE TAG
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE ORDERS U.S. TO PUT MOST OF FORT WADSWORTH IN GATEWAY AREA
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the United States Interior Department must accept most of Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island for inclusion in the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
THE EVENING HOURS
description: RUDY the doorman almost ruined Tuesday night's surprise farewell party for Robert Pearson, who is g iving up hairdressing to open a Texas-style barbecue restaurant in S tratford, Conn.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend in May.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a pre-tax loss of $339,617,000. c-Net income.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
VACATION DELAY TO SPEED CASES IN CITY'S COURTS
description: Eight additional courtrooms in State Supreme Court will be open this month and next to speed up the processing of felony cases and thus ease the overcrowding of jails, New York City's top court official said yesterday.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includng a gain of $468,000, or 18 cents a share, from the sale of the company's Electronic Packaging product line. c-Net loss.

title: 2 Sentenced in Slaying Of Professor in Florida
description: Two young men accused of the ritualistic slaying of Prof. Howard Appledorf, a proponent of the nutritional benefits of ''junk food,'' have been sentenced to life in prison after changing their pleas to guilty.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
METS' TORREZ LOSES 12TH
description: Mike Torrez, who was brought to the Mets this season as a senior role model for the younger pitchers, gave a record-setting lesson tonight in what not to do.

title: British Find Heroin; Arrest 3
description: British investigators said today that they had arrested a woman and two men after finding heroin valued at $3.8 million at Heathrow Airport. A spokesman said a 35-pound package of heroin was found wrapped in a blanket in the luggage of an Asian woman arriving from New Delhi with a stopover in Frankfurt. The discovery was described as the third largest ever made in Britain.

title: RIVAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
JUSTICE DEPT. FILES A PLAN FOR MINORITY HIRING
description: The Justice Department today filed a plan for hiring women and members of minorities for department jobs, 19 months after the plan was scheduled to be submitted to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: PASSENGERS GRAB MAN AND FOIL HIJACKING ATTEMPT
description: A man with a knife tried to hijack a Northwest Orient Airlines flight to Cuba today, but three passengers and a flight attendant overpowered him. He was arrested when the plane landed in Miami, officials said.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The per share figures are fully diluted.

title: LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $258,000 from the early retirement of pollution control revenue bonds for the quarter and 6 months and the 6 months also includes a gain of $1.1 million from a change in accounting for some supplies. c-Net loss

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Robintech Inc. Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: Robintech Inc., a pipe manufacturer, has filed a petition in United States Bankruptcy Court, asking for protection from its creditors while it attempts to reorganize its troubled finances.

title: GIULINI LEAVING POST AT LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC
description: Carlo Maria Giulini, the Italian conductor, will end his six-season tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic when his contract expires in September 1984. His poor health and that of his wife have been cited as the principal reasons for his leaving.

title: TURNPIKE BRIDGE IN CONNECTICUT REOPENS TODAY
description: The Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike will be reopened today to automobile traffic only, Connecticut's Transportation Commissioner said yesterday.

title: CITY INVESTING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $24.6 million from discontinued operations and a gain of $26.4 million from an accounting change.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
No Order Too Tall To Halt Dan Ford
description: Before his three-home-run performance against Seattle Wednesday night, Dan Ford, the Orioles' hard-hitting right fielder, had missed 25 games with an inflamed left knee.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Canada Ltd. said it had agreed to import and distribute vehicles made by Automobiles Peugeot of France, and that beginning Oct.1, it would have exclusive distribution rights.

title: SQUARE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The company said results do not reflect the 10 percent stock dividend declared May 19.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Dear Mr. President
description: Lately I've been reading a lot about how members of your party are worrying about something called the ''gender gap.'' A recent poll, for instance, showed that 57 percent of men but only 39 percent of women approved of your handling of the Presidency.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include a gain of $1.1 million, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of a unit.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani SLOUCHING TOWARDS KALAMAZOO. By Peter De Vries. 241 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $13.95.

title: WARNER POSTS A $283.4 MILLION LOSS
description: Warner Communications Inc. yesterday announced a staggering $283.4 million loss for the second quarter, a deficit much larger than had been expected by Wall Street analysts or previously indicated by the company.

title: FEMINIST LEADER MOVES TO QUASH MURDER CHARGE
description: An attorney for Ginny Foat, the former president of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women, asked a state district judge here today to quash the murder charge against her.

title: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

Year-ago share earnings are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split on June 30. Year-ago revenue figures have been restated.

title: AFFILIATED HOSPITAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
EX-E.P.A. AIDE'S TRIAL ON CONTEMPT CHARGE BEGINS
description: The trial of Rita M. Lavelle for contempt of Congress began here today with testimony by three prosecution witnesses that she had failed to appear as commanded at a March 21 subcommittee hearing. Her attorney said this was not ''willful commission of a crime.''

title: AMERICAN BRANDS, PHILIP MORRIS RISE
description: Two of the nation's three largest tobacco companies yesterday reported improved second-quarter earnings, while the third posted a decline.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S. THREATENS TO EXPEL ENVOY IN ASSAULT CASE
description: The United States has threatened to expel a high-ranking North Korean diplomat because his mission has been protecting a junior official from arrest for sexual abuse, aides in the United States delegation said today.

title: Trip to 2 Old Mansions
description: A day trip to historic houses and gardens will leave tomorrow at 9 A.M. from the New York Botanical Gardens on Southern Boulevard in the Bronx.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a tax credit of $601,000.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Foes of Whaling Say Colleagues Will Be Freed
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to hand over at sea seven Greenpeace activists arrested at a Siberian whaling station on Monday, a spokesman for the environmentalist group said here today.

title: Syria Claims Israeli Drone
description: Syrian troops shot down a pilotless Israeli reconnaissance plane today in Lebanon's eastern Bekaa region, the Damascus radio reported. Israel said the Syrians had fired antiaircraft missiles but no planes had been lost.

title: IF MOSCOW GAINS A FOOTHOLD IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: PAT HERNON
description: Pat Hernon, a radio broadcaster for WINS and a former sportscaster for NBC-TV, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Pelham Manor, N.Y. He was 59 years old.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
11 States Get E.P.A. Warning
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that 11 states were in violation of the Clean Air Act because they had failed to carry out inspection and maintenance programs to assure that controls to curb automobile tailpipe emissions were functioning properly.

title: 2 Die as Explosion Levels Sewage Treatment Plant
description: An explosion wrecked a sewage treatment plant today, killing two people and injuring more than a dozen others, the authorities said.

title: Simpson Takes Lead With a 64
description: Scott Simpson, playing in 102-degree temperature and high humidity, tied the course record with a 7-under-par 64 and took a 2-shot lead today in the first round of the $350,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: Saudi Investor Buys Stake in Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, a company with no shortage of aggressive, internationally known senior executives and major shareholders, now has another strong presence to contend with. Suliman S. Olayan, a Saudi Arabian investor with major holdings in several other American companies, has become the largest single holder of its common stock through a company he controls.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $3,725,000 for the quarter and $5.7 million for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $812,000 for the quarter and $2,781,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary credit of $675,000 for the 6 months.

title: Times Co. Payout
description: Directors of The New York Times Company increased the dividend on the company's class A and class B common stock yesterday to an annual rate of $1.40 a share, from $1.22 a share.

title: Marion Spitzer Thompson; Wrote Books and Screenplay
description: Marian Spitzer Thompson, the author of five books and a screenplay, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old and a longtime resident of New York City.

title: Soviet Weighs Joining Olympics
description: A Soviet official said today that his country had yet to decide if it would take part in the next summer's Olympics here. The official, Vladimir Mikoyan, press officer at the Soviet embassy in Washington, said that the security of Soviet athletes and the crime rate in Los Angeles, not deployment of United States missiles in Europe, would figure in the decision.

title: Waiting Game
description: Joe Bugel, the Washington Redskins' offensive line coach who played a key role in molding last season's championship team, said he had held discussions about coaching the new Pittsburgh franchise of the United States Football League, but had decided to stick with the Redskins for at least one more season. ''I just told them if they were still interested at the end of the season, fine,'' said Bugel, a Pittsburgh native, who said he had discussed the coaching post with the new club's owner, Edward DeBartolo Sr.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split which was effective last month.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: BIG V SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 25.
IT'S BACK TO MAINE FOR SCHOOLGIRL WHO DISARMED THE RUSSIANS
description: An 11-year-old American girl who has been the centerpiece of a Kremlin effort to enhance its image as a peacemaker ended a two-week visit here today during which she was showered with gifts, greeted by stadiums full of young people and otherwise treated as a major celebrity.

title: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1983.

title: DEBATE ON REPORTING OF NASHVILLE SCANDAL REOPENS
description: A new book has set off a lively debate about how the state's best-known newspaper, The Nashville Tennessean, reported a state official's fight against corrupt bosses.

title: A Challenge in Texas Lures Chicago Banker
description: Thomas Wageman, a Chicago banker with a reputation as a specialist in working out problem loans, will soon become a Texas banker with a bigger set of problems.

title: The City Game
description: Earl Monroe, the former Knick guard, learned his game of slick ball handling and graceful, creative moves while playing basketball on South Philadelphia's crude asphalt playgrounds. After three years of retirement, Monroe is going back to the playgrounds.

title: Kodak Introduces Blood Analyzer
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a computerized blood analyzer that it said is twice as efficient as competing products. The instrument, the Ektachem 700, is expected eventually to give Kodak a substantial share of the $1 billion a year clinical chemistry market.

title: Transcript of news session, page A4.
description: President Reagan, defending plans for largescale naval maneuvers off Central America, said today that it would be ''extremely difficult'' to bring about stability in the region so long as the Sandinista Government remained in control of Nicaragua.

title: BLUE RIDGE REAL ESTATE CO/ BIG BOULDER CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Woman's Beard Costs Job
description: Beverly Bonnell says she was dismissed from her job as a front desk clerk at the Y.M.C.A. because she refused to shave off her wispy black beard. Vivian Katagion, her supervisor, said that although the beard was unacceptable, Mrs. Bonnell was not dismissed but quit. Mrs. Bonnell contended she had been told she would be dismissed if she refused to shave and added, ''This is a Christian organization and they don't understand the body God gives you.''

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Bank and Iran Settle Claims
description: The Treasury Department today announced an agreement between Iran and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York to resolve a dispute over blocked assets that grew out of the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in November 1979.

title: COURT BACKS C.I.A. AIDE'S WIDOW
description: A Federal appeals court opened the way today to the possible public disclosure of Government records in the mysterious 1978 death of a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: TRIP CANCELED BY WEINBERGER
description: The Defense Department announced today that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had postponed plans to visit the Naval Supply Center in Oakland, Calif., and had canceled plans ''for any personal time on the West Coast.''

title: BUSINESS COMPUTING INTERATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago 6 months results since the company changed its fiscal year-end to Nov. 30 from Dec. 31.

title: Trials Postponed By High Winds
description: The United States and foreign trials to select the America's Cup defender and challenger were postponed today because of a strong northwesterly wind with gusts up to 40 knots.

title: NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SUSPECTED HEAD OF OMEGA 7 TERRORIST GROUP SEIZED
description: The man who is believed to be the leader of Omega 7, the anti-Castro terrorist group, was arrested in Miami yesterday afternoon. According to Federal authorities, Omega 7 has been one of the most active terrorist groups in the United States. It has taken responsibility for at least two murders and more than 30 bombings in Miami, New York, New Jersey and Washington in the last seven years.

title: ALCOA DOUBLES NET; DISTILLERS DOWN
description: The Aluminum Company of America, citing increased aluminum shipments, said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than doubled from a year earlier while revenues edged up 1.6 percent. The profitable quarter followed three consecutive periods of losses.

title: Reagan's Latin Envoy Ends Talks in Mexico
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, left here today after meetings with Mexican officials.

title: IF SPACE WEAPONS PROTECTED ALL ON EARTH FROM NUCLEAR ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: 21 DIE IN FIGHTING
description: The International Airport here came under rocket fire today and heavy artillery duels followed between Lebanese Christian and Moslem Druse militia forces in the nearby mountains.

title: MICHIGAN SUGAR CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $157,000 for the quarter and $536,000 for the 6 months and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $438,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $56,000 for the 6 months.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 23, 1983; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose only 0.2 percent in June and 2.6 percent over the last 12 months, the Labor Department reported. The 12-month rate was the lowest in 15 years, a new sign that inflation has been checked. (Page 1.) In the New York metropolitan area, consumer prices fell 0.5 percent. (39.)

title: TEXAS BANK UNIT GETS TAKEOVER BID
description: Texas American Bancshares Inc. said today that its board had received a takeover offer from Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., Houston, worth $50 a share, or $460 million total, and that its board would consider the proposal early next week.

title: HOW TO SAVE CAPITAL: SCATTER IT
description: We are a unique nation and we deserve a unique capital. We don't have one. Washington is like every other major American city; we are up to our eyeballs in traffic, in noise, in rudeness, in congestion. A strong case may be made for the proposition that the District of Columbia is run several degrees closer to capacity than other cities are.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HARRIS-LANIER MERGER
description: The Harris Corporation will acquire Lanier Business Products Inc. in a stock transaction valued at $378 million, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: MIDLAND GLASS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 26.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Rose Kennedy Turns 93
description: Rose Kennedy quietly celebrated her 93d birthday today at her family's summer retreat on Cape Cod. The family said the celebration was a small gathering, including her son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, at the Kennedy compound overlooking Nantucket Sound.

title: Gulfstream Chief
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation's chairman, president and chief executive officer, Allen E. Paulson, announced that he had increased his stake in the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to 28.3 percent of the common shares outstanding, through open market purchases in early July. Mr. Paulson, who also said in his filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he ''expects to acquire additional shares,'' now holds 1.1 million Wheeling-Pittsburgh common shares, including 135,600 acquired between July 5 and July 13 for about $3.3 million.

title: MIDWEST FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Collins Still Glum
description: On a team whose players appear content with their roles, Dave Collins is the exception. After spending a frustrating season with the Yankees last year, Collins was traded to the Toronto Blue Jays and given the starting job in right field.

title: AMERICAN STERILIZER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $508,000 for the quarter and $639,000 for the 6 months.

title: Fujitsu Net Up By 52% in Year
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said today that net income in its fiscal year ended March 31 rose 52 percent from a year earlier on the strength of sharp increases in sales of telecommunications and information equipment.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATION OF SENTINEL SECURITIES REPORTED
description: Sentinel Government Securities, a Wall Street dealer in money market instruments and Government securities, is being investigated by a Federal grand jury for reportedly creating millions of dollars worth of fraudulent tax shelters.

title: ENSTAR INDONESIA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HISTORY OF A PEOPLE IN A CLOUD OF SMOKE
description: Cigar smoking has long languished in disrepute. To most people, it is an abhorrent habit limited primarily to aging men stuck in their ways. In Grade B movies, villains and fat cats are easily identified by the stogies jammed in their teeth. Cigars are banned in airplanes and movie theaters, while cigarettes are tolerated.

West Plans Paris Meeting On Warsaw's Debts
description: Western governments have tentatively set next Friday for a meeting in Paris with Polish officials to renew negotiations on Poland's foreign debt after an 18-month interruption, the Economics Ministry said today.

description: Andrea Jaeger rescued the United States today in its advance to the semifinals of the Federation Cup, beating Renata Sasak of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 6-3, after Candy Reynolds lost her opening match.

title: STATE ORDERS A HALT TO TAKING DISABLED OFF WELFARE
description: The State Social Services Commissioner today ordered his staff to stop removing disabled New Yorkers from the state's welfare rolls, as has been required by Federal officials.

JAPANESE FROM GROUND UP
description: One of the basic rules of dressing is that one begins with the shoes. If the shoes are not right, the entire look, known in simpler days as the outfit, is all wrong.

title: Poland's Law, Poland's Debts
description: ''Those bills are worse than the martial law regulations.'' That was Lech Walesa's comment on the new civil provisions that will replace martial law in Poland. He was not exaggerating.

title: CRASH OCCURRED IN AREA OF HEAVY AIR TRAFFIC
description: The midair collision of two small aircraft yesterday occurred in an area where - especially at this time of year - there is heavy traffic of private planes, air taxis, charter operators and government craft. It is a mix of conventional fixed-wing craft, seaplanes and darting helicopters.

title: SALVADORANS DOUBT ELECTION CAN BE HELD BY END OF YEAR
description: El Salvador's political leaders are expressing increasing skepticism about the possibility of holding a presidential election by the end of this year, as the Reagan Administration has urged.

title: Trading Housing for Virtue
description: Progressive New York legislators may care about better housing for people with limited incomes, but they care more about avoiding criticism if the tax incentives for building such housing produce profits for entrepreneurs. That's why the Legislature has just eviscerated the J-51 program to stimulate construction of privately owned apartments. As a result, there will be less subsidy, less criticism - and much less housing.

title: TWO QUARTERBACKS, ONE JOB
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. T he veterans arrived yesterday, and for the first time in years, the Giants are a football team with leverage. There is no threat of a league strike to unsettle coaches and players. Within the division, it is the Cowboys, Cardinals and Eagles who have assorted problems this summer.

title: WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Toyota Confirms Lotus Accord
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, confirmed that it had concluded an agreement in principle with Lotus Car Companies P.L.C. to acquire a 16.5 percent interest in the British car marker.

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FILIBUSTER ON MX ENDED IN SENATE
description: Opponents and supporters of the MX missile reached an agreement today that ended an 11-day Senate filibuster. They agreed to vote Tuesday on whether to authorize production of the first batch of the missiles next year. Proponents of the $20 billion system expect to win.

title:
PATENTS;
Way to Analyze Gems
description: Peter J. Gielisse of Brewster, Minn., was granted patent 4,394,580 this week for a method of analyzing gems by subjecting them to electromagnetic radiation.

title: Reversal on Remodeling Men's Shelter
description: B owing to community pressure, New York has abandoned its plan to feed the homeless served by the men's shelter on the Lower East Side in another facility while the shelter is undergoing extensive renovations.

title: DETREX CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BAYLESS, A J, MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
CITY OPERA TALKS REMAIN STALLED
description: The two sides in the New York City Opera labor dispute met again yesterday for 90 minutes, but no progress was reported in settling the strike that has forced the cancellation of all performances at the New York State Theater since the scheduled season opening on July 7.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. It is the British Open trophy, awarded to Tom Watson, the fifth he has won. 2. Israel. The weapons were captured from the Palestine Liberation Organization. 3. Strengthened. Censure. 4. The Statue of Liberty. 5. Martial law. 6. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. His testimony before the House Banking Committee calmed fears that the board would tighten monetary policy to curtail the growth in the money supply and thus push up interest rates.

title: BRIEFING
description: Bureaucratic Plastic

title: Tainted Victory
description: Rudi Koopmans of the Netherlands, the European light-heavyweight champion, used an illegal drug before his knockout victory over Mannfred Jassman of West Germany in a title bout in Frankfurt July 9, according to a West German boxing official. The official, Walter Wagner, vice president of the Federation of West German Professional Boxers, said chemical tests had found that the Dutch fighter had used a drug identified as Anabolika before the bout. Wagner said the federation would ask the European Boxing Union to annul the bout's results and strip Koopmans of his title.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Reagan and His Staff By HEDRICK SMITH GAMBLING WITH HISTORY: Reagan in the White House. By Laurence I. Bar- rett. Doubleday. 488 pages. $19.95

Studds Is Replaced in Panel
description: Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, was named Thursday to replace Representative Gerry E. Studds as head of the Coast Guard and Navigation Subcommittee of the Merchant Marines and Fisheries Committee. Mr. Studds, a Massachusetts Democrat, was automatically stripped of his chairmanship when he was censured for having sexual relations with a male Congressional page.

title: Nuclear Panel Proposes Fines Against Plant at 3 Mile Island
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed fines totaling $140,000 against the owners of the nuclear plant on Three Mile Island in connection with cheating on operator training examinations.

description: Considering all of the hot air that blows around Yankee Stadium, the Yankees finally got a nice refreshing breeze last night. But the wind that blew Don Baylor's foul ball into a game-winning single in the first game did not return to help the Yankees in the second game of their doubleheader with Kansas City.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PUERTO RICANS DISPUTE CASH FOOD-STAMP PLAN
description: Puerto Rico's program of issuing money rather than stamps to people eligible to receive food stamps has stirred controversy on the island, where more than 50 percent of the 3.1 million inhabitants qualify for the program.

title: HOWELL ADDS WEIGHT TO WIN JETS' ROLE
description: Very carefully, so that he does not upset what he calls ''the chemical balance of my body,'' Wes Howell had added 10 pounds in his attempt to win a spot on the roster of the Jets.

title: Foil to Romankov
description: Aleksandr Romankov of the Soviet Union won the men's individual foil title for the fifth time as the 30th World Fencing Championships opened today with participants from 41 countries. Romankov beat Matthias Gey of West Germany, 10-8, in the final.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day yesterday listing second-quarter gross national product figures incorrectly reported net exports. They were $10.2 billion in 1972 dollars, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate.

title: Thornburgh Signs Bill On Pennsylvania Budget
description: Pennsylvania's budget crisis has ended with Gov. Dick Thornburgh signing legislation for a $620 million additional spending plan and a $495 million tax plan to help pay for it.

title: Reitz Returns
description: The St. Louis Cardinals were short on infielders for their Triple A farm team in Louisville, so when they heard about a fellow who'd been doing well in a St. Louis softball league, they signed him. Not that it was the first they'd heard of the prospect.

title: FROM RUSSIA BACK TO 'REGULAR THINGS'
description: Samantha Smith, the 11-year-old Maine girl who toured the Soviet Union for two weeks at the Soviet Government's expense, arrived home today to a heroine's welcome with a red carpet, roses and a limousine ride to her house.

title: Seychelles Pardons 6 Foreign Mercenaries
description: President France Albert Rene pardoned six foreign mercenaries today who were jailed for their part in an attempted coup in 1981.

description: Some residents moved out of their homes today and into backyard tents, frightened by the strongest aftershock since a devastating earthquake struck the town on May 2.
