title: U.S. Told to Continue Chicago School Money
description: A Federal district judge refused today to lift his order that the Federal Government help pay for Chicago's school desegregation.

title: TRADING SCHOOL LUNCHES BROADENS YOUNG TASTES
description: Quite a bit of time and energy goes into the study of how children develop - or fail to develop - desirable academic traits, such as reading, writing and creative thought. Little attention is paid, however, to the question of one's gastronomic education. It has been postulated that infants have only one strong and universal taste predilection: sweets. Why is it that some children manage to develop wide-ranging and sophisticated palates on their path to adulthood, while others never leave the Cap'n Crunch crib?

title: WARNINGS ON RAW SHELLFISH STILL PREVAIL
description: This summer may turn out to be little better than last for New Yorkers who like their clams on the half shell or for the people who sell them. While no new cases of viral hepatitis linked to the consumption of raw shellfish have been reported since last year, tainted clams have been implicated in many cases of gastroenteritis, a mild influenzalike illness.

title: Your Money; Computing Interest Gains
description: DETERMINING the interest earned from a bank deposit is a difficult task for most depositors. Because of the frightening complexities involved in calculating this amount -and in factoring in such variables as grace days, compounding and transaction mix - most individuals simply accept the figure provided by the bank or savings and loan association on the passbook or statement.

CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Thursday about the nomination of John F. Keenan to be a Federal judge misidentified Michael F. Armstrong, a member of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's judicial screening panel. Mr. Armstrong is a Democrat.

title: BIG GAIN IN DURABLES ORDERS
description: New factory orders for durable goods rose a strong 5.5 percent in June, mostly because of orders for military equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
58 Golden (and Silver) Years
description: The growing problem at Dodo Cheney's home in Santa Monica, Calif., became slightly more complex yesterday afternoon. Her two daughters had already been given the responsibility of creating an original way to display their mother's 127 tiny gold and silver tennis balls, each one signifying a national tournament championship. Now they will have to include 128, and that number could increase again very soon.

title: Japan Auto Output Up
description: Japanese auto production rose 3.3 percent in June from a year earlier, the fifth consecutive monthly gain in output, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. Passenger cars climbed 1.1 percent, to 636,752 units; truck output rose 8 percent, to 357,628 units, and production of buses fell 22 percent, to 4,820 units.

title: STOCKS END MIXED; VOLUME OFF SHARPLY
description: Stock market prices closed mixed yesterday after trading in a narrow, choppy range. While the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.80, to 1,231.17, broader measures of the market closed marginally lower. The New York Stock Exchange index slipped 0.05, to 97.74, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 0.17, to 168.89.

title: SUBURBAN AIRLINES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Recovering From Burns
description: It was just three months ago that the jockey Randy Romero, the nation's seventh leading winner in 1982, suffered first- and seconddegree burns over 65 percent of his body when liniment used in a rubdown burst into flames while he was sweating off pounds in a ''hot box'' at Oakland Park in Hot Springs, Ark. At the time doctors said it would be at least a year before he would be able to ride again. But after being treated in three hospitals and undergoing two skingraft operations, Romero is planning to resume his career at Louisiana Downs next Thursday - if he can get clearance from his doctors.

title: 'JAWS' SEEN IN 3-D
description: ''Jaws 3-D'' is a movie with unusual timing, since its real star - you know who that is - doesn't appear until an hour into the story. By that time he (who is this time a she) has worked up quite an appetite, and proceeds to eat some tourists and employees at Sea World, in Florida. That park is the second biggest star of this movie, which is no match for ''Jaws'' but probably no worse than ''Jaws II.'' It's harmless but unsurprising.

description: At his first convention, seven years ago, Harry McDonald and his colleagues were warned not to go bowling in a group. ''People will call you names,'' a young social worker told him. Her idea of worthwhile convention activity was psychotherapy.

title: IMPORTING AIR POLLUTION
description: Less developed countries often chafe under the economic and political power wielded by developed countries and the international lending agencies that act as their agents. In Arizona lately the roles have been reversed, and Arizonans have become outraged as the Export-Import Bank and a branch of the World Bank have approved loans for the expansion of a copper smelter in nearby Cananea, Mexico, that would pollute Arizona's air and compete with the state's hard-pressed copper industry.

title: Cairo Says an Oversight Delayed Debt Payment
description: The Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, Ashraf Ghorbal, said today that his country's failure to make a $30.2 million interest payment on debts for purchases of United States weapons was an oversight.

title: ROVING YOUTHS HARASS CROWDS
description: For more than two hours after the Diana Ross concert in Central Park, roving bands of youths attacked and harassed people in the area around the park, the police said.

title: 4 I.R.A. BACKERS GIVEN SENTENCES IN WEAPONS PLOT
description: Four men were sentenced yesterday to prison terms ranging from two years to seven years for plotting to smuggle guns, explosives and surface-to-air missiles from New York to the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title: FALLEN CONNECTICUT BRIDGE REOPENED
description: Twenty-five days after a section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge here collapsed, killing three people and snarling traffic in two states, the bridge was reopened today with a temporary replacement for the fallen portion.

title: AUTO UNION VOTES TO SEEK RISES IN PAY AT CHRYSLER
description: The United Automobile Workers will seek an immediate pay increase and a return to wage parity with workers at other auto companies when it begins negotiations with the Chrysler Corporation on Monday.

title: Matching Points With Rod Carew
description: On June 1, Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox was batting .372. Rod Carew of the California Angels was hitting .451.

description: For the past quarter century Arkla Inc., owner of the powerful Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company, has been an aggressive acquisitor of gas and oil leases and a developer of those lands.

AT L.I. CAMP, ARTS AND CRAFTS AND THE BIBLE
description: The sun shimmered on the waters of Southold Bay as several dozen youngsters settled on rough benches facing a large cross. A trumpet and French horn, nearly in tune with each other, sent the flowing melody of ''Amazing Grace'' into the cool morning air. Day had begun at Camp Quinipet.

title: European Youngsters Roll Up Their Sleeves
description: T he South Bronx is not the image New York exports to lure tourists, which is precisely why 16 young Europeans from eight countries are spending three weeks in the area building parks with neighborhood youngsters.

title: Sevellon Brown 3d, Ex-Editor Of Papers in Providence, R.I.
description: Sevellon Brown 3d, who was editor of The Providence Journal-Bulletin from 1953 to 1968, died Wednesday at Rhode Island Hospital. He was 70 years old.

description: For all her childlike delicacy and sometimes unnerving mid-performance spontaneity, Diana Ross has always been a practiced professional.

RATES JUMP
description: The Federal Reserve System yesterday reported a $300 million rise in the basic measure of the nation's money supply for the week ended July 13, a development that surprised the financial markets and caused a surge in interest rates. A drop of about $1 billion had been expected.

title: BankAmerica Service
description: The BankAmerica Corporation is considering changing the name of its consumer finance subsidiary to the Banc-America Financial Services Company, the holding company said Thursday. The current name, FinanceA@merica, was the object of a suit brought by the Finance Company of America, a commercial leasing company whose only office is in Baltimore. The suit has been settled, but terms were not disclosed, according to Richard Moyer, a vice president of FinanceAmerica in Allentown, Pa.

title: BOC Selling Stake In Medical Unit
description: The BOC Group P.L.C. of London announced that it would sell its 52 percent stake in Mountain Medical Equipment Inc., a producer of oxygen concentrators for home health care, and said it expected the sale to be made either to a corporate buyer, or through a secondary public offering of stock. The sale is to be made through BOC's United States subsidiaries, Airco Industries and Glasrock Medical Services, each of which hold 26 percent.

description: In his ballet version of ''Notre Dame de Paris,'' Roland Petit has reduced Victor Hugo's sprawling 19th-century Romantic novel - known here as ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' - to a two-hour cabaret act.

title: RIPE FOR REVOLUTION
description: President Reagan's bully-boy policy in Central America has baffled every one of our major Latin American friends, and virtually every one of our European allies.

description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Italian Judge Questions Turk in Pope's Shooting
description: An Italian judge today interrogated Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who shot Pope John Paul II, to check his testimony against new information from Bulgaria, Italian judicial sources said.

title: NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Comrade Batir
description: Batir the elephant lives in a zoo in Soviet Kazakhstan. There are no other elephants for miles, which may be why he started talking to himself. But not knowing how his kind communicate (his mother may have said a few things to him, but that was 13 years ago), he doesn't trumpet, roar, grumble or squeak. Instead he imitates the zoo attendants.

title: FURTHER SPREAD OF MINE FIRE UNDER 3 TOWNS FEARED
description: Three coal towns in northeastern Pennsylvania could be endangered by toxic fumes and cave-ins from a 21-year-old mine fire that is spreading underneath the communities, according to a Federal report.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS LOST $119.2 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said late last night that it lost $119.2 million in the second quarter, a deficit it attributed to a sudden plunge in sales of home computers and software. In a separate announcement, it said that the executive in charge of the home computer business, William J. Turner, had resigned.

title: IANTHIN IS FAVORED IN TROT
description: A 9-year-old French horse who has never raced in the United States will be cast in the favorite's role tomorrow night when the International Trot is contested for the 25th time at Roosevelt Raceway. Ianthin, who only this year reached his racing peak, is the choice even though another French horse, Ideal du Gazeau, will be seeking his third straight triumph in this $250,000 event.

title: Belgrade Trade Deficit
description: Yugoslavia more than halved its trade deficit with Western countries in the first six months of this year by increasing exports and cutting imports, the state-run Tanyug press agency reported today. The deficit in the first six months amounted to $990 million, down by $1.13 billion, Tanyug said.

title: DISTANT CROISSANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: American Airlines' Accord on Braniff
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved a settlement ending American Airlines' involvement in attempts by grounded Braniff International to reorganize.

title: Shulamith Kastein, 80, Dead; Speech Therapist and Teacher
description: Shulamith Kastein, a former director of the speech and hearing clinic at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: 4 DIE AS PLANE CRASHES IN JERSEY
description: A single-engine plane crashed Thursday night in a remote marsh west of Atlantic City, killing all four people aboard, officials said today.

title: International Paper Offer
description: The International Paper Company said the Justice Department had requested additional information concerning the company's pending cash tender offer for all the outstanding stock and convertible debentures of the Stecher-Traung-Schmidt Corporation.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 23, 1983
description: International American military involvement in Central America and preparations for a possible limited military blockade of Nicaragua have been approved by President Reagan, senior Administration officials said. Military exercises that the United States will soon conduct in Central America and the Caribbean are aimed at laying the groundwork for the expanded American presence and the possible blockade, the officials said. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.S. Embassy in Honduras has become the largest and most important American mission in Central America. Once a diplomatic backwater, the embassy, occupying two large and well-fortified buildings in Tegucigalpa, the capital, has recently become the symbol of the rapidly growing American presence in Honduras, the focal point of Washington's Central American policy. (1:6.)

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
METS WIN IN NINTH ON 2 HOME RUNS
description: The Mets won a game in an improbable fashion tonight: Keith Hernandez and Darryl Strawberry hit home runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.

title: Panda Receives Flowers After Losing Her Cub
description: The giant panda Ling-Ling slept in her den today, recuperating from the death of her first cub, as sympathetic well-wishers sent bouquets of flowers.

title: U.S. Backs A.T.& T.
description: The Justice Department agreed with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today that A.T.& T. should not be required to reimburse the Bell operating companies for costs they incur in restructuring the phone network after divestiture if the costs were not recovered by 1994. The payment would be required under a plan by Federal Judge Harold H. Greene.

title: U.S. FOUNDATIONS AID ZIMBABWE
description: Two leading American foundations, in an effort to help Zimbabwe make its education system more responsive to the needs of its predominantly black population, have provided a $1 million grant to the country's only university.

title: Joseph Hartman, Head Of Investment Concern
description: Joseph A. Hartman, a businessman who was active in civic and political affairs, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 63 years old.

SEAFIRST LOSES $158.2 MILLION
description: The Seafirst Corporation, whose troubled loans forced it into a merger with the BankAmerica Corporation on July 1, today reported a loss of $158.2 million for the second quarter.

title: Deere and Hitachi In Joint Venture
description: Deere & Company and Hitachi Construction Machinery Company Ltd. of Japan have announced a joint project to develop and market a line of hydraulic excavators designed for the North American market.

title: HABIB REPLACED AS U.S. ENVOY TO MIDDLE EAST
description: President Reagan announced today that Philip C. Habib was stepping down as his chief Middle East negotiator and would be replaced by Mr. Reagan's deputy national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane.

title: ANGEL WITH CLAY FEET?  AHA! IT'S PEARLYGATE
description: Five Congressmen buy secret controlling interest in an earthworm business located within a stone's throw of the Pentagon. It supplies worms to big military contractors who like to go fishing in the Potomac while waiting for Congress to decide whether to fund their companies. A newspaper investigation reveals that the contractors are required to pay as much as $5,000 per worm at this establishment, although worms of equal quality are selling nearby at Billy and Mabel's Worm Stand for two cents apiece. Thus is born Baitgate.

description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's decision to postpone his trip to the United States has stirred new talk here about his health, but there is no visible evidence that his condition has deteriorated lately or that physical disability was behind his decision to stay home.

description: A remote meter reader that operates over telephone lines has been invented for the Timex Corporation, Waterbury, Conn. Patent 4,394,540 was granted this week to Alan E. Willis, John R. Lowdenslager and Neal Goldstein, staff members.

MEETING KEEPS 600 JUGGLERS IN MOTION
description: The art of juggling goes back to ancient Egyptian, Greek and pre-Columbian civilizations. But there can rarely have been such a confluence of events and people as will take place Saturday at the Pepsico Summerfare '83 festival on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase, the site of the 36th annual International Jugglers Convention.

Cannon Case Taps
description: Federal authorities who prepared the counterfeiting case against Dr. Billy Cannon, the former football player, disclosed yesterday that during a recent 24-day period they had secretly recorded 4,000 telephone conversations between various parties involved in the case. The information was filed in Federal Court in Baton Rouge, La., in accordance with a law requiring authorities to notify targets of secret, court-authorized wire taps within 90 days of the discontinuance of the surveillance. Dr. Cannon, a dentist who faces as much as five years in prison, has since pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against three co-defendants in the case.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League said that Mike Butler, a defensive end on the Green Bay Packers, had agreed to join the Bandits for the 1984 season. ... Fred Schaus, the West Virginia athletic director, said the National Collegiate Athletic Association had started a new investigation into the university's basketball recruitment but gave no details.

title: Leleu Wins Stage In Tour de France
description: Philippe Leleu of France went on a solo run today and won the 20th stage of the Tour de France cycle race, covering the 169.2 miles from Morzine in 7 hours 22 minutes 56 seconds.

title: SCREEN: 'HEARTBREAKER'
description: ''Heartbreaker,'' which opened yesterday at the National and other theaters, is a primitive action-romance about those young people in Los Angeles who spend their spare time custom-fitting their automobiles to reflect their self-images.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Curry Meredith Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., yesterday Curry Chase Meredith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar S. Meredith of Dallas, was married to Henry Darlington 3d, son of Mr. Darlington Jr. of New York and Mrs. Grant G. Simmons Jr. of Atlanta. The Rev. Charles Sheerin, chaplain of the Trinity-Pawling School, performed the ceremony.

title: LIBERTY WINS TWO, LOSES 1 TO DEFENDER
description: In racing that was distinguished by subtle tactics and split-second timing, Liberty won two of three races from Defender today in the trials on Rhode Island Sound to select the America's Cup representative.

title: SUFFOLK READY TO CATCH UP TO NASSAU IN POPULATION
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY is catching up with Nassau County, at least as far as population is concerned. Sometime within the next 12 months, Suffolk is expected to draw even in the race.

title: SUMMER BULBS FOR THE GARDEN PATIO
description: Patio pots filled with flowering summer bulbs can make the old standard petunias and marigolds seem pretty ho-hum. I discovered their drama some years ago when I was trying to determine what would grow in a large glazed Mexican pot.

title: BEIRUT'S LATEST TRAUMA IS ECONOMIC CRISIS
description: Rarely can one pinpoint a day, let alone the minute, when a country's economy began sliding into recession. But ask Lebanese businessmen when their economy started heading into a tailspin and many will respond with little hesitation: 1:03 p.m., April 18 - the moment the United States Embassy in Beirut was destroyed.

title: AFRICAN HOMELAND ARRESTS A GENERAL
description: Until he landed this week in one of the jails that had been part of his expanding domain in the nominally independent homeland called Ciskei, a case could have been made that Lieut. Gen. Charles Sebe was the most powerful black man in South Africa.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING A RISE IN ADVISERS IN SALVADOR TO 125
description: The Defense Department has recommended to President Reagan that he raise the number of American military advisers in El Salvador to 125 next year, more than doubling the current total, senior Administration officials said today.

title: FREED U.S. EDUCATOR THANKS SYRIANS FOR HELP
description: David S. Dodge, the acting president of the American University of Beirut, who was freed this week after a year of captivity by Middle East terrorists, expressed public thanks to the Syrian Government for helping arrange his release.

title: THE PURISTS EXTEND THEIR REACH
description: The conclusion of the seven-volume survey of Mozart's complete symphonies by the Academy of Ancient Music on the L'Oiseau Lyre label is a landmark in the movement to perform music on the instruments and with the style the composers intended.

title: OUR DETRACTORS DESERVE A DOSE OF THEIR OWN MEDICINE
description: ARE WE tired of New Jersey's sneering critics and the snide asides directed at our fair state? Have we heard enough jokes about funnysmelling air and Jimmy Hoffa's final resting place?

title: SOME BIOLOGISTS FEAR SPREAD OF DISEASE OF BIGHORN SHEEP
description: Bacterial pneumonia is killing large numbers of bighorn sheep in western Canada, and some biologists say they fear it will spread to herds in the United States.

title: U.S. Eliminated in Cup Tennis
description: The United States was eliminated from the Federation Cup international women's tennis tournament today, losing its seven-year hold on the team trophy.

title:
STAMPS;
HIGHEST DENOMINATION EVER ISSUED BY THE U.S.
description: A stamp valued at $9.35, the highest denomination ever put out by the United States, is being issued on Aug. 14 at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The issue is intended for use principally for Express Mail Next Day Service.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Henry Kissinger Goes On

title: CHAD ARMY'S SUCCESS BRINGS CONFIDENCE TO CAPITAL
description: On just about every wall in this capital, there are posters of President Hissen Habre with slogans in French and Arabic exhorting the populace to support the current struggle against the insurgents.

title: Peru Authorities Holding 271 In Connection With Bombings
description: The police said today that 271 people were arrested after the bombings of six high-tension electrical towers two days ago and anyone found near power facilities would be shot on sight.

title: WHY HORSE RACING KEEPS FALLING SHORT OF ITS IDEALS
description: THERE may be no better emblem for the failed hopes of this season's crop of 3-year-olds than E.P. Taylor's Chumming. Woody Stephens, bidding on Taylor's behalf, paid a million dollars for the colt at Saratoga Springs in 1981. Chumming had the kind of bloodlines that should have made him a perfect fit for the classic races, but he arrived in Kentucky for the Derby last May without having won a stakes race. Stephens continued to tout him as a more talented colt than his stablemate Caveat, but you've got to remember that Stephens - like most trainers of note -is a convicted optimist.

title: MALPRACTICE SUITS INCREASE CARE COSTS
description: THE number of medical malpractice cases filed in Long Island courts and the amount of awards to plaintiffs in these cases have risen steadily over the last five years. This fact has forced the 5,400 physicians practicing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to pay the highest malpractice insurance premium rates in the state.

title: Alyson Henning Weds A.D. Walker 3d
description: Alyson Balfour Henning, daughter of Mrs. James Burns Cavanagh of New York and Greenville, Del., and Robert Edward Henning of Woodstock, Vt., was married yesterday to Alexander David Walker 3d, son of Mrs. John Hone Bartol and Mr. Walker Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Olofson Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Methodist Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: Meredith Wheeler to Wed J. A. Lindsey
description: Warren Calvin Wheeler of Bay Hill, Fla., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Meredith Doris Wheeler, to Jonathan Austin Lindsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Lindsey of New York. The wedding is to be on Sept. 10.

title: No Headline
description: Point: Group Homes Benefit Community The article about group homes for retarded people (''Planners Assess Homes for Retarded,'' June 26) described the benefits of deinstitutionalization for the clients. It should also be pointed out that group homes offer many benefits to the community.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A PROPOSAL in Suffolk County to eliminate town assessors' offices and administer property taxation on a countywide basis, as Nassau County now does, is scheduled for debate at a public hearing in Hauppauge on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Julia Averett To Be Bride
description: Mrs. Elliot Averett of New Vernon, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Julia Hall Averett, to Andrew Francis Buteux, son of Mrs. Harry Francis Buteux of New Hartford, N.Y., and the late Mr. Buteux. The wedding is to be Sept. 10.

title: DAY CAMP ENROLLMENT STEADY
description: ALTHOUGH school enrollments are declining, the Island's day camps are maintaining their numbers. Camps across the Island - private and nonprofit - report at least as many youngsters enrolled this summer as last. Some, in fact, have had to turn away hundreds of potential campers as enrollment limits were reached.

title: AUDUBON FESTIVAL
description: Toby, a great horned owl, will be among the live creatures to be encountered at the 16th annual Sharon Audubon Festival Saturday and Sunday at the Audubon Center, Route 4. He is a principal player in a program on caring for injured and orphaned wild animals, amphibians and birds.

title: TO HER RESCUE
description: Carrying a torch for 97 years is difficult even with an arm of copper-clad iron, so a team of architects last week recommended a $30 million overhaul for the Statue of Liberty. Richard S. Hayden, a member of the team, said some of the worst damage from corrosion and rust was to the statue's right arm and recommended a complete replacement of the torch. The statue symbolized American strength, he said, ''and to have that arm fall down wouldn't do.''

title: TOWARD ZERO BY ADDING 2
description: Governor Cuomo may yet succeed in killing the State Commission of Investigation, but he will need a slightly bigger grave to bury it. Mr. Cuomo agreed last week to add two new members to an agency he has said has outlived its usefulness.

title: WITH MIXED FEELINGS, SOMERS AWAITS I.B.M. AND PEPSICO
description: ''THE town is going to be discovered,'' Marguerite Dunscomb said regretfully, as she sat in a Somers coffee shop. ''As it is now, when you tell people where you live, they never heard of it.''

title: FOOTNOTES TO AN EMBASSY 'GRIM GRAM'
description: A visitor to El Salvador cannot miss them. Nearly every day, two or three pictures of the dead appear in the morning papers, their faces caught in black-and-white above the caption ''assassinated'' or ''disappeared.'' Only a fraction of the missing make the papers, but the pictures appear with numbing regularity; being ''disappeared,'' often by Government security forces freelancing for the extreme right, is a common form of death.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Vague promises no longer console us, threats and warnings and bombings no longer strike terror in our hearts. We have always relied on our own strength and our own will to survive.'' - President Amin Gemeyel of Lebanon. (6:6.)

title: PENSION RESTORED FOR GEN. WALKER
description: The Army has quietly restored the military pension of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker more than 20 years after he was admonished for ''derogatory public statements about prominent Americans'' and then resigned his commission.

title: NEW BRIDGE DETOUR, NEW UNHAPPINESS
description: There was relief in this Westchester County village today. Down the road in Greenwich, Conn., there was indignation. And between the two communities, there was no friendship lost.

title: 'Theorem of The Century'
description: One of the hottest papers in town is not personal or purloined, but 40 pages of equations by a West German mathematician. ''It is no exaggeration to say that, at least in number theory, this is close to being the theorem of the century,'' said Spencer Block of the University of Chicago -praise that even number fumblers could appreciate.

title: MOTHERS AS VICTIMS
description: INVENTING MOTHERHOOD The Consequences of an Ideal. By Ann Dally. 360 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $19.95.

title: Twin Victories
description: Eric and Elias Madrid, twin lightweight boxers from California, scored twin knockouts in Los Angeles Friday night. Elias stopped Billie Boyd of Houston in the first round, and Eric stopped Rick Ramos, also of Houston, in the second. The brothers have almost identical records: Eric is 10-0, with 8 knockouts, and Elias is 11-0, with 9 knockouts.

title: PLAY IT AGAIN, SAM, AND AGAIN AND AGAIN
description: MEN TODAY have more toys than boys did when I was one. For example, there are now 6 million Americans who own video cassette recorders; 25 million worldwide. On a mad impulse, I bought one three years ago. Since then, I've preserved more Crazy Eddie commercials, because they punctuated 3 A.M. movies, than Perier has bubbles.

title: Jobless Totals for May Improve in Most States
description: Unemployment figures improved in most states in May, though 10 percent or more of the work force was still hunting jobs in at least 19 states, the Labor Department says.

title: POTTERY WITH AN ART DECO TOUCH
description: The last thing anyone expects to see at teatime in late June on King Street in London is an international gathering of hundreds of pottery enthusiasts queuing up outside of Christie's for admittance to an auction of what Queen Mary once insisted was ''awful'' china. On June 29, however, that is exactly what happened - a great crowd appeared before the auction house opened its doors for the 6 P.M. dispersal of Clarice Cliff's hand-painted Art Deco designs.

title: BASEBALL TEAM LIFTS NEW BRITAIN
description: MORALE and civic pride in the old central Connecticut industrial city of New Britain were dealt a severe blow by the revelations over the last five years of municipal corruption and illegal gambling that led to the conviction of 27 people, including some high-ranking officials.

title: A Reconciliation
description: Earl Campbell, the Houston Oilers' running back, and Ed Biles, the coach, may not be buddies, but both say they have ironed out the differences that kept them from talking to each other last year. According to Campbell, the reconciliation took place two months ago when he and Biles met to discuss their relationship.

title: MAYOR OF SAN JUAN ORGANIZES 4TH PARTY FOR GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Puerto Rico's two principal political parties have been thrown a new challenge with Mayor Hernan Padilla of San Juan quitting the party led by Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo to start a new one.

title: JETS' SOHN GETS HIS CHANCE
description: Bobby Jones asked to be traded so that he might have the opportunity to become a starter elsewhere. The Jets accommodated Jones, one of their backup wide receivers, by sending him to the Cleveland Browns for a draft choice. That was good for Kurt Sohn.

title: CHOOSING UP SIDES
description: .2,0,147.2,2,496.8,0WASHINGTON, July 23 - The central fact about Central America is that it is central to the defense of the United States. If our nearest neighbors continue to be subverted and taken over by Communists, the region will offer the Russians a base directly threatening our security and increasing the possibility of nuclear war.

title: PHILIP MORRIS'S MARLBORO MAN
description: THE news took even James J. Morgan's friends by surprise. When the 41-year-old executive vice president for marketing at P hilip Morris Inc. announced July 8 that he was quitting to become t he new chairman and chief executive of Atari Inc., many were s tunned. ''I uttered an expletive,'' said James C. Bowling, Philip M orris's director of corporate affairs. Added William Ruder, p resident of the public relations firm that bears his name: ''I a lmost dropped dead.''

title: LONG ISLAND FISHERMEN ARE IN FINANCIAL TROUBLE
description: For the last several years, some Long Island fishermen have seemed as endangered as their catch. The clam haul, which traditionally accounts for at least half the industry's revenues, dropped from 9 million pounds in 1976 to 3.3 million last year. The usually lucrative bass catch last year was less than a third of what it was a decade ago. And the state's total dockside commercial take slipped to $45.1 million in 1982 from $45.3 million in 1981 - the first decline in recent memory. ''The New York onshore fishing industry is definitely suffering,'' said Gordon Colvin, state director of marine resources. ''The value of landings isn't even keeping up with inflation.''

title: Jane H. Frederick and Remy A. Rodas, Lawyers, Planning to Marry in October
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mr. Robert R. Frederick of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Hastings Frederick, to Remy Antonio Rodas, son of Albina Rodas of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Remy Rodas Eguino of La Paz, Bolivia. An Oct. 29 wedding is planned.

title: PERU SYMBOLIZES PLIGHT OF UNEASY LATIN DEMOCRACIES
description: On the 200th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar, the liberator of Peru, an economic depression and foreign debt are causing social unrest, challenging the democracy he championed, Peruvians say.

title: Shumate a Coach
description: John Shumate, whose basketball career was cut short three years ago because of blood-clot problems, has been hired as coach of Grand Canyon College in Phoenix, a perennial basketball power among small colleges. ''The doctors told me I should have no problems as long as I wasn't out on the court being kicked and pushed around,'' said Shumate, who played for Notre Dame and the Phoenix Suns. He spent last season as an unpaid assistant to Digger Phelps at Notre Dame.

title: '63 TEST BAN TREATY: IT CAN BE DONE AGAIN
description: Twenty years ago tomorrow, the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain initialed the first major arms control agreement among the nuclear powers - the limited test ban treaty.

title: Seychelles Frees 6
description: Six mercenaries who came to the Seychelles to overthrow the island's socialist Government and spent two years in jail for it left today for Johannesburg after being pardoned and ordered deported. They were two Britons, three South Africans and a Zimbabwean. Four had been sentenced to death.

title: POPULATION PRIZES FROM U.N. ASSAILED
description: Two $12,500 awards given by a United Nations population agency to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and to China's family planning chief have been denounced as a travesty by a United States economist whom the agency enlisted as an adviser.

title: RACIAL QUOTAS: 'ROAD TO CONFLICT AND TRAGEDY'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW WAVE OF MARINA CONDOMINIUMS
description: PLEASURE skippers who dream of the open water even when they are on d ry land have spurred a new housing demand along the New Jersey shoref or the dock-and-deck marina condominium.

title: COLUMBIA IS STARTING NEW LIBRARY TO HOLD RARE BOOK TREASURES
description: Columbia University will set up a new $3 million Rare Book and Manuscript Library in its Butler Library to house treasures spanning more than 4,000 years.

title: Robin Davis Is Wed to R.T. Jahncke
description: At St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L.I., yesterday, Robin Davis and Redington Townsend @Jahncke, vice presidents of E.F. Hutton & Company Inc. in New York, were married by the Rev. Malcolm Foster, an Episcopal priest.

title: 3 LEBANON LEADERS FORM AN ALLIANCE FOR SEPARATE RULE
description: The leader of the Druse minority in Lebanon announced today that he and a group of leftist and Syrianbacked leaders had created an alliance to oppose the Government of President Amin Gemayel.

title: CONSCIOUSNESS RAISING FOR EXECUTIVES
description: Child care costs, as any working parent knows, can make a big dent in the family budget. In fact, after housing, food and taxes, they are the average American family's biggest expense, said Nancy Kolben, director of the Employers' and Child Care Project of the Pre-School Association in New York. And because 56 percent of all mothers with children under the age of six were working last year, up from 32 percent in 1970, the problem is growing more complex from both a personal financial viewpoint and a corporate one.

title: DAIRY FUND JEOPARDIZED BY PROCESSOR'S DEBTS
description: A state-managed fund for the financial protection of dairy farmers is in jeopardy because of bad checks issued by a large upstate milk processor, according to papers filed in State Supreme Court here this week.

title: THESE DAYS, TEXAS THINKS BIG ABOUT CULTURE
description: At a time when much of the rest of the country is trimming arts budgets and wondering whether major cultural institutions will survive, Texas is launching a new round of projects with huge price tags: a $75 million house for opera and ballet and a third major art museum in Houston, an art museum and a symphony hall in Dallas, and a music festival with aspirations to international stature in San Antonio. Is this just a matter of the ostentation of wealth -where money goes, culture will follow? Texas is proverbially rich, and the economic recession has hit the state belatedly and comparatively mildly, so the simplest explanation of the culture gusher is at least plausible - especially since These days, many of the Texans with the means to fund it, are beginning to consider culture not as a frill but as the potent sign of their own and their state's prestige. The push to make Texas a great cultural center is on - though the question of exactly how much actual creativity money can buy still remains.

title: RARE GENETIC UNIFORMITY FOUND IN CHEETAHS
description: A study of blood samples from 55 cheetahs from two widely separated and isolated populations has shown them to be almost genetically identical.

title: COOLING THE BROW IN STYLE
description: FEW men and women in this age of air conditioning use hand fans to help them keep cool. But up to a generation or so ago fans were in common and fashionable use.

title: Egypt Starting to Slow Its Population Growth
description: Egypt has begun to check the growth of its population after almost a decade of steady increases, according to Egyptian and foreign population experts.

title: COUNTY'S FIRST 'CENTRAL CITY'
description: WHITE PLAINS has been designated the county's first and only ''central city'' by the Federal Office of Management and Budget. The classification, which took effect on June 30, follows new guidelines established by the Federal Committee on Metropolitan Statistical Areas, a panel of Government demographers that spent the last six years studying metropolitan growth.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Play Down the Alibi

title: A TIME FOR SONG
description: IT is a grand week for singing, to paraphrase Rodgers and Hammerstein, with all manner of vocal programs and sing-it-yourself opportunities available.

title: THE WILD CARD IS QADDAFI AS BIDDING RISES IN CHAD
description: For a country at war, Chad now appears remarkably peaceful. Soldiers in the capital relax in the shade by day and relax in the bars by night. There have been some recent skirmishes in the north, but even those exchanges were dismissed by a Government spokesman as ''not very violent, not very intense.''

title: CONCERTS WORTH A TRIP
description: IS this the time of year when the wanderlust strikes and the mountain highways beckon? One need not go all the way to Tanglewood to find music at the end of a rainbow drive. From most parts of the county, for example, it is less than two hours to Woodstock, N.Y., home of one of the oldest continuing summer music festivals in the United States.

title: AIDING THE JOBLESS PROVES A MAJOR JOB IN ITSELF
description: CAMDEN MARGARET MOLLO, a senior claims examiner in the state's Unemployment Insurance Office here, was not surprised last March when a stocky young man began to swear as she explained to him why he could not receive his unemployment benefits immediately.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: In listing transit information phone numbers for ''What's Doing in San Francisco'' (Travel, June 19), a sense of how intelligently and humanely the transit systems operate was not conveyed properly.

title: Highland Blade Romps on Dirt
description: Highland Blade had come so close without winning in major dirt races against top horses that he seemed due for a break. He got one when a weak field turned out to face him in the $288,000 Brooklyn Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, and he made the most of it with an easy victory.

title: DIVORCE IS NOT THE ENDING
description: CHILDREN IN THE CROSSFIRE The Tragedy of Parental Kidnaping. By Sally Abrahms. 297 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95. GROWING UP DIVORCED By Linda Bird Francke. 303 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: PROJECT TO STUDY STATE'S JOB NEEDS
description: TO stay a step ahead of important changes in the job market, the state is employing a modern-day Merlin who uses a computer instead of a crystal ball.

title: ORTGAGE DELINQUENCY RATES Percentages of mortgages held by savings and loan associations); 1983 1982 1981 ay 1.30 1.12 0.90 pril 1.27 1.11 0.87 arch 1.36 1.11 0.91; Source: U.S. League of Savings Associations
description: ORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) New York Last Week Previous Week Year Ago Conventional 13.64 13.42 16.73 Rollovers 12.83 12.74 16.61 Adjustable Rate 11.53 11.47 16.32 Source: HSH Associates New Jersey Conventional 13.60 13.44 16.52 Rollovers 12.43 12.39 16.39 Adjustable Rate 11.75 11.60 16.30 Source: HSH Associates Connecticut Conventional 13.16 13.12 17.36 Rollovers 11.25 11.23 17.06 Adjustable Rate 12.37 12.37 16.58 Source: The Millard Group Inc. Co-ops (NYC) Conventional 14.07 13.89 18.06 Rollovers 13.06 13.03 16.28 Adjustable Rate 12.13 12.03 17.04 Source: HSH Associates Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and ususally commit the tender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Admustable-rate mortgages have rates that ary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: FORCE WON'T WORK IN NICARAGUA
description: The Nicaraguan revolution is celebrating its fourth anniversary under a gathering storm. Gunboat diplomacy, displays of military hegemony, the invasion of Nicaragua by mercenary forces sponsored by Washington, the militarization of Honduras, the use of Panama as a springboard for the American war - all this is causing incalculable political stress throughout the Latin continent, where considerations about Marxism come after considerations of nationalism and cultural identity.

title: Egypt Accuses 25 of Plot
description: Twenty-five members of a Moslem fundamentalist group have been arrested on charges of planning to overthrow the Government and establish Iranian-style Islamic rule, news reports said today. The group was reported to be an offshoot of the Islamic Liberation Party, said to be an underground organization that operates in several Arab countries.

title: SPANISH FOOD WITH FEW SURPRISES
description: LA ZARZUELA in Rockville Centre is an extremely popular Spanish restaurant that has been open since 1981. It is an attractive place with rough white stucco walls accented with light wood, decorative Spanish tiles, copper and wrought iron. The country look is softened by plush dark blue upholstery and carpeting.

title: MADAGASCAR HAS AN ASSET THE U.S. JUST CAN'T IGNORE
description: The Indian Ocean loomed high not long ago in the strategic considerations surrounding the oil routes to the West. Instability in the Persian Gulf contributed to the concerns that prompted the United States to establish for emergency use a string of facilities stretching from Mombasa, Kenya, through Berbera, Somalia, and on to Oman.

title: JOAN ARMATRADING'S LONG JOURNEY TOWARD RENOWN
description: When Joan Armatrading's second album, ''Back to the Night,'' was released in 1975, the critics greeted it with confident enthusiasm. This is the record, they agreed, that will make Joan Armatrading a household name. The same prediction has greeted each of the Caribbean-born singer-songwriter's subsequent albums - including, it appears, her latest, ''The Key.''

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN A FRIEND LEAVES A FRIENDSHIP
description: MOST people know when love dies. The message may come in a last painful rendezvous, or in a tear-streaked letter. It may be embodied in the piece of china sailing at your forehead. Or, to paraphrase the urban balladeer, it might be ''those stumbling words that told you, 'Get the heck out of my apartment ...' ''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: A BICYCLE trip with a sense of mission will culminate in Westport early next month. Forty bicyclists from Scandinavia, the Soviet Union and the United States - including four from Fairfield County - will end their ''Bike for Peace'' mission with a testimonial dinner in the First Congregational Church of Westport on Aug. 8. The Soviet cyclists may also stay with local families for a few days.

title: SUNDAY, JULY 24, 1983
description: International The number of U.S. military advisers in El Salvador would be more than doubled next year under a Defense Department recommendation to President Reagan. Senior Administration officials said the Pentagon wants to raise the number of advisers to 125, more than double the current number. The officials said the Pentagon also proposed that the advisers be allowed to increase their mobility by accompanying Salvadoran forces into the field. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Honduran-based rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government are still without significant military gains and they are not a threat to the Government after more than a year of intense activity, foreign diplomats in Managua and Nicaraguan officials say. Their lack of military success has deepened the Government's fear that the Reagan Administration may now feel compelled to take harsher measures in its avowed desire to see its overthrow. (1:5.)

title: A TALE OF HOSPITALITY ON THE PARTY CIRCUIT
description: YOU never know what to wear to a dinner party this time of year. Especially if you've never been to the people's house before and don't know whether to expect drinks in the backyard or in an airconditioned living room. Or if it will be an eat-off-your-lap buffet or a three-course, sit-down meal.

title: Leslie Endlar, Teacher, To Wed Richard Zetlin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Endlar of Brookline, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ellen Endlar, to Richard I. Zetlin, son of Mrs. Don Pressman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Lee Zetlin of Stamford, Conn.

title: BEETS AND BROTH
description: One of our favorite cold soups for summer is borscht, which is of Russian origin and one of the tastiest liquids associated with hotweather dining. But there is another beet soup - of Polish origin, although it is also Russian by adoption - that is rarely found in cookbooks, even those that deal exclusively with soups, domestic or international. It is called chlodnik.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Tragedy / Comedy Lamentation

title: Janet E. Blucke Is Married To Kenneth M. Mueller Jr.
description: Janet Elizabeth Blucke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Warren Blucke of Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday to Kenneth Morgan Mueller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mueller of Rochelle Park, N.J. The Rev. David Forrey performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Cathedral of the Pines in Rindge, N.H.

title: DANCE: EIKO AND KOMA CONTROL TIME
description: Although it is customary to define dance as an art of movement in space and time, audiences are often more aware of the way dancers cover space than of how they pass through time. Nevertheless, certain choreographers do much to create striking illusions in time. Among them are Eiko and Koma, the Japanese dancers who presented a collaboratively choreographed program on Wednesday night at Duke University's Reynolds Theater as part of this summer's American Dance Festival.

title: TWO BODIES FOUND IN SUNKEN PLANE
description: A police scuba diving team yesterday recovered the bodies of the pilot and a passenger of a commuter seaplane that collided with a police helicopter over Brooklyn on Friday.

title: A Vacation With the Kids
description: Judith Kelman's article (''Vacation Tip: Take No Kids,'' May 29) immediately made me think to myself, ''Oh, but she doesn't know where to take kids on a vacation.''

title:
THE WORLD;
New Lebanon Has The Same Old Missing Pieces
description: Israel ordered a phased pullback of its troops near Beirut last week, ducking out of the lethal feud between Christian militiamen and Druse villagers in the Shuf mountains. The partial withdrawal, President Amin Gemayel feared, could mean de facto partition - leaving Lebanon's north and east occupied by Syrians and Palestinians, the south under Israeli control, and Mr. Gemayel's own sovereignty largely confined to greater Beirut.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All Sorts of Spices, Things to Nibble

title: Perfume
description: To the Editor: Marilyn Bender's article ''More Scents for the Dollar'' (Travel, June 26) suggests that one's Paris perfume purchasing - if less than the 800-franc detaxe amount is involved - be done at Galeries Lafayette, a department store. disagree.

title: 35 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 35 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Paula G. Lance Is Wed
description: Paula G. Lance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lance of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to John J. Gavin, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Gavin of Dorchester, Mass. The Rev. James Weaver performed the ceremony at the Pluckemin, N.J., Presbyterian Church.

title: EFFORTS TO OUST THE SANDINISTAS HELD INEFFECTIVE
description: After more than a year of intense activity, the Honduran-based rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government have failed to achieve significant military gains or to cause a serious political threat to the Government, foreign diplomats and Nicaraguan officials here say.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL TO HELP RETARDED AT AGE 21
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation yesterday setting up a placement system for the mentally retarded who become too old to be cared for in residential schools.

title: THE DELIGHTS OF DE VRIES
description: Ben Yagoda's article was the perfect tribute to Peter DeVries (''Peter Devries: Being Seriously Funny,'' June 12). My husband and I, usually parsimonious about buying hard-cover books, are among those who snap up every DeVries novel the minute it comes out.

title: Elizabeth Willis and Nial Neger, Teachers, Marry
description: Elizabeth Rixey Willis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett Willis of North Hampton, N.H., was married yesterday to Nial E. Neger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Neger of Fairfield, Conn. Msgr. Thomas Henahan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield.

title: Errorless Streak Ends
description: Just one night after setting an American League record for the most consecutive games without an error by an outfielder, Brian Downing, the California Angel left fielder, misplayed a liner Friday night, ending his 244-game streak. The error, on a ball hit by Chet Lemon of the Detroit Tigers in the sixth inning of a game in Anaheim, brought in two runs and provided the margin of defeat in the Angels' 13-11 loss.

title: A STUDY OF CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CHILDREN'S literature may seem like kids' stuff to some, but for 34 people who have gathered at the University of Connecticut at Storrs this summer, it is a serious subject.

title: Drive to Divest
description: To the Business Editor: Your article, ''Cutting Loose: The Drive to Divest'' (July 3), leaves the impression that divestitures are the only direction that companies are taking today. It is true that many divestitures are intended to focus a company's activities in areas where it can excel.

title: PREFABRICATED BUILDINGS EASE CROWDING OF PRISONS IN JERSEY
description: A 448-bed prefabricated prison that state officials believe is the largest of its type in the country has been officially opened by Governor Kean.

title:
CAMERA;
THERE IS STILL A STRONG CASE FOR SUPER 8 MOVIES
description: While home video cameras and videocassette recorders have cut deeply into the market for Super 8mm, movie cameras are still a viable and convenient way of recording the ''moving image'' in everyday life. Of course, there really is no argument against the merits of portable VCR's - video is a medium whose time has come and most manufacturers of Super 8mm equipment have or will be moving into the electronic moving-image business in the near future. Yet, the present situation of this business is not dissimilar to that of the present computer market.

title: SUBCONTRACTING THE BENEFIT
description: EXECUTIVES who may consider subsidizing their employees' child care o ften hesitate, fearing mounds of paperwork as high a newborn's P ampers supply. But a growing number of specialized, independent o rganizations have been setting up shop to handle that problem. What t hey do is market and run child care benefits for employers.

title: NEW JAPANESE DISHES ON THE MENU
description: ICHI RIKI'S entranceway of white stones, bamboo and natural wood shoji promises serenity, in sharp contrast to Nyack's lively Main Street. Three tatami rooms, a sushi counter seating 10 and two areas for Western-style dining provide an appropriate atmosphere for some well-made, authentic Japanese dishes. Since its opening two years ago, John Koshiba, the owner, has worked at his menu, balancing the familiar dishes from Japanese cuisine with some unusual ones rarely found in these parts.

title: Salvage Oil Dealer Convicted in Tax Trial
description: Russell M. Bliss, whose oil salvage business has figured prominently in Missouri's dioxin problems, was found guilty of criminal tax violations by a Federal District Court jury late Friday night.

title: Catherine A. Gallagher Is Wed on Long Island
description: Catherine Ann Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Gallagher of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Christopher Raymond Sheehan, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sheehan of Baldwin, L.I. Archbishop Edward T. O'Meara of Indianapolis, assisted by Msgr.

title: FILMS OF A PIANIST INSPIRE A FESTIVAL
description: There will be a Glenn Gould film festival on the Upper West Side this fall. Beginning Friday, Oct. 7, less than a week after the first anniversary of the pianist's death, Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, will offer three consecutive evenings devoted to the Gould career. In all, eight films and videotapes will be screened, featuring Mr. Gould in conversation and performance - as lecturer, conductor, filmmaker, philosopher and, of course, as pianist. It will be a serious and comprehensive attempt to assess the legacy of one of the most enigmatic musicians of our time.

title: Iran Says It Makes Gains In New Offensive on Iraq
description: Iran said today that it began a major new offensive against Iraq this morning and that its forces captured an Iraqi barracks used as a supply base for Kurdish rebels in Iran.

title: COMPETITION FIERCE FOR GIANTS
description: With the linebacker Lawrence Taylor continuing to hold out, the Giants began the first of their two-aday full-gear workouts in what some predict will be one of the most competitive training camps in recent seasons.

title: A PRIME TIME SOAP OPERA SPENDS THE SUMMER IN THE HAMPTONS
description: Two wealthy, socially prominent families are locked in a head-on struggle for the fortune they jointly control. A manipulative financier, driven by mysterious motives, wants to topple them both. All inhabit a world of spectacular affluence, vicious power plays and enough illicit liaisons to ruffle all but the most jaded sensibility.

title: Seoul Jails 4 Students
description: A Seoul court sentenced four college students today to prison terms ranging from one and a half to two and a half years for trying to organize an anti-Government demonstration at Seoul National University. The four were arrested on May 13 for violating a law banning outdoor gatherings. They distributed leaflets urging students to hold an anti-Government demonstration.

title: OPEN HOUSE FOR GREEN THUMBS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK AS MANY as 8,000 people are expected to converge at Cook College Saturday for the annual Vegetable and Flower Open House there. If luck holds, the weather will be pleasant, just as it has been for every Open House since the first one in 1965.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A player in Pennsylvania's Lotto game has won $8.8 million, which officials say would be the highest amount ever paid a lottery winner in North America.

title: Sheila Kearney Plans to Marry Jeffrey D. Cordtz
description: Edward B. Kearney of New York and Maryjane Lambert Kearney of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Marie Kearney, to Jeffrey Dan Cordtz, son of Dan Cordtz of New York and Mildred Cordtz of Rye, N.Y.

title: SCHOOL FOR THE DEAF MARKING CENTENNIAL
description: WEST TRENTON ACENTURY ago, 68 deaf New Jersey children journeyed to Trenton by railroad and horsedrawn carriage and became the first class at what is still the state's only residential school for the deaf.

title: JURY SAID TO QUESTION BOSTON AIDE'S PURCHASE
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations that a longtime close aide to Mayor Kevin H. White converted $100,000 in cash into municipal bonds in the name of Mr. White's mother, a Boston television station reported last night.

title: LEARNING SOCCER WITH AN ENGLISH ACCENT
description: FOR youngsters who take their soccer seriously, soccer camp on the Island this year has a decided English accent. The Long Island Soccer Camp on the Adelphi University campus has pursued a ''hire-English'' policy, said Dr. Menahem (Mel) Less, the director of the camp and a professor of biomechanics at Adelphi, because their knowledge and understanding of the game tends to be thorough. Moreover, he said, ''there are not many coaches in the United States between the ages 20 and 25 who have mastered the principles and metaphysics of the game.''

title: THE K.G.B. GOES ON THE OFFENSIVE AND THE WEST BEGINS STRIKING BACK
description: The Soviet intelligence and security agency, the K.G.B., has entered a phase of aggressiveness in its activities in the West, according to allied officials. The upsurge is cited as the principal cause of a series of expulsions of Soviet agents from countries around the world since the start of 1983.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are interested in going to the Panama Canal Zone in the fall. Where can we get tourist information? - S.K., Lockport, N.Y. Answer:The Panama Canal Zone is now called the Canal Area and is in the process of being returned to Panama as the result of treaties approved in 1977 by Panama and the United States.

title: FRENCH THEATER LOOKS TO AVIGNON FOR INSPIRATION
description: long theater festival that regularly features some of the newest and most provocative theater Europe has to offer.

title: Auto Crews Play a Key Role
description: As much a part of the show for stock car racing fans as the dozen cars drafting nose to tail at 200 miles per hour around the banking is what goes on when the racers duck into the pits for fuel and tires. A good Nascar pit crew can change a pair of tires and top up the gas tank in fewer than 12 seconds, which is considerably quicker than the mechanics at the corner gas station will manage when they are putting on snow tires in the fall.

title: Lisa MacCallum Wed To Kevin Grant Miller
description: Lisa Ann MacCallum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Clark MacCallum Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin Grant Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph George Miller of West Milford, N.J. The Rev. George Ruane performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
BUILT UPON BANKRUPT THEORIES
description: THE United States economy is now in the midst of a historic seige ofc reativity and growth. Evans Economics estimates that sales of p roducer durables - led by a surge in computers and related gear - a re rising an annual rate of 12.4 percent, four times the average p ace during the first three quarters of previous postwar recoveries, a nd have more than doubled as a share of G.N.P. over the last five y ears.

title: HARD TRAVELING ON THE WAY TO SHANGRI-LA
description: CLIFFORD D. MAY is the West African correspondent of The New York Times. By CLIFFORD D.MAY

title: Randi Neumann to Marry Scott Pomerantz in June
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Randi Jean Neumann, daughter of Kenneth Neumann of West Deal, N.J., and the late Margo Neumann, to Scott Pomerantz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Pomerantz of West Orange, N.J. The wedding is to be next June.

title: AN ECONOMIC DEMOCRACY
description: Following are excerpts from ''Beyond the Waste Land: A Democratic Alternative to Economic Decline,'' by Samuel Bowles, David M. Gordon and Thomas E. Weisskopf. THE prevailing economic wisdom has insisted on a trickle-down a pproach to economic recovery. It advocates a transfer of wealth fromt he needy to the powerful in order to fuel the engines of expansion. T rickle-down economics builds upon a fundamental premise - that the k ey to economic growth is expanding the stock of machinery and other p roductive equipment. This premise may be termed the c apitalshortage explanation of economic decline: The economy has g rown less rapidly as a result of sluggish capital formation.

title: Georges Auric Is Dead; Composed for 60 Films
description: Georges Auric, a composer for more than 60 French films, died today at his Paris apartment, friends of the family announced. He was 84 years old.

title: U.N. Guidelines
description: To the Business Editor: Murray L. Weidenbaum's article, ''The U.N.'s Bid to Play Consumer Cop'' (June 26), makes a number of points based on misconceptions which could lead to confusion as to the role of the United Nations.

title: FOND MEMORIES
description: IT IS LIFE IN NEW York City reminiscent of an earlier, gilded age. In the days of O. Henry or Edith Wharton, the setting would almost certainly have been a brownstone or a mansion on a numbered street. Today, however, old-guard New York must carry on as best it can in the more gracious of the pre-World War II high-rise buildings that line Park and Fifth Avenues. There, amid 11-foot ceilings, curved staircases and meandering corridors, the privileged grapple with what mus surely be the most enviable decorating dilemma of them all: How to make a mass of unrelated furnishings - some their own, others inherited - look intentional, comfortable, at home?

title: CUTBACK IN NUMBER OF LAW SECRETARIES CRITICIZED BY JUDGES
description: A REDUCTION in the number of law secretaries serving the county's six Family Court judges, with the saving in salaries transferred to other sections of the Ninth Judicial District, is causing consternation among some judges and lawyers, who charge that the move is threatening the efficiency of the court.

title: FLORENCE'S RUSTIC CULINARY ART
description: Forget what you may have heard about ''Florentine'' meaning ''made with spinach.'' Every region in Italy has its specialties, but the culinary idiom of Tuscany and especially Florence may be one of the least familiar, even to those with a working knowledge of Italian food. To dine in Florence often means discarding preconceived notions of what a restaurant meal should be.

title: CAMPAIGNS OF HATE THAT MUST BE STOPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: YESHIVA SHOOTING BELIEVED LINKED TO 2 OTHERS
description: Within 15 days in June there were three shooting incidents in upper Manhattan involving shots fired from passing cars. First, on June 7, four or five shots were fired into the lobby of the main administration building of Yeshiva University, at 500 West 185th Street in Washington Heights. Then, two days later, six shots struck the Jewish Memorial Hospital building, at 196th Street and Broadway. No one was injured in either incident.

title: WORKS BOTH ORIGINAL AND ABORIGINAL
description: AT Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing in Ossining (191 Main Street) is a small but impressive display of paintings by Australian aborigines (through Aug. 14). Though these beautiful works, executed on the bark of eucalyptus trees, continue a tradition that goes back 40,000 years, they are of recent vintage, which in some ways denies their authenticity. That is to say, the designs, such as those in most tribal art, pertain to ceremonies and beliefs that are on their way to extinction if not already dead.

title: Pirates Top Giants on Rookie's 4-Hitter
description: Dave Parker drove in four runs with a double and a two-run homer, and Jose DeLeon pitched eight innings of four-hit ball in his major league debut as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat San Francisco, 5-2, today.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BURLINGTON
description: LAURIE A. O'NEILL is a writer based in Danbury, Conn. BY LAURIE A.O'NEILL

title: No Headline
description: Caring for Young Is a Shared Task Dale Salm paints a bleak picture of the moms and dads of the 80's (''A Plea for Sharing Child-Rearing Duties'' June 19). While I have not done much research in this area, I did observe many parents of young children on a recent trip to Washington, D.C. and Williamsburg, Va.

title: Players Back Umpires on Video Replays
description: It may come as a pleasant surprise to the umpires, but three of every four players in the major leagues are opposed to the use of video replays to decide arguments in baseball games.

title: Bridgeport Gaffe
description: A day after dedicating a new $2.3 million firehouse, officials in Bridgeport, Conn., were red-faced. The city did not own the land under the firehouse, they discovered.

title: Travel and Tickets
description: Arranging for travel, accommodations and tickets for the Winter and Summer Olympic Games requires some advance planning. An article in today's Travel Section tells how.

title: AMERICAN IN PARIS: THE JOYS OF BASEBALL, IN FRENCH STYLE
description: Ileft the Metro at Liberte, looking for a place called Le Velodrome Au Bois De Vincennes, a large wooded park on the fringe of Paris. It had begun to pour since I'd left the apartment, but my curiosity was aroused. I knew ''American In Paris'' and ''April in Paris,'' but baseball in Paris? Napoleon might sooner have found fresh croissants in Cairo.

title: Counterfeiting Investigators Cite Other Suspected Crimes
description: Federal investigators tracing the source of $6 million in counterfeit $100 bills also turned up allegations of weapons sales to third world countries, drug violations and insurance fraud, an examination of court documents showed today.

title: Martial Law Ends, Effects Persist
description: Poland put an end to 19 months of martial law last week but the ''liberalization'' seemed mostly symbolic. The generals and colonels kept their key Government positions. A partial amnesty offered conditional freedom - on probation - to more than 100 political prisoners. But Polish officials said 60 others, notably Solidarity union leaders and dissident intellectuals, would stay in prison; some of them face charges of ''antistate'' activities. The rubberstamp Parliament voted, 386 to 1, to empower the regime to declare a state of emergency any time the Polish national pattern of periodic strikes and protests is repeated.

title: Clinic for Vermont Jobless
description: Help is on the way to unemployed Vermonters in Windsor County, where the machine tool industry has been hit hard by layoffs caused by the recession. A group of physicians' assistants said Tuesday that they would set up a clinic to provide free medical care for the jobless. The clinic is scheduled to open Aug. 1 for a three-month trial at the Springfield Convalescent Center.

title: BERLIN: NIGHT AND DAY
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Bonn bureau of The New York Times. BY JAMES M.MARKHAM

title: CITY OFFICIALS VOTED RAISES AFTER 4 YEARS
description: New York City's elected officials got their first raise in four years last week when Mayor Koch signed a bill authorizing the increases.

title: WHEN 'HIS' AND 'HERS' BEATS 'OURS'
description: FOR most couples, marriage brings with it joint ownership of whatever they have and acquire. It seems fitting that when two hearts beat as one they should open a joint checking account and share assets. Moreover, joint ownership seems to simplify a couple's finances - either one can write the check to pay the gas bill - and it also seems to promise that property will easily pass to the surviving spouse when death ends the partnership.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Junior Ken- n edy, infielder, on designated-for-assign- m ent list and brought up Jay Loviglio, in- f ielder, from Midland of the Texas L eague. SEATTLE (AL) - Called up Al Cham- b ers, outfielder, from Salt Lake City of the P acific Coast League; placed Al Cowens, o utfielder, on 21-day disabled list. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Placed Nate (Tiny) A rchibald, guard, on clear waivers. PHOENIX (NBA) - Cut Bo Overton, g uard, and Sam Mosley, Rick Lamb, Ed- w ard Bona and Joe Dykstra, forwards.

title: THE ANALYST AND HER ANALYSAND
description: AUGUST By Judith Rossner. 376 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title: A CAMP FOR THE YOUNG AT HEART
description: FALLS VILLAGE IN the recreation hall, Florence Muller and Jean Judashko were dancing to a Neil Sedaka record. In the lounge, Leon Schlam was playing chess. Selma Toback sat on the sun deck outside her room, writing postcards to friends and family back home in the Bronx.

title: The Curtain Gets Stuck at Madrid
description: Three years of tedious diplomacy gave way to less subtle examples of statecraft in Madrid last week, as the conference on East-West Relations in Europe drew fitfully toward a close. While the chief American delegate and his Soviet counterpart swapped acrimony on human rights issues, the island nation of Malta kept everyone from going home by refusing to approve the final document unless it called for a follow-up conference on Mediterranean security.

title: October Wedding For Mary Parson
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Parson of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Beth Parson, to Kevin William Donnellon, son of Thomas Andrew Donnellon of Cincinnati and the late Jane Hatfield Donnellon.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN ON a recent Sunday, two bizarre events happened to me: my daughter was graduated from high school and my friend Murray Chassin celebrated his 50th birthday.

title:
TV VIEW;
MTV - A SUCCESS STORY WITH A CURIOUS SHORTCOMING
description: Music Television, or MTV, is a whopping cable success with a problem. The 24-hour daily service offers a collection of videotapes featuring pop-music stars playing their own material. Some of the tapes are more or less straightforward recordings of concerts before enthusiastic audiences. At the other end of the spectrum, some tapes contain elaborate dramatizations that are keyed to the lyrics, sometimes rather loosely but often very cleverly. The result in any given hour can resemble a sea of capped teeth and fashionable leather togs, all held together with a variety of rhythmic beats. In any event, younger audiences evidently like the product, and MTV is establishing an important presence in both cable programming and record sales.

title: OUT, THEY EXPLAIN
description: Federal authorities in Chicago last week resumed their efforts to deport Dennis Brutus, the Zimbabwean-born poet and longtime critic of South Africa's apartheid polices. But they still aren't telling him why. Mr. Brutus, a professor at Northwestern University, has sought political asylum, saying he might be murdered in southern Africa. The Government says the case against him is based on classified information, to which he has been denied access.

title: RANGEL RELUCTANTLY TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: In 1980, Mayor Koch's decision to close Sydenham Hospital plunged Representative Charles B. Rangel from the heady world of Washington statesmanship into the sweaty street politics of Harlem. During one argument with city officials, a mayoral aide remembers, the Congressman exploded in frustration: ''You're making me a district leader again.'' Last week, Mr. Rangel found himself in similar straits when he was swept into the public debate over allegations of police brutality against New York City's minority groups.

title: MR. PRESIDENT, THE BALL IS IN YOUR COURT
description: IHATE to be the pit in the applesauce, Ron, but I don't think this N ew Federalism thing is going to make it. Don't get me wrong. I'm a ll for the idea of returning government to the local level, but if w hat just happened between me and our town recreation department is a n example of local, the level can get pretty subterranean.

title: MOVING UP ON EAST SIDE
description: Since Temple Shaaray Tefila moved from its last home on the West Side in 1959 to its current location on the corner of East 79th Street and Second Avenue, its membership has nearly quadrupled. Consequently, quarters in its adjoining community house have been tight, to say the least.

title: Miss Hoadley Is Wed To Stephen B. Burke
description: Gretchen Hoadley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Hoadley of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen B. Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Burke of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. John Weber performed the ceremony at the Hilltop Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J.

title: WARNING LIGHTS FLASH FOR EARPHONE USERS
description: Like other insidious ailments, hearing loss lies in wait for a long time and sneaks up slowly on its victims. Sometimes it takes years of traumatic exposure to high sound levels before any symptoms become manifest. Yet the vogue for portable sound equipment - such as Walkman-type radios and tape players - has already produced an alarming increase of clinically verified hearing damage, especially among rock addicts who like their music loud.

title: No Headline
description: Wild Mushrooms On the Island In regard to the article on wild mushrooms (''Mushrooms? Pick an Expert Picker,'' June 26), I hasten to inform readers that Amanita phalloides (known as death cap or death cup) has been found recently on Long Island. I have sent collections to the New York Botanical Garden, where they have been checked and placed in the herborium.

title: 100 Guggenheim Works Will Be Lent to Japan
description: One hundred paintings from the collection of the Guggenheim Museum will travel to the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Shirogane Garden this fall for an exhibition called ''Modern Art in the West.''

title: HARMONY IN DIFFERENT KEYS
description: SHE is panicked by performing. He thrives on it. She is a popular song and jazz stylist, rooted in the interiors of recording and radio studios, where she would rather remain. He is steeped in the slick style of up-front Broadway showmanship.

title: Sympathy Won't Help
description: As the death toll rose to seven in the Orly airport bombing, the French Government last week painfully weighed its longstanding sympathy for Armenian nationalism.

title: BLUE JAYS TRIUMPH TO KEEP FIRST PLACE
description: Ernie Whitt doubled home two runs and Jim Clancy scattered nine hits as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Texas Rangers, 3-2, tonight, to retain first place in the American League East. It was the Rangers' 14th loss in 18 games.

title: No Headline
description: Let Some Convicts Work Off Sentences I was happy to see the article, ''Service Instead of Jail Gaining Proponents'' (June 26).

title: Raclette
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's piece ''In the Swiss Valais, Raclette Is a Ritual'' (Travel, June 19) brought fond memories of the times when, as a student, I was introduced to raclette while skiing in Zermatt in 1935.

title: CRACKS EXTEND NUCLEAR SHUTDOWN
description: WORKERS at the Millstone 2 nuclear reactor in Waterford have found cracks in metal in the radioactive and nonradioactive parts of the facility, and repairs will keep the state's largest nuclear plant closed until the end of the year.

title: 200 Union Workers Riot At Montana Pipeline Site
description: Two-hundred union workers stormed a pipeline construction site today, smashing windows, slashing tires and damaging heavy equipment in a protest against nonunion, out-of-state workers, the officials said.

title: UNIVERSITY DEBATES COMPUTER'S ADVENT
description: MIDDLETOWN AFTER more than 500 students at Wesleyan University were turned away from an introductory computer class because of a lack of teachers and computer terminals, angry students demanded that the university enter the computer age.

title: IN WET YEAR, DROUGHT DEVASTATES WEST TEXAS
description: Gerry Puckett watched intently through the windshield as his station wagon lurched along the dry dirt road of his Glass Mountain Ranch. Behind the mountain a huge angry cumulonimbus cloud gathered, throwing dazzling bolts of lightning onto the desert floor and sending a chill wind whistling through the mesquite.

title: WHEN NEW YORK CITY BECOMES SUBJECT MATTER
description: Compared to painting, photography has a limited range of styles. But when the subject is varied and many-sided, photography can be varied and many-sided, too. Certainly this is true when the subject is New York City, as it is in three summer shows currently on view.

title:
ART;
IN SEARCH OF NAIVE SPIRIT
