description: THE drive to give form to the creative impulse is not unique to the trained artist. Many people with no formal schooling in the techniques of painting and sculpture have produced objects and images of undeniable esthetic value, often without a motive beyond that of personal pleasure.

title: PROUST IS FILMED AT LAST
description: PARIS DH. Lawrence called ''Remembrance of Things Past'' the ''deathrattle'' of the novel, but most literary critics placed Proust's work alongside James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' as one of the great monuments of modernism and fiction. Now, after 21 years and several abortive attempts, Proust's mythic characters are finding a new existence on film. A movie of ''Swann in Love,'' a novella within the novel, has entered the second month of shooting in Paris with Volker Schlondorff (''The Tin Drum'') directing Jeremy Irons as Swann, whose tortured love for Odette de Crecy taught the 20th century how violent tender emotions can be. Proust invented a new concept to sum up romantic passion: ''l'amour-maladie,'' love as disease.

title: Miss Grauer to Marry Richard S. Finkelstein
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Murray Grauer of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Eve Grauer, to Richard Scott Finkelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lester Finkelstein of Long Beach, L.I. The wedding is to be in June 1984.
Size: To three inches wide and four inches tall. Color: Column ranges from chocolate brown through reddish, yellowbrown, creamy white to white.

title: A RIPPLE EFFECT?
description: In every borough of the city, there are shining examples of blocks where the home improvements made by a couple of residents have served as catalysts for the rejuvenation of entire neighborhoods. With that sort of ripple effect in mind, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is investing $200,000 in home improvement grants to be used in seven older neighborhoods of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

title: THE DANCE: 'BLUE PANIC' BY TAPESTRY
description: ''Blue Panic,'' the two-act work that the Tapestry Dance Theater Company presented on Friday night at Performance Space 122, was a little bit of this and a little bit of that. Directed by Nikki Cole, produced by Vance Baxter Vogel, and conceived and choreographed by its cast, it offered a little dancing to pop records, a little dialogue, a little sentiment, a little melodrama and a little soulsearching.

title: BOXING AND THE BRAIN
description: In his article, David Noonan quoted James Florio, chairman of the Congressional subcommittee that is investigating boxing, but he overlooked the transcripts of those experts who spoke before the subcommittee. He might have mentioned my own testimony, stating that it is possible to manufacture gloves with modern fibers and foams that can reduce the dangerous impact of a gloved fist by more than 60 percent. He might have made reference to the work of Floyd Patterson in designing protective gear; to the new set of rules that permits a trained boxing physician to stop a fight; and to the special training seminars for physicians, trainers and referees to enable them to recognize brain traumas and related symptoms. ARNOLD DE PASQUALE Chairman Ad-Hoc Committee for a National Ring Commission Closter, N.J.

title: POLO: 'QUITE AN HONORABLE WAY TO DIE'
description: ''Let me explain to you the rules of polo as it is meant to be played,'' said Ali Ahmad Jan, Gilgit's superintendent of police. ''There are absolutely none.''

title: ADVANCES WITH GENES EXCITE CANCER RESEARCHERS
description: Dr. Chi Nguyen-Huu's laboratory in the urology department of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is a quiet place. The sound of research is rarely louder than the clink of test tubes or the whir of a centrifuge.

title: A New Option for The Infertile
description: For an estimated two million American women who cannot become pregnant, the odds that medical science might help them bear their own children have been poor. The technique of in vitro or ''testtube'' fertilization - in which an egg is surgically removed from a woman, united with sperm in a glass dish and then reinserted in the mother-to-be -has had only a 25 percent success rate and cannot be attempted with all infertile women. Some cannot tolerate the surgery; others do not have functioning ovaries or cannot produce healthy eggs.

title:
GARDENING;
BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS FOR GARDEN WEEDS
description: GARDENERS are familiar with the development of biological controls for insects and diseases. By infecting gypsy moth larvae with Bacillus thuringiensis and Japanese beetle larvae with milky spore disease, these two major plant pests may be brought under control. Many insects, including the gypsy moth, may be effectively controlled by introducing certain species of predatory wasps. Fire blight, a bacterial disease of apples and pears, can be held in check by spraying with certain antibiotics.

title: EXPLORING CANADA'S ALGONQUIN PARK
description: JOANNE KATES is the author of ''Exploring Algonquin Park'' (Douglas & McIntyre, Toronto) and restaurant critic of The Globe and Mail of Toronto. By JOANNE KATES

title: GARIFUNAS' LAST STAND
description: To the Editor:

title: SPRAWLING LOS ANGELES OLYMPIC PLAN TAKES PLACE
description: LOS ANGELES ONE year from Thursday, the Olympic torch will be lighted atop Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum where, 51 years ago, it was extinguished after the last Summer Olympic Games in the United States.

title: LITERARY CRIMINALS
description: A segment of the French intelligentsia was embarrassed a few weeks ago when a writer named Roger Knobelspiess was arrested for armed robbery. He was at large at the time because President Francois Mitterrand had pardoned him after he had served part of a five-year sentence for holdups carried out in 1977. Two books he wrote while in jail on the horrors of prison life in a non-Marxist state brought him the admiraton and support of such notables as the social historian Michel Foucault, Claude Manceron, a historian on President Mitterrand's staff, and, of course, Yves Montand and Simone Signoret. ''I am the legitimacy of the left,'' proclaimed Mr. Knobelspiess, and part of the left believed him. Said Mr. Manceron of Mr. Knobelspiess, ''France must not deprive itself of this natural resource.''

title: ADVISERS IN SALVADOR: A DEBATE SINCE '81
description: The role and number of American military advisers in El Salvador has been debated since the training of Salvadoran soldiers began in earnest in 1981.

title: BUSINESSES ARE RESPONDING TO UPTURN IN THE ECONOMY
description: SADDLE BROOK WITH the economy finally showing signs of recovering from its nosedive, New Jersey manufacturers are making decisions on the best way to get their businesses moving again.

title: BATTLING THE AIDS MYSTERY
description: IF the three patients suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the University Hospital at Stony Brook look out their windows, they can see acres of deep green woods stretching to the pale waters of Long Island Sound and Connecticut like a shadow on the horizon. Unfortunately, it's a view that may do little to relieve their despair.

title: PATENT TRADER IS PURCHASED
description: CARLL TUCKER 3d, whose father founded the Patent Trader newspaper in northern Westchester in the 1950's, bought it back last week from a Southern newspaper chain that had acquired it after his father's death.

title: A DARING NEW WORLD FOR THRIFTS IN THE MAKING
description: ROBERT R. DOCKSON is euphoric. Only six months ago, his California Federal Savings and Loan Association was losing millions. By May it was a sweetheart of Wall Street and the spark that set off an explosion of new stock issues by thrift institutions across the nation.

title: FAREWELL TO LEVITTOWN HIGH
description: ALL current and former students of Levittown Memorial High School were invited to attend the Panther Wake last month. This curiously named party was a bittersweet affair for those who attended, for it marked the closing of Levittown Memorial.

title: HEAVIER BURDEN OF POVERTY SEEN FOR NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN THE poverty of this city will only get worse, a special commission has concluded after a five-month study. In a report to be released Monday, the Special Commission on Poverty explored in detail what happened to cause the Census Bureau to rank New Haven seventh poorest in the nation among cities with a population of more than 100,000.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: GODPLAYER By Robin Cook. 368 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: DREAMY JOSEPH AND BUSINESSLIKE ETIENNE
description: THE MONTGOLFIER BROTHERS AND THE INVENTION OF AVIATION, 1783 1784 By Charles Coulston Gillispie. Illustrated. 210 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $35.

title: Five Towns
description: To the Editor:

title: A GUIDE TO TITLE SERVICES IN THE REGION
description: I N the anxious days before title to a house changes hands, the buyer's mind is not likely to turn in fevered curiosity to the fees that will be due for title services at the closing.

title: CONDOMINIUM BIDS RISE IN GLEN COVE
description: THE number of applications for condominium developments in Glen Cove is on the rise. According to Steven Misiakiewicz, building department administrator for the city, ''the condominium market in Glen Cove is wide open - we're nowhere near the saturation point.''

title: THE ROLE OF THE ORCHESTRATOR IN THE SOUND OF A MUSICAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Taping at Home
description: To the Business Editor: The Supreme Court's postponed decision in the home videotaping case, pending further argument, can bring comfort to neither party.

title: THE SZYMANOWSKI CENTENNIAL YIELDS A CROP OF RECORDINGS
description: One of the less fortunate aspects of last year's Stravinsky centennial was that it overshadowed that of Karol Szymanowski, but the phonographic dividends of the anniversary have been considerable for Szymanowski. Thanks to issues from several companies, the bulk of his orchestral and chamber music is now available in newly recorded performances, sympathetically interpreted.

title: No Headline
description: Artist Comments On His New Institute While generally welcoming and appreciating your regional art critic Helen Harrison's appreciative recent review of the opening of my art institute in Bridgehampton (''Firehouse Becomes His Own 'Museum,' '' June 26), I want to comment to the contrary, briefly.

title: Detroit's Ren Cen
description: To the Business Editor: Your article on the causes and effects of the Renaissance Center's failure to revive Detroit is certainly valid (''The Renaissance Center: Ford's Costly and Failing Bid to Revive Detroit,'' July 3). But perhaps another major reason for its demise is that architecturally, in concept, the complex was ill-conceived.

title: THREE RESPONSES TO YANKEE FAN
description: To the Sports Editor: I am convinced that Sidney Zion is ''putting us on; that he is in fact a National League fan, or even a Yankee hater. His article gives vivid illustration of what anti-Yankeeism is made of.

title: Blaze Kills 210,000 Chickens
description: About 210,000 chickens were killed in a fire at an egg farm that caused an estimated $3 million in damage, Jackson County sheriff's deputies said today. Some firefighters suffered minor injuries in the blaze Friday night at the Rose Acres Farms one mile north of Acme. Six chicken houses and a warehouse with machinery were destroyed, said Lewis Corya, a sheriff's dispatcher.

title: MARITIME FESTIVAL
description: If you've got it, why not flaunt it? And since Westhampton's past is closely tied to the maritime industry, that community's Free Library is staging a ''Down to the Sea in History Week.'' The festivities get under way today at 1 P.M., when the library's grounds, on Library Avenue in Westhampton Beach, are transformed into a 17th-century fishing village, complete with local fishermen demonstrating such activities as making winkle pots and nets and telling tall tales, plus a concert of folk music. On Friday at 7 P.M. the folk singer Stephen SanFilippo recreates the history of whaling through traditional folk songs. The celebration ends Saturday at 6:30 P.M., when William C. Nagle, a historic-model shipbuilder, explores his craft and Judge Harold Medina talks about his collection of model ships. Everything is free.

title: POLITICIZING EDUCATION
description: A BRIEF article in a recent issue of the ''Chronicle of Higher Education,'' a national weekly newspaper devoted to colleges and universities, reported that the closing of UConn's Torrington campus had been delayed. Innocent readers could have assumed that a rational and logical process was under way, rather than what has proven to be one of the most blatant examples of the politicization of higher education seen in this state during the past quarter-century.

title: MOUNTING FINANCIAL PROBLEMS IMPERIL PROGRESSIVE MAGAZINE
description: On Jan. 9, 1909, Robert M. LaFollette Sr. started a magazine he hoped would amplify the doctrines of his progressive movement.

title: Cladistics
description: To the Editor:$

title: IT'S NOT 'WOMEN'S ART,' IT'S GOOD ART
description: There are more good women artists in the United States than in any other country. This has nothing to do with the size of the population, or even with the overall number of women artists. It has to do with the quality of the work, but it also involves a social factor, a professional factor, a liberationist factor and even (on one recent reading) a neurological factor. It stands for the demise of an ancient, cumbersome and quite pointless distinction. There is no such thing as ''women's art.'' There is just good art, and a great deal of it is now being made by women.

title: Casper Ahead by 3
description: Billy Casper overcame a stiff wind and hard greens to shoot a two-over-par 73 today for a 54-hole total of 215 and a three-stroke lead in the $175,000 United States Senior Open.

title: PANEL CONSIDERS U.S. COPYRIGHT LAW
description: Seven years ago, when Congress finished the first complete overhaul of Federal copyright law since 1909, members turned from the 15-year-long project with relief. Copyright law, they felt, was finally up to date, able to accommodate such 20th century innovations as the Xerox machine.

title: Polly Norris Plans to Wed In September
description: Mr. and Mrs. William K. Norris of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Polly Foster Norris, to David Graham Ober, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Ober Jr. of Monkton, Md. The wedding is to be Sept. 24.

title: L.I. BOAT BLAST ENDS IN 3 DEATHS
description: A Shelter Island man and his companion were killed when their sailboat exploded early this morning, and the man's father died, apparently of a heart attack, trying to save them, the police said.

title: THE SOLITARY JOYS OF SCULLING
description: Peter Stoler is a senior correspondent for the Time-Life News Service. By Peter Stoler TANDING ON THE BANK OF THE Charles River at 6 A.M. in shorts and T-shirt, Walter Burke looks just like the dozens of similarly dressed joggers who are bending, stretching and psyching themselves for an early-morning run along the stream that separates Cambridge from Boston.

title: Brutality Inquiry Ends Abruptly
description: In a crowded and sweltering room in the Harlem State Office Building, a Congressional subcomittee had barely begun its inquiry into allegations of police brutality against black and Hispanic New Yorkers last week when it was disrupted by a spectator screaming, ''They killed my son.'' Though the tumult that followed precluded further testimony, at least in the minds of those who presided -some stayed on for a ''people's hearing'' - the episode did furnish fresh evidence of the strained relations between leaders of the city's minority groups and City Hall.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: GREAT NECK
description: GREAT NECK has come to symbolize American wealth in the same sense that Beverly Hills or Palm Beach d o, and in recent years it has attracted well-to-do foreigners - p rimarily Iranians and Asians - who know its reputation.

title: JAZZ: WILSON LEADS GROUP AT VANGUARD
description: Jack Wilson made his belated New York debut as a leader last week at the Village Vanguard. He has played piano in jazz groups since the 1950's, and has recorded as a leader since the 1960's.

title: MASSEY MAY BE WINNING AT LAST
description: TORONTO IN the five years that he has headed Massey-Ferguson Ltd., Victor Rice cut its work force by half, closed or sold 15 plants and wheedled hundreds of millions of quick bucks from nervous banks and governments under the threat of Massey's turning belly up. Along the way, the color red became as familiar on the company's balance sheets as on its giant combines rolling majestically across the world's prairies.

title: 'Japanning'
description: To the Business Editor: Now that the furor over the ''Japanning'' of America has subsided somewhat, a story I heard 50 years ago, as a senior engineering student at the University of Florida, may be timely.

title: BALLET: MISS MAKAROVA IN HUGO WORK
description: It must be fun to dance for Roland Petit, whose Ballet National de Marseilles is performing at the Metropolitan Opera House through July 30. Or so it looked in performances on Wednesday and Friday nights, when Gilles Cochinaire and Natalia Makarova took over roles in two full-evening dramatic ballets by Mr. Petit.

title: SPEAKING THROUGH OUR CLOTHES
description: THE FASHION SYSTEM By Roland Barthes. Translated by Matthew Ward and Richard Howard. 303 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $20.50.

title: EXHIBITION ON SHOGUNS TO TOUR U.S.
description: ''The Shogun Age,'' an exhibition of objects from the 350-year-old family collection of the Tokugawa shogunate of Japan, will begin touring the United States and Europe in December in the first showing anywhere of some of the finest examples of the art prized by the feudal lords.

title: A 'FIRST' FOR GIFTED STUDENTS
description: WEST LONG BRANCH MORE THAN 110 of New Jersey's top high school students have spent this hot July on the Monmouth College campus here, pondering problems that confront the state and the world.

title: THE ODDS IN EL SALVADOR
description: Lydia Chavez is The Times's correspondent in El Salvador. By Lydia Chavez HE SHABBY OLD FORD JOUNCED THROUGH THE FASH-ionable neighborhood of San Salvador, past the fortresslike homes of the rich. Col. John D. Waghelstein rode shotgun, in civvies, his cowboy boots buffed to a shine, a pistol tucked under his loose-fitting guayabera shirt. Beside him lay a satchel of charts and graphs.

title: LABOR'S NEW DRIVE TO LEARN ABOUT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: WITHIN minutes of his arrival at an employee picnic on Long Island, C harles E. Bryan was besieged with questions like ''How are we doing f inancially, Charlie?'' ''Are we really going broke?'' As members of t he International Association of Machinists employed at Eastern A irlines terminals at Kennedy and La Guardia Airports gathered aroundt he 49-year-old union president, their concern was not for the u nion's strike fund, but the airline's balance sheet.

title: TRAGEDY COMEDY; Bible Beater
description: In his Nobel lecture, the Colombian author Gabriel Garcia Marquez said that what resembles fantasy in Latin fiction is simple realism. He could have repeated this true tale about Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, the evangelical dictator of Guatemala.

title: EX-COLLEGE CHIEF
description: Roswell Gray Ham, the first male president of Mount Holyoke College, who retired in 1957 after 20 years in the post, died Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif., after a brief illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Linda Ziglar Wed To Gregory Miles
description: Linda Anne Ziglar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Maxton Ziglar of Hampton, Va., was married there yesterday to Gregory Lynn Miles, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leland Miles of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Robert C. Hastings performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church, Fox Hill.

title: Frances E. Willis, 84, A Former U.S. Envoy
description: Frances E. Willis, the first female career diplomat to become a full ambassador, died Wednesday at her home after a long illness. She was 84 years old.

title: Scott Defeats Coe In 3:51.56 Mile Run
description: Steve Scott of the United States beat Sebastian Coe by more than 20 feet tonight and won the one-mile run in 3 minutes 51.56 seconds at the British Amateur Athletic Association championships.

title: THE ROLE OF THE ORCHESTRATOR IN THE SOUND OF A MUSICAL
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT INVALIDATES STATE PERMIT FOR PCB BURIAL
description: A State Supreme Court judge has revoked a permit issued by a state siting board that would have permitted the Department of Environmental Conservation to dredge polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, from the Hudson River and bury them on land.

title: Bronco Lineman Jumps
description: Don Latimer, the Denver Broncos' nose tackle, has signed to play with the new Jacksonville, Fla., franchise of the United States Football League, and the Broncos' coach, Dan Reeves, is seething. Latimer, who plans to play out the last year of his Bronco contract this fall and join Jacksonville next spring, said he had accepted a two-year contract with the new team partly because he liked Florida, the state in which he grew up.

title: Study Finds Interferon Curbs Effect of Cancer
description: The natural disease-fighting substance interferon will substantially reduce the painful side effects of intestinal cancer, a new study shows.

title: No Headline
description: The 'Future' Seminar: Some Added Credits Tessa Melvin's article on the Hudson Institute's recent teachertraining seminar (''Teachers Gather to Study Future,'' July 10) was generally excellent. However, I was embarrassed that no mention was made of the individuals and organizations that made this pilot project possible.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE TREASURES AN ISLAND HOLDS
description: WITH the Atlantic Ocean as its eastern shore and Little Egg Harbor and Barnegat Bay as its western, this island has become a magnet for sun and surf devotees and summer fishermen. So strong is its attraction, in fact, that the modest year-round population of 12,000 swells to 100,000 during the summer months.

title: San Francisco Expects 10,000-Plus in Marathon
description: The San Francisco Marathon, which expanded its course to include more of the city in an effort to attract more runners, is expected to have more than 10,000 starters Sunday.

title: COUNTRY: PETER ROWAN
description: Peter Rowan came to the Lone Star on Wednesday with two guests, Flaco Jimenez on button accordion and Tex Logan on fiddle. His late set was a desultory jam session and was especially frustrating because Mr. Jimenez so rarely appears in New York.

title: 'SOUND OF MUSIC': RESOUNDING RETURN
description: WHAT can one say about ''The Sound of Music,'' Rodgers and Hammerstein's last and most simplistically sentimental collaboration? Nothing, except that it works.

title: IT STARTED WITH A T-SHIRT
description: ''WHEN I started,'' said Judy Loeb, ''the average age for a first birth was 22 and now it's between 29 and 30. Not only are the women older and more sophisticated, but they have for the most part begun careers, which means that they're more affluent and much more in need of a diverse wardrobe and for clothes to go to work in.''

title: CHINA NOW ATTACKS TAIWAN ARMS DEAL
description: China has lodged a strong protest with the United States over the sale of arms to Taiwan, the official New China News Agency said today.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
CHAPTERS IN THE LIFE OF AN ASPIRING WRITER
description: IN THE winter, I am an unpublished writer. In the summer, I am a writer manque. In the winter, I am a part-time college student (an English major) and a part-time nurse. When I am home during the day, I am home alone. The outdoors does not beckon. The house temperature is at an energy-saving 68, an invigorating temperature.

title: YOUTH GAGS ROB FANS AFTER SHOW
description: Bands of roving youths attacked and harassed fans leaving the Diana Ross concert in Central Park and others strolling nearby on Friday night, and the police said yesterday that more than 80 people had been arrested.

title: A-Bomb Sequel
description: When the Army got serious about building an atomic bomb in 1942, it looked for a wide-open test site and picked New Mexico. Arrangements were made with 149 ranchers to lease their land, and the White Sands Proving Ground was created.

title: Song for Chicago
description: Alderman Louis Farina was at an Armed Forces Week luncheon in Chicago in May 1982, and when the generals were introduced, they marched briskly down the aisle to the beat of military anthems. When Alderman Farina was introduced, the band struck up ''My Kind of Town,'' a song made popular by Frank Sinatra.

title: Sharon Douglas Becomes a Bride
description: Sharon Knox Douglas, daughter of Mrs. William W. Campbell Jr. and Lawrence H. Douglas, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel John McGinty, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward James McGinty of Greenwich. The Rev. William J. Good, the bride's greatuncle, who is rector emeritus of the Episocopal Church of the Epiphany in Providence, R. I., performed the ceremony at Le Chateau restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: EASING THE PAIN OF CAPITAL-GAINS TAX
description: The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance has begu to put into effect a interpretation of the state's newly enacted capital-gains tax on real-estate sales. It should lessen the impact of the tax on new construction and result in refunds for developers who already have made payments.

title: HARD CLAMS: NOW, FOR OPENERS...
description: IT HAS been said that more blood has been spilled over the years in trying to open hard clams than was lost during the Civil War. There may be some question about the authenticity of this statement, but there is no question that the hard clam can be a difficult adversary when approached by a novice for the first time.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissions is looking for volunteers among its 275 members and the public to help conduct the state's first monitoring program for acid rain.

title: THREE VERSIONS OF BRAHMS'S RHAPSODIES
description: The duplication and reduplication of familiar repertory on records are often as tedious as they are wasteful. Still, the comparisons they offer are occasionally helpful. We are celebrating, as nearly everyone must surely know by now, the 150th year of Brahms's birth, and three very different pianists from varied backgrounds have given us recordings of his two, much-played, much-recorded piano Rhapsodies, Op. 79.

title: CAR INSURANCE: STILL A DEAD END
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN and leaders of the State Legislature met for more than an hour and a half last week in an attempt to find some common approach to solving the state's nagging automobile-insurance problems. When it was over and the principals met with reporters, it became apparent that little headway was made.

title:
THE NATION;
No Scars Yet In Duel Over Carter Papers
description: A Congressional inquiry into the purloined Carter campaign papers showed signs of settling into trench warfare last week.

title: No Hiding Behind The Calendar for Jersey Polluters
description: A segment of Berry's Creek in the Hackensack Meadowlands has the highest fresh-water sediment concentrations of mercury found anywhere in the world. Last week, this and other aspects of a case against several chemical companies led the New Jersey Supreme Court to rule unanimously that ''those who poison the land must pay for its cure'' regardless of how much time has passed.

title: Veronica Whitlock Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Whitlock of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Veronica Penelope Whitlock, to Alexander Mellon Laughlin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laughlin of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The wedding is to be in October.

title: OYSTER BAY TAKES PLUNGE WITH POOL
description: TO an outsider, the four-foot-high platform on Tappen Beach in Glenwood Landing doesn't look like much. But area residents know that the rectangular structure used to provide summer solace. After six years, the Town of Oyster Bay has finally obtained Federal funds to replace the former Tappen Beach pool with a new $731,000 pool.

title:
THE NATION;
Draft Opponent Back on the Hook
description: A Federal district judge ruled in November that the Government had improperly revived registration for the draft and had then unfairly sought to prosecute a California man - a vocal opponent of registration -for refusing to sign up.

title: IS IT TRUE WHAT THEY SAY ABOUT SINGERS?
description: Idon't read the journal called Personality and Individual Differences as regularly as I should. In fact, I don't recall ever reading it at all. So I probably would never have known, were it not for a recent report in Britain's Sunday Times, that singers believe sopranos and tenors are more likely than their lower-voiced colleagues to suffer stage fright, to miss cues and otherwise to behave in erratic, conceited or difficult ways. People within the vocal calling, according to a survey made by Glenn D. Wilson of London's Institute of Psychiatry, also believe that lower-voiced singers tend to be taller, thinner and more determined to succeed professionally. They also think that low-voiced men are ''more inclined to have sexual affairs with fellow singers.''

title: For Many Blacks The Gap Remains
description: The glory days of the civil rights movement seemed even farther away last week after the release of a new study on the status of black Americans. Despite substantial gains in education since the 1960's, blacks are still overwhelmingly disadvantaged in almost every economic category, it showed.

title: FOR TENANTS, NEW STATE LAW HAS BROAD IMPLICATIONS
description: ON July 1, an unheralded change in state law eliminated the rather b road powers of New York City tenants to transfer their apartment l eases - often at a profit - to others. Under such transfers, called a ssignments, the new tenant acquired all the rights and r esponsibilities of the old tenant under the lease, including the r ight to renew the lease.

title: BOY'S SILENT WORLD BRIGHTENS WITH FRESH AIR FAMILY
description: Sunbeams shifted in the country church where Susanna Pray and Richard Campora were being married. Six children - her three, his two and a boy from the South Bronx whom she loved - stood at the altar. A song rose up from two young girls with a guitar, and the notes trembled in the heat.

title: Donna Leahy To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harrison J. O'Connor of Falmouth, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. O'Connor's daughter, Donna Lynn Leahy, to Walter Dillingham Wick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Arms Wick Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned in New York.

title: HOW TO FIND CARE
description: MANY employers tend to equate supporting child care with putting a n ursery school next to the chief executive's office. But that doesn'th ave to be the case. Because of increased demand by parents, c ompanies are beginning to seek alternatives to on-site child care. M ost companies now concerned with the problem are interested in i nformation and referral services about existing child care.

title: THIS IS THE LIFE AND ART OF LARRY RIVERS, OR SO IT SEEMS
description: NOTHING seems to be quite what it seems to be when it comes to the life and art of Larry Rivers. Not even his age. For heaven's sakes, that should be straightforward. His acclaimed 1979 autobiographical work, ''Drawings and Digressions,'' lists his birthdate as Aug. 17, 1923. You would think that would be reliable - he did write the book. Every newspaper and magazine clipping that has mentioned him in the last 30 years - and there have been thousands - has used that date. ''Current Biography,'' the bible of birthdays, uses that date.

title: OPERA FESTIVAL, DRAMA AND CRAFTS; Opera Festival Honors Janacek
description: Everybody knows about the Wagner performances at Bayreuth and the music festival at Salzburg. But what about Brno? Brno, a city of 365,000 people in the Moravia region of Czechoslovakia, is a magnet for music lovers each year when it pays tribute to its most famous citizen, the composer Leos Janacek. Janacek went to the city at the age of 11 in 1867 and taught and composed there until his death 57 years ago.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Summer often finds dancers performing in unconventional spaces. Thus, ''The Celebrate Brooklyn'' series offers examples of many dance forms at the 9th St. Bandshell at Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.

title: 2 HOSPITALS IN CITY PRESSED TO CUT CONSTRUCTION
description: New York State has warned St. Clare's Hospital and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center that their rebuilding plans will not be approved unless they eliminate what the state regards as unnecessary renovations and redundant services.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Bridgewater $75,200 *2*82 Oak Street 3-bedroom 1-1/2 bath, new colonial; *2*50-by-200 foot lot, kitchen with dinette area; *2*taxes to be assessed. Cranford $124,500 *2*505 Springfield Avenue, 5-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, *2*65-year-old colonial; refinished wood *2*floors, new wiring, cedar closets; taxes $2,719. Hampton $145,000 *2*Mechlins Corner Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*3-1/2-year-oldranch; 2 fireplaces, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,600 Hopatcong $64,000 *2*33 Musconetcong Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*18-year-old ranch; deck with lake view, wall-to-wall *2*carpeting; taxes $,610. Pompton Lakes $99,500 *2*104 Hemlock Road, 3-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, *2*50-year-old Tudor; lakefront lot, *2*beamed ceilings; taxes $2,330 Union City $125,000 *2*1900 Kennedy Boulevard, 4-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; mahogany floors, *2*fireplace, garage; taxes $4,364 OTHER AREAS Croton-on-Hudson, NY $78,000 *2*211 Cleveland Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old *2*frame ranch; den, playroom enclosed porch, *2*0.75 acre; taxes $4,068 Goshen, Conn $204,000 *2*Hyerdale Drive, 3-bedroom, e-bath, 5-year-old *2*contemporary, lakefront property, wide decks, *2*1 acre, taxes $2,000. Holtsville, L.I. $66,000 *2*22 Concord Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*6-year-old ranch; formal dining room, *2*den, taxes $2,400

title: UNDERSTANDING MONDALE
description: In discussing that Norwegian-American, Walter Mondale, David Harris makes the assumption that there is such a thng as Norwegian national character. Well, one of the greatest of Norwegians, Henrik Ibsen, used to make the same assumption, and, in ''Peer Gynt,'' advanced the notion that the main Norwegian gift is one forself-deception working itself out in mendacious, self-aggrandizing fantasies. Had he lived to read Thurber, Ibsen would have pronounced Walter Mitty a Norwegian. Walter Mitty -and Walter Mondale? ERIC BENTLEY New York City

title: Susan Kathryn Beucher Weds George L. Cady Jr.
description: Susan Kathryn Beucher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Joseph Beucher of Carle Place, L.I., was married yesterday to George Leonard Cady Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cady of Littleton, Colo. The Rev. Paul Danielle and the Rev. Michael O'Neil, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at the United Westbury Methodist Church on Long Island.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
INS AND OUTS OF AL FRESCO PEOPLE WATCHING
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN George Tsokris eats at Peter Pastor's Restaurant, he takes a camera. That is because he sits outside at a sidewalk table, where he and a few dozen others dining al fresco can watch the continuing ebb and flow of Mamaroneck Avenue.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FOR months, Daniel P. Nugent of Morristown, chief executive officer of ITT Grinnell, an industrial manufacturing company of New York City and Providence, has been trying to get local businessmen interested in playing golf.

title: Patricia Hannafey Married
description: Patricia Elizabeth Hannafey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Hannafey of Stratford, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Louis Fernandez, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Fernandez of New York. The Rev. Victor Martin performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Norwalk, Conn.

title: THEATER: 'GAMES' OPENS CYCLE BY BLACK WOMEN
description: Woodie King Jr.'s New Federal Theater and Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival are co-sponsoring a cycle of four plays by new black women playwrights through Aug. 7 at the Henry Street Settlement. The opening play, Joyce Walker-Joseph's ''Games,'' is a lackluster attempt at depicting a black man's domination over black women.

title: Study of Public Education Urges Basic Changes
description: Recent months have seen the issue of quality in public education rise to levels of debate usually occupied by war and peace. Last week, the most comprehensive study of American schools since the early 1940's pointed to ''deeply entrenched and virtually chronic'' problems that call for ''far-reaching restructuring'' of the system. Partisans on all sides of the current argument will find a richly documented source book, but will its prescriptions spur a consensus for action, or just more complaints?

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 7 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 2 5 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 3 3 19 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) A British actress caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 4 4 16 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 5 5 13 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 6 7 11 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 7 6 3 GODPLAYER, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $13.95.) The marriage of two physicians crumbles as death stalks their hospital's corridors. 8 8 8 ASCENT INTO HELL, by Andrew M. Greeley.

title: The Mutable Meanings Dilemma
description: ''When I use a word,'' the publisher said, ''it means just what I choose it to mean - neither more nor less.'' ''The question is,'' said a colleague, ''whether you can make words mean so many different things.'' ''The question is,'' said the first speaker, ''which is to be the master - that's all.'' Humpty Dumpty and Alice were, of course, the original parties in this exchange, but the vertiginous world that confronted Lewis Carroll's heroine in ''Through the Looking Glass'' has a counterpart in today's publishing circles because key words the book industry uses to segment and analyze its operations have taken on a dizzying variety of meanings.

title: HOMOSEXUAL THEME PUTS THEATER GROUP TO TEST
description: IN 1968, ''The Boys in the Band'' was an Off-Broadway breakthrough play about homosexuality. Over the next decade, other mainstream plays got on the ''Boys in the Band'' bandwagon, comically (''Norman, Is That You?'') or grimly (''Find Your Way Home''). Overall, the thrust of such works suggested that homosexuality was a psychoneurotic rather than a human condition.

title: President Attends Services For Frank Reynolds of ABC
description: President and Mrs. Reagan joined more than a thousand dignitaries, journalists and friends of Frank Reynolds today at funeral services for the ABC News anchor.

title: HIGHER TARGETS SET ON MONEY GROWTH
description: Paul Volcker had another surprise in his second round of Senate confirmation hearings - the Fed will ease up on its growth targets for the money supply for the rest of the year. Starting in July, the Fed will hold M-1 growth to a 5 to 9 percent range, up from a 4 to 8 percent target that has been in place since the beginning of the year. Moreover, the Fed will not try to offset the 14 percent growth rate in the money supply so far this year, but it will reinstitute the 8 percent upper limit in 1984. The move was seen as an effort to calm the shaky financial markets as well as to keep the recovery on track without letting it get out of hand. At the same time, the Fed chairman exhorted the Congressmen to reduce the huge budget deficits that he said were the ''most important single hazard to recovery.''

title: Three Responses To Yankee Fan
description: To the Sports Editor: I have the scorecard from the 1944 game with the Indians that started me out as a Yankee fan. While I might not be able to personally remember things at the Stadium before then, I feel qualified to respond to Sidney Zion's accolade to George Steinbrenner (''George Is a Bully, and I Say So What?,'' The New York Times, July 17).

title: NOVELISTS DISCUSS LITERARY COLLABORATION
description: NINE years ago, two young actresses met and became friends while working at the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut. Their lives carried them in different directions, but they kept in touch.

title: ONCE A SHOWCASE OF GROWTH, PUERTO RICO BATTLES A SLUMP
description: A decade ago the huge oil refinery and petrochemical complex along Highway 2 was hailed as the source of up to 40,000 jobs in a region hungry for economic development.

title: IN SUPPORT OF HOPE
description: Jane Alexander, the actress, will appear with the National Children's Choir at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday at the Marymount Convent in Tarrytown, on the Marymount College campus. The program will benefit Project Greenhope, , a support service for women returning from prison.

title: Economy Gets Very Uppity
description: This summer so far has been a scorcher - almost a match, it seems, for the economy. According to Commerce Department tabulations released last week, the economy rose in the second quarter at a annual growth rate of 8.7 percent, better than triple the first quarter's pace. It was the best gross national product reading since the first three months of 1981, 2 percentage points better than the Government had forecast only a month ago. The unexpected vigor, the President said, ''heartens us.''

title: CONQUERING FEARS, A SCULPTOR 'MAKES IT'
description: "I WAS afraid to sculpt. It was a sort of block I had - that I couldn't do it.

title: SONDHEIM SAYS GOODBYE TO BROADWAY - FOR NOW
description: The happiest theatrical news of the summer is a new musical that almost no one has seen - it's off-limits to drama critics and most theatergoers. Its title is ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' and it is now playing, exclusively to subscription audiences, in a workshop production at the Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: NOT for the first time, thieves have managed to climb 40 feet to the top of the historic library in Pound Ridge and scale a five-foothigh cupola to steal a brass rooster weathervane.

title: JOE GARDI'S NEW TITLE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. JOE GARDI knew he was going to like his new title as assistant head coach of the Jets as soon as Joe Walton offered it. Then he quickly discovered he was going to like the job even more than he had imagined.

title: WHITE WINE: STILL AMERICA'S FAVORITE
description: Three of every five glasses of wine Americans drink are filled with white wine. In 1982, a year when wine sales all over the country showed only a 2.6 percent growth rate, white wine managed to solidify its wide margin over red and rose in the table-wine category by an additional 6.9 percent. According to Impact, a trade publication that tracks drinking habits in the United States, American adults consumed on average just under 1.4 gallons of white wine in 1982, and white wine constituted 59 percent of all the wine Americans drank, up two points from 1981. That came to 232 million gallons, an increase of 15 million gallons.

title: UNDERSTATED STYLE IN NEW HAVEN
description: YOU know you are in Whistler's when you see a photographic blowup of the artist's mother near the entrance. Located in a below-ground, recessed building in New Haven between the Yale Repertory Theater and the Yale Center for British Art, Whistler's is a modern, stylish cafe and informal restaurant that seems an extension of the previous restaurant on the premises, West of Eleven.

title:
ART;
RUTGERS MUSEUM SEEKS TO GIVE PRINTS THEIR DUE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ONE would assume printmaking to be in its halcyon days. Since the 1960's, most eminent painters and many sculptors have found it an essential part of their careers to sit before an etching plate or a lithography stone and enter into a collaboration with expert printers.

title: Tour Leader Wins Stage
description: Laurent Fignon of France won the 21st leg of the Tour de France cycling classic today to fortify his overall lead in the race, which ends Sunday on the Champs-Elysees in Paris. Fignon won the 31-mile individual timed race from Plombieres to Dijon by clocking 1 hour 11 minutes 37 seconds.

title: LATEST SUFFOLK CURB EFFORT: CIGARETTE BILL
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY, perhaps the only place whose residents used to smuggle in bootleg laundry detergent, is considering yet another prohibition. This time it's the cigarette.

title: STUDY BEGINS ON BERGEN THORIUM HAZARD
description: MAYWOOD FEDERAL and state environmental agencies have begun an engineering study to determine the extent of thorium contamination in a residential neighborhood here and in neighboring Rochelle Park.

title: MODERN DANCE ACQUIRES A GALLIC ACCENT
description: It is not true that there were no modern-dance companies in France before World War II, but it is true that modern dance never did develop as an enduring art form in that country. There is some room for a reflection on the matter, given the current visit of five French modern-dance troupes, invited to make their United States debuts at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. recently and ending their stay today at the Pepsico Summerfare Festival in Purchase, N.Y.,

title: BOXING AND THE BRAIN
description: David Noonan concludes, correctly, that boxing causes irreversible damage to the brain. He also accurately notes that the rounds of public hearings that inevitably follow each new boxing death generally fail to result in legislation or regulatory changes to improve upon boxing's dismal record.

title: A 'LAST HURRAH' FOR ATLANTIC COUNTY'S REPUBLICAN COMMITTEE
description: MAYS LANDING ON THE surface, it appeared to be jusd another routine annual vote for the chairmanship of the Atlantic County Republican Committee. However, when the votes of the 140-member committee were counted and Mayor William Ross of Margate was defeated for the post, it meant the ''last hurrah'' for a 70-year-old Republican organization that had been created by a sheriff, the legendary Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, and honed into unprecedented effectiveness by State Senator Frank S. (Hap) Farley.

title: DEEP IN BOSIAN FOREST, A HOST CITY IS TRANSFORMED
description: NO one ever confused Sarajevo with St. Moritz. At the Bristol, one of the newer downtown hotels, in a dirty elevator, the little lights that mark the floors blinked inexplicably: 6, 3, 9, 7. Outside, the cab driver who took a visitor across town said he bought his stout 1962 Mercedes-Benz taxi when he was a migrant laborer near Ulm, West Germany. The Olympics would be a windfall, he said. Yugoslavia was having national debt problems, he conceded, and was still rationing gasoline. But by adding naphtha to the tank, he said, tipping an outstretched thumb like an oil-can spout, he could easily stretch his supply.

title: MX OPPONENTS GET THEIR SECOND WIND
description: When President Reagan asked the bipartisan commission to devise a compromise solution to the vexing problem of what to do with the MX missile, the hope was that a decade-long controversy could finally be put to rest.

title: Dr. Alvin Rose Calman Dies; Professor at Upsala College
description: Dr. Alvin Rose Calman, professor emeritus of history at Upsala College in East Orange, N.J., and a scholar of Napoleonic history, died of cancer Friday at Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital.

title: Crisis Revisited
description: To the Business Editor: Your interesting article, ''The Coming Crisis in Home Computers'' (June 19), quotes Everett Purdy as saying he had ''never seen any category of goods get on a self-destruct pattern like this.'' Mr. Purdy is probably not old enough to remember the early radio receiver marketing of the 1930's. The competitive pattern was quite similar to what's happening in home computers.

title: THE 'DISAPPEARED' AND THE JETTISONED
description: WIDOWS By Ariel Dorfman. Translated by Stephen Kessler.146 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95. SOUTH OF NOWHERE By Antonio Lobo Antunes. Translated by Elizabeth Lowe. 154 pp. New York: Random House. $11.95.

title: Ann Louise Stierhout Weds J.M. de Martin
description: Ann Louise Stierhout, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Stierhout of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Jon Michael de Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. de Martin of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick Schumacher performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Lutheran Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Joseph Piedmont, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: WEAPONS SEIZED IN APARTMENT OF OMEGA 7 SUSPECT
description: Federal agents seized a submachine gun, several .45-caliber automatic pistols with silencers and two walkie-talkies in a search early yesterday of the apartment in Miami where the man believed to be the leader of Omega 7, an anti-Castro terrorist group, was arrested Friday.

title: THERE'S A KNACK TO GETTING A STUCK WINDOW MOVING AGAIN
description: WHEN a double-hung window sticks or refuses to open and close easily, chances are that nine times out of 10 the problem is caused by one of two things: (1) Paint has been applied along the edges while the window was closed and thus has literally glued the sash frame in place. (2) So much paint has accumulated along the edges of the molding and inside the channels that the sash can no longer move freely up and down the way it used to.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART The 19th-century French painters who worked in the village of Barbizon, on the edge of the Forest of Fontainebleau, were romantics bent on capturing the feel of nature out-of-doors. Camille Corot is probably the best-known of these plein-air landscapists, but there are other Barbizon stars, among them Theodore Rousseau, Francois Millet (famous for his paintings of downtrodden peasants), Charles Daubigny, Constant Troyon and Henri Harpignies.

title: At Antarctica Station, Braving It at -128.6 Degrees F
description: Soviet explorers in Antarctica, experiencing conditions like ''the eternal cold of outer space,'' have recorded a temperature of 128.6 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, a record low, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Letters; Housing Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Wins Foil Title
description: Dorina Vaccaroni defeated Carola Cicconetti, 8-2, today and won the women's foil title at the world fencing championships in an all-Italian final. Luan Jujie of China took the bronze medal by beating Mandy Nicklaus of East Germany, 9-7.

title: CONCERT: FESTIVAL OFFERS MOZART-HAYDN PROGRAM
description: Friday's installment of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall divided its attention between Haydn and Mozart. The two Mozart pieces -the C minor Concerto (K. 491) and the ''Linz'' Symphony (K. 425) - represented a creative technique at its ripest. The two by Haydn - both dating probably from the 1760s - showed a young composer caught between two styles.

title: UNDERSTANDING MONDALE
description: David Harris's article, ''Understanding Mondale'' (June 19), provided me with a better understanding of one of the Democratic Presidential hopefuls.

title: DIGGING OUT
description: When Bill Walker spotted a foot-long fossil claw in a claypit near Surrey, England, in January, he suspected it was from no ordinary ancient meat-eater. Last week London's Natural History Museum confirmed that the amateur fossil hunter had indeed discovered the remains of a new species of carnivorous dinosaur. Scientists said the beast would have stood 10 to 15 feet high and carried weaponry dwarfing that of tyrannosaurus rex, the American carnivore.

title: UCONN EXHIBITS WORK OF ILLUSTRATORS
description: ''FANTASY, Fairy Tales and Fables: An Exhibition of Illustrated Children's Books'' is on display through Aug. 9 at the University of Connecticut Library.

title: OPERA FOR THE PUBLIC IS HIS MISSION
description: Vincent La Selva was jubilant about his concert performance of Verdi's 'Nabucco'' at the Bandshell in Central Park earlier this month. He was particularly pleased with the volunteer chorus that had rehearsed the work for two months. ''I like to have people involved,'' said the bearlike Italian-American conductor in his modest but airy studio in Carnegie Hall. ''I built that chorus. Here were 130 people who had never known 'Nabucco.' They had never sung opera, and 85 or 90 percent of them had never sung in Italian.''

title: THE TIE UP AT CITY HALL PUTS CHICAGO IN KNOTS
description: While Harold Washington prepared for his inaugural address in April, leaders of the city's Democratic political organization, which the Mayor-elect had vowed to tame, met in secret and put together a majority bloc within the City Council.

title: GUIDRY WINS ON 5-HITTER
description: This was what George Steinbrenner had in mind when he and his baseball people constructed the Yankees for 1983: Ron Guidry pitching a nifty game and Steve Kemp and Don Baylor providing the punch.

title: CALIFORNIA'S REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR WINS ON BUDGET BUT ALIENATES DEMOCRATS
description: Gov. George Deukmejian has won his second major battle with the Democratic-controlled Legislature, but Democratic leaders say the Republican's victory has left them so angry and bitter that he may find it impossible to get the Legislature to approve any programs.

title:
THE NATION;
Ethics Vote for Stiffer Penalty
description: The House ethics committee recommended reprimands - the mildest form of punishment - but the membership last week voted to censure Daniel B. Crane and Gerry E. Studds for having had sexual relationships with teen-aged Congressional pages.

title: CHANGES PROMISED AS METS LOSE, 7-3
description: The Mets took a 7-3 beating from the Cincinnati Reds tonight for the 20th loss in their last 28 games, and Manager Frank Howard promptly indicated that a new purge of the pitching staff was near.

title: APPOINTMENT CAME AMID LOANS
description: Edwin Meese 3d and Michael K. Deaver, two of President Reagan's closest advisers, received a total of at least $80,000 in payment-on-demand loans in 1981 that were arranged by their tax accountant, who received a Federal appointment that year.

title: Forget the Maine
description: If you want war, nourish a doctrine. Doctrines are the most frightful tyrants to which men ever are subject, because doctrines get inside of a man's own reason and betray him against himself. ... Doctrines are always vague; it would ruin a doctrine to define it, because then it could be analyzed, tested, criticized, and verified. ... Somebody asks you with astonishment and horror whether you do not believe in the Monroe Doctrine. ... You do not know what it is; but you do not dare to say that you do not, because you understand that it is one of the things which every good American is bound to believe in. Now when any doctrine arrives at that degree of authority, the name of it is a club which any demagogue may swing over you at any time and apropos of anything. - From ''War,'' by William Graham Sumner, 1903. The ideologues and idealists who inspired that warning, from a noted conservative, are swinging their club again. They have stampeded the country into Caribbean military ventures in virtually every decade of this century. Their alarms - anti-Spanish or anti-British or anti-Soviet - have rarely proved justified, and their interventions have done vastly more harm than good. But here they go again.

title: Suzanne Elizabeth Nalbantian Marries D.S. Reynolds at Armenian Cathedral
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Nalbantian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Nalbantian of New York and Old Westbury, L.I., was married at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in Manhattan yesterday to David Spencer Reynolds, son of Paul Ripley Reynolds of Kentfield, Calif., and the late Adelaide Koch Reynolds of Barrington, R.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vartan Megherian, assisted by Archbishop Tiran Nersoyan.

title: Katherine Alexinski Wed to Christopher Berman
description: Katherine Alexinski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Alexinski of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher James Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Berman of Greenwich, Conn., and Weston, Vt. Justice of the Peace Richard B. Combs performed the ceremony at the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn.

title: POLL REVEALS FEAR OF EL SALVADOR AS A NEW VIETNAM
description: A majority of Americans questioned by Gallup pollsters say they continue to think the United States will become involved in El Salvador as it was in Vietnam, and nearly half disapprove of President's Reagan's policies in Central America.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
LIMITING JAPAN'S ACCESS TO OUR RESEARCH
description: UNFORTUNATELY, there has been more talk than action in responding tog rowing foreign competition. Foreign governments have stepped up the pressure in selected h ightechnology industries through subsidies for capital, research andd evelopment and production; cooperation in the development of base t echnologies, and trade measures to protect home markets.

title: 28 AND THINKING OF GRANDCHILDREN
description: I'M 28. Married five years. No children. But constantly thinking of my grandchildren. How can that be? I've skipped a entire generation in my thoughts. I give little thought to what or who my children will be, but I have my time with my grandchildren all mapped out.

title: Karen Ann Weiss Will Wed Oct. 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Weiss of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Ann Weiss, to Richard Matthew Corbetta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Corbetta, also of Scarsdale.

title: Cake for the Poor
description: An unusual penalty was attached last February to the usual fines levied in a price-fixing conspiracy. Judge David N. Edelstein in Federal Court in Manhatttan ordered the defendants, six wholesale bakeries, to give free cake to the needy for one year.

title: Indian-Built Reactor, The First, Is Turned On
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi turned on India's first domestically built nuclear power station today and promised to use atomic energy only for peaceful purposes.

title: Cyprus
description: To the Editor: Marvine Howe's article ''Aphrodite's Divided Isle'' (Travel, June 12) was an informative guide to the wonderful attractions Cyprus holds for tourists. I must, however, take exception with it on several not insignificant points.

title:
DINING OUT;
SUMMERTIME ON THE SHREWSBURY
description: WATCHING the sunset from the deck of The Waterfront on a summer evening, one truly feels away from it all. This year-old restaurant is situated at Sea Bright's Navoo Marina, on the spit of land between the Shrewsbury River and the Atlantic; in fact, it is right at the docks where luxury cabin cruisers bob at their moorings.

title: Renaming Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS FOR GARDEN WEEDS
description: GARDENERS are familiar with the development of biological controls for insects and diseases. By infecting gypsy moth larvae with Bacillus thuringiensis and Japanese beetle larvae with milky spore disease, these two major plant pests may be brought under control. Many insects, including the gypsy moth, may be effectively controlled by introducing certain species of predatory wasps. Fire blight, a bacterial disease of apples and pears, can be held in check by spraying with certain antibiotics.

title: OF MEMORIES AND MADELEINES
description: Someone once described it as the cookie with the greatest literary clout. Indeed, one wonders where the moist and golden little tea cake called the madeleine would be without Marcel Proust.

title: COUNTY TAKES INVENTORY OF ITS PARKS
description: LIKE many other county residents, Todd Baldwin of White Plains is spending a lot of time this summer in county parks. He hikes the trails, pausing to reflect on what he sees. Unlike other visitors to the parks, however, Mr. Baldwin is paid for his rustic ramblings.

title: Drs. Jane Kocivar, Riggs Roberts Wed
description: Dr. Jane Kocivar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Kocivar of Bedford, N.Y., was married in Mount Kisco, N.Y., yesterday to Dr. Riggs Bailey Roberts, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Roberts Jr. of San Diego. Justice William F. Banks of the Town of Bedford performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Wurtzel.

title: JERSEY LISTS COMPLAINTS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE
description: Nearly 9,000 complaints of domestic violence were filed in New Jersey in the 12 months ended last March, the administrative director of the courts said this week.

title: JURY WRITES POSTSCRIPT TO A STORMY CAREER AT E.P.A.
description: In a faint, incongruous echo of the uproar touched off by her dismissal in February as head of the Environmental Protection Agency's ''superfund'' program to clean up toxic wastes, Rita M. Lavelle was tried this week for contempt of Congress - and found not guilty by a Federal District Court jury.

title: NEW HOPE FOR THOSE IMPATIENT WITH ELEVATOR SERVICE
description: THIRTY seconds is the average waiting time for an elevator in a New Y ork City office building. If the wait is longer, elevator s pecialists say, New Yorkers get upset.

title: Bad-Neighbor Policies Stir Central America
description: On the subject of Marxism President Reagan minces no words, and last week he used some of his strongest language to date. The Nicaraguan Government, he told the International Longshoremen's Association, was ''a dictatorship of counterfeit revolutionaries'' who are ''actively trying to destroy the budding democracy in neighboring El Salvador.'' Soviet and Cuban arms deliveries to Managua ''cannot be allowed to continue,'' he declared.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Black School to Rehire Winner of Bias Lawsuit
description: Howard University, a predominantly black institution, is rehiring a white faculty member who won a ruling by a judge that the school discriminated against him when it dismissed him and promoted blacks with less experience.

title: MILITARY INTERVENTION IN CENTRAL AMERICA?
description: Is United States military intervention in Central America out of the question? A good many people seem to think that it is, and not all of them are pacifists or isolationists. Indeed, one of the many bizarre features of the debate over Central America is the contribution being made by our own military men to the idea that sending troops to El Salvador is for all practical purposes impossible.

title: THOSE HARDY INSURANCE STOCKS
description: THE last few years have been rough going for the nation's property a nd casualty insurance industry, and 1983 appears to be following thep attern. For hundreds of companies in this field, fierce competition f or commercial insurance volume has forced premiums down, making the u nderwriting aspect of the business extremely unprofitable. And a lthough many companies are in the black, their profits have been d erived from such categories as investment income and involvement in l ife, health and other areas of insurance.

title: TOURING THE SAINT-GAUDENS SCULPTURE PARK
description: NOEL PERRIN is a professor of English at Dartmouth College. BY NOEL PERRIN

title: Amanda Moore to Wed Next Month; Melissa Moore Plans Nuptials for Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. David B. Moore of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Amanda Moore and Melissa Moore, to Timothy Maxwell and Kurt Look, respectively.

title: A COLD SUMMER MOUSSE MAY REVIVE WILTED APPETITES
description: SUMMER appetites wilted by unrelenting sunshine and sultry evenings can still be tempted. If the food is light, cold and goes down easily, providing sustenance in small portions and taking advantage of farm-fresh produce, who can resist?

title: SOMETIMES LOYALTY BECOMES MASOCHISM
description: Tenacity is vital for a chessplayer, but it can be overdone. You simply cannot abandon a favorite opening system every time an opponent poses a clever challenge to it. Opponents are going to be doing that so frequently that you would soon be left with no preferred methods of play, doomed to dabble in perpetually unfamiliar territory.

title: Mrs. Cheney Captures 60's Singles Grass Title
description: Dodo Cheney of Santa Monica, Calif., defeated her doubles partner, Sheila Evans of Indianapolis, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills and captured the 60-and-over singles title in the national senior women's grass-court championships.

title: Constance Craven To Wed Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Craven of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Louise Craven, to Brook Devonshire Dennis Boyd, son of Mrs. John B. Lister of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late C.M. Dennis Boyd. A Sept. 3 wedding is planned.

title: CAPTIVE RETURNED
description: Some suspected that the Syrian Government's help was motivated by something besides the ''humanitarianism'' cited by the Reagan Administration in the case of David S. Dodge last week. But no matter, for the former acting president of American University in Beirut was back home and in good health, released a year after being kidnapped in Lebanon. Mr. Dodge was thought to have been seized by an Islamic group with close ties to Iran's intelligence service.

title: OUT IN THE SURREY: A SYMBOL OF A GENTLER ERA IS KEPT INTACT
description: IT is a warm summer twilight and Detective Lieut. John Decker, commanding officer of the Bronx Homicide Task Force, has just come home from work. He pulls his car up the long driveway to his Yorktown home - a picturesque six-acre apple farm - and prepares for an evening's relaxation. A few minutes later, he heads back down the winding driveway, this time in the driver's seat of a fringe-topped surrey, clucking gently to a big chestnut horse named Charlie.

title: Helping Hands For Housing
description: Washington's decision to phase out local housing subsidies created the kind of vacuum the construction industry abhors. Last week, Albany stepped in to help fill it.

title: Suzanne Phillips to Marry Steven P. Mark in October
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Phillips of Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne R. Phillips, to Steven Paul Mark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mark of New Rochelle, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Joan Neuhaus Marries W.S. Locke, Geologist
description: Joan Thompson Neuhaus, daughter of Lacey T. Neuhaus and Philip R. Neuhaus, both of Houston, was married yesterday to William Stacy Locke, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Locke Jr. of San Antonio. The Rev. Robert Gibson performed the ceremony at the Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral in Houston.

title: BOXING AND THE BRAIN
description: David Noonan's article clearly reveals the need for ring reforms, providing fighters with greater protection from long-term injury and death. But any suggested reforms should only be instituted after careful study.

title: 'WHEN THE MIST CAME IN, WE COULDN'T SEE THE AUDIENCE'
description: Summer is upon us, and with it dance has moved out-of-doors in many varied locales. For the dancers involved, this is not the unsullied treat it might seem, since survival often comes ahead of art. Dancing out-of-doors has made for some memorable and bizarre happenings, and the controlled environment of an indoor theater hardly prepares participants for hazards that may await the unwary in alfresco performing.

title: THE DELIGHTS OF DE VRIES
description: As a Peter De Vries fan of long standing, I was happy to see him at long last canonized in the pages of The Times Magazine.

title: Lynne M. Chapian Marries W.D. Demaria in Queens
description: Lynne Marie Chapian, daughter of Edward M. Chapian and the late May Chapian of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to William Denis Demaria, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Demaria of Valley Stream, L.I. The Rev. Michael Buttero, assisted by the Rev. Carnig Hallajian, performed the ceremony at the Armenian Apostolic Church of the Holy Martyrs in Bayside, Queens.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Although Count Basie and his orchestra are still playing today, his current band is an extension of the band that the Count started in 1952, after cutting down to an octet for two years. The original Basie band, which came roaring out of Kansas City in 1936, was quite different from the 1952 (and later) band.

title: SCORING IN DIAMONDS
description: Computers have long been used by the American Contract Bridge League for dealing hands - a practice that has permitted many players to curse the computer unjustly for their failure to achieve good scores.

title: Parole Officer Is Found Slain in His Apartment
description: A 56-year-old parole officer was found stabbed to death in his Upper East Side apartment, the police said yesterday. The body of the man - James McKeon, an investigator for 25 years with state's Division of Parole - was found slumped on a couch in the living room of a third-floor apartment at 270 East 78th Street on Friday afternoon.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: POLAND Genesis of a Revolution. Edited by Abraham Brumberg. 322 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $19.95. Vintage Books. Paper, $7.95. By MARTHA BAYLES

title: THE 'DEADLY SINS' OF AN UNREPENTANT VEGETABLE GARDENER
description: Millions of American sinners grow their own vegetables. I'm one of them. I say we're a bad lot, and it's not right that we go unscathed. To set matters right, I offer this public avowal of the seven deadly sins of one typical vegetable gardener.

title: Fall Wedding Planned For Miss Richardson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lunsford Richardson Jr. of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Martin Richardson, to William Lincoln Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Lincoln Evans of Mercer Island, Wash. The wedding is to be in October.

title: AN UNHAPPY HEAVEN STORMER
description: AN ABYSS DEEP ENOUGH Letters of Heinrich von Kleist, with a Selection of Essays and Anecdotes. Edited, translated and introduced by Philip B. Miller. 297 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $16.95.KLEIST A Biography. By Joachim Maass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 313 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.HEINRICH VON KLEIST: PLAYS Edited by Walter Hinderer. Foreword by E.L. Doctorow. 341 pp. New York: Continuum. Cloth, $17.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: Aging and Senility
description: To the Editor:

title: A PROTECTED DETROIT BOOMS AGAIN
description: NO one was sure at the time, but in October 1982 the three-year depression plaguing the American automobile industry began to end. That month, car sales started a long, slow climb back from the lowest depths in two decades.

title: Fuel-Cost Pass-Alongs
description: Question: I live in a rent-controlled apartment. I never received any notices from management regarding a fuel adjustment in my rent. Am I supposed to pay the original rent? ... D.S.G., the Bronx Answer: Each year since 1980, depending on the type and amount of fuel and other conditions, owners have been allowed to increase rent in rent-controlled apartments to cover increases in fuel costs. In the case of fuels that have decreased in price, owners have been required to pass savings along to tenants in the form of a rent decrease, according to Harry Michelson, general counsel to the Rent Control Division.

title: St. Vincent
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH some people consider it a privilege to belong to exclusive clubs, there are those who feel more privileged than others. So it is with the Saved by the Belt Club, whose members are privileged to still be alive or not seriously maimed.

title: Susan S. Claghorn To Marry Sept. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Claghorn Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Strawbridge Claghorn, to Stuart William Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Woodrow Ferguson of Newton, Iowa. A Sept. 10 wedding is planned.

title: SHERIFF'S DEPUTIES CHARGED IN CRIMES
description: A small but steady stream of Cook County Sheriff's Department deputies have in recent months been indicted for or convicted of crimes ranging from bribery and theft of Federal property to child pornography and attempted murder.

title: GAS GUZZLING AT A PRICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Asks for Gift Of Liver to Save Child
description: President Reagan appealed to Americans today to help find a liver for an 11-month-old Texas girl who will die without a transplant.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: As one who loves Ireland - the original home of the McGoverns - I regret that the only way to fly there directly is on Aer Lingus. Maybe they'll do better if a few of us speak our minds. Here is my story - about an Aer Lingus Flight from Dublin to New York on May 19. was completing a two-week university lecture series in Dublin when I learned that our home in Washington had been gutted by fire, necessitating an earlier return to Washington. My wife Eleanor and daughter Teresa and I were all holding the return portion of roundtrip economy tickets, but thinking it might lift our drooping spirits, we decided to splurge and upgrade our tickets to first class.

title: A LESSON IN REUSE
description: Developers of a condominium conversion project in Irvington, N.Y., have taken adaptive reuse around another corner with the transformation of a 1891 brick schoolhouse into apartments.

title: 'STAYING ALIVE' SUCCUMBS TO A HOST OF MISSTEPS
description: Not even second-rateness comes cheap these days. According to Sylvester Stallone - the co-producer, the co-writer and, all by himself, the director of ''Staying Alive''- the film's principal, though unintentionally hilarious set, which is supposed to represent the set for a serious Broadway dance-musical called ''Satan's Alley,'' cost more than do many films today.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Historic Tapes Ten years ago this summer, public television broadcast gavel-to-gavel coverage of the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities, more commonly referred to as the Watergate hearings. From May 17 to Nov. 15, 1973, there were 250 hours of testimony, during which the Nixon White House was dissected and eventually toppled.

title: MUST YOU RETAIN A LAWYER?
description: FOR years, it has been customary in many parts of the metropolitan N ew York area for lawyers to draw up the contract for sale of a r esidence and make sure all documents are correct for the closing.

title: Miss Warner Is Betrothed To P. B. Nash
description: Mr. and Mrs. William W. Warner of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra de Peyster Warner, to Peter Baird Nash, son of Mrs. Roger Alden Derby Jr. of New York and Vero Beach, Fla., and James Mallory Nash of Warrenton, Va. A Dec. 10 wedding is planned.

title: WHEN A LAWYER BECOMES A CLIENT'S 'MASTER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss O'Sullivan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. O'Sullivan of New Rochelle, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite O'Sullivan, to Joseph Leo Conway Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Conway of Elizabeth, N.J.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FRANKLIN MINT WILL STRIKE NEW EGYPTIAN COIN
description: Old and new will be blended in an unusual manner later this year when Egypt, one of the world's oldest countries, joins forces with The Franklin Mint, one of the world's most modern minting facilities, to produce a new gold coin honoring Queen Nefertiti.

title: Panel Plans to Discuss Black Women in Theater
description: Michele Wallace, author of ''Black Macho and the Myth of the Superwoman,'' will moderate a discussion on ''Black Women in Theater'' tomorrow at 2 P.M. in connection with ''The Woman's Series: Four New Black Playwrights'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater.

title: Rochanya C. Hickman Married Upstate
description: Rochanya Charlotte Hickman, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. John Hampton Hickman 3d of Geneseo, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Eric Yves Jacques de la Motte-Thiery Generous, son of Mrs. William Henry Generous and the late Captain Generous of Baltimore and Nice, France. The Rev. Charles C. Greene performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: Eagle Helps Sutton Keep 6-Stroke Lead
description: Hal Sutton chipped in for an eagle on the 15th today, shot a two-under-par 69 and retained a sixstroke lead in the third round of the $350,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: Girl, 15, Is Critically Wounded In Lower East Side Crossfire
description: A 15-year-old girl was shot in the head and critically wounded last night when she was caught in a gun battle outside her apartment building on the Lower East Side, the police said.

title: Chandler Loses Split Decision
description: Jeff Chandler, the World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, suffered the first defeat of his career today, losing to unranked Oscar Muniz on a split decision in a 10-round non-title, super-bantamweight bout at the Sands Hotel and Casino here.

title: Senior Cuban Official Said to Defect to U.S.
description: A Spanish-language radio station in Miami has reported that a senior Cuban Government official defected to the United States last week. A State Department spokesman refused today to confirm or deny the report and declined to say whether the agency had received a request for political asylum for the official, who was identified by the station Friday as Jesus Raul Perez Mendez.

title: THE BIRMINGHAM BOMBING
description: SUNDAY, SEPT. 15, 1963, at 10:19 A.M. in Birmingham, Ala., a dynamite bomb exploded during services at the 16th Street Baptist Church, killing four black girls in a dressing room in the basement. In the number of people killed at a single stroke, the bombing was the most terrible incident of racial violence during the peak years of the Southern civil-rights movement. In the mindlessness of its evil, the 16th Street bombing was also the most heinous act of the era. Even the murders of three civil-rights workers in Mississippi in 1964 and the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968 had a rationale: The victims were participants in what they hoped, but did not fully expect, would be a nonviolent war.
