But Denise McNair, 11, and Carole Robertson, Cynthia Wesley and Addie Mae Collins, all 14, had not even been among the thousands of Birmingham students who flooded into the streets in May to join the famous ''children's crusade'' that Dr. King used to dramatize the brutality of the police tactics there. The children were killed simply because they attended church on the wrong day.

title:
GARDENING;
BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS FOR GARDEN WEEDS
description: GARDENERS are familiar with the development of biological controls for insects and diseases. By infecting gypsy moth larvae with Bacillus thuringiensis and Japanese beetle larvae with milky spore disease, these two major plant pests may be brought under control. Many insects, including the gypsy moth, may be effectively controlled by introducing certain species of predatory wasps. Fire blight, a bacterial disease of apples and pears, can be held in check by spraying with certain antibiotics.

title: No Headline
description: Yankees and Red Sox: An Exciting Rivalry As an avid Yankees fan, who always managed to have his roommate or closest working companion a Red Sox fan, I found John Cavanaugh's article, ''Busy Days for Red Sox Fans'' (July 3), timely and delightful.

title: WHEN FOOD WAS COMMENTARY
description: SAVORING THE PAST The French Kitchen and Table From 1300 to 1789. By Barbara Ketcham Wheaton. Illustrated. 341 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $17.95.

title: Strong Stuff at The Liquor Board
description: In trying to put the New York State Liquor Authority back on its feet, did Governor Cuomo's new chairman, Anthony V. Gazzara, step out of line? A month after his arrival in May, it was reported last week, Mr. Gazzara quietly asked for and got temporary authority to make all appointments and single-handedly run the agency. It was the first time since the S.L.A. scandal of 1963 that a chairman had been granted so much power.

title: A DEFENSE AGAINST NO SELF-DEFENSE
description: ''We are witnessing at the present time the evolution of a new disease process of unknown etiology with a mortality of at least 50 percent and possibly as high as 75 to 100 percent, and with a doubling of the number of patients afflicted every six months.'' This grim pronouncement by Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, chief of the laboratory of immunoregulation at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, was in a recent editorial in the Journal of the American Medical Association. He was describing AIDS, for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a disease that cripples the most potent and pervasive of the body's bulwarks against attack - the immune system.

title: KILTS-THE LONG AND SHORT OF IT
description: DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND, a novelist, lives in a castle in Scotland. BY DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND

title: ELECTION JUNKIES
description: Election Junkies

title: A TENNIS SUCCESS OFF THE COURT
description: GLASTONBURY: At any hour, Warren M. Bosworth Jr., is likely to answer his telephone and listen to Ivan Lendl or some other tennis star plucking the strings of his racquet.

title: BRAZIL'S MOVIES DISSECT A NATION
description: ''We're the new barbarians of international cinema and our films constantly subvert its rules,'' says the Brazilian director Carlos Diegues, ''and this at a time when cinema everywhere is suffering from lack of creativity and imagination.''

title: Beth McGoldrick Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Elizabeth McGoldrick, daughter of Mr.and Mrs. Peter Francis McGoldrick of Haverford, Pa., and Montreal, and William Paul Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Jenkins of Arlington, Va., were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward K. Braxton performed the ceremony at St. John Vianney Roman Catholic Church in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: Cosmos Beat Rowdies
description: Roberto Cabanas, who leads the league in scoring, had three goals tonight as the Cosmos beat the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 5-4.

title: TOPICS
description: THE lights are dimmed, the stage is set, and the nervous young performers are limbering up in the wings. The director is behind schedule; he screams instructions to the inert technicians who plod across the stage lethargically. The producer is nervous: she fidgets with the call sheets, checking name after endless name on her clipboard.

title: 'KING OF THE VIBES'
description: Lionel Hampton, who many jazz buffs would say is always a bargain, no matter the price, will be presenting a free concert in New Brunswick Thursday evening.

title: A VOLUNTEER JOB THAT PAYS IN LOVE
description: IT begins innocently, without fanfare. A friend at work asks me to join her in volunteering at the Connecticut Special Olympics for the mentally retarded.

title: TELEVISION VS. THE FIELD CAMPAIGN
description: SHORTLY after his successful 1978 Senate campaign, Bill Bradley was being hailed by state Democratic leaders as a future political star. They saw him as a man who might someday occupy the White House or, at the very least, as a Senator who would be unbeatable for years to come.

title: ST. LOUIS BEARS BRUNT OF HEAT WAVE AS U.S. TOLL RISES
description: For more than two weeks a deadly heat wave with temperatures in the upper 90's and low 100's has kept the daytime sky here a sickly pastel blue. Forty-two people in the St. Louis area have died from heat-related causes as of today, accounting for more than one-third of the national heat death toll of 123.

title: RESOUNDING 'SOUND OF MUSIC'
description: WHAT can one say about ''The Sound of Music,'' Rodgers and Hammerstein's last and most simplistically sentimental collaboration? Nothing, except that it works.

title: UNCLE SAM PAYS A HIGH PRICE FOR BEING IN 359 PLACES AT ONCE
description: American diplomats sat down with Portuguese officials in Lisbon last week to resume arduous negotiations toward renewing United States rights to an air base in the Azores. No one is saying what the price will be but the Portuguese are asking for much more than the $140 million in military aid they got under an agreement that expired in February. Earlier this month, the United States concluded a renewed base agreement with Greece that calls for $500 million in military assistance; last month, a basing pact with the Philippines carried a $900 million price tag.

title: THIRD INTERNATIONAL FOR IDEAL DU GAZEAU
description: Ideal du Gazeau of France became the first horse to win the International Trot three times as he took the 25th edition of the race tonight and raised his career earnings to more than $3 million.

title: AMONG INDIANS AND GEORGIANS
description: GOOD THUNDER By John Solensten. 214 pp. Albany: State University of New York Press. $12.95. BABY SWEET'S By Raymond Andrews. Illustrated by Benny Andrews. 212 pp. New York: The Dial Press, $15.95.

title: THE BOILING POINT
description: WASHINGTON NOT since the Vietnam war has an issue so engaged the political passions of the President and his advisers, Congress, the public and many nations around the world, as recent Reagan Administration decisions about Central America. Wounding and basic questions are again being asked about how to deal with revolutionary change in the third world, democracy versus communism, the proper role of Congress and whether to support or reject Presidential policies.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: 'STRIDER,' WITH MUSIC THUNDERS IN
description: THE Studio Theater of Lindenhurst has opened its summer season with a thundering production of ''Strider,'' the quasi-musical drama by Mark Rozovsky about horses, passion and discrimination.

title: GETTING TO THE OLYMPICS
description: T hose who hope to attend the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, next February are being offered several seemingly attractive packages that include round-trip transportation from the United States, accommodations, meals and tickets to the games at all-inclusive prices. Travelers who hope to attend the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles next July and August, however, are at this point faced with chaos.

title: MAN SEIZED IN PELHAM SLAYING
description: A 21-year-old unemployed Mount Vernon man was arrested today and charged with murdering a 72-year-old hardware store owner last Tuesday in neighboring Pelham.

title: MEADOWLANDS PROJECT TO AID SHORE BIRDS
description: LYNDHURST THE Hackensack Meadowlands is a critical habitat that each year provides tens of thousands of migrating shore birds with food and shelter during their seasonal flights between the Arctic tundra and tropical climes.

title: WOOING LISTENERS TO AMERICAN MUSIC
description: NEW LONDON THINK ''classical music'' and chances are you will not think American. American pop music is a trend setter around the world, but tens of thousands of forgotten classical scores are gathering dust because conductors and musicians do not have the time to resurrect them.

title: Italian Reports Gains On Forming Coalition
description: Prime Minister-designate Bettino Craxi completed a first round of talks with political parties today and said it was possible a Socialist-led coalition government could be in place by the end of the month.

title: SOVIET FREES 7 GREENPEACE PROTESTERS
description: The Soviet Union has freed six Americans and a Canadian who were taken into custody after they landed illegally at a Soviet whaling station in Siberia.

title: Defensive Backs Traded By Rams and Raiders
description: The Los Angeles Rams and Los Angeles Raiders exchanged defensive backs today, with Pat Thomas moving to the Raiders and Monte Jackson returning to the Rams.

title: HARTFORD YOUTHS RECLAIM BANKS OF CONNECTICUT RIVER
description: A GROUP of young men and women from Hartford inner-city neighborhoods have begun an urban renewal and reclamation project along the banks of the Connecticut River using rakes, sickles and lawnmowers.

title: CHILDREN AS VICTIMS
description: CHILDREN WITHOUT CHILDHOOD by Marie Winn 224 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE U.N.'S IMPERTURBABLE HOST
description: Being the host at a luncheon or dinner can frequently be trying even under optimal conditions. The early arrival of a guest, a kitchen mishap, even a sputtering candle can test the mettle of the most serene of party-givers.

title: October Wedding For CeCe Turner
description: Constance Cope Turner, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Turner of Walpole, N.H., and Walter Howe Haydock 3d, son of Alicia Roux of New York and the late Mr. Haydock, plan to be married in Locust Valley, L.I., in October.

title: THREE RESPONSES TO YANKEE FAN
description: To the Sports Editor: Sidney Zion's article disturbed my sense of fair play. The author pressed home the point that winning is all that counts; how you win, whether by fair or foul means is unimportant.

title: No Headline
PROSPECTS
description: Inventories Treading Softly

title:
THE NATION;
Carving Up California
description: The borders of California's 45 Congressional districts were a kind of memorial to the political acumen of the late Phillip Burton, the Democratic Representative from San Francisco who died in April. The reapportionment plan adopted after the 1980 census was largely his handiwork, and it sharply increased his party's share of the state's House delegation.

title: Best Gear May Be Simplest
description: OUTDOORSMEN must be on guard against the equipage syndrome, which in its most virulent stages finds one more concerned with acquiring gear than using it.

title: RX FOR THE TENDERFOOT
description: LEE N. NEWCOMER was a physician at Lake Hospital in Yellowstone National Park last year. He is currently practicing hematology/oncology at the Natalie Warren Bryant Cancer Center in Tulsa, Okla. By LEE N. NEWCOMER

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE ART OF BIBLICAL NARRATIVE. By Robert Alter. (Basic Books, $7.95.) Robert Alter, a professor of Hebrew and comparative literature at the University of California at Berkeley, began this study in hopes of throwing ''some new light on the Bible by bringing a literary perspective to bear on it,'' and soon discovered that the Bible stories have ''a great deal to teach anyone interested in narrative.'' Our critic, Frank Kermode, praised Mr. Alter's brilliant investigation of literary techniques used in the Hebrew Testament and admired the boldness and finesse of his readings.

title: OUT AND ABOUT IN CORNISH
description: HANK NICHOLS is a staff writer for The New Hampshire Times.

title: Hope Schuyler Is Engaged To Lieut. Henry D. Hacker
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Schuyler of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Hope Melanie Schuyler, to Lieut.

title: BATS IN THE HOUSE: THE 'CASCADE OF ROSES' REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COMING OF THE COMPUTER
description: A NEW age that may be more revolutionary than any since the time of Johannes Gutenberg is dawning for the book. Such is the consensus of representative members of the American book world, expressed during the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association held in Dallas last month and in other recent discussions. Here is a digest of their very educated guesses:

title: A SIDEMAN'S SONG ON THE MUSIC TOUR
description: LONDON HE has played for audiences of more than 300,000 people, yet the chances are good that not one of those listeners came away from the concert knowing his name. He has recently finished more than two months of hopping in and out of Europe's most celebrated cities in a private jet, but, at bottom, he remains a salaried employee.

title: HOT PURSUIT OF ENLIGHTENED SELF-INTEREST
description: ''That's listed as 'Lehrman for Governor,' '' the New York City operator replies when asked for the current number of Lewis E. Lehrman's office. His aspirations to run New York State were deflected by Mario M. Cuomo's victory last year, but Mr. Lehrman is maintaining a political presence as a campaign consultant whose compensation is loyalty, not money.

title: Correction
description: A lithograph reproduced in the June 12 Business Forum and in the June 26 Letters column was misidentified. It was ''Builders,'' 1932, by Harry Sternberg.

title: Hawaii Lava Flow Resumes
description: A new 360-foot flow of lava was seen Friday on the slopes of Kilauea, officials said, continuing an eruption of the volcano that began Jan. 3.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. This is the Royals' last regular-season game against the Yankees. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2:05 P.M.).

title: BLACKS ORGANIZE DRIVE FOR NEW VOTERS
description: WITH an opportunity to elect a black candidate to the Board of Legislators for the first time since it was created in 1970, some of the county's most influential black organizations and institutions are engaged in an intensive drive to increase by as much as 50 percent the number of black registered voters.

title: Sports of the Times; Why the Russians Will Be in Los Angeles Next Year
description: Ever since the United States boycotted the Moscow Olympics in 1980 over the Afghanistan situation, cynics have wondered if the Soviet Union will create a political reason to boycott the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles next year. Now, almost a year to the day before the pageantry in the Memorial Coliseum of the July 28 opening ceremony, Monique Berlioux, the executive director of the International Olympic Committee, has mentioned a reason for a Soviet boycott - the NATO plan to deploy Cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Western Europe by December.

title: MYSTIC DELI IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: THE genesis of the Two Sisters Deli in downtown Mystic was a strong family feeling and a particularly prolific zucchini crop. The delicatessen, on Pearl Street not far from the Seaport, was opened four years ago by Cindy Halsey Shaw, her husband, Bruce, and her sister, Katharine Halsey. The Shaws had left jobs and home behind in Massachusetts, and were seeking to change their life styles. Mrs. Shaw, who had always had an interest in food and gardening, planted a vegetable garden in Stonington. The zucchini took over and she proceeded to look for a market for her produce and the zucchini bread that she baked.

title: Susan F. Acito Married To Robert P. Houlihan
description: Susan Frances Acito, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Remo J. Acito of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert P. Houlihan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Houlihan of Schenectady, N.Y. Msgr. Robert Skelly performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at SS.

title: BOXING AND THE BRAIN
description: What a coincidence for David Noonan's article, ''Boxing and the Brain'' (June 12), to appear on the same day that U.S.B.A. lightweight championship contender Andy Ganigan got his brains battered by undefeated Jimmy Paul, who won the vacated title in Phoenix on a TKO by rendering Ganigan defenseless after several rounds in a scheduled 12-round bout.

title: No Headline
description: Continuing Education For Accountants This letter is a comment on the article ''What Accountants Need to Know'' (Long Islanders column, June 26). In this article, the president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants discussed the importance of continuing education for those who hold themselves out to be certified public accountants.

title:
GARDENING;
BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS FOR GARDEN WEEDS
description: GARDENERS are familiar with the development of biological controls for insects and diseases. By infecting gypsy moth larvae with Bacillus thuringiensis and Japanese beetle larvae with milky spore disease, these two major plant pests may be brought under control. Many insects, including the gypsy moth, may be effectively controlled by introducing certain species of predatory wasps. Fire blight, a bacterial disease of apples and pears, can be held in check by spraying with certain antibiotics.

title: ROCK: ESQUERITA AT TRAMPS
description: Record collectors know about Esquerita Milochi, the New Orleans pianist and rock shouter. His albums (as Esquerita and Eskew Reeder) from the 1950's, when he was marketed as Little Richard's competition, are rare and expensive. Mr. Milochi now lives in New York, and when he performed Friday at Tramps he claimed that a teenage Little Richard copied his ''obbligato holler'' from Mr. Milochi's early-50's gospel music.

title: NASSAU REP FINDS NEW HOME
description: IN its eight-year history, the Nassau Repertory Theater, the Island's only year-round Equity house, has been house-hopping, from a 500-seat playhouse in Mineola's Social Service Building, where it all began in 1975; to Hempstead's cavernous Adelphi Calderone Theater (capacity: 1,400), where the company spent one financially disastrous year, to the Herricks Community Center, a recycled junior high school with a 500-seat auditorium.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC The week in music offers opera to talk about and opera to see and hear as well. Despite the delays in the New York City Opera's season, its lecture/recitals on the music of Puccini are going on more or less on schedule. Monday at 6 P.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library, Bridget Paolucci will continue the series with a talk about ''Puccini, the Musician and the Man.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Everson Walls, the Dallas Cowboys' star cornerback who has been trying to renegotiate his contract, has rejected a new offer by the team that reportedly would have paid him $1.2 million over five years. Walls, who has two years remaining on his current contract, wants a three-year pact worth $900,000. ... Bruce Jenner, the former Olympic decathlon champion, wrecked his Mustang in a practice run for the Ford California GT race at Sears Point International Raceway, and it was doubtful the car could be repaired in time for today's qualifying. Jenner was not injured in the mishap, which occurred when his car lurched out of contol on the first turn and rolled over an embankment. ... Robin Yount, the Milwaukee Brewers' All-Star shortstop, is expected to miss several games because of a minor muscle strain in his lower back that caused him to be pulled from the lineup Friday night against the Chicago White Sox. ... Al Cowens, the Seattle Mariners' outfielder, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list, suffering from tendinitis in his right shoulder.

title: TOP 4 TEAMS STILL IN RUNNING IN SPINGOLD BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: The quarterfinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with all four top-seeded groups still in contention.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: DRUG ADDICTION: THE TREAT TO SPORTS KEEPS GROWING
description: WHITEY HERZOG, the field manager and former general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, is one of baseball's premier traders, and in recent years a new set of issues has cropped up in the course of his wheeling and dealing. ''Is he clean?'' is a question Herzog said he has been hearing more often these days. ''What's the way they say it now?'' Herzog said. ''Oh, yeah - 'Does he have a chemical imbalance?' ''

title: 42 FANS ARRESTED FOR ROWDYISM
description: At least 42 people, most of them White Sox fans from Chicago, were arrested for disorderly conduct from fights that broke out during weekend baseball games at Milwaukee County Stadium, city officials said today.

title: 42 Pro Athletes Have Sought Treatment
description: According to research by The New York Times, at least 42 professional athletes have sought treatment for alcoholism or drug dependency since 1977, and at least 23 have been convicted of drug or alcohol-related crimes.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S GREED FOR VIDEOCASSETTE DOLLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Shah's Widow in Cairo
description: Former Empress Farah of Iran was reported today to have arrived in Cairo to pay respects at the burial place of her husband, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, on the third anniversary of his death.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL TO ALLOW INSPECTION OF FOSTER-CARE RECORDS
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday signed a bill to require private fostercare agencies to open their confidential records to state inspectors. The agencies would be permitted to remove the names and identifying information on the children from the records before inspection.

title: Market Place; Stocks Rally; Caution Voiced
description: THE good, not-so-old days returned to the stock market last Wednesday in a rousing ''Volcker rally.'' The Dow Jones industrial average, staging its biggest one-day gain in nearly eight months, soared 30.74 points in response to testimony before Congress by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: FANS SAVOR GAME'S FINE PRINT
description: George Brett's controversial home run against the Yankees yesterday -nullified by the umpires after Billy Martin pointed out there was an illegal amount of pine tar on Brett's bat - drew attention from some men in high places as well as the man in the street.

title: A TRAIL OF WESTERN TECHNOLOGY IS FOLLOWED TO THE K.G.B.'S DOOR
description: Every year Western high technology with military applications, worth millions of dollars, disappears beyond the borders of the Soviet Union and its allies. Sometimes the Warsaw Pact's procurement effort is so effective that the embargoed equipment is even returned to the West for secret repairs. American laws and North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreements ban the transfer of such sophisticated microelectronic and computer equipment. But the volume reaching the Eastern bloc is startling, according to Western intelligence experts.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK HOMOSEXUALS' VOTES
description: With the approach of the 1984 campaign, the Democratic Party and its Presidential candidates are reaching out as never before to the nation's increasingly active minority of homosexual voters.

title: TYRONE DUKES
description: Tyrone Dukes, a former staff photographer for The New York Times, died of complications related to a liver ailment on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Executive Change item in Business Day on July 15 concerning the promotion of Dominic Mangone to vice president and controller of Montgomery Ward & Company incorrectly identified the company and the man he succeeded, Dale Feet.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a terrible rule, but if it had happened to me I would have accepted it.

title: A LEANER IMPERIAL CHEMICAL
description: In one of those can-you-top-this industrial debates a few years ago, an executive with Imperial Chemical Industries, one of Britain's largest companies, was informed that British Rail was larger. His reply was a tribute to Britain's talent for wry self-deprecation. ''Ah,'' he said, ''but we have more passengers.''

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds* 9.44 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.75 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: Castro Backs Peace Bid Of Four Latin Nations
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba, endorsing the peacemaking efforts of four Latin American countries, today condemned ''the substitution of confrontation for dialogue'' to resolve the conflicts in Central America.

title: THEATER OF THE DEAF GETS A PICTURE-POSTCARD HOME
description: The National Theater of the Deaf opened its new home, the Hazel E. Stark Center, in Chester, Conn., yesterday. Situated in a picturesque spot along the Pattaconk Brook, the Stark Center was established with a $250,000 gift from Irving Stark, a retired businessman from East Norwalk, Conn.

title: LATIN PANEL'S JOB
description: The issue of the President's commission on Central America is not Henry A. Kissinger. The real issue is the commission itself.

title: Arias in Semifinals
description: Second-seeded Jimmy Arias defeated Eric Korita, an amateur with a big serve, 7-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the $200,000 D.C. National Bank Tennis Classic on clay today.

title: NEWSPAPER CHAIN ALTERS OLD VOICE IN NEW SOUTH
description: In early June a photographer for The Delta Democrat-Times posed a local beauty queen in the arms of the marble knight guarding the grave of one of this city's historical figures.

title: STAGE PRODUCER AND DIRECTOR
description: Shepard Traube, a theatrical director and producer for more than 40 years and a founder and first president of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: LIBERTY OUTRACES COURAGEOUS BY 0:15
description: Amid driving rain and steep four-foot seas at times, Liberty defeated Courageous by 15 seconds in a tight, strenuous race in the trials to select the America's Cup yacht defender today.

title: Nancy K. Brown Married To David R. Weil in Jersey
description: Nancy Kathryn Brown, daughter of Maxine J. Brown of Presque Isle, Me., and the late James Brown, was married yesterday to David Robert Weil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Weil of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Bruce S. Block performed the ceremony at the Weil home.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A First Appearance In Woody Allen's New Film

title: IRAN REPORTS MAJOR ADVANCE IN NEW DRIVE AGAINST IRAQIS
description: Iran declared today that it continued to make gains against Iraqi forces on the second day of an offensive. The fighting was said to be the heaviest since a major Iranian drive into Iraq, further south, in April.

title: Hospital to Open AIDS Unit
description: San Francisco General Hospital will open a special care unit Tuesday for patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Hospital officials said it would be the first separate hospital ward in the country for victims of AIDS, a mysterious fatal malady that breaks down the body's immune system. They said the ward would treat both physical and emotional needs of the patient and would not be a ''leper colony.''

title: SAM STERNBERG
description: Sam Sternberg, a member of the ensemble of the Metropolitan Opera for 37 years and a cantor for 60 years, died of cancer Friday in Memorial Hospital.

title: WEEKS OF POLITICAL MANEUVERING FINALLY PRODUCED BUDGET FOR PENNSYLVANIA
description: After a month of tension, Pennsylvania's General Assembly finally voted the money to keep the state government running, then headed home Friday to learn what constituents might think of their final weeks and the maneuvers that led them first into and then out of a morass.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PRESERVING CAPITAL. And Making It Grow. By John Train. 274 pages. Illus- trated with Charts. Clarkson N. Potter/ Crown. $17.95.

title: The U.N. Today; July 25, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Christy N. Wise Wed To Robert A. Axelrod
description: Christy Nan Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newton E. Wise of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Axelrod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Axelrod of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Frank Evans and Rabbi Nathan Segal performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Tiburon, Calif.

title: Poland Sets Deadline On Granting of Amnesty
description: Polish prosecutors have set a one-week deadline for deciding whether amnesty should be granted to most political prisoners still in custody, the official press agency P.A.P. reported today.

title: FOR DANES, 'PAPERLESS MARRIAGES' AND FEWER BIRTHS
description: Nete Wingender and Vilhelm Niemann are almost, but not quite, the archetypical young Danish couple. They are: Blond. Unmarried. The parents of a 3-month-old child. They are not strictly typical, of course, because most Danish couples are not blond. But their approach to family life has become as Danish as apple Danish. Arrangements outside marriage now represent the standard household unit for young college-educated couples like Miss Wingender and Mr. Niemann. Births from these relationships account for more than one out of every three births in Denmark today, a figure three times the rate in France, which has the second-highest level of illegitimacy in the European Economic Community.

title: BASE IN HONDURAS BRINGS A LAWSUIT
description: An American landowner in Honduras has filed suit against three United States officials, charging that the Reagan Administration, in its haste to open a base for the training of Salvadoran soldiers in Honduras, seized ranch land belonging to him and is refusing to vacate it despite his demonstrated proof of ownership.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Dream Disposal
description: Do dreams presage the future, or help restore the mind, or enable the rampaging id to enjoy in fantasy the wishes that the superego denies? No, none of the above, according to a new theory of dreams proposed in Nature magazine by two biologists, Francis Crick and Graeme Mitchison. Dreams, they say, are a kind of mental housecleaning, their purpose being to help the mind detect and unlearn harmful memory associations.

title: Bulgarian Wins In World Fencing
description: Vassil Etropolski of Bulgaria defeated Gianfranco Dalla Barba of Italy, 10-8, and won the sabre title at the world fencing championships today. Etropolski's twin brother, Hristo, took the bronze medal with a 10-3 victory over Fernandino Meglio of Italy.

title: HOSPITAL DELIVERS CARE IN CHINESE
description: In the delivery rooms, doctors exhort mothers-to-be, ''Chut lek!'' In the kitchen, a chef swirls chicken pieces around a huge wok, while patients upstairs flourish chopsticks over rice and fried vegetables.

title: Decision File; Credit Company's 'Significant' Errors
description: The Trans Union Credit Information Company, one of the nation's largest credit reporting bureaus, has been making a ''significant'' number of errors in its reports on consumers, says the Federal Trade Commission.

title: The Voice of Experience
description: The United States Olympic hockey team opens training camp Aug. 7 at Colorado Springs. The team will play 65 exhibition games in preparation to defend its hockey gold medal at the Winter Olympics, Feb. 7-19 at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. In another kind of Olympic preparation, Herb Brooks, who led the 1980 team and became the Rangers' coach a year later, will look at the past and the future of Olympic hockey in a series of 31 five-minute radio broadcasts that began this month. Brooks is one of the 14 hosts of the Mutual Broadcasting System's ''Olympics '84'' radio reports. Among the others are Bobby Knight, discussing basketball; Sugar Ray Leonard on boxing; Billy Kidd on skiing, and Muriel Grossfeld on gymnastics.

title: STRANGERS' ADVICE ON THE BABY
description: ''That baby is too hot.'' ''That baby is too cold.'' ''Why are you carrying him in a pouch? He'll suffocate.'' ''Oh, a stretchsuit. That's not good for her feet.'' ''Don't take a baby out at night. The night air is harmful.'' THERE is something about the sight of a mother and an infant or even a toddler that compels people to offer unsolicited suggestions on how a baby should be dressed, fed, carried and otherwise cared for. Normally the givers of advice, usually but not always older women, would not dream of addressing a stranger on the street, but the presence of a baby seems to break the barriers.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, opening their last three-game series against the Braves this season, are 2-7 against them.

title: WHAT PRICE A POLITICAL PARTY'S VICTORY?
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEN OF CARDINALS STOPS DODGERS, 3-0
description: For Neil Allen, a change of scenery has also brought a change in fortune. More than a month after being traded from the Mets to St. Louis, Allen, who had been in the midst of a troubled season, suddenly has turned into one of the National League's most effective starting pitchers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Steel Band From the Bronx Plays at Naval Academy

title: Washington Watch; A U.S. Policy For Industry
description: WASHINGTON LOOKING toward the possibility of regaining control of the Senate and White House in 1984, some Congressional Democrats have embarked on a strategy aimed at enacting an industrial policy in 1985. What that means specifically remains elusive, but the direction is clear -more consultation among Government, business and labor leaders and a more active role for Washington in steering the American economy and possibly in keeping out imports.

title: (HUMAN) ATHLETES AND HERO-WORSHIP
description: Ira Berkow

title: Advertising; Equitable's Assignment For D'Arcy
description: AFTER an extensive search for an agency to handle its big corporate advertising campaign, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has decided on D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York. Plans call for a budget of $12 million.

title: TRADERS' RATE FEARS PERSIST
description: After the fanfare subsided, the Congressional testimony given last week by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. seemed to leave credit market participants just as fearful of higher interest rates as they were before.

title: PARCELLS SEES NO NEED TO REBUILD
description: When a pro football team has a losing season and a head coaching change, it inevitably faces a rebuilding, a regrouping, a starting over.

title: CUBANS FLEE IN BOAT BELIEVED TO BE HIJACKED
description: A group of Cubans arrived in the United States Thursday aboard a Cuban Government lobster boat that the crew said had been hijacked. The crew was sent back to Cuba and the 23 Cubans aboard are in detention, posing a sensitive problem for the United States.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: New Magazine Aimed At Women Physicians
description: The medical profession is inundated with publications aimed at doctors, and most live well on advertising revenues from the bigspending pharmaceuticals industry. And the consumer publishing field is inundated with publications for women because, in a majority of households, they make the most frequent buying decisions.

title: Strikers Prepare Answer for Con Ed
description: The union representing 16,000 striking workers at the Consolidated Edison Company will likely complete its answer today to an offer made Friday by the utility's management, according to the Federal mediator in the 38-day-old dispute.

title: Miss Mattheeussen Weds Hillel Zeitlin
description: Karen Rachel Mattheeussen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Mattheeussen of Benton Harbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Hillel Mordecai Zeitlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Zvi Zeitlin of Rochester and Santa Barbara, Calif. Rabbi David Zeller performed the ceremony at Wildwood Resort Acres in Lafayette, Calif.

title: AGENCY DECIDES AGAINST A MOVE TO QUEENS SITE
description: The biggest tenant in the World Trade Center, the State Workers' Compensation Board, is planning to move to downtown Brooklyn, rather than Queens as had been announced last year.

title: U.S. SEEKS INCREASE IN COVERT ACTIVITY IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing a major expansion of covert intelligence operations in Central America as part of a plan to increase American military activities in the region, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Pfitzinger Wins Coast Marathon
description: Pete Pfitzinger of Wellesley, Mass., won the San Francisco Marathon today, finishing in 2 hours 14 minutes 43 seconds.

title:
MONETARY CONTROL: A PARTISAN DEBATE;
Economic Analysis
description: The last few years have been tough ones for the Federal Reserve System, as the Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, in effect acknowledged last week in his testimony on monetary policy. Interest rates were sky-high until mid-1982, developing countries of the third world are staggering under a mountain of debt they cannot pay and the United States economy is just beginning to recover from its worst recession since World War II.

title: BIG TREASURY FINANCINGS AWAITED
description: Large Treasury financings will be a growing concern in the credit markets this week. On Wednesday the Treasury is scheduled to announce its borrowing plans for the rest of the quarter, including details of a financing of more than $15 billion in the first week of August.

title: DUTY FREE SHOPPERS SHIFTING TOP OFFICERS
description: Duty Free Shoppers, an international chain of duty-free shops based in Honolulu, is shifting its top command. Adrian Bellamy, the 42-year-old chairman of the Edgars Group, one of South Africa's largest retailers, will join the privately held concern in September, and in early 1984 he will become chairman and chief executive officer, according to Robert J. Futoran, who now holds those posts. Laurence Vogel, 46, the executive vice president, will become president at that time.

title: LEBANON CHIEF SAYS OPPOSITION ALLIANCE PRESENTS NO THREAT
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon said today that a newly announced alliance formed to oppose his Government posed no threat to the country or his administration.

title: Bridge: Another Cinderella Victory For Luella Slaner's Team
description: The Cinderella team of 1982 did it again here Saturday night in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. The New York group headed by Luella Slaner of Scarsdale, which upset all predictions by reaching the Vanderbilt final in Niagara Falls, N.Y., last year, reached the Spingold semifinal by snatching a last-deal victory from the top-seeded team.

title: Growth Seen In Third World
description: Economic growth in most developing countries should accelerate during the next decade, but the pace of the expansion will depend on the strength of recovery in industrialized nations, the World Bank said today.

title: Commodities; Longer Trading Hours
description: THE concept of futures exchanges staying open around the clock has long been discussed because most markets have always been international in scope and influence. But as the futures industry began staggering under an unceasing flow of new trading products during the last 18 months, thoughts of a 24-hour trading day faded.

title: Lauren Howe Wins
description: Lauren Howe sank a 25-foot birdie putt on the 17th hole and parred the final hole today to score a onestroke victory over Donna Caponi in the $200,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Mayflower Classic.

title: LITERARY LABOR OF LOVE IS SAVING YIDDISH BOOKS
description: The books were placed in cardboard boxes, neatly stacked by the door and left for the book collectors. They were the works of Leizer Treister, a Polish immigrant who settled in New York City in 1938. He wrote novels, short stories and plays in Yiddish until he died two years ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ''PRINTED MATTA''

title: Soviet Production Up
description: Industrial production in the Soviet Union rose 4.2 percent in the first half of this year, mostly because of better worker discipline, less absenteeism and greater efficiency, the Government's Central Statistical Board said Friday. Output of natural gas - a key earner of Western currency - rose 7 percent, coal stayed even at 363 million tons and oil rose 1 percent, to 307 million tons.

title: JETS GET NEW LEADERSHIP
description: BOBBY HAMMOND is now coaching the running backs. Ray Callahan is now coaching the defensive line. The new offensive-line coach is Jim Ringo, and Rich Kotite is the new receivers' coach. And Mike Faulkiner, armed with a clipboard, keeps tabs on practice for the new head coach, Joe Walton.

title: A SUMMIT DEADLINE
description: The question of a Soviet-American summit is pressing. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who talked recently with the Soviet leader, Yuri Andropov, and President Reagan, is convinced both now seek a meeting.

title: CZECHS CAPTURE FEDERATION CUP
description: Czechoslovakia won the Federation Cup women's team tennis title today, defeating West Germany in the final, 2-1.

title: FUND TO STABILIZE ARTS IS ORGANIZED
description: At a time when cultural organizations face growing financial uncertainty, three of the wealthiest private foundations in the United States are jointly establishing a multimillion-dollar fund to help qualified arts organizations achieve firmer fiscal management.

title: Chad Opens Offensive To Take Northern City
description: The Government has sent troops to the northern Chadian city of Faya-Largeau in an effort to recapture the city from Libyan-backed rebels who seized it one month ago, military sources said today.

title: A Dream Come True
description: Louis Collins relived some memories of the 1980-81 basketball season when, working toward his master's degree in education counseling, he played a total of 59 minutes in 18 games and averaged 1.7 points a game for the University of Virginia, which reached the Final Four before losing to North Carolina.

title: TANDON RIDES COMPUTER CREST
description: The Tandon Corporation was a small, specialized business back in 1979, making the delicate devices that record bits of information and retrieve them from computer files known as disk drives.

title: TURF RACE CAPTURED BY MAJESTY'S PRINCE
description: Majesty's Prince, who looked uninterested in running and hopelessly beaten at the top of the stretch, suddenly woke up and closed powerfully to win the $236,000 Sword Dancer Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: INTEL MANAGER PRESSES MARKETING IN EUROPE
description: Donald R. Street has few regrets about leaving the Intel Corporation's Santa Clara, Calif., offices for Britain, where he will be general manager for Intel's systems product lines for Europe.

title: Soviet Joins West In Denouncing Malta
description: The Soviet Union today joined the West in denouncing Malta for blocking final accord at the 35-nation European security conference, delegates said.

title: Volleyball Expert
description: The National Basketball Association Register devotes almost two pages to Wilt Chamberlain's accomplishments during his 14 pro seasons. Among his achievements were 31,419 points and 23,924 rebounds, the most in league history, and his 100-point performance against the Knicks on March 2, 1962.

title: Today's Special
description: Anyone who's been out to lunch in Manhattan lately knows there's a contagious nuisance stalking the restaurants. You've just sat down to lunch, gotten your drinks (Perrier for her, Goldstein for him) and started the conversation in earnest when a smiling man (''Hello, I'm LeRoy and I'll be your waiter'') arrives to make a speech, a virtuoso performance honed and honeyed by repetition.

title: MUSIC: FESTIVAL IN MOUNTAINS
description: A RELATIVELY new music festival - modest in means but admirable in its intentions - ended its second summer season Saturday night in New Paltz, N.Y. The series is called Music in the Mountains; it is directed by Gundaris Pone, a composer of some international success, who teaches at the State University of New York's campus at New Paltz; and its focus is American music. Last year's featured composer was Aaron Copland; this summer, Virgil Thomson has been on hand and his music very much in evidence. Saturday night's concert at the college's McKenna Theater offered Mr. Thomson's Suite from ''The River'' and also music by Henry Cowell, Harvey Sollberger and Charles Ives. Mr. Pone conducted an orchestra of about 50 players.

title: A REGULATOR WHOSE TIME HAS PASSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Taxing
description: It was only a fantasy to begin with, so probably no one expected it to last. But now it's clear. Washington has no intention of completing a rational fiscal and tax policy. It has, in effect, just declared a two-year holiday from tax increases, no matter how much they'll be needed.

title: PROD KREMLIN, MOYNIHAN SAYS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said today that President Reagan should apply direct pressure on Moscow to halt what he called its interference in Central America rather than increase the United States military presence in the region.

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS STATE IS SLIGHTED IN U.S. OUTLAYS
description: New York State continues to receive less in outlays from the Federal Government than its residents send to Washington in taxes, and this imbalance has increased under the Reagan Administration, according to a study by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: HOUSE LENDERS CASH IN ON OLYMPICS
description: Like latter-day Forty-Niners, hundreds of Los Angeles homeowners are poised to make a run for some big money by renting out their homes to visitors for the Olympic Games.

title: METRO-NORTH ACTS ON IMPROVEMENTS
description: Rail commuters from New York City's northern suburbs - long accustomed to strikes, slowdowns and sweltering heat - are witnessing improvements this summer in stations, equipment and track on a scale not seen in decades.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 25, 1983
description: International U.S. covert intelligence operations in Central America will be substantially expanded to accompany increased American military activities in the region, senior Reagan Administration officials said. The plans, generally approved by the White House include stepped up support for anti-Government insurgents in Nicaragua and a campaign of sabotage against Cuban installations in Nicaragua. The expanded operations authorized for the Central Intelligence Agency will be the most extensive since the Vietnam War, Administration officials said. (Page A1, Column 6.) Three U.S. officials are being sued by an American landowner in Honduras, who charges that the Reagan Administration, in its haste to open a training base for Salvadoran soldiers, seized ranch land belonging to him and is refusing to vacate it despite his proof of ownership. He is seeking an injunction against the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State and the Chief of Engineers of the Army Corps of Engineers. (A8:3.)

title: TV: U.S. INTELLIGENCE AND THE KLAUS BARBIE CASE
description: ''KLAUS BARBIE: The American Connection'' looks at the postwar involvement of United States intelligence officials with the man who was called the ''Butcher of Lyons.'' That there was such an involvement is certain; that Klaus Barbie committed monstrous crimes is certain, too. The question is whether the American agents were morally culpable in dealing with, even protecting, the former Gestapo officer. ''Klaus Barbie,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary, suggests they were. The documentary will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Margery Bonnett Is Wed
description: Margery Ellen Bonnett, a correspondent in Washington with People magazine, was married yesterday to David Eric Sellinger, an assistant United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. Rabbi Aryeh Azriel performed the ceremony at the Baltimore Hebrew Congregation. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Gerson Bonnett of Baltimore and Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sellinger of Newton, Mass.

title: LIMITS OF TRADE SANCTIONS
description: During the next six weeks, sharp Congressional debate about the renewal of the 1979 Export Administration Act will revive questions about East-West economic relations that have lain unresolved since the lifting of the sanctions on the Soviet-West European natural gas pipeline last November. To what extent does East-West commerce threaten Western security, and should these economic relations be used for political purposes? These questions will continue to divide the United States from its allies until we can resolve the differences between our conflicting interpretations of security.

title: EAGER STANDBYS FILL PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: A little after 3 P.M. last Friday, 20-year-old Laura Regina started to cry. She had been at the North Terminal of Newark International Airport since 5:30 A.M., trying to get a seat on one of People Express's flights to Jacksonville, Fla. Miss Regina, like thousands of others who crowd into the terminal on weekends, had been unable to get a reservation, so she was traveling standby.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMF Inc., White Plains, has appointed Wayne R. Stevenson president of its Texas Controls subsidiary in Dallas.

title: Hillel Weinberg Wed to Debra Weiner
description: Debra Ann Weiner, daughter of Dr. Robert L. Weiner and Dora Weiner, both of Denver, was married yesterday to Hillel Weinberg, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Milton Weinberg of Monsey, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Washington Hebrew Congregation by the bridegroom's father, who is the rabbi at Beth Haverim, the Reform Temple of Northwest Bergen County, in Mahwah, N.J.

title: FRENCH NOVICE, 22, IS WINNER OF TOUR
description: Young, talented, opportunistic and suddenly very ambitious, Laurent Fignon returned to his birthplace in triumph today as the winner of the first Tour de France bicycle endurance race he had entered.

title: Cubs 5, Padres 2
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Ron Cey drove in four runs with a homer, double, and sacrifice fly to lead Chicago. He hit his 13th homer of the season, off Tim Lollar (4-8), in the second inning to tie the game and delivered a two-run double with two away in the sixth and then scored on a single by Jody Davis to put Chicago ahead for good.

title: News Analysis
description: The controversy over charges that the New York City police have brutalized blacks has thrust black leaders and would-be leaders into the spotlight, sometimes willingly, sometimes less so.

title: Montanans Demonstrate Against Nonunion Help
description: About 75 union members brandishing baseball bats and boards protested today against the use of out-of-town nonunion workers at a Montana Power Company gas pipeline project.

title: THE PREREQUISITES OF TEACHER MERIT PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FIGHTING BREAKS OUT BETWEEN P.L.O. FACTIONS
description: Intense fighting broke out today between units of the Palestine Liberation Organization in eastern Lebanon, shattering a cease-fire that had held for three weeks.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT BLUE JAYS, 3-0
description: Rick Honeycutt became the first American League pitcher to win 13 games this season with a four-hit shutout tonight that gave the Texas Rangers a 3-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. The victory brought the Rangers to within a percentage point of first-place Chicago in the American League West and dropped Toronto into a tie with Baltimore for first in the East.

title: Anita Flax and Dean Lozow Marry in Larchmont
description: Anita Elise Flax and Dean Scott Lozow were married yesterday at the home of Dr. Carol C. Flax, mother of the bride, in Larchmont, N.Y., by the Rev. Richard Dannenfelser, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Pope Makes New Appeal For Missing Girl
description: Pope John Paul II today made a new appeal for 15-year-old Emanuela Orlandi, the Vatican employee's daughter who disappeared last month and is believed to have been kidnapped.

title: BOREDOM AND CYNICISM WILT BURMA'S POLITICAL LIFE
description: The problem with political life in Burma, said a Burmese intellectual in his 30's, is that ''nothing changes.'' Twenty-one years after Burma's leader, Gen. Ne Win, came to power in a coup, the Burmese appear to view political life in their country with deeper boredom, greater estrangement and a more thorough sullenness than they have for years.

title: Meganette Scores
description: Meganette, a filly, came from third place in the last 50 yards to win the $688,800 Rainbow Futurity by a nose today.

title: 3 WOMEN BEHIND 3 TOPS 'SOAPS'
description: Will Erica Kane discover the secret of the brooch? Will Countess Echo Di Savoia break up the marriage of Vicki and Clint Buchanan? And how about Dr. Grant Putnam, the espionage agent? Will he defect to save Celia? Stay tuned to ''All My Children,'' ''One Life to Live'' and ''General Hospital,'' because the three women who could tell you the answers right this minute, the producers of the programs, aren't talking.

title: Ponderosa Casa Lupita Added by Avrett, Free
description: Ponderosa Inc., a chain of 600 steakhouses based in Dayton, Ohio, decided slilghtly more than a year ago to join the Mexican food revolution that is taking place in the West and is inching east. So it acquired the rights to the concept and trademark of Casa Lupita, which had three restaurants in Seattle catering to more affluent diners than one would find in fast-food operations.

title: Amy Brant Kohen Marries Martin Cohn in Florida
description: Amy Brant Kohen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Roland J. Kohen of Miami Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Martin Henry Cohn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Perry D. Cohn of Passaic Park, N.J. Rabbi Sol Landau performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: WHAT CITY OPERA MUSICIANS ARE DOING WHILE THEY WAIT TO PLAY AGAIN
description: Anne Fryer, a violinist, collected $125 in unemployment compensation and borrowed thousands of dollars from her relatives. Bruce Revesz played the trumpet in the pit during a revival of ''Man of La Mancha'' in New Jersey and also collected unemployment. Livio Caroli relied on a few freelance engagements and his wife's income, and gave free oboe recitals to keep up his morale.

title: MONSANTO CHOOSES CHIEF AND CHAIRMAN
description: When Richard J. Mahoney responded to a help wanted advertisement run by the Monsanto Company in 1962, he was a traveling salesman for another, and smaller, chemical company. ''I was afraid the people I was working for would find out and I'd be out of work altogether,'' he recalls with a chuckle.

title: MONDAY, JULY 25, 1983; The Economy
description: Corporate profits have rebounded sharply in the second quarter. In some industries, particularly automobiles, air conditioners and televisions, the gains have been fueled directly by the long-awaited surge in consumer spending. Suppliers to those industries are also showing improvement. (Page D1.)

title: THE FAIRNESS ISSUE: REAGAN BATTLES HIS IMAGE AS A 'RICH MAN'S PRESIDENT'
description: The fairness and equity of President Reagan's budget and tax policies have emerged as a major political issue. The President has been trying to dispel an image as a ''rich man's President.'' White House strategists, fearing that the Administration may be vulnerable on the issue in the 1984 election, emphasize the President's compassion for poor people whenever they have a chance.

title: No Headline
description: Question Box S. Lee Kanner QUESTION: What is Gaelic football and what is its origin?

title: Debt Issues
description: * AIG Capital Funding, a unit of American International Group, will issue $150 million of commercial paper, through Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc.

title: GERMAN BANK BREAKS PATTERN
description: By almost any measure, the Berliner Handels- und Frankfurter Bank falls outside West Germany's snug banking mold. With $8.2 billion of group assets, it is only Germany's 26thlargest bank, yet it sits with the four biggest banks in the committee that oversees domestic bond issues.

title: A.D. 536 MEDITERRANEAN FOG TIED TO VOLCANO
description: Throughout the year 536 a ''dry fog'' dimmed the sun and moon in the Mediterranean region, scientists have deduced from early chronicles of the area. They believe the fog was caused by a distant volcanic eruption that may have been the most violent on earth since the last ice age.

title: UNIT OF AETNA LIFE HAS HIGH HOPES FOR BOSTON PROJECT
description: Urban Investment and Development, a shopping center developer that is a subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, had such success with Water Tower Place in Chicago, a highrise shopping mall replete with glittery boutiques, that it decided to try again.

title: Starling Retains Title on Decision
description: Marlon Starling successfully defended his North American Boxing Federation and United States Boxing Association welterweight titles today, taking a unanimous 12-round decision over previously unbeaten Tommy Ayers at the Showboat Hotel.

title: VENEZUELA RESISTING I.M.F. REIN
description: Jolted by recent declines in the price of oil, Venezuela is facing a debt crisis and is seeking to reshedule $16.3 billion in obligations to foreign creditors that fall due during the next 18 months. While many of the developing nations are facing financial strains, Venezuela has long been regarded as stronger than others because of its extensive oil holdings.

title: GIVING CONSUMER OF CREDIT NEEDED TOOLS
description: Unless a consumer can pay cash for every major purchase, the ability to obtain credit is essential. Houses and cars, loans and credit cards all depend on a person's credit worthiness. One would think that worthiness could be judged in an open and fair manner. But the methods for determining who is worthy and who is not are often discriminatory and irrational.

title: Golfer Loses Arm In Plane Accident
description: Jack Newton, the Australian golfer who won that country's 1979 open, severed his right arm after it was struck by an airplane propeller at Sydney Airport tonight.

title: IRAQI ECONOMY WEAKENS AS WAR WITH IRAN CUTS OIL EXPORTS
description: A ship with New Zealand butter destined for Iraq was steaming up and down the Gulf of Aqaba this week. The cargo will not be landed for overland delivery to Iraq across Jordan until Baghdad has paid for the preceding shipload of butter.

title: Queens Symphony Grant
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra has received a $60,000 grant from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, an 8 percent increase over last year's award. The orchestra said the money would be used to help pay for a children's educational concert, for the free ''Pops in the Parks'' concerts and for its discount-ticket program for students and the elderly.

title: DANCE: FIVE TROUPES FROM FRANCE AT PURCHASE
description: INVITED to the United States by the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., five French modern-dance companies grouped under the title Dance From France ended their visit to this country over the weekend at the Summerfare '83 festival in Purchase, N.Y.

title: GRANT AIDS TEACHER TRAINING
description: The entire faculty of the city's newest high school is attending a special course this month, aided by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. It is the largest grant ever given to the city's Board of Education by that Federal agency, according to board officials.

title: FLORENCE DOLOWITZ, WHO FOUNDED ORT IN AMERICA, IS DEAD
description: Florence R. Dolowitz, a founder and past president of Women's American ORT, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 94 years old and a longtime resident of New York City.

title: Elephant Kills Worker At Coast Animal Park
description: A three-ton elephant broke loose from its chains today at Lion Country Safari, killed the park's game warden and charged toward the San Diego Freeway before being captured.

title: Rape Suspect Held In $150,000 Bail
description: A 22-year-old Queens man accused of raping women in Flushing Meadow Park and robbing them and their companions was ordered held in $150,000 bail Saturday, a spokesman for the Queens District Attorney said.

title: Elisa H. Marke Weds Lawyer and Colleague
description: Elisa Hope Marke and Steven I. Foyer, assistant district attorneys in Queens, were married in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Irving J. Block performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: MUSIC: PIER ANIMALS REUNION
description: IT'S the rare performer older than 40 who can sustain a genuinely youthful sense of rock-and-roll sportiveness and not appear faintly ludicrous. But Eric Burdon, the intense lead singer of the Animals, who appeared together in their original 1964 lineup at Pier 84 on Friday, is one of those rarities.

title: GALLUP POLL SAYS 58% OF CATHOLICS FAVOR LETTING PRIESTS MARRY
description: Nearly three-fifths of American Roman Catholics believe priests should be allowed to marry, according to a Gallup Poll commissioned by two Catholic groups.

title: A Matter of Style
description: They've got trouble, my friends, trouble in River City. Just as the neighborhood pool hall in ''The Music Man'' had the boys buckling their knickerbockers below the knee, the slick version of pocket billiards, as played beneath the glittering chandelier of the Roosevelt Hotel ballroom, has created a new fashion problem.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle Thursday on Israel's decision to redeploy some troops in Lebanon in- correctly quoted a statement by Sec- retary of State George P. Shultz. Mr. Shultz, who made the remark to re- porters Tuesday in Washington, ex- pressed disappointment that Prime Minister Menachem Begin had post- poned a visit to Washington.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ford to Check Portrait

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A First at Mariners' Temple

title: Citing Lag in Fee, Prosecutor Refuses to Remain With Case
description: The special prosecutor who argued the state's case in the murder trial of Lemuel Smith says he will no longer work on the case until he receives the $40,000 in legal fees that he says is due him.

title: ISRAEL IS SENDING 2 HIGH OFFICIALS TO MEET REAGAN
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir will fly to Washington Monday to consult with President Reagan on the deteriorating situation in Lebanon, the Cabinet announced today.

title: GRAND MASTERS STIR MEMORIES ON COURT
description: Memories were replayed over the weekend at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. Ken Rosewall, 48 years old; Alex Olmedo, 47, and Mal Anderson, 48, seemed to move in slow motion much of the time. But like an old movie, they occasionally flashed dramatic touches of another era.

title: Seniors in Playoff
description: Rod Funseth shot a one-under-par 70 but carded a bogey on the final hole today that sent the United States Senior Open championship into an 18-hole playoff Monday between him and Billy Casper.

title: SALVADORAN REFUGEES IN NEW YORK REGION STRUGGLE FOR ASYLUM
description: The Portillo family passed around photographs of the coffin this morning. ''This was my father,'' said Jose Portillo, pointing to the body in the simple wooden box. ''Military or guerrillas, I don't know which, break into the house in 1981 and take my father and tie his hands behind his back. Then they shoot him. I don't know why. My father was a farmer, not a politican.''

title: FLOODING POSES THREAT TO EVERGLADES' ECOLOGY
description: Everglades National Park, 2,200 square miles of swamp and grassland, is suffering from an excess of water. The park's animal and plant life depends on a cycle of dry winter, wet summer. By the end of the rainy season this summer, however, the park will have been waterlogged for 18 months, and environmentalists fear a disaster unless there is prompt action.

title: Power Restored
description: Electricity was restored Saturday for the last 100 of an estimated 10,000 Consolidated Edison customers who lost it in a thunderstorm on Thursday, the utility said.

title: UNBORN VICTIMS OF ALCOHOL USE
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Toll in Japan Is Now 75 From Flooding and Mudslides
description: The number of dead from flooding and mudslides in southwestern Honshu climbed to 75 today with the discovery of more bodies under mounds of mud caused by heavy rains and landslides, the police said.

title: Officer Is Suspended; Accused of Firing Gun
description: A New York City police officer was suspended without pay yesterday after being accused of firing his revolver early Saturday morning during a traffic dispute on Staten Island while he was off duty, the police said.

title: CANADA JET LOSES POWER IN FLIGHT
description: An Air Canada Boeing 767 lost power on both its jet engines, apparently because of fuel problems, on a Montreal-to-Edmonton flight Saturday and made an emergency landing at a former military base about 60 miles north of Winnipeg.

title: Larry Katz Wed To Miss Brement
description: Diana Brement, daughter of Joan Brement of Bayside, Queens, and Marshall Brement of Reykjavik, Iceland, was married yesterday to Larry Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Katz of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Morton Gordon performed the ceremony at Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens.

title: EQUIPMENT OWNERSHIP HOLDS UP N.P.R. LOAN
description: Negotiations for a bail-out loan by the federally funded Corporation for Public Broadcasting to National Public Radio became snagged today over the question of ownership of some of the network's technical equipment.

title: No Headline

title: What P-I-K Spells
description: ''Payment-in-Kind'': when it was first proposed last year, it sounded like a painless way to reduce farm subsidies and at the same time unload old surpluses. But the program has yielded only marginal economic benefits, and, as politics, PIK, as it is called, has proved to be an f-l-o-p.

HOUSTON (NL) - Activated Alan A shby, catcher, and sent Luis Pujols, c atcher, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast L eague. title: BANKS BOLSTER PRIMARY CAPITAL
description: The nation's major banks have been reinforcing their financial underpinnings to prepare for a resurgence of loan demand as the economic recovery continues.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: PEETE MAKES UP 6 SHOTS TO WIN BY ONE AS SUTTON FADES TO A 77
description: Calvin Peete, six strokes back at the start of the final round, surged past Hal Sutton and scored a one-stroke victory today in the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: 'TENNIS ROCK': MCENROE AND GERULAITIS
description: WHILE they may make more money than most rock stars, guitar-toting tennis pros still cannot lure hordes of teen-agers to a concert, even a benefit for a worthy cause. As hosts of an evening of ''tennis rock'' at Pier 84 on Saturday, John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis drew one of the lightest turnouts of the season in an event whose proceeds will benefit the Special Olympics.

title: EARNINGS UP SHARPLY IN QUARTER
description: Corporate profits rebounded sharply in the second quarter. As the nation's largest companies report results for the three months, they provide further evidence that a surge in spending by consumers has spread through the economy.

title: TELLING DEMOCRATS FROM REPUBLICANS
description: How can you tell the difference between a Democrat and a Republican? Without claiming original authorship, Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, offered some helpful hints in a recent issue of the Congressional Record:

title: STAGE: ANGELA LANSBURY STARS IN 'MAME' REVIVAL
description: THOUGH they have their other failings, the people who have brought ''Mame'' back to Broadway are master archeologists. The new production at the Gershwin Theater looks like an almost exact replica of the musical that opened at the Winter Garden in 1966.

title: BRETT HOMER NULLIFIED, SO YANKEES WIN
description: Baseball games often end with home runs, but until yesterday the team that hit the home run always won. At Yankee Stadium yesterday, the team that hit the home run lost.

title: RAW SEWAGE FOULS HARBORS 11 YEARS AFTER POLLUTION LAW
description: Eleven years after Congress approved legislation to clean up the nation's waters, the Atlantic coast's two largest metropolitan areas, Boston and New York, are still releasing billions of gallons of untreated sewage into their harbors each year.

title: A SIBERIAN SOJOURN ENDS WELL FOR FOES OF WHALING
description: For seven antiwhaling activists released at sea by the Soviet Union after five days in custody, the worst moment in their ordeal came Thursday night, when their ship failed to keep a rendezvous to pick them up.

description: Harold Johnson won the second annual Manhattan Island Marathon Swim yesterday, and Julie Billingsley was the first woman to cross the finish line.

title: I.O.C. Director Denies Comment
description: The director of the International Olympic Committee today denied saying that she feared the Soviet Union might boycott the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles.

description: To the Editor:

title: METS LOSE, EXTEND SLUMP

title: Study Says Subway Plan Is Threat to Fossil Site
description: Construction of a subway stop at the famed La Brea Tar Pits would displace or destroy some of the world's most valuable fossil deposits, an environmental impact report said today.

title: FIGHTING CENSORSHIP
description: The Reagan Administration's recent decision to withdraw financial support from a publication that was said to express ideas contrary to Administration policy is rightfully being challenged. When a government body, be it a school board or a national administration, tries to censor ideas with which it does not agree, constitutional principles - and democratic government - are jeopardized.

description: After two weeks of preaching against the MX missile, Senator Gary Hart finally got a rise today out of the main Senate advocate of the proposed multiple-warhead weapon.

title: ON MARGARET MEAD: DERKE FREEMAN DENIES BIAS
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: I would like to comment on L.@S. Cressman's letter, ''Dr. Mead's First Husband Comes to Her Defense'' (Science Times, May 3). According to Professor Cressman, to say that Franz Boas, Margaret Mead's professor at Columbia University, sent her to Samoa ''to gather information to support his idea of the greater importance of nurture over nature'' is utter nonsense. While this may be Professor Cressman's sincere conviction, the historical evidence shows him to be at error in his recollections. Boas, this evidence indicates, did have very strong views about the relative importance of ''hereditary and environmental conditions'' in the etiology of human behavior, maintaining (in his own words) that ''the social stimulus is infinitely more potent than the biological mechanism.'' Further, as Margaret Mead herself reported (in ''Blackberry Winter,'' 1972, page 126), Boas sent her to Samoa in 1925 to work on ''the adolescent girl, to test out, on the one hand, the extent to which the troubles of adolescence, called in German Sturm und Drang and Weltschmerz, depended upon the attitudes of a particular culture and, on the other hand, the extent to which they were inherent in the adolescent stage of psychobiological development.'' Boas, Mead also recorded, believed that her work in Samoa would show that culture was ''very important.''

title: MUNICIPAL UTILITIES FACE RISING RATES
description: Municipally owned electric utilities are faced with higher interest rates on their new bond issues as a result of the default of the Washington Public Power Supply System on $2.25 billion of bonds.

title: Longtime President Retires at Mathematica
description: Tibor Fabian, who has been president of Mathematica Inc. for much of its 25-year existence, has announced his retirement. The Martin Marietta Corporation has acquired Mathematica, a Princeton, N.J., research and consulting concern that moved into computer software. Richard Walters, who has been president of Martin Marietta Data Systems, has been named to succeed Mr. Fabian. Martin Marietta paid $30.8 million for Mathematica in cash and stock.

description: The Passion of Sailing

title: WYOMING MAKES WAY, WITH SOME PAIN, FOR NEW RAILROAD LINE
description: The building of a new railroad line is stirring up dust in the farming communities of eastern Wyoming. The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, making a bid to compete with the Burlington Northern for Wyoming coal traffic, has started construction on one of the few new rail lines seen anywhere in the country in the last 50 years. The railroad's plan is bringing disruption, however, and it threatens to put Lost Springs out of business.

Nkomo Is Facing Ouster From Parliament
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwe opposition leader who is living in self-imposed exile, has eight days to return home or be expelled from Parliament, the Minister of Legal and Parliamentary Affairs said today.

title: ILLINOIS PRISONS THREATENING TO TURN AWAY INMATES
description: For about two more weeks, Illinois state prisons will accept prisoners from county sheriffs if they phone ahead for reservations. After that, the state says, it will run out of beds.

title: Indiana's Turner Sues Ford Motor
description: Landon Turner, who was a basketball star at Indiana University when he was paralyzed in an automobile accident two years ago today, has sued the Ford Motor Company and the Indianapolis auto dealership that sold him his car.

title: SCHOOLS' APPROACH TO COMPUTERS SEEN AS WRONG
description: BACA GRANDE, Colo. MOST schools are backing into the computer age with their eyes on the past instead of the future. They either use computers as drill machines or they try to train junior programmers with the mistaken notion that the economy will be pining for their skills. Unless there is a quick reversal of this misuse of the new technology, a precious opportunity will be lost to make the schools relevant to the children's and the nation's future needs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will never surrender Central Park to a small group of hoodlums.'' - Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern. (1:3.)

And Richard Flaxman, executive vice president, is assured that there will be a $2 million budget that will cover local market campaigns in such cities as Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Dallas, Houston and Miami.

title: K.G.B. OFFICERS TRY TO INFILTRATE ANTIWAR GROUPS

The cases are the best evidence offered by Western counterintelligence officers who believe that the Soviet espionage agency's highest priorities in Western Europe include attempts to exploit the disarmament movement.

Everson Walls, the Dallas Cowboys' holdout cornerback who had rejected the team's latest offer Friday, suddenly decided to report to training camp at Thousand Oaks, Calif., last night.
