title: CABARET: 'BANNED IN FRANCE,' SATIRICAL REVUE
description: Of the many mean-spirited characters who parade through ''Banned in France,'' the satirical revue that opened a sporadic run at O'Neals' 43d Street Cabaret last Thursday, the most unforgettable is Connie Chutzpah, a cable-television personality whose show, ''Celebrity Corner,'' is broadcast ''on location in front of Xenon's.'' Played with fiendish zeal by the actor-writer Terry Sweeney, Miss Chutzpah navigates through the limousine-infested currents of fame like a famished piranha desperately grabbing at celebrities like ''Princess Caroline of Morocco,'' Brooke Shields's mother and Omar Sharif for impromptu chats.

title: Mantle Clears Air
description: Mickey Mantle said yesterday that despite widespread speculation to the contrary, his absence from the Old-Timers' Game at Yankee Stadium on July 16 was caused by a family matter and had nothing to do with any animosity over his being barred by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn from all baseball jobs because he was employed by a casino. The 51-yearold former Yankee star, who in the past had regularly attended such games at the Stadium, said that he remained that day in Dallas, where he lives, because ''my son Billy was coming home from the Anderson Clinic in Houston, where he was undergoing chemotherapy treatments, and I thought I should be home.''

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Revenue figures include excise taxes.

title: CONWOOD CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1983. Year-ago results include operations of Manhattan Products Inc., which was sold in July 1982.

title: STANDARD OIL CO (IND) reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NO SOVIET BOYCOTT SEEN BY SAMARANCH
description: Despite renewed reservations by the top Soviet Olympic official, the president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said today that he was confident that the Soviet Union would send a team to the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: BELL & HOWELL'S NEW DIRECTION
description: When the Bell & Howell Company announced recently that it had received a takeover inquiry for its DeVry Institute of Technology, a chain of technical schools, the news may have surprised those who still think of the company as a camera manufacturer. But Bell & Howell's vow to fight the offer, from the National Education Corporation of Newport Beach, Calif., underscored the fact that the company has taken a new direction.

title: Jets Limit 2 Players' Practices
description: The Jets say that they are not particularly concerned, that what they are doing is merely a preventive measure.

title: COSTLIEST OF BURGUNDY'S VINES RUINED BY FIERCE HAILSTORMS
description: It was a very French disaster. About 3 A.M. Sunday morning, hailstones - described variously as being as big as small marbles or as pigeon eggs - pelted the vines in Vosne-Romanee near Dijon in a part of Burgundy known as the Cote d'Or.

title: MINNESOTA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
REAGAN'S BIG STICK
description: If President Reagan set out last week to convince the people of Nicaragua that he means to make war on them and overthrow the Sandinista Government, he scored a considerable success. But it may prove a costly one that the United States will long regret.

title: L.I. Man, 19, Faces 3 Charges of Rape
description: A 19-year-old Long Island man was charged today with three rapes, one attempted rape, five burglaries and various other crimes, and the police said they were investigating to see whether he might be linked to more.

title: RICHARD WILLIAM HOWELL
description: Richard William Howell, founder and retired chairman of the Roanwell Corporation, a former manufacturer of communications equipment, died of cancer Sunday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was too tantalizing an opportunity to pass up. Joan Collins was t o sign a contract with Revlon to act as the spokesman, personality a nd ad model for that company's fragrance (one doesn't say cologne o r perfume anymore) called Scoundrel, a scent best described as s trong. Last Wednesday, that's exactly what happened as Miss C ollins, the wicked witch of the television show ''Dynasty''; Michel B ergerac, the chairman of Revlon, and no fewer than 17 photographers c onverged on the Revlon boardroom for some good old-fashioned H ollywood hokum, which included signing the contract in front of e veryone.

title: BILL TO PHASE IN LILCO RATE INCREASE OVER 10 YEARS IS VETOED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo today vetoed a bill designed to phase in increases in electric rates over a 10-year period once the nuclear power plant at Shoreham, L.I., begins producing electricity.

The Best Teacher Is Experience
description: Pro football is more than running, passing, blocking and tackling. Part of it, says Joe Morris, is relaxing, and the Giants' halfback said his inability to relax was a major reason for his disappointing rookie season.

description: SUCH targets as stars and the mysterious energy source in the core of the Milky Way Galaxy are to be charted in detail through a novel system being developed at the University of California in Berkeley.

title: Chrysler to Pay Fine of $45,000
description: The Commerce Department said that the Chrysler Corporation had agreed to pay a $45,000 fine, but that it neither admitted nor denied allegations that it had failed to report 50 requests to engage in restrictive trade practices or boycotts against Israeli companies. Chrysler has also ''agreed to take corrective measures to avoid future violations,'' the department said.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Addresses of Employees Ruled Confidential
description: Citing rights to privacy, a Federal appeals court today said the Social Security Administration does not have to disclose the home addresses of its employees to a labor union.

title: PENTAGON DETAILS HONDURAS ACTION
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that Army and Marine troops and Navy tactical air crews will take part in the United States military maneuvers scheduled to begin in Honduras this week.

title: ROCK CONCERT: DAVID BOWIE AS PERFORMANCE ARTIST
description: THROUGHOUT his 15-year career as a rock performer, David Bowie has worked out new modes of presentation, won new converts, then challenged them, his older fans and his own limits by confronting them with new work in a new mode.

description: Four National Football League players, including two members of the Cincinnati Bengals, were suspended without pay yesterday through the fourth game of the coming regular season by Commissioner Pete Rozelle, who cited their violation of league drug policies involving use of cocaine.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BOY IS BORN AFTER TWIN HAD DIED
description: A woman who miscarried one of her twin babies three-and-a-half months ago has successfully delivered the second twin in what her doctor says is a unique case.

title: 3 Are Wounded In Williamsburg
description: A mother, her 13-year-old daughter and a pregnant friend of the mother's were shot and seriously wounded yesterday in their apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 26, 1983
description: International Henry A. Kissinger conferred with President Reagan and said that the new Presidential commission on Central America was unlikely to complete its work before next February, two months later than the original deadline set by Mr. Reagan. The former Secretary of State, who heads the commission, said the 12 panel members would probably travel to Nicaragua and other Central American countries. (Page A1, Column 6.) American Army and Marine troops and Navy tactical air crews will take part in the military maneuvers set to begin in Honduras this week, according to a senior Pentagon official. The policy-making official said the aircraft carrier Ranger, with its seven escorting ships, would begin operating 100 miles off the Pacific coast of El Salvador within 48 hours. (A10:1.)

title: ANIMAL CARE NO LONGER SIMPLE, FOLKSY PRACTICE
description: UNTIL recent times, whenever a horse, cow, pig, cat, dog or other farm animal or pet became seriously ill, a phone call to a veterinarian would usually bring him in short order. Who else would appear, one imagines, but one of those James Herriots of the world - the homey, rough-hewn, caring type who would have arisen at 3 A.M. and driven miles over rutted roads to save the sick animal.

If the United States International Trade Commission issues a final ruling that dumped printcloth is harming the United States industry, antidumping duties will be imposed.

title: FIGHTING PANIC ON AIDS
description: The saturation news coverage of acquired immune deficiency syndrome and a few sensationalized news reports have helped spawn an epidemic of fear and panic reaching far beyond high-risk groups. In light of the extraordinary concern over AIDS, balanced reporting should be matched by special efforts by those connected with science to speed the distribution of new information and to help news organizations interpret it.

description: National Public Radio, whose officials have said that the network faced imminent bankruptcy if it did not come up with at least $1.8 million, today rejected the latest proposal for a loan from the federally financed Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

description: AS technical jargon goes, ''interface'' is a fairly inoffensive example. No other word quite seems to fill its definition: basically, a boundary between systems having different characteristics. description: Merrill Lynch & Company, benefiting from a surge in trading commissions and underwriting fees, yesterday reported that second-quarter net income more than tripled, to $112 million, compared with the $36 million it earned in the similar period last year.

description: A 48-hour strike called by the Shining Path guerrilla movement shut down much of this Andean city today. Armored police vehicles patrolled the streets to guard against violence.

title: Peru Seeks Debt Pact
description: Peru is asking its Western creditor governments to allow it to delay repayments for eight years of $1 billion in debt falling due through February 1985, the Peruvian Economics Minister, Carlos Rodriguez Pastor, said today. Mr. Rodriguez made the statement while attending a two-day meeting of the Club of Paris, an informal group of creditor governments that meets to consider debt rescheduling requests.

title: WILDLIFE IS MAKING COMEBACK AT VOLCANO
description: Animal and plant life is returning to the Mount St. Helens volcano, where a cataclysmic eruption in 1980 flattened 150 square miles of brush and timber.

title: CYCLE COMPLETED FOR VAN PELT
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. M ore than six years ago, having played out his option and qualified for pro football's version of free agency, Brad Van Pelt went to Giants Stadium to speak about a new contract with Wellington Mara, the club president. Van Pelt had found a home at linebacker and had become the team's most valuable player, and yet, for the first 40 minutes of their meeting, he did not have much to say. ''I didn't really have the nerve to say anything about what I wanted,'' he said shortly afterward.

title: American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc., of Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had purchased two hospitals, the Collin Memorial Hospital, McKinney, Tex., for $14 million, and the Culver Union Hospital, in Crawfordsville, Ind. The company will lease and operate the Crawfordsville facility and construct a 120-bed replacement hospital at a cost of $18 million.

description: Jim Gott, a starting pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays, is not unaccustomed to traveling. His father, Gott said, is a self-made man who enjoyed his affluence by traveling with his family all around the United States and Europe.

title: Singer Posts Profit
description: The Singer Company, a diversified high-technology company based in Stamford, Conn., reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter ended June 30 climbed to $5.8 million, or 26 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends, compared with $400,000, or a loss of 5 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends in the quarter a year earlier.

title: ARCHITECTURE: 100 YEARS OF PHOTOGRAPHS ON VIEW
description: SO intertwined are the histories of architecture and photography that one is tempted to wonder whether photography would have been invented had there not been buildings to photograph - or whether architecture would have continued to develop had photography not been there to record it. Along with portraiture, architecture has been a central subject of photography for that entire medium's life. And there is no question that photographs of architecture influence our perceptions of architecture - and thus do come eventually to influence the nature of what gets built.

title: WHAT NICARAGUA WANTS
description: On the fourth anniversary of our revolution, we in the Government of Nicaragua issued a peace proposal addressed to the United States. We hope that it will be taken seriously by the Administration, Congress and public opinion.

title: Quake Near Coalinga, Calif.
description: An earthquake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale struck Coalinga this afternoon, one of a series of aftershocks from the quake that destroyed much of the town May 2. The United States Geological Survey said the quake was centered 11 miles northwest of the town. No serious damage or injuries were reported.

description: A Congressional committee was told yesterday that New York City ''is becoming a bleak place to live for far too many children.'' ''They are growing up in neighborhoods of despair with a dim prospect of securing jobs to support their families when they grow up unless they are adequately trained and educated and the barriers to employment, including racism, which persist in locking out their parents from any form of economic mobility, are removed,'' said Georgia L. McMurray, deputy general director of the Community Service Society.

description: BARRE, Pa., July 21- The Anthracite Newsstand, just off the shaded lawn of the Public Square, is clearly a thriving business, but it is also one of several battlegrounds in a feud that has divided this old hard-coal city for nearly six years.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES ROSE 38.1% IN MID-JULY
description: The Big Three domestic auto makers reported today that their sales of new cars rose 38.1 percent in mid-July from the same period last year, indicating that the recovery in the automobile industry is gaining momentum.

title: Ceremony Is Shunned By Hispanic Workers
description: Only a small crowd was on hand today as Mayor Thomas G. Dunn, who recently created a furor by ordering city employees to speak only English while on the job, held a ceremony to signal the start of Puerto Rican Week.

title: Martin Marietta Gains
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, citing a general improvement in the economy and strength in its commercial businesses, announced yesterday that net income increased 41.8 percent in the second quarter, to $57 million, or $2.70 a share, from $40.2 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. Revenues for the company, which makes construction aggregates, cement, and aerospace and military systems, rose 5 percent, to $953.5 million, from $907.7 million.

title: SPECIALTY COMPOSITES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,000 for the quarter and $6,600 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after tax credits of $350 for the quarter and $700 for the 6 months.

title: BRINK'S WITNESS WILL NOT TESTIFY IN FEDERAL TRIAL
description: Samuel Brown, a defendant awaiting trial on New York State charges in the 1981 Brink's robbery and shootout, refused to testify yesterday when he was called as a witness in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HECK'S INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $113,000 for the quarter and $730,000 for the 6 months.

title: 2 Die in a Blaze Said to Be Arson
description: Two elderly people died today in a fire that officials said tore through a three-story apartment house, severely damaged a two-story house next door and fit the ''same pattern'' as other recent blazes here. The officials said the fire was caused by arson.

title: A SWIMMING HOLE WITHOUT SWIMMING? IN ONE TOWN, YES
description: Far beyond exurbia, where even the antique shops start to thin out, children still spend sunny summer days in old-fashioned swimming holes, plunging from old tires attached to swinging ropes or diving from rocks and trees. The children seem happy to share the water with sunfish, crawfish, turtles and an occasional beaver, if not the dragonflies and horseflies, and seem not to mind at all a little mud oozing between their toes.

title: REDESIGNED CORVETTE IS SELLING OUT
description: Shortly after the General Motors Corporation introduced the redesigned 1984 Chevrolet Corvette in California in late March, the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith, received some unexpected first-hand evidence that the new sports car was quickly becoming a hit. He was awakened at his Bloomfield Hills, Mich., home at 1 A.M. one night by a phone call from an exuberant Corvette buyer in California who wanted to compliment him on G.M.'s newest product.

title: SUDDENLY, MR. BELL'S DATEBOOK IS FULL
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell is no longer the wallflower at the Cabinet prom, a man assigned to dismantle his own department.

title: BECTON, DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After special pretax charges of $75 million for the quarter and 9 months and a pretax gain of $43 million for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of the company's shares in Huntington Research Centre PLC. c-Net income.

title: Couple Sentenced In Child's Slaying
description: A Harlem mother was sentenced yesterday to up to 22 years in prison and her boyfriend was given up to life in prison in the beating death of her 4-year-old son.

title: Goodyear Closure
description: The Goodyear Tire Company said it would close its factory in Northern Ireland in three months, a move that would put about 750 people out of work. Goodyear-Great Britain, the British subsidiary of the American company, said the plant is losing as much as $1 million a month. The Goodyear factory at Craigavon, south of Belfast, was opened in 1967 to make conveyer belts, fan belts, hoses and other rubber products.

title: CHINA SAYS VIETNAM GROWS OPIUM TO EARN FUNDS
description: China has accused Vietnam of having grown opium since 1981 to earn foreign exchange for its hard-pressed economy. Its charge was made in the current issue of the monthly Liaowang. The magazine is published by the official New China News Agency, which also circulated some details in an earlier news dispatch.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 26, 1983; Companies
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System has defaulted on the $2.25 billion it borrowed to finance two nuclear power plants that were then canceled, leaving thousands of bondholders with paper that has lost most of its value. It is the largest default in municipal bond history. (Page A1.) The expected default has hurt other municpally owned electric unitilities, but not the tax-exempt municipal bond market in general. (D22.)

title: AN EXPERT URGES MULTIPLE REFORMS
description: John I. Goodlad is a former dean of the Graduate School of Education at the University of California at Los Angeles. For the past eight years, Mr. Goodlad has directed the most comprehensive study ever made of what goes on in American elementary and secondary classrooms. Last week, he released his report as a book entitled ''A Study of Schooling.''

title: Sallie Mae Is Planning Sale of Stock to Public
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced yesterday that it was developing plans for its first sale of nonvoting stock to the public. The association, known as Sallie Mae, was founded in 1973.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GENTLEMAN'S GENTLEMAN

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
KINARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss after losses on discontinued operations of $90,000 for the quarter and $69,000 for the 6 months. Revenue in year-ago periods restated for discontinued operations.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings for the latest year reflect the increase in weighted average shares outstanding resulting from an initial public offering in February.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $197,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. EFFORTS GROW TO PROTECT WATER
description: American governments at all levels are urgently seeking solutions to the increasing contamination of the underground water supply that provides drinking water for more than half of the country's population.

title: TELECO OILFIELD SERVICES, INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Suit by Texaco
description: Texaco Inc. said it had sued Internorth Inc. in a state district court, accusing it of having breached 43 contracts to purchase natural gas.

title: P.S.E.& G. Rates
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company said it had asked the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to approve a $41.5 million-a-year reduction in gas rates, effective Sept. 30.

title: 250 Flee Fumes
description: About 250 people were forced to flee their homes today when burning insulation from a warehouse fire spread toxic fumes through part of this village near Rochester, authorities said. Fifty people were treated for dizziness and breathing difficulties.

title: Marc Rich Assets May Be Frozen; Sale of U.S.  Unit Is Cited
description: A Federal judge in New York has given the United States Attorney's office permission to freeze some of the assets of Marc Rich & Company A.G., one of the world's biggest commodities traders, in order to collect $1 million in fines for contempt of court.

title: MARK PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Klockner a Holdout
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff and West German iron and steel industry leaders were unable to persuade Klockner-Werke A.G. to participate in a production quota agreement, an Economics Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Wang Net Rises 44%; Prime Computer Down
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., the Lowell, Mass., manufacturer of electronic office equipment, reported sharp increases in earnings, revenue and new orders for the quarter ended June 30 and for its fiscal year.

title: Murray in 'Razor's Edge'
description: The comedy actor Bill Murray will appear in his first dramatic role, as Larry Darrell, in the Columbia Pictures production of W. Somerset Maugham's novel ''The Razor's Edge.'' Mr. Murray starred in the television comedy ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Dance on Home Video
description: Three modern dance works by Merce Cunningham are now available on video cassettes for home use.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,600,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the quarter and $1,400,000 for the 6 months.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid June 27.

title: TIGHT RACE LOOMS IN CHICAGO TODAY
description: A tight three-way race is expected Tuesday for the Democratic nomination in the First Congressional District's special primary.

title: RADIATION RISK MAY BE HIGHER THAN THOUGHT
description: SCIENTIFIC findings that have been emerging in recent months are forcing the experts to take at new look at the potential health hazards of radiation. Indeed, various authorities now suggest that ionizing radiation - the kind that has traditionally been considered most worrisome - should probably be judged four to 20 times more likely to produce cancer than previously believed. However, these new risk estimates remain tentative and their significance for human health is still uncertain.

title: HUGHES HAS LOSS
description: The Coca-Cola Company, buoyed by the strong performances of both its domestic and foreign soft drink operations and a positive contribution by its Columbia Pictures subsidiary, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1983 rose 14.7 percent, while operating revenues advanced 16.6 percent.

title: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes after-tax charge of $14 million related to the writedown of certain plants. c-Net income.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AUG. 1 TO BE HELSINKI RIGHTS DAY
description: President Reagan said today that human rights were being violated in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe ''on a continuing and regular basis.''

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a writeoff of $5.8 million of investment in a Colorado mine.

title: SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $83,000,000 in the first quarter due to restructuring and merger related costs. c-Net income after a loss of $14,600,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of Mack Trucks and Golden West Broadcasters.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Speculating On Chapter 11
description: SPECULATING in companies in hopes they will emerge successfully from Chapter 11 proceedings under the Federal bankruptcy law can be a potentially rewarding strategy. But it should be used only by persons aware of the inherent risks.

title: POWER GROUP SAYS IT CANNOT PAY OFF $2.25 BILLION DEBT
description: In the largest default in municipal bond history, the Washington Public Power Supply System has officially stated that it cannot pay back the $2.25 billion it borrowed to finance two nuclear power plants that were never finished.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
New York Air Earnings Rise
description: New York Air announced yesterday that it earned $3.1 million in the second quarter of 1983 and attributed the first profitable quarter in its almost three years of operation to its decision to concentrate on business travelers.

title: Eurobonds Off In a Quiet Day
description: Trading in Eurobonds was quiet today, with prices slightly easier, dealers said.

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
REVERSE DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER OBFUSCATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bombs Explode in Kabul
description: Two bombs exploded in Kabul, the Afghan capital, today, killing one student and injuring six people, the state-run Kabul radio said.

title: POPULATION GROWTH BECKONING ECONOMIC DISASTER
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYER FAILS TO PROVIDE SEX TAPES IN COURT
description: Robert K. Steinberg, ordered to turn over videotapes he said he had seen of high government officials in sexual activities, showed up empty-handed at the courthouse today when he responded to a subpoena.

title: EARNINGS RISE 27.2% AT EXXON
description: The Exxon Corporation, benefiting from lower and more stable crude oil prices, increased its earnings in the second quarter by 27.2 percent, the company announced yesterday.

title: TOLEDO EDISON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
A PIECE OF WOOD IS MUCH COVETED
description: A 34 1/2-inch, 32-ounce piece of wood remained the hottest topic of conversation in baseball yesterday. Newspaper photographers wanted to take pictures of it, television cameramen wanted to film it, the Hall of Fame wanted to put it on display. All George Brett wanted to do was get his bat back.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
MEDALIST INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss includes losses of $2,175,000 in the quarter and $2,320,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-After gain of $128,000 from discontinued operations.

description: b-Includes gains from the sale of investments and other assets of $10,247,000 for the quarter and $13,299,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from the sale of investments and other assets of $2,169,000 for the quarter and $1,856,000 for the 6 months.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lyrical Welcome

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
STRESS ADDICTION: 'LIFE IN THE FAST LANE' MAY HAVE ITS BENEFITS
description: THE image of the harried overa@chiever is ubiquitous in today's stressful society. Typical is the person running for the subway when another will follow in a few minutes, the executive who is obsessed by goals to be met and surpassed, the doer who is compulsive about staying ahead of the pack, indeed who goes out of his way to take risks that give him a charge. Some researchers into human behavior believe that such driven people may actually be addicted to effects of stress, deriving pleasure from strife.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the 6 months.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
U.S. Unit of Airbus To Get a New Chief
description: Airbus Industrie of North America, a sales unit of the European aircraft consortium that makes the Airbus, said yesterday that Patrick Croze, a French executive, would become its president and chief executive in New York on Aug.1. Mr. Croze is currently executive assistant to Bernard Lathiere, president of the parent Airbus Industrie.

title: Stars Still Apart
description: Steve Ovett and Sebastian Coe, Britain's track stars, who have not faced each other for three years, were placed in separate events for the world track and field championships at Helsinki, Finland, in August. Ovett, who was spiked in the left foot during a race Sunday, was named to compete in the 1,500 meters and Coe will run in the 800.

title: Rats Need Their Sleep
description: Severe sleep deprivation results in debilitation and death in experimental rats, a group of scientists at the University of Chicago's Sleep Research Laboratory reported in a recent issue of Science magazine. While hardly a surprising conclusion, the researchers, led by Allan Recht@schaffen, noted that previous studies had not clarified whether the stresses of the stimulation required to prevent sleep could have caused the ill effects.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tales That Enrapture

title: ELECTRONIC MEMORIES & MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include a net gain of $52,000 from bond repurchases and a net gain of $113,000 on the sale of investments. Year-ago quarter and 6 months results include a net gain of $84,000 on bond repurchases and a net gain of $525,000 due to the refund of excess pension plan assets.

title: Special Envoy of U.S.  Begins Venezuela Visit
description: Richard B. Stone, President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, arrived in Caracas tonight from Panama, where he spent the weekend. There was speculation that he had been trying to arrange a meeting with Salvadoran leftist leaders.

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $17,685 for the quarter and $61,051 for the 6 months.

title: Earning the Job
description: Fran Polsfoot, a Denver Broncos assistant coach, was a college teammate of Jack Elway's at Washington State in the late 1940's. ''One time,'' said Polsfoot, ''I ran into Jack when he was coaching up in Montana someplace.

title: NATOMAS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Ex-Insurance Regulator Joins Cole & Deitz Firm
description: Albert B. Lewis, who left in March as New York State's Superintendent of Insurance after five years in the job, has become a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Cole & Deitz.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: Key Rates
Textile Talks With Chinese
description: The United States and China resumed negotiations in Geneva today on a textile agreement, trade sources said, with both sides optimistic that a pact could be reached to replace the one that expired last December.

title: City Center Is Offering Subscription Package
description: City Center Theater will offer a 10-company-subscription for its 1983-84 dance season, September through April. The 10 companies are Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the Twentieth Century (subscription dates Sept. 20-25), the Joffrey Ballet (Oct. 19-25), New World Ballet of Caracas (Nov. 15-20), Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater (Dec. 1-7), Jennifer Muller and the Works (Jan. 24-29), Lar Lubovitch Dance Company (Jan. 31-Feb. 5), Murray Louis Dance Company (Feb. 9-15), Nikolais Dance Theater (Feb. 21-26), Merce Cunningham Dance Company (Mar. 7-13) and Les Grands Ballets Canadiens (April 24-29).

title: Price Increase Seen for Oil
description: By the mid-1990's, oil prices will have risen 20 percent above their 1981 peak level and the OPEC nations will continue to be the main supplier of oil to consuming nations, according to the World Bank.

title: FOREMOST-MCKESSON INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $801,000 for the latest first quarter and $411,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for the acquisitions of Midwestern Cablevision Corp. and an affiliate, which were accounted for as poolings of interest. Year-ago results have been reclassified to reflect a change in accounting.

title: CHUBB CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Casper Wins in Playoff
description: Billy Casper won the United States Senior Open golf tournament today with a birdie on the first hole of sudden death after he and Rod Funseth tied at four-over-par 75 in an 18-hole playoff.

title:
Stocks Advance on Late Rally;
Dow Up 1.70, To 1,232.87
description: Stock prices followed bond prices higher in late trading yesterday, erasing the morning's declines. Analysts said steady buying from bargain-hunting institutional investors provided the steam for the price reversal.

title: FLORIDA EAST COAST RAILWAY CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $19,426,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of property.

title: Awards Upheld In Swann Case
description: The State Court of Appeals upheld today $40,000 awards to Lynn Swann, the former Pittsburgh Steeler wide receiver, and his two brothers and a cousin. The awards stemmed from a 1974 incident in which he charged he was beaten by the police the night he was chosen as a first-round draft selection in the National Football League.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NEW YORK TIMES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of associated companies of $847,000 for the quarter and $1,215,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes equity in earnings of associated companies of $1,793,000 for the quarter and $5,627,000 for the 6 months.

title: People
description: * Richard J. Passanant, chief financial officer and secretary/treasurer of McCaffrey & McCall, elected executive vice president, and Robert H. Cherins, a senior vice president, and president of the direct marketing division, elected to the board of directors.

title: Reactor at Indian Atom Plant Built by U.S. Is Closed Down
description: One of the two reactors at India's American-built Tarapur nuclear plant north of Bombay was shut down today for repairs, Atomic Energy Department officials said.

title: Change of Mind?
description: Bjorn Borg said yesterday that he was reconsidering his retirement and might play in a few small tennis tournaments next year. The fivetime Wimbledon champion, who has played in only one tournament in the last 18 months because he was tired of tennis, said, ''You never know what will happen in the future.

title: KISSINGER ASSERTS PANEL MIGHT TAKE UNTIL NEXT YEAR
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger conferred with President Reagan today and said that the recently established commission on Central America was unlikely to complete its work before next February.

title: Niagara Mohawk Files Bond Issue
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced from its Syracuse headquarters that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $100 million of first mortgage bonds.

title: Resales Up For Homes
description: Resales of single-family homes rose 1 percent last month, a real estate trade group said today, attributing the slowdown from May's pace to the increase in interest rates on mortgages.

title: PARKS CHIEF SAYS THE SHOWS WILL GO ON, BUT WITH CHANGES
description: Despite attacks by bands of marauding youths following the Diana Ross concert in Central Park Friday night, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that he would allow other performers to use the park.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $759,000 on the sale of assets. Results are in U. S. dollars.

description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend paid April 1, 1983.

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Pound the Gavel
description: Coach Joe Walton hasn't planned a full agenda, but the executive committee of the New York Jets holds its first session today. ''We'll set ground rules of what we're trying to accomplish,'' said Walton, who admitted he never made it to such a committee when he played for the Giants in the early 1960's.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend in February.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AVON UP SLIGHTLY
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, benefiting from a surge in its retail business and a turnaround in its financial services, yesterday reported an 88.3 percent rise in its second-quarter net income. The earnings rose to a record $308.3 million, or 87 cents a share, from $163.7 million, or 47 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Kellogg Posts A 12.6% Gain
description: The Kellogg Company reported today that earnings in the second quarter rose 12.6 percent, to $64.2 million, or 84 cents a share, from $57 million, or 74 cents a share, in the period last year.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Westinghouse May Sell a Unit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it is holding talks on the sale of its synthetic fuels division.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1.6 million in the quarter and $4 million for the six months.

Black & Decker To Offer Common
description: The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company announced that it had filed a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 4 million common shares.

description: b-Net income.

title: Business and the Law; Firms Seeking Phone Clients
description: FOR most law firms, the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into a number of regional companies has been a tantalizing new business opportunity.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Baby Doe Needs No Big Brother
description: In the spring of 1982, a baby with Down's syndrome and an incomplete esophagus was born in Indiana. His parents, supported by the courts, decided he should not be fed. ''Infant Doe'' died when he was six days old.

title: UNION ASKS $1-AN-HOUR PAY RAISE AT CHRYSLER
description: The United Automobile Workers told the Chrysler Corporation today that it wants an immediate $1-an-hour pay increase and eventual wage parity with workers at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company as the price for a new labor contract.

title: SmithKline's Net Up by 10%
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter increased 10 percent, to $116.4 million, or $1.40 a share, from $105.8 million, or $1.28 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: SNARLED ELECTRIC WIRES CAUSE DELAYS ON NEW HAVEN LINE
description: Part of a sandblasting machine, apparently pushed by vandals, fell to the tracks of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's New Haven line early yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., snarling overhead electric wires and the Monday morning travel plans of about 40,000 commuters.

title: Pregnant Women Given Warning on Acne Drug
description: Three women using Accutane, a new acne medication, have given birth in recent weeks to deformed babies, despite warnings against taking the drug during pregnancy, the drug manufacturer said today.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
American General, Gulf United Deal
description: The American General Corporation and the Gulf United Corporation said they had redesigned their proposed merger to ''get around some potential tax uncertainties.'' American General, an insurance holding company based in Houston, had agreed to buy the insurance businesses of Gulf United for $1 billion in stock.

title: MINORITY PROTESTERS INTERRUPT MARRIOTT HOTEL CONSTRUCTION
description: Construction was halted for three hours on the Marriott Marquis Hotel yesterday when scores of black and Hispanic protesters marched onto the site on Broadway, charging that the hotel's developers had reneged on agreements to hire minority workers and sub-contractors.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $574,000.

Y.

description: b-Including a net gain of $11.7 million, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of the plastic food bag line in the United States during the first quarter. Results reflect foreign currency translation changes.

title: MOSCOW WILL TRY AGAIN TO WIDEN THE POWERS OF FACTORY MANAGERS
description: The Soviet leadership today announced a package of economic experiments intended to show that the way to invigorate the country's largely stagnant industry lies through greater autonomy for individual plants.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results are restated for the acquisition of Kremers-Urban Co. accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: TIGERS DEFEAT MARINERS
description: Home runs by Lance Parrish, Chet Lemon and Alan Trammell carried the Detroit Tigers to an 8-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight.

title: DART & KRAFT INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Results for the latest periods include gains equal to 2 cents a share for the quarter and 8 cents a share for the 6 months from the repurchase of bonds and antitrust settlements.

title: 'WAYS IN THE NIGHT,' GERMANS IN POLAND
description: IT is meant as praise to say that ''Ways in the Night,'' which opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, has the manner of a private communication that intends that all the rest of us learn from its secrets. The German-language film, made for West German television, was directed by Krzysztof Zanussi, the Polish director known here principally for his ''Family Life,'' ''A Woman's Decision'' and ''Contract.''

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to July 3.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Interest Rates Rise Modestly; New Issues Are Awaited
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday for short- and long-term issues, amid continued nervousness about investor demand for a heavy supply of Treasury issues expected for sale next week.

title: People
description: * Michael K. Hickey elected to the newly created position of vice president of marketing of the ITT Business Communications Corporation.

title: COULD GUAM BE ANOTHER HONG KONG?
description: Sleek hotel towers. Duty-free jade and pearls. Suits made to order within 24 hours. International banks on streets that flow with hawkers, tourists, immigrants.

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
OUTGOING N.R.C. OFFICIAL LOOKS AT PAST AND FUTURE
description: John F. Ahearne, one of five members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, recently left the commission at the end of his five-year term.

title: JEROME MOROSS, 69, COMPOSER, IS DEAD
description: Jerome Moross, a composer who wrote symphonic works and scores for Broadway and films, died Monday in Miami of congestive heart failure and a stroke. He was 69 years old.

title: ROGER MUDD TO LOSE ANCHOR POSITION AT NBC
description: Roger Mudd, who has served for 15 months as the Washington-based co-anchor of ''The NBC Nightly News,'' will be dropped from the position in September, the network announced yesterday.

2 MEN ARE CHARGED IN SLAYING OF A GIRL BY A STRAY BULLET
description: Two Manhattan men were arrested last night and charged with the murder of a 15-year-old girl who was killed by a stray bullet during an attempted robbery last week.

title: Bausch & Lomb
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said it had received approval from the Federal Food and Drug Administration to market a new type of contact lens wearable for up to 30 days. The lens is based on a design that the company says should be more comfortable and more durable than many other lenses.

Woman Killed by Pipe Bomb
description: A woman was killed early today when a pipe bomb she apparently was making accidentally exploded, the police said. Investigators said they discovered several books on bomb-making in her apartment.

description: N.W. Ayer has joined the agency family of the Texize division of Morton-Thiokol Products, Greenville, S.C. The assignment is for Yes heavy-duty detergent and fabric softener and some new products, that were formerly served by Liller Neal, Atlanta.

title: Moffitt Regains Winning Touch
description: The low point was reached in August 1981. That was when the San Francisco Giants released Randy Moffitt, a relief pitcher who first joined the team in 1972 when Juan Marichal and Gaylord Perry were the foundation of the pitching staff and he was the young man who protected their leads.

title: TV: 'THE HAMPTONS'
description: SUCH goings on in East Hampton you wouldn't believe. With all that sexual stuff, conniving and social climbing, it will be a mercy for the rich people if they ever find time to get to the beach. ''The Hamptons,'' a five-part series that begins on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, is one steamy show.

description: Liquidators of the bankrupt Laker Airways cannot sue British Airways or British Caledonian Airways in United States courts on charges of antitrust activity, a British appeals court ruled today.

Heinz Company gave a party to honor 10 chefs from around the world, One was Felicite Doloir of Guadeloupe, who is in charge of restaurant sanitation inspection for the island and cooks weekends in her own restaurant. Of American products, she said in French, ''Most aren't even on the market in my country.''

THE PERIL OF SUCCESS IN NICARAGUA
description: Just what kind of government is the Reagan Administration trying to bring to power in Managua? Alas, neither the Administration nor its critics seem to have the vaguest idea.

title: Boxing Bill Is Rejected
description: The House rejected today a bill that would have established a 10-member panel to study professional boxing and make safety recommendations to Congress. The vote was 254 to 167.

title: Economic Scene; How to Win At Forecasting
description: WITH last week's announcement by the Commerce Department that the economy was growing at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.7 percent in the second quarter, everybody's favorite lagging indicator -the forecasts of the economists - will be shifting upward again. That forecast of the change in the economists' forecasts has proved to be more reliable than the forecasts themselves.

title: LTV Loss Widens
description: The LTV Corporation, a diversified steel and energy company, reported yesterday that its loss in the second quarter widened to $61.3 million, from $18.8 million in the corresponding period of 1982. The loss was more than triple that of a year earlier despite an extraordinary gain of $20.3 million from the exchange of common stock for debentures.

description: Reflecting the impact of lower crude oil prices and bigger profits on petroleum products, two of the nation's largest energy companies, Texaco Inc. and the Standard Oil Company of California reported higher second-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Power System Bonds Show Slight Rebound
description: Securities dealers reported yesterday that prices rebounded slightly for bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System. Market participants said demand from speculators was strong enough to absorb the relatively small amounts of bonds that have been offered for sale. However, they that prices could drop further if multimillion-dollar blocks of bonds were dumped on the market.

Giscard Received by Reagan For Talk on the Missile Issue
description: Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France told President Reagan today that the Atlantic allies must keep pressing for arms control after new medium-range missiles are deployed in Western Europe later this year.

Thousands at Funeral Of Police Copter Pilot
description: Thousands of police officers and top city officials today attended the funeral of a police helicopter pilot who died in collision with a commuter seaplane.

9 West Coast Shipyards Closed in Labor Dispute
description: Ten thousand metalworkers today struck nine shipyards from San Francisco Bay to Seattle. Picket lines went up at 7 A.M., and spokesmen for the private yards said the job action had stopped civilian and military work.

title: ZIMBABWE AIR FORCE TRIAL EMBITTERS WHITES
description: Until a year ago, Zimbabwe's Air Force was an elite, white bastion, little affected by the country's black majority rule. But such isolation ended with explosions at its main base, Thornhill, on July 25, 1982, that wrecked 13 jet fighters, or more than half of Zimbabwe's combat planes.

title: Power of a Smile
description: Normand Leveille, the 20-year-old Boston Bruin forward who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last October, is still struggling to learn to talk again after his ordeal, but he had no trouble communicating with his teammates Monday when he joined them for a $125-per-person fundraising golf tournament in his honor in Pembroke, Mass. Leveille, who has been receiving treatment in Canada, was driven round the Pembroke Country Club in a golf cart driven by Terry O'Reilly, who was impressed by Leveille's ability to communicate with his smile.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes after-tax inventory drawdown benefits of $17,000,000 for the quarter and $52,000,000 for the 6 months, and foreign currency translation gains of $10,000,000 for the quarter and $50,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes LIFO inventory drawdown benefits of $74,000,000 for the quarter and $154,000,000 for the 6 months, and foreign currency translation gains of $32,000,000 for the quarter and $93,000,000 for the 6 months.

title: BE FAIR TO MOZAMBIQUE
description: The Reagan Administration's policies in southern Africa may invite more raids like the recent bombing of Maputo, Mozambique's capital, by the South African Air Force. The raid, one of Pretoria's many incursions into neighboring countries, shows that Washington's policy toward southern Africa is flawed by a double standard: While harping on the presence of an alleged Soviet proxy, Cuba, in the region, our Government has failed to explicitly condemn the destabilization campaign being carried out by South Africa and its surrogate, the Mozambique National Resistance.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
CAPE COD RESIDENTS SHARPLY DIVIDED OVER CONGRESSMAN'S POLITICAL FUTURE
description: From the outside, the white frame house appears immune to controversy, tucked away behind a row of trees on Black Horse Lane in this small 18th-century town on Massachusetts Bay.

title: U.S. WARNS IRAN ON BLOCKING OIL FLOW IN GULF
description: The State Department warned today that the United States would use military force if necessary to counter any Iranian attempt to shut down all oil shipments through the Persian Gulf.

The Police Blotter
description: An unidentified gunman attempting to hold up a grocery at 7 A.M. yesterday at 80 West 183d Street, in the University Heights section of the Bronx, was fatally shot by a customer. The store owner, 48-year-old Jose Landa, said he did not know the customer, who fled ... Four Bronx postal workers were charged with auto theft and possession of stolen checks payable to two evangelists.

title: OPENING STATEMENT
description: I have an opening statement here. A while back I got a letter from a 13-year-old and I apologize for not having answered her as yet. She wrote, ''Don't you wish sometimes you could just stamp your feet and shout at the press or Senators to be quiet, sit down and listen to what you're saying?'' Well, yes, Gretchen, I sometimes do feel that way, and particularly over the past week.

title: Soviet Rock Groups Facing Disbandment
description: Soviet rock groups will be disbanded if they do not clean up their acts ideologically by October, according to cultural officials who today accused the musicians of being untidy and vulgar on stage.

title: ITALY'S STUMBLING ECONOMY
description: Along the narrow alleyways off the Piazzo del Duomo, Louis Vuitton luggage is piled beside mounds of new handbags, shoes and clothing that also bear prestigious designer labels. An enterprising merchant of snakeskin belts offers to fit the brand name buckle of the buyer's choice onto any article.

title: Warner's Ratings Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it was lowering the credit rating on three categories of Warner Communications Inc. debt. Moody's lowered its rating on Warner's commercial paper to prime two, from prime one, on senior debt to A-3, from A-1, and on subordinated debt to BAA-1, from A-2. The agency said the changes reflected a sharp deterioration in Warner's operating margins.

title: FIRST TULSA BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DOW UP 10.82 ON IMPROVED EARNINGS
description: Stock prices rallied yesterday as institutional investors responded to improved earnings posted by blue-chip companies. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.82, to 1,243.69. Its record high of 1,248.30 was set on June 16. Volume was heavy, with 91.3 million shares traded, up from 73.7 million shares on Monday. Advancing stocks outpaced declining issues by 1,030 to 592.

description: ''The continuing Japanese attack on our basic industries is another Pearl Harbor,'' cried Senator Donald Riegle on learning that Japan resists extending the ''voluntary'' curbs on its auto exports to the United States.

description: Soviet and Afghan Government troops as well as Afghan rebel fighters have suffered heavy casualties in the fiercest fighting of the year in the Ghazni area of southeastern Afghanistan, Western diplomats said today.

description: President Reagan, asserting that the United States was ''not seeking a larger presence'' in Central America, said tonight that his Administration's plans for military exercises were aimed at providing ''a shield for democracy and development'' in the region.

title: W. Linwood Chase Dies at 86; A Specialist in Child Behavior
description: W. Linwood Chase, former dean of the Boston University School of Education and a specialist on child behavior and adolescence, died July 18 of Alzheimer's Disease at Queen Anne's Nursing Home in Hingham, Mass. He was 86 years old and formerly lived in Hingham and North Eastham, Mass.

title: NOT WEIGHTY, BUT WOOS ALL THE SAME
description: When the Senate's two leaders converse on the floor, not all is about weighty matters. Take a recent exchange between Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, a Republican, and Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, a Democrat, concerning the hydrilla, the carp and the black fly.

title: SHAMIR AND ARENS MEET WITH SHULTZ
description: Israel's Foreign and Defense Ministers met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as the Reagan Administration continued its efforts to find a formula for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.

title: Price Rise By Pemex
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, the state oil monopoly, announced today a dollar-a-barrel increase in the price of its heavy Maya crude, which is used mostly for lubricants and industrial heating fuel, to $24 a barrel. The increase will mean about $750,000 a day in additional revenue.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: RESEARCHERS are discovering surprising effects of eating starchy foods such as pasta or kidney beans now that these complex carbohydrates are gaining credibility as nutritious foods that can be the basis of meals rather than side dishes. The findings are of interest to diabetics, athletes and anyone else who may be concerned about fluctuations in blood sugar.

title: Laser Beam Succeeds In Destroying Missiles
description: The Air Force has announced its first successful experiment using high-energy laser beams to knock out missiles traveling at speeds nearly 2,000 miles per hour.

title: Vasquez Is Granted Delay of Suspension; Saratoga Opens Today
description: When the oldest race track in the country opens here Wednesday for the 116th time, the Saratoga crowd will coo over the scenery and start looking ahead to ancient races like the Sanford, the Alabama and the Travers Stakes. But two jockeys, and possibly a third, who are the regular riders of leading candidates for those races will miss them because of suspensions stemming from legal proceedings.

title: Michigan Yields Are at 6 1/4% to 9 7/8%
description: A $135 million issue of Michigan highway revenue bonds is being offered with yields ranging from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9 percent in 1993 and 9 7/8 percent in 1999, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: Occidental Unit
description: In line with its diversification policy, the Ford Motor Company has agreed to acquire the Parker division of the Occidental Chemical Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash. The division, which manufactures metal surface treating products, has headquarters in Madison Heights, Mich., and accounted for less than 10 percent of Occidental Chemical's $2 billion in sales last year. Occidental Chemical, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, also said that George B. Berry, vice president and general manager of Occidental's plating systems division, would head a management group buying out the metal plating operation, which has headquarters at Warren, Mich.

title: BALBONI'S SLAM BEATS RANGERS

title: OPERA: 'DAS RHEINGOLD' AT FESTIVAL IN BAYREUTH
description: In high school physics we were told that for every action there was an equal and opposite reaction. That law still seems to be in force, even in the other world of opera. So it was no surprise to find Monday night that the new production of Wagner's ''Ring'' at this summer's Bayreuth festival was in many ways a revulsion against the previous ''Ring'' mounted at this Wagnerian shrine, the infamously bad ''French'' version unveiled seven years ago by Patrice Chereau under the musical direction of Pierre Boulez.

title: Menudo Signs Contract On Films and Television
description: Menudo, the singing quintet of teen-age Puerto Rican boys who have spawned Beatlemania with a Latin flavor, signed a movie and television contract today with Embassy Communications, headed by Norman Lear. Terms of the agreement, which provides for production of as many as five motion pictures, were not disclosed.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE word offal is to my mind one of the most unattractive in the English language. When I first heard someone mention offal, I immediately thought of ''awful'' and only later learned that the two are not related. Offal refers to the innards of animals: sweetbreads, brains, livers and so on. The word derives from ''off'' and ''fall,'' meaning, roughly, things that fall off when an animal is slaughtered.

title: Town's Farmers Defeat Forces Opposing Pigs
description: A battle between farmers and city dwellers ended Monday night when residents voted not to restrict the number of pigs per farm.

title: Rozelle Backed on Cocaine Suspensions
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle's four-game suspension of four National Football League players because of their involvement with cocaine received generally favorable reaction from various sectors of the league's community yesterday, including the N.F.L. Players Association.

title: Bridge: Brachman's Team Defeats Luella Slaner's in Spingold
description: The group of Texan stars headed by Malcolm Brachman of Dallas scored a convincing victory in the final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship early today.

title: New League in a TV Deal
description: The William B. Tanner Sports Network, a Memphis-based syndicator of sports events for television, has signed a letter of intent with the International Football League for exclusive rights to games in 1984, the league's first season. If full agreement is reached, Tanner will pay the I.F.L. $21 million, about $6.5 million more than the total of what the United States Football League is receiving each season under its two-year contracts with the American Broadcasting Companies and the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network.

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FINANCIAL CORP June 30 1983 1982 reports earnings for Revenue.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest periods include net gains of $322,000 for the quarter and $644,000 for the 6 months from the sale of assets. Year-ago results include a net gain of $4,257,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: The U.N. Today; July 27, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: A BRONX INDUSTRIAL PARK GAINS A TENANT
description: When the American Broadcasting Companies bought the seven-story, blocklong industrial building at 125 West End Avenue that it had occupied as a lessee, it served notice on the other major tenant that it wanted the entire building for itself.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including tax credis of $3.6 million for the quarter and $11.9 million for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
MESA PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Cerone Credited
description: Who gets the putout when an umpire rules a player out for using an illegl bat? That was one of the many questions in the aftermath of Sunday's incident at Yankee Stadium involving the home run by Kansas City's George Brett. The home run was disallowed because of excessive pine tar on Brett's bat.

title: Help for Team America
description: The North American Soccer League is considering a plan that would allow Team America to borrow American players from other league teams on a game-by-game basis for the rest of the season.

title: LAW FIRMS SQUIRM, THEN TURN TO PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: The 50 lawyers, members of some of the capital's most prestigious law offices, and curious visitors from the hinterlands, had paid $350 apiece to attend a ''workshop on expanding a law firm's practice'' at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel here.

title: British Bank's Profits Rise
description: The National Westminster Bank, one of Britain's four major clearing banks, reported today that pretax profits had risen 7.5 percent, to 230 million, or the equivalent of about $351.9 million, in the six months to June 30, from 214 million, or about $327.4 million, in the comparable period last year.

title: News Analysis
description: Preserving order is a police department's basic job. When order breaks down, as it did after last Friday's Diana Ross concert in Central Park, questions arise about what went wrong: Did the police perform as well as they could have? Is the city's Police Department being blamed for events that could not have been anticipated? Was such an event impossible to police?

title: REPUBLICAN JOINS CIVIL RIGHTS FRAY
description: Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a Maryland Republican, said today that although President Reagan apparently had the ''raw, naked legal power'' to dismiss members of the United States Commission on Civil Rights he would damage the agency by doing so.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CONSOLIDATED CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
A.T.&T. Request
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked for Government permission to offer a teleconferencing service across the Atlantic.

title: A COPPER SPILL KILLS THOUSANDS OF FISH UPSTATE
description: A copper compound of mysterious origin spilled into the Hoosic River here over the weekend and killed as many as 100,000 fish, environmental officials said today.

title: NEW SALVADORAN LAND STUDY INCREASES FIGURE ON EVICTIONS
description: More Salvadoran farmers have been evicted from land they received under the country's land redistribution program than the Reagan Administration indicated in a report to Congress last week, according to a joint study by El Salvador and the United States.

title: HISPANIC PUPILS' SOLE HOPE
description: In our not too distant past, 80 percent of all Mexican-American children in Texas had to repeat the first grade because they could not speak English. In New Mexico, one-third of all Hispanic children sat idle in the first grade, learning neither basic addition nor English. With bilingual education, this waste of human talent would never have occurred.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $800,000 for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 13.

title: Bidder's Past Studied
description: Jack Joyce, the director of security for the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that it would probably be a week or 10 days before he could complete his background report on Steve Belkin, the businessman who is seeking league approval to buy the Boston Celtics from the team's owner, Harry Mangurian. Joyce, however, declined to comment on a report in The Boston Herald that one of Belkin's associates was the target of a gambling investigation that could jeopardize Belkin's approval.

title: Decision Upsets Ovett
description: Steve Ovett, the British runner, is not happy with the decision of British sports officials limiting him to the 1,500-meter event at the World Track and Field Championships in Helsinki, Finland, next month. He wanted to run in both the 1,500 and the 800, but he was passed over in the 800 meters at Helsinki in favor of Sebastian Coe, Peter Elliott and Gary Cook. Ovett, who limped off the track after being spiked in last week's British amateur championship, said he thought he had convinced the selectors that he would be fit enough to compete in both.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $435,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of assets and income of $1,107,000 for the quarter and 6 months attributable to the sale of uranium oxide in prior years. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7,197,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

description: The Coastal Corporation of Houston has arranged a new $275 million revolving credit for a subsidiary, the Colorado Interstate Corporation, and a $100 million letter of credit for its Coastal Finance Company, which handles receivables from other subsidiaries.

VISIT TO EAST BY STRAUSS STARTLES BON
description: Franz Josef Strauss, the right-wing Premier of Bavaria, has stirred criticism within his own party and praise from his foes by visiting Eastern Europe.

title: FINANCE NEW ISSUES;
description: A $150 million issue of Illinois bonds rated Aaa/AA+ was offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 8.3 percent in 1993, 9.2 percent in 2003 and 9.25 percent in 2008. The underwriters are led by Citibank.

title: Turkey Again Tightens Curb on Political Parties
description: The ruling National Security Council issued a decree today that is expected to eliminate at least 10 of the 14 parties registered to campaign for the November elections.

description: b-Net income.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL

BASKETBALL KNICKS (NBA) - Signed Darrell Walk- e r, guard, the team's No.1 draft choice, to a multiyear contract.

title: BLUEFIELD SUPPLY CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Issue of Briefing Paper Is the Last to Be Raised
description: After answering repeated questions about his policies toward Central America, President Reagan appeared almost relieved when the final question of his news conference tonight raised the subject of the Carter briefing papers.

title: 'TAKING MY TURN' TAKES POSITIVE VIEW OF AGING
description: ''Taking My Turn,'' the joyous musical revue about aging that has won applause at the Entermedia Theater from critics and from audiences that range widely in age, almost missed playing anywhere. Aging was such an unpopular topic when the show was first put together seven years ago that the creators had to put it aside.

title: PASSANGER RAIL SERVICE IS NO 'FADING MEMORY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. Although the chances are probably slight that I will be faced with the problem of cooking possum (or, more properly, I suppose, opossum) I am curious to know how it is prepared.

U.S. SAYS SOVIET REJECTED OFFER TO LIMIT MEDIUM-RANGE WARHEADS
description: The United States asked the Soviet Union to consider limiting medium-range nuclear warheads in Europe to 50 for each side, but the Russians refused ''serious discussions along these lines,'' a senior American official said today.

In the 1982 quarter all figures are restated for the Narda Microwave acquisition on a pooling of interest basis.

title: Inmate Again Convicted In the Slaying of a Guard
description: A prisoner was convicted a second time today of first-degree murder in the slaying of a prison guard. The verdict carries an automatic death penalty under a law dating to the Civil War era.

title: COMMONWEALTH FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (NORRISTO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $667,000. c-There was no equivalent share earnings figure for the year-ago first quarter because Commonwealth Federal converted to a stock charter on April 14, 1983.

description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it had received a new acquisition offer from a group of investors led by the Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs.

description: b-Including gains of $256,000 for the quarter and $445,000 for the 6 months from equity in affiliates, losses of $553,000 for the quarter and $872,000 for the 6 months from minority interests and foreign currency translation losses of $24,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains of $349,000 for the quarter and $457,000 for the 6 months from equity in affiliates, losses of $467,000 for the quarter and $866,000 for the 6 months from minority interests and foreign currency translation losses of 68,000 for the quarter and $176,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend in January 1983.

title: 1. Sandals for Winter
description: Rubber sandals have been taking to the streets by the thousands for summer. Now there is a closed-up version to wear into the fall and winter. It's one way to be prepared for sudden rainstorms, but the shoes also have a look that goes well with sporty clothes. An adjustable crisscross strap snaps on the side. Made in Japan, the shoes come in gray or black. $40 in Shoe Biz at Henri Bendel, on the fourth floor.

title: Market Place; A Sears 'Store Of the Future'
description: SEARS, ROEBUCK & COMPANY, the world's largest retailer, with sales of $25 billion last year, is not considered fast on the draw. Instead, the company seems slow, deliberative, methodical and thorough.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sugar and Spices

title: COMPANY EARNINGS;
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday reported a second-quarter profit of $10.4 million, or 13 cents a share. It lost $56.2 million in the quarter a year before. Last year's period included a $14 million gain from the sale of tax benefits.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Toray's Interferon Plant
description: Toray Industries said it would soon start building a factory for commercial production of beta type interferon for completion in mid-1989. Toray said it had completed clinical tests of the product, which proved effective in treating some types of cancer and malignant tumors.

title: TRIBUNE COMPANY EXECUTIVE IN CHICAGO NAMED UNITED PRESS EDITOR
description: United Press International, the nation's second largest news agency, yesterday appointed a Chicago newspaper executive, Maxwell McCrohon, as its new editor in chief.

title: 100 Are Believed Dead In Rioting in Sri Lanka
description: More than 100 people are believed dead in rioting in Sri Lanka, according to a survey of police stations and other sources. Meantime, arson and looting lessened today in Colombo as troops and police officers patrolled the capital.

title: Careers; Studying Employee Buyouts
description: WITH unemployment high, competition from abroad intense and companies closing some of their small, money-losing divisions, the fear of being left without a job has been high lately among employees ranging from blue-collar workers to middle and top managers, and campaigns to save small factories have been starting at the community level.

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $402,000 for the quarter and $764,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary gain of $1,200,000.

title: YONKERS BUDGET STALLED 6 WEEKS AFTER DEADLINE
description: Six weeks after its legal deadline for adopting a 1983-84 budget and facing possible state intervention, the Yonkers City Council again failed tonight to approve one.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After realized investment losses of $383,000 for the quarter and $1,082,000 for the 6 months. c-After realized investment losses of $1,078,000 for the quarter and $2,104,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results do not include operations of United States Aviation Underwriters Inc., which was acquired in July 1982.

title: No Headline
description: Mike Westphal, an 18-year-old member of the West German Davis Cup team, upset top-seeded Brian Gottfried, 6-3, 7-6, in the first round of the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.
