description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,445,000 for the quarter and $4.6 million for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $282,000 for the quarter and $396,000 for the 6 months.

title: PERU IS FRUSTRATED IN BATTLE TO CRUSH REBELS
description: The Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry is faced with the difficult question of how a young democracy fights a guerrilla threat.

title: CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of June 30.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: STANDARD OIL OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
POLITICAL MEMO: GLENN MOVES WHILE RIVALS STAND STILL
description: The writer of this article is an editor at the New York Times whose reponsibilities include political polling. A former national political correspondent, he attended the meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Detroit July 14 and 15 to gather background for future polls. He reported to fellow editors in a memorandum, which he then adapted for publication.

title: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
THE POP LIFE
description: EVEN at the height of his pop-music success in the mid-1970's, Al Green never seemed very comfortable with stardom. His records sold in the millions, and by the mid-1970's the critics had singled him out as among the most gifted and imaginative black pop singers of the decade. But his shows were unpredictable. One performance would be intensely emotional, like a Baptist tent revival or like Mr. Green's performances last year in the Broadway revival of ''Your Arms Too Short to Box With God.'' But on other nights he would coax his band into playing so softly he could whisper over them and still be heard. At times, he seemed distracted, as if he were singing his pop hits but listening to another voice that only he could hear.

title: 3 SLAIN AS GUNMEN ATTACK HEBRON ISLAMIC COLLEGE
description: Occupied West Bank, July 26 - Masked gunmen opened fire on students on a college campus here today. Three people were killed and 33 students and faculty members suffered injuries or wounds, Israeli military sources said.

title: Reynolds Executive Chosen Avon Chief
description: Hicks B. Waldron, an executive vice president at R.J. Reynolds Industries, was named yesterday as president and chief executive of Avon Inc. effective Aug.15.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Stack, the New Jersey Generals' backfield coach, will return to Notre Dame to coach the receivers and coordinate recruiting. Stack was an aide at Notre Dame from 1969 to 1974. ... Sir Brian Burnett, the chairman of the management committee of the All-England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club since 1974, is retiring and will be succeeded in December by R.E. (Buzzer) Hadingham. ... Barbaro Garbey, an outfielder who was suspended from the American Association's Evansville (Ind.) Triplets after he struck a heckler following a doubleheader in Louisville, Ky., June 28, has been reinstated by the league, but will be fined $500, the Detroit farm club announced. ... The trade that sent Pat Thomas of the Los Angeles Rams to the Oakland Raiders for Monte Jackson, a cornerback, was canceled when Thomas failed a physical examination because of a knee problem.

title: Lung Infection Killed Panda
description: A respiratory infection that developed several days before birth killed the first panda born in the United States, a medical report said today.

title: TWO LARGE BANKS IN JERSEY TO MERGE
description: The First National State Bancorporation, one of New Jersey's largest bank holding companies, has announced that it will acquire the Fidelity Union Bancorporation of Newark in an exchange of stock valued at about $204 million.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Striped Bass Between Two Poles
description: The striped bass that lives in salt water but spawns in fresh is equally beloved of fishermen whose livelihood depends on their catch and those for whom the catch is rod-and-reel sport. All worry over the fish's future. Samples of young bass taken between 1974 and 1981 in Chesapeake Bay, their prime coastal nursery, show a precipitous decline in numbers. An intelligent plan is needed to save them.

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation has pulled out of a joint venture to produce pulp and paper in North Sumatra, an Indonesian spokesman said. Georgia Pacific originally held 25 percent of the $410 million venture to build the plant in Aceh, North Sumatra. The other shareholders are the Indonesian Government, 50 percent, and private Indonesian companies, 25 percent.

title: Time Inc. Changes TV-Cable Publisher
description: In a surprise move yesterday Time Inc., changed the publisher of its fledgling TV-Cable Week, which is potentially its biggest magazine property.

title: Chicago Mayor's Choice Wins House Nomination
description: Charles Hayes, a labor leader endorsed by Mayor Harold Washington to replace him as a United States Representative, won the Democratic nomination today in a special primary on the city's South Side.

title: Body of Woman Is Identified
description: A badly burned body found last Thursday in the air shaft of an abandoned building in Brooklyn has been identified as that of Baila Mayerfeld, a member of Community Board 9 in the Crown Heights section of the borough.

title: BELFAST M.P. VISITING LONDON
description: Gerry Adams, an Irish nationalist who was once considered one of Britain's most wanted guerrillas, went to the House of Commons today but refused to take his seat as a newly elected Member of Parliament.

title: INTECOM INC reports earnings for qtr to July 4.
description: b-After tax credits of $1.3 million in the quarter and $1.9 million for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: George H.R. Ross, Survivor Of Kennedy PT Boat Sinking
description: George H.R. Ross, who survived the sinking of a PT boat with Lieut. (j.g.) John F. Kennedy in World War II, died Sunday at George Washington University Hospital. Mr. Ross, who was 65 years old, had gone into a coma on July 12 when he suffered a heart attack.

title: Sam Goldpaper on Pro Basketball; Walker, No. 1 Pick, Signed by Knicks
description: The Knicks signed Darrell Walker, their top draft choice, yesterday to a four-year contract for a reported $1.2 million. Walker, a guard highly regarded as a defensive player, had been Dave DeBusschere's top priority in recent weeks. The Knicks' executive vice president wanted to make sure that Walker was signed in time to attend the rookie and free-agent training camp that opens with 21 players Friday at Princeton University.

title: ESTEBAN'S MEXICAN FOODS reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Liberty Wins Twice From Courageous
description: Liberty strengthened her position as the leading candidate to defend the America's Cup by winning two races today from Courageous in light air on Rhode Island Sound.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a gain from the sale of land of $3,283,000, or 1.02 a share.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a loss of $1,325,000 from the sale of property and an extraordinary credit of $5,028,000.

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON PRODUCING MX
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate tonight defeated an amendment offered by Gary Hart of Colorado that would have removed production of the MX missile from the 1984 military authorization bill. A vote for the amendment was to stop the MX; a vote against the amendment was a vote to build the missile.

title: CREATIVE COOK IN A SUMMER HOUSE
description: THERE are many groups of single people sharing beach houses for summer weekends, but one in particular on Long Island has worked out a system that successfully produces lively, creative dinners for large numbers, week in and week out.

title: Indians 2, Royals 0
description: Toby Harrah singled in a run and scored the other on a sacrifice fly by Pat Tabler to give Cleveland the victory. Lary Sorensen (5-8) pitched a seven-hitter to earn the victory.

title: TV: SPECIAL ON WATERGATE HEARINGS
description: ''SUMMER OF JUDGMENT: The Watergate Hearings'' is as compelling, as vital and as hypnotic a piece of television as you will see this summer, this season or this year. It is the retelling, intelligently annotated, in two hours of the Senate hearings 10 years ago on one of America's great political traumas. The documentary, produced by Ricki Green for WETA in Washington, will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Peru's Debt Is Rescheduled
description: Western governments to which Peru owes money agreed today to allow a delay in repayment of about $1 billion in medium-term and long-term debt due between May 1983 and February 1985.

title: Pimlico's Owners Purchase Bowie
description: Bowie Race Course, one of Maryland's four thoroughbred tracks, has been sold to the owners of another track in the state.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for qtr to July 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SENATE DECISION IS EXPECTED SOON ON PLAN FOR NEW COAL LEASE SALE
description: The Senate is likely to decide soon the immediate fate of Interior Secretary James G. Watt's hotly debated plan to make record tonnages of Federal coal reserves available next year for mining by private mine operators.

title: HOUSE MOVE MAY HURT CHANCES FOR I.M.F. BILL
description: The House of Representatives defeated decisively today an amendment to a bill to increase the Government's subscription to the International Monetary Fund that would have forced banks to absorb some of the losses on loans to foreign nations.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Walt Terrell, who has allowed just 5 earned runs in his last 19 innings, pitches for the Mets in their final meeting of the season with Atlanta, the divisional leader in the West.

title: NAFCO FINANCIAL reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
ONWARD AND UPWARD FROM 'AL DENTE'
description: IN the old days Americans overcooked their vegetables. There was a profound conviction that nature's products, at least as nature delivered them to the kitchen, were hazardous to human life and health. Salads of raw ingredients were viewed as indigestible; certain vegetables presumed dangerous, such as eggplant and cucumbers, were energetically salted or soaked to rid them of their ''poisons.'' All produce was cooked until its stubborn will to look and taste like itself was utterly broken.

title: G.M. PROFIT UP 85.7% IN QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that its profit rose 85.7 percent, to $1.04 billion, in the second quarter, its first billion-dollar quarter since 1979.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes pretax gains on property sales of $700,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,925,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months, and a pretax gain of $540,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter from the sale of an interest in a New York office building. c-After a pretax writeoff of an investment of $729,000, or 4 cents a share. d-Includes pretax gains on property sales of $570,000, or 3 cents a share. Year-ago results are restated from those originally reported which were based on a Jan. 31 year-end.

title: NEW YORK FISH MARKETS
description: OUR fish market probably looks different these days. It may be a clean new Korean-owned shop with neat ranks of refrigerated fillets and steaks. Or it may be one of the city's long-established fishmongers, such as De Martino's or M. Citarella, now under new ownership and offering new varieties of fish. Squid, fresh tuna and monkfish are among the species that used to be available mainly in specialty markets catering to Latin American, Chinese or Italian cooks and that can now be found in markets in most areas of the city.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Busy Dina Merrill

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Record Set in 800 Meters
description: Czechoslovakia's Jarmila Kratochvilova set a women's 800-meter world record of 1 minute 53.28 seconds today in an international track and field meet.

title: Foil Title to Italy
description: Italy captured the women's team foil title at the world fencing championships today, defeating West Germany by 9-7. Hungary beat the Soviet Union, 9-7, for the bronze medal.

title: Oerter Bones Up
description: After winning four Olympic gold medals in the discus from 1956 to 1968, Al Oerter is taking instruction again, instruction he hopes will help him make the United States team next year.

title: GTE Debentures About 85% Sold
description: A $100 million issue of GTE Corporation 12.45 percent debentures due in 1993 was offered for sale at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THESE are difficult times for our friends in the Outer Boroughs whose identity as New Yorkers has already been shaken by the canard that the city does not exist beyond the borders of Manhattan. First the telephone company proposed to strip residents of Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island of their 212 area code. And now comes word that the post office has summarily severed the three boroughs, along with the Bronx, from the city.

title: SELLING COMPUTERS LIKE SOAP
description: After years of analyzing and satisfying consumer tastes for soap, soda pop and cigarettes, professional marketers are being recruited into the top ranks of the microcomputer industry, to sell personal computers and video games.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include a gain of 3 cents a share from the sale of a closed retail unit.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 27, 1983; Companies
description: Peter G. Peterson, in a surprise move, stepped down as chairman of Lehman Brothers. His departure came just two months after he had agreed to share the duties of chief executive officer with a key associate, Lewis L. Glucksman, who will succeed him. Mr. Peterson, Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration, has led Lehman Brothers since 1973, turning the investment banking house from a troubled firm into one of Wall Street's most successful. (Page A1.)

title: CAM-OR INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Imperial Knife Account Going to Muller Jordan
description: Apparently Mintzer, Trostler & Rochschild, billing around $5 million, has gone out of business. That information comes from David Friedman, director of marketing of the Imperial Knife Company, a former client. which it was announced yesterday is going to Muller Jordan Weiss.

CENTRAL ILLINOIS LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

title: SHAPIRO QUITS AT WARNER'S
description: Robert W. Shapiro abruptly resigned today as president of the theatrical film division at Warner Bros. The company expects to announce his replacement as head of film production soon.

title: Honor Rejected
description: During his years in the Canadian Football League, Cookie Gilchrist was frequently the center of controversy, and now, 20 years after leaving Canada to join the Buffalo Bills, the former fullback is back in his accustomed role. He has refused induction into the Canadian league's Hall of Fame.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
LONDON BRIDGES (AND OTHER THINGS) FALLING DOWN
description: London Bridge was falling down so in 1968 it was crated and shipped to Arizona. Now Parliament's famous tower of Big Ben is crumbling at the edges, but it will stay put by the side of the Thames as it undergoes repairs and a face-scrubbing over the next year.

title: COHU INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,050 for the quarter and $284,446 for the 6 months.

title: A NEW COFFEE MAKER
description: COFFEE drinking in the United States, like everything else related to food and beverages, has become an increasingly specialized affair in recent years. Not long ago most Americans consumed simple percolated or drip coffee from preground beans in a can. By European standards, where the preference is for a dark and viscous highoctane brew, the pallid American version seemed a closer relation to tea. The Spanish and Italians, for example, generally drink ink-black espresso roast coffee in demitasse cups, while the French cut their morning drink with hot milk to make cafe au lait.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
REALIST INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Withholding Put Off Again
description: The Treasury Department announced today that it is delaying until Aug. 5 the enforcement of a law requiring that 10 percent of interest and dividends be withheld for income taxes.

title: THE GRAND STYLE: UNGARO'S GLITTER, LAGERFELD'S FLAIR
description: The size of the American contingent at the couture shows of Emanuel Ungaro is growing. Lynn Wyatt, Ann Getty, Joanne Cummings and Judith Taubman were among those who cheered his fall and winter collection this morning. There was much to cheer. There were fin de siecle or belle epoque echoes, but they served only as points of departure for clothes that were sexy in a timeless way. Many of the styles were supple and flexible, which makes them modern.

title: Powell Learning Some New Tricks; Ringo Helping Jet Tackle
description: After four straight seasons in the Pro Bowl, Marvin Powell, who is perhaps the finest offensive lineman in football, has met an equally impressive coach in Jim Ringo, a Hall of Famer. Now the pair is attempting to take Powell to what the player describes as ''a new plane.''

title: REAGAN'S LETTER TO LATIN PEACE GROUP
description: Following is a letter from President Reagan to the so-called Contadora group, which is made up of Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela and is trying to foster a settlement of the conflicts in Central America: Dear Mr. President, Thank you for the letter which you and the Presidents of Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela have sent to me concerning the meeting held in Cancun on July 17 to review the current situation in Central America.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $286,000 for the quarter and $601,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $82,000 for the quarter and $197,000 for the 9 months.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 27, 1983
description: International President Reagan sought to dampen reports of accelerated United States military involvement in Central America. At a news conference, Mr. Reagan asserted that Washington sought no ''larger presence'' and has ''no military plans for intervention'' in the region. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fidel Castro accused Washington of trying to deploy American troops in Central America through military maneuvers now beginning. The Cuban President said that over recent weeks the United States had been trying to create an ''atmosphere of terror'' around Nicaragua. Earlier, Cuba's Deputy Foreign Minister, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, told reporters that Havana would regard a quarantine or blockade of Nicaragua as an ''act of war.'' (A1:4-5.)

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition.

title: DOING IT THE NEW WAY
description: The modern American style about war is to back into it. Say you get a President who is out of touch with the times, and he comes by the office and says, ''By George, I want to go to war.'' You know right away you've got a hopelessly out-of-date oldtimer on your hands.

title: LIFE GOES ON WITHOUT TAYLOR
description: The continued absence of Lawrence Taylor has had at least one positive effect as well as the big and obvious negative one at the Giants' training camp.

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: NORTH KOREAN ENVOY PLEADS GUILTY TO SEX ABUSE CHARGE
description: After 10 months in seclusion, a North Korean diplomat left his refuge at his country's mission today and surrendered to Westchester County authorities on a charge of sexual abuse.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,582,000.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT seems that everyone wants to learn something about wine these days. Not necessarily to drink it, but to learn about it. There are wine schools cropping up all around. Adult education centers offer wine courses, restaurants have them too. Even conservative universities, nervous about their dwindling enrollments, are coming up with wine courses. Tasting groups are everywhere and wine books are appearing at a rate of one a month. Some fanatics go all the way and take up enology. Others get jobs in wineries. Some prefer handson experience, which they gather in a succession of bars.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table of second-quarter bank earnings in Business Day on Monday incorrectly listed the return on each $100 of average assets for the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. It was 63 cents.

title: SCT CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
C.F.A. Seeking a Truce
description: In a surprise move, the board of the College Football Association voted today to ask its 60 member schools to abide by the N.C.A.A.'s football contracts this season with ABC, CBS and the Turner Broadcasting System.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to July 1.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for a pooling of interests acquisition.

title: Suspect in Boys' Deaths Used an Assumed Name
description: A 32-year-old bookkeeper who is considered a prime suspect in the deaths of five young boys has spent two years living under an assumed name and in hiding from his family, the authorities said today.

title: DELUSIONS OF SUMMITRY
description: Can it be that we are once again succumbing to the illusions of summit diplomacy? Detente between the United States and the Soviet Union was made of arms control talks, summit meetings and expectations of a costless peace. We already have the arms control talks and now pressures are mounting for a summit meeting. It would be a grave mistake to give in to that allure - to take the easy path of competing with Moscow's public diplomacy rather than confronting its military strategy.

title: AIR CANADA TIGHTENS FUEL CHECKS ON TAKEOFFS
description: Air Canada, reacting to an incident Saturday in which a Boeing 767 made a forced landing at an old military base after running out of fuel, changed its procedures yesterday to forbid takeoffs if there is any malfunction in the on-board fuel-measuring system.

title: FRONTIER HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: 'No Shortage of Food,' Secretary Block Says
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that there was no world shortage of food, but that there was a major problem in moving food donations to the poor in developing countries.

title: CORECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Representative Ed Zschau misidentified Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey. He is a Democrat.

title: Valley National Bank Assignment to Dailey
description: Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, the latest member of the Interpublic Group of Companies family, has won the account of Valley National Bank, Phoenix, in a competition that included its new big brother, McCann-Erickson.

title: REACATORS MAY LOSE LIMIT ON LIABILITY
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has suggested in a draft report to Congress that it eliminate the $570 million limit on the liability of utilities for damages resulting from a reactor accident.

title: Con Ed Net Off 0.6%
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter dipped six-tenths of 1 percent, to $87.2 million, or 60 cents a share, from $87.7 million, or 61 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue rose 7.3 percent, to $1.18 billion, from $1.1 billion in the period a year earlier.

title: POLES WILL ENACT MORE RESTRICTIONS
description: With martial law formally ended, the Polish authorities plan to enact new laws this week tightening control over political dissidents and protesters.

title: Harvester Truck
description: The International Harvester Company produced its first 9670 truck at its Springfield factory, the plant that won a bitter battle for survival over a Fort Wayne, Ind., Harvester factory. Company officials said the truck was the first vehicle produced by the Harvester plant since the company's Springfield and Fort Wayne operations were consolidated. The state and Springfield offered Chicago-based Harvester a $30 million loan and a loan-guarantee package to choose the Ohio plant over the Indiana operation.

title: BBDO International's Earnings Advance 20%
description: BBDO International, parent company of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn and the first publicly held ad agency to announce secondquarter financial results, came out yesterday with some attractive figures - a 20 percent gain in quarter earnings and a 19 percent rise for the half year.

title: No Ruling Yet on Bat
description: The case of the pine-tarred bat is still unresolved. Lee MacPhail, the American League president, will rule today at the earliest and perhaps not until later in the week on the Kansas City Royals' protest over George Brett's nullified home run against the Yankees last Sunday.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Advertising; A Lehman Brothers Campaign
description: WHEN all around you people are talking about one great financial caper or another, but they are not giving the proper investment banker credit for pulling them off, because they don't know who the banker is - and it's your bank - the time has definitely come for a corporate advertising campaign.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HAROLD LLOYD. The Man on the Clock. By Tom Dardis. 357 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $19.75.

title: PUBLIC RADIO CRITICAL OF STAND ON LOAN
description: National Public Radio today accused the Corporation for Public Broadcasting of breaking off discussions on the terms of an emergency loan for the troubled network, which says it has no money to meet a Friday payroll or an estimated $4.5 million owed to creditors.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: 'BELL' NAME STILL RINGS...UH, BELLS
description: Given the choice, the subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company seem to prefer the familiar ring of the Bell name. After much wrangling between A.T.& T. and its 22 telephone subsidiaries, Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene said earlier this month that the subsidiaries, not their giant parent, had rights to the Bell name, trademark and logotype. Now some are wondering whether the new holding companies that announced their names before Judge Greene's ruling may have moved too hastily, losing a chance to use the Bell name to full advantage.

title: 250 More Flee After Upstate Fire
description: At least 250 more people were removed from their homes today in North Rose as crews prepared to clean up after an explosion and fire at a frozen-food warehouse.

title: SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting.

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
HAMPAR KELIKIAN
description: Dr. Hampar Kelikian, a surgeon who used his World War II battlefield innovations to correct childrens' deformities, died Sunday in Northwestern Memorial Hospital.

title: PETERSON LEAVING KEY LEHMAN BROTHERS POST
description: Peter G. Peterson, Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration and later one of Wall Street's best-known executives, stepped down yesterday as chairman and co-chief executive officer of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., the investment banking house.

title: Go, Chaminade
description: The highly publicized victory of tiny Chaminade University of Honolulu over the nation's top-ranked basketball team, the University of Virginia, last December put the Silverswords into the headlines and apparently into the minds of athletic directors all over the country.

title: BRIEFING
description: How Loud Is Too Loud?

title: Monfort Files Suit
description: Monfort of Colorado has filed suit in Federal court to stop what it says is an attempt by another meatpacker to monopolize the beef industry.

Year-ago quarter and 6 months results have been restated to exclude operations of discontinued business.

title: Erwin S. Barrie Dies at 97; Led Grand Central Galleries
description: Erwin Seaver Barrie, an art dealer and director of the Grand Central Art Galleries in Manhattan for more than half a century before his retirement in 1975, died last Thursday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He also had a home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Barrie was 97 years old.

title: TEXAS BANK UNITS AGREE TO MERGER
description: First City Bancorp, a bank holding company in Houston with $16.6 billion in assets, yesterday announced a merger agreement with Cullen-Frost Bankers Inc., a bank holding company in San Antonio with $3 billion in assets.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $49,246. c-Includes a realized investment gain of $177,400. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 7 percent stock dividend in December 1982.

title: BALLET: 'L' ARLESIENNE'
description: IN ''L'Arlesienne,'' a vibrantly evocative and atmospheric ballet by Roland Petit, the hero ends it all by taking a running, headlong dive out a window.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
CASTRO SAYS U.S. SEEKS TO DEPLOY TROOPS UNDER GUISE OF MANEUVERS
description: President Fidel Castro said today that the United States was trying to deploy troops in Central America through military maneuvers now beginning in the region.

Sports of the Times; Rozelle Makes the Right Call
description: In his 23 years as commissioner of the National Football League, Pete Rozelle has dealt with some complicated issues: rival leagues, players seeking better wages, antitrust legislation and the one-man independence movement of Al Davis.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
SENATE APPROVES A PLAN TO BUILD FIRST MX MISSILE
description: After two weeks of filibustering and posturing, the Senate Tuesday night finally approved a plan to produce and deploy the first group of 27 MX missiles, which would cost $4.6 billion. The vote was 58 to 41.

title: Corn and Soybeans Fall As Weather Improves
description: Improved crop weather sent prices of corn and soybean futures tumbling yesterday. At the close, the pivotal contract for corn delivery in December was down 7 3/4 cents a bushel, at $3.19, and the equally active November soybean contract had plunged 19 cents, to $7.175. But December wheat rose 3 cents, to $3.83 a bushel.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid Aug. 3.

title: The Importance of Reading Ernest
description: Because of such as ''A Farewell to Arms,'' a farewell to Ernest Hemingway is nowhere in sight. Twenty-two years after his death, an article in The Times reports, his books are selling better than ever.

description: One of the hottest things in sultry St. Louis this summer is Neil Allen, and he gives most of the credit to the Mets for a simple reason: They traded him to the Cardinals.

description: The Republican-controlled Senate Energy Committee today sent to the Senate floor, without recommendation, a measure to remove all Federal price ceilings on natural gas over a three-year period.

WILSON'S HOMER WINS IN 10TH
description: They needed 10 innings to do it, but the Mets beat the team with the best record in baseball again last night. With a home run from a most unlikely source, Mookie Wilson, they scored a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium.

title: SPACE AGE CLOTHING'S DEBUT
description: Fourteen years after the first moon landing, space age textiles are starting to show up in earthbound apparel. Thin thermal fabrics are replacing bulky fleece and down in skiwear. Dancers and athletes are beginning to wear clothing that feels soft and dry even when wet.

Hauser to Acquire A Cable Company
description: Hauser Communications Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire for more than $30 million the assets of the Arlington Telecommunications Corporation, a cable communications company serving about 27,000 subscribers in Arlington, Va.

Tire Account Goes To Della Femina
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners is prepared to hit the road. On Aug. 1, it will become agency for the Continental Products Corporation of Lyndhurst, N.J., a marketer of the car, truck and motorcycle tires made by Continental Gummi Werke of Hanover, West Germany.

title: PROFESSIONAL GARDENERS' ADVICE
description: ''I haven't had time yet to grow the table lamp,'' said Jack Hamilton, who has just retired after 37 years as Longwood's topiary gardener. He was referring to a topiary easy chair with a side table and a glass of Scotch growing out of it, all begun seven years ago.

title: TELEPHONE COSTS WILL BE INCREASED UNDER F.C.C. PLAN
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a plan yesterday that would add $2 a month to the cost of a residential telephone line, and $6 a month to the cost of business lines, starting in January.

description: Repeal of tax withholding from interest and dividend income became all but certain today after House and Senate conferees approved a compromise bill.

TAX LAW AIDING ARTS FAULTED BY FOUNDATION
description: The nation's tax laws provide significant deductions to wealthy patrons of the arts, giving them a major and often dominant voice in shaping arts policies while increasing every other taxpayer's burden, according to a new study for the Twentieth Century Fund.

title: VIEWER POLL CITED IN SEX BIAS CASE
description: A woman who filed suit over losing a television news anchor job testified today that she experienced emotional problems after her boss told her that an audience survey showed that viewers considered her too old, too unattractive and not deferential to men.

title: INSIDER BILL ADVANCES IN HOUSE
description: A House subcommittee approved legislation today that would set stiffer penalties for the illegal use of inside information in the trading of securities.

Formal Murder Charges Filed in Deaths of 5 Boys
description: A former Eagle Scout and missionary who led the police to the rural graves of five boys was charged today with murder, aggravated kidnapping and forcible sexual abuse.

title: HOW TO TRIM A TOPIARY PILLAR
description: The twin topiary pillars below, almost eight feet tall and 25 inches in diameter, flank one entrance of Longwood's topiary garden. It took seven years for Jack Hamilton, Longwood's topiary gardener who has recently retired, to complete the pillars.

title: Volvo Quits as Sponsor Of Tennis Grand Prix
description: Volvo will not renew its sponsorship of the Grand Prix of professional tennis when its contract expires after the 1984 season.

title: Harvester to Open New Creditor Talks
description: The International Harvester Company, a manufacturer of commercial trucks and farm machinery, plans to reopen talks with its major creditors in late August to once again reschedule its $3.5 billion debt, a company spokesman said today.

title: Executive Denies Role in 2 Deaths
description: Irwin Margolies pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he masterminded the 1982 murder of a Federal witness and the abduction and presumed murder of a potential witness.

title: WILLIE WILL BE THERE
description: F ans adored Willie Mays. That bright, boyish smile straight from the sandlots of Birmingham, Alabama. The perky greeting: ''Say Hey!'' The cap flying off as he rounded first and dug for second, leaving puffs of dirt in his wake. The whirling throws. The long-ball power in the clutch. Stopping for a game of stickball in the evening and, according to legend, walloping a pitch beyond two sewers.

Hope From a Hypnotist
description: Jim Eisenreich, the Minnesota Twins' oufielder who abandoned his career earlier this year because of an immobilizing nervous disorder, is being treated by a St. Paul hypnotist who hopes to have Eisenreich back on the Twin roster by Sept. 1. ''He's a gutsy guy and he has the potential to be a superstar,'' said the hypnotist, Harvey Misel, who has worked with dozens of athletes over the years and is now under contract to the Chicago White Sox.

title: Liberia Announces Timetable For Return to Civil Rule in '85
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe's military government said today that Liberia will return to civilian rule April 12, 1985, the fifth anniversary of the coup that brought General Doe to power.

title: Court Dismisses Breathalyzer Ban
description: A state appeals court today dismissed a ban against using Breathalyzer results as evidence in drunken-driving cases. The machines are used to measure the amount of alcohol in the bloodstream.

title: When the Law Is a Business
description: Led by the Texas bar, the organized lawyers of a half-dozen states are asking Congress to declare their profession exempt from the antitrust and consumer fraud laws. And Congress, which barely resisted a similar ''doctor knows best'' plea for privilege from the American Medical Association last year, is all too likely to take the request seriously.

CREW IS FOUND AT FAULT IN VOLGA BOAT DISASTER
description: A Soviet Government inquiry commission has found that ''gross violations by the motorship's command'' were to blame for the accident June 5 in which a passenger vessel struck a rail bridge crossing the Volga River at Ulyanovsk, killing at least a hundred people.

title: A DIVORCE BILL WITHOUT IMPACT ON RELIGION
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Young Brothers Killed in L.I. Crash
description: Two young Kings Park brothers were killed and their 4-year-old sister and mother were injured this morning when their convertible collided with a dump truck, the police said.

title: North to Alaska
description: Through the years, the N.B.A. has hoped for varying benefits from its exhibiton games. The league has tried several locations to test for future franchises and build interest for national television ratings.

title: Volleyball Incident
description: The coach of the United States volleyball team has acknowledged asking a star player to post a performance bond as a condition for rejoining the team for next summer's Olympics, and the player says he plans to file a grievance with the United States Olympic Committee. The coach, Doug Beal, who had previously denied seeking such a bond from the player, Tim Hovland, said that he had asked Hovland to put up an undisclosed sum of money to insure that he would not leave the team before the Olympics. Hovland, a former all-American at Southern California, had been a member of the national team but quit in a dispute with Beal last year.

title: Henry McLaughlin Dies at 90; Played 'Howdy Doody' Clown
description: Henry McLaughlin, a film and vaudeville veteran who played Clarabell the Clown for three years on television's ''Howdy Doody'' show, died of stroke complications Sunday. He was 90 years old.

title: PATELLAR REFLEXES
description: ''August is the month that psychiatrists take for their vacations,'' notes Norma Loquendi of Resume Speed, Tex. ''In recent years, right-wing columnists have also taken to disappearing in August. What's happening? Do they all go off together? It's bad enough that I have to cope with my neuroses alone - must I be left to form my own opinions?''

title: LESS THAN OPEN-AND-SHUT GERRYMANDERING

title: CUBA DIRECTS SALVADOR INSURGENCY, FORMER GUERRILLA LIEUTENANT SAYS
description: A former Salvadoran guerrilla who played a key role in anti-Government raids in San Salvador has told United States officials that Cuba has ''directed the activities'' of the insurgency since 1980 and that the guerrilla leadership is now operating from bases in Nicaragua.

title: CHEMISE RETURNS AT SAINT LAURENT
description: After Andre Courreges indicated that 1960's fashions were viable these days, Yves Saint Laurent pushed the clock a step farther back. This morning, as his contribution to the week of fall and winter couture showings, he placed the focus squarely on the chemise, as promulgated by the late Cristobal Balenciaga in 1957. It's hard to believe that the mere absence of a marked waistline shocked the world in those days, but it did. And today, Saint Laurent's chemises are the talk of the town.

title: 4 Marines Die in Auto Crash
description: Four marines were killed Tuesday night when the jeep they were in collided with a tractor-trailer two miles south of Gonzales in Monterey County. Sheriff's deputies said the four were on their way to Fort Hunter Liggett, where maneuvers are in progress.

title: JAZZ TRIO: TATE, BRYANT AND DUVIVIER
description: TEXAS tenor saxophonists are known for their volatile, oratorical solos; Count Basie band alumni are known for suave precision. Buddy Tate, a Texan who was with the Basie band from 1939 to 1948, can be depended on for solos that growl and moan yet swing with aplomb.

title: Florida Grapefruit Juice

The other finalists were Barnum Communications, New York; Beber, Silverstein & Partners, Miami, and a group made up of Gordon Hill Advertising, Toronto, which serves the commission in Canada, and Kenyon & Eckhardt, New York.

description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that the union would sponsor radio and television commercials in the next three weeks to present the officers' side of the story in the current controversy over police brutality.

title: YANKS WIN ON KEMP HIT
description: Steve Kemp will not remember this July as the most productive month of his career. Entering tonight's game against the Rangers, he had just three runs batted in during the first 26 days of the month. His frustration was apparent when he struck out in the third inning with his Yankee teammate Dave Winfield in scoring position.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Secret of the Pass

title: New Sanyo Chip
description: The Sanyo Electric Company said it had made a two-layer computer chip, an important step on the way toward production of a three-dimensional or multilayer chip, by stacking a single-crystal silicon layer carrying an electronic circuit on top of a conventional one-layer chip. Industry sources said chip producers have been trying to produce a multi-layer chip that could process information in parallel, as the human brain is thought to do.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Tools for ''blind'' riveting -that is, tools that will insert and clinch rivets while you are working from only one side -can be extremely useful for many repairs around the home and for assembling items made of metal, leather, plastic and canvas.

description: An article in Business Day last Monday about computer disk drives included an incorrect statement from the Kaypro Corporation on its pricing plan for the Kaypro II personal computer. The company now says the price will not be reduced below the present $1,595.

title: NUCLEAR INSURANCE: UNGARBLING A MESSAGE
description: To the Editor: Keiki Kehoe shows a complete misunderstanding of the insurance business. He asserts that the risk of a nuclear accident is very great because insurance companies do not want to insure against it. Insurance companies, however, are always very willing to write life insurance policies even though there is a 100 percent certainty of the risk occurring.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 28, 1983
description: International Gunmen identified as Armenians stormed the Turkish Ambassador's residence in Lisbon and, after keeping policemen at bay with gunfire for 90 minutes, blew up the building. Seven people died in the terrorist attack -five gunmen, a hostage and a policeman who had entered the buiding during the siege. (Page A1, Column 5.) Fifteen Jews made a pilgrimage from the United States and three other countries to England to pay honor to the woman who rescued them from Germany on the eve of World War II. They came thousands of miles to thank Dorothy de Rothschild, their 88-year-old benefactor. (A1:1-3.)

title: Oil Takeovers In Canada
description: Canadian oil companies that went on a takeover binge after the Government decided to ''Canadianize'' ownership of the industry performed far worse last year than other oil companies, a federal agency has found in a survey.

description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America said today that he might meet with Salvadoran rebel leaders on his current visit to the area, but he declined to give any details, saying ''publicity, though interesting, kills opportunities.''

description: If a United States Football League team plays in New York it will not be until the 1985 season, Chet Simmons, the commissioner, said yesterday. John Bassett, the Tampa Bay owner who heads the league's expansion committee, has held several meetings recently with Simmons to discuss that possibility.

GLOBAL MONETARY MESS
description: When President Francois Mitterrand called for a new Bretton Woods to resolve the world monetary crisis, his proposal was widely dismissed as little more than a gimmick to rescue the franc and his sagging popularity. This is unfortunate because the present unmanaged floating exchange rate system is unworkable. It is fostering inflation, increasing unemployment and creating global economic instability. Moreover, the monetary ''reforms'' of the 1970's showed that piecemeal tinkering will not restore monetary stability. Negotiations as grand and inventive as the Bretton Woods Conference of 1944 are required.

title: U.S. SETS TERMS FOR REFUNDING
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that its third-quarter refunding auctions next week would total $15.75 billion, or $750 million more than sold at the previous quarterly refunding, in May. Next week's auctions will consist of $6.5 billion of three-year notes, to be sold Tuesday; $5.25 billion of 10-year notes, on Wednesday, and $4 billion of 30-year bonds, on Thursday.

title: ALUMINUM'S MODEST UPTURN
description: In the 1850's, when aluminum sold for $545 a pound, Napoleon III used it to serve royalty at state dinners, relegating lesser guests to gold and silver. Later in the century, after two young men hit upon a process for producing the metal in quantity, the price plummeted to 57 cents a pound - a level that made aluminum better suited to soda cans than dinner service.

title: Advertising; Campaign To Assist Homeless
description: IT would seem that a public service advertising campaign to remind us of the homeless of New York would almost be a redundancy. But Norman Tanen says that the homeless who are found in train stations and parks, with their old clothes and shopping bags and vacant eyes, are just the most obvious victims of society, and that there are many more homeless, though less recognizable. And are we getting so accustomed to seeing the most visible homeless that they no longer have a heart-wrenching impact?

title: A Flamingo in Brooklyn
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Regarding ''Plastic Flamingos -Where Did They Go?'' July 21: I live in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Park Slope is a community largely devoted to the esthetics of life. We are a brownstone neighborhood, populated by many upwardly mobile types -nothing wrong there - so you can imagine my utter surprise when, as I was driving through the heart of our area I noticed two absolutely beautiful pink flamingos in a garden on the corner of Eighth Avenue and Carroll Streets. BETH LUCKHURST Brooklyn

title: OPERA: 'DIE WALKURE' AT THE WAGNER FESTIVAL IN BAYREUTH
description: Since this is the centenary of Richard Wagner's death, the new ''Ring'' being produced in this Bavarian citadel of Wagnerism might be expected to stimulate some thought about the composer's most ambitious and most disturbing work. However, if Sir Peter Hall has any clear idea of what he means to convey in the new ''Ring'' that he is directing here, his intent has not yet emerged.

News Analysis
description: President Reagan's repeated references in his news conference Tuesday to the Soviet Union and Cuba as key sources of unrest in Central America reflected growing frustration over the reaction to his policy at home. As the White House sees it, the public, Congress and the press have failed to appreciate the serious threat posed by Soviet and Cuban interference in the region.

title: People
description: * Brian J. Dillon named a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: UNITED SERVICES LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
NERVE GAS: A THREAT TO U.S. CREDIBILITY
description: The recent vote in the Senate providing $130 million for the production of nerve gas raises a fundamental question concerning the larger issue of arms control: Does the United States mean what it says? Our credibility is already suspect on the issue of nuclear weapons. We are now running the same risk on the issue of chemical weapons. At the very least we are sending out mixed signals.

title: Tribune Station
description: The Tribune Company said its subsidiary, the Tribune Broadcasting Company, had reached a preliminary agreement to purchase WANX-TV, Channel 46, an independent station in Atlanta, from the Christian Broadcasting Network for $32 million in cash. The sale is subject to the approval of the boards of both companies and to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: C. D. Halsey, Ex-Stockbroker And Head of Flower Hospital
description: Charles Day Halsey, a retired stockbroker and former president and chairman of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Canadian Scientists Support Ottawa on Acid Rain Stance
description: An independent group of Canadian scientists has endorsed Ottawa's tough position on acid rain and urged Canada and the United States to take prompt abatement measures.

description: A special session of the National Assembly has been called by Kuwait's Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to try to resolve the crisis at the country's unofficial stock market, the Souq al-Manakh, which crashed last year. Numerous bankruptcies are feared.

description: In Europe yesterday, athletes from many nations took part in several meets as a warmup for next month's World Championship track and field meet in Helsinki. There were some impressive performances.

title: A HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO ALLOW CONVENTION CENTER LEASE DEAL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today granted New York City's Convention Center an exemption that, if it becomes law, would allow the state's Urban Development Corporation to sell the center to private investors and then lease it back as a way of covering the projected construction cost overruns.

title: Market Place; Hot Days Help Utility Stocks
description: THE sun is beginning to shine for electric utility stocks. A mild winter tended to depress earnings in the final quarter of 1982 and the first quarter of 1983, but the heat wave this summer means a surge in kilowatt sales.

title: SEAPORT SITE OPENS TODAY WITH A FANFARE
description: New York's newest tourist attraction, the South Street Seaport, opens officially today as the re-creation of an ancient New York waterfront that, like the rest of the city, never seems to be quite finished.

title: CONCERT: FORTEPIANO AND PIANO AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: THIS year's installment of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra has received much justified praise. But of the three hours of playing (plus intermissions) at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, far and away the best work of the night came from the keyboard players, or more precisely two of them.

title: Manila Eases Curbs On Opposition Mayor
description: An opposition mayor has been transferred from a stockade to house arrest after President Ferdinand E. Marcos heeded protests from Jaime Cardinal Sin about the mayor's three-month detention.

description: When Paul Stewart was growing up in Clinton, Iowa, he liked to play cowboys and Indians with his friends, even though they always made him take the part of the Indian.

title: News Analysis
description: In a speech here Tuesday summarizing the accomplishments of his 25 years in power, Fidel Castro seemed to play down Cuban ties to the Soviet Union. ''Not in the past, not now or ever have we made decisions at a cost to others or expected others to fight for us,'' the Cuban leader said.

title: ART BY DISABLED SHOWN
description: A national exhibition of art by disabled people opened Tuesday evening in the lobby of the Warner Communications building at 75 Rockefeller Plaza, and three nondisabled artists encouraged future efforts by holding workshops at the opening reception for 50 handicapped youngsters and adults.

HELPFUL HARDWARE;
BIDET ATTACHMENTS TO MOUNT ON TOILET
description: THE bidet is now an accepted part of bathroom design, but the chances are slight that one could feasibly be added to an existing bathroom. The cost of additional plumbing would make installation very expensive.

title: Bridge: Close Reasoning Can Gain Success Against the Odds
description: If a player takes a succesful action that flies in the face of the percentages, there are three possible explanations. Perhaps he does not know the percentages; or an opponent may be holding his cards in clear view, or there may be technical reasons for knowing that the normal play is due to fail.

description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January 1983.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON I.M.F. DELAYED
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he would delay a vote on President Reagan's plan for an $8.4 billion increase in United States support for the International Monetary Fund until the Administration lines up enough Republican votes to pass the measure.

title: Kaiser Meets On New Offer
description: Directors of the Kaiser Steel Corporation met today to review an acquisition offer from a group of investors led by the Minnesota financier Irwin L. Jacobs, but had not reached a decision by mid-afternoon, a spokesman said.

title: THREE INDICTED IN DRYSDALE COLLASPE
description: In the first criminal prosecutions stemming from the collapse of the Drysdale Government Securities Corporation last year, two of the company's top officials and a former senior partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company were indicted yesterday.

title: Israel Arrests American
description: An Israeli court today ordered an American held for 15 days for questioning in the slayings of two nuns of the Soviet-backed Russian Orthodox Church in Jerusalem, the authorities said today. He was identified as Aoysius Jay Garrow of Michigan, about 29 years old. The nuns were found slain in their bedroom on May 20.

description: In a multimillion-dollar bidding spree that lasted all of 10 minutes yesterday morning, New York City got the highest price ever at public auction for one of its real-estate parcels.

title: The Misread Mandate
description: Under Anne Burford, President Reagan's first Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, protection of the environment was put into full reverse. The unpopularity of that policy, among other reasons, led to the retirement of Mrs. Burford and much of her crew.

Larry Gains, Fighter Who Held Two Titles
description: Larry Gains, a Canadian-born heavyweight boxer who defeated Max Schmeling and Primo Carnera but never got a chance for the world title that they later won, died Tuesday while visiting relatives in Cologne. He was 83 years old.

title: Bat Ruling Due Today
description: Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, is expected to rule today on whether umpires were correct in disallowing a two-run homer by Kansas City's George Brett because his bat had too much tar on it.

Macomber, chairman and chief executive, will take on the duties of president.

description: Federal authorities charged eight men yesterday with participating in conspiracies that included plans to sell $2 billion of sophisticated weapons to Iran and $15 million of machine guns to the Irish Republican Army.

Comings and Goings
description: A Federal judge in Chicago issued an order that prohibits the University of Illinois-Chicago from dismissing or reassigning its basketball coach, Tom Meyer, for at least 10 days. Meyer has filed a suit in which he says several university officials violated his constitutional rights by dismissing him last April when his players walked off the court in protest. ... Jeff Siemon, a Minnesota Viking linebacker, announced his retirement after 11 seasons with the club and said he would study for the ministry. ... Tony Ayala, a former top-ranked boxing contender, yesterday began serving a 35-year sentence for a sexual-assualt conviction at Trenton State Prison, a day after his request to be sent to Rahway State Prison, where good boxing facilities are available, was denied.

title: The U.N. Today; July 28, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NO LEBANON PARTITION
description: 138,0,3100,2BEIRUT, Lebanon - Are we witnessing the de facto partition of Lebanon? The Israeli Government's decision to withdraw to the Awali River suggests that perhaps we are - and some observers even argue that it may not be such a bad thing after all. In reality, partition is neither inevitable nor desirable - and the Administration should take steps now to avoid the drift toward a permanently divided Lebanon.

title: Howard Johnson Moves
description: Attention all ad agencies without restaurant or hotel chain accounts: Howard Johnson is going to be looking. According to a house memo that made the rounds at N.W. Ayer yesterday, Louis T. Hagopian, chairman, said the agency had resigned the assignments for both the motor lodges and the Howard Johnson restaurants.

title: Smith Asserts Reagan Is Committed to Rights
description: Defending President Reagan's record on civil rights, Attorney General William French Smith said yesterday that the Administration was ''more committed than any previous Administration to finding remedies for discrimination that promise to work.''

title: Small Boat, Long Trip
description: If you have any business with Bill Dunlop, you had better hurry.

Larry McWilliams tries to become a 10-game winner for the Pirates, one of the hottest teams in the majors in the last month. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Golf United States Women's Open, first round, at Tulsa, Okla. Among the field are these previous Open title winners: Amy Alcott, JoAnne Carner, Hollis Stacy and Pat Bradley.

title: CUOMO SIGNS 2 MEASURES TO FIGHT BIAS IN HOUSING SALES AND RENTALS
description: Governor Cuomo today signed two bills designed to attack discrimination in housing. One law, which is intended to help the elderly, bars landlords and real-estate brokers from discriminating on the basis of age in the sale, rental or leasing of all housing to people 18 years of age or over. The prohibition against such discrimination would not affect so-called retirement communities, many of which are limited to those 55 or older.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for qtr to July 9.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 28, 1983; The Economy
description: House-Senate conferees approved repeal of tax withholding on interest and dividend income. The compromise measure, voted out after a week-long deadlock, is expected to win swift approval in both houses of Congress. And President Reagan, whose opposition to the measure has apparently eased, is expected to sign it. (Page A1.)

title: A MOVE IN TO MOVIES
description: Thomas H. Baer, a New York lawyer, has been named president of Kings Road Productions Inc., an independent film company based in Los Angeles and New York. Mr. Baer, 46, has represented clients in the entertainment industry and has been active in public affairs and politics in New York.

title: HOUSE OPENS DEBATE ON COVERT LATIN EFFORTS
description: Congressional leaders today predicted a close vote as the House of Representatives began debate on a proposal to cut off secret aid to Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: Newark Airport to Get $4 Million U.S. Grant
description: Newark International Airport will receive a $4 million grant from the Federal Aviation Administration to improve its facilities for noncommercial aircraft, Governor Kean announced today.

title: Henry Primakoff Dead at 69; Professor of Science at Penn
description: Henry Primakoff, a University of Pennsylvania professor known for his work as a theoretical physicist, died Tuesday at his home in Penn Valley. He was 69 years old.

title: Bank Rates Show Rise
description: For the 10th consecutive week, interest rates for bank money market deposit accounts rose in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Interest rates in the New York area, however, declined slightly.

title: Gunman Kills 2 on Coast
description: An elderly man posing as a heart attack victim shot and killed one doctor and wounded another at a family health center today, then drove away and killed another man before wounding himself, the police said. The gunman was identified by the police as Ivan S. Dunbinsky, 73 years old, of San Francisco, who was listed in critical condition in a hospital after surgery for a head wound.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR'S CANDIDATE WINS PRIMARY FOR HOUSE SEAT
description: Charles Hayes handily won the special Democratic primary in the First Congressional District Tuesday. The victory was attributed to his endorsement by Mayor Harold Washington and campaigning by many of the same workers whose efforts helped put the Mayor in office last April.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
New Zenith Chief Aims at Continuity
description: For Jerry K. Pearlman, the new chief executive officer of the Zenith Radio Corporation, the key word yesterday was continuity. On his first day on the job, Mr. Pearlman, who was also appointed president and a director, pledged to maintain the company's strategy of cutting manufacturing costs and of relying on its strong research and enginering capabilities to move into new markets.

title: WICAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $170,000. c-Net loss.

title: Liberty Wins Three From Courageous; Keel Incident Is Resolved
description: Liberty convincingly defeated Courageous in all three races today in the last day of the United States observation trials to select the defender of the America's Cup. Courgeous has lost 11 races in a row, and Liberty has won its last 9.

title: U.S. JUDGE SAYS BOSTON CAN'T HOLD ELECTIONS IN NEW DISTRICTS
description: A Federal district judge has barred Boston from holding City Council and School Committee elections as scheduled this fall, throwing the city's political scene into chaos.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Nkomo Says He Can't Return
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader in exile here, said today that he would not return home in time to retain his parliamentary seat, which is being revoked because of his absence. The circumstances that made him fear for his life and flee last March 13 ''are still there,'' he said in a television interview. Even if he returns by next week's deadline, he said, he might not attend Parliament because he finds it ''appalling'' that it has done nothing about what he called Government troop brutality in his Matabeleland homeland.

Year-ago results include the operations of Benjamin Franklin Savings Association for only 8 months and don't include the operations of Foster Mortgage.

title: HOME BEAT
description: MARK DeANGELIS admitted that it all sort of happened ''by accident.'' But before he realized it, he and a friend, Jim Mullen, had invited a group of furniture artisans and designers to display their recent and heretofore unknown work in an exhibition dubbed ''Ourhaus.''

title: TENNECO UP
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its earnings jumped 40.1 percent in the second quarter, to $402 million. The gain by the nation's second-largest energy concern reflected lower crude oil prices and better profits on gasoline, factors that have helped several major oil companies.

title: IRANIAN TROOPS TAKE REPORTERS INTO IRAQ
description: A cluster of artillery shells hit the high ground above a northern Iraqi village Tuesday as reporters accompanied by Iranian officers watched from nearby military positions.

title: Court Approves MGF Oil's Plan
description: The MGF Oil Corporation of Midland, Tex., said it had emerged from involuntary bankruptcy following dismissal of a case filed against it by three holders of its 14 1/2 percent senior subordinated debentures.

title: Remington Settles Its Norelco Suit
description: Remington Products Inc. and North American Philips Inc. have settled a $50 million suit Remington filed against the maker of Norelco electric shavers.

7 DEAD IN LISBON IN ARMENIAN RAID
description: Gunmen identified as Armenians stormed the Turkish Ambassador's residence here today and, after keeping Portuguese policemen at bay with gunfire for an hour and a half, blew it up. Seven people died in the attack - five gunmen, a hostage and a policeman who had entered the residence during the siege.

title: 15 WHO FLED NAZIS AS BOYS HOLD A REUNION
description: On the grounds of an estate in the English countryside, 15 middle-aged Jewish men from the United States, Canada, Britain and Israel made a pilgrimage Tuesday to pay honor to the woman who rescued them from Germany on the eve of World War II.

title: ANOTHER O'NEIL AT RKO
description: Shane O'Neil, a member of the family that founded the General Tire and Rubber Company, has been named president and chief operating officer of its big RKO General Inc. subsidiary.

title: Opera Talks to Resume Amid Hint of Optimism
description: The two sides in the New York City Opera strike will meet again today at 5 P.M. in the law offices of Martin J. Oppenheimer, chief negotiator for the company. The meeting will be the first since Friday in the dispute, which has canceled all performances at the New York State Theater since July 7.

title: Appearance Delayed
description: Dirk Minniefield, a second-round draft choice of the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association who was traded to the Nets, failed to show yesterday for the opening of New Jersey's rookie camp at Princeton, N.J. A Nets' spokesman said that Minniefield did not appear, upon advice of his agent, because he has not yet signed a contract. But the spokesman said that none of the team's draft picks has come to terms. ... Sam Bowie, Minniefield's teammate at the University of Kentucky last season, is playing basketball again after spending most of the past two years on crutches. Bowie did it at a pickup game in Lexington, Ky., where Minniefield also took part.

title: Technology
description: ONE day recently, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided that five nuclear power plants were potentially dangerous and ordered them shut down. Then, on the very next day, the commission reversed itself. Such is the tenuous position of the regulator.

Preserving Landmarks
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: So the architect Anne Eisenhower thinks that her client should be allowed to poke her air-conditioner through the wall of her landmark apartment house just because somebody did it before the building was designated part of a historic district: ''Once the stonework was damaged, I did not see why it was so tragic to duplicate it on the other side and make a symmetrical mistake, so to speak'' (''On Air-Conditioners in Landmark Areas,'' June 30).

title: 9 SENATORS OPPOSE A REAGAN NOMINEE
description: Thomas Ellis, a Southern lawyer named by President Reagan for a part-time post in government broadcasting, said he would decide whether to withdraw himself from consideration as the White House and members of a Senate panel examine allegations of racism against him.

title: ORNAMENTAL TOPIARY: THE GREEN AND GENTLE ART
description: the slow training and clipping of trees and shrubs into decorative shapes - has been in and out of fashion at least since the Roman Empire when the topiarius, the ornamental gardener, was second only to the estate manager himself.

title: 4 Arabs Are Wounded In West Bank Incident
description: Four Arab students in the West Bank were wounded today when Israeli soldiers opened fire on rock-throwing youths.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on June 29, about a survey of staff attitudes in public interest groups, erroneously listed one group among those polled. S. Robert Lichter, co-author of the re- port, said the researchers had erred and the report was not based on infor- mation from Common Cause.

title: Japanese to Buy Planes
description: Japan Air Lines, 37.7 percent Government-owned, wants to buy about 10 new aircraft to replace its DC-8s and has asked three aircraft manufacturers to suggest suitable replacements, Yasumoto Takagi,president, said today. He told reporters the airline approached Boeing and McDonnell Douglas of the United States and Airbus Industrie of France.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AIDS Phone Line Expanding
description: The Government's special telephone information number on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has been swamped with 8,000 to 10,000 calls a day, so the system will be expanded from three to eight lines. The toll-free number is (800) 342-AIDS.

title: TALES OF TWO LIVES: ONE PUBLIC, THE OTHER PRIVATE
description: Representative Dennis E. Eckart was racing off the other day to spend the weekend in his Ohio district. When his 4-year-old son, Eddie, spied the suitcase in his hand, the boy asked why he was going.

title: Pirates Win, 10-1; 4-Hitter for DeLeon
description: Johnny Ray drove in four runs with two home runs, and Tony Pena drove in three runs with a two-run home run and a single to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 10-1 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight.

title: MORGAN BREAKS OUT WITH KEY HOMER
description: J oe Morgan of the Philadelphia Phillies has been through some slumps in his career, but none as deep as his recent one. Before Tuesday night's game with the Houston Astros, Morgan, a .274 hitter during his career, had gone 0 for 35 and was hitting .188. His last hit had been a single June 28 against the Montreal Expos.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Cuts Ribbon At Harlem Renovation

title: News Analysis
description: Ever since the nation's beginning, big banks have been unpopular in Congress and have often been the objects of Congressional wrath. This tradition lives on.

title: JETS AGAIN LOOK TO NEIL FOR AID
description: Kenny Neil remembers watching Joe Klecko toss around offensive tackles and sack the quarterback, and he remembers thinking, ''Wow! I can't do that.''

title: THERE'S GRAVEL TO SPARE IN A GOLD RUSH TOWN
description: If you could build houses from gravel, they would cost less here because Nome has gravel to spare. As it is, with all building materials imported by barge in the ice-free summer months on the Bering Sea, housing costs are unreasonably high.

title: 3 Killed Upstate; Suspect Gives Up
description: The estranged wife of a Pennsylvania man and her parents were found shot to death early today in the bedroom of her parents' home in Tonawanda, N.Y., several miles from here, authorities said.

title: BENSON FACES AN ANNUAL TEST
description: Since he broke into the National Football League in 1977, Brad Benson has been shuttled between offensive tackle and guard.

title: UMC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

title: UNION TALKS WITH CHRYSLER BREAK DOWN ON WAGE ISSUE
description: Contract talks between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers broke down today. Owen F. Bieber, the union's president, said the newly profitable auto maker had refused to meet the union's key demand of raising the pay of Chrysler's 56,000 unionized workers to that of workers at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. He said the concerns had also proposed putting limits on cost of living payments and health benefits.

title: Q & A
description: Q. A new butcher-block table has unsightly black stains from sulfuric acid. Commercial cleaners and polishes do not remove them. Do you have any suggestions?

title: PITNEY BOWES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 10.

title: Dollar Bonds Slip in London
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds were little changed this afternoon after declining early in the day by about 3/8 point, dealers said.

title: PATTY SHEEHAN HAS POISE TO GO WITH LONG DRIVES
description: Patty Sheehan's drive at the 16th hole in the final round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship last year bounced off the far bank of a water hazard and popped back into the pond. Incorrectly treating the pond as a lateral water hazard instead of a regular one, Miss Sheehan made an improper drop alongside the pond instead of dropping back on the tee side of the water. After playing out the hole and finishing the round, she was disqualified. It cost her a few thousand dollars.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Charter Co. agreed to offer a 10-year, $22.5 million subordinated loan to W .R. Berkley Corp., bearing interest four points below the prime rate but not lower than 8 percent.

title: ARGENTINES REPORTED TO HAVE SEIZED 200 IN 70'S WAR CRIMES
description: The Interior Minister has told political leaders that the military Government has secretly detained 200 members of its own security forces on suspicion of committing internal war crimes during the crackdown on leftist guerrillas, a Government spokesman said today.

title: East Germany Ready For Talks, Strauss Says
description: The right-wing Premier of Bavaria, Franz Josef Strauss, returned today from a trip to Eastern Europe and said that East Berlin was ready for new concessions and negotiations.

title: Pearle Health Registers Initial Offering of Shares
description: Pearle Health Services of Dallas said yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial public offering of 6.6 million common shares through a syndicate of underwriters managed by William Blair & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering price is estimated at $18 to $21 a share, Pearle said.

title: REGULATION BY MONEY BROKERS
description: Money brokers, the financial middlemen who funnel billions of dollars from institutional investors to banks and savings associations, say they are forming a self-regulatory organization. The move is apparently in response to growing Government criticism that money brokers are knowingly depositing money in problem banks in order to earn unusually high interest rates.

title: Japan's Video Exports
description: Exports of Japanese videotape recorders in June rose 70.2 percent from a year earlier, to 1.25 million units, a monthly record, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said today.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT ENDS INQUIRY OF DRUG USE CHARGES IN CONGRESS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was closing its inquiry into allegations of drug use by members of Congress and would not bring criminal charges against the two Representatives and one former House member who have been under investigation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is police brutality in New York City. It is widespread and it is pervasive.

title: Freed Lifer Wants New Murder Trial
description: A tearful former drug addict released from prison by a Federal judge said today that he would welcome another trial to prove he had spent nearly eight years in prison for a murder he did not commit.

title: Mintzer, Trostler Disbanded on July 1
description: Mintzer, Trostler & Rothschild, born seven years ago to succeed Mintzer & Trostler, which had succeeded Mintzer & Greene, did indeed go out of business July 1, and each of the three principals has gone his own way. None is far from the clients he was closest to.

title: Words to Newton
description: Six professional golfers competing in the Canadian Open sent their best wishes yesterday by videotape to the Australian player Jack Newton, who was severely injured last weekend in an aircraft accident in Sydney. Newton, who was defeated by Tom Watson in a playoff for the 1975 British Open Championship, lost his right arm and suffered internal injuries when struck by a whirling propeller of a light airplane that had brought him back to Sydney from a football game.

title: Weinberger Demands New Effort to Cut Costs
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has issued a new set of orders aimed at holding down the prices of spare parts for military equipment.

title: TV: 'SHOOTING STARS,' AN ABC MOVIE
description: ''THIS is not a television show - this is reality,'' Parker Stevenson, who is O'Keefe, says to Billy Dee Williams, who is Hawke. They are careening around corners in a Mercedes, trying to shake off pursuit. No matter what they say, however, this is still television. The two-hour ABC movie, ''Shooting Stars,'' will be seen tonight at 9 o'clock.

AVANT-GARDE DESIGNER'S APPOINTMENT AT PARSONS DRAWS A MIXED REACTION
description: THE Department of Environmental Design at New York's Parsons School of Design will start the academic year in September with a new chairman and a controversy. James Wines, a New York designer whose buildings have delighted the public but outraged many members of the architectural profession, was appointed in May as the new head of the nation's oldest interior-design department. While some critics have admired his work for its Chaplinesque wit, social comment and artistic control, others have dismissed it as a joke.

title: CHINESE BREAK UP AN ABDUCTION RING
description: Chinese courts have sentenced one man to death, another to life imprisonment and 30 others to varying prison terms for abducting and selling more than 150 women.
