title: RALLY HALTS AND DOW FALLS 13.22
description: A lack of follow-through buying reversed early gains yesterday in the stock market, sending prices lower. Technology stocks were hard hit.

NAPCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
A RADIO, EARPHONES AND RICHARD RODGERS
description: ALTHOUGH I own a portable radio with earphones, I almost never risk wearing it on the street: I'm one of those people who could be hit by a car even after looking both ways. An exception had to be made last month, however, when Columbia University's enterprising radio station WKCR-FM celebrated the anniversary of Richard Rodgers's birth by programming 50 straight hours of his music. Here are show tunes to die for, happily.

title: SAN FRANCISCO REAL ESTATE INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
WATT REMOVES AGENCY'S LAND FROM SALE PLAN
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt has quietly pulled the public lands controlled by his department out of the Reagan Administration's program to sell off some Federal property as a means of reducing the national debt.

title: Computer Stocks Slide
description: The price of stock in companies selling home and personal computers dropped sharply yesterday as a rumor spread that the International Business Machines Corporation would introduce the ''Peanut,'' its long-expected inexpensive home computer, by Sept.1.

title: Cardinals Take 2 From Expos
description: The St. Louis Cardinals extended their winning streak to six games by beating the Montreal Expos, 3-2 and 10-1, in a doubleheader. The victories moved the Cardinals 1 1/2 games ahead of the Expos into second place in the National League East.

title: Japan Minister to Make Tour
description: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe is going to visit the Persian Gulf and Eastern Europe in a diplomatic effort to find a more active Japanese role in world politics. The tour, beginning Tuesday, includes Iran, Iraq, Turkey, Rumania and Bulgaria.

title: PUBLISHING: THE DISPUTE OVER L'AMOUR'S STORIES
description: FIRE settled over the literary O.K. Corral this week, when Bantam Books, its author Louis L'Amour and Carroll & Graf publishers agreed to end the shootout that has preoccupied them for more than a month. Shortly before they were scheduled to go into Federal court Monday, the parties agreed to end the litigation that grew out of the decision by Carroll & Graf to publish two collections of L'Amour stories that are in the public domain.

title: One-Fifth of Giants' Roster May Be New
description: Barring injuries or unexpected developments in the 5 1/2 weeks before the season opens, 8 to 11 of the Giants' 15 draft choices seem sure to make the team. There will also probably be a free-agent rookie, the tight end Zeke Mowatt, on the 45-player roster. Coach Bill Parcells described Mowatt today as ''the most pleasant surprise in camp.''

title: Advertising; Ice Cream With Some 'Romance'
description: AT the heart of every Custom Creamery Flavor Factory is a machine. And while the concept of these compact, in-store franchise locations beginning to blossom in the land is new, the machine that makes possible the promise of ''over 2,000 ice cream fantasies'' is old.

title: Girl Has Liver Transplant With President's Help
description: The baby daughter of a White House electrician, rushed to Pittsburgh on an Air Force flight arranged by President Reagan, was in critical condition today, recovering from a liver transplant that required 10 1/2 hours of surgery.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
AFTER MEXICAN VOTE, SOUL-SEARCHING
description: The elections were held, the winners were declared and, in time-honored Mexican tradition, the shouts of ''Fraud!'' began.

description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that it had accepted a ''definitive'' acquisition bid valued at $270.8 million from a group of investors led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis industrialist.

description: ORAL HISTORY. By Lee Smith. 286 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: NEW PACT RAISES SOVIET PURCHASES OF AMERICAN GRAIN
description: The Administration today announced an agreement with Moscow committing the Soviet Union to buy at least nine million metric tons of American grain in each of the next five years. This is 50 percent more than it was obligated to purchase in the past.

title: Horse Racing; Winning Jockey Is the Owner
description: Among the oddities that seem only to happen at Saratoga was the appearance of R. Herman Playforth in jockeys' silk for the fourth race here today.

title: Rose Still Intent On Career Goal
description: Pete Rose spent some time in his hotel room in Houston yesterday afternoon thinking about Bob Knepper, the left-handed pitcher he would be facing last night in the Astrodome.

title: PINE TAR POPULAR BECAUSE IT GRIPS
description: The final irony in this matter of the celebrated aromatic hydrocarbon made from tree stumps - that is, the pine tar that made George Brett's bat easier to grip - may be that it was the Yankees themselves who supplied it to the Kansas City Royals.

title: Korean Diplomat Heads for Home
description: O Nam Chol, the North Korean diplomat who pleaded guilty Tuesday to sexual abuse, was given a conditional discharge by a Westchester County judge today and ordered to leave the United States immediately and never return.

title: Bridge: Nassau-Suffolk Regionals Get Spotlight on Weekend
description: Regional titles are never easy to come by in the New York metropolitan area, but they may be easier than usual in the Nassau-Suffolk Regionals this weekend. Many of the top stars may be too jaded to play well, or perhaps even to play at all, following 10 days at the Summer Nationals in New Orleans.

title: Officer Sentenced In Club Payoffs
description: A former police officer, Anthony Alfano, was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison and fined $4,000 for committing perjury and extorting payoffs from an after-hours club in Manhattan.

title: STEAK N SHAKE INC reports earnings for qtr to July 6.
Baxter Travenol
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., Deerfield, Ill., said that it would form a subsidiary, A.S.T.S. Inc., to consolidate the company's products, services and technologies used in the operating room. By concentrating its surgical-theater-related products in one unit, Baxter Travenol said, A.S.T.S. would have more opportunity for research and development in this field. The company is considering a plan which would offer an interest in A.S.T.S. to the public through an underwritten offering of its shares.

title: INCREASING EVIDENCE SAID TO LINK DIOXIN TO HUMAN CANCERS
description: Increasing evidence links dioxin to cancer in humans, three top Reagan Administration public health officials testified today at a House subcommittee hearing.

title: TWO AT 65 LEAD BY 1 IN CANADIAN OPEN
description: Ralph Landrum, a self-styled underachiever playing his first day as an accredited member of the PGA Tour, and Vance Heafner shot six-under-par 65's today to tie for the lead in the first round of the 74th Canadian Open.

title: TOXIC BLAZE UPSTATE LEAVES LINGERING CLOUD OF CONFUSION
description: A fire here this week shot poisonous chemicals into the air, keeping 750 people from their homes for as long as four days, sending more than 125 of them to the hospital for checkups and leaving the community wondering what, if any, long-term health effects residents may face.

title: 'NATIONAL LAMPOON'S VACATION'
description: HOW far does the four-square, straight-arrow Clark W. Griswold family travel in ''National Lampoon's Vacation''? Far enough for some fast, funny satire, and not so far out that the humor turns sloppy. ''National Lampoon's Vacation,'' which is more controlled than other Lampoon movies have been, is careful not to stray too far from its target. The result is a confident humor and throwaway style that helps sustain the laughs - of which there are quite a few.

title: 57 ARE INJURED IN ILLINOIS IN COLLISION OF AMTRAK TRAIN AND TRUCK
description: A fast-moving Amtrak train carrying 107 people derailed today after ramming a truck that reportedly tried to race it through a gateless crossing. The truck driver and 56 people aboard the train were injured.

title: ART IN CORNELL MUSEUM COATED BY CHEMICAL USED IN STEAM LINES
description: A substance routinely added to the steam lines at Cornell University has extensively coated artwork in the Herbert F. Johnson Museum here, and there have been numerous health complaints from museum workers.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Texas Instruments Loses a Top Officer
description: Texas Instruments Inc. has reported a second high-level resignation since it reported a loss of $119.2 million for the second quarter. Stewart Carrell, 49 years old, said he would resign as executive vice president for corporate development, effective Sept. 1. Mr. Carrell, who has been with the company 25 years, was regarded by many as next in line for the presidency.

title: Paper for Americans in Rome Is Ordered to Reinstate Editor
description: An employment arbitration judge today ordered that an American-owned newspaper in Rome must immediately reinstate its editor, who was locked out last month in a pay dispute, the editor's lawyer said.

title: KANSAS CITY WINS PROTEST ON CANCELED HOMER
description: The George Brett home run that was, then wasn't, is. The case of Brett's pine-tarred bat slipped in another direction yesterday when Lee MacPhail, the American League president, upheld a protest by Brett's team, the Kansas City Royals. He overruled the umpires at the game, who had canceled the two-run home run Brett hit in the ninth inning at Yankee Stadium last Sunday on the ground that he had too much pine tar on his bat.

title: Cathedral in California Ordered to Pay Taxes
description: The state today ordered Robert Schuller, the television evangelist, to pay $473,000 in back property taxes, declaring the minister's Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove was used for concerts and other commercial events.

title: SWAN BELTED EARLY BY SOARING PIRATES
description: The Mets made a valiant effort to sidetrack the onrushing Pittsburgh Pirates last night, but they were unable to undo the early damage wrought by Craig Swan and lost, 6-2, at Shea Stadium.

title: THE LIMITS FOR LIBEL
description: In reducing a jury award to Carol Burnett in her libel suit against The National Enquirer, a California Appellate Court has provided welcome relief from the inhibiting effects of major libel verdicts against news organizations. The press should be free to write about public figures without threat of a financially debilitating libel suit. Anything less than total freedom will lead inexorably to self-censorship, which is nearly as effective as official censorship.

title: CONGRESS BID TO EASE RISES IN PHONE RATES
description: Members of Congress said today that they would act this year to lessen the impact of projected increases in local telephone rates on the poor and residents of rural areas.

title: American General Net
description: The American General Corporation, a holding company based in Houston with interests in life and property-casualty insurance, said net income in the second quarter rose 81.9 percent, to $86.6 million, or 92 cents a share, from $47.6 million, or 62 cents a share, a year before. Operating earnings rose 51.3 percent, to $72.3 million, or 76 cents a share, from $47.8 million, or 62 cents a share.

title: KEAN IS AGAINST A RAILROAD PLAN FOR ATLANTIC CITY
description: Governor Kean expressed opposition today to rail service to Atlantic City unless it serves commuters as well as gamblers.

title: LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHORE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
IACOCCA CRITICAL OF G.M. PLAN
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, today attacked the proposed joint venture in Fremont, Calif., of the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation as giving the two car companies ''the power to manipulate prices so that consumers and competitors would suffer.''

title: Cuomo Signs Measures To Pay for New Prisons
description: Governor Cuomo today signed bills to provide funds for 3,400 new state prison cells, including a new prison in the Bronx and the conversion of the Erie County Jail into a state prison.

title: Friday; FOR NIGHT OWLS
description: When night falls, owls and moths, snails and mice come out to play or prey at the New York Botanical Gardens in the Bronx, but most humans don't get to see them because the place is closed at night. Tonight at 7, however, Urban Park Rangers will lead a night tour in the gardens, pointing out not only sights, but also sounds and smells. For instance, some crickets chirp faster as the weather gets hotter, so if you know the formula, you can determine the temperature. Also for instance, the sassafras tree's leaves smell like root beer and the black birch's like wintergreen. The tour will also explore a glacier's path and other bits of natural history. Participation is limited and registration required: 548-7880. BUSY DAY FOR CLARINET

title: FORD BALKS AT SAFETY AGENCY'S RECALL REQUEST
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is urging the Ford Motor Company to recall 345,000 subcompacts, contending there is a fire hazard, but the automobile maker says it has no plans to recall the vehicles.

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
'THE POPULAR BURTON' AND HER MISSION
description: When Sala Burton walked onto the floor of the House of Representatives a little more than four weeks ago to be sworn in as her late husband's successor in Congress, she found it, she said, ''a touching, bittersweet experience.''

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: The company is 50 percent owned by Dow Chemical and 50 percent owned by Corning Glass Works.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: RON BUSCH has only been president of Pocket Books for five years, b ut in that time he cracked the whip and doubled the company's p rofits. What better reason for a party?

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income which includes a tax credit of $1,863 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $18,058 for the 6 months.

title: Changes for Reds
description: It's bye, bye, black shoes for the Cincinnati Reds, the last major league team to hold out against the trend to gaudy footwear. At a team meeting Wednesday, the Reds' players, who had filed a grievance against the club for maintaining the black-shoe policy, accepted a compromise offered by the club's interim general manager, Bob Howsam.

title: CHRISTIAN UNITS TOLD BY ISRAELIS TO LEAVE SOUTH
description: The Israeli Army touched off widespread protests today by ordering the Christian Phalangist militia to close at least one of its offices and barracks in southern Lebanon.

title: 'Glass Menagerie' with Jessica Tandy due in December.
description: ''I'D like to continue working as long as I can stand up,'' Jessica Tandy said in her firmest tone of voice. ''I don't want to get rusty.'' At the rate the 74-year-old actress is working, she is not about to let that happen. Miss Tandy, who won a Tony Award last season as best actress for her performance as an Appalachian widow in ''Foxfire,'' will open Dec. 1 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater in Tennessee Williams's ''The Glass Menagerie.'' Her co-star will be Amanda Plummer. The production will be directed by John Dexter, who staged ''Equus,'' and will be produced by Elizabeth I. McCann, Nelle Nugent, Maurice Rosenfield and Lois Rosenfield.

title: RANCO INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-After a foreign exchange loss of $617,000. c-Includes a foreign exchange gain of $90,000.

title: U.S. Agency's Shift On Paradyne Seen
description: A Social Security Administration official, apparently reversing an earlier stand, now says the agency is dissatisfied with Paradyne Corporation computer equipment.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON CUTTING OFF COVERT AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 228 to 195 by which the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut off United States covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for cutting off the aid. A ''no'' vote was a vote against cutting off the aid. Voting ''yes'' were 210 Democrats and 18 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 50 Democrats and 145 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Erdreich, no; Flippo, no; Nichols, no; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, no.

title: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a foreign exchange gain of $298,000. c-After a foreign exchange loss of $22,000. d-Net loss.

title: Article 065908 -- No Title
description: Marc Rich & Company A.G., a major international commodities trader, paid $1,350,000 yesterday toward a $50,000-a-day fine that began June 29.

title: Early Starters
description: Just as they do for the men's open, United States Golf Association officials intentionally pair some golfers together in first and second rounds of the women's open for a reason - usually a common bond of golf achievement.

title: AN ARCHITECT-SAILOR'S L.I. PROJECT CONTAINS BOAT SHIPS
description: Several years ago, Stephen Shilowitz, an architect by vocation and an avid sailor by avocation, was confronted with a problem most people would love to have: finding a berth for his 36-foot-long sloop, a family heirloom custom-built for his late father.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax benefits of $100,000 for the latest 6 months and $500,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Article 065290 -- No Title
description: The Intermountain Power Agency has signed two contracts for an estimated $800 million in long-term coal purchases from the Coastal States Energy Company.

title: ERICH ROHMER, 'PAULINE AT THE BEACH'
description: IT is late summer on the coast of Normandy where the beaches are broad and the weather unpredictable. As always, the North Atlantic is far too cold for anyone used to swimming in the soothing warmth of tropic seas, but the afternoon sun is bright and hot and the breezes are bracing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Kidding About Being Funny

title: SAB HARMON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Certain year-ago results have been reclassified to conform with 1983 results.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about Federal outlays for New York State incorrectly attributed a suggestion for a study of the Fed- eral-state fiscal relationship. The sug- gestion, for the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York to assist in the study, was made by Governor Cuomo.

title: THEATER: 'MISS LIBERTY,' A BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION
description: Irving Berlin is himself one of the great glories of the American musical theater. His bountiful music and lyrics have become an essential part of our everyday speech and life, especially in matters celebratory and patriotic. As a salute to Mr. Berlin on his recent 95th birthday and to the Goodspeed Opera House on its own 20th birthday, Michael P. Price, the Goodspeed producer, has brought back ''Miss Liberty'' for a full summer run.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COURT FINDS INNIS TO BE LEGITIMATE HEAD OF CORE
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Roy Innis was the legitimate leader of the Congress of Racial Equality, capping a five-year dispute over who was authorized to direct and solicit funds for the organization.

title: Fans Boo Moreno
description: When Omar Moreno, the center fielder, issued a ''play-me-or-trademe'' ultimatum, it struck some Houston Astros' fans as unseemly. Moreno, who bats left-handed and has had trouble hitting some lefthanded pitchers, had missed only eight games this season. After missing three more games after his outburst, Moreno returned to the lineup for Wednesday night's game against the Philadelphia Phillies and was booed by the Astros' fans every time he came to the plate (he was hitless in three appearances) and jeered in the second inning when he allowed a ball to drop in front of him for a hit.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.

title: LYNCHINGS BRING A TOUCH OF THE WILD WEST TO INDIA
description: ''Five Thieves Lynched,'' the headline announced, almost as if it were in, say, The Tombstone (Ariz.) Epitaph in 1883 instead of in The Hindu, an Indian national daily, in 1983.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ametek Inc. has agreed with the Union Carbide Corp. to terminate their previously announced agreement for Ametek to buy the Karbate Graphite equipment business from Union Carbide.

title: Property Tax Rise Seen in Rockland
description: Rockland County property owners can expect a 20 percent rise in property taxes in 1984, the chairman of the County Legislature's Budget Committee said today.

title: Masters' Control
description: Control of the season-ending Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden was a major factor in Volvo's decision not to renew its sponsorship of the men's Grand Prix, Bjorn Ahlstrom, the president of the Volvo North American Corporation, said yesterday. Volvo had offered a five-year, $25 million contract to extend its role as sponsor, but the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, which governs the Grand Prix, rejected the offer, he added.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $53,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: ANGRY YANKEES DEFEND THE RULES AND UMPIRES
description: The Yankees defended the sanctity of the baseball rules book today, insisting that Lee MacPhail, the American League president, had been unfair to them and to the umpires in upholding the Kansas City Royals' protest and restoring George Brett's disputed home run of last Sunday.

title: TEXT OF LEAGUE PRESIDENT'S RULING IN BRETT BAT CASE
description: Following is the text of the decision by Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, on the protest of last Sunday's game at Yankee Stadium by the Kansas City Royals.

title: Synthetic Fuels Loan Guarantees
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation announced its intention today to award $2.19 billion in loan and price guarantees to a Colorado oil shale plant.

title: Fujitsu-European Venture Reported
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's leading computer maker, has reached an agreement with International Computer Ltd. of Britain and Siemens A.G. of West Germany to market its supercomputers in Europe through their distribution networks, the Kyodo news service reported.

A JUDGE WHO LIKES ACTION
description: In nearly 34 years on the Federal bench, Irving R. Kaufman has rarely been content to be just a judge. The Commission on Organized Crime announced here today is the latest of a long list of panels and commissions Judge Kaufman has headed or served on.

title: Airbus Industrie
description: Airbus Industrie has offered to help British Airways lease second-hand Boeing aircraft, if the airline agrees to buy 13 A320 aircraft at a discount in the spring of 1988, industry sources said. They said that Airbus was also prepared to offer a discount of 10 to 20 percent on the standard A320 price of $25 million a plane.

title: ALEXANDER ADVANCES IN JERSEY
description: John Alexander of Australia played a strong tactical clay-court game to defeat Libor Pimek of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-3, today to gain the semifinals of the Mutual Benefit Life tennis championship.

title: Animal Test Wounding Banned by Weinberger
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger ordered a reprieve for pigs and goats today until the Defense Department can review the experimental use of animals in research on combat wounds caused by high-powered weapons.

title: SHULTZ SUPPORTS ISRAELI PULLBACK
description: Concluding three days of meetings with Israel's Foreign and Defense Ministers, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that ''any notion'' that the pullback of Israeli forces in Lebanon ''is part of an effort to stay in Lebanon is totally wrong.''

TAX SUIT ASKING $21 MILLION FROM WILSON' LIBYA DEALS
description: The Internal Revenue Service says that Edwin P. Wilson, a former intelligence agent, received $50 million from Libya as a result of business dealings and that he owes $21 million in back taxes and penalties, according to documents recently filed with the United States Tax Court.

OGDEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
COURT MODIFIES A.T.& T. BREAKUP
description: The Federal judge presiding over the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed in part yesterday to an A.T.& T. request and modified one of his conditions for approval of the company's plan to divest itself of its local operating companies.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

SALVADOR GUERRILLA UNITS ABANDON A USEFUL TACTIC
description: One of the most miltarily useful and innovative tactics to emerge from the guerrilla war in El Salvador has involved not pulling triggers.

title: Man Falls on Wire On the New Haven
description: A man jumped or fell 35 feet to his death from a fence above the railroad tracks of the New Haven line here today, hitting an electrical wire and causing fires that forced power to be shut off on the line during the evening rush, fire officials said.

title: TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
DRESHER INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
Carving the Shoreham Turkey
description: New York's Governor Cuomo deserves a cheer for his veto of a bill that would have limited the rate increases needed to pay for Long Island's new Shoreham nuclear plant. Ostensibly a plan to phase in costs over 10 years, the measure was only the Legislature's cynical effort to duck responsibility for a multibillion-dollar nuclear turkey.

title: BALLET: NATALIA MAKAROVA WITH NUREYEV
description: RUDOLF NUREYEV and Natalia Makarova had never danced on the same stage together in the United States until Wednesday night when both appeared as guests with Roland Petit's Ballet National de Marseilles.

title: ART: SHOW OF DRAWINGS AT XAVIER FOURCADE
description: AMONG the summer exhibitions in dealers' galleries, the one that stands out for breadth of outlook and weight of representation is the show of drawings at Xavier Fourcade, 36 East 75th Street. Mr. Fourcade has taken his own artists, mixed them with some major European figures and rounded off the whole thing with four bronze heads by William Crozier.

title: Cuomo Reappoints Wagner
description: Governor Cuomo today reappointed former Mayor Robert F. Wagner of New York City as a member of the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, for a term ending July 1, 1989. Mr. Wagner was first named to the board in 1976.

title: Cadbury Aide Is Named Rank's Chief Executive
description: After a four-month search, the Rank Organization, Britain's hotelto-copier conglomerate, has appointed Michael B. Gifford as group chief executive, effective Sept. 1.

title: POP MUSIC AT THE SUMMERPIER
description: BETTY CARTER, the most resourceful, musical and eloquent singer in jazz today, is opening this year's Summerpier series of jazz concerts tonight at 8 o'clock at the just-reopened South Street Seaport. Admission is free. You can simply pack a blanket or a chair, take the IRT express, Nos. 2, 4 or 5, to Fulton Street (or call 669-9400 for alternative directions) and sit listening to Miss Carter's virtuosic scat-singing while the Seaport's historic sailing vessels rock gently at anchor and traffic rumbles a low-key counterpoint from the spidery heights of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: 2 Previous Cases Cited
description: Lee MacPhail, the American League president, cited two pine-tar incidents in the 1975 season in his ruling yesterday on the George Brett home run. One reached him as a protest; the other, involving the Yankees, did not.

title: A CURRENT VIEW OF AMERICAN INDIANS
description: THE American Indian has been a character on television since television began; he was an abiding preoccupation for the people who made movies long before that. In a real way, of course, the American Indian has been invisible, too. Television documentaries examine social problems of the reservations; movies may deal with Federal treaties. There still isn't much shown about the present culture and heritage of the Indians other than an occasional glance at their arts and crafts.

title: The Sandinista Puzzle
description: The Reagan Administration apparently is convinced that the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua has perverted the genuine democratic revolution of 1979 into a Communist dictatorship -at least that the nine commandantes who run the state are moving inexorably in that direction.

WOMAN SEEKS A PLACE IN THE DUGOUT
description: ''BLUE SKIES AGAIN,'' which opens today at the Guild Theater, successfully demonstrates so many different kinds of ineptitude that it might well be studied in film schools as a lesson in how not to make a genre movie. This one is about the baseball rookie who becomes a major league star, not overnight but in half an inning with one hit.

description: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its striking musicians met yesterday for two and a half hours, but the talks broke off again and the company presented an ultimatum that if a settlement is not reached by Aug. 15, all performances until Sept. 15 will be canceled.

title: Olympic Torch Relay To Help Youth Sports
description: A cross-country program that could generate as much as $30 million for youth athletics in the United States will be tied to the carrying of the Olympic torch from New York City to the Los Angeles Olympics next year.

title: CHEERING THRONG JAMS FULTON STREET FOR OPENING
description: As workers looked down from unfinished buildings and carpenters lugged ladders and toolboxes through the good-natured crowd, thousands of cheering people jammed into Fulton Street yesterday to celebrate the opening of the South Street Seaport.

title: Money Is Stolen in Break-In At Mondale's Headquarters
description: A burglar stole several hundred dollars in cash and a videotape recorder from Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign headquarters, the police reported Wednesday.

ART: PRINTS OF MASTERS AND OTHERS
description: AT Associated American Artists until Aug. 5, there are prints as far as the eye can see. Farther than that, actually, for this establishment, which is situated at 663 Fifth Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets, has a branch in Philadelphia, too. Currently, there are prints to be seen at the Museum of Modern Art also (in the lowerlevel lobby), but they are another matter, being fewer, newer, larger and mostly in color.

title: CITY CHILDREN PLAY AND LEARN IN VERMONT
description: Something new has been added to this genteel landscape of fields, woods, New England clapboards and mountains that define the horizon like walls of green pillows.

title: RATES JUMP ON VOLCKER TESTIMONY
description: Prices plunged and yields rose for long-term Government securities and corporate bonds yesterday after Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that corporate credit needs were beginning to clash with Treasury borrowings to finance the Federal deficit.

title: Politician Denied AccessTo Jailed I.R.A. Members
description: The British Government today barred an Ulster politician from visiting jailed members of the Irish Republican Army.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Tom Seaver tries to slow the pace of the surging Pirates. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. The decision in the George Brett bat case has trimmed the Yankees' hot streak a bit. Still, they go into Chicago having won 11 of their last 12, rather than 12 of their last 13, and Don Baylor goes in with 16 hits in his last 32 times at bat. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Golf United States Women's Open, second round, at Tulsa, Okla. Janet Anderson tries to retain her title.

description: The Mexican Government has sent to private bank creditors a draft refinancing agreement covering $20 billion owed by state agencies, it was announced yesterday. The draft agreement was prepared by Mexico and its bank advisory committee.

description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block and his wife, Sue, went grocery shopping this afternoon, and dozens of reporters went with them.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 34-year-old Bronx woman, Bernadette Brown, was arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping a 3-old-month girl she had been minding. The infant, Lindsay Lugo, had been left by her mother, Aixa Lugo, with the baby-sitter in the family apartment at 1605 Walton Avenue on Tuesday.

title: GENTLE TRANSITION AT LEHMAN

title: KENNETH B. CLARK AND THE N.A.A.C.P.
description: To the Editor: I would like to commend Dr. Kenneth B. Clark for his excellent article concerning the debilitated condition of the N.A.A.C.P. f space had allowed, I am certain Dr. Clark would have pointed out the nonexistence of effective N.A.A.C.P. action at the local level, which is quite disturbing considering the range and importance of local issues: police brutality, alienation and antisocial behavior among youth, institutionalized economic deprivation, etc.

title: 'CRADLE' CAST REVIVES THE SPIRIT OF THE 30'S
description: All three were born long after that historic opening night in 1937. The oldest, Randle Mell, is only 31. He dances and sings and shouts his exuberant way through the role of Larry Foreman, the union organizer in ''The Cradle Will Rock,'' Marc Blitzstein's labor opera now in revival at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. He also plays the corrupt artist Dauber.

description: For the first time in 36 years, Delta Air Lines Inc. reported a loss for its fiscal year, which ended June 30. Economic Scene; The Spencer Prophecies
description: THE economic philosophy of the Reagan Administration is in some ways closely akin to that of Herbert Spencer, the 19th-century British philosopher, who took it as axiomatic that the continued expansion of the role of government reduces the field of individual initiative, prevents development of self-reliant, thoughtful and altruistic people, and eventually produces infantile adults, complete with ''bib and papspoon,'' who expect the state to feed and care for them.

title: A TASK FOR ARMENIANS
description: This month's murder of a Turkish consular official in Brussels, the bombing at Orly Airport that killed seven and the attack on the Turkish Ambassador's residence in Lisbon in which another seven people died, were only the latest incidents of violence by Armenian terrorists against Turkish targets. In the last eight years, 27 Turkish diplomats and some innocent bystanders have been killed or wounded in such attacks.

It concerns a handsome prince, his beautiful bride and a band of sidekicks something like Robin Hood's, not to mention an enchanted movable mountain and a little golden gizmo that has magical powers.

title: West German Inflation
description: West Germany's Federal Statistics Office said consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July from June. Economists had expected a month-to-month rise after an increase in West Germany's value added tax to 14 percent from 13 percent took effect July 1.

description: President Reagan today named a 20-member commission that he said would spend nearly three years analyzing organized crime and recommend judicial and legislative changes to help fight it.

title: AT SEAPORT, OLD NEW YORK WITH A NEW LOOK
description: THE new South Street Seaport, which opened yesterday in Lower Manhattan, is not quite little old New York, but it is certainly trying very hard to be. The complex of restored old buildings, cobblestone streets and carefully designed new structures centered on Fulton Street beside the East River is as elaborate an evocation of the New York of the 19th century as we are ever likely to see. What is most remarkable about it is that it is an evocation done, for the most part, with neither the literalness of Colonial Williamsburg nor the cuteness of Disneyland. This assemblage of several blocks' worth of shops, restaurants, cafes and exhibitions is made up as much of things that are new as of things that are old - and surprisingly, instead of breaking an illusion of 19th-century perfection, the new parts of this place make it all the richer and deeper an urban experience.

title: Light Japanese fare for hot weather
description: IF ever a restaurant was perfectly suited to its location and to the season, it is Kodama, a trim, bright Japanese restaurant on 45th Street, just west of Eighth Avenue. The raw-fish specialties and small intricate dishes of dumplings, grilled eggplant and chilled bean curd, the light grilled-fish specialties and the cold-noodle combinations are just right for our hot, humid summer. By coincidence, these dishes are equally suitable for pretheater dining, when lightness before the curtain goes up can prevent drowsiness once it is up.

title: VOLCKER WARNS THAT RATES MAY RISE
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the forces that could lead to a new rise in interest rates were building in the economy.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 29, 1983; International

This is 50 percent more than Moscow had obligated itself to buy in the past. U.S. officials described the accord as ''symbolic of the normalization'' of farm trade between the two countries. (Page A1.)

title: Greek Envoy to U.S. Named

He said Mr. Papoulias would replace Ambassador Nicholas Karandreas, who resigned for personal reasons. It was not announced when Mr. Papoulias would assume his duties in Washington.

Political leaders would do the people a favor if they climbed down off the barricades and put together a bold, comprehensive policy that answered both the economic and security problems of Central America. To ignore one or the other is sheer folly.

title: POP JAZZ
description: OVER the last few summers, the Hudson River Valley has become a center for world music, with two annual festivals that bring together musicians from five continents. The second of the two takes place tomorrow - Sunday in case of rain - at Bear Mountain State Park, where musicians who work in such American traditions as mountain music, blues and jazz will perform along with jugglers, storytellers, Celtic folk revivalists, Indian classical musicians, Turkish musicians, a Senegalese griot and a pan-African pop band.

title: EGYPT ACTS TO SHIELD NATURE FROM MODERN LIFE'S RAVAGES
description: Egypt has enacted its first conservation legislation in modern history. The law was approved July 20 by the People's Assembly in the waning hours of the summer session, after more than 24 hours of intermittent debate. The act has not yet been published in the Government Register but an unofficial English translation has been made available by environmentalists.

title: The Human Tide Ebbs a Little
description: True or false: (1) In poor countries, more people means less food. (2) Fewer infant deaths means bigger families. (3) A large proportion of Roman Catholics means no chance for population control.

title: COURT BARS RESCINDING PAROLE
description: The State Court of Appeal ruled today that Gov. George Deukmejian had exceeded his authority in rescinding the parole date of a convicted killer, William Archie Fain, and ordered his release from prison. The scheduled parole of Mr. Fain, who was convicted of the 1967 killing of a teen-ager, had set off a wide public protest.

Dogs Attacking Dogs
description: T he A.S.P.C.A. and the Animal Medical Center believe that organized dogfights, similar to cockfights, are increasing in New York City. Both are illegal.

Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds dropped $550 million, to $165 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

description: Three Democratic Presidential contenders sharing a platform with the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that they believed they could win the Presidency with a black running mate.

title: Record sales at 2 houses.
description: CHRISTIE'S and Phillips, Son & Neale, the second and third largest art-auction houses, after Sotheby Parke Bernet, achieved record sales worldwide this season, according to figures released yesterday by the two London-based concerns. The Christie's totals for the season, which ends officially on Aug. 31, were a substantial gain over its previous record year, 1981, and the Phillips total was well above its 1980 record.

description: An appeals court today upheld $550 million in rate increases for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company. The increases were approved by the Board of Public Utilities to pay for costs the utility incurred in the Three Mile Island nuclear plant accident.

title: JANUARY RISE TO 75 IS PUT OFF
description: As workers prepared for tomorrow's fare increase to 50 cents on PATH trains between Manhattan and New Jersey, Port Authority officials said yesterday that a second increase, which would have raised the fare to 75 cents as of next Jan. 1, had been put off for five months.

title: E.P.A. STUDY GROUP MAY URGE 50% CUT IN ACID RAIN EMISSIONS
description: A group appointed by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to study acid rain has drafted a proposal that includes a 50 percent cut in sulfur dioxide emissions in 21 Eastern states. The figure is double what the Reagan Administration is reported to have been considering.

title:
PATENTS;
A Game Based on Golf
description: James W. Boswell, president of Sports Innovations of Tallahassee, Fla., was granted a patent this week for a game apparatus he has named ''Scramble-Golf and Country Club.'' He says the equipment can be set up at a golf course or at home.

title: MONEY SUPPLY INCREASES $1.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $1.4 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended July 20, heightening fears in the already nervous credit markets that interest rates will rise.

title: UNC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 30, 1983
description: International No reduction in covert aid for Nicaraguan rebels is planned by the Reagan Administration, senior Administration officials said, following the House vote Thursday to cancel such aid by Sept. 30. The vote is not binding unless it is approved by the Senate and signed by President Reagan, which are considered unlikely. Administration officials dismissed the vote as ''partisan politics.'' (Page 1, Col. 6.) Cuba would halt military aid to Nicaragua if agreement is reached for all countries to stop sending arms and advisers to Central America, Fidel Castro said in remarks broadcast on American television. In response, President Reagan said that he was willing to give Mr. Castro ''the benefit of the doubt.'' Administration officials said, however, that the United States could not accept any agreement for the withdrawal of foreign military forces from Central America unless it is verifiable. (1:5.)

title: Maryland Aide Guilty Of Food Stamp Fraud
description: A Federal jury today convicted a Maryland State Senator, Tommie Broadwater, and four other people of handling illegally obtained food stamps through a supermarket Mr. Broadwater owned in a Washington suburb.

title: New Mayoral Spokesman
description: M ayor Koch has appointed William Rauch, an aide to Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper, to be his press secretary. The 32-year-old Mr. Rauch (pronounced RAU) had been the Mayor's advance man from 1978 until earlier this year, when he went to work for Mr. Lipper.

title: Rent Office Blocks Tudor City Towers
description: The City Rent Control Office has denied Harry Helmsley permission to build apartment towers on the two parks in Tudor City. The Helmsley organization will appeal, according to a lawyer for the group, Alan M. Gelb.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Net income Share earnings for the latest quarter include a foreign exchange loss of $250,000 and a gain of $400,000 from the sale of fixed assets.

Celtic Deal Collapses
description: Steve Belkin has withdrawn his offer to buy the Boston Celtics, saying reports linking him to former business associates convicted of bookmaking would only detract from the reputation of the National Basketball Association franchise. Belkin, 36, is owner of Trans National Tours, which had agreed to a reported $12 million to $15 million buyout of the Celtics.

description: On any school day 50,000 people are studying or working at the sunny, palm-dotted campus of the University of California at Los Angeles. Hundreds of thousands more live near the campus in neighborhoods of upper middle-class apartments and homes.

title: A VICTIM IS ARRESTED
description: Three explosions today ripped through a downtown hotel owned by the followers of an Indian guru and injured two people, including a California man who was later charged with arson.

title: Cam Fella Sets Roosevelt Record
description: Cam Fella, the 1982 harness horse of the year, turned in the fastest mile in Roosevelt Raceway's 43-year history tonight in winning the first leg of the United States Pacing Championship Series in 1:56 2/5.

title: Selassie of Ethiopia

title: CONGRESS VOTES FOOD STAMP MONEY
description: Congress, hoping to avert a threatened cutback in food stamp benefits, gave final approval today to a stopgap spending bill containing $1.2 billion for food stamps and a $9,138 pay increase for senators.

title: Bridge: New York Players Gained Mixed Record in Nationals
description: In every national championship tournament, there are four or five major championships and more than 20 minor ones. In New Orleans last week, the New York players did fairly well in the major events, with Drew Casen and Alan Kudisch winning the master mixed teams; Kathie Wei, Judi Radin, Gail Moss and Jacqui Mitchell forming the nucleus of the winning women's Swiss team; Ira Rubin winning the men's Swiss, and the Slaner team reaching the final of the Spingold Teams.

title: ZIP-A-DEE-DOO-DAH!
description: For a national March to Mediocrity, how about the sloppy cadence of your nine-digit ZIP code? Sponsored by your Postal Service, the badly designed ZIP Plus 4 invites errors, resists memorization.

DU PONT RISES 9.7%; SUPERIOR OIL OFF
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter increased 9.7 percent, aided by cost cuts and strong gains by its fibers and polymer products businesses. Sales advanced 4.7 percent.

description: The unexpected announcement last week that The Houston Post was for sale has stirred speculation here over whether this city is in for an old-fashioned newspaper war like the one that has gripped Dallas, its rival city to the north.

Stone, the United States special envoy, said today that Nicaragua should open talks with its opponents and ''fulfill the promises'' it made when the Sandinistas took power in 1979. Mr. Stone, on the ninth day of a visit to the region, also said United States ships now off Nicaragua may ''decrease the risks'' of fighting in Central America. He arrived in Colombia from San Jose, Costa Rica.

description: He seemed to have it all. First captain and president of his class at West Point. All-American running back and Heisman Trophy winner. Rhodes Scholar. Ph.D. from Princeton. White House Fellow. Paratrooper. Ranger. Combat infantryman. Holder of the Legion of Merit. Brigadier general at the age of 43.

description: For animal welfare activists, the Pentagon's about-face last week on shooting dogs to train military surgeons in the treatment of gunshot wounds was a rare success story. They say the victory illustrates a paradoxical dimension of the animal welfare issue in the nation's capital.

Jones, Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, became chairman today of the panel's Coast Guard and Navigation subcommittee. It had been headed by Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, who was censured by the House last week for having had a sexual relationship with a male Congressional page in 1973 and automatically lost the chairmanship.

3 AMERICANS ARE WINNERS IN INTERNATIONAL BALLET COMPETITION

Katherine Healy, 14 years old, of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was awarded a first prize in the junior division. Bonnie Moore, 18, of Phoenix won a junior third prize, and Maria Teresa Del Real, 20, of Miami won a third prize in the senior division.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Short Vacation For Police Commissioner

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A 13-year-old girl who wandered into a park area where children were playing was raped for 40 minutes by two youths, but several people stood by without helping until an 11-year-old boy went to call the police, the authorities said today.

title: GARVEY'S STREAK ENDED
description: Steve Garvey, the National League record-holder for consecutive games played, suffered a dislocated left thumb tonight in the first game of a doubleheader against the Atlanta Braves, bringing an end to his streak at 1,207 games.

title: LEBANESE PHALANGISTS URGE FORCES TO END PROTEST OVER ISRAELI MOVES
description: The Christian Phalangist militia called today on its supporters in southern Lebanon to end their protest against moves by the Israeli occupation forces to close Phalangist offices in the area.

title: Crimes of Rage
description: The violence that followed the Diana Ross concert in Central Park again focused attention on New York City's police: Could they have prevented the rampage of robberies and random beatings? Were too few assigned to the event and deployed improperly? Might some have slowed down on the job in petulant response to charges of brutality?

title: PIRATE HOME RUNS TOP SEAVER
description: Tom Seaver pitched a superlative game at Shea Stadium last night and held the Pirates to four hits in eight innings. Unfortunately for him, two of those hits were towering homers that enabled first-place Pittsburgh to win for the second night in the five-game series, 2-1, at Shea Stadium.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $14,647,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,636,000.

Farm Policy In E.E.C.
description: Common Market executives offered proposals today aimed at cutting $7.5 billion in farm subsidies over the next three years in a move they hope will save the organization from bankruptcy.

title: President of El Salvador Says Elections Will Be Postponed
description: Provisional President Alvaro Magana said tonight that elections for a new president would not be held this year as planned because of delays over passage of a new Salvadoran constitution.

title: Massey-Ferguson, British Link Cited
description: The British Government, represented by the Export Credits Guarantee Department, has a stake in Massey-Ferguson Ltd. which could convert into a maximum equity holding of 18.6 percent, Government sources said.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reversal on Brett Has Martin Upset
description: Billy Martin's time off in Texas on Thursday, an open day on the Yankee schedule, was a total loss. First he found out that Lee MacPhail, the American League president, had ruled against the Yankees on the subject of George Brett's pine-tar home run. Then he went fishing on Eagle Lake with his 18-year-old son, Billy Joe, and came back empty-handed.

title: I.M.F. BILL ADVANCES IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives, with the backing of the Democratic leadership and the Reagan Administration, defeated two amendments today that would have killed a bill increasing by $8.4 billion the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund. The defeats apparently paved the way for approval of the bill next week.

title: License Revoked
description: California racing officials have terminated a temporary owners' license granted to a Malibu woman earlier this month after learning that she was the wife of Anthony Ciulla, the convicted race-fixer.

title: Snead, 71, Goes Like 60
description: He is 71 years old now, he has trouble with his eyes, and it's hardly surprising that Sam Snead misses some easy putts these days. ''I out-thought myself,'' Snead said Thursday after missing two key putts during a friendly round at the Homestead Lower Cascade Golf Course in Hot Springs, Va.

title: SOMETHING YOU CAN COUNT ON
description: People say things are changing too fast these days. It's hard to keep up. First they took convertibles away, now they're back. Then they took gunboat diplomacy away and it's back. Then they took Henry Kissinger away, and now he's back - on the gunboats. There's no way to know what to depend on. They keep changing the rules.

title: BONDHOLDERS HOPE FOR BAILOUT BUT GO TO COURT
description: Carol Levitan, a Dayton, Ohio, woman who owns $250,000 of defaulted Washington Public Power Supply System bonds, believes that the Federal Government will eventually come to the rescue. Irving C. Rosenkrantz, a retired lawyer living in Hollywood, Fla., who owns $20,000 of the issues, is pessimistic about a bailout. And Ernie Anderson, a semiretired rancher in Kettle Falls, Wash., who invested $200,000, simply cannot understand how a contract between utilities can be worth even less than his bonds, which now bring 15 cents on the dollar.

title: WITTY ACTOR WON OSCAR

description: Poland's Western creditor governments agreed in principle today to resume talks with Warsaw on rescheduling its debt, lifting the embargo they imposed after martial law was declared 18 months ago, the French Finance Ministry announced.

description: The Treasury Department announced today that it would sell its rights to purchase 14.4 million shares of Chrysler Corporation stock - a sale likely to bring the Government a profit of at least $250 million, officials said.

title: JUNE TRADE DEFICIT NARROWED
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $4.9 billion in June from a record $6.9 billion in May, the Commerce Department reported today. It pointed to a drop in oil imports and a strong export performance.

description: At least 33 people were killed today in a new outbreak of violence in the Sri Lankan capital, a Government spokesman said.

title: Woman, 88, Slain

The woman, Josephine Nuvolonia, of 316 East 49th Street, was found on her kitchen floor at 10:05 P.M. by her son Leo, who had become worried when he could not reach her, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell. The apartment had been ransacked.

title: POP: JOAN ARMATRADING
description: In a pop music climate that tends to reward performers for doing one thing well, Joan Armatrading goes about as far as an individual can go in evoking interlocking cultures and diverse, complicated personalities. At Pier 84 on Wednesday, the West Indian-born, British-reared singer, songwriter and guitarist touched more than half a dozen different stylistic bases, with songs that spanned a wide psychological spectrum, without losing her quirky individuality.

title: BOLIVAR'S IDEALS AND 1983
description: ''So while America lives, the echo of his name shall resonate in the best and most virile of our hearts.'' Thus wrote Jose Marti, the Cuban revolutionary poet, of Simon Bolivar, who led the struggle to liberate northern South America from Spanish rule. Leaders of the nations created in that process - Venezuela, Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia - celebrated the 200th anniversary of Bolivar's birth in Caracas last Sunday and, echoing his words, issued a ringing appeal for unity and peace in a continent free of foreign interference.

This year the Mets pay tribute to their 1973 team, which won the National League pennant. Among the veterans of that team who will be present is Willie Mays. (Television - Channel 9, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 4 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30) Red Sox vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Boston. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Football Pittsburgh Steelers vs. New Orleans Saints, Hall of Fame Game, at Canton, Ohio. This is the National Football League's exhibition opener, played in conjunction with the induction into the Hall of Sonny Jurgensen, Bobby Mitchell, Paul Warfield, Bobby Bell and Sid Gillman. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Sting, at Chicago. The Cosmos look for their first victory over the Sting this season, having lost two previous games. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Racing Saratoga Race Track, 1:30 P.M. Deputy Minister is the early 5-2 favorite in the Whitney Handicap. title: RECITAL: ROBERT GLASGOW
description: Because their viable repertory is admittedly limited, organists can be forgiven occasional performances of works that might not pass muster musically on the programs of, say, pianists or symphony orchestras. But when organists start devoting the bulk of recital programs to marginalia, as Robert Glasgow did at Riverside Church on Tuesday evening, the thoughtful listener may well protest.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD SET UP GROUPS TO BATTLE CRIME
description: In Greenwich Village, some residents are up in arms about street prostitution. Exasperated by what they see as the Criminal Court's lack of response to the situation, they have taken matters into their own hands. They record the license numbers of cars whose occupants patronize the prostitutes, then contact the registered owners and threaten to expose them to friends, families and employers.

Ten springs have come and gone since he first stepped onto the field in a Met uniform, a 6-foot-4-inch rookie outfielder with the long legs and hunched shoulders that inspired his nickname. The Stork inspired a group of young women from Brooklyn to call themselves the Storkettes, and to sit and cheer and print a newsletter about the doings of their hero.

Minniefield had 562 assists and averaged 8.7 points in his 4 seasons at Kentucky and was known for good defense. Minniefield was the ninth player selected in the second round of the N.B.A. draft, by the Dallas Mavericks, who traded him to the Nets.

The girls are the ones scampering about in nighties or towels or flimsy underwear, most of which they have a way of losing at the slightest provocation. The boys are the sweaty, breathless ones who chase desperately after the girls, hoping to take Polaroids of them while they're undressing, or maybe watch them in the shower.

Adviser to Solidarity Is Freed in Poland
description: A leading adviser of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, Prof. Bronislaw Geremek, was freed from jail today, a source at his home in Warsaw said.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL OUTLAWING DRIVERS' USE OF HEADPHONES
description: Governor Cuomo signed a bill today making it illegal to wear headphones while driving a car or motorcycle or peddling a bicycle.

title: COVERT MISSION LIME
description: We have been swamped with complaints from people in Secaucus, Passaic and Bloomfield, N.J. On Thursday night these towns were struck by an accidental drop of soft lime gelatin which, they assert, was released maliciously while we were testing a prototype of our attack dirigible for the Pentagon.

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income.

title: REGENTS APPROVE PLAN TO TOUGHEN COURSE STANDARDS
description: The State Board of Regents today approved a farreaching plan for curriculum and other changes designed to increase academic rigor in public and private schools throughout the state.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
STRESS ON APPEARANCE CITED IN SEX BIAS CASE TESTIMONY
description: A woman who used to be a newscaster for the television station that demoted its anchor Christine Craft testified today that she was appalled when consultants advised her that appearance was more important for women on the air than for men.

title: 9,000 NEW JOBS PREDICTED AS S.I. WINS NAVY BASE
description: A seven-ship Navy group led by the battleship Iowa is to be based on Staten Island, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. told an applauding crowd of New York City political and civic leaders yesterday.

title: Miss Sheehan's 142 Leads 4 by 3 Shots
description: Despite four consecutive bogeys on the front nine and playing for the second day with temperatures over 100 degrees, Patty Sheehan scored another par 71 today to take sole possession of the lead midway through the 38th United States Women's Open.

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,724,000 for the quarter and $3,209,000 for the 9 months and losses on disposal by spin-off of discontinued operations of $3,523,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $710,000 for the quarter and $885,000 for the 9 months.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARENTS GUILTY IN BOY'S DEATH
description: A 20-year-old mother of five children was found guilty of murder today in the beating death of her 3-year-old son. The child's father was convicted of aggravated manslaughter.

title: ALEXANDER IS SUING IN HOWDEN AUDIT
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the United States insurance broker that took big write-offs against earnings because of troubles at its Alexander Howden Group subsidiary in Britain, said today that it had sued the firms that audited Howden before it was acquired in 1982.

title: THIRST THAT'S HARD TO QUENCH
description: A thirst for travel is a common phenomenon that is easily understood. Thirst while traveling is equally common and somewhat harder to explain. Just put me down 100 or 1,000 miles from home and I am almost instantly and intensely thirsty, especially if admonished not to drink the local tap water. Though memories of such grand thirsts tend to fade once I am back home, it takes only a few minutes on foreign soil to induce the syndrome. Parched All the Way

title: UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR 'ATOMIC CITY'
description: At the headquarters of the Washington Public Power Supply System here in this desert-like country southeast of Seattle, across the Cascade Mountains, morale is as low as it is among the investors left holding the the system's defaulted bonds.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Court Approves Subway Escalators
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Albany ruled yesterday that new escalators could be installed at the Herald Square subway station without providing access for the handicapped.

title: COMPUTALOG GEARHART reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL GETS ACCESS TO REAGAN'S FILES
description: Representative Donald J. Albosta said today that the White House had agreed to give his House subcommittee ''direct access'' to portions of President Reagan's 1980 campaign files so that investigators could search for materials stolen or passed along from President Carter's campaign.

title: BLOCK OFFERS WHEAT CHANGES
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, in an effort to get Congress to act on his proposal to freeze crop target prices, today unveiled two options for cutting wheat acreage for 1984.

title: PRODUCTIVITY UP SHARPLY
description: Productivity at the nation's businesses, excluding agriculture, rose at an annual rate of 4.3 percent in the second quarter, the best showing in more than two years, the Labor Department said today.

title: Convicted Briber Becoming Witness
description: A South Plainfield garbage company executive sentenced to two years in prison for bribery will become a state witness in continuing investigations of the solid-waste industry, Criminal Justice Director Donald L. Belsole said today.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and year reflect a charge of $1.3 million for litigation costs.

title: STOCKS FALL ON A WAVE OF SELLING
description: Stock prices slid sharply under an unrelenting wave of selling by institutional investors concerned about rising interest rates. The selling, which began Wednesday and continued Thursday, culminated yesterday in a drop of 17.13 points in the Dow Jones industrial average, putting it at 1,199.22, the first time the indicator closed below 1,200 since July 19, when it closed at 1,197.12.

title: Bernard J. Ridder Sr.; Newspapers' Publisher
description: Bernard J. Ridder Sr., former publisher of The Journal of Commerce in New York and board member of the Knight-Ridder newspaper chain, died of cancer today at his home. He was 70 years old.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INDICATORS CLIMBED 1% LAST MONTH
description: The index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to forecast the direction of the economy, rose 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. ACTION CALLED PROVOCATIVE
description: The Foreign Ministry claimed today that the United States Navy frigate Clifton Sprague was less than 15 miles off Nicaragua's Pacific coast in ''an attitude that is clearly provocative and offensive to the national sovereignty.''

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Mike Brown, p itcher, on the 21-day disabled list; re- c alled Dennis Boyd, pitcher, from Paw- t ucket of the International League. CHICAGO (AL) - Recalled Chris N yman, first baseman, from the team's f arm club in Denver; optioned Lorenzo G ray, infielder, to Denver.

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: RAISING FIGS- IT'S A FAMILY TRADITION; by SUSAN GILBERT
description: As Bart Irace sat in his Queens backyard with family and friends, he talked about figs and how much he loves eating and growing them. ''In Italy, I'd pick a fig right off the tree, cut it in half and put it on bread with a slice of cheese,'' he said. ''Just like a steak sandwich.''

title: U.S. Requests the Extradition Of F.A.L.N. Member in Mexico
description: The United States has formally requested the extradition of William Morales, a fugitive F.A.L.N. terrorist convicted of bombings in New York City, a spokesman for the American Embassy said today.

title: SOVIET SAYS HARE KRISHNA CLOAKS HIDE C.I.A. DAGGERS
description: Although no sightings have been reported yet of saffron-robed youths chanting rapturously in Soviet streets, the Hare Krishna movement seems to have made sufficient inroads into the Soviet Union to alarm the authorities.

title: AS CROWDS GROW IN THE HAMPTONS, SO DO QUESTIONS
description: CROWD counts are notoriously unreliable. They are also irresistible. Someone, for example, could not resist estimating the number of people in Southampton Town over the big Fourth of July weekend at 300,000, a figure that eventually found its way into local press reports. The 300,000 figure - about the same number of people as inhabited all of Suffolk County just 30 years ago, and almost seven times Southampton Town's present year-round population - might have been greeted with considerable skepticism had the evidence of this year's apparently unprecedented influx not been so highly visible in the Hamptons.

title: Katherine Woodard Marries J.G. Bell
description: The marriage of Katherine Manly Woodard, assistant director of the Edward Thorp Gallery, to Jeffrey Graham Bell, president of Morgan Research Inc., an executive recruiting concern, took place in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: GOLDEN ANNIVERSARY
description: Half a century ago black bridge players had virtually no opportunities to play in clubs and tournaments. They therefore formed their own organization; and although the discrimination that provoked their action withered away in the 1950's, the American Bridge Association has continued to flourish. This week it celebrates its 50th anniversary in New York, where its Summer Nationals will begin Thursday at the New York Statler Hotel.

title: POP-SONG LYRICIST
description: Howard Dietz, who put words to more than 500 songs, including such popular classics as ''Dancing in the Dark,'' ''That's Entertainment,'' and ''You and the Night and the Music,'' died of Parkinson's disease yesterday afternoon at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Legal Uncertainty
description: THE fate of the proposed Prattsville, N.Y., pumped-storage hydroelectric project involving Schoharie Reservoir and Esopus Creek appears to hinge on interpretation of procedures to be followed under provisions of Section 401 of the Federal Clean Water Act.

title:
PROOF IN ADVERTISING;
WITH SUGGESTIONS FROM THE AD INDUSTRY
description: EVERY evening, when you and I sit down before our television sets, w e know that along with the news and entertainment we will see a c ertain number of advertising messages. We should be able to accept t he claims made in these commercials as true. The same goes for the a ds we see or hear in magazines, newspapers, radio, posters and all o ther media.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Hartsdale, N.Y. $135,000 *2*25 Shaw Place, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old *2*frame split-level; den, patio, newly painted *2*outside, 0.4 acre; taxes $3,112. Larchmont, N.Y. $252,000 *2*90 Brookside Drive East, 4-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, *2*55-year-old frame colonial; sun room, pool, *2*terrace; taxes $4,925. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $82,500 *2*1719 Summit Street, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old *2*frame Cape Cod; family room, deck, new *2*heating, 0.25 acre; taxes $2,354. Brookfield, Conn. $179,000 *2*5 Bonny Road, 4-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, 5-year-old *2*colonial; 2 fireplaces, 24 days on market, *2*in cul de sac, 1.9 acres, taxes, $2,066 Darien, Conn. $268,500 *2*9 Salisbury Road, 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old *2*ranch; cathedral ceiling in family room, *2*1.8 acres; taxes $3,058. Weston, Conn. $190,000 *2*9 Merry Lane, 4-bedroom, 2-1/2 bath, 13-year-old *2*colonial; in-ground pool, built-in bookcases, *2*2 acres, taxes $3,343 OTHER AREAS Plainview, L.I. $105,250 *2*63 Cedar Drive, 4-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*25-year-old high ranch; formal dining room, *2*family room, den; taxes $2,500 North Bergen, N.J. $93,000 *2*317 74th Street, 3-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*25-year-old high ranch; formal dining room, *2*family room, den; taxes $2,086 Pequannock, N.J. $86,000 *2*30 Ackerson Avenue, 4-bedroom, 1-1/2 bath, *2*22-year-old colonial; all brick, 1-car garage; *2*taxes $2,127

title: THE MOTHER-TO-BE WHO DRINKS
description: YEAR-OLD Tara was the size of a child 12 months younger. Her head looked disproportionately small even for her little body, the slits of her eyes were shorter than normal and her smooth, tightly drawn upper lip lacked the vertical groove that usually runs between the nose and mouth.

title: HARMONIES AND DISCORDS
description: WINTER MUSIC By Karen Rile. 293 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: Car Hits Food Line, Killing One, Hurting 7
description: An automobile ran into a line of elderly and handicapped people waiting to receive surplus food today, killing a woman and injuring seven other people, the police said. The driver of the car was charged with public intoxication.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: NINE months after he narrowly defeated Lawrence J. DeNardis to represent Connecticut's Third Congressional District, Bruce A. Morrison still owes $90,000 in campaign expenses.

title: LACK OF DATA CITED ON ACID RAIN ISSUE
description: ALTHOUGH acid rain is one of the more prominent environmental concerns, its extent and its possible effects in the county remain uncertain. Opinions are often based more on speculation than on hard evidence, officials concede, because detailed information is scarce.

title: A LIBRARY KNOWN AS 'BASEBALL'S ATTIC'
description: Christy Mathewson went into his windup, and a few feet away, Tom Heitz went into a room that brings alive the world of distant baseball summers.

title: Garvey, Streak Ended, Has Surgery
description: Steve Garvey underwent surgery today to repair torn ligaments in his left thumb, an injury that ended his consecutive-game streak Friday night and will sideline him for at least three weeks.

title: Rental Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing Is Held in Manhattan For Suspect in Omega 7 Case
description: Eduardo Arocena, reputed leader of the Omega 7 anti-Castro terrorist group, appeared briefly before a magistrate in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday and was ordered to remain in custody in $1 million bail.

title: Barbara Cook, Aide to the First Lady, Is Married to James Parnham Fabiani
description: Barbara J. Cook, Nancy Reagan's deputy press secretary, was married yesterday to James Parnham Fabiani, a senior associate in the government-relations concern of Schlossberg-Cassidy & Associates in Washington. The Rev. Mark S. Anschutz performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: Jane Winans Has Nuptials
description: Jane Phillips Winans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Winans of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis McKim, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. William I. McKim of New Castle, Pa. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Scot Thompson, o utfielder, to Iowa of the American Associ- a tion; designated Jay Loviglio, infielder, f or assignment; activated Gary Woods, o utfielder; purchased contract of Joe Car- t er, outfielder, from Iowa. BASKETBALL NEW JERSEY (NBA)- Released Dan C alandrillo, former Seton Hall star, Jerry K elly, Oscar Taylor, Keith Bennett, Joe M yers, and Kevin Black, all forwards, and T yren Naulls, guard.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MORRIS PARK
description: SOMETHING in the scene at Angelo & Sons Luncheonette captures the spirit of Morris Park. Joe Minotti, w ho was at the counter the other day dealing with a sandwich and c offee, said cheerfully that Angelo's has ''the worst coffee in the w orld.''

title: ISLAND WHIRL WINS
description: With an eighth of a mile to go, seven of the best horses in the country were strung out across the stretch at Saratoga Race Track today and the Whitney Handicap was anybody's race.

title: Evidence Grows Against Dioxin
description: Scientists cannot prove dioxin causes cancer in humans the same way they can for animals, but leading public health officials have seen enough smoke to suspect a fire. Testifying before a House subcommittee on the environment last week, their message was clear even if their language was cautious. ''No study suggests we should not be concerned,'' said Dr. Vernon N. Houk, director of the environmental health center at the Centers for Disease Control.

title: Fire Threatens Adriatic City
description: A raging forest fire early today threatened the Adriatic resort of Dubrovnik, now packed with more than 50,000 foreign and Yugoslav vacationers. Emergency warnings were issued just after midnight as 2,000 men fought to keep the flames away from fashionable villas overlooking the city.

title: BRAZILIAN POLICE FIND BRUTALITY HABIT-FORMING
description: Andre Franco Montoro, the first elected governor of Sao Paulo in nearly two decades, promised the voters he would humanize a police force that had earned the reputation of being the most violent and unaccountable in Brazil. A notorious battalion known as Rota had killed more than 700 people in the last three years. Members wore black berets and armbands and made the sign of the cross on passing their unit insignia. Rota had its own files and radio communications. It answered not to the state police chief but to its own commander. Rota members once fired on a police patrol that had disputed jurisdiction during an arrest.

title: LOVE OF LIGHT, LOVE OF SOUND
description: TO the average eye, light is simply light and shadows are a lifeless phenomenon that are of little note except on a blistering hot day. To a professional photographer, however, the intricate play of shadow and light may represent much more.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ABOUT two of every three requests by developers to build homes in the Pine Barrens are approved by the state's Pinelands Commission, according to the panel's own figures.

title: Renaissance
description: To the Business Editor: Your unduly pessimistic article about Detroit's Renaissance Center (July 3) would have left your readers better informed had it told them about the following positive outcomes of Henry Ford's decision to invest in downtown Detroit:

title: Susan Freeman Wed To Francis Martin 3d
description: Susan Thompson Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Thompson Freeman of Geneva, Ill., was married yesterday to Francis Martin 3d, son of Mr. Martin Jr. of Reno and La Quinta, Calif., and Katherine M. Martin of San Francisco. The Rev. Robert F. Grafe performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Portland, Ore.

title: WHAT RIGHT-TO-KNOW ACT MEANS
description: THE Worker and Community Right-to-Know Act has been overwhelmingly passed by the State Legislature and is currently waiting approval by Governor Kean. As the sponsors of this landmark piece of legislation, both State Senator Daniel J. Dalton (Democrat of Blackwood) and I would like to explain what this bill will mean to the residents of New Jersey.

title: U.S. SAID TO DELAY SOME WAR GAMES
description: The Defense Department has been prevented from deploying ground combat forces to Honduras for maneuvers until November because of prior troop commitments, costs and lack of transport, according to senior military officers.

title: PALESTINIAN STUDENTS NOW GRADUATE INTO UNCERTAINTY
description: Once they could count on lucrative jobs in the Persian Gulf or in the service sector at home. But this year many Palestinians graduating from the growing universities in the Israelioccupied West Bank face futures as manual laborers or without jobs at all. The classes of 1983 have seen prospects in the oil-rich countries dried up by economic and political troubles, while the limited number of worthwhile positions in the West Bank have been largely taken by earlier graduates.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Talladega 500 Nascar race, at Talladega, Ala. Cale Yarborough was an early qualifier for the pole position, pushing his Chevrolet to 201.744 m.p.h., but the defending champion is Darrell Waltrip, who was the 10th qualifier with 198.322. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, doubleheader, 1:05 P.M. The Banner Day competition will take place between the two games. Mike Torrez (6-12) and Walt Terrell (2-4) are the Met starters against Lee Tunnell (5-3) and Jose DeLeon (2-0). (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1 P.M.)
