Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago, 2:15 P.M. Dave Righetti tries to win his 12th game, against the surging Sox and Brett Burns (5-6). (Television - Channel 11, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 2:15 P.M.).

title: ACCESSORIES TAKE ON A STARRING ROLE
description: There is an ulterior motive for the special attention to accessories in the couture collections for fall and winter introduced this week.

title: Harvey Perloff, U.C.L.A. Dean And Aide to John F. Kennedy
description: Harvey S. Perloff, an adviser to President Kennedy on Latin America and the dean of the Graduate School of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of California at Los Angeles since 1968, died today at the age of 68.

title: JACKSON BROWNE BELTS IT OUT
description: ''In pop music in the 1970's, there was an emphasis on writing, on the song,'' the singer-songwriter Jackson Browne recalled recently. ''But nobody wants to make songwriter records anymore, not even songwriters. It just isn't as much fun as wearing snakeskin shoes.''

title: Laura Knapp Buck Engaged to Wed Samuel Rhoads Marshall in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Clifton Buck of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Knapp Buck, to Samuel Rhoads Marshall of Haverford, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall of Devon, Pa.

title: PROPOSALS CLOUD IMMIGRATION BILL
description: Four committees in the House of Representatives have proposed major amendments to a comprehensive immigration bill, clouding the prospects for passage of the legislation.

title: The Muddy Aims of a Bad War
description: So great are the powers of a pertinacious President that Mr. Reagan may yet wangle from Congress the legal fig leaf he needs to continue his not-so-secret war against Nicaragua. Distaste for this adventure is as much visceral as reasoned. It deeply affronts the American sense of fair play for a big country to promote the lawless subversion of a tiny neighbor.

title:
GARDENING;
DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS PERIL GARDENS
description: EARLIER this month the Central Park thermometer registered the highest temperature recorded for that date, and, according to the weather forecasters, the period ahead promises both higher than normal temperatures and lower than normal rainfall. This adds up to a combination of drought and heat stress for our gardens.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. ** Comparable data unavailable because method of computing home ownership costs has changed.

title: E. 57TH ST. LOT FOCUS OF DEVELOPMENT CLASH
description: A26,000-SQUARE-FOOT development site in a prime commercial district o n Manhattan's East Side is the subject of a legal fight between the W allace family, which owns the land, and Madison Equities, holders ofa long-term lease on the property.

title: Diplomats Forced To Run Faster in Central America
description: Nine nervous nations met in Panama City over the weekend to seek a way out of the Central American imbroglio before armed conflict spread. Soviet freighters reportedly approaching Nicaragua with arms shipments, American naval units beginning to maneuver in the same waters and massing of troops on the Nicaraguan-Honduran border gave the meeting an air of urgency.

title:
GARDENING;
DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS PERIL GARDENS
description: EARLIER this month the Central Park thermometer registered the highest temperature recorded for that date, and, according to the weather forecasters, the period ahead promises both higher than normal temperatures and lower than normal rainfall. This adds up to a combination of drought and heat stress for our gardens.

title: Topics; High Tension / High Tech; The Case for Stress
description: Back in the 50's, a businessman's ulcers were de rigueur. They signified commitment to high risk and hard labor. By the 60's, however, the ulcer was no longer an honorable wound in the battle for success; now any sacrifice to stress was a shameful surrender to the wrong values.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: Real Art Ways asserts that its eighth annual jazz festival coming up this week is the only New Jazz festival held in New England. Two and a half-hour performances are scheduled at 8 P.M. Friday, Saturday and next Sunday on the Old Statehouse lawn, 800 Main Street, Hartford, and they are free. In the event of rain, the concerts will move to Real Art Ways headquarters, 40 State Street.

title: Making Waves
description: To the Business Editor: Your interesting article (''Corporations Put New Wind in Yachting's Sails,'' July 17) reminded me of my free-wheeling days in Bahrain, when the ''open portfolio'' marketing job at Pan American World Airways gave me the chance to organize the first Pan Am Hobie Cat Regatta in the Arabian Gulf. Now that I have been away from Pan Am for several years, I must admit that as a regular member of Bahrain Yacht Club's Hobie Fleet 438, I had a rather biased role in the project. It is doubtful the race had any immediate measurable effect on Pan Am's load factor in or out of the island, but the company did get its money's worth in publicity.

title: SALE-LEASEBACKS INTRIGUE THE NATION'S MUNICIPALITIES
description: LEASEBACK arrangements, familiar in the world of commercial r eal estate, are arousing attention from municipalities across the c ountry as a means of raising funds for capital construction or i mproving existing facilities. The idea is that the municipality w ould sell a public building to a private investor or group and leasei t back for long-term use.

title: TECHNOLOGY SAID TO INCREASE DANGER OF WAR
description: The rapid improvement of systems of communication and information are making the nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union more dangerous and unstable, a Washington research group warned today in a report.

title: Statistical Abstracts
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH SOCIALISM STUBS ITS TOE
description: PARIS NEARLY two years after President Francois Mitterrand set about to nationalize the country's leading industrial corporations and most of its banks, his hopes of creating what he once described as ''the industrial equivalent of our force de frappe'' is drowning in a sea of red ink. France's embarrassed Socialists are finding that the mighty bastions of French capitalism they pledged to harness for the service of the state, look suspiciously like a row of corporate lemons.

title: ORIGINALITY STANDS OUT IN SCULPTURAL VARIETY
description: UNTIL this century, sculpture usually meant solid, threedimensional representation, and it was presented either on a pedestal or as part of an architectural scheme. Innovations that date from approximately 1910 have brought radical changes in the whole conception of what sculpture might be, and the resulting artistic freedom has unleashed the imagination and stimulated a wealth of stylistic ideas.

title: A BALLET EPIC GEORGE BALANCHINE NEVER FINISHED
description: Last fall, even though hospitalized by the illness that finally ended with his death in April, George Balanchine was still planning the ballet epic he had been thinking of, off and on, for some 40 years. Though it was never actually realized, few projects seem to characterize the idiosyncratic vision of this prolific choreographic genius as profoundly as the work that was to be titled ''The Birds of America.''

title: PSYCHOLOGY APPLIES TO TENNIS, TOO
description: ENGLEWOOD WHEN tennis opponents go up against Ted Farnsworth, they usually find themselves at a double disadvantage. With his steady baseline style, he keeps them on the court for a long time, testing their stamina and concentration. And being a psychology major at Princeton University, he feels that he can outthink them and win the mental duel that is part of a match.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SALT LAKE CITY
description: GEORGE RAINE, a correspondent for Newsweek in San Francisco, was formerly a reporter for The Salt Lake Tribune.

title: Sept. 17 Wedding For Miss Bancroft
description: Gertrude Storey Bancroft, an editor for the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Stephen Linn Akers, an investment banker with DBL Preferred Management, also in New York, plan to be married Sept. 17.

title: ROMANCE SUCCEEDS IN RUTGERS OFFERING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ACCORDING to a spokesman for the Rutgers Theater Company, no worthy work could be found to fill the summer's ''original play'' slot, which ends next Saturday.

title: Cuomo Signs Measure On Privacy Protection
description: Governor Cuomo today signed into law a measure limiting what information state agencies may collect on individuals and how they may distribute that information.

title: SALVADOR REBELS REPORTED TO GET LITTLE ARMS AID
description: The flow of military supplies to Salvadoran rebels from outside the country has been only a trickle for many months, according to officials here and in Washington.

title: TWO YOUNG DEMOCRATS BATTLE IN GREENBURGH
description: TWO young lawyers, each of whom has spent half of his life in politics, are engaged in one of the toughest primary fights in the county - the struggle for the Democratic nomination for County Legislator in the town of Greenburgh.
To the Editor:

title: Home Port: Staten Island
description: Staten Island's ships are about to come in. The Navy said last week the battleship Iowa, a cruiser, three destroyers and two frigates would be based in the borough, creating a $500 million-a-year windfall that will include jobs for 3,200 military personnel and perhaps as many as 6,000 civilians.

title: Cow Power
description: Over the years the Foster Brothers Farm of Middlebury, Vt., has milked more than its 600 cows to keep the largest dairy farm in the Champlain Valley going. In early 1982 the farm added yet another twist: the production of electricity with cow manure.

title: Headliners; Then There Was One
description: Will ''The NBC Nightly News'' be any clearer without Roger Mudd co-anchoring the show from Washington? Network executives said they thought so last week and announced that Mr. Mudd would be dropped from that job in September to become a senior correspondent. With Mr. Mudd in Washington and Tom Brokaw, the other co-anchor, reporting from New York, ''there was no internal logic'' and it was ''confusing,'' said Reuven Frank, the president of NBC News. That explanation didn't wash with Mr. Mudd, who said the network's decision was ''shortsighted.''

title: Matching Houses With Homeless
description: What better way to employ the unemployed than in fixing up places for the displaced, especially if the places happen to be city-owned apartments seized for nonpayment of taxes. That was the gist of a memorandum sent to the New York City Board of Estimate last week by Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr.

title: Dr. Sharon Hochweiss Weds Dr. Gary Horbar
description: Dr. Sharon Hochweiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Hochweiss of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Gary Horbar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Horbar of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Seymour Cohen, past president of the Rabbinical Assembly and the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in New York.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A DISABLED BABY, A MOTHER WITH GUILT
description: MOTHERS of babies afflicted with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, or FAS, have complex social, financial and emtional problems, say professionals who have counseled them.

title: Some Practical Aid for the Arts
description: Stunned by cutbacks of Federal and state funding, cultural organizations across the country have lately faced an existence even more threadbare than is traditionally endured. But a new multimillion-dollar fund established by three philanthropies may soon help keep the audiences inside and the wolves outside.

title: AMENDMENT ON COUNCIL REDISTRICTING FACES BATTLE
description: Opposition is developing among a number of New York politicians to a proposed City Charter amendment that would give the Mayor control of City Council redistricting.

title: NEW HAVEN MAYOR TO FACE NEW FOE
description: IN New Haven, as in Hartford, and Bridgeport, a black man is running for Mayor this year. However, New Haven's Edward White Jr. differs from the others in that he is running as a Republican.

title: Reagan Renews Effort To Restrain Spending
description: President Reagan, citing ''horror stories'' of Government spending similar to those from his Presidential campaign, today pledged once again to restrain the ''growing administrative monster'' of Federal bureaucracy.

title: No Headline
description: The Consequences Of Lilco Rate Rise I would like to know what is ''orderly'' about the energy policy of the Citizens for an Orderly Energy Policy (''Pro-Shoreham Group: Voice Now Heard,'' July 3). And how dare they pretend to speak for a consensus of the scientific community? They say they have given up on the public and will ''concentrate on the business community, they'd have the most clout.''

title: IS LEBANON SLIDING TOWARD PARTITION?
description: Lebanon feels partition is closer today than at any time since the darkest days of the 1975-1976 civil war. Druse and Christian militias are mobilized for a duel to the death in the Shuf mountains southeast of Beirut, as soon as the Israelis move out of the way. The American and French Embassies are besieged by crowds of Lebanese seeking visas and travel agents are doing a brisk trade in one-way tickets.

title: MASTERS OF THE CORPORATE TURNAROUND
description: GEORGE C. SCOTT, the actor, may have summed it up best in his screenp ortrayal of General George S. Patton Jr. Standing majestically on a h illtop in dress jodhpurs, clenching a riding crop at the side, he g azes across a battlefield that is littered with the bodies and s moldering wreckage of a tank battle.

title: BET THE PONIES: BEFORE OR AFTER THE RACE
description: IN the world of speculative investments, few can match the glitter - or the risk - of thoroughbred horses. ''It's a tough game, but wheni t's good there's nothing like it,'' says W. Cothran Campbell, p resident of Dogwood Farm Inc. in Atlanta.

title: CANADA'S STRATFORD FESTIVAL STRIVES TO REGAIN ITS LUSTER
description: tended gardens are in vivid bloom, and smiling tourists stroll and pose and snap photographs, just as they have done for 30 years.

title: 'WE KILLED THE MONROE DOCTRINE IN 1898'
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME EXPOSURES
description: OUT OF THE FORTIES By Nicholas Lemann. Illustrated. 147 pp. Austin, Tex.: Texas Monthly Press. $21.95.

title: MX Countdown Lurches Along
description: The MX missile, touted by its defenders as an essential strategic weapon and a valuable bargaining chip, held its own last week. But it still hasn't quite cleared the Capitol Hill launching pad.

title: PORTRAIT OF A GIANT
description: Excess Profits: The Rise of United Technologies, by Ronald Fernandez. Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. Reading, Mass. 320 pages, $16.95. FROM the publication in 1934 of ''The Merchants of Death,'' a book suggesting that munitions m anufacturers not only made unconscionable profits but that they h elped start World War I, to Dwight Eisenhower's valedictory warning a bout the military-industrial complex, Americans have had mixed f eelings about the corporate giants that make the weapons of war.

title: HELP FOR COUPLES WITH DISABILITIES
description: ''THESE kids haven't had someone they could be protective of, someone special they could care for,'' said Norman Adler of Babylon, father of a young man enrolled in the Married/ Engaged Couples Program of the Association for Children With Learning Disabilities.

title: FOr the U.A.W., Nothing Gained
description: When Chrysler announced this month that its second quarter profits had been the best ever, the United Auto Workers immediately asked the corporation to share the wealth. Last week the union went away from three days of talks with an empty cup and its leaders talked about a hard line to come when bargaining resumes a few months before the current contract expires in mid-January.

title: Packers Help a Coach
description: It occurred to Dan Crookman, the football coach at Will Rogers High School in Tulsa, Okla., that his team would probably do better if it could run the end reverse as well as the Green Bay Packers. Crookman, whose team had a 5-5 record last year, said he had come to that conclusion after watching James Lofton, the Packer wide reciver, score two long touchdowns on such plays in televised games last fall.

title: Catherine Allegra Is Wed
description: Catherine Wadsworth Allegra, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Allegra of Ruffs Dale, Pa., was married in Florence July 22 to James Michael Tanner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tanner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Dr. Fulvio Abbone, Alderman of Florence, performed the ceremony at the Palazzo della Signoria.

title: Diane Jane Davignon Weds S.J. Lubiak Jr.
description: Diane Jane Davignon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Davignon of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen J. Lubiak Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lubiak of Franklin Township, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Peter Jessen, a Presbyterian minister, at the Chanteclair Chateau restaurant in Warren Township, N.J.

title: WHy Boston Can't Vote
description: With only two months to go before City Council, School Committee and mayoral primaries, a Federal district judge last week added Boston's election districts to the list of city institutions in receivership. The decision - the latest produced by a decade of lawsuits involving the city's jails, public service hiring and even the management of its beloved baseball team, the Red Sox - did not specify under what conditions elections could be held. It was quite specific on the condition barring them. Nine districts drawn up by the City Council last year, Judge Andrew A. Caffrey ruled, violate the constitutional principle of one person, one vote because they vary in population by as much as 23.6 percent.

title: NAMES FOR THE TOP JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Confident Jets Try to Polish Their Skills
description: It was worth a second look. So Chris Ward called to the orthopedist for the Jets, Dr. James A. Nicholas, and said, ''Doc, let me see that ring again.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: First-Quality Wares Up to 75% Off

title: URUGUAY'S CONTRADICTION OF ELLIOTT ABRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN CITES REACTION TO PLEA
description: Six children were in critical but stable condition today after undergoing liver transplants at hospitals in Pittsburgh, Minneapolis, Shreveport, La., and Memphis.

title: Acquaintances
description: To the Editor:

title: WATERLOO: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: A part of New Jersey history has been re-created at Waterloo Village in a setting as serenely pretty as it might have been more than 200 years ago.

title: NEW ISSUES ARISING IN SHOREHAM DEBATE
description: IF the $3.2 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant existed only in a soap opera or a socially conscious feature-length movie, the last two weeks might well be hailed as the scriptwriter's ultimate triumph. Suddenly the already sizable cast of characters in the long-running drama over the nearly completed reactor swelled to include - in relatively major roles - one of the nation's largest defense contractors, two United States Senators, two Governors and a host of subordinates.

title: INQUEST IN THE ANDES
description: Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian novelist, was a nominee for the 1982 Nobel Prize in Literature. This article was translated by Edith Grossman.

title: THE UNHURRIED GLORIES OF THE SMOKIES
description: WILMA DYKEMAN is a novelist and historian whose 14 books include ''The French Broad,'' ''The Tall Woman'' and ''Return the Innocent Earth'' (Holt Rinehart and Winston).

title: ALEXANDER TO FACE DREWETT IN FINAL
description: Third-seeded John Alexander and unseeded Brad Drewett won their matches today to set up an all-Australian men's singles final Sunday in the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open.

title: R. S. Petretti Wed To Lola Langner
description: Lola Emily Langner and Richard Stephen Petretti were married yesterday by the Rev. Paul Walsh at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: THE REAGAN DOCTRINE
description: WASHINGTON ''T HE Democrats can't get their act together,'' Senator Paul E. Tsongas complained last week in frustration over the difficulty of mobilizing a party opposition to President Reagan's Central America policies. The Massachusetts Senator needn't have limited his remarks to Democrats. The entire Congress was having trouble dealing with Mr. Reagan's plans to escalate the American military presence and not-so-covert operations in Central America.

title: FEDERAL BRINK'S PROSECUTION NEARLY COMPLETED
description: Prosecutors in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan are expected to complete their case this week after having presented more than 100 witnesses since the trial began almost four months ago.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Reincarnation of Shirley MacLaine

title: Case for 'Theirs'
description: To the Business Editor: For a long time, I have been irritated by generalized advice given to married couples regarding the undesirability of joint ownership. Nowhere in his article, ''When 'His' and 'Hers' Beats 'Ours' '' (July 24), does Harvey D. Shapiro mention that in case of death, joint ownership (as compared with single ownership) avoids a costly and cumbersome probate proceeding.

title: Miss McNeil Plans to Wed D.C. LeVine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Victoria McNeil, to D. Christopher LeVine of Villanova, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Caldwell LeVine of Philadelphia and Ocean, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: HOTELS
description: To the Editor: We read Enid Nemy's ''Memo to Hotel Managers'' with great interest. Although we're not members of the Leona Helmsley school of hotel management, we would agree with her comments to the effect that the best hotels treat all of their guests - men and women -with a consistently high degree of respect and thoughtfulness.

title: Katha Diddel Plans to Wed Next Month
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Diddel of New York and West Falmouth, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Katha Diddel, to Paul Hendrik Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Warren of Waikanae, New Zealand.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ON THEIR TOES
description: Classical ballet gets the park treatment this week as two of the Island's major dance companies pirouette in to join the outdoor concert circuit. Tonight at 8 o'clock at Eisenhower Park's Chapin Lakeside Theater in East Meadow, the Eglevsky Ballet will perform such favorites from its repertory as ''Legs of Lamb,'' ''Serenade,'' ''Vivaldi Pieces'' and ''Minkus Pas de Trois.'' The Concert Orchestra of Long Island, conducted by Laszlo Halasz, will provide the live music for this free program.

title: DRAGONS AND PEOPLE SNATCHERS
description: NEVERYONA Or: The Tale of Signs and Cities. By Samuel R. Delany. 385 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $6.95. MILLENNIUM By John Varley. 249 pp. New York: Berkley Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHILE I was strolling on the beach one day, my nose twitched. It often twitches when I get to the beach. At the beach, where most people are busy twitching one part of their body or another, my nose was not twitching enough really to make a spectacle of itself. What made it twitch was the scent of the sea, that special smell that lets you know you, even if you have been blindfolded, that you are at oceanside.

title: Fear of Flying
description: They may be afflicted with acrophobia, aerophobia, agoraphobia, stenophobia or thanatophobia, but all share a common phobia: fear of flying. Two years ago Thomas Bunn, having spent more than 10,000 hours in the sky flying Air Force jet fighters and airliners, became ''hooked,'' he says, on teaching people like this to relax and actually enjoy flying.

title: FINISHING OFF THE CORPORATE STATE
description: BEYOND THE WASTE LAND A Democratic Alternative to Economic Decline. By Samuel Bowles, David M. Gordon and Thomas E. Weisskopf. 465 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: SIX YEARS FOR THE PRESIDENT?
description: Tom Wicker writes, ''No President since Dwight Eisenhower in the 1950's has been elected to and served two full terms.'' Mr. Wicker seems to have made the same assumption that so many of us do: that because five of our first seven Presidents (Washington, Jefferson, Madison, Monroe and Jackson) served two full terms, other good or popular Presidents have served similar long terms throughout our history until recently. The facts don't bear this out.

title: Emma Rein Married to Robert A. Alessi, a Lawyer
description: Emma J. Rein, daughter of Mrs. Thomas M. Rein and the late Dr. Rein of Highland Park, N.J., was married in New Brunswick, N.J., yesterday to Robert A. Alessi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph J. Alessi of Jericho, L.I. The Rev. Herbert J. Stab of Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Piscataway, N.J., performed the ceremony in the Voorhees Chapel at Douglass College.

title: Michele Tomasik to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Tomasik of Venice, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Michele Tomasik, to Glenn Eichler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Eichler of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Tomasik, senior associate editor of Premium/Incentive Business magazine, and her fiance, managing editor of National Lampoon magazine, plan to be married Sept. 24.

title: PIZZA AND CHICKEN AS INVESTMENTS
description: year-old Roger H. Lipton of Southampton and New York City, they are the ingredients of business.

title: Hot Line Still Hot
description: Two months ago REWRITE, the grammar hot line in New York City operated as a volunteer public service by York College's English department, faced a summer shutdown unless the public offered to pay the teachers for lost vacations. This was reported here, as was the line's role as a national arbiter of grammar.

title: Laity Supports Married Priests
description: Priests should be many things to many people, but married is not one of them, Pope John Paul II has reaffirmed. A majority of American Roman Catholics disagree.

title: Orchids
description: To the Editor: I was vicariously enjoying Hawaii's Big Island as described by Fletcher Knebel in the article ''Five Climates in Three Hours'' (Travel, July 3) when the phrase ''millions of commercial orchids'' jarred me and took me back 24 years. t was the summer of 1959 and Hawaii had just become a state.

title: APHORISMS FOR DIPLOMATS
description: Each year, in each country, the management of conflict and cooperation seems to be somewhere near the center of the human experiment. Not long ago I sat down for a weekend and tried to figure out what I have learned during four decades about peacekeeping and peacemaking. The result: 13 aphorisms from experience.

title: No Headline
description: Program for Gifted: A Graduate's Views Andrew Carlan's letter to the editor on June 26 regarding programs for the gifted presents an affront to the residents of the Lawrence School District that cannot go unanswered. I feel deeply offended and wronged when he maintains that the present academic standards are farcical. As a recent graduate, I can attest that on a national level Lawrence ranks among the best high schools in the nation.

title: Fighting a Subpoena
description: Harvey Martin, the Dallas Cowboy defensive end, has moved to quash a subpoena calling on him to testify as a defense witness in the trial of an acquaintance accused of a cocaine conspiracy. In asking Federal Judge Robert W. Porter to cancel the subpoena, Martin's lawyers called it ''frivolous'' and said it was an attempt by the defendant, Lauriberto Ignacio, ''to sensationalize what is otherwise a routine drug prosecution.''

title: SEMINOLES TO SET UP THEIR OWN COURT SYSTEM
description: The Seminole Tribes of Florida are setting up a judicial system that they say will incorporate traditional Indian values that have no place in state or Federal courts.

title: O WESTERN WIND
description: PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent who lives in Rome, is the author of ''Rome. The Sweet Tempestuous Life'' (Congdon & Lattes).

title: Blaze Damages 1,400 Acres Of Trees in Jersey Pinelands
description: A fire spread across more than 1,400 acres in the Ocean County Pinelands today, levellng thousands of scrub pines and emitting plumes of smoke that could be seen 20 miles away.

title: NORWEGIAN ENAMEL: LUSTROUS TRADITION
description: The art of enameling has been raised to a high order by skilled Norwegian craftsmen. And in Norway the name David-Andersen is practically synonymous with enameled holloware, flatware and jewelry. ''It is our enamel on silver that has made us famous,'' said Jon David-Andersen, manager of the Oslo firm founded in 1876 by his great-grandfather, David Andersen.

title: A DAY TO LIVE IN THE MEMORY
description: FROM the first hint that plans were in the offing to the day of the actual event there was a gestation period of eight months and one week. Our high school class held its first reunion since graduating in the 1950's and disproved all laws of inverse reaction - the long anticipation culminated in a super party.

title: LANGUAGE RIFT UNRESOLVED
description: ELIZABETH FOR THE most part, City Hall employees here have said little publicly about a controversial memorandum that Mayor Thomas G. Dunn sent to department heads last month.

title: 'MR. INSIDE' GOES SOLO AT LEHMAN
description: WITH his rumpled appearance and quiet demeanor, Lewis L. Glucksman h ardly looks like the kind of man to have ascended to the top of one o f Wall Street's most prestigious investment houses. And, Mr. G lucksman, by his own admission, is a private person - a loner whose p assions in life are boating and carpentry and who feels u ncomfortable in the public eye.

title: MODERN DANCE A LA FRANCAISE
description: Five modern-dance companies from France have recently visited the United States and all said what they had to say in very different ways. Perhaps this is the result of a felicitous selection by Charles Reinhart, director of the American Dance Festival, and Stephanie Singer Reinhart, the festival's associate director. When Susan Buirge, the American choreographer who is artistic advisor to a French festival, La Danse a Aix, suggested the series for the American Dance Festival, the Reinharts looked over some 50 troupes in live auditions or on videotape.

title: Collectors' Items
description: To the Editor: Let me add my travel ''collecting'' experiences to those of Robert D. Hershey Jr., the author of ''Destinations: Among My Souvenirs'' (Travel, June 1). My single travel objective has been to visit 425 specific art museums in the Americas and Europe.

title: RUSSIA'S LONG FLIRTATION
description: Red Carpet, by Joseph Finder. A New Republic Book/Holt Rinehart & Winston, N.Y. 372 pages, $16.95. IN the midst of a devastating famine in the 1930's, George Bernard Shaw visited Russia and was fed generously by his hosts. ''Starvation?'' he remarked when he returned. ''Why, I've never eaten so wonderfully!''

title: RESTAURANT PLAN IRKS CIVIC GROUP
description: WHILE restaurants are an essential part of the Long Island economy, a Stony Brook civic association is saying ''enough is enough.'' The Route 347 advisory committee of the Three Village Civic Association, which attempts to monitor developments along the fourlane roadway running through Stony Brook, is opposing a proposal for a Mexican restaurant. The restaurant could bring 170 to 230 new jobs to the community.

title: CARDINALS BEAT EXPOS, 3 TO 2, ON A 4-HITTER
description: Dave LaPoint (9-6) teamed with Bruce Sutter on a four-hitter, and Willie McGee scored two runs, helping the St. Louis Cardinals to defeat the Montreal Expos, 3-2, tonight and maintain possession of second place in the National League East.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
NEW PARENTS, OLD PARENTS, THEIR ADOPTED CHILDREN
description: IT is mid-morning, and a group of people with teen-age sons and daughters is gathered in a small room. They sit on comfortablelooking chairs and sofas and sip coffee and make small talk about the weather. And, like parents sometimes do when they get together, they show each other pictures of their children.

title: Student, 20, Wins $7 Million From 2 She Accused of Rape
description: Miki Akano, a 20-year-old Japanese exchange student, was awarded $7.2 million in damages Friday in a lawsuit she filed after a state court acquitted two men she said had raped her.

title: INDEPENDENT MOVIES TAKE A TURN FOR THE BETTER
description: Not so many good, individually stylish independent films reach commercial distribution that we can ignore those that finally do break through, even when they are something less than perfect. In some cases the imperfections are what catch the attention, as in Slava Tsukerman's deadpan delirium of a drug dream, ''Liquid Sky,'' and Charlie Loventhal's ''First Time,'' a classy update on undergraduate comedies.

title: LANDRUM, ON 67-207, REGAINS PACE BY 1
description: Ralph Landrum, in his first season on the PGA Tour, retrieved his lead today in the third round of the Canadian Open. On a steamy day and on a course that played long because of overnight rain, Landrum shot 67, four under par for the Glen Abbey Golf Club.

title: FOR THE 'TONIGHT SHOW,' JOAN RIVERS IS THE NEXT BEST THING TO JOHNNY
description: CARSON By FRANK J. PRIAL

title: Jill Owesny Wed To J.R. Lawrence
description: Jill Allison Owesny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Owesny of Spring Hill, Fla., formerly of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to James Ricketts Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Lawrence of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Lewis S. Stone performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Harbor Church on Block Island, R.I.

title: COMPETITION BREEDS ADVANCES IN AUDIO EQUIPMENT
description: Yes, I do read my mail. I just can't answer it all or provide individual consultation on audio problems. But from time to time, this column talks back to its readers. For example: Q. What I resent about the audio industry is its constant hawking of something better (or claimed to be better) when what we have is good enough. How can we stop this endless and frustrating agitation?

title: MOre Than One Way to Show a Smaller Deficit
description: In budgeting as in business, the bottom line is what counts. But in the former perhaps more than the latter, how you get there can count even more. That was the reason Congressional Democrats were quick to characterize as disingenuously cheery the revised budget estimates President Reagan sent to Capitol Hill last week.

title: Love by Computer
description: Rumson, who is very modern and works hard to stay that way, would be hurt if he were called a gentleman, so we can be honest at the outset. Rumson is no gentleman.

title: THE ALLIES HOLD THEIR BREATH AS FLEET MOVES TO HONDURAS
description: Across Western Europe a mood of unease began to take hold last week, a fear that the Reagan Administration was moving toward a military confrontation in Central America.

title: AT COOPERSTOWN, THE PAST HAS ITS DAY
description: Major league baseball takes its annual plunge into the past today when the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., will be opened to Brooks Robinson, Juan Marichal, George Kell and Walter Alston.

title: Tipper and Tippee
description: To the Business Editor: John Fedders (''A Call for Stronger Deterrents,'' July 17) is curiously oblique in explaining how trading upon material, nonpublic information is intrinsically fraudulent, deceptive or the moral equivalent of theft.

title: Ex-Rep. Diggs Gets License In Maryland as an Undertaker
description: Former Representative Charles X. Diggs, who left Congress after being convicted in a payroll kickback scheme, has been granted an undertaker's license in Maryland.

title: 21 Bodies Recovered In Colombian Mudslide
description: Rescue workers found 21 bodies today at a hydroelectric project where officials said 120 people died in a mudslide.

title: KOREAN FEAST FOR SUMMER
description: With the ingredients easy to find in America's many Oriental marketplaces, dishes that contain vegetables and transparent noodles, or cold crab meat, are ideal for the heat of summer.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE MARKS ISRAEL'S ''YEAR OF COURAGE''
description: Israel is celebrating its new year - the year 5744 in the Hebrew calendar - with a set of four commemoratives devoted to its synagogues, which are not only houses of worship for Jews, but are also considered as the repositories of sacred writ and law and the teachings of the prophets.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYThe American city is the subject of a group show of photographs from the Seagram Collection, and a varied lot of photographs it includes. At one end is Arthur Siegel's 1939 ''Right of Assembly,'' an aerial shot of hundreds or possibly thousands of striking automobile workers at a crowded meeting, each one as tiny as dots in a pointillist painting.

title: ARE THE TEAMS DOING ENOUGH IN N.F.L. DRUG CASES?
description: VISIT almost any National Football League locker room, and when you develop the confidence to talk with some of the players, you will hear the refrain that the National Football League owners are only interested in making money.

title: ARMENIAN ATTACK UNSETTLES LISBON
description: The attack by Armenian extremists on the Turkish Embassy here this week has induced the Portuguese Government to reexamine the possibilty of creating a special service to gather intelligence.

title: FURNITURE THAT MOVED WITH THE EMPIRE
description: Furniture that is portable, flexible, folds up easily and offers ingenious storage. Sounds modern? Well, it's not - it's a century or more in age. However, these designs are in some ways as practical as anything produced today. They are the chairs, settees, desks and beds made in India for British use from the late 18th century through the 19th, a period during which part of the country was governed at first by the East India Company and, from 1858 on, was under the British Crown.

title: Miss Dietel Weds Dennis F. Krieger
description: Cynthia Lyon Dietel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Dietel of Flint Hill, Va., and Deer Island, Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dennis Francis Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Krieger of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of the New Canaan,Conn., Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the Dietel home on Deer Island.

title: Story Shem Plans October Marriage To Photographer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Shem of Libertyville, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Story Shem, to Michael Arthur Worden Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.Worden Evans of Vancouver, British Columbia. The wedding is to be on Oct. 29.

title: ON WASTE, TOWNS JUST WON'T QUIT
description: DESPITE the problems faced by Connecticut's first two garbage-toenergy projects - in Windham and in Bridgeport - nearly 100 communities in the state are considering similar projects, using mistakes already made to avoid pitfalls themselves.

title: SUMMERTIME SETTING ON THE PORCH
description: USUALLY the drive to the restaurant is not the part you look forward to, but with The Cook on Shelter Island it's a different story. Unless you are a resident of the bit of hilly landfall nestled between the Island's two forks, the trip will involve a ride on the ferry from Greenport or North Haven and, either coming or going, you may catch the sunset over the water. It's the stuff of romance.

title: THE PART-TIME SEDUCTION
description: IHAVE the ideal part-time job. I teach at a nearby university and I a m surrounded by stimulating people I like and respect. Because my h ours are flexible, I am able to balance the responsibilities of my j ob with the demands of my family. The knowledge that I am growing p rofessionally as well as contributing to the growth of my students p rovides a job satisfaction beyond compensation - so I am told. I h ave also been told that only women can afford to have this job.

title: FIRE DAMAGES ALABAMA CENTER THAT BATTLES KLAN
description: Members of the Southern Poverty Law Center say they had expected some retaliation for taking legal action against Ku Klux Klan organizations, but nothing like what happened early Thursday.

title: ENGAGING EXPERIMENTS TRANSFORM A SANDY SITE
description: With every new incarnation - and it's now in its fifth - ''Art on the Beach,'' the sculpture show that has an annual summer run on the Battery Park City Landfill at Manhattan's tip, gets more ambitious. In the past, its not-for-profit sponsor, Creative Time, Inc., has regarded the sandy sweep of acreage on the Hudson -with its stunning backdrop of Lower Manhattan architecture - as an arena for both the visual and performing arts. It has encouraged performers to use the site-oriented works made by visual artists as settings for inspiration for their own inventions.

title: MANY CULTURES SPEAK THROUGH LATIN MUSIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: A PANORAMIC VIEW OF A FRENCH MASTER OF STILL LIFES
description: Our major museums did not exactly stand in line to import the exhibition of paintings and drawings by Jean-Baptiste Oudry (1686-1755) that opened last winter at the Grand Palais in Paris. Had it been Watteau or Fragonard, they would have shifted things around and sat up all night to clinch the deal. But Oudry had problems of identity.

title: Miss O'Donnell Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Ann O'Donnell, daughter of Mrs. James J. O'Donnell Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Lieutenant Commander O'Donnell, U.S.N., was married yesterday to George Peter Parthemos, son of Mrs. Peter George Parthemos of Youngstown, Ohio, and the late Mr. Parthemos. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Harrison, N.Y.

title: STATE TAKES OVER SHAKESPEARE STAGE
description: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE wrote that ''all the world's a stage,'' but now one stage built in his honor has been transformed into Connecticut's newest state park.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: CONFLICTING INTERESTS BY DONALD H. BELL Donald H. Bell teaches at Harvard University and is the author of ''Being a Man: The Paradox of Masculinity'' (Lewis Press).

title: INNS WITH A MOUNTAIN TANG
description: Like Queen Victoria wearing too much rouge, the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is absolutely regal and overwhelmingly respectable, if a bit tarted up around the edges. The park has assumed the motherly responsibility of providing a safe trip to the forest , and millions of visitors each year drive past the trees. Those who never leave their cars miss the splendid heart of the Smokies, which beats free and seductive just beneath the dowager's skin.

title: CONSUMER RATES
'ANYONE COULD HAVE TAKEN HIM'
description: IWALK into the department store with nothing more on my mind than t he jacket I want to buy for my son. Directly inside the front door s tands an older woman. Although her arms are loaded with clothing t hat she intends to buy for her young grandchildren, the garments arel ong forgotten.

title: Sean Connelly Exchanges Vows With Susan Lynch
description: Susan Lynch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Lynch of Barrington, R.I., was married there yesterday to Sean Connelly, son of Mary Connelly of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Oscar R. Ferland performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART As everyone knows, the history of American art in the 20th century would have been very different without the contribution of painters and sculptors who came to this country as immigrants from Europe. Not only did that immigration bring us major individual talents - a Gorky, a Rothko, a Nevelson - but it set up a climate of feeling that communicated itself to the American art world as a whole.

title: DIVERSE ITALIAN FARE WITH PROMISE
description: FROM the outside, La Fortuna may look like just another roadside Italian restaurant. Inside, as you enter through a light, pleasant bar, a somewhat dour maitre d'hotel greets and leads you into a small, attractive, softly lit dining room with cream-colored walls, shuttered windows, and a rear wall lined with decorative wine crates and bottles.

title: FASCINATING RARITIES IN BILLINGS FESTIVAL
description: DOES the phrase ''American music'' send you scurrying in the opposite direction, or suddenly remind you of another engagement? Then you're the target of the William Billings Institute of American Music, a nonprofit educational corporation in New London which believes that the rich heritage of music in America has been underperformed, and therefore remains underappreciated.

title: CALIFORNIANS ON EDGE AFTER FREQUENT QUAKES
description: With the strain on their nerves showing, people here say that unless the quivering earth stops wrenching them from battered homes, this small community on the western edge of the San Joaquin Valley will turn into a ghost town.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FESTIVAL GOES OUTDOORS
description: NOW a well-established feature of Connecticut's annual summer antiques fare, the Glastonbury Outdoor Festival will welcome 200 exhibitors next Saturday. The dealers will set up their booths on the village green of this handsome community of 18th-century houses. The show will include a greater-than-usual amount of good early furniture and decorative accessories, along with collectibles such as baskets and toys.

title: Ethnic Killings Shake Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka is a 25,000-square-mile dot off southeast India, crowded with 15 million people who gave a bloody demonstration last week of their inability to get along with each other. The death toll from the worst clashes in 30 years between the majority Sinhalese, about four-fifths of the population, and minority Tamils was reported to be at least 140.

title: Meg Lesser Is to Be Married
description: Alyce Levy Lesser of Charlevoix, Mich., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Meg Lesser, to Steven David Roberts of New York. Miss Lesser is also a daughter of the late Harry Lesser Jr. of St. Louis.

title: SIX YEARS FOR THE PRESIDENT?
description: Tom Wicker's searching article on the pros and cons of a single six-year Presidential term omitted at least one home-grown precedent. The Confederate Constitution, adopted on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Ala., contained that very provision.

title: Moral Judgments Of Football Hall
description: To The Sports Editor: Ira Berkow's observations of July 20 concerning the fitness of Billy Cannon for the college football Hall of Fame questioned the National Football Foundation's ability to make moral judgments as to ''good citizens.''

title: PELHAM MURDER RENEWS BRIDGE DISPUTE
description: PELHAM THE recent murder of a well-known 72-year-old storekeeper here has renewed a six-year-old border dispute between this small village and its neighbor - the city of Mount Vernon - over a small bridge that links the two municipalities.

title: HIGH MOSCOW AIDE OUT AMID CRITICISM
description: The head of the Soviet Union's construction industry has left his post as Deputy Prime Minister, in what appears to be one of the highest-level demotions since Yuri V. Andropov took charge last year.

title: New Hampshire Loons Gain
description: New Hampshire's endangered loon population is beginning to flourish despite the threat of acid rain and development, environmentalists say. A census July 16 by 1,000 volunteers at 134 New Hamshire lakes and ponds reported sighting 256 adults and 65 chicks of the bird with the haunting cry.

title: Peace Campers Upstate Charged in Disturbance
description: Authorities charged 53 women peace campers with disorderly conduct today, after their march to the Seneca Army Depot was blocked by 300 flag-waving townspeople who jammed a bridge.

title: No Headline
description: Steinbach Takes Lead AUSTIN, Tex. July 30 (UPI) -Mike Steinbach bowled the highest sixgame series on the professional circuit this year, averaging 262 today to take the first-round lead in a Pro Bowlers Tour tournament.

title: French Film Festival Moves to 40's and 50's
description: The final months of the 10-month French film festival at the Museum of Modern Art, Fifth Avenue and 53d Street, will include classic films from the 1940's and 1950's, as well as those from the beginnings of French film making.

title: SECOND BEST BY THE BAY
description: The clang of trolley bells has returned to Market Street this summer as a sop to those who come here to ride the famous cable car system and find it closed for repair.

title: Paula Ann Kanuga to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Kanuga of East Patchogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Ann Kanuga, to John Patrick Tirelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gathan Tirelli of Greenwich, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: A's 13, Angels 8
description: Carney Lansford drove in the tie-breaking run with a double, and Jeff Burroughs hit a two-run single to highlight a five-run rally in the seventh inning by the A's in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader. The A's, who trailed by 7-0, had 20 hits.

title: THE THREE R'S GET A FOURTH: IT'S REAGAN
description: TO LISTEN to President Reagan, one might conclude that he has set forth a creative path for educational renewal in the United States. High standards, a return to basics, merit increases for teachers, local control, etc., are the catchwords we hear from the President.

title:
CALIFORNIA'S NUCLEAR HALT;
A MORATORIUM THAT HAS PAID ITS WAY
description: WHEN the Supreme Court on April 20 unanimously upheld California's nuclear power moratorium, the decision was widely i nterpreted as a vindication of states' rights in utility regulation a nd a death knell for the nuclear industry. But the most interesting r eaction to the Court's ruling may have come from the loser in the c ase, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, which had sued to block t he moratorium but now says it will have ''no effect'' on its plans.

title: CUOMO UNDECIDED ON PARKLAND BILL
description: Animosities between environmentalists and residents of New York's six-million-acre Adirondack Park have been revived as Governor Cuomo considers whether to sign a bill that would give landowners economic incentive to guarantee that their land would never be developed.

title: U.S. MOVES TO REOPEN MANCHURIAN CONSULATE
description: More than two years ago, the United States and China exchanged diplomatic notes granting the Chinese a consulate general in New York in exchange for a United States consulate general in the Manchurian city of Shenyang.

title: EX-HEART PATIENTS HELP OTHERS
description: MILTON WINER, who has had three cardiac bypass operations in 13 years, said he had found a good way to lift the spirits of a patient facing heart surgery; he just walks into the room.

title: STATE JUDGES TO BE JUDGED
description: TRENTON ATTORNEYS in New Jersey will be asked to judge the judges in a new program soon to be tested by the Committee on Judicial Performance of State Supreme Court.

title: JERSEY IS PRESSING DEBTORS TO PAY UP
description: New Jersey's Treasurer said this week that local governments, school districts, businesses and citizens were being pressed to pay their debts to the state.

title: Elizabeth Muran, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Van V. Muran of Brookville and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mary-Ann Muran, to Jefferson Alison 4th, son of Mrs. Carlyle J. Coash of Old Brookville and Mr. Alison 3d of Dunlap, Ill. A Sept. 17 wedding is planned.

title: Ingrid L. Rand Weds Michael A. Sorensen
description: At St. Bartholomew's Roman Catholic Church in East Brunswick, N.J., yesterday, Ingrid Lydia Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Rand of Highland Beach, Fla., was married to Michael Anthony Sorensen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Sorensen of Wildwood Crest, N.J. The Rev. Gervase Walters performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS PERIL GARDENS
description: EARLIER this month the Central Park thermometer registered the highest temperature recorded for that date, and, according to the weather forecasters, the period ahead promises both higher than normal temperatures and lower than normal rainfall. This adds up to a combination of drought and heat stress for our gardens.

title: Cuba Orders Ouster Of U.S. Marine Guard
description: A Marine guard at the United States Interests Section here has been ordered to leave Cuba within 24 hours for wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with the phrase ''Cuba yes, Fidel no,'' diplomatic informants said today.

title: NEAR HIT, NEAR MISS: CHICAGO CAN'T QUITE FIND ITS KIND OF SONG
description: In Jeff Jacobs' book, the song ''My Kind of Town'' is definitely outdated, and the line that says ''Chicago is one town that won't let you down'' is about as obsolete as the one urging visitors to see the Union Stockyards, which left the city in 1971.

title: TAKING OUT HEALTH INSURANCE FOR A TRIP
description: In this era of spiraling medical costs, the traveler can hardly be blamed for hesitating to embark on a trip outside his or her own country without assurance that expenses will be covered in the event of accident or illness. The logical precaution is to have insurance, and for the majority of American travelers that is no particular problem since most employee insurance programs or other health insurance plans provide reimbursement for medical expenses incurred anywhere in the world.

title: METAPHOR GETTING ITS DUE AS A WELLSPRING OF SCIENCE
description: History repeatedly hints that scientists find inspiration for their discoveries in art, perhaps a striking landscape or other cultural or esthetic experiences. The great 17th century astronomer Johannes Kepler was motivated by a mystical devotion to musical harmonies.

title: IT'S STILL A SCHOOL DESPITE THE CONVERSION
description: A RECURRING character in the Peanuts comic strip is the school building to which Charlie Brown, Lucy and the rest return every September. Usually the building has some pithy things to say about goings-on it has observed inside and outside. I wish the Thornwood Elementary School on Kensico Road could be put into this role: if the old building has a consciousness, it must be sending out frantic messages right now: ''Help! Let me out!''

title: AN ISLAND FOR THE DEDICATED
description: DAVID YEADON, the author of 13 travel books, is preparing a book on the islands of America for publication next spring.

title: Deputed Testamony Takes the Haskell
description: Deputed Testamony, getting a well-judged ride from Herb McCauley, came from last place in a field of 10 3-year-olds today to win the Amory L. Haskell Invitational by a neck from Bet Big, a long shot.

title: WEST BANK PUTS DISPUTES ASIDE TO RALLY TO ARAFAT
description: Occupied West Bank - The open Syrian and Libyan support for rebels opposing the leadership of Yasir Arafat has led diverse groups of West Bank Palestinians to unite behind him even though many of them have serious complaints about some of his policies.

title: SIX YEARS FOR THE PRESIDENT?
description: Too often, it seems as if our Presidential elections turn on the state of the nation in the last few weeks before the voting. No wonder, then, that a President running for a second term has every incentive to sacrifice the country's long-term interests in favor of short-term policies that, in looking good for the moment, might win four more years of power.

title: BOSTON BLACKS LOOK TO VOTING AND ECONOMIC GAINS
description: The reminder is there whenever Melvin H. King walks out the door of his house in Boston's battered old South End. Looming over him, a few blocks away, are the shining towers, luxury hotels and expensive stores of Copley Place, the largest commercial development project in the country. Only a concrete ditch for both a new subway line and railroad tracks separates Mr. King's predominantly black and poor neighborhood, with its abandoned buildings, from the $500 million development.

title: Brazil
description: To the Business Editor: Your article ''Brazil's Economy -After the Miracle'' (July 17) was timely and informative. Nevertheless, two points should be made. The first concerns an error regarding the economic status of the lower classes during the years of the ''miracle.'' The second concerns the context of political and industrial change in which the present economic difficulties are occurring.

title: Budget Won't End Woes in Yonkers
description: The on-again, off-again flirtation between Yonkers and bankruptcy nearly became a full-fledged romance last week. But more than a month late and two days before State Comptroller Edward V. Regan threatened to intervene under legislation passed in 1976, after the city's first blush with insolvency, the City Council unamimously passed a $216.3 million budget for the fiscal year which began July 1.

title: LET'S HELP OUR LATIN FRIENDS
description: President Reagan's decision to conduct naval exercises in international waters off Central America and the Pentagon's announcement that United States military personnel will take part in joint exercises in Honduras have shocked some Americans. Others see in these traditional shows of force evidence that at last we may be overcoming the paralysis of power that has gripped us since the fall of Saigon.

title: NEW GARDENERS
description: For 40 YEARS, PATRICIA Mason's mother, Leslie Michaels, had devoted herself to creating a personal garden whose design was dictated by a lively curiosity in growing a wide range of plants. The cut-leaf beech, China fir and other large specimen trees were not deemed at all incompatible with humbler species such as goldenrod, black-eyed Susans, the easily overlooked jack-in-the-pulpit or blue gentian.

title: JOB PROSPECTS FOR TEEN-AGERS CALLED WORST IN CITY'S HISTORY
description: New York City's teen-agers face the worst employment picture in the city's history and the situation shows no sign of improving, according to city officials, economists and social workers who deal with job seekers.

title: Suspect in Killing of 4 In Chino Is Arrested
description: A prison escapee wanted in connection with the slashing deaths of four people at a Chino ranch in June was arrested today, sheriff's deputies said.

title: MIDWIFE OF MODERNISM
description: SYLVIA BEACH AND THE LOST GENERATION A History of Literary Paris in the Twenties and Thirties. By Noel Riley Fitch.Illustrated. 447 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $25.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke welcomed the county's Albany delegation to a breakfast of coffee and doughnuts a week ago and got some advice in return. Actually, the message from the legislators was put nicely, but firmly: ''Get your proposed legislation up to Albany faster.''

title: Heaviest Giant Is Making Slow Progress
description: Leonard Marshall is the major disappointment of the Giants' training camp. At 285 pounds, he is also the heaviest player here, even though his nightly Big Mac forays have been halted.

title: Oregon State Inquiry
description: Reports that some Oregon State basketball players may have sold tickets to team boosters and received other special favors have prompted a preliminary investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, according to Coach Ralph Miller. ''If they sold tickets or did anything wrong, they did it knowingly,'' said Miller, whose Beavers have won the Pacific-10 Conference championship in three of the last four years.

title: Barbara Roome Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Willemse Roome of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Shaw Roome, to Boris Gonzalez Lobo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge Gonzalez Diez of Vero Beach, Fla., Jerez de la Frontera, Spain, and Madrid.

title: RULES SOUGHT ON CANOEING
description: ON any sunny Saturday or Sunday from May through October, hundreds of canoeists descend upon a stretch of the upper Housatonic River in northwestern Connecticut. The 10-mile section between Falls Village and Cornwall Bridge offers a little bit of everything - flat water, tricky white water and challenging rapids, as well as the beauty of densely wooded hills and rolling farmland.

title: IN THE ORBIT OF MENACE
description: TENDER PREY By Patricia Roberts. 263 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $13.95. SPEAK, ANGEL By Mary Elsie Robertson. 210 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: REAL-LIFE TV DRAMA HELPS MEDICAL STUDENTS LEARN
description: A PATIENT is prepared for surgery and draped, with all but one area of her body still. At the right lower quadrant of her abdomen, a surgeon and his team work in concert - cutting, removing, cleaning and stitching away - removing from her body an inflamed appendix that threatened to burst.

title: No Headline
description: Six Years for the President? Perhaps inadvertently, Tom Wicker's article, ''Six Years for the President?'' (June 26), sets forth a strong case for the abolition of the 22d Amendment. Since the adoption of this amendment in 1951, Dwight D. Eisenhower has been the first and only President to serve two full terms.

title: Bee Touches Off 3-Car Crash
description: A man was killed Friday in a three-car collision touched off when a driver was stung by a bee. Cpl. Barry Beck of the state police said Robert Turner, 17 years old, swerved when he was stung and sideswiped a van driven by Ronald Bussey, 40. Mr. Turner's car collided head-on with one driven by Robert Benson, 79, who was killed.

title: No Headline
COLLECTORS' ITEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Boyle in New Film
description: Peter Boyle has been signed by 20th Century-Fox for a major role in ''Johnny Dangerously,'' a parody of gangster movies that will begin filming in Los Angeles in early August. Mr. Boyle, who will play a New York gang leader, has previously appeared in ''Outland,'' ''In God We Trust'' and ''Young Frankenstein.''

title: FOR ONE BEGINNER, A GAME PLAN AT 60
description: and I sometimes suspect these are all young sages - is no barrier to sex, aerobics, the discovery of the wok or just about anything else one can name.

title: A THEATRICAL COMMUNITY WHERE THE PLAY IS EVERTYHING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ellen Cohn writes frequently about the performing arts. BY ELLEN COHN WATERFORD, Conn. Imagine that you're a director -still young in your career but not without success. You're in demand in the more prominent regional theaters; you've received good notices Off Broadway; you're paid quite well when you work in television. And one wintry morning, Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's National Playwrights Conference invites you to join the coming summer's company.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: 28 YEARS LATE, A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA POINTS TO A NEW FUTURE By DONALD J. DeSANDRE

title: LEAVING CONGRESS BEHIND: VIEWS FROM FORMER MEMBERS
description: BEFORE his announcement this month that he would not be a candidate for his old seat in Congress in 1984, Toby Moffett spent months struggling with the conflicting drives of a public man newly exposed to private life.

title: THEATER: MURRAY HORWITZ IN 'SHOLOM ALEICHEM'
description: English has not been unkind to Sholom Aleichem, the great Yiddish writer and storyteller who drew his material from the common folk, whether in the shtetls of Eastern Europe or in the immigrant ghettos of New York. His writings have been converted into a Broadway hit, ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' that has swept the world in many languages. He has been published in English in many volumes. And his words are now being heard, in English, in the comfortable and handsomely furnished back-room showplace of a Chelsea restaurant and nightclub.

title: Utah Murders
description: Arthur Bishop, whom police have questioned several times in recent years about the disappearance of young Salt Lake City boys, apparently came up with some answers last week.

title: Susan Frank Sets Wedding Oct. 1
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Woodrow Frank of Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of ther daughter, Susan Jane Frank, to Dr. Jeffrey Wayne Daum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Daum of Fort Lee, N.J. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Abort the Correction!

title: David A. Kenney Wed To Pamela A. Kimball
description: Pamela Ashley Kimball, daughter of Dorothy Fisher Kimball and William M. Kimball, both of New York, was married yesterday to David Anderson Kenney, son of the Rev. and Mrs. W. Murray Kenney of Cambridge, Mass.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 8 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 2 6 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 3 3 20 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) A British actress caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 4 7 4 GODPLAYER, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $13.95.) The marriage of two physicians crumbles as death stalks their hospital's corridors. 5 4 17 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 6 5 14 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 7 9 2 THE SEDUCTION OF PETER S., by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $15.95.) The sudden, danger-filled success of a long out-of-work actor.

title: Miss Fecht Is Married
description: Dorothy Anne Fecht, daughter of Dagny M. Fecht of Manchester, N.H., and the late Vitus T. Fecht Jr., was married yesterday to John Kirk Luntey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Luntey of Sands Point and Shelter Island, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Bryn Mawr, Pa., Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George E. Hollingshead Jr., assisted by the Rev. John J. O'Connor.

title: TV Newscaster Quits On the Air in Nigeria
description: A television newscaster, protesting ''news full of falsehood,'' quit on the air and walked out of the studio in Enugu, the capital of Anambra state, The Lagos Daily Sketch newspaper reported today.

title: GIving Crime A Bad Name
description: High-powered inquiries and unflattering publicity have apparently done little over the years to reduce the influence of organized crime. Nonetheless, the White House last week announced the formation of a commission whose primary duty will be, at least initially, to give the mob an even blacker reputation with public hearings around the country.

title: Wedding in Fall For Miss Wight
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Wight of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Welles Wight, to Reed E. Bunzel, son of Alison Stuart of Arcata, Calif., and John H. Bunzel of Belmont, Calif. A November wedding is planned.

title: STATE DRAFTS CAMPAIGN TO CUT UNEMPLOYMENT
description: THE state's Department of Labor is developing a double-pronged attack on unemployment. Last month, the jobless rate in New Jersey was 8.4 percent, as compared with 10 percent nationally.

title: Political Convert
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYERS IN JERSEY WILL JUDGE JUDGES
description: Lawyers will assess the performance of trial judges in three New Jersey counties, the State Supreme Court announced this week. The review may eventually be used in all the state's counties.

title: WHEN ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS CANNOT BE AVOIDED
description: To the Editor:

title: Warehouse Explosion Hurts 9 And Damages Much of Town
description: An explosion today leveled a warehouse, knocked nearby buildings off their foundations and shattered windows in nearly every house in this southern Minnesota town, witnesses said.

title: TAG SALES CAN COST SOME TROUBLE
description: TAG sales are great fun. Everybody says so. They are profitable, too, for sellers and buyers alike - and, so far, untaxed. I say: more power to those home-front entrepreneurs who are provident enough to pick up a few times a year enough change to make a down payment on an offspring's first college semester. Or whatever - a weekend at the Cape, an extra half-bathroom, dinner at Tavern on the Green.

title: IF YOU LIVE IN THE PATH OF RUNOFF WATER, DIG A TRENCH
description: HOMES on the side of a hill, or part way down on any long slope of land, often have a problem with water that comes pouring down over the surface every time it rains hard, or when melted snow starts to run off. In many cases the water creates a dampness problem inside the basement or crawl space under the house. In other cases, even if the water doesn't find its way into the basement, the runoff still causes annoying soil erosion around the outside of the house foundation and unsightly washouts in the lawn or in gardens and flower beds.

title: Vacancy Rent Allowances
description: Question: I plan to move into a different apartment in the rentstabilized complex in which I now live. I will move one month before my lease expires. How much is the owner entitled to charge me over the present tenant's rent? What penalty must I pay for moving before my lease expires? ... C.A.S., Mineola, L.I. Answer: The Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board authorized increases of 6 percent for a one-year lease, 10 percent for a two-year lease and 12 percent for a three-year lease. Martin A. Shlufman, attorney for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, also points out that beginning Oct. 1 owners are not obliged to offer three-year leases. Since you are moving within the complex, there is a vacancy allowance of a half month's rent collectible in monthly installments over the term of the new lease. If your landlord loses income on the unit you vacated, he could charge you that amount.

title: JAN STEPHENSON LEADS BY TWO
description: Pat Bradley, the 1981 United States Women's Open champion, gained a temporary lead in the third round of the 38th annual championship today with a spectacular early push that included a hole-in-one and enabled her to tie the nine-hole record for an Open with 31.

title: RESIDENT OF A HOME FIGHTS BAN ON RETURN
description: FINDING adequate, affordable housing in the New York metropolitan area is a challenge for most people. But when one is 48 years old, divorced, bright, articulate and paralyzed from the neck down, as is Howard Greene, finding a place to live is almost impossible.

title: A LINK TO LIFE
description: Sally Kalson's article about the unsung heroes who coordinate organ-procurement programs focuses attention on the vital importance of organ donations.

title: SRI LANKA CHARGES ALIENS STIR RIOTING
description: A Sri Lankan official charged today that rioting that swept the country this week was the result of a plot to overthrow the Government.

title: ABSTRACT INFLUENCES PAINTER'S REALISM
description: SINCE abundant foliage in the expected color practically follows one to the door of the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., the viewer might be amazed at the pronouncement by Wolf Kahn, who has 22 paintings and drawings on exhibition there, that he does not care much for green.

title:
GARDENING;
DROUGHT AND HEAT STRESS PERIL GARDENS
description: EARLIER this month the Central Park thermometer registered the highest temperature recorded for that date, and, according to the weather forecasters, the period ahead promises both higher than normal temperatures and lower than normal rainfall. This adds up to a combination of drought and heat stress for our gardens.

title: MANEUVERING TO GET A NAVY BASE FOR S.I. BEGAN AT 1982 PARTY
description: Over cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at a party here last year, Sidney Frigand learned that the Navy was looking for a base in the Northeast for the battleship Iowa and six other combat ships.

title: CONGRESS DIGS IN AFTER LEGISLATIVE VETO
description: Kenneth W. Dam, Deputy Secretary of State, assured Congress last week that the abolition of the so-called legislative veto need not alter the relationship between the Administration and Capitol Hill. If anything, he said, it would lead to greater consultation.

title: Miss Rodriguez And Eric Olson Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Beatriz Antonia Rodriguez and Eric Jon Olson, fourth-year medical students at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, took place at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. Stuart Sandberg performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''IT'S ANTI-THOUGHT and a distortion of the relationship between author and subject,'' said Flora Rheta Schreiber, a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York City.

title: Is There a Sauce?
description: One drawback of surviving on a diet of ants is having to catch so darned many.

title: IN-GROUND POOLS: MAKING THE RIGHT CHOICE
description: EVERYTHING about their new 20-by 42-foot swimming pool appears to delight Nancy and Robert Marshall of Cos Cob, Conn. "Testing the water, clening it, getting a little tadpole out - the puttering is fun," Mrs. Marshall said.

title: U.S. SEEKING RELICS OF ELLIS ISLAND'S PAST
description: Archeology students wearing paper smocks, dust masks and hard hats are searching the dank and crumbling rooms of Ellis Island's old immigration center for remnants of its long and colorful history.

title: DR. ARCHIE F. HAY
description: Dr. Archie F. Hay, deputy director of the Bergen County Board of Freeholders and a former County Superintendent of Schools, died of a heart attack Thursday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Waldwick, N.J.

title: BY BARBARA BELL
description: BARBARA BELL is a writer who lives in Paris.

title: No Headline
description: Other Considerations About Malpractice The article by Charles G. Loeb Jr., (''Patients, Doctors Need 'Partnership' on Malpractice'') contains some erroneous assumptions that call for a response.

title: RESTRAINT IS THE POINT
description: SOME TAME GAZELLE By Barbara Pym. 252 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $13.95.

title: HOW LISTENING TO THE NEW MAKES US RECONSIDER THE OLD
description: Most of the time, we amble semiconsciously through what we think we know. But every once in a while our somnolence is shaken awake, if only for a moment, by little jolts of insight that first remind us we don't actually know nearly much as we thought we did, but then, if we're lucky, lift our overall awareness to a higher level.

title: PROTECTING NEW-HOME BUYERS
description: FOR the buyer of a brand-new home, there is always the fear that t here may be a hidden defect in the construction, the systems or the f inish. Horror stories persist concerning floors that buckle and s iding that soon falls away from exterior walls.

title: Margaret Yanow Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mitchell Yanow of Ladue, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Jean Yanow, to Robert Alan Ouimette, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred T. Ouimette of Falmouth, Mass., and Sarasota, Fla. A September wedding is planned in St. Louis.

title: PIRATES RALLY TO DEFEAT METS
description: Unlike the World Series championship team that scored in bunches and seemingly at will during the 1979 season, the newer, younger Pittsburgh Pirates of this season have been characterized by a methodical, run-by-run attack.

title: CARNEGIE CENTER II
description: Princeton and its environs have become one of New Jersey's most dynamic centers of corporate growth in recent years. Now the planning board in West Windsor Township, of which Princeton is a part, has approved long-term plans for still another site, 246 acres west of Route 1.

title: Rose Fredericks, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Rose E. Fredericks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Fredericks of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth A. LaBresh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James LaBresh of Bloomington, Minn. The Rev. David Ames, chaplain of Brown University, performed the Episcopal ceremony at Hammersmith Farm in Newport, R.I.

title: LITERATURE TO WRITING
description: CENTURY FRENCH LITERATURE By Germaine Bree. Translated by Louise Guiney. 390 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $25.

title: THE KREMLIN ALSO USES A CARROT AND STICK
description: In the Kremlin, the blunt instrument never lies far from hand. But lately, at least in relations with the United States, there has been a finely balanced manipulation of the carrot as well as the stick. Since Leonid I. Brezhnev's death in November, Yuri V. Andropov has been busily ringing the changes, putting forward trimly packaged arms proposals one week, warning of unhappy consequences if they are rejected the next, and insisting all the while that Moscow would like nothing better than a return to the more productive days of detente.

title: THE VISUAL WIT OF MOHOLY-NAGY
description: If ever form could be said to equal content in photography, it is in the work produced in the 1920's by Laszlo Moholy-Nagy. Moholy's program for a ''New Vision'' was more than a platform for formalism; it was a radical instrument intended to liberate modern man from the constraints of habit and history. In his 1925 book ''Painting, Photography, Film,'' Moholy proclaimed that through the new photography ''everyone will be compelled to see that which is optically true, is explicable in its own terms, is objective, before he can arrive at any possible subjective position.'' In short, seeing was to make possible a new way of believing.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: WE. By Yevgeny Zamyatin. (Avon/Bard, $3.95.) A 1921 novel by a major Soviet writer that directly influenced George Orwell, ''We'' is about One State, a vast metropolis of glass which functions as ''a kind of metronome, magisterially ticking out the tiniest rhythms of daily life.'' In his 1972 review of this translation by Mirra Ginsburg, Stephen Koch alerted readers to a key difference between ''We'' and ''1984.'' The ''first volume in the library of totalitarian fantasy'' was intended to be funny, he said; ''Zamyatin sees his great city of glass not as an imminent reality but a satiric absurdity.''

title:
ART;
THE ABSTRACT INFLUENCES PAINTER'S REALISM
description: SINCE abundant foliage in the expected color practically follows one to the door of the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, the viewer might be amazed at the pronouncement by Wolf Kahn, who has 22 paintings and drawings on exhibition there, that he does not care much for green.

title: ...AND A HIGH LEVEL OF REGULAR GIGS
description: THE East End music scene, thanks to a strong combination of local and imported talent and the positive disposition of numerous club owners, is as robust this summer as it has been in years. Particularly impressive is the high level and quantity of jazz duos and trios appearing regularly in the area.
