title: PHILOSOPHER ON THE NARROW EDGE OF FAITH
description: MARTIN BUBER'S LIFE AND WORK The Middle Years 1923-45. By Maurice Friedman. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $29.95.

title: CONSTANCE CHILDS IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel R. Childs of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Crimmins Childs, to David Rosengarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Rosengarten of New York.A Sept. 9 wedding is planned.

title: Army Said to Leave Nkomo's Stronghold
description: The army's Fifth Brigade, which was trained by North Koreans, is believed to have been withdrawn from troubled Matabeleland Province, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: MEDIATORS LIGHTEN BRONX HOUSING COURT LOAD
description: When tenants, landlords and lawyers first sit down to talk with Dean Emmanuelli, they all agree about one thing. They do not like him much.

title: RAYMOND MASSEY, FAMOUS FOR HIS PORTRAYAL OF LINCOLN
description: Raymond Massey, who starred in movies as Abraham Lincoln and on television as Dr. Gillespie in the ''Dr. Kildare'' series, died Friday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles, relatives said today.

title: Extra Effort Of Kurt Sohn
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to comment on the article, ''Jets' Sohn Gets His Chance'' (The New York Times, July 24).

title: RUNNER COMPETES WITH HER INJURIES
description: TWO summers ago, the long-distance runner Burke Koncelik of East Hampton set the women's course record for the Olympic Village Summer Road Race in Huntington. Also in 1981, she set several course marks in Central Park races, won a gold medal at the National Athletic Congress in Texas and received international attention at invitational races in Sweden, Germany, Aruba and Britain and at others throughout the United States.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Just when it seemed the ballet season was over, a group of ballet figures will almost literally loom over the horizon. Liberty State Park in Jersey City, N.J., will be the novel setting for a special performance by a mixture of American and foreign dancers.

title: CONGRESS EYES ORGANIC-FARMING STUDY
description: NOT too long ago, the only people who took organic methods of agriculture seriously were a handful of faddists, and a few backyard gardeners who could risk a meager harvest if the insects attacked, the soil lacked nutrients or the weather turned bad. But on Long Island, the unconventional notion of farming without chemical fertilizers or pesticides is receiving a new respectabilty.

title: IN LITCHFIELD, AN ARMY THAT TRIES TO BE SERIOUS
description: AT first they could not hit the proverbial broadside of a barn, not to mention the shower curtain they strung up as a target in an abandoned gravel pit that they called their military practice range.

title: AID IS SOUGHT FOR JOBLESS FARM WORKERS IN ARIZONA
description: An organization that assists migrant laborers says one-third of the state's farm workers have lost their jobs or will soon be laid off and has asked Gov. Bruce Babbitt to declare a state of economic emergency.

title: 3 CANDIDATES DESCRIBE EDUCATION AS DEMOCRATS' ISSUE, NOT REAGAN'S
description: Three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination assured governors from their party today that Democrats were in political control of the education issue despite President Reagan's efforts to use it against them.

title: Javits Admitted to Hospital For Treatment of His Ailment
description: Jacob K. Javits, the former Republican Senator from New York, entered a hospital Friday for treatment of the degenerative nerve disease that helped cut short his long political career three years ago.

title: CHAVEZ AND FARM WORKERS ADAPT TACTICS TO THE TIMES
description: More than 20 years after he began his struggle to unionize the fields of the Southwest, Cesar Chavez is trying to restore the momentum of the United Farm Workers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: RABID raccoons have created a major health scare in the Maryland suburbs adjoining Washington, and New Jersey wildlife officials are worried that, sooner or later, the infected animals will make their way into the state.

title: No Headline
description: No-Problem Problems My husband and I first came across the term ''no problem'' a couple of years ago when trekking in Nepal (''Full Figuring,'' by William Safire, On Language, July 3). We had just requested a re-routing of our itinerary from the mountainous edge of the Arun Valley down to the Terai jungle area at the Chitwan Game Preserve.

title: EFFORT UNDER WAY TO GIVE SHAKESPEARE STAGE A NEW START
description: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE wrote that ''all the world's a stage,'' but now one stage built in his honor has been transformed into Connecticut's newest state park.

title: CARTER SEEKS ROLE AS NETS PLAYMAKER
description: For two seasons Reggie Carter played the role of the patient Knick, the fourth guard in a system that revolved around three.

title: SNOW FELL IN JUNE
description: VOLCANO WEATHER The Story of 1816, the Year Without a Summer. By Henry Stommel and Elizabeth Stommel. Illustrated. 177 pp. Newport, R.I.: Seven Seas Press. $15.

title: RAPID RISE FOUND IN USE OF PUBLIC LIBRARIES
description: Circulation at the nation's public libraries has increased at more than twice the rate of population growth in the past four decades, according to data compiled by a University of Illinois professor .

title: Arizona Aide Penalized For Favor to a Player
description: In an effort to head off a second round of sanctions against the University of Arizona athletic program, Athletic Director Cedric Dempsey said he had imposed tough disciplinary measures against an assistant basketball coach who gave a plane ticket to a player last fall.

title: TEACHERS BACK IN SCHOOL, TO ATTEND SUMMER SEMINARS
description: Until this summer, Phil Mead said, he had spent 13 years teaching American history and geography at Central High School in St. Paul, but he had never been offered an equitable return - the opportunity to learn.

title: BID TO KEEP KUHN SEEMS TO HAVE FAILED
description: ON Tuesday morning, July 19, a delegation of five owners and p residents of National League clubs walked into the office at the A nheuser-Busch hangar at Lambert International Airport in St. Louis. T he extraordinary, high-powered group was there not to discuss beer o r airplanes but to campaign for the re-election of Bowie Kuhn as c ommissioner of baseball.

title: KEY CAREY AIDE TO LEAVE STATE HOUSING POST
description: The chief aide in the gubernatorial administration of Hugh L. Carey said today that he would soon give up his last major post in the state government.

title:
ART;
SHOW, 'THE CONSTRUCTED IMAGE,' HAS EIGHT DISTINCT VISIONS
description: A GROUP show at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle, ''Photography: The Constructed Image'' is devoted to the work of eight photographers. On view through Sept. 2, the show is an ambitious survey that includes some of the most important work in photography today.

title: MALE AND LONELY
description: MOON DELUXE By Frederick Barthelme. 240 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: Pet Experiment
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUBLES OF THE ATOMIC BROTHERHOOD
description: NUCLEAR INC. The Men and Money Behind Nuclear Energy. By Mark Hertsgaard. 339 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: For many people, reading occult literature used to be like lifting weights: They did it but didn't talk about it because they thought they might be the only ones. But there has been a great change in the last 20 years. Thousands of bookstores have occult sections and some very prosperous stores sell only occult books. There are also an increasing number of popular authors in the field. In 1981 ''From the Mundane to the Magnificent,'' the spiritual autobiography of Vera Stanley Alder - whose ''Finding of the Third Eye'' has a great following - sold 50,000 copies and Martin Schulman's four volumes on ''Karmic Astrology'' sell by the thousands every year.

title: A MULTIPLICITY OF MUSICAL SOUNDS
description: THERE is a woodwind ensemble playing down at the pistol range, and an intermediate brass class practicing in the kitchen. Baton twirlers strut across the main floor, while a lone guitarist seated on the stairs strums quietly to himself.

title:
PROOF IN ADVERTISING;
GOVERNMENT'S RX FOR ACCOUNTABILITY
description: THE Federal Trade Commission, earlier this month, issued rulings i nvolving the advertising practices of Bristol-Myers (maker of E xcedrin, Excedrin P.M. and Bufferin) and Sterling Drug (maker of B ayer Aspirin, Vanquish, Cope and Midol). At stake were charges r aised in the early 1970's that advertising for these popular o verthe-counter drugs, promoted as therapeutically superior to other p ain relievers, lacked adequate scientific support.

title: IN BELL SYSTEM BREAKUP, SMALL IS EXPENSIVE
description: Several years ago, the telephone company serving the small Michigan town of Hickory Corners increased its basic monthly rate by 60 percent. Of the 3,000 families living there, 14 of every 100 decided they no longer could afford a telephone. Sometime later, in Big Run, Pa., the telephone company doubled its basic rate; one out of five customers dropped off the line.

title: THE NEW MATH OF CONVERSIONS
description: WHEN examining the laws governing the conversion of rental b uildings into cooperatives or condominiums in New York State, it h elps to keep a calculator close at hand.

title: SALVADORAN SAYS HE IS TRYING FOR EARLY VOTE BUT IS DOUBTFUL
description: The Provisional President of El Salvador said today that he was continuing his efforts to arrange presidential elections late this year, but that to hold them at that time would be ''very difficult.''

title: No Headline
description: Improving Services For Another Group P.A.T.H. (People Acting Together with Hope), an advocacy group of active and concerned relatives and friends of the ''so called'' mentally ill, would like to compliment you on two articles on July 10, ''Looking at the Brain as Never Before'' and '' 'Home' Functions Amid Rift.''

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT THE JAPANESE
description: say me-yak-ee), Rei Kawakubo (ray cow-wa-coo-bo) and Yojhi Yamamoto (Yo-ge ya-ma-mo-toe). Though there are several other talents whose designs are spreading commercially - among them Matsuda and Kansai - it is this trio that is spearheading a startlingly original fashion movement.

title: By Sports of The Times; Sage Advice From Solly Diamond
description: SOLLY DIAMOND went through life at his own pace and with his own wisdom. Once, for example, he sized up a particular person this way: ''If you put his brain in a canary he would fly backwards.''

title: A New Armenian Death Mission
description: Five Armenian nationalists last week found a suicidal way to crack the ''wall of silence'' they complained was muffling their cause. They stormed into the Turkish Embassy compound in Lisbon, lost one man in an exchange of shots with security guards, seized the Ambassador's residence and were killed, after a 90-minute siege, in an explosion they apparently ignited. A Turkish diplomat's wife and a Portuguese policeman also died.

title: 163 Children Die in Tanzania
description: A mysterious disease has killed 163 children in the Kilwa district of southern Tanzania in the last three months, the Government press agency said today.

title: Herbert Dunn Married To Kathleen Williams
description: Kathleen Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Matthew Williams of White Plains and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married yesterday to Herbert E. Dunn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert K. Dunn of Kailua, Hawaii. Justice of the Peace Barbara DeWolfe Little performed the ceremony in the garden of Hildene, the Robert Todd Lincoln Estate, in Manchester, Vt.

title: BECKETT DISTILLS HIS VISION
description: In his art, Samuel Beckett pursues a course of courageous and pragmatic pessimism. Despite personal dilemmas and public calamities, man strives onward, adapting himself to each crisis and devising new methods of endurance. In his latest fiction, ''Worstward Ho,'' Beckett urges, ''Try again. Fail again. Fail better.'' From his point of view, the destination is unavoidable but the journey can be alleviated. For the past 25 years, since ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' he has been distilling his vision, bringing his theater and his fiction into closer proximity and writing plays for one or two voices, a speaker and a silent listener or sentinel. Often these are two aspects of one persona. In some of the plays we do not even see a whole man or woman: the incessantly moving lips of the woman in ''Not I''; the disembodied head surrrounded by a flaring corona of white hair in ''That Time.'' In others we glimpse an isolated figure in limbo: the daughter calculating her steps in ''Footfalls.'' Though these plays are brief, some lasting a scant 15 minutes, in performance the effect can be awesome - a biographical time line refined into a single mesmerizing image.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Bird No. 1 on Computer
description: Moses Malone of the Philadelphia 76ers may be the National Basketball Association's most valuable player in the eyes of the press, but when an array of statistics was fed into a computer, Larry Bird's name popped out as the league's best player.

title: R.B. Golum Betrothed To Pamela Joan Ruben
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Ruben of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Joan Ruben, to Robert B. Golum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Golum of Long Beach, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
EXPLORING THE STATE'S RESORT AREAS
description: WHEN visiting resort areas, it is easy enough to find a large restaurant on the main thoroughfare, but small eating places tucked away on side streets are often jealously guarded by the local gentry.

title: EVENING OF KERN IS A PLEASURE
description: IVORYTON Playhouse's ''Ladies and Gentlemen, Jerome Kern!'' is being promoted as ''the most tuneful musical revue ever.'' For once, such hyperbole just might be justified.

title: An Exercise in Engineering
description: THE first time I saw Honda's new baby, I was with a couple of Detroit engineers. As we walked by the silver car, both of them clucked a bit and shook their heads in what - coming from the competition - amounted to a nod of approval. ''Looks like a Mercedes,'' one of them grumbled.

title: Cup Aspirants Rich and 'Poor'
description: The seven foreign syndicates competing this summer in the trials to select the America's Cup defender fall into the categories of the haves and the have-nots.

title: 21 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 21 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. It also named five that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Yugoslavs Relax Reins On Lagging Economy
description: Prime Minister Milka Planinc has asked Parliament to reduce Government intervention and allow freer rein to market forces in the debt-ridden economy.

title: ENCHANTMENTS OF THE HUNDRED ACRE WOOD
description: POOH BEAR moved into my apartment a few months ago. I cannot say exactly when because it was some time before I knew it was him. I was helping my 5-year-old son, Michael, into bed one night when I learned of Pooh Bear's arrival. ''And here's Smokey,'' I said, tucking a soft, brown stuffed bear beneath the covers. ''That's not Smokey,'' Michael replied. ''That's Pooh, Winnie the Pooh.'' ''Oh,'' I said, somewhat surprised. ''I hadn't recognized him. When did hemove in?'' ''Weeks ago,'' came the reply, as if I should have known. That was fine with me. I had grown tired of preventing forest fires when Smokey was Smokey. And I thought that even a bear with very little brain would be an improvement over one with an obsession with pyromania.

title: Soviet Warns of Retaliation If U.S. Deploys New Missiles
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that the Soviet Union would take retaliatory measures if the United States went ahead with plans to deploy new medium-range missiles in Western Europe. He stressed that Moscow was not seeking nuclear superiority.

title: SOLAR GRILL CUTS COOKING TIME
description: A SILVERY parabolic dish that sits in the backyard of Dr. Raymond J. Krisst of West Hartford is sometimes mistaken by passers-by for a work of modern art or a space age radio antenna.

title: NICARAGUA IS NOT AN ENEMY
description: You don't have to think that the Sandanistas are doing anything right to know that the United States is doing everything wrong. But that hardly takes care of the matter. The Administration appears totally out of touch with reality. What, for example, does President Reagan mean when he calls the Sandinistas ''totalitarian,'' their Government ''Marxist-Leninist''?

title: RENTALS: SCARCE AND COSTLY
description: THERE is a critical shortage of rental housing on the Island, according to planners and real-estate agents here, and this has made the median price of rental housing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties the highest in the state.

title: 'TOREADORS,' A MERRY FARCE
description: JEAN ANOUILH'S politically metaphorical play, ''Antigone,'' is the one most often chosen by small theaters. The Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, however, has reached deeper into Anouilh's collection and pulled out ''The Waltz of the Toreadors,'' a complex farce that has a serious, nonfarcical theme plopped plunk in its middle.

title: OPERA: BAYREUTH CAST PERFORMS 'SIEGRFIED'
description: It is getting late in the game here and Sir Peter Hall still has not dropped a hint as to what his new production of Wagner's ''Ring'' is all about. The suspicion grows that it may be about nothing at all. Thursday evening's premiere of ''Siegfried,'' the third installment in the four-work cycle, came and went without the appearance of any vital connective thread. It is as if the British director, having decided against imitating all recent interpretations of the ''Ring,'' found himself with an empty bucket.

title: SOME SIMPLE RULES TO SMOOTH THE WAY FOR SUNDAY MARKETING
description: NOT all that long ago, I was pleased as punch ($1.26 for a halfgallon container) that supermarkets in suburbia had finally been allowed to open Sunday. After all, who had any orange juice in the house at 9 o'clock on Sunday morning? No one. Invariably, Dad - or a designated driver - had to scour the community for some mom and pop store to be open so that the family could have its morning o.j.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COMPUTER SYSTEM FOR COLLECTORS AND DEALERS
description: Computer technology has thus far not played a major role in affecting the direction of the coin market -but that may change soon if two Michigan men are correct. Joseph Lepczyk of East Lansing and Dr. Lawrence B. Brilliant of Ann Arbor have devised a new computer system aimed at serving the needs of everyone who buys and sells coins, and they claim it has the potential to alter the hobby's future course in a fundamental manner.

title:
CAMERA;
POINTERS ON CHOOSING AND USING TRIPODS
Perfumes
description: To the Editor: In reference to the article, ''More Scents for the Dollar'' (Travel, June 26), I should like to add to your suggestions for sources of perfumes: Ann Paree, 14 rue Duphot, 75001 Paris.

title: A LEGACY OF WEAKNESS
description: Some defenses make a good impression in the early stages of a game. They permit a smooth development of the pieces, and if the opponent is not tactically accurate these pieces can counterattack punishingly.

title: GIRLS' JUNIOR GOLF
description: The first-ever Westchester County Girls' Junior Golf Championship will be played starting at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle ''to fill a gap in the Westchester Golf Association,'' said Lloyd Monroe, the club pro.

title: In Poland, the Mixture as Before
description: Since the end of martial law the week before last, only a few Poles have noticed a difference. Officials said 1,181 prisoners, the great majority non-political, had been released under an amnesty but socalled temporary measures and permanent changes in the penal code voted by Parliament last week made it clear the repression of dissent would continue to be part of routine life in Poland.

title: ENHANCING IMAGERY BY USING ALL THAT GLITTERS
description: ACCORDING to Shakespeare, ''All that glisters is not gold,'' an observation borne out by the current exhibitions at two Southampton galleries, where, at the moment, there is a great deal of glistering - or, to use more modern terminology, glittering -going on. The shows in question feature works by artists using gold leaf and other metallic finishes to enhance the visual and emotional impact of their imagery.

title: A Purchaser Of Last Resort For Shoreham?
description: The first to be evacuated from the Shoreham nuclear power plant may be its owner, the Long Island Lighting Company. Governor Cuomo asked the New York Power Authority last week to explore the purchase of the nearly completed $3.2 billion reactor in an effort to assist the ailing utility and reduce huge rate increases for its customers.

title: CONSERVATIVES PRESS FIGHT TO CURB LEGAL AID
description: Some political brawls here never seem to end, they just fade into the background with fists flying unabated. One of these is the bitter fight between liberal, activist legal aid lawyers and their conservative Republican enemies in Congress and the Reagan Administration.

title: TEHERAN REPORTS DRIVE AGAINST IRAQ
description: Iran said today that it had opened its second offensive in a week against Iraq, attacking on the central battlefront.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: CHADIANS ANNOUNCE RETAKING KEY TOWN FROM THE INSURGENTS
description: The northern town of Faya-Largeau, held by rebels, was retaken today by the Government forces of President Hissen Habre, the Chadian military command announced.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM For its sheer strangeness alone, Slava Tsukerman's ''Liquid Sky'' is worth recommending, though certainly not to everyone. This New Wave fantasy, now at the Waverly on Sixth Avenue at 3d Street, has enough sex, violence, all-around meanness and bizarre fashion sense to make it a specialty item as far as most audiences are concerned.

title: HOT-AIR BALLOONS
description: ''Balloonsbury, N.J.'' will be the official postmark and legal name of the Hunterdon County commmunity of Bloomsbury next weekend. That is when 65 hot-air balloons will be competing in the Northeast Regional Balloon Championships and the 200th anniversary of balloon flight will be observed.

title: Athletes Seem Too Serious
description: To the Sports Editor: For some time I have been annoyed by the lugubrious attitudes and facial expressions displayed by athletes, many of whom are talented, admired, emulated and inordinately wealthy. They rarely smile.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A NEW YORK children's charity has pledged $200,000 toward the purchase of a former elementary school building to house a Syossetbased preschool for children with learning and behavioral problems.

title: Nell Hoffman and R.E.L. Bonaparte Are Married
description: Nell Hoffman, an associate in the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, was married yesterday to Robert Edward Lee Bonaparte, an associate in the Washington office of the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. The Rev. Judith Wagner, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Faculty Club of the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are living through a period of a teen-age employment disaster. What has it done to the teen-agers and the city? We have created a lost generation.'' - Herbert Bienstock, director of Queens College's Center for Labor and Urban Problems Research and Analysis. (32:1.)

title:
DINING OUT;
A PIECE OF SWITZERLAND IN RYE
description: QUIVERING with exclamation points, recent advertisements for Jacqueline's seem bursting with the news that the restaurant is ''going Swiss.'' The stylized mountaintop logo, a smart new blue and white menu displaying the banners of the Swiss Cantons and some Alpine-sounding dishes certainly testify to Swissness. But a look at the old Gipfel's menu, as well as at Jacqueline's early and most recent menus reveals that, except for the prices, the more it changes, the more it is the same. The owner, Hans Altenhoff, and the chef, Christian Schwab, both Swiss-born, have been with the restaurant since its inception in 1971. It would seem that while you can take the boys out of Switzerland, you can't take Switzerland out of the boys.

title: Tillie Laird Plans To Marry Oct. 15
description: Tillie Page Laird and Hunter Donaldson Brown plan to be married Oct. 15 in Wilmington, Del. The announcement of their engagement has been made by Miss Laird's parents, Mrs. Frederic Eli Mygatt 3d of Wilmington and Washington Depot, Conn., and Joseph Packard Laird of Wilmington.

title: DEBATE GROWS ON U.S. LISTING OF HAITIANS IN AIDS CATEGORY
description: An international controversy has arisen over whether American health officials have unfairly categorized residents of Haiti and Haitians in the United States as having an increased risk of contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, a fatal and thus far incurable disease.

title: ART OF THE FAR NORTH FOCUS OF TORONTO SHOW
description: The great concepts of Western art do not carry much meaning in the Far North, where the pale horizon seems limitless, winter nights are months long and the culture is part of an ages-old way of life.

title: THE 'MACHISMO GAME' IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTER FOR ARTISTS ENCOUNTERS A SETBACK IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE WHAT began last October as plans for a visual-arts center in The Loft, an underutilized industrial building at 55 Webster Avenue, has become a successful grouping of studios for artists and designers on the building's fourth floor. But the arts center will not expand to other floors, as originally planned, because of financial considerations facing the landlord, a spokesman for the city said last week, and a real-estate agent representing prospective artist tenants must now seek space elsewhere.

title: 1973 METS REVIVE A MONTH OF GLORY
description: Like a blur, the Mets won the pennant in 1973, rushing from last place in August as if they had been hiding the master plan in their back pockets all along. But when the players returned yesterday for the 10-year class reunion, faces smiling, still young, it wasn't destiny they thanked.

title: The Political Environment
description: President Reagan's front-line generals on environmental policy took a few steps beyond the White House trenches last week. William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said the Administration had misread its mandate on the environment.

title: PROVING MOB VIOLENCE IS HARDEST OF ALL
description: Shortly after midnight on June 22, 1982, three black New York City transit workers leaving a bagel shop near a Brooklyn subway yard were the target of a white youth shouting racial insults. One of the black men took exception. More young whites converged. The workers' station wagon stalled and the crowd began breaking its windows. Within minutes, two of the blacks were running for their lives, one seriously hurt by a bottle thrown at his head. The third lay dying, beaten with fists and a stick.

title: 2 P.L.O. FACTIONS CLASH NEAR A LEBANESE TOWN
description: Palestinian guerrilla factions battled today with artillery and machine guns outside this town before Syrian troops arranged a cease-fire, witnesses said.

title: CHILEAN HIGH COURT REBUFFS PINOCHET ON PROTESTS
description: The Chilean Supreme Court, in a rebuff to the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet, has upheld the dismissal of charges against six political leaders who were arrested for trying to organize a protest demonstration this month.

title: Orioles Defeat Rangers, 7 to 4
description: Scott McGregor won his 13th game, and Eddie Murray's triple highlighted a four-run seventh inning as the Baltimore Orioles won their fourth straight game with a 7-4 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight.

title: Brett Gets His Bat Back
description: George Brett got his pine-tar bat back today, just in time for the Kansas City Royals' game with the Detroit Tigers.

title: FOOD STAMP PLAN SIGNED BY REAGAN
description: White House officials dispatched a $7.1 billion supplemental appropriation bill to Camp David by special courier today and President Reagan signed it so as to prevent food stamp benefits from being curtailed for lack of funds.

title: AUSTRALIA YACHT IN CUP SEMIFINAL
description: Australia II became the first America's Cup yacht to qualify for the August challenger semifinals when she defeated Challenge 12 of Australia by 50 seconds today.

title: Nuptials for Miss Keepnews
description: The marriage of Mary Susanne Keepnews to Walter L. Renz took place yesterday at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y. Judge Francis A. Nicolai of Westchester County Court performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Lawrence William Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Keepnews, who was State Superintendent of Insurance. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Renz of Larchmont, N.Y. His father is fashion advertising manager for Harper's Bazaar magazine.

title: 9 LATIN MINISTERS FAIL TO ACHIEVE ACCORD ON REGION
description: The foreign ministers of nine Latin American countries ended a round of meetings here today without agreeing on how to put a Central America peace plan into effect.

title: Jill Schosberg Is Wed To Timothy J. Stoller
description: Jill E. Schosberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Schosberg of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy J. Stoller, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stoller of Red Hook, N.Y. Judge Albert A. Blinder of the New York State Court of Claims performed the ceremony at the Capriccio Restaurant in Brewster, N.Y.

title: Ins and Outs at The Brink's Trial
description: There was order, but not always defendants, in the court last week as the Brink's trial slowly proceeded in Goshen, N.Y. The trio of self-described ''freedom fighters,'' ejected two weeks ago for arguing with Judge David Ritter, returned on Monday, only to walk out a day later. ''For us to give legitimacy to picking a jury for an illegitimate trial is to condition people to accept fascist measures,'' said Judith A. Clark before she, David J. Gilbert and Kuwesi Balagoon (formerly Donald Weems) left.

title: SYRIA'S CLAIMS: THE OLD ORDER
description: SYRIA'S territorial claims to its neighbors have deep historical roots. From antiquity until the early 20th century, ''Syria'' referred to the whole settled area at the eastern end of the Mediterranean, from the Taurus Mountains in the north to the Sinai peninsula in the south and from the Mediterranean Sea in the west to the Syrian desert in the east.

title: Roosevelt Watts Dies; Transport Union Aide
description: Roosevelt Watts, international secretary-treasurer of the Transport Workers of America and one of the first blacks to hold a top position in a major labor union, died of cancer Friday at Astoria General Hospital in Queens. He was 68 years old and lived in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Town of 6 People Wins Suit Against a Railroad
description: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company lost a suit against Lost Springs, Wyo., on Friday.

title: Public Radio Gets Reprieve, But Stay Tuned
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting decided last week to keep National Public Radio on the air with a plan to rescue it from $9.1 million in debts. The corporation distributes Federal money to public radio and television. Under terms of a tentative agreement, scheduled for completion Tuesday, it will lend the radio network $8.5 million, forgive $600,000 in debts and institute strict financial controls over day-to-day operations. NPR received an advance of $500,000 so it could meet its Friday payroll.

title: Comings and Goings
description: George Halas, the 87-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears, has been released from Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He underwent surgery in May for an intestinal problem. ... Bob Cousy and Oscar Robertson are among the former N.B.A. stars who have agreed to suit up for an oldtimers' game Aug. 9 in Monticello, N.Y., before the annual Maurice Stokes benefit game. ... Following the lead of New York boxing authorities, the Nevada State Athletic Commission voted unanimously to ban the trainer Carlos (Panama) Lewis. He was banned in New York after having been accused of tampering with a boxer's gloves. ... A Louisiana horse trainer, Joe Dorignac 3d, the son of the owner of the Fair Grounds in New Orleans, was suspended from racing for 30 days after cocaine had been found in the bloodstream of one of his horses.

title: Jennifer Stevens Is Married
description: Jennifer Dawn Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gardner Stevens of Williamsburg, Mass., was married in Northampton, Mass., yesterday to Charles Thompson Vogelbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vogelbach of Thompson Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. James Moore, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College. Mrs. Vogelbach is a graduate of Wellesley College and her husband of Harvard College.

title: FOR MUNICIPALS, THE BIGGEST DEFAULT
description: Default finally came at the Washington Public Power Supply System, and bondholders of some $2.25 billion now have little hope of ever getting their money back. It was the biggest municipal default in history - one expected since the State Supreme Court earlier in the month upheld a lower court ruling that 88 utilities were not obligated to meet payments on the bonds. ''The money just isn't in the till,'' said a power system spokesman, after the system had informed Chemical Bank that it could not pay its debts on partially completed nuclear plants Nos. 4 and 5. The default should make it much more difficult for other municipalities in the Pacific Northwest to borrow money. Now brokerage firms and the supply system itself are bracing for a possible avalanche of lawsuits from debt holders.

title: WHERE SCULPTORS FORGE THEIR ART
description: Silhouetted against a big square window that looks out on to one of the Hudson River's most graceful curves, the artist Nancy Graves, blue paisley scarf tied around her blond hair, reaches into her sturdy canvas bag and gently places several fish maws, a lotus flower, some okra, bamboo shoots and wicker rings on a desk at the Tallix Art Foundry in Peekskill, N.Y. If Richard Polich, owner of the foundry, and his workers possibly can, they will cast these forms in bronze and help Miss Graves build one of her elaborate, fanciful works of art. That is why, since 1977, she has been making this trip an average of two times a week.

title: THE CROSBY SYSTEM-ARTISTIC HEALTH THROUGH CONTAINMENT
description: ''The question that always haunts me,'' reflected John Crosby of the Santa Fe Opera the other day, ''is to know which comes first - the repertory or the artist? You can't just say we'll do 'Aida' and then see who's available. You have to have a plan - a repertory plan that captures the interest of conductors and singers and at the same time fits their talents.''

title: 54 Youths Are Seized In Sweep of Times Sq.
description: A 12-hour sweep of the Times Square area to crack down on roving bands of youths who have been preying on tourists ended early yesterday with 54 arrests, the police reported.

title: NASSAU DEMOCRATS CAUTIOUS
description: DESPITE the jailing of Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican chairman, Democrats in the county are not optimistic about the possibility that they can capitalize on the Republican problems and make major inroads this fall in town governments.

title: SUMMER BRINGS BASIL, FAVA BEANS AND RASPBERRIES
description: FRESH basil, fresh fava beans, and raspberries at a reasonable price are among the many summer treats now available. A salade Ni,coise with fava beans instead of string beans is a delightful variation on the traditional Mediterranean. In recent years, fava beans (or broad beans, as they are known in England), have become increasingly popular. They can now be found in farmer's markets and in roadside stands, sold in large furry pods that must be peeled before the beans are cooked.

title: A Link to Life An omission in Sally Kalson's otherwise excellent article, ''A Link to Life'' (June 19), was the information that organ donation can be a simple and uncomplicated procedure, thought over not in the stage of emotional crisis in a hospital, but at home, while all is well.  Most states have an organ-donor card as part of the driver's license. For nondrivers, and for those living in the few states that do not provide such easy access, organ-donor cards can be obtained from hospitals.
description: The cards contain information about which organs are to be donated; two witnesses are required for the donor's signature to be valid; and again in most states, there is a box on the front of the driver's license where one can indicate that he is an organ donor.

title: FROM MUSEUM TO MARKET
description: The Smithsonian Institution is going public, in a manner of speaking. Or at least that part of it that produces recordings. It has undertaken an agreement with Intersound, producer and distributor of such labels as Pro Arte and Quintessence, to market through retail stores its original recordings of the classics and of American music, including jazz. Up to now, these recordings have been sold only through the mail - primarily to Smithsonian magazine subscribers - and at its shop in Washington.

title: NATURAL GAS SHORTAGE ON THE U.S. HORIZON
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My husband and I are race-car buffs and we also enjoy driving in Europe. There seems, however, to be no way to find out the schedule for Formula One Grand Prix races, which we could use in our travels here and abroad. Could you find us a calendar? - L.F.T., Nantucket, Mass. Answer:The 1983 Formula One Grand Prix race season began March 13 in Brazil and will end Oct. 15 in South Africa. (Formula One generally refers to single-seat fenderless cars, with 1.5-liter turbocharged engines, that represent the leading edge of automotive technology.) Major automobile manufacturers currently represented in Formula One racing include Renault, Fiat (the owner of Ferrari), Alfa-Romeo, Porsche, Ford and Honda.

title: ARE THE TEAMS DOING ENOUGH IN N.F.L. DRUG CASES?
description: MY use of pharmacological technology in professional football began with the Dallas Cowboys and ended with the New York Giants. That was in the 1960's. Drugs were misused and misunderstood then, they are misused and misunderstood now, and they pose a grave threat to the game.

title: Requiem for a Grain Embargo
description: ''If we are going to feed the Russian Army,'' asked Senator Moynihan, ''what right have we to complain about the way ... the Soviet Union causes trouble anywhere in the world?''

title: POLITICS AND PRAYERS MIX AT CATHEDRAL IN SALVADOR
description: The Metropolitan Cathedral of San Salvador has a look of anguish about it. Steel reinforcement bars twist out of the walls, inside and outside. Thick plastic sheets cover the high, arched windows that in other churches would be radiantly mystical with stained glass. Vertical neon tubes light the altar. The flowers always seem wilted, the plastic bouquets always dusty.

title: French Rail Pass
description: To the Editor: Apropos European train travel, I would like to bring to your readers' attention ''la carte vermeil,'' the senior-citizen pass (for those 55 and over) that we purchased in France in 1982; it is valid for a year and entitles one to about half-price on all French railroads in all classes, even TGV. A. M. FRAADE

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Poisoned Well Tetrachloroethylene. Dibromochloropropane. These tongue-twisters are but two of some 700 manufactured chemicals currently poisoning America's drinking water. ''The cheapest way to get rid of hazardous material is to throw it into the ground,'' says Ann Black of ABC News. Miss Black has produced ''Water - A Clear and Present Danger,'' an ABC Closeup on the frightening state of the nation's drinking water. The hour-long documentary will be broadcast Friday evening at 10.

title: Charles Reginald Jelicks Jr.  Weds Maureen Anne Leidl
description: Maureen Anne Leidl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph F. Leidl of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married there yesterday to Charles Reginald Jelicks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jelicks of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. John T. Uris performed the ceremony in Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: AND THAT'S THE WAY IT WAS
description: JONES BEACH has been a member of the wedding ever since my parents married themselves to Long Island 35 years ago. But as Frankie in the Carson McCullers play noted, ''Life is surely a sudden place.'' Jones Beach has changed all of a sudden, and yet slowly over the years.

title: THE KING OF THE H.M.O. MOUNTAIN
description: IN 1933, a plucky young surgeon named Dr. Sidney Garfield picked the Mojave Desert as a place to mend the sick, near the site where an aqueduct was being built to carry water to Los Angeles. Alas, most ill workmen journeyed past him to be healed. So Dr. Garfield hatched a plan. If insurers prepaid him 5 cents a day a worker, he would furnish all their medical care. His waiting room filled up.

title: SHORE UTILITY FINDS ITSELF IN A 'CATCH-22'
description: PLEASANTVILLE CONFLICTING orders by state and Federal regulatory agencies have given a small electric utility here a multimillion-dollar headache. ''It's a 'Catch-22' situation,'' said Joseph G. Salomone, vice president of the Atlantic Electric Company. ''We have a Federal order saying that we have a binding agreement, and a state order saying that we have no agreement.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 31, 1983
description: International Quotas for Chinese textile exports have been agreed on by China and the United States, it was reported in Geneva by the correspondent of China's official press agency. The agreement would end a trade battle that strained relations and led to a sharp reduction in China's purchases of American farm products. (Page 1, Column 6.) Talks in Panama on a peace plan for Central America ended inconclusively as the foreign ministers of nine Latin American countries failed to agree on how to put the plan into effect. However, the ministers said that they had ''advanced in the process of negotiations intended to build a stable and enduring peace.'' (1:4.)

title: UNDER MANHATTAN BRIDGE, A MALL
description: For the last few years, the city has been searching for ways to capitalize on the space underneath its East River bridges. Until recently, however, most of the ideas had gone no further than the drawing board.

title: BIRDING IN EAST AFRICA, MOSCOW ON PARADE; Kenya Safaris Focus on Birds
description: Yes, there will doubtless be glimpses of lion and cheetah and oryx and dik dik and elephant and Cape buffalo and giant forest hog. Perhaps even a rhino. And, of course, visits among the Masai and Kikuyu and Samburu tribesmen. But the real focus of the 21-day safaris scheduled to leave New York Nov. 7, Nov. 28 and next Jan. 2 - bound for such destinations as Nairobi, Olorgesailie, Samburu and Mombasa - is birds: red and yellow ground barbets, gray-headed social weavers, Somali ostrich, pygmy falcon, eagles, cormorants, pelicans, spoonbills, lammergeyer, vultures, bustards, lilac-breasted rollers, Fisher's starlings and more.

title: WARY FRESH AIR FUND CAMPERS AWAIT 'THE HAIRY MAN'
description: One fine, hot Saturday, the children of Camp Hidden Valley woke to stirrings of fear. Reports had come in, mainly from counselors, that an awful hairy thing was loose in the woods.

title: U.K. Train
description: To the Editor: As a Britisher, born and bred (till the age of 65) in England, I feel sure there must have been an inquiry after the trip from London to Edinburgh in a Great Western Railway train described by Milton Stoneman in his letter (Travel, June 26). Someone would want to know how a GWR train got diverted to the London and Northeastern Railway line, and heads would have rolled.efore nationalization of the British railways, there were two routes from London to Scotland.

title: JAZZ ON L.I.: A FESTIVAL'S DEBUT
description: AS a jazz impresario, Ann H. Sneed naturally believes that the music she brings to Long Island as the executive director of the International Art of Jazz is ''what people want - a response to the tremendous interest in this art form.'' And this week, at least, her assessment of the public's musical taste seems right on target. With 10 concerts on tap, including the debut of the Island's first free jazz festival, jazz is the centerpiece of the Long Island summer music scene.

title: Window Where Oswald Fired To Be Protected by a Shield
description: Visitors to the old Texas School Book Depository Building will no longer be allowed to look out the window where Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President Kennedy in 1963, according to a preservation plan for the historic site.

title: 600 Flee Explosion Of Tank Car in Louisiana
description: A valve on a tank car ruptured today at a plastics plant, setting off an explosion that ignited two other containers, injured two workers and forced more than 600 people to flee their homes.

title: TAPPING YOUR C.D. BEFORE IT MATURES
description: ''S UBSTANTIAL penalties for early withdrawal'' seems to be a ubiquitous phrase these days. It crops up on ads and passbooks of financial institutions offering certificates of deposit maturing in a specified number of months or years. But those penalties hardly include being flogged in public. Rather, financial institutions will only reduce the interest you receive if you withdraw the funds before maturity.

title: GREAT ARTISTS OF THE PAST LEAVE THEIR IMPRINT ON THE MOVIES OF TODAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carrie Rickey writes frequently on art and on film. By CARRIE RICKEY

title: MERINGUE, IN MEIRINGEN
description: When Napoleon visited the Swiss town of Meiringen, the story goes, a local chef prepared a cookie made with sugar, cinnamon, nuts and egg yolks. In order not to waste the leftover egg whites, the chef whipped them together with sugar, then slow-baked puffy mounds of the new concoction until they were dry and crispy and served them in saucers brimming with sweet cream. Napoleon is said to have called the dessert meringue after the town.

title: CRAFTS
description: AMONG the recently published books on crafts, a few stand out as particularly fitting for this season. ''Woodworking With Kids'' by Richard Starr (Taunton Press, Newtown, Conn., $18.95) offers one answer to a youngster's perennial question, ''What can I do?''

title: ON CREATIVE LOAFING
description: This is the time of year to consider the advantages of creative loafing, and the Congress of the United States, by unanimous consent, is taking the month of August off to consider them.

title: WE'RE OLD, NOT SENILE, RONALD
description: There is a theory of health-cost containment in vogue in Washington and among certain members of the medical establishment that suggests that good old supply-and-demand principles can reduce not only what it costs to treat the elderly and the poor but also the whole cost to our society of health care.

title: Lasting Impression
description: Others will learn from the mistakes of a Nebraska highway contracting firm that was recently found guilty of bid rigging.

title: EXPANDING PLANS AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: In 1979, Symphony Space, a nonprofit, community-supported performing-arts organization that often sponsors programs in which neighborhood performers participate, bought an old theater at 95th Street and Broadway in January 1979. Then it applied for a propertytax exemption as an educational and cultural insitution.

title: A FAITH IN INDIA HOPES TO HEAL 1,800-YEAR RIFT
description: Leaders of Jainism, one of the ancient faiths of India, say they are trying to move gradually toward eliminating some of the 1,800-year-old differences that keep it split into two major sects. They are hoping to make a beginning, they say, through cooperation on social welfare projects.

title: SYNGE TO JOYCE
description: A COLDER EYE The Modern Irish Writers. By Hugh Kenner. 301 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: PIED PIPER OF THE CLARINET
description: Robert W. Stock is a senior editor of this magazine.

title: WAS A MEDAL SO IMPORTANT?
description: AWEEK after the funeral of Sergei Shlibashvili in Tbilisi, Georgia, the international diving schedule moves toward t he 1984 Olympics. But nobody who was present at the World UniversityG ames earlier this month will soon forget the deliberate and perhaps f earful pace of the young Soviet athlete as he practiced the dive t hat would kill him.

title: HOUSING FOR AGED GAINS IN GREAT NECK
description: ONE aspect of a controversy that has been simmering since last spring on the Great Neck peninsula has been resolved. With approval last week by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development of tenant-selection criteria for admission to a 74-unit low-income housing project for the elderly on Middle Neck Road and Arrandale Avenue, a long, contentious chapter in the story is approaching a conclusion - barring unexpected eventualities.

title: Hotels
description: To the Editor: The article, ''Memo to Hotel Managers'' by Enid Nemy (Travel, July 10) contained many items of interest to both men and women. Very few hotels have adequate light for reading, so much so that I often carry my own bulb.

title: Lebanon's Risky Real Estate Game Goes On
description: Lebanon's capacity for self-government was tested anew last week and the results were not brilliant. Syrian forces suddenly withdrew to the outskirts of the northern city of Tripoli, vacating strongholds that were promptly occupied by rival Lebanese militias. The militiamen thereupon resisted efforts by Beirut authorities to bring in national police.

title: YANKS LOSE TO WHITE SOX BY 5-1 AND FALL TO FOURTH
description: Three hits each by Tom Paciorek and Vance Law sparked the White Sox to a 5-1 victory tonight and sent the Yankees back into fourth place in the American League East with their second straight loss.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Salting It Away

title: A CLASSIC SUBURB FEELS GRAYING PAINS
description: The demographics that have changed countless cities and suburbs across the country have finally caught up with a place whose name was once synonymous with growth. An aging population and a shrinking school enrollment has forced Levittown officials to do something that would have been unthinkable in the boom years - close a high school. Work was under way last week to convert it into a district, adult- and special-education headquarters.

title: HIGH TENSION HIGH TECH; Sailing Upscale
description: Anyone can see that an airplane built in 1983 is much more sophisticated than the DC-3 of World War II days. Only sailors - and racing sailors at that - see how big a gap separates the design of the J-boats that raced for the America's Cup in the 20's and 30's from those that shape the fleet competing off Newport this summer.

title: CHURCHES SEE CHARITY'S LIMITS
description: When President Reagan announced massive cutbacks in federally funded antipoverty programs in his first budget, he said he expected the private sector - mostly the nation's churches and charitable organizations - to fill the gap. Church leaders protested loudly, saying their organizations were far too poor to compensate for the reduction in Government money for housing, remedial education, food stamps and related programs.

title: WHAT PRICE FOR CONTROLS ON HEALTH COSTS?
description: EVERYTHING we hear and read seems to suggest that we are on the threshold of extraordinary innovations in American medicine. The innovations that the medical profession is gearing up for, however, have quite a different emphasis from the ones that the public is being exposed to in the media.

title: THE NETWORKS SHRUG OFF VIOLENCE
description: Granted that the television networks are an easy target, that violence has many causes, and that when it first was argued that television contributed to the rise in violence the argument was made more from instinct than from data. Grant all these things; it is still depressing when the networks now insist that a viewer who has seen, say, 18,000 simulated murders by the time he is 17 has not had his psyche altered.

title: Belgium
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed the article by Jane Gross on the Oude Abdij in Lo, Belgium, ''Flemish Inn Aims High'' (Travel, April 17), and recently returned from a five-week trip that included an unscheduled stay there. t all started with a telephone call from Amsterdam to inquire about reservations.

title: INSTITUTE FOCUSES ON PROBLEMS FACED BY NEW TEACHERS
description: IN an effort to improve their teaching performance in the classroom, a small group of teachers from independent schools in Westchester recently participated in a three-week summer institute held at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: JACKSON MOVES FAST FOR ONE WHO HASN'T YET DECIDED TO RUN
description: After leaving the Atlanta hotel where the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's Operation PUSH held its annual convention last week, one politician marveled, ''He's got a train going.'' In the parlance of politics, that means Mr. Jackson has already whipped up fervor among his followers for his possible 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: FRANCIS T.P. PLIMPTON, 82, DIES
description: Francis T.P. Plimpton, the diplomat, lawyer, civic leader and former president of the City Bar Association, died yesterday at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: West Bank Arabs Stone Car
description: Arabs in the occupied West Bank town of Qalqilya stoned a car today, slightly injuring the Israeli driver, the military command said.

title: A NEW GUIDE RATES SECONDARY SCHOOLS
description: A NEW book of statistical information about New Jersey's public and private secondary schools may be useful for parents who are considering switching educational systems within the state.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ENTERTAINERS and athletes are among the people admired by children, who often try to emulate them. One such person is 24-year-old Marc Feinson of Fair Lawn, a professional clown known as ''Mr. Giggles.''

title: ON THE TRAIL OF $300 BILLION IN GOVERNMENT INEFFICIENCY
description: For nearly a year now, J. Peter Grace has commanded an army of some 1,400 volunteer business executives combing the Government for inefficiency, extravagance and fraud. It is the most ambitious search ever undertaken for ways to curb Federal spending, now running at a rate of $83 million an hour.

title: PUTTING GOLF ON THE FAST TRACK
description: John Tarkov is a senior editor of Geo Magazine.AS IF WE DIDN'T HAVE ENOUGH PROBLEMS TO DEAL WITH IN America, we now confront this one: Professional golfers have not been playing the game at a suitably brisk pace. This is a chronic condition, like a recurring wart on the nose of the Republic. The golfing immortal Gene Sarazen, for one, inveighed against it 50 years ago. But now, the problem is magnified.

title: PACE PROFESSOR DISCOVERS EARLY BLACK VOICE FOR LIBERTY
description: WHILE doing research for a book on egalitarian ideology, Dr. Ruth Bogin, who teaches American history at Pace University in Pleasantville, has discovered a previously unknown document written by the first black spokesman against slavery in the United States, Lemuel Haynes, a black minister who lived in New England.

title: A NEW MUSEUM JOINS THE RANKS
description: MUSEUMS seem to be multiplying like rabbits these days, and the newest one in New Jersey, the Noyes, is in Oceanville, a hamlet close to Atlantic City and the Brigantine Wildlife Refuge.
